Blustery Day
description: Marco Ostoja of Yugoslavia, a qualifier with a No. 216 world ranking, after losing to a loudly hot-tempered Jimmy Connors at La Quinta, Calif.: ''It's sad he needs all that to beat a player like me.''

title: New Offers Made In GATX Bidding
description: The GATX Corporation said today that a third new bidder had emerged for the company and an old suitor, the Leucadia National Corporation, had raised its offer.

title: BLOCK, H & R INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FILM OF FEELING The second annual Harlem Film Festival, in Aaron Davis Hall (690-6900), will conclude today with a program that includes documentaries and the feature film ''Sugar Cane Alley.''

description: b-Net loss.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday with an article on Canada's economic problems mislabeled one set of statistics. The figures showed the growth of the total Federal debt since 1975, not the budget deficit.

description: b-Net income.

title: KOCH OUSTS A COMMISSIONER ON CONFLICT-OF-INTEREST ISSUE
description: Mayor Koch dismissed his Commissioner of Business Development yesterday for owning stock in a company that is relocating - and is receiving financing for its move - with city help.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Omar Moreno, outfielder.

title: Fire Report on Brewers
description: Three Milwaukee Brewer coaches and an Arizona plumbing company technician remained hospitalized for treatment of burns yesterday as the Fire Department in Chandler, Ariz., pinpointed the cause of the fiery gas explosion that rocked the Brewers' new spring training clubhouse Thursday, injuring nine people, including Manager George Bamberger and General Manager Harry Dalton. According to John Pinch, an assistant Chandler city manager, the technician, Jeff Sutton, was installing a heating unit in the clubhouse coaches room when he bled the natural gas lines to remove air from the lines.

title: ZERO COUPON REAL ESTATE
description: SOME of the features that have made zero coupon bonds a popular investment can now be found in a few specialized real estate offerings. Like the bonds, these limited partnerships, with a ''multiplier'' effect, offer investors an opportunity to accrue interest and receive a lump sum payment at maturity.

title: SENATOR LUGAR SAYS U.S. SHOULD OFFER TO CUT OFF AID TO CONTRAS IF NICARAGUA HOLDS A 'FREE ELECTION'
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the United States should offer to drop its support of the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government if the Sandinistas hold a free election ''like the Philippines.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 1, 1986
description: International

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: Share earnings results reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $417,000 and after a $12.6 million writedown of inventory, writeoffs of $5.2 million for deferred startup costs, $1.3 million for goodwill and $700,000 for equipment of discontinued plant. c-Net income.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WINFIELD AT CAMP SITE
description: Dave Winfield and George Steinbrenner have seldom agreed on anything, most recently Winfield's absence from the Yankees' first full-squad workout. However, when he arrived today, Winfield expressed the same hope that Steinbrenner has made repeatedly: that the Yankees not get off to a slow start, as they did last year.

title: NESTOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BY D.R.G. AND H.M.O., DOCTORS HAVE CHANGED
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE McMANUS DEMOCRATIC CLUB, SERVICE, NOT ISSUES, WINS VOTES
description: ''Come in, come in,'' said a smiling Bernie Cohen, waving with one hand, holding a telephone in the other. ''Nothing sinister here.'' Mr. Cohen is vice president of the McManus Democratic Club on West 48th Street, housed in a small, store-front office that was bustling with activity. Neighborhood residents came in one after another asking for help in all sorts of problems that plague humankind in New York: relief from threatening landlords and jury duty, replacement of burned-out street lights and traffic lights, ridding a block of drug pushers, finding a lawyer for an unjustly accused son, finding a summer job in the Parks Department for a daughter.

title: Oil Trades Under $13 Before Recovering a Bit
description: Prices for crude oil breached another benchmark yesterday, trading below the $13-a-barrel level for the first time in nearly eight years before recovering somewhat.

title: DON'T ROCK MEXICO'S POLITICAL STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am obviously not pleased in having to make these decisions.

title: Ida Lublenski Ehrlich, 99; Playwright and Producer
description: Ida Lublenski Ehrlich, an author, playwright and producer, died Saturday at Putnam Hospital Center in Carmel, N.Y. She was 99 years old and lived in Carmel.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shares outstanding represent weighted common equivalent shares.

title: HAMBURG LAUDS DOHNANYI IN CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA VISIT
description: Christoph von Dohnanyi's return to his native Hamburg has been called a ''triumphal march'' and a ''stunning comeback'' by West German critics, some of whom noted that they may have underrated the former director of the Hamburg State Opera.

title: BRENNAN TO PAY ENTIRE AMOUNT OF BRIBERY FINE
description: William C. Brennan, the former State Supreme Court justice who was convicted of bribe-taking, has agreed to pay a fine and penalties totaling $224,300 after Federal prosecutors said they they would subpoena the financial records of his real-estate partnership with a city commissioner and others.

title: Jersey Denies Overture
description: The Yankees and the team's owner, George Steinbrenner, weren't commenting, but Jon F. Hanson, the chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, flatly denied yesterday that authority officials had made any overtures to the Yankees in an effort to lure the club from Yankee Stadium to a new baseball stadium planned for the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. The denial, a sharp break with the authority's policy of not commenting on speculation about negotiations with major league teams, came after Vincent Tese, the chairman of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, citing unnamed ''sources,'' said that authority officials had offered to buy out the club's lease on Yankee Stadium, which runs through 2002, and to guarantee the team a minimum attendance of 2.2 million a year if the club would move to the Meadowlands.

title: AQUINO AIDES, AT PALACE, AWED BY 'MADNESS OF IT'
description: An advance party from the office of President Corazon C. Aquino toured the back rooms of Malacanang Palace today and found, as one of the visitors said, that ''behind the facade of stately offices is madness.''

title: AUTOMATIC SPENDING CUTS SET TODAY
description: Spending in hundreds of Federal programs around the country will be cut by 4.3 percent Saturday as a new budget-balancing law takes full effect.

title: NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JOHNSON CALLED ALERT AT WILL SIGNING
description: J. Seward Johnson ''was of sound mind and memory'' on April 14, 1983, when he signed a will disinheriting his children and leaving $400 million to $500 million to his wife, a lawyer who witnessed the signing testified yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate Court.

title: FIVE IN POLAND REPORTED AILING IN HUNGER STRIKES
description: Five imprisoned Solidarity activists on long hunger strikes are in perilous physical condition, according to opposition sources.

title: MEET WALTER ZAPPER, PUBLIC FRIEND NO. 1
description: This teen-age punk, wearing the livery and hair style of his ilk, sauntered along West Fourth Street carrying a monster box, the volume of its rock music matching the level of a Concorde on take-off. He gazed at Walter Zapper, walking in the opposite direction. Sizing up the generation and cultural gaps in a millisecond, he sneered. Clearly the implied attitude was, ''If you don't like it, Square, what you gonna do about it?'' The punk felt secure. He was mistaken.

title: TIE-COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $3,354,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and included gains of $39,000 for the quarter and $655,000 for the year from discontinued operations. d-Includes a loss of $2,859,000. The company noted that half of its fourth quarter losses primarily were attributable to an $8 million writedown of inventory and a $5 million provision for the restructuring of operations. The 1985 inventory writedowns totaled $34 million and the provision for restructuring of operations was $10 million. The 1985 year also included a $17 million loss on the sale of assets of a division.

description: b-Net income.

4 MORE POLICE OFFICERS ARRESTED IN MIAMI AREA
description: Four police officers and a former officer have been added to the growing list of law-enforcement officers in the Miami area who have been charged with crimes.

title: BLACKS VIE IN NEW ORLEANS VOTE TODAY
description: For the first time in the city's history, New Orleans voters will go to the polls Saturday to choose as Mayor one of two black candidates in a runoff election.

title: Knox Holds On With Slim Lead
description: Kenny Knox, the surprise leader after Thursday's first round of the $500,000 Honda Classic, birdied the last two holes in the second round today, finished with a one-under-par 71 and kept the lead by a shot over Andy Bean with a seven-under 137.

title: END TO SMOKING AIDS HEART ILLS, STUDY SAYS
description: Patients with heart disease who refuse to quit smoking are nearly twice as likely to die of heart attacks than those who stop smoking, researchers have reported.

title: IDEAL BASIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $42,790,000 for the quarter and $174,584,000 for the year. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $7,590,000 for the quarter and $4,926,000 for the year. The year result also includes a gain of $4,198,000 from early extinquishment of debt. d-Net income.

description: b-Net income.

title: THE OCEANS ARE CHOKING ON PLASTIC DEBRIS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Video Signal Processor For Cleaner TV Picture
description: A video signal processor patented this week for the RCA Corporation is described as offering a smoother, cleaner television picture that eliminates interline flicker and line crawl.

title: MUSEUMS CELEBRATE LIBERTY'S CENTENNIAL
description: This is the 100th birthday year of the Statue of Liberty, and the city's museums are wishing her ''Happy Centennial'' with a burst of exhibits. In the months to come, New Yorkers will be able to see a score of inventive and original shows inspired by the majestic symbol of America and the related theme of immigration to the New World.

title: WORLD LEADERS REMEMBER PALME AS A STATESMAN FOR PEACE
description: President Reagan tonight expressed shock and sorrow at the death of Prime Minister Olof Palme and praised him as ''a man who made compassion the hallmark of Swedish policy.''

title: RAUCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET ASSERTS RECOGNITION OF AQUINO RULE IS AUTOMATIC
description: The Soviet Union, which recently indicated support for President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, said today that its recognition of President Corazon C. Aquino was automatic.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SOME DIFFICULT MOMENTS IN THE GOVERNOR'S TRAVELS
description: As Governor Cuomo finished an impassioned speech this week at Princeton University on the plight of the country's poor, a freshman stood up to ask a question.

title: EX-SINGER TO STAND TRIAL IN BELUSHI MURDER CASE
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith, a former singer and companion to rock musicians, was ordered today to stand trial on a charge of second-degree murder in the drug overdose death of the comedian John Belushi four years ago.

title: SAN DIEGO SYMPHONY MAY FILE BANKRUPTCY
description: The San Diego Symphony is $2 million in debt and will file for reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy code unless the public comes to its rescue, according to M. B. Merryman, president of the symphony's Board of Directors.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writeoff of a large jewelry account. The net effect of this charge was $630,000. c-Net income. d-Including a gain of $603,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of subsidiary for the quarter and year. The year result also inculdes a gain of $700,000 from a change in tax laws relating to export sales.

title: KEEPING AN EYE ON SUSPECT MAIL
description: The contents of the messages that a spy or criminal suspect receives are plainly of major interest to the Government. But the names, addresses and even the cancellation on the outside of all letters going to the suspect may also provide useful clues.

title:
PATENTS;
New Way to Prepare Anti-Cancer Proteins
description: The Cetus Corporation of Emeryville, Calif., received a patent this week on a new process for preparing Interleuken-2 and Beta Interferon, proteins being used in clinical studies of hundreds of cancer patients. Patent No. 4,572,798 was obtained by Kirston E. Koths, director of protein chemistry, and Robert F. Halenbeck, a staff scientist.

title: UNION MAY END SUPPORT FOR MEATPACKERS' STRIKE
description: The parent union of the Minnesota local on strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company is considering ending its sanction of the six-and-a-half-month walkout, a union official said today.

title: VIATECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $509,000 from equity in earnings of Dixie Union. c-Net loss after a gain of $209,000 from equity in earnings of Dixie Union.

title: POP: RANCE ALLEN GROUP MIXES GOSPEL AND DISCO
description: ''Whatever we feel like doing, we do that very thing,'' said the singer-keyboardist Rance Allen, who brought his trio to Sounds of Brazil Wednesday. ''But we do it to the glory of God.''

title: A FUNNY SMELL
description: The perfume and cosmetics industry, which figures it loses vast sums each year to makers of phony fragrances and cosmetics, is starting a campaign to press Government agencies to take a stronger stand against counterfeiters.

title: WHY G.M. WANTS TINY LOTUS
description: There was excitement late in January in this quiet village 120 miles north of London when Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, swooped down in a helicopter for a tour of Group Lotus Cars P.L.C. Just five days earlier, on Jan. 22, G.M. announced that it had acquired 58 percent of the tiny sports car and engineering company for $18.5 million.

QUESTECH INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

title: END THE WICKS LAW WASTE
description: What do New York's La Guardia High School, Wollman Skating Rink, the Fashion Institute of Technology, One Police Plaza, Woodhull Hospital and Yankee Stadium have in common? All were plagued by poor construction work, long delays and huge cost overruns.

title: DETREX CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HARNISCHFEGER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,300,000 for the latest quarter and a gain of $2,847,000 from the effect of an accounting change for the year-ago period.

title: Videotex Unit Shut By Times Mirror
description: The Times Mirror Company closed its Gateway videotex service, ending service for 3,000 subscribers, most of whom were personal computer users in Los Angeles and Orange counties.

title: THE RETURN OF AN EXILE: 'IT'S THE GREATEST STORY'
description: Raul S. Manglapus remembers exactly how long he was away - 13 years, 5 months and 7 days.

title: CIRCLE EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $53,000 for the quarter and $137,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $41,000 for the quarter and $99,000 for the year.

title: NETS DEFEAT SPURS BY 113-110
description: Tonight, the Nets played as if they had put their nightmarish week behind them. The shock of losing Micheal Ray Richardson is still there, but his absence has given way to a stability that had been missing for two months.

title: HERNANDEZ AND BERRA CONSIDER STANCES ON RULING
description: Dale Berra, the Yankees' reserve infielder, said today he was pleased to have a chance to avoid suspension for the season, but he stopped short of accepting the alternative Commissioner Peter Ueberroth offered in disciplining 21 players for drug-related matters.

title: EGYPT'S SECURITY POLICE CHIEF OUSTED
description: Egypt's Interior Minister, Ahmed Rushdi, regarded as one of the country's most powerful political figures, was dismissed today in the aftermath of a rebellion by thousands of paramilitary policemen under his command.

title: HMO AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $365,000.

title: ONE-WAY TOLL PLAN VOTED FOR VERRAZANO'S TRAVELERS
description: Starting March 20, cars and trucks coming from Staten Island will be able to cross over to Manhattan free, because of a change that is expected to increase traffic congestion in Brooklyn and lower Manhattan.

title: NORTH CANADIAN OILS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TOP DEMOCRATS DISPUTE KOCH ON PARTY DEALINGS
description: Democratic leaders, disputing Mayor Koch's accounts of his relations with party officials early in his administration, say he is trying to shift the blame for municipal corruption to them.

title: STOCKS UP IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Investors continued to swarm into the stock market yesterday after Thursday's record-breaking session, and prices closed mostly higher although a select group of blue-chip stocks that included I.B.M. came under heavy selling pressure.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LINDENAUER PLEADS NOT GUILTY AS OFFICIALS DEBATE SUBPOENA
description: A conflict between Federal and local prosecutors over a subpoena yesterday overshadowed a court session in which a former city official pleaded not guilty to extorting $410,000 from companies collecting overdue fines for the Parking Violations Bureau.

title: GOTBAUM CRITICIZES CITY ON CONTRACT-NOTICE LAW
description: A law making it easier for the public to review expensive city contracts before they are awarded is being ignored by the Koch administration, the head of city's largest municipal union charged yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: A group of French artisans who came to the United States to create a new torch for the Statue of Liberty have decided to open a business here, a lawyer for the group said today.

title: AD AGE ISSUE TO BE DROPPED
description: Crain Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would fold the struggling midweek issue of Advertising Age, its flagship publication.

title: Sports People; LaFontaine to Return
description: Pat LaFontaine, the only Islander who didn't make the team's weekend road trip, will be reactivated Tuesday when the Islanders play a home game against the Montreal Canadiens. He has been out since suffering a separated shoulder Jan. 25. . . . Mark Osborne, the Ranger who missed five games with a sprained right ankle, reinjured the ankle in Thursday's game against the Pittsburgh Penguins and will miss tonight's game against the Washington Capitals.

title: BRAZIL FREEZES WAGES AND PRICES IN SWEEPING ANTI-INFLATION DRIVE
description: President Jose Sarney ordered drastic economic changes today in ''a war of life and death'' against inflation. The decree includes a wage and price freeze and the creation of a new currency.

title: AN UNSETTLING QUESTION AT ROME TRIAL
description: A prosecutor's request for acquittal in the trial over the shooting of the Pope has raised the uncomfortable question of how Italy could hold a Bulgarian defendant for more than three years when the state's own prosecutor now admits there was insufficient evidence for conviction.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Avondale Mills, Sylacauga, Ala., said its board would meet and advise shareholders by March 12 on the company's position on Dominion Textile Inc.'s unsolicited $24-a-share tender offer.

title: STEWART-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $1,480,000 related to the sale of property. c-Includes a nonrecurring charge of $3,462,000, a tax credit of $1,662,000 and a reversal of deferred tax liabilities related to the accumulated income of a subsidiary.

title: U.S. Expert on Influenza Says Epidemic May Have Peaked
description: A Federal health official said Thursday that the most widespread influenza epidemic to grip the nation in five years had apparently peaked and was now on the wane.

title: AID CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring tax benefit of $5,282,000 due to the 'fresh start adjustment.'

title: AT 65 AND OVER, EXERCISE FOR EVERY NEED
description: Tanned, blue-eyed Ellen Wenzel reaches, reaches, reaches, stretching her arms, shoulders and torso upward. She holds several pretzel-like twists that work the muscles in the legs, back and stomach. It's her way of staying flexible, she explains, after an hourlong Body in Motion exercise class she attends every Thursday morning at the 92d Street Y to keep her 100-pound figure trim enough for the electric blue leotard that hugs it.

title: Bolivian Floods Kill 2
description: Heavy rains and rising waters from Lake Titicaca have killed at least two farmers, destroyed the crops of 140,000 Aymara Indians and caused $54 million damage, the Civil Defense Board said today. Waters from the lake, the highest navigable lake in the world at 12,506 feet above sea level, have risen nine feet the last two weeks from the heaviest rains of the region this century, the authorities said. Reports from Puno, on the Peruvian side of the lake, indicate that tens of thousands of Peruvians have lost crops, livestock and homes in the flooding.

title: CHIFFON'S FINE FORM
description: Triple layers of white organdy ripple around the neckline of his signature chiffon dresses. Many styles float gently to the floor, interrupted by a thin chiffon sash at the waistline, which the mannequin often removes halfway down the runway and places around her neck. Side drapery hints at the sarong look without ever descending into vulgarity.

title: HOW THE ADOPTION SYSTEM IGNITES A FIRE
description: Fourteen-year-old Patrick DeGelleke said he didn't mean to kill his adoptive parents when he set fire to their home a year and a half ago in Marion, N.Y. According to testimony in a trial last month, it seems he wanted it to look as though he had disappeared in the fire so he could flee to Cincinnati, Ohio, in search of his birth mother.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $156,000 and a gain on the early retirement of debt of $2,717,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $80,000, a gain on the early retirement of debt of $736,000 and a tax credit of $745,000.

Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, made the remark after he inadvertently skipped a page near the end of his keynote address to the Communist Party's 27th congress, a speech that lasted five and a half hours. 11. Andres Segovia gave a guitar recital before a dinner at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, where he was honored as one of 21 ''Lions of the Performing Arts.'' 12.

title:
PATENTS;
Adhesive Compounds To Halt Tooth Decay
description: Dental compounds that are described as being strongly adhesive, with the ability to set rapidly and prevent tooth decay, were patented this week by Henry R. Rawls of the Louisiana State University School of Dentistry and Barbara F. Zimmerman, a research associate. The two acrylic polymers can be used for filling and sealing teeth and for making dentures.

title: MISSING MONEY IS CITED IN MUSEUM FUNDS CUTOFF
description: A pattern of mismanagement that led the city to freeze financing for El Museo del Barrio last November involves the disappearance or misuse of more than $120,000, according to current and former museum trustees, city officials and documents turned over to the City Department of Investigation.

title: Alice Baker Kean Dies; Led a U.N. Committee
description: Alice Baker Kean, president of the United Nations Hospitality Committee in the 1970's, died Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 64 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Millbrook, N.Y., and South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Kaiser Suit Names 2 Former Officers
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had filed suit against two former employees who have been retained as consultants by the investment group led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., which is trying to take over the company.

title: BANKAMERICA FUND PLEDGE REPORTED
description: Three of the BankAmerica Corporation's four Wall Street fund-raisers have told the troubled banking company that they are prepared to raise at least $1 billion in new capital, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: MIW INVESTORS OF WASHINGON (DC) (O) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $3,073,000 for the latest year and $1,375,000 for the earlier year.

title: HIGH COURT RULING PUTS CITY IN WEST IN SPOTLIGHT
description: Clustered together on Third Street, the main street of this old industrial suburb of Seattle, are a Roman Catholic church, two funeral homes, the headquarters of the Eagles lodge and a movie theater that shows sexually explicit films.

title: U.S. MAY SEIZE SOME MARCOS MONEY
description: Administration officials said today that the United States was willing to return Philippine currency removed by Ferdinand E. Marcos or his associates when they fled if the money was removed in violation of that country's laws.

title: LAWMAKER APOLOGIZES FOR 'INELEGANT' WORDS
description: Representative Bob Dornan, Republican of California, conceded today that he had used ''inelegant phrasing'' in a House speech attacking a Soviet television commentator, but the lawmaker denied his remarks were anti-Semitic.

title:
PATENTS;
A Device to Control Urinary Incontinence
description: A manually operated hydraulic sphincter, designed to solve urinary incontinence, has been patented for Johns Hopkins University.

title: CREST-FOAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a transmission error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the rate of time it takes for the New York Federal Reserve Bank and the New York Clearing House to process $1 trillion a day. It is $35 million a second over an eight-hour day.

title: REAGAN APPROVES ARMS FOR SAUDIS BUT FACES HARD FIGHT IN CONGRESS
description: President Reagan has decided to sell more than $300 million worth of missiles to Saudi Arabia despite the strong possibility that the sale will be blocked by Israeli supporters in Congress, a senior White House official said today.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AN EXPLETIVE FROM REAGAN
description: President Reagan, at the end of a picture-taking session today at which reporters were seeking to question him about the Philippines, turned to an aide and said, ''Sons of bitches!''

title: AQUINO MIGHT BYPASS GOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE
description: President Corazon C. Aquino said today that she was studying the option of declaring what her aides called a ''revolutionary government'' that would allow her to bypass the institutions left behind by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This man was one of 34 happy beneficiaries of a recent event. Who is he and what were the circumstances? 2. ''I am embarrassed, I am chagrined, I am absolutely mortified.'' Who made this remark and what were the circumstances? 3. A $15 million system that, it was suggested, might have prevented the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger was installed on the launching pad at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California but was scrapped for the pad at Cape Canaveral, Fla. What system is it and why was it scrapped? 4. The new lower-fat chickens recently introduced in supermarkets around the country contain (slightly less/moderately less/significantly less) fat per average serving than regular chickens. 5. A Rome prosecutor, in his recommendation to the jury in the trial of three former Bulgarian officials accused of plotting to assassinate Pope John Paul II, did not urge a verdict of guilty or not guilty but a third alternative permissible under Italian law. What verdict is it and what does it imply? 6. The only writer to have won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction and for poetry (twice) has achieved an even rarer distinction. Who is he and what is it? 7. A change in internal Administration polls prompted President Reagan to deliver a major address. What was the subject what had the polls disclosed? 8. According to a New York Times/ CBS News Poll, (15/25/35/45/55) percent of the public said they would be willing to pay more taxes if the increase would help troubled farmers save their land. 9.

title: Cameroonian Visits U.S.
description: President Paul Biya of Cameroon ended his official visit today. He called the prospects for increased aid from the United States probable, and he offered to lower taxes on American oil companies.

title: DYNAMICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $5,739,000, or $1.34 a share, from a U.S. Claims Court patent award.

title: OFFICIALS ARREST MAN ACCUSED OF WAR CRIMES
description: The Justice Department announced today that a Philadelphia man accused of persecuting Jews in Poland had been arrested and that deportation proceedings would begin.

title: PRODUCT DESIGN & ENGINEERNG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 14, 1986.

title: HELPING YOUTH ALONG THE ROAD
description: Auto racing has traveled many different roads during its decades of development, but few of those roads have ever taken the sport into the inner city. Now Dave Rosenblum has blended his racing career with a dash of social consciousness to create a small, well, inroad.

title: MARCOS SAYS HE QUIT TO STOP CARNAGE
description: Speaking publicly for the first time since he was deposed as President of the Philippines, Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he had decided to surrender power despite having ''overwhelming force'' in order to avoid ''the bloody carnage of our innocent civilians.''

title: CYANIDE PURCHASE IS LINKED TO DEATH IN NASHVILLE
description: A Nashville man bought a pound of cyanide five days before he was found dead of cyanide poisoning near a bottle of Tylenol containing a cyanide-tainted capsule, the Nashville police said yesterday.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The earlier year revenue was not available.

title: 6 TIED TO LATE-NIGHT CLUBS INDICTED IN CONSPIRACY CASE
description: Six former owners and employees of two Manhattan after-hours clubs were indicted yesterday on charges that they evaded liquor and tax laws and then conspired to impede investigations of those crimes.

title: MUSIC: MEHTA CONDUCTS 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'
description: Indelible performances of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' tend to fall in either of two stylistic categories, even though it is true that so stupendous a work will always overflow categories in all directions. This deeply contemplative but at the same time emotionally gripping score can weave its spell as a piece of devotional mysticism or, at the other end of the scale, as quasioperatic drama. Now and then, in fact, an opera director actually mounts a staged version, which seems to be stretching things but at least testifies to the score's power to stir secular as well as religious imaginations.

title: RELIABILITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest period losses include a charge of $695,000 for the shutdown of a plant in California.

title: A NEW CLEVELAND FEARS BUDGET CUTS
description: In the 1960's the Hough neighborhood in this city's eastern sector attracted national attention for the severity of its riots and the extent of its poverty, crime and decay.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $378,694 from discontinued opeartions. c-Net loss.

title: LONG-TERM BONDS UP SLIGHTLY
description: The bond market continued its roaring rally at the opening yesterday, with long-term issues rising more than a point in the first hour. But then profit taking cut back the gains and left bond prices up only slightly for the session.

title: BONN LOWER HOUSE APPROVES LAW ON IDENTITY DOCUMENTS
description: The lower house of Parliament approved a law today introducing credit-card sized computer-readable identity documents for West Germans that opposition politicians have charged could lead to increased surveillance of individuals.

title: IN 'MY WEEKLY READER'?
description: When Russell B. Long retires at the end of this year, he will have served 36 years in the Senate, only six years short of the longevity record set by Carl Hayden of Arizona when he left office in 1969. And like other veteran lawmakers, Senator Long is often exasperated by the relative inexperience of younger Administration officials.

title: NEW WAY TO CUT COSTS OF POWER
description: UP along the Hudson River, new meters in a couple of hundred homes tell residents how much power they use during the day, when it costs the most, and how much at night and on weekends, when it is cheapest.

title: ALL THE SIDES OF TV STORY
description: It is a basic tenet of American journalism: Get both sides of the story. But how far news organizations should go to pursue that ideal is at the center of a debate prompted by White House criticism this week of ABC News for allowing a Soviet commentator to rebut President Reagan's televised plea for increased military spending.

title: PACIFIC NUCLEAR SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in December 1985 and no year-ago results are available.

title: DOSKOCIL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $640,000 for the quarter and $3,449,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $540,000 for the quarter and $3,449,000 for the year.

title: TARGETED-JOBS TAX CREDIT PUTS PEOPLE TO WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT ARE WE SELLING?
description: As part of its ''public diplomacy'' initiative, in which the agency has previously tried to sell Europe on the necessity of American missiles and the virtues of a space-based defense against Soviet ones, the United States Information Agency has organized a session in London to brief public affairs officers in European embassies on selling the American point of view in the next, unscheduled, summit talks with the Soviet Union. Among those taking part are Jack Matlock, the senior Soviet expert on the National Security Council, and Paul H. Nitze, the senior arms control adviser.

title: BUBKA ACHIEVES ANOTHER BEST
description: With the crowd going ''Ssh'' and Madison Square Garden remarkably quiet, Sergei Bubka broke his world indoor best in the pole vault last night by gliding over 19 feet 6 1/4 inches.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AN UNACCEPTED $10,000 CAMPAIGN CONTRIBUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: DISSENT ON PHILIPPINES
description: Excerpts from a statement by Senator Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, on why he cast the lone vote Wednesday against a resolution welcoming the ''peaceful and expeditious transfer of power'' in the Philippines:

title: CIGAR SMOKING EXPLAINED (NO IFS, ANDS OR BUTTS)
description: Of all the permutations of tobacco, the cigar is surely the most detested and maligned. Why, then, would anyone take up cigar smoking?

title: SIX BOOKS NOMINATED FOR FAULKNER AWARD
description: Six books have been nominated for the PEN/Faulkner Award as the best work of fiction published in 1985.

title: AQUINO SAYS ALL HELD FOR POLITICS WILL BE RELEASED
description: President Corazon C. Aquino today ordered the release of all remaining prisoners jailed by the Marcos Government on charges that are considered political by the new Government.

title: NEW SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 1, 1986
description: International Sweden's Prime Minister was slain. The Prime Minister, Olof Palme, was shot on a street in Stockholm shortly after he left a movie theater with his wife. Mr. Palme, who was 59 years old, was the leader of Sweden'sSocial Democratic Party. He was Prime Minister since September 1982 and also served in the job from 1969 to 1976. He was the first European head of government to be slain while in office in 47 years. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Freedom for all Filipinos jailed by the Marcos Government on charges considered political by the new Government was ordered by President Corazon C. Aquino. The order to free all remaining such prisoners promptly became surrounded by confusion an controversy, with debates going on inside and outside the Government on both definition of political crimes and the wisdom of freeing people believed to be leaders of armed insurgencies. Officials estimate that about 450 detainess will be eligible for immediate release. [ 1:3. ] Brazil is freezing wages and prices and will establish a new currency in what President Jose Sarney called ''a war of life and death'' against inflation. Mr. Sarney said drastic measures were needed because inflation had become Brazil's ''worst enemy.' Price rises in January and February pointed toward an annual inflation rate of 500 percent. [ 1:4. ] Egypt dismissed its Interior Minister in the aftermath of a rebellion by thousands of paramilitary policemen under his command. At least 36 people died in the rioting, which was triggered Tuesday night by a rumor that the conscript policemen would be held on duty an extra year.

title: FOR THE CHERRY TREE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUDANESE REBELS BLOCK U.N. FAMINE RELIEF
description: Rebels controlling the southern Sudan have refused a United Nations request to allow a convoy to enter the area and bring food to 900,000 people facing starvation there, a Western relief official said in a telephone interview today.

title: Jobs-Statistics Office Suffers a Loss of Jobs
description: The latest report from the local Federal office that reports on jobs and joblessness: It is short of jobs.

title: Long Service
description: Wednesday was Sadie Nussbaum's 90th birthday. Just before 6 P.M., she was in the Plymouth Theater on 45th Street preparing for her usual night's work distributing Playbills and seating the audience.

title: BROCK CALLED FAVORITE FOR WORLD BANK POST
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock is now the favored candidate of the White House to become president of the World Bank, a senior White House official said today.

title: GAS LEAK SICKENS 30 WORKERS AT S.I. LANDFILL
description: About 30 workers in a Sanitation Department garage at a Staten Island landfill became ill yesterday morning after methane gas escaped from a malfunctioning storage tank at a gas recovery plant across the street, the authorities said.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES SAY EX-CHIEF LEADS CANDIDATES FOR NASA POST
description: White House officials said today that Dr. James C. Fletcher, a former Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, had emerged as the leading candidate to take over the troubled agency in the wake of the Challenger disaster.

title: PYRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $5,018,000, or 33 cents a share, from property dispositions.

title: Article 674786 -- No Title
description: A man posing as an electrician used a bogus work order to get into the Upper East Side apartment of an heir to the Macy's retailing fortune yesterday morning and stole jewelry valued at $125,000, the police said.

title: IVACO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a reduction of $2.4 million due to a change in the method of accounting for investment tax credits. c-Including a special gain of $1,508,000.

title: China Growth Surges
description: Chinese economic growth last year more than doubled Government targets and urban inflation was the highest since the Communist Party took power in 1949, the State Statistical Bureau said today.

title: OTTAWA LIBERALS JOLTED BY DEPARTURE OF A STAR
description: Canada's opposition Liberal Party, still recovering from its crushing defeat in the 1984 national elections, has been jolted by the sudden departure of Jean Chretien, one of its most effective politicians.

title: LET ANYONE WHO HAS A COLLEGE DEGREE TEACH
description: To the Editor:

title: VICTORIANS IN LOVE
description: THE TENDER PASSION: The Bourgeois Experience, Victoria to Freud. By Peter Gay. 490 pages. Oxford University Press. $24.95. In the first volume of his massive examination of bourgeois life during the 19th century, the historian Peter Gay took it upon himself to re-examine the sexual behavior and attitudes of the Victorians, both here and in Western Europe. ''Education of the Senses'' (1984), as that volume was called, proved to be a witty, erudite and controversial study that challenged many of the stereotypes commonly held about that not so distant era - besides arguing that the middle classes of that period were considerably more interested in sex than its genteel manners suggested, the book presented a thoroughgoing reassessment of the role and nature of Victorian women, persuasively arguing that the old image of them as repressed, frigid, anesthetic creatures was as inadequate as it was demeaning.

title: Reaching Best 7-Card Fit Is a Challenge for Bidders
description: All bidding systems are designed to locate eight-card fits in major suits, and competent bidders, given a free run, rarely fail in that respect.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing IMSA Grand Prix of Miami (Television - Channel 41, 4 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Nets, at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks will retire Earl (The Pearl) Monroe's No. 15 at halftime. (Television -MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:20 P.M.) title: MILITARY LEADERS DEBATE PROPOSALS
description: Proposals to streamline the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's top uniformed military command, brought a barrage of criticism today from retired admirals and generals.

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE SCREEN: 'HOLLYWOOD VICE SQUAD'
description: All vice squads are not created equal. Television's Miami version has, as has been amply noted elsewhere, a lot of flash; on the other hand, ''Hollywood Vice Squad,'' which opened yesterday at the National and other theaters, is decent but dull.

title: TREBLINKA SUSPECT IN ISRAEL TO FACE TRIAL
description: John Demjanjuk, a 65-year-old retired automobile worker from Cleveland and accused Nazi war criminal, was delivered by United States marshals to Israeli justice today at Tel Aviv airport.

title: TERRORISM FIGHT BY F.B.I. DESCRIBED
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation prevented 23 planned terrorist acts in this country last year and took ''a number of terrorists out of circulation,'' William H. Webster, Director of the bureau, said today.

title: JAILED CHILEAN DISSIDENT CALLS FOR RESISTANCE
description: One of four dissidents imprisoned over the last week said today that the latest crackdown by the military Government was an effort to block a new wave of anti-Government demonstrations planned for March.

title: ACCORD AT EASTERN AVERTS A WALKOUT
description: Eastern Airlines and its flight attendants reached a tentative agreement today, averting a strike.

title: A MASTER BREWER'S SECRETS
description: ''In some parts of the country beer is served extremely cold - in Texas they frost the glasses,'' says Mortimer W. Brenner. And that, he says, is how to get away with serving the least expensive beer. ''If it's really cold, below 32 degrees, you numb your sense of taste.''

title: Eastern's Fares Cut Up to 75%
description: Eastern Airlines cut fares by up to 75 percent today, including some $89 flights to Florida, fighting back against low-cost competitors. At the same time, USAir and People Express Airlines cut prices, intensifying a nationwide fare war.

title: Trade Gap Hits a Record $16.5 Billion
description: The excess of imports over exports widened again last month to a record $16.5 billion, strengthening the view of some Reagan Cabinet officers that a further fall in the dollar is needed to stanch the trade hemorrhage.

title: JOHN PAUL URGES PRESS TO DEFEND THE TRUTH
description: Pope John Paul II urged the press today to denounce any attempt to falsify or distort the facts.

title: MAX FRISCH, SWISS AUTHOR, GIVEN $25,000 NEUSTADT PRIZE
description: Jurors from nine nations yesterday named Max Frisch, the Swiss author and perennial Nobel Prize candidate, winner of the $25,000 Neustadt International Prize for Literature. The prize, given every two years, is sponsored by the University of Oklahoma and its literary quarterly, World Literature Today.

title: Calling All Cars
description: For good or ill, reminders of Super Bowl XX keep popping up all over. Take the other day, when Jim Steeg, the National Football League's director of special events, paid New Orleans another visit and discovered that one of a fleet of 150 courtesy cars that the N.F.L. provided reporters, broadcasters and teams for the championship game had been sitting in a hotel's lot ever since.

title: TEXFI INDUTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $26,000. c-Including a tax credit of $26,000.

title: LOOKING BACKWARD
description: Often it seems there is one America in which we live our lives and another in which our imaginations reside. That is the America of the 19th century, and we cherish its relics without recalling the inconveniences.

title: LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Less Paid to Farmers
description: The prices that farmers receive for raw products dropped 2.4 percent in February, falling to 10 percent below the level of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: SOPHISTICATED AUDIENCE
description: Many of Representative Mac Sweeney's constituents dwell in the wide open spaces of Texas's 14th District, and the freshman Republican has told the people back home that he has to intention of caving in to big-city interests. A flier promises that he will fight for those things ''important to South Texans'' - and it goes on to list immigration, terrorism, Social Security, trade, oil import taxes and satellite signal scrambling.

title: MINORITY VILLAINS ARE TOUCHY NETWORK TOPICS
description: ''The Children of Times Square,'' a new ABC-TV movie to be shown Monday, offers a case study of how television attempts to deal with a controversial story that casts minority-group members in an unsympathetic light. The film focuses on a group of children and young teen-agers who act as drug runners in New York.

title: RESEARCHERS SAY LABORATORY TESTS MAY PRODUCE A VACCINE FOR AIDS
description: Antibodies from animals infected with the AIDS virus protect some cell cultures from death that normally results from the virus, researchers said today.

title: Bankers Cautious on Brazil Program
description: Many major international banks came out in support of the anti-inflation measures announced in Brazil yesterday but bankers said it was too soon to say whether the program would be complied with throughout the economy.

title: THREATS CITED AGAINST A FIGURE IN GOTTI CASE
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that the complainant in a Queens assault and robbery case had been threatened in order to ''dissuade'' him from testifying against the defendants, who are John Gotti, the reputed head of the Gambino crime family, and another man.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $877,000 for the quarter and $1,032,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $9,726,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income.

title: PRESIDENT'S COMMISSION CRITICIZES MILITARY STRUCTURE AND SUPPLIERS
description: A Presidential commission sharply criticized the nation's military establishment and its suppliers today but recommended relatively modest measures to correct the deficiencies.

title: Disclosure on Hoyt
description: LaMarr Hoyt, the San Diego Padres pitcher, was stopped by United States Customs agents for drug violations two weeks before he checked himself into a rehabilitation center for evaluation of a possible substance abuse problem, authorities said yesterday. Hoyt was detained briefly by agents at the San Ysidro border checkpoint south of San Diego on Feb. 10, said John Miller, public affairs officer with the United States Customs Regional Pacific Office in Los Angeles.

title: Pilgrim Air Deal
description: Business Express, a commuter airline based in Bridgeport, acquired Pilgrim Airlines for an unspecified price in a deal that will make Business Express New England's largest commuter air carrier.

title: IMMIGRATION EXHIBITS AT CITY GALLERIES
description: Following is a list of exhibitions on the Statue of Liberty and immigration at city museums, libraries and galleries: New-York Historical Society, Central Park West at 76th Street: ''Statue of Liberty: America's Symbol of Freedom in Souvenirs and Ephemera,'' now to June 22. ''Statue of Liberty:

title: TAKING MEASURE OF AMERICANS
description: In a suburb of Philadelphia, a group of sociologists and statisticians is collecting the measurements of thousands of Americans. Their goal: to establish new size standards for American clothing.

title: THE SLEEPER IN THE TERMS
description: It sounds comfortable, this suspended sentence Peter Ueberroth offered to the group of ballplayers we shall shorthand as the Pittsburgh 11 and their 10 colleagues, but the terms are not as simple as they sound.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Sports Pages yesterday with an article about the Snook High School basketball team in Texas misidentified a player. He was Joey Slovacek, not Walter Martin.

title: PARADISE FRUIT reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $165,059.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: The latest quarter and year results reflect $6.1 million in costs of acquiring Home Club Inc. in January 1986.

title: K.G.B. SAYS SPIES FOR WEST WERE CAUGHT
description: The head of the K.G.B. said today that his men had caught Government employees whom he accused of spying for Western nations that ''snatch at our secrets.'' He warned other Soviet citizens against engaging in espionage.

title: LACK OF INSURANCE PERILS PARADE IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: San Francisco scrambled today to save its famed Chinese New Year's parade, set for March 8, after insurance companies refused to write a liability insurance policy for it.

title: State Escapes Flu Epidemic
description: New York's influenza season is a bit more severe this year than during the previous two winters, but the state appears to have escaped the worst aspects of what Federal officials call the most severe flu epidemic in five years.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS OPPOSING COVERT AID TO ANGOLA REBELS
description: Democratic Congressmen have begun a campaign to block President Reagan's covert military aid plan for Angolan rebels in what could be the start of a pitched battle, House aides said today.

title: SWEDISH PREMIER SHOT DEAD AS HE STROLLS WITH HIS WIFE ON MAIN STOCKHOLM STREET
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden was assassinated Friday night on a Stockholm street minutes after he left a movie theater with his wife.

title: A BELGIAN WOMAN IS CHARGED BY SOUTH AFRICA WITH TREASON
description: A Belgian woman was charged here today with treason or terrorism in helping the main black guerrilla group fighting white rule.

title: STUDY BY U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION REPORTS ON BEST WAYS OF TEACHING
description: In a step likely to provoke new debate on the Federal role in American education, the Department of Education is to give President Reagan a list of 41 findings about ''what works'' in public schools.

title: NAMING MOONS
description: To the Editor:

title: PLACES TO WORK OUT
description: Here is a sampling of courses for older people. Check with local Y's, schools and gyms for others.

title: 30-YEAR MORTGAGES BELOW 10%
description: With increasing frequency, conventional 30-year fixed-rate mortgages are being offered at interest rates below 10 percent. This week marks the first time in more than six years that single-digit rates have been available on fixed-rate mortgages.

title: APARTHEID'S 'REFERENCE BOOK' IS FULL OF SAD STORIES
description: Beulah Rollnick looked across her desk at the man with his head cocooned in a bandage and pondered, out loud, whether there was any hope left at all ''in this bloody country.''

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special net charge of $3.4 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: Unocal Outlay Cut
description: The Unocal Corporation said today that it had slashed its capital and oil exploration budget for 1986 by 20 percent, because of falling oil prices.

title: POP GOES THE SAMENESS
description: The war of the cola giants -Pepsi and Coca - threatens to wipe out the third world of soda pop. The supercolas have already swallowed 7-Up and Dr Pepper and there is grave doubt that Royal Crown Cola can survive as an independent carbonating force.

title: Ferocious
description: Ron Greschner of the Rangers salutes Tim Kerr, the Philadelphia Flyers' 6-foot-3-inch, 225-pound center: ''Trying to keep him out of the crease is like trying to tackle a jaguar. Not the animal. The car.''

title: Ins and Outs
description: ''I'd be here no matter what I'm doing,'' Gordon J. Davis, who left his post as Parks and Recreation Commissioner three years ago, said the other evening as he looked around the milling crowd in the Tower Suite restaurant in the Time-Life Building, ''but I don't have to work the room like I used to.''

title: BASEBALL ORDERS SUSPENSION OF 11 DRUG USERS
description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday suspended for one year Keith Hernandez of the Mets, Dale Berra of the Yankees and five other major league players for cocaine use. However, Mr. Ueberroth offered to lift the suspensions if the players agreed to certain conditions, including contributing 10 percent of their salaries this year to programs to combat drug abuse and submitting to drug tests for the remainder of their careers.

title: Zenith Unit Wins Contract
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation said today that one of its subsidiaries had been awarded a $242 million contract to supply microcomputers to the military Under terms of the contract, the largest Government award for microcomputers, the Zenith Data Systems Corporation will supply about 90,000 of the company's Z-200 personal computers to the Air Force, Navy, Army and Marine Corps. The consumer electronics company, which is based in Glenview, Ill., said it would begin shipments within the next 30 days.

title: 'SUNSHINE BOYS' OF THE TURF
description: The old rancher and the old tap dancer were soaking up the Florida sunshine this morning outside Barn 15 at Gulfstream Park. Carl Grinstead, the rancher, idly moved the turquoise clasp up and down his string tie as he explained why his horse is not for sale.

title: Australia Steel
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said it would spend $71 million overhauling and updating equipment at the coated products division at its Port Kembla steelworks in New South Wales. The program will make the company's Springhill Works one of the three most modern steelmaking mills in the world, Broken Hill said. The program is in addition to $500 million already being spent on improvements at the Port Kembla works.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: To Uplift the Mood
description: The ebullient developer Donald J. Trump was the guest speaker yesterday at the weekly luncheon of the City Club of New York. The topic was his proposed 150-story tower, which would be the the world's tallest building if it were built as part of the so-called Television City project on a 100-acre site along the Hudson River.

title: IN JUBILANT PHILIPPINE PROVINCES, 'THE SUN SHINES DIFFERENTLY NOW'
description: Outside the capital, in the provincial cities of this 7,000-island archipelago, the collapse of the Marcos Government has been greeted joyously.

title: PENN ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHUTTLE WORKERS ARE REDUCED 10%
description: Space agency officials today ended weeks of rumor and speculation among the citizens of Florida's ''space coast'' by announcing a 10 percent reduction in people working on the shuttle program.

title: ISLANDERS HOLD OFF WINNIPEG BY 6-3
description: Denis Potvin scored two goals and set up another tonight and Billy Smith provided standout goaltending to spark the Islanders to a 6-3 victory over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized investment gains of $3,581,000 for the quarter and $4,417,000 for the year and tax credit of $1,727,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after realized investment gains of $383,000 for the quarter and $487,000 for the year.

title: THE PENTAGON SHELL GAME
description: President Reagan seems unbothered by the now-certified fact that his proposed 1987 budget violates the balanced-budget law he signed only 11 weeks ago. There he was on television again, warning that cuts in his ''modest 3 percent'' increase in military spending would jeopardize arms negotiations with Moscow and ''may put peace itself at risk.'' These cries of wolf have lost credibility, not least because the dollar figures Mr. Reagan passes on from the Pentagon are simply wrong. No serious debate can evolve from such deception.

title:
PATENTS;
Sending Orbit Data By Light
description: A METHOD of transmitting information from an orbiting satellite to the Earth, using light as the carrier, was patented this week for the Navy.

title: OLOF PALME, ARISTOCRAT TURNED SOCIALIST, DOMINATED THE POLITICS OF SWEDEN
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden, who was shot and killed on a street in Stockholm last night, was the dominant figure in Swedish politics in the 1970's and 1980's and was a forceful, often acerbic voice on the world stage as well.

title: CLUBHOUSE POLITICS AMID THE PALMS
description: The breeziest political clubhouse west of the Rockaways met this morning, as every morning, on Gov. Enrique Zaldivar's bamboo porch.

title: 'OUTRAGE' GIVES A NEW TWIST TO VIGILANTISM
description: Buying a handgun in another state, Dennis Riordan, a white man, drives up to New York City's Harlem, gets out of his automobile and murders a black man named Charlie Johnson. Driving directly to a police station, Riordan announces, ''I just killed a man at Lenox Avenue and 117th Street.'' So begins ''Outrage,'' the made-for-TV movie on CBS at 9 this evening.

title: FROM STORY LINES TO VALUE LINE
description: AT first, Arnold Bernhard seemed destined to be a writer. He won a writing competition while he was an English major at Williams College. And, after he graduated in 1926, he landed a job as a theater critic with Time magazine.

title: Gasoline Spill in Kentucky
description: Gasoline spilled into storm drains and sewers here Friday, sending fumes into downtown buildings, closing businesses and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of people for several hours, the authorities said.

title: 'MAIN STREET' STRUGGLES TO MAKE A PLACE FOR ITSELF
description: Last September, when NBC News launched ''Main Street,'' a ''magazine'' series designed specifically for adolescent viewers, network officials promised that each monthly hourlong edition would offer its targeted audience of 11-to 16-year-olds something other than just cartoons or rock videos. And although that promise has in large measure been fulfilled, the road ahead for ''Main Street'' appears to be a bumpy one.

title: A BULL AND A TOAD RETURN TO DISNEY
description: For several decades, Walt Disney was a model parent. He watched over his often rambunctious children - Mickey, Pluto, Jiminy and their brethren - with unblinking concern, monitoring every aspect of their grooming, their comportment and their professional commitments.

title: SHARON KEIM WEDS DR. R. P. Grelsamer
description: Sharon Lee Keim, a daughter of Ruth A. Keim of New York, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and New Milford, Conn., and Dr. Hugo A. Keim of Cliffside Park, N.J., and Pawling, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Ronald Paul Grelsamer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philippe Grelsamer of New York. Walter Lawton, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of New York, performed the ceremony in the Grand Ballroom at the World Trade Center.

title: A MAKEUP ARTIST TAKES HER TALENTS TO THE BOARD ROOM
description: FOR the last two years, Leslie Smith of Norwalk, a freelance makeup artist, has been helping local corporate executives look good.

title: SPECULATING IN AIDS RESEARCH
description: When AIDS was recognized as a major threat to public health, stocks in companies doing research on treatments became objects of intense speculation. In the past week, investors in Newport Pharmaceuticals learned just how risky that kind of speculation can be.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FACING SUICIDE
description: Charlotte Ross, president and executive director of the Youth Suicide National Center based in Washington, will be the keynote speaker Tuesday evening in a public-education program entitled ''Tell Me Where the Road Turns: Preventing Youth Suicide.''

title: SUNRISE HIGHWAY: NO END IN SIGHT
description: IN 1952, Virginia Bailey and her husband, Charles, of Rosedale, Queens, bought their suburban dream house -a four-and-a-half-room cottage snuggled in the woods of a quiet, picturesque Suffolk County community called Sayville.

title: On Language; Of 'The' I Sing
description: AS THE CODEBREAKER in Edgar Allan Poe's ''The Gold Bug'' taught us, the most common word in the English language is the. Because familiarity bred Aesopian contempt, we tended to take the for granted. Not anymore.

title: A CHIP NOT OFF THE OLD BLOCK
description: JHOOLA, in Huntington, is a branch of an Indian restaurant of the same name in Smithtown. The parent restaurant, last visited several years ago, is a particularly attractive place and could be relied upon for high quality. Now it appears that what Jhoola has to offer does not travel well.

title: THE MYSTERY OF A JINXED RENOVATION ON PARK AVENUE
description: THE building seems jinxed, hoodooed, snakebitten, sitting there for years on Park Avenue in the Upper East Side Historic District - empty.

title: Eastern Takes A Texas Air Offer Of $600 Million
description: After winging it through months of financial turbulence, Eastern Air Lines agreed last week to turn over the controls to high-flying Texas Air Corporation.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It was either fix it, sell it or merge it. Since we couldn't fix it, we merged it, and we're very pleased with it.'' Frank Borman

title: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; I.R.S. Hopes To Run Well After Tune Up
description: IF the amount of embarrassment it suffered from last year's failures is any guide to the Internal Revenue Service's resolve to prevent a recurrence, then this year's filing season should be smooth indeed.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FANTASY AND PARODY
description: The Glory of Spain Featuring Andres Segovia, Victoria de los Angeles, Alicia de Larrocha and Roque Montoya Video Arts International 54 minutes. $49.95 The Prado in Madrid, one of the world's great museums, is particularly rich in works by El Greco, Velasquez and Goya, and a film was made there in 1967 to celebrate the wonders of some of the paintings by these three masters.

title: BEFORE PICKENS, THERE WAS MACHIAVELLI
description: WITH so much attention focused today on hostile takeovers and the corporate raiders who engineer them, it is surprising that no mention is made of the first and most effective raider of them all, Niccolo Machiavelli, author of the Renaissance classic ''The Prince.'' His book is largely about the arcane craft of seizing, and then managing, takeover targets.

title: PLANT FUIT TREES IN EARLY SPRING
description: I am always heartened when in markets on the continent, there are always five or six different varieties of pears. I buy one of each because my weakness for these sumptuous fruits nears gluttony. Alas, domestic markets rarely offer anything but Bartlett, Bosc and occasionally Anjou. To enjoy some of the more fragile, delicately flavored, old-fashioned varieties, the answer is to grow your own.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Is it true that you can be on standby for cruises at a lower price? - D. C., Anaheim, Calif. Answer:Cruise lines do not offer standby fares - officially. In practice, some lines have been known to reduce rates if they have many empty cabins as the sailing date approaches. Inquiring about such ''specials'' through travel agents that do a lot of cruise business or through the shipping companies themselves may enable a passenger to get a lower fare. But cut rates often reflect a trade-off of some kind. Two lines have late-booking plans that reduce fares but restrict the passenger's options. Norwegian Caribbean Lines has what is calls the Sea Saver, which offers lower fares on the seven-day Caribbean and Mexican cruises of the Norway, Starward, Skyward and Southward, provided reservation is made not more than four weeks before sailing.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: THE HISTORY WEEK Women's History Week will receive special attention not only at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers but also at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, the White Plains Library and the Unitarian Church in Croton.

title: IS MURDOCHOUT ON A LIMB?
description: To create one of the world's largest communications empires, Rupert Murdoch has assumed an enormous $2.6 billion debt. He has expressed confidence that the means will be found to repay the debt without undue strain, and some analysts and banking experts agree. But others say that Mr. Murdoch's financial position has serious vulnerabilities, and that by leveraging it so fully, he is taking the biggest risk of his life.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CHANGES AT THE AIRPORT

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All Sorts of Options In Retirement Study Adults interested in continuing education have many choices in the county, some offering an expanded social world as well as information or training in seminars and workshops.

title: SOME CASSETTE RECORDERS MARCH TO DIFFERENT DRUMMERS
description: As I recently explained to a member of my family who had dyed her hair green, departures from the norm are not always commendable.

title: 'LIVING WILL' MAY BE WORTH THE PAPER IT'S WRITTEN ON
description: JAMES H. McLAUGHLIN sat down at his typewriter four years ago and drafted a ''living will,'' a statement that he did not want his life prolonged by artificial means if there were no hope of recovery.

title: New Rules For Special Situations
description: WITH all the attention the latest proposals for overhauling the tax system have received, many people have undoubtedly lost sight of the Tax Reform Act of 1984 and other tax legislation. Yet millions of taxpayers will feel for the first time the impact of certain changes as they prepare their current returns. Alimony

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of misinformation supplied by the New York City Department of Transportation, an article on parking violations in The Week in Review last Sunday incorrectly described the department's power over cars with unpaid parking tickets. The department has the authority to hold a car it has towed until the vehicle's owner has paid all its outstanding parking fines.

title: WHEN COMPLAINTS REACH A CRITICAL MASS
description: Here, fenced and guarded and nestled against a mountain ridge in eastern Tennessee, stands an atomic fuel factory that has become the center of a dispute over precisely how safe working conditions should be in a nuclear installation.

title: HINDU REVIVALISM MAKES FOR MOSLEM ANXIETY
description: For 37 years, the doors at a crumbling religious shrine in the Ganges River plain were padlocked because of a dispute between Hindus and Moslems. Now a judge's decision to reopen the building as a Hindu temple has sparked violent Moslem protests. Across India, a half dozen people have been killed in clashes, particularly in the Moslem-dominated, northern state of Jammu and Kashmir. Army and paramilitary police are enforcing curfews in many cities. The disturbances reflect increasing disaffection among Moslems and a trend toward religious hostility that frightens many politicians and religious leaders.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ENTREPRENEUR
description: Women entrepreneurs are launching new companies at a rate five times faster than men, and according to the most recent report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2,565,000 women are self-employed on a full-time basis. Some of the better-known women entrepreneurs include Mary Kay Ash, Debbi Fields and Liz Claiborne, but there are many more.

title: Court Rules Out Capture Of Last Wild Condors
description: A Federal appellate court has upheld an order barring the Interior Department from capturing the last California condors remaining in the wild.

title: A MEAL AND A FRIENDLY EAR
description: THE middle-aged man sat stiffly in one of the 100 chairs in the Charity Restaurant, looking at the freezing rain outside. Across his lap was a new, neatly folded blanket; in his left hand, a paperbound copy of the ''Good Word'' Bible.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LOVERS AND FUGITIVES.

title: Board Discloses Friedman Assets
description: Interest in New York City's municipal corruption investigations has generated light as well as heat in unexpected places, and last week the dancing searchlights picked out a list of assets held by Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, and his wife, Jackie. The City Board of Ethics denied a request by Mrs. Friedman, the deputy director of the Mayor's Office of Special Projects and Events, that her annual disclosure forms be kept private.

title: ANGELA NORTH TO BE WED TO A. S. MANSON MAY 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Alton North of Blue Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Angela North to Anthony Sando Manson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Manson of the Bronx and Santa Monica, Calif.

title: JOANN BANEY TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Baney of Pittsburgh have announced the enagement of their daughter, Joann Baney, to Philip Bentley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Bentley of New York. A May 17 wedding is planned.

title: SWARTHMORE TO SELL STOCKS LINKED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The trustees of Swarthmore voted today to sell all of its $42.5 million in investments in companies that do business in South Africa.

title: CONGRESS ACTS ON LOANS BY V.A.
description: A POSSIBLE suspension of the Veterans Administration's program guaranteeing home mortgages was apparently averted last week. Congress passed legislation increasing a ceiling on the loans, and President Reagan was expected to sign the measure.

title: Space Defense Group Planned
description: The Defense Department may establish a federally financed research organization to promote President Reagan's plan for a space-based defense against missiles, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: PERFECT PIECES: CLASSIC AND SHAPELY
description: Linen Blouse by Gene Pressman and Lance Karesh for Basco, top center, $54. At Barneys New York and Bacio, Minneapolis. Polyester skirt by Agnes B., $145; 1063 Madison Avenue, near 80th Street, and 116 Prince Street, near Wooster Street.

title: WHEN IT'S BETTER TO LEASE THAN TO BUY
description: WHEN his 1978 Lincoln Mercury Monarch began to spend more time in the shop than on the road, Michael A. Mertz, a vice president of the Irving Trust Company, started pricing new cars. After suffering a severe case of sticker shock, Mr. Mertz discovered auto leasing.

title: PUT OFF BY BEAUTY AND OTHER STORIES
description: WINTER'S TALES New Series: One. Edited by David Hughes. 189 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95. AS I watched the mailman skid up my ice-covered walk, ''Winter's Tales'' in his gloved hand, I vowed to read the book slowly, reflectively - as a reviewer. But seven pages into the first story, Muriel Spark's ''Executor,'' when a woman haunted by her uncle's ghost prays, ''Make me strong, and guide and lead me as to how Mrs. Thatcher would conduct herself in circumstances of this nature'' - a prayer that perfectly sums up her character - I found myself gobbling up the feast of these fine stories.

title: POLK AWARD WINNERS ANNOUNCED BY L.I.U.
description: Thirteen George Polk Awards, including three to staff members of The New York Times, have been announced by Long Island University.

title: WASHINGTON'S HARDER LINE ON DESPOTS
description: President Reagan's decision that the time had come for President Ferdinand E. Marcos to resign sent shock waves around the world last week. Taken with the Administration's helping in the departure of President Jean-Claude Duvalier from Haiti on Feb. 7, the decision sent a powerful message to friendly despots: anti-Communist and old ally or not, an authoritarian regime that loses control of its people cannot count on continued American support.

title: CLASSIC SHAPE-UPS
description: Exercise is as popular as ever, but the thinking behind it has begun to change. Regimens have become more moderate, goals more realistic. Many women are cutting back, either because they no longer see a muscular body as desirable or, perhaps, attainable. There is also an increasing awareness of the physical stress very arduous exercise can cause. And enjoyment is beginning to be considered as important as endurance.

title: A New Complexity In Papal Plot Trial
description: There was another twist last week in the complicated Italian trial of seven men accused of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981. The chief Government prosecutor, Antonio Marini, concluded 30 hours of summation by saying that the three former Bulgarian officials on trial should be acquitted, not because he believed they were innocent but because of a lack of proof of their guilt, which is a distinction with a difference in the Italian system.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Grand Prix of Miami, GTO race. Bruce Jenner, the 1976 Olympic decathlon winner, will be driving a Ford Mustang in this second day of competition in and around the streets near Biscayne Boulevard. This is another 45-minute timed race, the winner driving the longest distance in that time. (Television - Channel 41, 2:30 P.M. tape delay). Basketball Celtics vs. Detroit Pistons, at Boston. (Television -Channel 2, 2 P.M.) Colleges: Midwestern Collegiate Conference Championship Game at Indianapolis (Television - ESPN, 2 P.M.) East Coast Conference Championships, at Towson, Md., 2 P.M. and 4 P.M., semifinals. Memphis State at Louisville (Television - MSG, 2 P.M.) North Carolina at Duke. The Tar Heels were dislodged from the No. 1 ranking by the Blue Devils last week. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.) Iowa at Indiana (Television - Channel 2, noon). Boxing Mark Breland vs. Richard Aguirre, 10 rounds, welterweights, at Lancaster, Pa. This is the Brooklyn-born Breland's 10th professional fight in an undefeated career since turning pro after winning his gold medal in the Los Angeles Olympics. He has four knockouts. (Television - Channel 7, 3 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Washington Capitals, at Madison Square Garden. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:20 P.M. Devils vs. Winnipeg Jets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 5:05 P.M. (Television - MSG, 5 P.M. Radio -WMCA 570, 5 P.M.) Oilers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Edmonton, Alberta. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Aqueduct, 1 P.M. Green Shekel is the 2-1 early favorite in the $75,000-added Togoggan Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at six furlongs.

title: SNOW CHIEF IS FIRST IN FLORIDA DERBY
description: Snow Chief and Badger Land, who finished first and second in the El Camino Real Derby in San Francisco four weeks ago, crossed the wire in the same order today in the $500,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a hospital that provides testing and treatment for Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease was misidentified in the Feb. 3 article, ''Victims Of Nerve Disease Organize.'' The hospital is the Newington Children's Hospital in Newington.

title: PAMELA CLEMENT BECOMES A BRIDE
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Pamela Kay Clement, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Clement of Milford, Mich., to Albert James Macchioni, the son of Albert J. Macchioni and Frances Macchioni, both of Pittsburgh. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: EVANGELIST AND DEMOCRATS' CHIEF TRADE FIRE
description: The potential of a Presidential candidacy by the Rev. Pat Robertson for making religion a major issue in 1988 was demonstrated here today at a gathering of Southern Republicans.
