title: DRIVE TO LIMIT PRODUCT LIABILITY AWARDS WROWS AS CONSUMER GROUPS OBJECT
description: Manufacturers and insurance companies are mounting a major drive to halt or at least reduce huge awards won by people who are injured by defective products.

title:
DINING OUT;
CANDLELIGHT AND SPARKLE IN SOMERS
description: WHEN a restaurant has provided consistently felicitous service, surroundings and food for five years, it is difficult to complain about aspects of this hospitality that have gone astray. Silvano Panizzut, owner of Silvano's, obviously takes great pride in his establishment. He is always on hand, greeting guests, making menu suggestions, fixing a drink or opening a bottle of wine, giving everything a warm and personal touch. And the dark wood-paneled and half-timbered dining rooms glowing with candlelight and sparkling table appointments make a suitable background for these attentions.

title: 12 NATURALIZED CITIZENS TO GET MEDAL OF LIBERTY
description: Twelve prominent Americans, 11 men and 1 woman, all of whom rose from immigrant beginnings, were selected yesterday as the first recipients of the Medal of Liberty, to be presented at the Statue of Liberty centennial celebration this summer.

title: ROBIN D. SEDLAR BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Robin Diane Sedlar, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Stephen Sedlar of Greenwich, was married to Howard Merritt Steele 4th, the son of Col. Howard M. Steele, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Steele of Alexandria, Va., and Longboat Key, Fla. The Rev. Richard Nye, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: THE AFRICA THAT FEW SEE
description: The warm evening air of Dakar and a sincere welcome seem to embrace us at the home of a Senegalese pharmacist we have never met before.

title:
GARDENING;
BEST TIME TO PRUNE FRUIT TREES IS NOW
description: ALTHOUGH winter is still with us, there will be many good days during the next several weeks when getting out into the garden will be profitable, and there are many tasks that can be undertaken.

title: DETAILS OF LILCO'S EVACUATION PLAN
description: I am writing in response to Bob Stein's Jan. 19 letter to the Long Island editor regarding what he calls ''some of the details of the Lilco Shoreham evacuation plan.'' As a certified radiation health physicist and someone who has been closely involved with the development of Lilco's emergency preparedness plans for the Nassau Coliseum, I would like to set the record straight on the elements of the plan he addresses. 1. He refers to ''directing over 150,000 radiation-exposed people and cars'' to travel to the Nassau Coliseum for monitoring and decontamination. There are three misconceptions in this statement. First, in its emergency planning efforts, Lilco has used a generally accepted population estimate of 160,000 people for the 10-mile Emergency Planning Zone around Shoreham. Although it is exceedingly unlikely that an evacuation of this entire zone would ever be required, it seems obvious that if it ever was required, not every resident would drive a car out of the area. Thus there would be considerably fewer than 150,000 cars going to the Coliseum.

title: Second Homes
description: WHEN the Reagan Administration proposed last year, as part of its tax-overhaul plan, to eliminate the mortgage-interest deduction for second homes, many sectors of the resort and vacation home industry reported a chilling effect on the market.

title: CANDIDATE SEARCH GOES FAR AFIELD
description: The budding contests for Governor and United States Senator in New York are demonstrating some political wisdom - the stronger the incumbent, the more likely it is that challengers will emerge from left field, or even stage left.

title: BROWN WINS TITLE AS CORNELL IS UPSET
description: Helped by a 56-53 upset victory by Princeton over Cornell, Brown captured its first Ivy League basketball championship tonight.

title: Therapy Center Seeks Renewal of Punishments
description: A school for autistic students asked a court to allow the resumption of punishments that include slappings and spankings, a lawyer said Friday.

title: JACKSONVILLE WINS IN SUN BELT
description: Jacksonville got a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs tonight by capturing the Sun Belt Conference tournament with a 70-69 triumph over Alabama-Birmingham.

title: BUBKA ISSUES PARTING SHOTS
description: Sergei Bubka had criticized Billy Olson only two weeks before as being materialistic and greedy.

title: REAGAN HAILS PROPOSALS ON PENTAGON MANAGEMENT
description: President Reagan, hailing a Presidential commission's recommendations to improve Pentagon management, said today he would ask Congress to stop ''scrutinizing every paper clip, bolt and bullet'' in the military budget.

title: DRAMAS IN WHICH THE CHANDELIER TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: In ''The Summing Up,'' W. Somerset Maugham accurately described his plays as ''drama not of action but of conversation,'' a category that could also include plays by, among others, Noel Coward, Frederick Lonsdale and, in America, S. N. Behrman. Each dealt with the domestic infelicities of the rich and the sybaritic. In partial imitation of Restoration comedy, their plays drew sustenance from an expenditure of style. If the dialogue was often less than scintillating, the plays could make an asset of superficiality; the characters satirize themselves by being themselves. Especially with Coward and Behrman, inconsequence could be elevated to wit.

title: CHRISTINE ROBERT TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robert of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Silver Spring, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christine Elizabeth Robert to Harold Michael Lynn, a son of Max Lynn of Miami and the late Frances Alexander Lynn. A fall wedding is planned.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON BECOMING A BIOLOGIST. By John Janovy Jr. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) In ''On Becoming a Biologist,'' John Janovy Jr. writes that biologists see the worth of a plant or an animal ''in its contribution to our understanding of life, not necessarily in our ability to convert it into money or prestige.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONE IS A WANDERER. By Francis King. (Little, Brown, $16.95.) Francis King's editors are not really his friends. Why, otherwise, would they allow this English novelist and critic to publish a collection of 21 stories so wildly uneven in quality? Mr. King's last novel, ''Voices in an Empty Room,'' showed him master of a subtle, melancholy style, rich and understated. At his best he achieves this in his short stories, but it occurs rarely in this collection. ''Indirect Method'' is a poignant story about an Englishwoman who returns to Japan and visits her family's former houseboy, now a married businessman, who had been her lover. The great chasm between them, and the failure of emotion to bridge it finally, is beautifully rendered, as it is in ''The Festival of the Dead,'' about an Englishwoman whose Japanese lover mourns the death of his young son. ''The Goat,'' an unsettling account of the death of an adored animal, and ''A Corner of a Foreign Field,'' about an old Japanese scholar of English literature, are both small jewels. But the rest of the stories are crude and heavily ironic, lacking depth, perception and finesse. We have the feeling that he is dashing these off. In three of the stories, for example, there appears a woman whose hair is ''an improbable shade of orange.'' Using the same trite phrase three times in the same book is not a criminal offense, but it makes the author's position clear: Mr. King simply can't be bothered to think up a new phrase, one that startles and delights and brings a character into vivid focus.

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; State Taxes Vary Widely
description: SANDRA RUFFIN, an executive with an insurance company, estimates that she cut her income tax liability by 10 percent when she left New York City to live and work in Hartford.

title: THE SHREW IS TAMED AGAIN...
description: ONE of the few luxuries afforded small theaters is the ability to occasionally produce classics or lesser-known works. Theater Three in Port Jefferson, for example, is offering Shakespeare's ''The Taming of the Shrew,'' which not only reintroduces audiences to Shakespeare's wry comedy, but also allows the actors to develop and expand their craft.

title: TO RHODE ISLAND TOWN, A ROSE IS A ROSE IS A THORN
description: Karl Jones fired the opening salvo in the war of the roses when he sold his famous garden to developers last August.

title: AUCTION OF ARTWORKS TO AID CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Original artworks and signed first editions by noted artists and writers are among the items to be auctioned at a benefit tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Victoria Munroe Gallery, 415 West Broadway.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: March 2, 1986 Fiction

title: Building Sale Contract In Palace, Report Says
description: Documents left behind when President Ferdinand E. Marcos fled his presidential palace in Manila included a 1982 contract for the $70 million purchase of an office building at 40 Wall Street in Manhattan, according to the Sunday issue of The Washington Post.

title: COAL FOR DAVY JONES'S LOCKER
description: COASTER By George Foy. 326 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95. JOHN PENROSE, the central figure in George Foy's complex thriller, is the owner-captain of a beat-up coastal freighter taking on a cargo of highly volatile coal dust at a Welsh port. En route to its destination, the cargo liquefies, shifts and sends Penrose's ship to the bottom of the English Channel. He makes a claim on a Lloyd's of London underwriter for insurance, the claim is denied, and Penrose finds himself launched on a series of hair-raising, frequently nightmarish adventures.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE POSTPONED GENERATION: Why America's Grown-up Kids Are Growing Up Later. By Susan Littwin. (Morrow, $16.95.) What a dismal picture of the young! Pampered by their parents, intellectually stunted by poor education, made cynical by politics and boggled by changing sex roles, they respond by prolonging adolescence for 10 extra years.

title: IONA SEEKING TO BROADEN HORIZONS
description: ''IF you're going to connect students to all parts of the world through technology, I think you have to give them some sense of the kind of person on the other end of that technological device,'' said Brother John G. Driscoll, president of Iona College in New Rochelle. ''They're not all Western-thinking, and unless you have some appreciation of the very deep differences, the communication is going to be trivial.''

title: THE 1:20 AMTRAK TO BASKETBALL HEAVEN
description: THERE is one week each year when I am a kid again. It is a week when all the memories of past N.I.T.'s and Holiday Festivals are suddenly so vivid that it seems like yesterday. It is a week when my family and work responsibilities take a back seat to the serious task of living basketball. It is the week of Big East tournament.

title: NETS DEFEAT KNICKS, 102-100, ON SHOT WITH 1 SECOND LEFT
description: On a night when a near-sellout crowd ventured to Madison Square Garden to honor the former Knick star Earl Monroe, the Nets spoiled the celebration.

title: MORE FAREWELLS AT CITY HALL
description: RANKING officials continue to fly off the City Hall merry-go-round. A dismissal and three resignations last week brought to about 20 the number of appointees who have left or announced plans to leave since Mayor Koch won his third term in November, promising changes.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a producer's change of plans, an article and picture caption on page 1 in the Arts and Leisure section today, as well as a theater listing in The Guide, about the Public Theater production of ''Hamlet'' contain outdated information. The opening has been postponed until next Sunday.

title: Bids to Witness Execution
description: Seven people, answering a death row inmate's auction call, have bid at least $1,000 for the right to see the condemned killer die.

title: DARIEN PRODUCTION OF 'EVITA' SOARS OVER OTHERS
description: THE Darien Dinner Theater's staging of ''Evita'' soars above that of the many other theaters that have been offering the pop opera since performance rights were released last year.

title: Finding a Pro To Prepare Your Return
description: FOR many taxpayers the questions of whether to seek professional advice and whom to consult can be as daunting as filling out the tax returns.

title: RUTH H. LEWIS IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Ruth Honey Lewis to Heath Culp has been announced by the future bride's parents, Joyce Brandt Lewis and Charles M. Lewis, both of New York. Her fiance is a son of Dr. Lawrence H. Culp of Menlo Park, Calif., an internist, and Dr. Claire Langston of Houston, a pediatric pathologist. An August wedding is planned.

title: HENDERSON AIMS FOR BETTER YEAR
description: His legs carried Rickey Henderson around the bases a career-high and major-league-leading 146 times last season and to a Yankee-record 80 stolen bases. The legs, though, are only the second-most important part of Henderson's body.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GRANIA: She-King of the Irish Seas. By Morgan Llywelyn. (Crown, $17.95.) What becomes a legend most? ''Battle and murder''? ''Imprisonment and impoverishment''? Thus ponders Grania, legendary 16th-century Irish chieftain and self-proclaimed She-King of Ireland, as her life passes before her eyes in cinema verite detail.

title: HITTING THE CULTURAL HIGHLIGHTS
description: Following is a report on cultural highlights in Europe of special interest to visitors -from exhibits in England marking the 900th anniversary of the Domesday Book to performances in Denmark celebrating Hans Christian Andersen year. It was compiled by Carol Plum based on reports from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Rome and Bonn. Details of music festivals abroad will appear in a guide to be published in the Travel section on May 4. ENGLAND The Royal Shakespeare Company opens at the Barbican Center in London at the end of March with the rarely performed ''Mephisto'' by Ariane Mnouchkine, adapted from the Klaus Mann novel. This will play in repertory with ''Troilus and Cressida'' and ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' through April, May and June. In July there will be a premiere of a play by Pam Gems called ''The Danton Affair.'' The Royal Shakespeare Theater in Stratford-on-Avon opens April 8 with ''Romeo and Juliet,'' directed by Michael Bogdanov. A new Royal Shakespeare Company production of ''The Winter's Tale,'' directed by Terry Hands, with Jeremy Irons in the role of Leontes, opens April 30, followed by ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' In September, Jeremy Irons will appear in ''Richard II,'' directed by Barry Kyle. November brings ''Macbeth'' to the stage with Jonathan Pryce and Sinead Cusack. The production will run through January 1987. A new theater for the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford-on-Avon will open May 8. It will be called the Swan Theater and will be used to present plays by Shakespeare's contemporaries.

title: SCANDINAVIAN JOURNEY, ALASKAN FESTIVAL
description: Looking at The Artistry Of the North The architectural glory of Petrodvorets, the ornate summer residence of Peter the Great, the painterly masterworks created by artists such as Caravaggio and Rembrandt, Munch and Picasso. This, as well as spectacular landscapes, may be seen and admired on an art and architecture tour, scheduled for this spring, that will take its participants to Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland and the Soviet city of Leningrad.

title: FROM QUEENS TO BUENOS AIRES, TANGO CASTS ITS SULTRY SPELL
description: The triumph of the Broadway revue ''Tango Argentino'' suggests that we may be in for another tango craze like the one that began in this country before World War I and lasted into the 30's. ''Tango Argentino'' is not the cause of the current tango revival, but is simply at the crest of a wave of renewed interest that has been gathering strength for several years.

title: CHEFS UPSET OVER A TEST OF COOKING
description: At the Culinary Institute of America, the famous cooking school in Hyde Park, N.Y., some of the 1,850 aspiring chefs are unhappy about a new requirement for graduation: preparing a meal.

title:
GARDENING;
BEST TIME TO PRUNE FRUIT TREES IS NOW
description: ALTHOUGH winter is still with us, there will be many good days during the next several weeks when getting out into the garden will be profitable, and there are many tasks that can be undertaken.

title: What Makes An Entrepreneur
description: The entrepreneurs, as portrayed in Daniel Goleman's article ''The Psyche of the Entrepreneur'' (Feb. 2), are in rivalry with their fathers, love their mothers, are diligent, want to better themselves, are risk takers, have an inner standard of excellence, crave autonomy, get fired from their jobs, are intuitive, have charisma, exhibit social adroitness and charm, need to rebel, are wily in their risk-taking, have self-confidence, may founder, may succeed, need applause, are egotistical, have the ability to spot trends, are fascinating to the young and hold out a hopeful message that life is not a trap but a promise. This also sounds like the account executive in a brokerage house, a minister of the Gospel, the C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company and, for that matter, millions of other Americans. This is not meant to criticize the article, but rather to applaud it in its affirmation of America as the land of entrepreneurs. ROBERT M. COLTON Program Manager Industry/University Cooperative Research Centers Program National Science Foundation Washington

title: SICILY TRIAL ALREADY UNRAVELING 2 MAFIA MYTHS
description: The magistrates prosecuting the Sicilian Mafia in the largest trial of its kind ever conducted believe they have scored two victories recently, victories against myths sometimes more powerful than men.

title: GIFTED PIANISTS TEST THEIR METTLE
description: Of all Schubert's piano sonatas, the one in B flat is by far the most commonly played, both live and on recording. Yet it remains fresh, interesting and moving even after dozens of hearings. It is a piece to which many pianists have brought many things, and numerous recorded readings have much to recommend them; Alfred Brendel's on Philips comes to mind, as does the version beautifully played by the Hungarian pianist Dezso Ranki and newly released on Denon compact disk 32C37-7488 (44 minutes), entitled ''Ranki Plays Schubert.''

title: CARLEY E. DENLINGER AND HARRY LEE, LAW STUDENTS, MARRY IN CONNECTICUT
description: Carley Elizabeth Denlinger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland W. G. Denlinger of Newtown, Conn., and Harry Lee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Lee of Bethesda, Md., both third-year students at the Columbus School of Law at the Catholic University of America, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newtown. The Rev. Kent C. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: TEAMING UP AGAINST AIDS
description: SOMETIMES, WHEN HE IS SPEAKING about AIDS, Myron Essex sounds like a man possessed. The effect is odd and somewhat incongruous with the way he looks and with what he does for a living.

title: CON SPIRITO QUINTET, A WOODWIND ENSEMBLE
description: The Con Spirito Woodwind Quintet, a Pittsburgh-based ensemble that offered a program of works by Franz Danzi, Faye-Ellen Silverman, Gyorgy Ligeti and Samuel Barber at the Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night, plays with wit, elegance, teamwork and, yes, spirit.

title: Brazil Opens War On Inflation
description: Brazil's inflation seemed to be approaching a rate of 500 percent last week, so President Jose Sarney hit the brakes.

title: DEMOCRACY ASSERTS ITSELF IN THE PHILIPPINES
description: IT took the Filipino people 18 days to shed a President once their rage had been stoked at the ballot boxes. It was a historic wonder to see: shabby knaves who murdered and cheated their countrymen of the precious vote were swept aside by people who rose up in an act of self-determination inspired by the most basic human stuff - weeping, cheering, praying, singing and a sheer yearning for democracy.

title: THE FOLLY OF INFLATING QUARTERLY PROFITS
description: To meet quarterly revenue targets, the Daisy Systems Corporation, a Silicon Valley computer maker, often rushed to ship as many computers as possible at the end of each quarter. Sometimes that meant shipping new products that had not yet been perfected. Other times it meant forgetting to include floppy disks, or other vital parts.

title: COUNCILMAN TAKES 58% OF VOTE IN NEW ORLEANS MAYORAL CONTEST
description: After a bitter campaign in the runoff to succeed Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial, Sidney Barthelemy, a Council member with 12 years' experience in city government was easily the winner over State Senator William Jefferson, a Harvard-educated lawyer, with all the returns in tonight.

title: ANTI-APARTHEID CLERIC SAVES BLACK CALLED INFORMER
description: The Rev. Allan Boesak, President of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches and a prominent anti-Government campaigner, was reported today to have jumped from the altar at a mass funeral rally to save the life of man denounced by another cleric as a police informer.

title: FINE PERFORMANCES BLOOM IN WINTER
description: Before it's too late, let's talk about some remarkable performances currently on view. The actor's lot must be a maddening one. When a film is very good, the actor's contribution tends to be taken for granted, absorbed into the film itself, and when the film is somewhat less than great, the performance has a way of being tossed out with the container that holds it.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: March 2, 1986 Fiction

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The current national welfare system, although aimed at assisting poor people who cannot meet their own needs, provides unneeded benefits to many people who are not poor, reduces incentives for work and self-reliance and discourages strong families and community ties.'' - Charles D. Hobbs, deputy assistant to the President for policy development. [ 1:2. ]

title: PEACE MARCHERS SET OFF ON A CROSS-COUNTRY TREK
description: Waving American flags, balloons and banners, with some carrying children on their shoulders, 1,200 people marched away from City Hall here today on a walk to promote nuclear disarmament that they hope will take them 3,235 miles to Washington.

title: STUDENTS BRIEFED ON PLANS OF UTILITY
description: MECHANICAL engineering seniors at the Stevens Institute of Technology here learned last week that the economics of deregulation was playing a parallel role with emerging technologies in the future of the utilities industry.

title: STAGE: 'MADAME ZORA,' A BIOGRAPHICAL MUSICAL
description: WHEN Zora Neale Hurston was a child in a black community in Florida, her adored mother instilled her with ambition, telling her to ''jump at the sun,'' a suggestion that became a kind of motto for Hurston's extraordinary life. Motherless at 9, a runaway at 14, she never suppressed her high-vaulted dreams. She willed herself to become a novelist, folklorist and controversial icon of the Harlem Renaissance.

title: TWIN PIANISTS TO PLAY WITH THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The duo-pianists Guher and Suher Pekinel will make their New York concert debut on March 6 in a performance of Mozart's Concerto for Two Pianos in E-flat (K. 365) with the New York Philharmonic, under the direction of Zubin Mehta.

title: CHALLENGER'S FAILURE AND NASA'S FLAWS
description: When President Reagan named a blue-ribbon panel three weeks ago to investigate the space shuttle disaster, many thought its members would simply offer their dignified blessings as space agency engineers tracked down, then fixed, the failed hardware that led to the eerie fireball that consumed the Challenger over Cape Canaveral. Now, hardly anyone can remember a time when it seemed that equipment, and not the agency itself, was at fault for the explosion that claimed seven lives.

title: Buckley's Pen Is Quick
description: To the Editor:

title: MITTERRAND SOCIALISM UNDER SIEGE
description: FANCOIS MIT-terrand stood the other evening at the end of a red carpet stretching a quarter-mile through a vast exhibition hall in Lille, a depressed industrial city that is in the spiritual heartland of French Socialism. Spotlights glared harshly through the smoky air of the hall, illuminating filigrees of electrical wiring and webs of metallic scaffolding. An agitated whispering swept over the audience of 20,000 and then died away like a wind disappearing, to be replaced by a loudspeaker version of the Marseillaise.

title: Ozark and T.W.A. Sign Pact
description: Ozark Airlines and Trans World Airlines Inc. today signed a $250 million merger agreement that makes Ozark a subsidiary of T.W.A., which remains the nation's fifth largest airline. The agreement, tentatively approved Thursday by Ozark's parent company, Ozark Holdings Inc., was signed at early this morning by Ozark officials in St. Louis and at the same time in New York by T.W.A. officials. The merger, which will pay $19 each for approximately 12.8 million shares of Ozark stock, is subject to the approval of shareholders and the Department of Transportation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map last Sunday showing museum sites in Israel incorrectly spelled the name of the kibbutz near Beersheba that is the home of the Museum for Bedouin Culture. The kibbutz is Lahav.

title: Changing the Party?
description: As Soviet officials strive to explain Mikhail Gorbachev's blueprint for change, it becomes increasingly evident that the crucial point is the way the party works.

title: No Headline
description: The huge portrait of Saddam Hussein dwarfing the troops outside the army command post on the mud flats in the Fao peninsula is unusual.

title: DAVID BROWN IS WED TO MAUREEN E. RUTTER
description: Maureen Elizabeth Rutter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Rutter of York, Pa., was married there yesterday to David Gerard Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Augustus Brown 2d of Blue Bell, Pa. Msgr. Thomas R. Brenner performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: CARROLL A. RAMBO IS WED IN CAPITAL
description: Carroll Ann Rambo, an editor in the NBC News Washington bureau, and Walter Robert Mears, a vice president and the executive editor of The Associated Press in New York, were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Stephan E. Klingelhofer performed the ceremony.

title: SO YOU'RE THINKING OF A CONDOMINIUM IN FLORIDA -- THINK AGAIN
description: IF ever there was a time when it could be said that heaven and earth conspired, it was the winter of 1981. No one could have envisioned more perfect weather or a more accommodating market than there was on the Gulf Coast of Florida that year. Although interest rates were high, condominium fever ran higher still, sweeping all attempts at objectivity aside.

title: MARIE SOLAZZO MARRIED TO ROBERT DEL CIELLO ON L.I.
description: Marie T. Solazzo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Solazzo of Astoria, Queens, and Sound Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Del Ciello, the son of Concetta Del Ciello and Angelo Del Ciello, both of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Thomas Hammond performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour in Manhasset, L.I.

title: G. R. SCHONFELD PLANS TO WED SALLY FELDMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eli Feldman of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sally Feldman to Gordon Raphael Schonfeld, a son of Frances Schonfeld of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Gabriel Schonfeld. The wedding is planned for June.

title: 2 Officers Seized in Larceny
description: Two police officers have been arrested on charges of embezzling more than $10,000 from the Wilton Police Association, a fraternal organization, over the past six years. The officers, Sgt. Ernest Lepore and Detective Lawrence Stoeckle, have been suspended without pay for nearly a month, Police Chief Angelo Toscano said. They surrendered to the Wilton police Thursday and were charged with first-degree larceny by embezzlement and conspiracy to commit first-degree larceny by embezzlement, the chief said.

title: Investing For After-Tax Returns; New Approaches Required
description: OF all the imponderables facing investors today, none is as critical as the proposed overhaul of the nation's tax code. The proposals before Congress, if enacted, would change the general economic climate, as well as the tax situation of individual investors.

title: It May Be Time to Rethink the Jury System
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN BY STARS, 5-4
description: Willi Plett and Tom McCarthy each scored two goals to spark the Minnesota North Stars to a 5-4 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: ITALY'S ROYAL HEIR, IN EXILE, PLEADS TO RETURN
description: Once upon a time there was a King of Italy. But his family is no longer welcome here. In fact, the heir to the throne is begging to come back.

title: AUTO-INSURANCE REFORM IS NEEDED, BUT HASTY DECISIONS IN TRENTON COULD MAKE A BAD SITUATION WORSE
description: NEW JERSEY is probably the only state in the nation where it is sometimes cheaper to buy a used car than to insure it.

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; I.R.S. Tries To Reduce Paper Load
description: MANY taxpayers this tax season did not receive the usual forms and instructions in the mail from the Internal Revenue Service. Instead they received a postcard.

title: A THREAD OF CONTINUITY RETIRES
description: HAS Cantor Ephraim Steinhauer forgotten a thing?

title: SHCOOL ROUND THE YEAR CALLED WAVE OF FUTURE
description: Proponents of the plan to expand the year-round calendar to more schools in the half-million-pupil Los Angeles School District say the idea may represent a wave of the future for school systems with problems of overcrowding.

title: WHAT THE HINDENBURG MAY REVEAL ABOUT THE CHALLENGER
description: The hydrogen-fueled fireball that consumed the ship had barely subsided before investigators pounced on the wreckage in an all-out search for scapegoats. The disaster had cast a pall over a transportation system that had taken decades to develop. The technological prestige of a nation seemed at stake.

title: NO SEX PLEASE -- WE'RE ELFISH
description: THE LITTLE PEOPLE By MacDonald Harris. 299 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95. RURAL England, which is surely now among the tamest and most conquered of landscapes, goes on being the setting for an improbably large number of stories that draw on the primeval forces of wild nature, the dark backward of gods and fairies, the old Druid forest and the barrow and megalith. MacDonald Harris is an American, and at first it seems that may be what makes his particular variant on the standard themes so strangely unreal; but no, it's more than that.

title: PANEL SHIFTING SHUTTLE INQUIRY BEYOND LIFTOFF
description: Members of the Presidential commission investigating the space shuttle explosion say the exact cause is still a mystery despite extensive public hearings this week that focused on space agency procedures and the debilitating effects of ice and cold on the Challenger and its twin booster rockets.

title: GRASP THE REAL LESSONS
description: The Reagan Administration is trying to claim credit for the peaceful transition in the Philippines - and to a large extent it is succeeding. In fact, the White House fought against the inevitable turnover and would have preferred to continue supporting former President Ferdinand E. Marcos. It remains to be seen whether President Reagan has grasped the lessons of the peaceful revolution in Manila.

title: F.B.I. Says Tylenol Had Been Opened
description: To find out who put cyanide in two packages of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules found in Westchester County, investigators first have to figure out how and where they were poisoned. The Federal Bureau of Investigation still did not have the answer last week, but it did uncover a clue.

title: VIEWING THE CRISIS FROM THE BACK 40
description: THE fact that troubled farmers are winning more sympathy from city residents than from their rural neighbors, according to the latest New York Times/CBS poll, did not surprise John Schnittker and other agriculture experts or even many farmers. There are easily identifiable reasons for the phenomenon, said Mr. Schnittker, a Washington consultant who was a Deputy Secretary of Agriculture in the 1960's - not the least of them the closer knowledge of agriculture among rural people. ''They are right out there and can see the mistakes that have been made,'' Mr. Schnittker explained.

title: Iran Says Its Troops Push Near Iraqi Town
description: Iranian troops on an offensive into northern Iraq pushed within 13 miles of the provincial capital of Sulaimaniya today, a war communique broadcast by the Teheran radio said.

title: SOME TAX PROPOSALS FOR BOTH PAYERS AND EVADERS
description: Last week, a Senate subcommittee held hearings on proposals to tax imported oil. Other tax plans are under review as the Finance Committee prepares to begin drafting its version of tax-revision legislation later this month. An examination of the variety of measures being considered, and their prospects, follows.

title: GROUPS TRY TO STEM TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: IN recent weeks several groups affiliated with schools, churches and youth centers around the state have been responding to what educators and health professionals call a national crisis - the increasing number of teen-age suicides.

title: LIVING AMONG THEIR ENEMIES
description: CONFLICTS AND CONTRADICTIONS By Meron Benvenisti. 210 pp. New York: Villard Books. $15.95. IN A. B. Yehoshua's novella ''Facing the Forests'' (published in Israel in 1963), a young Israeli watchman, a forest scout, is haunted by the remains of an Arab village that was bulldozed to make way for a newly planted forest of slender pine trees. The watchman shares the solitude of the forest with an old Arab who cannot speak and an Arab child. The solitude is interrupted every now and then by groups of hikers who come to admire the work of the Afforestation Department. One such group of hikers turned up with a map and inquired as to the whereabouts of an Arab village. ''A village?'' the watchman asked. He knew of no such village: ''The map must be wrong, the surveyor's hand must have shaken.'' But the old Arab, in excited gestures, ''pointing fervently, hopelessly, at the forest,'' confirms that a village once stood there. The young watchman now wants the forest to burn down. Eventually, on the last night of his assignment, he looks away as the old Arab burns down the forest in a ''riot of horror and glee.'' And out of the smoke and haze, the ruined village appears before his eyes ''in its basic outlines as an abstract drawing, as all things past and buried.''

title: ASCOLI QUINTESSENTIAL ITALY
description: To the ears of most Italians Ascoli Piceno has a quaint provincial sound. Foreigners who hear it for the first time may ask, Ascoli what? Some travel agents blink at inquiries about the town because it is usually bypassed by international tour operators.

title: IN QUEST OF THE EVER ELUSIVE HAMLET
description: Boyish and jaunty, he looks more like a graduate student than a theatrical luminary; old black jeans, battered Topsiders and a sweatshirt have been his customary attire of late, hardly a get-up to recall John Barrymore or Laurence Olivier in a regal role. On closer inspection, however, the sweatshirt is arresting. ''Property of Wittenberg University Philosophy Department'' it reads on the front. When Kevin Kline turns around, centered in the middle of his back is a small, discreet logo: the symbol of infinity, with only one word, ''Hamlet,'' floating below it.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GRACE ESTATE HIKE The ink is barely dry on the check for $6.3 million that the Town of East Hampton recently paid for 431 acres of the Grace Estate, but the land is already being opened to the public in a limited way. The tract that dominates the northwest section of the town is not a formal park, but rather is to be left in its natural state of woods, bluffs and wetlands. The Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference will be among the first groups to make use of the estate's extensive trails system when it holds a free ''Grace Estate Special'' hike today for early birds. For information and registration, call 473-6760 before 8:30 A.M.

title: MONACO
description: Monaco may look a bit different here and there to visitors who return this year. The renovation of old buildings, the construction of new ones and the reclamation of land from the Mediterranean Sea are all now beginning to show results. Climbing up and down Monaco's steep cliff-side streets was always a tiring business, but visitors this year will find five strategically situated public elevators that make life easier for strollers. This summer visitors will also see the start of some important changes at Monaco's best-known tourist attraction, the green-domed casino at Monte Carlo.

title: DANCE: EASTERN OFFERINGS BY SERENA THEATER
description: VIVID color, good humor and infectiously cheerful humor filled the stage when the Serena Dance Theater performed on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Serena, the star and chief choreographer of the program, is a generous performer with a nice sense of humor and an uncanny, fleeting facial resemblance to Ruth St. Denis. Her dancers share her humor and warmth. And there were several standout numbers in ''Visions of Salome,'' a program of 14 Eastern dances.

title: CHRISTINE MITCHELL TO WED
description: Christine Anne Mitchell and Gregg Griffith Asplundh, seniors at St. Lawrence University, plan to be married in the fall.

title: KATHERINE BARRETT TO WED B. C. SWETT
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York and Water Mill, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Leah Barrett to Benjamin Chanler Swett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven C. Swett of Purdys, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May. Miss Barrett, a graduate student in English at Columbia University, graduated from the Brearley School and magna cum laude with the class of '82 from Harvard College.

title: BARN TO TOWN HOUSES
description: A barn dating from the 1850's, part of what was once the Stults Farm, has been sacrificed for six three-story town houses in the heart of downtown Princeton, N.J.

title: MISS HENNING TO WED WALTON VINCENT CLARK
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert V. Henning of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Ruth Henning to Walton Vincent Clark, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Clark of Winston-Salem, N.C. A June wedding is planned.

title: At St. Bart's, Round Three
description: Officials of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church said last week that they would appeal to a higher authority - the Federal courts - in an effort to win permission to build an office tower on the grounds of the church at Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets. Their statement came after New York City's Landmarks Preservation Commission rejected the building proposal for the third time in three years.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FANTASY AND PARODY
description: P.D.Q. Bach's 'Abduction of Figaro' Featuring Peter Schickele Video Arts International 144 minutes. $59.95 In his full-length opera ''The Abduction of Figaro,'' Peter Schickele (speaking through his imaginary composer P.D.Q. Bach) pulls together the stock characters of Mozartean opera and then uses music to make us laugh at them.

title: Children, Custody And the Courts
description: As a reflection of a father's grief - and a grandfather's anger - over the outcome of a custody dispute, James E. Smith Jr.'s article ''A Sense of Injustice'' (About Men, Jan. 26) is as accurate as it is poignant; and his opinion that the judge made a mistake in his son's case is clear beyond any doubt.

title: JAZZ PIANOS: TRENNER AND HALE
description: AT a time when jazz piano solos tend to be made up of running lines of single notes, Donn Trenner has returned to New York after almost 30 years in California with a style that places emphasis on chords. He played at the Knickerbocker Saloon on University Place through last night, joined in a two-piano setup by Corky Hale and backed by the bassist Jay Leonhart.

title: DONNA N. SCHNEIDER PLANS TO MARRY PHILIP M. SCHER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Schneider of Woodmere, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Nancy Schneider, to Philip Michael Sher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Sher of Clifton, N.J.

title: A BUILT-IN ELECTRONIC BUDDY SYSTEM
description: ONE reason that a piece of business software becomes popular - besides doing something useful - is that other people are using it. There is someone to turn to for help and advice on its idiosyncracies. These mentors, and, naturally, some degree of marketing savvy, have kept Lotus 1-2-3, dBase, and WordStar on the industry's equivalent of a best-seller list for so long that it seems cast in concrete.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FANTASY AND PARODY
description: The Best of Elvis Costello and the Attractions CBS/Fox Video Music 65 minutes. $24.95 Elvis Costello likes his video clips casual and unslick, belying the intricate structures of the songs behind them.

title: THE LIFE AND HARD TIMES OF CINDERELLA
description: MARYA A Life. By Joyce Carol Oates. 310 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95. WE punish Joyce Carol Oates for the crime of her productivity. A book a year, in some years two - we respond as if she did it just to make us look bad, the A student who hands in for a geography assignment not only a weather map of the Hawaiian Islands, but a papier-mache model of a volcano as well. Our sense of her work as a mass ready at any moment to engulf us makes us reluctant to read, as they come toward us, the individual works and to differentiate among them. Partly, we assume that if there are that many none can be any good, as if literature were a finite resource like, say, a soup meant to serve 10 which had been cynically thinned to fill the bowls of 36.

title: WAS SOVIET SEAMAN SWITCHED FOR A NON-DEFECTOR
description: Four months after a Soviet seaman jumped into the Mississippi River and said he wanted to defect, only to be sent home after apparently changing his mind, 60 senators want to reopen the case amid allegations that Soviet officials switched seamen.

title: LYNNE LUMSDEN AND JON B. HARDEN, EXECUTIVES IN PUBLISHING, TO BE WED
description: Lynne Ann Lumsden, executive vice president and publisher of Dodd, Mead & Company and a partner in the Gamut Publishing Company, is engaged to Jon Bixby Harden, a financial consultant to Dodd, Mead.

title: ONWARD AND UPWARD WITH THE SHELMIKEDMU
description: KRIPPENDORF'S TRIBE By Frank Parkin. 192 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. JAMES KRIPPENDORF, the protagonist of Frank

title: RENT LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES MADISON, MINUS HALO
description: DECISION IN PHILADELPHIA The Constitutional Convention of 1787. By Christopher Collier and James Lincoln Collier. 331 pp. New York: Reader's Digest Press/Random House. $19.95. THE major anniversary of a great event in American history usually produces a flurry of books, needed or not. We need books about the creation of the Constitution, so we can look forward with anticipation to the bicentennial of its birth in 1987.

title: UCONN IS TAKING NEW LOOK AT SPORTS
description: AS an All-America basketball player at Long Island University in the 40's, Dick Holub managed to graduate in four years, although his junior and senior years were interrupted by four years in the Army Air Corps during World War II.

title: NEWTON REZONING ACTIVELY SOUGHT
description: WHEN officials in the Boston suburb of Newton first received certified letters from Shirley Jaffe, an aggrieved property owner, a year ago, they dubbed them Jaffegrams.

title: IT THERE AN ARMS CONTROL DIALOGUE OF TWO MONOLOGUES?
description: Despite the skepticism some Administration officials feel toward the arms control process, the prospect of agreements has helped President Reagan make his case for increased military spending. In his televised speech Wednesday, Mr. Reagan asserted that the United States military buildup had ''brought the Soviet Union to the negotiating table and given us this historic opportunity to achieve real reductions in nuclear weapons.''

title: BEHIND A RISE IN SEXUAL-ABUSE REPORTS
description: A 16-year-old high school student from this Suffolk County suburb was arraigned last week on charges of having hired a classmate to murder her father. The police say the young woman, Cheryl Pierson, told them her father, who was shot dead on Feb. 5, had sexually abused her for the last five years.

title: MUSICAL 'KUNI-LEML' STAGED
description: AVROM GOLDFADN, who is often referred to as the grandfather of Yiddish theater, was not only the first important Yiddish dramatist, he was the first to put women on stage in Yiddish plays.

title: JAZZ/IN THE CLUBS
description: When Michele Bautier opened a two-week engagement at Freddy's, 308 East 49th Street, on Jan. 21 singing a program of songs by Duke Ellington and Harold Arlen, it was her debut in New York. In fact, it was the first time she had sung as a soloist anywhere except Asbury Park, N.J., and the Poconos. However, the musical underground had been anticipating her, spurred by the enthusiasm of Sylvia Syms and Margaret Whiting who had been judges when Miss Bautier won a talent contest at Freddy's last summer that resulted in her January engagement.

title: MISS RAMSDEN TO WED MICHAEL RABIN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Ramsden of Barrington, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine L. Ramsden, to Michael Z. Rabin, the son of Dr. Pauline L. Rabin and the late Dr. David Rabin of Nashville. An August wedding is planned.

title: NETS FINISH WEEK THEY'D RATHER FORGET
description: Be certain of this: The Nets are not going to put the events of last week in a promotional film for prospective ticket buyers. They bickered on the court and in their dressing room, they tumbled further into the throes of another slump and they suffered perhaps their greatest loss, the banishment of Micheal Ray Richardson from a game that was his lifeblood.

title: 99 WINSLOW HOMER WATERCOLORS IN NATIONAL GALLERY RETROSPECTIVE
description: Winslow Homer once predicted that if he won a place for himself in the pantheon of American artists, it would be for his watercolors. ''You will see,'' he told a collector, ''in the future I will live by my watercolors.''

title: Learning Disabled And Competition
description: A Jan. 26 article on the Special Olympics said that ''mentally retarded and learning-disabled children and young adults participate.''

title: GLEAMING FILIGREE IN LISBON
description: Filigree, the ancient art of ornamental openwork wrought of fine gold or silver wire, is flourishing in Portugal today as it has for generations.

title: RANGERS ARE SHUT DOWN BY CAPITALS, 4-0
description: It was necessary only to see Glen Hanlon flopping round the goal to know that the Rangers were dominated tonight. But there were other sights that were as convincing, that of the Rangers being taken bodily off the puck time and again.

title: 120,000 SQ. FT. FOR KENWOOD
description: The Kenwood USA Corporation, a manufacturer of video and audio components, plans to build a distribution and sales office in the International Trade Center, a duty-free trade zone in Mount Olive, N.J.

title: BERRA AND SCURRY ACCEPT PUNISHMENT
description: Dale Berra and Rod Scurry, two of the three Yankees disciplined by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for their use of cocaine, readily accepted the penalties today, with Scurry calling the action ''a great day for baseball.'' Al Holland, the third member of the Yankees involved, continued to decline comment on the penalty Ueberroth levied against him.

title: TOWER FOR POWER
description: For basketball fans, a 37-story, 224-unit condominium tower rising next to Lincoln Center almost certainly will hold bittersweet memories of another tower.

title: U.S. POLICY IS SET ON TERROR FIGHT
description: The Reagan Administration, in a new policy declaration on combating terrorism, will endorse only the most cautious use of force in retaliation against terrorist acts, Administration officials said today.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
...AS BARD STARS ON HOFSTRA STAGE
description: AFTER 24 years as director of Hofstra University's Shakespeare Festival, James Van Wart knew he should not have been surprised to find something new in an old favorite.

title: Government Units Battle Near Cairo
description: Paramilitary security police who normally enforce the law ran afoul of it in Egypt last week, and the surge of violence shook the Government of President Hosni Mubarak and cost Interior Minister Ahmed Rushdi, one of the country's most powerful politicians, his job.

title: BOARD PANEL SEEKING NEW SOURCES OF REVENUE
description: FOR Daniel P. Thomas of Yonkers, it is getting harder to tell where his job at Mount St. Vincent College ends and his job as a Westchester County Legislator begins. In both cases, he has one overriding concern: raising money.

title: MUGABI: AT BOXING'S FRONT DOOR
description: EARLIER this week, camp aides of the middleweight contender John (the Beast) Mugabi were worried about the rattlesnakes of Rio Rico, Ariz., a small settlement tucked away in mountainous territory, 16 miles from the Mexican border.

title: WINFIELD HELPING YOUTH COMBAT DRUGS
description: Drug developments in baseball do not all center on suspension and rehabilitation. Dave Winfield of the Yankees and Joe Beckwith of Kansas City, along with other members of the Royals, for example, are in the forefront of a growing effort by players to polish the sport's tarnished image.

title: PROBING SOCIETY'S TABOOS - ON CANVAS
description: The single painting that announced Eric Fischl's arrival in the art world - the one that riveted the attention of art critics and earned him a reputation as a ''controversial'' artist - is called ''Bad Boy.'' First shown in a New York gallery in 1981, it depicts a young man groping for money in a woman's purse, even as he watches her stretching out seductively, naked, on a rumpled bed.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: SPRING IN PHILADELPHIA For a week, starting next Sunday, hundreds of orchids will tremble under the assault of computerized rainstorms at the Philadelphia Civic Center.

title: The Curve Comeback
description: When Azzedine Alaia's fashion show blazed through the Palladium last fall, it did more than mix uptown and downtown on the 14th Street border. It helped officially introduce a new look in women's fashion. The tiny Tunisian has put the glovelike fit back into women's clothes.

title: U.N. RECOGNIZES ITS SUCCESSES
description: The United Nations Postal Administration will issue on March 14 a set of three se-tenant blocks to commemorate the United Nations Development Programme (U.N.D.P.). The blocks illustrate some of the U.N.D.P.'s more successful projects.

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; Avoiding the Minimum Tax
description: RECENTLY, a corporate executive was looking forward to exercising an incentive stock option that would enable him to pick up some shares for less than their market value. But his accountant cautioned him that what seemed like a bargain could increase his taxes -because the difference between fair market value and incentive option prices is one of the tax preference items of the alternative minimum tax.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
SUFFOLK MOVES TO SAVE LAKE RONKONKOMA
description: LARRY HOLZAPFEL'S bookstore on Lake Shore Road in Lake Ronkonkoma is one of the last structures to survive from a time when the area was one of the Island's premier resorts.

title: CELEBRATING THE PRESERVATION OF 300 YEARS OF ARCHITECTURE
description: ''THERE is a remarkable number of different kinds of buildings and buildings from different periods here in Westchester County. Too often people pass by and don't see them.''

title: THEATER: CHARLES S. DUTTON IN ''OTHELLO,'' AT YALE
description: In his Broadway debut in August Wilson's ''Ma Rainey's Black Bottom,'' Charles S. Dutton played a jazz musician driven to violence. He was so deeply in character that a skeptic might have wondered if his performance were an accident of circumstances. Now Mr. Dutton has moved upward to the challenge of ''Othello'' (at the Yale Repertory Theater, the original scene of his first triumph). He gives ample evidence that he is an actor of range as well as of raging intensity.

title: THINGS GO BETTER WITH GOETHE
description: ON Sept. 3, 1985, page 11 of The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung was half-filled by an advertisement for a brand-new publication called The New Medical Journal. The advertising copy bore an epigraph signed ''Goethe'': ''Beginnings are always hard; they often don't lie ready to hand . . . and what everybody wants will emerge only slowly.'' Now of course there is a saying in German that beginnings are hard. But to say that would be too boring, so we get Goethe to say it, even though in this case he is really only repeating what we call the wisdom of the people.

title: MURDOCH SAVORS HIS BRITISH COUP
description: NEVER has a potentate under seige appeared so relaxed and pleased with himself. Rupert Murdoch still sits behind rolls of barbed wire and high steel gates at ''Fortress Wapping,'' as the new headquarters of his British newspaper empire has been dubbed since he consolidated here on the banks of the Thames in the face of a strike by 5,800 print and other workers. But having maintained nearly complete press runs without the strikers for five weeks, he is past the point of gloating or claiming victory. Whatever the pickets outside may think, in his own mind he has won.

title: NKOMO SAYS SOLE AMBITION NOW IS PEACE
description: Joshua Nkomo, the often fiery and ambitious leader of Zimbabwe's main opposition party, seems a subdued man as he speaks softly of personal hopes for peace in his lifetime in a nation scarred by years of civil unrest.

title: BOTH SIDES BUOY IN PAY-EQUITY CASE
description: THE recent resolution of what lawyers are calling a landmark lawsuit in Washington State has generated optimism on both sides in a suit charging that women employed by Nassau County are paid less than men for doing the same kind of work.

title: MISS MEYERS IS AFFIANCED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John A. Meyers of Greenwich, Conn., and North Palm Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter Katherine Jane Meyers to Matthew E. Gormly 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gormly Jr. of Encino, Calif. A September wedding is planned.

title: Should Ellis Island Be for the Few or the Many?
description: To the Editor:

title: Children, Custody And the Courts
description: I am moved to write because I suspect that child custody has become the weapon of choice for those men who seek to punish women for daring to ask for equality.

title: LAURA Z. HOBSON, AUTHOR, DIES AT 85
description: Laura Z. Hobson, the author of the acclaimed 1947 novel on anti-Semitism in America, ''Gentleman's Agreement,'' died of cancer at New York Hospital Friday night. She was 85 years old and had lived in New York almost all her life.

title: Women's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE SERPENT AND THE RAINBOW. By Wade Davis. (Simon & Shuster, $17.95.) Zombies are more than legend, it seems. Haitian sorcerers actually use substances than can drastically reduce the body's metabolic rate and cause a condition of seeming death.

title: GERMANS DEBATE NEW ANTI SEMITISM
description: A spate of anti-Semitic remarks by West German politicians has touched off a national debate in which Chancellor Helmut Kohl has been accused of unwittingly reviving hostile feelings toward Jews.

title: LEIGH ARMSTRONG PLANNING TO WED DAVID HOVEY JR.
description: The engagement of Leigh Kenaston Armstrong to David H. Hovey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hovey of Simsbury, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John K. Armstrong of Bloomfield, Conn., and Chatham, parents of the bride-to-be. A June wedding is planned.

title: Questioning Begins In Yugoslav Nazi Trial
description: A magistrate has begun pretrial interrogation of Andrija Artukovic, extradited from the United States last month on suspicion of being a Nazi war criminal, a Belgrade newspaper said today.

title: SWEDEN'S ACTING LEADER: INGAVAR CARLSSON
description: Ingvar Carlsson, the Acting Prime Minister of Sweden since the assassination of his longtime friend and political ally, Olof Palme, is described by colleagues as an intellectual, an organizer and a debater with a sense of humor and low-key manner that make him easy to approach. The 51-year-old Mr. Carlsson, as Deputy Prime Minister, had been Mr. Palme's right-hand man since the Social Democratic Party resumed power in 1982.

title: CUOMO SEEKS TO AID PARENTS TO CHILD SUPPORT
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed legislation to make it easier for a divorced parent with custody to secure child-support payments from the other parent.

title: CABLE TV
description: When the 10-best lists were drawn up at the end of 1985, many of them - including that of Vincent Canby of The Times - reserved a place for ''Desperately Seeking Susan,'' the zany farce that makes its cable debut this week on Cinemax: Sunday at 3:30 P.M. and 11; on Tuesday at 2 P.M. and 8; and on Saturday at 10 A.M. and 10 P.M.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: SCHOOL CASE PUTS FOCUS ON ISSUE OF GIFTED
description: JEAN and Ira Bennett remember the day two years ago when they accompanied their daughter, then 9 years old, to a lottery drawing.

title: REPRIMANDED NUNS PUSH DISSENT ISSUE
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns who signed a second advertisement supporting the right to dissent from the church's teaching on abortion after they were reprimanded for signing the first say they are fighting for a less hierarchical church.

title: NEW SUMMARY SUNDAY, MARCH 2, 1986
description: International No firm leads in the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme were reported by the Swedish police. Investigators were working on two hypotheses. One was that Mr. Palme, who was shot twice from behind Friday night as he walked home from a movie with his wife, was the victim of a psychopath. The other was that he had become the target of exile or refugee groups bent on revenge for difficulties with Swedish authorities. ''They are breaking into every Croat and Kurdish apartment in Europe,'' a former official with good police contacts said. [ Page 1, Column 6. ] Indications of vast Marcos wealth were aboard the he two United States Air Force planes that brought former President Marcos and 88 relatives and associates to Hawaii last week, according to United States Government sources. Documents detailed investments worth potentially hundreds of millions of dollars. [ 1:1. ] The U.S. will use antiterrorist force cautiously. A new policy declaration by the Reagan Administration to be issued Thursday will state that ''a judicious employment of force'' may be required to deter further terrorist attacks, but will rule out random acts of retaliation against states harboring terrorists. [ 1:5. ] National The cause of Challenger's explosion is still a mystery, members of the Presidential investigation commission said, despite extensive public hearings last week that focused on space procedures and the debilitating effects of ice and cold on the space shuttle. The chief suspect, the panel members say, is the failure of a seal between segments of the shuttle's right-hand booster rocket.

title: CONDOS BREAK OUT OF TOWN-HOUSE MOLD
description: WITH the construction of high-rise buildings after several years of concentration on town houses, Westchester's condominium boom is looking upward.

title: Sex and Newgate Callendar
description: To the Editor:

title: SKIMMIN GHT SUMMITS OF THE ALPS
description: To poets, hedonists and conquering generals from sterner places, the Alps have always been the symbolic frontier of the South, where the wine flows easier and the warm begins. Nowadays scores of roads and railroads cross or tunnel their way through the mountains, and hundreds of aircraft fly high over them, but on a recent morning I undertook a more metaphorical kind of journey over that old barrier between sensibilities . . .

title: PUNISHMENT, BUT NO POLICY
description: IN his book about the 1984 Summer Games, ''Made In America,'' Peter Ueberroth confessed how his Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee announced the Olympic torch relay that would fascinate the nation without knowing how it actually would be implemented.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FAIR LAWN
description: IN the late 1920's, the architects Clarence S. Stein and Henry Wright bought two square miles of Fair Lawn, then a simple farming borough in northeastern New Jersey, for the site of one of the first planned communities in the United States.

title: PATRICIA BEILMAN TO WED DAVID POOR
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert L. Beilman of Madison, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Marie Beilman to David Brownlow Poor, a son of Mrs. Daniel Poor of Ridgewood, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mr. Poor. A May wedding is planned.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FANTASY AND PARODY
description: The Magnificent Ambersons Starring Joseph Cotton, Agnes Moorehead, Dolores Costello; directed by Orson Welles, 1942 VidAmerica 99 minutes. $19.95 Orson Welles's ''Magnificent Ambersons,'' adapted from the Booth Tarkington novel about the rise and fall of an American family at the dawn of the automobile age, is only half a movie.

title: Kind Words for Alfred Douglas
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTOR'S LICENSE REVOKED
description: The State Medical Board has revoked the license of Dr. Felix Balasco, a cardiologist convicted of accepting kickbacks for implanting certain brands of pacemakers in patients with heart trouble, the board's chairman said Thursday. The chairman, Dr. Thomas Cole, confirmed that the board decided Wednesday night to lift the license. The board suspended the license Jan. 29. Dr. Belasco had been convicted in Federal District Court.

title: IRATE CARTER REBUTS REAGAN ON MILITARY AND SECURITY POLICY
description: Former President Jimmy Carter accused President Reagan today of ''habitually'' misstating the record of United States military modernization programs and of following an agenda for national security that had little chance of success.

title: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; Taking On The I.R.S. -- And Winning
description: David and Goliath has long been a popular tale of the triumph of the underdog. So what could better offset the travails of tax time than news of fellow taxpayers who took on the I.R.S. and emerged victorious? What follows are stories of four who have done so - although, unlike Goliath, the I.R.S. has a right of appeal. 'Suing Is Scary' DONNA L. TODD of Billings, Mont., never imagined that one day she would sue the Government of the United States. But, then again, the 55-year-old mother and grandmother said she had never expected that the Government could behave so badly.

title: THE SCHOOL TEAM THAT NEVER LOST
description: THE girls' volleyball team at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., was formed to satisfy Federal equal-rights requirements, but opponents soon learned that on the playing court things were decidedly unequal.

title: FARE RISES EXPECTED
description: FOR THE first time in nearly three years, NJ Transit bus and train passengers are facing a fare increase.

title:
HOW TO HELP THE PHILIPPINES;
Support Civilian Control
description: One of the most formidable tasks confronting the Philippine President, Corazon C. Aquino, will be gaining control over the nation's armed forces. As the United States starts to build relations with her Government, it should support her efforts to establish civilian control over the military. In this, the roles of both the Reagan Administration and Congress could be critical.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ENTREPRENEUR
description: It seems unlikely that a person with the psychological makeup of an entrepreneur, as discussed in Daniel Goleman's article, would be found in a classroom taking a course on entrepreneurship. As a venture-capital investor, I would look for my entrepreneur on campus in the local shops and garages. SIGMUND E. HERZSTEIN JR. Boston

title: TOWNS TO SHARE HELICOPTER
description: WHEN an elderly man and a teen-ager were reported missing in their 24-foot cabin cruiser off of Old Saybrook last July, the police searched Long Island Sound for them by boat without success.

title: Financial Ironies Cited In Housing Homeless
description: I read, with great interest, your Feb. 9 article on the county's homeless problem that discussed the newly formed homeless commission [ ''Commission Begins Its Work on Homeless'' ] .

title: FAME FOR HOLZMAN
description: Those were the glory days for the Knicks, and their soul - as well as their coach - was William (Red) Holzman, who in his 14 seasons led the Knicks to the only National Basketball Association titles they have won, in 1970 and 1973. Now Holzman and five others, including Billy Cunningham and Tom Heinsohn, have been named to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame at Springfield, Mass.

title: BEATING THE REJECTION FACTOR: A TELEVISION STAR AT AGE 27
description: ''I DON'T know how anyone would do this work if they weren't nuts for acting,'' said Margaret Colin. ''The rejection factor is so enormous.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Feb. 9 in the Arts and Leisure section about compact disks misstated the production policy of Telarc Records. Although the company has issued some albums in the CD format only, it continues to issue LP's.

title: A MAVERICK COACH GUIDES BRADLEY TO ITS BEST RECORD
description: EIGHT years ago, the administrators at Bradley University did something that at first seemed curious to this middle-sized city that has come to represent America's heartland. They brought in Dick Versace as the head coach of the basketball team.

title: Use of the Coalition On Homeless Urged
description: I am writing concerning the article in the Westchester Section on Feb. 9: ''Commission Begins Its Work on the Homeless.''

title:
MUSIC;
BACH SCHOLAR TO CONDUCT AT JOINT RUTGERS BAROQUE FESTIVAL
description: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY'S Newark and New Brunswick campuses are joining forces to present the New Jersey Choral Festival today through March 12.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The City's Ineffable Customer Writers are happiest when they are lamenting something. This is part of a ''Grand Lament for the City of Paris,'' by the 19th-century poet Jules Laforgue. It is quoted in one of the essays of ''Unreal City'' (St. Martin's), edited by Edward Timms and David Kelley.

title: DEBRA MICHAELS TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Michaels of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Debra Ann Michaels to Ronald Bruce Heimler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Heimler of Hewlett, L.I., and Morris, Conn. A May wedding is planned. Miss Michaels is a fashion model for Mademoiselle Sweaters in New York. Mr. Heimler is vice president of Lady Audrey Fashions, a division of Walter Heimler Inc., a New York costume jewelry company of which his father is president.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE NEIGHBORHOOD WATCH. By Mell Lazarus. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Loring Neiman, to turn Byron's phrase, awakes one morning to find himself destitute.

title: U.S. SAYS MARCOSES BROUGHT IN PROOF OF VAST HOLDINGS
description: Real estate deeds, stocks and bonds and other documents detailing investments potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars were aboard two United States planes that brought Ferdinand E. Marcos and his party to Hawaii this week, Government sources said today.

title: DELAWARE 'OYSTER EAT' CALLS WANDERERS HOME
description: Like hundreds of other men who live in, know or have just passed through this tiny peninsula town, Pete Patton for the last 20 years has felt a pull on his heart each February.

title: RISING YOUN STARS
description: In the second half of a head-to-head team match both strategy and hopes are affected by the score. A team with a substantial lead will try to avoid large swings and pray for dull deals. In contrast, the trailing team is likely to ''swing from the rafters'' and will pray for slam hands that can provide some action.

title: BOY OR GIRL? BEYOND A FEUDAL THROWBACK, WHAT MATTER?
description: ''YOU had a boy. Congratulations! That's really something.''

title: Swedish Premier Assassinated on Stockholm Street
description: Olof Palme, the Prime Minister of Sweden and an internationally prominent left-wing activist, was shot and killed by a gunman Friday night on a brightly lit street corner in downtown Stockholm. He had dismissed his security guards and was walking with his wife after attending a movie premiere.

title: A MIXED MARKET FOR CO-OP RESALES
description: ''TEN PARK AVENUE. E. riv vu. 1 br, 1 libr convt, LR, din alcove, kit, 2 full bths, patio. A steal at $400k now reduced to $350k. Avail Feb. Owner, no fee.'' This recent newspaper advertisement, and others like it, have raised some disquieting questions among owners and would-be owners of cooperatives and condominiums in New York City. Is the resale market full of anxious, price-cutting sellers? Has the phenomenal run-up of prices of the 80's finally peaked? Are sellers actually taking losses - or are they merely settling for smaller profits? Are buyers now holding back, waiting for a market they perceive to be soft to slide? Or has the market simply stabilized before taking off again?

title: Baseball Punishes 11 for Drug Abuse
description: Some of major league baseball's biggest stars were given an ultimatum last week by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth: tithe for drug-prevention programs this year, perform community service for two years and submit to spot drug tests indefinitely, or stay off the diamond.

title: WHY NOT BANK WHERE YOU BUY A CAR?
description: THE Ford Motor Company has acquired First Nationwide, a multibillion-dollar savings and loan with offices in several states. This acquisition most likely will raise two specters that sporadically haunt the discussion of United States banking - fears of mixing banking and commerce and the creation of giant corporations. Are acquisitions of this sort contrary to the public interest?

title: SYRACUSE 75, CONNECTICUT 58
description: Dwayne (Pearl) Washington scored 17 points and Rafael Addison added 15 as Syracuse gained a share of the Big East Conference regular-season title.

title: 14 STORIES
description: The architect Romaldo Giurgola, designer of the Houses of Parliament in Canberra, Australia, is contributing his graceful style to a building planned for downtown Stamford, Conn.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ENTREPRENEUR
description: The underbelly of much entrepreneurial success is often the inability of the individual to maintain a relationship.

title: RUSSIAN AND AMERICAN SHOWS AT THE BENTON
description: THE American folk painter, John Kane, and the Russian avant-garde are the subjects of concurrent shows on view through March 9 at the University of Connecticut's Benton Museum in Storrs.

title: SWEDISH OFFICIALS PURSUE 2 THEORIES IN PALME SLAYING
description: High police officials said tonight that they lacked firm leads in their hunt for the assassin of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: EVIDENCE REPORTEDLY BACKS MARCOS CHARGE OF PLOT BY ARMY OFFICERS
description: The military confrontation that led to the ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos was touched off by his discovery last weekend of a plot by army officers to remove him, Philippine military sources said today.

title: REAGAN AIDES WANT LID ON BENEFITS FOR POOR
description: Reagan Administration officials have been developing a proposal that would, for the first time, limit the total value of assistance low-income people could receive from all Federal benefit programs.

title: Face Up To Filipino Thinking
description: The honeymoon between the United States and the Government of Corazon C. Aquino may eventually give way to tension if Washington does not face the facts of Philippine nationalism. Washington and Manila share an interest in reviving the Philippine economy, restoring democracy and restructuring the military, but their interests regarding American military bases in the Philippines do not coincide.

title: FROM SCHOOL TO STARDOM: A TEEN-AGER'S LARK FOR HELENA BONHAM CARTER
description: Helena Bonham Carter has the kind of features that inspire cliches: luxuriant brown hair, wide-set almond eyes, a lovely heart-shaped face, little bow lips - a face that belongs on a cameo. There is something undeniably old-fashioned about her, nostalgic, even wistful. Perhaps this helps to explain why Miss Bonham Carter, a 19-year-old schoolgirl who had hoped to study English literature and philosophy at Cambridge, with no professional acting training and only one television play to her credit, was chosen to star in period roles in two major motion pictures opening within a month of each other.

title: ART WORKS BY WOMEN AT THE NEW ROCHELLE PUBLIC LIBRARY
description: THE New Rochelle Council on the Arts is sponsoring a Women in the Arts festival this month at the Public Library downtown, saluting Westchester women.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE Public Service Electric & Gas Company will hold a news conference in Governor Kean's office later this month to introduce its 52-page color brochure on corporate headquarters in New Jersey and the television commercial and print advertisements that will accompany it.

title: STAKING CLAIMS TO HOMEWORK HELP AND A MOTHER'S LOVE
description: MY friend Sue works full time, but reads all the books her son's English teacher assigns, to help him comprehend the nuances of plot and theme. Is Sue helping her son to learn or is she doing his work for him?

title: Buckley's Pen Is Quick
description: To the Editor:

title: Children, Custody And the Courts
description: James Smith has revealed perhaps more than he realized of the causes of his son's divorce.

title: L. P. BOISSIERE JR. WEDS NINA LOCKER, A LAWYER
description: Nina Fran Locker and Lionel P. Boissiere Jr. were married yesterday at the Stanford Park Hotel in Palo Alto, Calif. Rabbi Charles H. R. Familant officiated.

title: No Violation Is Found In Harvard Research
description: A foreign affairs expert at Harvard broke no university rule when he examined the demise of dictators in research secretly financed by the Central Intelligence Agency, the school has decided.

title: RECITAL: ANNIE FISCHER
description: THE pianist Annie Fischer was born and trained in Hungary, but her playing epitomizes classic Germanic sobriety and musicality. Unlike the Romantically virtuosic Russians or the elegant French - stereotypes, but valid enough to evoke - pianists like Wilhelm Kempff, Artur Schnabel, Rudolf Serkin and Miss Fischer aim for the structural form and spiritural heart of music, refusing to worry overmuch about note-perfect accuracy.

title: Taking The Terror Out of Audits
description: ALTHOUGH the very mention of the word audit - let alone receipt of an I.R.S. notice - inspires visions of huge fines or prison, most tax experts insist that audits can be relatively painless, if somewhat annoying and time-consuming.

title: RAMBEAU -- NOT RIMBAUD OR RAMBO
description: AVAILABLE LIGHT By Ellen Currie. 297 pp. New York: Summit Books. $16.95.''T

title: Challenging The I.R.S. In the Courts
description: EACH year thousands of taxpayers turn to the courts seeking relief from I.R.S. rulings. One court last year accepted a mother's argument that the expense of sending a child to summer camp qualified as fully deductible child care for a working parent. Another ruled that partners in a law firm could not deduct their lunch expenses because of the restaurant they chose.

title: SETBACK FOR ODOM
description: A superior court judge in Santa Ana, Calif., refused to drop one of two felony counts against the former pitcher John (Blue Moon) Odom, who was arrested last May on charges that he sold cocaine.

title: KENNETH A. CITAK MARRIES SHARI FELICE FABRIKANT
description: Shari Felice Fabrikant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fabrikant of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth Anton Citak, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Citak of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Ronald Sobel, assisted by Cantor Mark Kula, performed the ceremony at the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York.

title: OF POWER AND HOT BUTTERED POPCORN
description: As a topic for cocktail circuit chatter, it probably does not rank with the impact of the new deficit-reducing law or the Democrats' chances to regain control of the Senate this fall.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PRIVATE AFFAIRS By Judith Michael. (Poseidon, $17.95.) This latest effort by the husband-and-wife team who also produced, under the pseudonym Judith Michael, the best-selling novels ''Deceptions'' and ''Possessions,'' is meant to be a tale of love, power and intrigue in the worlds of newspaper and television journalism.

title: TRYING TO PUT A BRAKE ON COMPUTER THEFT
description: LAST year, the senior vice president of a major insurance company was found to have embezzled $28 million over a two-year period through fraudulent use of his company's computer system. Yet no law-enforcement officials were summoned. Instead, the vice president was given a retirement dinner, complete with gold watch. As for the $28 million, he listed it as ''miscellaneous income'' on his tax return and properly paid the state and Federal taxes due on it.

title:
MUSIC;
BLOMSTEDT IN RETURN TO RUTGERS PODIUM
description: THE San Francisco Symphony, now on a two-week, seven-city tour under its new music director, Herbert Blomstedt, will play Saturday at 8 P.M. at Rutgers University.

title: BONN AIDE URGES MISSILE DEFENSES
description: The West German Defense Minister urged Western Europe today to develop its own antimissile system independently of the United States' space-based defense program.

title: TRANSIT HUB EYED FOR THE MEADOWLANDS
description: SEVEN years ago, Allied Outdoor Advertising bought 26 acres of swampy land near the New Jersey Turnpike in Secaucus with the intention of putting up a few more eye-catching billboards. Since then, it has erected just two signs, but it has been kept busy making plans for the property.

title: KEAN STICKS BY PLAN FOR TOUGHER TEST
description: In 1983, Governor Kean called for a new high school proficiency test that would be ''tougher than its flabby predecessor.'' After two years of dry runs the test is ready, but it has raised opposition from school boards, who want it postponed, and teachers, who want it scrapped.

title:
DINING OUT;
UPDATED ROLE FOR A TAVERN OF OLD
description: RURAL Ringoes was an overnight stop in Colonial times for the Swift-Sure Stage on its runs between Philadelphia and Elizabethtown. According to ''The Area Guidebook of Bucks and Hunterdon Counties,'' the community was named for John Ringo, whose inn was the only resting place for miles.
