title: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; Shifting Personal Strategies
description: WITH Congress drawing up plans to overhaul the income-tax system, 1986 could be a watershed year in Federal tax policy. A restructuring would not only change individuals' tax bills, but would also alter the relative economic merits of a broad spectrum of investments and financial transactions, forcing major rethinking of traditional tax-planning strategies.

title: JULIA B. HUNT TO MARRY SIDNEY T. BOGARDUS JR.
description: Julia Blair Hunt, a senior at Yale University, and Sidney Tuttle Bogardus Jr., who graduated from Yale last year and is a medical student at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, plan to be married in June. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Hunt of Chicago.

title: FIGHT GROWS ON NASSAU SALES-TAX EXTENSION
description: ALTHOUGH Nassau County reported a record $60 million budget surplus for last year, it says it needs an extension of the one-cent increase in the sales tax it received three years ago to meet expenses.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
IN ART OR IN TRADE?
description: When Diana Korzenik came upon the letters and artworks of the Cross family in 1981, she finally had the means to flesh out the story she had been wanting to tell about the art education offered to 19th-century Americans. In DRAWN TO ART: A Nineteenth-Century American Dream (University Press of New England, $35) we read that Foster, Emma and Henry Cross, born to a Manchester, N.H., farm couple between 1846 and 1852, were inveterate scribblers.

title: NEW BANKING CHIEF OFF TO SMOOTH START
description: CONNECTICUT'S new Banking Commissioner was primed and ready for his first big legislative struggle. The struggle, it turned out, never happened, giving the Commissioner, Howard B. Brown Jr. a much smoother first month in the job than he had anticipated.

title: Filipino Leaves U.S. To Talk With Aquino
description: The chairman of the new Philippine Government's transition committee in the United States flew to Manila yesterday to advise President Corazon C. Aquino on the state of Philippine-American relations and discuss future plans.

title: DELPHIE ANDREWS BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Swedenborgian Church of the New Jerusalem in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Philadelphia Masters Andrews, the daughter of Philadelphia Carpenter Andrews of Somerville, Mass., and Richard H. Andrews of Watkins Glen, N.Y., was married to James Everett Broughton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Everett L. Broughton of Littleton, Mass. The Rev. F. Robert Tafel performed the ceremony.

title: FUGITIVE DRAMA WITH A TWIST
description: ERNEST R. KEISER, whose smooth talk helped the Government lure a notorious fugitive back to this country for trial, became a fugitive himself a little over a year ago.

title: CONSUMER RATES
MAKING THE GRADE
description: Harold Jensen of Villanova and Steve Hale of North Carolina were named to the Academic All-America team selected by a vote of college sports-information directors. Jensen, a junior, has a 3.38 grade-point average on a scale of 4.0 as a finance major.

title: PARIS
description: Reverence for the fine arts, the applied arts and just plain style is basic to being French, and cultural curiosity is as inbred as the taste for lamb on Sunday or a tolerance for halfhearted heating and Lilliputian-sized elevators. In Paris, people who make things happen have a way of dreaming up new ideas while reanimating old ones. Artists in all fields seem to respect computer technology as much as Moliere, Rameau or Watteau. The Concorde jet and the new superfast TGV train are mobile monuments to a particularly French kind of inventiveness - they are what happen when realism meets up with fantasy. French fashion designers are singularly adept at exploiting this dichotomy.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLY SMOKE. By G. Cabrera Infante. (Harper & Row, $16.95.) How does G. Cabrera Infante like his writers? ''Excessive, rhetorical, baroque,'' says the Cuban-born novelist and critic who is now a British subject.

title: PARIS BONN MILITARY ACCORD IS REACHED
description: France and West Germany announced new steps this weekend aimed at strengthening their defense cooperation at the end of a meeting here between President Francois Mitterrand and Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: MANILA DELAYS THE RELEASE OF FOUR JAILED COMMUNISTS
description: The Government of President Corazon C. Aquino said today that it was delaying the release of four Communist guerrilla leaders arrested by the Marcos regime until their cases could be further examined. Among them is Jose Maria Sison, the founder and former head of the Philippine Communist Party.

title: HE STANDS TALL AMONG THE GIANTS OF CUBISM
description: It is the duty of every great museum to produce from time to time a perfect small exhibition - a show that can fit comfortably into one or two quite small galleries and yet give us fresh, exhilarating and definitive insights into a subject that we thought we knew very well already.

title: ANALYSTS ARE BULLISH ON LILCO'S PROSPECTS
description: JUST a few months ago, events did not bode well for the Long Island Lighting Company. The utility was embroiled in a battle with New York State and Suffolk County over an emergency evacuation drill for the area around the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station. The company was in debt to dozens of banks over the $4.5 billion cost of the Shoreham plant, and many financial analysts and public officials thought bankruptcy was a possibility.

title: ENGINEERS CAPTURE TRACK TITLE
description: When Ed Zarowin retired in 1984 as the boys' track coach at Brooklyn Tech, his teams had won 16 Public Schools Athletic League city titles over a 22-year span. Len Malech, who coached the Tech girls' teams to 17 city crowns in six years, took over for Zarowin last year and won the outdoor championship.

title: Court Says Cities Can Curb, Not Ban Pornography
description: While reaffirming that it violates free speech to suppress pornography outright - unless it falls into the narrowly defined category of ''obscenity'' - the Supreme Court ruled last week that communities may confine the locations of adult movie theaters.

title: IF THE STATE IS GOING TO PROMOTE TOURISM AT HISTORIC SITES, IT SHOULD PROTECT THOSE SITES
description: MANY people have seen by now the ads of the state's Travel and Tourism Advisory Council promoting New Jersey's role in American history and, hence, New Jersey tourism.

title: BRUINS TROUNCE DEVILS, 8-3
description: Charlie Simmer's three goals and a potent power play led Boston to an 8-3 rout of the Devils today. The victory ended the Bruins' four-game losing streak at home.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MUSIC IN MONTCLAIR Philippe Entremont, the pianist-conductor, and the Vienna Chamber Orchestra will appear in Montclair Thursday evening as part of the Unity Concert series.

title: BATTLING BRAZIL'S INFLATIONARY FIRES
description: IN private, the elegant, soft-spoken Dilson Funaro hardly matches his public image of an empire builder who in six months has become Brazil's most powerful minister. Yet, since taking over the Finance Ministry last August, the 52-year-old industrialist has become the undisputed boss of the country's $250 billion economy.

title: FITTING THE IMAGE
description: MORE MEN SEEM TO BE WORKING out in an effort to keep fit, or at least to project an image that they are. As a result, the lines separating clothes for active sports and those for more passive activities have blurred, creating a freshly casual approach to leisure-time dressing.

title: 4,000 WILD TURKEYS BACK IN THE FORESTS
description: THE WILD TURKEY, America's largest game bird, is making a strong comeback in Connecticut, a state once thought to be too densely populated and industrialized to support it in large numbers.

title: OLAJUWON A RESIDENT
description: Akeem Olajuwon, a fixture in the Houston Rocket lineup for two seasons, has received permanent residency status from the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The 7-foot native of Lagos, Nigeria, who was the N.B.A.'s first draft pick in 1984, previously had a temporary working visa, said Robert Rivkind, an attorney who handles immigration matters for Olajuwon. The working visa would have expired in August, Rivkind said.

title: CUTTING THE COST OF A TRIP TO EUROPE
description: Vacationers with specific goals in mind for their overseas trip this year can stretch their dollars with travel and other passes that are designed to cut costs. If you intend, for example, to visit several cities in France in a short time, or pack in several castles and gardens in Britain, tour Norway or range around West Germany by train, it's worth doing homework on the options available.

title: 30 STATES REPORT GLASS IN BABY FOOD, F.D.A. SAYS
description: In the two weeks since consumers began reporting finding glass in Gerber baby foods, the Federal Food and Drug Administration says its has received complaints from 30 states, and one state, Maryland, has banned sales of Gerber strained peaches.

title: PATRICIA A. EYDT TO MARRY ROBERT F. VANCE JR. IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Eydt of New York and New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Eydt, to Robert F. Vance Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vance of Greenwich, Conn.

title: IT IS THE NATURE OF THINGS TO CHANGE -- EVEN 'MY' FARM
description: TEN years ago, when we bought a new home in White Plains, our next-door neighbor welcomed us to the area by remarking, ''I wish your house had never been built. Look how all the empty space around here is disappearing!''

title: IN LOVE WITH SARA FFITCH
description: WALKING ON GLASS By Iain Banks. 239 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. THIS novel contrasts three different sets of fantasies: those of a young man in love with a woman who he (and everyone else) knows is already involved with someone; those of a paranoid workman who should be hospitalized; and, finally, the highly conventionalized fantasies regularly presented in works of science fiction and fantasy. Iain Banks has taken on an ambitious formal task.

title: MUSEUM EXHIBITION DEPICTS LIFE OF AN EXTINCT JEWISH COMMUNITY IN CHINA
description: FOR almost 1,000 years, until the first part of the 19th century, a tiny, exotic Jewish community of no more than 2,000 people flourished in a place far from other Jews and with little or no contact in the world outside its native land. Its Jews observed the Sabbath and the holy days, refused to eat pork, practiced circumcision and studied the Torah.

title: BRIDGE REPAIRS TO SNARL NORTH JERSEY TRAFFIC
description: Motorists using Interstate 80 are in for months of traffic snarls, delays and disruption when the State Department of Transportation begins repairs in mid-March on 10 highway bridges between Totowa and Elmwood Park in Passaic County.

title: PEIRRE BOULEZ IS COMING BACK FOR A VISIT
description: On every level, Pierre Boulez counts as one of music's most dominating figures today. A conducting superstar, he was music director of the New York Philharmonic from 1971 to 1977 and led the centennial production of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the Bayreuth Festival. In his youth a leading avant-garde composer and one of music's fiercest polemicists, he now counts almost as an old master. And at Ircam, his futuristic ''Institut de Recherche et Coordination Acoustique/Musique'' in Paris, he serves as a sort of latter-day amalgam of Diaghilev and Nadia Boulanger, galvanizing the forces of composition worldwide, overseeing popular new-music concerts and helping train a new generation of composers equally at home in the intricacies of late-modernist music and state-of-the-art computer technology.

title: BRAZILIAN LEADER IN DARING GAMBLE
description: A year after becoming Brazil's first civilian ruler in two decades, President Jose Sarney has for the first time seized the political initiative by introducing ing a daring package of economic measures aimed at ending the country's inflation.

title: NEWARK: INSIDE THE 'OUTSIDER' ART
description: PAIRED exhibitions representing opposite orientations toward art are strikingly complementary at the Robeson Center Gallery of Rutgers University here.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of misleading information supplied by Holland America Line-Westours, some fares in the Feb. 9 cruise directory were incorrectly stated for the company's trans-Panama Canal voyages. The correct fares are $3,595 to $5,545 for the 21-night sailing from Tampa to Vancouver of the Nieuw Amsterdam, $3,245 to $4,930 for the 20-night Oct. 12 return voyage, $3,045 to $4,730 for the 18-night Sept. 23 sailing from Vancouver to Fort Lauderdale of the Noordam, $2,795 to $5,025 for the 18-night May 10 sailing from Fort Lauderdale to Vancouver of the Rotterdam and $2,745 to $4,825 for the 19-night Sept. 11 return voyage.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A series of photographs in Fashions of The Times, part 2 of The New York Times Magazine today, show new fashions that are reasonably priced. Because of a mechanical error, the photographs on pages 94 and 95 appear without captions. The photographs are reproduced with the captions on page 58 in the second part of the main news section.

title: BUT CAN THEY TYPE?
description: AS the midterm college graduates descend on the job market, they will find, to their good fortune, that they are entering it at a time when we are experiencing our best employment picture in two decades. The majority of these graduates will learn an expensive lesson, however. It will be an educational test: an ordeal of frustration and disillusionment.

title: LYNN KOENIG IS ENGAGED TO THOMAS CARD KELLNER
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Wolfgang W. Koenig of Summit, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Ellen Koenig, to Thomas Card Kellner, a son of James T. Kellner of Syosset, L.I., and Mrs. Harold E. Mitchell of Glen Head, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: A CELEBRATION OF WOMEN Nikki O'Neill, wife of Governor O'Neill, is to introduce Betty Friedan, author and women's rights activist, as the keynote speaker at the Connecticut Women's Celebration in Stamford this weekend. Mrs. Friedan's speech is to be given at an opening banquet beginning at 6 P.M. Friday in the Hotel Stamford Plaza. A trade show on women's interests will be in progress from 5 to 7 P.M. Admission is $45.

title: A PLACE FOR THE HOMELESS TO CALL HOME
description: WHEN Ruth Hardwick starts her day, her concerns are like those of any other restaurateur: making sure the tables are properly set, the coffee urn is full and brewing, the sugar bowls are filled and there are plenty of eggs on hand for the breakfast rush.

title: Filing the Return: Advice From Experts; Take Care In Matching Your Records
description: WITH proposals flying about Washington to overhaul the nation's income tax system, 1985 may have been the calm before the storm - forms for 1985 taxes remain much the same as in the previous year.

title: DETAILS OF LILCO'S EVACUATION PLAN
description: In accusing the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of abrogating its public responsibilities through its efforts to conduct an exercise of the Shoreham emergency plan, Bob Stein is pointing his finger at the wrong people.

title: ON AN ANGOLAN STREET, TRACES OF A RICHER PAST
description: A decade ago Portuguese colonialists would sit at sidewalk cafes on the Marginal, sipping coffee and reading yesterday's newspapers from Lisbon.

title: Senate Agrees To Try a TV Pilot
description: Torn between being passed over by the eye of history and having its deliberative untidiness laid out before the world, the Senate last week finally tipped a toe into the electronic age, agreeing by a vote of 67 to 21 to televise its proceedings starting June 1 - though only on a trial basis. In midsummer, the senators will vote on whether to make gavel-to-gavel broadcasting permanent.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of mechanical errors, a Westchester Opinion article Feb. 16 on George Washington's last will and testament contained four misplaced lines. The two paragraphs affected should have read as follows:

title: STATE COURT OFFICIALS RECOMMEND CREATION OF 28 MORE JUDGESHIPS
description: The New York City Criminal Court needs 23 more judges to help handle heavy caseloads, and the county district courts on Long Island need 5 more, according to the state's chief judge and chief administrative judge.

title: STATE AGENCY INSURING AUTOS SAYS IT FACES FISCAL COLLAPSE
description: TWO years ago the state created the sixth largest auto-insurance company in the nation. Now, according to the head of the agency, it is New Jersey's biggest political and fiscal time bomb.

title: Sex and Newgate Callendar
description: To the Editor:

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
WHEN TABLEAUX VIVANTS FLOWERED IN THE MAGAZINES
description: One of the forgotten masters of early 20th-century photography is Lejaren a Hiller, a pioneering advertising illustrator who took himself seriously as an artist, and rightly so, according to his own ideas of what art is.

title: Why Stocks Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: EVERY 30 YEARS OR SO, A LONG VACATION
description: AFTER 54 years on the job, George M. Ferris, head of brokers Ferris & Company, is, by his own account, a multimillionaire. Yet he still is happiest seated at his desk in his wood-paneled office in the heart of Washington. looking up occasionally to watch his company's 25 or so brokers through a large pane of glass.

title: PRODIGIES TAKING THE STAGE WITH YONKERS PHILHARMONIC
description: WHOEVER complained about youth being wasted on the young obviously was not referring to musicians. Ever since the 6-year-old Mozart started composing rings around his elders, there has been great fascination with prodigies and their startling accomplishments. For most future professionals, however, childhood is a time of personal growth rather than public display, a time of hard study and intense concentration on the gradual honing of skills that may one day fill Carnegie Hall.

title: QUEST FOR AN UNEVENTFUL JOURNEY
description: As the public and the travel industry contemplate vacation time ahead, this is a winter of uncertainty, of uneasiness in the wake of terrorism in Europe and the eastern Mediterranean last year and the 1,948 deaths from 34 accidents worldwide that made 1985 the deadliest year in air-travel history.

title: DR. LAWRENCE WED TO JAMES B. KILGORE
description: Dr. Denise Elaine Lawrence, a psychiatrist, and James Bernard Kilgore, president and general manager of The Princeton Packet, a group of eight newspapers in central New Jersey, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. David C. Gaise, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the Edith Memorial Chapel of the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School.

title: FOR WAYNE IS SUCCEEDING BY STICKING TO ITS SMOKESTACKS
description: Win Moses Jr. realized his city had an identity problem soon after he was elected in 1979, when he called several out-of-town business leaders to make a pitch about moving their factories here. ''I'd say, 'Hi, I'm the Mayor of Fort Wayne.' They'd say, 'Where in Texas is that?' ''

title: A WRITER CALLED RED SMITH
description: WHEN RED Smith died, at the age of 76, in 1982, he was in his 55th year as a newspaperman. He began his career with The Milwaukee Sentinel in 1927, a month or so after Lindbergh made his solo flight across the Atlantic. And as Lindbergh was proved more than just a stunt pilot, Smith proved much more than just a sportswriter.

title: THE DANCE: SANDMAN SIMS ON TAP
description: A TRUE virtuoso performed Thursday night at Symphony Space. The program, ''The Tap Tradition,'' was a presentation of the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile Indoors 1986, and its star was Sandman Sims, one of our finest tap dancers.

title: HOLYCROSS AND FAIRFIELD REACH FINAL
description: Led by Jim McCaffrey's 35 points, Holy Cross reached the championship game of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament with an upset 81-77 victory over Iona today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: REAGAN TO WAGE DRIVE FOR CONTRAS
description: President Reagan, warned by his advisers that the conflict in Nicaragua is entering a decisive period, will begin an all-out drive over the next two weeks for increased help for United States-backed insurgents, senior officials said today.

title: When Filling Out Returns Overtaxes the Psyche
description: WHILE most of us manage to cope with the annual rite of filing tax returns, even if at the last minute, some find it so harrowing that they fail to file at all.

title: Why It's a Bad Policy To Be Soft on Dictators
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG ARTISTS OFFER WORKS OF MATURITY
description: IT IS no exaggeration to estimate in the thousands the number of young artists in the metropolitan New York area eagerly seeking career opportunities.

title: HAZARDS OF BUYING FROM PLANS
description: BUYING a house or condominium from the developer before construction crews have even arrived on the site has become an increasingly common practice in recent years, particularly in suburban areas of New Jersey and Long Island.

title: STEVEN MAYER, PIANIST, PLAYS IVES SONATA
description: Steven Mayer's decision to perform Ives's ''Concord'' Sonata for piano as half of his program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night was certainly heroic, no doubt about it. But his idea of playing transcriptions of Art Tatum's interpretations of ''St Louis Blues'' and ''Tiger Rag'' must be accounted nothing short of inspired.

title: DEBRA TRUST BETROTHED
description: The engagement of Debra Ann Trust to Kenneth Roy Ackerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Ackerman of Rye Brook, N.Y., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Trust of Brooklyn, parents of the bride-to-be.

title: PERFORMERS WITH A GIFT FOR THRIVING IN OLD AGE
description: In their restless search for the secret of long life, so well chronicled in supermarket tabloids, scientists have been overlooking one startlingly obvious answer.

title: GRIM HERNANDEZ UNDECIDED ON WHETHER HE WILL COMPLY
description: Keith Hernandez said today that he would not decide whether to comply with the drug-abuse penalties imposed by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth until the action had been reviewed by an arbitrator.

title: Children, Custody And the Courts
description: I sense the grief of James Smith over the breakup of his son's marriage and the loss of the grandchild in a court of law.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
INVITATION TO A DINNER TO PAY BACK THE OTHERS
description: SINCE I like cooking, I have tended over the years to give what the ladies' magazines refer to as ''small, intimate dinner parties for eight.'' But, because of my full-time job and my children's Saturday careers of basketball, soccer, baseball, cookie sales, birthday parties, pool parties, and so on, I had fallen terribly and embarrassingly behind reciprocating invitations in the last two years.

title:
WINE;
CHOICES IMPROVE ON RESTAURANT LISTS
description: ONLY a few years ago, a visitor to the county might have surmised that serious wine consumption was a dinner-party event or that residents aware of great vintages were more concerned with collecting than drinking.

title: CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT THE COUNTY AIRPORT
description: AS Samuel F. Smith 3d was making preparations late last month to move from the office where he served as manager of the county's airport to one across the parking lot - from which he will serve as general manager of six airports managed by Pan Am World Services, including Westchester's - a county policeman who works at the airport served him with a ''warrant of eviction.''

title: THE STAKES IN 'CONTEXTUAL ZONING'
description: AT City Hall and in Albany, public officials dwell upon their eagerness to stimulate housing construction. But in many neighborhoods where development might occur, homeowner groups supported by elected officials have succeeded in thwarting high-rise intrusions.

title: Lower-Calorie Meal Plan Keeps an Elephant Slim
description: All it took was some low-calorie hay, a few pushups, no monkey biscuits and fewer peanuts for Bunny, the elephant at Mesker Park Zoo, to lose 640 pounds.

title: IN THE REGION OF LOST MINDS
description: THE MAN WHO MISTOOK HIS WIFE FOR A HAT And Other Clinical Tales. By Oliver Sacks. Illustrated. 233 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95. WHEN the Psalmist lamented the Jewish exile by the waters of Babylon he wrote:

title: ANOTHER BATTERING FOR TEXAS BANKS
description: LAST year, to replenish its coffers and lock in some core deposits, First City Bancorporation of Texas conducted a five-month compaign for new accounts that was extravagant even by Texas standards.

title: ACCENT AT FORUM IS BRITISH
description: WITH its production of Simon Gray's seldom-seen ''Stage Struck,'' which runs through March 16, the enterprising Forum Theater Group here is inaugurating a mini-British festival.

title: 82 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 82 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: MUSIC: BRAHMS REQUIEM
description: THE Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig returned to Avery Fisher Hall Friday night with Brahms's ''German Requiem.'' It was an invitingly international performance for such an intensely German work.

title: The New Chic Classic and Shapely
description: Some have more of one; some, of the other. The best have a bit of both. This spring, no matter what city they were created in, the clothes that look and feel the newest blend the by-now classic ease of men's-wear and sportswear separates with a shapely curviness that hugs the body, emphasizing the breasts, waist and hips - especially the hips. Such clothes bring together two currently strong yet disparate design directions that are interpreted in many different and individual ways in the collections of trend-setting designers in New York, Paris, London and Milan. The combination calls on designers' cleverest devices as well as on an interesting alchemy of fabric and form. The resultant fashions possess a sort of chic that seems tailor-made for the 1986 woman. They are feminine yet comfortable - easy to move around in at a fast pace.

title:
GARDENING;
BEST TIME TO PRUNE FRUIT TREES IS NOW
description: ALTHOUGH winter is still with us, there will be many good days during the next several weeks when getting out into the garden will be profitable, and there are many tasks that can be undertaken.

title: BRADLEY'S CLOSE CALLS
description: Jan. 11 at Drake: Bradley 69, Drake 67 - Taking ball out of bounds with one second to play and score tied, Jim Les throws long pass to Hersey Hawkins in lane. Hawkins hits turnaround jumper to win. Jan. 13 at Dayton: Bradley 79, Dayton 77 (OT) - Taking the ball out of bounds with one second to play and Dayton ahead by 2, Les throws to Hawkins beyond top of key.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VOLUNTEERS
description: The Westchester Task Force for National Volunteer Week is sponsoring a countywide poster contest open to adults and teen-agers on the theme of volunteer activities. ''I couldn't say exactly what we're looking for, but we want to convey the message via the posters that volunteers make an important difference,'' said Millicent Schacher, a member of the task force and supervisor of volunteers at the Pleasantville Cottage School. She added: ''There are so many varieties of volunteer activities that people have a wide range of choices for subject matter.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Critic's Choice in The Guide today about the German tenor Peter Schreier gives outdated information for a concert at the Metropolitan Museum. Because of illness, Mr. Schreier has been replaced by Robert White, who will perform tonight at 8.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FOR many 12-year-old girls, bicycling is an ordinary pastime. But for Jessica Leigh Grieco of Emerson, it's a serious game.

title: Crosby Hall
description: To the Editor: The history and description of Crosby Hall in A. L. Rowse's article, ''At Home with History in London'' (Travel, Jan. 19) have evoked nostalgic memories of a beloved English teacher at Hunter College who invited my wife and me to have dinner with her at Crosby Hall, where she was staying during her summer vacations.

title: Haiti Will Seek Duvalier's Return
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier was still making his absence felt in Haiti last week. So much so, in fact, that the interim Government said it would seek his extradition from France, along with the return of Col. Albert Pierre, the longtime chief of his notorious secret police, who fled to Brazil.

title: A FOLKSY SPOT FOR LUNCH
description: THE ELMCREST in New Canaan began life as a luncheonette, a favorite gathering place of local politicians and townsfolk. A change of ownership brought changes in the type and quality of the food served.

title: Recent Sales in New Jersey
description: Oakland $177,000 155 Manito Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*2-car garage, family room with fireplace; taxes $3,157. Park Ridge $237,500 57 Braemer Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; *2*library, 2-car garage; taxes $4,292. Roselle Park $105,000 42 West Roselle Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; *2*new roof, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,922. Short Hills $240,000 18 Hawthorne Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; *2*patio, fenced rear yard, basement rec room; taxes $3,510. West Orange $230,000 Honeysuckle Avenue *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old colonial in *2*Llewellyn Park; Florida room, den with fireplace, *2* $1,174 annual park fee; taxes $4,759. OTHER AREAS Avon, Conn. $251,250 2 Cadbury Turn *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; screened *2*porch, sprinkler system, 1 acre; taxes $2,625. Eastchester, N.Y. $287,000 437 California Road *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old frame split-level; *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, Florida room; taxes $5,900. title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
IN THE STARS
description: STARS for sale! Stars for sale! Now, for $100 you can buy a star at the Hudson River Museum. A comet goes for $500, a constellation is $1,000 and a galaxy will set you back $10,000.

title: In Gratitude for the Neediest
description: Perhaps it was the visibility of the homeless and hungry lining up at soup kitchens. Perhaps it was guilt, the realization that amid general prosperity the number of the poor, especially poor children, is actually growing.

title: WHERE EARLY QUAKERS ASSEMBLED
description: The village of Jordans nestles among the towering beechwoods of South Buckinghamshire, in an area of rich fields crisscrossed by public footpaths. Although it lies only a half-hour from the bustle of London's Heathrow Airport, the village seems remote and peaceful, a place pervaded by the contemplated quiet of generations of Quakers who have lived and worshipped there. With its meeting-house, hostel and historical associations, Jordans is the English epicenter of the Society of Friends.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CAN THE 'NEW DANCE' FUSE WITH CLASSICAL BALLET?
description: It came as a jolt to realize that until a week ago, the Ohio Ballet had never performed in Manhattan. Considering that this small and admirable troupe founded by Heinz Poll in Akron has been seen in various other locations in New York City or within commuting distance since 1978, one felt the company has already presented a clear picture of itself to New York audiences.

title: THE MOST IMPORTANT LESSON THAT COULD HAVE BEEN TAUGHT
description: TWENTY-FIVE years ago, I taught a course called Unified Studies in a junior high school in Elizabeth. I had majored in English and had had enough courses in social studies to qualify me to teach either subject.

title: MARILYN HORNE SINGS CARNEGIE HALL RECITAL
description: Marilyn Horne has been a busy singer in New York these past days, and Thursday night the distinguished American soprano took Carnegie Hall's stage for herself, singing for a sold-out house that flowed onto the stage. Martin Katz was her accompanist.

title: TALKING TO WALL STREET'S ELDER STATESMEN
description: RETIREMENT. Fervently awaited by some, accepted with resignation by others - and totally rejected by a highly energetic few.

title:
INVESTING;
THE WISDOM OF A LIMITED STOCK PORTFOLIO
description: ''WE don't like padding and we don't like filler,'' said Daniel L. Grossman, a partner of Tukman Capital Management, an investment firm in Marin County, California.

title: WEST COAST PORTS ARE WAITING FOR THEIR SHIP TO COME IN
description: ''San Francisco - where the Far East begins,'' proclaims a poster issued by the city's port authority. Such a slogan is more wishful thinking than fact; the once-bustling port is puny compared to others on the West Coast. But San Francisco is trying hard to catch up. More than $40 million is being invested to improve pier and rail facilities, and city officials are actively wooing prospective customers.

title: PRIZE-WINNING CHILI ALTERED AFTER ATHLETE'S DEATH
description: A Providence restaurant has stopped using peanut butter as a thickener in its prize-winning chili after a nationally ranked 18-year-old squash player from Brooklyn died of an allergic reaction after eating it.

title: TV's Identity Crisis
description: WHEN I TURN ON public television I see penguins. A year or two ago it was seals, but now it's penguins. They're real penguins, too, not the sort of penguins you might see on commercial TV.

title: THE DOLLAR'S REACH AROUND THE WORLD
description: A year ago, an American traveling abroad could save money by spending it. It almost seemed as if the entire world had bowed low before the dollar, and a degree of comfort, even luxury, was available to Americans simply by getting on the next plane out.

title: YOUTH CHOIRS JOIN WITH ORCHESTRAS
description: THERE is a busy fortnight ahead, with at least 10 orchestral programs on the agenda and a number of intriguing vocal concerts.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HENDRIX F.C. NIEMANN, former executive director of the New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority, which operates the New Jersey (Television) Network, says that the structure and function of the authority interfere with First Amendment freedoms and that he will tell a legislative committee Tuesday the authority should be reorganized.

title: COALITION SUES TO BLOCK A SCHOOL BUILDING PLANNED FOR BUFFALO PARK
description: A coalition of environmentalists and preservationists has sued the Buffalo Board of Education to prevent the construction of a building for a magnet school in a park designed by Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: How to Go It Alone At Tax Time
description: FRANCIS C. PARSON, known as Buck, likes to live dangerously. He is learning to fly a small airplane, and he prepares his own tax returns.

title: ARMS AND THE STATE
description: THE arms industry has always been an important part of the state's economy, but officials are now asking whether it has become too important.

title: CLASSIC HISTORY
description: Suddenly, words like ''classic'' and ''simple'' have moved to the top of the fashion vocabulary. Even in Paris couture, where clothes are traditionally ornate and elaborate, styling has been toned down. ''Wearable'' has become an acceptable characteristic of the new season's clothes rather than a synonym for boring. Nor does classic imply bulky, awkward clothes of ambiguous gender.

title: EAGLES PUT ON WINTER SHOW FOR VIEWERS IN DANBURY
description: THE first time Jay Angle saw a bald eagle at the Shepaug Dam in Southbury, he said, ''I got so excited I started hooting and hollering - I had to be quieted down.''

title: A NIGHT OF NOSTALGIA FOR MONROE, FANS
description: Knick fans relived the glory of the 1973 championship season last night when Madison Square Garden rocked again to the chant of ''Earl, Earl, Earl the Pearl.''

title: Philippine Communism Is a Phantom Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Retirement Planning Faces Curbs
description: IF a tax bill is passed by Congress and signed by the President, planning for retirement will change, in some cases dramatically. In general, the proposed changes would curtail or eliminate a number of tax breaks now accorded to those planning for retirement.

title: LACK OF SPACE CAUSING WOES FOR LIBRARIES
description: The John C. Hart Memorial Library in Shrub Oak, in northern Westchester County, has too many books and too little space.

title: About Men; An Earring
description: I HAD NO PARTICU-lar reason in mind when I had my ear pierced about five years ago, but I've been called on to explain it ever since.

title: IN BRIDGEPORT, A PRECINCT ON WHEELS
description: TWENTY years after Bridgeport closed a police precinct in the roughest part of town, a new one has rolled in - literally.

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; Using Trusts To Save Tax
description: WHEN his baby was born, one mid-level insurance executive, after passing out the cigars, went to see his attorney. He wanted to make sure that when the time came for the child to attend college, the family would be able to pay for it. So in September 1981, he transferred about $25,000 worth of stocks into a trust fund for his son.

title: ST. JOHN'S EARNS TIE FOR BIG EAST TITLE
description: St. John's earned a share of the Big East regular-season championship last night and may have put a lock on next year's title as well when Walter Berry announced that he would return for his senior season.

title: GORBACHEV WARNS FAWNING SPEAKER
description: Compared with the adulation bestowed on Leonid I. Brezhnev at the last Communist Party congress, in 1981, the name of Mikhail S. Gorbachev is being mentioned as little as possible at the current convention.

title: TV in the Senate
description: The Senate of the United States has decided to experiment with televising its proceedings. This could help restore the great debating tradition of the United States or it could bring back vaudeville. It all depends on the rules.

title: ST. JOSEPH'S JOINS WEST VIRGINIA IN FINAL
description: Wayne Williams, a junior guard, stole the ball under his basket with 6 seconds left and then converted one of two free throws with no time left tonight to send St. Joseph's to the championship game of the Atlantic 10 Conference tournament.

title: 2 PROSECUTORS PRIMISE COOPERATION IN INQUIRY 2 Prosecutors Promise Cooperation in Inquiry
description: Acting to quiet an apparent dispute between their offices, Federal and local prosecutors pledged ''full cooperation'' yesterday in ongoing investigations into allegations of municipal corruption, a spokesman for Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said.

title: Wine; PAUILLAC PRESTIGE
description: IT MAY BE POSSIBLE, IN FACT EVEN desirable, to argue over what constitutes the most important wine region of France.

title: WORK ON 'STAR WARS' FOUGHT
description: THE Brookhaven National Laboratory's second research contract for the Strategic Defense Initiative project has come under criticism from a group of Brookhaven scientists. The group, 80 of whom signed a protest petition, fear that the contract may lead the laboratory into weapons work for the first time.

title: TAKING OFF THE ROSE-COLORED GLASSES IN MOSCOW
description: ONE of the most talked-about events at the Communist Party congress last week was the speech by Boris N. Yeltsin, the new Moscow party chief.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Few photographers produce a coherent and innovative body of work by the age of 22. But then few photographers are as prodigious as was Francesca Woodman.

title: MYSTERY OF 200-YEAR-OLD DECLARATION: WHOSE IS IT?
description: The sale of an original printing of the Declaration of Independence, newly discovered in Exeter, has been postponed until it can be determined whether the document belongs to the state or to a historical society.

title: Naval Surgeon Convicted
description: Comdr. Donal M. Billig, former chief of heart surgery at the Bethesda Naval Hospital, near Washington, D.C., was convicted by a military jury last week on two counts of involuntary manslaughter and one of negligent homicide.

title: TOUGHEN UP ON 'GOONS'
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: PEACE, O RIVER By Nancy Garden. 246 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up) IN ''Peace, O River,'' a somewhat grim, unrelievedly message-driven novel, Nancy Garden uses the contemporary issue of nuclear waste to propel what is essentially a thinly veiled cautionary tale about class and social status.

title: A Citizen Tries To 'Ask the Governor'
description: As I read my local paper the other day, I was greeted with the smiling face of my Governor, Thomas Kean. It was an advertisement that said: ''Tonight, Ask the Governor.''

title: SCHOOLS ADOPT ABUSE PROGRAM
description: WHAT one school psychologist calls ''a special lesson about strangers'' is being taught in elementary-school classrooms throughout Westchester and across the state.

title: THE LONE STAR STATEKEEPS ITS ALLURE
description: Texas banks may be having their troubles, but big banks outside the state still see the Lone Star State as a lush market they would like to enter.

title: A PROPER STUDY OF THE MAN
description: ALEXANDER POPE A Life. By Maynard Mack. Illustrated. 975 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $22.50. ALEXANDER POPE had a very long period of development as a poet; in fact, one could say it was lifelong. A modern reader new to his work, picking up, say, some close-printed one-volume edition and flicking through the pages, is apt to notice first that with very rare exceptions his poetry is composed in 10-syllable couplets and then to conclude hastily that it is all basically similar, as if one poem in couplets must be like another. In fact, Pope's gamut goes all the way from the prettiness of the early ''Pastorals,'' through the delicate fantasy of ''The Rape of the Lock'' and the surreal and savage burlesque of ''The Dunciad,'' to the calm and luminous irony of the ''Imitations of Horace,'' which discuss life and relationships very directly in a language stripped of ornament and staying very close to prose - though, thanks to the fineness of the poet's ear for rhythm and cadence, never becoming merely prosy. Pope had inherited from Renaissance literary culture the doctrine that literature naturally groups itself in genres, or ''kinds,'' and that there is an appropriate set of conventions and an appropriate linguistic level for each kind, so that training oneself for a fresh attempt on one is like learning a new language. He succeeded in so many kinds that his achievement is complex and not at all easy to assess beyond the simple remark that it is brilliant.

title: No Headline
description: BOB FELLER, a Hall of Fame pitcher with 20 years of service, gets a yearly pension of $9,360. Bill Stein, a utility infielder, with 12 years of service, could get a yearly pension of $34,728.

title: NURSING HOME: LESSON IN LIFE
description: EVERYONE should go to a nursing home. People should go not when they are old, but while they still know where they are; while their eyes perceive shapes clearly, not as ceive shapes clearly, not as shapes that disappear in the distance.

title: Verbatim; Thinking Business
description: 'I do have a different view than Chairman Volcker, a man I greatly respect.

title: NUCLEAR PROGRAM OF T.V.A. SHARPLY CRITICIZED
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority has come under sharp Congressional attack for allowing what lawmakers termed potentially criminal actions in its stalled nuclear power program.

title: MODERN SOUNDS ON THE ORGAN
description: The organ has long been known as the ''king of instruments.'' But ours has not been a century particularly keen on royalty, and the instrument has been neglected by all too many recent composers.

title: CAROLINE BOUVIER KENNEDY TO WED EDWIN SCHLOSSBERG
description: The engagement of Caroline Bouvier Kennedy and Edwin Arthur Schlossberg has been announced by her mother, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis of New York. A summer wedding is planned.

title: A FULL LIFE AFTER 60 ADVOCATED IN BOOK
description: WHAT do Marten Tafel, Ruby Hemenway, Russell Cumming and Sophocles have in common? Mr. Tafel is the Westport science teacher who refused to accept early retirement. Miss Hemenway wrote her first weekly newspaper column at the age of 92. Russell Cumming, at 77, was named Man of the Year by the Big Brothers of America, and Sophocles wrote his last great play when he was 90 years old.

title: MOSTLY INFORMAL BENEFITS
description: Studying in Britain March 3 - The British American Educational Foundation offers recent American high school graduates an opportunity to study at one of 96 British private boarding schools for a year for credit before entering college. Last year, 75 Americans participated in the plan, which is being extended to include an exchange program of secondary school teachers under the Fulbright-Hays Act. The foundation provides scholarships to the American students, and as the program grows, more funds are needed. This has prompted a benefit preview showing of the movie ''A Room With a View'' starring Maggie Smith at the Paris Theater, 4 West 58th Street, at 7 P.M. Tickets, $250 for 6 P.M. cocktail party at Barclay's Bank next door to the theater, and supper at the Plaza after the movie, or $175 for movie and supper alone, from 212-874-4098. Women in Need March 3 - There will be cocktails and, according to plans, assorted politicians and actors - David Dinkins, Miriam Friedlander, Carol Bellamy, Maureen Stapleton and Ruth Messinger - at a 6 P.M. benefit for Women in Need, an organization that helps keep homeless women and their children together. After the party in the Ellington Room of the Manhattan Plaza, 400 West 43d Street, guests will attend a series of one-act plays across the street at the Westside Arts Theater. Tickets, $50, from 212-279-4200. Scientists' Concerns March 5 - The Siebert sisters -Renee, a flutist with the New York Philharmonic, and Cynthia, a pianist with the American String Quartet -and an ensemble will perform Mozart, Albinoni, Poulenc, Griffes and Prokofiev at an 8 P.M. concert to benefit the Union of Concerned Scientists, advocates of nuclear arms control and energy conservation.

title: STUDENTS ACCLAIM CIVIL RIGHTS PIONEER
description: ROSA PARKS, whose refusal to move to the back of a bus in Montgomery, Ala., on Dec. 1, 1955, set off the modern civil rights movement, brought ''living black history'' to Montclair State College here as Black History Month drew to a close.

title: SMALL INDEPENDENT INSURANCE AGENTS COMPLAIN OF SQUEEZE
description: IN THE mounting auto-insurance crisis, in which companies are losing money and premiums are rising, are small independent agencies being squeezed out of business?

title: Article 834386 -- No Title
description: At least $14 million in cash, cars and other property has been seized under a two-year-old New York law authorizing prosecutors to confiscate the illegal profits of criminals.

title: OPERA COMPANIES MERGE IN STAMFORD
description: THE Connecticut Grand Opera and the Stamford State Opera, in an effort to cease competing for the same audience, will merge in July, the directors of the companies announced last week.

title: EX-OFFICIAL PART OWNER IN BUILDING WHERE CITY RENTS
description: The owners of a Times Square building that leased space to New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission warranted that no city employee had a financial interest in the lease although Lester N. Shafran, then head of the Parking Violations Bureau, was a limited partner in the building.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW ISSUES FROM THE VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II has become perhaps the most widely traveled spiritual leader in the history of the Roman Catholic Church. In recognition of this, Vatican City has issued a series of seven new coins whose designs were inspired by John Paul's global journeys.

title: T. E. LEES TO WED SUZANNE O'NEILL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. O'Neill of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Honora O'Neill to Timothy Edward Lees, a son of Theresa K. Lees, also of Upper Saddle River, and William R. Lees of Morristown, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 31. Miss O'Neill, a special assistant to Governor Kean of New Jersey, was formerly a legislative assistant to United States Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey.

title: P.L.O. SAID TO CONSIDER ENDING PACT WIOTH JORDAN
description: A senior Palestinian guerrilla official says the Palestine Liberation Organization is considering scrapping an agreement with Jordan in order to head off what the official called attempts by King Hussein to create a substitute Palestinian leadership. King Hussein has already scrapped the year-old accord.

title: INTRICACIES OF TORTS AND INSURANCE
description: FEW folks, other than lawyers, really know about torts. Yet it may become a household word before the end of the year. What is a tort? Broadly speaking, it is a part of the law that provides remedies for a wide range of unlawful conduct. Much of the current debate centers on its applications in insurance.

title: A CHEAP DATE
description: Do not think less of your favorite American hero or heroine because he or she appears on a postage stamp of modest denomination. At a first-day ceremony for the new 5-cent stamp honoring Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court, the general counsel of the United States Postal Service, Louis A. Cox, made it clear that in the commemorative world, everything is relative. ''After all,'' Mr. Cox said of the Black stamp, ''this one is equivalent to two and a half Igor Stravinskis or one and two-thirds Henry Clays.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LAST CHANCE FOR OUR CHILDREN: How You Can Help Save Our Schools. By Bill Honig. (Addison-Wesley, $12.95.) According to Bill Honig, California State Superintendent of Public Instruction, American public schools should return to teaching the ''time-tested values of traditional education.'' Mr. Honig believes that none of the educational innovations we have tried in the last 20 years have been successful.

title: OUTLOOK UNCERTAIN ON OCEAN POLLUTION
description: DESPITE decades of heavy pollution and years of bureaucratic delay, there is some evidence that the waters off New Jersey are getting healthier.

title: Put Museum on Ferry
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM CHINA, A BALLET COMPANY IN THE CLASSIC STYLE
description: Since its beginnings in 1954 the Central Ballet Company of China has overcome more than its share of challenges. In 1958, the year the original ballet troupe assumed its present name, there was a performance of ''Swan Lake'' for Mao Ze-dong and other leaders in Zhongnanhai, the corner of the old Forbidden City where the Chinese hierarchy lives. But in that same year, Mao thrust the country into chaos with his Great Leap Forward, an enterprise that had nothing to do with plies. After a few months, the madcap attempt to turn the country into an instant industrial powerhouse had people in the ballet practically starving.

title: Shots in Stockholm
description: Olof Palme was the only Scandinavian national leader whose name was generally known in the United States. He gained that distinction by his passionate and reasoned campaign for a world order in which nations large and small would forsake warfare.

title: Busting Loose On Wall Street
description: The United States has lived with low inflation for several years, but some people have only recently begun to bank on it.

title: MARSHALL VINDICATED
description: Frank Marshall, United States champion from 1909 to 1936, has generally been criticized for playing a one-sided tactical game that verged on neglect of strategy. However, in the light of some recent developments, the criticism will have to be muted somewhat.

title: AWAITING RULING ON ASYLUM, HAITIANS PONDER GOING HOME
description: Haitians seeking political asylum but who have been detained, some since the early 1980's, by United States immigration officials are beginning to consider returning to their homeland after the departure from Haiti last month of President Jean-Claude Duvalier.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE NEW YORK TIMES WORLD OF NEW YORK: An Uncommon Guide to the City of Fantasies. Edited by A. M. Rosenthal and Arthur Gelb in association with Marvin Siegel.

title: LIFE'S FAVORITE AGE IS SOMEWHERE TWIXT 20 AND ...
description: ONE of the nice things about life today is that comparatively few people feel as old as they really are. This doesn't apply to teen-agers, who often believe that they have lived through, experienced and seen just about everything there is to live through, experience and see. Naturally, all that intense living makes them feel a lot older than they are, frequently even more ancient, and certainly wiser, than their parents.

title: A BENEFACTOR TELLS WHY HE DID IT
description: ''I could give you some advice about age, if you'd only take it seriously,'' Avery Fisher offered. ''Don't get any older.

title: OBJECT LESSONS
description: COPIES OF FABRICS AND WALL-papers, porcelain and jewelry from the permanent collection of the Musee des Arts Decoratifs in Paris - tokens of history, really - are available both here and in Europe. Like reproductions from other museums around the world, they carry with them the expert endorsement of style and authenticity. But more than items from other museums, these can be said to have an added cachet because the Musee des Arts Decoratifs, long considered one of the epicenters of French style, is relatively unfamiliar to Americans. Part of the reason has been its inaccessibility. Beginning in 1980, the institution's rooms were gradually closed for refurbishing, and finally the entire museum was shut for about two years so that extensive renovations could be made to the building that is part of the vast Palais de la Louvre in the Marsan Pavilion on the Rue de Rivoli.

title: Women's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IN ONE NEWSPAPER: A Chronicle of Unforgettable Years. By Ilya Ehrenburg and Konstantin Simonov. (Sphinx Press, $24.95.) Four decades after the end of World War II, much of the immediacy and the passion have gone from the articles that Ilya Ehrenburg and Konstantin Simonov wrote for the Russian Army newspaper, The Red Star.

title: FATHERLY ADVICE
description: Brian McRae joined his father in a Kansas City Royals uniform for the first time yesterday at the full squad's opening workout in Fort Myers, Fla.

title: REFUGE IN THE LIBRARY, ON THE FARM AND IN MEMORIES
description: ACADEMIC FESTIVAL OVERTURES By Daryl Hine. 189 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10.95. THE LONG APPROACH By Maxine Kumin. 80 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95. THE PAST By Galway Kinnell. 57 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. Cloth, $13.95. Paper, $5.95. DARYL HINE, celebrated for translations of the Homeric Hymns and Theocritus, has embarked on his own autobiography in classical disguise in ''Academic Festival Overtures.'' Though the poem is written in self-proclaimed alexandrines (by alternating 13 and 12 syllables), its indented patterning is suggestive rather of Ovid (part ''Tristia,'' part ''Amores''). The narrative impulse races through long paragraphs, while a rhyme scheme insistently coagulates internal elements into epigrammatic quatrains. It is a virtuoso achievement, as remarkable in its way as anything by Auden. It is also a remarkable record of a yearning, bookish and inhibited boyhood. Behind the metrical screen Mr. Hine imposes on his memoirs, he paces to and fro - as if watching from be-hind the self-imposed bars of his caged existence.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE FLOWER AND THE LEAF: A Contemporary Record of American Writing Since 1941, by Malcolm Cowley. (Elisabeth Sifton/Penguin, $7.95.) The real heroes in this collection of essays by Malcolm Cowley ''are the members of his own generation . . . Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Wilder, Cummings, Faulkner, Thomas Wolfe and Hart Crane,'' our reviewer, Robert M. Adams, wrote last year. ''The Flower and the Leaf'' and Mr. Cowley's other collections dealing with American writing, he said, ''are smoothly written, good-humored, more biographical than critical, modest in their methodological machinery and limited . . . by Mr. Cowley's polite and dryly skeptical sense of proportion.'' SHILOH AND OTHER STORIES, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) This collection of stories by Bobbie Ann Mason ''shows not only how good she can be but how consistently good she remains,''

title: WORLD LEADERS REMEMBER MAN OF PEACE
description: Tributes continued to come in today from world leaders shocked and saddened by the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden.

title: PAMELA HUSTED TO WED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John G. W. Husted of Nantucket, Mass., of the engagement of Mr. Husted's daughter, Pamela Frowert Husted, to Piers Savile Charles Lloyd Owen, a son of Maj. Gen. David L. Lloyd Owen, British Army, retired, and Mrs. LLoyd Owen of Swainsthorpe, Norfolk, England. The future bride is the daughter also of the late Ann Hagerty Husted.

title: PROTESTERS STAY ANONYMOUS AND STAY IN JAIL
description: If they would just give their names, they could get out of jail. But the two John Does and the Jane Doe - all arrested last month for protesting the launching of a new Trident nuclear submarine here - repeatedly refused to tell court officials who they are.

title: CRIME
description: It seems that Jim Stinson, a writer from California, has worked on four films that never were released. But at least one of his works has come to fruition -his first novel, DOUBLE EXPOSURE (Scribners, $13.95). It has a good deal about films in it. Pornographic films, to be exact. It also is a nicely written, jaunty, action-filled piece of work. Welcome to the fold.

title: A Historic Week In Manila
description: SUNDAY - After defecting and setting up resistance at army camp, former Defense Minister and former deputy armed forces Chief of Staff call on President Marcos to resign. MONDAY - Crowds block troops advancing on rebels.

title: FRANCES MEI SOO WOO TO MARRY GARY HOPPE
description: Frances Mei Soo Woo, a tax lawyer for the SCM Corporation, and Gary Hoppe, a partner in the law firm of Olwine, Connelly, Chase, O'Donnell & Weyher, both in New York, plan to be married May 3, her mother, Lai Shou Woo of Seattle, has announced.

title: A West German City Honors Anne Frank
description: An elementary school in Bergen has been named after Anne Frank, ending a controversy over how to honor the girl who died in the Bergen-Belsen death camp in 1945.

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; Eliminating A Double Tax
description: IF you run a small business with partners or members of your family, or invest in real estate, work as a freelance writer, artist or tradesman or engage in a number of other economic activities, subchapter S of the Internal Revenue Code provides you the option of setting up an S corporation, and therein may lie significant tax savings.

title: ALEX KATZ PAINTING IN THE HIGH STYLE
description: ''I ALWAYS FELT THE WORLD WOULD CATCH UP WITH ME,'' says the painter Alex Katz. ''I never wanted to be part of a movement'' - his thin, tense face lights up with a rascal's smile -''unless there could be one called Katz-ism.''

title: Hepburn And the Cabdriver
description: Carrie Donovan's article ''Hepburn Style'' (Jan. 19) prompted me to respond with my own recollection of the Hepburn style in the 1930's.

title: One Killed in a Queens Fire
description: An unidentified man was killed in a one-alarm fire that broke out at 9:30 A.M. yesterday in a house at 48-45 63d Street in Woodside, Queens. The police said the victim, who was found dead in the kitchen, appeared to be in his early 30's.

title: DANCE: LIMON COMPANY
description: THE man in the spotlight reaches up, his arms a little heavy with the effort. His fingers find a resting place in the air and start to move. He has become the 3-year-old he once was, coming upon his first piano. And an odyssey called ''Growing Up in Public'' has begun.

title: GARDEN SHOW BRINGS OUTDOORS INDOORS
description: AS SOME workers hammered and others hauled, Warren Cook summed up the scene:

title: Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points; Minimizing Estate Taxes
description: EVEN though 1981 legislation went a long way toward easing concerns about how big a tax bite the Government will take from estates, there is still planning that people at all income levels should do for the day when life's twin certainties -death and taxes - converge.

title: FROM FLORIDA AND ELSEWHERE, WINTER'S FRUITS OFFER SOME ZEST
description: THE produce stands overflow with shiny orbs of gold and orange at this time of year.

title: THOSE BEGUILING BAGLES: A BAKER BAKES HIS DOZENS
description: BAGELS, bagels everywhere. Thousands of dozens of them, filling the county's breadbaskets each week. Whether poppy or sesame, garlic or plain, all depend for their taste on high-quality flour mixed with water, yeast, malt and a pinch of salt.

title: Robot Statistics
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
LECTURES: MORE THAN JUST TALK
description: AT THEIR best, lecture series involving antiques offer something more than an intellectual diversion packaged into entertaining 45-minute segments.

title:
GARDENING;
BEST TIME TO PRUNE FRUIT TREES IS NOW
description: ALTHOUGH winter is still with us, there will be many good days during the next several weeks when getting out into the garden will be profitable, and there are many tasks that can be undertaken.

title: JEWISH NUN AND MARTYR
description: EDITH STEIN A Biography. By Waltraud Herbstrith. Translated by Bernard Bonowitz. Illustrated. 127 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $15.95. PHILOSOPHER and mystic, Edith Stein began life in 1891 as a precocious, high-strung, intellectually flamboyant child in a strict Jewish family in prewar Germany. From the outset she was an obsessive, energetic scholar and in time she became passionately drawn to philosophy, especially phenomenology, the description and classification of phenomena, and went to learn from its master, Edmund Husserl, at Gottingen.

title: WHAT MAKES AN ENTREPRENEUR
description: Bankruptcies have indeed been multiplying in recent years, as Daniel Goleman notes, but this indicates that far too much capital is too easily available to be thrown away in useless ventures. It also indicates that the many entrepreneurs who contribute nothing are merely unemployed people who temporarily support themselves by dreaming up impossible schemes for others to finance. Applause for the occasional success should take second place to the search for ways to avoid such outrageous waste. FREDERICK C. THAYER Professor Graduate School of Public And International Affairs University of Pittsburgh Pittsburgh

title: 74TH APPEAL FOR NEEDIEST ENDS AT $2,726,331
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 74th annual appeal Friday with record contributions of $2,726,331.40 given by 13,105 donors sharing their good fortune and concern for the homeless, the ill and the despairing in the New York metropolitan area.

title: MISS RUSSELL WED TO GARY BLACK JR.
description: Jacqueline Russell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Cushman Russell of Chagrin Falls, Ohio, was married yesterday to Gary Black Jr., the son of Mrs. Nicholas Louis Ballich of Stevenson, Md., and Mr. Black of Glyndon, Md. The Rev. Howard Van Dine performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Stowe, Vt.

title: WORKING WEEKENDS AT THE AGE OF 89
description: 'I HAVE a theory,'' said Philip L. Carret. ''The top brass should have at least a year's salary invested in their company.''

title: 40% OF THE POOR ARE CHILDREN
description: FAMILY AND NATION The Godkin Lectures, Harvard University. By Daniel Patrick Moynihan. 207 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. CHILD poverty is epidemic in the United States. But poverty is unfashionable; most politicians struggle to show their unconcern with old-fashioned ''liberal'' issues. So Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior senator from New York, should be congratulated for devoting his 1985 Godkin Lectures at Harvard University, reprinted in this book, to a plea for concern. Children make up only 27 percent of the nation but 40 percent of the people in poverty; they are, Mr. Moynihan points out, ''the only age group over-represented in the poverty population.'' The situation is particularly alarming among minorities - in 1984 almost half of America's black and over a third of its Hispanic children lived below the poverty line. We are compromising our future as well as our humanity.

title: A SIMPLE EXCERCISE THAT NEEDS NO GYM OR FANCY EQUIPMENT
description: THE headline read: ''Walking Found to Benefit Out-of-Shape, Highly Fit.'' They did not have to do a scientific study. I could have told them that. I have been taking a brisk, morning walk every day for six years. But I suppose it is nice to have the scientific proof. I've always believed I was exercising when I walked. Now I know I am.

title: STATE SETS A PLAN TO LET TRAM RESUME RUNS TO ROOSEVELT I.
description: State officials announced last night that they had found a way around the political deadlock that had been keeping the Roosevelt Island Tramway closed and that the tramway would resume operations tomorrow at 8 A.M, The aerial tramway linking Roosevelt Island with Manhattan closed Feb. 14 when its liability insurance coverage expired. It remained out of service while the Governor and the Republican-controlled Senate argued over proposals for the state to assume liability for the tram.

title: Youth Held in Couple's Death
description: A 17-year-old Bucks County high school student was arrested today and charged with first-degree murder in the fatal shooting of his grandparents in their home. The police said they found George Mezeffa, 73, and his wife, Veronica, 72, dead in their home Friday. The couple's grandson, Richard Mezeffa, who lived with them, was arrested near the home at about 3 A.M.

title: A Not-So-New Soviet Man
description: ''The Government has lost the confidence of the people, so it has to elect a new people.'' Flora Lewis recalled Bertolt Brecht's penetrating quip in Moscow, where she's been listening to a rejuvenated leadership's ideas for getting the Soviet Union moving again. The German Communist playwright first made the comment while watching the suppression of a workers revolt in his workers' state in 1953.

title: WHY FORD SHOULDN'T BE YOUR BANKER
description: AS the president of a savings bank, I have been dismayed by the lack of attention paid to the Ford Motor Company's acquisition late last year of First Nationwide, a well-managed thrift institution with assets of $11 billion. I am dismayed because this transaction may signal the beginning of an era of marked acceleration of concentration in economic power.

title: Q AND A
description: '81 RENT GUIDELINES RULING

title: Israelis Report Foiling Arab Kidnapping Plot
description: Israeli troops patrolling the Lebanese border early this morning thwarted an Arab terrorist attempt to seize Israeli hostages in Galilee, military sources said tonight.

title: DELAWARE PLANS 6-LANE HIGHWAY
description: AFTER 20 years of false starts and two years of consultants' studies and public hearings, Delaware highway authorities have announced the route of a bypass designed to relieve the traffic that clogs U.S. 13, the state's main north-south artery.

title: BUSINESS ADVISERS ASSIST ARTS GROUPS
description: ARTS organizations in New Haven have been concentrating on more than just creativity. With the help of area business volunteers, they have been learning the art of business.

title: Strike Is Threatened At Disneyland Hotel
description: Workers at the Disneyland Hotel have rejected a proposed contract and threatened to strike unless a better wage package is offered.

title: EYEING COLLEGE HOCKEY'S BEST
description: Four senior forwards who led their respective teams to regular season championships loom as the favorites for the Sixth Annual Hobey Baker Award as college hockey's best player for 1985-86.

title: Overt, Not Covert
description: To the Editor:

title: MURDER-FOR-HIRE TRIAL IN JERSEY PACKS THE HOUSE
description: Among the many people who have not missed a day of the month-old murder-for-hire trial of Robert O. Marshall here are Oakleigh (Aunt Bug) DeCarlo and Wanda Diane Thompson, who had not known each other before the murder but now share Mr. Marshall's home.

title: SHAKING SCANDALS FROM CITY AGENCIES
description: THE hard part about prosecuting government corruption is that with few exceptions, somebody involved in the crime has to squeal. The smoking gun is a metaphor from murder cases, not white-collar crime.

title: Tax Shelters Under Fire
description: TAX shelters are under siege once again on Capitol Hill. Since the 1960's, Congress has mounted a number of assaults against tax shelters. But the current debate in Washington on overhauling the income tax system poses the most serious threat yet to the enticing write-offs that have for years lured throngs of upper-income Americans into deals ranging from shopping centers and railroad box cars to wildcat oil wells and motion pictures.

title: A PLAYWRIGHT SEEKS THE TRUTHS OF HIS CHILDHOOD
description: ''You write a play mostly out of yourself,'' says Israel Horovitz. ''There's a need to get a certain thing down.'' Mr. Horovitz has felt that need since 1957 when - at the age of 17 - he wrote his first play, a father-son story called ''The Comeback.'' After that youthful effort, he segued into such diverse subjects as New York delinquents, racial inequities, primary English classes, 75-year reunions and gargantuan mackerels.

title: BOOK COVERS THAT WRITE A NEW PAGE IN EXPRESSION
description: BOOKS are important to R. B. Kitaj, the well-known American artist who has been working in London since the late 50's. He uses more than their physical characteristics, tapping into writing structure, ideas and language in a manner that is unique.

title: Cuomo Proposes AIDS-Test Curb
description: Governor Cuomo proposed last week legislation that would bar insurance companies from requiring applicants to take or asking whether they had taken blood tests for AIDS.

title: WIND DRIVES UP GOLF SCORES
description: A chilly, daylong north wind that gusted well above 40 miles an hour over the Tournament Players Club at Eagle Trace today made it impossible for some of the world's finest golfers to shoot their customary low scores.

title: Why Stocks Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: MIS ING LETT RS IN N W JERS Y SIGN
description: IT was a troubled bridge that curved over the waters of the Delaware River at Trenton this week.

title: CATTLE, HORSES, OIL AND THE GOOD TIMES OF THE WEST THAT WAS
description: Times are so tough here that even the Prince of Wales took good-natured notice of Houston's problems on his recent visit.

title: ROBIN FERN ZORN WED TO RICHARD R. DEMAIO
description: Robin Fern Zorn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin F. Zorn of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Robert DeMaio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. DeMaio, also of New York. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club, assisted by the Rev. John Fitzgibbons, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Foggy Statute
description: The law is clearer on some issues than on others, and in the case of Representative Bobbi Fiedler of California, it seems to have been obfuscatory. One of eight candidates in a Republican primary contest for a United States Senate seat, she was accused of violating an untested provision of a state election law by offering $100,000 to an opponent to drop out.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Sunday is frustratingly packed with worthwhile musical events, but fortuitous spacing between them - and the possibility of alternative dates over the week - allow the enterprising listener to miss very little. Ken Noda's recital of Mozart, Schubert and Schumann at Alice Tully Hall, for example, is at 3 P.M. leaving room Sunday evening for Peter Schreier at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: BUSINESS FOUND TO BE SUREST PATH TO WEALTH
description: Becoming a doctor, lawyer or accountant is still a good way to get rich in this country, but the richest of the rich got that way through banking, insurance and real estate, according to a Government study made public today.

title: Data Bank March 2, 1986
FRANCE'S VINTAGE VILLAGE OVENS
description: Maurice Bal dusts a speck of flour from his thick woolen beret and with broad, rhythmic motions sweeps large, crackling rounds of sourdough bread from the wood-fired oven.

title:
Taking Advantage Of the Law's Fine Points;
Timing Can Be Everything
description: IT is not just how much you pay in taxes. It is also when you pay it. Taxpayers often have a choice in the matter, and this year those choices matter more than ever. As a rule, accountants advise clients to accelerate deductions. If you take the tax savings this year rather than next, you pick up an extra 12 months to earn a return on the money. The other side of the coin is income, and taxpayers sometimes choose to postpone it, along with the concomitant tax.

title: SUSAN VOLL IS AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kevin J. Voll of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Mary Voll to Perrin Louis Arturi, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Arturi of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Music Festival Site
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Are Contaminated At Britain Atom Plant
description: Five workers were contaminated today in the third radioactive leak in four weeks at Britain's only nuclear reprocessing plant, the operators said.

title: TEXAS AIR COMES TO EASTERN'S AID
description: Texas Air's $600 million bid for Eastern shook up the passenger carrier industry and carries long-term implications for the post-deregulation era. Frank Lorenzo, Texas Air's chairman, is aiming to build a major route system by combining Eastern's modern fleet with his smaller Continental and New York Air operations. That would probably require him to divest some of the Washington-New York-Boston shuttle routes that New York Air has been working to build against Eastern's shuttle. But the cost-cutting for which Mr. Lorenzo has become known in the industry promises continued fare competition.

title: ISRAEL MOVES TO NORMALIZE ITS LINKS TO AFRICA
description: Senior Israeli officials dealing with Africa have expressed confidence that Israel's resumption of diplomatic relations with the Ivory Coast will be followed by major advances in normalizing African links this year.

title: EFFORT TO ATTRACT STUDENTS TO TEACHING IS LAGGING
description: A NEW initiative by the Kean administration to revitalize the teaching profession has met with scant interest from the high school students it is supposed to attract.

title: WALL COVERINGS: WHERE YOU START IS WHERE YOU FINISH
description: BEFORE starting to hang a patterned wall covering in any room, you should give some thought to where the first strip will be hung.

title: RAVE REVIEWS FOR THUNDERBIRD
description: EVERY year, the world's automobile manufacturers wheel their wares onto a race track for the International Motor Press Association's test day. When that happened at the most recent IMPA event at Lime Rock, Conn., the car that drew the raves was not a Porsche or Ferrari or any of the other semiprecious gems. It was a Ford.

title: KATHERINE GRIDLEY TO WED AN EDITOR
description: Katherine Mead Gridley and John Bentley Barstow plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Gill Gridley Jr. of New York and Norfolk, Conn., have announced.

title: Another Cost of New York City's Cable Delays
description: Some 5.7 million people live in New York City's four outer boroughs, but among them only about 1,000 households in Queens have cable television service. Even so, corporations set up by the Borough Presidents of Queens, Staten Island and the Bronx have spent more than $700,000 since 1983 to prepare for the production of community programming on cable systems.

title: DANCERS FIND STATE OFFERS CHANCE TO GROW WITH THEIR ART
description: PROFESSIONAL ballet dancers, not always receptive to working in New Jersey, are now flocking to the state and, they say, for good reason.

title: LILY AFSHAR, A GUITARIST, IN NEW YORK DEBUT
description: The guitarist Lily Afshar, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night, began her musical training in her native Iran. After immigrating to the United States in 1977, she took a bachelor of music degree at the Boston Conservatory and a master's degree at the New England Conservatory.

title: DID YOU PROTEST THE WAR, MOM?
description: BEING a college student at midlife surrounded by many students half my age has prompted me to reminisce about the ''carefree'' days of my youth. My apathy 20 years ago embarrasses me. Where was I when the world was going on? I now ask myself.

title: HOW GREEN MY DUGOUT?
description: HAVING had our first cup of coffee of the day, let's talk about baseball players and addiction. One of the side effects of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's actions Friday was that nobody was judged guilty solely of using or supplying amphetamines around the clubhouse.

title: WHAT TO DO ABOUT HERALD SQUARE'S DOWDY OLD RETAILER
description: The case-study method of teaching business requires students to study a company and suggest ways to solve its problems. This article takes the same approach, with a twist: The subject is Gimbels and the ''students'' are businessmen, competitors, consumer advocates and other outsiders with ideas on what Gimbels should do next. FOR more than 140 years, Gimbel Brothers has been one of the enduring names in American retailing and for more than half that time its gray, hulking structure in New York's Herald Square has been its best-known public face. But when one of the store's brass nameplates was whipped off by wind last year ago and never replaced, that may have been prescient.

title: PHILADELPHIA BLACKS: MORE GET TO THE TOP, BUT MOST ARE LOW ON THE LADDER
description: Not far from Independence Hall, among row on row of neatly trimmed 18th-century brick town houses, is the spire of another, lesser-known monument to the nation's early years: Mother Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church.

title: MARTA A. JOHNSON AND M. B. JUDSON MARRY IN TENAFLY
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday Marta Ann Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Mark Johnson of Tenafly and Sun Valley, Idaho, was married to Matthew Bowditch Judson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Judson of Chapel Hill, N.C., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. John C. Cronenberger performed the ceremony.

title: UEBERROTH CAME TO SEE USERS AS DETERRENTS
