description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said yesterday that, after much private thought and discussion with two top aides, he had decided against outright suspensions of players who had used cocaine because he believed those players could be ''a positive force'' in combating drugs.

title: NUNS AND PRIESTS WORKING WITH COMMUNISTS DIVIDE CHURCH
description: The creation of a small but highly active organization of Roman Catholic priests and nuns that has worked to help the New People's Army, the military arm of the Philippine Communist Party, has caused a serious rift in the church here.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Rates: Made in Japan The nation's falling interest rates have the stock and bond markets soaring. Will rates tumble much lower? They could, says economist Sam Nakagama, largely because interest rates in Japan are dropping. ''We expect key Japanese rates to fall much lower in the short term because of plunging oil prices,'' said Mr. Nakagama, of the consulting firm of Nakagama & Wallace. Since Japan is a big oil importer, cheaper crude means less demand for yen, which puts downward pressure on Japanese rates. As a result, more Japanese investors are attracted to higher rates in dollar-denominated assets - such as United States Treasury bonds - lowering rates here, too.

title: Poetic License
description: Robert Penn Warren has received, among other honors, three Pulitzer Prizes, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the Bollingen Prize for Poetry, the National Medal for Literature and, of course, the acclaim of his peers. Last week, on the advice of fellow poets, Mr. Warren was appointed the first poet laureate of the United States.

title: MUSIC: LUENING TRIBUTE
description: LESS than four months short of his 86th birthday, Columbia University got around Friday to staging an 85th-birthday retrospective concert for Otto Luening at McMillin Theater. The orchestral program, with the National Orchestra of New York under Efrain Guigui, proved a stylistically and chronologically wide-ranging, earnestly performed musical event and a nicely emotional human event.

title: LOVE AND MARRIAGE
description: The proposal to force the Federal Government to balance its budget each year by amending the Constitution is headed for the Senate floor and already provoking considerable controversy. Senator Warren B. Rudman of Vermont, a chief sponsor of the measure now seeking to accomplish the same thing through legislative strictures, told reporters the other day that he would probably support the constitutional amendment, too, because ''if Gramm-Rudman-Hollings is the engagement, the amendment is the marriage.''

title: Psst, There's a Secret Scenic Bus to Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: GA. TECH IS UPSET BY ILLINOIS, 59-57
description: Efrem Winters hit a 13-foot jumper with 31 seconds remaining today to give Illinois a 59-57 upset victory over Georgia Tech.

title: Real Estate Losing Some Of Its Luster
description: WHATEVER Congress does this year in the way of overhauling the tax law, apprehension over change has already affected the real estate investment market. The conviction seems to have taken hold that the tax benefits in real estate investment will be trimmed. Consequently, according to many investment specialists, those seeking tax shelter in real estate investment have lost some of their ardor.

title: GOVERNORS' INTEREST IN PRIVATE PRISONS RISING
description: The nation's governors increasingly support privately operated prisons as a method to ease overcrowding and reduce costs, according to views expressed at the winter meeting of the National Governors' Association.

title: A PAPER PLANE FOR GLOBAL FLIGHT
description: IT seemed an unlikely goal: an aircraft made largely of stiffened, honeycombed paper that was to fly two people around the world without refueling.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NO MAN'S LAND By Reginald Hill. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) Reginald Hill is known for his mystery novels, but here he investigates an infrequently reported aspect of World War I. The focus is on a band of soldiers of diverse ranks and nationalities who have withdrawn from the war and are living in an abandoned underground complex in a part of no man's land they call Desolation.

title: Angiulo Convicted Of Racketeering
description: A scene that has been recurring across the country with escalating frequency over the last few years unfolded in a Boston courtroom last week as reputed organized crime bosses and their lieutenants heard a Federal jury convict them of racketeering charges.

title: CONEHEADS IN CAMELOT
description: SATURDAY NIGHT A Backstage History of ''Saturday Night Live.'' By Doug Hill and Jeff Weingrad. Illustrated. 510 pp. New York: Beech Tree Books/William Morrow & Company. $17.95. IN the mid-1970's, satire changed from what closed on Saturday night to what people stayed at home to watch on Saturday night. For a time ''Saturday Night Live,'' like rock music before it, captivated a generation and attained a near-mythic status.

title: SHE MIGHT HAVE HAD IT ALL
description: ''PRETTY GOOD FOR A WOMAN'' The Enigmas of Evelyn Scott. By D. A. Callard. Illustrated. 202 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $14.95. IT was 1929, and his publisher felt that the provocative but minor William Faulkner would need critical support if his new book was to to be well received. It was submitted to a better-known writer, and the result was a small pamphlet. It began: ''This essay by Evelyn Scott, whose recent novel 'The Wave' placed her among the outstanding literary figures of her time . . . is being distributed to those who are interested in Miss Scott's work and the writing of William Faulkner. 'The Sound and the Fury' should place William Faulkner in company with Evelyn Scott.''

title: MISS SCHWARZ, NURSE, IS WED TO A PHYSICIAN
description: Laurie Ann Schwarz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Schwarz of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Richard Gorfine, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Gorfine of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Mark Hurvitz performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Vietnam Gives Reports On Missing Americans
description: Vietnam has handed over reports on 49 cases involving Americans missing in action in the Vietnam War and repeated its promise to repatriate more remains of American servicemen, a United States officer said today.

title: AGENCIES AIDING NEEDY IN NEW YORK FEEL CUTS
description: Private agencies caring for New York City's needy, faced with reduced government aid and rising operating expenses, say they are beginning to scale back programs.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: EARLY reports indicate that a large number of homes in the northwestern part of New Jersey may have a radon problem, but state officials say they are still two years away from any firm conclusions on the possible health risks.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FANTASY AND PARODY
description: Mary Poppins Starring Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, David Tomlinson, Glynis Johns, Hermione Baddeley, Elsa Lanchester, Arthur Treacher, Ed Wynn; directed by Robert Stevenson, 1964 (G) Walt Disney Home Video 139 minutes. $84.95 Even on the home screen, ''Mary Poppins'' is supercalifragilisticexpialidocious.

title: LOVE ME, LOVE ME NOT
description: Representative Robert J. Mrazek, the two-term Long Island Democrat, has been an object of conflicting Republican interests lately, and it's got him puzzled. Last week John T. Dolan of the National Conservative Political Action Committee branded him as one of the ''Ortega 33,'' whom he identified as lawmakers with ''pro-Communist, pro-Sandinista voting records.''

title: TOYS THAT GO BEYOND FUN AND GAMES
description: Many of the vintage toys gracing the shelves of Andrew Carnegie's library in the 1902 mansion he built at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street - now the home of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum - might well have resided there when they were new. Most of the more memorable trains, trucks, planes, dolls, optical and mechanical toys, building blocks, shop interiors and doll houses on view in ''Toys From the Nuremberg Spielzeug Museum'' were popular in this country when they were produced at the turn of the century or later, the period when the steel tycoon and his family lived there.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
'WOMEN'S HISTORY WEEK
description: Women's History Week is now celebrated nationwide, but it originated at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, where the 14-year-old Women's History Program was the first to offer a gradute degree in the field. The original purpose of the week was to recognize and publicize the role women played in history.

title: Lisbon
description: To the Editor: Marion Kaplan's article on Lisbon (Travel, Feb. 2) served as a painful reminder of a memorable hour my wife and I spent in Portugal's capital several years ago.

title: 662 Submit Petitions to Run For School Board Positions
description: The Board of Elections said yesterday that 662 people had filed as candidates in upcoming elections for the city's 32 community school boards. The filing deadline for candidates was midnight Thursday; the elections are in May.

title: HISTORIC HOUSE SLATED FOR MALL
description: A PLAN to construct a mini-mall that would include Sag Harbor's oldest building has renewed concerns that the village may be losing its historic appearance and character.

title: GETTING THE ANGLE ON ARCHITECTURE
description: LIKE baseball, architectural photography is a game of inches. The slight turn of the hand or twist of the tripod head can make an incredible difference in how the image looks - the visual difference between a strikeout and a home run. Buildings are larger than photographers in more ways than size. They present truly imposing challenges.

title: The Frailties of Machines and Men
description: The Presidential panel on the shuttle disaster has elicited some riveting testimony. Parts of it are quite reassuring. Morton Thiokol, maker of the shuttle's booster rockets, has some meticulous, articulate engineers. Months before the accident, they had warned of ''losing the flight'' unless improvements were made in the booster rocket seals that are a leading suspect in the tragedy. For fear the seals wouldn't work in the colder weather predicted on Jan. 27, they argued strenuously against launching Challenger the next day.

title: NOW AQUINO IS TAKING AIM AT CITY HALL
description: Emboldened after deposing a President, Corazon C. Aquino is now fighting city hall.

title: Estimating Taxes Due
description: FOR most Americans, settling with the Federal Government is a chore to be endured but once a year. But for the eight million or so taxpayers who file estimated taxes, the chore falls due four times a year.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SHAKER PIECES TO BE SHOWN IN DANBURY
description: WHEN Ed Clerk, a collector from Bethlehem, was traveling in Maine recently, he came across a Sister's sewing stand different from any he had ever seen.

title:
FOOD;
VICTORIA'S SWEET TOOTH
description: IN 1837, VICTORIA AS-cended to the throne of England. For 64 years, she reigned as monarch, arbiter of taste and symbol of permanence for a country in flux. Britain was experiencing growing pains because of the Industrial Revolution. The expanding middle class, without traditions of its own, looked toward the sovereign as a model of manners and style. Ostentation was universal - in architecture, furniture and uncomfortably exaggerated gowns. At the table, excess reached its pinnacle. Favored by a royal sweet tooth, desserts and tea snacks spiraled to lofty heights as a showcase for talent and new equipment. From biscuits and bombes to trifles and puddings, Victoria relished each sugary creation.

title: OSCAR WAS STRANGER THAN FICTION
description: THE GOD OF MIRRORS By Robert Reilly. 403 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. MAKING novels out of the lives of historical figures is always dangerous. This is particularly so for Oscar Wilde. Even 40 years ago, Richard Aldington could write, ''Almost everything that could be said about Oscar Wilde has been said already.'' Not quite. Definitive biographies and fictionalizations kept emerging, and Wilde himself spoke beyond the grave, for ''De Profundis'' was published uncut for the first time in 1960. The dangers in Wilde's case are further compounded by the fact that he self-consciously turned his own life into a fiction. One of his most persistent paradoxes, which he managed to make entirely convincing, was that life imitates art. His acquaintances all testified that Wilde's greatest art was his conversation. His disregard of facts was one of the primary facts about him.

title: FRENCH FLAG, ITALIAN SOUL
description: Whenever I find someplace I think is terrific, someone always pops up and says, ''You should have been here 10 years ago.'' Well, Corsica, which I think is terrific, is 10 years ago - and more.

title: STUDY SAYS WEAPON COSTS STRAIN ECONOMIES
description: Soaring global military expenditures since World War II are a major cause of environmental deterioration and economic decline in many countries, according to a new State of the World report by the Worldwatch Institute.

title: Remarque's First Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; Tax Bill Puts Senate On the Spot
description: UNDER the Constitution, tax legislation must originate in the House of Representatives, and few senators paid much attention last year while the House was writing a bill that would overhaul the Federal income tax system.

title: DR. JODY A. ROSS TO WED UROLOGIST
description: Dr. Jody A. Ross, a pediatrician, and Dr. Douglass R. Birns, a urologist, both at Mount Sinai Hospital, plan to be married in September, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Ross of Springfield, N.J., have announced.

title: AIDE TO ACADEMIA
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser to President Reagan, has been named a counselor at Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies. Since he left the White House last year, he has also become active as a public speaker on international affairs with an emphasis on the Middle East, where he served earlier as the President's personal representative.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
ROUND AND ROUND
description: IT'S a Saturday afternoon at Mad Platters, and two teen-age boys are discussing Ozzy Osbourne, heavy metal music star.

title: A NEW CALL TO SAVE LOCAL FOOD STORES
description: A NEW report calls on Hartford's community leaders to view the need for neighborhood supermarkets in a new light - as a public policy issue, just like housing.

title: Overhauling The Nation's Tax Policy; 3 Experts Look Ahead On Tax Plans
description: With Congress working on a sweeping restructuring of the tax system, three tax and investment authorities were asked to assess the impact of the proposed changes on individuals. They are: Leon M. Nad, associate vice chairman of Price Waterhouse; Madeline I. Noveck, president of Novos Planning Associates and of the New York City Society of the Institute of Certified Financial Planners, and Herbert M. Paul, a tax lawyer and professor of taxation at New York University. They were interviewed by Gary Klott and Jan M. Rosen of The New York Times staff. QUESTION: In the midst of the uncertainty surrounding the Congressional debate, how are you advising your clients?

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: METS' HANDYMAN REPORTS EQUIPPED
description: Tim Corcoran, the newest member of the Mets, was unpacking his gear from a red Philadelphia Phillies dufflebag and was saying he hoped that he had make the team as a pinch-hitter and first baseman. He was told he might have a better chance if he had a catcher's mitt.

title: CAMPAIGN BY MOUNTAIN CLUB
description: QUIETLY and persistently, for more than a century, the Appalachian Mountain Club has introduced millions to the glories and fragilities of forest, lake and mountain.

title: Babbitt Etches in Acid
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas has not exactly assumed a position of prominence yet in competition for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination, but at least one politician with national aspirations regards him as the pick of the current G.O.P. litter. Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, an increasingly likely entrant in the Democratic national competition, said last week he thought Mr. Dole was ''the best in both political and Governmental terms'' of the potential Republican candidates.

title: HOLLYWOOD SEEKS CONTROL OF OUTLETS
description: Hollywood is trying to expand its hold over the exhibition outlets for the movies and television shows that it produces by buying television stations and movie theaters.

title: Astronauts' Stamp
description: Four dozen members of the House have joined Representative Raymond J. McGrath, Republican of Nassau, L.I., in an effort to persuade the United States Postal Service to issue a commemorative stamp honoring the seven astronauts who died in the Challenger explosion in January.

title: Sequent's $50 Million Contract
description: Sequent Computer Systems of Portland, Ore., a startup company whose principals staged a well-publicized exodus from the Intel Corporation two years ago, is expected to announce Monday the sale of more than $50 million worth of components and technology to Siemens A.G., the large West German electronics and electrical company.

title: The Congregation, and Its F.B.I. Spy, Will Rise
description: Last Sunday, the minister of the small Baptist church I belong to did a very nice thing. During the pastoral prayer, along with remembering the sick and the shut-ins, he also asked the Lord to bestow a special blessing on our informer.

title: DANCE: DARRELL BARNETT
description: THE problem with the four ballets choreographed by Darrell Barnett and directed by Lee Minskoff that the Darrell Barnett Dance Company presented Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church was their overall blandness.

title: 12 HOUSTON CHILDREN SHOT WHILE PLAYING WITH PISTOLS SINCE DEC. 30
description: Even in Houston, where a gun is a common household item, no one can remember a situation quite like it.

title: DANCE: BARSNESS COMMENTARIES
description: ERIC BARSNESS breezed into the St. Mark's Church Danspace on Saturday night and took on Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht, the world of classical and avant-garde dance, Yma Sumac and the Italian opera in the space of a single, nutty hour and a half. No topic is sacred with Mr. Barsness, though he handles his themes with an intelligence, affection and deadpan innocence that make him good company.

title: LATE STARTERS LOOM AS DERBY PROSPECTS
description: Snow Chief's powerful victory in the Florida Derby here Saturday made him a strong early favorite for the Kentucky Derby on May 3, and his disdainful handling of the best 3-year-olds in Florida made it look like he has a big edge on his peers.

title: PANEL ON CLASH IN PHILADELPHIA FAULTS OFFICIALS
description: In a stinging rebuke to Mayor W. Wilson Goode, a special commission has concluded that the city's top officials were ''grossly negligent'' in the May 13 confrontation with the radical group Move and has called for a grand jury investigation.

title: Washington Watch; Customs Shift On Textiles
description: THE United States Customs Service is set to put into effect next Sunday a new rule requiring formal entry documentation of all commercial textile imports regardless of value. Protests prompted the agency to retreat from imposing the new rule in February.

title: The U.N. Today; March 3, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10:30 A.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: Bangladesh Schedules An Election April 26
description: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the head of state, said today that he was calling elections for the last week of April to end four years of military rule.

title: BUYERS SEE MORE SIGNS OF GROWTH IN ECONOMY
description: The nation's economy continued to show strength in February, with higher production and rising new orders, according to a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: SPACE TRIP IS STILL ASTRONAUTS' GOAL
description: The pilot of the last successful space shuttle mission said today that despite recent disclosures of communications breakdowns among space agency managers before the Challenger flight, he knows of no astronauts planning to quit the shuttle program.

title: A BIG CHILL GREETS IDEA ON MARCOS
description: Would Ferdinand Marcos like to settle in Maine?

title: Arms Protesters Set Off On Coast-to-Coast Trek
description: Nearly 1,200 marchers packed up their traveling town this morning and set off on the second day of a coast-to-coast journey to urge nuclear disarmament.

title: REGIONAL BANKING FOR OREGON
description: As a young Oregon rancher, John A. Elorriaga was protected by the law if a neighbor poached on his land. Now, as a banker, he is preparing for the day when the law no longer keeps out-of-state banks off his territory.

title: NOT EVERYONE LAUGHED AT CITY'S POLITICAL ROAST
description: Early in Saturday night's Inner Circle show, a roast of New York politicians in general and the Mayor in particular, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin noted the obvious: ''Not everybody,'' he said, ''is laughing.''

title: Measuring Bonds Over Time
description: The past three weeks, as the yield for the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond fell to 8.27 percent, from 9.30 percent, have been exhilarating for bondholders. But that rally has not reduced the anxiety of traders and investors, who must decide whether the rally will continue.

title: New Role for Ex-Official At Battery Park City
description: After deliberately staying out of the spotlight, the former chairman of the Battery Park City Authority has emerged publicly to stake another claim in lower Manhattan, this time as a private developer.

title: LLOYD DEFEATS JORDAN IN FINAL
description: Chris Evert Lloyd ended Kathy Jordan's giant-killing spree with a 6-2, 6-4 victory today in the final of the Virginia Slims of California.

title: This Time Was His Chance To Make It Peter & Terry
description: Some of his ninth-grade classmates at the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx might have wondered yesterday who was that older performer on stage with Terry Mullane.

title: Outdoors: Heritage of the Hunter
description: IT may have something to do with growing older - one tends to reflect on the preciousness and brevity of all life when the predator's shadow sweeps over the moor - but of late my once-fierce urge to be successful while hunting has waned.

title: PBS 'Gala of Stars' To Originate in Vienna
description: or the first time, ''Gala of Stars,'' a feature since 1980 of the Public Broadcasting Service national membership drive and annual fund-raising campaign, will originate in Europe -at the Vienna State Opera. The program will be broadcast March 16 in New York on Channel 13 and simultaneously in stereo on WNCN-FM at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. STUDY DISPUTES CANCER RISK OF FORMALDEHYDE
description: Scientists at the National Cancer Institute say in a new study that there is little evidence that formaldehyde causes cancer among the 1.4 million workers who are exposed to the chemical.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986 International Restoration of Filipino human rights began with President Corazon C. Aquino's ''Proclamation No.1'' restoring the writ of habeas corpus. She said new government structures would be formed to hear and act on recommendations and complaints of citizens. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] A West Bank Mayor was shot dead as he was walking from his home to City Hall. A spokesman for the Israeli Civil Administration in the occupied territories said Mayor Zafer el-Masri of Nablus, a Palestinian appointed by Israel who was regarded as an alternative to the slogans of the Palestine Liberation Organization, had been killed by a single assailant. The central area of Nablus was under curfew, and access to the city was blocked by the Israeli army. [ A1:2. ] Palestinians in Israel-occupied land say they have been stunned, dismayed and frightened by the rupture in the yearlong effort by King Hussein and Yasir Arafat to devise a joint position on Middle East talks. Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip say they were even more disconcerted by King Hussein's call on them last week to decide who should lead them. [ A3:1. ] A cut in Brazil's interest rate on nearly a third of the country's foreign debt was agreed on by a group of international banks which made $31 billion in loans. The agreement was reached Saturday night after about a month of negotiations and a day after President Jose Sarney ordered sweeping economic changes to combat Brazil's soaring inflation.

title: Market Place; Value-Oriented Fund Manager
description: LAST Thursday, when the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 1,700 for the first time, most stockbrokers and investors were cheering. Leonard M. Heine Jr., a money manager in Westport, Conn., described the market's rise in recent months - the Dow, after all, had dipped below 1,300 in late September - as ''mind-boggling.''

title: Truce Extended in Colombia
description: A large guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces, signed an indefinite extension of a 21-month truce with the Government today, the Government announced. President Belisario Betancur said the agreement showed that peace was possible among Colombians and that ''discussion will always be better than confrontation.''

title: UEBERROTH CHANGES TACTICS, GETS HIS WAY ON DRUG ISSUE
description: From the day he became baseball commissioner, Peter Ueberroth has singled out cocaine use among players as the No. 1 problem facing the sport. And he has been almost as consistent in adopting and pursuing a strategy for solving the problem: Having all players submit to urine tests on demand.

title: Austrian Is First In Slalom Race
description: Guenther Mader won the first race of his career, Rok Petrovic clinched the season slalom title and Pirmin Zurbriggen gained ground on the overall leader today in Europe's final World Cup ski race of the season.

title: CHILDREN LOST AMID SQUALOR
description: SOMEWHERE around the edges of ''The Children of Times Square,'' a television movie on Channel 7 tonight at 9 o'clock, there no doubt lurks a moral. The producers, Marcy Gross and Ann Weston, have made statements about how they hope that, as a result of seeing the film, parents will take more interest in their own children.

title: Peace of Mind for $155
description: What's the price of peace of mind for the aging American who fears financial ruin from severe illness? About $155 a year could buy a lot, says Otis Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services. If so, why not put this bargain to Congress instead of burying it in a broader study?

title: NEW ZEALAND SAYS FRANCE BLOCKS FOOD TRADE
description: Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand has accused France of blocking food imports from New Zealand in a bid to obtain the release of two French secret agents jailed for their role in sinking the Greenpeace ship Rainbow Warrior.

title: Bridge: A Team in Iceland Tourney Overcomes Odd Handicap
description: The world's northernmost tournament regularly attracts star players from several continents, but often the local competition, in a cold country, proves too hot to handle.

title: CATHOLICS AND ABORTION: ISSUE IS RIGHT TO DISSENT
description: How far can Roman Catholics go in dissenting from the teachings of the church and still consider themselves good and loyal Catholics?

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
In the Family
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates were once famous for being fam-a-lee, but as clans go they were nothing compared with the basketball team at Lewis University in Romeoville, Ill. At Lewis, the family's name is Niego, which rhymes with ''we go,'' which in turn pretty much sums up the Big Red: As Niego, We Go.

title: Indiana to Take Over Auto License Offices
description: Under a law passed late Friday night, the state will take over a system of politically controlled motor vehicle license offices that have been criticized as one of the most profitable political patronage operations in the nation.

title: 747 GETS 48 HOURS TO JOIN AIR FORCE
description: At Hangar 19 at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, 60 people aboard a Boeing 747 called the Clipper Sea Serpent tossed out the in-flight magazines, rolled up the rugs and took away the coffee makers, ovens, movie projector and screen.

title: A 10,000-Mile Run to Raise Money to Help Fight AIDS
description: ''At the onset of the AIDS epidemic,'' said Brent Nicholson Earle, ''I was immobilized by the despair of having so many dear, young people, with so much to offer, plucked from our midst.''

title: Japan Reports Trade Surplus
description: Japan had a trade surplus of $2.39 billion in January, up sharply from the same month a year earlier but not so high as the record surplus in December, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

title: Thrift Unit Reopens
description: Sierra Federal Savings and Loan Association of Denver will reopen today as a branch of Commercial Federal Savings and Loan Association of Omaha following the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's closing of Sierra Friday.

title: Bankers Trust Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court has permitted the Bankers Trust Company to continue its commercial paper operations until it is able to hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that banned Bankers Trust from the business. The ruling Friday was the latest chapter in a legal battle between the banking and securities industries over the lucrative commercial paper market.

title: B.P. 'Comer' Given Standard Oil Task
description: The brusque manner in which the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., which controls the Standard Oil Company, installed Robert B. Horton late last week as the new chairman and chief executive of the Cleveland-based concern startled Wall Street analysts. But none said that they found the choice of Mr. Horton at all surprising.

title: The Meaning of a Golan Heights Town to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Champlin Chief Gets New Post
description: William T. Smith, currently chairman and chief executive of the Champlin Petroleum Company, a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation, has been named vice chairman of the parent company, the railroad and energy company announced.

title: FRENCH ROTHSCHILDS AWAIT RIGHTIST WIN
description: Two bearers of the best-known name in French banking work away in a modern Paris office on the Avenue Matignon, waiting for the day when they can put that name back on their front door.

title: China Factory Said to Fail
description: A factory in the northeastern city of Shenyang will become the first company to go bankrupt in China since 1949, the Peking Review magazine said today.

title: NEVER AT TREBLINKA, SUSPECT IN ISRAEL SAYS
description: A Ukrainian immigrant to the United States who was extradited to Israel to be tried for war crimes denied in court here today that he had ever been at the Treblinka death camp or collaborated with the Nazis.

title: Penny Wise
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR SALE: THE MOON AND THE STARS
description: Justin Moreau wanted to bring outer space down to the street level. So he and a friend, Robert Hanfling, who used to discuss the universe over coffee, did just that. They, along with another partner, opened a new Star Magic shop at 275 Amsterdam Avenue at 73d Street. It sells everything from quartz crystals (50 cents to $2,000) to Newtonian reflector telescopes ($299.95, four-inch model; $849.95, six-inch model) to new music by Andreas Vollenweider (albums and tapes from $5.98 to $19.98). The Year of the Comet

title: Power System Settles
description: The executive board of the Washington Public Power Supply System has approved a $2.5 million settlement of a suit against an electrical contractor it accused of bid-rigging involving $393 million in contracts on two discontinued nuclear power plants. The settlement with the Howard Foley Company, of Washington, one of six electrical contractors sued by the power system, was reached Friday.

title: Hungarian Film
description: ''The Revolt of Job,'' a Hungarian film set during the Holocaust, will be screened on Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street.

title: It Takes Smarts to Play Ball Well
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: CHARLES NEIDICH IN CONCERTO
description: CHARLES NEIDICH, a Pied Piper of the clarinet whose eminence among young practitioners of that instrument was ratified last year with a victory in the Naumburg Clarinet Competition, distinguished the American Symphony Orchestra concert yesterday in Carnegie Hall with as lively an account of the Mozart concerto as one is likely to hear.

title: Low Inflation in E.E.C.
description: Consumer prices in the European Economic Community rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January for an annual inflation rate of 4.7 percent, the lowest since 1970, the community's statistics office said Friday.

title: GREINTON OVERTAKES 157-1 SHOT TO WIN
description: Greinton, coming back from a four-month layoff, scored a half-length victory over the 157-1 shot Herat today to capture the $1,359,500 Santa Anita Handicap.

title: Advertising; Agency's Burning Message
description: WHILE other agencies may woo potential clients with lunches, dinners, the theater and rounds of golf at fashionable clubs, the people at Kolker, Talley, Hermann would rather put their money into self-promoting advertising. Advertising is, after all, what they are all about.

title: Topple Me Another
description: An old political saying goes: ''An orchid from your opponents is like an onion from your supporters.'' I make up instant adages like that when no quotable wisdom is handy for one of those strange situations that cry out for folk wisdom.

title: Back in the Ring
description: He's undoubtedly not the only politician who's ever been dubbed the Fighting Senator, but as a member of the Indiana Legislature, Ken Snider earned the nickname the hard way: by beginning a professional boxing career at age 37.

title: Poverty Is Thriving Under Reagan
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Says Indians May Run High-Stakes Bingo
description: Two Indian tribes in southern California can run high-stakes bingo and card games, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: CITY OPERA: 'BRIGADOON' OPENS SERIES
description: THE New York City Opera ruffled numerous feathers when it abruptly announced in 1982 that it was abandoning its traditional separate fall and spring seasons and offering instead a combined summer-fall season. That decision seems in retrospect to have been a critical part of the process by which Beverly Sills, the general director, brought the company back to life.

title: KOCH PRESSES CABLE TV CONCERNS ON OFFERINGS
description: The Koch administration has begun pressing the cable-television companies that serve Manhattan to upgrade their systems and to offer at least double the number of channels they now provide to subscribers.

title: U.S. DISTRIBUTING LISTS OF HOSPITALS WITH UNUSUAL DEATH RATES
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is sending state agencies lists of hospitals whose death rates or rates of complications exceed the national average. The letters ask the agencies if corrective action is necessary.

title: IN SLUMS, HOPES FOR A BETTER LIFE
description: Victoria Marcelo couldn't afford to go to the party today in Manila.

title: ANDY GRIFFITH IN 'A PERFECT MURDER'
description: EYEBROWS flaring, Andy Griffith comes across splendidly tonight as a smart Southern criminal lawyer with a surprise witness and a subpoena or two up his sleeve in a neatly constructed two-hour film, ''Diary of a Perfect Murder'' (Channel 4 at 9).

title: Slowdown in U.S. Sales Continues
description: The lack of new Treasury securities - an important factor in the bond market's recent rally - will continue this week when the only Government financing is the regular weekly auction of new Treasury bills.

title: 2 YANKS SIGN PACTS AND CITE PRESSURE
description: March 2 - For the equivalent of the major-league minimum salary of $60,000, the Yankees could have had a happy left side of the infield that George Steinbrenner said was the key to the team's season.

title: A FALL FROM GRACE IN BIOTECH
description: The 40th birthday party of Refaat el-Sayed two weeks ago was a glittering affair, attended by many of the biggest names in Swedish business and social circles.

title: TOURNAMENTS WILL MEASURE STRENGTH OF BIG EAST
description: HOW good is the Big East this year?

title: Lacy Accepts Drug Penalties
description: Lee Lacy, the Baltimore Orioles outfielder, said today that he would take drug tests, perform community service and pay an estimated fine of $34,250 rather than serve a 60-day suspension for being connected with illegal drugs.

title: MANHATTAN CENTER GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: August Martin and Manhattan Center will meet in next weekend's semifinal round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs, thanks to victories over Beach Channel and Adlai versity.

title: CENTER CHIEFS PONDER SPACE, INSIDE AND OUT
description: After 20 years of planning, 3 mayors, 6 years of construction and a budget that grew from $375 million to $486 million, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is to open its doors April 3.

title: Lopsided Selections
description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce endorses candidates for the Senate and House, by its own account, ''to elect lawmakers, both Republicans and Democrats, who share the business community's objectives for economic growth, lower inflation rates and higher employment.'' To carry out this policy, the chamber keeps a ''report card'' on every incumbent's voting record, and those who score 70 percent or higher are eligible for endorsement.

title: EXPERT ON POLICE
description: James F. Ahern, the New Haven Police Chief who gained national recognition as an expert on student unrest and police-community relations, died of cancer Friday at his home in Wilton, Conn. He was 54 years old.

title: WATT'S GOALS AT INTERIOR, BUT IN A DIFFERENT STYLE
description: Before banging heads the other day with the Chrysler chieftain Lee A. Iacocca, Interior Secretary Donald P. Hodel was one of the more obscure members of the Reagan Cabinet.

title: MANY WEST COAST FILIPINOS HEAD FOR NATIVE LAND, WITH OTHERS EXPECTED TO FOLLOW
description: In the wake of the Philippine presidential elections, community leaders say increasing numbers of Philippine-Americans on the West Coast are traveling to their homeland or planning visits to the country they left for political or economic reasons during the Marcos Administration.

title: AIDES PREDICT PROBLEMS IN JAVITS CENTER PARKING
description: The biggest problem facing the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, in the opinion of many city officials and trade-show planners, is that it lacks its own parking.

title: SHULTZ SAYS NICARAGUAN REBELLION WILL END IF AID IS DENIED
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz says that if the United States fails to provide military aid quickly to the Nicaraguan rebels, Sandinista rule will be consolidated, the guerrilla resistance will be crushed and Washington will have to contend with a dangerous ''Soviet and Cuban base on the mainland of Latin America.''

title: Workers at Disneyland Hotel Cancel Their Plans for Strike
description: Employees of the Disneyland Hotel will continue working without a contract but will hold demonstrations to encourage a boycott of the hotel, union leaders said today.

title: Carcinogen Found In Much Cocaine
description: Half the cocaine seized in Florida late last year contained benzene, a carcinogen that has been banned from consumer products because it has been shown to cause leukemia, a Federal agency said today.

title: Tommy Farr, Fighter, Dies; Went 15 Rounds With Louis
description: Tommy Farr, the first fighter to go the 15-round distance with Joe Louis, the former world heavyweight champion, died of liver cancer at his home Saturday. He was 71 years old.

title: T.W.A. Sales Pact Ends An Era for Ozark Chief
description: When Edward J. Crane, president and chief executive of Ozark Airlines, agreed last week to sell the carrier to Carl C. Icahn, who owns Trans World Airlines, the deal represented more than just the $250 million price tag it carries, or the fact that a huge carrier was swallowing up a much smaller one. In some respects, it also represents the end of an era.

title: BRELAND TRIUMPHS ON EARLY KNOCKOUT
description: In the days before he was to fight Mark Breland, Richard Aguirre, an undefeated welterweight from San Diego, tried to stare down the celebrated Olympic gold medalist when the two men met. The tactic was meant to show Breland that he was not afraid of him, and, by Breland's reckoning, Aguirre may have won that bout on points.

title: Growers in Florida Battling a Cold Wave
description: Freezing temperatures in the South today sent Florida growers scrambling to protect their fruit and vegetable crops.

title: Private Access to Public Cash
description: Looking for more corruption in New York City contracts, prosecutors are turning to cable television - and well they might. Though only a few homes outside Manhattan are wired for cable, the politicians of Queens and the Bronx have, for years, collected rich fees from the companies they selected to receive their cable franchises.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: LOUISVILLE BEATS MEMPHIS STATE, 70-69
description: With Memphis State leading by a point and on the free-throw line with eight seconds left today, Coach Denny Crum of Louisville was asked by one of his players what to do if he rebounded the missed free throw.

title: Who Will Be Next After Shcharansky?
description: To the Editor:

title: BELAFONTE DECLINES SENATE RACE
description: Harry Belafonte told Governor Cuomo and other Democratic Party leaders last night that he would not seek the party's nomination to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, this year.

title: PISTONS' STREAK ENDED BY CELTICS
description: Danny Ainge scored a career-high 27 points and joined Kevin McHale in leading a surge late in the third quarter today that lifted the Boston Celtics to a 129-109 victory, ending the Detroit Pistons' franchise-record 10-game winning streak.

title: Ulster Protestants Call For Support in Strike
description: Protestant leaders today called on the public to support a general strike on Monday to protest the British-Irish agreement that gives the Irish Republic a say in the affairs of Northern Ireland.

title: Zimmerman Tops Baugh by 1 Shot
description: Mary Beth Zimmerman rolled in a birdie putt on the final hole of the Uniden Invitational today to win her second consecutive Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament, defeating Laura Baugh by one stroke.

title: THEY'RE FILIPINOS AND NOW PROUD OF IT: THE PEOPLE CELEBRATE THEIR TRIUMPH
description: They streamed along boulevards and back streets today, bearing balloons and icons, guitars and firecrackers -hundreds of thousands, possibly millions, of jubilant Filipinos heading for a park on the shores of Manila Bay to join in a mass of thanksgiving.

title: Washington Watch; Defense for a Phone Rule
description: The Federal Communications Commission may decide this month whether to relax a rule requiring the seven regional Bell Telephone operating companies to run their regulated local telephone services and unregulated business ventures separately. Billions of dollars ride on the decision.

title: RANGERS BEATEN AGAIN BY CAPITALS, 4-2
description: As if one night had gone into the next, nothing really changed. There was hardly any pressure from the offense and no coordinated attack. When the Rangers soared, they were sensational, but their flights were brief.

title: Advertising; USA Network Account Grows at Della Femina
description: And in New York, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, which is already doing trade advertising for the USA Network, has won the consumer portion of the account as well.

title: Swarthmore Clarifies Policy on South Africa
description: The president of Swarthmore College said today that the board of managers' decision to sell the school's $42.5 million in investments in companies doing business in South Africa was conditional on the school finding a financially prudent way of doing so.

title: Topics; By Air and by Sea Late Crossings
description: A passenger ferry's five-week trial run between Brooklyn's old Fulton Landing and Manhattan's Pier 17 last fall enticed seven companies to bid for permanent service. The city's Department of Ports and Terminals, which must lease the docking space for the venture, hoped regular East River crossings would begin this spring.

title: LURING DISTRICT JOBS BACK
description: ''D.C. has been a one-company town,'' says Madelyn C. Andrews, a special assistant to the deputy mayor. But the company, the Federal Government, is not hiring as it used to, and so the town has had to hit the hustings in order to sustain its people.

title: Manned or Unmanned Flights?
description: The Challenger space shuttle tragedy, combined with concern over the Federal budget, has provoked sharp debate over whether we should allocate money to manned or unmanned flight. Congress and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration must soon face difficult decisions on that issue.

title: Space Concern Dismissed 4 In Drug Inquiry, Report Says
description: One of the companies that builds fuel tanks for the space shuttle dismissed four employees in 1982 and 1983 to remove suspected drug users ''from any contact with space hardware of a critical nature,'' according to space agency documents.

title: Boston Bank Pays Big Fine
description: A Boston bank was fined $100,000 Friday after admitting it failed to tell the Internal Revenue Service about almost $1 million in large cash transactions, including some by Gennaro J. Angiulo, a reputed organized crime leader convicted of racketeering acitivity.

title: Going Public
description: The home team has driven to within a yard of the goal line but has time for only one more play. A touchdown will win, a field goal means overtime. As the coach mulls alternatives, his quarterback reminds him of a new kind of consequence: ''Don't forget, we've got a stockholders' meeting right after the game, and every screaming man, woman and child in this stadium will be there.''

title: BANKS LOWER RATE FOR BRAZIL LOANS
description: A group of international banks said yesterday that they had agreed to reduce the interest rate they are charging Brazil on $31 billion in loans, nearly a third of that country's foreign debt.

title: INDIA'S NEW BUDGET FOCUSES ON POVERTY
description: The new budget proposed by Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi shifts the focus of his economic policies by proposing a substantial increase in Government spending for education, housing and aid for the poor.

title: NEW GENERATION OF WOMEN'S PUBLICATIONS
description: Just when the women's movement seemed to be running into trouble, as the political fervor of the 1970's gave way to the pragmatism of the 1980's, a new generation of grass-roots women's magazines and newspapers has emerged around the country.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The plan to bomb the Move house was reckless, ill-conceived and hastily approved.

title: Catching Up
description: * Clifford Allen, a 17-year-old basketball player, is currently in a juvenile-detention center in Paso Robles, Calif., but hopes to play for Jerry Tarkanian at Nevada-Las Vegas next season (''Rebels Are Shaped Into a Team,'' The New York Times, Feb. 23). Until the other day, though, the 6-foot-10-inch Allen had never played a game of organized high school ball. Then, in his first time out, competing for the center's El Paso de Robles School in a qualifying round of the state championship tournament, he proved as talented as his reputation had indicated, finishing with a school-record 32 points and 18 rebounds.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ORAL HISTORY In 1925, the International Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters began organizing the black men who waited on passengers in railroad sleeping cars. It succeeded, and got a contract with the Pullman Company to improve the workers' lot. Under A. Philip Randolph's leadership, the union also became a political force, working in the forefront of the battles to end racial discrimination in war plants during World War II and in the armed forces after the war.

title: BATTLE OF THE BANDS: LEFT VS. RIGHT IN A LOIRE VILLAGE
description: Over the last century this village along the Loire has had not one but two brass bands, separated by a chasm of contrary opinion.

title: HEPBURN TO PAY TRIBUTE TO TRACY AT BENEFIT
description: The famous face is 76 years old, but the frizzled gray head is held high and proud; the eyes are bleary, but the look is sharp and inquisitive. Revered as a paragon of style, she is dressed in an old black turtleneck, a baggy sweater vest, and drawstring pants with one hem frayed and the other hacked off to a saw-toothed edge, as if by serrated garden shears. But should anyone fail to identify her immediately as one of the most famous movie stars of the 20th century, as soon as she opens her mouth that incomparable voice instantly transports one back through the decades and the memories. Katharine Hepburn is talking about Spencer Tracy.

title: WEST BANK MAYOR, NAMED BY ISRAEL, KILLED BY GUNMEN
description: The Israeli-appointed Mayor of Nablus, who represented to many West Bank Arabs an alternative to the politics of Palestinian radicals, was shot dead today as he was walking from his home to City Hall.

title: Advertising; Almond Growers Pick Dancer Fitzgerald
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample also got some good news, coastwise, on Friday.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Office Gets Cigna National Account
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach/Los Angeles, which has been producing ads for Cigna Healthplan of California for two years, has now been assigned the $10 million to $12 million national advertising account of the Cigna Corporation's health maintenance organization subsidiary.

title: TROUBLED ISLANDERS LOOKING FOR HELP
description: It's that time of year again - the Islanders are struggling, playoffs are looming and Al Arbour and Bill Torrey are scheming.

title: QUALIFIER'S 70 TOPS ODDS AND THE FIELD
description: Kenny Knox, who struggled for years on the PGA Tour, paid $100 to enter a qualifying 18-hole round last Monday, hoping to become one of four players in the field of 140 to earn a berth in the $500,000 Honda Classic. He said that left $2,200 in his bank account - ''since I was always broke.''

title: PALESTINIANS IN OCCUPIED REGIONS STUNNED BY HUSSEIN-ARAFAT BREAK
description: Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip say they have been stunned, dismayed and frightened by the rupture in the yearlong effort by King Hussein and Yasir Arafat to devise a joint position on Middle East peace talks.

title: MORIAL RIVAL WINS MAYORAL RACE: VOWS TO MEND NEW ORLEANS' RIFTS
description: By a comfortable margin, Sidney Barthelemy, a political enemy of outgoing Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial, was elected Saturday to succeed him.

title: JAPAN'S PUSH IN UPSCALE AUTOS
description: The new luxury, high-performance model that the American Honda Motor Company will introduce later this month is likely to raise the eyebrows of current Honda owners used to more Spartan cars. It comes with a high-tech 151-horsepower V-6 engine, a racing style suspension, plush interior and a sticker price close to $20,000. It is not even called a Honda.

title: Expense Account Gloom
description: In the most generous of times, Federal employees traveling on government business have always complained of small allowances for meals and lodging, and now that deficit-reduction legislation is in effect, some discussions of the problem have verged into gallows humor.

title: NEW HOUSING RESTORES LIFE TO CHICAGO LOOP AREA
description: When Susan Millner answered the urgent banging on her apartment door here not long ago, she encountered a gang of rubbercoated men, axes and face shields at the ready. It seems smoke from her popcorn popper had set off an alarm, automatically summoning help from the neighborhood fire station to her high-rise apartment building.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE DREAM OF DELIVERANCE IN AMERICAN POLITICS. By Mona Harrington. 308 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: U.S. ARMY UNITS TO BUILD 6TH AIRFIELD IN HONDURAS
description: In a continuing expansion of military centers in Honduras, United States Army units will begin on Monday to build an airfield, according to an American Army spokesman. It will be the sixth airfield to be built by such units here in the last three years.

title: G.E. Negotiations Resume
description: Negotiations resumed today in a 10-day-old strike by 3,700 workers at a General Electric Company aircraft engine plant, with 1,500 more workers at two other plants threatening to join the walkout Monday if no significant progress is made. Members of Local 201 of the International Union of Electronic, Electrical, Technical, Salaried and Machine Workers walked out Feb. 21 to protest G.E.'s grievance procedure. Union stewards at G.E.'s Everett and Medford plants voted last week to join the walkout.

title: U.S. SEEKS ECONOMIC GLOBAL PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is moving cautiously toward establishing a permanent means of regulating the world economy to try to avert such disruptions as the rise of the dollar and the associated consequences for American jobs and trade, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Government's Cruel Game With the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When the New York Yankees set the major league record by winning five consecutive World Series from 1949-53, how many members of the 1949 team played in all five Series?

title: STATE IS FAULTED ON EXEMPTIONS FROM JURY DUTY
description: Automatic exemption from jury duty for people in more than 20 professions should be abolished in New York State, a court reform organization said yesterday.

title: Marjorie Peerce Becomes a Bride
description: Marjorie Joan Peerce, a daughter of Stuart B. Peerce of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Barbara P. Peerce, was married yesterday to Mark Lawrence Fuerst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joel M. Fuerst of Warwick, R.I. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House in New York.

title: BULLET THAT KILLED PALME FOUND, BUT POLICE STILL REPORT FEW CLUES
description: Police investigators today found the bullet that killed Prime Minister Olof Palme, and they said two witnesses saw the gunman as he escaped on foot through the side streets of downtown Stockholm.

title: CONCERT: Gala Honors Fisher Artists
description: YESTERDAY'S celebration of the Avery Fisher Artist Program was both a reunion and a renewal. Held (appropriately) in Avery Fisher Hall, it notified the music world that Richard Stoltzman, the clarinetist, is the newest recipient of the $25,000 tax-free prize that bears Mr. Fisher's name. It also brought together the seven previous winners for a gala afternoon of chamber music. The event marked the 10th anniversary of the program.

title: Bush Opens Celebration Of Texas Independence
description: Vice President Bush rode a covered wagon in a parade to the Alamo today to help open celebrations of the 150th anniversary of Texas's Declaration of Independence from Mexico.

title: TURNER-MGM MERGER VOTE IS TODAY
description: Stockholders are to vote Monday on the $1.25 billion merger of MGM/UA with Ted Turner's television business.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Steel Imports Drop Sharply
description: January steel imports plunged by more than a third from the period a year ago, it was reported Friday.

title: MIDDLE WEST'S FARM CRISIS REACHES THE EAST
description: From the snowy pastures of upstate New York to the brown fields of New Jersey, many farmers on the edge of the metropolitan area are in trouble.

title: Woman Is Slain in S.I. Home And Her Husband Is Charged
description: A 43-year-old man stabbed his wife to death yesterday in their Staten Island home, according to the police.

title: Allied-Signal Executive Shifting to Henley Post
description: Last fall, Allied-Signal Inc. stunned Wall Street by announcing that it would spin off more than 30 companies with combined assets of more than $3 billion and send its president, Michael D. Dingman, off to run them. Ever since, Paul M. Montrone, Allied-Signal's executive vice president for finance and administration, has tried to be a good soldier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 3, 1986
description: International

title: Kohl's Party Sustains Losses in Bonn Vote
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrat Party sustained heavy losses today in the first of a series of electoral tests prior to Mr. Kohl's bid for re-election next January.

title: Man for All Seasons
description: When the political leader of a small country engages the imagination and the respect of leaders around the world, he must have special qualities of character. His persuasiveness comes not from power but from himself.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee. The Bucks, leading the Central Division, have already clinched the season series against the Knicks with victories in the first four meetings.

title: LACROSSE POWERS MEET EARLY
description: For most of the lacrosse teams around the country, this is a time of testing, trying new players and tuning up offenses.

title: Alice Harvey Is Bride Of Dr. John B. Eigner
description: Alice Karen Harvey, a daughter of Mrs. Robert B. Harvey of New York and the late Mr. Harvey, was married yesterday to Dr. John Barton Eigner, a son of Mrs. Signey Eigner of Surfside, Fla., and the late Dr. Eigner of Lynn, Mass. Grand Rabbi Levi I. Horowitz performed the ceremony at the Beth Shalom Synagogue in Lawrence, L.I.

title: THE STAGE: 'JONAH' AT THEATER 4
description: THERE'S no dog in ''Jonah and the Wonder Dog,'' the awkwardly titled new play at the Negro Ensemble Company, but we do meet a man who's accurately described as ''a pit bull with steam coming out of his nostrils.'' The man is Jonah Howard, a successful middle-aged black politician on the verge of seeking a Senate seat from Nevada. As played with gruff sarcasm and self-contradictory posturing by Douglas Turner Ward, Jonah is the sort of cantankerous, dogmatic but likable blowhard who used to preside over Norman Lear's situation comedies. It's no surprise to discover in the program that the author of ''Jonah,'' Judi Ann Mason, is indeed a past winner of the Norman Lear Award for Achievement in Comedy Playwriting.

title: Guthrie Theater Names New Artistic Director
description: Garland Wright, an artistic associate with the Arena Stage in Washington, has been named artistic director of the Guthrie Theater.

title: YOUNG CONFERENCE SEEKS MATURITY WITH MUSCLE
description: UNTIL three Big East teams reached the Final Four in Lexington, Ky., last March, no conference in the history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament had managed to send more than two.

title: EMPLOYERS ARE SPLIT ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION GOALS
description: Gary Mickle, a 35-year-old black biologist, says he might still be living in Newark with little chance of bridging the 20 miles to Merck & Company's headquarters here if the Government had not prodded the company to recruit blacks and women.

title: WILLIAM DOLLAR, 78, DANCER, CHOREOGRAPHER AND TEACHER
description: William Henry Dollar, a leading ballet choreographer, dancer and teacher, died Friday at his home in Flourtown, Pa. Mr. Dollar, who had been suffering from lung cancer, was 78 years old.

title: RARENTS' REACTION TO BAD MARKS
description: THE report card has arrived. The grades are not good. Some of them, in fact, are poor indeed. The parents are properly concerned. But what's the best way to react to the bad news?

title: WILLIE MAYS IS 24 AGAIN
description: OUT near the chain-link fence in right-center field at Indian School Park where the San Francisco Giants go through their early spring training drills, Willie Mays was talking with Jeff Leonard.

title: Washington Watch; Bank Bill on the Ropes
description: After the Supreme Court overruled the Fed last month and ruled that only Congress could outlaw limited-service banks, members of Congress finally thought they had a strong enough issue to get H.R. 20, a bill to bar such institutions, out of the Rules Committee, where it has been tied up for months. But their hopes seem to be fading fast.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday last week on the Rangers' fortunes in hockey incorrectly identified the two teams in the four major professional sports that have gone the longest without winning a championship. They are baseball's Chicago teams, the Cubs, who last won in 1908, and the White Sox, who last won in 1917.

title: NO. 1 DUKE TOPS NORTH CAROLINA
description: The situation seemed perfectly suited to the sort of legerdemain for which North Carolina Coach Dean Smith is famous. With two regulars sidelined by injury, his Tar Heels were decided underdogs today against the nation's top-ranked team, which was playing an emotional home finale for its four senior starters. What's more, the Tar Heels needed a victory to preserve a streak of 19 consecutive first-

title: LIBBEY IN TALKS ON GLASS UNIT
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company, the primary supplier of automotive windows and windshields for the General Motors Corporation, is negotiating the possible sale of its 87-year-old glass operations to Pilkington Brothers P.L.C., one of the world's leading glass makers.

title: Pope to Visit Colombia
description: Pope John Paul said today that he would visit Colombia in July, and he expressed hope that he could tour other Latin American countries ''in the not too distant future.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AMC Entertainment Inc., Kansas City, Mo., a motion picture exhibitor, has named Ron D. Leslie president and chief operatig officer.

title: 2 LEAGUE TITLES AT SAME SITE
description: For the first time ever, the championships of two college basketball conferences will be determined on the same day at the same site -Monday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: ELECTROLUX OF SWEDEN MAKES BID FOR WHITE
description: Electrolux A.B., a Swedish company that is one of the world's largest appliance makers, said it would begin a tender offer today to purchase the 15.8 million outstanding shares of common stock of White Consolidated Industries at $45 a share in cash.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 11 about the Exxon Corporation gave an incorrect price for Exxon's purchase of the Reliance Electric Company.

title: Toyota Taiwan Venture
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest auto maker, will produce passenger cars and commercial vehicles in Taiwan in a joint venture with a local concern beginning in 1988, a company official said Friday. The company will not export vehicles from the plant until 1990, according to the official, who asked that he not be identified.

title: PERLMAN AND ZUKERMAN TO QUIT ICM
description: Itzhak Perlman and Pinchas Zukerman, violinists who developed important careers under ICM Artists Ltd. and contributed considerably to the reputation of the management company, have made known their intention to leave ICM when their current contracts expire, a company official said over the weekend.

title: Make U.S. Autos Competitive Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Labonte Winner In Nascar Race
description: Terry Labonte gained control early and fought off four challengers to win the Goodwrench 500 Nascar race today at North Carolina Motor Speedway.

title: ANDERSON URGES CUOMO TO SET UP COMMISSION ON CORRUPT SCANDAL
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, saying that prosecutors investigating possible corruption in New York City government were ''stumbling all over each other,'' called on Governor Cuomo yesterday to appoint a special commission to oversee the inquiry.

title: Advertising; ACCOUNTS
description: * Radio Station WMCA to Van Brunt Advertising.

title: REPORT SUGGESTS CHANGES TO GAIN SUBWAY RIDERS
description: The subway system could attract more riders by running faster, more frequent and less crowded trains, according to a private report to be made public today.

title: The Battle for Central Africa
description: Libya's Colonel Qaddafi, whose troops have long controlled northern Chad, would dearly love to extend his influence to the rest of that country and thereby into central Africa. France, historically the dominant outside power in that region and the guarantor of Chad's southern-based Government, struggles to contain the colonel on behalf of most of the central African governments.

title: A RUSSIAN AND HIS AMERICAN FRIEND
description: Delighting in his new cowboy boots as he stomps around a friend's apartment on the East Side of Manhattan, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Russian poet, is describing how Dr. Albert C. Todd, a professor at Queens College, saved his life during a poetry reading.

title: U.S. AIDE FAULTS NATO STRATEGY
description: A senior Defense Department official said today that NATO should reconsider its strategy for defending against a Soviet attack.

title: Miss DeBuono Marries Fellow Lawyer
description: Laureen DeBuono, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard DeBuono of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Stephen Solari 3d, a son of Marion Leary Solari of San Francisco and the late Mr. Solari Jr. The Rev. Dr. Paul Chapman, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: TRIAL OF EX-NAVY MAN NAMED AS SPY FOR SOVIET SET TO BEGIN
description: What is being billed by prosecutors as one of the most important and complex espionage trials in decades is scheduled to begin this week in a Federal courtroom here.

title: STAUB PLANS TO STAY RETIRED
description: Le Grand Orange walked into the sunshine onto the baseball diamond this morning, and this time he was not carrying a bat. But the small group of spectators recognized him at once and broke into cheers for one of the esteemed folk heroes of the big leagues and one of the best pinch-hitters in history.

title: Topics By Air and by Sea Future Flights
description: It took a while to persuade Helen L. Thomas that T.W.A. meant to pay her $50,000. She had won the grand prize in a long-forgotten contest to predict the nature of commercial aviation 30 years out from 1955.

title: PEARL IS UNDER MAGNIFYING GLASS
description: TWO Pearls, connected by a strand made up of a basketball and a nickname, were brought together again last week. A 22-year-old college junior entered a small office in Rockefeller Center and recognized a 41-year-old record-company impresario with an easy smile. Dwayne Washington, the junior guard from Syracuse University, shook hands with Earl Monroe, the former Knick, at a time when the two faced new passages in their lives.

title: AQUINO ANNOUNCES FULL LEGAL RIGHTS WILL BE RESTORED
description: In her first public declaration as President, Corazon C. Aquino today issued what she called Proclamation No. 1 restoring full protections against arrest without charges.

title: NIGHTLY HUNT FOR L.I. DRUNKEN DRIVERS IS RISKY JOB
description: At 4:14 A.M. today, near the end of an unusually quiet shift, Officer Albert Anderson of the highway patrol spotted the car in the eastbound lane of Route 454 beneath a Long Island Expressway overpass.

title: THE FRONT-RUNNERS HIT THE ROAD HAZARDS FIRST
description: All Presidential front-runners are not created equal.

title: Ground Fighting Heavy In Iran-Iraq War
description: Heavy ground fighting was reported today in the Iran-Iraq war, and Iranian television showed Iranian soldiers in sight of a large mountain settlement it said was Chwarta, some nine miles inside northern Iraq.

title: DEVILS WIN, 6-4, ON 3 LATE GOALS
description: The Devils trailed until there were 4 minutes 25 seconds to play, but they rallied with inspiration to defeat the Winnipeg Jets, 6-4, tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: TROOPS IN CONTROL OF RIOTERS IN CAIRO
description: Government troops consolidated their control over Cairo today and the streets were returning to normal after a rebellion last week by paramilitary policemen.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 4, 1986
description: International

title: BASIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $300,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $4,376,000 from the disposition of discontinued operations. c-Net income including a gain of $379,000 from discontinued operations.

title: SOFTWARE FOR TAX TIME
description: BETWEEN now and the April 15 deadline for filing income tax returns, thousands of home computer owners will buy specialized software that will be used just once a year. Some people, in fact, seek to justify the purchase of the computer itself as a tax preparation tool, in the belief that having one will make the annual ordeal much less traumatic.

title: YALE'S LIMIT ON JEWISH ENROLLMENT LASTED UNTIL EARLY 1960'S, BOOK SAYS
description: Not until the early 1960's did Yale University end an informal admissions policy that restricted Jewish enrollment to about 10 percent, according to a new book published by Yale University Press.

title: THEATER: A REVIVAL OF 'BLACK GIRL'
description: THE Second Stage, which gives new life to worthy plays that were neglected the first time around, has reversed its usual practice with its latest production, ''Black Girl.'' When staged Off Broadway in 1971, J. E. Franklin's drama was well received and attended, prompting the making of a film version a year later. The Second Stage ''Black Girl,'' directed by Glenda Dickerson, doesn't add to the play's reputation - it diminishes it. The merits of Miss Franklin's work are nowhere apparent in this frequently amateurish 80 minutes of screeching and confusion.

title: IMPROVEMENT SEEN FOR POLE VAULTERS
description: Sergei Bubka's legacy to American indoor track may go beyond Friday night's pole vault of 19 feet 6 1/4 inches, the highest ever indoors.

title: SWEDISH LEADER SAYS HE TOO MAY SHUN SECURITY
description: Olof Palme's successor said today that his attitude about his personal security was the same as that of the slain Prime Minister's and that he expected sometimes to walk on the streets without guards.

title: U.S. GROUPS URGE VATICAN TO ACT ON ABORTION AD
description: Vatican officials said today that antiabortion groups in the United States were urging action against the signers of advertisements asserting the right of Roman Catholics to dissent on the issue.

title: MANILA SAYS $5.5 MILLION MAY BE IN MARCOS CARGO
description: The head of the Central Bank of the Philippines said today that officials here still did not know for certain how much currency might have been on the transport plane that followed Ferdinand E. Marcos into exile in Hawaii.

title: Letter: On Shoreham; High Time to Replace Lilco
description: To the Editor:

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 RECORD CONCERNS JOIN PROMOTER CURB
description: Two more record companies said yesterday that they would discontinue the use of independent promoters.

title: Prices for Crude Oil Close Near $12 a Barrel
description: Continuing their march downward, prices for crude oil closed in the $12-a-barrel range yesterday for the first time since 1978.

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: DRUGS EFFECTIVE AGAINST HYPERTENSION
description: BOSTON, March 3 (AP) - The practice of using drugs to treat mild and moderate high blood pressure saves lives and is especially effective for preventing strokes, a new analysis concludes.

title: CASTLE & COOKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring special charges of $5 million. c-Net loss. Following its merger with Flexi- Van, the company changed its financial reporting year-end from June to December.

title: WILLIAMS, W W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COTTON STATES LIFE & HEALTH INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $338,815 for the quarter, $761,453 for the year and a nonrecurring deferred tax credit of $1,730,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including capital gains of $96,260 for the quarter, $275,573 for the year and a nonrecurring deferred tax credit of $1,730,000 for the quarter and year. Share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid October 1985.

title: KLOSS VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARTISTS PAY TRIBUTE TO SPENCER TRACY
description: Frank Sinatra once asked Spencer Tracy if he had any advice on how to be a good actor.

title: CALL FOR RECALL OF GERBER BABY FOOD REJECTED
description: Consumer organizations and the Government argued today over whether to recall jars of Gerber baby food from stores.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $179,000. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $46,100.

title: WHITE, UP BY $10.25, HITS HIGH
description: The stock of White Consolidated Industries soared yesterday above the price that Electrolux A. B. of Sweden offered for the Cleveland-based appliance maker.

title: JUDGE PRESSES ON PLANS IN MANES CASE
description: A Federal judge pressed prosecutors yesterday on whether they planned to seek an indictment of Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President, and they said they would respond to his question next week.

title: Belafonte Says He Won't Run for Senate Seat
description: Harry Belafonte said no to a run for the United States Senate yesterday. But like a good politician he took 20 minutes to do so, then spent 25 minutes answering questions and swiping at President Reagan, Mayor Koch, some black politicians and politicians generally.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Strike at de Gaulle Airport
description: A strike by airport firefighters cut airline traffic by one-half today at Charles de Gaulle Airport. With firefighters maintaining only minimum safety coverage, some airlines moved operations to Orly, the other major airport in Paris, or diverted flights to other French cities.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Jan. 29 of L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology, incorrectly described Federal scrutiny of his activity and that of his aides. The Internal Revenue Service is investigating their financial dealings, but there is no Federal grand jury investigation of allegations that Mr. Hubbard and his aides violated Federal tax laws and other statutes.

title: UNIFICATION FIGHT LURES HOLMES BACK
description: The former champion (the International Boxing Federation version) sported five gold and diamond rings, a gold Piaget watch, a pin with his initials in diamonds, a diamond-encrusted bracelet and a gold pendant containing the initials ''L.H.'' composed of diamonds.

title: Pulitzer Action on Bid
description: The directors of the Pulitzer Publishing Company directors recommended today that shareholders reject a $500 million takeover offer from A. Alfred Taubman, the real estate developer. Three family members who control 54 percent of the stock had previously said they would not accept the offer.

title: A NEW WAVE IN THE BIG EAST
description: For the last three seasons, Big East basketball was so dominated by the same group of super players and teams that it sometimes seemed as if the conference belonged to Georgetown's Patrick Ewing and St. John's Chris Mullin.

title: GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,283,000 to reflect a reduction in the carrying value of certain assets and investments.

title: FAIRFIELD GAINS N.C.A.A. BERTH
description: Fairfield University went from last to first in a year in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference and tonight earned its first berth to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: FRANCHISE SOUGHT
description: An offer will be made for a Minneapolis-St. Paul franchise in the National Basketball Association, according to Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota.

title: SURVEY CITES SEXUAL ATTRACTION IN THERAPY
description: ALMOST 90 percent of psychotherapists say they have been sexually attracted to their clients at least once, according to a recent national survey.

title: Eastern Talks With Lenders
description: Managers of Eastern Airlines provided its 60 lenders yesterday with details of its agreement to be acquired by the Texas Air Corporation and the new contracts with two of its unions containing major concessions.

title: CARTER'S KNEE IS STILL INFLAMED
description: The Achilles' heel of the Mets, so to speak, is Gary Carter's right knee. He has had three operations on it, he wraps it in a specially designed metal brace for all games and he conceded today that the knee was inflamed after only two weeks of spring training.

title: DEL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split payable March 26.

title: HAPPY FAREWELL
description: While the current commissioner is busy laying down the law, a former commissioner finds time to crank out a tune. Oh, well, Peter Ueberroth has his job to do, and Happy Chandler has his.

title: Envoy to Indonesia Named
description: The Senate today confirmed Assistant Secretary of State Paul D. Wolfowitz to be the Ambassador to Indonesia. The Senate also confirmed Gaston Sigur Jr., a staff member of the National Security Council, to succeed Mr. Wolfowitz at the State Department. Arthur H. Davis, a State Department consultant and former envoy to Paraguay, was made Ambassador to Panama.

title: CITY STUDENT IN TIE FOR SCIENCE PRIZE
description: For the first time since 1978 two high school students, a boy from New York and a girl from Florida, tied for first place in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search competition, each winning a $20,000 college scholarship.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POLICE KILL 7 BLACKS, REBEL SUSPECTS, NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: The police said today that they had ambushed and killed seven black nationalist guerrillas in a black township near Cape Town.

title: How to Eliminate Cheating on Gas Excise Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A DEADLY BUSINESS' ON CBS
description: THE very word Mafia has become a sociological barometer of sorts. There is no doubt that the Mafia exists, despite the best efforts of understandably upset, law-abiding Italians to minimize its presence. But there are periodic debates on what to call it - organized crime, the Brotherhood, Cosa Nostra, the mob, you name it. Right now, just plain Mafia is back in style. One piece of evidence: the sensational gangster trials under way in Italy. Another: ''A Deadly Business,'' tonight's television movie at 9 on CBS.

title: TRIMEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
