description: Before John Portman started designing them, hotels were not glass cylinders sitting on concrete bases. Neither did their lobbies sport lakes and open upward into atriums; nor did glass elevators scuttle up and down like transparent beetles.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dale Earnhart, the Nascar driver who was suspended for a year and fined $5,000 after colliding with the car driven by Darrell Waltrip in a race in Richmond, Feb. 23, won immediate reinstatement and a reduction of his fine to $3,000 after appealing the penalties, but he said he wasn't satisfied with the action by the appeals committee and was considering a further appeal. . . . Condredge Holloway, the 32-year-old former University of Tennessee quarterback who has been playing for the Toronto Argonauts, signed a two-year Argonaut contract that will bring him an estimated $450,000 and make him the highest-paid player in the history of the Canadian Football League. . . . . . . John Ferguson, the general manager of the struggling Winnipeg Jets, took over as interim coach, replacing Barry Long, who was retained as a front-office assistant.

title: Cabinet Maker Accepts Offer
description: The Triangle Pacific Corporation, the nation's largest maker of kitchen and bathroom cabinets, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Beta Partners, a San Francisco investment group headed by Edward L. Scarff, for about $201.7 million, or $53.50 a share.

title: DOW DECLINES SOME MORE, TO 1,686.42
description: Blue-chip stock prices fell sharply on Wall Street yesterday, but the overall market was mixed as investors were forced to weigh the benefits of declining interest rates against signs of a surprisingly weak economy.

title: Electrolux Plan
description: Electrolux A.B. of Sweden said it would sell the air-conditioner and dehumidifier businesses of White Consolidated Industries if its $711 million tender offer for the Cleveland-based company succeeded. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Electrolux said it had a 1983 agreement, made in connection with its sale of the Emerson Quiet Cool Corporation, to stay out of the United States markets in air-conditioners, dehumidifiers and kerosene heaters until Sept. 30, 1988. The board of White met yesterday but made no announcements.

title: IF IT'S TUESDAY, IT'S LOBBYING DAY IN ALBANY
description: The Adelettes from H. B. Thompson Junior High School in Syosset, L.I., wore pleated shirts and snappy red bow ties and crooned ''Basin Street Blues'' under the banner of the New York State School Music Association.

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $7.5 million for the closing of some operations for the quarter and a loss of $12.7 million for the year, from unusual items associated with the company's domestic restructuring program. c-Net income.

title: Saudi Arms Again
description: President Reagan was reported yesterday to have assured King Fahd that the Administration would exert maximum pressure on Congress to approve the sale of $350 million in missiles to Saudi Arabia. The King says the weapons are needed to protect Kuwait and the Persian Gulf oilfields from of Iranian advances in the war with Iraq.

title: Pioneers Feeling Fenced Out
description: When last we looked in on the C. W. Post basketball team, the Pioneers, forced late in the season to forfeit five games because of a player's ineligibility, had been shut out of the N.C.A.A.'s postseason Division II party and were hoping against hope for selection by the National Invitation Tournament. Yesterday there was some news, and rarely has a more discouraging word been heard around Greenvale.

title: Top Executive Resigns At Beleaguered Pengo
description: Pengo Industries, a beleaguered maker of oilfield exploration tools, said yesterday that William T. Trice, chairman, chief executive and president, had resigned to pursue other professional interests.

title: DEMOCRATS CHASE DOLLARS WITH COMPUTER AID
description: A few weeks ago a staff member of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee saw a news item that said one of the committee's perennial political enemies, the National Conservative Political Action Committee, had scheduled a news conference the next day to open a $1.5 million television attack on 33 Democratic House members.

title: WHIMSY, ROMANCE
description: Closeted in Chintz Fans of chintz will like these new pad-ded hangers, in a pink floral print against a pale yellow background. A handmade set of four is $22.50.

title: Plant for G.M.-10
description: General Motors said its Chevrolet-Pontiac group would invest $500 million to modernize its plant here for production of the G.M.-10, a front-wheel-drive car to be introduced in the 1988 model year. G.M. said it could not predict how the modernization would affect the 5,885 jobs at the plant, which now makes Buick Century and Oldsmobile Cutlass Sierra cars. The plant will be closed 16 weeks, starting in December, to install the automated equipment.

title: DOLLAR HAS MIXED DAY; GOLD CLIMBS SHARPLY
description: The dollar turned mixed yesterday in nervous trading. Undermining the currency were signs that United States economic growth is slowing; supporting it was speculation of further interest rate cuts overseas.

title: Dewey Comes to Town
description: Tom Dewey has finally made it to Washington after all. The grandson of the Republican Presidential candidate of 1944 and 1948, who was a top-heavy favorite to defeat Harry S. Truman in 1948, began work last week as a policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation.

title: STAGE: CHEKHOV'S 'THREE SISTERS', AT THE HARTMAN
description: The central problem of Margaret Booker's uneven yet rewarding production of ''The Three Sisters'' at the Hartman Theater is the sisters. Miss Booker, who makes her directorial debut here after 14 years as artistic director of the Intiman Theater in Seattle, uses Randall Jarrell's fluid translation and David Potts's stunning sets to good effect in telling the sad story of the three young women who are not destined to break out of their existences in a provincial Russian barracks town and go to Moscow.

title: DEP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TWO NEW CBS SITCOMS, AIMED AT THE YOUNG
description: IT'S counter-programming time for CBS between 8 and 9 P.M. on Wednesdays. ABC is offering ''McGyver,'' an adventure series still in search of an audience. NBC has a not spectacular but solid hit in ''Highway to Heaven,'' a syrupy exercise starring Michael Landon as an angel. The only thing left, obviously, is the situation comedy, and CBS is bringing forth two new ones clearly aimed at younger audiences: ''Fast Times'' at 8 o'clock, and ''Tough Cookies'' at 8:30. The premieres are not likely to leave executives dancing in the chilly corridors of corporate headquarters.

title: IN PARTIAL VERDICT, U.S. JURY FINDS 6 RADICALS GUILTY OF 2 BOMBINGS
description: After 13 days of deliberations, a Federal jury convicted six self-described revolutionaries yesterday of conspiracy charges and of setting off bombs at two military reserve centers.

title: RIFFS TO RIFT: PRAGUE DUELS WITH SOME JAZZ FANS
description: For the last few years, the sharpest and most openly waged battle for free expression in Czechoslovakia has pitted a group of jazz fans interested in Western culture against the Government.

title: American Slain in Mexico
description: An American visitor was shot and killed in the Pacific resort of Mazatlan on Monday, a United States Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Joint Legal Ownership Provides Safeguards
description: To the Editor:

title: Concert Publicity Can't Save Farm
description: The 310-acre farm of a family whose plight was nationally publicized in the FarmAid concert last fall was sold today at a foreclosure auction.

title: DUARTE IN OFFER TO NICARAGUA
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said today that he was sending a proposal to President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua under which they would agree to open simultaneous negotiations with the armed rebels opposing their Governments.

title: 2d Bid for Alamito
description: The Megawatt Corporation, a New York-based company, has offered $128 a share, or a total of $281 million, for the Alamito Company, an electricity wholesaler based in Tucson, Ariz. Megawatt said it planned to finance the merger with $20 million in equity capital and $260 million from the General Electric Credit Corporation. Alamito, which said the offer was being reviewed, recently rejected a bid by Homans McGraw Tully Valeo & Company that the Boston investment bank valued at $372 million.

title: Thrown for Loss
description: Lawsuits. The drug scourge. Threats of declining TV revenue. A league commissioner has all sorts of headaches these days. But it was a backache that put Pete Rozelle of the National Football League in the hospital this week.

title: PISTONS BEAT STRUGGLING NETS
description: They had a two-game winning streak, and it seemed to give the Nets some momentum. But it came to an emphatic halt tonight at the Silverdome. Their defense collapsed, their offense stuttered, and suddenly they were back to familiar times: a 120-103 loss to the Detroit Pistons.

title: SINGLE GOLDEN LION TAMARIN SEEKS TO MEET...
description: Birds and bees rely on Mother Nature to find suitable companions. But some monkeys in Washington and elsewhere need Jonathan D. Ballou and his computer.

title: Bol Is Stopped
description: The Washington Bullets' victory over Milwaukee the other day brought a milestone on the downside for Manute Bol: He failed to block a single shot, the first time that had happened in 47 games. A record? Nowhere close. From April 5, 1984, to last Nov. 12, Bol's rejection rival, Mark Eaton of Utah, put together a string of 94.

title: JEWISH GROUPS ANGERED ABOUT WALDHEIM'S PAST
description: Jewish organizations expressed outrage today over published reports that former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim served under the Nazi military command responsible for the deportation of Greek Jews, and they called on all international organizations to make efforts to exclude former Nazis from positions of power in the future.

title: SOLO DINING: NEW OPTIONS IN PRIVACY VS. COMPANY
description: SOLITARY diners traditionally have had a rough time of it. Waiters tend to ignore them for the meager tips they bring, restaurateurs resent them for tying up tables and the other customers always seem to be staring at them. Even these slights might be tolerated if the dining rooms were quiet enough and bright enough for reading - but generally they are not.

title: FORD MOTOR OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $56 million for the quarter and $134 million for the year.

title: Market Place; Retail Outlook Is Restrained
description: N erratic Christmas season and a so-so January are prompting retailing analysts to reduce their estimates for the 12-month earnings that major retailers will soon report.

title: Select Company
description: He's only a part-timer these days, but when Phil Russell of the Devils appears in three more games, he'll join a fairly select group: the 56 players in N.H.L. history - just three currently active - who've made it an even 1,000. Heading into last night's play, these are the leaders in active tenure: Gil Perreault1,155 Marcel Dionne1,147 Don Lever1,010 Phil Russell997 Larry Robinson991 Bob Gainey970 Dave Lewis927 Lanny McDonald926 Denis Potvin913 Tom Lysiak907

title: MACHINE VISION: A BUSY FIELD
description: For all its promise, the machine vision industry is shaping up as a classic example of a dazzling new high-tech business that, in its infant stages, has attracted far more players than it could support.

title: For a Special Primary
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN A. GLENDINNING
description: John A. Glendinning, a former New York State Deputy Commissioner of Labor and former finance director of the State Republican Committee, died of cancer Sunday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Bellerose, L.I.

title: Newspapers and Others Face Rise in Postal Rates
description: Postal rates for newspapers delivered in the county where thay are published, as well as for charities, schools and libraries, will increase Sunday for the second time this year under a new rate approved today by the governors of the United States Postal Service.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 5, 1986
description: The Economy

title: THE NEW SCHOOL TO OFFER BACHELOR'S DEGREE IN JAZZ
description: TAKING advantage of New York's position as the major jazz center of the world, a four-year undergraduate course in ''Jazz and Contemporary Music,'' with a faculty drawn from the huge pool of outstanding jazz musicians who live and work here, will begin in September as a division of the New School for Social Research.

title: INTEGRATED CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PHILIPPINES PUTS MARCOS HOLDINGS IN THE BILLIONS
description: The Philippine Government said today that it had documents linking former President Ferdinand E. Marcos to overseas property holdings whose worth could be in the billions of dollars.

title: SWEDES PONDER EFFECT OF PALME'S DEATH ON SOCIETY
description: Reflecting on the hunt for Prime Minister Olof Palme's murderer, a senior adviser to the Government said, ''The best thing would be a mad Swede.''

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone Wins Fred Alger Account
description: Foote, Cone & Belding has been asked to do the first corporate image campaign for Fred Alger Management, a pension fund management and individual investment firm.

title: The Dangers of Neo-Interventionism
description: A new interventionist spirit is abroad in the United States. It has seized conservatives who want to intervene to support Jonas Savimbi's Unita forces in Angola, the contras in Nicaragua and ''freedom fighters'' in Afghanistan. But it has also re-emerged among liberals and centrists who are pushing for sanctions against South Africa and oppose United States support for repressive regimes. It is a dangerous tendency, and one that may in the end involve us in places we don't want to be.

title: CAIRO LINKS STRIFE TO FOES OF REGIME
description: The Egyptian Government said today that Moslem fundamentalists and political opposition groups might have been behind the rebellion last week of police conscripts in an attempt to overthrow President Hosni Mubarak.

title: MUSIC: YALE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA
description: THE Yale Symphony Orchestra decided to showcase itself Monday night in Carnegie Hall as part of its 20th-anniversary season, and offered a most stimulating 20th-century program for the occasion. The first half consisted of closely linked central European music, starting with Hindemith (''Symphonic Metamorphoses on Themes of Carl Maria von Weber''), who had strong Yale connections. The program continued with Busoni's sensuous ''Berceuse Elegiaque'' and the American premiere of an orchestral song cycle by Franz Schreker. After the intermission came Shostakovich's oddly shaped but affecting Symphony No. 6, whose 17-minute opening Largo takes up more than half its overall length.

title: The Miseries of Mr. Mubarak
description: The recent police riots in Cairo were ostensibly stirred by a rumor that youths, drafted to serve for three years for $4 a month, would have to serve another year. But the mutiny, which claimed 37 lives, clearly expresses a deeper discontent. Whether fomented by Moslem fundamentalists or wholly spontaneous - either explanation is credible - the riots spell trouble for the regime of President Hosni Mubarak, and for Washington as well.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Quality and Value in Nuts While J. Wolsk & Company is not the easiest place to find, it's well worth the effort. At 81 Ludlow Street, between Delancey and Broome Streets, near the approach to the Williamsburg Bridge, the nut, dried fruit and candy store has been a Lower East Side institution since 1938. Two years ago, it moved from a cramped space to its present sparkling location on the same block.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After a loss of $1,657,000 from discontinued operations and a provision of $9.3 million for disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Advertising; Counihan & Bridgewater Has $1 Million in Billings
description: Counihan & Bridgewater is a new ad agency that has opened its doors at 324 East 50th Street with more than $1 million in billings.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $650,000. c-After a writedown of $92.9 million.

title: ROOKIES FINDING METS ARE SPOTLESS
description: For the first time in years, the Mets may go north from spring training with no rookies on the team. If so, it would mark a dramatic departure from custom for a team that traditionally takes all the help it can get.

title: An Explanation
description: Maybe Manute was just tired. Asked after a recent loss to Boston why he always looked so worn out following games against the Celtics, he offered a simple, patient explanation. ''You see,'' he said, ''they pass the ball on and on.''

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FEARS RISE AS DEFICIT ESTIMATES DROP
description: New forecasts of sharply declining Federal budget deficits, projected by both the Reagan Administration and the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, sent tremors through Capitol Hill in early February. Could it be that, after years of struggling with little success to bring down record deficits, the deficits were falling anyway?

title: NAVY GAINS BERTH IN N.C.A.A. FIELD
description: David Robinson scored 26 points and Vernon Butler 24 as Navy captured the Colonial Athletic Association title with a 72-61 victory tonight over George Mason.

title: ITT AIMS KEY LINE AT EUROPE'S OFFICES
description: The ITT Corporation, in a major effort to widen its share of Europe's lucrative office equipment market, today introduced a new range of European office data processing and telecommunications equipment.

title: Conboy Hires Assistant
description: The new City Investigations Commissioner, Kenneth Conboy, has hired Peg Breen, co-producer of the public-television program ''Inside Albany,'' as his executive assistant. Miss Breen, 39 years old, is to begin her $72,000-a-year job Monday.

title: PLANTING TIME APPROACHES, BRINGING A CREDIT SQUEEZE
description: Planting time is approaching once again in the nation's major food-producing regions, and many Federal loan offices are running out of the funds that farmers most troubled by debt need to finance their operations.

title: AMERICAN BILTRITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $130,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,452,000, or 61 cents a share, for the year. c-Including tax credits of $540,000, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,532,000, or 60 cents a share, for the year.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,137,612 for the quarter and $3,230,321 for the year. c-Including capital gains of $196,656 for the quarter and $1,130,851 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a reduction in 1984 deferred acquisition costs. Year-ago fourth quarter net is restated to include a charge of $642,000, and the year result is restated to include a charge of $1,620,000. Share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in November.

title: Goldsmith Recruits Lily-Tulip's Chief
description: Albert J. Dunlap, widely credited with reversing the fortunes of Lily-Tulip Inc., a paper products manufacturer, resigned as chairman and chief executive yesterday to become president and chief executive of the company that controls Sir James Goldsmith's 48 percent stake in the Crown Zellerbach Corporation.

title: RISING OPPOSITION STALLS REAGAN DRIVE TO DEVELOP U.S. LANDS
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to sell off as much public land in the West as possible and to accelerate development of natural resources on the rest has been largely stalled.

title: Pulitzer Offer
description: A. Alfred Taubman says he wants to negotiate with officers and directors of the Pulitzer Publishing Company who rejected his $500 million bid to take over the publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch. ''We would be willing to discuss with you or your representatives any aspect of the transaction,'' Mr. Taubman said in a letter to Joseph Pulitzer Jr., chairman of Pulitzer Publishing.

title: RELIGIOUS FIGURES PROTEST CONTRA AID
description: Nearly 200 religious figures formed a human cross on the Capitol steps today, commemorating people who have died in Nicaragua, and they accused the Reagan Administration of preferring ''terrorism to the pursuit of peace.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chemical Bank has appointed Deborah S. Prutzman senior vice president and assistant general counsel.

title: U.S. SEES POSSIBLE ATOM RELEASE IN A SHUTTLE BLAST
description: Federal officials acknowledged today that a space shuttle explosion on the launching pad could, under some circumstances, release a harmful cloud of radioactive material.

title: TRUMP DROPS 5-YEAR EFFORT TO EVICT TENANTS
description: After a five-year struggle to avoid eviction, tenants of a 15-story building on Central Park South owned by the developer Donald J. Trump have won the right to stay in their rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments.

title: Utah Congressman Quitting
description: Representative David S. Monson, Republican of Utah, said today he was quitting after one term in Congress, but he disputed suggestions that a lack of party support was prompting him not to run for re-election. Mr. Monson said he would leave office at the end of this term because he wanted to spend more time with his family and avoid the ''grueling'' ordeal of another campaign.

title: MASSTOR SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PALME IS NAMED A RECIPIENT OF AN F.D.R. FREEDOM MEDAL
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden, who was assassinated Friday in Stockholm, was named yesterday as the recipient of a 1986 Roosevelt Freedom Medal. It was the first time the medal had been awarded posthumously.

title: Leak in the White House
description: In some respects, Ronald and Nancy Reagan are no different from any other American couple living in a 170-year-old house. No matter how careful the residents are about upkeep, once in a while the place springs a leak.

title: Customs Service Is Overzealous on Art Seizures
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL CARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After an extraordinary charge of $996,000 resulting from an accounting change.

title: BRIEFS
description: * B.A.T. Industries, London, said it had agreed to sell the major interests of its Grovewood Securities Ltd. subsidiary for about $173 million to buyers brought together by Citibank Investment Bank.

title: Endowment Shuts a Gate
description: It won't affect as many people, but the National Endowment for the Humanities has followed the lead of the Internal Revenue Service and decided to stop giving money to grant applicants who are already delinquent on Federal student loans.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JORDAN CHALLENGE TO P.L.O. FALTERS
description: King Hussein's challenge to Yasir Arafat's leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization appears to have met a cold reception from Palestinians, according to Western diplomats and Palestinian and Jordanian sources.

title: JUSTICES REQUIRE ACCOUNTING OF NONUNION PUBLIC EMPLOYEES' DUES
description: The Supreme Court today imposed new procedural requirements on public employee unions to assure that dues collected from nonunion employees under contracts permitting such dues are not spent on union political activities.

title: Off-the-Cuff And On-the-Air
description: WNET-TV set up a box this week where viewers can drop their opinions about the station.

title: Funds Seen For Argentina
description: Argentina is expected to be able to borrow about $270 million from the International Monetary Fund on March 14, authorities indicated yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN LEADER IN AN OFFER ON NAMIBIA
description: South Africa proposed today that a United Nations plan for the independence of South-West Africa should begin on Aug. 1, but made clear the offer was conditional on the withdrawal of Cuban troops from neighboring Angola.

title: 6 Killed in Beirut In Renewed Shelling
description: Christian and Moslem militias resumed shelling here on Monday, and the police said six people had been killed and 29 wounded.

title: Advertising; Firestone Switch
description: The Building Products division of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has switched its account to Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, New York, from Lord, Sullivan & Yoder, Marion, Ohio. It is a business-to-business account and, according to Ricardo C. Calvillo, chairman of the agency, the assignment will begin with a strategic review and then get into sales promotion as well as advertising.

title: CRITIC OF DUVALIER IS MOST TRUSTED MAN IN HAITIAN JUNTA
description: The generals and priests were poised on the dais at the former presidential palace, ready for oratory to commemorate the end of 29 years of Duvalier family rule. For the first time in years, the palace doors were swung open - a fact widely noted, for the large building had so long sucked all the nation's power inside.

title: Chrysler Truck Engine
description: The Chrysler Corporation has begun making a 3.9-liter V-6 truck engine, to be optional on the Dodge Dakota pickup. It was developed for $70 million, the company said, by cutting the front two cylinders off a 5.2-liter V-8 engine and using an existing engine block.

title: SCREEN: 'SALVADOR' BY STONE
description: THE early 1980's were especially grim for El Salvador.

title: ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DRUG-TEST RULING IS EXPECTED SOON
description: The issue of drug-testing clauses in individual player contracts should be settled within the next month, Donald Fehr, the players' union chief, said today.

title: ARREST OF NURSE SPURS AN INQUIRY INTO 438 DEATHS
description: The State Department of Health will investigate 438 pediatric deaths that occurred at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center during a 15-year period when a nurse now accused of killing two of her own children worked in pediatrics.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SET TO PROCLAIM END OF EMERGENCY LAW
description: President P. W. Botha announced today that the state of emergency imposed by the Government seven months ago would be lifted soon, possibly on Friday. But he indicated that new laws, replacing the emergency decree, would bolster the nation's pervasive security legislation.

title: No Tin In This Ear
description: No one is more gracious than I about confessing and correcting error, but to have error unfairly imputed to me when every fact has been triply checked and verified as absolutely accurate . . . well, you know what Julius Caesar said about the sting of the adder's tooth: ''I'm too old to cry and it hurts too much to laugh.''

title: Gambino Trial Jurors Report They Are Split
description: After more than 100 hours of deliberations, the jurors in the trial of eight reputed Gambino crime family figures on car theft, conspiracy and murder charges said last night that they were unable to reach a decison on the major murder charge and some lesser ones.

title: VALUABLE BORDEAUX IS STOLEN
description: Thieves with a fine taste for wine have stolen the most expensive cases of Bordeaux from a restaurant on San Francisco's Telegraph Hill, according to the restaurant's owner.

title: Start Planning for Post-Reagan America
description: Although world realities may have tempered some of President Reagan's policies, he still clings to well-honed myths: that economic growth can best be achieved by unleashing private ambition and that the United States' influence in the world can best be advanced by predominant military power. Hence, Mr. Reagan's program as set forth in the messages and speeches he has delivered to Congress and the country in the new year: further increases in military spending, more cuts in economic and social programs and preservation of tax preferences for the well-off.

title: BONDS RISE IN VOLATILE TRADING
description: Volatile trading and a record supply of new corporate bonds cast a shadow over the ebullient bond market yesterday, where prices of long-term Treasury issues fluctuated widely before closing modestly higher.

title: MEESE DEFENDS POLICY ON ALIENS
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d told a House panel today that the Reagan Administration was holding its own in its efforts to stem the tide of illegal immigration.

title: When Scholars Work With the C.I.A.
description: News reports about Central Intelligence Agency funding of various academic projects have focused renewed attention on the relationship between the intelligence community and the academic community. This relationship is complicated by the nature of C.I.A. activities, which run the gamut from legitimate political analyses based on public data to clearly illegitimate covert operations. More broadly, there is a fundamental contradiction between intelligence agencies' predilection for secrecy and the principle of openness that is the hallmark of academic scholarship.

title: LICENSED TO PRUNE: A CORPS OF ARDENT TREE LOVERS
description: Marianne Holden could not restrain herself any longer. She whipped out her trusty 12-inch folding saw and attacked the Japanese pagoda tree.

title: What's Right With Keeping 200,000 G.I.'s in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Basketball Pitch
description: Since 1960 the only role Minneapolis has played in the National Basketball Association is as the answer to a trivia question: How did the Lakers of lakeless Los Angeles get their name? Now, 26 years after the Minneapolis Lakers left the ''Land of 10,000 Lakes'' for the smog basin of southern California, two local businessmen are leading an effort to establish an N.B.A. franchise in Minneapolis-St. Paul. To give credence to their effort, Marv Wolfenson and Harvey Ratner flew to New York yesterday to present David Stern, the N.B.A. commissioner, with a $100,000 check representing earnest money in the city's bid for an expansion franchise.

title: EX-CITY OFFICIAL'S ROLE IN S.I. PROJECT IS UNDER FEDERAL INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators are seeking to determine if a former City Planning Department official improperly helped a developer in efforts to acquire valuable city land for a shopping center on Staten Island. The official was hired by the developer within six months of leaving his city job.

title: AN AMNESTY ON U.S. TAXES?
description: Like knights in search of the Holy Grail, lawmakers are always looking for painless ways to raise revenue. In that vein, dozens of Senators and Representatives are promoting legislation that would create an amnesty period during which Federal tax evaders could pay what they owe without penalty.

title: METROMEDIA SET TO SELL GLOBETROTTERS, ICE SHOW
description: Metromedia Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Harlem Globetrotters, perhaps the best-known and certainly the most-traveled basketball team in the world, to the International Broadcasting Company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report Feb. 24 about a rent strike voted by Roosevelt Island residents to protest the shutdown of the tramway misstated the number of apartments there and the monthly rental income. There are 2,137 apartments, of which 1,764 are rentals that produce $1.25 million a month, according to the Roosevelt Island Housing Management Corporation.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect the 5-for-4 split effective Sept. 6, 1985.

title: ARMS TALKS ADJOURN WITH NO GAINS
description: The Geneva arms talks recessed today without progress on the limitation of nuclear weapons, Reagan Administration officials said.

title: 4-GOAL 3D PERIOD SPARKS ISLANDERS
description: The Montreal Canadiens have usually beaten the Islanders by playing a no-mistake brand of hockey and had already done so twice this season in two games. But tonight, what began as a tight game with Montreal controlling the pace, evolved into a rout as the Islanders beat the Canadiens, 6-3, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: DEFENSE ATTACKS KEY TESTIMONY ON DRUG MONEY
description: Defense lawyers yesterday tried to discredit a witness who testified that he had transferred millions of dollars in cash from pizzeria owners in this country to secret bank accounts in Switzerland.

title: 2 More Afghan Officers Are Reported to Defect
description: Western diplomats said today that two senior Afghan Army officers had defected to Pakistan in the latest in a series of desertions from the Soviet-backed Afghan armed forces.

title: O'NEILL ASSAILS AID REQUEST FOR CONTRAS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, led a Democratic counterattack today against a new Administration request for $70 million in military aid and $30 million in economic aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: AT 5-3, BOGUES TOWERS IN ASSIST COLUMN
description: There have been few bright spots this season for Wake Forest, the fourth team in 33 years to go without a victory in Atlantic Coast Conference play.

title: RUSH TO A FILIPINO FREE PRESS REPLACING REVOLUTION FERVOR
description: John Peter Zenger never mentioned a chicken farm as the alternative to the fourth estate, but that is how Luis D. Beltran, one of the premier newspaper columnists here, survived during the decade when he was banned from Filipino journalism.

title: DEALERS-TURNED AGENTS: NEW ROLE IN ART WORLD
description: At the end of a highly successful sculpture exhibit at a SoHo gallery last year, the art dealer Patricia Hamilton noticed a surprising fact: more than half of the works had been sold to California art collectors who had bought them from the show's catalogue, sight unseen.

title: PLAN TO AID F.S.L.I.C. IS OUTLINED
description: A senior Treasury official recommended today that the 12 regional banks of the Federal Home Loan Bank system shore up the depleted Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation with hundreds of millions of dollars of loans or investments.

title: Soviet-Singapore Trade
description: The Soviet Union plans to increase two-way shipping and trade links with Singapore, the Soviet trade representative here said today. The official, Mikhail A. Vilenchik, said some 965 Soviet ships including auxillary vessels passed through Singapore last year, making the Soviet Union the leading merchant navy in the area. Chinese trade officials in Singapore also claimed to have the largest number of merchant vessels in the area, with more than 1,100 ships passing through Singapore last year.

title: Advertising; Ingalls And BBDO Join Forces
description: AN agreement has been reached for BBDO International, America's sixth-largest agency, to acquire Ingalls Associates, a 75-year-old Boston agency. The plan calls for Ingalls to be merged into BBDO's Boston outpost, Quinn & Johnson/BBDO to form Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, with billings of $140 million.

title: Advertising; New Agency For Magnavox
description: Backer & Spielvogel has been named agency for the $14 million advertising and sales promotion account of the Magnavox line of electronic home entertainment products.

title: HEAD OF MISSILE SHIELD URGES RESEARCH GROUP
description: The director of the program for a shield against attacking missiles said today that he had asked permission to create a Government-financed intensive research group to provide ''squeaky clean'' advice on the design and operation of the space-based defense.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including gains from discontinued operations of $378,694 for the quarter and $2,032,473 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: Jesse Jackson's Views
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson spoke out last night against many of the nation's large universities, saying black athletes who were recruited ''as appendages to the university'' are being exploited for their entertainment value and should be paid so long as they graduate. Mr. Jackson was speaking in Wilberforce, Ohio, at the 99th anniversary celebration of Central State University, a small, predominantly black school. He praised the program there and at other black schools, saying they are cost-effective.

title: AQUINO SHY, BUT HER OWN WOMAN
description: President Corazon C. Aquino telephoned her official spokesman at home at 8 A.M. on Sunday. Informed that he was still asleep, Mrs. Aquino decided not to wake him. She was said to have felt embarrassed about ordering him to the phone.

title: GULFSTREAM TO SALUTE STEPHENS
description: Wednesday has been officially renamed Woody Stephens Day at Gulfstream Park, but it seems as though every day is Woody's day around here. There is nothing unusual about the 72-year-old trainer's sending out lots of winners, but this winter his success has been uncanny, even by his standards.

title: Bid for BL Units
description: The General Motors Corporation, as expected, gave formal notice that it would bid for parts of BL P.L.C., the former British Leyland, as the deadline neared for offers on the state-owned auto maker. A G.M. spokesman said the company would inform BL's banker, Hill Samuel, of its interest in buying out BL's Land-Rover and truck divisions before the midnight deadline tonight. By late afternoon just one rival, a consortium led by Land-Rover's management, had emerged to challenge G.M.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TRANSACTIONS IN A FOREIGN CURRENCY. By Deborah Eisenberg. 214 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MANY factors influence people's choices of ski equipment. Does it match their ski clothes? Is it a new and popular design? Is it the brand used by an admired ski star? Is it on sale? The most important factor governing this decision should be safety, but it is a factor skiers seldom consider. Safe equipment is appropriate to your size and ability, fits properly and has up-to-date features to minimize the risk of injury.

title: MANHATTAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net realized gains on investments of $655,000 for the quarter and $2,524,000 for the year. The year result also is after a pretax charge of $14.6 million resulting from the writedown of deferred acquisition costs. c-After net realized losses on investments of $235,000 for the quarter and including net realized investment gains of $1,377,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: Shamrock Layoffs
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it would lay off 600 employees, or about 5 percent of its 11,500 workers, by May 1, in a ''streamlining of the corporation.'' The Dallas-based company said its board had decided to ''focus the corporation's resources on the oil and gas business,'' and would consider selling the Diamond Shamrock Chemicals Company in Irving, Tex., and the Diamond Shamrock Coal Company in Lexington, Ky.

title: MAYOR SCHEDULES A DINNER TO PAY OFF $555,000 DEBT
description: Mayor Koch, who raised $7 million in his re-election campaign last year, nevertheless ran up a $555,000 deficit. In the name of ''campaign finance reform,'' he has scheduled a fund-raising event for May 15.

title: LINDAL CEDAR HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $59,545 for the quarter and $154,428 for the year. c-Includes tax benefits of $106,928 for the quarter and year. The share earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid last November.

title: 24 Countries Seek Reform
description: A group of 24 developing nations wants to widen discussion on international monetary reform to deal with debt and capital flows, monetary officials said today.

title: ONE OF CHINA'S TOP WRITERS
description: Ding Ling, who emerged from an obscure rural backwater to become one of China's foremost writers and her country's most articulate champion of women's rights, died yesterday in a Peking hospital of an unspecified illness, the official New China News Agency reported. She was 82 years old.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE scene is a Command line bus, traveling from Brooklyn to Manhattan for a $3.50 fare, exact change only. Among the passengers is Sylvia Tolk, who sees a young man with an attache case board and then call out, ''Does anyone have change of $5?''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MENU terminology and the etymology of kitchen names have always fascinated me. It pleases me to know that dishes named Marengo have to do with a battle in which Napoleon was victorious, that peach Melba was created by Escoffier for the opera singer and that the word forestiere refers to mushrooms, preferably woodland mushrooms, for all the obvious reasons.

title: Ship Explosion Kills Five
description: Rescue workers suspended efforts today to find the bodies of three crewmen from the Greek freighter Galini that exploded in the Bay of Biscay on Monday, a maritime radio station said.

title: Navratilova Seeded First
description: Despite a loss to Kathy Jordan in an early-round match during a tournament in Oakland, Calif., last week, Martina Navratilova retained her No. 1 ranking on the Women's Tennis Association computer and will be the top-seeded player for the Virginia Slims championships at Madison Square Garden, beginning March 17. The championships represent the final event of the 1985 tennis season.

title: REAGAN SETS EXAMPLE FOR EDUCATORS
description: In a tribute to the educational value of memorization, President Reagan and Secretary of Education William J. Bennett today recited alternating lines of Robert W. Service's ballad about life in the Yukon, ''The Cremation of Sam McGee.''

title: Israel Spying Suspect Said to Be Cooperating
description: Jonathan Jay Pollard, a Navy intelligence analyst accused of selling military secrets to Israel, has been cooperating with the American authorities in an attempt to strike a plea bargain and avoid a trial, Reagan Administration sources said today.

title: U.S. NAVY PROJECT SPLITS JAPANESE TOWN
description: The voters of this small bayside community have recalled their 26-member city council because of its support for plans to build a large housing complex for Americans stationed at a nearby naval base.

title: Harvard Paper Declines Ad Seeking Nude Models
description: Playboy magazine is looking for women from Ivy League colleges to pose in the nude for its pages, but The Harvard Crimson has declined to run an advertisement from the magazine soliciting models.

title: Unilever's Earnings Grow
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch food and household goods company, reported today that its fourth-quarter pretax profit jumped 50.5 percent from a year earlier. The figure was $:322 million, or $467 million at the present exchange rate of $1.45 to the pound, compared with the previous $:214 million.

title: HOW NOW, PLAGIARIST MAO?
description: An official magazine said Monday that popular poems attributed to Mao Zedong in the 1960's were actually the work of a university student who was jailed when he complained.

title: THE SAME ANDUJAR
description: In his last previous public appearance, Joaquin Andujar, the red sleeves of his sweatshirt flailing, had to be restrained by his St. Louis Cardinal teammates from attacking the umpire Don Denkinger as their World Series went up in flames. For that scene, the 33-year-old right-hander was suspended by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for the first 10 days of the coming season. Then last Friday he was branded a first-degree drug offender by the commissioner, subject to drug testing, a donation of 10 percent of his $1.3 million salary to drug-abuse prevention, and 100 hours of community service over each of the next two years.

title: CALIFORNIA BANK BID REPORTED
description: The First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, owner of one of the biggest banks in California, has approached the BankAmerica Corporation with a merger proposal, insiders close to both companies disclosed last night.

title: SHULTZ IS TOLD FOREIGN AID BILL FACES SHARP CUT
description: The chairman of a key House appropriations panel told Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that unless the White House and Congress reached an overall budget compromise, the House was unlikely to approve more than a minimal level of foreign aid this year.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MORE EMPLOYERS FAVOR BONUSES OVER RAISES
description: To the alarm of union leaders, employers are increasingly turning to one-shot bonus payments to avoid paying costly annual wage increases, according to a private study.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 5, 1986
description: International Ferdinand E. Marcos's holdings overseas could be worth billions of dollars, according to documents cited by the new Philippine Government. One set of documents appears to tie holdings of the Marcos family to two New York real estate investors, Ralph and Joseph Bernstein, who have been cited for contempt of Congress. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: 'Junk Bonds' Still Offer High Yields
description: Now that Treasury bond yields have fallen to nearly 8 percent, and many corporations are offering new bonds yielding less than 9 percent, investors are finding that so-called junk bonds are the only sector of the bond market where double-digit interest rates are still available.

title: Strike in Massachusetts Idles Fourth G.E. Plant
description: Workers at a fourth General Electric Company plant went on strike today, raising the number of idle employees to 6,100 and halting production of $1 billion worth of military aircraft engines.

title: In a Crowded Park, Dead Trees and Dead Limbs Are a Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: Top C.I.A. Aide Quits; New Official Is Named
description: President Reagan today accepted the resignation of John N. McMahon, the second-ranking official at the Central Intelligence Agency, and replaced him with Robert M. Gates, the agency's Deputy Director for Intelligence.

title: 50 SENATORS PUT FOCUS ON BUDGET
description: A bipartisan group of 50 senators sent a letter to President Reagan today urging him to reach an agreement with Congress on the 1987 Federal budget before going ahead with revision of the tax system.

title: Smithsonian Novelist
description: Walter J. Boyne, director of the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum, the author of nine nonfiction books on aviation, is coming out with his first novel. Crown Publishers has ''The Wild Blue'' on its fall list, but several thousand copies are winging out to reviewers in May. The book chronicles 30 years in the life of six Air Force families. Mr. Boyne is a retired Air Force colonel and pilot, and his co-author, Stephen L. Thompson, is an Air Force brat and writer.

title: THE CROWD'S THE THING AT MET REHEARSAL
description: WHAT'S the hottest ticket in town? One that money cannot buy. It is a ticket to Metropolitan Opera dress rehearsals, which, for the last half century or so, have been reserved for a motley group of schoolchildren and adults who contribute financially to the opera company.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including an income of $21.5 million from discontinued operations.

title: The Packard Bombshell
description: The military machine on which President Reagan urges Congress to lavish money at an even faster pace is inefficient, uncoordinated, red-tape-ridden and dangerously gold-plated. That, put more politely, is the view of the President's blue-ribbon commission on military management, headed by former Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard. It finds both the Pentagon and Congress at fault for the way weapons are conceived, bought and tested. Its ideas for reform merit urgent attention. The problem, in the commission's analysis, begins with the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The chiefs of the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps don't first agree on national security goals and then, under a given budget, buy the weapons to meet them. Each service has its own wish list of new weapons, which the Joint Chiefs only staple together for the Secretary of Defense. Since each chief cares most about his own service, and the chairman lacks power to resolve priorities, interservice needs like air and sea transport get short shrift.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings results are fully diluted.

title: SALES AT CITY'S STORES OFF 3.5%
description: New York's big retailers have started their 1986 fiscal year, which begins in February, on a sour note. Sales in city stores last month showed an average decline of 3.5 percent compared with the period a year ago, a monthly spot-check showed yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FROM THE MIND'S EYE Artists have visions, and Christoph Wecker, a photographer, conceived of a blend of department-store mannequins and city architecture. His photographic mixtures, planned and carefully composed, were concocted by first taking pictures of mannequins in store windows along 57th Street and Madison and Fifth Avenues. After going through each roll of film, he rewound the film to the first frame and made a second exposure. This time, still strolling around the city, he took a photograph of a building or facade.

title: LAYER CAKE MADE EASY
description: THE most challenging part of making layer cakes is getting the layers to stack evenly. Cakes rarely emerge from the oven perfectly flat. The top usually has a slight dome caused by uneven heat distribution - the batter around the rim cooks faster than the center, losing moisture and sinking slightly.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Have you ever tasted a Greek or Turkish dish called the priest fainted? A. The Turkish name for it is imam bayeldi or bayildi. The word imam means priest or holy man. The dish is made with eggplant slices cooked in a large amount of olive oil to which tomatoes and onions are added. One story has it that a holy man sampled the dish and requested a cook to show him how it was prepared. When he viewed the quantity of olive oil that went into its preparation he fainted. Q.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Feb. 25 about speculation that Frank Borman would leave his job as chairman of Eastern Airlines carried an incorrect description, provided by the company, of the voting on its proposed acquisition by the Texas Air Corporation. Arthur R. Taylor, an outside director, was absent from the board meeting but voted by telephone in opposition to the sale. Two Eastern executives, Wayne A. Yeoman and Joseph B. Leonard, voted for the sale.

title: SAUNDERS LEASING SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter and year are after dividends on the $1.20 preference stock which was issued in 1985.

title: ARISTEK COMMUNITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR LOWLY KNICKS, EASY TIME AT LAST
description: The Knicks, the brunt of countless jokes since the start of their decline several months ago, unleashed their frustration on the Washington Bullets last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat shipyard will shut down for two weeks during the Christmas-New Year holiday season, the the first shutdown of the shipyard in 35 years. All 18,000 employees will be affected, company officials said. Eletric Boat's general manager, Fritz G. Tovar, said in a memo that the shutdown was intended ''to provide for more efficient operations during a period of time when absenteeism is higher than normal and to take advantage of plant holidays.''

title: ZAMBIAN DEBT REVISED
description: The Paris Club of Western creditor nations has agreed to reschedule Zambian debt payments over 10 years, the French Finance Ministry said today. Zambia's foreign debt totals about $2.8 billion.

title: MILITARY OBJECTS; JOSE MARIA SISON: A MISSION REMAINS
description: Soon after his arrest in 1977, Jose Maria Sison was given three books calculated to irritate a Philippine Marxist revolutionary: the Bible, a collection of writings by his country's President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's ''Gulag Archipelago.'' He says he found them all far-fetched. Mr. Sison, the founder of the Communist Party of the Philippines, says his mission in life is ''for attaining the national freedom of the country and the development of democracy.''

title: GENETIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results have been adjusted for the spinoff of its cardiovascular business in July.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIRSCHFELD OPENS DRIVE TO RUN WITH CUOMO
description: Defying the tradition that one doesn't run for the nomination for lieutenant governor, the developer Abraham Hirschfeld announced his candidacy yesterday to be Governor Cuomo's running mate.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $455,000 for the cost of a litigation settlement.

title: PERSIAN GULF OIL PARLEY
description: Oil ministers of Gulf Cooperation Council nations will meet here Saturday to coordinate policy ahead of OPEC's March 16 meeting in Geneva, industry sources said today. Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates are members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting ountries; the two other members of the Gulf Cooperation Council, Oman and Bahrain, are not.

title: A Sales Record For Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, said that the $2.6 billion of mortgage participation certificates it sold in February was a record for any month.

title: ROYAL PAGEANTRY AND PARTIES IN MOROCCO
description: King Hassan II, celebrating the 25th anniversary of his rule, wore a flowing white robe with the hood folded back on his head as he rode in a gold satin saddle atop a black Arabian stallion. A footman walked briskly at his side carrying a tall purple umbrella to shade the King, though there was little sun in the outer courtyard of his parapeted winter palace here.

title: PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED BY LONE STAR INDUSTRIES
description: Lone Star Industries, a leading producer of cement and other building materials, said yesterday that William M. Troutman, executive vice president and chief operating officer since 1983, had been elected president.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arco Pipe Line Co., Los Angeles, has elected Daniel O. Gallas president, succeeding Horace B. Edwards, who will retire.

title: Edwards Charges Amended
description: A Federal prosecutor has asked a judge to strike 4 of 49 counts of mail and wire fraud against Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and two others, whose second trial is scheduled to begin March 24. An amended indictment and attached motion filed Monday by John Volz, the United States Attorney here, leaves standing charges of fraud and conspiracy to violate the Federal racketeering law against Governor Edwards, Ronald F. Falgout and James J. Wyllie Jr.

title: Testing for Drugs; Tested by Drugs
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder calls the proposal ''idiotic,'' and the House Judiciary Committee chairman, Peter Rodino, describes it as ''unwarranted.'' Representative Charles Schumer frets about creating ''a police state in government office buildings,'' and the American Civil Liberties Union thunders about a Government ''war against innocent American citizens.''

title: C.D. Yields Dip; Money Funds Gain
description: Average yields for six-month certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts fell for the week ended yesterday, while the yields on money market mutual funds showed a slight gain.

title: THE FRUSTRATION IN ARGENTINA
description: The sweeping economic plan of wage and price controls that President Raul Alfonsin introduced here last June 14 has been held up as a model of the way to deal boldly with hyperinflation. Indeed, only last Friday Brazil was applauded for introducing a similar program to tackle its own economic problems.

title: RECITAL: LARS ROOS, PIANIST
description: LARS ROOS is described in his program biography as ''probably the only concert pianist who has a diploma as a masseur'' and as a popular Swedish television personality with many albums of salon music and light classics to his credit. But any wariness serious concertgoers might have felt at his Merkin Concert Hall recital Tuesday was allayed by the sight of the program (solid Beethoven, Schubert and Brahms, with Hugo Alfven to represent the player's homeland), and dispelled entirely by his playing of it.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE BOURNE SUPREMACY. By Robert Ludlum. 597 pages. Random House. $19.95. MURDER FOR LUNCH. By Haughton Murphy. 268 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $9,252,899 resulting from a settlement with the company's lead lender for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $273,426 from the reversal of a tax credit. d-Including a tax credit of $1,599,321.

title: PANEL MEMBERS SAY THEY WEREN'T GIVEN FINAL CRIME REPORT
description: Several members of the President's Commission on Organized Crime asserted today that they were never shown the final version of the commission's report on drug enforcement, issued Monday. They said they were surprised and upset to read of its recommendation for widespread drug testing.

title: 2 SENATORS PROMISE TO INSIST ON TRUTH FROM C.I.A.
description: Two members of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence said today that they would insist that the man nominated to be the new Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency tell the panel when it has been misled by any agency official, including the Director.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including life insurance proceeds of $1,418,871, or 20 cents a share.

title: CONCERT: 'REPONS,' BY BOULEZ
description: THE return of Pierre Boulez to New York, as centerpiece of a festival breathlessly entitled ''Boulez Is Back!,'' may yet turn out to be the seismic cultural event that publicity has already proclaimed it. However, the New York premiere of his ''Repons'' Wednesday night at Columbia University Gymnasium did not live up to the Concorde-like screams of hyperbole that have preceded the arrival of this 45-minute breeding of live music with computer-generated sounds.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $683,093 for the quarter and $3,388,831 for the year on the sale of investments. The net for 1984 was increased by $537,209, which was the cumulative effect of a change in accounting method for accrued loan income.

title: United Fares Cut to Hawaii
description: United Airlines said today that previously announced fares between major Unites States cities and Hawaii would be cut by as much as 18 percent for fall and summer travel.

title: SAFEGUARD HEALTH ENTERPRISE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMMANDED AT WAKE ISLAND
description: Rear Adm. Winfield Scott Cunningham of the Navy, who was the commander of United States forces on Wake Island when it was captured by the Japanese shortly after the attack on Pearl Harbor, died here Monday. The retired officer was 86 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

title: ROZELLE WANTS STRICTER DRUG PLAN
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that he has told the chief labor negotiators for both the players and the owners that he intends to develop a league-wide drug program that would include random testing and that he would implement it if the negotiators failed to agree upon a program of their own.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Regan's Wonder Diet
description: In Mr. Reagan's first term, the assorted ways White House staff members used to take off a few pounds of excess weight, with methods ranging from the scientific to the semi-mystic, attracted considerable attention. Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, has shed 10 pounds since Christmas, and when he was asked how he did it, Mr. Regan had a typical no-nonsense response: ''I eat less.''

title: TULSA STOPS BRADLEY'S 22-GAME STREAK
description: Brian Rahilly and David Moss scored 22 points apiece to lead Tulsa past Bradley, 74-58, in the title game of the Missouri Valley Conference tournament tonight, snapping the Braves' winning streak at 22 games.

title: WHY THE TWO HOUSES BEHAVE THE WAY THEY DO
description: In December, the day after the House of Representatives approved the most sweeping overhaul of the Federal income tax system since World War II, Richard G. Darman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, was of two minds.

title: SOVIET OFFER ON ATOM TESTS REPORTED
description: A Pentagon official said today that the Soviet Union had indicated it might be willing to consider additional verification measures for an unratified 1974 agreement that limits the size of underground nuclear tests.

title: STAGE: 'MEDEA,' BY PAN ASIAN REPERTORY THEATER
description: SOMEONE leaving the Susan Bloch Theater after the Pan Asian Repertory Theater's ''Medea'' was heard mentioning soap opera. That is not entirely unfair; many soaps are held together by bits purloined from classics. And ''Medea,'' the tale of a woman with unusual powers who plots a wild revenge after her husband, the most famous hero in the world, abandons her for a princess, might inspire years of torrid television afternoons.

title: HOSTAGE REPORTED KILLED IN BEIRUT
description: An extremist Moslem organization announced today that it had ''executed'' one of four Frenchmen it has been holding hostage. There was no independent confirmation of the announcement.

title: Numbers Game For Hernandez
description: Particularly in these top-dollar days, no self-interested superstar can afford to make a decision without due consideration to the tax consequences. Which brings us, once again, to Keith Hernandez, who among other things has been ordered by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth to donate $135,000 - 10 percent of his salary -to a drug-prevention program if he is to escape a year's suspension.

title: INQUIRY SUBPOENAS TONS OF RECORDS BUT IS ANYBODY LOOKING AT THEM?
description: In their search for corruption in New York City government, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have subpoenaed an avalanche of documents so immense it could fill a subway car.

title: JOYFUL INMATES POUR OUT
description: Haiti's new Government declared a broad amnesty and threw open the doors of the country's largest prison today, permitting dazed and laughing inmates to pour into the sunny downtown streets.

title: ANTIQUES, EASTER EGGS OF UKRAINE
description: Third Annual Armory Antiques Show, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. 212-777-5218.

title: PIEZO ELECTRIC PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $16,993,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,611,057. The latest year loss from discontinued operations includes a non-recurring charge of $11.7 million related to the sale of Cadillac Cable Corp.

title: A Seductive Approach To Banking by Machine
description: What the customer expected to hear when she picked up the telephone next to the cash machine was the reassuring voice of a bank employee.

title: Advertising; Numerous Changes at Thompson
description: AS the adworld and much of the business community expected, the board of the JWT Group late Tuesday named Joseph W. O'Donnell chairman and chief executive officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company, its largest subsidiary and the world's fourth-largest advertising agency.

title: Halt Those Bankers Using Getaway Cars
description: The new Philippine Government hopes to recover some of the estimated $3 billion in assets the Marcoses accumulated. Many of them are thought to be in this country. Representative Stephen J. Solarz thinks America should cooperate: ''This is one way we can help the Government acquire the resources it needs.'' In fact, this is a way we could help a lot of deeply indebted countries whose corrupt officials, businessmen and ordinary citizens have enriched themselves, legally or illegally, and shipped money abroad.

title: HABITAT 67 IS SOLD TO ITS RESIDENTS
description: Habitat 67, the modular apartment building complex in Montreal designed by Moshe Safdie for Canada's centennial world's fair, Expo 67, has been sold to the people who live there.

title: SWIFT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HERS
description: FOR most of my life I have pursued a policy toward my body that could best be characterized as benign neglect. From the time I could remember until the time I was 15 it looked one way, and from the time I was 15 until I was 30 it looked another way. Then, in the space of two years, I had two children and more weight changes than Ted Kennedy, and my body headed south without me.

title: A Correction:
description: A letter Tuesday erroneously attributed to Woodrow Wilson actions of President William Howard Taft following the fraudulent re-election of Porfirio Diaz in Mexico in 1910. Taft's Ambassador to Mexico, Henry Lane Wilson, played a leading role in United States dealings with Diaz and recognition of Francisco I. Madero.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Best Weapon in South Africa
description: Disinvestment, the withdrawal of foreign capital from South Africa, would be a disaster for all its citizens; so say a variety of moderate South Africans. Not so, say South Africa's increasingly bitter black leaders; they contend that disinvestment would cripple apartheid and thus warrants the short-term economic cost. The moderates seem to make a better case, but that doesn't matter much. The debate is quickly becoming irrelevant.

title: THEATER: ANAIS NIN'S PARIS YEARS
description: ANAIS NIN has long had a coterie of fervid admirers who make great claims for her, but one would have thought only the most obsessed imagination could envision her longum opus, the many-volumed ''Diary,'' as the stuff of drama. Whether it is, is still an open question. Lee Kessler's selection of material, mostly from the pages written during the 1930's, is often interesting, and at times her presentation of it seems indeed to be the interior conversation of the writer. But the compelling moments add up to minutes, and Miss Kessler's ''Anais Nin: The Paris Years'' goes on for two hours.

title: PACKWOOD SEES INDUSTRY TAX LOAD
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that he expects the Senate to approve legislation this year that would ''significantly'' shift the Federal income tax burden to businesses from individuals.

title: REMOVING FURNITURE SCREWS
description: Compared with nails, screws are the Johnny-come-lately of the fastener business. While nails and wooden pegs have been around for centuries, screws got their real start in life early in the 1700's.

title: Bryant to Sue Stars
description: Kelvin Bryant is suing the Baltimore Stars of the United States Football League for breach of contract and interfering with his ability to negotiate with other teams. Bryant, 25, is seeking a temporary injunction to allow him to negotiate with the Washington Redskins of the National Football League before the suit is settled. The Redskins selected Bryant in the seventh round of the 1983 N.F.L. draft.

title: SOVIET CONGRESS IS URGING ECONOMIC CHANGES
description: The Communist Party congress approved a resolution today calling for ''truly revolutionary changes'' in the economy.

title: SENATE BUDGET UNIT BEGINS WORK AS REVENUE RISE IS SOUGHT
description: The Senate Budget Committee began working today on a draft Federal budget for the 1987 fiscal year, with the committee's chairman, Pete V. Domenici, advocating that steps be taken to raise revenue by as much as $20 billion.

title: BARRING JAMS OF SATELLITE TV
description: LAST October, on two consecutive nights, viewers outside the New York area watching WOR-TV saw nothing but static on their screens. A few months earlier, The Movie Channel experienced interference on one of its transmission channels for nine hours.

title: Soviet S.D.I. Fears
description: There is tangible disappointment here at the rather indifferent Western response to Mikhail Gorbachev's grandiose proposal to abolish nuclear weapons by the year 2000.

title: RESCUING THE LOEWS IN FLATBUSH
description: Ben Vereen recalls accompanying his mother to her cleaning job at Loews Kings Theater - Brooklynites pronounce that ''LOW-ees'' - and dancing on the huge stage while she worked. Barbra Streisand was an usher at the mammoth theater. And if you believe Anita Pfleiderer, who works in a school office, most of Nassau County grew up, as she did, in the neighborhood, and they still talk about their Saturday afternoons in the Flatbush Avenue palace of celluloid dreams.

title: SKETCH DRAWN IN PALME SLAYING
description: The police said today that a young woman had managed to draw a portrait of a man she saw Friday night soon after the slaying of Prime Minister Olof Palme who may have been the assassin.

title: New Fighting in Chad Breaks a 2-Week Lull
description: New fighting has erupted in Chad between Libyan-backed rebels and Government forces after a two-week lull, France said today.

title: Greece Expels Guru; He Goes On to Spain
description: The Greek Government today expelled Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, the wandering Indian guru, and he left for Spain in his executive jet.

title: SENATE, ENDING A DEADLOCK, BACKS $5 BILLION IN FARM AID
description: The Senate broke a three-week deadlock late today to approve an emergency $5 billion infusion for farm programs along with a package of changes in the two-month-old 1985 Farm Act.

title: France Widens Charges Against Gestapo Chief
description: A Paris court decided today to press new charges against Klaus Barbie, the World War II head of the Gestapo in Lyons, but the move may delay his trial until 1987, judicial sources said.

title: GEORGE H. NELSON, DESIGNER OF MODERNIST FURNITURE, DIES
description: George H. Nelson, the architect, industrial and furniture designer, editor and writer and one of the most influential thinkers in industrial design, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INTELLECTUAL INQUIRY The president and chief executive officer of the New York Public Library, Vartan Gregorian, is a historian by training, with a special interest in the humanities. He also is a professor at two local universities. Tonight he will deliver the 92d Street Y's annual Distinguished Lecture in the Humanities, which he has titled ''Toward a Fragmented Culture?'' In it, he will comment on America's pluralism, the over-specialization of academic disciplines, and historical, scientific and functional illiteracy, and the doubts about developing a truly integrated culture. He also will explore societal manipulation and whether Jeffersonian ideals are still possible in America.

title: The Service Road To the Gravy Train
description: There is a wonderful way to get rich quick in this town.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1.8 million resulting from an income tax adjustment related to a sale of International Technology Corp. common stock for the quarter and income of $173,000 and $5,847,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. c-After income of $706,000 for the quarter and $3,850,000 for the year from discontinued operations. The latest year results include a pre-tax gain of $12.5 million, or $6.8 million after taxes, and minority interest, on the sale of International Technology stock and also includes a $4.4 million after-tax gain on the June 3, 1985 sale of the company's Rowe International Inc. subsidiary, which has been reclassified as discontinued operations. The latest quarter and year results include the operations of National Can Corp. since April 16, 1985, the effective acquisition date. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 5, 1985, and the January 1986 dividend of one share of participating preferred stock for each share of common stock outstanding.

title: REMOTE-CONTROL UNITS: GETTING TO KNOW THEM
description: MAYBE we're all getting lazy. It certainly seems that way when you look at the latest trend in video and sound systems. Everything runs by remote control. No more getting out of your chair, out of your bed or off the couch. Now you can do it all from a distance - switch channels, start and stop tapes, adjust the volume or search for your favorite scene in a movie.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $269,816 for the quarter and $886,729 for the year. c-Including realized investment gains of $313,773 for the quarter and $1,334,897 for the year.

title: COUNTY OFFICIALS URGE U.S. TO KEEP HIRING GOALS
description: The National Association of Counties has joined several state and local government organizations in opposing proposed changes in a Presidential order under which Federal contractors have been required to set numerical goals for hiring women and members of minorities.

title: HAZARDS OF THE TRADE: FISH AND FLYING PICKLES
description: STUNG by criticism, actors, playwrights and directors have been known to respond with brickbats - or worse. As ire rises, an uncontrollable desire for vengeance takes possession and otherwise mild-mannered people move to the state of high dudgeon. Those engaged in the craft of criticism have all been subjected to outraged letters and telephone calls, and some have been slapped or punched in public or had foodstuff flung in their faces. Occasionally, a messenger arrives bearing objects expressing derision.

title: A TROUBLED HIGH SCHOOL IN BROOKLYN WILL CLOSE
description: Eli Whitney High School, a vocational school in Brooklyn that has been on the decline for more than a decade with waning attendance, failing grades and violence in its halls and classrooms, will be closed within two years, New York City school officials said yesterday.

title: DATAKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MATEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $639,000 for the quarter and $981,000 for the year. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $165,000 for the quarter and $283,000 for the year. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations. The latest fourth quarter and year losses from discontinued operations include a charge of $570,000 from the disposal of the Matec Microelectronics subsidiary.

title: IRANIANS REPORT SHELLING A KEY IRAQI AIR BASE
description: The Teheran radio reported today that Iranian forces shelled the key Iraqi air base of Shuaiba on the southern front in the Persian Gulf war. It also said a major headquarters was hit with new heavy-artillery guns.

title: Vatican Called 'Positive' On Anglican Reunion
description: A high Vatican official, responding positively to efforts by a theological commission to reconcile the Anglican and Roman Catholic churches, has indicated that the way may someday be cleared for Rome to accept the validity of the Anglican priesthood.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized capital gains of $23,299,777, principally from the sale of Richardson-Vicks Inc. common stock, for the quarter and realized capital gains of $24,024,031 for the year. Also, an extraordinary tax credit of $3,866,763 is included for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and after realized capital losses of $291,901 for the quarter and $1,633,723 for the year. The company said latest quarter results also reflect a $5 million strenghtening of the loss reserve on the books of its reinsurance subsidiary.

title: RIGHT EYE INJURED
description: Mookie Wilson, already limited after two operations on his right shoulder, was lost to the Mets for perhaps two months today when he was struck in the face by a thrown ball and suffered a severe eye injury.

title: BONN CUT IN DISCOUNT RATE SEEN
description: The German Bundesbank, in a move likely to spark an international round of interest rate cuts, is expected to loosen credit by lowering its 4 percent discount rate by one-half a point Thursday.

title: TRUSTCOMPANY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. STUDY IS READY ON TERROR POLICY
description: An Government task force on terrorism has recommended that potential injury to innocent civilians be considered in determining the need for American military intervention.

title: U.S. INQUIRY ON CANADIAN SUPPLIER
description: The Defense Department has opened an inquiry into allegations that a Canadian company, Fleet Aerospace, has sold defective components to large military contractors in the United States, a spokesman for the Pentagon said today.

title: Advertising; People
description: * TBWA Advertising Inc. has promoted Geoff Hayes to senior vice president, executive art director.

title: MUSIC: FREDA PAYNE, SINGER
description: THE pop-soul singer Freda Payne is best-remembered for her 1970 hit ''Band of Gold,'' an up-tempo dance tune very much in the Motown groove. But Miss Payne, who opened a weeklong engagement at Sweetwater's (170 Amsterdam Avenue, near 67th Street) on Tuesday evening, has a more sophisticated, jazzy side to her musical personality.

title: 35 Groups Oppose Liability Caps
description: Thirty-five consumer organizations said today that they had formed a coalition to oppose the efforts of manufacturers and insurers to place limits on liability awards by courts.

title: Congressman Out of Coma
description: Representative John E. Grotberg, who lapsed into unconsciousness six weeks ago after suffering complications from an experimental cancer treatment, has emerged from the coma, a spokesman for the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., said Tuesday. Doctors said they were listing the condition of the 60-year-old Illinois Republican as ''serious but stable.'' Mr. Grotberg, a candidate for re-election, has been hospitalized since January.

title: Nitze Critical of Soviet
description: Paul H. Nitze, the American arms control adviser, said here today that the Soviet plan for ridding the world of nuclear weapons by the year 2000 was intended mainly for propaganda and was inimical to Western interests.

title: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
