description: b-Including tax credits of $100,000 for the quarter and $3,875,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md., 7:30 P.M. The Knicks went up a game in the season series with their victory over the Bullets Tuesday night. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: Big East Tournament, quarterfinals, at Madison Square Garden. Syracuse vs. Boston College, 1 P.M. (Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 1 P.M.). Georgetown vs. Pittsburgh, 3 P.M. St. John's vs. Seton Hall (Radio - WCBS, 880; and WSOU-FM, 89.5; 7 P.M.) Villanova vs. Providence, 9 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M., 3 P.M., 7 P.M. and 9 P.M., live). E.C.A.C. Metro Tournament, quarterfinals, at Coraopolis, Pa. Marist vs. St. Francis (Brooklyn), 1 P.M.; Wagner vs. St. Francis (Pa.), 3 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson vs. L.I.U., 6 P.M. (Radio -WNYE-FM, 91.5; 6 P.M.); Loyola (Baltimore) vs. Robert Morris, 8 P.M.; Big Sky Conference, at Reno; Metro Conference, at Louisville, Ky.; Mid-American at Rockford, Ill.; Mid-Continent, at Springfield, Mo.; Mid-East Conference, at Philadelphia; Pacific Coast Conference, at Inglewood, Calif.; Southwestern Conference, at Jackson, Miss.; N.C.A.A. Division II Regionals at campus sites. Golf Doral Eastern Open, at Miami, opening round. Mark McCumber is the defending champion. L.P.G.A. Kemper Open, at Kauai, Hawaii, opening round. Jane Blalock broke five years of frustration by winning this tournament last year. Hockey Devils vs. Detroit Red Wings, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The Devils have played two overtime games with the Red Wings, winning one and tying the other. (Radio -WMCA, 570, 7:35 P.M.) Rangers vs.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax benefits of $155,000 for the quarter and $555,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: RICHARD MANUEL, 40, ROCK SINGER AND PIANIST
description: Richard Manuel, the singer, pianist, songwriter and occasional drummer with the rock group the Band, was found dead Tuesday in his motel room in Winter Park, Fla. The police said the death was apparently a suicide. Mr. Manuel was 40 years old and lived in Woodstock, N.Y.

title: Scholarship Established In Joseph Duell's Name
description: The New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet has announced the establishment of the Joseph Duell Memorial Scholarship, named after the City Ballet dancer and graduate of the school who died Feb. 16.

title: COEUR D'ALENE MINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HOUSE PANELS BAR HELP FOR CONTRAS
description: Two House panels voted today to disapprove President Reagan's proposal to send $100 million to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: HESS, EXPECTING LOSS WILL OMIT ITS DIVIDEND
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation, buffeted by the impact of sharply declining oil prices, yesterday said that it expected a substantial loss for the first quarter and would omit its quarterly dividend. Further, the company said it would undertake a sweeping retrenchment that included a sharp reduction of its capital budget and layoffs of some employees.

title: G.O.P. PLANS TO PRESS CORRUPTION ISSUE
description: New York Republicans moved yesterday to try to capitalize on the current investigations of officials in the Koch administration.

title: CENTRAL SPRINKLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Place Like Home
description: In what is shaping up as a Ping-Pong trade, Matt Winters, a former Yankee minor leaguer who signed with the Chicago White Sox as a free agent only to be traded back to the Yankees along with the former Yankee Ron Hassey last month, has been sent back to the White Sox organization, this time as a personal loan from George Steinbrenner. It seems that Winters, a 25-year-old outfielder who spent eight seasons with the Yankee organization, is from Buffalo and had been assigned by the White Sox to their Buffalo Bisons farm club in the American Association, which had been using him as the focus of a pre-season ticket promotion. According to the Yankees, when Steinbrenner heard of the Bisons' plans for Winters, the Yankee owner agreed to lend him to the White Sox organization so he could play for the Bisons while remaining Yankee property, a long established practice in the minor leagues.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,644,000 for the quarter and $2,059,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $564,000 for the quarter and $919,000 for the year.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Barry Rona was named executive director of the Player Relations Committee by Peter Ueberroth, baseball commissioner. Rona succeeds Lee MacPhail, who retired last December.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan to Meet Australian
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia will hold talks here on April 17, the White House announced today.

title: MICHIGAN GIRDS FOR FLOODS AND EROSION AS GREAT LAKES SURGE
description: The Great Lakes, which surged to record levels in 1985, have continued to rise. And some officials expect record erosion and flooding when the thick winter ice pack melts in a few weeks.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
JANUARY HOME SALE GAIN 4.4%
description: Sales of new homes climbed 4.4 percent in January to their highest level in two years as falling mortgage interest rates spurred buying, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net losses related to the company's investment in CSI-Marketing Inc. of 1 cent a share for the quarter and 2 cents a share for the 9 months.

title: WHEELING BOARD MOVE
description: A former United Steelworkers of America official who helped negotiate an end to a bitter strike against the financially troubled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation was seated today on the company's board.

title: METAL DATE PLAQUES
description: IF your house is a historic landmark or if you just want to display the date it was built, plaques and markers can be found at various foundries around the country. They can be mounted on doors, near the entrance or at the corner of the house, and they can be attached to any surface.

title: BELGIAN TAX FUGITIVE'S BID
description: A fugitive from a tax fraud investigation into Antwerp's diamond industry has offered to return to Belgium if two of his employees now in jail are released and he is assured a chance to defend himself, Belgian newspapers said today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Manila dispatch in some copies yesterday on Corazon C. Aquino's presidential duties gave a misleading account of the possible origin of explosive booby traps found in the presidential palace after the departure of Ferdinand E. Marcos. One theory holds that the devices may have been planted by guards of the fleeing President and were intended to harm his opponents. But Philippine military sources have speculated that they were an element in a plot against Mr. Marcos.

title: THEATER: ETHYL EICHELBERGER'S 'LEER'
description: AS a curtain-raiser to his ''Casanova,'' Ethyl Eichelberger does ''King Lear,'' in a demented solo version aptly entitled ''Leer.'' There is a funhouse grin plastered across the face of the old king. He is every inch a joker. The double-barreled bill, ''Leer'' and ''Casanova,'' is running at the Performing Garage.

title: Mexico Trims Its Oil Prices
description: Mexico cut its crude oil prices an average of 61 cents a barrel to an average $14.46 a barrel in the last two weeks of February, Pemex, the Government oil monopoly, said tonight.

title: Narrower Definition Of Negligence Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: IRISH PREMIER VOWS TO PRESS ON WITH ULSTER ACCORD
description: The Irish Prime Minister, Garret FitzGerald, vowed today to press ahead with the British-Irish agreement in Northern Ireland in spite of opposition from the unionist majority who paralyzed the province with a strike on Monday. The unionists say Dublin should have no say in their affairs.

title: LAWMAKER URGES SHUTTLE PANEL TO LOOK AT 1985 POSTPONEMENTS
description: The head of a Congressional subcommittee yesterday urged a close comparison of decisions involving the fatal launching of the space shuttle Challenger Jan. 28 with those in the postponement of another shuttle liftoff a year earlier.

title: A 10-Speed Solution To Tram Troubles
description: Footnote: A bicycle was instrumental in getting the Roosevelt Island tram back in service Monday.

title: Injury Sidelines Propp
description: Brian Propp, the Philadelphia Flyers' top scorer with 35 goals and 47 assists in 65 games, will be out two to three weeks because of an eye injury he suffered in Tuesday night's game against Buffalo. Lindy Ruff of Buffalo hit Propp with a stick, cutting the right eyelid, scrapping the cornea and breaking blood vessels, according to the team doctor, who said the left wing would remain hospitalized for two more days of treatment and observation.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOVIET CRAFT CONTINUES ON COURSE WITH COMET RENDEZVOUS TODAY
description: The Soviet Union's Vega 1 spacecraft continued on course today for its rendezvous with Halley's comet, but scientists said its second round of photographs lacked the clarity of earlier ones.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 6, 1986
description: International

title: MUSIC: BOWERY ENSEMBLE
description: THE Bowery Ensemble's unusually appealing new-music concert Tuesday night at Cooper Union began and ended with earth - Frederic Rzewski's ''To the Earth'' (1985) at the beginning; the first performance of the revised version of Pauline Oliveros's ''Earth Ears'' (1985) at the end. In between came some technically interesting but musically less rewarding excursions by Joel Chadabe into a realm of computer music, far from Mr. Rzewski's and Miss Oliveros's earthy delights.

title: MILITARY OBJECTS
description: The founder of the Communist Party of the Philippines and three other men said to be key Communist figures were freed today, despite objections from the military.

title: Ex-Reagan Aide Named As Editor of U.S. News
description: David R. Gergen, a former assistant to President Reagan and now senior managing editor of U.S. News & World Report, was named today as editor of the weekly newsmagazine.

title: EX-OFFICER TO GO TO JAIL IN A FATAL HIT-AND-RUN
description: A former New York City police officer was sentenced to four months in jail and 56 months' probation yesterday for his involvement in a fatal hit-and-run accident while on duty last year.

title: Goal Is at Issue in Key Affirmative-Action Case
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. Talks on Argentina
description: The International Monetary Fund has scheduled a meeting of its executive directors on Monday that could lead to nearly $1 billion in fresh loans to Argentina from both the I.M.F. and commercial banks, according to I.M.F. and Argentine officials.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $40,519 for the quarter from disposal of discontinued operations and a loss of $9,666 from disposal of discontinued operations for the 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $23,562 for the quarter and $57,102 for the 9 months. Sales figures represent sales from continuing operations.

title: CONTRA FORCES NOW VIEWED AS A MUCH-REDUCED THREAT
description: The main Nicaraguan rebel force is in its worst military condition since its formation in 1982, according to several Western diplomats and senior guerrilla officials.

title: Braves Trade Cerone
description: Rick Cerone, the former Yankee catcher who played last season for the Atlanta Braves, was traded yesterday to the Milwaukee Brewers along with two minor leaguers for Ted Simmons, the 36-year-old switch-hitter who plays both catcher and first base. The 31-year-old Cerone, who played five seasons for the Yankees before being traded after the 1984 season, hit .216 in Atlanta as he competed with Bruce Benedict for the regular position.

title: Celtics 108, Bulls 97
description: Larry Bird led Boston with 26 points as the Celtics stretched their winning streak to seven games. Chicago had gone ahead, 43-41, on Kyle Macy's jumper with 7:43 left in the second period, but the Bulls scored only one more field goal before intermission, as the Celtics went on a 19-6 spurt.

title: SUSPECT IN THRIFT CRISIS PLEADS GUILTY IN OHIO
description: Ronald R. Ewton, co-founder of the Florida securities firm whose collapse prompted a thrift crisis in Ohio last year, pleaded guilty today to state charges of financial wrongdoing involving business transactions with the Home State Savings Bank.

title: New Hearing Scheduled For 12 at Dartmouth
description: David T. McLaughlin, the president of Dartmouth College, said tonight that 12 students suspended by a disciplinary committee for destroying shanties built to protest college investments in South Africa would be given a new hearing.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PESTICIDES FINALLY TOP THE PROBLEM LIST AT E.P.A.
description: This year, nearly 25 years after Rachel Carson first warned of danger in her book ''Silent Spring,'' the Environmental Protection Agency has put pollution by pesticides at the top of its list of most urgent problems.

title: SIX IN GAMBINO TRIAL GUILTY OF ROLES IN A CAR THEFT RING
description: A Federal jury, in a partial verdict, convicted six of eight reputed mob figures yesterday of participating in an international car-theft ring and found two of the six guilty of murdering two men who had threatened to expose the operation.

title: Deferred Sentencing Strains New York City's Probation System
description: To the Editor:

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: WINNING TAPESTRIES WITH ARCHITECTURAL THEMES
description: LAURA FOSTER NICHOLSON, a Houston weaver, entered an international competition intended for architects and emerged with a top prize at the Venice Biennale. Five of her tapestries, depicting the 18th-century Villa Farsetti surrounded by fantasy gardens, are on display at the Hadler-Rodriguez Gallery.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
U.S. AND SOVIET OFFICIALS MEETING TODAY ON AFRICA
description: High-ranking Soviet and American experts on Africa will meet in Geneva on Thursday to discuss issues concerning southern Africa, the State Department said today.

title: MUSIC: A WOODWIND QUINTET
description: THE Quintet of the Americas gave an unhackneyed program of woodwind music Monday evening at the Center for Inter-American Relations on Park Avenue. The players are Sato Moughalian (flute), Matthew Sullivan (oboe), Joseph Stone (clarinet), Barbara Oldham (horn) and Edwin Alexander (bassoon). It was not clear in what sense the quintet is of ''the Americas,'' as opposed to North America, but if there were no Latin American names among the personnel, there were three on the program.

title: Missed Sign
description: Vince Coleman of the St. Louis Cardinals, who doesn't yet have Hernandez's kind of money to worry about, sent a round-about but clear signal that he was looking for a couple of hundred thousand in a new contract: ''I don't want anything with a '1' in it.''

title: JACQUES CHIRAC, ON THE STUMP, LIMBERS UP FOR '88
description: It was a typical day for the Mayor of Paris: a 17-hour, 2,000-mile tour of three cities, featuring airplane rides, fast car trips, several small meetings and three major speeches, all aimed ultimately at making him the most powerful man in France.

title: Bridge: Even With Much Revealed, A Slam Remained in Doubt
description: Uncertainty about slam prospects is common enough during the bidding. Much more rarely, there is uncertainty when both partnership hands are in view.

title: KEYCORP PURCHASE
description: Keycorp, based in Albany, will acquire the Seattle Trust and Savings Bank for $74 million, in the first purchase of a Washington state bank by a New York bank. Keycorp, a regional bank holding company, has assets of $7 billion and operates in 12 states, including Alaska and Oregon. Seattle Trust, with about 650 employees and $693 million in assets at the end of 1985, is based in Seattle and has 25 banking offices around Puget Sound.

title: PIRATES DEFEAT UCONN
description: Seton Hall escaped two seasons of tournament doldrums last night with a convincing 76-66 victory over Connecticut at Madison Square Garden in the qualifying game of the Big East Conference tournament.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BROAD TALKS ON MEXICAN DEBT
description: Mexico is pursuing a two-pronged approach in debt discussions under way with its creditors and Washington, bankers and financial community sources said today.

title: HOMR IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH most resilient flooring materials require little maintenance - regular cleaning and occasional waxing keep them looking fresh for many years - sometimes repairs are necessary. Fortunately, most are simple.

title: TWO AUSTRALIAN ORCHESTRAS PRESENTED ON A&E
description: WHILE it might have been more interesting to hear the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra and the Sydney Symphony play some unknown music from their native land, tonight's presentation of these two leading Australian orchestras in works by Tchaikovsky and Prokofiev (Arts & Entertainment Network, 9:30 P.M.) is worth watching.

title: SARA ROBY
description: Sara Roby, who established a foundation to encourage figurative artists when Abstract Expressionism was at peak popularity, died of kidney failure Sunday at Nantucket (Mass.) Cottage Hospital.

title: EASTERN RECALLING FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it would recall 735 of the more than 1,000 flight attendants that it had laid off and would hire additional attendants to support an expansion in service.

title: MOVING AND RESTORATION OF POOL TABLES
description: CERTAIN large and heavy pieces of furniture such as pool tables are a problem when it comes time to move them. Sometimes movers will subcontract to pool and billiard supply stores for the project, but often direct contact with the companies will prove less expensive. In Manhattan, the Blatt Bowling and Billiard Corporation at 809 Broadway (between 11th and 12th Streets) and V. Loria & Sons at 178 Bowery (near Delancey Street) are two supply companies that will restore and move tables for private customers.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Acquired Ted Simmons, catcher, from the Milwaukee Brewers for Rick Cerone, catcher, David Clay, minor-league pitcher, and Flavio Alfaro, minor-league shortstop.

title: GF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $2,071,000 for the quarter, $2,712,000 for the year and a loss from discontinued operations of $1,198,000 for the quarter, and a gain from discontinued operations of $1,405,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $899,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $802,000 from discontinued operations for the year.

title: 18-WEEK LEAVE FOR NEW PARENTS URGED IN CONGRESS
description: Men and women could get up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave and job guarantees when their children are born, under a bill introduced in the House on Tuesday.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $206,000.

title: BALLESTEROS BAN IS CRITICIZED
description: Ben Crenshaw, winner of the 1984 Masters, said today that the PGA Tour decision to bar Seve Ballesteros of Spain from playing all but one event on the United States tour this year ''is bad because it excludes one of the two best players in the world.''

title: GEORGIA IS SHAKEN BY JURORS' AWARD
description: Four weeks after a Federal jury awarded $2.5 million to Jan Kemp, a former instructor at the University of Georgia, the case continues to make waves in the state.

title: Orchestral Auditions For Waterloo Festival
description: The Waterloo Festival and School of Music in New Jersey will hold auditions for orchestral instrumentalists and pianists for this year's summer festival, the executive director, Shirley Greitzer, has announced. The auditions will be held at the Juilliard School, at Lincoln Center, on Monday and on March 17 and 24.

title: CONCERT: PIA SEBASTIANI, PIANIST
description: PIA SEBASTIANI'S piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night served as yet another reminder that the numbers of excellent performing artists are far greater than the public is aware of. An Argentinian who is currently on the faculty of the Ball State University School of Music in Muncie, Ind., Miss Sebastiani exhibited the technical assurance and artistic authority one associates with pianists much better known than she.

title: FIXED MORTGAGE RATES FALL TO AVERAGE 11.34%
description: Interest rates on fixed-rate mortgages dropped slightly between early January and early February, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

title: STEEL UNION ENDS A 16-DAY WALKOUT
description: The United Steelworkers of America accepted a wage freeze and benefit increases Tuesday night to settle a 16-day strike against four of the largest can makers in the United States, then set out today to win a better contract with a strikebound Canadian company.

title: Tanglewood's Season Will Be 10 Weeks Long
description: The Boston Symphony's 1986 season at its Tanglewood summer home in the Berkshires will open on June 27 and continue until Aug. 31, marking the second consecutive summer with a 10-week season, the symphony has announced. In addition to the orchestra's weekend concerts, there will be a full schedule of chamber music, vocal recitals, prelude concerts, open rehearsals and special events, in the main shed and in the smaller theater-concert hall across the lawn.

title: HORATIO ALGER NOVEL FOR ADULTS TO BE ISSUED
description: An adult novel by Horatio Alger Jr., a sharp departure from his rags-to-riches stories that enthralled and inspired generations of young readers, will be published for the first time this summer, more than a century after Alger wrote it.

title: Sallie Mae Uses Australian Dollars
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced a 200 million Australian dollar issue of zero coupon notes due in 1996 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $122,000 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-After a gain from the sale of assets of $570,000 and a tax credit of $342,000. d-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $177,000.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings result have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 share split of common stock in June 1985.

title: NURSING COSTS FORCE ELDERLY TO SUE SPOUSES
description: After 51 years of marriage, Morris and Bertha Hafner could not believe that their modest lives together would ever come to this: that she would be forced to sue him for support while he lay helpless in a Bronx nursing home.

title: Hawks 122, 76ers 114
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 37 points, including 7 in overtime, to lead the Hawks. The Hawks, who have won seven of their last eight games, and the Los Angeles Lakers, are the only teams to remain undefeated against Philadelphia this season.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $73. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $16,105 and including a gain of $5,865 on the disposal of discontinued operations. Revenue represent interest and other income.

title: A Caring Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Let Senate Confirm Commanders
description: To the Editor:

title: 52-1 Shot Wins in Florida
description: Patricia J. K., beaten as the 9-to-10 favorite in an Aqueduct stakes race last month, redeemed herself at odds of 52-1 today with a major upset victory over Noranc, Family Style and I'm Sweets in the $180,850 Bonnie Miss Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: A PASSION FOR GLASS
description: THE new shop is not, according to its owner, Marc Hurwitz, left, ''a gift shop.'' Instead of a wide range of items, the store sells silver, flatware and, especially, the former attorney's passion - glass.

title: CABLE TV PANEL TO STUDY MISSPENDING ALLEGATIONS
description: The State Commission on Cable Television voted yesterday to hold public hearings on allegations that corporations set up to provide community programming in New York City had misspent hundreds of thousands of dollars provided by cable operators.

title: HANZLIK A GEM FOR NUGGETS
description: Bill Hanzlik lived in a world of anonymity during his first five seasons. While the fans, first in Seattle and now in Denver, cheered the players who scored the points, the lean, 6-foot-7-inch Hanzlik was the forgotten man when he set the pick that made the basket possible or shut down the opponent's top scorer.

title: CITY AIDE REGULATES FLOW OF RECORDS TO PRESECUTORS
description: With subpoenas flying around these days like paper airplanes, Laurence A. Levy has taken on the job of air controller.

title: U.S. SETS STRATEGY ON MARCOS'S CASH
description: The United States is preparing to turn over to a Federal court the issue of what to do with the possessions brought to Hawaii last week by Ferdinand E. Marcos and his associates, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Political Warlords Come Under Siege
description: State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican of Staten Island, is doing battle with warlords in the guise of county chairmen.

title: MANILA WINS ROUND WITH MARCOS IN NEW YORK COURT
description: A New York State Supreme Court Judge yesterday gave the new Philippine Government permission to seek depositions from Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, concerning the properties they are said to hold in the United States.

title: BABY-BOOMERS: REALITY VS. DREAM
description: Baby-boomers are in an economic squeeze. As they marry and begin families, many are encountering financial hardships their parents never faced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 6, 1986
description: Markets

title: MARCOS REPORTEDLY EXPECTED CASH TO BE FLOWN TO HIS PHILIPPINE ESTATE
description: When Ferdinand E. Marcos ordered crates of Philippine currency assembled with his baggage and other possessions last week, he thought they would be flown to his estate in the northern Philippines, not to the United States, he has told Senator Paul Laxalt.

title: 11 Killed and 6 Missing In Norwegian Avalanche
description: An avalanche struck 31 members of a Norwegian Army ski patrol on NATO maneuvers in northern Norway today, and at least 11 were killed, military officials said.

title: Indiana Wins in a Rout
description: Steve Alford, a junior guard, scored 31 points and the freshman Ricky Calloway added 19 tonight to lead Indiana over Michigan State, 97-79, and give the Hoosiers sole possession of first place in the Big Ten race.

title: Acquisition For Clabir
description: The Clabir Corporation, a holding company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said that it had agreed to acquire the 77 percent of the General Defense Corporation that it does not own for a package of securities valued at about $18 a share, or about $117 million. Under the agreement, General Defense shareholders would receive 0.72 of a share of a new series of Clabir preferred stock for each share they own.

title: LOS ANGELES BACKS REMAPPING
description: The Los Angeles City Council voted today to reapportion its districts in the face of a Federal lawsuit that said a 1982 redistricting plan deprived Hispanic residents of fair representation.

title: 7 RECENT BOOKS YIELD IDEAS FOR SPRING PLANTING SEASON
description: AT this time of year with spring gardening plans under way, a number of recent, specialized books may prove useful. Take, for example, Peter Chan's ''Better Vegetable Gardens the Chinese Way'' (Garden Way Publishing, $9.95 soft cover).

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sue Mengers Leaving ICM
description: Sue Mengers, one of Hollywood's best-known agents, has resigned from International Creative Management, the resignation to be effective when her contract expires July 31. Miss Mengers, who was Barbra Streisand's agent for 12 years and whose client list currently includes Anne Bancroft, Michael Caine, Sidney Lumet and Nick Nolte, said Tuesday that she planned to move to New York and ''take time out'' after 20 years as an agent.

title: FAR-FLUNG UNITY OF FIRST INTERSTATE
description: As banking experts tell it, 60-year-old Joseph J. Pinola is providing a glimpse of what interstate banking might look like in the future.

title: HUMANITY AND IDEALS OF DALTON
description: His team had just won a national championship. Years from now, when Ralph Dalton reviews the mental scrapbook of his five years at Georgetown, there may be many other times that come to mind more quickly than that evening in Seattle in the spring of 1984. But the group effort Dalton has supported throughout those years will be forever measured by the night when there were no more brackets to reach and no more opponents to play, when even John Thompson, their coach, could put down his towel, stop his fussing, and enjoy what they all had achieved.

title: Security Puzzle
description: Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, speaking to the World Affairs Council on President Reagan's opposition to a mobile single warhead missile dubbed Midgetman, Feb. 12:

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $877,000 for the quarter and $2,690,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $616,000 and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $10,558,000. Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend in February 1986.

title: TAPAS, TABLEAUX: DINING IS DIFFERENT
description: CALL it unconventional, iconoclastic or in some cases bizarre, the downtown style in restaurants is a refreshing change of pace from the starched conventionality of the midtown expense-account temples.

title: FINGERPRINT TIES 'PIZZA' TRIAL DEFENDANT TO MONEY
description: A fingerprint was presented as evidence yesterday to link a key defendant to money laundering in the ''pizza connection'' drug trial in Manhattan.

title: V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Feb. 28, 1986.

title: MAN TRIED AS GUNMAN IS CLEARED
description: A New Jersey insurance broker, Robert O. Marshall, was convicted and sentenced to death today for plotting the murder of his wife.

title: MCCALL PATTERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Rangers Lose 3d Straight
description: Brian Mullen, Ray Neufeld and Dale Hawerchuk scored goals for Winnipeg in a span of 73 seconds during a five-minute power play in the first period tonight to lead the Jets past the Rangers, 4-1. John Ferguson, the team's general manager, was coaching his first game since replacing Barry Long Tuesday.

title: Deadly Shooter
description: Jeff Ruland of the Washington Bullets, answering a reporter who was asking Manute Bol for verification that he once killed a lion with a spear: ''No, with one of his foul shots.''

title: DOW UP BY 0.24
description: Stock prices were mostly lower yesterday on Wall Street, as investors, already worried about the economy, added interest rates to their list of concerns.

title: CML GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday on testimony to a House subcommittee by Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson incorrectly described the status of a proposal to create a Government-financed research organization on a defense against nuclear ballistic missiles. The proposal has not received formal approval from Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: HIGH COURT RULES THAT POLICE ARE LIABLE IN WRONGFUL ARREST
description: The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 2 today that police officers are liable to pay damages for clearly unreasonable arrests and searches even when they obtain judicial warrants beforehand.

title: All Is Not Well in Research on Human Subjects
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASE ASSETS IN JORDAN
description: The Bank of Jordan said today that it had bought the local assets of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Chase decided to leave Jordan rather than increase its capital, as the Government had ordered. Michel Marto, a Chase official, estimated the book value of the assets at $57 million.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Kornhauser & Calene has formed an affiliation with the Garrido Group of Miami, which will do Hispanic market advertising for K.& C. clients.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The bond market rally faltered yesterday, as prices of long-term Treasury issues fell as much as 3 points, before ending the day with losses of more than 2 points.

title: THE CITIZENRY RARELY SEES 'KANE' OR HIS ILK
description: From colonial days through much of the 19th century, this city was considered the creative center of American visual arts. Just as Boston and Harvard have been the guardians of the written word, Philadelphia and the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, the country's oldest art school, have been the soul of the visual arts.

title: FITCHBURG GAS & ELECTRIC LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $4,720,000 to record the partial writeoff of the company's investment in the Seabrook nuclear units. c-Net income.

title: A STOCK PICKER MOVES TO LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: Mario J. Gabelli has won a following as one of Wall Street's savviest stock pickers since he left Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in 1979 to form his own firm. But no one associated his name with leveraged buyouts.

title: What's Wrong With This?
description: Ink Mendolsohn, a writer for the Smithsonian Institution's News Service, asked herself that question a few weeks ago as she reviewed old studio still pictures of a new Warner Brothers leading man of 1937 named Ronald Reagan. He was younger of course, by almost half a century, but Mr. Reagan holds his years well.

title: Credit Card Promotion
description: At a glance, the item in Management magazine, the house organ of the Office of Personnel Management, looks like one of those credit card advertisements, the ones that say something like, ''If I didn't have this card, nobody would know my name.''

title: And Nothing But
description: Basketball is producing either too many players or too few nicknames.

title: NICARAGUA BUSINESSMEN EXPRESS FEAR OF ATTACKS BY THE SANDINISTAS
description: A group of leading Nicaraguan businessmen issued a strong denunciation of the Government today, saying they feared for their lives and liberty.

title: Utah Electric Project In $359 Million Issue
description: The National Cooperative Services Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell nearly $359 million of bonds as part of a sale and leaseback transaction involving a new electric generating plant leased by the Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative.

title: Books: Wars at Sea
description: THE GREATEST CRUSADE: Roosevelt, Churchill and the Naval Wars. By Richard Hough. Illustrated. 274 pages.

title: TECH-SYM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and $717,000 for the year. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $165,000 for the quarter and $453,000 for the year.

title: WALDHEIM SAYS HIS PAST WAS MISREPRESENTED
description: Kurt Waldheim, former Secretary General of the United Nations, said yesterday that his affiliation with a German Army command responsible for the deportation of Greek Jews in World War II was being misrepresented to disrupt his campaign as an independent candidate for the presidency of Austria.

title: Yankees Will Try Berra as a Catcher
description: The Berra family, one of baseball's best known, may have another Yankee catcher on the way.

title: The U.N. Today: March 6, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee Against Apartheid - 10:30 A.M.

title: Army to Provide Water To Schools Near Arsenal
description: The Army has announced that it will provide bottled water to more than 5,000 students at schools near its Rocky Mountain Arsenal after municipal wells were found to be contaminated with a dangerous chemical.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $110,000. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $969,000 from the sale of the company's instrument products division.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PROTOCOL COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN PACIFIC
description: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company is offering 1,000 clerical workers, including 300 in the San Francisco area, $20,000 each if they agree to quit.

title: STATE PROPOSES 7.5% PHONE RISE
description: The New York Telephone Company's rates would go up 7.5 percent over the next 18 months under a plan offered to the utility today by the State Public Service Commission. No other increases would be allowed during that period.

title: STUDY LINKS STATUS IN DRAFT TO RATE OF DEATH BY SUICIDE
description: A new study has found that men with low draft numbers in 1970 to 1972, and thus vulnerable to military service in Vietnam, have suffered significantly higher suicide and motor vehicle death rates than men with higher draft numbers.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BOISE CASCADE
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, the forest products company, said it was registering about 1.2 million of its outstanding shares owned by Sonat Inc. with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Mortgage-Agency Proposal
description: The Vice Chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Preston Martin, said tonight the Government's role in three housing finance agencies should be gradually eliminated.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WITNESSES TURN UP IN BENIGNO AQUINO ASSASSINATION
description: A new inquiry into the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the Filipino opposition leader, has turned up additional witnesses to the airport shooting in 1983, according to Mr. Aquino's brother, Agapito.

title: 25,000 AT FUNERAL IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: At least 25,000 people, including diplomats from the United States and six other Western countries, crammed a crude and dusty sports stadium in this bleak township today for the funeral of 17 people killed in four days of rioting here and elsewhere around the country last month.

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $317,000 for the quarter and $596,000 for the year. c-After a gain of $8 million for fresh start tax credit for the quarter and year and a capital loss of $97,000 for the quarter and capital gains of $384,000 for the year.

title: ARTEL COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FREEDOM OF GENDER IN DANCES FROM INDIA
description: One of the fascinations of Asian dance-drama for Western audiences is the freewheeling way in which it deals with gender. New Yorkers will have a chance to observe that element of the art in an unusual program presented by Asia Society at its Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium tonight, with two performances of Indian dance by Vedantam Satyanarayana Sharma and Padmashri Sanjukta Panigrahi.

title: KEY'S CHIEF NOTED FOR TURNING PROFIT
description: In his 33 years in the drug business, Michael Jaharis has earned a reputation as a savvy salesman quick to recognize an unsung marketing opportunity and turn a profit on it.

title: CBS UNIT TO CURTAIL PROMOTERS
description: CBS Records yesterday followed the lead of others in the record industry by saying it intended to ''curtail substantially'' its use of independent record promoters.

title: GENETICS CONCERN ON THE SPOT
description: Befitting its impoverished state, Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. occupies one floor of a threadbare building in a unglamorous part of Oakland. There are bullet holes in the windows of the lobby. The oasis, however, is the roof of the building, which covers two acres and houses six greenhouses, as well as wooden decks, picnic tables and a tennis court for employees.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,261,000 from a marketing cost reimbursement and a favorable contract dispute settlement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''American troops have not been asked for and are not needed.

title: LINDENAUER AND PROSECUTORS SAID TO BE NEGOTIATING DEAL
description: Prosecutors were negotiating a deal yesterday under which the only person so far charged in New York City's municipal corruption scandal would agree to testify against other city officials, senior law-enforcement officials said.

title: FRANCE TESTS LONGER-RANGE SUB MISSILE
description: The French Defense Ministry announced today that a submarine had successfully fired a multiple-warhead missile over a distance of 6,000 kilometers (3,720 miles).

title: CHICAGO RIVET & MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * BMW of North America Inc., Montvale, N.J., said it was raising the suggested retail price of its cars an average of 2.5 percent because of the declining value of the dollar.

title: BL Bidders Announced
description: The British Government today announced a list of bidders, including General Motors, for a large chunk of BL P.L.C., the nation's biggest auto maker.

title: THE DANCE: LIMON COMPANY IN 'HEART TO HEART'
description: THERE'S a certain type of music occasionally piped into elevators and waiting rooms that is almost insistent in its innocuousness. On Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, the Limon Dance Company offered the New York premiere of a dance that resembled such music.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column on Jan. 22 about an Arab investment group that bought control of the Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Holding Corporation, the parent of a New England brokerage house, incorrectly reported the status of the Al-Mal Group, an investment management firm based in London.

title: WHITE MOVES TO BLOCK OFFER
description: White Consolidated Industries moved yesterday to block a tender offer by Electrolux A.B. of Sweden.

title: DAY-GLO ESTHETICS: THE NEW DOWNTOWN STYLE
description: IRREVERENT, fun, awkward, colorful, charged with energy rrand purposely in dubious taste, a new style has emerged in downtown Manhattan, developed by young designers and artists over the last several years. A brash celebration of the moment, the look affects everything from interior design and furniture to clothes, hair, jewelry and even food. Apartment walls, for example, are painted in Day-Glo colors mixed with tartan patterns; at a dinner, shrimp and lobsters are arranged to look like antediluvian animals emerging from smoky dry ice.

title: FOREIGN MINISTRY COMING ALIVE WITH LAUREL
description: Accompanied by a bell-choir of telephones this morning, the press room clerks at the Philippine Foreign Ministry were putting up a map of the world - a sure sign, someone suggested, that this somnolent department was going to be a different place under Salvador H. Laurel.

title: REAGAN STEPS UP HIS DRIVE TO GIVE $100 MILLION TO NICARAGUA REBELS
description: President Reagan appealed again to Congress today to endorse his request for $100 million in aid to Nicaraguan rebels, saying it was needed so that the United States would not have to send American troops there.

title: DIAGNOSTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: REPUBLIC HEALTH
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the large aerospace and information systems concern, said it had joined a group that last month proposed a $288 million leveraged buyout of the Republic Health Corporation. McDonnell Douglas, with 13 percent, and LeRoy A. Pesch, a Republic director who heads the buyout group, are the largest stockholders in Republic Health, one of the nation's largest health-care services companies. It currently operates 84 facilities in 24 states.

title: Debasing the Language
description: George Orwell taught us that politicians corrupt words in order to sell corrupt policies. If Orwell were here now, how savagely he would be dissecting the latest example of Newspeak: the Reagan Administration's sales campaign for aid to the Nicaraguan ''contras.''

title: Tourism Down, Egypt Says
description: Egypt's revenue from tourism has dropped 40 percent since the riots last week by police conscripts, the Minister of Tourism said today. The minister, Fouad Abdel Latif Sultan, said, ''If the present drop continues at the current rate, it could be a kind of crisis for tourism in Egypt.'' Mr. Sultan said only 8,000 tourists had arrived since February 26, compared with 18,000 in the corresponding period last year.

title: MISTRIAL MOTION DENIED IN TERRORIST BOMBING CASE
description: A juror's request to be allowed to attend a Naval Reserve association meeting led to a motion yesterday for a mistrial in the case of six accused terrorist bombers.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MAXXAM GROUP OFFER ALAMITO
description: The Alamito Company, an electricity wholesaler based in Tucson, Ariz., said it had received a merger proposal from the Maxxam Group Inc. and Bear, Stearns & Company offering $135 cash per common share.

title: E.E.C. SEEKING U.S. TALKS
description: The European Economic Community's executive commission invited the United States today to defuse a trade dispute over the accession of Spain and Portugal to the community through negotiations in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade body.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Letters Depict Grim Deaths Of Dead Couple and Children
description: Letters apparently written by a couple who died in a fire with three children describe how they drugged and shot the children, set their home ablaze and then killed themselves in frustration over the treatment of disabled veterans.

title: Nutmeats
description: In 1981, in the early days of the first Reagan Administration, the Department of Agriculture proposed that catsup be classified as a vegetable for school lunch purposes. Now the department is proposing that nuts are meat.

title: MONCRIEF SITS OUT BUT NETS STILL LOSE
description: Sidney Moncrief spent the evening on the bench, and that alone should have given the Nets a rather secure feeling tonight. But their lingering troubles - a disjointed offense, a lackadaisical defense -ruined them again. They dropped their second game in a row, this time by a 119-106 score to the Milwaukee Bucks, and their record dropped to 32-32.

title: DOTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: STAFFING OF S.E.C. IS DEBATED
description: John S. R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, reacted angrily today to criticism that the S.E.C. is understaffed. ''The F.B.I. can't put an agent on every street corner,'' he said, ''and neither can the S.E.C.''

title: ORDERS TO FACTORIES RISE 0.4%
description: Factory orders climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in January as a surge in military orders offset weakness in many other areas, the Commerce Department said today.

title: EASTERN PILOTS SAID TO BE SEEKING ANOTHER BUYER
description: Eastern Airlines' pilots are casting about for a carrier other than Texas Air to buy their troubled company, and in recent days their representatives have negotiated with Pan Am and Braniff, various sources close to the situation said yesterday.

title: REGAN CALLS FOR BIGGER STATE TAX CUT
description: New York State should cut taxes in the next fiscal year even further than Governor Cuomo has proposed, the State Comptroller declared today.

title: N.B.A. Thievery
description: With eight steals Tuesday night against Washington, Chris McNealy of the Knicks eclipsed by one a team record shared by Henry Bibby, Walt Frazier, Butch Beard, Micheal Ray Richardson and Ray Williams, but fell three short of the N.B.A. mark. These are the 10 best single-game theft performances in league history: Larry Kenon, Spurs, vs.

title: SUDDEN OUTBREAK OF DRIPS MOISTENS COMMUTERS AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: Rail commuters at Grand Central Terminal are putting their trench coats to double duty - braving indoor rain.

title: Jartran Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
description: Jartran Inc., a nationwide truck and trailer rental company hurt by intense competition and heavy losses, said today that it had filed for reorganization and protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: SHAMROCK HAS 7.4% OF FOOTE
description: Shamrock Holdings, a company controlled by the Disney family, has bought 280,900 shares of Foote, Cone & Belding, raising its stake to 7.4 percent of the Chicago-based advertising agency.

title: TOOL IMPORTS WORRY U.S.
description: The United States may ask Japan to voluntarily restrict its sales of machine tools in this country or face import restraints on national security grounds, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Bonds Fall Daily Limit; Heating Oil Advances
description: Treasury bond futures fell by the daily limit in trading on the Chicago Board of Trade today on a wave of profit taking.

title: BIOSPHERIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTEL RAISES PRICES OF MEMORY CHIPS
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it had raised the prices of its erasable programmable read-only memory chips, known as Eproms, by 25 percent over November 1985 levels, confirming that a long-term slide has been reversed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Manila dispatch Feb. 24 about Lieut. Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, the new Philippines Chief of Staff, described him as a nonsmoker. A photograph on the front page of the same issue showed him holding a lighted cigar. The general has explained that he stopped smoking several years ago, but resumed in mid-February, when he helped lead the rebellion that drove Ferdinand E. Marcos from power.

title: AOI COAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pursuing the Marcos Loot
description: The size and audacity of Ferdinand Marcos's lootings are staggering, but so are the legal problems of restoring them to the Philippines. The Aquino Government, still counting, believes that Marcos & Co. have taken as much as $10 billion out of the country. That disgusting planeload of crated pesos, jewelry and artworks that followed the Marcoses to Hawaii may turn out to be nothing more than trinkets beside the billions they have already stashed around the world.

title: Tire Explodes Killing 2 at Air Base Upstate
description: Two airmen at Griffiss Air Force base in Rome, N.Y., were killed yesterday when an aircraft tire exploded in a maintenance hangar, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Juventus Beaten By Barcelona, 1-0
description: A late goal by Julio Alberto gave Barcelona a 1-0 victory today over Juventus, the defending champion, in the long-awaited meeting of two of Europe's soccer giants in a Champions' Cup quarterfinal match.

title: MAD HATTERS, ARTWEAR ALICES
description: FIVE steep steps lead down to Patricia Field, the Eighth Street shop that is a mecca for downtown fashion. In an hour there last Saturday, mad hatters, motorcycle boys, an all-in-black pack, Renaissance friars, English eccentrics, an Edie Sedgwick, a George Jetson, a stylized Rastafarian, skateboarders and a girl in graffiti ''artwear'' browsed and bought in the 14-year-old store.

title: Outgunned
description: A candid Joe Harrington, coach of George Mason's basketball team, after falling to Navy in a conference title game: ''I don't think we could have beaten them if we had the Army, the Air Force and the Marines.''

title: ALBERT L. LEHNINGER, LEADING BIOCHEMIST, AT JOHNS HOPKINS
description: Dr. Albert Lester Lehninger, University Professor of Medical Science at Johns Hopkins University, died Tuesday of a respiratory ailment at John Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 69 years old and lived in Sparks, Md.

title: PRODUCTION COST DISPUTE PERILS HOUR TV DRAMAS
description: The television networks and the Hollywood studios that produce network shows, long at odds over program costs, have come to what some in the industry call a crisis that could change the look of prime time.

title: STUDY INDICATES MODERATE EXERCISE CAN ADD YEARS TO A PERSON'S LIFE
description: A continuing study of nearly 17,000 Harvard alumni has demonstrated that moderate physical exercise in adult life can significantly increase life expectancy.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have rapid-start fluorescent lights in our dining room. Although we recently installed new tubes, which light perfectly, they give off an incessant buzz when they are on. The circuit breaker is O.K. Can this nuisance be corrected? A.Yes, in most cases. First, take the tubes out and clean both the tubes themselves and the contact pins at each end. When you replace the tubes, press them in a little more firmly than usual and twist back and forth a few times to insure good contact.

title: BANKAMERICA ASSERTS IT'S NOT IN MERGER TALKS
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that it was ''not negotiating a merger'' with the First Interstate Bancorp or anyone else.

title: AGENCY UNDER A CLOUD AWAITS ITS NEW CHIEF
description: By most accounts, John A. Pendergrass, whose confirmation as head of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is expected, will have his work cut out for him.

title: Goal Is at Issue in Key Affirmative-Action Case
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCK-SPLITTING SURGE IS SEEN
description: THE bull market of recent months promises to produce a bumper crop of stock splits. These splits, almost invariably, are concentrated in issues whose share prices have escalated since 1985.

title: THE THURSDAY CONFERENCE
description: Rick Pitino admits he did not think much of the first goal he encountered in his players when he became the head coach at Providence College this season.

title: Retrial for Ex-Dolphin
description: Three years after Eugene (Mercury) Morris began serving a 20-year sentence for selling cocaine to an undercover agent, the Florida Supreme Court yesterday overturned his 1982 conviction and ordered a new trial for the former Miami Dolphin running back. The 5-1 court majority did not rule on Morris's contention that the police, working with a disgruntled gardener employed by Morris, had entrapped him into selling the cocaine, but it held that the trial judge had improperly excluded the testimony of a potential witness who swore that the gardener had admitted his role in an entrapment.

title: 3 Convicted in Palau Killing
description: Three men were found guilty today of murder and conspiracy and face life sentences in the assassination last year of the first elected president of Palau.

title: Ronnie Cuber Quartet
description: The baritone saxophonist Ronnie Cuber is leading a quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, below 23d Street (242-9066). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: CHRYSLER MOVE IN BRAZIL
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it plans to open a new supply office in Brazil to increase its imports of auto parts from low-wage countries.

title: WORK WEAR DEAL
description: The Work Wear Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by an investor group led by Paine Webber Inc. for $86.8 million, or $28 a share, in cash for its 3.1 million shares outstanding.

title: CARDINAL SEES POPE ON MANILA ROLE
description: Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, today defended the actions of the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines before Pope John Paul II, who the Cardinal said had expressed concern about excessive political involvement.

title: ST. JOHN'S AND SYRACUSE POST BIG EAST ROUTS
description: He began the season with an eye on becoming the consummate playmaker. Two-thirds through the schedule, he shifted and became a scorer. Now, as postseason play begins, Dwayne Washington is doing everything.

title: DIRECTOR INSURANCE DRYING UP
description: When the Armada Corporation lost its directors' and officers' insurance earlier this year, causing 8 of the 10 members of the board to resign, the Detroit-based manufacturer of alloys and exhaust systems set a special requirement for the replacement candidates: they could not be too rich.

title: MOVE BY DUVALIER TO RIVIERA IS SEEN
description: After nearly four weeks in a luxury hotel in the French Alps, Jean-Claude Duvalier was reported today to have won permission to move to a small village on the French Riviera.

title: STATE PROPOSES A REVISED CODE ON RENT IN CITY
description: The Cuomo administration today proposed a series of changes, the first in more than a decade, in the Rent Stabilization Code, which governs nearly a million apartments in New York City.

title: Eleonora Duse Series
description: The Italian actress and playwright Eleonora Duse, considered a rival of Sarah Bernhardt, is the subject of a daylong series of events tomorrow at the Y.W.C.A., Lexington Avenue and 53d Street.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ANTIQUES FOR BROWSING Browsers and collectors who have recovered from all the other antiques shows in the last few months and are beginning to sniff around again may perk up at Sanford Smith's Armory Antiques Show this weekend. Seventy-five exhibitors from all over the country as well as England, France, Sweden and the Netherlands will be on hand to display items that range from classical antiquities to Art Nouveau and Art Deco. There will be folk art and quilts, American Indian art, Chinese and Japanese works, American and English arts and crafts and more. The show is open from noon to 10 P.M. today and tomorrow and from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and 67th Street. Tomorrow, there will also be an all-day symposium from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. on American painting with an agenda that includes lectures on taxes and insurance, today's market and restoration and conservation, along with a round-table discussion by dealers who will answer questions from the audience. Admission to the show alone is $6. The $60 price tag for the symposium includes lunch and admission to the show. Information: 249-8575. TRUFFAUT'S 'ENGLISH GIRLS' Devotees of Francois Truffaut may be interested in re-evaluating his 1971 film ''Two English Girls,'' which opens today at Cinema Studio 2. Before his death in 1984, the director reassembled the film, restoring excised footage and completing his own vision of the work.

title: UNIVERSITY AVE. RENEWAL IS A BRONX SUCCESS STORY
description: Until 1973, the Bronx campus of New York University had been the center of a small, healthy academic community. Faculty and staff filled the private homes and solid five-story apartment buildings that lined University Avenue, and they shopped in the stores on Burnside Avenue and Fordham Road.

title: ELECTROLUX'S OFFER REJECTED BY WHITE
description: White Consolidated Industries, hoping for a higher bid, said yesterday that it had rejected a buyout offer of $45 a share, or $711 million, from A.B. Electrolux of Sweden. White, the nation's third-largest maker of major home appliances, said that in any sale of the company ''more than $45 a share should be obtainable for the stockholders.''

title: Topics; Uncommon Marketing High-Priced Play
description: A mail-order catalogue catering to upwardly mobile urbanites offers futuristic playground toys, including tricycle and wagon, said to offer aerobic, isometric and isokinetic benefits.

title: CITY WILL BATTLE SCOFFLAWS WITH 'BOOTS' AND MORE TOW TRUCKS
description: New York City will increase the number of vehicles it tows, institute wide use of the restraining device known as a boot, and target the ''heavy hitters'' among scofflaws under a new plan to collect parking fines, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Nixon's 'New Realism'
description: A guardedly optimistic Richard Nixon believes that a ''new realism'' in Soviet-American relations - sounding rather like the detente he termed outmoded - could bring about some relaxation of tensions between the superpowers.

title: Relying on Experts
description: Representative James H. Scheuer was one proud lawmaker last week when he discovered that four of the 40 finalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search were from his Queens-Bronx-Nassau district in New York.

title: Tribute to Armstrong
description: Arvell Shaw, the bass player and noted alumnus of the Louis Armstrong Orchestra, is among the musicians who will take part in an Armstrong tribute tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Merle Avenue Junior High School in Oceanside, L.I. Also appearing will be Doc Cheatham, Joe Dixon, Jack Wilson, Ray Mosca, Benny Powell and Norris Turney.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMISSION'S REPORT ON BOMBING
description: Following are excerpts from the findings, conclusions and recommendations in a report issued today by the Philadelphia Special Investigation Commission, which examined the police confrontation on May 13 with the group known as Move: xhSummary of Findings and Conclusions 1. By the early 1980's Move had evolved into an authoritarian, violence-threatening cult. 2. The residents of 6221 Osage Avenue were armed and dangerous, and used threats, abuse and intimidation to terrify their neighbors and to bring about confrontation. 3. Mayor Goode's policy toward Move was one of appeasement, nonconfrontation and avoidance. 4. The Managing Director and the city's department heads failed to take any effective action on their own and, in fact, ordered their subordinates to refrain from taking action. 5. The city administration discounted negotiation as a method of resolving the problem. Any attempted negotiations were haphazard and uncoordinated. 6. In the first several months of his administration, the Mayor was presented with compelling evidence that his policy of appeasement was doomed to fail. 7. In the summer of 1984, the Mayor was told that the legal basis existed at that time to act against certain Move members. Yet the Mayor held back. 8. From the fall of 1984 to the spring of 1985, the city's policy of appeasement conceded to the residents of 6221 Osage Avenue the continued right to exist above the law. 9. More than any other factor, intensified pressure from the residents of Osage Avenue forced the Mayor to devise a strategy for resolving the problem quickly. 10.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REPORTS RELEASE OF MORE THAN 300 DETAINEES
description: South Africa has released almost all of those remaining in detention since the imposition of a state of emergency last July, the police said today.

title: Liberia Ends Curbs
description: President Samuel K. Doe has lifted a ban on activities by journalists, teachers and students that was imposed after an attempted coup in November. A statement Wednesday said Liberia's press, students' and teachers' unions and the provisional student leadership council of the University of Liberia here could resume activities.

title: Senators Vote to Ban Armor-Piercing Bullets
description: The Senate today gave overwhelming approval to a bill banning the import, manufacture and sale of armor-piercing bullets, which tests have shown can easily penetrate the bullet-proof vests worn by many police officers.

title: U.S. Aid Is Misguided
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz are asking Congress to believe the only way to establish our kind of democracy inside Nicaragua is to support the contras on the outside. Their argument makes neither moral, political nor historical sense.

title: Trumpeter at West End
description: The trumpeter Joe Newman will lead a swing quintet featuring Ted Dunbar on guitar tonight through Sunday at the West End Cafe, 2911 Broadway, at 114th Street (666-8750). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 and 1:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, and at 9 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight on Sunday. There is a $6 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: ACTED IN 'SOLDIER'S STORY'
description: Adolph Caesar, the gravel-voiced actor who starred in the stage and film versions of ''A Soldier's Story'' and in the recent motion picture ''The Color Purple,'' died of a heart attack yesterday in Los Angeles. He was 52 years old and a resident of New York City.

title: WILLIAM H. MARRIOTT
description: William H. Marriott, 77 years old, who published a number of Sunday newspaper supplements, died Wednesday of lung cancer. Mr. Marriott founded the supplement Family Weekly in 1953 and sold it four years later when it was distributed in 113 newspapers. Mr. Marriott was most recently involved in the publication of several regional newspaper supplements in California. Survivors include his wife, Phyllis; four sons, William Jr., Patrick, Phillip and David, and a daughter, Toni Garland.

title: TEXANS OF THE WORLD HONOR ALAMO HEROES
description: They remembered the Alamo today.

title: PIONEER ACCEPTS MESA'S BID
description: The Pioneer Corporation, a diversified energy company with sizable natural gas reserves but several struggling operations, said today that it had approved a merger offer from Mesa Limited Partnership, an energy concern headed by T. Boone Pickens.

title: 12 People Questioned In the Slaying of Palme
description: Police hunting the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme detained a dozen people for questioning today, but released them, saying false leads were expected from the publication of a composite drawing of the suspected assassin.

title: ARMED SERVICES PLAN DISCHARGES TO MEET BUDGET
description: Under new budget constraints, the armed forces plan soon to discharge about 35,000 enlisted men and women 30 to 60 days early, spokesmen for the four services said today.

title: Rebuttal Scripts
description: In an effort to persuade the Russians to stop jamming foreign language broadcasts by the Voice of America, Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, is putting together some old scripts to send to Moscow. He hopes thereby to show his Soviet counterpart that the news in foreign languages beamed there is not really any different from the English version, which meets no Russian interference.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Governor Cuomo's opposition to adding judges in some courts incorrectly described bills before the State Legislature. The bills deal with a plan to unify all courts in the state, not with whether to finance new judgeships.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AMERICA IN EUROPE: A History of the New World in Reverse. By German Arciniegas. Translated from the Spanish by Gabriela Arciniegas and R. Victoria Arana. 298 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95. FROM the moment Europeans discovered America, it began to modify their lives, their politics, their economies, their ideas. Even more importantly, perhaps, by confirming their hopes, it raised fresh ones. It was a dream come true - not exactly in the way that had been anticipated, but palpably enough to hold out the possibility that many other dreams might come true as well.

title: Funds for Philharmonic
description: A live radio broadcast of a concert by the New York Philharmonic today at 2 P.M. will highlight the opening of a three-day fund-raising event for the orchestra that will run through midnight Sunday at Lincoln Center.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''THIS is the pulpit you've been waiting for,'' the Very Rev.

title: LEBANON HOSTAGES STIR PARIS DEBATE
description: Ten days before crucial parliamentary elections, a controversy has erupted in France over the Government's efforts to free four French hostages held in Lebanon.

title: SHAPER OF MODERN ART IN U.S.
description: Georgia O'Keeffe, the undisputed doyenne of American painting and a leader, with her husband, Alfred Stieglitz, of a crucial phase in the development and dissemination of American modernism, died yesterday at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 98 years old, and had lived in Santa Fe since 1984, when she moved from her longtime home and studio in Abiquiu, N.M.

title: DEMANDS GROW FOR NEW INQUIRY ON AQUINO SLAYING
description: Demands increased today for a new and deeper inquiry into the 1983 assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader whose death began the chain of events that drove Ferdinand E. Marcos into exile last week.

title: EWING INJURED IN LOSS
description: Because qualifying for the playoffs has become all but a mathematical impossibility for the Knicks, most of their remaining 20 games will be little more than opportunities for the players to maintain their conditioning and perhaps refine their skills.

title: U.S. Tax Amnesty Could Raise $7 Billion in '87
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST GERMAN OUTPUT
description: Industrial production in West Germany rose about 2.5 percent in January from December, despite a lull in the construction sector, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Berkeley Federal Savings and Loan Association, Millburn, N.J., has appointed its president, Anthony C. Majeski, to the additional position of chief executive officer.

title: Rollins at Bottom Line
description: The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins and his band will perform tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30; tickets are $10.

title: FILM: 'WHATEVER IT TAKES'
description: ''WHATEVER IT TAKES,'' which opens today at the Eastside Cinema, apparently means to be a conventional movie - a comedy-drama about the tragedies and triumphs, private and professional, of a struggling New York cartoonist.

title: FOR DOBRYNIN AND WASHINGTON, 'END OF AN ERA'
description: The State Department broke with tradition when it came to addressing the announcement that Anatoly F. Dobrynin, after 24 years as the Soviet ambassador in Washington, would be returning to Moscow. And that was as good a measure as any of the mark Mr. Dobrynin has made on this city.

title: SPANISH GOVERNMENT'S FUTURE COULD HINGE ON VOTE ON NATO
description: The future of Spain's Socialist Government has become suddenly uncertain amid indications that its position may be rejected when Spaniards vote next week in a referendum on membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:19 A.M. today and set at 2:08 P.M.

title: Art Appreciation
description: Coach Frank Layden, after watching the Los Angeles Lakers destroy his Utah Jazz, 130-84: ''It was like a Rembrandt versus a Schultz cartoon.''

title: Keep Moving
description: A person who burns 2,000 or more calories a week in moderate exercise will probably live longer than one who doesn't. That's the conclusion of a study of 17,000 Harvard alumni just published in the New England Journal of Medicine, and it's going to make a lot of joggers very happy.

title: TURNER, MGM/UA DEBT RATINGS CUT
description: Ratings were reduced yesterday for $1.9 billion of bonds of Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. and the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, Moody's announced.

title: PANEL DID NOT SEE FINAL REPORT URGING DRUG TESTS
description: The vice chairman of the President's Commission on Organized Crime acknowledged today that none of the commission's members had seen the final version of the panel's report on drug enforcement before it was made public.

title: Edward Sadowsky for Queens President
description: The turmoil that led to the resignation of Queens Borough President Donald Manes has one fortunate consequence. Edward Sadowsky, a longtime lion of the New York City Council who recently left politics, can now become temporary Borough President. By choosing him next Tuesday, the Queens members of the Council can bring a breadth of vision to the office, and a breath of life to Queens politics.

title: JUDGE VOIDS NEW YORK LAW ON OUT-OF-STATE LAND SALES
description: A Federal judge in Syracuse has declared unconstitutional a state law requiring sellers of out-of-state land to register their offerings with the state and submit their advertisements for state review.

title: 2 HOUSE UNITS BAR CONTRA AID PLAN AND ONE BACKS IT
description: Two House committees voted today to disapprove President Reagan's request for $100 million for the Nicaraguan rebels, while a third backed the plan.

title: DOCTOR'S ROLE IN COSMETICS ADS CRITICIZED
description: Several well-known dermatologists strongly object to a series of advertisements in which Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the South African surgeon who conducted the first successful human heart transplant in 1967, promotes a face cream, saying it ''can make older skin behave and look like younger skin.''

title: LETTERS LINK DEATHS OF 5 TO TREATMENT OF VETERANS
description: A man and a woman appear to have taken their lives and the lives of her three children to publicize the couple's belief that Vietnam veterans and their families are ill-treated.

title: BROADWAY
description: RIGHT from the beginning, Lucille Lortel believed in it. She discovered and co-produced it in London. Now she's giving some special support, which means money, to the Roundabout Theater Company, which is going to introduce ''Cheapside'' to New York.

title: No Insurance Claim If You Don't Belt Up
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,500 WELLS SHUT BY TEXACO
description: Texaco Inc. said it had closed 1,500 oil wells in California's huge Kern River field because plunging crude oil prices have made them unprofitable.

title: GULFSTREAM CLOSES WITH UPSET ON TURF
description: Powder Break, the only mare in a field of 11 older horses, shot through the inside in the closing yards today to beat the boys by two lengths in the $300,000 Pan American Handicap on closing day at Gulfstream Park.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE calendar proclaims that spring is only two weeks away, but are you really in the mood for a cold asparagus salad and gazpacho? Of course not. The cold facts are that winter has no intention of packing up for at least a month, and a serious snowfall is quite possible before it's all over.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1986
description: International Japan will lower its basic interest rate, to 4 percent, effective Monday, senior Bank of Japan officials said. The announcement followed by a day West Germany's cut in its main lending rate, to 3.5 percent. France and the Netherlands quickly followed. This series of cuts inspired conjecture that the Federal Reserve might soon lower its discount rate, now at 7.5 percent. [ Page D1. ] Boeing and three Japanese companies will jointly develop and produce a medium-sized commercial jet using advanced technology. The agreement by Boeing, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasawki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries culminated two years of talks on the 7J7 plane. [ D1. ] Companies Pioneer, the energy company, agreed to merge into Mesa Limited Partnership, headed by T. Boone Pickens. The merger was valued at between $763 million and $830 million, in new Mesa securities. Analysts said the purchase was consistent with Mr. Pickens's strategy of acquiring proven energy reserves, rather than exploring for new reserves. They added that the deal would increase Mesa's natural gas reserves by more than two-thirds. [ D1. ] White Consolidated, hoping for a higher bid, rejected a buyout offer of $45 a share, or $711 million, from Electrolux of Sweden. White, a maker of home appliances, said that in any sale, ''more than $45 a share should be obtainable for the stockholders.'' [ D4. ] The Economy Soaring stock prices are enriching millions of Americans, at least on paper. The value of all publicly traded stocks has jumped by more than $450 billion since September, giving added zip to the economy, as many investors have begun to spend more freely.

title: GROUP OF DEVELOPERS OFFERS NEW HOUSING IF RULES ARE ALTERED
description: In an effort to ease the city's housing shortage, a group of the city's leading developers has told Mayor Koch that they would build 3,000 units of middle-income housing at no profit, but only if the city agrees to changes in building regulations and requirements.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES FALL A BIT
description: Short-term interest rates fell about a tenth of percentage point yesterday, amid widespread hope that the Federal Reserve would soon lower the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions.

title: Seoul Indicts 51 Students In Protest for Direct Vote
description: Fifty-one students who demonstrated for direct presidential elections last month were indicted today on charges of violating laws banning unauthorized rallies, the prosecutor's office announced.

title: GROUP RECOMMENDS MORE JUDGES AND POLICE TO FIGHT CRIME IN CITY
description: Citing what it called a rising trend of serious crime in New York City, an oversight group called yesterday for more police officers and judges, a merger of the transit and city police forces and a crackdown on low-level drug dealing and other ''quality of life'' crimes.

title: GETTING READY FOR A RATE CUT
description: IN cutting its discount rate to 3.5 percent from 4 percent, West Germany's Bundesbank has yielded to pressure, particularly from the American Government, to clear the way for a cut in the Federal Reserve's discount rate and lower interest rates generally. Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said the cut in the German discount rate might signal lower interest rates in other countries.

title: Ex-New Yorker Wins Houston Hot-Dog Fight
description: A transplanted New Yorker has won a three-year battle against the city bureaucracy to sell hot dogs from pushcarts at selected city parks.

title: ZINMAN AND THE BALTIMORE TO PLAY ROMANTIC WORKS
description: ''Lately it's become fashionable to speak of a return to tonality,'' David Zinman, the music director of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, said recently. ''But Dominick Argento has always remained a tonal composer, no matter what his colleagues were doing at the moment. I've never really cared whether somebody writes tonal music or atonal music; what concerns me is whether it is good music - music that has something to say and says it in a distinctive manner.''

title: Carlevaro, Guitarist
