description: The guitarist Abel Carlevaro will play a program of works by Villa-Lobos, Sor, Torroba and Albeniz at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Tickets are $7.50 to $10; information: 831-8603.

title: TEWKSBURY BACK FOR SECOND CHANCE
description: The day lives vividly in his mind; it was the kind of day that doesn't happen often for a teen-ager from a tiny New Hampshire town of 600.

title: Tyner at Fat Tuesday's
description: The pianist McCoy Tyner, the bassist Avery Sharpe and the drummer Louis Hayers are a trio tonight through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (212-533-7902). Sets begin at 8, 10 and midnight tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; there is a $12.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: F. Francis D'Addario Dies, 63; Industrialist in Connecticut
description: F. Francis D'Addario, a Connecticut business executive with interests in real estate, hotels, broadcasting and legal gambling, and four others were killed Wednesday when a twin-engine turbo prop plane in which they were traveling crashed in Eola, Ill., according to a company official. He was 63 years old and lived in Trumbull, Conn.

title: The Campaign That's Killing the Contra-Aid Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: MEHTA LEADS BOULEZ 'RITUEL'
description: THE New York Philharmonic's two-week series of concerts celebrating the return of Pierre Boulez (''Boulez Is Back!'') entered its second stage last night with a program that featured his ''Rituel,'' a 1975 work dedicated to his late colleague Bruno Maderna. Mr. Boulez, who was the Philharmonic's music director from 1971 to 1978, was on hand in a side box to hear the performance conducted by his successor, Zubin Mehta, and to share in the mixture of applause and boos that rang out at the conclusion of the 26-minute piece.

title: BALLET: PEKING TOUPE'S 2D PROGRAM
description: After the young Chinese ballerina Tang Min and her youthful partner, Zhao Minhua, had performed the ''Don Quixote'' pas de deux on Wednesday night, an equally young member of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's staff who came onstage to bring them flowers couldn't resist shaking each dancer's hand.

title: Topics; Uncommon Marketing Taking Off in Botswana
description: American aid to developing countries ought to go for development, but the exception now being made for Botswana, a democratic black-ruled state on South Africa's border, is both proper and instructive.

title: Council Hears a Dissent On Foreign Affairs
description: The Philippine Islands were on the City Council's agenda yesterday, and Staten Island registered an objection.

title: Comet Calls Cont.
description: The Halley hot line, interrupted while the comet was passing around the Sun, is back in operation at the United States Naval Observatory. Effective at midday yesterday, anyone calling (900) 410-8766 got a recorded report on the comet's whereabouts, pointers on observation and other scientific Halley news in layman's language.

title: TREES FOR NEPAL AND FOR OREGON
description: According to an old political saying, favors that members of Congress do for their individual constituents grease the wheels of representative government.

title: A Smetana Premiere
description: The Opera Orchestra of New York, under the direction of Eve Queler, will present what is believed to be the first American performance of Smetana's ''Libuse'' at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, Lehman College, in the Bronx tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. The cast will include Gail Limansky, Frances Ginsberg, Mark Pedrotti and Rita Mazurowski. Tickets are $5 to $10. Information: 960-8833.

title: BILL TO SHUT WEAKENED BANKS SEEN
description: The Senate Banking Committee will vote out a bill this year with a provision giving Federal agencies the power to close weak banks and savings and loan associations before they fail, the committee's chief of staff predicted today.

title: Supreme Court Delays Execution in Florida
description: The United States Supreme Court late today postponed the execution scheduled for Friday of Aubrey Dennis Adams, convicted of killing a child in Florida.

title: The U.N. Today: March 7, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND

title: Air Traffic Safety Is Questioned
description: A Congressional investigation raised new concerns today about the nation's air traffic control system, concluding that there were too few experienced people for the job and recommending that the Government impose air traffic restrictions.

title: HOSPITAL SECTOR DOING BETTER
description: STOCKS of hospital management companies, a sector that has failed to participate in the bull market in recent months, are showing a bit of progress this week. Moving in the vanguard of this tentative advance is the Hospital Corporation of America, a one-time Wall Street favorite that has disappointed its followers since the final half of 1985.

title: A PETERSEN OFFICIAL'S BIG YEAR
description: PETER F. CLANCEY'S first year as senior vice president and national advertising director of Petersen Publishing has been fairly momentous.

title: STUDENTS SPURN MEAL PROGRAMS, GROUP ASSERTS
description: More than 500,000 New York City public school students are discouraged from participating in school meal programs because of obstacles such as limited access to lunchrooms and a lack of publicity about the programs, a nonprofit advocacy group for the poor said yesterday.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: PAT STEIR calls her paintings ''conceptual art,'' which may surprise anyone who has seen her best-known work, the key painting in her recent ''Bruegel Series (A Vanitas of Style).'' The painting, based on a still life by Bruegel, is quite contemporary in its size (20 feet high by 15 feet wide), but its image seems traditional: a blue vase of flowers with sprigs of leaves and small blossoms surrounding its base.

title: COMET MISSION: OMEN FOR COOPERATION IN SCIENCE
description: One of the most notable achievements of the Soviet Union's Vega spacecraft, apart from knowledge about Halley's comet, is the demonstration that Soviet and American scientists can set aside political differences and work together in space exploration.

title: COMMISSION'S MEMBERS
description: Following are biographical sketches of the commission members who investigated the bombing of the headquarters of the radical group Move:

title: POP/JAZZ
description: OUT OF THE BLUE, the jazz sextet that is performing through Sunday at Carlos 1, started out as an idea in search of musicians. When Bruce Lundvall, president of Manhattan Records, decided to revive the Blue Note jazz label, he recalled that the original company recorded up-and-coming musicians, building a pool of players who were familiar with one another's music.

title: HOUSING FAMILY IN A SHELTER COSTS CITY $70,000 A YEAR
description: The cost of housing a family of four in a barracks-like shelter in the Bronx as risen to nearly $6,000 a month, or $70,560 a year, city officials acknowledged yesterday.

title: THE SCREEN: 'NOMADS,' GANG OF ROOTLESS SPIRITS
description: ''NOMADS'' begins with Lesley-Anne Down, the best-looking doctor in Los Angeles, catching a severe case of hysteria from Pierce Brosnan, the best-looking anthropologist with a French accent, by gazing deeply into his bloodshot eyes. The nomads are rootless spirits who have found their way from Eskimo mythology to Southern California, where rootlessness is in, and from there into the psyche of the rootless anthropologist.

title: Meadowlands Racing Off
description: Harness racing was suspended indefinitely at the Meadowlands today after contract negotiations between management and standardbred owners broke down.

title: Lucy Shelton Recital
description: The soprano Lucy Shelton will present a free recital at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, Sunday at 2:30 P.M. The program will include music by Dowland, Purcell and Handel. Information: 662-2133.

title: A CORNER OF INDIA, WHERE A MINYAN IS HARD TO FIND
description: On Fridays at dusk a certain tranquillity settles on Jewtown Road. That is the actual name of a dusty, narrow street that bustles all day with cars, scooters and ox carts. The evening air is scented with pepper and ginger from local spice warehouses.

title: PULITZER PURCHASE OF COMPANY SEEN
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company has agreed to buy the South Town Economist, a company in Chicago that owns a daily paper of the same name as well as community papers that together reach about 440,000 readers, according to sources familiar with the negotiations.

title: TV STATIONS SOLD
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, and the Hearst Corporation said that they had completed the previously announced purchase of seven independent television stations from Metromedia Inc. for more than $2 billion.

title: STATE IS PAYING FEES TO FIRMS OF LEGISLATORS
description: The State Insurance Department awards hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees each year to the law firms of key state legislative leaders, including the Speaker of the Assembly, according to state records.

title: Eurobond Pioneer Back In Investment Banking
description: Michael von Clemm, the investment banker who resigned in January as chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd., the pioneering force in the Eurobond business, will join Merrill Lynch as chairman of the company's global investment banking organization, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Quartet at Vanguard
description: The alto saxophonist Arthur Blythe is leading his quartet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Writers' Passbooks
description: A cornerstone of apartheid in South Africa are the passbooks that blacks must carry or face imprisonment. Yesterday, a group of leading American writers symbolically tossed facsimile passbooks bearing their own pictures into a mailbag, to be sent on to the South African Government, to show their feeling about the repression.

title: Song, Dance and Resilience
description: When Mayor Koch danced and sang and had water sprinkled on him last weekend - his performance with members of the ''Singin' in the Rain'' cast after the Inner Circle lampoon show - he showed ''great grace under pressure,'' Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: AUCTIONS
description: OLD Master paintings are prominent this season: there are in-depth exhibitions such as the one devoted to the 18th-century French painter Francois Boucher at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and then there are shows like ''The Treasure Houses of Britain'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, which covers the immense diversity of the Old Master genre - everything from solemn portraits by Rubens and Rembrandt to the luminous landscapes of Canaletto.

title: Jury Investigates Role Of Officers in Suicide
description: A Manhattan grand jury is investigating whether two Port Authority policemen withheld evidence surrounding the suicide of a prisoner in their custody last year, the head of the authority police said last night.

title: CRAFT SWEEPS BY HALLEY'S COMET
description: An unmanned Soviet spacecraft plunged through the atmosphere of Halley's comet this morning and sent back the first pictures showing the icy core, formed as the Solar System was evolving 4.6 billion years ago.

title: DEVILS ROUT RED WINGS, 7-2
description: The Devils took advantage of a team weaker than themselves in every category tonight and equaled their widest margin of victory for the season as they trounced the Detroit Red Wings, the worst team in the National Hockey League, 7-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was New Jersey's fifth victory in its last seven (5-1-1) games at home.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in SportsMonday on the growth of the Big East Conference incorrectly reported the negotiations for the conference's television package. NBC did not bid on the package.

title: TOP COACHES RATE FORWARD AS OUTSTANDING SCHOOLBOY
description: Herman Reid Jr., better known as J. R. Reid, has made his decision, and that has taken some of the excitement out of next month's signing period for college basketball recruits.

title: WARNER-LAMBERT AGREES TO SELL UNIT
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its Deseret Medical division to Becton Dickinson & Company for $225 million.

title: Michigan Rolls in Big 10
description: Roy Tarpley scored 22 points, and Antoine Joubert had 17 tonight as Michigan routed Ohio State, 99-82, and joined Indiana at the top of Big Ten Conference.

title: FILM: 'DEATH OF AN ANGEL' FROM PETRU POPESCU
description: GRACE MACKENZIE (Bonnie Bedelia), a pretty, middle-class widow, is introduced as she's being ordained as an Episcopalian priest before an upscale Los Angeles congregation. Watching the ceremony with skepticism is Grace's teen-age daughter, Vera (Pamela Ludwig), who was paralyzed from the waist down in the same automobile accident that killed Grace's husband.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 9.50 9.50 10.50 DISCOUNT RATE * 7.50 7.50 8.00 FEDERAL FUNDS * 7.63 7.77 8.47 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.69 6.76 8.72 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 6.68 6.76 9.07 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 7.88 7.91 11.92 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 8.20 8.21 11.90 TELEPHONE BONDS 9.42 9.45 12.88 MUNICIPAL BONDS * 8.07 8.05 10.39 * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Michele Bautier, Freddy's Supper Club, 308 East 49th Street (888-1633). The ''new kid on the block,'' as the 35-year-old jazz singer from Asbury Park, N.J., calls herself, has returned to Freddy's, where she made her acclaimed, sold-out New York debut last month interpreting the music of Duke Ellington and Harold Arlen. Miss Bautier, who could as easily sing rock and funk as jazz, has it all - a wailing dark alto that cuts to the marrow of a ballad like ''I've Got It Bad,'' an almost supersonic top register and a tigerish intense scat style. For this engagement, the singer is working with a new ensemble that includes Mike Abene on piano, Dick Sarpola on bass, and the drummer Joe Cocuzzo. The program is still Ellington and Arlen, but with additions like ''The Man That Got Away.'' Shows tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11, and there is a 3 P.M. Sunday brunch. Admission is $20 tonight and tomorrow, and $15 on Sunday. There is always a two-drink minimum.

title: BUSH, ISSUING TERROR REPORT, AFFIRMS CURRENT U.S. POLICIES
description: Vice President Bush said today that the Government's policy on combating terrorism would remain one in which there was a willingness to retaliate, but not to ''wantonly destroy human life.''

title: HIGH LEVEL CHANGES ANNOUNCED AT GTE
description: The GTE Corporation announced a series of top-level management changes yesterday, setting the stage for a three-man race to determine who will succeed Theodore F. Brophy as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Brophy reaches mandatory retirement age in April 1988.

title: FLIGHT ATTENDANTS ON STRIKE AGAINST T.W.A.
description: Flight attendants struck Trans World Airlines early today after negotiations broke down just after midnight. doors.

title: ROSENFELD, SIROWITZ DROPS SNAPPLE
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey reported yesterday that it had resigned the Snapple business that it got last month because the billings would not have been as much as management had thought.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1986
description: International Two House panels rebuffed President Reagan by voting to disapprove his request for $100 million to aid Nicaraguan rebels, while a third panel endorsed the proposal. The votes were held as legislators from both parties expressed anger at the Administration's lobbying tactics and accused the White House of ''red-baiting'' legislators who oppose its Nicaragua policy. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Family History
description: Hal McRae is a 39-year-old designated hitter, his son Brian is an 18-year-old infielder, they're both in the Kansas City Royals' spring camp at Fort Myers, Fla., and they're both apparently headed for the history books.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago White Sox, at Sarasota, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Tom Seaver will pitch for the White Sox, and Ron Darling and Ed Lynch will see some action for the Mets in this exhibition opener for New York. Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. When these teams met Tuesday in Pontiac, the Nets were routed. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Celtics, at Boston. The only game the Knicks have won against the Celtics was on Christmas Day. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Bulls vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Chicago. Bulls are still in the running for a playoff spot despite the loss of Michael Jordan. (Television - WTBS, 8:05 P.M.) Colleges: Big East semifinals, at Madison Square Garden (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M., and ESPN, 9 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, St. John's game, WNYE-FM 91.5, Syracuse vs. Georgetown.) Atlantic Coast Conference tournament, at Greensboro, N.C., quarterfinals: Duke vs. Wake Forest, noon; North Carolina State vs. Virginia, 2 P.M.; North Carolina vs. Maryland, 7 P.M., and Georgia Tech vs. Clemson, 9 P.M. (Television - ESPN, noon, 2 P.M. live; and midnight and 2 A.M. tape.) ECAC Metro Tournament, at Coraopolis, Pa., semifinals, 6 P.M. and 8 P.M. S.E.C. Tournament, at Lexington, Ky., semifinals. (Television - MSG Network, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M.) Women: M.A.A.C. Championships, at Holy Cross. Swimming Senior Metropolitan Championships, for men and women, at Columbia University's Dodge Center Pool, 119th Street and Broadway, 5 P.M. Admission is free all three days, with starting times at 5 P.M. each day.

title: 'Irving Berlin's America' On Channel 13 at 9 P.M.
description: The music of Irving Berlin is virtually synonymous with the American dream, at least as it was dreamed for nearly half a century, from just before World War I until the early 1960's. That is the premise of ''Irving Berlin's America,'' an adoring, patriotic salute to the songwriter, who will turn 98 in May. The show, on Channel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock, is the latest presentation in WNET's ''Great Performances'' series.

title: DEMOCRATIC UNIT BACKS RULES PLAN
description: The governing body of the Democratic National Committee today endorsed proposed changes in the party's Presidential nominating process despite a warning by the Rev. Jesse Jackson that some of the revisions would discriminate against voters who are members of minority groups.

title: JAPAN SAYS IT WILL JOIN IN RATE CUT
description: The Bank of Japan will lower its basic interest rate by half a point, to 4 percent, its governor said today.

title: FILIPINOS SAY MARCOS WAS GIVEN MILLIONS FOR '76 NUCLEAR CONTRACT
description: Former President Ferdinand E. Marcos received most of an $80 million payment 10 years ago for awarding a lucrative contract to build the first nuclear power plant in the Philippines, according to Filipino lawyers, bankers and Government officials.

title: Fire at Activists' Office
description: Offices of a campaign for the release of the jailed black leader Nelson Mandela were heavily damaged by fire today, and anti-Government activists blamed the South African security police.

title: SUGAR PLANTERS LOOK TO AQUINO, ONE OF THEIR OWN
description: Hacienda Luisita, about five miles north of here, is a big sugar estate, a self-contained home to more than 20,000 people on thousands of acres of fertile land. It could be one of any number of plantations functioning around its sugar mill, except that it is the family home of President Corazon C. Aquino. And it is slowly going broke.

title: RANGER COMEBACK TOPS FLAMES, 5-2
description: Pierre Larouche scored twice, including the 100th power-play goal of his National Hockey League career, as the Rangers came from two goals behind to defeat the Calgary Flames, 5-2, tonight.

title: BOEING, 3 JAPAN CONCERNS IN JET PACT
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had entered an agreement with three major Japanese aircraft manufacturers for the joint development and production of the 7J7, a medium-size commercial aircraft projected to enter service in 1992.

title: REAGAN GETS BILL WITH CHANGES IN FARM ACT
description: The House today sent President Reagan a package of changes in the Farm Act of 1985, including a measure calling for higher fees on dairy farmers to meet deficit-cutting targets set by Congress.

title: U.P.S. REBUFFED IN A BID TO VOID PARKING TICKETS
description: A lawsuit by United Parcel Service challenging some of the thousands of parking tickets it has received has been thrown out by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan. The city's Department of Transportation said the estimated $2 million in fines owed by the company must now be paid.

title: HOW WOMEN MAY TRANSMIT AIDS TO MEN IS SUGGESTED BY RESEARCH
description: New evidence of the AIDS virus in women could help explain how the disease can be spread among heterosexuals, scientists say. The evidence was obtained from studies of 21 women, all of whom had multiple sexual partners or sexual relations with either bisexual men or intravenous drug users.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY FAVOR BILL TO ALLOW CAMERAS IN COURTS
description: Legislative leaders have reached an agreement on a bill that would allow experimental coverage by televison and radio broadcasters of court trials in New York State.

title: JERSEY RIDERS COMPLAIN TO PATH'S TOP MAN
description: ''They took away the benches,'' a commuter, Donald A. Ellenberg, complained about the waiting room in the Journal Square Transportation Center.

title: 2 AIDES IN PHILADELPHIA CRITICIZED OVER DEATH OF 5 CHILDREN IN CLASH
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode was not to blame for the decision that led directly to the death of five children last May in the confrontation with the radical group Move, the chairman of a special inquiry said today. But he said the Mayor had been negligent and irresponsible throughout the crisis.

title: Topics; Uncommon Marketing Mao's Ghost
description: It's no secret that many Western political leaders are not the real authors of their books, speeches and campaign slogans. Their ghosts are widely honored and rewarded.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: One could hardly imagine a less likely subject for a movie than the refurbishing of a laundromat. But in his first film script, for ''My Beautiful Laundrette,'' Hanif Kureishi has come to terms with the angers and fears of growing up as a Pakistani in a London that resented and feared the new wave of immigrants.

title: Repression Is a Fact
description: Critics of United States policy in Central America are invariably among the first to point to human rights violations in right-wing dictatorships supported by the Reagan Administration. But when it comes to reporting on the state of freedom in Nicaragua, they engage in precisely the same kind of apologia they rightfully condemn when offered by Administration spokesmen.

title: A Time of Testing For Canada's Chief
description: These are testing times for tory governments in the English-speaking world. Ronald Reagan is a lot more popular than some of his policies, which could cost the Republicans a passel of Congressional seats and control of the Senate this year. The magic has worn off Margaret Thatcher after seven stormy years at Britain's helm. And in Canada, just 18 months after winning a landslide election, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and his Progressive Conservative Party have seen their public support slip noticeably in the polls.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS KNEW MARCOS WAS LEAVING WITH MONEY
description: American officials in the Philippines were aware that Ferdinand E. Marcos was taking currency with him when he left Clark Air Base for Hawaii, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Former Arrow Air Pilots Tell of Lax Maintenance
description: Two former pilots for Arrow Air told Congress today that the charter airline did minimal maintenance and pushed pilots to the point they would fall asleep in the cockpit.

title: Beethoven Quartets
description: The Guarneri Quartet continues its cycle of the complete Beethoven quartets tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: KEY AIDS ENZYME IS FOUND AND PRODUCED IN PURE FORM
description: Scientists have identified and produced in pure form the enzyme that is the key to the ability of the AIDS virus to infect human cells.

title: Agriculture Nominee Approved by Senate
description: The Senate today approved the nomination of Richard E. Lyng as Secretary of Agriculture by a vote of 95 to 2. Mr. Lyng is expected to be sworn in before the end of the week.

title: AFTER A BUSY DAY, LAWYERS CALL LINDENAUER NEGOTIATIONS NEARLY COMPLETE
description: Prosecutors and a defense lawyer have worked out most elements of a deal under which the only figure charged so far in the city's municipal corruption scandal would plead quilty to Federal charges and testify against other city officials, lawyers familiar with the negotiations said last night.

title: U.S. to Face Ecuador
description: Jimmy Arias will face Andres Gomez of Ecuador in the opening Davis Cup singles match here Friday.

title: CRIME PANEL URGES BROAD U.S. ATTACK ON THE TEAMSTERS
description: Organized crime's influence over the teamsters' union is ''so pervasive'' that the Government should consider removing union officers and placing union activities under court supervision, a Federal commission said today.

title: PART-TIME CADDIE LEADS BY 1
description: Mark Calcavecchia was caddying for Ken Green in the Honda Classic last Thursday and Friday. Today he was the leading player in the first round of the Doral Eastern Open.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Witkowski, the former Columbia quarterback who set several Ivy league passing records, was signed as a free agent by the Detroit Lions, the team that cut him before last season. . . . Tom Burgess, a Colgate quarterback who broke or tied 14 school records for passing and offense in his single season as a starter in 1984, has signed a contract to play for the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League. . . . Andy Christoff, a former Notre Dame defensive coordinator, has been named defensive backfield coach at Georgia Tech. . . . Jerry Neudecker, an American League umpire for 22 years, has been named assistant supervisor of umpires for the league. . . . The season is over for Lindy Ruff, the Buffalo Sabre left wing who broke his shoulder in a game against Hartford Wednesday. . . . Serge Lang, a former journalist who helped create the World Cup ski competition in 1966, will receive the 1986 A.T.&T. skiing award for his contributions to the sport.

title: REDEVELOPMENT PLAN STALLED AFTER BOARD OF ESTIMATE VOTE
description: The Board of Estimate last night agreed to demolish 22 owner-occupied homes to make way for new housing in the East New York section of Brooklyn, but leaders of the redevelopment project denounced the action as inadequate and said they would not proceed.

title: A Crisis in Strategic Materials Is Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Pirates of Penzance'
description: More than 100 years ago, Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Pirates of Penzance'' was first performed in New York.

title: House Committee Approves $250 Million Aid for Ulster
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to approve a $250 million aid program for Northern Ireland to help support the agreement between Britain and Ireland that gives Ireland a voice in governing the province.

title: Smith in Accord
description: Lonnie Smith, the Kansas City outfielder, announced yesterday that he would accept the conditions imposed by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth as an alternative to a year's suspension for his involvement with cocaine. ''I have decided to accept the commissioner's decision in its entirety,'' Smith said in a statement.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: UNTIL recently, most of my forays to Mexican restaurants in New York resulted in one gastronomic Alamo after another: a series of assaults on the digestive system that could put me out of commission for days. The whimsical names changed and the Margaritas came in different colors, yet the food was, for the most part, greasy and leaden - fast food served slowly. Only in the last several years have a handful of serious establishments appeared that offer something other than deep-fried tortillas heaped with iceberg lettuce and gloppy overcooked fillings. One of the more engaging new spots is Cafe Marimba, an enchantingly designed restaurant on the East Side.

title: Bridge: Computer System Provides Play When Alone at Home
description: Frustrated players who work unusual hours, live in a country area or are unwilling or unable to go out to a club or tournament can take heart. A recent innovation makes it possible to play bridge in one's home, with the other players widely scattered - perhaps in three different states.

title: BUNDESBANK'S ACTION
description: West Germany's central bank lowered its discount rate by one-half percentage point today, to 3.5 percent. The move was intended to stimulate the nation's economy and pave the way for other interest rate reductions around the world.

title: A Correction
description: In his column yesterday, Anthony Lewis erred in describing as civilians 11 people executed by contras in Cuapa, Nicaragua. The victims were 10 captured soldiers and a school night watchman.

title: The Campaign That's Killing the Contra-Aid Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE AND STAGE TROUPES DOING THE UNEXPECTED
description: THE world has grown smaller. Jet travel and satellite hookups are commonplace. There is a new familiarity with foreign cultures, as foreign cultures absorb one another. To have talked of Asian dance not too long ago would have been to talk of Kabuki, perhaps, or Kathakali. This weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, however, the Central Ballet of China is performing the Western art of ballet.

title: Benefit at the Net
description: At this season most Washingtonians discussing Georgetown University sports are talking about basketball. But not seven United States Senators, the Secretary of the Treasury, four Ambassadors, the Republican national chairman and some reporters, all of whom are among those burnishing their backhands for a court appearance Sunday in support of Georgetown women's tennis.

title: GEORGETOWN, VILLANOVA WIN
description: This time a year ago, a perfect game was required in order to beat Georgetown. At the start of another month of tournament play, an ill-timed toss of a roll of toilet paper helped the Hoyas win yesterday.

title: 'Music From the Soul'
description: ''Sweet Auburn: Music From the Soul,'' a celebration of black performers of the 20th century, will be presented tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Bronx Community College Hall of Fame Playhouse, University Avenue and West 181st Street.

title: ART: JACK YOUNGERMAN AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: JACK YOUNGERMAN will be 60 years old this month. Whether coincidentally or not, the Guggenheim Museum is marking the occasion with a retrospective of his paintings and sculptures that can be seen through April 27. For much of its length it makes a brave, brisk show, full of forthright contrasts of color that swing to and fro like bells in a belfry and forked, explosive, somersaulting imagery that never quite turns representational.

title: FILM: '16 DAYS OF GLORY,' ON LOS ANGELES OLYMPICS
description: ABOUT a quarter of ''16 Days of Glory,'' Bud Greenspan's 2-hour-and-25-minute documentary on the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Games, is given to the decathlon competition between Daley Thompson of Britain and Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany, and it's a prize-winner. The portentous narration - ''They walked into the arena like the gladiators of old'' - becomes less irritating, the celebratory music less obtrusive as we meet the competitors and watch these likable young men perform their extraordinary feats.

title: AN ARTIST INSPIRED BY NEW MEXICO'S LANDSCAPE
description: It would be difficult to imagine American painting in the first half of this century without the presence of Georgia O'Keeffe. The presence, as much as the work, was what impressed, and it in no way diminished with age. It was a memorable experience to see her come into a room, even when she was well over 90. Gliding along the floor with one tiny quick step after another, she fixed the newcomer with an eye that was both penetrating and remarkably clear. No words were wasted, and it was evident that she had no time for bores, but she spoke her say - firmly, clearly, completely and concisely -without equivocation.

title: Above-Par Putter
description: The Malaysian Open golf tournament being played this week will have to do without Tunku Abdul Rahman, but not because he hasn't been sorely tempted to join the field. The 83-year-old former Prime Minister recently received a present: a rare kind of putter called the Game Winner, which comes complete with air horn, bell, rear reflector, battery-powered headlights and tape measure, and with these instructions from the maker:

title: TALKS COLLAPSE IN TIN CRISIS
description: An emergency meeting of The International Tin Council broke up in disarray today after members failed to endorse a plan to end the four-month-old tin crisis. The collapse of the talks could trigger a financial crisis in the London commodities community, according to industry sources.

title: The Navy Needs to Tell New York City More
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SAYS THE CHOICE IS BETWEEN BACKING HIM OR COMMUNISTS
description: President Reagan, discussing his proposal to send aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, said today that members of Congress must choose between supporting his Administration or supporting Communists.

title: The Reckless Rush to Tax Amnesty
description: Full of fads: that's Congress, especially when there's revenue to be raised, and the newest fad is tax amnesty. Several states, New York included, have now collected vast sums with such amnesties, stirring appetites on Capitol Hill. Yet when it comes to Federal tax collection, amnesty is bad policy. Congressmen who suddenly see it as a ''painless'' way to narrow the huge budget deficit should know better.

title: DOW BREAKS ITS SLUMP, GAINING 9.94
description: The decision by West Germany to lower its interest rates helped stock prices rise sharply yesterday, snapping a slump on Wall Street that lasted nearly a week.

title: OFFICIAL TO COME TO U.S. WITH PAPERS ON MARCOS
description: The head of a commission seeking the return of Ferdinand E. Marcos's secret wealth plans to travel to the United States with documents he says ties the former President to real estate holdings in New York.

title: FLETCHER, RELUCTANT TO THE END, PICKED TO HEAD NASA A 2D TIME
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Dr. James C. Fletcher to a second tour of duty as head of the space agency.

title: Navratilova Advances
description: The top four-seeded players, including Martina Navratilova, ranked No. 1, and the defending champion Hana Mandlikova, advanced to the quarterfinals of the $150,000 United States Women's Indoor Tennis Championships with straight-set victories today.

title: Some Good News About Football
description: Amid all the musty, discouraging news about American football -from illicit inducements and academic improprieties among the colleges to evidence that even in high school an increasing number of players find steroids too alluring to forgo - there is the occasional breath of fresh air. At hand is a study concluding that football fatalities on all levels - from high school and sandlot right through the pros - were down again last season, in continuation of a trend that dates from the early 1970's.

title: G.M. AND EGYPT
description: The General Motors Corporation said the Egyptian Government had accepted a proposal for a joint car-assembly venture with the state-owned Nasr Car Company. First-year production would be about 30,000 vehicles, with most of them to be sold in Egypt.

title: CONCERT: PIERRE BOULEZ IN PREMIER OF 'REPONS'
description: THE return of Pierre Boulez to New York, as centerpiece of a festival breathlessly entitled ''Boulez Is Back!,'' may yet turn out to be the seismic cultural event that publicity has already proclaimed it. However, the New York premiere of his ''Repons'' last night at Columbia University Gymnasium did not live up to the Concorde-like screams of hyperbole that have preceded the arrival of this 45-minute breeding of live music with computer-generated sounds.

title: Refund to the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: OMBUDSMAN BARS FOOD-TUBE REMOVAL
description: A request to remove a feeding tube from a comatose nursing-home patient, and thus end her life, was denied today by the State Ombudsman for the Institutionalized Elderly in the first legal test of the New Jersey Supreme Court's landmark ''right to die'' decision.

title: YUGOSLAV NEWSPAPER SAYS ARCHIVES SHOW WALDHEIM WAR ROLE
description: One of Yugoslavia's leading newspapers today charged former Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations with taking part in Nazi military operations against Yugoslav partisans, but the Foreign Ministry withheld comment.

title: DYKSTRA GOES TO CENTER FIELD
description: Mookie Wilson was regaining the vision in his damaged right eye today, but the Mets still expected to lose him for at least two months and they named Lenny Dykstra as his replacement in center field.

title: Dining Out Guide: Intimate
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHANTERELLE, #89 Grand Street (966-6960) -

title: TWO TO HEAD SALOMON UNIT
description: Salomon Brothers Inc., the nation's leading underwriter of corporate debt and equity issues, yesterday named Jay F. Higgins and Harold Tanner as co-heads of its corporate finance department.

title: SCREEN: 'LAUNDRETTE,' SOCIAL COMEDY SLEEPER
description: DON'T be put off by the title, which makes it sound like a failed French farce. ''My Beautiful Laundrette,'' written by Hanif Kureishi and directed by Stephen Frears, is the first real sleeper of the year.

title: REAGAN'S RESOLVE: CONTRA AID A MUST
description: President Reagan is pressing for military aid to Nicaraguan rebels despite misgivings among his advisers about the political risks of the effort, and also about the tactics that some key aides have employed, White House officials said today.

title: CABARET: SONDHEIM SONGS
description: WHEN Jackie Cain and Roy Kral somewhat reluctantly agreed to do a program of Stephen Sondheim's songs seven years ago for Gil Weist's ''American Popular Song'' series at Michael's Pub, they discovered a wealth of material that was uniquely suited to their singing talents. And ''discovery'' it was because they had never used any of Mr. Sondheim's material before.

title: THE SCREEN: 'ROOM WITH A VIEW
description: LUCY HONEYCHURCH would seem to be the quintessential, well-brought-up young woman of Edwardian England. She's pretty, polite and minds her elders, who believe in the efficacy of manners and the class system. In the genteel world in which Lucy has been raised, people are what they appear to be. Yet Lucy is seething with unrecognized passions. Says the startled clergyman, Mr. Beebe, when he hears Lucy playing Beethoven on the piano, ''If she ever takes to living as she plays, it will be very exciting -both for us and for her.''

title: WOODY ALLEN'S SELECTIVE VISION OF NEW YORK
description: After meeting two attractive young women at a party, an architect takes them on a quick spin around Manhattan to show them his favorite buildings. The whirlwind tour offers up a series of images of an elegant, gracious New York: the lavish Beaux-Arts facade of the Ansonia; the intricate ornamentation of the Alwyn Court, down to the crowned salamander over the main doorway; the charming tucked-away town houses of Pomander Walk. Then the architect pauses dramatically in front of a modern building, a grim wall of concrete studded with slitlike openings. ''That's just a monstrosity,'' says one of the women. ''It ruins everything else,'' the other agrees.

title: AUBURN UPSET, 65-63, IN S.E.C.
description: Chauncey Robinson scored 25 points and Raymond Brown added 22 as Mississippi State survived three missed free throws in the final 37 seconds to upset Auburn, 65-63, in the quarterfinals of the Southeastern Conference basketball tournament tonight.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
description: Assets of the nation's 362 money market mutual funds increased $1.04 billion, to $211.30 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: STAGE: SQUAT THEATER'S 'DREAMLAND BURNS'
description: IN the nine years since it made its first American appearance, Squat Theater has refined its technique and become more discriminating in matters of taste. This is not to suggest that the nomadic, exiled Hungarian troupe has lost any of its radical fervor. Squat's new show, ''Dreamland Burns,'' written and directed by Stephan Balint, is a disquieting look at people who might be regarded as land-lost. Seemingly in touch with their environment, they are, in fact, adrift in their own fantastical nightmares.

title: Addabbo Hospitalized For Effects of Collapse
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat from Queens, collapsed at a luncheon today and was taken to an area hospital.

title: THE 'WEALTH EFFECT' OF A WALL ST. BOOM SPURS THE ECONOMY
description: Soaring stock prices since the end of September are making millions of Americans wealthier - at least on paper. In an extraordinary burst, the value of all publicly traded stocks has jumped by more than $450 billion in that span, giving added zip to the economy, as many investors have begun to spend more freely than before.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The stock market's gains probably don't lead to people eating steak instead of hamburger.

title: FREQUENT FLEERS, COME TO ELBA ESTATES
description: Do you suppose Jean-Claude (Baby Doc) Duvalier would have stepped aboard a U.S. Air Force jet to Paris, rather than ordering his Tonton Macoute bully-boys to fight it out, if he knew he was destined to become in effect a stateless person?

title: BLACK MUSICALS HAVE CAUSE TO SING
description: EMBATTLED by the same economic woes that have afflicted the rest of the theater in recent years, the black musical, which was the hope of Broadway in the 1970's, is nevertheless bustling in Off Broadway avenues and beyond. As elsewhere in the musical theater, hard times have prompted a retrospective mood, with producers and creators gazing back on a tradition that is still being rediscovered.

title: Unknowing Endorsements
description: Abraham Hirschfeld's candidacy for the Democratic nomination for lieutenant governor was barely airborne when the flak started.

title: DOBRYNIN JOINS KREMLIN LEADERSHIP AS CONGRESS ENDS
description: A nine-day congress of the Soviet Communist Party ended today with several additions to the top Kremlin leadership, including Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the longtime envoy in Washington, and the first woman in 25 years.

title: GEORGE S. RADER
description: George S. Rader, a retired New York City Criminal Court judge, died Monday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 84 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: ART: 'CHOICES' PRESENTS AN ESTHETIC OF DAILY LIFE
description: ''CHOICES: Making an Art of Everyday Life'' is an unusual, daring and flawed show. Its subject is the way in which some men and women have been trying to make their lives art and art their lives. They perform, engage strangers in therapeutic and socratic dialogues, make videos and posters, chart every move and invent projects that test the limits of their will and imagination. When they do work in a traditional medium like painting, the aim is never esthetic.

title: REAGAN '87 BUDGET REJECTED BY PANEL
description: The Republican-controlled Senate Budget Committee today rejected President Reagan's proposed 1987 budget on a vote of 16 to 6.

title: Tough Criminal Laws Proposed in Britain
description: The Government proposed tough measures today to fight a rising crime rate, including life prison terms for carrying guns, seizure of criminal assets to pay victims and elimination of jury trials in some cases.

title: CARRYING A QUEEN'S MESSAGES
description: It's a dark and stormy night in Mongolia, and as the Trans-Mongolian Express lumbers its way across the Gobi Desert, two members of an elite British diplomatic corps are on board, carrying on a tradition almost 500 years old.

title: 'DRESS GRAY,' A MILITARY MYSTERY TALE
description: GORE VIDAL taking on West Point, or a reasonable facsimile of the academy - the prospect is no doubt enticing for fans of the writer's iconoclastic and stylish wit. But ''Dress Gray,'' his adaptation of a novel by Lucian K. Truscott 4th, which will be shown on Channel 4 Sunday and Monday at 9 P.M., turns out to be a bit more complicated than still another fusillade against what is perceived as the military mentality. Mr. Vidal does indeed have wicked fun with the villainous figure of an Army general who makes Dr. Strangelove look like a model of sanity, but he ends up with rousing, even sentimental words of encouragement for the military institution itself.

title: THE SYRACUSE QUIET MAN
description: The Syracuse University basketball team draws most of its attention with Dwayne Washington, whose exotic moves often seem to come from another planet, and Rony Seikaly, the tall, enthusiastic presence from Greece, and the Carrier Dome itself, the biggest sixth man in college basketball today.

title: LATEST M.T.A. FINANCING HAS TOP YIELD OF 8.09%
description: In its second financing in as many weeks, the Metropolitan Transit Authority is offering $573.9 million of revenue bonds, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: FIRST CHAIRMAN NAMED AT PILLSBURY FOODS UNIT
description: In a move that reflects renewed emphasis on its consumer foods business, the Pillsbury Company yesterday named Thomas R. McBurney to the newly created position of chairman of the concern's United States foods division.

title: Lower East Side Man Held in Girl's Slaying
description: A restaurant worker was arrested yesterday in New Jersey and charged with kidnapping and killing a 12-year-old girl on Manhattan's Lower East Side last month.

title: AMERICAN FIBER OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MUSIC: VIENNA CHAMBER
description: The Vienna Chamber Orchestra may be a very vital musical force in its home city, but the concert it presented at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was pretty uneventful for much of its course.

title: FROM THE HEART
description: The adage, of course, is that if you absolutely have to bet, then bet with your head, not your heart.

title: RICHARD YASHEWSKI
description: Richard Yashewski, senior vice president of the investment banking and brokerage concern of Butcher & Singer and past president of the Market Technicians Association, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Lloyd Harbor, L.I. He was 43 years old.

title: LIFE-SAVING OPERATIONS FOR 2 IN JERSEY
description: For the past two weeks, 3-year-old Troy Grant and 6-year-old Carlos Cyrus have been the center of attraction at the pediatric unit of the Deborah Heart and Lung Center here.

title: The Whittling Away Of Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $99,000. c-After an extraordinary gain of $91,000, or 2 cents a share. d-After a net operating loss carryforward of $200,000.

title: MONTEFUSCO, YANKEES AT ODDS
description: By all medical logic, John Montefusco should not even have been in spring training with the Yankees. By Montefusco's logic, he should not be here after today.

title: STATE IS UNDER NEW DELHI RULE
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi ousted the leader of the Moslem-dominated state of Kashmir today and in effect placed it under his control.

title: Charge of Drunkenness Dropped in Burford Case
description: A county judge today struck down an intoxication charge against Anne McGill Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, after her attorneys said ''she might have been obstreperous'' but was not drunk in a jailhouse incident here.

title: SETTLEMENT IS IMPOSED IN TIN CRISIS
description: The London Metal Exchange announced a method today for ending the four-month-old tin crisis. But it is a forced solution, coming after rescue talks collapsed, that will mean huge losses for metals brokers and damage the integrity of the exchange, the world's largest metals market, according to analysts.

title: JURORS RETURN FINAL VERDICTS IN BOMB TRIAL
description: The Federal trial of six people accused in a series of terrorist bombings ended yesterday when the jury -which had rendered a partial verdict Tuesday - found four defendants guilty of five more bombing counts.

title: ST JOE GOLD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW SALMON: LESS BONE, FAT, CALORIES AND TASTE
description: Chicken of the Sea has come up with a canned salmon that could pass for canned white meat tuna packed in water or for any other nonfishy-tasting fish.

title: KIRKLAND FAULTS JUSTICE DEPT. ON UNION CRIME
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that it was the fault of law-enforcement officials, not labor leaders, if some unions had been infiltrated by organized crime.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:14 A.M. today and set at 2:01 P.M.

title: The Mob Commission Moves On
description: After embarrassing itself with an ill-considered proposal to test workers for drug abuse, the President's Commission on Organized Crime has partly redeemed itself with a provocative report on how hoodlums have penetrated unions and legitimate businesses. It rightly criticizes the Federal Government, including the present Administration, for letting the mob make such inroads.

title: BUYING STOCKS INTERNATIONALLY
description: INVESTING in foreign companies is, virtually by definition, more difficult than investing in American corporations. But for individuals who decide to participate in this category, the potential rewards could be substantially greater than for investors in domestic securities.

title: WOOLWORTH (F.W.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CHARGES DROPPED IN SIX FLAGS CASE
description: A Superior Court judge dismissed manslaughter charges today against two executives of the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park in connection with a fatal fire in the park's Haunted Castle attraction.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE SOARS TO 7.2% IN LARGEST RISE IN ALMOST 6 YEARS
description: The nation's unemployment rate soared six-tenths of a percentage point in February, the biggest monthly rise in almost six years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SPINNING NEW CABLES FOR BRIDGE'S 2D CENTURY
description: The Brooklyn Bridge's lacy webbing of stays and suspenders - exalted as ''choiring strings'' by Hart Crane - are about to be replaced in a four-year project that will also help keep a struggling Pennsylvania steel plant alive.

title: RULING ON LETTERS IS DUE IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal district judge is expected to decide soon if jurors may see letters that prosecutors have described as a virtual confession by Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy communications specialist charged with spying for the Soviet Union.

title: GRIEVANCE PROCESS SPURS STRIKES AT THREE G.E. PLANTS NEAR BOSTON
description: About 7,500 striking workers at General Electric plants in three small nearby towns are threatening a long walkout in a dispute over relations between union stewards and company foremen.

title: AUTO WORLD TRENDS AND A TREND SETTER
description: It is shaped like a big shoe box, sits high on four fat, ribbed tires and bears the unfamiliar name of Pinzgauer. The importer describes it alternately as ''the most capable all-terrain vehicle on earth'' and ''an expensive toy'' and is betting that 1,200 American customers a year would be willing to pay $50,000 apiece to own one.

title: The Lowing Herds Wind Slowly Over the Hill
description: It is 7:30 A.M. Marvin's cows are going out to pasture. I can look out my kitchen window and see them moving single file down along Route 100. Nothing else is moving this cold morning.

title: CANNON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notions of the Nation-State Are Inappropriate to Arab Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN APPOINTS HABIB AS ENVOY TO CENTRAL AMERICA
description: President Reagan, saying the United States was seeking a ''diplomatic solution for Central America,'' announced today that he was appointing Philip C. Habib to serve as special United States envoy to the region.

title: Reforms Can Save South Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS MOSCOW'S MISSIONS TO U.N. REDUCED
description: The Reagan Administration ordered the Soviet, Ukrainian and Byelorussian Missions to the United Nations today to reduce their personnel by more than a third, accusing them of espionage and calling the size of the missions ''a threat to national security.''

title: BID FOR ANONYMOUS JURY IN GOTTI TRIAL IS DENIED
description: A judge in Queens yesterday denied a prosecution request that an anonymous jury be selected in the trial of John Gotti, the reputed organized-crime leader, on charges that he and an associate assaulted and robbed a man in 1984.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters dispatch from Kansas City in some copies Wednesday about proposed guidelines to avert such design flaws as those found to have caused the skywalk collapse at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City incorrectly identified the engineers' organization that received the proposals. The group is the American Society of Civil Engineers.

title: METS ROUT SEAVER, WHITE SOX
description: The Mets rang up the curtain today in the first of their 31 exhibition games, and it seemed somehow appropriate that the man on the mound for the Chicago White Sox was Tom Seaver, who pitched the Mets to their last pennant 13 years ago.

title: ROWLEY-SCHER REPROGRAPHCS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized gains of $11,624,000 for the quarter and $46,816,000 for the year. c-Including realized gains of $4,510,000 for the quarter and realized losses of $15,798,000 for the year.

title: REST OF SHUGART SOLD BY XEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had sold the remaining assets of the Shugart Corporation, its money-losing maker of floppy-disk drives for personal computers and word processors, to a California investment partnership for an undisclosed price.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Ralph Sampson of the Houston Rockets was fined $2,000 by the National Basketball Asociation for throwing a punch at Bill Hanzlik of the Nuggets in game in Denver Tuesday night. . . . Mike Norris, the former Oakland A's pitcher, has come to terms with the San Jose Bees to play for the independent Class A team this season, according to his agent. . . . Orlando Woolridge has apologized to team officials for missing two games this week.

title: BURST AGRITECH INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
GREASE MONKEY HOLDING CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS EXPEL 3 CBS NEWSMEN
description: South Africa ordered the expulsion today of three representatives of CBS News, one of them an American. The action came after the network broadcast videotape footage this week of a mass funeral in a township near Johannesburg from which television cameras had been formally banned.

title: NEW HYPOTHESES OFFERED AT SHUTTLE INQUIRY
description: Space agency officials today disclosed a series of problems with a booster rocket before the launching of the shuttle Challenger, more details of what then happened just before the spaceship's explosion, and some new hypotheses on what caused the disaster.

title: J. L. UPCHURCH JR. AND MISS ALLISON ARE WED IN DALLAS
description: Laura Elizabeth Allison, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. W. John Allison Jr. of Dallas, was married yesterday to Jesse Lloyd Upchurch Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Upchurch of Fort Worth. The Rev. Donovan K. Riley performed the ceremony at the Highland Park Presbyterian Church in Dallas.

title: SCREEN: 'HIGHLANDER,' WITH SEAN CONNERY
description: What, you may ask, is an actor like Sean Connery doing with fourth-place billing in a movie like ''Highlander''? Well, since you asked, he is a 2,437-year-old Egyptian who shows up in 16th-century Scotland to inform young Connor MacLeod that they are both immortal and that MacLeod must go through the centuries until the climactic ''last gathering'' when the immortals will engage in a duel to the end, for ''there can be only one.''

title: GERBER DEALS GINGERLY WITH TALES OF TAINTING
description: When the Gerber Products Company learned Feb. 11 that a woman had reported finding glass in a jar of its baby food in Schenectady, N.Y., company officials treated it as a routine consumer complaint.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a credit of $482,000, or 43 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Gregory Haimovsky, Piano
description: The pianist Gregory Haimovsky will play music by Beethoven, Chopin, Schumann, Debussy and Messiaen, this afternoon at 2 o'clock at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets: $8 to $12.50; information: 362-1911.

title: OUTSHINING THE STARS
description: The Stern Auditorium at Mount Sinai Hospital was crawling with literary lions and big-name journalists: Calvin Trillin, Jervis Anderson, Tom Brokaw, Nora Ephron, Charlayne Hunter-Gault and Jules Feiffer.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL IN CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: Smith International Inc., a leading maker of oil drilling tools, equipment and services, filed for protection from creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: MARCOS FAMILY JEWELRY BROUGHT TO HAWAII IS PUT AT $5 MILLION TO $10 MILLION
description: The value of jewelry brought into Hawaii by the family of Ferdinand E. Marcos is estimated at $5 million to $10 million by the United States Customs Service, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: Katherine Towle, 87, Ex-Dean at Berkeley
description: Katherine A. Towle, the first woman to be named dean of students at the University of California at Berkley and the first director of the women's marines, died March 1 of a heart attack at a retirement home in Pacific Grove, Calif. She was 87 years old.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS SEEK UNITED FORCE
description: Senior leaders of anti-Sandinista rebel groups based in Costa Rica say they want to form a united Nicaraguan opposition. But they say that so far neither Congress nor the Reagan Administration has supported their efforts.

title: RODINO RUNNING FOR 20TH TERM
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democract of New Jersey, said today that he would seek re-election to a 20th consecutive term because his district needed an experienced legislator to battle the Reagan Administration's budget cuts.

title: SOUTHERN DEMOCRATS PRESS PLAN FOR A REGIONAL PRIMARY
description: Despite warnings that they could upset the balance in their party's Presidential nominating process, Southern Democrats said today that they would press ahead with plans to organize a single primary for the region as a way of strengthening their political hand in 1988.

title: Puerto Rican Music
description: Traditional music of Puerto Rico will be presented tonight at 8 at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, by the World Music Institute (362-3366). Los Pleneros de la 21 will perform bombas and plenas, and Grupo Criollo will play rural music of the island. Tickets are $10.

title: Veteran in Murder Pact Called Psychologically Ill
description: A Vietnam veteran who took part Tuesday morning in a murder and suicide pact that led to five deaths was psychologically disabled, the authorities said today.

title: Reagan Portrait Slashed
description: The portrait of Ronald Reagan hanging in the State Capitol with those of other governors of California was slashed by a vandal, requiring its removal for repair, officials said today. ''The 30-inch cut goes from the bridge of the nose to the beltline,'' said Susan Hogg, a spokesman for the Department of General Services. Mr. Reagan was Governor from 1967 to 1975.

title: New York City Scandals - in 1972 and Now
description: The scandal involving New York City's Parking Violations Bureau and Queens and Bronx Democratic clubs brings on a sense of deja vu.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CHEERS AND BARBS IN RUSSIA
description: There is something awesome about the volume of words generated at a Soviet Communist Party congress.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE CUTS ITS LOAN RATE TO 8-YEAR LOW, 7%
description: The Federal Reserve Board cut the interest rate it charges financial institutions today by half a percentage point, to 7 percent, its lowest level in almost eight years. In turn, banks nationwide cut their prime rate half a point, to 9 percent.

title: PGA TOUR TO PUNISH O'GRADY
description: The PGA Tour has notified Mac O'Grady that it intends to take disciplinary action against him once again for ''conduct unbecoming a professional'' as a result of statements attributed to the outspoken golfer in recent newspaper reports.

title: ARIAS LOSES IN DAVIS OPENER
description: Arthur Ashe, the former United States Davis Cup captain, called it the strangest Davis Cup match he had ever seen. The current captain, Tom Gorman, could only shake his head. For Jimmy Arias, it was surely one of the most disappointing losses of his career. And at the end of the day, Ecuador had taken a 1-0 lead against the United States in the first round of Davis Cup play at Francisco Segura Cano Stadium.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL MODESTLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday following a cut in the Federal Reserve discount rate and a weaker-than-expected February employment report.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET HOLD TALKS ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: American and Soviet officials have completed two days of talks on ways to stop the spread of chemical weapons, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: SELECTERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Blood Baths Came After Somoza Ouster
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $34,000 for the quarter, $28,000 for the year and a loss of $2,252,000 on disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and year. c-Net income after a loss of $52,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and losses of $2,095,000 on the sale of investments, $1,776,000 on writeoff of excess cost over fair value of assets acquired, both for the year. The year result also includes gains of $553,000 from discontinued operations, $7,767,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $123,000.

title: EMPLOYEE GROUP BUYS VICKERS SHIP
description: Workers and managers at Britain's only nuclear submarine maker pulled off the country's biggest worker buyout today. The Government sale of Vickers Shipbuilding and Engineering to a management consortium -despite a higher bid from an outsider - was announced to Parliament by Industry Secretary Paul Channon.

title: PRETORIA ENDS EMERGENCY DECREE AND RELEASES 327 FROM PRISONS
description: South Africa rescinded its state-of-emergency decree today and released what it said were the last 327 of almost 8,000 people detained since last July, when the decree went into effect.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CONSUMER SATURDAY 2 BOOKS OFFER HELP TO PARENTS
description: PARENTS may find themselves short of the time, energy or money they need for raising children, but there is one thing they will never have to do without: advice. Bookstores are crammed with how-to books on every nuance of raising, feeding, educating and loving the up-and-coming generation.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Spring exhibition opener for the defending National League champion Cardinals. Both teams train in St. Petersburg and play games at Al Lang Stadium. (Radio - WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Opening of spring-training games for the Yankees. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Big East championship, at Madison Square Garden (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 7 P.M., only if St. John's is in the final; also WNYE-FM 91.5, if Syracuse is in the final); Big Eight Conference semifinals, at Kansas City (Television - MSG, 8 P.M. and 10 P.M., tapes); Atlantic Coast Conference, semifinals at Greensboro, N.C. (Television - ESPN, 1:30 P.M. and ESPN, 3:30 P.M.); Western Athletic Conference, championship game (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); Big Sky Conference championship Game, in Reno, joined in progress (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.); Southeastern Conference championship, at Lexington, Ky., (Television - Channel 4, 2:30 P.M.); E.C.A.C. Metro championship, at Coraopolis, Pa. 7 P.M.; E.C.A.C. Metropolitan New York New Jersey Division III championship, Old Westbury at Staten Island (Radio - WSIA-FM 88.9 FM, 6:55 P.M.); Indiana at Michigan, showdown for the Big Ten championship. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Washington Capitals, at the Nassau Coliseum, 5:05 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 5 P.M. Radio -WOR 710, 5 P.M.) Devils vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1:35 P.M. (Television - MSG, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA 570, 1:30 P.M.) Lacrosse Syracuse vs.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PHILIPPINES REVOKES THE PASSPORTS OF MARCOS AND 88 OTHERS TO PREVENT THEIR RETURN
description: The Philippine Government today revoked the passports of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos and the 88 relatives and associates who fled with him to Hawaii. Officials here described the move as intended to block their return to the Philippines.

title:
PATENTS;
REDUCING THE COST OF SUN POWER
description: ALVIN M. MARKS received his 106th patent this week for an invention he believes will lower the home cost of sun-powered electricity to less than a penny per kilowatt-hour. Consumers now pay about 10 cents. Mr. Marks, who heads a research company in Athol, Mass., has exclusively licensed the patent rights to Phototherm Inc. in Amherst, N.H.

title: Chadian Official Says Army Killed 864 Rebels in 2 Days
description: Chadian troops killed 864 rebels in fighting in the north of the country two days ago, Foreign Minister Gouara Lassou said today.

title: SOVIET DATA INDICATING COMET WRAPPED IN DUST
description: Preliminary analysis of the data from the Soviet Union's Vega 1 spacecraft indicates that the nucleus of Halley's comet may be a slighly elongated body wrapped in a cocoon of dust perhaps a kilometer thick, scientists participating in the mission said today.

title: Books of The Times; Tyranny of the Past
description: A FAMILY MADNESS. By Thomas Keneally. 336 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95. The consequences of history fascinate Thomas Keneally - not so much history's abstract effects on nations and ideology as its impact on ordinary people; its cold, impersonal power to warp the shape of one's life and mold one's heart and mind. In ''The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith'' (1972), he examined the tensions between white and aborigine cultures in turn-of-the-century Australia, through the story of a half-caste ''mission black'' who became an outlaw killer. In ''Confederates'' (1980), he looked at one summer's events during the American Civil War and their impact on four individuals. And in the award-winning ''Schindler's List'' (1982), he demonstrated how the horrors of the Holocaust inspired, in one man, a courageous moral passion that goaded him into heroic action.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the pooling of interests in 1985 with Direct Response Group Inc.

title: SOLARZ APPLAUDED AND JEERED BY MANILA STUDENTS
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, a longtime critic of Ferdinand E. Marcos, received some jeers amid applause today when he addressed students at the University of the Philippines.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error in Harvey Cox's article ''The Spy in the Pew,'' published Monday, the minister of Mr. Cox's Baptist church was described as ''he.'' The original manuscript used the word ''she.''

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Diplomats and Sheep
description: John J. Maresca, a senior Foreign Service officer who is currently a visiting fellow at Georgetown University, has gone public with a sore subject that has been quietly simmering at Foggy Bottom for some time: abdication of leadership in policy decisions by Foreign Service professionals.

title: Failing to Take a Problem by the Handle Bars
description: ''What would you say,'' I asked my friend Mersh, ''is the most irritating aspect of living in New York?''

title: LOSS INCREASES FOR WHEELING
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, which is operating under Federal bankruptcy protection and endured a 98-day strike last year, reported substantially wider net losses for the fourth quarter and all of 1985.

title: Classroom Is Reopened After Threat of Plague
description: Health officials today allowed San Francisco State University to reopen a classroom where a test tube broke, spilling a culture of the bacterium that causes bubonic plague.

title: GUARDS SENTENCED IN INMATE BEATINGS
description: Six Trenton State Prison guards who were convicted of participating in or failing to stop ''sadistic'' beatings of defenseless inmates were sentenced to prison terms of three to five years today.

title: BISHOPS RESIST U.S. SUBPOENA OF DOCUMENTS
description: The National Conference of Catholic Bishops said yesterday that it would not comply with Federal court subpoenas asking it to turn over internal documents on its anti-abortion activities, and that it would be willing to risk a citation for contempt of court.

title: BIG BANKS CUT PRIME BY 1/2 POINT
description: Banks across America lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by a half-point, to 9 percent, the lowest level since the fall of 1978.

title: PLEA AGREEMENT IN CITY SCANDAL REPORTED MADE
description: The only person charged so far in the New York City corruption scandal has agreed to plead guilty and cooperate with investigators, law-enforcement officials said yesterday. The deal was outlined in a signed agreement, but putting it into effect was delayed by a dispute over when the guilty plea would be entered, the officials said.

title: AMERICAN FILM INSTITUTE HONORS BILLY WILDER
description: A few hours before Billy Wilder was handed the American Film Institute's 14th annual Life Achievement Award Thursday night, he paced his elegant apartment in a West Los Angeles high rise - dodging the Picassos and Braques from his recently sold beach house that were stacked on the floor. And he worried. The people he would like to thank, he said, ''are all dead now'' - the director Ernst Lubitsch, his early collaborator Charles Brackett, William Holden, Gary Cooper, Tyrone Power, Erich von Stroheim, Gloria Swanson, Humphrey Bogart.

title:
PATENTS;
A METHOD TO TEST SEMICONDUCTOR LASERS
description: AT&T; Bell Laboratories of Murray Hill, N.J., received a patent this week for a method of testing semiconductor lasers such as those it will begin installing next year in the fiber optic trans-Atlantic cable system for service with Europe.

title: So Sad About the Senate
description: It was inevitable that the United States Senate would finally submit to having itself televised. The last time I saw the place it was obvious the jig was up. Most of the members, from the look of them, could have been TV news-show anchors. Blow-dry hair styles locked down with plenty of mousse, smiles by Eveready, incisors and canines dazzling enough for a mouthwash commercial . . . It was a sad spectacle.

title: BLACKMUN ON SEARCH FOR THE CENTER
description: Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun is constantly aware that the Supreme Court ruling for which he is best known, the 1973 decision legalizing abortion, could someday be reversed.

title: ANDUJAR ACCEDES
description: Joaquin Andujar, the Oakland A's right-hander, yesterday accepted the three-part penalty handed down by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth for the pitcher's involvement with illegal drugs. The 10-year veteran was one of seven players Ueberroth conditionally suspended last week for one year.

title: To Make Children's Clothing Measure Up
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EARLY MORNING CALL The South Street Seaport Museum (669-9400) is operating the side-wheel excursion boat Andrew Fletcher for a trip out into New York Harbor for a relatively early morning - from 10 A.M. to noon - close-up look at the Statue of Liberty. Experts will ride along to talk about the statue's current restoration work as well as its original installation.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on equity of $20,504,000 for the quarter, $55,732,000 for the year and losses from discontinued operations of $15,106,000 for the quarter, $51,622,000 for the year. c-Including equity income of $2,357,000 for the quarter, $7,481,000 for the year and after losses from discontinued operations of $41,839,000 for the quarter, $48,760,000 for the year. d-Net income. Year-ago preferred stock dividends exceeded final net. Earnings or losses on equity relate to the company's interests in its unconsolidated real estate subsidiaries.

COMTREX SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
