MEDIA GROUPS MOVE TO KILL FAIRNESS RULING
description: A dozen broadcast and journalism organizations have asked a Federal appeals court to order the Federal Communications Commission to stop enforcing rules requiring fairness on the air.

title: What a Party
description: It is often said that Democrats will celebrate anything short of a trip to the dentist, and maybe even that, so it is no surprise that the official opening of the National Democratic Club at 30 Ivy Street, S.E., will start with a ribbon cutting at 10 A.M. next Tuesday and go on right through a reception from 7 to 11 that evening.

title: SUBDUED CROWDS DRAWN TO THE CAPE
description: A car pulls up to the beach and its occupants get out, stretch, and trudge across the sand, cameras swinging from the neck.

title: DESIGNED ART DECO BUILDING
description: Jacques L. Delamarre Sr., an architect whose projects included some of the most important Art Deco buildings in New York City, died Feb. 27 in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 80 years old and lived in Palm Springs.

title: CITY FINDS RISE IN COMPLAINTS OF BIAS AGAINST HOMOSEXUALS
description: Complaints of violence and discrimination against homosexuals have more than doubled in the last year, in large part because of public fears about AIDS, the city's Human Rights Commission reported yesterday. It called on the City Council to provide ''legislative protection'' for homosexuals.

title:
PATENTS;
NEW PUZZLE CUBE
description: An educational puzzle cube patented this week can be pulled apart and turned into an unlimited number of shapes.

title: CCA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $467,311, or 9 cents a share. c-Net loss.

title: IN BOSTON, ACRES OF SPRINGTIME
description: ''It's kind of like an art museum here - there's something for everyone to enjoy,'' said Richard H. Daley, executive director of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society. He was taking a visitor around the three and a half acres of the New England Spring Flower Show as exhibitors were putting in their displays for the Saturday opening.

title: CARBON DIOXIDE DISPUTE BUBBLES IN UTAH COUNTY
description: Many people here in southern Utah are hoping that the gas that puts the fizz in soda pop will put a spark to the region's ailing economy.

title:
PATENTS;
A PRECISE LASER BEAM IN GLAUCOMA TREATMENT
description: An instrument to precisely aim laser beams in the treatment of glaucoma and other conditions was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: SYRACUSE 75; HOYAS 73
description: Perhaps someone just forgot to mention to the players from Georgetown and Syracuse that the Big East basketball tournament is really nothing more than a time to prepare for more important games. For a third consecutive year, the Hoyas and the Orangemen created the same edge-of-the-seat suspense - and exchanged the same glares and shoves - that have characterized their postseason meetings.

title: KEY TESTIMONY BEFORE PRESIDENTIAL PANEL INVESTIGATING CHALLENGER DISASTER
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, held by a Presidential investigative panel yesterday at the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Fla., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The current size of the Soviet U.N. missions is not warranted by the staffing needs for official U.N. business.

title: ANGIOMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge; The Hand of a Lifetime Had Odd Twist for Texas Player
description: Players who pick up a hand of a lifetime tend to remember it for a lifetime, especially if the result is a disappointing minus score. Paradoxically, the sad story can have a happy ending, and did on the diagramed deal.

title: F.D.I.C. FUND EXPANSION
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, reporting that its financial results for 1985 fell short of expectations, said yesterday that it had added $2.3 billion to its reserve for losses, bringing them to $4.5 billion.

title: ARAFAT AND AIDES DIFFER OVER RESPONSE TO HUSSEIN
description: More than two weeks after King Hussein of Jordan ended a joint negotiating effort with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat and his senior aides remain split on how the P.L.O. should respond, Palestinian sources said here today.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $1,180,000 for the quarter and $173,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $3,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,274,000 for the year.

title: CHURCH LEADERS DELAY DECISION ON HOMES PLAN
description: Organizers of a disputed redevelopment project, rebuffed by the city's Board of Estimate, said yesterday that they would put off for three weeks a decision on whether to go ahead with plans to build 1,500 low-cost, single-family homes in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: GOVERNMENTS ACT ON IMPURE CHEESES
description: The French Government announced here today that it was acting to prevent the shipment to the United States of brie cheese contaminated with bacteria that can cause illness.

title: DOXSEE FOOD CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $427,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MARKET RISE IS MODEST DESPITE CUTS IN RATES
description: Wall Street had been expecting a cut in the discount rate for so long that, when the Federal Reserve Board actually made the move yesterday, stock prices gained only slightly.

title: SKEPTICISM IN JAPAN
description: Economists and business executives here welcomed the Bank of Japan's decision today to cut its basic interest rate by half a point, but they expressed doubts that it would stimulate as much economic growth as bank officials have predicted.

title: SHELTON JONES PLAYS HIS ROLE
description: Shelton Jones did not really believe he would do what he did on that Sunday night in Los Angeles nearly two years ago. He was playing in a high school all-America game in Pauley Pavilion on the U.C.L.A. campus. John Wooden, the Wizard of Westwood himself, was watching from the stands. Danny Manning and Delray Brooks, who would soon be heading for the Olympic trials, were being tested. David Rivers was beginning to build a dazzling national reputation. But for one breathless moment on that one night, Jones outdid them all.

title: Freedom Names
description: To the Editor:

title: RADA ELECTRONICS INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAW SHOULD CHANGE TO LET POLICE DETAIN ALL RUNAWAYS, PANEL SAYS
description: State and local laws should be changed to allow the police to detain runaway, neglected and other missing children, a Justice Department advisory panel recommended today.

title: INTELSAT ACTS TO SWITCH LAUNCHINGS FROM SHUTTLE TO FRENCH ROCKET
description: Intelsat, the international nonprofit satellite organization, wants to switch the launching of the first of its new communications satellites from NASA's space shuttle to a European Ariane 4 rocket, an Intelsat spokesman said today.

title: WALDHEIM SAYS REPORTS ON PAST ARE 'UNFOUNDED'
description: Kurt Waldheim told the World Jewish Congress yesterday that published reports linking him to Nazi wartime misconduct were part of a ''unsubstantiated and unfounded'' campaign against him.

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCHERING SET TO ADD KEY
description: Key Pharmaceuticals Inc. has agreed to be acquired by the Schering-Plough Corporation in a stock deal valued at about $587 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: Paintbrush Diplomacy
description: An exhibition of art from the Soviet Union, including facsimiles of rare Russian manuscripts dating as far back as the 11th century and counterpointed by contemporary paintings by Ukrainian schoolchildren, is attracting unusual interest in the rotunda of the Cannon House Office Building. The exhibit, through the 14th of this month, grew out of a visit by Representative Tom Lantos, a California Democrat on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, to the Soviet Union in January 1985.

title: FILM: 'SCREEN TEST' DIRECTED BY SAM AUSTER
description: Not only people but animals will do just about anything to break into the movies, even pornographic ones shot by teen-agers. That is the vaguely satiric premise behind the teen-age sex comedy ''Screen Test,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner and other local theaters.

title: Duvalier Moves To the Riviera
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the ousted Haitian President, arrived today with his family at their new residence in exile, an isolated luxury villa in hills inland from the French Riviera.

title: SPANIARDS IN TUG-OF-WAR ON NATO MEMBERSHIP
description: Spain has recently become an arena for intense international lobbying by Americans, Russians and Western Europeans of various political parties who are trying to influence the outcome of a referendum Wednesday on whether the country should remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 33. 1. The photograph is of Kurt Waldheim, former Secretary General of the United Nations, who is now a candidate for the presidency of Austria. It and the documents indicate that Mr. Waldheim was attached to a German Army command in World War II that fought brutal campaigns against Yugoslav partisans and engaged in mass deportations of Greek Jews. 2. There are no parking facilities because a 1980 environmental report said more parking would attract more cars to midtown Manhattan, aggravating air pollution and congestion. 3. A recommendation for a widespread national program to test most working Americans for drug abuse. 4. Horatio Alger Jr. 5. A procedure in which someone who holds something claimed by other parties asks a court to resolve the matter. 6. Metromedia Inc. sold them to the International Broadcasting Company. 7. Mr. Whipple, the director emeritus of the Smithsonian Institution's Astrophysical Observatory, was the first scientist to suggest that cores of comets were largely made up of ice. 12.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN ALIEN-SMUGGLING TRIAL
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the 18th week of the trial of 11 religious leaders accused of smuggling Central American refugees into the United States.

title: British Turn Away Guru Convicted in the U.S.
description: The Britzsh authorities refused to allow an Indian guru, Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, into the country today and held him at Heathrow Airport after he arrived in a private jet.

title: CITY'S JOBLESS RATE RISES TO 8.4% BUT GAINS IN ECONOMY ARE CITED
description: The unemployment rate in New York City jumped more than 1 percentage point to 8.4 percent last month, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: NO. 1 SORE POINT: HOUSING
description: What are people complaining about? Housing, mainly, according to a tabulation of calls received last year by the Brooklyn Borough President's Complaint Unit.

title: L.I. MAN WOUNDED IN ISRAEL
description: A pistol shot grazed the head of an American tourist in the Old City of Jerusalem today, a hospital spokesman said. The tourist, identified as David Blumenfeld, 50 years old, of Great Neck, L.I., was treated at Hadassah Hospital for a scratch from a bullet fragment, a spokesman said.

title: DISSENTING JUDGE
description: A Federal judge criticized Government prosecutors for granting immunity to the major league baseball players who testified against drug dealers in Pittsburgh. Describing the players as ''distributors'' who had shared drugs among themselves, the judge, Donald E. Ziegler, made his remarks before imposing a four-year sentence on Jeffrey Lynn Mosco, a former bartender who had pleaded guilty in January to 3 of 11 counts of distributing cocaine.

title: POWERTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest quarter results include Semiconductor Circuits Inc. from Nov. 6, 1985. The share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split, effective May 15, 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 8, 1986
description: International

title: SL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $19,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the 6 months. c-After income of $145,000 from discontinued operations. Share earnings reflect 4-for-3 stock split paid in February 1986.

title: RICHARDSON CALLED 'RELIEVED'
description: A week and a half after being barred by the National Basketball Association for repeated cocaine use, Micheal Ray Richardson is ''relieved.''

title: REAGAN AND OTHER POLITICAL LEADERS PAY TRIBUTE TO FORMER SENATOR
description: As word spread of the death of former Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday, leaders and former officials from around the country praised the man who President Reagan said last night ''was known for his intellect, for his integrity, for his dedication.''

title: REORGANIZATION OF THE MILITARY COMMAND VIEWED AS CERTAINTY
description: Congressional leaders said today that Congress was virtually certain to adopt a wide-ranging reorganization of the nation's military command structure despite strong opposition from the Pentagon. .

title: Student Held in Shooting
description: The police have charged an unidentified student with attempted murder as a juvenile in the shooting today of a mathematics teacher who had the 14-year-old freshman suspended. The teacher, Norma Cooper, shot in the shoulder with a .357-magnum pistol, was in fair condition at a hospital, the authorities said today. The shooting occurred at Thornridge High School in suburban Chicago.

description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Ecuadorean Commander Refuses Order to Resign
description: The armed forces commander took refuge in an air force base tonight after refusing President Leon Febres Cordero's order to resign for insubordination.

Jacob Javits
description: What a record it was: three and a half decades of service to New York and the nation, and to world diplomacy. Jacob Javits was ever a force to be reckoned with, a Senator to be consulted and courted, an authority on foreign affairs; informed and informative on every major matter of legislative concern.

description: b-Net income.

description: Jacob K. Javits, who began life in a Lower East Side tenement and, as a United States Senator for 24 years, became one of the most respected and influential political figures in the nation, died of a heart attack yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: b-After a loss of $163,337 from discontinued operations.

title: Three Ways to Improve Efficiency in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: TURKOMAN HIALEAH STAR
description: Only 8,997 people turned up on opening day at Hialeah Park this afternoon, but they were treated to a spectacular performance by Turkoman in the Tallahassee Handicap.

title: THE CASE FOR HERNANDEZ
description: When Keith Hernandez returned to Shea Stadium last September after having testified with immunity in the Pittsburgh drug trial to having a few years ago snorted cocaine, he was given a great ovation by the huge Mets crowd.

title: IN CABLE TV-LESS QUEENS, SATELLITE DISH IS KING
description: He is little better than a street-corner pusher in their book, this young man in Queens who makes his own friends pay $5 or $10 to watch St. John's basketball games at his house - and they have to bring the beer and potato chips. He knows who he is.

title: Nashville Cyanide Death Is Ruled a Suicide
description: A Nashville resident who died of cyanide poisoning with a nearly empty container of Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules under his bed committed suicide, a medical examiner ruled today.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $807,000 for the quarter and including a gain of $150,000 on the termination of a pension plan and a tax credit of $212,000, both for the year.

title: AND PHILADELPHIA IN BLOOM
description: In the make-believe world of flower shows, the simulation of spring is a special delight. In Philadelphia, pots of brilliant azaleas, rhododendrons, tulips and daffodils are being tucked into artificial soil and landscaped into gardens to create a full-fledged spring for opening day on Sunday.

title: CURB ON AD WRITE-OFFS IS OPPOSED
description: Some of the strongest corporate supporters of the tax-revision plans offered by President Reagan and passed by the House of Representatives are rallying against a Senate proposal to limit the write-offs businesses can take for the cost of advertising.

title: Violin Recital Canceled
description: The violinist Viktoria Mullova has canceled the recital scheduled for tonight at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue, because of illness. Tickets will be honored instead for a performance by the American violinist Ida Levin, who will play Beethoven's Sonata in G (Op. 96); Bach's Sonata No. 2 in A minor for solo violin, and Bartok's Sonata No. 1. Charles Abramovic will be the piano accompanist.

title: KENTUCKY AVERTS UPSET IN S.E.C.
description: Winston Bennett scored 15 points tonight to lead top-seeded Kentucky to a 61-58 victory over Louisiana State.

title: Harold W. Scott, Ex-Chairman Of New York Stock Exchange
description: Harold W. Scott, a former partner of Dean Witter & Company and past chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, died Monday at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 80 years old.

title: Israeli Ballet Troupe To Perform in Poland
description: An Israeli ballet company, Bat-Dor, will fly to Poland Sunday for six performances in three Polish cities in the first cultural exchange between the two countries since most Eastern European countries broke relations with Israeli during the 1967 Middle East War.

title: T.W.A. CANCELS HALF OF ITS FLIGHTS AS ATTENDANTS STRIKE OVER WAGES
description: Trans World Airlines canceled half its domestic and international flights yesterday and consolidated many others as striking flight attendants walked picket lines at more than 30 airports around the country.

title: DEMOCRAT'S LAMENT
description: In one of his rare news conferences in his Manhattan office, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan worried yesterday over the Democrats' inability to find a major challenger to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: NETS LOSE AND SLIP UNDER .500
description: There was still enough time on the clock. Five seconds. Buck Williams had worked himself free under the basket, and he waited for the inbounds pass from Mickey Johnson. But it never came.

title: Readings for Children At La Mama Festival
description: An afternoon reading of legends and tales from native American, Japanese, Moroccan and Indian writers will be held for children and their families at 3 P.M. tomorrow at La Mama, 74 A East Fourth Street, as part of a arts festival.

title: ALLIED NURSING CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $75,000 on settlement of a contractual agreement.

title: CYBER DIGITAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: In the 1984 quarter and nine months periods the company was in the development stage and had no operating revenue.

title: IMEX MEDICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: South Korean Policemen Storm a Campus
description: Riot police officers firing tear gas stormed the campus of Seoul National University today to disperse student protesters as American politicians arrived to assess chances for greater democracy in South Korea.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results do not include the operations of Cilco Inc. or Richards Medical Co., which were acquired from Rorer Group Inc. on Feb. 28, 1986.

title: New Zealand Pilot on Liner That Sank Gives Up License
description: The New Zealand pilot blamed by a Government inquiry for the sinking Feb. 16 of the Soviet cruise liner Mikhail Lermontov has surrendered his license.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT CHARGE AND RATE RISE ALLOWED
description: The Public Service Commission of Indiana today allowed the Public Service Company of Indiana to write off $1.79 billion in costs from its canceled Marble Hill nuclear plant and increase its rates by a total of 8.2 percent over four years.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. The man in the center of this photograph, taken in 1943 in Yugoslavia, says its recent release, and the release of related documents, were meant to embarrass him at a crucial time. Identify him and explain. 2. The deliberate omission of an important amenity at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, nearing completion after 20 years of planning and a budget that grew to $486 million, is expected to create major problems for prospective exhibitors and visitors. What is missing, and why? 3. Several members of the President's Commission on Organized Crime said they were never shown the final version of a commission report and were surprised and upset with one of its recommendations. What recommendation was it? 4. Unlike the characters in the author's 103 juvenile books, the hero and heroine of ''Mabel Parker; or, The Hidden Treasure,'' an adult novel that was written more than 100 years ago and will be published for the first time this summer, refuse to equate wealth with happiness. Identify the author. 5. The White House will employ a legal procedure, an interpleader, in the dispute over the contents and ownership of the possessions flown to Hawaii last week by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his associates. What is an interpleader? 6. The Harlem Globetrotters and the Ice Capades will share a similar fate.

title: NEW, UNCENSORED EDITION OF ORWELL
description: George Orwell was so extensively censored by his editors that his publishers in both England and the United States have decided to republish his complete works to reflect more accurately what he actually wrote.

title: OFFICIALS CITE INQUIRY BY STATE
description: The executive director of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx, Joseph N. Cintron, was forced to resign yesterday amid reports that he is a target of a state investigation into kickbacks and bribery, according to city officials.

title: NARRANGANSETT
description: The Narragansett Capital Corporation said it had received a cash offer from the Monarch Capital Corporation to acquire the company for $55 a share, or a total of about $121 million.

title: Holding Mayor Goode's Feet to the Fire
description: A whitewash is what critics expected last year when Philadelphia's Mayor, Wilson Goode, appointed a commission to investigate the disastrous police confrontation with the radical group Move. A withering denunciation is what the commission has now produced. Mr. Goode wins credit for appointing independent, credible investigators. But that's the only shred of credit.

title: THE LIABILITY INSURANCE SPIRAL
description: Two years ago, the W. H. Brine Company, a Milford, Mass., manufacturer of lacrosse and soccer equipment, paid $8,000 for $25 million of liability insurance. This year, the best quote they could get was $200,000 for $1 million of insurance - and the company decided not to take it.

title: RUTH SMADBECK
description: Ruth Smadbeck, chairman of the board of the Heckscher Foundation for Children, died Thursday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. She was 86 years old. Mrs. Smadbeck spent more than 50 years with the Heckscher Foundation in Manhattan, which provided a community center and services for disadvantaged children.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Ken Dixon, pitcher, Al Pardo, catcher, and Kelly Paris, infielder, to one-year contracts.

title: NAVRATILOVA TOPS SHRIVER, 6-4, 6-4
description: Top-seeded Martina Navratilova defeated her doubles partner, Pam Shriver, 6-4, 6-4, tonight to advance to the final of the $150,000 Computerland United States Women's Indoor championship.

title: ST. JOHN'S 75; VILLANOVA 64
description: St. John's, taking another step in a remarkable season, moved into the championship game of the Big East Conference tournament last night with a decisive 75-64 victory over Villanova at Madison Square Garden.

title: MUSIC: VLADIMIR ASHKENAZY PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: Those grumbling about the ''warhorse'' nature of Vladimir Ashkenazy's piano program Wednesday night had only to look around them for their answer. Mr. Ashkenazy's deep talent had a great deal to do with all those people who filled Avery Fisher Hall and flowed onto the stage, but the combination of exceedingly familiar pieces - Beethoven's ''Waldstein'' and ''Appassionata'' Sonatas and the Schumann ''Carnaval'' among them - certainly did not scare anyone off.

title: SUN RA AT SWEET BASIL
description: The keyboardist Sun Ra and his Arkestra - a big band with a far-reaching repertory - will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (212-242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: U.S. Aides Deny Soviet Switched Ship-Jumper
description: United States officials insisted today that the Soviet authorities did not switch seamen in the case of a Ukrainian who jumped ship in New Orleans last Oct. 24, was forcibly returned to his vessel and later rejected repeated offers of asylum.

title: WILFRED AMERICAN EDUCAIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $743,000 on the cancellation of indebtedness for the quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $622,000 from the cancellation of a lease.

title: 2 SMALL SLUM VICTIMS NOW PAST MANILA'S AID
description: The political upheaval that occurred up north in Manila is falling at least two lifetimes short of having any effect on the hungry children of Purok No. 6 in the Magsungay slum.

title: LA SALLE COACH RESIGNS
description: He coached the La Salle basketball team to two conference championships in seven years, compiling a 119-87 record, but after a 14-14 record this season Dave (Lefty) Ervin decided it was time to bow out.

title: SIFTING FACTS FROM CHAFF
description: Testimony today before the inquiry into the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger highlighted a growing debate among space agency officials, who in recent days have suggested widely varying theories for the accident.

title: LUCILLE BALL TO RETURN IN FALL SERIES ON ABC
description: Lucille Ball will star in a new series on ABC in the fall, Brandon Stoddard, the president of ABC Entertainment, has announced.

title: ALTEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ON THE ROAD
description: Whoever it was that first said ''this too shall pass'' probably wasn't talking about the United States Football League. Still, just consider all the franchise births, franchise deaths, franchise mergers and franchise shifts since the U.S.F.L. took to the turf three years ago, to say nothing of the way players and coaching staffs have been forced to scurry so as to avoid being knocked down by the revolving door.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a United Press International dispatch in some copies March 1 on the slaying of Prime Minister Olof Palme referred incorrectly to the last European head of government killed in office before Mr. Palme. He was Prime Minister Luis Carrero Blanco of Spain in 1973.

title: HEALTH VIOLATIONS ARE CITED AT CITY SHELTER FOR FAMILIES
description: The City Health Department yesterday cited one of the largest city-run shelters for homeless families for a variety of what it called ''important'' violations, but declined to shut the center because the problems were not ''life threatening.''

title: Aspirin Labels to Warn About Reye Syndrome
description: The Food and Drug Administration today ordered drug companies to put labels on aspirin bottles warning of a possible link between the pain reliever and Reye syndrome, a sometimes fatal childhood illness.

title: HUDSON RIVER WALK
description: Nature lovers in search of early signs of spring may see some willows, skunk cabbage and wintergreen tomorrow on a walk along the Hudson River. The walk, which is free, is sponsored by Washington's Headquarters Museum, Virginia Road, North White Plains, N.Y. Departure is 2 P.M., from the museum. Information and directions: (914) 949-1236.

title: HIGH COURT RULING ON ILLEGAL SEARCHES LEAVES OFFICERS KEY TARGETS IN SUITS
description: In refusing to rule out damage suits against police officers who make unconstitutional arrests and searches under judicial warrants, the Supreme Court provides logical counterweight to its narrowing of other remedies for official lawlessness.

title: REPORT ON MINING CRITICIZES DEBEERS
description: A Government-appointed inquiry in this South African-controlled territory accused the DeBeers diamond concern today of unlawful mining practices on the coastal diamond fields where it has monopoly rights.

title: JUDGE DENIES NEW YORK REQUEST TO SHUT A COPPER PLANT IN JERSEY
description: A Federal judge rejected a request today to shut down a copper-smelting plant in Carteret, N.J., that New York State officials say is spewing potentially carcinogenic chemicals into the air over Staten Island.

title: MARYLAND UPSETS N. CAROLINA IN A.C.C.
description: For the second time in just over two weeks, the Maryland Terrapins were decided underdogs as they faced North Carolina, this time in the opening round of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament. And, as they had done on North Carolina's home court on Feb. 20, the Terrapins overcame a second-half Tar Heel lead to post an impressive victory.

title: RULING IN HAWAII IS AGAINST MARCOS
description: A Federal judge here today rejected arguments by Ferdinand E. Marcos that the United States Customs Service should not make public a list of Philippine currency he and his party brought to Hawaii last month.

title: CAMACHO DEFENSE SET
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho, the undefeated World Boxing Council lightweight champion, will defend his title against the former champion, Edwin Rosario, in a 12-round bout at Madison Square Garden June 13, according to the promoter, Don King. The card will include a 10-round bout between Mike Tyson, the young heavyweight sensation who is the W.B.C.'s 10th-ranked contender, and an an opponent to be named later.

title: COM-TEK RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CELLULAR TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JOHNSON'S WIDOW LOSES JERSEY SUIT
description: A state judge today dismissed a lawsuit filed by the widow of the pharmaceutical heir J. Seward Johnson Sr. that had sought to wrest control of her husband's favorite charities from her stepson.

title: Florida Youth, 19, Begins Job As a Small-Town Police Chief
description: Robert C. Hendry, a 19-year-old college student, began his duties today as police chief of this small town in northwestern Florida, where eight men have held the office in less than four years.

title: U.S. Limits the Size of Signs Displayed in Lafayette Park
description: New rules will limit uncarried protest signs in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House, to 4 feet by 4 feet, but there is no limit on what a demonstrator may carry.

title: Historic Hotel Ends 82-Year Philadelphia Run
description: Without fanfare or ceremony, the historic Bellevue Stratford Hotel closed its doors today after its last two guests checked out.

title: In China, the Year - and Claws - of the Tiger
description: During a mass public sentencing in Peking in January, a deputy mayor said, ''In the Year of the Tiger, all criminals will face heavy and rapid punishment.'' His words frighteningly echoed the anticrime drive of autumn 1983, when a call for ''heavy and rapid punishment'' led to the executions of more than 5,000 people, one for stealing six wristwatches.

title: Memorial for Palme Held in Washington
description: Olof Palme, the Swedish Prime Minister who was shot dead a week ago, was honored at a memorial service today by officials and diplomats as well as prominent and ordinary Americans.

title: Robert Strawbridge Jr. Dies; Former Polo Star and Official
description: Robert E. Strawbridge Jr., one of the nation's leading polo players in the 1920's and 1930's and a longtime official of the sport, died Thursday at his farm in Chatham, Pa. He was 89 years old and had suffered a series of strokes in recent weeks.

title: WITHERSPOON'S PLEA
description: Tim Witherspoon, who was found to have traces of marijuana in his system the night he won the World Boxing Association heavyweight title from Tony Tubbs in Atlanta Jan. 17, told a W.B.A. disciplinary hearing that he should not be penalized for making ''one little mistake.'' Asserting that he was ''not a criminal,'' Witherspoon told the W.B.A. counsel, James Binns: ''All my life I tried to make good, and everybody makes a mistake.'' Binns, who conducted the hearing in Philadelphia, said other W.B.A. officials would review the transcript and decide later whether to strip Witherspoon of his title.

title: Lower Interest / Common Interest
description: Washington, Bonn and Tokyo have just given the world economy the right signal at the right moment. Their simultaneous reduction of official interest rates offers a rare example of timely collaboration.

title: JAZZ: DECODING SOCIETY AT SOUNDS OF BRAZIL
description: The latest version of Ronald Shannon Jackson's Decoding Society, which performed Thursday at Sounds of Brazil, recalls the band he used to play drums for - Ornette Coleman's Prime Time. Like Mr. Coleman's group, the Decoding Society now includes a lone saxophonist, Eric Person, plus two electric-bassists, Melvin Gibbs and Reginald Washington, and two guitarists, Vernon Reid and Cary De Negris.

title: EWING WATCHES KNICKS LOSE
description: The Knicks could wander into some arenas without Patrick Ewing and still expect to make the game exciting - perhaps even win - because of their consistently strong defense and methodical playing style. But Boston Garden isn't one of those arenas.

title: IU INTERNATIONAL PLANS UNIT CUTS
description: The IU International Corporation said it would sell most of its Hawaiian agribusiness unit, C. Brewer & Company, to a management group through a leveraged buyout. It is also selling one of its distribution services units, Unijax, to the Paper Corporation of America, a subsidiary of the Alco Standard Corporation.

title: FLXIBLE OFFERS TO BUY BACK FAULTY BUSES FROM THE CITY
description: The company that built the problem-plagued Grumman Flxible buses has offered to buy them back, and the New York City Transit Authority is seeking approval to sell them, New York City and State officials said yesterday.

title: The Nation's No. 1 Priority
description: To protect ourselves from budgetary chaos, we have sent Generals Gramm, Rudman and Hollings charging off to stiffen the spine of our Congressional troops. To deal with a lingering taxpayer revolt, our Commander in Chief is attempting to disarm the insurrection with tax reform.

title: Elika L. Sosnick, M. F. Rosenbaum Are Wed in West
description: Elika Lisa Sosnick and Michael Francis Rosenbaum were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco by Rabbi Robert Kirschner. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Sosnick of Davis, Calif.

title: Engineering Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: Q AND A
description: Overseas Tax Deferral Question: If I buy my new primary residence in a country other than the United States, am I still eligible for the deferral on capital-gains tax on the profit from the sale of the previous home? . . . E. R., Butler, N.J. Answer: Yes. Section 1034 of the Internal Revenue Code does not impose limitations on the location of the principal residence, according to Larry Batdorf, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service in Washington, D.C. For a copy of Publication 54, ''Tax Guide for U.S. Citizens Aboard,'' or Publication 523, ''Tax Information on Selling Your Home,'' write: Forms Distribution Center, Box 25866, Richmond, Va. 23260. Rent-Increase Exemptions Question: If an elderly tenant qualifies for the senior citizens' rent-increase exemption, does the landlord get any subsidy? . . . M. T., Staten Island Answer: Yes. The landlord receives a tax-abatement credit equivalent to the rent exemption that can be applied against city real-estate taxes, according to Barrington Wright, assistant commissioner in the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. For more information, call 566-5541. Rowhouses With a Past Question: What can you tell me about the rowhouses at 251, 253 and 255 West 70th Street? . . . L. S., Manhattan Answer: They were built in 1885-86 by Stanton Riker and designed by W. H. Youngs in a form of the Queen Anne style used by speculative builders, which at least The New York Times/Jack Manning one critic called the ''reign of terror'' and others called ''wild works,'' according to Christopher Gray, an architecture historian. Mr. Gray said they were a reaction to the monotony of simpler brownstones.

title: MARXIST'S GREAT LEAP: CAPTIVITIY TO CELEBRITY
description: They call him Joma, and women bring handkerchiefs or scraps of paper to him for his autograph.

title: On Language; The Caplet Solution
description: QUICK, WHAT'S A caplet?

title: A TIME OF WORRY FOR MILFORD'S SHELLFISHERMEN
description: IT was a cold morning at Milford Harbor, not exactly weather for swimming, but just fine for catching oysters.

title: LADY KNIGHTS ON LONG RUN TO TOP
description: ON the upper level in the virtually empty West Virginia University Coliseum, 12 young women completed a workout, chugging in single file, forming a scarlet and white train. There have been no free rides for the Rutgers women's basketball team this season. That was established last October, when Coach Theresa Grentz required the players to awake before dawn to run laps on the university track to earn new warm-up uniforms and sneakers for the season.

title: A VIEW OF PATERSON'S PAST
description: CEDAR LAWN, in the southeast corner of Paterson, is a beautiful example of the Victorian garden cemetery. It was dedicated in 1867, having been laid out by Gen. Edbert L. Viele, an expert topographical and landscape engineer.

title: A FRENCH CAMPAIGN GETS LOW RATINGS
description: Amid the campaign rhetoric that has washed over this country for the last few weeks, the results of one poll stood out, conveying a serious message for what is commonly, and with some derision, known as the political class. The poll, published in the rightist newspaper Le Figaro, asked whether the legislative election next Sunday would make a difference in French daily life or the standard of living. Fully 64 percent of the replies were ''no.''

title: Valerie J. Edinger To Wed in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles B. Edinger of Dix Hills and Montauk, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Valerie Jean Edinger to Frederick Jordan Knecht, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Knecht of Bedford, Mass. The wedding is planned for August.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SAM SHEPARD: The Life and Work of an American Dreamer. By Ellen Oumano. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) The strongest impression that emerges from Ellen Oumano's study of Sam Shepard is that of a man with a remarkably straightforward artistic impulse, a simple, urgent need to write.

title: HAGLER CONQUERS MADISON AVENUE
description: NOT long after he beat Tommy Hearns last April in three rounds of sustained violence, Marvelous Marvin Hagler appeared before his public again, this time in more congenial circumstances.

title: FAST AT BROWN ENDING AFTER SUSPENSION ORDER
description: Four students protesting Brown University's investments in businesses doing business in South Africa halted a nine-day fast today after their temporary suspension from the school.

title: THE MELLON BANK'S FALL FROM GRACE
description: EACH day as Andrew Mellon had his hair trimmed in the anteroom outside his second-floor office, he would peer down into the marble lobby of the Pittsburgh bank his father had founded. When an important customer walked in, he would jump out of his chair, run down a flight of stairs and greet the visitor.

title: 3 Large Old Brass Mill Sites Up for Sale
description: THREE sizable and significant parcels of land - two in downtown Waterbury and a third in New Milford - along with vacant mill buildings already on these sites -have just been placed on the market.

title: IN OPERA, BALLET'S AN EQUAL
description: THE New Jersey State Opera, which is celebrating its 20th anniversary by offering three operas this season, will present the second at Symphony Hall here next Sunday.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Dwight Gooden is the scheduled starter for the Mets. (Television -Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami, 1:35 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Phoenix Suns, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1 P.M. (Radio - WNBC 660, 1 P.M.) Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago, 1 P.M. (Radio - WPAT 930, 12:50 P.M.) #76ers vs. Indiana Pacers, at Philadelphia, 1 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Atlantic Coast Conference championship, at Greensboro, N.C. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. live and ESPN, midnight tape). Big Eight Conference championship, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - MSG, 1:30 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Brackets, Seedings and Pairings, at Kansas City, Mo. (Television - Channel 2, 6 P.M.) Boxing Donald Curry, champion, vs. Eduardo Rodriguez, 15 rounds, for World Boxing Association welterweight championship, at Fort Worth, Tex. Curry has a 24-0 record with 18 knockouts, and Rodriguez is 20-1 with 13 knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 5 P.M.) Pernell Whitaker vs. John Montes, 10 rounds, lightweights, at Hampton, Va. (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M.) John Collins, champion, vs. Robbie Sims, 12 rounds, for the United States Boxing Association middleweight title, at Las Vegas. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) Devils vs. Sabres, at Buffalo, 7:05 P.M. The Sabres have a 21-game streak of domination of the Devils (18-0-3).

title: BUSH IS IN PORTUGAL TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF ITS PRESIDENT
description: Vice President Bush arrived in Lisbon today to attend the inauguration of the Socialist leader Mario Soares as President.

title: FREED FROM CODE SHACKLES, MOVIES STILL LIMP ALONG
description: Near the end of John Huston's ''Prizzi's Honor,'' an R-rated satirical melodrama and one of the best films of 1985, a husband and wife, madly in love with each other but career rivals, square off in their bedroom, she with a gun, he with a knife, their love being no match for their cupidity. In the film's final moment, the survivor of that lethal bedroom scene faces the future afresh, unencumbered by guilt but with a new mate and a guaranteed bankroll. Though it has its ups and downs, says ''Prizzi's Honor,'' life in the underworld can be profitable as well as beautiful.

title: BATTLE-WEARY CONTRAS AWAIT REINFORCEMENTS
description: AS President Reagan leaned on Congress last week to back increased American involvement in the guerrilla war in Nicaragua, the insurgent army the Administration hopes will topple the commandantes in Managua languished in Honduras, apparently no longer a match for the Sandinista troops.

title: TEACHER'S PET COURSE
description: WHEN Gwen Murphy, a retired teacher, arrived for her first video-production workshop in Yorktown recently, she was astonished to discover the class was being conducted in her old classroom.

title: SURREALISTIC VIEWS IN PLAY BY SHEPARD
description: FOR all his newfound fame, Sam Shepard remains enigmatic as a playwright and elusive as a personality. ''True West,'' however, is one of his most accessible and oft-performed works. Even so, you can make of it what you will, for the play is as wide open as the spaces - the country and the desert - with which Mr. Shepard is so consumed thematically.

title: VILLANOVA RUNNER FOLLOWS FATHER'S PATH
description: Charles Lamont Jenkins Jr. is a chip off the old block in more ways than one.

title: Polling Uproar In Delaware Town
description: TOWN Council elections in Felton, Del., population 547, usually draw few candidates and little interest beyond the town limits.

title: DRUG TESTS, LAWSUITS ON N.F.L. AGENDA
description: Drug testing, three antitrust lawsuits and the progress of antitrust legislation in Congress are among the critical issues facing National Football League owners and executives as they begin their annual spring meetings today in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: Island Ash Fills: Selecting a Site
description: The article on ash fills on Long Island on Jan. 26 [ ''Dispute Over Ash Fill Intensifies'' ] omitted a major point.

title: THERE ARE THOSE WHO DON'T CARE
description: WITH whom shall I quarrel, I've asked myself time and again. With my cousin who brought

title: TRIAL SET IN SUIT OVER 7 CANCER CASES
description: The families of seven children, victims of cancer that their parents say was caused by industrial pollution of drinking water, are suing two major corporations for damages in a case that is to go to trial Monday in Federal District Court in Boston.

title: Defending 'Soaps'
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: A BETTER WAY WITH GARBAGE SANDY ABRILZ of Bay Shore is making Long Island garbage history. But, she says, ''Please don't make me famous for that.''

title: MANHATTAN CENTER, LINCOLN GAIN FINAL
description: Stan Dinner complained after Manhattan Center's Class A Public Schools Athletic League semifinal against August Martin yesterday at St. John's Alumni Hall. Poor shooting, poor ballhandling, lack of inspiration, said the coach. But his Manhattan Center team won, 51-47, to advance to Saturday's final against Lincoln, which defeated Boys and Girls (17-6), 83-71, in the other semifinal.

title: MEMORIES CROWD OLD BROWN COUCH IN A NEW HOME WITH ONE OCCUPANT
description: LATELY I've been especially appreciating the big brown couch that sits in my otherwise bare living room. It hugs the far wall, looking at once grand because of its size and homey because of its age. It can seat six people comfortably, but these days it usually seats one. For I live alone, and that couch came from a household of eight.

title: Gretchen E. Freeman to Marry Alan H. Silverman
description: Gretchen Elizabeth Freeman, an administrator of the Chase Manhattan Bank art collection, and Alan H. Silverman, the vice president, general counsel and director of administration for Post-Newsweek Cable in Bloomfield, Mich., are planning to be married May 25. The announcement was made by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Wroe Freeman 3d, of Pine Bluff, Ark.

title: OJEDA IS UNSTEADY
description: The Mets and the St. Louis Cardinals met today for the first time since last October, but nothing was at stake this time. And it's a good thing for the Mets that it wasn't, because the Cardinals flashed some of their pennant pizzazz and overpowered them, 10-2.

title: Anne Edmondson Becomes the Bride Of Coe Kerr 3d, Brokerage Executive
description: Anne Keresey Edmondson was married yesterday to E. Coe Kerr 3d of Mill Neck, L.I., by the Rev. Dr. Earle W. Pratt Jr. at the Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mahlon William Edmondson of Lawrence, L.I. Mr. Kerr is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Kerr Jr. of Brookville, L.I.

title: Paula Bagger to Wed James Vradelis
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Bagger of Westfield, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Paula Marie Bagger, to James Theodore Vradelis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Vradelis of Oakwood, Ohio.

title: RATTLING SABERS FOR FENCING
description: ''I THINK people would be fascinated to see two people dueling in real life, as contrasted to choreographed dueling in a movie,'' said Michael Lofton of Hempstead. ''Modern fencing has a lot to offer. It's a beautiful sport to watch.''

title: BRAZIL IS KEEPING ITS HEAD ABOVE THE RED INK
description: IMPRESSED by Argentina's success in using ''shock'' treatment to end double-digit and triple-digit inflation, Brazil has prescribed the same medicine for its own overheated economy. President Jose Sarney insists, however, that the measures he announced 10 days ago ''are not a copy of any program in any other country.''

title: Laura Zabriskie To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. and Mrs. George Zabriskie of Larchmont, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Laura Tyler Zabriskie to Dr. David Edward Catlin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Catlin of Bozeman, Mont. The wedding is planned for June 21.

title: Could It Happen Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPLORING FRANCE'S HEARTLAND
description: On my last trip to France I decided to have a good look at the Gallic heartland. A cluster of dots on a map of central France represented places - Bourges, Nevers, Moulins, among others - that I had often driven through without stopping on the way to and from the Champs-Elysees.

title: MASSACHUSETTS WEIGHS TRASH-TO-ENERGY PLAN
description: Massachusetts officials are proceeding with an aggressive plan to construct municipal trash-to-energy incinerators, but environmentalist critics warn that the facilities can emit dangerous pollutants.

title: TWO HOMES REPORTED LEASED BY MARCOSES
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos has found at least a temporary new home here in the hills overlooking Honolulu, sources in the real estate business said today.

title: An Honor Scorned
description: Loyal Democrats who get mass-mailed Republican appeals for funds often just throw them away. But occasionally a letter fired scattershot at an upper-income mailing list makes someone angry.

title: DANCE: NOHO THEATER
description: THE Noho Theater Group of Kyoto presented an informal evening of Noh music and dance on Wednesday that was an enjoyable blending of cultural influences. Its lack of theatrical adornment offered a clear view of the company's work and some Japanese music and dance traditions, enhanced by informative commentary from Richard Emmert.

title: ALMOND KNOCKING, BASS BREEDING AND OTHER LITERARY PURSUITS
description: SOMETHING there is about playing Santa Claus for $5 an hour a few months before one's fifth book is to be published that turns a fellow's mind to the cosmic view.

title: BLACK WOMEN EXCHANGE VIEWS OF CORPORATE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEANITA McCLAIN, a young woman who grew up on Chicago's impoverished South Side, was at the age of 32 the first black to become a member of The Chicago Tribune's editorial board. She was also named by Glamour magazine as one of the 10 most outstanding working women in the country.

title: SMITH PULLED IN ISLANDER LOSS
description: The Islanders could not do what they had predicted they would do: play as an indivisible unit and perform with playoff fervor.

title: MEETINGS TO FOCUS ON SCHOOL TRUANCY
description: ATTENDANCE policies that reduce truancy through the collaboration of school and community services are the subject of two conferences this week.

title: IT'S POTHOLE TIME AGAIN
description: LATE-WINTER potholes - as sure a sign of spring as returning robins - may bring smiles to purveyors of wheel covers and aligners of front ends, but they are the bane of motorists, who risk life and limb dodging the ever-deepening holes in the road.

title: Frances Durkin Plans To Marry T. S. Spruth
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Durkin of Bedford, N.Y., and New York City have announced the engagement of their daughter Frances Xavier Durkin to Thomas Stevens Spruth, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Spruth of Mendham, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss Durkin, a former second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank in Caracas, Venezuela, is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Idaho State University in Boise.

title: AN OCTOGENARIAN'S CRUSH
description: IN THE DARK By R. M. Lamming. 230 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. Love, rarely a thing we can find by chasing it down, often comes from unexpected places; most often it sneaks up on our blind side. Arnold Lawson, age 84 and in surprisingly good health, has lived for 20 years with his taciturn but devoted housekeeper and his library of thousands of rare and scholarly books. He sees himself as a recluse and wants only to read his beloved books and be waited on by his hated housekeeper. His favorite pastime is berating her as she silently goes about the business of caring for him. ''She achieved the look of a perfect drudge - and an energetic one at that, the sort who glories in her slavery. Ancient Rome was probably full of them: offer them freedom, and they would purse up their lips at the insult.''

title: 90 SCIENTISTS WIN RESEARCH GRANTS
description: Ninety young scientists have been awarded $25,000 Sloan Research Fellowships under one of the oldest fellowship programs in the United States.

title: CHIEF OF POLICE IN RYE HONORED
description: WHEN Wilf Laidlaw, chief inspector of England's Northumbria constabulary, first appeared in full-dress uniform on foot patrol in Rye a few years ago, residents were astonished. ''People were bumping into walls,'' Detective Gene Berry, a member of the local police force, recalled with a chuckle. By the time the chief inspector of Scotland Yard paid a visit recently, residents had become almost nonchalant.

title: Commuters' Woes A Continuing Problem
description: Efforts to improve commuter bus service into New York City are being frustrated by morning rush-hour delays of 15 to 30 minutes entering the special Lincoln Tunnel bus lane.

title: GREENWICH VILLAGE MON AMOUR
description: STAIRWAY C By Elvire Murail. Translated by M. L. Linden. 192 pp. New York: A Bard Book/Avon Books. Paper, $3.95. MY father told me about French women. ''No matter how homely, no matter how poor, the one thing they all have is style. They can walk down the street in the most ordinary dress and look like they just stepped out of Christian Dior. They do it with a touch of perfume, a scarf at the neck.''

title: U.S. STUDY FAVORS FAMILY PLANNING
description: Most developing countries would benefit economically from a lower rate of population growth, a study by the National Research Council says.

title: GENTLE PERSUASION AT GENERAL DYNAMICS
description: AS his B-24 bomber tumbled from the sky over Germany 42 years ago, pilot Stanley C. Pace leaped through a wall of flames and plunged from the bomb bay, parachuting to the ground. He spent months recovering from his burns in a German hospital and was subsequently shipped off to a prison camp, but he survived the ordeal.

title: WILLIAMS LOSES APPEAL
description: John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball star, lost a last-ditch chance to avoid a new trial on sports bribery charges. The Louisiana Supreme Court, upholding an appellate court decision, ruled, 4-3, that in declaring a mistrial, the original trial judge, Alvin Oser, had erred in barring further prosecution of Williams.

title: OPERA AS CONVERSATION IS REALLY NOT ENOUGH
description: Because there is some rough, slouching beast in us that prefers simple explanations to complicated ones, we sometimes forget that history is a tangle of cross-purposes, not a logical, linear march from then to now. There is no one straight road, for instance, leading from opera's birth to opera in its present perilous state. At any one moment in the past, important composers can be found riding off in all directions, some intent on inventing the music of the future, certainly, or being part of it, but others in pursuit of goals that historians generally find less interesting, such as making a living, being an entertainer, stirring up patriotic sentiments, satisfying patrons or simply following the mysterious impulse to create.

title: IS IT BROKE? SHOULD WE FIX IT?
description: CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM AND EFFECTIVE GOVERNMENT By James L. Sundquist. 262 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $26.95. Paper, $9.95. THE bicentennial of the American Constitution takes place in 1987. Before the party begins though, it is legitimate to ask just which Constitution we will be celebrating. There is the original Constitution, which set out the powers and duties of the separate branches of the Federal Government, structuring our political institutions. There also is the document, cited frequently by many contemporary legal scholars and some jurists as the basis for judicial activism, that might accurately be described as the phantom Constitution, setting forth what ought to be the laws of the land. And then there is the unwritten Constitution, that body of arrangements and agreements subject to adaptation from time to time to meet changing circumstances, which enables the original Constitution to endure with little alteration over the years.

title: A BIRD IN THE HAND
description: Bent Larsen once said,''If I have the chance to take the opponent's queen on the move or to mate in five, I take the queen and mate later.''

title: AGENCY MOVES AGAINST CHEMICAL IN PAINT STRIPPERS
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has moved to designate methylene chloride, which is widely used in paint strippers and aerosol paint sprays, as a hazardous substance.

title: Sponsor Suit on No-Buy Pledges Allowed
description: TENANT association leaders engaged in a bitter fight over the conversion into a cooperative of a building on lower Fifth Avenue may be sued for harassment, a justice in State Supreme Court in Manhattan has ruled.

title: HOW TO LOOK AT AN ENGLISH VILLAGE
description: ''The next Augustan age will dawn on the other side of the Atlantic,'' prophesied Horace Walpole to his friend Horace Mann in 1774. ''At last some curious traveller . . . will visit England and give a description of the ruins of St. Paul's, like the editions of Balbec and Palmyra.'' Well, there are as yet no St. Paul's ruins these two centuries on, although millions of annually touring feet are shaking it to bits; but American visiting of Britain on what might be called intensive cultural terms is certainly today's equivalent of the two Horaces' information-gathering wanderings through Europe.

title: Another Number in the Parking Bureau Follies
description: To the Editor:

title: Upper Upper West Side Attracting New Settlers
description: THE West 96th Street barrier is falling.

title: PHILIPPINE CHURCH: POWER AND HEALING SETH MYDANS
description: WHEN the Archbishop of Manila, Jaime Cardinal Sin, raised his hand in benediction at a huge outdoor thanksgiving mass last Sunday in honor of the new President, Corazon C. Aquino, his thumb and index finger seemed almost automatically to form the ''L'' sign that was her campaign symbol.

title: THE PAST IS PRESENT
description: CHILDREN, AS EVERY PARENT KNOWS, ARE IMPATIENT; THEY want what is new right now. This spring and summer, what is new is also old, with many of the latest children's fashions taking their inspiration from a mother's or grandmother's closet.

title: HOW TO DETECT A PRIME TAKEOVER TARGET
description: UNTIL recently, predicting merger and takeover activity was a bit like predicting earthquakes - interesting but nothing you would place much faith in. This may be changing, though, with the emergence of an apparently dominant cause of current takeover activity -the tension between managers and shareholders over the payout of free cash flow. By identifying the elements in this conflict we can more easily define the industries that are ripe for mergers.

title: Convicted Official Re-elected
description: days after she was sentenced for helping cultivate 1,600 marijuana plants, the Town Clerk was re-elected to the $1,000-a-year post by six votes on Town Meeting Day. The clerk, Anna Marie Tonzini, 33 years old, received a 90-day suspended sentence Feb. 27. After her re-election Tuesday, she said, ''It is encouraging the townspeople had faith in me.''

title: TOPICS
description: THE oil glut won't last. Optimists predict fuel shortages by the end of the century; realists, by the end of the decade, and for pessimists it is already too late.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 9, 1986
description: International

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: YOUTHFUL PLAYERS With all the effort that goes into music lessons, it doesn't hurt to show how perfect practice can make young musicians. And that's exactly what's happening this week as three of the Island's youth ensembles play Show and Tell. Under Paul Rudoff's baton, the Training Orchestra takes the stage first, today at 3 P.M. at Bethpage High School, on Cherry Street, in a free concert featuring Schubert's Symphony in C major and Mozart's Flute Concerto in D major, with Alyson Hubbard as flute soloist.

title: Score 1 for Understatement
description: The invitation to the fund-raising reception that Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri is giving Wednesday for his re-election campaign may be the most restrained pitch for a $500 contribution in the long history of such affairs. The card says only that the cocktail party will honor the Congressman as he ''brings St. Louis to Washington.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: WOMEN'S History Week may have officially ended yesterday with International Women's Day, but its spirit lives on at Cleveland Elementary School in Englewood.

title: WESTERN GOVERNMENTS GIVE POLAND RELIEF ON DEBT
description: Western governments have agreed to give Poland more favorable repayment terms on $1.7 billion in debt, according to diplomats here.

title: POLL IN EUROPE FINDS FEW SUPPORT A U.S. MILITARY REPLY TO TERRORISM
description: People in France, Britain and West Germany say they believe American military action against international terrorism would only make the problem worse, even though they are dissatisfied with their own Governments' handling of the problem, a New York Times Poll shows.

title: A TALENT IS A TERRIBLE THING TO WASTE
description: MICHEAL RAY RICHARDSON of the New Jersey Nets was banned late last month from the National Basketball Association for drug use. Under the rules of the N.B.A. antidrug policy that was collectively bargained between the Players Association and the owners, a player receives two chances at rehabilitation before being subjected to the penalty of the permanent ban.

title: RED BANK 'KITCHEN' EASES PLIGHT OF THE POOR
description: THE day that Lunch Break, a soup kitchen here, opened, seven destitute people were fed in the basement of St. Thomas Episcopal Church. Now, approaching its third anniversary, it serves 10 times as many hungry.

title: NOISE EVOKES MODERN CHAOS FOR A BAND
description: What's the essence of rock and roll? That's a question the Jesus and Mary Chain - a British band whose first album, ''Psychocandy,'' has just been released in the United States (Reprise 9 25383-1, also available on cassette), and which will perform Saturday at the Ritz - would be pleased to have the world consider.

title: NAVRATILOVA TAKES U.S. INDOOR TITLE
description: Perhaps the majority of Martina Navratilova's opponents can no longer be regarded simply as sparring partners who measure success against her in terms of how long the matches last and how many games they win. Even Miss Navratilova noted that a significant number of fans root for her now, sensing perhaps the end of the era of her domination. She still usually wins, of course, but on occasion, tennis can be a trying experience.

title: A TOUGH TIME FOR FED WATCHERS
description: EVEN in the most placid of times, what goes on at the Federal Reserve's stately Constitution Avenue headquarters is the subject of intense, if often arcane, debate. The Fed and the markets in which it moves are scrutinized by what must be the world's highest-paid fraternity of professional students who, much like Kremlinologists, examine every action - often every opaque word -and then set about arguing the meaning and the merits.

title: TINKER'S PRIME TIME AT NBC
description: IT WAS MORE LIKE A LOVE-in than a press conference. To introduce its new television season and spotlight some of its stars, NBC in January convened several dozen out-of-town reporters at a Los Angeles hotel. The press tour, an event organized twice a year by each of the networks, is usually a time to put some tough questions to television executives - and Grant A. Tinker, NBC's chairman, fielded earnest queries about troubled shows and the recent announcement that General Electric would take over NBC's corporate parent, RCA. But for most of his stint behind the podium, Tinker, immaculate in a yellow sweater, khakis and a suede jacket, graciously accepted praise for the network's ascent to the top. NBC's main problem, he suggested, was that it wouldn't receive special treatment as the underdog anymore. ''We're not that far ahead,'' he said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Swarthmore, Pa., in some copies last Sunday on a decision by Swarthmore College's board of managers to sell the school's investments in companies operating in South Africa omitted a condition of the sale. The school said it would sell the stock if the action is financially prudent.

title: On the TV Front
description: The debate over United States involvement in Central America is going public in a big way, with both sides struggling to win the hearts and minds of Americans with television blitzes. The National Conservative Political Action Committee says it will spend $1.5 million on a campaign to sell Americans on aid to the rebels in Nicaragua.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ZARATHUSTRA'S SISTER: The Case of Elisabeth and Friedrich Nietzsche, by H. F. Peters. (Markus Wiener, $9.95.) In 1893 the widowed sister of Friedrich Nietzsche devoted herself to the care of her deranged and bedridden brother. She gained control of his letters and manuscripts, wrote a three-volume biography of him, established the Nietzsche Archives, manipulated the dissemination of his ideas and, long after Nietzsche's death, befriended Hitler and Mussolini and sought Nazi patronage of her work. In The Book Review in 1977, Martin Green called the story ''a real tragicomedy of the intellectual life'' and found H. F. Peters's account scholarly and workmanlike. A CANTICLE FOR LEIBOWITZ, by Walter M. Miller Jr. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $6.95.) The world, in this fantasy, has been destroyed centuries earlier in a nuclear holocaust and quasi-medieval mankind, armed with the dimly understood remnants of 20th-century science, appears doomed to make the same mistake again. Reviewers in 1960 called Walter M. Miller Jr.'s vision of the future as a repetition of the past ''altogether exceptional'' and ''a remarkable science-fiction novel that soars above the level of mere science fiction into the realm of satire, parable, allegory and philosophy.'' ORIGINAL LETTERS FROM INDIA (1779-1815), by Eliza Fay, edited by E. M. Forster. (Hogarth Press, $6.95.) This collection of letters by Eliza Fay, an Englishwoman who sailed for Calcutta with her lawyer husband in 1779, was originally published in 1817 and reissued in 1925 with notes by E. M. Forster. Reviewers in 1925 said ''the charm of her style consists in its incongruities of detail. . . . She is conventional and unexpected, formal and suddenly forthright.''

title: FALLING DEBRIS FORCES CLOSING OF SECTION OF THE F.D.R. DRIVE
description: Southbound traffic along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between East 92d and East 72d Streets was halted yesterday for almost five hours because of falling bricks and debris from an underpass near East 82d Street.

title: JOHN HUGHES: HIS MOVIES SPEAK TO TEEN-AGERS
description: The high-tech austerity of the office that the film maker John Hughes occupies at Paramount Pictures here is relieved only by a single, framed sketch on one wall. In the drawing, from The New Yorker, one of the cartoonist James Stevenson's stolid, middle-aged couples approach a movie theater box office and grumpily ask the cashier, ''How old are the people in this picture?''

title: INVITING THE DUMPING OF UNSAFE DRUGS
description: THE House and Senate are considering legislation that would relax a longstanding rule forbidding the export of drugs not yet proved safe for Americans. The legislation is winning considerable bipartisan support, largely for economic reasons advanced by the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries. But the evidence is thin to justify such a major reversal in policy.

title: ARCTIC AIR SETS RECORDS IN 25 NORTHEAST CITIES
description: Frigid arctic air and gusty winds froze the Northeast today, breaking century-old records with spring just 12 days away.

title: ROLE MODELS, BUT NOT GOOD MODELS
description: MY first reaction to some of the contemporary statistics about teen-age pregnancy is incredulity. I simply find the numbers too difficult to comprehend.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Hanover, N.H. on Jan. 19 gave an incorrect telephone number for the Lyme Inn in Lyme, N.H. The number is 603-795-2222.

title: DERELICT ALCOHOLICS HARD PEOPLE TO HELP
description: THE police used to cart them off to the ''drunk tank.'' Now Connecticut's unruly street alcoholics land in a hospital emergency room - much to the chagrin of the hospitals, which are telling the state these people belong somewhere else.

title: WHITE HOUSE MOVE ANGERS CAPE COD
description: When the Cape Cod National Seashore was proposed in 1959, there was widespread opposition from towns on the lower Cape whose residents feared losing their freedom to use the beaches and inshore waters.

title: TEAM OWNERS RESPONSIBLE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE YOUNG HEMINGWAY. By Michael Reynolds. (Basil Blackwell, $19.95.) In the recent spate of Hemingway books and biographies, Michael Reynolds's study of Hemingway from his early youth to the time just before his expatriate years is a welcome addition.

title: Condominiums Are Approved For Island Fort in Maine Bay
description: The first condominium project on an island in Casco Bay has won the unanimous approval of the city's Planning Board after a two-year review marked by emotional exchanges between islanders and developers.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A SCIENTIST UPDATES 'OTHELLO'
description: THERE are times, Mirta T. Mulhare said, that she feels ''positively schizo - you know, caught between my scientific curiosity and my artistic inspirations.''

title: Dana A. Kotcher Is Married on L.I.
description: Dana Anne Kotcher and Dr. Lawrence T. Choy were married yesterday at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club in Manhasset, L.I., by Rabbi Eugene Lipsey. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Kotcher of Manhasset.

title: MAN VS. CROW: YOU HAVE TO TALK THEIR LANGUAGE
description: MY TINY farm crowds in close to my many-windowed house. I am either working on the farm or looking at it every day and every night for most of the year. Of course, I inevitably see the birds, the beasts, the insects, the worms and the plant diseases that are out there, too, feasting in what they plainly regard as their private supermarket and what I regard as my source of cash income.

title: FAMILY IN STORRS FEELS SHIFT IN MANILA
description: WHEN Delia Aguilar received word early one morning in August 1984 that her sister, Mila, had been imprisoned in the Philippines, she immediately began making telephone calls.

title: IN SPANISH VOTE, THE ISOLATIONIST URGE
description: A referendum Wednesday on whether Spain should quit the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has split the nation over the fundamental question of its national identity.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AS SOON AS IT RAINS. By Kaylie Jones. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Academic indecision, a difficult love, a semester abroad - these are familiar clippings from a college diary.

title: TWO DREAMERS AWAKE TO A DOGFIGHT
description: DONALD C. BURR must have had powerfully mixed feelings when he heard about Texas Air Corporation's seemingly successful $600 million bid for Eastern Air Lines Inc.

title: Lisa Kaye to Wed James J. Fuld Jr.
description: Lisa Jill Kaye and James J. Fuld Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fuld of New York, plan to be married May 17, according to an announcement by the future bride's mother, Jeanne Kaye of New York.

title: STRICTER TREE LAW WEIGHED
description: ''EVERY time a chain saw starts up, my phone starts ringing,'' Robert G. Lustyik, a Tarrytown Village Trustee and professional arborist, said - and then he added, cheerfully, that ''it's going to get worse.''

title: Kirby Delany Wed to J. L. Williams 3d
description: Kirby Delany, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Forbes Delany of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Joseph L. Williams 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams Jr. of Greenwich. The Rev. Richard H. Stearns performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Wendy Loucks to Marry
description: Wendy L. Loucks and Michael A. Schutzer will be married in May, the parents of the bride-to-be, the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Loucks of East Brunswick, N.J., have announced. Miss Loucks graduated from Muhlenberg College and received a master's degree in gerontology from the University of Southern California. Mr. Schutzer, a graduate of Bucknell University with an M.B.A. from the University of North Carolina, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Schutzer of Cranford, N.J.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR TO ANSWER CRITICS
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode is preparing for what are widely regarded here as two of the most important days of his wounded administration in the aftermath of a harsh report on a deadly police confrontation with the radical group Move.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: Over the last two decades we have learned more about the universe and our place in it than in all the previous 10,000 years. THE CAMBRIDGE ATLAS OF ASTRONOMY (Cambridge University, $90) thus admirably fulfills the need for an up-to-date atlas of the space age.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LET US KNOW. By Diane Vreuls. (Viking, $14.95.) These 12 short stories range from brilliantly evocative fiction to experimental tales so laden with non sequiturs and symbolism that they threaten to collapse under their own weight.

title: What Money Can't Buy in Nicaragua
description: To hear the President, the $100 million question is simple: How can Congress withhold that amount from the brave rebels in Nicaragua? Aren't they like the Hungarian freedom fighters who threw stones at the Soviet tanks? Failure to back the Nicaraguan contras will bring Communism within a two-day drive of Harlingen, Texas.

title: F.A.A. TECH CENTER FACING JOB REVIEW
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center here is undergoing a federally mandated job review designed to save money by contracting work to outside concerns.

title: IF IT'S WEDNESDAY, IT MUST BE THE TUESDAY NIGHT MOVIE
description: March is television's ''what if'' month. What if Saturday's action drama were moved to Tuesday? What if Tuesday's movie became Wednesday's movie? What if Thursday's blockbuster were tried on Sunday? Such scheduling shifts are on the minds of programming executives throughout the year, but in March - when the three-network race has been pretty well decided, when there are no ratings ''sweeps'' to worry about and when clues are sought as to what might work for the coming fall season - schedule makers tend to test their theories on the public. Viewers may consider the tests both confusing and inconvenient, but the theories can be fascinating.

title: PANAMA STRIKE IS PLANNED
description: The Panamanian labor confederation has set a Monday deadline for the start of a general strike of indefinite duration to protest proposed changes in the nation's labor laws. The changes would slash payment for overtime and cut back on other benefits.

title: AMERICAN PAST, AFRICAN PRESENT
description: West as It Was For Traders And Explorers When members of a legislature speak, the forum is likely to be an ornate hall and the topic may be less than riveting sometimes. But when Harry Fritz, a Democratic Representative in the Montana State House and the holder of a doctorate in history, speaks this June, the subjects will be ones he knows well: the wilderness of Lewis and Clark, the lives of fur traders, the quest for gold, the Indian campaigns of the 19th century and Custer's last stand.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN IN ACCORD ON FISHING OFF ALASKA
description: An agreement phasing out Japanese salmon fishing in international waters off Alaska was reached today in the eighth round of talks since June 1985 between Japanese and American officials.

title: WHEN REALITY TAKES TO THE STAGE
description: If someone had invented the plot, it might seem too incredible: a straight-arrow city official resigns from his post, then changes his mind and requests his job back - but the mayor has already decided to appoint someone else. In a rage, the official - a former policeman and fireman -shoots the mayor and another city official, a prominent homosexual activist.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE LION AND THE LIZARD. By Jane Rawlinson. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) The social and psychological upheavals brought to Iran by the ouster of the Shah and the rise to power of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini promise an exceptionally interesting book, but Jane Rawlinson's novel offers rather a predictable treatment of the material.

title: NORWAY FROM PEAK TO FJORD
description: The premier train ride in Norway, linking gracious Bergen with vibrant Oslo, climbs past mountain hamlets, snowcapped ridges, sparkling lakes and thousands of rural vacation homes, huts as they are called, where Norwegians zealously return to nature during the long summer days.

title: Dance
description: ''The Cook's Name is Sam'' is the title of a new piece by Kenneth King, to be presented at St. Mark's Church this week, starting Thursday. But this won't be a dance about male liberation.

title: ALICE AND HER WONDERLAND HAVE A BALLET OF THEIR OWN
description: Ballets about literary figures are, it seems, a 20th-century invention. The foremost of the genre would certainly have to be Frederick Ashton's colorfully passionate view of Arthur Rimbaud in ''Illuminations'' and the profoundly poetic revelation about Emily Dickinson's life and work rendered by Martha Graham in ''Letter to the World.''

title: THE VOICES BEHIND THE STARS AT THE MET
description: Peter Hall is blocking the first act of the new production of ''Carmen'' at the Met. Cigarette girls enter, and line up in threes to go into the factory - a dozen times. Assistant stage directors dash about, calling for group A (first sopranos) and group B (seconds) to come in sooner, make the line straighter. A few mezzos are told to enter from downstage to improve the picture. All the women move forward languidly to sing the smoking chorus. ''Now!'' Peter Hall calls into the microphone, from the third row of the house. ''Everybody, blow smoke!'' The cigarettes, he has promised, will be herbal.
