title: LINDEN ASKS GO-GO LICENSING
description: IN AN effort to curb the crime that officials say goes along with it, an ordinance to regulate and license live entertainment in taverns here has been introduced in the City Council.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TRAINS AND CHANGE
description: Alert students and others in the county, viewing the filmstrip ''Here Comes the Train: The Railroad and How It Changed Life in the 19th Century,'' will find themselves looking at familiar territory. Most of the photographs used in the educational filmstrip are of Westchester sites. Only a few scenes of farm and country life were taken from Currier & Ives prints to fill in where county pictures were not available.

title: SCHUMANN'S SYMPHONIES ATTRACT NOTED INTERPRETERS
description: There are those for whom Robert Schumann's four symphonies occupy a special place of affection. With their formal awkwardnesses, thick orchestrations, earnest pictorialisms and lumbering rhetoric, they clearly cannot challenge the greatest masterpieces of the symphonic genre. Yet their shining lyricism, stirring drama, sweeping force and nobly Germanic solemnity have appealed to performers and audiences ever since they were composed, between 1841 and 1851.

title: Brooks Redux
description: One of the early headquarters buildings of Brooks Brothers - that bastion of tradition - is changing once again.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: HOME rule took a beating at a recent conference on ''New Jersey Growth Management'' at Princeton University at whichmore than 200 government and business officials discussed land-use planning.

title: WARINESS SEEN ON SHARING WORKPLACE POWER
description: New business techniques that replace old hierarchies with systems in which workers share power with executives are making little headway, experts on the workplace say, because they threaten executives' authority, salaries, perquisites and their image.

title: PINIELLA WINS IN DEBUT
description: If Lou Piniella does nothing else in his Yankee managerial career, he at least came through for the boss today. With Lee Iacocca and Donald Trump at Fort Lauderdale Stadium as guests of George Steinbrenner, Piniella directed the Yankees to a 4-1 opening-exhibition victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: PINIELLA RECALLS CLASH WITH WEAVER
description: LOU PINIELLA and Earl Weaver met as equals yesterday when the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles began their exhibition schedule. That had not been the case previously and, in fact, they were very much unequal when they first got together in 1965, Weaver as the manager and Piniella a player at Elmira, N.Y. If both have mellowed slightly with age, consider how volatile they must have been 21 years ago. On one particular day, at least, it was like mixing nitroglycerin and dynamite.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SEEDLINGS CAN BE STARTED NOW
description: THE time has come to start the preliminary activities of the gardening season, such as sowing the seeds of those annual flowers and vegetables that do best when planted during cold weather.

title: HOW '9 1/2 WEEKS' PUSHED AN ACTRESS TO THE EDGE
description: Even the critics who dislike her new movie, ''9 1/2 Weeks,'' agree that Kim Basinger is beautiful. Blonde, with full sensuous lips and a certain subtle luminescence to her skin, she projects an air of sexuality mixed with an almost childlike vulnerability that reminds some viewers of Marilyn Monroe. ''There was something else I always saw in Marilyn Monroe,'' she said recently. ''Terror. She seemed terrified inside.''

title: AN UNSUNG GREEK ISLE
description: Asking Greek friends to recommend the vacation island of their dreams led to frustration. The typical answer ran something like: ''Island X used to be marvelous. But that was before it became popular and all the Germans (or Scandinavians, hippies, nudists or homosexuals - it depends on the friend's prejudices) took it over. Wouldn't set foot there anymore.'' The choice came down to abandoning the notion of a Greek island holiday or searching the maps of the Cyclades, Sporades, Dodecanese and Ionian archipelagoes for an island that no friend had mentioned that is accessible without a private yacht.

title: RADICAL THERAPY FOR THE DRUG PROBLEM
description: Behind the call for widespread drug testing and other controversial recommendations issued last week by the President's Commission on Organized Crime is a genuine sense of despair.

title: AMATEUR STATUS AN ISSUE FOR SAILORS
description: Efforts to protect their amateur status are making competitive sailors increasingly cautious these days as professionalism makes its way into the sport. But often, answers to questions on propriety are shaded in gray.

title: SWEDEN POLICE GET LETTER ON KILLING OF PALME
description: The police said today that they had received an anonymous letter describing events on the night Prime Minister Olof Palme was assassinated and appealed to the writer to get in touch with them.

title: CONCERT HALLS INSPIRE SPEAKER DESIGN
description: It was just 30 years ago - still in the pre-stereo era - that A. Stewart Hegeman introduced the first multidirectional loudspeakers. Mr. Hegeman, who is now retired, never received proper credit for his pioneering work a generation ago, but his ideas - though not generally followed - have never lacked devoted adherents.

title: Waldheim's Past Clouds His Future
description: Kurt Waldheim has often brushed aside questions about his youth in Nazi-ruled Austria. But last week, after researchers for the World Jewish Congress came up with German and Austrian documents the former Secretary General of the United Nations acknowledged that he had joined a Nazi student union and a unit of the Nazi paramilitary SA, or Brownshirts, in 1938, and that he was later on the staff of an Austrian general, Alexander Lohr, who was executed as a war criminal in in 1947. Mr. Waldheim said he joined the Nazi groups as a student to preserve his chances for a diplomatic career and protect his family; his father had lost a teaching job for supporting a leader who resisted the Nazi takeover of Austria.

title: New Equipment Used For Each Blood Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: NO DUST GATHERS IN THE NOSTALGIA BIN
description: For those who prefer to live in the past, there is no time like the present. In classical music, reissues - from the very earliest days of recording to the very near past - flood the marketplace, as record companies seek to preserve the best (and sometimes the mediocre) in order to slake the thirst of collectors and to turn an additional profit.

title: REFUSE-BURNING: SOLUTIONS OR A NEW PROBLEM?
description: AS more garbage-to-energy incinerators are proposed for New York City and the Hudson Valley, the mass-burning refuse plant on Charles Point in Peekskill has become a testing ground for the question of whether these facilities solve the garbage crisis or merely shift the burden of pollution from landfills to the air.

title: Headliners Misplaced
description: On the court, Martina Navratilova is known for her offense: a booming serve, wicked ground strokes and a smashing game at the net. It became evident last week that Miss Navratilova has not neglected her defense, either.

title: OVERCOMING THE THREAT FROM JAPAN
description: AS they have in virtually every consumer electronic market, Japanese manufacturers have made inroads into the typewriter market. But this time, American manufacturers have fought back successfully.

title: COMPUTING THE REAL VALUE OF HOUSEWIFE LABOR
description: Angela Amato's article ''Housewives Get No Respect. . .'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 16 ] raises an important issue. It seems that our materialistic society fails to recognize the value of a thing unless a dollar price has been attached to it.

title: ANTITRUST LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVE OUR DREAMS ALONE!
description: NIGHT LIFE The Interpretation of Dreams. By Liam Hudson. Diagrams. 184 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95. DO we still need to dream? This is the most original and provocative question that Liam Hudson, a professor of psychology at Brunel University in Uxbridge, England, asks in ''Night Life,'' a new book on a venerable subject - the interpretation of dreams. In our technological society, ''the dream is at risk,'' he announces with alarm. Comparing ours with ancient times, he has the impression that ''our dreams have become tame.'' He imagines scenarios that might threaten our very capacity to dream. Television, with its rapidly shifting images, its discontinuous narratives and its vicariously thrilling subject matter, may increasingly be doing our dreaming for us. And Mr. Hudson wonders whether the social uses of computers will expand to the point that their way of ''thinking'' will come to rule over our inner lives, forcing everything into rational channels, making all intelligence, in effect, into artificial intelligence. In that event, our imaginative powers might simply atrophy. Dreaming would no longer have an adaptive function in such a society, and if dreams continued to exist at all, they would be little more than a psychic vestige, a sort of mental appendix.

title: Theater; BASEBALL MUSICAL COMEDY IN ROCKLAND STRIKES OUT
description: WHAT with a new Actors Equity contract, the support of a loyal congregation and an ever-increasing audience, the Belfry Repertory Company, in St. Paul's United Methodist Church in this Rockland County community, may be the only church-cum-professional-theater group in the area.

title: SUPPORT FOR STRIKE COULD HURT T.W.A. SERIOUSLY
description: Trans World Airlines, already hard pressed, could be seriously hurt by the strike of flight attendants if other unions join the walkout, industry experts say. They say the possibility of that appears slim, but there were reports yesterday of strong support of the strike in some places.

title: JAZZ: BENNIE WALLACE AND JOHN SCOFIELD
description: TWO kinds of jazz-rock came to the Bottom Line Thursday - one gutsy, the other gleaming and hollow.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Tainted Wells Trouble Suffolk
description: THE water in Elaine Griffith's Nesconset home has corroded the pipes, rotted out the coffee maker, ruined household appliances, turned the laundry gray and is, in Mrs. Griffith's opinion, unfit to drink.

title: SUIT FILED OVER TRANSIT FARES
description: A transit workers' union has filed a lawsuit accusing this area's transportation agency of adopting racist policies that force poor, inner-city minorities to subsidize the fares of well-to-do suburban commuters.

title: Nelson S. Walsh Becomes Fiance Of Victoria Smith
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Smith 3d of Mill Neck, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Warrington Smith, to Nelson Salt Walsh, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Walsh of Buffalo and Lorraine, Ontario. The wedding is planned for June.

title: STALINGRAD AND STALIN'S TERROR
description: LIFE AND FATE By Vasily Grossman. Translated by Robert Chandler. 880 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50. AN important novel written in the Soviet Union will almost certainly prove unpublishable there, but it will usually find its way to the West sooner or later. In the case of Vasily Grossman's ''Life and Fate'' this has happened much later rather than sooner. Grossman's novel was completed in 1960. In other words it was written at about the same time as Boris Pasternak's ''Doctor Zhivago,'' the work with which the practice of smuggling out illicit writings began 30 years ago.

title: AGAINST THE IDEA OF 'ELITIST' SCHOOLS
description: Three cheers for Dr. Richard Doremus's article, ''Do We Really Need a Science High School?'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 9 ] . As the parent of a third- grader currently enrolled in our local Syosset public school and also attending a program for gifted elementary youngsters in the same school, I agree with Dr. Doremus that Governor Cuomo is advocating the worst possible course of action for the science education of Long Island's students.

title: A CITY AGENCY THAT GREW RAPIDLY FACES SCRUTINY
description: At the turn of the year, before the scent of corruption began to preoccupy municipal government, a little-known city agency called the Public Development Corporation was riding a crest of bureaucratic success.

title: TWO BAGS FULL
description: ONE OF THE DISHES MOST OFTEN ASSOCIATED WITH New Orleans is pompano en papillote, and we are often asked to explain precisely what ''papillote'' means.

title: Downwind From the Bomb
description: In Howard Ball's article ''Downwind From the Bomb'' (Feb. 9), Federal District Court Judge Bruce S. Jenkins is reported as having awarded $2.7 million to 10 cancer victims. There is no doubt that high levels of radiation can cause cancer, but we lack knowledge of low-level effects.

title: CHILDREN A 'MAINSTAY'
description: ALTHOUGH not all museums in New Jersey devote a major share of their exhibits and activities to children, officials feel that children are generally a mainstay in the life of any museum.

title: SAUSAGE: THE SURPRISE GUEST APPEARING AT DINNER PARTIES
description: CERTAIN dishes never go out of style because they were favorites in childhood.

title: REAGAN AIDES OPEN COMPROMISE TALKS ON AIDING CONTRAS
description: The Administration, facing a possible defeat in Congress of its $100 million aid proposal for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, has quietly begun negotiations with Capitol Hill to work out a compromise.

title: Mary C. Heller To Marry in Fall
description: The engagement of Mary Constance Heller to William Winslow Gridley has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Heller of Winnetka, Ill. Mr. Gridley is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gill Gridley Jr. of New York and Norfolk, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FLOATING down the runway, they dipped left and right, swaying to the music and striking poses in the classic fashion-show manner. But the fashions were vintage and the theme was feminist politics in ''The Politics of Fashion'' at the Community Services Building in Paramus last Sunday.

title: DEMOCRATS, WITH LITTLE DISSENT, APPROVE NEW NOMINATING RULES
description: The Democratic National Committee, still polishing a new image of harmony and discipline, approved changes in its 1988 Presidential nominating rules today and, in contrast to past debates of this kind, left no blood on the floor.

title: Downwind From the Bomb
description: I agree with Howard Ball about the Downwind people. But how about the more than 200,000 G.I.'s, like myself, who were used as guinea pigs for the nuclear testing program.

title: OUT OF THE BOUDOIR AND INTO THE STREETS
description: PAINTERS AND PUBLIC LIFE In Eighteenth-Century Paris. By Thomas E. Crow. Illustrated. 290 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $40. TO some readers, Thomas E. Crow's first book might suggest only another chronology of 18th-century French painting, beginning with Watteau and ending with Jacques Louis David. But to those more familiar with the revisionist methods of current art history, ''Painters and Public Life: In Eighteenth-Century Paris'' will represent the most comprehensive and valuable study of art and public life in that era now in print. Mr. Crow, an assistant professor of art at Princeton University, attempts, with much success, to investigate almost every manifestation of what might be considered public - public life, spaces, opinion, discourse, art and, finally, the public itself, which he sees as ''nothing more nor less than a series of representations.''

title: A ROOKIE TO REMEMBER
description: ONE home run sailed above the 397-foot sign in center field at the Oakland Coliseum and landed in uncharted territory up near the back of the bleachers. Another soared onto the left-field roof at Comiskey Park in Chicago, high above the 372-foot sign. And during batting practice at Yankee Stadium late last season, Jose Canseco, the Oakland A's rookie left fielder, is reputed to have slammed five balls into the monument area beyond the 411-foot sign in left-center field.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Savings Deficit America's rate of national savings - the cash salted away by business, individuals and government - is now at 4 percent of national income, a 30-year low. Since savings ultimately finance investment, a low rate does not bode well for future economic growth.

title: The Man From Moscow
description: Anatoly Dobrynin, the Soviet Ambassador in Washington, is going home, having spent 24 of his 66 years in the big Soviet Embassy on 16th Street in back of the Washington Post building.

title: Claire Ferenbach Is Wed in Jersey
description: Claire Romayne Ferenbach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Schooley Ferenbach of Morristown, N.J., and Point O'Woods, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Brendan Whelan, a son of Mrs. Thomas Brendan Whelan of Alexandria, Va., and the late Colonel Whelan, U.S.A. Msgr. John Corr performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Polenta
description: To the Editor: ''Italy's Polenta: More Than Mush'' (Travel, Jan. 19) evoked loving thoughts of my grandfather, who was the polenta maker in our family.

title: ADULT CLASSES TAUGHT WITH BREVITY
description: A HAMDEN businesswoman has given an innovative twist to adult education that has been attracting hundreds of people with hungry minds and busy schedules back into the classrooms.

title: Houston Children And Loaded Guns
description: The combination always carries a deadly potential: unattended children and loaded pistols. In Houston, where guns are common household items, the potential has been realized with alarming frequency in recent months.

title: RARITIES ILLUMINATE THE DAYS WHEN POP MUSIC MEANT JAZZ
description: During most of this century, pop music and jazz have followed somewhat parallel paths, but at a slight distance from each other. Briefly, for a few years in the 1930's, their paths crossed, and during that time jazz was pop music and vice versa. Those were the Swing years, which started on Aug. 21, 1935, when Benny Goodman's Orchestra found in the Palomar Ballroom in Los Angeles the responsive audience it had trekked across the country looking for. Those years effectively ended after World War II when returning G.I.'s found that, with the emergence of be-bop, jazz was no longer a dance music. Actually, even before the United States entered the war, pop music was going back to its earlier sweet, nonjazz style, with the popularity of Glenn Miller's music and Harry James's discovery that he could draw a wider audience playing such plaintive ballads as ''You Made Me Love You'' than he could with ''Two O'Clock Jump.''

title: EGYPT'S ARMY PRAISED IN QUELLING RIOTS, BUT FOR MUBARAK, CRISIS IS NOT OVER
description: President Hosni Mubarak appears to have weathered a riot by his riot policemen - his worst domestic crisis yet - but he still faces what diplomats and other commentators here say they see as an overwhelming, perhaps insoluble, economic and political crisis.

title: REBEL ECUADOR OFFICER OFFERS TO GIVE UP
description: A general who took over an air base after he was dismissed for insubordination offered to surrender today if President Leon Febres Cordero agreed to discuss corruption allegations against two other military leaders.

title: Margaret Crawford Is Wed To George T. Griswold Jr.
description: Margaret Kerr Crawford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Crawford of New York, was married yesterday to George Turnure Griswold Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Griswold of Erie, Pa. The Rev. William A. Wendt performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: A TIGHTROPE FOR PRETORIA
description: In its 18 months of harshness and confrontation, South Africa's violence has bred a new kind of arithmetic - the statistics of loss.

title: Public Schools That Are Adopted
description: WHEN more than 30,000 white pupils left the public schools in Memphis to avert court-ordered busing in 1979, the Board of Education counterattacked with Adopt-a-School.

title: A DONKEY AMONG HORSES
description: SOUND-SHADOWS OF THE NEW WORLD By Ved Mehta. Illustrated. 430 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $17.95. PICTURE the skinny teen-age boy, blind, self-conscious with ambition, cramped in a musty broom closet - his mildewed, cobwebbed room of his own - dreaming of Shakespeare. ''Oh, my yearning is simply to become like this great man,'' he types in his journal (a journal he will never be able to read himself). ''I know that's impossible. But if one aims one's arrow at the sky, it will at least get to the top of the trees.''

title: DUKE, TECH REACH FINAL
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference tournament may not possess the importance it once held when only the winner advanced to postseason National Collegiate Athletic Association play. But that has not lessened the intensity that has marked the tournament's 33-year history.

title: Irradiating Food
description: A long campaign in industry to irradiate food on a large scale to control insects and retard spoilage appeared to have been won last summer.

title: Filipinos May Sue Marcos in U.S. Courts
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: SOME 40 MILES FROM CAPE Town, on the fringe of the wine-farming region of the Cape Province, lies Stellenbosch, the second-oldest town in South Africa.

title: Terrance Whelan to Wed Michelle Arrix in Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Arrix of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Arrix, to Terrance Michael Whelan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Whelan of Hamilton, Mass.

title: IN MANILA PALACE: SILK DRESSES, 6,000 SHOES
description: A renowned Filipino art collector helping the new Government sort through the possessions that Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, left behind at Malacanang Palace said today that she was flabbergasted by her findings.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: EVERY DAY IS SUNDAY. By Ralph Schoenstein. (Little, Brown, $14.95.) Ralph Schoenstein decided to tour American retirement communities partly, he says, because he realized that ''the leisure village was the major social revolution of our time'' and partly to decide whether he wanted to move to one someday.

title:
MUSIC;
ORPHEUS GROUP IN MONTCLAIR
description: THE conductorless Orpheus Orchestra, which has been nicknamed the ''headless wonder,'' will appear three times in New Jersey in the next several weeks.

title: ISRAEL 'EAGER AND WILLING' TO JOIN 'STAR WARS'
description: A close aide to Shimon Peres put the Israeli Prime Minister's position on President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' missile-defense program in unequivocal terms.

title: A MUSICIAN BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: I LOOK at the keys and my fingers want to dance. Dance! I urge them, but they can't. Poor awkward things, I have cheated them. Abandoned them when they were small to a lifetime of wishing.

title: Alison Hall Is Engaged To Michael L. Mauze
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jackson O. Hall of St. Petersburg, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Bennett Hall to Michael Laurence Mauze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mauze 3d of Summit and Bay Head, N.J. A June 1 wedding is planned. The future bride is an admissions counselor at Davidson College, where she and Mr. Mauze graduated.

title: EXTRA POWER, WITHOUT THE HASSLES
description: THE Software Publishing Corporation has had remarkable success with its basic, no-frills software packages, familiar to most under the company's own PFS label and to others as the Assistant series licensed to I.B.M. The PFS family of programs offers about 80 percent of the features that most users need in, say, a word processor or a data base manager. More important, these programs are capable of being put to work by the average - even the computer-shy - individual without any of the mental gymnastics so often associated with computer software.

title: LANDFILL A TARGET OF STATE
description: THE State Department of Environmental Conservation is trying to close a private landfill in Coram that it says has been operating illegally and polluting the environment for several years.

title: WILL THE LOSER KEEP HIS SPOILS?
description: THE dispute over the wealth of Ferdinand E. Marcos seemed to be heading for a lengthy legal battle last week, a prospect that apparently was unsatisfactory both to supporters of the former Philippine President and to the new Government of Corazon C. Aquino. At issue was $1.5 million in Philippine pesos, more than $5 million in jewelry, and documents brought to Hawaii by the Marcos entourage, as well as the status of real estate holdings in New York, which were temporarily frozen by a State Supreme Court Justice at the request of the Philippines.

title: Nancy Mills Is to Wed Charles Fishman in '87
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Mills of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Ellyn Mills to Charles Lawrence Fishman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Melvin I. Fishman of Great Neck, L.I. A May 1987 wedding is planned. Miss Mills and Mr. Fishman are third-year students at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: The Dobrynin Channel
description: For 24 years, Moscow's man in Washington has been Anatoly Dobrynin, a skilled professional with a cherub's demeanor who gained the trust of six American Presidents while retaining that of five very different Soviet leaders. One can only speculate whether there is some wider meaning to his unexpected appointment to a Kremlin secretariat. But the narrower meaning is plain. Mikhail Gorbachev will now have at his elbow a man who knows better than almost anyone how superpower relations work - or don't.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: NEW PRESIDENT NAMED FOR CLARK FOUNDATION
description: The Clark Foundation of New York, one of the 30 wealthiest private philanthropies in the country, has named a new president, Peter D. Bell, a former official of the Federal Government and of the Ford Foundation.

title: A FAMOUS TRAVELER MARKS ANNIVERSARY WITH A TRIP
description: MOST travel writers hesitate to divulge their favorite vacation spots. And Eugene Fodor, whose guides to destinations around the world have been published for 50 years, is no exception.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SEEDLINGS CAN BE STARTED NOW
description: THE time has come to start the preliminary activities of the gardening season, such as sowing the seeds of those annual flowers and vegetables that do best when planted during cold weather.

title: ANTITRUST LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: 69 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 69 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: IN CANADA, A LAND BEYOND ROADS
description: Nesting birds, migrating whales, immense chunks of sea ice, and nearly endless daylight are just a few of the extraordinary sights in June in Churchill, Manitoba, a small subarctic settlement (population 1,300) at the southwest corner of Hudson Bay. Situated well beyond roads, Churchill is as far north as you can go by rail in Canada, and in late fall it's a prime place for viewing polar bears. For several early summer weeks, until mosquitoes and black flies grow fierce, Churchill is also a rich site for watching birds. Over 125 species, from snowy owls and whistling swans to the rare Ross's gull, breed among the sedges and mosses of the spongy tundra, and in the stunted trees and myriad ponds of this low, flat landscape.

title: Raphaella Smits
description: It was a good week to be covering debuts. On Sunday night, Raphaella Smits played a beautiful program of music for the eight-string guitar at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Yale Confronts Anti-Semitic Past
description: Yale University had a Jewish admissions quota for almost four decades, a new book published by the Yale Press has disclosed. Starting in 1923, the book reports, the university's Jewish enrollment was deliberately limited to about 10 percent.

title: Miss Kokubun, Robert McCain To Wed in June
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Kei Kokubun of South Pasadena, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristina May Kokubun, to Robert Williamson McCain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Williamson McCain Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Patton's Prejudices
description: To the Editor:

title: Fury Over Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: PEIRRE BOULEZ LEADS PARIS ENSEMBLE
description: EACH of Pierre Boulez's three New York concerts with his Paris-based Ensemble InterContemporain offers a different agenda. The first, on Wednesday, was devoted entirely to Mr. Boulez's own recent work with electronics. The third, tonight at Avery Fisher Hall, amounts to a retrospective of modernist music from Schoenberg to the present.

title: In Philadelphia, No Sugar Added
description: THERE was mustard to squirt on beef frankfurters but no ketchup in sight. And there was a variety of fruit for dessert but no pastries as the Philadelphia public school system kicked off National Nutrition Month by observing ''Sugarless Wednesday'' last week.

title: BLACK LEGISLATORS MEET ON DROPOUTS
description: A group of black state legislators, at a hearing yesterday on ways to lower dropout rates among black and Hispanic students, were told that the problem requires more money and changes in social attitudes.

title: CHOPPING DOWN A FOREST OF BAD GUYS
description: THE BOURNE SUPREMACY By Robert Ludlum. 597 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95. READING Robert Ludlum's latest thriller is a bit like watching a blacksmith forge a very long chain. The making of the first few links is interesting enough as an exercise in brute manipulation. What is lacking in finesse and artistry is made up for by lots of noise and energy. But after watching the smith link together a foot or so of chain, one perceives a certain sameness to the effort. The chief suspense is in how long the man will keep at it.

title: A.S. McElwaine Wed To Barbara Lyn Lieber
description: Barbara Lyn Lieber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Lieber of Neenah, Wis., was married yesterday to Andrew Scott McElwaine, the son of Sandra McElwaine and Robert M. McElwaine, both of Washington. The Rev. Lawrence Cantu performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Falls Church, Va.

title: HER SINS AND HER SON
description: BLANCHE AND NICKY By Elliot West. 323 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $18.95. PROSTITUTES in fiction are rarely more than sentimental variations on cliches. Fanny Hill performed with as much emotional virtuosity as a pornographic film star, and even Emile Zola's Nana, who may be the most enduring fictional representative of her trade, seemed to be as much a victim of circumstances as a woman driven by her own passions.

title: MEDICAL-HOTEL PLANS ARE DIFFERENT
description: While, at first glance, the recent proposals by Yale-New Haven Hospital and Temple Medical Center to build medical hotels in New Haven [ ''Approval Sought for Medical Hotels,'' Feb. 9 ] appear to be almost identical, closer examination shows them to be really quite different, especially with regard to the types of patients who might be placed in each facility.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WHISTLE WORK Connie Sherman, a Mercy College art teacher who has a studio in Garrison called Whistle Stop, will conduct a whistle workshop from 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Friday at the Westchester Art Workshop in the County Center in White Plains. She will teach about 20 people how to make a number of ceramic whistles at one sitting.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Prices Sink At Swim Outlet The Beach in Pleasantville is the new name and location for Gulbenkian Swim, formerly in North White Plains and specializing in swimming clothing and accessories, plus items for snorkeling, sunning and running. The grand opening sale could suit students headed south for spring break; the promotion ends March 22, with weekly features added to the initial list of markdowns.

title: 'A PRETTY INTERESTIN' LIFE'
description: FORREST GUMP By Winston Groom. 228 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $14.95. THIS novel is a tale told by an idiot (with an I.Q., he tells us, ''near 70'') who, in the course of his travels through three decades of American landscape, becomes a football star, a war hero, a Ping-Pong ace, a one-man band, a chess champion, a movie actor, an astronaut, a professional wrestler and a business tycoon. Forrest Gump also gets to visit China - he in fact saves Mao Zedong from drowning - and he spends four years in the jungles of New Guinea among cannibals. Winston Groom's picaresque novel is a kind of defanged ''Candide,'' an unabrasive satire of the idiocy of life in our time as manifested in various touchstone events and institutions.

title: Amie Karp to Wed in May
description: Lieut. Col. Daniel J. Karp, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Karp, of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amie Yael Karp to Crist Edward Inman, a son of Titika Inman and the late Ray Inman of Greenwich, Conn. A May 4 wedding is planned by the future bride, an editorial assistant with Silhouette Books in New York, and Mr. Inman, a sales representative for Prudential Financial Services in Tarrytown, N.Y. Her father until recently was the senior group director of materials management for Revlon Inc. in New York.

title: THE LANDSCAPE MAINTAINS ITS HOLD ON AMERICAN ARTISTS
description: When compared with contemporary art in Europe, the most influential new American art can seem almost without purpose. German artists born during and in the aftermath of World War II have an artistic subject. So do Italians, in their own struggle with the recent and distant past. The dominant subject of 1980's mainstream American art - popular culture - can seem pale and even trivial by comparison.

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
SELLING YOUR HOME WITHOUT AN AGENT
description: ON Manhattan's upper East Side, Brad Holbrook is offering to sell a ''very brite 1-BR'' apartment with ''rvr vu.'' Real estate agents need not apply. Like many sellers, Mr. Holbrook has eschewed the services of a broker in favor of the Sunday classifieds and his telephone-answering machine.

title: CONCERT: ATLANTA GROUP PLAYS PREMIERE OF 'LICKS'
description: THE Atlanta Chamber Players began their Thursday night concert at Merkin Concert Hall with the New York premiere of Jonathan Kramer's ''Atlanta Licks.'' A likeable, gently swinging combination of jazz, Minimalism and neo-Classicism, ''Atlanta Licks'' called to mind some of the early ballets of Darius Milhaud. Mr. Kramer deliberately limited his pitch selection to six notes; this gave the work a near-absence of chromaticism and a melodic predictability that occasionally grew a little wearisome.

title: ONE MAGIC MOMENT TAKES THE BAHAMAS
description: One Magic Moment and Big Jolt scored impressive victories at Hialeah Park today to emerge as late-blooming possibilities in the 3-year-old picture.

title: Driving? Try the Vineyard
description: All spaces for cars on the ferry to Nantucket are booked for every Saturday in July and August, but some Saturday spaces on ferries to Martha's Vineyard are still available. Residents of Nantucket and the Vineyard say they cannot get their own cars to and from the mainland. Ferry bookings from Memorial Day through Oct. 31 are 25 percent higher than last year, the Woods Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority said.

title: HOTEL FARE IN AN UPSCALE SETTING
description: IF you don't believe that major hotels nationwide have been making an effort to upgrade their image, drop by the new showplace Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in Stamford. Better still, have a meal at its upscale restaurant, Cezanne's. You will be in for more than a few surprises.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART IMPLANT
description: The West Berlin newspaper Tagesspiegel reported today that a 39-year-old man received a West German-made artificial heart after he suffered a heart attack in a coronary bypass operation. The article said the surgery was performed Friday at Charlottenburg University Clinic in West Berlin.

title: DEVILS DEFEAT FLYERS BY 7-3
description: It was a day to set and equal records for the Devils, who scored 5 goals on their first 10 shots and never looked back in defeating the Philadelphia Flyers, 7-3, this afternoon at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Verbatim; Helping New Parents
description: 'Over the past 20 years, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of families with two working parents. It is time we began to match the abundant rhetoric about doing something to assist the American family with some practical steps to accomplish that end.' Representative William L. Clay head of the House subcommittee on labor-management relations, promoting a bill introduced last week that would guarantee new fathers and mothers up to 18 weeks of unpaid leave.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A RATE BUT HERE, A RATE CUT THERE
description: Interest rates fell worldwide, with West Germany, France, the Netherlands and Japan leading the way with cuts in their discount rates. The Federal Reserve soon followed, cutting the United States rate by half a point, to 7 percent. And major American banks quickly dropped their prime rates to 9 percent, the lowest in more than seven years. While few would admit it, the seemingly coordinated actions indicated that the Group of 5 major industrialized nations had heeded American wishes. The United States has been seeking to lower interest rates in order to spur the worldwide economy, but was worried that if it moved first, the dollar would be sent into an uncontrolled fall as investors fled into other currencies. And with interest rates already dropping because of the fall in oil prices, the central banks' moves become more a nudge than a shove.

title: UNLIKELY PARTNERSHIPS GIVE NEW LIFE TO VINTAGE MUSICALS
description: In lieu of new musicals, there have always been a certain number of revivals on Broadway, but, as production costs continue to escalate, even those have become a rarity. For musical revivals, we can now look to opera houses and concert halls, which have the economic means and the facilities to encompass such large-scale work as part of a repertory season or as a special series of concert performances. From there, it is often one step to public television. Working in tandem with public television, opera houses and concert halls could become the preservers of this indigenous American art form.

title: Nairobi
description: To the Editor: Like so many of your readers who have ever journeyed to East Africa, I read with pleasure and nostalgia the series of articles on the region that appeared in the Jan. 12 issue of the Travel section. The camera safari to Kenya's and Tanzania's game preserves is, I think, one of the last of the great romantic travel adventures.

title: A Strong Attack On the Teamsters
description: Law enforcement officials and dissident union members have contended for years that the teamster's union had powerful ties to organized crime. The allegation was made again last week, this time from a new quarter - the President's Commission on Organized Crime - and with particular vehemence.

title: PRESCHOOL PROGRAM EXPANSION SOUGHT
description: MIDDLE-INCOME parents in the Lawrence School District are fighting to get a state-financed prekindergarten program -now restricted to disadvantaged youngsters - opened to their children.

title: 7 KILLED IN COLOMBIA AS ELECTION APPROACHES
description: Guerrilla violence, including a bomb tossed into a Caribbean port restaurant, has killed seven Colombians, the police said today, on the eve of national elections.

title: Morris Manors
description: Since 1975, the New Vernon, N.J., estate of Warren Kinney, a gentleman farmer, has stood idle. Now, however, the 102-acre property is being prepared for the construction of 22 homes that will cost $1.2 million to $1.7 million.

title: O'ROURKE FAVORED FOR ALBANY RACE
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, could have the Republican nomination for Governor if he wanted it, according to Republican officials in New York and Washington.

title: JAZZ: SEXTET, OUT OF BLUE
description: OUT OF THE BLUE, the young jazz sextet that Blue Note Records selected through auditions last year, is in the process of finding its own identity. The group - Michael Philip Mossman on trumpet, Kenny Garrett on alto saxophone, Ralph Bowen on tenor saxophone, Harry Pickens on piano, Ralph Peterson on drums and a substitute bassist, Charles Fambrough - is appearing through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street, working up material for its second album and refining its ensemble sound.

title: Joan M. Wiesen Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Margot Wiesen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Wiesen of New York and Riverhead, L.I., was married last evening to Dr. David M. Lieberman, the son of Dr. Arnold Lieberman of Ocala, Fla., and the late Hilda K. Lieberman. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York.

title: ABLE WERE THEY ERE THEY SAW CABLE
description: THE FANCIEST DIVE What Happened When the Media Empire of TIME/LIFE Leaped Without Looking Into the Age of High-Tech. By Christopher M. Byron. 280 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $16.95. WHEN I worked for Time Incorporated I knew there was a 34th floor, somewhere up above, that commanded everything I was happy to ignore, which is to say everything on the corporate level. As I was of course opposed to that level on principle, I joined the Newspaper Guild -whose memos reflected as great an impertinence toward the actual business of writing a story as management's did. In practice, I stayed out of the 34th floor's way and it stayed out of mine.

title: ULSTER STRIKE TURNS VIOLENT
description: The general strike called by Protestant leaders last week shut down much of Northern Ireland but it failed to achieve its broader aims.

title: Jermyn Street
description: To the Editor: I agree that a stroll down Jermyn Street in London (Travel, Jan. 12) is unique in this world, but I must point out that shopping for ready-made shirts in London is not like New York.

title: SUSPECT RIGHTS ISSUE IN MURDER CASE IN WEST
description: Lawyers defending a suspect accused of a series of nighttime murders have been asserting at a preliminary hearing that the police systematically violated his legal rights.

title: THE THREE SIDES OF THE PALESTINIAN SIDE
description: The murder last week of Nablus Mayor Zafer el-Masri, apparently by Palestinian extremists, appears to have destroyed - for now - whatever remained of the so-called Middle East peace process. It has also cut off abruptly recent attempts to cultivate a ''legitimate,'' ''pragmatic'' Palestinian leadership in the West Bank that could counterbalance the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: CANADA SEEKS TO END DISCRIMINATION IN JOBS
description: Canada has moved to ban mandatory retirement of civil servants at age 65 in a drive against discrimination.

title: The Bow's Art
description: I have, for a long time, used a method of tying a bow tie that is simple, foolproof and produces a very tight knot. In fact, I have won wagers that my tie was a pretied clip-on when it was not.

title: LABOR TAKES A CHAIR IN THE BOARD ROOM
description: Two years ago, unions representing pilots, machinists and flight attendants at Eastern Airlines gave the ailing carrier wage concessions in exchange for a seat on the board of directors and a big chunk of common stock.

title: NEW BOOK TARGETS HUNTERS, RIFLEMEN
description: BLESSED with huge areas of wildlife habitat open to the public and with enlightened game-management agencies, American hunters have long had a love affair with the rifle, from the ubiquitous .22 rimfire used by the farm boy on cottontail rabbits to the .300 Winchester Magnum, which is suitable for elk, moose and brown bear.

title: MANILA MAY TRY AN ABSENT MARCOS
description: The Philippine Government may put Ferdinand E. Marcos on trial in absentia on charges of illegally accumulating a vast fortune during his 20-year presidency, a senior official disclosed today.

title: LIBERALS: THEIR OWN WORST ENEMY
description: BACK WHEN I WAS A KID, AN ENTER-prising 14-year-old at my summer camp decided to conduct a poll, bunk by bunk, on the Presidential race then under way. It was a couple of days after Lyndon B. Johnson had the Democrats assembled in Atlantic City in 1964 nominate him by acclamation. The result of the poll, something like 124 for L.B.J. and one for Barry Goldwater, stunned more than a few of us; we couldn't figure out who had voted for Goldwater.

title: TAIPEI AND OPPOSTION DIFFER ON MEANING OF FALL OF MARCOS
description: The Taiwan Government and its opponents are drawing sharply different conclusions about what the fall of President Ferdinand E. Marcos may presage for this island nation.

title: YUGOSLAVS WIN TITLE
description: Yugoslavia defeated Hungary, 24-22, today to win its first world handball championship. The bronze medal went to East Germany, which defeated Sweden, 24-23, Friday.

title: ET VOILA! LE MINITEL
description: SITTING IN HIS SUNNY ST. GERMAIN-des-Pres living room, Nicolas Prinet, a Paris businessman, recalls the time when the French telephones were so unreliable that ''it was easier to reach your girlfriend by Paris Metro than to phone her.''

title: STATE PANEL LOOKING AT LEASING AND SALE OF SOME CITY LAND
description: A State Senate committee is looking into possible irregularities at three city agencies in the sale and leasing of city-owned land.

title: Deborah Beth Lindenauer Is Planning June 1 Wedding to Peter A. Weinberg
description: The engagement of Deborah Beth Lindenauer to Peter Amory Weinberg has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. S. Martin Lindenauer of Ann Arbor, Mich. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
BASEBALL'S ENDLESS CYCLE OF SCANDAL
description: YOU almost have to pity the baseball commissioners. Gambling, alcoholism, racism, barroom rowdyism, aberrent sexual behavior, game-fixing are some of the sinister problems they face over the years. Comes now the titanic monster of drugs. Poor Peter Ueberroth. How can he possibly deal with it?

title: Topics; Sanctuaries Costly Wallpaper
description: A bar located just a few miles over the Canadian border has papered an entire wall with unpaid New York traffic tickets. This scofflaw decor reflects the fact that Canada doesn't require its residents to honor American summonses.

title: POSTINGS
description: A rental apartment building is rising among the jumble of office and condominium construction in Battery Park City.

title: IN FINAL SECONDS, PRACTICE PAYS OFF
description: He had played the same game that who-knows-how-many basketball players have played: The scoreboard clock inside his head is ticking down to the final seconds as he works to get the shot and calls the numbers out loud. ''I still do it,'' Ron Rowan said. ''Every day, we have contests. Five, four, three, two. You've got to make the shot at the buzzer.'' Of course, someone must always play the role of the buzzer.

title: STATE CHALLENGED ON POLLUTION TESTS
description: THE Town of Brookhaven is battling the State Department of Environmental Conservation to keep the agency from closing 5,400 acres in Bellport Bay to shellfishing.

title: AWAITING A.T.& T.'S CALL
description: HE started as a splicer's helper at the Northwestern Bell Telephone Company in 1943. Today, James E. Olson is by all accounts the front-runner to become chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in August when Charles L. Brown retires at age 65.

title: BETTER THAN 5 C.I.A.'S
description: BETWEEN WASHINGTON AND JERUSALEM A Reporter's Notebook. By Wolf Blitzer. 259 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.95. AMERICANS, Israelis and even Arabs derive endless fascination from scrutiny of the strange and - dare I say it? -special relationship between America and Israel. The topic is both simpler and more complex than is commonly supposed.

title: Downwind From the Bomb
description: Atomic testing in the Pacific Trust territories did not end with the establishment of the Nevada Test Site in 1950. Although the Korean War was, in fact, used as a rationale for the establishment of the Nevada site, the first hydrogen bomb was tested at the Eniwetok Proving Grounds in the Marshall Islands the following year.

title: A 'BOOK TRAVELER' ON THE ROAD
description: MINUTES after opening for the day, Dana C. Gilligan, proprietor of Bookends on East Ridgewood Avenue in Ridgewood, received some good news: She would soon have an autograph party to attract customers.

title: 4 FRENCHMEN VANISH IN BEIRUT
description: Four French television crewmen were kidnapped Saturday by gunmen in predominantly Moslem West Beirut, witnesses said. The attack came hours after an anonymous caller who said he spoke for the group Islamic Holy War threatened to kill one of another group of French captives.

title: AN ITALIAN DRAMA OF CONJURING AND ILLUSION IS REVIVED
description: With his staging at the Piccolo Teatro of Milan of Eduardo de Filippo's ''Grande Magia'' (''The Great Magic Act''), Giorgio Strehler has concluded what he considers his trilogy on the theatrical art of illusion, the first two parts being Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' and Corneille's ''Illusion.'' ''La Grande Magia'' opened early last month to enthusiastic critical response.

title: IN GRANTCHESTER, A POET REMEMBERED
description: There are 17 names on the newest stone slab in the Poets' Corner of Westminster Abbey. The ''war poets'' - a term that to the English always means the poets of the First World War - have at last come to a collective, respectable rest. Most of those who now receive their country's homage are in fact renowned for poems that protested the war they were sent to fight. Not all of them, however: the glamorous Rupert Brooke is remembered not for opposition but for heroic assent. In the sonnets he wrote shortly before his death in 1915 (a year before the Battle of the Somme dramatized the war's catastrophic futility), Brooke embraced the possibility of dying for the cause. His words would be recalled in pulpits across the country and in an obituary signed by the First Lord of the Admiralty, Winston Churchill. Surely Brooke's most famous lines are the ones that open ''The Soldier'':

title: COUNSELING OFFERED TO SIBLINGS OF THE DISABLED
description: Vanessa was considered a normal 8-year-old. But Vanessa's parents, almost overwhelmed by caring for infant twins with severe physical handicaps, were nonetheless worried about her.

title: HUGE BLOCK OF POWER AT STAKE IN FIGHT FOR DAMS
description: A battle for control over 366 federally licensed dams in 32 states that generate relatively inexpensive hydroelectric power is nearing a turning point.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTE
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening. Excerpts are from reviews by Times critics. Prizzi's Honor

title: For 'People Power' in U.S., What Now?
description: The Washington-based Coalition Against the Marcos Dictatorship plans a name change.

title: DEVICES THAT CAN HANDLE THE WORK OF WINDING
description: MANY a picture has been lost because a photographer forgot to advance the film or was not fast enough at winding during a good action sequence.

title: PLYWOOD AND PARTICLE BOARD EDGES: THE BIG COVER-UP
description: PLYWOOD and particle board are extremely popular for building all kinds of cabinets, shelves and other projects. The panels are strong and more resistant to warping than standard lumber, and needed widths are easier to cut in one piece.

title: Theatrical Device
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC DEFENDERS FIND A CHALLENGE IN AIDING THE POOR
description: AS John F. McMahon begins his third four-year term as the Federal Public Defender for New Jersey, he believes, more than ever, that ''money can't buy'' better legal defense services than his office provides.

title: BEFORE 'LOOK BACK IN ANGER'
description: To the Editor: In writing about ''the ups and downs of the British theater'' during this century, Benedict Nightingale [ Feb. 16 ] makes the astonishing pronouncement: ''Little that so much as aspired to be serious was written, for instance, between the years 1914 and 1956, when John Osborne's 'Look Back in Anger' arrived to sandpaper ears that had become accustomed to imitation velvet.''

title: The Economy Sends Some Mixed Signals
description: Depending on whom you asked last week, the United States economy (a) is strong and may get even stronger, or (b) is showing serious signs of weakness.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: ANTICS IN BRIDGEPORT A nightmare speed-up of life at the office will unfold in Bridgeport, Conn., Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the third annual Office Olympics for Easter Seals. The event at the Algonquin Club will test velocity, accuracy and lunacy.

title: Three Trials, 13 Convictions
description: The scales of justice were relieved of a heavy load in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Mays Landing, N.J., last week. Found guilty, pending possible appeals, were six of eight reputed Gambino crime family members accused of participating in an international car-theft ring; six accused terrorist bombers, and a New Jersey insurance broker charged with successfully plotting the hired murder of his wife.

title: Polenta
description: To the Editor: There are some of us who are allergic to pasta, and indeed all wheat products, so we were very appreciative when Paul Hofmann described the varieties of corn-derived polenta available to travelers to Italy.

title: GAS-PRICE SURVEY TO BE TALLIED
description: BY the end of the week, investigators in the State Attorney General's office should have an idea of how their inquiry into retail gasoline prices is progressing. Tomorrow is the deadline for 2,445 licensed gas stations in the state to respond to questionnares sent by the office Feb. 28.

title: A Pole In Moscow
description: The most interested and concerned bystanders of Mikhail Gorbachev's overhaul program for the Soviet Union are necessarily the countries of Eastern Europe. Although most have gone well beyond reforms proposed by Mr. Gorbachev, their prospects for going further are inevitably defined by the standards of acceptability set in Moscow.

title: Coercing American Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE IN THE COMPUTER AGE: IS IT REALLY GETTING SIMPLER?
description: THE computer, the simplifier of 20th-century living, has affected our lives in many far-reaching ways.

title: CHINESE CARPETS SPAN THE RAINBOW
description: Although the study of Chinese painting, sculpture and porcelain have long been popular and scholarly pursuits in this country, antique carpets are only beginning to garner comparable attention in a consideration of Chinese arts and crafts. Therefore, the exhibition of ''Pattern and Symbol: Chinese Rugs and Carpets,'' opening tomorrow and continuing through March 26 at the Chinese Porcelain Company, 25 East 77th Street, is of exceptional interest.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If the management system is not big enough to stop the space shuttle program whenever necessary to make flight safety corrections, it will not survive and neither will our three space shuttles or their flight crews.'' - John W. Young, chief of the astronaut office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. [ 1:6. ]

title: Hudson St. Lofts Draw Offices
description: IT was music that brought Bruce Sinder to TriBeCa nine years ago when he was 24 years old. He was trying to make a living playing the guitar and the piano, and writing songs on the side.

title: Times Square
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH TEXTILES ''The Splendor of French Style,'' a new exhibit at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, traces the development of textiles in France from the 15th to the late 19th century. The show, which will run through May 25, was conceived by Marianne Carlano, the museum's curator of costume and textiles, and Jacqueline Jacque , chief curator of the Musee de l'Impression sur Etoffes/Musee de Papier Peint in Mulhouse, France.

title: NORDIQUES 6, WHALERS 3
description: The left wing Michel Goulet scored three goals to raise his season's total to 46, and Anton Stastny scored twice.

title: SCATTERING OF ASHES PLANNED
description: The artist Georgia O'Keeffe's ashes will be scattered in New Mexico, her longtime home, her attorney, says.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
COMET REMINISCENCES
description: For most of us, the chance to see Halley's Comet is a once-in-a-lifetime event. There are some, however, who can recall having seen the comet as children when it last appeared in 1910. Jon Elvert, astronomer and senior lecturer at the Andrus Space Transit Planetarium of the Hudson River Museum, is seeking such people, to interview them and record their recollections for use as part of an upcoming planetarium show in the spring.

title: Headliners; Persistence Pays
description: The hot dog pushcart has arrived in Houston, thanks to a former New Yorker who wasn't going to let a Texas city fence her in. Shirley Rubenstein, who fought for more than two years for the right to sell hot dogs from a mobile unit in a city that banned mobile food vendors, won her battle last week when the City Council voted to allow a pilot project in which pushcarts might serve certain downtown parks. Mrs. Rubenstein, who had been selling hot dogs without a license, once chained herself to her cart to make sure officials would not confiscate it.

title: Social Events; Signs of Spring
description: Dinner With ''Carmen'' March 10 - The final new production of the Metropolitan Opera season will be ''Carmen'' with Maria Ewing, Catherine Malfitano, Luis Lima and Michael Devlin. The occasion calls for a black-tie benefit for the Metropolitan Opera Association starting with cocktails at 5:30 and dinner at 6 on the Grand Tier before the 8 P.M. performance. Tickets are $35, $100, $150 and $250 for the performance, from 212-362-6000, and $100 for dinner tickets, from 212-870-7428. Scandinavian Party March 11 - The American-Scandinavian Foundation has fostered the exchange of people, ideas and culture between this country and Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden for 75 years, prompting a dinner-dance celebration. The black-tie benefit at the Plaza starts with cocktails at 7 P.M. Tickets, $250, from 212-874-4098. Cocktails at Tiffany's March 11 - The Isabel O'Neil Foundation for the Art of the Painted Finish promotes and trains workers in a special form of furniture decorative art. To see examples, hear an explanation and aid the foundation, attend a cocktail party from 6 to 8 P.M. on the second and third floor of Tiffany's on Fifth Avenue at 57th Street. Tickets, $50, from 212-605-4217. For Special Students March 13 - The Kildonan School in Amenia, N.Y., is a boarding school for boys with the language disability dyslexia. In addition to its standard one- or two-year programs of intensive training after which students usually are able to cope with regular school courses, there is a seven-week tutoring program in language skills offered by the affiliated Camp Dunnabeck on the Kildonan campus.

title: SURGE OF ILLEGAL ALIENS TAXES SOUTHWEST TOWNS' RESOURCES
description: A tide of illegal immigrants sweeping over the border from Mexico is straining border communities from Texas to California, according to officials throughout the region.

title: INTERNATIONAL SHOW WILL OPEN THIS WEEK
description: Interpex, the international stamp show sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers Association, will be held Thursday through Sunday in the Rotunda of Madison Square Garden. Show hours are Thursday noon to 7 P.M.; Friday 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Saturday 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Daily admission is $3, children under 14 accompanied by an adult will be admitted free. Seniors over 62 will be admitted free on Sunday.

title: POISON IVY: BEWARE WHEN PRUNING
description: Poison ivy, the summer scourge, is wintering at home in Connecticut. It lurks under freshly fallen snow and receding gray ice gathering strength for the busy season ahead. The soft vines harden adn turn gray. They snap like any dried branch but within hides a potent yellow heart full of life, enough to cover me with nasty red blotches for four weeks.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Just when you thought it was safe to skip the next 10 post-nuclear-holocaust novels because there was nothing new to say, along comes Susan B. Weston's CHILDREN OF THE LIGHT (St. Martin's Press, $16.95). Her cleanly written, tightly constructed, painfully moving novel fulfills Ezra Pound's prescription for a work of literature: ''Make it new.''

title: FOR A TOWN'S RECORDS, THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: NO one has challenged Bryant Andrews's ability to supervise the bookkeeping for the Town of Columbia, but there is an argument over where he should do it.

title: WHAT MOFFETT MUST FACE BEFORE O'NEILL
description: While the Governor's office is the ultimate goal, the task these days for Connecticut's Democratic and Republican gubernatorial contenders is much more mundane than winning election as the state's chief executive.

title: POLICY ON DRUGS IS NECESSARY
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Better for Bisser
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Kempton Plans To Be Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Kempton of Swansea, Mass., and Easton, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Kempton, to James Sylvester Mulholland 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mulholland Jr. of Hillsdale, N.J., and Southampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for August. The future bride, an alumna of the Lincoln School in Providence, R.I., and Bates College, is a candidate for a master's degree at the Columbia University Graduate School of Social Work.

title: SWEDEN'S LEADER AND HIS LONG RUN
description: In 1946 Sweden's Prime Minister, Per Albin Hansson, expired suddenly one evening on a trolley on his way home from the office. It was, a retired Swedish diplomat remarked the other day, the perfect death for a Swedish Prime Minister: on the job, unpretentious, in the midst of ordinary citizens.

title: REPUBLICANS DEVELOP COMMITTEES TO OFFER ANTICORRUPTION MEASURES
description: Thirteen New York Republicans, prompted by allegations of corruption in city government, announced yesterday that they had formed a council and an advisory task force to recommend anticorruption measures.

title: TORN BETWEEN SHADOW AND SUNSHINE
description: THE WOMAN walked resolutely to the table, speaking quickly, to let Keith Hernandez know she was not going to interrupt his lunch.

title: A BAN THAT'S BATTERING BIOTECHNOLOGY
description: THE United States' pre-eminent position in biotechnology is jeopardized by a Federal law that bars the export of new drugs that are not yet approved in this country. Unless the law is changed to permit the export of drugs to countries where they are already approved, biotechnology is likely to suffer the same international usurpation experienced by the semiconductor industry.

title: ELEMENTARY HARMONIES SECOND TO NONE
description: EVERY Wednesday evening, long after the final classes of the day have been dismissed, the deserted corridors of the Springhurst Elementary School in Dobbs Ferry echo with the sounds of lush three-part harmonies as the best elementary school vocal group in the United States prepares for its first national appearance.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
MILAN: COLD COMFORT
description: A BITTER cold spell created the climate for the clothes that Milanese designers are showing this week for next fall and winter.

title: AIRPORTS AIDED ON SAFETY
description: TEN of New Jersey's small to medium airports have received state Department of Transportation grants to upgrade facilities and improve the margin of safety they can offer the aviation community and the traveling public.

title: CULTURAL EXCHANGE MUST NOT BE SECOND BEST
description: Some of the happiest days of my life have been spent in the two great Russian museums - the Hermitage in Leningrad and the Pushkin in Moscow - that are shortly to send to this country an exhibition of French Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings. However that exhibition may turn out, the resumption of normal cultural relations between the United States and the Soviet Union makes possible a gamut of exchanges that could be both wider and more rewarding than anything as yet envisaged.

title: Israel Reassesses Its Chances for Peace
description: Thomas Friedman's article concludes with the only sensible approach for an eventual solution to the Near East dilemma. ''A peace process with a future'' can come about only when Israeli and Palestinian communal leaders take the initiative within the framework of broader diplomatic efforts. Diplomacy and United Nations-sponsored resolutions haven't helped much, if at all, to reach a spirit of reconciliation WILLIAM ALLIN Geneva

title: HOUSTON
description: The oil boom is over for now, and many a Houstonian is glad of it. In its rush to become the country's fourth largest city (pop. 1.7 million) and to build the glittery glass palaces that rise out of the East Texas prairie, Houston may have grown too fast. Now things are slower, traffic lighter. Compared with Dallas, its more austere sibling rival, Houston is an open place without pretensions. It combines the hospitality of the Old South with the self-reliance and determination of the Wild West, all glued together with the free enterprise ethic.

title: GIVING STUDENTS A CHOICE OF SCHOOLS
description: How valuable are the specialized public high schools that bring together exceptionally talented pupils for advanced studies in science, technology or the arts? The issue has recently divided Westchester County and Long Island school officials, on one side, and the Cuomo administration on the other.

title: KENTUCKY TOPS ALABAMA IN S.E.C. FINAL
description: The Kentucky Wildcats got a lift from a reserve sophomore, Cedric Jenkins, when they came from behind today to beat Alabama (22-8) by 83-72 and win the Southeastern Conference title. The Wildcats (29-3) were down, 43-40, at halftime after trailing by as many as 9 points in the opening half, but the 6-foot-9-inch Jenkins put them ahead in the opening minutes of the second half and the all-America forward Kenny Walker, held to 4 points in the first half, kept them there with a barrage of down-the-stretch free throws. Walker was Kentucky's leading scorer with 20 points, 16 from the line. Metro Louisville, Memphis St. Win LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) - Herbert Crook scored 19 points as Louisville shot 70 percent from the field in the first half en route to an 86-65 victory over Cincinnati in the semifinals. Louisville (25-7) will meet Memphis State (27-4) in Sunday's championship game. Memphis State edged Florida State (12-17) by 73-71 in the other semifinal on a final-second shot by Andre Turner. Cincinnati (12-16) shot only 29.6 percent from the field in the first half. For the game, 61 fouls were called on both teams. Louisville was 38-for-53 from the line, and Cincinnati 17 of 28. Southwest Texas Tech, A&M Gain DALLAS (AP) - Winston Crite's unstoppable inside work and a tenacious man-for-man defense lifted Texas A&M to a 55-47 victory over Texas (18-11) in the semifinals. The Aggies (20-10) will meet Texas Tech Sunday in Reunion Arena for the automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: YOU MAY PLOW HERE: The Narrative of Sara Brooks. Edited by Thordis Simonsen. (Norton, $12.95.) Those who have been troubled by the allegedly negative portrayals of black families in Alice Walker's novel ''The Color Purple'' and Bill Moyers's recent television documentary on black unwed mothers will be pleased with the prominence of industry, thrift, integrity and family solidarity in this book.

title: DOCTORS WEIGH STRIKE OVER INSURANCE
description: Hundreds of doctors around Massachusetts say that malpractice insurance rates have risen so high and controls on their fees have become so strict that they cannot continue in practice without changes in the system.

title: Modular Housing Is Going Public
description: GROUND will be broken in Connecticut this spring for two pilot modular housing projects for the elderly as part of a state study of whether such a method of construction is appropriate for public housing.

title: TEXAS FARM CHIEF IS ON THE OFFENSIVE
description: Jim Hightower, the Texas Agriculture Commissioner, flew into the heart of Reagan Country this week to talk about farming.

title: Gail King Is Engaged To Dr. Victor Meskill
description: The engagement of Gail Heidinger King, the assistant principal for special education at the Julia Richman High School in New York, to Dr. Victor P. Meskill, president of Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Heidinger of Brooklyn, parents of the bride-to-be. A July wedding is planned.

title: DANCE: LISA KRAUS OFFERS A 'GRAND TOUR'
description: LISA KRAUS took her audience into exotic terrain in ''The Grand Tour,'' performed on Friday at the Danspace at St. Mark's Church. Shining through, with magic, humor and poignancy, was a sense of wonder at the unfamiliar.

title: ANTITRUST LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: EURYDICE MYTH IN LA MAMA'S 'ORFEI'
description: LEAVE it to Ellen Stewart. When another theater group was unable to perform at Miss Stewart's La Mama theater, the redoubtable doyenne of the avant-garde got together with a few friends and created a ''dance-opera'' called ''Orfei.'' Performed on Thursday night at the La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street, the piece is the product of La Mama's East First Street Music Workshop. ''Orfei'' is a pleasant, sometimes stirring way to spend an hour. It also offers a retelling of the Greek myth of Orpheus and Eurydice that makes the legend live with a peculiarly lyrical intensity.

title: BOMB SCARE DELAYS READING
description: A telephoned bomb threat temporarily interrupted a poetry reading by the Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night, the police said. A male caller told the police in a call at 8:40 P.M. that a bomb would go off in 15 minutes as an act of protest by the ''Ukranian reaction force,'' the police said. A police bomb squad inspected the cathedral, at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, and declared there was no danger at 10:53 P.M.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE are dozens of worse things that can be reeled off without stopping for breath. There is, for instance, luring away someone else's lover or spouse. There's undercutting colleagues, deliberate lying and inexcusable rudeness. There's picking up a chocolate bar in the supermarket and finishing it before reaching the checkout counter.

title: IF SPAIN LEAVES NATO BOTH COULD BE THE POORER
description: With the approach of a referendum Wednesday on whether Spain should quit the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, one of the central issues - the military significance of membership - often seems obscured in the national debate. Until now, political rather than military questions have been predominant.

title: THE RUSSIANS ARE BUSY IN THEIR CORNER OF SPACE
description: With its successful Vega 1 mission through the unknown interior of Halley's comet last week, the Soviet Union demonstrated a space-age savvy that may prove as memorable as the coup of taking the world's first detailed look at a famous interplanetary traveler.

title: A NEW APPROACH TO EATING DISORDERS
description: IN an effort to understand more about the eating disorders anorexia nervosa and bulimia, two institutions in the county have embarked on new programs in recent months.

title: ABOVE ALL, HE PLEASED HIS PATRONS
description: REMBRANDT His Life, His Paintings. By Gary Schwartz. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Viking. $50. IN his fascinating study of Rembrandt, Gary Schwartz is engaged in recovering the true likeness of the painter that lies beneath the mellow chiaro-scuro of his self-portraits, and the image that emerges is neither saintly nor endearing. From a thorough and careful study of documents, mostly concerning patronage, the author vividly characterizes Rembrandt as a repugnant and untrustworthy person. Greedy, vain, unsociable, boorish and arrogant, this Rembrandt hardly fits the stereotyped portrait of the kindly old grandfather who warms our hearts with his probing portrayals of man's humanity.

title: U.S. IS HOPEFUL SUMMIT PLANS WILL GO AHEAD
description: The United States expressed guarded confidence today that the cutback ordered in the Soviet missions to the United Nations would not damage relations with Moscow or present new problems in arranging the next summit meeting.

title: CHURCH TO TURN OVER A CHAPEL ON GOVERNORS I. TO COAST GUARD
description: At first glance, St. Cornelius Chapel on Governors Island looks radiant. Its red tile floors gleam in the afternoon sun; its bright white walls are dappled with stained-glass hues.

title: Kari McCabe To Be a Bride
description: Kari Birgitta McCabe and Donald Craig McBride, partners in McBride & McCabe Interiors in New York, plan to be married in July. The announcement of their engagement has been made by her parents, Robert Karr McCabe of Paris, and Mrs. Osborn Elliott of New York and Stonington, Conn. Mr. McBride is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Francis McBride of Des Moines.

title: NEW COURT SOUGHT FOR BENEFIT CASES
description: The Reagan Administration wants to establish a new court to hear the thousands of cases filed each year by people who contend they have been improperly denied Social Security retirement or disability benefits.

title: Pretoria Says The Emergency Has Ended
description: The Government of South Africa lifted the seven-month-old state of emergency and released 327 people from prison last week, trying to show that things were improving in the racially divided land. But the national security forces retained broad powers to counter increasing violence.

title: VALUE OF SEAT BELT: A CASE IN POINT
description: STOPPED at an intersection and waiting for the traffic to clear, Joyce Lynch glanced up at the rear-view mirror, saw a car coming and thought to herself: ''He's not going to stop!''

title: Stephen Alexander Kowal To Wed Elizabeth R. Uhl
description: A September wedding is planned by Elizabeth Ross Uhl and Stephen Alexander Kowal, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Uhl of Pelham, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Kowal is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Kowal of Pelham.

title: TOO FEW STRANGERS IN STRANGE LANDS
description: THERE are times that no news is actually news, and our recent vacation is a case in point. We spent 10 days in the Caribbean and met no one from Long Island, Queens, Brooklyn, the Bronx or Manhattan, or even the island that is Staten.

title: Federal Study Exonerates Formaldehyde
description: When it comes to public health, scientific studies generally fall into two classes: those that settle disputes and those that prolong them. A report on formaldehyde issued last week by the National Cancer Institute seems to belong to Category 2.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE POETRY AND POETICS OF AMIRI BARAKA: The Jazz Aesthetic. By William J. Harris. (University of Missouri Press, $20.) For almost 30 years, the poetry of LeRoi Jones/Amiri Baraka has been a loose cannon on the deck of American verse. Mr. Baraka learned to write as a beatnik, then rejected mentors like Charles Olson and Allen Ginsberg for black nationalism in the 1960's. In tracking the explosive spurts of growth in Mr. Baraka's literary voice, William J. Harris identifies his conscious models as angry jazzmen like John Coltrane and Charlie Parker, both of whom, he writes, attempted to destroy white music so that a new black music could be born. Mr. Baraka used this ''jazz aesthetic'' to invert and transform what the white avant-garde taught him about the poetic process into an actual weapon for black revolt. In his plays, white stereotypes of blacks were transformed from docile figures into strong, often murderous heroes; ''If Bessie Smith had killed some white people she wouldn't have needed that music,'' says a character in Mr. Baraka's 1964 play, ''Dutchman.'' In his 1970 play, ''Jello,'' Jack Benny's faithful chauffeur, Rochester, takes up the razor as a black militant and terrorizes his boss. To jazzify his poetry, Mr. Baraka adapted a ''fast rap'' of scatting, ''songification'' and other oral and performance techniques to grab the ''zoom trembling in its cage.'' He succeeded in synthesizing a powerful Afro-American poetry rooted ''in the tradition, always clarifying, always new and centuries old.'' Mr. Harris, who teaches English at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, also discusses the racism and absolutism that have marred Mr. Baraka's work, factors that might explain his relative exclusion from the American literary scene.

title: MOTHER MAINE
description: THE GIRL WHO WOULD BE RUSSIAN And Other Stories. By Willis Johnson. 180 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95. IN the early 1950's, Richmond, Me., a small town on the banks of the Kennebec River, became the site of a colony of White Russian immigrants still loyal to the memory of czarist days. These original immigrants are now old and dying, and their rich ethnic community is dying out with them. But Willis Johnson has made this colony the subject of his first book of fiction, ''The Girl Who Would Be Russian,'' a superb collection of seven traditionally realistic stories.

title: WHERE THE FISH HAVE ANTIFREEZE
description: SOUTH LIGHT A Journey to the Last Continent. By Michael Parfit. 306 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95. EVERY year, the National Science Foundation outfits five or six journalists in survival suits and bunny boots and sends them on a whirlwind tour of Antarctica to publicize United States scientific research programs there. Usually the results are newsy stories in the daily papers and the general interest magazines. Michael Parfit took the tour too - he saw the same scientists, the same antifreeze-producing fish, got the same briefing at the South Pole, even saw what may be the very same stiff dead seal I'd seen on my press tour a few years earlier. But Mr. Parfit stayed on. His ''South Light: A Journey to the Last Continent'' covers a whole season, from a harrowing whiteout landing in the early spring, when a supply plane touches down in a snowstorm so dense that air, sea and land have become indistinguishable, to a last-minute escape by icebreaker in the late fall.

title: GROUP SAYS INTERIOR DEPT. LAGS ON PROTECTING LAND
description: The Interior Department has largely failed to carry out a legal mandate to identify and protect ''areas of critical environmental concern'' on public lands, according to a report by the Public Lands Institute.

title: DANCE: THE SENTA DRIVER COMPANY
description: WHAT a peculiar art dance is.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: March 9, 1986 Fiction

title: Teddy Roosevelt's Metaphor
