description: In his article ''Secs Appeal'' (On Language, Jan. 26), William Safire asked the coiner of the metaphor ''like trying to nail Jell-O to a tree'' to step forward.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor: In regard to ''Turkey's Resting Place of Stone Gods,'', (Travel, Feb. 2), I would like to call attention to the map where Mount Nemrut is very prominently pointed out. While there is indeed an important mountain named Mount Nemrut in eastern Turkey and it is at the western end of Lake Van, it is not the same Mount Nemrut as described in the article, which is actually between the Kahta and the Euphrates Rivers. It would indeed be quite a trek from Adiyaman to the Mount Nemrut near Lake Van. (It is merely the case of mistaken identity, having two mountains with the same name in the same general part of the country.) It is not difficult to travel in that part of Turkey. The cities of Gaziantep, Malatya and Diyarbakir all have good hotels with good food, and respectful, though sometimes naive, service. While English is not commonly spoken, French or German can be encountered, and the people are pleasant and helpful with the bewildered tourist. I have traveled extensively in Turkey, only lately gaining a smattering of Turkish, and have fared very well. The hotels in Adiyaman are adequate, though hardly luxe, but not unlike the kind of rustic places you might expect in Vermont or Colorado. (It is best to drink the water delivered as tea to make sure it is safe.) Making arrangements to get to Mount Nemrut is surprisingly easy, particularly from Adiyaman.

title: ST. JOHN'S RALLIES TO WIN CHAMPIONSHIP, 70-69
description: St. John's, down by as many as 13 points in the second half, began a furious rally with 16 minutes left that ended when Ron Rowan hit a 14-foot jumper with 8 seconds remaining last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: COMMUTERS' WOES A CONTINUING PROBLEM
description: The Feb. 23 article on commuter complaints discussed a mostly one-sided view of NJ Transit issues.

title: Change Ahead for Rent Stabilization
description: In a 73-page document of immediate, intense interest to nearly a million New York City families, the Cuomo administration last week proposed changing the Rent Stabilization Code for the first time in 11 years. No legislative action is needed to put the changes into effect, although public hearings will be held in Manhattan in April.

title: BETTER MANAGEMENT WOULD SAVE TREES, STATE FORESTERS SAY
description: DESPITE the fires, insects and diseases that pose a constant threat to Connecticut's 1.8 million acres of forest land, more aggressive management will insure that the state's forests continue to thrive, experts say.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE BRITISH
description: AS IS WELL KNOWN, THE ENGLISH ARE innately, irremediably and irreplaceably peculiar. Of all Noel Coward's songs, ''Mad Dogs and Englishmen'' is quite rightly the one most generally accepted. Like the Russian bear, the Australian kangaroo, the Havana cigar, the Swiss bank account and the Finnish hangover, the English eccentric is part of a universal currency that has never had to be rescued by the World Bank. In airports, in hotels and on beaches, an Englishman stands out by reason of his dress, his bearing, his speech and his immunity to ridicule. As far as he is concerned, what an Englishman does is right, and to hell with everyone else.

title: GAMBLING ON OPTIONS WITH I.R.A. MONEY
description: BROKERAGE firms have begun expanding the risks investors take in their individual retirement accounts. Last weekend, Brown & Company, a Boston-based discount affiliate of Chemical Bank, introduced a national advertisement inviting I.R.A. customers to ''go 'long' options'' - that is, to buy the volatile instruments outright for speculation on the stock market. The practice, while controversial and not yet widespread, has been quietly permitted in I.R.A.'s by a number of other brokerage houses, usually for large customers, and competitive pressure to attract more I.R.A. money seems destined to prompt more firms to relax restrictions.

title: Ken Noda
description: Not many pianists appear with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, the Chicago Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic and several other distnguished ensembles before making a solo New York debut.

title: INTELLECTUAL 'MEALS' FOR ELDERLY
description: ON THE theory that nourishing the mind is as important as feeding the body, the New Jersey Committee for the Humanities is offering Hemingway, Faulkner and Steinbeck to the state's elderly.

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 5 AND WOUNDS 30 IN EAST BEIRUT
description: A car bomb exploded today in East Beirut, the predominantly Christian sector, and 5 people were reported killed and 30 wounded. It was the seventh bombing in the area in seven weeks.

title: Sharon Lifland Engaged
description: The engagement of Sharon Ilene Lifland to Glenn A. Ruppel has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Elmer Lifland of Easton, Pa.

title: AMERICAN POETRY, NOW SHAPED BY WOMEN
description: IN her pathbreaking autobiographical essay ''When We Dead Awaken,'' the poet Adrienne Rich describes growing up in the 1940's and 1950's under the tutelage of male literary masters from whom she learned ''that poetry should be 'universal' - which meant, of course, nonfemale.'' My own education, in the late 50's and early 60's, was similar. When I was a student, there were six Romantic poets: Blake, Wordsworth and Coleridge in the first generation, followed by Byron, Shelley and Keats in the second. Then came the Victorians, of whom Tennyson, Browning and Matthew Arnold were the major figures. After that, one would read Hardy perhaps, Hopkins certainly. During long years of undergraduate loneliness, I solaced myself reciting long mouthfuls of Hopkins, savoring those resonant cadences so full of ecstasy and despair. It made no difference that Hopkins was a Jesuit priest and I was a Jewish coed. Thanks to the magic of poetry, he was I, I was he. Finally, there were the supernovas of the moderns: Yeats, Eliot, Frost, Stevens, Pound, Williams. That was literary history as my professors taught it - and it became my own history. In turn they lit up my sky; I was they, they were I. Needless to say, I read few women poets. The wicked and hilarious Aphra Behn, who should have been snuggling next to the wicked and hilarious Lord Rochester in my 17th-century text, wasn't in the book at all. Poor Dorothy Wordsworth, devoted sister and secretary to William, was absent from among the Romantics, though the prose poetry of her Grasmere journals - which William mined for his poems - is as fresh as new grass.

title: THE BALANCE OF PAYMENTS HAS A POLITICAL FULCRUM
description: Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, issued the marching orders a few days ago: There will be a comprehensive House trade bill; it will be on the floor the week of May 12, and the majority leader, Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, will monitor its progress. ''The trade deficit continues to be one of the greatest problems threatening our economy,'' said Mr. O'Neill, signaling his intention to make it a problem as well for the Reagan Administration.

title: Heather D. Crain To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rance Crain, of Lake Forest, Ill., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Heather Damon Crain to Kenneth Hamilton Hanson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hanson, also of Lake Forest.

title: SENIOR-CITIZEN CARD - PART OF A RITE (RIGHT?) OF PASSAGE
description: THE realization that I was no longer considered ''middle-aged'' came to me suddenly. There I was, sitting on a New Jersey-bound bus at the Port Authority Terminal, when the driver shouted to the starter:

title: Julie Ann Smith Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Layton F. Smith of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., and Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Ann Smith, to Donald S. Rietdorf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn F. Rietdorf of Nashville, Tenn.

title: WOMEN IN GOVERNMENT: STATE FOUND TO LAG
description: NEW JERSEY has one more woman in its Legislature than it did a year ago, but the state still ranks behind most others in its percentage of female lawmakers, according to a recent Eagleton survey.

title: UTAH SENDS DANTLEY HOME
description: Utah's all-star forward Adrian Dantley was sent by the club back to Salt Lake City following a Jazz victory Friday night at Phoenix.

title: L.I. RETIREES HEADING BACK TO THE JOB
description: OLDER workers are returning to the Long Island job market in growing numbers, according to employment analysts. To many employers, plagued by a shortage of young people to fill jobs, they are a welcome sight.

title: FOUR DECADES LATE, L.I. MAN IS 'BAR MITZVAH BOY'
description: In the 70-foot-high vaulted hall, adorned with oversize menorahs and stained-glass windows, Henry Rodrigues today sang words from the holy books and was accepted as a member of the adult congregation of his synagogue.

title: ZACCARO'S PUNISHMENT IS A GIFT FOR 3 GROUPS
description: Over the last year John A. Zaccaro, the husband of Geraldine A. Ferraro, has gone through a decayed building on the Lower East Side and given advice on how it could be turned into an emergency shelter for troubled youths.

title: JOHN LENNON, FROM THREE PERSPECTIVES
description: Quixotic, charismatic and possessed of a singular gift, the late John Lennon was also a man of deep conviction, whose musical and humanistic goals were often intricately entwined. Some new insights into his dual role as galvanizing performer in the concert hall and idealistic preacher on the world stage may be gleaned Friday night, when Showtime will devote more than two hours to Lennon and his family.

title: GREEN SHOOTS A 64 TO VAULT INTO LEAD
description: Hubert Green equaled his personal low for nine holes on the PGA Tour today with 29 on the front of the Doral Country Club's Blue Monster course. He completed a round of 8-under-par 64 in strong, variable winds to charge from seven shots off the pace and take the lead by two shots in the third round of the 25th annual Doral Eastern Open.

title: PURCHASE STUDENTS PRESS FOR SAFETY
description: STUMBLING in the dark on a makeshift path of frozen dirt, a group of students from the State University of New York at Purchase chanted ''one, two, three, four, walking at night is what streets are for. Take back the night.''

title: 'OUTLAW' TRASH TROUBLING TOWNS
description: TWO weeks ago, the Town of Huntington started a new policy at its landfill in East Northport. Each day, workers sift through the garbage brought by 20 trucks, chosen at random from among the 115 or so trucks that bring some 900 tons of garbage daily.

title: CORPORATE AID TO SCHOOLS RISES IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Private industry has stepped up its aid to New York City's public schools, spurred in large part, business and school officials say, by concern that an increasing number of students are ill suited to the city's changing job market.

title: U.S. HAS 2-1 DAVIS CUP LEAD
description: Ken Flach and Robert Seguso, the world's No. 1 doubles team, defeated Andres Gomez and Ricardo Ycaza, 6-2, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, today and put the United States ahead, 2-1, in its first-round Davis Cup match with Ecuador.

title: THE LIGHT IN HIS ATTIC
description: IN 1974, when Shel Silverstein offered children the prospect of venturing to the place ''Where the Sidwalk Ends,'' the invitation was irresistible. Here lay an opportunity for the young to defy danger signs and discover a world where rhyme and picture engendered delight, where children might find their foibles, wishes and hates mirrored by Mr. Silverstein in a manner that tradition and propriety, hitherto, and suggested be kept private and unspoken. Oh the thumb-sucker's thumb

title: HERNANDEZ WON'T CHALLENGE UEBERROTH
description: Keith Hernandez ended a week of uncertainty today and said that he would comply with the drug penalties imposed by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth.

title: WHY THE NETWORKS SHOULDN'T ACT LIKE SOVEREIGN NATIONS
description: How far can, and should, television go in presenting a Soviet, or anti-democratic, anti-United States position? The question will not go away; it is constantly resurrected. The networks grow increasingly supranational, roaming the world like sovereign powers. Journalism and self-interest clash; expedience and opportunity play a part. It is unlikely, for example, that ABC News would have put a Communist functionary in Moscow on the air to rebut President Reagan's recent speech on military spending if ABC News had not been all over Moscow in the first place, covering the Communist Party Congress. Even Roone Arledge, the president of ABC News, was there. Television news is egocentric, and ABC News presumably thought that because it was in Moscow, the center of journalistic gravity and urgency had to be there, too. Ergo, ABC allowed Vladimir Posner, a party spokesman, to criticize Mr. Reagan as ''dishonest'' on a domestic American issue.

title: THE COSTS OF EDUCATING THE HANDICAPPED
description: Re: Jane Goldblatt's letter to the editor on the cost of educating the handicapped [ Feb. 2 ] , I feel compelled to respond. To begin with, education of the handicapped is the law. As far as cost is concerned, the figure quoted ($8,390) is a very rough yearly average, as cost is determined by support services required by the individual's needs.

title: ANOTHER NUMBER IN THE PARKING BUREAU FOLLIES
description: To the Editor:

title: A DRAMA OF DEPTH
description: ''THE MAGIC HOUR,'' a new play by Edward Friedman, now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater Main Stage in East Farmingdale, is an absorbing slice of life's drama that takes place in the office of a New York City psychologist.

title: L.I. TO OFF OFF BROADWAY, VIA HOLLYWOOD
description: KAREN SOROCA remembers Jericho as ''a teeny Quaker town'' where mail was picked up at the local post office and there was just one general store around. Then, she said, ''it changed overnight'' into what is commonly called suburbia.

title: 'TRAILER VILLAGES' BELONG TO THE PAST
description: A very interesting article appeared Feb. 16 about the new manufactured housing being built by the Housing Authority in Westport. In the article, ''mobile homes'' are referred to as ''much better than the public may perceive them to be'' and only once did the article refer to ''small, tin trailers'' of the 1960's.

title: Headliners; Not a Candidate
description: Harry Belafonte, the singer and civil rights activist, last week gave up an opportunity to find out exactly how many fans he has in New York. Joining a list of noncandidates that includes Geraldine A. Ferraro, who ran for Vice President in 1984; Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, and District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, Mr. Belafonte decided not to seek the Democratic nomination to challenge United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in November.

title: Art
description: The rigorously abstract work of Dorothea Rockburne is about appearance and illusion, austerity and romance, generosity and order. Like the Renaissance artists she has recently been in contact with in Italy, she uses mathematics less as a means of establishing control than of enabling her to go beyond it, less as a method for bringing art under the rule of reason than as a means of making sensuality and expression possible.

title: WELL-MEANING ACTS HAUNTING FARMERS
description: A FEW years ago, when Wayne Cooke used an approved pesticide on his strawberry fields at Hilltop Orchards in Branford, he thought he was doing nothing out of the ordinary.

title: Lindenauer Agrees to Talk About Corruption
description: After nearly two months of heavy pressure from Federal prosecutors, Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of New York City's Parking Violations Bureau, succumbed last week.

title: STEELWORKERS RENEWING TALKS WITH 5 COMPANIES
description: The United Steelworkers of America, after ending a strike against four major makers of cans, has renewed contract negotiations with five troubled steel companies.

title: The Baby Food Scare Continues
description: Consumer reports of glass fragments in Gerber baby foods continued to pour in from around the country last week, but Federal officials rejected the demand of two consumer groups that the products be recalled, arguing that it would accomplish nothing.

title: MONEY, BUT NO TAKERS
description: A PROPOSAL to use interest-free loans to create low-cost apartments in the Town of Smithtown was stuck on the drawing boards for two years because of financing delays. But now that the money is available, the town is having difficulty finding property owners to participate in the program.

title: THE WEBS THEY WEAVE AFTER LEAVING CITY HALL
description: Here is the way the world works.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRASH: TOO MUCH AND NOWHERE TO GO
description: On some mornings, 25 or 30 yellow trash-collection trucks line up at the gate of the municipal incinerator in northwestern Philadelphia, one of two in the city. At the other end of the lot, dump trucks pull away with steaming loads of ashes, bound for some faraway landfill.

title: WAYFARING IN THE COTSWOLDS
description: We gathered on Sunday night at the hotel in Cheltenham, a pleasant Regency spa town full of gardens, suburban lawns and storefronts with caryatids. There were 15 of us that first night at dinner: 4 men and 11 women. We examined one another curiously. Ann and I decided we could outwalk most of them, even though we were older than the average. The weather reports for the next day were rotten. ''We'll gather downstairs in the morning at 9,'' said Christopher. We all went to bed early. There was nothing much else to do in Cheltenham on a rainy Sunday night. The next day the adventure would begin.

title: MORE BYPASS SURGERY: COSTLY AND UNNEEDED
description: PLANS of two Fairfield County hospitals to begin open-heart surgery were recently reported. Whether the hospitals have to seek approval by the proper state agency, and what will occur if they do not, are interesting issues. One hospital is filing for approval, the other claims it need not do so. A third in the state has similar plans.

title: Remembering Palme
description: To the Editor:

title: MOBILE HOMES ARE NOT TRAILERS
description: Robert A. Hamilton's article on the use of mobile, manufactured housing by the Westport Housing Authority [ ''Westport Starts Trailer-Park Public Housing,'' Feb. 16 ] is timely by letting consumers know that today's mobile, manufactured home is indeed a viable choice that is not only safe and sound, but also attractive and affordable.

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE, ALMOST
description: IT PROBABLY pays to be a regular at Millie's Place in Great Neck. Then you might be accustomed to the chummy familiarity of the serving staff, some of whom sit down at tables to chat with the patrons or are ready with an arrogant quip if you make a comment.

title: AUSTRIA MAGAZINE REPORTS NEW DATA ON WALDHEIM AND NAZIS
description: An Austrian magazine that published reports accusing Kurt Waldheim of a Nazi past says it has found new evidence to support the charges.

title: Quality Child Care: The Need Is Real
description: I was delighted to see the Feb. 2 article on ''Day Care: Capacity and Cost Cited as Factors in 'Crisis' '' so prominently featured in The Times. For thousands of Westchester working mothers, the shortage of adequate quality child care is, literally, a continual worry. The lack of sufficient funding is therefore of utmost concern to all of us.

title: Laurence Dreyfus
description: Laurence Dreyfus's Saturday night debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall must be counted as one of the season's most exciting. Mr. Dreyfus plays the viola da gamba, an instrument similar to a cello that was popular during the Renaissance, Baroque, and Classical periods and then died out until its 20th-century revival; he was accompanied by the harpsichordist Arthur Haas.

title: Miss Thomas Engaged To Ronald L. Roseman
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Thomas to Ronald Lee Roseman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold L. Roseman of Birmingham, Ala., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Howard E. Thomas of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the future bride. An August wedding is planned.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN TYPEWRITERS
description: FOR years, personal computers and word processors have threatened to make typewriters obsolete. And, in fact, from the mid-1970's through 1979, typewriter sales dropped steadily.

title: NEW FORDHAM COACH
description: Fordham, which is hoping to move its football program up from Division III to Division I-AA, has found a coach with I-AA experience to take over as head coach next year.

title: RECITAL: FRIEDLAND, CLARINETIST
description: SHERMAN FRIEDLAND, who studied at the New England Conservatory and has lived many years in Montreal, played 20th-century clarinet music before a small audience at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night. There was variety here despite the relative chronological closeness of the four pieces.

title: 1949 TEST LINKED TO RADIATION IN NORTHWEST
description: An experiment at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in 1949 spread radioactivity across parts of Washington and Oregon, more than 100 times as much as was released in the Three Mile Island reactor accident in 1979, newly declassified documents show.

title: Sarah Feldman Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Feldman of New York and Lakeville, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Feldman to David Scharfstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Scharfstein of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Downwind From the Bomb
description: If the people who make the decisions and the ''experts'' who certify that there is no danger involved in testing atomic bombs were told to send their families to live for a month during and following any test in the areas involved, I wonder if these tests would be considered so safe. This could be applied to other dangers also, such as the dumping of hazardous wastes, in various ways. CONSTANCE STOCKDALE Putnam, Conn.

title: Sheila Anne Clifford to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl Clifford of Mahopac, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sheila Anne Clifford to David William Boyd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Boyd of Wheeling, W.Va. The wedding is planned for May 10. The bride is a legislative auditor with the Maryland Department of Audits in Baltimore. Mr. Boyd is a computer software consultant in Cockeysville, Md.

title: DAWKINS EXPECTED TO RETURN TODAY
description: The smile was back.

title: Music
description: Australia is just about as far from the United States as it's possible to go and -with the exception of Nellie Melba, Joan Sutherland, Peter Dawson and the rock band ''Men at Work'' - the music and musicians of this remote continent are all but unknown here.

title: SWEDEN'S GLASS: A FINE ART
description: ''Glass is alive,'' says the Swedish designer Rolf Sinnemark. ''It is never still.'' For Goran Warff, his colleague at Kosta Boda, ''there is magic in crystal.'' Swedish designers experienced in ceramics, wood and metals love to work with glass and - in close partnership with master glassblowers, cutters and engravers - create masterpieces that captivate growing numbers of fans at home and abroad.

title: SENATORS TO SPEAK AT FUNERAL FOR JAVITS ON MONDAY
description: Jacob K. Javits will be buried in New York City tomorrow, with United States Senators from both political parties on hand to eulogize a distinguished and admired colleague.

title: CYPRUS UNIONS CALL A STRIKE
description: Greek Cypriot labor unions called a one-day strike for March 19 today to protest employer demands that pay increases linked to inflation be amended or ended. The strike call was supported by unions representing Government employees, the police, teachers, bankers, journalists and electricity workers. Employers said the system of pay awards linked to the inflation rate, which is now about 6 percent a year, is crippling the island's export drive by forcing up labor costs.

title: THE HERO WAS PREGNANT
description: GOING TO SEE THE LEAVES By Linda Collins. 197 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95. AS the American baby boomers begin to enter their 40s, perhaps the experience of middle age will become a more serious subject for our literature, and the midlife crisis will be recognized as more than a sociological chestnut dismissible by yet another Hollywood cackle. If so, the baby boom generation may have found a sympathetic interpreter in Linda Collins, whose work has appeared previously in many magazines, though this is her first collection of stories. ''Going to See the Leaves'' describes the trials and poignancy of transit into the middle years with sobering precision and shows evidence of a mature talent.

title: THE U.S. AND THE U.S.S.R ARE TALKING SOTTO VOCE
description: The relatively benign mood of Soviet-American relations, which continued for about three months after last November's summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, has soured somewhat in the last two weeks. Despite the leaders' stated commitments to proceed toward a nuclear arms treaty, the latest round of talks adjourned in Geneva last Tuesday with little sign of progress. In major speeches the week before, they denounced each other's military postures.

title:
DINING OUT;
THOSE OLD, FAMILIAR ITALIAN DISHES
description: DINERS tired of new wave Italian cooking that would, say, combine linguine with squid ink or place with the care of a jewel-setter freshly roasted yellow, black and red peppers on petals of endive can assuage their nostalgic hunger at Marianacci's, a basic neighborhood Italian restaurant, but with Syracuse china. Depend upon this kitchen to produce the familiar dishes available at most Italian-American restaurants and to prepare most of them with equal skill.

title: May Wedding Is Planned For Elizabeth Dougherty
description: Elizabeth Sutro Dougherty, a commodity trader for The Holco Trading Company, and Andrew Peter Halle, a vice president in the commodity finance group of the Bankers Trust Company, both in New York, plan to be married in May, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Winfield Dougherty of Morristown, N.J., New York and Coreys, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Halle is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Halle of Kingston-on-Thames, Surrey, England.

title: BUSH BID ON DELEGATES GAINS
description: The Federal Election Commission has tentatively agreed that Vice President Bush's political action committee can influence delegate races in Michigan precincts so long as it does not advocate a Bush candidacy.

title: SAN FRANCISCO'S NEW CONDUCTOR - A MAN OF FIRM BELIEFS
description: As an impoverished music student at Juilliard the conductor Herbert Blomstedt used to sneak into the backstage area of Carnegie Hall to hear the world's great symphony conductors rehearse. Tonight and tomorrow he will pass through that stage door again, this time as the conductor and musical director of the San Francisco Symphony.

title: IN ALBANY, MALPRACTICE ISSUE AWAITS SOLUTION
description: The issue of medical-malpractice insurance, which posed a major problem late in last year's legislative session when some doctors threatened to strike if their premiums were not limited, remains unresolved by New York State politicians.

title: Trapped in the 'NASA-Speak' Machine
description: One of the great brooding themes of American literature is the dread of mechanism - the fear that the free individual will be caught up and crushed in some sort of system. This is usually rendered as a quasi-military social organization.

title: Street Fashion; A SPRING TO THE STEP IN THE WINTRY SUN
description: OPTIMISTS are never out of fashion, or out of season. As if to prove it, a number of stylish couples seized upon a bit of unseasonably warm recent weather to shed their heavy clothes and pretend, for a day at least, that spring was here.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
FINE FEATHERED FRIENDS
description: EVERYONE knows the story of Nancy the Nanday conure - everyone, that is, who frequents Bird Jungle.

title: MUSIC: CUMBERLAND WIND QUINTET
description: THE CUMBERLAND QUINTET is a wind ensemble that has been operating out of Tennessee Technical University for the past 16 years. Most of the group's work is in that particular state and also the wider Southeast.

title: LOS ANGELES DISTRICTING MAY NOT SETTLE DISCRIMINATION SUIT
description: A City Council plan to raise its Hispanic membership through redrawn election districts appears to have some way to go before the move can settle a Reagan Administration lawsuit charging discrimination.

title: The Contras Are Like Filipinos? Absurd.
description: One sure sign that winter is on its way out is that Washington is already immersed in talk of the latest spring line in contra analogies.

title: MANILA HAS DATA ON MARCOS HOLDINGS
description: The Philippine Government seized boxes of documents in Manila on Friday linking Ferdinand E. Marcos to holdings around the world, according to Philippine officials and private consultants to the Government.

title: BEAUTY IN A WOODPILE
description: WINTER is slipping away and our woodpiles are dwindling. I miss the huge sculptures of them -one close to the doorstep, another by the garage, a third perfectly placed in the backyard for viewing from a kitchen window.

title: WHO BENEFITS FROM CHARITY
description: WHO NEEDS charity? It is a question I've thought a lot about in the last few months while involved in a food and clothing drive for homeless men, women and children.

title: STALKING THE OWL ON ITS HOME GROUND
description: LOOKING like a procession of druids with flashlights, but sounding like more than 60 people crashing through the suburban woods, five dozen night stompers went on an owl prowl near Stamford one recent chilly weekend night. They were seeking any sight or sound of the nocturnal raptors.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SEEDLINGS CAN BE STARTED NOW
description: THE time has come to start the preliminary activities of the gardening season, such as sowing the seeds of those annual flowers and vegetables that do best when planted during cold weather.

title: MUSEUM TESTS SKILLS
description: FOR the last several months, there has been a boom in development in Monmouth County, but much of it has been at the county's museum here, where schoolchildren plot and plan communities complete with shopping malls, highways and high-rise housing.

title: Marquis of Malpractice
description: MY DOCTOR ASKED for an appointment. I said I could work him in toward the end of next month. He said it was an emergency.

title: AN ENSEMBLE 'EVITA' SOARS AT DARIEN
description: THE Darien Dinner Theater's staging of ''Evita'' soars above that of the many other theaters that have been offering the pop opera since performance rights were released last year. Here is technically first-class, thoroughly professional staging that stresses ensemble over stars, which is how ''Evita'' was conceived by Harold Prince. ''Evita'' does not require stars; it makes them.

title: Q and A
description: Question:My husband and I are interested in hiking in Hawaii. We are trying to find groups that organize camping tours, take care of the meals and baggage and meet the campers at designated places. - J. P. K., Lynbrook, N.Y. Answer:Several companies run escorted trips, with meals and tansportation provided, for campers who want to hike. Generally, the campers ride in a van or minibus from one campsite to the next on the tour and go on hiking excursions to waterfalls, beaches and other spots from each site. With Trek Hawaii, which is represented by Island Odysseys Hawaii (677 Ala Moana Boulevard, Honolulu, Hawaii 96813; 800-367-5696), groups of from 10 to 15 campers are escorted by a leader and a cook. A four-day trip to either Kauai or Maui costs $390 a person. A 12-day tour with visits to the Big Island, Maui and Lanai costs $1,170, including interisland flights and a two-and-a-half-hour cruise.

title: LIST OF EVENTS FORCES ONE TO SELECT FARE
description: ''CAN we ever have too much of a good thing?'' Cervantes wondered, and looking at the concert lineup next weekend one is tempted to ask the same question. The thought occurs that some computer whiz ought to be able to devise a system to avoid this frustrating sort of cultural logjam; none has, so we must choose from a long list of tempting musical possibilities.

title: FREE CONCERT SCHEDULED
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra, under Yakov Kreizberg, will give a free concert at Symphony Hall here today. The concert begins at 3 P.M.

title: ASTRONAUTS' CHIEF SAYS NASA RISKED LIFE FOR SCHEDULE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has exposed astronauts to numerous potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressure to maintain its launching schedule, the chief of the agency's astronaut office has asserted.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: RARE EARTH. By Mary Lee Grisanti. (Doubleday, $17.95.) Coinciding with Yelena G. Bonner's visit to the United States and Anatoly B. Shcharansky's release from the Soviet Union, ''Rare Earth'' is at the very least a timely novel.

title: NEW YORK CRIME STEADY IN 1985 DESPITE RISE IN LAST HALF OF YEAR
description: The number of serious crimes reported in New York City held about steady in 1985, despite an increase of nearly 4 percent in the last half of the year compared with the same period in 1984, the Police Department said last week.

title: MAYORS TO MOUNT EFFORT TO RETAIN FEDERAL AID
description: As more than 3,500 mayors and other city officials from around the country gathered here this weekend to begin lobbying against cuts in Federal aid to cities, their leaders said the prospects for success had never been so grim.

title: Communications Problems Are New for NASA
description: To the Editor:

title: A HIGHBROW LOVES A LOWBROW
description: TRANSACTIONS IN A FOREIGN CURRENCY By Deborah Eisenberg. 214 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95. IN this provocative debut collection of stories, ''Transactions in a Foreign Currency,'' Deborah Eisenberg's characters are exhaustingly fascinating, made to travel outside the native land of their inner selves into a world that appears astonishingly regulated, where ostensibly enlightened men collect women the way superpowers assert spheres of influence, where sexual diplomacy becomes a contest ''to adhere to the slippery requirements of distant authorities.'' Charlotte, the physically awkward narrator of ''Flotsam,'' is told by her fashionable roommate: ''You're lucky that you're so nice. . . . Men are going to treat you really well in your next life.'' Needless to say, niceness is a disability. Charlotte, alternately bludgeoned and ignored by romance, is a victim of her own inclination to be overwhelmed by beauty and by folks like those Padgett Powell describes in his novel, ''Edisto,'' as knowing ''the whole alphabet of worldly maneuver.'' How to survive in the midst of women who always win, men who always manipulate?

title: Margaret Poyner
description: Margaret Poyner's Tuesday night concert at Carnegie Recital Hall had much to recommend it. Miss Poyner studied at Duke University, Syracuse University, and with Marlena Malas, Helen Boatwright and Gerard Souzay, among others.

title: WHY OLD TYPING HABITS DIE HARD
description: SOME typewriter trivia:

title: KNOWLEDGE OF A GARDEN'S CLIMATE CAN HASTEN BLOOM
description: For many gardeners, winter is that long grey time of year between the last leaf raking and the first growing plant. This period of time is not connected to the calendar with its arbitrary dates. It is more pragmatic and concerned with what is actually going on in the garden.

title: TV VIEWERS MIXED ON R-RATED MOVIES
description: IN an attempt to win viewers, an independent commercial television station in Waterbury recently stopped deleting brief scenes of nudity and certain four-letter words from its prime-time movies.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Something's Going Around, and Around
description: ''I can hardly hear you,'' the woman whispered painfully into the phone. ''Me either,'' the younger woman replied hoarsely. ''Something's going around, and it sounds as if we've both got it.'' She was right; folk wisdom is often wise, and as we learned last year, when people say there's something going around, there is. It's true again this year, but with a twist.

title: DANCER RESENTS 'HASSLE'
description: ''I REALLY don't want to deal with the hassle of licensing because, for one reason, I don't want to be treated like a common criminal and subjected to a background search,'' said Eunice Kortlang of Greenwood Lake, a dancer at a tavern here.

title: The Bow'sArt
description: Abbott Combes's article ''The Bow's Art'' (Feb. 2), stirred memories. I won my right to wear a bow tie at St. Paul's School back in 1933, and wore it with pride - still do.

title: Developing a New Route 1 Corridor
description: WHEN Richard DeCaprio and George Hudak mention the rapidly developing Route 1 corridor, they are not referring to the area around Princeton, where millions of square feet of office space have been built, but to the grimier and more congested stretch between Newark International Airport and the southern end of Linden.

title: Asian Power and Paternalism
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DOME CALLS, AGAIN
description: IT looked so simple. Syracuse had a 13-point lead and Syracuse was going home to pack the Carrier Dome with 30,000 crazies next weekend as the champions of the Big East.

title: If Only Someone Could Pull a Plug
description: Nearing the end of a wet winter that has filled the Great Lakes to the brim and beyond, communities around the world's largest fresh-water lake system have been dreading spring. ''Things look real bleak,'' said Thomas Martin, director of Michigan's Office of the Great Lakes.

title: HOW STATE LAWMAKERS CAN BENEFIT FROM TIES
description: State lawmakers are engaged in a variety of professional and investment activities that are directly affected by legislation they enact, according to state documents, and they benefit from dealings with some agencies that the state oversees.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW FROM ISRAEL
description: For the first time in more than a decade, the general public is being given a chance to acquire Israel's annual gold and silver Independence Day commemorative coins. The coins are available only to subscribers of the Israel Government Coins and Medals Corporation, but this year, Israeli officials have announced details early to give non-subscribers a chance to enroll in time to buy the coins.

title: LEGISLATIVE MOVES TIED TO '87 RACES
description: THE Republican-controlled State Assembly and the Democratic-controlled Senate continue to watch each other warily as they go their separate ways toward the 1987 legislative elections.

title: Israel Reassesses Its Chances for Peace
description: In his article ''No Illusions: Israel Reassesses Its Chances for Peace'' (Jan. 26), Thomas L. Friedman has described the four most widely discussed solutions to the conflict over Judea and Samaria (the West Bank): withdrawal, partition, autonomy, functional compromise. However, because none of these proposals is acceptable to both the Israeli public and the local Arab population, new ideas must be considered.

title: LINDO OF JEFFERSON NEARS MARK FOR 600
description: For the second week in a row, Errington Lindo of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn just missed the national indoor record for 600 meters. This time, however, at today's New York State Indoor Interscholastic Track and Field Championships in the Carrier Dome, the 18-year-old senior might have broken the record if his starting position was better.

title: P.T. BARNUM, MASTER SHOWMAN OF THE 1800's, IS THE STAR OF AN EXHIBITION
description: AT the tender age of 12, Phineas Taylor Barnum learned the art of the humbug - the hard way.

title: IN PHILADELPHIA, A MAYOR'S CAREER IS CALLED INTO QUESTION
description: Even before the ashes had cooled from the fire ignited by the police bombs last May, Mayor W. Wilson Goode had accepted ''responsibility'' for the fiasco. But he steadfastly denied he was to blame; his subordinates, he insisted, were really at fault.

title: IN AND OUT OF LOVE AND FAITH
description: GENTLEMEN IN ENGLAND A Vision. By A. N. Wilson. 311 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. MIXED with our nostalgia for the coziness of Victorian life is an impatience with all the things it left unspoken. If, as writers like Peter Gay and Steven Marcus have suggested, Victorians were not quite so repressed as we once thought, they nevertheless maintained the outward signs of repression, which almost amounts to the same thing. When they did exercise their sexuality, they denied it a full acknowledgment, a recognition of its place near the heart of things. To some of us this denial is intolerable, for it is the essence of the modern to say what one feels, to break an ancient silence into which we seem to have been shushed by church, state or society. More and more, we live by pronouncing ourselves. In A. N. Wilson's novel ''Gentlemen in England'' the infinitely articulated manners of his Victorian men and women might be seen as a defense against understanding one another - or even the darker side of themselves. For a novelist, this defense has certain advantages: it gives a character privacy and allows his personality to develop as a pure distillation. As someone said, character is a secret psychosis - but in the 20th century we can't keep secrets.

title: SOVIET SEES U.S. VIOLATION
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass today characterized the American order as an ''unprecedented'' and ''hostile'' move that violated the United States' commitments as the host country for United Nations headquarters.

title: RUMANIANS ARE URGED TO LET 2 SCHOLARS GO
description: Senators Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, and Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, have urged Rumania to allow two mathematicians to go abroad.

title: STATEN ISLAND CAPTURES METRO DIVISION III TITLE
description: Tony Petosa scored 30 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead Staten Island to an 80-64 victory over Old Westbury last night as the Dolphins won the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro Division III championship.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Machine for Unknown Purpose Listen to the silence - this is the novelist W. H. Hudson's way of getting close to nature. He is quoted in ''Patagonia Revisited'' (Houghton Mifflin) by Bruce Chatwin and Paul Theroux.

title: PRISONERS' APPEALS DELAY JERSEY EXECUTIONS
description: Hours after his conviction Wednesday for hiring someone to murder his wife, Robert O. Marshall, a Toms River insurance broker, joined 17 others on death row at the Trenton State Prison here.

title: FIRST JAPANESE PROBE GETS PICTURES OF COMET
description: The Suisei space probe, Japan's first major venture in space exploration and one of five unmanned craft tracking Halley's comet, passed within 89,500 miles of the comet today and took photographs of it, officials said.

title: WHERE WE LEARN DEMOCRACY
description: FREE SPACES The Sources of Democratic Change in America. By Sara M. Evans and Harry C. Boyte. 228 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95. IN an era when fighting for clean air or racial justice is interpreted as special-interest politics and when selling the Federal Housing Administration, the Grand Coulee Dam and the United States Postal Service to private interests is construed as the public good, it is hardly surprising that America's understanding of such terms as public and private should appear as more than a little warped. In fact, a continuing struggle over the meaning of public and private has been central to the nation's ideological battles of this century.

title: LONG ISLAND RADIO: THE OTHER MARKET
description: Your Feb. 16 article, ''L.I. Radio Beats City Stations for Listeners' Hearts and Ears,'' was interesting reading but unfortunately only told half the story.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOME FRONT. By Patti Davis with Maureen Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) Despite its catalogue of flaws as narrative fiction, this roman a clef by President Reagan's daughter offers a tiny harvest of redeeming social value.

title: QUETZAL AND MAN IN GUATEMALA
description: BIRD OF LIFE, BIRD OF DEATH A Naturalist's Journey Through a Land of Political Turmoil. By Jonathan Evan Maslow. 249 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. ''I

title: RISING STAKES FOR NEGLIGENT DOCTORS
description: As Cmdr. Donal M. Billig began a four-year prison sentence last week, many in the medical profession were wondering if the longstanding debate over how to discipline bad doctors had taken a new turn.

title: IN FRONT BY A NOSE
description: The American Contract Bridge League has long consisted of a large body, a small head and two tiny feet. The body is the United States, with a current membership of over 160.000; the head is Canada, with over 18,000; and the feet are Mexico, with 433, and Bermuda, with 111.

title: Weather Vanes Feel Ill Wind
description: WHEN some New England law-enforcement officials now think of ''hit and run,'' weather vanes, not motor vehicles, come to mind.

title: SHUTTLE INQUIRERS TAKING NEW TACK
description: Investigators pursuing the causes of the space shuttle disaster believe that the major disclosures about equipment failures and management decisions have largely been made public, people familiar with the investigation said today.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SEEDLINGS CAN BE STARTED NOW
description: THE time has come to start the preliminary activities of the gardening season, such as sowing the seeds of those annual flowers and vegetables that do best when planted during cold weather.

title: ADDING BRAINS TO A SIMPLE MACHINE
description: THE technology gap between electronic typewriters and their electric predecessors seems to get wider all the time.

title: SHUBERT POSTS FIRST PROFIT
description: NEW HAVEN'S Shubert Performing Arts Center generated applause last week without lifting the curtain - by announcing its first-ever quarterly profit.

title: CONFESSIONS OF AN ISLANDERS NUT
description: MY HUSBAND has created a monster - and even he doesn't know how it happened.

title: 3-STATE WARNING ISSUED ON CONTAMINATED MILK
description: Warnings about drinking milk have been issued to pregnant women and nursing mothers as officials try to determine the extent of pesticide-contaminated milk in parts of Arkansas, Oklahoma and Missouri.

title: Lucy Luckhardt Plans To Marry S. A. Calder
description: The engagement of Lucy Anne Luckhardt to Stephen Andrew Calder has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Luckhardt of Easton, Conn., and Yarmouth, Me.

title: SOVIET DEFECTOR FACES TRIAL IN EMIGRE'S DEATH
description: A 44-year-old Soviet defector has been ordered to stand trial for the death of his former lover, a Soviet emigre who testified for the prosecution at the first espionage trial of Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Recent Sales
description: Emerson $129,000 84 George Road *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 32-year-old ranch; *2*wall-to-wall carpeting, 2-car garage; taxes $2,051. River Edge $205,000 11 June Court *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old split-level; *2*3-zone heat, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,180. Rockaway $142,000 8 Debbie Place *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old bilevel; *2*stained-glass windows, wall-to-wall carpeting, patio; *2*taxes $2,283. Sayerville $107,000 129Weber Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old split-level; *2*natural woodwork, shutters, family room; taxes $1,678. Wayne $138,000 376 Alps Road *2*5-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old Cape Cod; *2*spiral staircase, circular driveway, mother-daughter; *2*taxes $2,001. West Orange $110,000 2 Orange Place *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*sun room, 2-car garage; taxes $2,488. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $177,825 91 Concord Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old Tudor/ Norman; *2*sun room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $1,597. Branford, Conn. $220,000 61 Goodsell Point *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 56-year-old Cape Cod; *2*waterfront location, 80- by 420-foot lot; taxes $1,349. Manhasset, L.I. $380,000 107 Shoreview Road *2*5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; *2*den, fireplace, basement, patio, deck; taxes $3,800.

title: Deborah Kieffer
description: The mezzo-soprano Deborah Kieffer, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night, has sung with the New York City Opera, the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the Tulsa Opera and the Opera Orchestra of New York. She is currently on the faculties of Catholic University and the Levine School of Music in Washington.

title: SUIT SEEKS RETURN OF LAND TO BEDFORD
description: FIVE Bedford residents in a joint legal challenge are seeking to have 252 acres of land in the village of Mount Kisco be made part of the town of Bedford.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: March 9, 1986 Fiction

title:
ART;
NEUBERGER FEATURES MANGOLD
description: THE current art scene is less frenzied than it was a year ago. A chief beneficiary is minimal art, which looks especially healthy. As happens time and time again, what recently looked boring now appears refreshing.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BLOOD VOTE. By Jack Lindsay. (University of Queensland Press, $15.95.) Written in 1937 but not published till now, Jack Lindsay's novel depicts Australian labor politics during World War I. The action begins on November 7, 1917, while the Government is beginning a drive to win voter approval for military conscription (and, far away, the Bolsheviks are launching their own revolution).

title: 3 PHOTOGRAPHY SHOWS: FROM PORTRAITS TO 'AVAILABLE FORMS'
description: OF THE three photography shows reviewed this week, the largest is ''Viewpoints,'' on display through April 6 at the Squibb Gallery on Route 206 in Lawrence Township.

title: Welfare Fraud With Official Help
description: AFTER New York City's Human Resources Administration reported in December that employees at three hotels in Manhattan had connived with transients to defraud the city of welfare checks, Mayor Koch made a surprising admission.

title: PROMISES AND COSTLY DISAPPOINTMENTS
description: Joseph Travis explained his new venture in a letter dated Oct. 11, 1985, to subscribers to his NEAR Inc. travel-emergency services. He was establishing CostLess Travel Worldwide, he wrote, in response to the many requests he had received for additional benefits. ''Through prior arrangements with major airlines, hotel chains, tour operators, cruise lines and other travel suppliers,'' he wrote, ''we are able to purchase their unsold space and products at 25 cents on the dollar and resell it to you at 50 cents on the dollar.''

title: POLICEMAN HURT IN DISPUTE
description: A police officer was stabbed three times yesterday, but not seriously injured, when he tried to break up a dispute between a man and a woman at Second Street and the Bowery.

title: GENTLEMEN PREFER GOLF
description: Joaquin Andujar, ejected for arguing a call in the World Series last October, had to be restrained by his St. Louis Cardinal teammates after charging the umpire Don Denkinger. Before being traded to Oakland, the pitcher was suspended for 10 days by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth, effective at the start of the coming season.

title: Cable TV
description: To the French, it was no less than the best foreign film of the year. To the British, who will bestow their Academy Awards next Sunday, it was worthy of no less than four nominations, including best film; and in the United States, it has been nominated for best screenplay. The film is ''The Purple Rose of Cairo,'' Woody Allen's achingly sweet, comic excursion into cinematic reality and illusion in Depression-era New Jersey, which will make its cable debut on Cinemax Sunday at 10 A.M. at 8 P.M. and Saturday evening at 7:30.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: STATE TO SEEK TIGHTER RULES ON EXPANSION BY HOSPITAL
description: ONLY hospitals with at least 200 beds and an 80 percent overall occupancy rate would be allowed to build or renovate under tough new regulations expected to be proposed this week by the state's Commissioner of Health.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
LONDON: NEW CLASSICS
description: THE MOOD IN LONdon is more serious for fall and winter 1986 than it has been in recent seasons. Both newcomers and established designers alike seem to be turning out simpler, more wearable designs.

title:
SPORTS;
TEAM SECRET: 5 BECOME 1
description: THERE is only one high school in Hempstead, but its basketball team is making its mark as one of the best high school teams in New York State.

title: Linda J. LeBeau To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. H. Alton LeBeau Jr., of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda Joan LeBeau to Christian Eric Victor, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eric Victor de Perre of Paris. The wedding is planned for May 2.

title: POP: VIOLENT FEMMES
description: A YOUNG, well-groomed, restive and thoroughly spoiled audience filled Carnegie Hall for Friday's concert by the Violent Femmes, a three-man band from Milwaukee.

title: Miss Conger Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clement E. Conger of Alexandria, Va., and Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Shelley Louise Conger, to Michael Francis Dabrowski, a son of Mrs. Hector Marsiglia of Thiells, N.Y., and Francis Dabrowski of Philadelphia.

title: Topics; Sanctuaries Ere I Saw Elba
description: ''In the old days you went to the Riviera, and nobody made a fuss about it,'' Russell Baker wrote recently about the housing problems of Haiti's President for Life and his First Lady. ''You emptied the state treasury into armored trucks . . . picked up a palace here, a palace there . . . ran into interesting people, too.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHUTTLE MEMORANDUM BY ASTRONAUTS' CHIEF
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum released here today that was written by John W. Young, chief of the astronaut office of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, which accompanied an ''enclosure'' listing what he says are routine but dangerous conditions in the space shuttle program.

title: Ethics Policy Brings Teacher Complaints
description: The superintendent of schools says he was just filling in a blank page of a policy manual with what seemed a simple reflection: Instructors should behave morally and ethically in and out of school.

title: POSTINGS
description: A community of condominium town houses, coupled with a marina and newly renovated restaurant, is being formed along the Manasquan River in Monmouth County, N.J.

title: SAVINGS BANKS ASSAY EFFECTS OF DEREGULATION
description: IN January 1974, when Paul A. Schosberg became president of the New York League of Savings Institutions, the Scarsdale-based trade association had 141 institution members statewide. Twelve years later, as the thrift industry moves into the final phase of deregulation, the league's member organizations have been reduced to 86, including eight headquartered in the county.

title: Women's Conference In Nairobi Faulted
description: In the Feb. 16 New Jerseyans column, we read about Leigh Hallingby and her experiences at, and opinions of, the United Nations Women's Conference in Nairobi, Kenya. We are told that she represented the northern New Jersey chapter of the National Organization for Women.

title: FROM SEA TO SHINING SEA
description: One of the reasons people travel is to bring something home. Note the traffic jam at customs. We are reluctant to leave Thailand without a temple rubbing, Greece without a flokati rug. And while this urge to acquire is in direct conflict with another reason people travel - to unburden themselves - even an ocean can activate the consumer instinct. We sit before the sea half-thinking that it owes us something - perhaps the secret of buoyancy - for our having made the effort to show up.

title: THE END FOR LEWIS
description: After Texas beat Houston, 78-62, in the quarterfinals of the Southwest Conference basketball tournament Friday, the Cougars' coach, Guy Lewis, wasn't crying in his trademark red and white polka dot towel. Instead, Lewis celebrated the loss by exclaiming ''Yipee! It's over.''

title: GREENWICH VILLAGE PUTS DRUG DEALERS ON NOTICE
description: When they were not blowing whistles or banging cymbals at people they suspected were drug dealers, the more than 200 Greenwich Village residents, young and old, raised their voices.

title: STEREO TV - IT'S ALL IN THE SOUND
description: Last week, RCA ventured the prediction that more than half the color television sets sold this year will be equipped for stereo. The same would then hold true for video cassette recorders, for VCR's and television sets work, so to speak, hand in hand. It makes no sense to have stereo capability in either unless it is matched by the other.

title: MICHIGAN TAKES BIG 10 TITLE
description: Roy Tarpley's 21 points paced a powerful Michigan attack as the Wolverines clinched their second consecutive Big Ten championship today with an 80-52 victory over Indiana.

title: DANCE: BALLET OF CHINA IN 'GISELLE' PAS DE DEUX
description: ALTHOUGH its hero and heroine often dance together in the graveyard scene of its second act, ''Giselle'' does not possess a conventional pas de deux that can easily be presented as a self-contained unit. Any excerpt from that act is bound to look like a fragment.

title:
ART;
WORKS THAT MOLD, AND ARE MOLDED, BY NATURE
description: ARTISTS respond to nature in many and varied ways, often with results that defy conventional definition. For the work of Keith Long and Richard Wands, the two artists now sharing the Works II Gallery in Southampton, the term ''landscape'' is an inappropriate categorization, yet both men are deeply involved with the natural environment and their creations reflect this preoccupation.

title: TREAT PLAYERS LIKE OTHERS
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN;
THE ROCKAWAYS
description: THE ROCKAWAYS offer a special set of amenities to homeowners. They can commute by rapid transit to jobs in midtown Manhattan in little more than an hour and have a splendid beach and ocean bathing at their doors when they get home.

title: ROOTS ARE TRACED IN A SPIRITUAL SUITE
description: AT FIRST glance, Howard Roberts would seem to have relatively modest goals for ''The Spiritual Heritage,'' his new vocal suite that will have its world premiere on Saturday in Freeport.

title: POLAR BEAR KILLED AT ZOO IN AN ATTEMPTED MATING
description: A 925-pound polar bear named Caesar mauled and killed his intended mate, Princess Snowball, at a zoo here Friday, a spokesman for the zoo said.

title:
ART;
AN UPBEAT SHOW OF FAMILIAR ARTISTS IN STAMFORD
description: AT first, some mystique surrounds the title of the current offering at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford. The show is ''Connecticut Collects,'' and the query is what sets Connecticut apart from the rest of the country in the realm of taste?

title: About Men; Ingrained Reflexes
description: IN 1970, THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA was forced by a legal decision to open its doors to women, but when I enrolled in Mr. Jefferson's University in 1960, its undergraduate college was still an all-male institution.

title: U.N. STUDYING LEGALITY OF U.S. CUTBACK ORDER
description: High-ranking United Nations officials said today that they were investigating the legality of the United States order to the Soviet missions to reduce their personnel by more than a third.

title: Miss Henderson To Wed May 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Henderson of New York and Nissequogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Anne Henderson to Tyrone Bert Stephens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Bert Stephens of Boca Raton, Fla. A May 31 wedding is planned.

title: AKRON MOVES TO N.C.A.A.
description: The following conference championship games played yesterday decided automatic bids to the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament:

title: MORRIS EXTENDING LONG ARM OF LAW
description: USING a new countywide computer program, law-enforcement officials in Morris County not only have been catching people for whom there are outstanding warrants for nonindictable offenses, but also have been collecting money owed to towns.

title: TOWNS PREPARE FOR LOSS OF $54 MILLION IN FEDERAL AID
description: THE end of general revenue sharing will mean $54 million less in Federal aid for Connecticut's 169 municipalities, state officials say, and as the towns and cities prepare their budgets, many are bracing for spending cuts and tax increases as a result.

title:
ANTIQUES;
RARE BRASS AND PEWTER IN GREENWICH
description: GARLAND PASS of Avon and his wife, Frances, collect, research and sell fine, early metalware, particularly pewter and brass. They will be among the exhibitors at the Seventh Annual Greenwich Antiques Show, March 21-23.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PLANE CRAZY: A Celebration of Flying. By Burton Bernstein. (Ticknor & Fields, $16.95.) Didn't everyone in long-ago America spend the happiest hours of childhood hanging around the local airport, envying the freedom of the men and women who came and went in rackety little machines that mysteriously responded to their will? Well, I did, and so did Burton Bernstein.

title: Kathleen Traynor Planning to Wed Richard Millard
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Traynor of Berkeley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Suzanne Traynor to Richard Dudensing Millard, a son of Mrs. Peter deFlorez Millard of New York and Barneveld, N.Y., and the late Richard Bowen Dudensing. The wedding is planned for May 3.

title: Talking New Windows; Co-ops Find Planning Eases Pain
description: BEFORE the Age of Co-op Living, the only significance of windows in New York City apartments was the daylight they brought in and, if the occupant was lucky, the view.

title: Kaaren Erickson
description: There is a perennial shortage of sensitive lieder singers, and on the evidence of a Wednesday night recital at the 92d Street Y, we may hope for great things from the soprano Kaaren Erickson. Miss Erickson - who has sung leading roles for the New York City, Seattle and San Francisco Operas and most recently for the Metropolitan Opera - has a voice that is healthy and sweet, a cultivated musicianship and a straightforward way with a song.

title: CORDERO INJURED
description: Angel Cordero Jr. suffered a bruised liver and a broken leg yesterday when his horse, Highfalutin, fell nearing the first turn and another horse stepped on the jockey during the fourth race at Aqueduct.

title: IN IVY LEAGUE, ONLY HARVARD BARS PINUP AD
description: Dozens of Harvard women found their way this week to a suburban Holiday Inn where a photographer from Playboy magazine took Polaroid snapshots of them, clothed, and asked them to fill out applications listing their hobbies, academic majors and measurements.

title: CAMBODIAN GUERRILLAS REPORT KILLING 200 VIETNAM TROOPS
description: Cambodian guerrillas said today that they killed 200 Vietnamese soldiers and wounded 150 others in a raid on a town near Phnom Penh.

title: BUSINESSES OFFERED ENERGY PROGRAM
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES will pay businesses and municipalities to use less electricity, under a new four-part program to conserve more than $250 million worth of energy before the turn of the century.

title: Technology Is Fallible
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ AT RUTGERS Dick Hyman, the pianist-composer, will present the ragtime, jazz and show music of Eubie Blake in New Brunswick Friday evening. The concert, part of Rutgers University's annual salute to the New Jersey Jazz Society, will begin at 8 o'clock in the Nicholas Music Center on the Douglass College campus.

title: BOMBS ROCK BANGLADESH IN ELECTION PLAN PROTEST
description: Bombs exploded and a Government car was attacked today during a nationwide strike called by opposition parties to protest the military Government's plan to hold parliamentary elections under martial law on April 26, witnesses and the police said.

title: DEATH RATES USED IN HOSPITAL STUDY
description: Some intensive care units save up to three times as many lives of severely ill patients as others, according to a federally financed study of 5,030 patients in 13 hospitals.

title: AQUINO TO DISCUSS TRANSITION TACTIC
description: President Corazon C. Aquino moved her Government today from an office building to its permanent quarters in a guest house on the grounds of Malacanang Palace.

title: DANCE: 'BRIGHT ORCHARD'
description: ''BRIGHT ORCHARD'' was certainly a sweet dance but it was not very substantial. Collaboratively choreographed by Diane Frank and Deborah Riley and performed by a cast of 13 capable dancers, ''Bright Orchard'' was offered Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: BATTLE OVER JOHNSON ESTATE GOING INTO 2D WEEK IN COURT
description: The court battle over the $500 million estate of the late J. Seward Johnson, an heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, moves into its second full week in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan today.

title: Bold Moves, at Last, in Brazil
description: Among the world's debtors, Brazil stands out as owing the most - $100 billion. Though its economy is large and fundamentally strong, it suffers sharp inflation and pervasive poverty. Hope lies only in strong measures to restructure its economy, combined with strong outside support.

title: More Rivalry
description: The Democratic Governors Association assigned one political luminary to each table for its week. Though Governor Cuomo of New York canceled his appearance at the last minute and no appropriate replacement could be found, the guests at what would have been his table did not lack for attention. Two other 1988 Democratic Presidential hopefuls who were on hand, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, swarmed over the Cuomo-less guests, anticipating that such attention might present a contrast with their absent rival.

title: And Soon Deductibility Will Be Nibbled Away
description: To the Editor:

title: Tainted Milk Recalled In 2 Southern States
description: Dairies in Arkansas and Oklahoma recalled more than 60,000 gallons of milk today after tests showed it contained too much of a pesticide suspected of causing cancer, state health officials said.

title: AD COUNCIL CAMPAIGN WARNS ABOUT COCAINE
description: Ill-conceived public assumptions about cocaine, which are contributing to a frightening increase in the use of the drug, are the target of a new Advertising Council campaign prepared by Needham Harper Worldwide for the National Institute on Drug Abuse. The simple but effective theme line is: ''Cocaine.

title: U.S. TELLS WHAT IT EXPECTS WALKER TO SAY ON SPY RING
description: Since John A. Walker Jr. was arrested last year, he has remained a tantalizing puzzle, unwilling to comment publicly about his decision to become a Soviet spy and recruit his son and brother into espionage.

title: FLYERS BEAT RANGERS BY 4-1
description: With their shortcomings exposed -little offensive pizzazz, a mistake-prone defense and the inability to alter their game to fit the challenge -the Rangers lost to the Philadelpia Flyers last night, 4-1, and their push to make the playoffs lost more precious time.

title: Australia Is Told I.R.A. May Try to Kill Queen
description: A warning that Irish Republican Army terrorists might try to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II of Britain as she visits Australia caused a nationwide alert by the authorities, newspapers said today.

title: CONAGRA RULING SET
description: Conagra Inc., the Omaha-based diversified food company, said Friday that the Nebraska Supreme Court had reversed a lower court decision, ruling that it was not entitled to a $16 million in damages from Cargill Inc. arising out of a 1978 takeover fight for the nation's second-largest beef packing company.

title: Bridge: An Unusual Smother Play In a Board-a-Match Event
description: Two rare bridge birds met recently in a Michigan tournament. It was a sectional board-a-match teams event, which was once common but is now in danger of extinction.

title: KEAN TELLS THE G.O.P. TO WIDEN
description: Governor Kean, who won a landslide re-election victory in November by capturing the votes of blue-collar workers and members of minority groups, came here Saturday night to deliver a warning.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
description: The Economy The prospect of smaller deficits is changing the debate about future economic policies. Signs that $200 billion budget deficits are a thing of the past could reinforce President Reagan's opposition to cuts in spending for Social Security and the military and stiffen his opposition to a tax increase, economists note. But some are fearful that the forecasts of smaller deficits could divert attention from the deficit problem before it is really solved. [ Page A1. ] Weak economic statistics may push interest rates lower during the next few weeks, but the decline is not expected to be as sharp as during the past month. [ D1. ] A resurgence in fixed-rate mortgages is raising concern that savings institutions could be hurt as they were in the 1970's and early 1980's if interest rates climb again. [ D1. ] Companies Peoples Jewellers raised its bid for Zale, the nation's largest jewelry retailer, to $45 a share in cash and notes, from $40. Zale's board refused last Monday to consider the first bid. [ D1. ] Altman's has offered its president's job to a Dallas retailer, Jack Schultz of Sanger-Harris, industry sources say. [ D2. ] International Western Europe's economic prospects are at a 10-year peak, thanks to the sustained drop in oil prices and the value of the dollar. [ D1. ] A long-term decline in oil prices would hamper Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to revitalize the Soviet economy. [ D10. ] OPEC oil production will average 800,000 barrels a day less in the first three months of this year than in the last quarter of 1985, dropping to 16.8 million, the International Energy Agency reported.

title: Dr. King's Church Is 100
description: About 200 congregants marked the 100th birthday today of Ebenezer Baptist Church, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his father or his grandfather preached for 80 years.

title: A LINE OF DEFENSE UNDER STRESS
description: To help American savers sleep at night and to give more stability to the American banking system, the Congress, more than 50 years ago, created a Federal agency that insures deposits at the nation's commercial banks.

title: OPTIMISM IN WESTERN EUROPE
description: Buoyed by the sustained drop in both oil prices and the value of the United States dollar, Western Europe's economic prospects are brighter today than at any time in the past decade.

title: HIGH STAKES FOR HEARNS
description: Thomas Hearns will have a lot at stake, financially and professionally, Monday night in challenging James Shuler for the North American Boxing Federation middleweight title.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Zimbabwe Muddles On
description: Contradictions: The front page of The Herald, the Government-controlled daily, reports that Zimbabwe's Minister of Youth Sport and Cultures is appealing to the Soviet Union for help in the struggle against apartheid and Zionism. The same edition on page 6 carries a complete listing of prices on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange. This capital's central business district is blossoming with high-rise office buildings; its tree-lined avenues would be the pride of any small Sun Belt city. A few blocks away, the tenants of crumbling bungalows grow corn in their front yards to supplement wages.

title: U.A.W. Reaches Settlement
description: The United Auto Workers union and Volkswagen of America announced today that they had reached tentative agreements for contracts covering employees in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Texas.

title: O'CONNOR WARNS MEDICAL SCHOOL CHOICE IS CHURCH LINK OR ABORTION
description: The Archdiocese of New York is threatening to drop its support of a medical college that it saved from financial failure eight years ago unless two city hospitals affiliated with the school stop performing abortions.

title: Catching Up
description: * If you thought the Chicago Bears were a pretty good football team, you should hear how they're faring as video performers. The ''Super Bowl Shuffle'' rap-session cassette that went on sale late in December has sold 238,000 copies, which places it among the dozen best-selling tapes in history.

title: Teacher Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY G. TRENTIN
description: Henry G. Trentin, a former senior partner of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting and consulting firm, died of cancer Feb. 28 at his home in Centerville, Mass. He was 72 years old and also had a home in Short Hills, N.J.

title: INTERPUBLIC BILLINGS
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies is again sharing the data sent to Advertising Age for its annual billings issue. The trade publication does not use all of the information. The holding company's three agency networks, for example, contributed $4.74 billion in billings last year. The smallest, Marschalk Campbell-Ewald Worldwide, broke $1 billion for the first time, while McCann-Erickson was at $2.3 billion and SSC&B:Lintas was at $1.44 billion

title: DANCE: 'LASTING EFFECT'
description: MONICA LEVY'S ''Lasting Effect,'' a new dance-theater piece performed yesterday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, began with an argument of sorts between Michael Sean Edwards and his screen image, projected on a wall behind him. The flesh-and-blood Mr. Edwards and Hilary Easton, portraying former lovers, had another continuing tiff during the full-program piece. Each of the arguments had to do with reality: Is the Michael Edwards on the dance floor more ''real'' than the projected Michael Edwards? Is Miss Easton's memory of a car breakdown and party real if she wasn't, as Mr. Edwards suggests, really there?

title: CONTINUING RATE FALL EXPECTED
description: A spate of weak economic statistics expected during the next few weeks may help keep alive hopes that interest rates will continue to fall, though not so precipitously as during the past month.

title: Exiled Top Communist In South Africa Is Dead
description: Moses Mabhida, who organized black workers in South Africa and headed the South African Communist Party, has died at the age of 62, it was announced today.

title: HEPBURN IN TRIBUTE TO TRACY
description: THE moment is as wrenching as it is unexpected. Katharine Hepburn, a fiercely private person, begins reading a letter she wrote to Spencer Tracy long after he had died in 1967. It is an extremely personal document, openly reflecting the special love that existed between them. Tears welling in her eyes, she recalls that ''living wasn't easy for you, was it?'' She mentions his drinking problem and the puzzling fact that ''you couldn't enter your own life but you could be someone else.'' For all of that, she declares, he was still ''the world's best movie actor.''

title: NEEDHAM IS 2D AGENCY FOR HASBRO-BRADLEY
description: Needham Harper Worldwide has become the second agency for Hasbro-Bradley, the country's largest toy company, by winning a competition that came down to five finalists, each of whom prepared campaigns for three products.

title: 2 UNITS SOLD BY ALCOA
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it had sold two of its subsidiaries - the Rea Magnet Wire Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., and Algonquin Industries of Guilford, Conn. -to a management group for an amount under $50 million. The sale is part of a redeployment of assets.

title: German Not Informed He Has Artificial Heart
description: The first West German to receive an artificial heart has not been told his own heart was replaced by a mechanical device, his doctor said today.

title: DOYLE DANE PROFIT OFF
description: Citing the economy and budget cuts by clients, the Doyle Dane Bernbach Group said its fourth-quarter revenues fell 1 percent and net income fell 59 percent. Revenues came to $61.24 million, down from $62.1 million a year earlier. Net income was $1.65 million, or 29 cents a share, down from $4 million, or 70 cents a share.

title: Dr. Susan Cohn, Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Susan Ellen Cohn, a daughter of Alan D. Cohn of New York and Armonk, N.Y., and the late Nancy D. Cohn, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan David Klein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey W. Klein of Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi Joan Friedman performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: CITY REPORT CITES 50% PROFIT AT A WELFARE HOTEL
description: The rates at the Holland Hotel, used by the city to house homeless families, should be cut by a third, according to an internal city report that found the owners earn nearly a 50 percent profit.

title: WOMEN HONOR AQUINO AND CALL FOR HER HELP
description: From the picket line and prison, from the comfortable middle class to the peasant feminist movement, women of the Philippines called on President Corazon C. Aquino today to put their cares on her agenda for reform.

title: P.L.O. ACCUSES U.S. OF CAUSING COLLAPSE OF JORDANIAN TALKS
description: Seeking to avoid a complete break with King Hussein of Jordan, the Palestine Liberation Organization has accused the United States of causing the collapse of the Middle East peace initiative between the King and Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. leader.

title: U.S. TOPS ECUADOR IN DAVIS CUP PLAY
description: Jimmy Arias defeated Raul Viver today to give the United States a 3-2 first-round victory over Ecuador in Davis Cup play.

title: CURRY RETAINS TITLE WITH KNOCKOUT
description: Donald Curry knocked out Eduardo Rodriguez with a crashing left-right combination to the head in the second round and retained the undisputed world welterweight championship today before a frenzied crowd of hometown fans.

title: Maria Zompakos Wed To Jeffrey Butterfield
description: The wedding of Maria Christina Zompakos, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelos Zompakos of Flushing, Queens, and East Marion, L.I., to Jeffrey Mason Butterfield, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Butterfield Jr. of Allendale, N.J., took place yesterday. The Rev. George G. Passias performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Flushing.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CINEMATIC Horton Foote has won Academy Awards for two screenplays. His adaptation of ''To Kill a Mockingbird'' earned him the honor in 1962, and he received an Oscar for ''Tender Mercies'' in 1983. Last month, he received another Oscar nomination - for his screenplay for ''The Trip to Bountiful.''

title: STUDY SHOWS MANY FAMILIES TAKE STEPS TO PREVENT CRIME
description: One-third of all American households have a burglar alarm, participate in a neighborhood watch program or engrave their valuables with an identification number, according to a report made public today.

title: COST-CUTTER IN POST AT BANK OF AMERICA
description: Thomas A. Cooper, who last week was named president and chief operating officer of the troubled but sought after Bank of America, is not your ordinary financial type.
