title: MUSIC: DAVID TAYLOR'S 6 SONGS
description: DAVID TAYLOR'S Six Songs Avec Benediction et Divertissement were accompanied yesterday afternoon by a printed historical apologia for his pastiche style, but one suspects their main reason for being was the chance they gave Mr. Taylor to bring his bass trombone front and center.

title: N.F.L. Meetings Open in California
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., March 9 -

title: U.S. Should Set Nursing-Home Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Put the Burden on the Borders, Not on Employers; Costs to Municipalities
description: To the Editor:

title: GIULIANI URGES DISCLOSURE BY DONORS
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, proposed yesterday that campaign contributors in New York be required to disclose their financial interests in government contracts and government regulatory actions.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article Feb. 24 on Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, mischaracterized his status. Dr. Sakharov was confined to internal exile in the city of Gorky in 1980 by administrative action but has never been convicted of any illegal activity.

title: BRASS MAKERS ASSAIL IMPORTS
description: The nation's brass producers today accused seven countries of unfairly subsidizing or selling their brass products in the United States at less than cost.

title: 2D CRAFT, BOMBARDED BY DUST, GETS CLOSE VIEWS OF HALLEY'S
description: Vega 2, the second of the Soviet Union's two unmanned missions to Halley's comet, flew within 5,200 miles of the comet's nucleus today and sent data apparently confirming theories that the elliptical nucleus is solid.

title: AGENCY REBUTS TOP ASTRONAUT ON SAFETY RISK
description: Top space agency officials took sharp exception yesterday to charges by the agency's chief astronaut that shuttle crews have been repeatedly exposed to potentially ''catastrophic'' hazards because of pressures to maintain launching schedules.

title: The U.N. Today; March 10, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: KOREAN CARDINAL BACKS OPPOSITION
description: The Roman Catholic primate of South Korea, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, gave his support today to opposition party demands for swift constitutional changes that would permit direct presidential elections.

title: Amy Sue Gordon Marries Gary Wolff in Great Neck
description: The Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Amy Sue Gordon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gordon of New York, to Gary Scott Wolff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lou Wolff of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbis Haskel Lookstein and Fabian Schonfeld performed the ceremony.

title: RUSSIAN WHO PEERED INTO HALLEY'S
description: Not long after his graduation from Moscow State University in 1955, Roald Z. Sagdeyev attended a Geneva conference on atomic energy and met American scientists for the first time. ''It was 30 years ago,'' Mr. Sagdeyev, the physicist who heads the Space Research Institute, said last week. ''I was very young. I was looking at them as extraterrestrials,'' Barely pausing, he added, ''Throughout my career, I felt very close to my American colleagues.''

title: 26 Held in Soccer Fighting
description: Mounted police used dogs and tear gas Saturday to break up fighting between rival soccer fans that spread into the city center, and 26 fans were arrested, the police said today.

title: BULLS TROUNCE KNICKS, 114-101
description: Hubie Brown and Stan Albeck could spend hours consoling each other over the troubles they have seen this season. Both men could lament the injuries that have left them without their best players. Albeck, the coach of the Chicago Bulls, has also had to steer his team through dissension that has been created by the drug problems of one player and the unhappiness of another.

title: Opposition Leader Plans To Return to Pakistan
description: The Pakistani opposition leader Benazir Bhutto intends to end her exile in London and return home at the end of March, risking arrest by doing so, her spokesman said today.

title: LTV AUDIT BY STEELWORKERS
description: The United Steelworkers Union says it concluded from an independent audit that the LTV Corporation's steel division faces bankruptcy unless cost-cutting steps are taken immediately and steel imports are reduced by the Reagan Administration.

title: SANTUCCI SON'S CAR IS SET ABLAZE IN DRIVEWAY OF PROSECUTOR'S HOME
description: An automobile belonging to the son of Queens District Attorney John J. Santucci was set ablaze last night in the driveway of the District Attorney's home in Ozone Park, the police said.

title: MAZZILLI SEEKING A SECOND CHANCE
description: The wind is whipping the miniature palm trees that frame Pirate City into a frenzy of dull green fronds. Out on the practice field, the Pittsburgh Pirates complain about the unseemly Florida chill permeating their spanking white outfits. Their black windbreakers, they tell Jim Leyland, the new manager of one of baseball's worst teams, ought to be fur-lined.

title: DUKE DEFEATS GA. TECH FOR A.C.C. TITLE
description: A group of Duke seniors intent on making up for past disappointments rose to the occasion again today, scoring 4 points and staging a key defensive stand in the last seconds to emerge with a 68-67 victory over Georgia Tech in the championship game of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament.

title: CANADIAN JOBLESS RATE
description: About 1.34 million Canadians were unemployed last month, about 6,000 fewer than in January, for a seasonally adjusted jobless rate of 9.8 percent, the Government's Statistics Canada said Friday. The unemployment rate, a four-year low and essentially unchanged from January, is not expected to improve much this year or next. Finance Minister Michael Wilson predicted in last week's budget that the rate would decline to 9.6 percent by the final quarter of this year and to 9.1 percent by the final quarter of next year.

title: Vietnam Veterans' Nonstop Con Game
description: For the last few years, we have seen and heard horror stories about American soldiers' experiences in Vietnam. It is true that many went through mental and physical anguish -and still do. But, I'm sorry to say, there's a con job going on here and no one will admit it. The public, in its unabashed desire to wallow in guilt, is being duped.

title: Questions and Concern Over Sidewalk Clocks
description: Once near extinction, sidewalk clocks may rebound so vigorously that they become too much of a good thing in the eyes of the city's Art Commission.

title: TOWN ENDS SILENCE ON TOUCHY ISSUES
description: Over the decades, this town of working-class whites has been known for its late-night taverns and racial intolerance. If anybody in town thought these were bad traits, for the most part they kept it to themselves.

title: Manchester Loses
description: The defending champion Manchester United was eliminated from the English F. A. Cup today, losing by 2-0 at home to West Ham United in a fifth-round soccer replay. A header goal by Geoff Pike in the 18th minute and a second-half penalty shot by Ray Stewart earned the visitors a quarterfinal berth against Sheffield Wednesday.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR APOLOGIZES FOR CONFRONTATION WITH RADICALS
description: In his first response to a critical report on the police confrontation with the radical group Move, Mayor W. Wilson Goode delivered a formal apology tonight, expressing sorrow and contrition to ''each and every Philadelphian who has suffered.''

title: DAWKINS POWERS THE BLUE DEVILS
description: FROM the moment four seasons ago that he stepped onto a basketball court in the uniform of the Duke Blue Devils, great things have been expected of Johnny Dawkins.

title: South Korean Retains Title
description: Yoo Myong-woo of South Korea won a unanimous 15-round decision today over the challenger Jose de Jesus of Puerto Rico and retained his World Boxing Association junior-flyweight crown.

title: ISLANDERS BEATEN AGAIN BY CAPITALS
description: The Islanders promised playoff-style hockey for their weekend series with the Washington Capitals, the team they have eliminated from the playoffs for three consecutive seasons. But the Capitals spoiled the Islanders' weekend with a 3-1 victory today at Capital Centre, their second triumph in two days.

title: For Jpn-Americans
description: It's not at all clear that Congress can legislate away what it perceives to be a racial slur - if a majority comes to share that perception - but Representative Mike Lowry is giving it a try anyway. The Washington State Democrat has introduced a resolution expressing the ''sense of Congress'' that Americans should use ''Jpn'' instead of ''Jap'' as an abbreviation for ''Japanese.''

title: 80,000 IN MARCH TO CAPITOL TO BACK RIGHT TO ABORTION
description: At least 80,000 marchers supporting the right to abortion passed the White House today and gathered at the Capitol in what some leaders of the women's movement called a sign of its rejuvenation.

title: Housing Near to Norad Has Air Force Worried
description: Housing developers are encroaching almost to the gates of the North American Aerospace Defense Command, and Air Force officials are worried about security.

title: MET'S NEW 'CARMEN' HAS A FAMILY FLAVOR
description: Sir Peter Hall says the worst drawback to directing your own wife on the opera stage is having to give endless interviews about what it's like to direct your own wife on the opera stage.

title: Missing Lawyer Is Found
description: Dennis M. Buckley, the Waterbury Corporation Counsel, was found Saturday after being reported missing several days, the police said.

title: FAR LEFT IN SPAIN LEADS FIGHT AGAINST NATO MEMBERSHIP
description: Tens of thousands of Spaniards joined in a song festival and rally here today that underlined the fact that the far left is providing the leadership in the drive against Spain's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: 76ERS END 3-GAME SLIDE
description: Moses Malone scored 34 points and had 17 rebounds today as the Philadelphia 76ers broke a three-game losing streak with a 120-102 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: VILLANOVA RALLIES FOR INDOOR TITLE
description: Villanova won the IC4-A indoor track and field championship today with a script that would have been too absurd for a Grade B movie. Consider the elements: A key Villanova distance runner finishes last in his race. An opposing coach protests that the runner did not give an honest effort. Meet officials agree and disqualify the runner and the relay team he was supposed to anchor.

title: RADON IN HOUSES IS VIEWED AS WIDER THREAT IN 3 STATES
description: Potentially harmful levels of radon, a radioactive gas that can cause cancer, may be contaminating homes over a much wider area of New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania than previously believed, according to scientific experts and public health officials.

title: OPEC PRODUCTION EXPECTED TO FALL
description: Crude oil production by the 13 members of OPEC is expected to average 800,000 barrels a day less in the first three months of this year than in the last quarter of 1985, the International Energy Agency said today.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:06 A.M. today and set at 1:45 P.M.

title: GOODEN EXCELS AS METS ROUT CARDINALS
description: Dwight Gooden pitched three shutout innings against the St. Louis Cardinals in his spring training debut today, and did nothing to diminish his image or to prompt the Mets to run for the hills.

title: ST. JOHN'S, DUKE, KANSAS AND KENTUCKY SEEDED FIRST
description: For the second straight season, the St. John's Redmen's road to the Final Four will begin out West. They were seeded No. 1 in the West in the tournament brackets announced last night by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: GLASS SAVORS ST. JOHN'S VICTORY
description: At the height of the emotional celebration following St. John's thrilling 70-69 victory over Syracuse on Saturday, Willie Glass stood on the rim of the basket where Ron Rowan, just a few minutes earlier, had made a last-gasp jump shot that gave St. John's the Big East tournament championship.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ethyl Corp., Richmond, has named Ray Wilkins Jr. president of its Chemical Group.

title: ROLE OF THE FLOOR TRADER
description: THE strong suit of the futures industry has long been its influence in Washington. It liberally dispenses lobbying funds and campaign contributions there and has received, in turn, several highly lucrative legislative benefits, such as favorable tax laws and protection from certain kinds of competition.

title: A MENCKEN FOREBEAR ALSO DEFLATED EGOTISM
description: There are gifts that run in families, and there are gifts that jump about in families. For an interesting example of the latter, consider the case of Johann Burkhard Mencke (1674-1732) and H. L. Mencken (1880-1956), who was descended from one of Mencke's cousins. (The n that the family eventually tacked on to the end of the name was lifted from the Latin form, Menckenius.) Johann Burkhard Mencke was a celebrated scholar in his day, who taught history at the University of Leipzig and produced a number of bulky tomes, as well as studies in such historical byways as the significance of the hat as a symbol of liberty and the celebration of birthdays among the Romans. For posterity, however, his chief claim to be remembered is that he also wrote ''The Charlatanry of the Learned.''

title: Naval Academy Senior Rejects Order to Resign
description: A Naval Academy midshipman accused of taking cocaine while on a weekend leave said today that he would not resign from the academy and would present his case to the Secretary of the Navy.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, exhibition game, at Clearwater, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) College: Arizona State at Texas. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Mavericks vs. Boston Celtics, at Dallas. The Celtics routed the Mavericks, 137-117, in Boston earlier this season. (Television - WTBS 8:05 P.M.) Boxing Marvelous Marvin Hagler, champion, vs. John Mugabi, 12 rounds, for the undisputed world middleweight championship, at Las Vegas, Nev. Starts approximately 10:55 P.M. James Shuler, champion, vs. Thomas Hearns, 12 rounds, for the North American Boxing Federation middleweight title, at Las Vegas, approximately 9:45 P.M. Richard Sandoval vs. Gaby Canizales, 15 rounds, World Boxing Association bantamweight championship. Sandoval (29-0 with 16 knockouts), from Pomona, Calif., will make his third title defense against Canizales (32-2 with 25 knockouts) in this bout, which opens the closed-circuit telecast from Las Vegas at 9 P.M. Mike Tyson vs. Steve Zouski, 10 rounds, heavyweights, and James (Buddy) McGirt vs. David Odem, 10 rounds, super lightweights, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 7 P.M. Live features are preliminaries for the Hagler-Mugabi closed-circuit telecast from Las Vegas. Tyson, from Catskill, N.Y., is going for his 19th consecutive professional career knockout victory. Track & Field Colgate Women's Games XII, finals, at Madison Square Garden, 4 P.M. The Olympic gold medalist Diane Dixon of the Atoms track team, the grand-prix points champion in the recently completed indoor season, leads the field of 233 in this largest of indoor meets for women.

title: Ellen Goldner, Official At College, Is Married
description: Ellen Goldner, the daughter of Sylvia Goldner of New York and the late Leo Goldner, was married yesterday to Norman Roth, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Roth of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: REMAINS MAY HOLD CLUES TO SAFER SPACE JOURNEYS
description: The discovery of the remains of the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Challenger could allow forensic scientists to determine not only how the crew members lost their lives, but also whether the shuttle can be redesigned to include safety features that might save the lives of future space travelers.

title: Polo Detour
description: Robert E. (Bobby) Strawbridge Jr., the polo player and longtime official of the sport who died last week at age 89, seemed to have been born with a silver stirrup on his foot.

title: DANCE: CHINESE BALLET CAST CHANGES
description: IT was a more confident, more assured and increasingly impressive public face that the Central Ballet of China showed off for packed houses at the Brooklyn Academy of Music over the weekend. As a whole, the company from Peking is even better than first apparent.

title: ALTMAN IS SAID TO OFFER TOP POST TO DALLAS RETAILER
description: Jack Schultz, the general merchandise manager for women's apparel at the Sanger-Harris department stores in Dallas, has been offered the post of president of the B. Altman stores based in New York, according to retail trade sources.

title: CABARET: JOHN HERRERA SINGS
description: JOHN HERRERA, who is currently appearing on Broadway as Neville in ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' belongs to a younger breed of stage singer whose style of theatrical belting incorporates some of the freedom of rock. Mr. Herrera, who appeared at Don't Tell Mama on Friday and Saturday nights, possesses a ferociously declamatory second tenor that suggests a better-trained version of Harry Chapin. That's no coincidence.

title: FIXED-RATE MORTGAGES HELD THREAT TO LENDERS
description: For the first time since mid-1983, more Americans are choosing fixed-rate mortgages than adjustable-rate ones. The attraction for the consumer is that fixed rates have fallen below 10 percent. But the trend has savings executives, Government regulators and other industry experts concerned.

title: INDIRECT U.S. TAX ON MUNICIPAL BONDS CHALLENGED
description: The Federal Government's ability to tax interest on municipal bonds indirectly has been challenged by a retired Santa Barbara, Calif., couple, who were required to pay the tax on their 1984 return.

title: Old Friends
description: Rivalry between two nations that both claim the longest continuous friendly diplomatic relationship with the United States has provoked an international controversy, spirited but not yet ominous.

title: NEW SPLIT ON WORLD BANK POST
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock has taken himself out of the running for the presidency of the World Bank, creating new divisions between the Treasury Department and the White House.

title: People
description: * Ira Carlin, media director of McCann-Erickson New York, has been elected an executive vice president.

title: Karen Lehmann Wed to a Lawyer
description: The wedding of Karen E. Lehmann, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manfred R. Lehmann of Lawrence, L.I., and Jerusalem, to David Farrell Eisner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Eisner of Pittsburgh, took place yesterday at the Park East Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Shlomo Wolbe performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald.

title: BEAN SINKS BIRDIE TO WIN IN PLAYOFF
description: Andy Bean said: ''I'm one of those golfers out here who plays. So if you give me a chance I'll sneak up on you.''

title: GUIDE FOUND SLAIN IN CASINO
description: A 57-year-old woman was found murdered in a lounge of Caesar's Atlantic City Hotel Casino Saturday night, the Atlantic city police said yesterday. The city Medical Examiner's office said she had been strangled.

title: NO ALTERNATIVE IS SUGGESTED TO 4-LANE HIGHWAY ON L.I.
description: After four years of study, a consulting firm says it cannot offer any alternative to a new four-lane highway to end congestion on the Montauk Highway, the only continuous east-west road through resort areas on the South Fork of Long Island. Residents and officials there are widely opposed to such a new highway.

title: NETS TURN BACK SUNS BY 115-111
description: Darryl Dawkins returned to action today after a 15-game absence, but played for only 5 minutes before feeling a twinge in his injured groin area and leaving the game. Nevertheless, the Nets ended a three-game losing streak.

title: Ease Up on Debtor Nations
description: Secretary of the Treasury James A. Baker 3d had two goals in mind when he announced his third-world debt repayment plan nearly six months ago. One was to increase economic growth in debtor countries. The second was to insure full repayment of the debt to United States banks. But the international debt crisis has reached a point where we cannot have it both ways.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1986
description: International A French political realignment is expected to result from next week's legislative elections. But the larger change may be that France, in the five years since the Socialist Government came to power, has become more like other democracies. Surveys have shown a tendency for the French to abandon traditional antagonisms and move toward a broad consensus. As a result, alternating governments of the right and the left are possible. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: Egyptian Military Is Meeting the Challenge of New Weaponry
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARCOS 'THRILLA'
description: ON a steamy June morning in 1975 among the palm trees of Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Muhammad Ali retained his heavyweight title against Joe Bugner in 15 sweltering rounds. Hours later, the champion appeared with Joe Frazier to announce that the third bout of their five-year war would be held three months later in Manila.

title: EXPLETIVES OF TRUMAN STOP HERE
description: It's not that people here don't appreciate the city's most famous son. It's his language that they could do without - or at least with a little paler version of it than the offering served up by a former New Yorker in the musical comedy ''The Buck Stops Here.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the At the Movies column in Weekend Feb. 28 about an option taken by Walt Disney Pictures on a new book by Sue Miller misidentified the title of her novel. It is ''The Good Mother.''

title: A CUSTOMIZED WAY TO SIDESTEP RISK
description: Many of the options created to enhance corporate finance issues often find their way into the burgeoning market for over-the-counter options. Here, options to buy or sell large amounts of such financial instruments as currencies and Treasury securities are tailor-made to suit the needs of a large corporation or financial institution.

title: Museum Offers Tour
description: Beginning this Sunday at midnight and continuing into next Monday morning, the South Street Seaport Museum is sponsoring a seaport district supper and a tour of the nation's largest wholesale fish mart, the Fulton Fish Market. The regular Thursday tours, which start at 6 A.M. on alternate weeks, will resume April 3.

title: KANSAS HOLDS OFF IOWA STATE IN FINAL
description: Danny Manning scored 23 points and held Kansas together in the final minute today as the Jayhawks edged Iowa State, 73-71, in the final of the Big Eight tournament.

title: 'BETWEEN TWO WOMEN,' ABC MOVIE
description: ''BETWEEN TWO WOMEN'' is a lovely little television movie - no car chase, no missiles, no mayhem, not even an extraneous scene. It might be satisfying for this alone, but a delicate joy goes further than that: ''Between Two Women'' is about an adult relationship. It doesn't hurt, either, that the relationship is between Farrah Fawcett and Colleen Dewhurst. Even when we're not gripped, we're beguiled. Something is going on.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN WHITE ARRESTED IN BLASTS
description: The South African police said today that they had arrested a white woman as part of an investigation into a series of recent bomb explosions, one of them at a police station in Johannesburg.

title: QUIET TOWNS BRACE FOR DEVELOPMENT
description: With its old barns and quiet woods, this sprawling town in northern Westchester County, about 50 miles from mid-Manhattan, is still a sleepy community.

title: CORPORATE LITIGATION EXPERT
description: Charles L. Stewart, a partner in the Manhattan-based law firm of Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives, died Friday at New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: TAUBMAN: SYSTEMATIC ACQUIRER
description: A. Alfred Taubman, a barrel-chested real estate entrepreneur and art collector from Detroit, has a voice like fine brandy and an air of gentle self-confidence. When he leans back in his chair and draws on an expensive cigar, the 61-year-old Mr. Taubman could easily fill the role of someone's kindly rich uncle.

title: Outdoors: Ice Fishing for Smelt
description: DURING a two-day introduction to ice fishing for smelt, I learned that those who are devoted to the sport have no truck with dawdling.

title: ECONOMIC CALENDAR
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: RECITAL: HORSZOWSKI
description: MIECZYSLAW HORSZOWSKI, who was playing Beethoven piano concertos in Warsaw before the Wright brothers flew, gave a dapper and engaging recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, where he has appeared dozens of times over the past six decades (it wasn't built in time for his New York debut in 1906). His virtues were largely those The New York Times praised after a recital on the same stage in 1926: ''moderation and urbanity'' and a ''scholarly spirit'' that did not preclude ''earnest, old-fashioned sentiment.''

title: Uganda Forces Capture Key Northern Town
description: The National Resistance Army, which seized power in Kampala in January, said today that it had captured the northern Uganda town of Gulu, the chief remaining outpost of troops loyal to the former Government.

title: INVESTMENT STRATEGIST TAKES GLOBAL APPROACH
description: When he left his job as chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch in 1983 to form his own investment advisory firm, Richard J. Hoffman imagined he had carved out his dream job. He turned out to be wrong, but for all the right reasons.

title: AS 'FRENCH DIFFERENCE' FADES, POLITICAL CONSENSUS EMERGES
description: A week before legislative elections that are likely to bring a major political realignment, many people in France are searching for ways to sum up the five years since the Socialist Government came to power promising fundamental change.

title: Ecuadorean General Is Told to Surrender
description: Gen. Frank Vargas Pazos, Ecuador's ousted armed forces chief, was warned today to leave the Manta air base where he took refuge Friday or face a military showdown.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Citizen Watch Company to SSC&B:Lintas USA for new line of watches.

title: CORPORATIONS INUNDATE BOND MARKET
description: With bond yields at their lowest level since 1978, large corporations are returning to the long-term debt market in droves. New bond issues totaled more than $5 billion last week, and securities dealers expected the heavy supply to continue in coming weeks.

title: TINA TURNER HELPING PEPSI'S GLOBAL EFFORT
description: With the help of Ogilvy & Mather, Pepsi-Cola International has found an answer to the puzzling challenge of how to create an advertising effort that is multinational and local at the same time.

title: KEMP-BRADLEY 'SUMMITS'
description: The Jack Kemp-Bill Bradley team is taking its campaign for managed exchange rates to Europe.

title: KEMP, SWIVELING RIGHT AND LEFT IN SPEECHES, AIMS FOR ULTIMATE GOAL
description: ''This is not the Grand Old Party any more.''

title: DAUGHTERS, IN-LAWS AND STRESS
description: WHEN Barbara Dolan of Chicago wants to invite a friend to the ballet, she telephones her mother-in-law.

title: SIKH HELD IN GANDHI MURDER PLOT IS TO GO ON TRIAL
description: A 35-year-old Sikh, a computer scientist who has lived and worked in the United States since 1982, is to go on trial today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges that he plotted to assassinate Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India when he visited this country last year.

title: BRANIFF REPORTS '85 GAIN
description: Despite reporting a quarterly loss, Braniff Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy proceedings two years ago, posted a profit of $23 million, or $1.87 a share, on revenues of $244.3 million, for fiscal 1985. It lost $86.3 million in 1984. On Friday, the Dallas-based airline reported a $1.5 million loss, on $53.8 million in revenues, for the quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: Still Separate, Still Unequal
description: To the delight of the Reagan Administration and the dismay of civil rights lawyers, the Federal courts seem ready to let Norfolk, Va., off the hook. A Court of Appeals panel recently held that Norfolk's schools have overcome their segregated past and may abandon a 14-year-old busing plan in favor of neighborhood schools.

title: ECONOMIC DEBATE RESHAPED BY SIGNS OF LOWER DEFICITS
description: Government and business economists are beginning to take account of widespread signs that $200 billion budget deficits are a thing of the past.

title: Thomas C. Dillon, 70, Former Head of BBDO
description: Thomas C. Dillon, former chief executive officer of BBDO International, one of the world's largest advertising agencies, died of cancer Friday at New York University Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ORIOLES ARE SORTING OUT PITCHING PUZZLE
description: The numbers would be woeful for any team; for the Baltimore Orioles, they were shocking, embarrassing, heretical. The Orioles, who in the previous 17 seasons had 23 20-game winners, established club records last year for highest earned-run average (4.38), most runs allowed (764), most home runs given up (160), most hits allowed (1,480) and highest opponents' batting average (.270).

title: Rutgers Women Get Bid
description: The Rutgers women's basketball team, which lost to Penn State in the Atlantic 10 final Saturday, yesterday received an at-large bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament on the basis of its 27-3 record.

title: Black America Is Far From Economic Parity
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.C. AND BIG TEN EACH PUT 6 TEAMS IN N.C.A.A.
description: Led by Duke University, the nation's top-ranked team, the Atlantic Coast Conference yesterday placed six of its eight teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Assocation basketball tournament.

title: IT'S A 'SMEAR,' WALDHEIM SAYS
description: Kurt Waldheim today repeated denials that he had been a member of two Nazi organizations and again charged that reports linking him to a hidden Nazi past were part of a ''smear campaign.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WHITE HOUSE MESS. By Christopher Buckley. 224 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: POLE WOOS, AND WINS, GORBACHEV
description: Political figures close to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski are having a hard time not sounding effusive as they discuss the visibly close relations that emerged between the Polish leader and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Soviet party congress.

title: Surgery for Cordero
description: Angel Cordero Jr., injured in a fall during a race Saturday at Aqueduct, was listed in serious but stable condition yesterday at New York University Medical Center, where he underwent more than four hours of surgery for a lacerated liver Saturday night.

title: DEVILS FALL TO SABRES
description: Gil Perreault scored the 500th regular-season goal of his career tonight and Doug Smith scored the winning goal as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Devils, 4-3.

title: THEATER: KEVIN KLINE IN 'HAMLET' AT PUBLIC
description: IF there is a young American more accomplished than Kevin Kline in playing major classical roles - in terms of imagination, intelligence, bearing and voice - he has yet to make an appearance on a New York stage. As he moved from ''Richard III'' to ''Henry V,'' while finding time for such lighter-shaded heroic characters as the Pirate King in ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and, last season, Captain Bluntschli in ''Arms and the Man,'' Mr. Kline has displayed a dazzling virtuosity. His success in ''Hamlet,'' which opened yesterday at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, is all the more admirable because many of the actors in the company are not in his solar system.

title: BUDGET CUTS EXPECTED FROM SAUDIS
description: Saudi Arabia is planning to announce a budget Monday that, coming in the midst of a worldwide oil crisis, will include further cuts in government spending, according to bankers and diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

title: Groceries' Service Rated High
description: Americans rate supermarkets and banks the highest for quality of service, while they rate automobile repairing, local government, real estate concerns and public transportation at the lowest end of the scale, according to the results of two Gallup Polls made public yesterday.

title: A FRENCH TV CREW IS SEIZED IN BEIRUT
description: Four French television crew members were abducted in West Beirut on Saturday, and an anonymous telephone caller said today that they had been seized by the Islamic Holy War organization.

title: HAWAII WARMTH TO MARCOS TURNS ICY
description: When Ferdinand E. Marcos arrived here Feb. 26, Gov. George R. Ariyoshi greeted the deposed Filipino President warmly at Hickam Air Force Base, put an arm on his shoulder, and invited him to remain permanently in Hawaii.

title: MUSIC: ANDREI GAVRILOV WITH THE BALTIMORE
description: THE Baltimore Symphony came to Carnegie Hall with its new music director Saturday night. He is David Zinman, who conducted what promised to be an interesting mix of music and turned out as an evening of bizarre contrasts.

title: MUGABI AIMS AT WILY TARGET
description: On the face of it, the record of John (The Beast) Mugabi appears far easier to decipher than, say, hieroglyphics or Buddy Ryan's defenses.

title: DETAINING CUBANS EXACTS RISING TOLL
description: The increasing number of Cubans imprisoned indefinitely by United States immigration officials to await deportation is exacting a growing toll on the Government and on the prisoners.

title: VOLUME PEAKS AND PRICE TOPS
description: IN a bull market, volume on the New York Stock Exchange typically reaches a peak before stock prices form their top.

title: Pate Brings Together Religions on 38th St.
description: Since 1917, the Lou G. Siegel restaurant has been drawing diners who like its stuffed cabbage, matzoh ball soup or other strictly kosher delicacies. In the heart of the garment center, at 209 West 38th Street, the restaurant's lunchtime crowd includes many businessmen in yarmulkes.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Family Business
description: It wasn't quite a holdout in the usual sense, but the fact remains that when the pitchers and catchers of the Boston Red Sox reported to spring training in Winter Haven, Fla., last month, only two of them were unsigned. Roger Clemens was brought into the fold 48 hours later. It was almost a week, though, before the club reached agreement with Marc Sullivan, a delay that might have proved embarrassing if people had misunderstood.

title: TED BATES ACQUIRING KOBS UNIT
description: LARGELY because of its clients' needs, Ted Bates Worldwide, the world's third-largest advertising agency, has joined the numerous other top agencies that have direct marketing subsidiaries. It is acquiring Kobs & Brady of Chicago and New York, effective April 1, and plans to take it international.

title: U.S. EGG PRODUCERS AT ODDS OVER EFFORT TO BUILD MARKET
description: Farmers, business executives and lawyers are trying to decide which comes first, the chicken or the egg marketing order. At stake is the price of eggs.

title: DEAD ARE ABOARD
description: Navy divers have found the crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger, containing remains of the astronauts who died after the craft exploded high above the Atlantic 40 days ago, space agency officials said today.

title: NO LOCAL TEAMS AMONG 32 IN N.I.T.
description: With the exception of St. John's, Fairfield and Marist, which made it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, this was a down season for the metropolitan-area teams. Thus, the National Invitation Tournament, which once flourished with local teams, will be without one for the first time in its 49-year history.

title: ITALY'S HOUSEWIVES GRUMBLE
description: Italian housewives are aware of the vital role they play in daily life here and they think they deserve at least a little remuneration for it.

title: THOUSANDS HONOR MAIMONIDES BY YEAR OF STUDY
description: At a quarter to 8 yesterday morning, Ruchama Clapman was awakened by her 7-year-old son, Mordechai, who stood swaddled in his winter coat at her bedside.

title: SPIELBERG IS HONORED BY DIRECTORS
description: Steven Spielberg got satisfaction from the Hollywood establishment Saturday night, when the Directors Guild of America voted him best director of 1985 for ''The Color Purple,'' a movie about the experience of impoverished Southern blacks in the years before World War II.

title: GROUP URGES M.T.A. REFORMS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority should focus its long-term capital-spending plans on attracting more passengers and on reducing operating costs, according to a private study to be released today.

title: One Dies, 2 Are Hurt After a Church Shooting
description: A man apparently enraged at the breakup of his engagement opened fire with a pistol today in a church, killing his former fiancee's brother-in-law and wounding two women, officials said.

title: FUTURE OF LIBERAL CLERIC IS DISCUSSED AT VATICAN
description: The Rev. Charles E. Curran, a theologian with liberal views on birth control and other issues, met for two hours over the weekend with high Vatican officials in Rome amid reports that his status as a teacher of Roman Catholic doctrine might be in jeopardy.

title: GASOLINE PRICE FALLS BELOW $1 AND MORE CUTS ARE EXPECTED
description: Gasoline prices have fallen below $1 a gallon at some service stations in the New York metropolitan area, and experts say the decline will continue.

title: Put the Burden on the Borders, Not on Employers
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL'S DECLINE SEEN CURBING SOVIET PLANS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to revitalize the Soviet economy would be hampered by a sustained depression in oil prices, according to Western diplomats and economists.

title: ANOTHER CONRAIL OFFER
description: In the latest wrinkle in the saga of the sale of the Consolidated Rail Corporation, former Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis has been sending out feelers about making a bid for the Government's 85 percent interest in the big freight railroad.

title: COLLEGES FACING AGE SHIFT FIND SMALL IS BETTER
description: Four years ago officials of Hampshire College in Massachusetts found that to keep enrollment at 1,200 students, they were accepting freshmen who in the past would not have met their academic standards. They decided to get smaller.

title: Underrepresented?
description: Washington likes to think of itself as a capital, if not the capital, of the legal profession. But when The American Lawyer, for an article in its March issue, chose 27 lawyers, 45 years of age and younger, as future leaders of the bar, only three of them turned out to be practicing in the District of Columbia.

title: STAR OF WARHOL FILMS PLAYS A TV DETECTIVE ON 'FORTUNE DANE'
description: In ''Fortune Dane,'' the new ABC police series starring Carl Weathers, one of Mr. Weathers's sidekicks is a detective named Perfect Tommy, a tough character with a shady past who seems almost surprised to have landed a respectable job. The actor who plays Perfect Tommy, Joe Dallesandro, expresses some of the same astonishment in considering his own metamorphosis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For me, personally, May 13 was the most tragic day in my life.

title: Pakistan Reports Five Killed In a Battle Over Poppy Fields
description: Five people were killed Saturday and 31 wounded in a battle between armed opium farmers and paramilitary forces sent to burn their poppy fields, the Government reported.

title: Selling a Lavender Line Along Route for Parade
description: It may be the longest stripe ever painted down a pavement for a parade. Whether it enjoys that distinction or not, the line will certainly be distinctive.

title: OPTIONS ADD LIFE TO FINANCING
description: Options on stocks have long been regarded as dynamic, if slightly arcane, tools for professional traders and speculators. Now Wall Street is devising a whole new range of options for corporations to play the financing game.

title: Severe Flu Outbreak In U.S. Seen as Waning
description: The worst influenza outbreak in the United States in five years has peaked and is on the decline, Federal health officials say.

title: Langston Hughes Honored by Festival
description: Beginning today with the opening at the Cohen Library of an exhibition of memorabilia, the Langston Hughes Festival, sponsored by the City College of New York to honor the Harlem poet and writer, will include an awards gala, a choral-speaking festival and a symposium, ''The Worlds of Langston Hughes.''

title: MULTINATIONAL TRADE VIEW
description: THE fierce trade bill battle between organized labor and multinational corporations over the impact of offshore production on United States jobs is expected to intensify with the creation of the Committee for Production Sharing, a new business lobbying organization involving 140 multinational corporations that stand to lose some favorable trade privileges under several bills before the House of Representatives.

title: FOLK: THE WILLIAMSES
description: THE husband-and-wife folk singing and songwriting team of Robin and Linda Williams is a reminder that contemporary country music doesn't just mean Nashville or Texan ''outlaws'' and their descendants. Frequent guests on the American Public Radio series ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' the couple belong to an older and gentler Appalachian tradition that exalts above all the simple values of close harmony and clear-sighted narrative.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In regard to regular-season scoring, which player in the history of the National Basketball Association has averaged the most points per inch of height in his career?

title: G.M., CHRYSLER LAYOFFS
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would lay off 2,200 workers at its Pontiac Fiero sports-car assembly plant in Pontiac for a week because of rising dealer inventories. The Chrysler Corporation said that it would lay off 3,000 hourly workers for a week at its Sterling Heights plant so it could add equipment for a new line of subcompact cars, the Dodge Shadow-Plymouth Sundance cars.

title: PEOPLES RAISES BID FOR ZALE
description: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto sweetened its bid yesterday for the Zale Corporation, the largest jewelry retailer in the United States, offering $45 a share in cash and securities, or about $475 million (United States).

title: Taking a Gamble
description: Who says baseball and gambling don't mix?

title: Seattle Hiring Decision Hurt Whites, Judge Says
description: A Superior Court judge says a decision to hire only women and black men in the Seattle Fire Department's last recruit class discriminated against qualified white men who had also applied.

title: ON STAGE AT THE MET, A CAST OF 800 GUESTS STAR AT PARTY
description: The Metropolitan Opera gave a glittering black-tie dinner-dance on its vast stage last night. The backdrops were Marc Chagall's joyous settings for ''The Magic Flute,'' and the cast was the 800 guests, who loved being on the other side of the footlights.

title: HANOI'S ECONOMIC REVOLUTION
description: After years of hesitancy and disagreement within the Vietnamese Communist Party, Hanoi now appears to be committed to major reforms in almost every area of the nation's economic life.

title: A Defining Issue
description: Every so often in Washington there is an issue that defines political character, cutting far deeper than party labels. That was so of McCarthyism 30 years ago. It is so today on the question of aid to the Nicaraguan contras.

title: DOES SATAN LURK IN TURIN, OR JUST SOME AMATEURS?
description: Is Satan haunting this most modern and rational of Italian cities?

title: PROPOSED 'COMMANDO' RAID IS STOPPED BY INDIANA POLICE
description: The five men in Room 113 of the Motel 6 last Sunday memorized the plan, checked their weapons and gave the go-ahead.

title: Defeating Defeatism
description: The voice of defeatism in the United States says that no amount of support for anti-Communist guerrillas in Nicaragua will ever oust the Sandinista dictatorship.

title: BANK MACHINE FRAUD PLEA
description: In what appears to be the biggest fraud ever involving a bank automated teller machine, a computer programming error enabled a Fairfax Station, Va., man to withdraw more than $140,000 from another person's account.

title: CONTROL DATA EXECUTIVE NEW WINNEBAGO CHIEF
description: Winnebago Industries, a leading manufacturer of recreational vehicles and mobile homes, has named Gerald W. Gilbert, a vice president of operations support services at the Control Data Corporation, as its new chief executive officer.

title: Ken Yasui, Tokyo Politician; Led Upper House in 1977-80
description: Ken Yasui, former president of the upper house of Parliament, died today at the Nihon University Hospital here.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Apollo Computer Inc., Chelmsford, Mass., said it had signed a letter of intent with Texas Instruments Inc. to enter into a cooperative development program using Texas Instruments' artificial intelligence technology and Apollo's technical work stations.

title: VAN DORN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Cops and the Corks
description: The latest meeting of the New York M.T.A. board needs to be judged by an item missing from the agenda: merger of the transit police with the regular city police. After more than a year's foot-dragging, Mayor Koch and the board ought to explain why this reassuring measure still remains only a proposal.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 6
description: Share earnings reflect 3-for-2 split effective Dec. 9.

title: IROQUOIS BRANDS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $2,764,000 from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $303,000 from a capital adjustment at a subsidiary.

title: BUSH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 23
AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge of $350,000 in connection with the costs expected to be incurred through a proposed merger. c-Net loss. d-Including a gain of $2,209,000, or 55 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: JEFFREY MARTIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: NOMINEE FOR COMMERCE JOB
description: The Reagan Administration yesterday nominated Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, to fill the vacant position of under secretary for economic affairs.

title: No Headline
description: NIGERIAN DEBT MEETING

title: HAGLER STOPS MUGABI IN 11TH
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler retained his undisputed world middleweight title tonight when he knocked out John (The Beast) Mugabi at 1 minute 29 seconds of the 11th round.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LIBBEY GLASS UNIT
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company announced it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its glass business to Pilkington Brothers P.L.C. of St. Helens, England.

title: HURCO COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a charge of $520,000 for foreign currency exchange losses.

title: Polish Debt Agreement
description: Poland has reached an agreement to reschedule slightly more than $1.6 billion of its debt to Western governments, an official close to the talks said today. Before the pact, Poland's annual debt service to both governments and foreign commercial banks was estimated at almost $6 billion.

title: 6 WORLD LEADERS ASK HALT IN NUCLEAR TESTS UNTIL SUMMIT MEETING
description: Six world leaders have appealed to President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev to forgo nuclear testing until the next summit meeting, according to a worldwide group of legislators who organized the initiative.

title: Dr. David J. Impastato Dies; Early Backer of Electroshock
description: Dr. David J. Impastato, a psychiatrist who pioneered the use of electroshock therapy in the United States, has died of pneumonia. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan until two years ago, when he moved to Pasadena, Calif., where he died Feb. 28.

title: Whither Fletcher?
description: The appointment of 66-year-old James C. Fletcher as Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration could give a big boost to private financing of the nation's space program.

title: U.N. AIDE TO JOIN AQUINO
description: A former high-ranking United Nations official is scheduled to arrive in Manila Tuesday to become one of two Deputy Foreign Ministers.

title: MYLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $275,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: EQUION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $959,088 for the quarter and $1,826,712 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $1,080,299 for the quarter and $1,849,589 for the 6 months.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Fighting The Nation's Fortresses
description: THIS time, it isn't just New York that's doing something wrong. It's Dallas, Houston, Albuquerque, Topeka, Atlanta and even Minneapolis.

title: SIR ALEC RELUCTANT MEMORIST
description: As Sir Alec Guinness tells it, he never had the slightest intention of writing his autobiography; he was only trying to fend off those who would wring it out of him. ''Hamish Hamilton, the publishers, asked me to do an autobiography,'' Sir Alec recalls. ''I said, 'I don't like theater autobiographies.' But all these other publishers were after me, so I said to Hamish Hamilton, 'If I say I've promised it to you, will you protect me from all these other people?' So that went on for about 10 years, and finally Hamish Hamilton said, 'We've protected you all this time - how about turning something out?' ''

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $824,000 for the quarter, $880,887 for the year and gains from the sale of stock by an unconsolidated subsidiary of $20,639 for the quarter, $186,370 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including capital gains of $459,856 for the quarter, $1,540,187 for the year and a gain of $159,331 from the sale of stock by an unconsolidated subsidiary for the quarter and year.

title: Hidden Message
description: An anecdote in the weekly newsletter published by the National Basketball Association seems to suggest that kids these days are growing up either a little too bright or a lot too impressionable.

title: COUSINS PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE DANCE: NEW JERSEY COMPANY
description: DANCECOMPASS, a likable modern-dance group currently in residence at Montclair State College in New Jersey, appeared Sunday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church in a program featuring choreography by its versatile artistic director, Nicholas Rodriguez.

title: SPEC'S MUSIC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE DANCE: 3 TRIBUTES TO WATER
description: THERE was water everywhere when Muna Tseng Dance Projects offered ''Water Trilogy'' on Sunday night at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. Choreographed by Muna Tseng, directed by Emmanouil Koutsourelis and set to liquescent taped scores by Bruce Tovsky and Mike Vargas, the three tributes to water were often refreshing.

title: 108 MORE VIETNAM DEAD TO BE LISTED AT MEMORIAL
description: The names of 108 Americans killed in the Vietnam War will be added next month to the 58,022 names of the dead and missing already etched into the Vietnam Veterans Memorial here, leaders of the memorial's search committee said today.

title: Coming to Terms With Medicine
description: A new dictionary has been published with definitions of tens of thousands of words whose meanings changed or existence has only come about in recent years in the fields of medicine and biology.

title: SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Shares outstanding represent average units.

title: SUSPENSION & PARTS INDUSRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $238,598 from termination of a pension plan.

title: ANOTHER KNOCKOUT MAKES TYSON 19-0
description: Beads of perspiration were spread across his broad back and there was a contemptuous sneer on his face. As usual, Mike Tyson had forsaken the robe that often makes fighters look like peacocks, entering the ring at the Nassau Coliseum tonight looking as if he had every intention of making his stay as brief as possible.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE AND COMMERCE
description: The outlook for commercial ventures in space, already clouded by insurance problems, became hazier as a result of the Jan. 28 space shuttle disaster. For telecommunications executives or those hoping to develop products in the weightless conditions of space, questions about what caused the Challenger explosion are bound up with worries about when the shuttles may fly again.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SHERWOOD, ROONEY AGREE ON A MERGER
description: The Rooney, Pace Group Inc. and the privately owned Sherwood Capital Group Inc. announced yesterday that they had reached an agreement in principle to merge in a stock transaction of unspecified value.

title: HANDYMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net gains from sales of real estate of $2.5 million for the quarter and $6.4 million for the year. The year result also includes a net gain of $200,000 from liquidation of LIFO reserves. c-Including a net gain of $1.5 million on the sale of real estate and a net gain of $1.4 million from liquidation of LIFO reserves, and from high sales generated from the going-out-of business sale in the company's Texas and Oklahoma stores.

title: WHITMAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: WON OSCAR FOR 'LOST WEEKEND'
description: Ray Milland, the urbane actor who won an Academy Award and many other honors for his riveting portrayal of a sympathetic alcoholic in ''The Lost Weekend'' in 1945, died of cancer yesterday at Torrance Memorial Medical Center in Torrance, Calif. He was 81.

title: USLICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment gains of $353,000 for the quarter and $1,444,000 for the year. c-After investment gains of $26,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the year.

title: JUDGE VOIDS POWER OF STATE TO ENFORCE AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: A state judge ruled today that the State Department of Transportation had no authority to enforce affirmative action rules designed to award construction contracts to women and other minorities.

title: PAVELICH OF RANGERS IS ABSENT
description: Distressed by a frustrating season, Mark Pavelich, who has talked recently about retiring, did not report to the Rangers' practice here this morning. As of late afternoon, the player had not contacted the team to explain his absence.

title: 2 Guialdo Sisters Follow Tradition
description: Marsha Guialdo remembered when she was 8 years old and her sister, Louan, was 10. They knew their mother, Pollina, had been a champion runner and jumper in their native Trinidad, and she told them she could beat them in a race.

title: U.N. EXPERTS DEBATE U.S. ORDER TO MOSCOW
description: The decision by the United States to force the Soviet missions to the United Nations to reduce their size has touched off a debate among experts in international law.

title: FAMILIES REACT: RELIEF AND DISMAY
description: The announcement Sunday that remains of the space shuttle crew had been found 100 feet deep in the Atlantic brought a mixture of comfort, renewed grief and in some cases anger and dismay to relatives of the dead Challenger astronauts.

title: Records of Legal Fees Subpoenaed by Jury
description: A Queens grand jury has subpoenaed records of $5 million in legal fees awarded by the New York State Insurance Department last year, a portion of which was paid to the law firms of legislators and their top advisers.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seven More Are Killed In South Africa Protests
description: South Africa's political protest was reported today to have spilled into one of the nation's so-called tribal homelands, Lebowa, where the police said they shot and killed seven black demonstrators over the weekend.

title: NORTHEAST OHIO AXLE reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $2,941,000. c-Net loss

title: OVEX FERTILITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $28,529.

title: SHUT SCHOOLS FOR PASSOVER, BOARD URGED
description: Community school boards and professional groups have warned the Board of Education that that New York City's schools will face serious disciplinary and personnel problems unless the board rescinds its decision to keep the schools open during Passover.

title: LEADER OF CITIES LEAGUE CALLS PLAN FOR AID CUTS 'DISASTROUS'
description: The president of the National League of Cities asserted today that proposed cuts in Federal aid to cities would amount to a ''disastrous dismantling of Federal-local partnerships'' and require imposition of ''regressive'' local taxes.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: The Marcos Party In Honolulu
description: Following is the list of people who accompanied Ferdinand E. Marcos from Manila to Hawaii, as made available by the State Department: ANTONIO, Fe AQUINO, Agripina ARANETA, Gerogrio ARANETA, Irene ARUZA, Arturo ASUNCION, Rosa AZURIN, Ramon BATANT, Emilio BAUTISTA, Maria BAYLEN, Evelina BENITEZ, Jose BOLIBO, Ferdinand BONDOC, Griselda CALAPINI, Ricardo CINCO, Romeo COJUANGCO, Carlos COJUANGCO, Carmen COJUANGCO, Danielle COJUANGCO, Eduardo COJUANGCO, Marcos COJUANGCO, Paola COJUANGCO, Soledad CORPUZ, Minerva DELEAR, Ricardo (since returned to the Philippines) ESPADERO, Mervyn ESPINELI, Menandro ESTABILLO, Alberto FLORA, Manuel FELIX, Alfredo FULE-FORONDU, Laureauo FULE-FORONDU, Octavio FULE-FORONDU, Paloma GALLEGO, Maria GANUT, Alejo GIMENEZ, Fe HUPPANDA, Teresita ISIDERIO, Neinita LABAN, Agnes LAGUARDIA, Pacita LUGA, Jovercio LUMAKANG, Olivia MAGNO, Delmar MANOTOC, Ferdinand MANOTOC, Fernando MANOTOC, Imee MANOTOC, Tomas MARANON, Ramona MARCOS, Aimee MARCOS, Ferdinand Jr. MARCOS, Imelda MARCOS, Restituto OCAMPO, Prospedo (since returned to the Philippines) OCHINANG, Dari ORTALEZA, Buenaventura PANARIGAN, Salvador PASCUA, Eufemlo PINEDA, Narciso QUIRAO, Eva RAMOX, Cloven RANADA, Herminia RATLIFF, Rudy RAZA, Nora RESURRECCION, Faida RESURRECCION, Male RESURRECCION, Nephthys RUIZ, Agnes SADLARIN, Nestor SANIDAD, Eustacia TAGAL, Lucila TAUQUERIDO, Bernadette TUASON, Anna, TUASON, Fabian TUASON, Helma TUASON, Mark TUASON, Reina TUASON, Reynaldo VALDOZ, Ana VELASCO, Geronimo VILLA, Gil VILLA, Orlanac VER, Aida VER, Fabian C. VER, Irwin P. VER, Maria Agnes VER, Maria Ramona VER, Marita E. VER, Rexor VER, Wyrlo VERIDIANO, Monino ZAGALA, Juanita

title: Influence-Peddling
description: Concerned about what they fear could turn into another vehicle for influence-peddling in a town where influence enjoys a bull market, a group of 50 lawmakers headed by Representative Howard Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, are promoting a bill that would bar top Administration officials from representing foreign governments for 10 years after they leave office.

title: STILL INSPIRED AFTER 26 YEARS
description: ''Listen,'' Millie Cantor said, ''I'm trying not to cry.'' She was sitting on her living room couch, describing all the wonderful services offered by the Levittown Public Library, and sobbing. Mrs. Cantor finds libraries inspiring.

title: Diplomats Seek Safety In Bumper Stickers
description: To: All Ambassadors and Consuls General.

title: GUIDE KILLED IN ATLANTIC CITY DIED IN A LOUNGE, POLICE SAY
description: A 57-year-old tour guide slain Saturday night at Caesars Atlantic City Hotel Casino was killed in a guest room kept unlocked so tour escorts could use it as a lounge, the authorities said yesterday.

title: A BIG 3 AGENCY SETUP SEEN
description: EVERY one of America's gigantic ad agencies - with the possible exception of Young & Rubicam - could be ''also-rans'' or listed among ''all others'' in five years, Jagdish N. Sheth told an unchagrined audience at the Plaza Hotel yesterday.

title: Two Marcos Properties Frozen by Court Order
description: A New Jersey court yesterday barred the sale of two properties, including a 13-acre estate near Princeton, that the new Philippine Government believes belong to the family of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: A 'Disinvited' Democrat
description: Manhattan Democrats still have not forgotten Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos's defection from their ranks to support Peter F. Vallone of Queens for the City Council majority leadership two months ago.

title: The U.N. Today: March 11, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: A diagram yesterday with an article about the sighting of the space shuttle Challenger's crew cabin showed the astronauts' seating arrangement incorrectly. A corrected diagram appears today on page C8.

title: CHURCH IN HAITI LAUNCHES LITERACY DRIVE
description: The Roman Catholic bishops of Haiti have begun a nationwide campaign to end the illiteracy of this poorest and least educated nation of the Western Hemisphere.

title: Rozelle Discusses Drugs
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle said today that illegal drugs were a ''serious potential economic problem'' that eventually could affect the income of the National Football League.

title: NEW YORK CITY TO SELL $450 MILLION OF BONDS
description: New York City officials announced plans yesterday to sell $450 million of bonds this month through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: SHULMAN SAID TO HAVE 4 OF 5 VOTES NEEDED FOR BOROUGH PRESIDENCY
description: With a formal vote on an interim Queens borough president scheduled for tomorrow, at least four of the nine Queens City Councilmen are supporting Claire Shulman, the Acting Borough President, according to two of the Council members.

title: SENATE CONRAIL SALE BILL FACING HOUSE REVISION
description: After a year of delay, senior Democrats in the House of Representatives are moving toward action on the Senate-passed Reagan Administration bill to sell Conrail to private owners.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Sandoval Hurt in Title Loss
description: Gaby Canizales captured the World Boxing Association bantamweight title tonight when his bout with the champion, Richie Sandoval, was stopped at 2 minutes 47 seconds of the seventh round. Sandoval was carried from the ring on a stretcher but was reported later to be in stable condition.

title: TED LEWIS
description: Edward (Ted) Williams Lewis, a former Washington columnist for The New York Daily News, died today of pneumonia at Sibley Memorial Hospital, his family said.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Legal Abortions Decline
description: The number of legal abortions in the United States fell by more than 4 percent from an estimated 1,574,000 in 1982, to 1,508,000 in 1984, according to an analysis of reports from state health departments. The rate of abortions fell even more, by 5 percent, because the number of women of childbearing age rose slightly in that period.

title: PRO-MED CAPITAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
FORMER CITY AIDE ADMITS EXTORTION IN A PLEA BARGAIN
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer admitted in a Federal court yesterday that, as the Deputy Director of the city's Parking Violations Bureau, he extorted bribes from contractors ''on behalf of myself and others'' from 1981 to the beginning of this year.

title: ABOARD THE E TRAIN: A MOTORMAN'S JOURNEY INTO DARKNESS
description: Commuters pushed and squeezed through the doors of an E train, but James L. McCarthy remained serene in his seat.

title: CRAFT HOUSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WOMEN LOBBY CONGRESS ON ABORTION RULES
description: Hundreds of women went to Capitol Hill today to argue with their Congressmen that civil rights statutes should protect their right to have an abortion paid for by an institution receiving Federal funds.

title: INDOOR WORKOUT HELPS BURNS
description: Britt Burns, the Yankees' new starting pitcher, is not as suntanned as most of his teammates. Not that players lie in the sun for hours during spring training, but their faces and arms became tanned just by going through daily workouts.

title: WOODBINE PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIG JAPANESE TRADE SURPLUS
description: Japan recorded a trade surplus of $3.9 billion in February, a record for the month resulting from a sharp increase in exports to the United States and Europe and the Japanese yen's appreciation against the dollar, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Defense in Pope Case Urges Full Acquittals
description: Defense lawyers for seven Bulgarian and Turkish defendants in the papal shooting trial have begun their final pleas, calling for the full acquittal of their clients.

title: INLAND STEEL TO CHANGE STRUCTURE
description: The Inland Steel Company, the nation's fourth-largest steelmaker, said today that its board of directors had adopted a plan to change its corporate structure to that of a holding company.

title: Israeli Reaction Is Mild
description: Israel does not plan to mount a major campaign to fight a new sale of American weapons to Saudi Arabia, senior Israeli officials said today.

title: STAGE: 'WILLIAMS & WALKER,' MUSICAL
description: THE virtue of theatrical modesty is illustrated by ''Williams & Walker'' at the American Place Theater, as it was several seasons ago by ''Do Lord Remember Me'' on the same stage. The earlier show was an album of slave memories. ''Williams & Walker'' is Vincent D. Smith's musical portrait of the popular black vaudevillians Bert Williams and George Walker.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Moderate Earthquake Strikes Santa Barbara
description: An earthquake shook buildings today, startling residents and causing gas leaks.

title: Fire Briefly Shuts G.M. Plant
description: Fire at a construction site at the General Motors assembly plant here slightly injured several workers and forced the plant to close for a while today, a spokesman for the company said. An employee fire brigade and firefighters from North Tarrytown and Tarrytown had the fire under control by 12:15 P.M. but the plant's 2,500 early-shift workers were sent home at 11:30 A.M., the spokesman said. The plant's second shift was not affected.

title: UNIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A STAR IN COMPUTER PRINTING
description: At last May's annual shareholders meeting of the Eastman Kodak Company, one shareholder gave a three-minute speech blasting the company for throwing away money on its subsidiary, Atex Inc., which makes computerized publishing systems for newspapers and magazines.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, exhibition, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs.

title: TOFU TIME INC reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 1
description: b-Net income

title: T.W.A.-UNION TALK SET FOR TOMORROW
description: Trans World Airlines and the flight attendants' union that is on strike against it agreed yesterday to resume contract negotiations, Federal mediators said.

title: PORTA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a credit of $737,000 representing the cumulative effect on years prior to 1984 of an accounting change.

title: IN MILAN, AN EMPHASIS ON FORM AND FORMALITY
description: For about a decade now, ever since they decided to concentrate their showings in this city, Italian designers have practically cornered the world market on luxury casual clothes. With an insouciant air and a cheerful kind of wit, they used precious fabrics for relaxed clothes and captured the top end of the sportswear business.

title: TEXAS TEACHERS TAKE BASIC-SKILLS EXAMINATION
description: Ruby Bryant has taught English to high school students in Houston for 18 years. Today the state of Texas asked her if she knew how to write a complete sentence and conjugate a verb.

title: DECEIT IS UPHELD IN KEEPING A LAWYER AND SUSPECT APART
description: The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 today that the police may use deception to keep a defense lawyer away while they interrogate a criminal suspect.

title: BRIDGEPORT'S GETTING A BRIGHTER FACE
description: For the last 20 years, as corporate office buildings etched a new skyline for lower Fairfield County, the image of this city remained mired in grime, crime and poverty.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,200,000. c-Net loss

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the London Metal Exchange's plan to end a four-month-long crisis in tin trading misstated the settlement price that the exchange was imposing on all outstanding tin contracts. It is just over $9,000 a ton.

title: SENATORS EULOGIZE JAVITS AT FUNERAL
description: The worlds of New York and Washington, the cities that Jacob K. Javits so often shuttled between in his 24 years in the Senate, came together yesterday to praise him as a man of principle, a striver for social justice and, in his final years, a man of striking courage.

title: Bird Has 50 In Defeat
description: Rolando Blackman's two free throws with eight seconds left capped a remarkable rally that offset Larry Bird's 50 points tonight, carrying the Dallas Mavericks to a 116-115 victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: MICHELIN SELECTS A NEW 3-STAR
description: The 1986 Guide Michelin for France, published today, added another restaurant to the list of those receiving its highest rating, three stars.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SANCTIONS: U.S. COMPLIANCE HIGH
description: Most American companies doing business in South Africa say they are applying fair labor standards, including nonsegregated work faciltiies and equal pay for comparable work, according to the State Department. It is administering sanctions, adopted by the Reagan Administration in September, requiring all United States companies with more than 25 employees in South Africa to register by Feb. 15.

title: Doors of Subway Cars Open on Moving Train
description: The doors on five cars of a southbound IRT No. 6 train opened as the train left the 14th Street station in yesterday morning's rush hour, the Transit Authority said.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS OFFER
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation is offering $150 million of 9 7/8 percent sinking fund debentures due in 2011 at a price of 98.407, to yield 10.05 percent, through underwriters led by Lazard Freres & Company.

title: PLAYERS
description: If what Michael Jordan accomplished this week had taken place on the basketball court, it would have been called a ''power move'' - the kind of forceful and determined flight to the rim that usually results in a score.

title: CASH BUSINESSES ENTICE HEAD OF MEDIA CONCERN
description: P.T. Barnum would have liked Thomas K. Scallen.

title: One Hand Clapping
description: One of the main objects of theoretical physics is to discover how the fundamental forces of nature are related to each other, and some scientists believe they could make a giant leap toward that goal by establishing the existence of a hypothetical particle called a magnetic monopole. Researchers at Imperial College in South Kensington, London, report that they may at last have sighted such a particle.

title: AGENCY'S STATISTICS CHALLENGED
description: FOR several years the Department of Education's statistics center computed the dropout rate for the nation's high schools to be 27 percent, so it was something of a shock last fall when the Census Bureau, after a more exhaustive study, said the rate was 16 percent.

title: WISCONSIN SOUTHERN GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $721,000 from the sale of property and investments. c-Including a gain of $4,543,000 from the sale of property and investments.

title: REAGAN TO DISCUSS IMMIGRATION BILL
description: President Reagan will meet Tuesday with two key members of Congress in an effort to stimulate action on a comprehensive immigration bill, according to White House officials.

title: A LOW KEY WEAVER OF TALES
description: Myron Cohen, a durable nightclub comic who spun tales in the patois of the garment district for more than a quarter of a century, died yesterday at Nyack Hospital in Nyack, N.Y., where he had been taken from his home in New City after a heart attack yesterday morning. He was 83 years old.

title: KIDDER NAMES MERGER CHIEFS
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company yesterday named the co-directors of a new 30-member group to concentrate on the investment bank's merger and acquisition and corporate finance activity involving high-technology companies.

title: COLAROSSI JOINS CATO JOHNSON
description: Benjamin Colarossi, who has been creative director and chief executive officer of Ross Roy/Colarossi Griswold, is leaving to become president of Cato Johnson, a New York-based international sales promotion and design subsidiary of Young & Rubicam. He will replace A.C. (Ace) Dalton, 58 years old, about whom, apparently, Y.&R. has a big announcement pending regarding an ''intriguing assignment.''

title: SHARED CASH MACHINES BOOM
description: Every day, all around the New York City area, thousands of people are withdrawing money from automated teller machines at banks where they do not even have an account. And it is all perfectly legal.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Per share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in January. The bank is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: PHOENIX MEDICAL TECHOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $106,000.

title: RUMMAGING THROUGH MARCOS'S DESK
description: Documents found in the desk of the former President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, portray the final days of a desperate and harried man struggling to cling to office while still enmeshed in the minutiae of the power he had accumulated.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TIN RESCUE EFFORT FAILS AND SHEARSON FILES SUIT
description: A last-gasp effort by the International Tin Council to revive its rescue plan failed today, leaving brokers on the London Metal Exchange facing huge losses and an uncertain future.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STARTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $202,000.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SECRETS OF BEARING A BURDEN
description: THE sight is depressingly common throughout the less developed countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America: women walking for miles with enormous burdens of wood or water on their heads, loads often nearly as heavy as the carriers. A new study of women in Kenya helps explain why the women are able to bear such burdens without collapsing, but it also raises new questions.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After a loss of $33,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain of $3,260,000, or 71 cents a share, on discontinued operations for the year. The gain on discontinued operations in the prior year includes $3,169,000, or 69 cents a share, arising from the sale of real estate on Aug. 22, 1984.

title: QED EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Whole Picture in South Africa
description: President P.W. Botha's right hand has lost none of its cunning in negating the concessions he offers with his left. Consider his newest gesture, releasing the last 327 people South Africa has detained during a seven-month state of emergency. There is less violence now, Mr. Botha claims, so emergency laws are no longer needed. But the police retain most of their power - and still keep reports of the country's turmoil off the world's TV screens. These are not hedged gains; they are no gains at all.

title: Affronted Affronter On the House Floor
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUITABLE OF IOWA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $4,309,000 for the quarter and $15,347,000 for the year. c-Including a realized investment gain of $230,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary net gain of $3,211,836, or 52 cents a share, for the year.

title: Midshipman, Accused In Drug Case, Sues Navy
description: A United States Naval Academy midshipman facing dismissal for suspected cocaine use filed suit today, charging the Navy's drug-testing process violated his constitutional rights.

title: Teen-Age AIDS Victim Learns Science at Home
description: Ryan White, the 14-year-old AIDS victim, set up a home laboratory today so that his seventh grade science teacher could instruct him on dissecting a grasshopper in the youth's first home teaching session since he was banned from school in July.

title: British Train Engineer Killed
description: A collision between a passenger train and a pair of diesel locomotives in north-central England killed one engineer and injured 26 other people, the police and British Railways officials said today. A company spokesman said the passenger train ''was on the wrong track'' when the accident occurred Sunday night in Chinley village, near Buxton, the police said. The engineer of the passenger train was killed.

title: EWING IS THROUGH FOR SEASON
description: Patrick Ewing's injury-plagued season came to an end yesterday. The heralded 7-foot Knick rookie center faces arthroscopic surgery for the removal of a piece of floating tissue in his right knee.

title: Working Profile: Alfred H. Kingon; Being a Fly on White House Wall and Loving It
description: On the wall of Alfred H. Kingon's office of the West Wing basement rests a large photograph of three men - President Reagan, Donald T. Regan, the chief of staff, and Mr. Kingon himself - all staring, puzzled and skeptical, across a table at a crucial White House meeting on tax issues.
