title: LAUREL CONCERNED BY MARCOS CALLS
description: Vice President Salvador H. Laurel said today that he was concerned by reports that Ferdinand E. Marcos, from his exile in Hawaii, was trying to regroup his political allies in opposition to the new Government.

title: FORD-FIAT TALKS
description: The Ford Motor Company and Fiat S.p.a.'s Iveco subsidiary are close to forming a joint venture to market and develop new trucks in Europe, the trade newspaper Automotive News said. The newspaper quoted reliable sources as stating that current plans were for Iveco to manage such a venture, although each company would hold 48 percent equity with 4 percent held by a merchant bank that would have Iveco operate on its behalf.

title: DOW CLIMBS 3.12 POINTS, TO 1,702.95
description: Prices rose moderately yesterday on Wall Street as the stock market, already too rich for many investors' tastes, failed to respond to further declines in interest rates.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Abel Carlevaro In Guitar Program
description: Several elements set Abel Carlevaro's Sunday afternoon concert at the 92d Street Y apart from the standard guitar recital. Mr. Carlevaro plays a modified instrument, with a restyled body that lacks a sound hole. The resulting sound is unusually clear, resonant but without the long decay and the occasional traces of blur one finds on a traditional instrument.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ANITEC IMAGE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Including a tax credit of $198,000. c-Including a tax credit of $2,384,000 and income of $142,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Glueck to Fordham
description: Larry Glueck, a former assistant coach at Harvard, signed a three-year contract as head football coach at Fordham.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: CALVIN KLEIN'S clothing designs have never been the slightest bit controversial, but his advertising campaigns are something else. From Brooke Shields and ''Nothing comes between me and my Calvins'' to the underwear billboards to those Obsession ads of a woman surrounded by men, they have aroused constant comment. They have also been extremely successful in selling both the products and the designer's name.

title: IMREG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: KIN GIVEN HOPE SHUTTLE BODIES ARE IDENTIFIABLE
description: The crew compartment and the remains of the Challenger astronauts were not intact when discovered, family members reported today, but one relative said officials believed some identifications were still possible.

title: CHESS: NIKOLIC OF YUGOSLAVIA WINS THE REYKJAVIK INTERNATIONAL
description: The 12th Reykjavik International Tournament in Iceland was a triumph for the 25-year-old Yugoslav grandmaster Predrag Nikolic. He scored 8-3 to take the first prize of $12,000 in the 11-round Swiss system event.

title: TRANSACT INTERNATIONAL DIVISION OF GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $162,186 for the quarter and $392,128, or 6 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Including an income of $160,431, or 2 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $630,000, or 10 cents a share, resulting from a cash settlement reached in connection with a lawsuit for the quarter and a net gain of $4,094,000, or 61 cents a share, for the 6 months resulting from a cash settlement in an Alcon Laboratories lawsuit and a partial settlement in a lawsuit with Campbell-Republic.

title: STUDY CITES SAVINGS IN A T-46 HALT
description: The Air Force could save more than $2 billion over the next five years by canceling further production of the Fairchild Republic Company's T-46 trainer and instead modifying existing T-37 planes, according to a Congressional Budget Office study released today.

title: CHARGES DOUBTED BY MAYOR GOODE
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode said today that he did not think he should or would be indicted for his role in the crisis last May involving the radical group Move. He pledged his administration's cooperation in any grand jury investigation of the matter.

title: Did Crew Die Instantly? Questions Re-emerging
description: Questions about how much the Challenger's crew knew about the danger they faced were re-emerging today after the discovery of wreckage of the space shuttle's cabin.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Net income.

title: JOHN HANCOCK PICKS SUCCESSOR TO CHIEF
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, the nation's sixth-largest insurance concern, announced yesterday that E. James Morton, president and chief operations officer, will succeed John G. McElwee as chairman and chief executive when Mr. McElwee retires at the end of the year.

title: LEAD HAZARDS ARE CITED IN SHELTER FOR HOMELESS
description: The Legal Aid Society said yesterday that private tests it had commissioned by an independent laboratory showed that homeless families in a Manhattan shelter had been exposed to lead and asbestos contamination.

title: Colombian Liberals Win; Guerrillas Get 1.5%
description: The Liberal Party claimed a victory today over the governing Conservative Party in elections in which leftist rebels got 1.5 percent of the vote.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
School Star Charged
description: An all-state football player in Florida who planned to attend Norfolk State on an athletic scholarship was in custody yesterday in Fort Lauderdale on a murder charge. Jeff Lawson, a 17-year-old defensive lineman at Dillard High School, was accused of first-degree murder in the shooting death of Andre Vincent Doe, a convicted cocaine dealer.

title: S.E.C. Cites 5 In Bank Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused five former officials of a now-defunct California banking company of illegally driving up the price of its stock.

title: ENGINEERED SYSTEMS & DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AUDIT OF SHELTERS IS PLANNED
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it had stopped referring homeless families to the Holland Hotel near Times Square and announced that it would audit costs and services at the city's five group shelters.

title: SATELCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $2.2 million from the sale of a subsidiary for the quarter and year.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Penny Plueckhahn and James Wilson have been promoted to senior vice president/management supervisor at Tracy-Locke, Dallas.

title: MANUFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $504,571 representing cumulative effect of accounting change on prior years.

title: Hit-Run Killer Is Told To Serve Community
description: A Brooklyn man who pleaded guilty to killing an elderly woman last year in a hit-and-run accident while driving without a license was sentenced yesterday to 300 hours of community service.

title: ELECTROLUX OFFER OF $47 ACCEPTED
description: White Consolidated Industries, the nation's third-largest maker of major home appliances, said yesterday that its board had unanimously agreed to a sweetened buyout offer from Electrolux A. B. of Sweden of $47 a share, or $742.6 million.

title: IS PHYSICIANS' PENMANSHIP MORE HAZARD THAN JOKE?
description: POOR handwriting is such a notorious trait of physicians that many people consider illegible penmanship a pre-requisite for joining the profession. Doctors joke about their illegible scrawls, and some skeptics even think medical school admission committees use poor handwriting as a criteria in selecting medical students.

title: FETAL TESTS CAN NOW FIND MANY MORE GENETIC FLAWS
description: THE couple already had two children afflicted with the grim reality of cystic fibrosis. They could not face having another. The disease It causes digestive problems, breathing problems, lung infections, with an almost continual threat of death from early childhood onward. The woman ended her next pregnancy by abortion.

title: Ned Calmer, a Writer And Ex-News Analyst
description: Ned Calmer, a writer and longtime CBS news analyst who worked closely with Edward R. Murrow, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Affronted Affronter On the House Floor
description: To the Editor:

title: Status on Cordero
description: Angel Cordero Jr. remained in serious but stable condition at New York University Medical Center following surgery for a lacerated liver. John Deats, director of public information for the hospital, termed Cordero as ''on the road to recovery'' from injuries he suffered Saturday in a spill at Aqueduct.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; 'Brecht's Berlin' At Cafe La Mama
description: ''Brecht's Berlin,'' a staged cabaret that weaves familiar Brecht-Weill songs with recitations of more obscure lyrics by Bertolt Brecht, features four young actor-singers dressed in Weimarian disarray, who contort themselves in poses inspired by German Expressionist painting.

title: CALPROP CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1985.

title: VSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $2,539,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Judge Refuses to Block An Execution in Texas
description: A Federal judge refused today to block the execution of one of two condemned killers scheduled to die early Wednesday and a state judge considered a request to stop the second execution.

title: CONTRA AID TROUBLING TO EXILES
description: Many Nicaraguan exiles here are deeply troubled by President Reagan's proposal to send $100 million in aid to the anti-Government rebels in Nicaragua.

title: IN CASTING, COMPUTERS PLAY NEW ROLE
description: When the casting agent Geoffrey Johnson was filling roles recently for the television mini-series ''Rage of Angels - The Story Continues,'' he needed to find a young actor who could box. Being more a devotee of Variety than Ring, this presented some problems for Mr. Johnson.

title: HIT MAN BECOMES MINUTE MAN
description: Thomas (Hit Man) Hearns is back.

title: TOWER IS REPORTED TO RESIGN FROM JOB AS ARMS NEGOTIATOR
description: Three American officials said today that former Senator John G. Tower was resigning ''for personal reasons'' as an arms negotiator.

title: COMET ASSESSMENT: QUESTIONS ANSWERED, BUT VEGA RAISES OTHERS
description: THE Soviet Union's two Vega spacecraft have given scientists their closest glimpse yet of a comet, the celebrated Halley's comet, already answering some of the simpler questions but surprising astronomers with revelations of an interior swarming with a blizzard of dust, a jumble of icy boulders and a tumult of electrically charges gases and molecules.

title: Student at Brooklyn College Raped and Knifed on Campus
description: A 19-year-old Brooklyn College sophomore was raped in a classroom building yesterday morning by a man who forced her into a bathroom where he also stabbed her in the stomach and slashed her neck, the police said.

title: INDUSTRY AND CONSUMER GROUPS JOIN TO ASK PESTICIDE LAW CHANGES
description: The agricultural chemical industry joined in an unusual alliance with environmental and consumer groups today to propose specific legislation to strengthen the law controlling the use of pesticides.

title: Georgia on Their Minds
description: Gerald Rafshoon, the sometime image-molder and all-round political operative for Jimmy Carter, is holding a Washington fund-raising event tomorrow night at his Georgetown home for Hamilton Jordan, Mr. Carter's White House chief of staff who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the Senate from his home state of Georgia.

title: A Trial That Is Crucial to Philanthropy
description: On Feb. 3, a trial began in California that may throw American philanthropy into turmoil.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax benefit of $2,741,000. c-Net income including a tax benefit of $128,000.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE MAUL AND THE PEAR TREE. The Ratcliffe Highway Murders 1811. By P. D. James and T. A. Critchley. Illustrated. 234 pages. The Mysterious Press. $17.95. >WAPPING is a very old part of London, a riverside district a little to the east of the City, with a main road called the Highway - formerly Ratcliffe Highway - running along its northern edge. Until recently it was hemmed in by docks, and at the beginning of the 19th century it was a region of marine store dealers, ships' victuallers, sailors' lodging houses, with a population depending almost entirely for its livelihood on the trade of what was then the busiest port in the world.

title: JAGUAR CARS IS LEAVING BOZELL OVER CONFLICT
description: Jaguar Cars, the Leonia, N.J., importer of the high-ticket British autos, has decided to do something it really did not want to do. It is leaving its agency, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, because of a developing conflict problem.

title: SCITEX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $5.6 million writedown of inventory at Dec. 31, 1985. c-Net income

title: ALASKA NATIONAL BANK (ANCHORAGE, ALASKA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $772,000 from the sale of real estate, a tax loss carryforward of $391,000, and a downward revision for an accounting change.

title: United Airlines
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, said it would add 10 flights a week from the United States across the Pacific this spring. United, the nation's largest carrier in terms of passengers flown, acquired Pan American's Pacific routes last month for $750 million.

title: PRAIRE OIL ROYALTIES COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Share earnings reflect 4-for-1 stock split of Jan. 8, 1985.

title: Problems With the Homosexual-Rights Bill . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-OFFICIAL SAYS HIS FRAUD GOT COMPUTER PACT
description: Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, the former deputy director of the city's Parking Violations Bureau, said yesterday that he had helped Citisource Inc. ''fraudulently obtain a contract'' to produce hand-held computers for issuing traffic summonses. A principal stockholder in the company is Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader.

title: No Move for Boeheim
description: Jim Boeheim said he had discussed the possibility of moving to Ohio State, but that he had decided to remain at Syracuse, where he has spent his entire basketball coaching career. ''They were interested somewhat and I was interested somewhat, but we didn't continue the discussion,'' Boeheim said.

title: LONG ISLAND LIGHTING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MURDER TRIAL STARTS FOR SURVIVALIST AND SON, BOTH ACCUSED OF TORTURE
description: The leader of a survivalist cult and his teen-age son went on trial for murder today, with the prosecutor saying they had committed lurid acts of torture and killing in the name of a vengeful God.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has elected to its board Sir Ronald Halstead, former chairman of the Beecham Group P.L.C. of Brentford, England.

title: ZIMBABWE SCHOOLS ARE SWAMPED BY HIGH HOPES
description: A cluster of schoolgirls, dressed in neat uniforms and boaters, gazed adoringly at the American pop stars on album covers decorating the window of a record store in this modern capital city.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a gain of $227,000, or 6 cents a share, relating principally to the sale of land for the quarter and $2,672,000, or 66 cents a share, primarily from the sale of land and 9 stores for the year.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $455,000. c-Including a tax credit of $485,000.

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Don't Stigmatize the Adopted
description: To the Editor:

title: ...It Will Make New York a Better City for All
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. SHUTTING DOWN 4 PLANTS
description: The General Motors Corporation has decided to halt production temporarily at four of its assembly plants, in an action that auto industry analysts described as the start of the first round of cuts needed to bring car supplies into line with sales demand.

title: STATE DEPT. LISTS THE MARCOS RETINUE
description: The State Department issued a list today of the people who accompanied Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, into exile last month, and it indicates that most are domestic servants, guards and personal aides to the Marcos family.

title: LYNCH COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SBARRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIBRARY USERS AREN'T TAKING CUTS SILENTLY
description: Angry students, writers and scholars held a noisy sit-down demonstration in the main reading room of the Library of Congress today to protest budget cuts that have forced elimination of the library's traditional evening hours.

title: CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $184,777 for the quarter and year. c-Net income. d-Including gains on sale of TBC common stock of $1,800 for the quarter and $213,327 for the year.

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,300,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $904,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Striking Meatpackers Arrested in Protest
description: About 100 striking meatpackers and supporters were arrested today after they padlocked the corporate headquarters of Geo. A. Hormel & Company and linked arms in what the Austin police chief called ''mass civil disobedience.''

title: U.S.F.L. Plans New Fall Lineup
description: The United States Football League will have a new divisional alignment and playoff format for the 1986 season, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Harry Usher.

title: The Testing Invasion
description: It's too bad that Keith Hernandez has abandoned his original inclination to challenge the punishment for ballplayers' drug abuse that the Commissioner, Peter Ueberroth, recently decreed. At a time when preventive and/or punitive drug testing is becoming a national issue, the Mets first baseman's case might have provided some of the thorough airing this question needs.

title: CALMAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss on discontinued operations of $358,000.

title: Rights Units Say Seoul Tortured 2 Dissidents
description: Several human rights organizations accused the South Korean Government yesterday of torturing two members of a political opposition group and denying them medical treatment.

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the relationship between the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and New York Medical College misattributed a statement about the school's future. It was John Cardinal O'Connor, not Alfred F. Moran, director of Planned Parenthood, who said, ''The last thing in the world I want to do is control the medical college.''

title: CHAPTER 11 FILING BY MORROW
description: ''Being in the microcomputer business is like going 55 miles an hour three feet from a cliff,'' George Morrow once said. ''If you make the wrong turn you're bankrupt so fast you don't know what hit you.''

title: BOND YIELDS PLUMMET; MORE FED EASING SEEN
description: Bond yields declined sharply yesterday, as forecasts of a sluggish economy and a drop in overnight interest rates led to heightened speculation that 30-year Treasury bonds yields may stay below 8 percent.

title: DOERR, LOMBARDI MAKE HALL OF FAME
description: Bobby Doerr and Ernie Lombardi, two of the solid hitters in baseball's golden era of hitting in the 1930's and 1940's, were voted into the Hall of Fame today by the Committee on Veterans.

title: COURT CURBS TOXIC WASTE TAX
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that some of the special taxes New Jersey has collected from oil and chemical companies for toxic waste cleanups were pre-empted by the Federal Superfund law and must be refunded.

title: Don't Stigmatize the Adopted
description: To the Editor:

title: CORDLESS PHONES RAISE AN EAVESDROPPING ISSUE
description: Cordless telephones are at the center of a debate in the New Jersey Division of Criminal Justice over whether current wiretap laws apply to the interception of conversations pulled out of the air.

title: UNICORP CANADA CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $10,178,000. c-After a special gain of $1,106,000. Preferred dividends exceeded net income in the latest year, therefore, no share earnings. The company said 1985 results include those of Union Enterprises Ltd. from the April 1 acquisition date and the latest year's special charge is from a provision for loss on the disposition of Unicorp Resources Ltd. and tax credits.

title: Ex-Judge Dies in Prison
description: Former Circuit Judge Daniel P. McDonald, serving a life term for killing the law partner of the man who defeated him for the judgeship, died, apparently of a heart attack, in his cell early today. Mr. McDonald, 43 years old, had been serving a life prison term in the killing of James Klein, 31, on June 22, 1985.

title: NAVY MAN ARRESTED IN SPY CASE
description: A Navy enlisted man has been arrested for investigation of selling classified Government documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: A College Coach Turns Sleuth
description: There was a substantial list of colleagues who found Jim Dennison's recent experience at the University of Akron unsettling. None of them, however, took it more to heart than Rich Johanningmeier, who was led to make a very unusual career change.

title: St. Patrick's Parade to Be A First for Milo O'Shea
description: Although he is a native-born Irishman, Milo O'Shea has never marched in a St. Patrick's Day parade. This year will be a first for the 59-year-old actor.

title: SCHEIB, EARL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
'ANIMALS: HOW SMART ARE THEY?' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''I NNOVATION'' doesn't really tell us how smart animals are, even if tonight's episode is called ''Animals: How Smart Are They?'' Actually, ''Innovation'' is too smart itself to try to answer the question. All the evidence isn't in yet, and the evidence we have is contradictory. Nonetheless, ''Innovation'' works intelligently, even entertainingly, with what it has. It can be seen on Channel 13 at 8:30 P.M.

title: Wings Trade Larson
description: The Detroit Red Wings traded their co-leading scorer, Reed Larson, to the Bruins for Mike O'Connell and also dealt Greg Smith to the Capitals for Darren Veitch. All the players are defensemen. The Red Wings have allowed 350 goals in 67 games, the most in the league. . . . The center Kirk Muller, who had two 4-point games last week, is the first member of the Devils to be named the league's player of the week, sharing the honor with Jarri Kurri of the Oilers. . . . Bob McGill, a defenseman for the Maple Leafs, has been given a seven-day suspension by the National Hockey League for a slashing incident in a game against Detroit March 1.

title: STROKES LINKED TO STRESS OF GETTING UP IN MORNING
description: People are most likely to suffer strokes between 8 A.M. and 9 A.M. - the time already known to be most dangerous for heart attacks - and experts believe these crises may be triggered by the stress of getting up in the morning.

title: MIXED PATTERN FOR FAST FOODS
description: FAST-FOOD restaurants are experiencing a major shakeout as many newcomers to the business - hurt by too-quick expansion and undercapitalization - succumb to major chains.

title: Mets' Wilson Improves
description: The Mets got more cheering news on Mookie Wilson today when the 21 stitches were removed from alongside his damaged right eye and an early return to light exercise was predicted, perhaps as early as next week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 11, 1986
description: Companies White agreed to a sweetened buyout bid from Electrolux of Sweden of $47 a share, or $742.6 million. White, the nation's third-largest home appliance maker and producer of such brands as Frigidaire, Kelvinator and Gibson, last week rejected a $45-a-share, or $711 million, offer from Electrolux. [ D1. ] Inland Steel will change its corporate structure, making it easier for the steelmaker to enter new businesses and form joint ventures. Inland also said that it would sell three million shares of common stock, might seek to acquire J. M. Tull Industries and expects a first-quarter loss of about $40 million. [ D1. ] House revisions of the Conrail sale bill passed by the Senate are planned by Democrats. Supported by key Republicans, they are bent on revising the Senate bill into one they can advertise as doing more to protect service, competition, jobs and the Treasury. [ D1. ] G.M. will halt production temporarily at four assembly plants, idling 10,600 workers. Analysts said they were not surprised by G.M.'s move because of rising inventories. [ D4. ] T.W.A. and striking flight attendants agreed to resume talks, Federal mediators said. [ A24. ] Morrow Designs filed for bankruptcy, the latest victim of a two-year consolidation in the personal computer industry. [ D9. ] Rooney, Pace and Sherwood Capital agreed to merge in a stock transaction of unspecified value, the companies said. [ D4. ] If the Air Force cancels Fairchild Republic's T-46 trainer and modifies existing T-37 planes, it could save more than $2 billion over the next five years, a Congressional Budget Office study says.

title: REAGAN SEES A 'MORAL OBLIGATION' BY U.S. TO AID NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: President Reagan, conceding that his proposed $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels faces an uphill battle in Congress, said today that the United States had a ''moral obligation'' to provide the assistance.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
U.S. PLANS TO SELL ADVANCED MISSILES TO SAUDI ARABIA
description: The Reagan Administration will notify Congress on Tuesday that it intends to sell Saudi Arabia $350 million worth of advanced missiles, White House officials said today, There are indications the proposal will face strong opposition on Capitol Hill.

title: HASTINGS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRAINING BANK AIDS AS BROKERS
description: NO one knows how many bank officers and employees will be affected by the Securities and Exchange Commission's regulation 3b-9, but Maryann Giarratano of the American Institute of Banking believes that ''thousands of people'' in the banking industry will be obliged to take courses so that they can become registered representatives, just like stockbrokers.

title: AMOSKEAG CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an income of $3,990,000 from equity interest in Fieldcrest Mills. c-Including an income of $1,900,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,495,000. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Biblical Sense
description: In addition to his well-known way with words, you can say this for Frank Layden: He has a way with weighty symbolism.

title: PARK-OHIO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,974,000 from the termination of a pension plan for the quarter and year.

title: A Tough Speech, but Will Gorbachev Deliver?
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address to the Communist Party Congress last week was familiar enough - more of the calls for economic reform and revitalization that have become standard fare among the Soviet elite. Mr. Gorbachev's language was forceful and far-reaching, but it will mean little in the long run unless it is backed up by deeds - and there is no indication yet that the General Secretary is going to be able to put his money where his mouth is.

title: Redmen Start Looking West
description: When the St. John's players learned that they were going to Long Beach, Calif., as the West Region's top-seeded team in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, their immediate reaction was unabashed joy.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MGM ASSETS DRAW INTEREST
description: Trafalgar Holdings, the private investment company headed by Charles W. Knapp, said today that it had discussed the possible purchase of the MGM Studios in Culver City, Calif., and other assets from the Turner Broadcasting System. Turner had said earlier that Mr. Knapp was among those who have expressed interest in purchasing assets of MGM film studios.

title: MIDAMERICA BANCSYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of tax credit of $115,000 for the quarter and including a tax credit of $598,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $115,000.

title: Only California Condor Egg In Wild Is Found Destroyed
description: The only California condor egg produced in the wild this season was found destroyed beneath its nest in a rugged area of Ventura County, biologists said today.

title: U.S. IN CRACKDOWN ON CITIZENS BAND INTERFERENCE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has begun a campaign to end use of illegal citizens band radio signal boosters, which cause interference on nearby televisions, radios and stereos.

title: LAC MINERALS
description: In the latest development in a dispute of almost five years, LAC Minerals Ltd. said it would continue to run a Canadian gold mine while it appeals a court order, issued Friday night, for it to surrender ownership of a mine in Hemlo, Ontario, worth more than $2 billion (United States), to a competitor, International Corona Resources. LAC stock plummeted $12.75 today in New York Stock Exchange trading, closing at $16.875.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CAVETT SHOW FOCUSES ON TELEVISION WRITERS
description: HAVING opened up shop a few months ago on cable's USA channel, Dick Cavett has been spending most of his talk-show time in a Manhattan theater about the size of a walk-in closet. Tonight's edition, at 10 o'clock, was taped in Hollywood. Somehow Mr. Cavett has managed to find an even smaller theater, which, as is revealed when he suddenly decides to test the acoustics from offstage, is only half full with what appears to be passing neighborhood residents and dedicated members of his personal staff. It may be that Mr. Cavett is working slowly toward eliminating the studio audience completely. The idea has merit.

title: G.A.O. SAYS MILITARY HAS 'INFLATION DIVIDEND'
description: The extra funds available to the Pentagon because it overestimated inflation have increased by several billion dollars since September, according to calculations by the General Accounting Office.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 6
FOXBORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $43.6 million from restructuring expenses for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: Spain's Choice: Westward or Backward
description: Spain's referendum tomorrow on continued NATO membership has turned into a referendum on its relationship with the United States. If that is a surprise for Americans used to thinking of Spain as a comfortable friend and ally, it is also a surprise for the politicians who called and shaped the vote. And it obscures Spain's stake in a European future. Strong emotions about the past roil beneath the surface of Spanish political life. This campaign has stirred them. How they are now expressed is more important than NATO membership.

title: SCHOOL VIOLENCE: THE JAPANESE VERSION
description: THE police in Tokyo arrested a 14-year-old junior high school student last month for striking a classmate in the face 20 to 30 times.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Works by Caltabiano At Merkin Concert Hall
description: Two tightly argued and imaginatively conceived instrumental pieces went far Sunday night at Merkin Concert Hall to explain the impressive list of honors and commissions Ronald Caltabiano has achieved in his mid-20's. One, a Lyric Duo for viola and harp, sets out to combine opposing musical elements - ''variation and development forms, lush textures and pointillism, tonal centers and serialism, rhythmic organization and freedom'' - and that is a theme that runs through both the music and the dramaturgy of Mr. Caltabiano's output to date.

title: A Non-Catholic Mourned At Funeral at Cathedral
description: Thomas C. Dillon was mourned at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in a funeral service conducted by John Cardinal O'Connor.

title: MALRITE COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $8,651,000 from the disposal of assets for the latest year and after $375,000 for the earlier period.

title: Rematch Ordered
description: Tim Witherspoon, who tested positive for marijuana after beating Tony Tubbs for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title, must give Tubbs a rematch within 90 days, James Binns, the association's counsel, said yesterday.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
MARTIN J. BUERGER
description: Martin J. Buerger, former Institute Professor of Mineralogy and Crystallography at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died of Alzheimer's Disease Feb. 25 at his home in Lincoln, Mass.

title: SAVINGS BONDS' VALUE AT PEAK
description: The value of United States savings bonds held by the public reached an all-time high of $80.83 billion last month, surpassing the old record of $80.55 billion set in December 1978, the Government said today.

title: DATABASES: USEFUL NEW 'NOTEBOOK'
description: HISTORICALLY, database managers were designed to deal mainly with short entries such as addresses for mailing lists, inventory tracking data and performance records like school grades. In theory, they should also be useful to lawyers, students and other researchers in sorting and organizing notes. But far too many databases are overly limited in the amount of text they allow to be stored in either a given record or any of its fields.

title: OXOCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes writedowns of about $25.4 million for the quarter and $71.7 million for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $217,868 for the quarter and year. d-Net income There were no share earnings for 1984 because the net did not cover preferred dividend requirements.

title: Turoff Leaves City Post As Taxi Commissioner
description: Jay L. Turoff, who said two weeks ago that he would resign April 30 as chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, changed his mind and left office yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BOY FROM EAST 112TH Now 71 years old, the playwright Arthur Miller has had a lifetime of success. A Pulitzer Prize, Tony and Drama Critics Circle awards and, before he was 40, six Broadway productions. His plays include ''Death of a Salesman,'' ''All My Sons,'' ''The Crucible,'' ''A View from the Bridge,'' ''The Price'' and ''After the Fall.'' He wrote a movie, ''The Misfits,'' which starred his wife at the time, Marilyn Monroe, and his television credits include ''Playing for Time,'' with Vanessa Redgrave. He has also written essays and short stories and has frequently discussed his theatrical aspirations, motives and observations.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect 3-for-2 split on April 1, 1985.

title: CHIEF ECONOMIST POST IS FILLED AT BIG BOARD
description: Roger M. Kubarych, who scarcely a year ago moved to the Conference Board as its chief economist, will be leaving the nonprofit organization on April 1 to become chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS COMPLAIN ON TRADE
description: Thirteen Democratic Senators, using information supplied by the Administration, called on President Reagan today to investigate what they called unfair trade practices by West Germany, the European Common Market, South Korea, Brazil and Japan -and to bar some of their products if the practices are not ended.

title: STANDARDIZED-TEST MAKERS SHIFT COURSE IN RESPONSE TO CRITICS
description: Testing companies, acknowledging qualms over the growing reliance on standardized multiple-choice exams, are developing techniques that they say will make their tests more reliable and comprehensive.

title: WORRIED SWEDES QUESTIONING WIDE REACH OF RESEARCHERS
description: Deep anxieties over privacy issues were stirred here recently with the discovery that for 20 years a team of sociologists had been compiling detailed profiles of nearly 15,000 Swedes by systematically rummaging through computerized official records.

title: Surprising Zenith Portable
description: ZENITH recently won a major contract to supply 15,000 portable computers to the Internal Revenue Service, beating out such other manufacturers as International Business Machines, Compaq and Data General. A few days later it won an even bigger prize, a contract to supply 90,000 microcomputers to the military.

title: JACKSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including credits from a 'fresh start' tax adjustment of $138,000 for the quarter, $552,000 for the year and realized investment gains of $331,092 for the quarter, $3,041,028 for the year. c-Including credits from a 'fresh start' tax adjustment of $2,785,800 for the quarter, $25,195,900 for the year and realized capital gains of $2,086,058 for the quarter, $1,677,297 for the year. Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid March 7, 1986.

title: CODENOLL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 11, 1986
description: International Congress is to be notified today that the Reagan Administration intends to sell Saudi Arabia $350 million worth of advanced missiles, White House officials said. The action is to be taken amid indications that the proposal faces strong opposition on Capitol Hill. But the reaction of the Israelis was mild. [ Page A1, Column 4. ]

title: NAVY REBUTS G.A.O. WITH STRONG DEFENSE OF PLAN FOR S.I. BASE
description: In a vigorous rebuttal to a Congressional audit, the Navy has prepared a defense of its plan to disperse the fleet to new home ports, including the basing of the battleship Iowa at Staten Island.

title: For the Disabled, More Justice Delayed
description: If time is money, stalling is saving: that's the only rational explanation for the Reagan Administration's approach to the Social Security disability program. The Government saved hundreds of millions by finding ways to delay payments to hundreds of thousands of people clearly entitled to the money. That drove hordes of them to the Federal courts for relief, creating a huge backlog of cases.

title: AN EX-PROSECUTOR USES EXPERIENCE IN PLEA DEAL
description: Irving P. Seidman, the defense lawyer who after two months of stormy negotiations obtained the plea-bargaining deal for Geoffrey G. Lindenauer, began his courtroom career prosecuting corrupt city employees and mob figures in Brooklyn.

title: Someday It Might Be Called the Octagon
description: The Pentagon, built in World War II, still claims to be the world's biggest office building, a five-sided warren of cubicles covering 3.6 million square feet of space and interconnected by 17 miles of corridors.

title: Temper, Temper, Temper
description: Feuds are not unheard of in the Senate, but they usually don't spill into public view with one Senator attacking another on or off the Senate floor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How would the U.S. feel if the Swiss told us how large a staff we could have at the Geneva arms talks?'' - Richard Gardner, Columbia University law professor and a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State. [ A4:5. ]

title: SULCUS COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 4:02 A.M. today and set at 1:37 P.M.

title: ALCOA PRICE SHIFTS
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it had set new prices on its aluminum foil, plate and sheet products. Prices on converter foil used in packaging were raised 6 percent over previous market prices and prices for common alloy sheet products were increased 5 percent, a company spokesman said. Alcoa also eliminated a 5 percent discount to distributors on standard items stocked in mills.

title: MARTIN AGENCY BUYING STENRICH GROUP
description: The Stenrich Group, a seven-year-old direct marketing agency here, is going to be acquired by the Martin Agency of Richmond. It will continue to operate under its own name and management.

title: RYKOFF-SEXTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
PAPER MAKERS HOPEFUL
description: The paper industry is expecting a good year in 1986 and is excited about it. A weaker dollar, lower energy prices and interest rates, eased inflation and a less intractable deficit problem have created a beneficial economy in which industry can thrive, executives said yesterday.

title: TEXACO TAKES STEP IN APPEAL
description: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it had begun the process of appealing a Texas jury's multibillion-dollar award to the Pennzoil Company.

title: Don't Stigmatize the Adopted
description: To the Editor:

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,028,000 for the quarter and $1,076,000 for the 6 months. The latest quarter loss from discontinued operations includes a charge of $992,000 from the settlement of litigation. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the quarter and $55,000 for the 6 months.

title: HIGH-TECHNOLOGY EFFORT REFLECTS NEW WEST BERLIN MOOD
description: Some of the heat that flamed Berlin's student revolt in the 60's is now going into a renewal of innovative capitalism here, holding out hope for an end to a quiet crisis of decline in the city's economy.

title: EUROPEAN BISON, BRED OF ZOO STOCK, ROAM THE WILD AGAIN
description: The hulking European bison that once survived only in zoos are lumbering unafraid these days along the Polish-Soviet border in an old czarist hunting preserve where the last of their unpenned ancestors died out 67 years ago.

title: Hagler's Next Bout: Himself
description: During the sixth round, Marvelous Marvin Hagler hit John Mugabi with everything but a blackjack table.

title: Gramm-Rudman Is Not Court Material
description: A three-judge Federal court has fired the opening salvo in the judiciary's examination of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit- reduction law by ruling that the statute is unconstitutional. Reasonable people differ over the wisdom of that law. But something is lost in the debate over its merits: the critical issue of whether the courts should be tinkering with the new law at all.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 18
RIGHTS BILL HEARINGS ON TV
description: Live, all-day coverage of the New York City Council hearings on the proposed homosexual-rights bill will be televised today, beginning at 10 A.M., on WNYC-TV (Channel 31 on UHF and Channel 3 on Manhattan Cable). The columnist Ken Auletta will act as commentator for the broadcast, which lasts until 4:30 P.M. and features interviews with public officials, religious leaders, homosexuals and other citizens from the metropolitan area. A wrap-up of the hearings is planned at 10 P.M.

title: IN BRIGHT FUTURE'S SHADOW, A VILLAGE OF VIOLENCE LURKS
description: In the darkness, Anna Soto can hear rats gnawing at her bedposts. Thelma Murphy can watch drug deals from her livingroom window. Norma Zayas can smell the garbage in the hallway outside her door.

title: UNITED OKLAHOMA BANCHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflects provisions for losses on the sales of overseas operations of $9.2 million for the quarter and year. c-Net income d-After losses from equity in discontinued operations of Chromalloy American Corp. of $606,000 for the quarter and $1,034,000 for the year. The latest fourth quarter loss reflects substantially higher provisions for underwriting losses at the company's offshore insurance subsidiary, and as a result, insurance operations reported net losses of $5.6 million for the quarter, compared with $300,000 for year-earlier period. The latest year net includes a loss from insurance operations of $10.1 million, compared with a loss of $500,000 for the earlier period's net.

title: Bridge: Being Hasty in Discarding Can Be a Costly Procedure
description: Unseemly and thoughtless haste in discarding unwanted material can be costly for those who have to deal with planning outdoors, in cities, or indoors, at the card table.

title: DYNAMICS CORP. TO LIFT CTS STAKE
description: In a move that the CTS Corporation described as ''unfriendly,'' the Dynamics Corporation of America said it planned to buy one million CTS shares in a partial tender offer for $43 in cash per share, to raise its stake in CTS to 27.2 percent, from 9.7 percent.

title: ISLAMIC GROUP ISSUES NEW THREAT ON FRENCH HOSTAGES IN LEBANON
description: A Moslem extremist group, making public what it said was a photograph of the slain body of a Frenchman kidnapped a year ago, warned today that the lives of other French hostages depended on the speed with which the French Government responded to its demands.

title: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROTESTANT CAUSE HURT BY BELFAST STRIKE
description: In front of a string of bleak, shuttered shops in downtown Belfast, a group of men gathered to watch two cars burning. Before the automobiles were set ablaze, the drivers had been stopped, dragged out and told they were not going to work during a one-day general strike called by Northern Ireland's Protestant leaders.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch last Thursday about efforts to control pesticides incorrectly described the health effects of the chemical aldicarb. It is under special review by the Environmental Protection Agency because it may affect the human nervous system.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Philadelphia Festival March 20 through March 23 are the dates for the second annual celebration of ''The Book and the Cook'' in Philadelphia. Forty-one cookbook authors - among them Diana Kennedy, Barbara Kafka, Paula Wolfert, Franco and Margaret Romagnoli, George and Piret Munger, Giuliano Bugialli and Craig Claiborne - will work with 40 Philadelphia restaurants during the four-day festival to prepare, supervise, consult and otherwise oversee the preparation of meals. Last year, some of the writers even ended up serving meals.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some of the foods in my pantry, including flours and pasta, are infested with small, annoying insects. How do I get rid of them without resorting to a chemical spray? A. Here's a folk remedy: Add one or two bay leaves to each package as it is opened and before storing it in the pantry. I can offer no scientific assurance that the leaves will eliminate those insects, but I am assured they will. Q. I often encounter a long, white radish known as daikon. How is it used? A. Daikon, a vegetable rich in vitamin C, is one of the most widely used ingredients in the Japanese kitchen. It is long and white and it should be firm and unblemished. The sizes vary greatly from the slender to the bulbous. When sliced and eaten, it is quite crisp, with the texture of an ordinary radish. Daikon is used raw in salads, as a garnish or cooked in soups and casseroles. Q. A friend recently returned from Puerto Rico and brought with her a gift package of something called annatto seeds. Can you tell me how they are used? A. Annatto seeds are widely used throughout the Caribbean as a coloring and flavoring agent. They are the dried, small, red fruit of a tropical tree and are used in the preparation of what is known as achiote lard or oil.

title: JOHN GRECO
description: John Greco, a lawyer who built the Waterbury, Conn., shrine and tourist attaction known as Holy Land, U.S.A., died Sunday at Monsignor Bojnowski Manor nursing home after a long illness. Mr. Greco was 90 years old and had lived at Holy Land until he was taken to the nursing home on Saturday.

title: U.S. PERTOLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization March 7Feb. 28March 8 #1986#1986#1985 Gasoline production, daily#6.1#6.6#6.1 Distillate production, daily#2.6#2.6#2.3 Gasoline stocks#240.2#244.6#223.3 Distillate stocks#109.4#114.6#118.2 Crude imports, daily#3.1#3.0#2.3 Product imports, daily#1.8#1.9#1.6 Crude stocks#336.9#333.1#325.4 Crude production, daily#8.9#8.9#8.9 Refinery utilization (%)#75.4#78.0#73.3 Source:

title: T.C.U. Beats Montana by 7
description: Carl Lott scored 27 points to lead Texas Christian to a 76-69 victory over Montana tonight in an opening round game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: 2 GUARDS OF MARCOS, BACK FROM HAWAII, TELL OF THE FINAL HOURS
description: The final hours of Ferdinand E. Marcos as President were marked by such anxiety and confusion, former aides said today, that members of his palace entourage were listening to the opposition radio station to find out what was going on.

title: Time for Packing
description: This is the time of year when some college basketball coaches start packing for postseason tournaments and others just start packing. Among the latter are Bill Foster, the 55-year-old South Carolina coach. Foster, whose Gamecocks lost their last eight games and ended with a 12-16 record, leaves South Carolina with the distinction of being the only college basketball coach to have won more than 20 games in a season at four different Division I schools (Duke, Rutgers, Utah and South Carolina). . . . Stan Morrison, whose Southern Cal team finished last in the Pacific-10 Conference this season after sharing the championship a year ago, resigned last night and will become an associate athletic director at the school. . . . Leonard Hamilton, a Kentucky assistant credited with recruiting several Wildcat all-Americans, was named head coach at Oklahoma State, succeeding Paul Hansen, who was told last month that his contract would not be renewed. . . . Boyd Grant, whose Fresno State Bulldogs turned in a 15-15 record, his first nonwinning season since he became coach in 1978, was dismissed. . . . John McDougal was dismissed as the Northern Illinois coach after turning in a 15-12 season that brought his 10-year record to 136-141. . . . Tom Apke, the Colorado coach who ended the season with 17 straight losses, was dismissed with two years remaining on his contract. . . . Bill Trumbo, the Idaho coach for the last three seasons was dismissed after finishing last in the Big Sky Conference each season.

title: BLACK CHURCHES JOIN THE FIGHT
description: FAMILY planning clinics are not the only groups galvanized into action against teen-age pregnancy. An increasing number of black churches across the country are also creating pregnancy-prevention programs and support groups for young mothers.

title: STATE-CITY PANEL APPOINTED TO SEEK END TO CORRUPTION
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch appointed a joint state-city commission yesterday to examine instances of corruption, favoritism and conflicts of interest in government and to recommend reforms.

title: 'UPSET' MONTEFUSCO QUITS YANK CAMP
description: John Montefusco, who had made a good beginning to come back from major hip surgery, ended at least the Yankee phase of that effort today by telling the team he would not return to camp. He then got into his car and started the long drive home to Colts Neck, N.J.

title: CAR MAGAZINES' BIG 3 ARE HOT
description: ''We were starting to wonder if America would ever get up the gumption to build cars like the Taurus and the Sable: Friendly to look at, functional to use, and full of the world's best technology.''

title: Tales Set to Music
description: An evening of music and storytelling is planned by the Baca Ensemble on March 25 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Gun Bill Goes to House Floor
description: The House Judiciary Committee today sent to the floor a compromise gun control bill that the gun owners' lobby argues would fall far short of easing what it considers burdensome provisions in the safe streets law of 1968.

title: Nazi Charge Against Waldheim Is Unjust
description: To the Editor:

title: '86 ORANGE JUICE DATA
description: Americans will buy more orange juice this year than ever before because of a drop in price and an abundant supply, according to Dr. Dan Gunter, economic research director at the Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences at the University of Florida. He predicted that United States consumption would reach 950 million gallons in 1986, compared with 817 million gallons in 1985. The price for orange juice is expected to average $3.28 a gallon in 1986, a decrease of 52 cents from last year.

title: NEW INQUIRY ON KOHL OPENS IN BONN
description: The Bonn prosecutor's office announced today that it was opening a judicial investigation into the possibility that Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave false testimony to a parliamentary inquiry.

title: KAISER SUITORS
description: A group seeking control of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had raised its stake to 21.6 percent of the shares outstanding from 20.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it bought 664,077 common shares last Friday for $18 a share. The group is led by J. A. Frates, an Oklahoma investor, and Alan Clore, a British investor.

title: Philharmonic to Play With School Orchestra
description: Students will make up the audience and share the stage at Avery Fisher Hall on April 21, when the New York Philharmonic and the All-City High School Orchestra give a joint concert, sponsored by the educational department of the New York Philharmonic. The program is part of a dropout prevention program co-sponsored by the New York City Board of Education.

title: Drug Abuse Doesn't Begin Over the Gulf of Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday on the tornado in the Middle West, which damaged planes at Greater Cincinnati International Airport, described a DC-9 airliner incorrectly. It has two engines, not four.

title: VOTE SET APRIL 11 ON BEATRICE DEAL
description: The Beatrice Companies said today that its shareholders would vote on April 11 on the proposed $6 billion acquisition of the company by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York-based investment firm. The directors of Beatrice have already approved the Kohlberg, Kravis offer.

title: Innocents Abroad On the Hill
description: This afternoon, between a House vote on an Irish aid bill and a committee hearing on narcotics, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of upstate New York, sat in his office and talked with an earnest constituent who handed him a bright yellow sheet listing a catalogue of woes.

title: Sonny Terry, 74, Singer And Harmonica Player
description: Sonny Terry, a Southern blues vocalist and harmonica player who was an important figure in the folk-music revival of the 1940's and 50's, died Tuesday in Mineola, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''SUN CITY,'' the recent album by rock, funk, jazz, Latin and other pop-music stars protesting South African apartheid, drew considerable attention in the news media to the continuing struggle between that country's ruling white majority and its severely restricted black majority. But it left several questions unanswered: Is there black pop music in the areas of South Africa set aside for blacks? What does it sound like? What is the place of pop music in such a volatile situation?

title: THEATER: BECKETT, IN JAPANESE STYLE
description: SAMUEL BECKETT'S ''Quad'' is a ghostly sonata - a brief, wordless exercise in movement and geometry. Four performers, armless in sack-like gowns, their faces hooded in cowls, move in swift triangular patterns within a large square marked by light. To the sound of insistent drums, the four rush through predetermined steps, singly and in groups. Looking like spectral monks scurrying to prayer, they studiously avoid contact with one another, just as they avoid the center of their quadrant. The author labels that spot ''the danger zone.''

title: Why Holiday Dates May Widely Diverge
description: Since the Crucifixion occurred during Passover, it would appear that the dates of the Christian feast of Easter and the Jewish Passover should roughly coincide. But the adoption of different ways of fixing the dates of the holidays over the centuries leads to occasional divergences.

title: At NASA, Where Was 'What If'?
description: As an engineer who has worked in manned space flight for almost 20 years and who hopes to see it continue, I was shocked to hear the acting administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, William R. Graham, say, ''The final product was a Datafax sheet of paper saying that [the booster manufacturer] supported the launch'' of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: MICKELBERRY TAKES $3.3 MILLION WRITE-OFF
description: The Mickelberry Corporation, the holding company whose properties include Cunningham & Walsh and Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, opted to take a $3.3 million write-off for good will in the fourth quarter, which meant that its net income showed a loss of a $2.6 million, or 45 cents a share, from the corresponding quarter in 1984.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: HOW herbs and spices are used - or misused - depends primarily on the culinary idiosyncrasies of a particular country. Tarragon plays a pivotal role in the French kitchen, yet it is not widely used in Italy. Basil, a key to fine Italian cooking, only recently became popular in France. Dill, an essential herb for Scandinavian cooks, has traditionally played a fairly minor role in other parts of Europe, with the exception of Greece.

title: Accord at Meadowlands
description: Harness horsemen and the operators of the Meadowlands race track agreed today on a one-year contract, ending a labor dispute that had closed operations since last Thursday night. Racing will resume Wednesday night.

title: SENATORS FIGHT SAUDI MISSILE DEAL
description: Opponents of a missile sale to Saudi Arabia said today that more than 50 senators had agreed to try to block the deal.

title: Brothers Charged
description: Bill and Don Whittington, the auto racing brothers who won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1979, have been charged with evading millions of dollars in taxes on the profits of a huge marijuana smuggling operation, according to court papers filed by Federal authorities in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The brothers, who reportedly built a $16 million fortune that includes a Georgia road racing track, aviation operations, a mobile home park and a recreational vehicle dealership, have been engaged in plea bargaining since December and are expected to forfeit $7 million.

title: Nicaragua, the Last Domino
description: The Administration wants to ''stand for democracy in Nicaragua'' - exactly, President Reagan says, as we did in the Philippines. The comparison is silly. Of all the many differences between Managua and Manila, the most obvious is the democratic values of the opposition.

title: COUNCIL PANEL APPROVES HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS BILL
description: A bill to forbid discrimination against homosexuals in employment, housing and public accommodations was approved last night by the City Council's General Welfare Committee and will now go to the full Council for final action. It was the first time since 1974 that such a bill has passed out of the committee.

title: TURPIN OVERPOWERS KNICKS
description: Last December, Mel Turpin scored a career-high 29 points against Patrick Ewing. Last night, without Ewing to worry about, the 6-foot-11-inch, 265-pound barrelchested Turpin did even better.

title: Topics; Send 'Em a Message U.N. Countdown
description: The Administration's desire to reduce the Soviet delegations to the United Nations offends some experts in international law, but it hardly offends common sense. Washington and Moscow have always roughly reciprocated their exchange and treatment of diplomats.

title: ARCHDIOCESE TO KEEP LINKS TO MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York says it will not require a private medical college affiliated with the archdiocese to give up a $24 million contract with two municipal hospitals in which abortions are performed.

title: PENNSYLVANIA IN OFFERING
description: Pennsylvania is offering $100 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Yields range from 4 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 5 1/2 percent in 1991, 6 percent in 1996, 6.45 percent in 2001 and 6.55 percent in 2005.

title: Molloy Captures Catholic Title, 69-66
description: Archbishop Molloy, led by 23 points from Kenny Anderson, scored a 69-66 overtime victory over Tolentine in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Class A championship game last night at Fordham University.

title: P.S.A.L. COACHES RECRUITING PLAYERS
description: Coaches in many of the city's top public high school basketball programs actively recruit players, even though the practice violates Public Schools Athletic League rules, according to a number of coaches and others familiar with the city's athletic programs.

title: Coping With AIDS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: THE OBSTACLES TO TRADE GAIN
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that the gap between what the United States buys and sells abroad - a record $148.5 billion last year - should narrow once a lower-valued dollar has had time to work into cheaper exports and costlier imports.

title: Famine Relief Audit Issued
description: U.S.A. for Africa has raised $44.5 million for hunger relief, mostly in royalties from ''We Are the World,'' the Grammy-winning record issued a year ago, according to an audit released Saturday. The group's directors have spent or allocated about $19 million for immediate famine relief in eight African nations and committed another $24.5 million for long-term agricultural and health projects in Africa. About $900,000 has been spent or allocated for efforts in the United States.

title: Golf; HAZARDS OF PHILIPPINE COURSE RECALLED
description: Tom Sieckmann, a 31-year-old Nebraska golfer who sharpened his competitive game through seven years on numerous foreign golf tours, remembers well his experiences in the Philippines when Ferdinand E. Marcos played with the pros. Sieckmann won the Philippine Open in 1981, the same year he won the Thailand, Brazilian and Singapore Opens. But it was a year or two later that he became involved with the former President of the Philippines.

title: Firsts, at Last
description: Monday night marked an extraordinary double in hockey and basketball. To begin with, the Hartford Whalers beat the Canadiens at Montreal for the very first time, ending their string of 23 nonwinning efforts at the Forum - 18 losses and 5 ties -since joining the National Hockey League six years ago.

title: CITIES LOSE GREYHOUND TO THE SUBURBS
description: Over the years, countless travelers have learned the future, along with their weight, by plunking a penny in the chrome and mirrored scale in the Greyhound Bus terminal here.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 12, 1986
description: Markets Wall Street recorded one of its its biggest gains ever in a single session as the public, driven by shrinking yields in the money markets and other investments sensitive to interest rates, plowed funds into stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 43.10 points, its second-largest one-day gain, to close at a record 1,746.05. Other market gauges were equally buoyant. Trading volume soared to its fifth-heaviest level ever. [ Page A1. ] Strong gains in the bond market continued, as prices for outstanding Treasury issues rose as much as 1 1/2 points, and the yield of the bellwether 30-year issue fell to 7.92 percent - the lowest level since December 1977. [ D17. ] The dollar declined. Many traders expect Government reports to show a sluggish U.S. economy, which could depress interest rates. Gold rose $1.75, reaching $343.50 an ounce in New York. [ D18. ] Treasury bond futures soared to levels last seen eight years ago on the belief that interest rates would go still lower. [ D18. ] Companies Revco received an offer from senior executives to acquire the company for $33 a share in cash and shares of preferred stock that it valued at an additional $3 a share, or a total of $1.16 billion. The nation's largest drugstore chain said it had set up a committee to evaluate the bid. [ D1. ] American Air expects to be unprofitable in the first quarter because of fierce fare-cutting. Analysts said other airlines would also have losses in the current quarter.

title: ABNORMAL DEATH RATE CITED AT 43 HOSPITALS IN STATE
description: Forty-three of New York State's 291 hospitals were identified yesterday by the Federal Government as having abnormal mortality rates, either significantly higher or significantly lower than the national average.

title: LEWIS MATHE, BRIDGE PLAYER WHO WAS WORLD CHAMPION
description: One of the world's leading contract bridge players, Lewis L. Mathe, died Monday at his home in Canoga Park, Calif. He was 70 years old and had been suffering from a heart condition.

title: GEORGIA PARDONS VICTIM 70 YEARS AFTER LYNCHING
description: The State of Georgia awarded a posthumous pardon today to Leo M. Frank, a Jewish businessman who was lynched in 1915 for a murder he denied committing.

title: ART COLLECTION, IMELDA MARCOS STYLE
description: Imelda Marcos routinely took large numbers of paintings from a major museum here to display in her houses around the Philippines, a team of Government inspectors found today.

title: A FAMILY AFINNITY FOR IRISH TEA PAYS OFF
description: THEIR breath rising like vapor from piping hot cups of tea, Richard and Jo Bewley darted about their chilly two-car garage one afternoon looking for marmalade among the towering rows of cartons marked ''Product of Ireland.'' The orders for St. Patrick's Day were nearly ready for shipment, and the garage was bursting with Irish tea, biscuits and jams that would soon be on breakfast tables throughout the United States.

title: 2-PART, $300 MILLION PENNZOIL PACKAGE
description: The Pennzoil Company is offering a two-part package of debt securities totaling $300 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: City Cites 199 Notices Of Pending Contracts
description: Responding to union charges that the city had failed to make public hundreds of pending contracts worth more than $50,000 each, the Koch administration has said it published notice of almost 200 such contracts in The City Record.

title: REPAIR WORK ON THE F.D.R. TO SLOW NORTHBOUND LANES
description: Starting next month, northbound motorists on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive can expect delays as work picks up on the renovation of the 40-year-old highway.

title: Soaring Costs
description: At a meeting of the White House Domestic Policy Council the other day, Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige gave a small demonstration of the widespread belief that increased expenditures can win Administration approval, even in these days of economic stringency, if they are related to the military. Mr. Baldrige scribbled a few lines on a notepad and handed James C. Miller 3d, director of the Office of Management and Budget, the following doodle:

title: J. WALTER THOMPSON LISTS U.S. CHANGES
description: Last week the worldwide J. Walter Thompson Company announced a slew of promotions starting at the top. Yesterday J. Walter Thompson, U.S.A., its domestic operation, had a few of its own, which were announced by Burton J. Manning, chairman and chief executive.

title: The Power of the Subpoena
description: Like kings exercising their divine right, Congressional committees consider there is little, if any, information they are not entitled to examine in an investigation. And if someone questions that right by refusing to produce requested documents, Congress has the power of subpoena.

title: CITY INVESTIGATORS IMPOUND RECORDS AT TAXICABS AGENCY
description: City investigators have impounded records of the Taxi and Limousine Commission after discovering that taxi medallions and documents at commission headquarters had disappeared or been tampered with, city officials reported yesterday.

title: TEXAS MAN EXECUTED BY INJECTION
description: A man convicted of shooting to death a city marshal after being stopped during a robbery investigation was executed by lethal injection early today, becoming the second person put to death in the United States this year.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on March 3 about the Indian Government's budget misidentified the nation's Finance Minister. He is V. P. Singh.

title: CAN A STRICTLY NON-TV TYPE PULL ABC FROM DOLDRUMS?
description: John B. Sias, the new president of ABC, is a television executive of a sort the industry has never before encountered. Mr. Sias has never read a single television script. What's more, he says he probably never will.

title: SCALI, McCABE APPOINTS
description: Lee Graham, 45, has been promoted to president from executive vice president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct Response, filling a job slot vacated about a month ago by Jerry Reitman. Mr. Graham will run the domestic operation of the Scali, McCabe, Sloves subsidiary and will also coordinate its international expansion. He had been a vice president of marketing for CBS Columbia House division and worked as well for American Express.

title: A Most Unlikely Occasion
description: We dropped by Great-Uncle Jim's the other night for the big wedding anniversary, it being the 36th for him and Great-Aunt Simone. They were barely cordial to us, at least until they saw we'd brought two bottles of champagne.

title: SANDINISTA DENIES EXPORTING REVOLT
description: Nicaragua's new chief delegate to the United Nations today denied the Reagan Administration's accusation that her Government was exporting revolution throughout Central America, and she called on Washington to negotiate a peaceful settlement of the region's conflicts.

title: A FORD STAKE IN CERADYNE
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had paid about $10 million for a stake of about 11 percent in Ceradyne Inc. of Irvine, Calif. Ford and Ceradyne have agreed to set up a new company, Ceradyne Advanced Products Inc., to develop automotive uses for ceramics.

title: Drug Abuse Doesn't Begin Over the Gulf of Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev's First Year
description: Mikhail Gorbachev has now completed his first year as General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party in Moscow, and Washington is still trying to figure him out.

title: 'JERUSALEM,' GEOGRAPHIC VISIT ON 13
description: WHAT is Jerusalem? ''A sacred city of the soul,'' ''a haven, a refuge,'' and, ''Jerusalem: Within These Walls'' suggests, the repository of the most awesome historical detritus in the world. Millennia, not centuries, cohabit. The National Geographic special, on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight, is fascinating.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Calay Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., which makes automated design systems for printed circuit board layouts, has named John Virtue chief operating officer.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
FILENE'S EXPECTED TO ADD FOOD LINE
description: Filene's, the Boston-based chain of fashion stores, is expected to announce this morning the opening of gourmet food departments in all 16 of its stores, according to retail trade sources.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 12, 1986
description: International

title: Sci-Fi as an Out
description: Kiki Vandeweghe of the under-.500 Portland Trail Blazers explains why he prefers science-fiction books: ''When you read about somebody blowing up a universe, losing a game doesn't seem so bad.''

title: PRETORIA TO LET 3 CBS JOURNALISTS STAY
description: The Government today reversed an order expelling three CBS News journalists.

title: CORRECTION
description: A logo of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on the Washington Talk page on Monday appeared in some copies in an outdated version. The agency now insures deposits of up to $100,000 per account, not the $20,000 shown.

title: POLICY EXTENDED OF HOSPITALIZING THE HOMELESS
description: The Koch administration has decided to extend through the summer a program in which psychiatric teams may hospitalize homeless people considered a danger to themselves, a top city official said yesterday.

title: U.S. RELEASING LISTS OF HOSPITALS WITH ABNORMAL MORTALITY RATES
description: The Health and Human Services Department is preparing to release lists of the nation's hospitals that have mortality rates significantly higher or lower than the national average, the first such lists ever compiled.

title: Nystrom Gains In Milan Tennis
description: Joakim Nystrom of Sweden advanced today into the second round of the $385,000 Fila Trophy indoor tournament, making short work of a countryman, Jonas B. Svensson.

title: 3 QUEENS BOARDS SAY SCHOOLS WILL BE CLOSED FOR PASSOVER
description: Three community school boards in Queens said yesterday that they would defy the central Board of Education and order all schools under their jurisdiction to close during the first two days of the Passover holiday next month.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,825,000 from termination of domestic pension plans for salaried employees for the quarter and year, and after losses from discontinued operations and provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $13,875,000 for the quarter, $72,258,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $524,000 for the quarter and $1,560,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: The Astronauts' Fear of Flying
description: Fear and outrage have appeared in the corps of astronauts. John Young, the chief astronaut, has chided NASA for putting schedule above safety. Sally Ride, one of the shuttle crash investigators, says she's not ready to fly again. In the darkness of space, astronauts know no fear. What terrifies them is their glimpse of NASA's decision-making.

title: F.B.I. IN INQUIRY ON E.P.A. RECORDS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has opened a preliminary inquiry into allegations that attorneys for the Reagan Administration misled the President, Congress and a Federal court in the withholding of Environmental Protection Agency data from two House committees in 1983, sources said today.

title: NASA WOULD SHIFT SOME LAUNCHINGS TO PRIVATE SECTOR
description: The space agency has decided on a major revision of its space operations by shifting to a mixed fleet of shuttles and unmanned rockets to launch earth satellites, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration confirmed yesterday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DIALOGUE on Avenue of the Americas in the mid-40's between an out-of-towner (in Stetson) walking north, and Sheldon Sachs, a native New Yorker, walking south:

title: WINE TALK
description: AS a rule, it seems only fair to avoid topics that exclude most readers. Vicarious thrills are fine up to a point, but tastings of rare wines that no one else will experience and visits to exalted, exclusive French chateaus are of the discredited, eat-your-heart-out school of wine reportage. They have little currency here. Having said that, it is still incumbent on me, and quite pleasurable as a matter of fact, to report on a wine that few will ever have a chance to taste.

title: George Abbott Luncheon
description: The writer, director and producer George Abbott will be honored at the 37th spring luncheon of the Dramatists Guild on May 16 at 11:30 A.M. at the Plaza Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Mr. Abbott, who celebrates his 99th birthday in June, has directed more than 100 plays in a career spanning more than 70 years.

title: Take Candy and Soda From Food-Stamp List
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Releases Funds for Farm Loans
description: President Reagan today authorized the release of emergency funds and approved other bookkeeping actions, allowing the transfer of $750 million so the Government can keep up with the demand for farm operating loans this spring, a White House spokesman said.

title: KOCH NAMES AN OFFICIAL OF UNICEF CITY'S NEW HEALTH COMMISSIONER
description: Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, special coordinator of the United Nations Children's Fund, has been named the city's new Health Commissioner, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: HENRY J. FRIENDLY, FEDERAL JUDGE IN COURT OF APPEALS, IS DEAD AT 82
description: Henry J. Friendly, a Federal judge in New York for 27 years and a man with a national reputation for crafting scholarly, well-written legal opinions, died in his Park Avenue apartment in Manhattan yesterday, apparently a suicide, the police said. He was 82 years old.

title: KEYCORP-PACWEST
description: Keycorp, a financial services company based in Albany, said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Pacwest Bancorp of Portland, Ore., for $76 million, or $41 a share. Keycorp, which has more than $7 billion in assets, announced last week theacquisition of Seattle Trust and Savings Bank. Last year, Keycorp bought Bank of Oregon, and it has two other Oregon acquisitions pending: Citizens Valley Bank in Salem and Beaver State Bank in Beaverton.

title: People
description: * Carol Cotton has been named senior vice president, management supervisor on new business and strategic planning at Dancer Fitzgerald, Sample, San Francisco.

title: Coping With AIDS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CHICAGO'S MAYOR SEEKS FEDERAL VOTING OBSERVERS
description: Mayor Harold Washington wants Federal monitors to come to this city for next Tuesday's court-ordered elections in seven black and Hispanic wards because ''there's a lot of hanky-panky going on.''

title: WHERE POLITICS IS THOUGHT FOR FOOD
description: ''Madame chairperson, we know you for what you are,'' charged Moe Doctrow, a member of the powerful Food Committee at the Hebrew Home For The Aged. ''An antifish fanatic. Because of your prejudice the stuffed flounder before us does not have a prayer.''

title: Paris Aide Reported In Touch With Captors
