description: A French mediator, Dr. Razah Raad, was reported today to have made contact with Moslem extremists holding French hostages.

title: Television I
description: The bright young men and women who work for high-level Government officials learn early on that anticipating the needs and interests of the chief is critical to success. Those lucky enough to work in the White House try to anticipate a little earlier and more accurately than the rest.

title: Cuban Army General Ends Nicaraguan Duty
description: The senior Cuban military officer in Nicaragua in recent years has ended his tour here and returned to Cuba, according to the official Sandinista newspaper, Barricada.

title: FUND TRACKS S.&.P. 500 INDEX
description: INDIVIDUALS who complain they cannot ''beat the market'' or who fear their stock portfolios are at the mercy of giant institutional investors might find it worthwhile to consider the Vanguard Index Trust.

title: CHIP ORDERS UP IN FEBRUARY
description: Orders for semiconductors increased in February, with the book-to-bill ratio rising to 1.10, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade organization based in San Jose, Calif.

title: REAGAN AGREES TO PRESS FOR IMMIGRATION BILL
description: President Reagan met today with key members of Congress to express his support for legislation designed to stop the flow of illegal aliens into the United States.

title: F.C.C. POLICY ON PHONES
description: The Federal Communications Commission is set to propose abolishing its rule barring the regional Bell Telephone operating companies from selling equipment in conjunction with basic telephone service.

title: Gogol Knew Russians Were No Collectivists
description: To the Editor:

title: Contaminated Milk Is Found in 6 States
description: The state has placed 31 more dairies on a quarantine list, bringing to 64 the number found to have milk contaminated with the pesticide heptachlor that has led to recalls in six states, the state health department said today.

title: WEIGHING IN WITH THE BEST EASTER HAMS
description: ALL over the world, wherever the pig is eaten, hams are, too.

title: HARD FIGHT SEEN TO SALVAGE T.V.A. PROGRAM
description: Salvaging the Tennessee Valley Authority's troubled nuclear power program will be ''doable'' despite years of mismanagement, the program's new manager told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today. But he said the effort would be costly and might take several years.

title: MANILA PRESSING U.S. ON MARCOS FINANCIAL RECORDS
description: The Philippine Government and a Congressional subcommitttee have intensified efforts to gain access to financial documents brought to Hawaii by Ferdinand E. Marcos, according to American and Philippine officials.

title: A SYNDICATE APPROACH AT MARSH & McLENNAN
description: As the nation's largest insurance brokerage firm, Marsh & McLennan Inc. has for years matched its large corporate clients with property-casualty insurers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: AMERICAN HOECHST CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TIMES SQ. TOWER'S RENEWAL
description: THE new owners of One Times Square, the historic tower in Times Square, are planning to modernize its office space and transform a long-vacant two-level exhibition area on the lower floors into a small retail fashion mall.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE DANCE: CUNNINGHAM OPENS SEASON
description: THE Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which presented the New York premiere of Mr. Cunningham's richly inventive ''Arcade'' last night, appeared at one point to be opening its first two-week season at the City Center without Mr. Cunningham onstage. This impression turned out to be untrue but it did strike a thematic note.

title: BELDING HEMINWAY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $775,000, or 28 cents a share, on the sale of a portion of the company's cellular telephone investments for the quarter and year. The year result also includes net equity in earnings of investments of $1,031,000, or 37 cents a share.

title: Ewing Injury Confirmed
description: Dr. Carl McCartee, the Georgetown University team physician during Patrick Ewing's playing days there, examined the 7-foot Knick center yesterday in Washington and confirmed the diagnosis made Monday by Dr. Norman Scott that Ewing has a floating soft tissue in his right knee. Dr. Scott, the Knicks' team doctor, has recommended arthroscopic surgery.

title: 2 MARCOS BACKERS SOUGHT BY MANILA
description: The Government ordered the arrest today of two members of the National Assembly in connection with killings during the presidential campaign last month, in the first direct action against major supporters of the Marcos Government.

title: RANGERS' PAVELICH REPORTEDLY RETIRING
description: While the Rangers' management remained unable to make contact with Mark Pavelich this afternoon, some of his teammates said tonight he already considered himself retired.

title: GRUMMAN VEHICLE
description: The Grumman Corporation said that a vehicle it is building jointly with the General Motors Corporation had passed a critical test that might result in the awarding of a contract to build 99,150 delivery trucks for the United States Postal Service. A spokesman for the Postal Service said the agency's capital investment committee would review the test results this week.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial on Spain yesterday said incorrectly that all 12 members of the European Common Market belong to NATO. Ireland, a market member, does not.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Shares (ADS).

title: Hess Is Winner
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland won a women's World Cup slalom race today and maintained her lead in the season slalom standings.

title: THE STAKES ARE HIGH IN SPAIN'S NATO VOTE
description: A producer for Spanish television had insisted for weeks that she would vote to pull Spain out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the coming referendum.

title: CORRECTION
description: A film review of ''Salvador'' on March 5 misidentified the protagonist in some references. He is Richard Boyle, not Richard Burke.

title: NETS SLIP AND GO TO 33-34
description: Much has been speculated concerning the Nets' current slide, how it might cause them to slip in the standing and face the Central Division-leading Milwaukee Bucks in the opening round of the playoffs instead of the Philadelphia 76ers, with whom they are better matched.

title: MAKING FLOUR AT HOME
description: HOME bread makers tend to be a health-conscious lot who spurn the overbleached commercial products that lack texture in favor of their own distinctive, tasty creations.

title: 3 PAINLESS INNINGS FOR BERENYI
description: In some ways, this was a painful day for the young men of the Mets. Dwight Gooden had root-canal work on two teeth. Darryl Strawberry still had some inflammation on his knee. And Shawn Abner, the rookie who hit two home runs in the opening exhibition game, suffered a bruised left forearm when he was struck by a pitched ball.

title: JANSON'S SON REVISES CLASSIC ART TEXT
description: The book is a campus classic, a seven-pound, 750-page tome filled with pictures and prose, remembered by tens of thousands of liberal-arts graduates simply as Janson's - the basic college textbook on the world's great painting and sculpture.

title: TRADING HEAVY
description: Wall Street yesterday recorded one of its biggest gains as the public, driven by shrinking yields on investments that are sensitive to interest rates, plowed funds into stocks in a frenzy of buying.

title: Bennett Backs Testing Of Skills of Teachers
description: Secretary of Education William J. Bennett today defended the use of basic skills tests such as the one given to teachers in Texas on Monday and predicted that such tests would become increasingly common.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN SELECTS AN ECONOMIST AS CHIEF
description: Texas American Bancshares Inc., the state's seventh-largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that Lewis H. Bond will step down as chairman and chief executive after the company's annual meeting on April 24.

title: EXPERTS AWAIT RECOVERY OF SPACE SHUTTLE'S TAPE RECORDINGS
description: Teams of technical experts are awaiting the recovery of tape recordings and computer data from the wreckage of the Challenger's crew compartment, space agency officials said today.

title: FLUOR PROFIT OF $6.6 MILLION
description: The Fluor Corporation, an engineering, construction and natural resources company, announced net earnings of $6.6 million, or 8 cents a share, for the first quarter ended Jan. 31, compared with a net loss of $32.6 million for the quarter last year.

title: INSTAN REPLAYS GET APPROVAL BY N.F.L.
description: After more than a year of discussion, limited experimentation and hours of debate, the National Football League owners voted today to use video-taped replays as an officiating aide. The motion, which passed by a vote of 23-4, with one abstention, will be used for the 1986 season, starting with the preseason games, but must be approved again for use in seasons beyond.

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. HURTS RELATIONS BY ITS U.N. ORDER
description: The Soviet Government said today that ''direct damage'' to relations with the United States could result from the American order that the size of Soviet missions to the United Nations be reduced.

title: SEX THERAPY AND RELIGION
description: THE rabbi had been unable to consummate his marriage, and he and his wife were childless. Driven by the biblical commandment to be fruitful and multiply, the couple went to see a sex therapist.

title: MERRILL LYNCH HIRES SHEARSON EXECUTIVE
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which has recently been reaching beyond its ranks to grab top-notch talent, announced yesterday that Richard F. Morrison, a senior executive vice president at Shearson Lehman Brothers, would join the firm as its top technology officer.

title: Accounts
description: * DeLong Sportswear of Grinnell, Iowa, to Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zirbel, Des Moines.

title: BONDS POST SHARP INCREASES
description: Strong gains in the bond market continued yesterday, as prices for outstanding Treasury issues rose as much as 1 1/2 points, and the yield of the bellwether 30-year issue fell to 7.92 percent - the lowest level since December 1977.

title: Bridge: A Biography of Culbertson Portrays a Complex Figure
description: The most remarkable figure in the history of contract bridge is certainly Ely Culbertson, who within a decade rose from obscurity, using calculated showmanship to popularize the game and himself with it.

title: EFFORT RESUMES TO RECOVER SHUTTLE CABIN
description: The space agency resumed its efforts today to recover the broken crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger so that forensic experts can identify the decomposed remains of the astronauts that have been discovered inside.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SUNNY SIDE OUT Long before eggs were identified as a source of cholesterol they were an ancient symbol of resurrection. As such, they have been associated with the Easter ritual. Pysanky are Ukrainian Easter eggs. Before Christianity, raw eggs were decorated in the area to celebrate the coming of spring. The designs represented the sun, moon and stars, as well as flowers and animals, and symbolized the universe. With the advent of Christianity, fish, churches and crosses were incorporated into the designs.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES COLORADO - Dismissed Tom Apke, head basketball coach.

title: Digging Beneath the Scandal
description: What? Another New York City corruption inquiry? Yes, and for good reason: Most of the investigations already under way - by five borough prosecutors, two United States Attorneys, the city's Department of Investigation and others - seek evidence of crime. The commission now proposed by Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch, to be headed by Michael Sovern, president of Columbia University, would explore the scandals' underlying causes.

title: MAXIMUM YIELD 7.86% ON TEXAS UTILITY BONDS
description: A $535.6 million financing by the Austin, Tex., municipal utility system to refund previously issued debt was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.86 percent for bonds due in 2013 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss after a charge from plant consolidation costs of $5,800,000 for the quarter and year.

title: THE LIBERATED DUCK: A SUMPTUOUS STORY IN SEVERAL PARTS
description: WHATEVER the excesses of the ''new cuisine,'' there is no denying that some of its hallmarks are of lasting value. Take the shattering of the duck, its liberation from the straitjacket of the roasting pan.

title: Carnesecca to Test Strategy With Best
description: It is fitting that Lou Carnesecca, the Big East's coach of the year, will begin his quest for a national championship in a regional tournament stocked with some of the grand masters of the profession.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COAL INDUSTRY PREDICTS DECLINE IN ACID-RAIN SOURCE
description: A coal industry report published today contends that sulfur dioxide in the air, a source of acid rain and other pollution, is diminishing and will continue to do so despite increased use of coal by power plants.

title: RUTH TAYLOR
description: Ruth Taylor, a former Commissioner of Public Welfare for Westchester County, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Miriam Osborn Memorial Home in Rye, N.Y., where she had lived many years.

title: MUDSLINGING OVER CONTRAS
description: The debate over United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels turned nasty in the last week, and a surprisingly wide range of onlookers believe that the sharpened language has at least as much to do with domestic politics as it has with the situation in Central America.

title: THE OBSESSION IS DANGEROUS
description: The obsession of history has hypnotized Marvelous Marvin Hagler, just as it hypnotized Larry Holmes when the former heavyweight champion was hoping to match Rocky Marciano's 49-0 record. Now the undisputed world middleweight champion wants to surpass Carlos Monzon's achievement of 14 successful title defenses in the 160-pound division. But the question is -will Marvelous Marvin Hagler be hypnotized into the danger of hanging on too long as Larry Holmes did before being dethroned by Michael Spinks, or will he survive a November rematch with Thomas Hearns and a showdown with Donald Curry next year?

title: BEHIND MARKET'S STRONG RISE
description: For more than a year, a powerful influence on the stock market has been an arbitrage between the stock index futures market and the underlying stock market. Yesterday's action simply provided another example of how this strategy can contribute to sudden and powerful shifts in stock prices.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: A five-bedroom garden apartment in Sunnyside for $60.32 a month sounds too good to be true. It is.

title: Allen's Proposal
description: George Allen, the former football coach who is attending an international sports congress in West Germany as chairman of the President's physical fitness council, said that he had proposed a Soviet-American exchange of youth fitness tests and that Soviet athletic officials had agreed. ''This can do a lot to get the youth of the two countries to identify and work with each other,'' he said.

title: Wildlife-Checkoff Program Benefits New York State Resources
description: To the Editor:

title: Thatcher Rebuffs Gorbachev on Arms
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has told Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, that Britain cannot accept a freeze on British and French nuclear arsenals as a condition for a Soviet-American agreement on the withdrawal of all medium-range nuclear missiles from Europe.

title: TROUBLED FARM BANKS TO GET REGULATORY AID
description: In the face of intensifying financial pressure on thousands of banks that lend heavily to farmers, the three Federal banking agencies announced today that they would liberalize their accounting standards to keep more banks open and make more loans available to farmers.

title: Machinists Ordered Back To Jobs at T.W.A.
description: Machinists, ordered to stop honoring picket lines set up by flight attendants on strike against Trans World Airlines, returned to work this afternoon, an airline official said.

title: Odds Against Shuttle
description: To the Editor:

title: Hormel Strikers Voting On Closer Ties to Union
description: Striking meatpackers at Geo. A. Hormel & Company began voting today on whether their local should resolve differences with its parent union and try a joint contract offer to the company, union leaders said.

title: PACKWOOD, IN TAX PLAN, WOULD CURB DEDUCTIONS
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, today showed President Reagan a draft overhaul of the Federal income tax that would reduce the value of deductions for state and local income taxes claimed by upper-income taxpayers.

title: College Urges Caution After Rape of Student
description: The president of Brooklyn College has urged students to walk in pairs when in dark areas of the campus and to avoid studying alone, after the rape and stabbing Monday of a 19-year-old student in a men's room at the college.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Brown, president of the American League, denied a request by the Baltimore Orioles to rescind the trade in which they acquired Jackie Gutierrez, an infielder, from the Boston Red Sox for Sammy Stewart, a pitcher. The Orioles said Gutierrez developed health problems they were unaware of at the time of the trade, but Brown ruled that the trade was made in ''good faith, with neither club knowingly misrepresenting the facts.'' . . . Julius Erving, the Philadelphia forward, has a sore knee that kept him out of the 76ers' game against the Indiana Pacers last night and may keep him out of the Knicks' game tonight. . . . Walter Berry, the St. John's junior, was named college player of the year by the United States Basketball Writers Association.

title: DISCOVERIES
SUDDENLY, PROSECUTORS FIND FLOOD OF TIPS ON CORRUPTION
description: The calls and letters keep coming to investigators all over the city, about bad guys and crooked deals and dirty contracts - not to mention dirty floors.

title: CONCERT: SAN FRANCISCO SYMPHONY
description: THE San Francisco Symphony, under the direction of its new music director, Herbert Blomstedt, played an uncommonly well-balanced program at Carnegie Hall Sunday night. In contrast to many visiting orchestras -who present the occasional rarity at home but trot out only the most familiar works in the repertory during New York visits - the San Francisco Symphony offered a largely unfamiliar masterpiece, ''Tapiola,'' by Jean Sibelius; the first local performance of a challenging new work by the American composer Charles Wuorinen, ''Movers and Shakers,'' and, finally, one of the few warhorses of which it is difficult to grow tired, Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 in A (Op. 92).

title: VATICAN TELLS PRIEST TO RETRACT VIEWS
description: The Vatican has ordered the Rev. Charles E. Curran, a liberal theologian at Catholic University of America, either to retract his views on birth control and other sexual issues or face the loss of his authorization to teach Roman Catholic doctrine.

title: CONCERT: BEETHOVEN BY JUPITER SYMPHONY
description: WHILE one appreciates the amenity of outdoor programs, it was good to hear the Jupiter Symphony - a fixture of the Lincoln Center plaza concerts every summer -play within the acoustically balanced confines of Alice Tully Hall Monday night.

title: ELRON ELECTRONICS INDUSRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision of $24,386,000 for writeoff of investment and loans in Elscint. c-Net income.

title: New Strength Coach
description: Norman Temnograd, a Soviet-trained weight-lifting and wrestling coach, has been hired as a strength coach by the Minnesota Vikings.

title: REVCO GETS $1.16 BILLION BUYOUT BID
description: Revco D.S. Inc., operator of the nation's largest drugstore chain, said yesterday that its board had received an offer from a group of senior executives to acquire the company for $33 a share in cash and shares of preferred stock that it valued at an additional $3 a share, or a total of $1.161 billion.

title: TEMPLES OF PROTECTION AND HELP ON 42d STREET
description: Forty-Second Street seems to have everything else. Soon, it will have three Greek temples.

title: Habib: The Man With the Golden Suitcase
description: Virtually every postwar President has found himself calling on special envoys to handle particularly difficult international assignments. President Truman asked George C. Marshall to try to resolve the Chinese civil war; President Johnson used Cyrus R. Vance on missions to Cyprus and South Korea, and President Reagan has called repeatedly on an apparent favorite, Philip C. Habib.

title: DICHTER, BACK AT JUILLIARD, REMEMBERS PIANO TEACHER
description: Misha Dichter, the pianist who graduated from the Juilliard School 18 years ago and went on to fame around the world, returned yesterday to teach a master class. He said it was his way of saying thank you to Rosina Lhevinne.

title: MALAYSIA ACCUSES BANKING OFFICIALS
description: The Government of Malaysia today made public a report charging former officials of the country's largest bank with financial mismanagement and corruption.

title: A QUIET NEW TALENT AT MILAN SHOWINGS
description: His clothes are gentle, nonassertive, quite different from the mainstream of Italian fashion. Romeo Gigli's showing early Sunday morning in a factory on the Corso Como drew more than 500 people who remained to cheer the collection's quiet, pre-Raphaelite charm.

title: BUDGET WRITERS OPTIMISTIC ON REACHING A BIPARTISAN ACCORD SOON
description: The chairman and the ranking Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee said today that they were optimistic that they could reach agreement on a bipartisan budget package for the fiscal year 1987 that would include increased revenues and less money for the military budget than President Reagan has requested.

title: AMERICAN AIR EXPECTS A LOSS
description: Last November, Richard J. Ferris, chairman of UAL Inc., predicted a ''bloodbath'' for the airline industry in the first quarter because of fare cutting. Yesterday, in the third month of the quarter, there was an indication that at least red ink would be flowing.

title: HOUSE CALLS FOR A DOG GROOMER
description: ''WHO'S the best dog?''

title: IF YOU'RE ON THE OUTS WITH THE 'IN' CROWD
description: IN a city that never sleeps, I get a lot of sleep. That's because I'm still waiting to be invited to one of the seemingly endless rounds of fetes, galas and bacchanals reported in the press.

title: COURT REJECTS WIDE U.S. POWER TO BAR ALIENS
description: A divided Federal appeals court here rejected today the Reagan Administration's assertion of unfettered power to bar aliens from visiting the United States solely because of associations with Communist organizations.

title: ECUADOR GENERAL ENDS REVOLT
description: The former air force commander surrendered today, ending a five-day standoff at a military base, after an official whose dismissal he had sought submitted his resignation, the Government announced.

title: TONELLI JOINS FLAMES, FACES ISLANDERS
description: It was instant drama: not only was an Islander bulwark traded away this morning, but tonight he had to face his team wearing enemy colors. And his former teammates, several of whom skated alongside him to four Stanley Cup victories, had to treat him rudely, like the opponent he had suddenly become.

title: 4 CARTING OFFICIALS FACE CHARGES OF BID RIGGING
description: Four executives from three carting companies were indicted yesterday on charges they rigged bids in an attempt to obtain a Transit Authority refuse collection contract in 1984.

title: Hanoi Says It Found More U.S. War Dead
description: Vietnam has told United States officials that it has found the remains of 21 Americans and can identify 10 of them by name, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: HAGLER NOT SO SMUG IN BOUT
description: In the seventh round of his grueling fight Monday night against John (The Beast) Mugabi, Marvelous Marvin Hagler took a deep breath and a look flickered across his face that bespoke weariness - a deep-down resignation to a long and difficult fight.

title: Sandoval Test Is Normal
description: A CAT scan on Richie Sandoval, who was knocked down five times by Gaby Canizales while losing his World Boxing Association bantamweight title Monday night, has proved normal, but Sandoval is expected to remain in Valley Hospital Medical Center a few more days for further observation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These paintings show the Marcoses lost track of all distinction between public and private, between what was theirs and what belonged to the country.'' - Alejandro Roces, leader of a group of Philippine civilian and military inspectors at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila. [ A8:6. ]

title: TEXT OF NOTE ON PROVIDING SPACE ACCESS
description: Following is the text of a memorandum dated March 7 from William R. Graham, Acting Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, to Richard H. Truly, the agency's associate administrator for space flight and head of the shuttle program.

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC FOR THE ORGAN
description: WE live in a secular age, and most pipe organs dwell in sacred spaces -in churches, where they are both removed from our daily musical life and cursed with a religious aura that dissuades composers and public alike. Still, since so many of this century's composers have been concerned with sound-color and timbral experimentation, the organ would seem an excellent instrument for them. Even though electronics have taken over some of the organ's functions, there is still nothing like a pipe organ in full, rumbling cry.

title: Girl, 10, Found Hanged With Her Jump Rope
description: A 10-year-old girl was found hanged with a jump rope in her bedroom today in what the police said was an apparent suicide.

title: PARTY LEADERS SAY REAGAN WILL HAVE TO ACCEPT DEAL ON NICARAGUA
description: While President Reagan was opposing all compromise with Congress on his request to aid the Nicaraguan rebels, leaders in both parties said today that the President would eventually have to accept far less than he wants.

title: This Ski Race Was All Downhill
description: Last Sunday may or may not have been a day of infamy for World Cup skiing. Either way, it was a milestone, because by all accounts it marked the first time that a group of world-class racers had seized absolute control of an event from officials and organizers, and in a fashion that most people involved with the sport found disturbing.

title: Lost: Amor
description: A reproduction of Augustus Saint-Gaudens's ''Amor Caritas,'' the 40-inch bronze bas-relief of an angel holding a tablet, has been stolen from the Oak Hill Cemetery in Georgetown, where it had decorated the tombstone of a World War I American diplomat. The theft was discovered last December, but the cemetery kept it a secret for three months in an attempt to recover the valuable art work without publicity.

title: ROSE OF ISLAM AND A THORN FOR INDONESIA'S RULERS
description: As Indonesia prepares for an election next year, the Special Territory of Aceh, conservatively Moslem and historically rebellious, is a place to watch.

title: NEW CONCERNS ABOUT WHAT BABIES EAT
description: ''OPEN wide, the airplane's coming in for a landing,'' the father urges his 18-month-old son while looping a spoon lazily above the highchair. After a bit more cajoling, the baby opens his mouth, and the spoon speeds in.

title: CLINICS TAKING BIRTH-CONTROL HELP AND ADVICE TO THE TEEN-AGERS
description: TO combat the increasing problem of teen-age pregnancy, a growing number of family planning agencies are trying to take their services to the teen-agers and make it easier for teen-agers to use them.

title: PUBLISHING: TWO NEW HISTORY SERIES
description: Having put the final editorial touches on the 20th volume in its ''Vietnam Experience'' series, the Boston Publishing Company has just about written ''finis'' to a collection that has sold more than five million copies. But the company, founded in 1978 for the express purpose of publishing the Vietnam books, is not about to go out of business now that it has exhausted its original subject.

title: Rabbi Jacob Kamenetzky, 95, Expert on Law of the Talmud
description: Rabbi Jacob Kamenetzky, an expert on Talmudic law, died Monday of complications from a heart attack, at Mount Sinai Hospital in Baltimore. He was 95 years old and lived in Monsey, N.Y.

title: DENATIONALIZATION FOR FRANCE
description: Some of the best-known companies in French industry and banking will shortly be coming onto the auction block if, as the polls predict will happen, France's right-wing opposition alliance wins next Sunday's parliamentary election.

title: JAPANESE SETBACK ON CHIP PRICES
description: The Department of Commerce today issued a preliminary determination that eight Japanese electronics companies have been selling a computer memory chip in the American market at less than fair value.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GENTLEMEN IN ENGLAND. By A. N. Wilson. 311 pages. Viking. $17.95. SEVERUS EGG, writes A. N. Wilson in his latest novel, ''recognized ruefully that he had been born some 20 or 30 years late. He had been but a lad when Byron died. But to have known Byron! As he now realised, Mr. Egg had been born just early enough to see the excellence, all the light, all the fun, and just late enough to watch it all evaporate, banished by lumpishness and self-righteous mediocrity.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Dunedin, Fla., spring exhibition game. Basketball Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:30 P.M. The Hawks and the Nets are 2-2 in the season series.

title: HARD TIMES ON THE TEXAS PANHANDLE
description: The great Panhandle of Texas has seen good times and bad times. These are very bad times.

title: What's New in Kabul
description: Edward Hurwitz, a career Foreign Service officer and Russian-speaking Soviet specialist, has been transferred from his post as senior diplomatic representative in the United States Embassy in Afghanistan and is serving as consul general in Leningrad.

title: RICHARD Y. HOLCOMB
description: Richard Y. Holcomb, a senior partner of the New York law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, died Sunday at his home in Irvington, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Television II
description: With considerable trepidation, the Senate will allow C-Span, the television cable service, to broadcast coverage of its floor proceedings starting today at 10 A.M. Until June 1 the senators will be heard but not seen; while they speak, the screen will identify the speaker. After June 1 the audiences of stations that choose to pick up the coverage will get both picture and sound.

title: NEW GUIDELINES FOR CHEMICAL IN WORKPLACE ARE WEIGHED
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration is considering issuing new rules to protect more than a million workers who may be exposed to methylene chloride, a widely used chemical, according to agency documents.

title: Different View
description: The best argument that has ever been made against the practice of awarding automatic berths in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament to the winners of 25 conference tourneys was almost made last weekend.

title: TRACKING THE EYE IN AD STUDY
description: THE blight of clutter, at least as it applies to magazines, has been a golden opportunity for Elliot C. Young.

title: The U.N. Today; March 12, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OPERA: 'CARMEN' AT THE MET
description: THE tone of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Carmen,'' which had its first performance on Monday night, establishes itself early, when the doom-haunted gypsy, in the person of Maria Ewing, slouches in from the wings and stands for a long while with her back to the audience. We guess at once that this is a pouty teen-ager determined not to ingratiate herself with us in any way, and as it turns out, we guess right. Miss Ewing pursues this eccentric concept to the end, which might be more plausible if her basically light mezzo were a true Carmen voice. It is not. On opening night, at least, she covered many deficiencies by barking, snarling or crooning the notes.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:58 A.M. today and set at 1:29 P.M.

title: U.S. CHECK SYSTEM STUDIED
description: A Treasury Department auditing official, Maurice S. Moody, told a Congressional panel today that the department's system for processing $1 trillion a year in Government payments sometimes failed to verify the signatures of the 7,000 Federal disbursing officers.

title: Thousands March Through Seoul Streets
description: About 2,000 opposition leaders and their supporters marched through the streets of the capital today in a campaign for constitutional reform to permit direct presidential elections.

title: Cruel and Unusual Banishment
description: A year ago, diplomacy seemed to have found a way out for the criminally dangerous Mariel emigres. Under an agreement worked out with Fidel Castro, Cuba was to take back 2,800 criminals he sent to the United States among the 125,000 refugees in the 1980 boatlift from Mariel. Just over 200 had been repatriated when, in May, the agreement abruptly collapsed.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHEN Flo Hyman, a world-class volleyball player, died in January, many people were stunned. She was, after all, only 31 years old and seemed to be in top physical condition. As medical experts later discovered, the immediate cause of death was a rupture in the body's main artery, the aorta. The underlying cause, however, was a disorder of the connective tissue called Marfan syndrome; Miss Hyman was not aware that she had this disease.

title: FITCH DOWNGRADES GULF STATES RATINGS
description: Ratings on the debt of the Gulf States Utilities Company has been downgraded by one rating agency and is under review by two others.

title: FAULTING OTHER BLACKS IS DENIED BY BELAFONTE
description: Harry Belafonte disputed yesterday reports that he had criticized black elected officials who had been cool to his potential candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York.

title: Topics; Send 'Em a Message T-Shirt Diplomacy
description: Last week President Reagan revealed what he really meant when he muttered ''S.O.B.'' after a recent news conference.

title: LIST OF HOSPITALS THAT ARE ABOVE OR BELOW AVERAGE U.S. MORTALITY RATES
description: The following list, issued by the Health Care Financing Administration of the Health and Human Services Department, tallies the number of Medicare patients discharged from hospitals in 1984 and the percentage of those who died in the hospital. The hospitals listed are those with mortality rates that are higher or lower than average.

title: Georgia Murder Trial Delayed
description: The trial of Carlton Gary on charges of rape and murder in the deaths of three elderly women eight years ago has been postponed. With 300 prospective jurors waiting in the hallways and hundreds of witnesses on notice to testify, Judge Kenneth Followill of Muskogee County Superior Court granted a defense motion Monday to postpone the trial until Mr. Gary's physical and mental fitness to participate in his defense are determined.

title: HEINZ, H J CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 23, 1985.

title: 93 Grocers Are Charged In Bogus-Coupon Ring
description: Postal inspectors charged 93 grocers today with participating in a ring they said had fraudulently redeemed $186 million in coupons. Agents said they broke the ring by using coupons for a nonexistent roach spray.

title: Army's Weapon Test Challenged by Report
description: The latest test program for the Army's new Bradley fighting vehicle was set up by the service in such a way that the weapon was protected from damge, a General Accounting Office report says.

title: Whitaker Injures Hand
description: After eight professional bouts, Pernell Whitaker, the Olympic lightweight champion, is unbeaten but has suffered his share of injuries. The boxer, who was out four months after breaking his right foot in November, has now learned that he broke his left hand in his comeback victory over John Montes last Sunday and will be out as long for as six months.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,047,744 for the quarter and $3,241,189 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $963,693 for the quarter and $2,848,519 for the year.

title: HERS
description: It was always the look on their faces that told me first. I was the freshman dormitory counselor and they were the freshmen at a women's college where everyone was smart. One of them could come into my room, a golden girl, a valedictorian, an 800 verbal score on the SAT's, and her eyes would be empty, seeing only a busted future, the devastation of her life as she knew it. She had failed biology, messed up the math; she was pregnant. That was when I became pro-choice. It was the look in his eyes that I will always remember, too. They were as black as the bottom of a well, and in them for a few minutes I thought I saw myself the way I had always wished to be -clear, simple, elemental, at peace. My child looked at me and I looked back at him in the delivery room, and I realized that out of a sea of infinite possibilities it had come down to this: a specific person, born on the hottest day of the year, conceived on a Christmas Eve, made by his father and me miraculously from scratch.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $6,350,000 and a gain from minority interests in discontinued operations of $440,000. c-Net income and after a gain from insurance proceeds of $2 million, a loss from discontinued operations of $3,189,000, a gain of $32,000 from minority interest in discontinued operations and a tax credit of $205,000. Sales represent sales from continuing operations.

title: Sea Change in France
description: The long French campaign for legislative elections next Sunday is heating up at the end. After months of bland reassurances and forced smiles, which were leaving the voters unworried but indifferent, the rivals are sharpening their positions. But the volleys of the last few days aren't likely to matter much.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BECK IS REINJURED IN LOSS
description: Late yesterday afternoon the Rangers learned that their hottest scorer, Pierre Larouche, had a broken thumb. Then they went out and lost to the Calgary Flames, 3-2, last night at Madison Square Garden, and during the game their captain, Barry Beck, suffered muscle spasms in his left shoulder that may portend a more severe injury for him.

title: POP: AYIZAN, A HAITIAN BAND
description: THE better-known Haitian pop bands play lilting, major-key dance music with spiraling guitar lines. Ayizan, the Haitian band that performed Tuesday at Sounds of Brazil, offers something different.

title: BRAND INSULATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $551,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $764,000.

title: BATTLE WITH RIGHT RECALLED BY BELL
description: Former Education Secretary T. H. Bell says his four years in the Cabinet were a constant battle against a ''lunatic fringe'' on the right that did not want to spend a dime on education.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a tribute to George Abbott on May 16 misidentified the organizer. It is New Dramatists, not the Dramatists Guild.

title: LIVINGWELL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $197,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $690,000. c-Net loss after a loss of $750,000 from discontinued operations and including a gain of $4,388,000 from an accounting change.

title: UNIT OF SCALI, McCABE NAMES NEW PRESIDENT
description: Lee Graham, 45 years old, has been promoted to president from executive vice president of Scali, McCabe, Sloves Direct Response, filling a job slot vacated about a month ago by Jerry Reitman.

title: NOVO INDUSTRI A/S reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: All dollar amounts have been translated from Danish krone at the rate in effect on Dec. 31, 1985 of U.S. $1 equals 8.969 krone. Share earnings represent American Depositary Shares (ADS).

title: CUOMO AND LEGISLATORS DIFFER IN BUDGET TALKS
description: Facing an April 1 deadline for adoption of a new state budget, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders met today but remained far apart on such key issues as aid to mass transit and the size of this year's budget surplus.

title: TOP EQUIMARK SALARIES CUT
description: Senior executives of the Equimark Corporation announced yesterday that they would cut their salaries as part of a cost-reduction program in which 200 employees would be dismissed. Analysts said this was the first time in their memory that a bank's senior management agreed to reduce their own salaries.

title: Youth Hurt in Rocket Blast
description: A teen-ager lost a thumb and part of a forefinger Tuesday night when a homemade rocket exploded in his hand, the Nassau County police said. The teen-ager, Andrew Jennings, 18 years old, of Stewart Manor, was in stable condition at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola. The police said the accident had occurred in the parking lot of the Stewart Manor Country Club, where Mr. Jennings is a maintenance worker.

title: TO PREVENT THE LOSS OF CHILDREN
description: Shopping centers across the country have agreed to promote child safety through a weeklong campaign, beginning April 7 to fingerprint millions of youngsters 3 to 14 years old.

title: A DRIFTER LIFTS HIS 'BURDEN' BY ADMITTING A '68 SLAYING
description: In the early hours of July 31, 1968, Lenore Mussenden, a 21-year-old college student, was shot once in the chest by a man who confronted her in front of her Staten Island apartment building. The man fled. She died six days later, and her murder went unsolved.

title: A POPSICLE FOR THE 80'S: JUST ONE STICK
description: In the end, it was a market survey that laid waste to a memory.

title: New York State Needs Those Tourist Dollars
description: To the Editor:

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings results reflect 20 percent stock dividend paid in November 1985.

title: HALLWOOD GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $551,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $548,000 for the quarter and $741,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings results have been adjusted to reflect a 1-for-14 reverse stock split paid Feb. 14.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We believe the resolution we introduced in Geneva presents the human rights situation in Chile in an objective way and hope that other countries will support us in supporting this text.'' - Charles E. Redman, State Department spokesman. [ A5:1. ]

title: Danish Premier Makes Major Cabinet Changes
description: Prime Minister Poul Schluter announced a major shuffle of his minority, four-party coalition Government late Tuesday night, the most extensive ever in Denmark.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Living Section yesterday about teen-age pregnancy misstated the number of live births in 1984 to women under 20 years old in New York City. Such women accounted for 13,339 live births, or 11.8 percent of the total in the city.

title: WARNINGS ISSUED ON EATING SHELLFISH THAT IS UNCOOKED
description: Medical scientists have concluded that a disease agent called the Norwalk virus is a major cause of outbreaks of intestinal illness among people who eat uncooked shellfish, prompting officials to strengthen their oft-ignored warnings against consumption of any raw clams and oysters.

title: ATHLETES AS ROLE MODELS
description: Just to get their attention, Tony Elliott tells young people about the day he tried to hold up his own cocaine dealer. Even on a professional football player's salary, he was out of money and cocaine, and desperate for both.

title: Strict Controls Set For Parade Police
description: The New York City Police Department said yesterday that it would increase the supervision of its officers on duty before and after Monday's St. Patrick's Day parade. Officials said the action was a response to the death of a pedestrian in a hit-and-run accident involving a police sergeant on the eve of last year's parade.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $298,000 related to a loss on investments.

title: HOW AQUINO GOT HELP FROM FRIENDS IN U.S.
description: Robert Trent Jones Jr. met Corazon C. Aquino and her husband around 1964, while Mr. Jones was in the Philippines designing a golf course that was a project of Mrs. Aquino's family. The friendship grew over long dinners at the family's sugar plantation. It persisted through the years of Benigno S. Aquino Jr.'s imprisonment and American exile.

title: OIL PRICES RISE AGAIN, BUT OUTLOOK IS UNCLEAR
description: Prices for crude oil and petroleum products continued their rally on the world oil markets yesterday, finishing at their highest levels in nearly two weeks.

title: CONTROL RESOURCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $138,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $368,000, or 31 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $180,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $359,000, or 32 cents a share, for the 9 months. Corrected from Thursday, Feb. 27, editions.

title: N.A.A.C.P. ASSERTS YONKERS PLAN TO INTEGRATE SCHOOLS IS DEFICIENT
description: A school integration plan proposed last month by the Yonkers Board of Education was criticized today as inadequate by the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: MERCHANDISE TRADE GAP UP TO $124.3 BILLION IN '85
description: The nation's trade deficit grew to a record $124.3 billion last year as American agricultural exports sank to their lowest level in eight years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: 4 in Queens Seized After 26 Holdups
description: Four Queens men have been arrested and accused of going on a two-week robbery spree in the borough to buy ''crack,'' a smokable form of cocaine, the police said yesterday.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary tax credit of $1,150,000 for the quarter and year.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $24.1 million, or 30 cents a share, from sale of stock of St. Joe Gold Corporation. c-Net loss including income of $2,281,000 from discontinued operations.

title:
GARDENING;
GARDEN POCKETKNIVES: SELECTING THE STYLES AND THE FEATURES
description: A BLADE crudely chipped from stone was man's first tool; today, a good pocketknife is still the gardener's standby. Nearly the perfect tool, it is light, versatile and simple to use. Indeed, from the orchid house to the orchard, there is no substitute for a sharp sturdy pocketknife.

title: For Jobs Program, A Slight Faux Pas
description: Lisa Gabler is everything that the New York City Partnership looks for as an exemplar of the students it has placed in its summer jobs program -except for being such a student herself.

title: HOSPITAL DEATH DATE: AT LEAST ONE PLUS
description: As the Federal Government reluctantly made public its lists of hospitals with unusual mortality rates today, Federal officials, consumer advocates and the hospital industry agreed that the data were valuable in at least one important respect.

title: NEW CLIMATE FOR MERGERS
description: CORPORATE takeovers repeatedly provided fireworks for big and small investors alike in 1985 and helped propel stock prices sharply higher. Now, as a result of the equity market's continued surge, Wall Street professionals believe certain changes are in the offing.

title: SOEDERSTROEM ON MUSIC AND MARRIAGE OF STRAUSS
description: The Swedish soprano Elisabeth Soederstroem thinks that the world has got the wrong slant on Richard Strauss's domestic life, and that it's all the fault of Alma Mahler.

title: HEALTHMATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STOCKS UP AS VOLUME SURGES
description: Buyers swarmed into the stock market again yesterday, sending trading volume to its second-highest level ever and pushing up the price of most shares. Blue-chip issues, however, retreated a bit.

title: ENERGY PLAN CUTS COSTS
description: Lois Talbot thought her modest, two-bedroom home was warm enough, but the Bonneville Power Administration wanted to test it.

title: In Favor of More Pistol-Packin' Mamas
description: To the Editor:

title: KEYSTONE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $496,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $132,000 for the year.

title: CONSORTIUM OFFERS TREE-CARE COURSES
description: Lovers of the urban tree can learn to care for curbside trees in courses offered by the New York City Street Tree Consortium Inc., beginning the first week in April in all five boroughs.

title: DH TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $975,000 relating to anticipated costs associated with consolidating operations and establishing a manufacturing facility in Tijuana, Mexico for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: A NEW YORK DESIGNER TACKLES AMARILLO
description: AROUND these parts when the nights grow long and the wind howls across the high, arid plains, they still tell of the New Yorker who came all the way to decorate a Texas ranch house. It seems that she was a Park Avenue decorator, with a lot of clients and a fancy reputation. But wouldn't you know that the Texans met her right at the plane with a pickup truck? And then, didn't they drive her out to the ranch and set her to work sewing chintz curtains and bedspreads?

title: CITIBANK EXECUTIVE MOVES TO NORWEST
description: The Norwest Corporation, the nation's 21st-largest bank holding company, announced yesterday that Richard M. Kovacevich, a highly regarded group executive at Citicorp, has become vice chairman and director of its banking group.

title: Books: History Lessons
description: THINKING IN TIME: The Uses of History for Decision Makers. By Richard E. Neustadt and Ernest R. May. 329 pages. The Free Press. $19.95. IN explaining the other day why President Reagan was so insistent on offering Ferdinand E. Marcos haven in the United States, a State Department official said that Mr. Reagan was determined that the former Philippine leader not be treated ''as shabbily as the Shah of Iran.'' The official added, however, that Mr. Marcos was more concerned that he not end up like the former ruler of South Vietnam, Ngo Dinh Diem, who was killed during the coup that ousted him in 1963.

title: MAYS, J W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a prior year real estate tax refund of $44,562. c-Net loss. The latest 6 months net includes a prior year real estate tax refund of $95,988, compared with $50,434 for year-earlier period. Sales results represent sales inclusive of leased departments.

title: QUESTIONS ON DRUG PENALTIES
description: Jackie Mosco, whose brother Jeffery would be going to prison in 48 hours, wondered one day last week about the consistency in the way Commissioner Peter Ueberroth and the authorities viewed some of the testimony in the Pittsburgh cocaine cases.

title: Some Boston Rail Lines Shut Down by Pickets
description: Striking railroad workers from Maine closed commuter rail service into Boston from the north and west today, but about 6,000 commuters made it to the city on shuttle buses pressed into emergency service.

title: CRAFT NEARS COMET ENCOUNTER
description: A half-ton spacecraft is now in position to speed past Halley's comet in man's closest encounter yet with the mysterious vagabond of the planets.

title: SUMMING UP MILAN'S SPIRITED FASHIONS
description: Suggestions for dressing Italian-style at the fall and winter fashion openings, which ended here today, ranged from superbly tailored coats and jackets to lugubrious black leather, The tailored clothes are best at Basile, where brown and white patterned jackets are softened with white cashmere cabled sweaters or bright silk blouses. A one-button short jacket, not too nipped, paired with an easy skirt is the newest shape and it is most agreeable.

title: Quinones Repeats Stand on Passover
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones reiterated yesterday that the New York City public schools would be open on the first two days of Passover next month, despite statements by some community school boards that they will close their schools.

title: RODEO DRIVE ISSUE: TOO MUCH GLITTER?
description: On a weekend morning on Rodeo Drive recently, women tried on $2,000 suits in Chanel's palatial private dressing rooms. Hostesses, in caps and starched aprons, served soda or fruit juice, coffee or tea.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $2,925,779 for the quarter and $12,802,670 for the year. c-Net loss. d-Including capital gains of $2,218,787 for the quarter and $4,320,184 for the year. The year result also includes a tax credit of $321,156.

title: G.& W., IN CANADA DEAL, WILL KEEP PRENTICE UNIT
description: The Canadian Government announced today that it would let Gulf and Western Industries keep the Canadian operation of Prentice-Hall that G.&W. acquired when it bought the parent publisher in 1984.

title: ARMY GROUNDS 2 HELICOPTER FLEETS AFTER MISHAPS
description: The Army decided today to temporarily ground its two newest helicopter fleets, the UH-60 Blackhawk and the AH-64 Apache, because of safety concerns.

title: Swedes Elect Carlsson To Succeed Palme
description: Parliament elected Ingvar Carlsson, a Social Democrat, to succeed Olof Palme as Prime Minister today without any opposing votes.

title: Thomas Hampson, Baritone, Plans Debut
description: Thomas Hampson, a baritone, will make his New York recital debut on March 31 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. Mr. Hampson, who made his operatic debut with the Opera Theater of St. Louis, has sung with companies in Hamburg, Cologne, Zurich, Dusseldorf and Vienna.

title: Still on the Run
description: Abel Kiviat was in town the other day for one of his increasingly rare public appearances - the occasion was a preview showing of Bud Greenspan's film about the 1984 Games, ''16 Days of Glory'' - where he happily posed for photographers with two of his successors, Mary Lou Retton and Nelson Vailes.

title: MARCOS LEGISLATOR GIVES UP BUT DENIES ELECTION KILLINGS
description: A pro-Marcos assemblyman linked to the deaths of as many as 11 supporters of Corazon C. Aquino surrendered to military authorities today and said he looked forward to facing his accusers.

title: CHICAGO DECLARES ITSELF NUCLEAR WEAPON-FREE ZONE
description: In a rare display of political unanimity, Chicago's City Council today declared this city the largest nuclear weapon-free zone in the country.

title: KING INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $273,003 for the quarter and $356,545 for the 9 months. c-Net loss for the quarter and 9 months, after losses from discontinued operations of $1,792,767 for the quarter, $1,546,210 for the 9 months. The quarter result also includes an extraordinary loss of $168,200.

title: Addabbo Is Reported In Coma With Cancer
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens was reported in a coma yesterday at a Washington hospital, and a spokesman at his office said he had bladder cancer and was not expected to survive.

title: FIX-IT QUANDARY: FINDING A SHOP
description: IT used to be that when the toaster stopped making toast or the vacuum cleaner swallowed the curtains, New York City residents had only to go down the block or around the corner to get the appliances fixed. Lately, however, they have had to put up with more than temporarily dusty rugs and untoasted bread: just finding someone to repair small appliances is increasingly difficult.

title: MOST IN POLL SAY CITY CORRUPTION IS WIDESPREAD AND HURTS SERVICES
description: Most New York City residents perceive corruption as being widespread in the city government and believe that it has a considerable effect on the quality of the services the city provides, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: The Miller Lexicon: No, No, No, No, No
description: After more than seven months as director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, James C. Miller 3d is leaving his mark on Capitol Hill. Somewhat like Zorro, he is zapping his adversaries with an ''N,'' as in ''no.''

title: NEWBURGH TRIES TO RECAPTURE ITS PAST GLORY
description: Few people here are optimistic enough to believe that things will ever look as bright again as in 1952, when Look magazine named Newburgh that year's ''all-American city.''

title: MUSIC: OF AN BY AUSTRALIANS
description: THE Australian performers and composers who joined forces for a concert Tuesday at Symphony Space styled their program, with some justification, ''terra australis incognita.'' That is the description given the vast southerly continent by its earliest European explorers, and though Australia's musicians have long since taken their numerous places on the international scene, her composers have been at best vaguely known in the world beyond.

title: LASER PHOTONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAVELICH QUITS CLUB AND MAY RETIRE
description: Mark Pavelich, citing differences with the Ranger coach, Ted Sator, and a personal desire ''to enjoy the other things in life,'' said today that he was through with hockey for this season and maybe forever.

title: LASERCARD LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENTAGON BACKS AIR-TO-AIR MISSILE DESPITE DOUBTS
description: The Defense Department has told Congress that an Air Force missile will work as planned despite warnings from a senior Pentagon official that adequate test data about how the weapon would actually perform in combat is lacking.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The bathroom in our country house has its only window directly above the bathtub-shower. so every time we use the shower, the window frame and sill get soaking wet. This window is the only source of light in that room so we would prefer not to block it with plastic curtains or other obstructions. How can we protect the sill and frame from the rot and mildew that can be caused by all the water? A. The best solution I have seen is to install a second shower curtain along the back wall of the tub-shower. This can be hung from a regular shower rod, just like the one in front of the tub, except that this rod is mounted on the wall above the window.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Well-Founded Fear
description: Sophia Vargas, as I shall call her, is a 22-year-old Salvadoran who fled to the United States and seeks asylum here. This is her story.

title: SPAIN VOTES TO REMAIN IN NATO IN DRAMATIC VICTORY FOR GONZALEZ
description: In a dramatic victory for Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, Spaniards voted today to remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Bridge; Using Weak Two-Bid Offers Advantages in Tournaments
description: Major improvements in bidding often take a long time to become standard practice. An example is the weak two-bid that was devised more than half a century ago by Charles Van Vleck.

title: CABARET: NANCY WILSON
description: NANCY WILSON is the headliner at the Blue Note (131 West Third Street) through Sunday, but the instrumental quartet that accompanies her deserves equal billing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The weather records column in some editions on Tuesday misstated the Monday condition for Freeport, in the Bahamas. It was cloudy.

title: HUTTON TRUST CHARGES MADE
description: A former employee of the E. F. Hutton Trust Company has accused the Delaware-based concern of mishandling trust assets and of violating fiduciary responsibilities to trust beneficiaries.

title: CELLTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: KNICKS SCARE 76ERS BUT LOSE AGAIN
description: With only a month to go in the National Basketball Association regular season, facing the Knicks is becoming a plus for teams battling to get into the playoffs or bettering their positions for the playoffs.

title: A NEW WAY TO BUILD CARS
description: WHEN the General Motors Corporation opens assembly plants in Kansas City, Kan., and Doraville, Ga., in the fall of 1987 they will be largely missing a key element of traditional mass production: an assembly line. Instead, the company plans to assemble cars using hundreds of motorized, unmanned carriers called automated guided vehicles, which will carry a car as it goes through the assembly process.

title: A Lucrative Error
description: It was a mistake that Marion Bonneau is happy she made. Very, very happy.

title: INACOMP COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Including a $75,000 writedown of an equity investment.

title: NORTH ATLANTIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
PROGRAM ON AGING AND HEALTH
description: Four free seminars on health care for the aging will be held at the Cornell University Cooperative Extension in Brooklyn through mid-May.

title: KEYSTONE ACCORD
description: Anderson, Greenwood & Company, which manufactures valves, said it had tentatively agreed to be acquired by Keystone International Inc. through an exchange of shares that the company valued at $105 million.

title: U.S. IN REVERSAL, FAULTS CHILEANS OVER RIGHTS ISSUE
description: The Reagan Administration, in a reversal of policy, expressed ''deep concern'' today over what it called ''the troubling human rights situation in Chile.'' It called on other countries to support an American resolution condemning Chile at the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

title: FED RETAINS CURB ON CHECKING
description: The Federal Reserve Board rejected today as unlawful suggestions that banks grant to businesses unlimited check-writing privileges on money market accounts, an arrangement that would have given corporations the equivalent of an interest-bearing checking account.

title: The Mayor Savors An Evening of Reminiscing
description: The silver invitations from the Village Reform Democratic Club said it was a celebration of the 25th anniversary in public life of Mayor Koch and Councilwoman Carol Greitzer.

title: PRISONS TRY TO BRIGHTEN CHILDREN'S VISITS
description: RAYMOND M. was recently in the Bronx House of Detention, serving a six-month sentence for drug posession. When his 5-year-old daughter, Antoinette, came to visit, she spent time in a room full of dolls, toy trucks and storybooks that looks more like a kindergarten than a jail.

title: MONEY FUND, C.D. YIELDS FALL
description: Average yields for six-month C.D.'s, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds all showed moderate declines for the week ended yesterday.

title: It's Not the Syndrome That Commits a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: ITT IS BEING SUED OVER TYPESETTER
description: More than 100 people who bought a typesetting package from the ITT Corporation have filed a $1.1 billion lawsuit charging the company forced them out of business by discontinuing the product.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago White Sox, at St. Petersburg, Fla., exhibition game, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Montreal Expos, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., exhibition game, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball N.C.A.A. Division I Tournament, East Regional, at Greensboro, N.C. First Round: Duke vs. Mississippi Valley State (Television - ESPN, noon); Old Dominion vs. West Virginia; Virginia vs. DePaul (Television - ESPN, 9:30 P.M.); Oklahoma vs. Northeastern (Television - ESPN, Friday, 8 A.M., tape). Southeast Regional, at Baton Rouge, La.: Purdue vs. L.S.U.; Memphis State vs. Ball State; Virginia Tech vs. Villanova (Television - ESPN, Friday, 1:30 A.M., tape); Georgia Tech vs. Marist. Midwest Regional, at Dayton Ohio: Kansas vs. North Carolina A&T (Television - ESPN, 2:30 P.M.); Jacksonville vs. Temple; Michigan State vs. Washington (Television - ESPN, Friday, 4 A.M., tape). Georgetown vs. Texas Tech (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M.). West Regional, at Ogden, Utah: Alabama-Birmingham vs. Missouri; North Carolina vs. Utah (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M.); Bradley vs. Texas-El Paso; (Television - ESPN, 4:30 P.M.); Louisville vs. Drexel. Golf Hertz Bay Hill Classic, opening round, at Orlando, Fla.

title: Prize-Winning Violinist
description: Robert Davidovici, a violinist and winner of the Carnegie Hall International American Music Competition, will give a recital on April 2 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after writedowns of $26,460,000.

title: MUSIC: DANIEL HEIFETZ, VIOLIN
description: MOZART, Faure, Bartok, Lee Hoiby - a lineup of composers like that for a violin recital suggests that the works of four distinct musical personalities have been selected precisely for the variety of style, mood and color they will provide in a single program. And these were the composers selected by Daniel Heifetz for his appearance in the Peabody Concert Series at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night.

title: Roll 'em
description: Senators Paul Laxalt of Nevada and William S. Cohen of Maine, along with the Soviet poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, think a good way to promote understanding between citizens of the United States and the Soviet Union is an evening at the movies. The two Senators, both Republicans, have proposed a Soviet-American film festival in which each country would select 10 films to show the other.

title: New Twist
description: Chico Resch, when asked whether the Philadelphia Flyers could get him to return next season without much arm-twisting: ''I have very weak wrists.''

title: POPE CONFRONTING 2 CASES OF DISSENT
description: The Vatican is confronting dissent this week in two of the most powerful branches of the Roman Catholic Church in the world.

title: Lendl Advances In Straight Sets
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia rolled to a 6-3, 6-1 victory over Juan Aquilera of Spain today in the first round of a Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: 3-PART BOND ISSUE BY DESERET CO-OP
description: The Deseret Generation and Transmission Cooperative of Utah is offering $377.9 million of bonds in three parts through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: BOOSTER PART FOUND
description: As Navy divers worked to recover the debris of the crew compartment and the remains of the Challenger astronauts, other searchers have discovered what could be a key section of the space shuttle's suspect right-side solid-fuel booster rocket.

title: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ GETS A SQUIBB ACCOUNT
description: E. R. Squibb & Sons of Princeton, N.J., has hired Penchina, Selkowitz as the first consumer agency for the Dignity line of products from its Convatee division.

title: Auto-Export Restraints Help the U.S. Economy; Pay Off Job Losers
description: To the Editor:

title: THRIFT UNIT RESCUE PLAN IS OUTLINED
description: Edwin J. Gray, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, outlined to Congress today a plan to borrow $10 billion from the 12 Federal Home Loan Banks over the next five years to prop up hundreds of ailing savings and loan associations.

title: KENWIN SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $149,000, or 35 cents a share, from the termination of a pension plan.

title: SENATE PANEL EXPECTED TO BACK 5-YEAR F.C.C. TERMS
description: A bill reducing the terms of members of the Federal Communications Commission to five years from seven is expected to be approved Thursday by the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COTTAGE TO TENEMENT Between 1763 and 1863 most Irish immigrants to New York were cotters, or, to use the American term, sharecroppers. In the 1840's all 500 residents of the Irish farming village of Roscommon emigrated to New York. Not only was the journey hazardous, but once here immigrants also had to make the adjustment from life in rural cottages to living in city tenements.

title: Floods in Brazil Kill 2 And Strand 32,000
description: Seven days of tropical storms have flooded towns and villages in the northeastern state of Ceara, drowning at least 2 people and leaving 32,000 homeless, according to the Government's civil defense coordinator.

title: BIRDFINDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $200,288 for the quarter and $362,438 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MEESE CONFIRMS OFFICIALS ARE BEING INVESTIGATED
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d confirmed today that a series of formal investigations had begun into charges that senior Reagan Administration officials misled Congress and a Federal court in withholding Environmental Protection Agency files in 1982 and 1983.

title: DANCE: MARIA BENITEZ SPANISH GROUP
description: THE Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company offered a panorama of Spanish dances on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. Miss Benitez is a fine artist and she was given competent support by her dancers and musicians. The result was an evening of many pleasures. Yet it did not add up to form a truly satisfactory whole.

title: RECITAL: SAYURI IIDA, PIANIST
description: SAYURI IIDA'S pianism is characterized by a sort of brusque, strenuous brilliance. Her Tuesday evening concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was at its best in music of aggressive intensity, such as some Etudes by Rachmaninoff and Scriabin.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-After a pretax gain of $1,124,000 from the sale of property for the quarter and year.

title: EQUITY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. SAYS MANILA WILL BE PROVIDED MARCOS'S PAPERS
description: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told the leaders of a Congressional subcommittee today that the Reagan Administration would turn over to the Philippine Government copies of about 1,500 financial documents brought to Hawaii by Ferdinand E. Marcos, the legislative leaders said.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: A DECADE OF CHANGE FOR BUSINESS NEWS ON TV
description: More than a decade ago, most analysis of business-news developments was reported in newspapers and magazines. The television industry, dependent on pictures to tell a story and hampered by a technological inability to portray business happenings quickly in a graphic and interesting manner, largely confined its business reporting to nightly readings of the Dow Jones industrial average, consumer price indexes and occasional consumer reports.

title: PATIENCE PAYS SPOILS TO BERRY
description: On the team's five-hour flight from New York, Walter Berry, the St. John's center, passed some of the time by signing an autograph, joking with teammates and thumbing through magazines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 13, 1986
description: International Washington will give Manila copies of 1,500 financial documents taken to Hawaii by Ferdinand E. Marcos, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told the two leaders of a House subcommittee. The Congressmen also said Mr. Baker had told them that copies of the documents would be made available to their panel within a few days. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: THRUWAY YIELD VARIES TO 6.05%
description: A $161.3 million issue of New York State Thruway Authority bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5 percent for maturities in 1988 to 5.50 percent in 1991 and 6.05 percent in 1996.

title: Government Rejects Ford Bid On 2,000 Cars With Air Bags
description: The Federal Government will not buy cars equipped with air bags this year because it was unable to agree on a price with the Ford Motor Company, Federal officials said Tuesday.

title: MANILA IS FREEZING ALL MARCOS ASSETS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino issued an order today freezing all the assets of Ferdinand E. Marcos, his wife and their associates.

title: BROOKLYN PREVIEWS FRENCH MUSEUM
description: A taste of the Musee d'Orsay, the new national museum of 19th-century art that is scheduled to open in Paris this December, will be on view beginning tomorrow at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Builder of Shuttle Rockets Brings Back Ex-Executive
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. has asked a veteran executive to return from retirement to head its solid-fuel booster rocket operation. The company explained that it needed a respected figure in that post after the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THEATER: 'DEAD WRONG'
description: THE average made-for-television mystery is a prize winner next to Nick Hall's ''Dead Wrong,'' a purported suspense thriller at the Riverwest Theater. In this feeble yarn, Anita Gillette plays a Mount Kisco heiress whose husband (David Groh) is philandering. Her response is to see ''Cats'' in the company of a gigolo (Michael Wilding).

title: See Jim and Pat Cook. Jim Cooks First.
description: ''Pat has a big book. Pat reads the big book. Jim reads the big book. Pat reads to Jim. Jim cooks.'' So begins the riveting tale of how a girl named Pat and a boy named Jim make raisin pudding and ham and tomato on toast.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the year.

title: NASA SHIFT MAY BE BOON TO ROCKET INDUSTRY
description: The space agency's decision to let the private rocket industry supplement the shuttle in lofting satellites gives this struggling business its best chance yet to develop the nation's first commercially run launching apparatus, analysts and executives said today.

title: Las Vegas Star: Ace in Classroom
description: When the G.T.E. academic all-America team in women's basketball was announced the other day, one player was included for the third straight season: Misty Thomas, a pre-med major with a 3.93 grade-point average, the highest on the entire academic squad. And if there's any legitimacy to the maxim that star athletes are in effect ambassadors for their schools, then Miss Thomas's school landed a much-needed diplomat with her enrollment in 1982.

title: Control Pests and Monopoly, Too
description: As tyrants from George III to Ferdinand Marcos have learned, rulers can give no more coveted favor than a monopoly. Congress, no tyrant, is nonetheless a soft touch in handing out monopolies under the guise of ''patent restoration.'' Last year it let drug companies prolong their monopoly on patented drugs beyond the 17-year term. This week the Senate is preparing a similar bonanza for pesticide manufacturers. There's a reason for the giveaways, but it does Congress little credit.

title: DROP IN OIL PRICES IS RAISING FEARS OF NEW U.S. RELIANCE ON IMPORTS
description: Tumbling oil prices, which have made economists euphoric and brought glee to investors and motorists, are also raising fears that the nation may again allow itself to become dangerously dependent on foreign supplies.

title: Testing Plan Delayed
description: Officials of the Boston Marathon postponed a decision on whether to require drug tests at the April 21 race but agreed to notify all participants by mail of any later decision to require such tests. Guy Morse, the race administrator, said the Boston Athletic Association, which conducts the race, expected to make a final decision within the next three weeks, after marathoning's international governing body, the International Marathon Association, decides whether to require such tests for all race participants. The testing would be aimed at detecting steroids and other banned substances used to enhance athletic performance.

title: U.S. BRIEF ON UNITARY TAX
description: The Justice Department said today that it had filed a court brief contending that California's unitary tax on foreign corporations violates the United States Constitution.

title: Sending Innocents, Sort of, Abroad
description: When a young state or local official considers a run for Congress, inexperience in foreign affairs can often loom as a powerful stumbling block.

title: Big-Band Alumni
description: Musical alumni of the Duke Ellington and Count Basie orchestras will appear in concert next Thursday at 8 P.M. at New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW DESIGNS IN DISHES
description: THEY are simply the ultimate in mix and match, as far as china is concerned, anyway. The dishes, designed by Eamonn McMahon for the British China Company, include seven fresh-looking patterns that come in black and white, blue and white or orange and white.

title: Skiing at Coin-Operated Areas
description: To most skiers, technological advances mean such things as snow grooming and snowmaking, ski designs and boot improvements. But in the last couple of years, significant changes in equipment used for racing have altered the way skiers, from top international competitors to rank beginners, race.

title: WESTERN UNION DEBT PLAN SET
description: The Western Union Corporation filed a restructuring plan with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. It would include exchanging new debt securities and common stock for all of the company's outstanding debentures and notes.
