title: Ewing's Third Opinion
description: Before undergoing surgery, patients often seek a second opinion. Patrick Ewing, the Knick rookie who has been told he needs arthroscopic surgery on his painful right knee, has been doing better than that.

title: Fasting Man Quits Hospital
description: Mitch Snyder, on a hunger strike on behalf of the homeless, entered Howard University Hospital Tuesday night but left today, saying, ''They wanted to help me but I didn't want the treatment.'' Mr. Snyder, 42 years old, began his hunger strike on Feb. 12, Ash Wednesday, and pledged to consume only water until the Reagan Administration changed its policies toward the homeless in the capital.

title: PRUDENTIAL IN DEAL FOR LUMBERMENS
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurance company, said it planned to acquire the Lumbermens Mutual Insurance Company of Mansfield, Ohio.

title: ROCKWOOD HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tainted Dairy Herds Grow to 79 in 3 States
description: Health officials in Arkansas, Oklahoma and Missouri say cattle feed containing a pesticide has contaminated milk from 79 dairy herds and led to recalls of milk in four states.

title: BOESKY BUILDS $1 BILLION WAR CHEST
description: Ivan F. Boesky, one of the most aggressive and feared arbitragers, is in the process of amassing a significantly larger war chest for his stock market forays.

title: TALKS BREAK OFF IN STRIKE AT T.W.A.
description: Hopes of a quick end to a six-day strike by flight attendants against Trans World Airlines were dashed today when contract negotiations were broken off.

title: D'ARCY, MASIUS SIGNS WITH AGB TELEVISION
description: Mike Moore, senior vice president and corporate media director of D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles, has reported that he has signed up for the AGB Television Research Service that will supply demographic data on TV viewers collected with its people meter.

title: 2 DOMESTIC CARRIERS IN TIE TO JAPAN AIR
description: In a bid to counter stiff competition from United Airlines, Japan Air Lines has agreed with Delta Air Lines and Western Airlines to offer additional services and connecting flights.

title: CALENDAR: COLLECTIBLES AND HOME FURNISHINGS
description: Antiques and Collectibles, New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street, 212-247-0354.

title: HAWAII DEBATES HOW TO KEEP 'PARADISE A PARADISE'
description: Twenty-six years after a Rockefeller helped bring prosperity to an impoverished corner of Hawaii by creating a resort at the edge of a lava field, there is a new surge of resort development here that has some people asking: How much tourism is too much?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CHILDREN OF LIGHT. By Robert Stone. 258 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: PROMOTING LAW FIRMS ON TV
description: GAIL KOFF, a lawyer, has written a book and it is being advertised on television. Although you cannot prove it from the firm's title, she is a founding partner of Jacoby & Meyers, so it is not surpising that the book is getting that kind of promotional attention.

title: INVESTIGATORS ARE SAID TO BELIEVE TAXI AGENCY FILES WERE TAMPERED WITH
description: City investigators believe that someone at the Taxi and Limousine Commission tampered with the agency's records in an effort to obstruct inquiries into allegations that valuable taxi medallions were being given out in exchange for payoffs, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: SPORTSWEAR UNIT SHIFTS
description: Campus Sportswear of Paramus, N.J., has a new agency, Terry Conway of the advertising department confirmed yesterday.

title: SHARON DEFEATS BEGIN'S SON IN ISRAELI PARTY VOTE
description: Ariel Sharon defeated Menachem Begin's son in an election today for a key position at the Herut Party's convention here.

title: It's Time to Kill The Death Penalty
description: Opponents of the death penalty in New York State have long suffered from a disabling mixture of complacency and terror. We are complacent because our two most recent governors promised to veto any death penalty legislation. Yet we are terrified by the slim margins by which attempts to override a veto have failed and because of the overwhelming public support that opinion polls suggest exists for state-sanctioned executions.

title: CAP URGED ON INTEREST DEDUCTIONS
description: The tax-overhaul plan drafted by the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Bob Packwood, would make the tax-exempt interest on all newly acquired state and local government bonds subject to the alternative minimum tax on upper-income individuals. If enacted, it would be the first broad-scale imposition of Federal income tax on interest earned on state and local bonds.

title: WOLVERINE WORLD WIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $229,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year. Both latest periods' results include an after-tax gain of $3.3 million, or 47 cents a share, from the sale of its West German subsidiary.

title: 'MOLE' DEPICTS BONN INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: A onetime Nazi SS officer who for a decade was the Soviet Union's most highly placed agent in West German intelligence re-emerged today in a luxury hotel here to present his memoirs.

title: METS' CONTRACT OFFER TO ROHATYN IS LACKING CLOUT
description: Felix Rohatyn may be one of the heavy hitters in financial circles, but he has turned down an offer to take his swings in a new job: shortstop for the Mets.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Caldor Inc., Norwalk, Conn., a discount department store chain and a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corp., has appointed Arthur M. Heller senior vice president and general merchandise manager of hard lines.

title: 2 IN CONGRESS OFFER COMPROMISE PLANS ON AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: In an effort to head off a defeat for President Reagan, two of his supporters on Capitol Hill suggested compromise proposals today that would combine United States aid to the Nicaraguan rebels with a stronger push for a negotiated settlement in Central America.

title: LIFESTYLE RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Including a gain of $870,000 on the sale of two restaurant leases.

title: Best Versus Best
description: Whatever the magnitude of their achievements thus far, the only thing that matters from here on in is how the 64 teams selected for the N.C.A.A.'s big tournament fare against the rest of the field. Here is a standing of the top 16 teams - the four with the highest seedings in each of the four regionals - in terms of records this season against opponents that are also in the tournament:

title: CUTS AT KODAK UNIT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's Chemicals division, which has not had any layoffs in at least 25 years, said it would trim its work force by 5 percent this year and would offer special payments to those who retire or quit by April 24.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $811,000 from an accounting change. c-Net income

title: REAGAN IS TO BACK STEPS ON ACID RAIN
description: President Reagan will endorse a report calling for action to curb acid rain, Administration officials said today.

title: Those Wonderful Wachtmeisters
description: Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, appreciates his counsel. Vice President Bush appreciates his form on the tennis court. And much of official Washington, not easy to impress on the dinner circuit, appreciates his hospitality.

title: The U.N. Today: March 13, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 26 IN UNESCO ACT TO REMOVE LEADER
description: The 26 Western member nations in Unesco are seeking to block an expected re-election bid by the organization's Director General, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow of Senegal, diplomats said today.

title: A PROFILE OF W.C. FIELDS TONIGHT ON CHANNEL 13
description: EVEN today, in a mundane world seemingly dominated by flourishing stockbrokers and real-estate speculators, few things are more refreshing than the spectacle of William Claude (W. C.) Fields tilting tipsily against pretentiousness. In the 1933 movie ''International House,'' Fields crash-lands his autogyro plane, called the Spirit of Brooklyn, into the middle of a swank party being held in Wuhu, China. He thinks he has reached Kansas City, but the prissy Franklin Pangborn shouts out ''Woo-hoo.'' Ripping a huge flower from his lapel, Fields snarls, ''Don't let the posy fool ya.'' Maybe you're lost, Pangborn suggests. ''Kansas City is lost,'' snaps Fields, ''I am here.''

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: SLIDING doors that stick or skip out of their tracks can usually be easily repaired.

title: CABIN WRECKAGE BROUGHT ASHORE
description: The salvage ship Preserver steamed into port tonight carrying what sources said were more remains of the crew of the space shuttle Challenger, parts of its flight deck, a crew member's personal effects and two unused spacesuits.

title: TIN SETTLEMENT OF $220 MILLION
description: London Metal Exchange brokers paid obligations of nearly $220 million today in a forced settlement of the crisis in the world tin market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 13, 1986
description: Markets

title: Tryout for Bartkowski
description: Steve Bartkowski, the longtime Atlanta quarterback who was released by the Falcons at midseason and later spent two games with the Washington Redskins, may have found a new home in Los Angeles.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. Reports of changes follow:

title: Appreciating Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: FROST BROTHERS
description: Manhattan Industries, an apparel concern, said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its 13-store Frost Brothers chain in Texas to Torie Steele Wyly and Sam Wyly of Dallas. The Frost stores, which also include a Gucci boutique in Boston, had sales last year of about $12 million. Miss Wyly has two apparel stores and Mr. Wyly is chairman of Sterling Software Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 3 Yeats Verse Dramas In a Staged Reading
description: The actors Stockard Channing, Brian Doyle-Murray, Michael O'Donoghue and Kathryn Walker will appear in a staged reading of three verse dramas by W. B. Yeats on Monday night at 8 at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, in New York City.

title: CALIFORNIA DROPS SOHO MUSEUM PLANS
description: Citing the ''many difficulties'' he had encountered in its construction, Edward R. Broida, a California real-estate developer, has abandoned the much-heralded museum of contemporary art he had planned to open in SoHo by the end of this year.

title: MOYNIHAN IS FOR 'NO MERCY' ON GRAFT
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan called on Federal prosecutors and judges last night to ''show no mercy'' to corrupt officials.

title: LDBRINKMAN CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $284,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Tests on Pizzas for Schools Said to Show No Tampering
description: Preliminary tests on pizzas sold to schools, prompted by the discovery of razor blades found in two pie crusts, disclosed no evidence of product tampering, a supplier said today.

title: Get the Train Back On the 63d St. Track
description: To the Editor:

title: DELAY IS SOUGHT ON VOTE ON BUDGET AMENDMENT
description: Senate Republican leaders today postponed a vote on a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution when opponents said they had the votes to block approval.

title: NEW N.F.L. REPLAY RULE STIRS DEBATE
description: The approval of a taped replay system as an officiating aid in the National Football League signals the start of a new electronic age in football, many proponents of the system say.

title: NICARAGUA IS CRACKING DOWN AS VENDORS DEFY PRICE CURBS
description: Early on a recent Saturday, a squad of Government agents swooped into the Roberto Huembes Market here and began handing out fines to merchants who were ignoring price controls.

title: Mets and Yankees Win
description: Sid Fernandez, the left-hander, pitched for the second time in spring training yesterday, and gave up two hits and one run in three innings as the Mets defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-3, at Dunedin, Fla., and won their fourth game in five starts.

title: Fluoride Leak Prompts Alert
description: Residents in about 150 homes were warned by the police early today not to use their water because a high concentration of fluoride had leaked into the water system.

title: 2 More Counts Dropped In Alien-Harboring Trial
description: The judge in the trial of church members charged with harboring illegal aliens dropped two more criminal counts today while the defense sought dismissal of the remaining 36 charges against the 11 defendants.

title: FOR STORING SPORTING GEAR
description: IN city apartments with limited space, storing sports equipment can be a problem. But there are hooks and racks on the market to help.

title: EMPLOYEES AT BOROUGH HALL GREET SHULMAN WITH KISSES
description: When Claire Shulman arrived at Queens Borough Hall from City Hall early yesterday afternoon, she had barely stepped out of her car when several Borough Hall employees descended on her with curbside kisses and handshakes.

title: ALASKANS TURNING FROM OIL BOOM TO REALITY
description: Alaska, which had an annual budget of nearly $5 billion at the peak of its North Slope oil boom in 1980-81, today was faced with the prospects of having $900 million less to spend in the coming fiscal year than was forecast in January. And state officials are trying to come up with a budget that is less than half those of the state's boom years.

title: U.S. SEEKS TRUSTEE FOR ROBINS
description: The Justice Department today asked a Federal judge to appoint a trustee to take control of the A. H. Robins Company, charging that company officers had improperly spent money after the large pharmaceutical company filed for reorganization last year under Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: HPSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIMIT ON TRUCKS IN MIDTOWN TO BE TIGHTENED BY SUMMER
description: Starting this summer, the city will tighten its restrictions on tractor-trailer trucks in midtown Manhattan during weekday afternoons.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HOUSE VOTE LIMITS USE OF POLYGRAPH
description: The House of Representatives today approved legislation that would prohibit most private companies from giving polygraph, or lie-detector, tests to prospective or current employees. The vote was 236 to 173. The legislation establishing the general ban on use of the tests in the private sector came after the House accepted amendments that would permit lie-detector tests to be given to four specific categories of workers. The employees who would still be subject to such tests include workers in day-care centers and those involved in the production and transmission of electricity, the manaufacture of dangerous drugs and those serving as security guards.

title: PIERCE, S S CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income.

title: MAKING SPACES FLEXIBLE: 6 SOLUTIONS
description: OPEN space in a New York apartment is rrtreasured, and those who have it usually want to keep it: few wish to see their open-plan living rooms or lofts diminished by walls and small rooms. Still, there are private moments even in a spacious, light-filled loft - times when you want simply to shut a door.

title: NASA URGED THAT REAGAN CITE TEACHER'S VOYAGE
description: Space agency officals recommeded to the White House in early January that President Reagan take note in his State of the Union Message of the space shuttle voyage of a New Hampshire school teacher, White House officals said today. The space shuttle Challenger was originally scheduled to be aloft on the day of the speech.

title: Reagan Aide Assails Pretoria for Banning 2
description: The Reagan Administration's top official on African affairs condemned the South African Government today for ''banning'' two black anti-apartheid campaigners and said Pretoria's stated willingness to negotiate with blacks was a sham.

title: 2 CHARTER AIRLINES ASSAILED BY G.A.O.
description: The General Accounting Office, the Congressional auditing agency, has drafted a report asserting that two charter airlines flew military flights in violation of the Federal Aviation Administration's safety regulations.

title: MASSEUR SAYS JONHSON HEIR WAS ALERT IN HIS LAST DAYS
description: A masseur who attended J. Seward Johnson, the heir to the pharmaceutical fortune who died in 1983, testified yesterday that the octogenarian millionaire was alert and coherent and on excellent terms with his third wife, Barbara Piasecka Johnson, in the final months of his life.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TESTING & CERTIFICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax benefits of $498,000 for the quarter and $1,613,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $160,000.

title: Robert La Fosse Joins New York City Ballet
description: Robert La Fosse, formerly a leading dancer with American Ballet Theater, has joined the New York City Ballet as a principal dancer.

title: CITY FIGHTS U.S. BILL THAT WOULD LIMIT BONDS
description: New York City's plans to spend $1.5 billion this year and more in years ahead for capital projects ranging from hospitals to the Central Park Zoo could be curtailed because of a Federal tax overhaul bill now before the Senate Finance Committee, according to city officials said.

title: MOORE MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $1,275,000 for the quarter and year. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effective May 23, 1985.

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Sellers Daughter, 23, Indicted in Drug Case
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted six Californians - including the daughter of the late Peter Sellers, the actor - on charges of participating in a cocaine ring.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASHTON-TATE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring extraordinary gain of $1,000,000. Revenue results represent net revenue figures. Latest fourth quarter and year include results for Multimate International Corp. from Dec. 4, the date of its acquisition, to Jan. 31.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:54 A.M. today and set at 1:20 P.M.

title: SOUTH KOREA AFTER MARCOS
description: Few outside events have fired the imagination of South Korea's political dissidents as much as the fall of Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippines. It takes little prodding, sometimes none at all, to set opposition politicians to talking hopefully about how the same sort of lightning might strike here.

title: ARCHITECTURAL THEMES IN FILM AND BROADWAY PLAY
description: IT has taken a gifted playwright, Michael Frayn, to confront a question about architecture that is so brutal in its simplicity that most architects struggle to avoid it. There are many ways to phrase it, but they all come down to the issue of just how far architecture ought to go - just how much of a prescription architects should give people, just how fully their designs should be telling people how to live.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS COUNSEL PUPILS AFTER A SUICIDE
description: School officials said today that they were taking steps to reassure local children who have been left frightened or grief stricken after the apparent suicide of Rachel Greenberg, a 10-year-old Great Neck girl.

title: HAWKS OUTPLAY NETS
description: There were boos tonight. The Nets heard them at the end of the first half and again late in the third period. And when the game was over, they did not argue the fact that they were deserved.

title: Aram Haigaz Chekenian, 85, Author of Books in Armenian
description: Aram Haigaz Chekenian, who wrote hundreds of short stories, essays and poems, all in Armenian, died Monday in Booth Memorial Hospital in Flushing, Queens. He was 85 years old and lived in Rego Park.

title: WORLD BANK TO BROADEN BORROWING IN 2 MARKETS
description: The World Bank yesterday announced two innovations to broaden its financing activities in the domestic bond market and the international currency swap market.

title: GAP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31,000 for the quarter, $2,170,000 for the year and a loss of $4,560,000 for the quarter and year, from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $740,000 for the year. Share earnings results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in January.

title: INTEREST RATES UP SLIGHTLY
description: After falling sharply in recent sessions, interest rates on short- and long-term securities rose slightly yesterday.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 8
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $2,346,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of a non-retail unit. c-After a charge of $2,654,000 for the purchase of an insurancce policy to cover any liabilities it might have in connection with the liquidation of one of the company's public liability insurance carriers that had been placed in liquidation by the Missouri Insurance commissioner in December 1985.

title: Heard the Latest?
description: The smokestack industries may lag, but Washington's rumor mill works overtime, even if the gears sometimes seem to stick.

title: No, Don't Roll 'em
description: Although the Senate ended a historic ban yesterday on the broadcasting of its floor proceedings, the Supreme Court pointedly declined to take judicial notice.

title: Floridian Gets a Pardon For a Criminal Past
description: A Florida civic leader whose criminal record was uncovered last year when he ran for the school board has received a full pardon on a charge of writing a fraudulent check, for which he served a year in prison in 1958.

title: LORIMAR-TELEPICTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Net income. c-After an extraordinary charge of $2,550,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: IRAQ PARDONS 2 LINKED TO BEIRUT HOSTAGE
description: Iraq has pardoned two Iraqi men whose expulsion from France two weeks ago was given as a reason for the reported ''execution'' of a French research scholar by Moslem extremists in Lebanon, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: ALL AMERICAN GOURMET reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $76,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $634,000.

title: A Return Home
description: It has been 11 years since Martina Navratilova abandoned Czechoslovakia and settled in the United States, but now, for the first time since her defection, she may be going back to the land of her birth - as a member of a United States national team. Miss Navratilova, who became a United States citizen in 1981, has accepted an invitation to play on the American team at the Federation Cup competition scheduled for Prague in July. . . . Marty Riessen has been named captain of the United States Federation Cup and Wightman Cup tennis teams, replacing Tom Gorman, who is now captain of the United States Davis Cup team.

title: Word Machine
description: Edgar Jones, the Cleveland Cavaliers' dispenser of quotable quotes, when urged to describe his development as a basketball player: ''There's something you need to learn, and that's E. J.'s theory of evolution.

title: SHELL OIL OFFERING $250 MILLION NOTES
description: The Shell Oil Company today is offering $250 million of 8 3/8 percent 10-year notes at 99 1/2, to yield 8.45 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: TORNADOES LASH ALABAMA, LEAVING TWO DEAD
description: A series of tornadoes plowed a 225-mile swath of destruction through Mississippi and Alabama today, killing two people, destroying dozens of homes and businesses and ripping the steeple off a church.

title: Auto-Export Restraints Help the U.S. Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: SEBASTIANI VINEYARDS GOES OUTSIDE THE FAMILY
description: For the first time in its 82-year history, Sebastiani Vineyards will have a president who is not a Sebastiani.

title: SHULMAN ELECTED TO SUCCEED MANES
description: Claire Shulman was unanimously elected Borough President of Queens yesterday in a special vote by the borough's nine City Council members.

title: MICKELBERRY REPORTS $2.6 MILLION DEFICIT
description: The Mickelberry Corporation, the holding company whose properties include Cunningham & Walsh and Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson, opted to take a $3.3 million write-off for good will in the fourth quarter, which meant that it lost $2.6 million, or 45 cents a share.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including a gain of $571,000 on sale of land.

title: A DELICATE CAMPAIGN ISSUE IN THE SOUTH OF FRANCE
description: Christophe Deuxtata, a 22-year-old mechanic, has a fresh scar that stretches from the bottom of his left ear lobe right across his throat.

title: ARMANI: ARTFUL TAILORING AND A STANDARD FOR STYLE
description: A sure sign that a designer has achieved mythic status is the applause that bursts out as each style appears on the runway, even if it does not differ markedly from the style that went before.

title: Golfer Given 2d Warning
description: Mac O'Grady was notified today for the second time in five days that the PGA Tour office intends to discipline him for ''conduct unbecoming a professional golfer'' because of statements he made that were quoted in a newspaper article. The latest remarks were critical of the Riviera Country Club course, site of the recent Los Angeles Open, and critical of PGA Tour officials.

title: Persson a No-Show
description: Stefan Persson, the nine-year Islander defenseman who was traded to the Winnipeg Jets Tuesday afternoon, did not report to Winnipeg on schedule yesterday, and several Islander teammates said he had told them he might retire rather than join the Jets. Persson, who was supposed to arrive in Winnipeg in time to suit up for the Jets' game against Edmonton, remained sequestered at his home in Manhasset, L.I., and was unavailable for comment during the day, but his agent, Art Kaminsky, said Persson was pondering retirement and planned to make up his mind and announce his decision today. In the meantime, the Jets did not immediately ask for his suspension.

title: The Nicaragua Push
description: Supporters of President Reagan's efforts to provide $100 million in aid to the Nicaragua rebels are making it clear they will play tough, even with Republicans, to get the President what he wants.

title: Case Against Lawyer In Pie-Throwing Ends
description: A lawyer whose wife was convicted of hiring a clown to stuff a whipped-cream pie in a school administrator's face no longer faces felony charges in the case.

title: LIFTING SOVIET SECRECY
description: News Analysis The Soviet Union, breaking with tradition by showing a new openness about its space program, announced yesterday that astronauts were preparing for an earth-orbiting mission to be launched today. They were expected to occupy a new Soviet space station.

title: U.N. Bids U.S. Consult Soviet on Mission Size
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has advised the United States to negotiate with the Soviet Union before enforcing cuts in the size of the Soviet missions to the United Nations.

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to FIFO from LIFO for its new vehicle inventory.

title: BOXERS LOOK AT GOLDEN GLOVES AS FIRST ROUND TO GREATNESS
description: Moments after he had won the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight title from Marvin Johnson in 1980, Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, surrounded by his supporters, flashed back to a similar scene years earlier.

title: Reagan as Canute - But Backward
description: Ronald Reagan is playing a favorite role: King Canute - but he has the role backward. Though there is wide agreement that the tide has turned on military spending, Mr. Reagan is trying to keep it flowing in the same direction. In fact, he wants to speed up the flow.

title: HARVARD STUDY URGES OVERHAUL OF MEDICARE
description: Researchers at Harvard University recommended sweeping changes in Medicare today, including higher premiums for affluent elderly people and expanded coverage of nursing-home care.

title: 10 AT BROWN TIED TO SEX RING CASE
description: The police said today that nude photographs of dozens of women, including 10 students at Brown University and two at a nearby college, had been seized as evidence in a prostitution ring case.

title: GENETIC MUTATION IS LINKED IN A STUDY TO HEART ATTACKS
description: Doctors have discovered a genetic mutation that appears to be linked to heart disease, researchers said.

title: PROVIDENCE BEATS B.U.
description: Providence sank 12 of 13 free throws in the last three and a half minutes and withstood a last-minute scoring spree by Jeff Timberlake to edge Boston University, 72-69, in a first-round National Invitation Tournament game tonight.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $7,000 for the quarter and $147,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: The World Bank Needs a Leader
description: For almost five years the Reagan Administration viewed the World Bank with suspicion and served it with a generous dose of neglect. Multinational aid was not its meat, and the bank's loans, while capitalistically sound, seemed too tolerant of socialistic enterprise abroad. Finally last September it appeared that Treasury Secretary James Baker had put an end to that negativism. He proposed that the bank become the leading agent in working out long-term remedies for the crushing debt borne by developing countries. His welcome initiative serves both American and international interests.

title: Oilers Stop Jets With 8-5 Barrage
description: Craig MacTavish and Jarri Kurri scored twice, and Mike Krushelnyski engineered four goals as the Edmonton Oilers beat the Winnipeg Jets, 8-5, tonight.

title: GEORGIA U. PRESIDENT QUITS OVER DELAY ON HIS CONTRACT
description: Dr. Fred Davison, stung by the decision of the State Board of Regents to postpone renewing his contract, today resigned the presidency of the troubled University of Georgia, an office he has held for 19 years.

title: MANES'S LIFE: RAPID ASCENT, DIZZYING FALL
description: Donald R. Manes's rise to political power was a rapid one; his fall from power, when it came, was even more so, and to his friends and colleagues far more startling.

title: DOW HITS RECORD AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Trading activity slowed a bit on Wall Street yesterday, but the stock market continued its journey into record territory despite some newfound nervousness about the direction of interest rates and oil prices.

title: Calling All Sports Fans
description: Three Washingtonians who learned something about marketing and influencing the public in Democratic politics are setting up a new organization, the National Sports Club, to serve the interests of sports fans and participants. Brian Lunde, former executive director of the Democratic National Committee, says the club will be ''a sort of AAA for people who watch and play sports,'' providing its members publications, services, contests with prizes like Superbowl tickets and bargains on sporting goods and apparel, all for a $30 annual fee.

title: PANELS ON CITY CORRUPTION
description: Public officials have established or proposed the following panels and investigatory authorities since a city corruption scandal surfaced in January:

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Diner's Journal
description: ANY restaurant that has the chutzpah to call a dish ''Fish Nostrand Avenue'' can't be all bad. With that admitted prejudice in mind, I stopped by a leafy new spot in the West Village called Caribe - ''offering Caribbean, Spanish and West Indian Cuisine.'' While I was not in the mood for the plat du Brooklyn, I did have a savory oxtail with fried plantains that will bring warm smiles to aficionados of this much underrated peasant dish.

title: U.S. CLEARS SOME TV CHANNEL SWAPS
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to allow channel swaps between local commercial and noncommercial television stations within the same broadcast band -that is, within either the UHF or VHF band but not from one band to the other. Such swaps will not be subject to applications from third parties, the commission said.

title: 1986 BUDGETS CUT BY EXXON, CHEVRON
description: The Exxon Corporation and the Chevron Corporation yesterday announced sharp reductions in their planned 1986 capital spending budgets. Exxon said it would now spend $8 billion, $2 billion less than its original projection for the year, and Chevron cut its planned capital spending to $3.5 billion, from $5 billion.

title: Songs by Poindexter
description: Buster Poindexter will sing selected rock songs from the 1940's to the 1980's tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (212-228-6300). Shows are at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.50.

title: A FISCAL CONSERVATIVE HEADED FOR WORLD BANK: BARBER BENJAMIN CONABLE JR.
description: When Barber B. Conable Jr. was approaching retirement in 1984, after 20 years in Congress, he was asked why he had decided to quit.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The American people believe in human rights and oppose tyranny in whatever form, whether of the left or the right.'' - President Reagan. [ A1:6. ]

title: DOW JONES SEEKS TO BAR TAKEOVERS
description: Dow Jones & Company said it would seek shareholder approval of several anti-takeover proposals at its annual meeting on April 16. The measures provide for a staggered board and what the company described as a ''fair price'' provision that would require a potential purchaser to make the same offer to all shareholders.

title: REVIVAL HOUSES: CURLING UP WITH A GOOD DOUBLE BILL
description: SOME filmgoers' most vivid memories do not involve the plot permutations of a futuristic fantasy in 70 millimeter. Instead, they recall that fortuitous day in a darkened revival house when they first glimpsed Fred Astaire gliding across the screen in ''Top Hat,'' or Orson Welles murmuring the immortal ''Rosebud.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 14, 1986
description: International The President will oppose despots of the anti-Communist right as well as the pro-Soviet left, Mr. Reagan said in a policy statement set to be made public today. The new policy differs in emphasis from the one enunciated by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, former chief American delegate to the United Nations, which held that ''traditional authoritarian'' Governments were ''less repressive,'' more susceptible to change and better for American interests than Marxist-style dictators were. [ Page A1, Column 1. ]

title: THOSE TITILLATING HIGH-LEVEL RESIGNATIONS
description: There is nothing like a high-level resignation to get people talking in this city.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH TRAINING CONTRAS
description: Defense Department officials said tonight that President Reagan was prepared to use military advisers to train rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government if Congress approved the $100 million in aid the President has requested for the insurgents.

title: BROOKLYN UNION
description: The New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation is offering $62.5 million of 7 percent tax-exempt bonds, due in 2020, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds, issued on behalf of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, are a conversion of variable-rate demand obligations sold by the development corporation last December.

title: Frisking Each Other
description: Who would have thought that a conservative Administration, with a Justice Department headed by a denouncer of criminal-coddling, would be the one that presided over the retreat of law enforcement in America?

title: BROADWAY
description: IT may be that vitamins and tofu have produced a new breed of multitalented people. It may be that other pastures look irresistible. Or perhaps it's that writers, long the low men on most totem poles, got fed up. Whatever the reason, the result is that more and more writers are adding acting to their dossiers (Sam Shepard is perhaps the most visible example). Some are not only acting, but also doing so in their own plays.

title: The Mayor Takes a Poll
description: Should Mayor Koch resign?

title: MUSIC: PITTEL SAXOPHONE QUARTET
description: THE saxophone is one of our newer instruments and remains - in terms of concert music at least - one of our lonelier ones. Its charms are real but isolated, and its current repertory, some of it original, much of it borrowed from other instruments, is still in search of substance.

title: Singers and a Sax
description: Two singers, Jay Clayton and Urszula Dudziak, and the soprano saxophonist Jane Ira Bloom will perform ''spontaneous music'' today and tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street, below East Fourth Street (212-505-5660). Tickets are $8.

title: ART: 'NEW 19th CENTURY' AT BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: THE main purpose of ''From Courbet to Cezanne: A New 19th Century'' is to call attention to a museum that will soon change the face of the French art world. It is called the Musee d'Orsay. When it opens at the end of the year in an extensively remodeled former train station in the heart of Paris - the capital of 19th-century art - 19th-century art will have a capital building.

title: WEST SIDE BOOK FAIR
description: Books about Judaica, food, cartoon arts and sports are among those on sale this weekend at the West Side Antiquarian Book Fair at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d Street.

title: A Time for Decision
description: Does it sound reasonable to you that Congress should give President Reagan the money he wants for the Nicaraguan ''contras,'' if Mr. Reagan will resume negotiations with the Sandinista regime and fully inform Congress as to how the money is spent?

title: Pedaling Up to Texas Along the Ortega Trail
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaders of Peace March Seek Funds for Supplies
description: Participants in the cross-country ''great peace march'' held pep rallies today in an effort to lift sagging morale and met to discuss ways to raise $100,000 for an extra water truck and other supplies needed for the march to abolish nuclear weapons.

title: MILITARY CONTRACTS
description: The Air Force announced that The General Electric Company received a $770.8 million increase to a contract for engines for F-14 and F-16 fighter aircraft and the United Technologies Corporation received a $506.2 million contract for engines for the F-15 and F-16.

title: CITY TAKES OVER HIGH SCHOOL PROJECT
description: The city, not the Board of Education, will finish the building and repairing of the city's showcase arts high school, which is years behind schedule and plagued with flaws, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: SENATE VOTES INQUIRY ON DEFECTION EFFORT BY A SOVIET SEAMAN
description: The Senate today approved a resolution by voice vote to set up an independent investigation of the case of a Soviet seaman who tried to defect last October when his ship was in the lower Mississippi.

title: GLENFED REJECTS STAKE OFFER
description: Glenfed Inc., the holding company for Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, said it was approached this week about acquiring a stake in the Citadel Holdings Corporation, but turned down the offer.

title: EXAMINATION OF REMAINS SHIFTS TO NASA LAB
description: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that efforts to identify the remains of the seven Challenger astronauts would be conducted at a secluded, high-technology space agency laboratory here.

title: HOW THEATER DEVELOPMENT FUND DEVELOPS THEATER
description: Just about everybody in New York who puts on performances or attends them knows about the ''TKTS'' booth at Duffy Square that provides half-price tickets to Broadway and Off Broadway shows. What relatively few people know, however, is that the operation is but one of several sponsored by the Theater Development Fund.

title: ALLETTA MORRIS McBEAN
description: Alletta Morris McBean, for many years a trustee of the Animal Medical Center on East 62d Street in Manhattan and long active in a variety of philanthropic organizations, died Monday at her home in Hillsborough, Calif., a suburb of San Francisco, after a long illness. She was 73 years old and also had an apartment in Manhattan and a house in Newport, R.I.

title: Kirk Lightsey, Pianist
description: Kirk Lightsey is playing solo piano tonight and tomorrow at Burgundy, 467 Amsterdam Avenue, above 82d Street (212-787-8300). Music begins at 9 P.M.; there is a $7.50 minimum.

title: Beaux Arts Trio
description: The Beaux Arts Trio will present Schubert's Sonata in B flat (D. 28) and ''Notturno in E flat'' (D. 897); Schumann's Trio No. 1 in D minor (Op. 63) and Mendelssohn's Trio No 1 in D minor (Op. 49) today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $12; information: (212) 570-3949.

title: AUCTIONS
description: GUERNSEY'S, the auction house that in recent years has organized daylong sales of circus memorabilia and pre-Castro Cuban cigars, will stage another marathon auction this weekend, this time offering original comic and illustration art from newspaper comic strips, cartoons, magazine covers and political posters.

title: Aid to Angolan Rebels Stirs Clash in Congress
description: Lawmakers clashed today over a bill that would block President Reagan's program of secretly aiding the rebel forces fighting the Angolan Government.

title: DALLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,814,000 for the quarter and $7,976,000 for the year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $718,000 for the quarter and $1,010,000 for the year.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Singers Honor Doctor
description: Singers from the Metropolitan Opera, Broadway shows and the Top 40 chart will perform at 11 A.M. Sunday at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, in honor of the man to whom they entrusted the health of their vocal cords. The occasion is a memorial to Dr. Eugen Grabscheid, who died Feb. 3. Until his death at the age of 82, he was still working full time and making emergency calls backstage.

title: THIOKOL APPOINTS HEAD OF SPACE UNIT
description: At one of the most turbulent times in Morton Thiokol Inc.'s history, the company has turned to one its most respected rocket makers for help.

title: Commuter Crash Kills 3 in Michigan Woods
description: A Simmons Airlines commuter flight carrying nine people crashed in heavy fog and rain tonight, killing three people and injuring six, Alpena County sheriff's deputies said.

title: U.S. URGES TEST FOR ALL AT HIGH RISK OF AIDS
description: Federal health officials recommended yesterday that the millions of Americans at high risk of contracting AIDS should undergo periodic blood tests to determine if they have become infected with the virus.

title: SCREEN: SPHEERIS'S 'BOYS NEXT DOOR'
description: ITS title notwithstanding, ''The Boys Next Door'' is about a couple of teen-age outsiders - not your average boys next door -atypical guys who, though they look ordinary enough, are alienated from everybody in their community except each other.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
G.M. EXPECTED TO REMODEL PLANT
description: The General Motors Corporation is expected to announce formally on March 24 that it will remodel its Oshawa, Ontario, assembly plant to produce the W-body midsize cars scheduled for introduction in 1989.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANKRUPTCY WOES AT ROBINS
description: When the A. H. Robins Company filed bankruptcy proceedings seven months ago, it was seeking a way to handle thousands of claims from women who said they were injured by its Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.44 billion, to $212.73 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive weekly increase and the largest increase since Jan. 8, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: METEOROLOGISTS SAY EL NINO WILL HIT IN SUMMER AND FALL ERIK ECKHOLM
description: Meteorologists predicted yesterday that El Nino, the momentous, sometimes devastating shifts in Pacific Ocean waters and climate, will strike this summer and fall. They said they had developed a reliable method for forecasting the phenomenon a full year in advance.

title: ST. JOHN'S STARTERS CHEMISTRY MAJORS
description: Outside the California-Irvine arena, Ron Rowan turned up the collar of his red warm-up jacket and zipped it up in the steady drizzle.

title: VILLANOVA TOPS VIRGINIA TECH
description: Harold Jensen scored 20 points as the defending national champion, Villanova, held off a late Virginia Tech surge for a 71-62 victory today in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Southeast Regionals.

title: PARK AVE. TUNNEL PLAN TO CUT COST AND DELAYS
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad will be able to repair the aging train tunnels under Park Avenue without extensive delays for riders or motorists, officials said.

title: INQUIRIES ON MARCOS RAISING ISSUE OF PROSECUTION IN U.S.
description: The fall of Ferdinand E. Marcos has spawned or intensified several investigations of his personal and governmental dealings, raising the potential question of whether Mr. Marcos himself could face prosecution, Administration officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Honolulu dispatch on Tuesday about Filipinos who accompanied Ferdinand E. Marcos to Hawaii listed one former official erroneously. The official, Geronimo Velasco, Minister of Energy, joined the former President in Hawaii but did not travel with him from the Philippines. The same error occurred in an accompanying list of those who traveled with Mr. Marcos.

title: THE SCREEN: 'GUNG HO,' DIRECTED BY RON HOWARD
description: SEVERAL years ago the veteran screen writer Edwin Blum watched a segment of television's ''60 Minutes'' about the opening of a Nissan auto plant in Smyrna, Tenn. Mr. Blum, whose credits include ''The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes'' (1939) and ''Stalag 17'' (1953), thought this Japanese challenge to Detroit could make a funny movie.

title: Reagan Applause
description: President Reagan has reacted warmly to the first public appeal by Project '88: Americans for the Reagan Agenda, an organization that has two goals: lobbying for the President's budget and legislative program and keeping Republican activists uncommitted on the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Swiss Account: How It Works
description: Individuals who have money in a Swiss bank to take advantage of Swiss secrecy laws can earn interest on savings and investment accounts, but not on checking accounts in dollars or other foreign currency.

title: Spain Votes Against Quixote
description: Defying many predictions, Spaniards voted decisively Wednesday for remaining in NATO. Since their popular Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, staked all on this plebiscite, the result was above all a vote of confidence for his policy.

title: 2 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS LOFTED TOWARD NEW SPACE STATION
description: The Soviet Union launched two astronauts today toward a rendezvous with the new space station Mir, and in a rare move the takeoff was shown live on national television.

title: DOME SUSPENDS SOME PAYMENTS
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced that it had suspended some payments on its $5.3 billion (Canadian) debt for 14 months, effective May 1.

title: BRADLEY BEATS TEXAS-EL PASO
description: Jim Les scored 22 points and Hersey Hawkins had 21 as Bradley defeated Texas-El Paso, 83-65, today in a first-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association West Regional.

title: AGE OF SPACE: A SOVIET STEP
description: Two Soviet astronauts were launched into orbit yesterday, bound for a large facility the Russians call Mir in a move seen by many space experts as the beginning of the age of the space station.

title: DEVILS SQUANDER 3-GOAL LEAD
description: Too many inaccurate passes, too much poor goaltending and too little execution on the power play were the problems for the Devils tonight in their 7-4 loss to the Toronto Maple Leafs at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: MARCH 1-10 AUTO SALES DOWN 4%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles declined 4 percent in the first 10 days of March from the corresponding period last year, the nation's seven major manufacturers reported today.

title: French Election Coverage
description: Live French television coverage of the legislative elections Sunday will be beamed by satellite from 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. to the Apollo Theater in Harlem to an audience of business, political and foreign affairs leaders. The event, which will include political debate by French leaders, will be organized by Francois Chateau, a French lawyer living in New York; Olivier Grinda, president of Holmes Investments, and Daniele Bidermann, president of the New York French Film Festival of 1984.

title: FEBRUARY RETAIL SALES DIP
description: Sales at the nation's retail outlets fell slightly in February, the second straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: SWIZZLE STICKS CAUSE A STIR
description: The venerable swizzle stick, exact date of birth unknown, is stirring things up on the current social scene. In the 1920's Cartier introduced personalized silver-plated swizzle sticks, the purpose of which was to eliminate the bubbles in champagne. The stick was apparently an item of status to the society swells of the day. Noel Coward, Gertrude Lawrence and George Gershwin were among those who toted their own silver-plated sticks around town. (Cartier sells them still at $50 - $85 if topped with a black onyx ball - plus an additional $8 for the de rigueur monogram.) The status swizzlers that are making waves in the drinks of the moment are rather less elegant than Cartier's, composed as they are of carnival-colored paper, transparent plastic or flexible tubes that glow in the dark. If the silver-plated originals are the ''Rhapsody in Blue'' of swizzle sticks, the current crop is right out of MTV. Overture to the Show

title: RE-EXAMINING I.B.M.' ROLE
description: WHILE the market continues to reach new highs, its perennial pacesetter, the International Business Machines Corporation, has been lagging badly. A rash of disquieting news pushed the stock down 7 3/8 points in the final two days of February. But not all analysts are pessimistic about the company's immediate prospects.

title: O'GRADY WARNED AGAIN
description: Commissioner Deane Beman of the PGA Tour notified Mac O'Grady yesterday that he may be fined up to $12,000 and suspended from the tour for as many as 12 events because of statements made by O'Grady that Beman said ''threaten the image and good will of tournament golf and the PGA Tour.'' The action came as O'Grady was handed his third notice within a week of the Tour's intent to punish him for violations of the rules of conduct.

title: HISTORIC DAY FOR McRAE AND HIS SON
description: At the batting cage, the veteran Hal McRae of the Kansas City Royals turned and looked behind him. ''Brian,'' he called to a young teammate being interviewed nearby, ''give up the camera.''

title: SURGERY FOR EWING
description: Patrick Ewing is scheduled to undergo arthroscopic surgery today to remove a floating piece of tissue in his right knee. Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team physican, will perform the procedure at Lenox Hill Hospital. Ewing will be treated on an outpatient basis. The surgery was scheduled yesterday after Dr. J. Richard Wells of Chevy Chase, Md., the fourth orthopedic surgeon Ewing had visited recently, came up with the same recommendation as the other three doctors.

title: ZOOMING IN ON MUFFLER BUSINESS
description: THE first thing that SSC&B: Lintas USA has done for its new clients, Speedy Muffler King and Car-X Systems, is to turn people into autos.

title: RUNNING JOKE
description: One more from Frank Layden, the rotund coach of the Utah Jazz, who, when asked whether he would run in a team-sponsored marathon, replied: ''No, but they can put the course around me.''

title: Moving Day
description: At dawn next Friday, the gambrel-roofed wooden house that John Cook built in Smyrna, Del., in 1770 is scheduled to start lumbering down the highway aboard a flatbed truck, headed for the National Building Museum in Washington. When it arrives at noon the next day, it will be unloaded in the museum's Fourth Street N.W. parking lot, to become the first building in the historic architectural park planned there.

title: A COLD TICKET
description: Speaking of the Knicks, there was a vivid illustration the other day of the wide gap between dreams and what has become reality.

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $237,800,000 for the quarter and $250,000,000 for the year. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $3,100,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the year.

title: BRITISH AIR SALE DELAYED
description: A passengers' class action lawsuit, filed in the United States against British Airways, is delaying denationalization of the carrier.

title: SPAIN'S DECISION: LET'S BE PRACTICAL
description: Behind Spain's vote Wednesday to stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was a sense of pragmatism that reflects how far this once fratricidal country has come in a decade.

title: HOWARD GREENFIELD
description: Howard Greenfield, who wrote the lyrics for ''Breaking Up Is Hard to Do,'' ''Happy Birthday, Sweet Sixteen,'' ''Love Will Keep Us Together'' and more than 450 other songs, died of heart failure March 4 in Los Angeles. He was 49 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: YOUNGER CUOMO STEPS FROM FATHER'S SHADOW
description: Two years after leaving state government, Andrew M. Cuomo remains the most trusted and powerful adviser to his father, the Governor, influencing everything from political strategy to the appointment of key administration officials.

title: In Re Foreign Lawyers
description: Despite widespread local grumbling that Washington already has too many lawyers, the District of Columbia Bar has changed its rules to permit foreign lawyers to practice here as Special Legal Consultants. This new category will not, however, be able to convey real estate, write wills and trusts or bring divorce actions, being limited to providing advice on foreign and international law. The change had the support of the State Department and the United States Trade Representative.

title: RECITAL: HANS JENSEN, CELLIST
description: HANS JORGEN JENSEN, a Danish cellist who studied at the Juilliard School and made his New York debut in 1976, gave a recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night with his wife, Fumiko Tokunaga, at the piano. Mr. Jensen has taught at the University of Houston since 1979.

title: SWISS BANK FOUND WITH $800 MILLION IN MARCOS'S NAME
description: The Philippine Government has identified an $800million Swiss bank account held by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos, an official of the Government commission seeking to recover Mr. Marcos's hidden wealth said today.

title: Don't Dump Nuclear Junk in Maine Lakes
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRUPTION INQUIRY THAT IS CHANGING THE FACE OF NEW YORK POLITICS
description: The human and legal drama that would come to wrench New York's political establishment began with the seemingly inexplicable: Donald R. Manes, the affable Borough President of Queens, found in his car near Shea Stadium with a slashed wrist and ankle.

title: The Aging: 'A Captive Population'
description: The several million people who live in nursing homes share more than illness or incompetence. They are likely to be poor, single and childless. Given their dependency, the $9 billion Washington spends annually on nursing homes should be well spent. Yet the Reagan Administration remains determined to relax its supervision. A new study makes clear why that's wrongheaded.

title: CONSUMER DEBT UP IN JANUARY
description: Americans took on $6.9 billion in new debt in January, reflecting a 15.2 percent annual rate of growth in consumer debt, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: AMERICAN music owes a remarkable debt to the Yorubas of West Africa. This weekend, three Latin-jazz concerts will, implicitly and explicitly, pay homage to Yoruba traditions.

title: MESSENGER WHO TRIED TO SELL SECRETS GETS 3 YEARS
description: A former Washington messenger who confessed he had tried to sell secret Government documents to the Soviet Union was sentenced today to three to nine years in Federal prison.

title: The Way to Honor Old Immigrants ...
description: In the middle of New York harbor, in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, sits a 23-acre island that is as sacred a piece of land as this nation can claim. Yet a rare opportunity to preserve and meaningfully interpret this quintessentially American landmark is in danger of being squandered.

title: 17 Dartmouth Students Found Guilty in Protest
description: A Dartmouth College panel today found 17 students guilty of trying to block the removal of a shanty erected on the campus green in protest of South Africa's policies of racial separation, but imposed no penalties.

title: MAKING A POINT
description: One measure of just how discouraging the Knicks' season has been is that there's every possibility they'll finish without a 1,000-point scorer. And the measure of just how rare that is comes from the National Basketball Association's record books, which disclose that no team has failed to put at least one such player on the court in the last 31 years, since Bobby Wanzer totaled 942 for the Rochester Royals in the 72-game 1954-55 season, the first with the 24-second clock.

title: BECK OUT INDEFINITELY
description: The Rangers are preparing to continue their hunt for a playoff spot without their leader on defense, Barry Beck, the team captain.

title: Reluctantly Single Gives Up the Lottery of Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Man Is Charged With Rape at a College
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man has been charged with raping and stabbing a woman Monday in a Brooklyn College classroom building. He was also charged with two recent sexual assaults near the campus.

title: General Defies House Arrest, Seizes 2d Ecuadorean Base
description: A general who took over a coastal air base for four days and forced the resignation of two top Government officials seized a second military base today and demanded the arrest of the two officials and the dismissal of the President.

title: PASQUA EARNS YANKEES' FAITH
description: The Yankees rejected a trade with the Montreal Expos for Andre Dawson because, they said, the Expos wanted Dan Pasqua in return. The Yankees passed up the chance to sign a willing Kirk Gibson as a free agent because, they said, they had to have an outfield spot for Pasqua. Ken Griffey again wants to be traded because the Yankees have said they will use Pasqua as their left-handed-hitting left fielder.

title: A PROFESSORIAL STROLL AROUND IRISH NEW YORK
description: When Dr. James Patrick Shenton lectures on American ethnic and racial history, the past unfolds in an articulate tumble of events and causes, anecdotes, numbers, dates and ironic asides. His students at Columbia must take notes furiously.

title: CONCERT: EMIGRE ORCHESTRA
description: THE Soviet Emigre Orchestra can be likened to a small-scale version of the Philharmonia Hungarica. Both are, essentially, orchestras in exile: the Hungarica is centered in Vienna, the Soviet Emigre Orchestra in New York.

title: HOYAS STRUGGLE BUT WIN
description: Reggie Williams scored 22 points tonight as Georgetown held off Texas Tech, 70-64, in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: KOCH APPOINTS PANEL TO SCREEN CITY APPOINTEES
description: Mayor Koch, in his first formal move to insulate his appointments from political influence, yesterday created a committee to seek out and screen potential appointees to as many as 50 positions on nine city commissions and boards.

title: HOME PORT PLAN FAULTED BY GOLDWATER IN LETTER
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has denounced as ''pure unadulterated politics'' the Navy's plan to deploy its expanding fleet in new home ports, according to a letter made public today.

title: Hormel Local Votes End To Feud With Its Union
description: Meatpackers on strike against the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant in Austin, Minn., have approved a resolution calling for a reconciliation with their parent union and authorizing a more conciliatory contract offer to the company.

title: U.S. TO PRESS ARMS VERIFICATION
description: A senior Administration official said today that the United States would present detailed proposals on the verification of medium-range missile limits when the Geneva arms talks resume in May.

title: U.S. WON'T CONSULT SOVIET ON U.N. MISSIONS
description: The United States said today that it would not consult with Moscow on the size of the three Soviet missions to the United Nations and that it stood by its order reducing the mission size.

title: AT HOSPITAL, A GRIM ACCOUNT OF DEATH
description: Police officers and security guards surrounded the emergency room at Booth Memorial Hospital on Main Street in Flushing and a few passers-by watched from their cars as a steady rain fell.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Detroit Tigers, at St. Petersburg, 1:05 P.M. Orioles vs. Yankees, at Fort Lauderdale, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich. (Television - Channel 9, 8 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Division I Tournament, opening round. East Regional, at Syracuse: St. Joseph's (Pa.) vs. Richmond; Indiana vs. Cleveland State (Television - ESPN, 2:30 P.M., live); Navy vs. Tulsa (Television - ESPN, 7 P.M., live); Syracuse vs. Brown, 9:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8 A.M. Saturday, tape. Radio - WNYE-FM 91.5, 9:05, live.) Southeast Regional, at Charlotte, N.C.: Kentucky vs. Davidson (Television -ESPN, 10 P.M., live, joined in progress); Western Kentucky vs. Nebraska (Television - ESPN, 6 A.M. Saturday, tape); Alabama vs. Xavier (Ohio); Illinois vs. Fairfield (Television - ESPN, noon, live). Southeast Regional, at Baton Rouge, La.: Purdue vs. Louisiana State (Television - ESPN, 10 A.M., tape). Midwest Regional, at Minneapolis, Minn.: North Carolina State vs. Iowa (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M. live, joined in progress); Notre Dame vs. Arkansas-Little Rock (Television - ESPN 1:30 A.M. Saturday, tape); Iowa State vs.

title: Reagan Providing Chad $10 Million in Arms
description: President Reagan has ordered up to $10 million in military equipment be sent to Chad in its war with Libyan-backed rebels, the State Department said today.

title: TRUMP TOWER RESIDENT HELD IN 72D ST. KILLING
description: The owner of a pair of million-dollar condominiums in Trump Tower was arrested yesterday on charges of murder and promoting a policy-numbers operation that earned $500,000 a week, according to the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: F.A.A. INSPECTORS' REPORT ON CONTINENTAL AIRLINES' SAFETY WAS ALTERED, THEY TESTIFY
description: Two retired air safety inspectors for the Federal Aviation Administration accused superiors today of covering up findings of safety and training violations at Continental Airlines.

title: DRUG-CLAUSE HEARING
description: The issue of drug-testing in major league baseball will come up for a key test today when Thomas Roberts, baseball's impartial arbitrator, conducts a hearing on a grievance filed by Joel Youngblood, who charges that the San Francisco Giants improperly withdrew a two-year, $900,000 contract offer after he refused to accept a last-minute demand for a drug-testing clause. Youngblood contends that he and the Giants had reached agreement before the club demanded the drug-testing clause. He further maintains that the Giants' refusal to sign him represented improper discrimination against him because of his support of the union's position on testing.

title: A Dry Spell At 2 Watering Holes
description: At two well-known West 54th Street watering places these days one cannot get anything stronger than a Perrier or a Tab. The places are the Dorset Hotel at No. 30, off Fifth Avenue, and the Warwick Hotel at the corner of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: SCREEN: 'BAD GUYS,' BY JOEL SILBERG
description: ALTHOUGH the name of Sylvester Stallone is missing from the credits, he deserves more or less honorable mention as the inspiration for the funniest scenes of ''Bad Guys,'' a movie without a serious bone in its head.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: YOU could barely see the guests for the balloons at Mortimer's the other night as Glenn Bernbaum presided over the 10th anniversary of the restaurant that has evolved in a decade into a club for the East Side's rich and famous. Big white and black balloons obscured the ceiling, much of the bar and some of the guests, who included Gloria Vanderbilt, Bobby Short, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., Mercedes Kellogg, C. Z. Guest and Jerry Zipkin.

title: YANKEES, WPIX IN BOTTOM OF 9th
description: Among the things that have long distinguished New York from Podunk are Broadway, world-class restaurants and televised home-team baseball games that are always shown from first pitch to last, not joined in progress. Well, two out of three ain't bad.

title: Ravioli in 108-Ounce Cans Recalled in 5 States in West
description: A California company is recalling extra-large cans of ravioli distributed in five states because they may contain food spoilage organisms, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about resort development in Hawaii misidentified a hotel. It was the Mauna Lani Bay Hotel, not the Mauna Kea.

title: STAGE: EMILY MANN'S 'EXECUTION OF JUSTICE'
description: IN Emily Mann's ''Execution of Justice,'' the case of the People vs. Dan White is on trial in the court of theater and is found guilty of a miscarriage of justice. That conclusion is reached after a thought-provoking evening that is scrupulous in its quest for objectivity. With the playwright acting as investigative reporter, the play is not a polemic but a judicious assessment of a turbulent episode in recent American political history.

title: A Witness on Hunger Was 'Used,' Koch Says
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that a 10-year-old boy who lives in a city welfare hotel had been ''used'' when he testified about hunger at a Congressional hearing last week.

title: U.S. VOWS TO RESIST DESPOTS OF RIGHT AS WELL AS OF LEFT
description: In a major policy statement to be made public on Friday, President Reagan says explicitly for the first time that his Administration will oppose dictatorships of the anti-Communist right as well as the pro-Soviet left.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about a city study critical of rates at the Holland Hotel, where some homeless families are housed, included an erroneous identification from the study for another hotel occupied by homeless families. It is the Red Cross Emergency Family Center at 515 West 41st Street, not the Travel Inn Motor Hotel at 515 West 42d Street.

title: IONA COACH MAY LEAVE
description: Pat Kennedy, the Iona College basketball coach who has been applying for other jobs ever since he started making his mark at Iona, finally got one yesterday - perhaps.

title: Low-Volume Rock
description: Jonathan Richman and the Modern Lovers will play low-volume rock- and-roll tomorrow night at Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place (212-477-3728). The Legendary Wid will play an opening set at about 11:30 P.M., and Mr. Richman will appear at approximately 1 A.M. Tickets are $14.

title: BROWN RELAXED FOR SYRACUSE CHALLENGE
description: The coach prides himself on his one-liners. He also wears a preppie-looking short-sleeved shirt on the sideline during games and wonders why he gets funny looks. And the star player has been asked to bring home an autograph of the opposition's star player for his friends.

title: Two Songwriters
description: The songwriters Michael Hurley and David Massengill share a double bill tonight at Folk City, 130 West Third Street (212-254-8449), for two shows, at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.. Tickets are $8.

title: 'FOLLIES IN CONCERT' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''FOLLIES IN CONCERT'' on Channel 13 tonight at 9 is likely to create some confusion, if not resentment, because it is not what this title suggests. It might better have been titled ''Follies: Four Days in New York.''

title: U.S. CHOICE FOR WORLD BANK MADE
description: President Reagan has chosen Barber B. Conable Jr., a former Republican Congressman from upstate New York who served in the House for 20 years, to be president of the World Bank, the White House announced today.

title:
EAST REGIONAL;
DUKE SURVIVES A SCARE FROM MISSISSIPPI VALLEY ST.
description: For 28 minutes, a stunning dream was coming true at the Greensboro Coliseum this afternoon.

title: Dining Out Guide: Popular Spots
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ALO ALO, #1030 Third Avenue, at 61st

title: VERMONT CHURCH JOINS DEBATE ON ALIEN REFUGEES
description: The debate over who should be allowed into the United States and who should pick them came into sharp focus here tonight when a Federal official asked a church not to meddle in immigration policy by sheltering a refugee family.

title: LAWS COST CAR BUYERS, STUDY FINDS
description: A Federal Trade Commission study said today that state laws limiting the establishment of automobile dealerships in 36 states cost consumers $3.2 billion last year.

title: ARMORY ANTIQUES SALE
description: Clothing, furniture, jewelry and rugs are among the antiques that will be available at an antiques and collectibles sale this weekend at the New York State Armory, 125 West 14th Street.

title: FLAWS IN EQUIPMENT AND TRAINING FAULTED IN OKLAHOMA TOXIC LEAK
description: Federal investigators have concluded that inappropriate equipment and lack of effective safety training were the primary causes of the January accident at an Oklahoma uranium processing plant that killed one worker and sent 130 people to hospitals.

title: Paper Company Drops Plans for Dam in Maine
description: The Great Northern Paper Company, citing problems with state regulatory agencies, said today that it was abandoning a plan to build a $100 million dam that was opposed by environmentalists and rafting enthusiasts.

title: F.D.I.C. SET TO WIDEN AID POLICY
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation told Congress today that the agency's implied policy of not liquidating large insolvent banks would now be applied to smaller banks.

title: English Rock Band
description: The Jesus and Mary Chain, a rock band from England, will perform tonight at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (212-254-2800). The set begins at about 1 A.M. Saturday; tickets are $13.50.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 14, 1986
description: The Economy

title: BOZELL, JACOBS GREETS DE LAURENTIIS GROUP
description: The De Laurentiis Entertainment Group, which had been one of the up-in-the air accounts awaiting a home, is being welcomed by Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Pacific in Los Angeles with all the warmth a $35 million account is entitled to.

title: HEADED THE BONN PARLIAMENT
description: Eugen Gerstenmaier, a former President of the Bonn Parliament, one of the founding fathers of West German democracy and an architect of conciliation with Israel, died today, sources close to his family said. He was 79 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WRECK OF THE TITANIC FORETOLD? Edited by Martin Gardner. Illustrated. 157 pages. Prometheus Books. $18.95.

title: A Surprise Discount For Florida Travelers
description: Some small print was missing from a big advertisement yesterday, and a lot of Florida-bound air travelers found themselves with windfalls as large as $60.

title: RANGERS' PAVELICH AND ''THE SYSTEM''
description: He said he played the game only for fun, but Mark Pavelich's new bosses missed the point. They thought they would lock him into their system, make him fit their job description, which is the kind of computer talk that goes on with the New York Rangers these days.

title: SHULTZ BACKS 'MODERATE FORCE' AGAINST TERRORISTS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today endorsed the use of ''moderate force'' by the United States to abduct and bring before American courts suspects in terrorist attacks charged with killing or wounding Americans abroad.

title: THE OPERA: BENACKOVA IN SMETANA'S 'LIBUSE'
description: WHEN Smetana's ''Libuse,'' the work that was destined to become Czechoslavakia's national opera, was being written between 1869 and 1872, European music was in the grip of Wagner fever. The ''Ring'' had yet to be produced, but such earlier works as ''Tannhauser,'' ''Lohengrin'' and ''Der Meistersinger'' were already in the bloodstream of almost every composer. Certainly one can hear many Wagnerian influences in ''Libuse,'' which apparently had its first American performance last night at Carnegie Hall under Eve Queler's baton. Again and again one could hear familiar Wagnerian chord progressions, turns of phrase and motivic allusions.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Judy Carmichael Trio, Hanratty's, 1754 Second Avenue, between 91st and 92d Streets (289-3200). Judy Carmichael raised some local eyebrows as well as ears when she made her debut in New York in October 1982, playing stride piano, a music associated with ruggedly muscular male pianists. Miss Carmichael is young, slim and female, but when the great jazz saxophonist Benny Carter heard her playing on a tape, he was puzzled because he thought he was hearing one of the stride pianists of the 1920's, although the recording was obviously much more modern. For more than three years, Miss Carmichael has played frequently at Hanratty's as a soloist, but this weekend she will be part of a trio, something she has been working up to gradually. Last September, she gave a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall with a quartet that included Freddie Green, the guitarist in Count Basie's band; another guitarist, Howard Alden, and the bassist Red Callender. In October, she made an album with Mr. Alden, Mr. Callender and the cornetist Warren Vache, and she played another concert in November at Cooper Union with Mr. Vache and Mr. Alden. More recently she found that Michael Hashim, the alto saxophonist with the Widespread Jazz Orchestra, lived around the corner from her on the West Side and they played a weekend at Struggles in Edgewater, N.J., with Mr. Alden on guitar. Now she is in the midst of three weekends at Hanratty's with a trio made up of Mr. Hashim and varying guitarists.

title: SHAMIR'S LEADERSHIP IS IN DOUBT
description: The Herut Party convention collapsed in chaos early today, raising doubts about the future of Israel's main right-wing party and its leader, Yitzhak Shamir.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM AT CITY CENTER
description: THE Merce Cunningham Dance Company is off and running this season with unusually fine dancing - actually, great dancing - and Wednesday night's program at the City Center made this abundantly clear.

title: Officials in Five States Recall Milk for Tests
description: Officials in five states recalled milk for tests or destruction yesterday and health officials prohibited 85 farmers in three states who used a contaminated pesticide from selling milk.

title: Don't Play Politician, Pope Tells Brazilians
description: Pope John Paul II told Brazilian bishops at a special meeting today that they should not try to ''substitute for politicians'' and that some forms of liberation theology needed to be ''cleansed of elements that might adulterate it.''

title: CONDOMINIUM CONSTRUCTION IN TRIBECA
description: Some years ago, so the story goes in real estate circles, Dan Aykroyd, the actor, and John Belushi wanted to own a nightclub in the TriBeCa section of Manhattan. They bought property on Greenwich Street between Warren and Murray Streets, most of it a parking lot, to build on.

title: 16-Year-Old Teaches Class in L.I. Mix-Up
description: Security at a Long Island elementary school has been tightened after a 16-year-old girl was accidentally assigned as a substitute teacher for a third-grade class, school officials said today.

title: LEADER OF LEFTIST REBELS KILLED BY COLOMBIA POLICE
description: The police today killed the leader of Colombia's main leftist guerrilla group in an apartment shootout in the capital when he tried to resist arrest, the National Police chief said.

title: CHARLES L. STEWART
description: Charles Lyman Stewart, a former partner in the law firm of Dunnington, Bartholow & Miller, died of a stroke March 7 at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
U.S. SAYS FRANCE MISSED CHANCE TO SEIZE BEIRUT HIJACKING SUSPECT
description: American officials say the French Government recently missed an opportunity to arrest a Lebanese Shiite who has been accused of masterminding the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jetliner last year.

title: THE SHAPING OF BRAZIL'S PLAN
description: THE authors of Brazil's bold new anti-inflationary strategy are a handful of young economists with Ph.D.'s from leading American universities. But their package of measures, which local wits have nicknamed the ''Tropical Plan,'' appears to be very much ''Made in Brazil.''

title: CONCERT: PIERRE BOULEZ LEADS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: IT was deja vu as well as deja entendu at the New York Philharmonic last night. Pierre Boulez, the previous music director, was back on the Avery Fisher Hall podium leading the orchestra for the first time in nine years. And not only did he choose a program very much like those he used to present here in the 1970's, but the response was very much the same, as well.

title: REACTION WARM TO CONABLE SELECTION
description: The news that Barber B.
