Conable Jr., the former Representative from New York, would be named the next chairman of the World Bank later this year brought a generally positive response yesterday from international financial figures and former colleagues on Capitol Hill. While they agreed that he did not have an international reputation or banking experience, they said his knowledge of international issues was broad and his intellectual powers great.

title: MILAN PERSPECTIVE: REALISM RULES FOR FALL
description: Italian clothes for fall and winter are, above all, serious. They are made well in attractive, luxurious fabrics. Mannequins glide along on low-heel shoes, often shaped like bedroom slippers. High-heel pumps appear only with dressier clothes. Hair is slicked back into ponytails and the models' faces are pale, with no aggressive makeup, complementing the subdued style of the tailored clothes, what the Italians do best.

title: DEATH COULD BE DOUBLE LOSS FOR CORRUPTION INVESTIGATORS
description: Donald R. Manes's death came just as Federal prosecutors were turning the full attention of their municipal corruption investigation directly on him.

title: OFFERING BY ROTHSCHILD
description: L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin Holdings Inc. yesterday consummated its plans to convert from a partnership to a publicly held company, as it offered 7.7 million common shares at a price of $20.50 a share.

title: WOMAN WINS IDITAROD
description: She had to retake the lead from a resurgent wayward competitor, but Susan Butcher, a 30-year-old kennel operator, swept across the finish line first in the Anchorage-to-Nome Iditarod Sled Dog Race early yesterday in Alaska. She set a speed record for the 14-year-old event in becoming the second woman to win the 1,158-mile race (Libby Riddles won last year) over some of the world's coldest, windiest and most desolate terrain.

title: MANES IS A SUICIDE, STABBING HIMSELF AT HOME IN QUEENS
description: Donald R. Manes, who resigned as Queens Borough President last month after an apparent suicide attempt and widening allegations of corruption against him, died last night of a self-inflicted knife wound of the heart, the police said.

title: NEW CHIP RULING GOES AGAINST JAPAN
description: The Commerce Department found today that the Japanese are unfairly selling the current generation of memory chips and an advanced chip barely off the drawing board to the United States market at prices below the cost of production.

title: Gooden Gives Up a Run
description: Dwight Gooden gave up his first run of spring training tonight, but otherwise pitched three strong innings for the Mets against the Chicago White Sox and said that he was ''about 80 percent of what I want to be on opening day.''

title: SUFFOLK OFFICERS TAKEN OFF JOBS IN DRUG INQUIRY
description: Two top Suffolk County police officials have been removed from their jobs amid allegations of illegal drug confiscation by officers at the department. And today county officials appointed a special panel to review the department's overall management.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: EVERY diner has faced the situation at one time or another. You are sipping a cocktail and perusing the menu when a waiter comes over and says, ''I'd like to tell you about our specials this evening.'' He then begins a soliloquy that rambles on like ''The Canterbury Tales,'' detailing this dish and that, as your eyes glaze over and your memory board short-circuits from the overload.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.2 million for the quarter and $2,380,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: Monteverdi 'Vespro'
description: Monteverdi's ''Vespro Della Beata Vergine'' will be performed at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, Sunday at 8 P.M. Dennis Keene will conduct a 40-voice chorus and an orchestra of 22 players, including members of the New York Cornet and Sacbut Ensemble. The concert is free, but donations will be accepted. Information: (212) 254-8553.

title: When Sex Discrimination Causes Job Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: LILCO REGISTERS $525 MILLION ISSUE
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $525 million of bonds in April, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: Protecting, Not Endorsing Homosexuals
description: The heated debate about amending New York City's anti-discrimination law to protect homosexuals turns, finally, on one main issue. The opponents, led by the Catholic Archdiocese and orthodox Jewish groups, believe the bill confers governmental sanction on a life style they hold to be immoral. Our contrary view thus bears repeating as the City Council approaches next week's vote.

title: SKYSCRAPER TOUR
description: A walk past the skyscrapers of mid-town is planned Sunday morning by the 92d Street Y. The walk, led by David Hupert, a city planner, will begin at 11 A.M. with a visit to the A.T.& T. building, at Madison Avenue and 55th Street. Other stops on the tour will be the I.B.M. and Equitable buildings and the Parker-Meridien Hotel. The fee is $10. Reservations are required: 831-8603

title: KOCH, IN TALK AT LAW SCHOOL, CRITICIZES NEWS COVERAGE OF CORRUPTION SCANDAL
description: The question from the law student to Mayor Koch was brief and polite: If he knew back when he was in law school what he knows now, would he have gone into politics?

title: 2 IN A SEX CASE MAY BE VICTIMS, BROWN U. SAYS
description: Brown University officials said today that there were no plans to discipline students implicated in a prostitution ring, saying the university regarded the women as ''possible victims, not criminals.''

title: A L LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the retroactive effect of a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in August 1985.

title: ISLANDERS WIN ON BOSSY GOAL
description: Even Mike Bossy, the man who won the game, was unenthusiastic about the way the Islanders went about their work tonight at the Civic Center, where they squeaked past the Hartford Whalers, 3-2, in the final moments.

title: Bridge; Champion Who Challenged Domination by East Coast
description: An era in American bridge history ended this week when Lew Mathe died in California at the age of 70. After World War II, using simple, direct bidding methods, he led the West Coast challenge to the traditional domination by New York and Philadelphia experts.

title: 'Benny Goodman' Special On Channel 13 Tomorrow
description: For Benny Goodman nostalgiacs, the two-hour fund-raising program called ''Benny Goodman - Let's Dance'' on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. tomorrow can rouse some satisfying memories. The contemporary band that Mr. Goodman leads through several of his earliest hits, including ''Don't Be That Way,'' ''King Porter Stomp,'' ''Down South Camp Meetin' '' and ''Stealin' Apples'' - all of them arrangements by Fletcher Henderson to whom Mr. Goodman dedicates the program - has the smooth, relaxed flow that was characteristic of the Goodman band, particularly in the warm, singing ensembles by the saxophone section.

title: Chairman Rebuilding Former Daon Corp.
description: Four years ago the Daon Development Corporation teetered on the edge of bankruptcy. Today the Vancouver-based real estate developer has a financial sugar daddy, a new corporate name and a renewed claim as one of Canada's hottest property developers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday 'COUNTESS' IN BROOKLYN The New Theater of Brooklyn opened a new production in its new home this week with ''Countess Mitzi,'' a portrait of love in turn-of-the-century Vienna by the Austrian playwright Arthur Schnitzler. Cynthia Lammel stars as Countess Mitzi, with Neal Randell as the Count and David Reinhardsen as the Prince. Weekend performances are today and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 at 465 Dean Street, off Flatbush Avenue. Tickets are $8. Information: (718) 230-3366.

title: BONDS UP; 1-YEAR BILL AT 6.61%
description: Bond prices moved erratically yesterday, falling during the morning, but then rising sharply in the afternoon as prices of energy futures contracts declined.

title: F.A.A. SAID TO PLAN FINE OF EASTERN
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has begun action to levy a record multimillion-dollar fine against Eastern Airlines for violating safety rules, agency officials say.

title: If There's a Nuclear Disaster, Who Pays?
description: Indian citizens injured in the Bhopal disaster in December 1984 have yet to receive a cent of compensation; their Government's case awaits trial in American courts. When Pennsylvanians had to evacuate after the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island in 1979, however, emergency payments started within 24 hours. Why the difference? Because the liability insurance of nuclear plants is governed by a special law. But Congress should renew that law, the Price-Anderson Act, which expires next year, because the alternative is a lot worse.

title: DOMENICI PROPOSES BUDGET THAT REJECTS REAGAN AIMS
description: Rejecting President Reagan's priorities, the Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee today proposed a 1987 budget that gives the military an increase only to make up for inflation and includes $16.2 billion in revenue increases.

title: Ellis Island Conference Center, for New Ideas for the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN SPACECRAFT GRAZES COMET
description: The European spacecraft Giotto, badly battered but still surviving man's last, bold attempt in this century to unlock the secrets of Halley's comet, plunged to within 335 miles of the the comet's icy nucleus this morning.

title: ...And No Way To Treat Refugees
description: A dedication ceremony will be held next week in the small town of Oakdale, in central Louisiana. The subject will be immigration. The ceremony is not, however, a preview of the national rededication of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island scheduled for July 4. Rather, it is to commemorate the opening of the largest immigration detention center in the country.

title: BRITISH TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent American Depositary Shares. Each ADS represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: HOW'S this for a plot? Take a 22-year-old man working as a store detective in Connecticut because he has pulverized his vocal cords touring the South as a blues singer and musician. Now, warned by a doctor that he risks throat cancer if he continues to sing, he's hoping to earn enough money to go to film school at New York University - a return to his childhood love of writing and movie making.

title: TWO BIG BANKS CUT LOAN RATES
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Marine Midland Bank said yesterday that in response to the lower interest rate environment they were reducing interest charged on a wide range of consumer loans.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN PALME KILLING
description: The police announced today that they had arrested a man in connection with the investigation of the assassination of Prime Minister Olof Palme, but the suspect was not immediately charged.

title: MILITARY FAULTED ON EQUIPMENT LOSS
description: Because of chronic flaws in military bookkeeping and management, the armed services have no idea how much military equipment is stolen or lost, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: BOARD OF EL MUSEO VOTES TO DISMISS DIRECTOR
description: The Board of Trustees of El Museo del Barrio voted overwhelmingly last night to dismiss the museum's executive director, Jack Agueros. The move by the trustees follows a dispute over the administration of El Museo that began last November, when the city's Department of Cultural Affairs halted funds to El Museo amid charges of financial mismanagment.

title: Republicans Set Date For 1988 Convention
description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the Republican national chairman, today set the Republican Party's 1988 national convention for Aug. 15-18.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:50 A.M. today and set at 1:11 P.M. On Saturday it will rise at 3:46 A.M. and set at 1:02 P.M.

title: THE SCREEN: WALTER HILL'S 'CROSSROADS'
description: JOE SENECA turns in such a solid performance as an old blues hand in ''Crossroads'' that when he is on screen, the movie seems to settle in around him and you can almost overlook the trite goings-on. Almost. Despite Mr. Seneca, some good blues numbers and a few evocative glimpses of the Deep South in the 1930's, ''Crossroads,'' which opens today at the U.A. Twin and other theaters, tries to travel down two or three roads at once and winds up at mighty familiar places.

title: A Rembrandt Reported Slashed in Leningrad
description: A Soviet newspaper has reported that a Rembrandt painting was slashed twice with a knife and had acid thrown on it last year.

title: PACKWOOD PUTS TAX CUT FOR INDIVIDUALS AT 8.4%
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, proposed a revision of the Federal tax system today that would provide an income tax cut for individuals averaging 8.4 percent, to be paid for by a sharp increase in corporate income taxes and excise taxes.

title: Kirov Ballet to Tour In U.S. This Summer
description: The White House and the Soviet Embassy announced today that the Kirov Ballet would perform this summer in Washington, Philadelphia and Los Angeles as a result of the cultural agreement reached last November by the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: SHUTTLE RECORDERS AND COMPUTERS REPORTED FOUND
description: Divers have recovered all four flight recorders and some of the five computers aboard the space shuttle Challenger, sources close to the disaster investigation said tonight.

title: KNOWING THE SCORE: WHAT'S WHERE IN MUSICAL NEW YORK
description: NEW YORK has been the musical capital of the world since the end of World War II, when an infusion of European immigrants joined the talent already here and transformed the city's cultural life.

title: COCAINE RING IS BROKEN UP IN BROOKLYN AND S.I. RAIDS
description: A ''sophisticated'' organization of cocaine distributors that included two New York City police officers and 13 other present and former city employees was broken up in a series of raids Wednesday night and yesterday, the authorities said.

title: ALEX KATZ AND THE ART THAT CONCEALS ITS ART
description: BY my count, Alex Katz has had nine exhibitions in Manhattan during the last eight years, not to mention a great many elsewhere. Add to that his incisive presence on the local scene, the laconic wit and ''Thin Man'' style that he brings to any public appearance and his convivial way with both letter and postcard, and we are left with one of the most visible of living American painters, Yet it would be a great mistake to suppose that his retrospective exhibition at the Whitney Museum, which can be seen through June 15, is ''the mixture as before.'' It may make precisely the initial impact that we expect - one of a world in which everyone has nice clothes and is having a good time. Nobody fights, gets sick or goes hungry in a Katz. If, exceptionally, it rains, a king-size umbrella with the prettiest blue lining stands waiting to be unfurled.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Wilson and Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: BALDI'S ELIGIBILITY IN QUESTION
description: Officials at St. John's said tonight that the National Collegiate Athletic Association was conducting an inquiry that could result in Marco Baldi, the Redmen's freshman backup center, being declared ineligible to play in the national tournament.

title: THEY WHO BEG TO DIFFER ON AID TO NICARAGUA
description: They have formed a human cross on the steps of the Capitol and covered the Congress with position papers. They have lobbied and demonstrated, issued sober reports and made passionate appeals to morality.

title: SPECIAL TAXI MEDALLIONS STILL MISSING A YEAR AFTER TEST ENDED, AUDIT FINDS
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission was unable to account until last week for scores of taxi medallions issued under an experimental program that was supposed to have ended more than a year ago, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: CBS EXPECTING PROFIT IN PERIOD
description: CBS Inc. said that it expected to earn between 25 cents and 50 cents a share in the first quarter, surprising Wall Street analysts who had been projecting that it would lose as much as 50 cents a share.

title: RACE ISSUES KEY TO JUDICIAL NOMINEE
description: The nomination of a United States Attorney in Mobile, Ala., to be a Federal district judge became entangled today in a fierce debate over the nominee's attitudes toward black people.

title: MAKING THE CAPITAL LAUGH
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos takes over Hawaii. Richard M. Nixon retakes the White House. Ted Turner takes over an airplane when he can't take over anything else.

title: MOSCOW AGAIN EXTENDS A-TEST HALT
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union was extending its halt on nuclear testing for as long as the United States held off from now on. The Soviet test halt was to have expired March 31.

title: New Guidelines Issued On Exposure to Solvent
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has issued new guidelines to reduce workplace exposure to methylene chloride, a widely used solvent shown to cause liver, lung and blood cancers in laboratory mice and listed by the Government as a probable human carcinogen.

title: SICILY'S JUDICIAL LEGACY TO NEW YORK
description: In the rocky hills of western Sicily, the little town of Santa Margherita di Belice - St. Margaret the Blessed -is known for wine, olive oil and the poverty of its hardscrabble farming. In New York, it is known for judges. Legal scholars and lawyers say that for reasons bound up in both the cultural environment in western Sicily and the immigrant experience in New York in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, law became something of a cottage industry and a generally shared dream among Santa Margherita's immigrants and their descendants.

title: DRUG FOUND TO GIVE PATIENTS WITH AIDS SHORT-TERM HELP
description: An experimental anti-AIDS drug has bolstered the immune systems in 15 of the first 19 patients to receive it and has produced short-term improvement in some of their symptoms, but it does not cure the disease, according to a medical journal report.

title: IN LYONS, 2 CONNOISSEURS SERVE UP THREE-STAR ELECTION FARE
description: They say that to be elected to office from this pastel-colored capital of French cuisine you have to appreciate the virtues of good sausage.

title: When Sex Discrimination Causes Job Differences
description: To the Editor:

title: Manes Case: a Chronology
description: Following is a short history of the events leading up to the death of Donald R. Manes:

title: SOME BOND RESTRICTIONS POSTPONED
description: In a first attempt to ease some of the uncertainty surrounding tax-revision legislation, Congressional tax writers and the Administration reached an agreement today on postponing the effective date of some of the proposed restrictions on tax-exempt bonds issued by state and city governments.

title: TV: SIDNEY SHELDON'S 'IF TOMORROW COMES'
description: Here is one possible scenario. Sitting around pool side at the hotel, a bunch of Hollywood sitcom writers decide to amuse themselves by concocting the silliest mini-series plot they can imagine. Falling about with laughter, they turn to an unsmiling gentleman nearby and shout, ''Sidney, take it, it's yours, make a million.''

title: BEER PRICES UP SINCE BOTTLE LAW
description: MAJOR brands of beer sold in New York State have increased by more than 60 cents a six-pack since the state's bottle deposit law took effect in September 1983, according to the State Consumer Protection Board.

title: No Nerves Now
description: If there was a team in this year's N.C.A.A. basketball championship that seemed most vulnerable to tournament jitters, it had to be Cleveland State. The 14th-seeded Vikings not only drew No. 3 Indiana for their first-ever game in the N.C.A.A. tourney, but also had to contend with the cavernous Carrier Dome.

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $12.3 million writedown of foreign properties and loss on sale of investment in High Plains Oil Corp. c-After a special gain of $12.6 million.

title: Treasury Rates Are Mixed
description: Interest rates on Treasury issues due in five years or less fell slightly yesterday, while rates for long-term issues moved higher in volatile trading.

title: OPERA: U.S. PREMIERE OF SMETANA'S 'LIBUSE'
description: When Smetana's ''Libuse,'' the work that was destined to become Czechoslavakia's national opera, was being written between 1869 and 1872, European music was in the grip of Wagner fever. The ''Ring'' had yet to be produced, but such earlier works as ''Tannhauser,'' ''Lohengrin'' and ''Der Meistersinger'' were already in the bloodstream of almost every composer. Certainly one can hear many Wagnerian influences in ''Libuse,'' which apparently had its first American performance Thursday night at Carnegie Hall under Eve Queler's baton. Again and again one could hear familiar Wagnerian chord progressions, turns of phrase and motivic allusions.

title: Philippe Guibourge, French Designer, Dies
description: Philippe Guibourge, the French fashion designer who created the House of Chanel's first ready-to-wear line, died of chronic hepatitis March 7 in Paris. He was 54 years old. Mr. Guibourge introduced the collection in 1977, six years after Coco Chanel's death.

title: Iowa Near Record 9th Title
description: Jim Heffernan pinned Clemson's Joey McKenna in 4 minutes 55 seconds, and five of his Iowa teammates also won in today's semifinal round of the N.C.A.A. wrestling championships.

title: Operating Net Up at Cargill
description: CHICAGO, March 14 -

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $871,000. c-After a losss from discontinued operations of $256,000.

title: U.S. Official Urges Changes by Pretoria
description: An American official, declaring that this is a ''year of testing,'' urged South Africa today to move quickly to dismantle apartheid.

title: ECONOMY UP AS FRENCH VOTE
description: After five years of Socialist rule, France is approaching Sunday's parliamentary elections with a stronger economy and a firmer attachment to capitalist values than at any time since the left came to power, and perhaps before.

title: U S TRUCK LINES INC OF DELAWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A Los Angeles dispatch on Feb. 26 about the gubernatorial candidacy of Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles characterized him incorrectly. He was not the first black American elected mayor of a major city with a white majority; Carl B. Stokes achieved that record in Cleveland in 1967.

title: KENTUCKY OFFICIALS ARRESTED
description: After a three-year investigation into corruption and drug smuggling, agents of Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested a former State Police Commissioner, a state judge, a former gubernatorial candidate, a county executive, a sheriff and seven others.

title: THE CASE FOR BRIBERY
description: I asked a New York city politician how to handle Nicaragua. He couldn't place Nicaragua at first. Was it somebody in the Sanitation Department who had been indicted?

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a net credit of $58,071 due to tax forgiveness of a DISC subsidiary. Share earnings and shares outstanding results reflect 20 percent stock dividend which was payable April 17, 1984 and from the 25 percent stock split made payable Sept. 20, 1985.

title: Missing Money Cited At Children's Agency
description: A city investigation has found embezzlement and has indicated missing funds at a private children's agency in Harlem that has a contract with the Human Resources Administration.

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIGH PHILIPPINE COMMUNIST SEES LITTLE CHANCE FOR A LASTING PEACE
description: The Communist Party of the Philippines, which has been waging an increasingly successful guerrilla war, does not expect success from any peace talks that may be held with the new Government, a senior Communist official said today.

title: Chevron Seeks Employee Cuts
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that its chairman, George Keller, had asked management for reports due April 15 indicating how they could reduce their staffs by 10 to 15 percent. The announcement, which came in a letter to employees, followed the news that Chevron would cut its 1986 capital spending and exploration budget by 30 percent in response to falling prices for petroleum products.

title: Cornell, Clarkson in Final
description: Yale attacked but Cornell won. A goal by Duanne Moeser for the Big Red in the second overtime period decided the first semifinal game of the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey tournament tonight at the Boston Garden.

title: U.S. WEIGHS DEAL ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: White House officials said today that with the possibility of a House defeat of President Reagan's aid request for Nicaraguan insurgents, Mr. Reagan was now prepared to compromise on how and when the assistance from the United States is provided.

title: DEATH OF A GIRL LEADS TO INQUIRY ON PARAMEDICS
description: Investigators are studying allegations that a 10-year-old Brooklyn girl with heart disease died after city paramedics refused to climb stairs to her family's 12th-floor apartment at a Coney Island housing project.

title: Bulls Activate Jordan
description: Despite expressing misgivings earlier in the week, the Chicago Bulls yesterday activated the guard Michael Jordan after a four-and-a-half month layoff because of a broken bone in his foot, a team spokesman said. To make room for Jordan, Chicago placed the center Jawaan Oldham on injured reserve, said Tim Hallam, the spokesman.

title: ROCKETS CUT LUCAS AFTER DRUG TEST
description: The point guard John Lucas was released today by the Houston Rockets after failing a drug test and has entered a drug treatment program at a hospital in California, the team announced.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: DASHED AMBITIONS UNDERLIE A CLASSIC PORTRAIT OF SUICIDE
description: In many ways, Donald R. Manes matched a classic portrait of one type of suicide victim.

title: Protestant Churches Join Vote Call in South Korea
description: A group of major Protestant churches accused the military-backed Government today of ''utter disregard'' for basic rights and declared its support for constitutional changes demanded by the political opposition.

title: FIRST CAPITAL HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GEORGE HANFMANN, ARCHEOLOGIST AT HARVARD
description: George M. A. Hanfmann, the John E. Hudson Professor of Archeology Emeritus at Harvard University who was a distinguished scholar, author and curator, died of a heart attack Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: Gifted
description: Because the Smithsonian Institution's National Zoological Park has done such a good job in the breeding of the endangered golden lion tamarin, using a computer to match them up genetically, a shipment of 10 rarer-still golden-headed lion tamarins are expected to arrive at the zoo today. Zoo officials believe this will be the first time that this small monkey, with a golden head and a black body, has been kept in an American zoo.

title: THE U.S. AND DICTATORS
description: In announcing a foreign policy framework today that commits the United States to ''democratic revolution'' around the world, President Reagan offered a rationale for his efforts to obtain aid from Congress for rebels in Nicaragua.

title: LYNDEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Antiques Auction
description: An antiques and collectibles auction to benefit three historic Queens buildings will be held today at 6 P.M. at the Bowne Street Community Church, 143-11 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing.

title: A New Kennedy Makes A Good Impression
description: By her count, 105 people crowded into Nadine B. Hack's apartment at 920 Fifth Avenue, near 73d Street, the other evening for a private reception to raise funds for Kathleen Kennedy Townsend's campaign to become a United States Representative from Maryland.

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: TIBET FOR THE TIBETANS, NOT THE CHINESE
description: Each March, in sad rituals that go largely unnoticed outside the scattered cities and towns that serve as hosts to small numbers of Tibetan refugees, those Tibetans commemorate the day in 1959 when they rose up against the Chinese annexation of Tibet. On March 10, refugees stage small demonstrations, short marches and in some places a quiet presentation of petitions to local officials of the People's Republic of China. Then they peacefully go home.

title: U.S. WARNS IRANIANS ON THREATS TO OTHER NATIONS IN PERSIAN GULF
description: The United States warned Iran today that if it carried the war against Iraq into other Persian Gulf nations, such a move would be regarded as ''a major threat to U.S. interests.''

title: QUEENS CAMPAIGNERS RECALL THE IDEALISM OF '65
description: ''We were going to change the world,'' said Representative Gary L. Ackerman of Queens, recalling some heady days in the spring of 1965, when he and a flock of other idealistic young upstarts set out to elect Donald R. Manes - only 31 years old and their hero, nothing less - to the City Council.

title: TEXT OF THE REAGAN MESSAGE TO CONGRESS ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's message, titled ''Freedom, Regional Security and Global Peace,'' which was sent to Congress today:

title: KNICKS HANDED 6th STRAIGHT LOSS, 112-89
description: Kelly Tripucka scored 21 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons handed the Knicks their sixth consecutive loss, 112-89.

PATENTS;
Rotating Gun System For Armored Vehicle
description: A weapon system for an armored vehicle was patented this week for the General Motors Corporation.

title: DANCE: BY SALLIE WILSON
description: A man and woman, refugees from a masked ball, move about a dark plaza, find each other and fall in love. That is the premise of Sallie Wilson's ''Piazza San Marco,'' performed on Thursday in a program of dances by Miss Wilson and Ken Ludden at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: SHOREHAM PLANT HAS PROBLEMS, INSPECTORS SAY
description: Inspectors for the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission have found ''serious deficiencies'' in the performance and supervision of technicians who measure radioactivity at the Shoreham nuclear power plant, according to a report released tonight.

title: OPEC MINISTERS TO MEET AMID GROWING DISPUTE
description: This weekend's emergency session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva is expected to be dominated by a bitter dispute between Saudi Arabia, the group's most powerful and influential producer, and an alliance of African members supported by Iran.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $76,000 for the quarter and $217,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ohio State Advances, 65-62
description: Brad Sellers converted both ends of a one-and-one situation with 18 seconds remaining tonight, giving Ohio State a 65-62 victory over Ohio University in a first-round game of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: Two Canadian Experts Win Grand National Pairs Title
description: Two Canadian experts won the Grand National Pairs title here Thursday night, setting the stage for 10 days of play in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: MARTIN TO QUIT PANEL STUDYING CITY CONTRACTS
description: John S. Martin Jr., who was appointed by Mayor Koch less than two months ago to suggest ways to eliminate corruption in the awarding of city contracts, announced yesterday that he would resign because his commission had become redundant.

title: RECORDS REBUT REAGAN'S COMMENT ON HOW MARCOS MADE HIS MONEY, FILIPINO SAYS
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos's tax returns show that he was not a wealthy man before becoming President of the Philippines 20 years ago, the head of a Philippine Government commission said today.

title: Rangers Recall Allison
description: Mike Allison, a Ranger center who was sent down to New Haven on Dec. 28, has been recalled by the New York club after spending most of his minor league time on the injured list. Allison, who scored six goals and had six assists in New Haven, has not played since breaking his right wrist Jan. 18. He is expected to replace Tom Laidlaw tonight when the Rangers take on the Penguins in Pittsburgh; Laidlaw has back spasms.

title: 39.03 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,792.74
description: Another sharp rise in stock prices yesterday gave Wall Street its best and busiest week in history as investors, seeing inflation continuing to decline and sensing that interest rates would do the same, loaded their portfolios with equities.

description: b-Net loss

title: Semiramis Alia Is Dead a 58; Wife of the Albanian Leader
description: Semiramis Alia, the wife of the Albanian leader, Ramiz Alia, has died of a ''grave disease,'' the official Albanian press agency reported today.

title: Books of The Times; Design for Living
description: OBJECTS OF DESIRE. Design and Society From Wedgewood to IBM. By Adrian Forty. 272 illustrations. 260 pages. Pantheon Books $24.95. Why did the Montgomery Ward catalogue of 1895 offer customers a choice of 131 different pocket knives? Why were wireless sets concealed inside pieces of furniture - like cabinets, desks and even chairs - during the early days of radio? Why did white replace red and brown as the favorite color of decorators at the turn of the century? These are just a few of the questions the British scholar Andrian Forty proposes to address in his fascinating new study of design.

title: 2 Plane Crashes Kill 6 In Northern Michigan
description: Two planes crashed eight hours apart in dense fog that blanketed the northern part of Michigan's Lower Peninsula, killing six people and injuring six others, the authorities said today.

title: Turning the Tables On a Fund-Raiser
description: Arthur Krim has been a national Democratic fund-raiser for more than a quarter of a century. The Democratic National Committee plans to turn the tables on Mr. Krim and his wife, Mathilde, on April 14, honoring them at fund-raising event at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that has an impressive roster of sponsors and speakers.

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PIER 90 BLOSSOMS FOR PREVIEW PARTY
description: No decorations were needed for the party last night at the cavernous Pier 90 of the Passenger Ship Terminal -at least none beyond the profusions of orchids, primroses, tulips, daffodils, camellias, and hundreds of other blooms, shrubs and trees that covered a space the length of three football fields. The event was a celebration of the New York Flower Show and its theme, ''Garden Fantasies 1986.''

title: Cuomo and Koch Head List for Manes Funeral
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch head the list of dignitaries who are to attend the funeral tomorrow for Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President.

title: U.N PANEL URGES CHILE TO HALT RIGHTS ABUSES
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission, in a resolution, urged the military Government in Chile today to halt torture and other human rights abuses by the police and security forces and to re-establish ''democratic institutions.''

title: Robins Judge Stays on Case
description: United States District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. refused to disqualify himself yesterday from the A. H. Robins Company bankruptcy case, in which thousands of women are claiming damages for injuries they say was caused by the Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: What Housing Authority Does for the Homeless

title: PIANO: SERGEI EDELMANN
description: The pianist Sergei Edelmann was born to play Chopin Etudes. At his Thursday night concert at the 92d Street Y, Mr. Edelmann began with Opus 10, No. 1 and concluded with Opus 25, No. 12 - the first and last, respectively, of the two standard collections of Etudes - but in between he did some picking and choosing.

description: Sherman Kent, a former official of the Central Intelligence Agency who was an early member of its forerunner, the Office of Strategic Services, died Tuesday at his home. He was 82 years old.

title: CRIME GROUP FEUD ON GAMBLING SEEN
description: An increasingly violent conflict has broken out between the Luchese organized-crime family and New Jersey-based Cuban-emigre organizations over New York City's illegal numbers rackets, police and prosecutors said yesterday.

description: b-Net income.

title: MARYLAND RESCINDS 19-DAY BAN ON SALE OF GERBER PEACHES
description: Gov. Harry Hughes lifted a 19-day ban on the sale of Gerber strained peaches today, saying state investigators had determined that the reported findings of glass fragments in the baby food were not caused by manufacturing problems.

title: 2 YANKEE RELIEVERS COMPETE
description: They have so many similarities they could very well be one pitcher. If they were, the Yankees' relief picture would be in sharper focus.

description: Dressed in their cleanest clothes, poor people were bused today from their ramshackle reality to the presidential palace abandoned by Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: LeROY BOWSER
description: LeRoy Bowser, a regional vice president of the National Urban League and a member of the New York State Advisory Board on Human Rights, died of spinal cancer Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 57 years old and lived in Brooklyn Heights.

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings of Royal Dutch Petroleum Co.'s latest fourth quarter was $2.89 a share, compared with $2.48 a share for the year-earlier period. The latest year's results totaled $9.11 a share, against $11.14 a share for earlier year. The share earnings of Shell Transport were $1.65 for the latest quarter and $5.16 for 1985, against the year- earlier periods of $1.54 for the quarter and $6.82 for 1984.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REGGAE STEPS IN The first major feature film made in Jamaica by Jamaicans was Perry Henzell and Trevor D. Rhone's ''Harder They Come.'' In 1973 this movie introduced both Jimmy Cliff, the film's hero, and the Jamaican music form, reggae, to international audiences. In time, after making the customary cinematic rounds, it acquired the appellation ''cult film'' and could be seen for many months at a Manhattan movie house every Friday at midnight.

title: Helpful
description: The Consumer Federation of America has developed a rating system for members of Congress to gauge their support on issues deemed helpful to consumers. Last year, according to the federation, Democratic lawmakers managed a record high level of support, voting 67 percent of the time in favor of the consumer in the federation's view.

title: A CITY PAUSES TO REFLECT ON CLIMATE OF SUSPICION
description: On the city streets and in the corridors of government, the faces were solemn, the mood reflective. There was surprisingly little talk of disgrace. They spoke instead of sorrow and regret and sometimes of the finer qualities of the man who had somehow lost his way and was dead.

title: LEADERS TRAVEL TO STOCKHOLM FOR FUNERAL AND DIPLOMACY
description: Foreign leaders and delegations converged here today for the funeral of Olof Palme, the assassinated Prime Minister. The funeral promises to provide an occasion for high-level diplomatic contacts on subjects ranging from Soviet-American relations to southern Africa.

title: Nystrom Won't Return
description: Bobby Nystrom, the 12-year Islander veteran at right wing who has been sidelined for the last two months with an eye injury, will not return to the team this season, General Manager Bill Torrey announced yesterday. Torrey said that Nystrom, whose contract expires at the end of the season, would continue to join the team at practice and act as a coaching and scouting assistant to the club.

General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, twice suspended in the last year for questionable dealings with the military, was awarded $1.37 billion in Pentagon contracts today for jet fighters and a nuclear missile submarine. The Air Force awarded the St. Louis-based concern two contracts totaling $786.1 million to build F-16 jet fighters and the Navy awarded the company $587 million to begin work on America's 13th Trident ballistic missile submarine.

title: Texas Air Backed On Eastern Stake
description: The Transportation Department gave the Texas Air Corporation permission today to buy more Eastern Airlines stock, but said most of the shares must go into a voting trust until the Government decides whether the airlines can merge.

title: GROSSINGER'S, BOWING TO OLD CUSTOMERS, PLANS SPECIAL PASSOVER REOPENING
description: Grossinger's, the quintessential Catskills resort that was sold last fall to a group of investors, has been closed since Feb. 2 to ''stem further financial losses,'' lawyers for the resort said.

title: Jet Accord Is Reached By Air Force and Navy
description: The Air Force and Navy announced plans today to cooperate in developing a new generation of fighters and ground-attack jets for the 1990's.

title:
PATENTS;
Patent Aide Nominated
description: Donald W. Peterson, patent counsel for the Monsanto Company of St. Louis, has been nominated by the White House for the post of Deputy Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks, which has been vacant since last year. Approval by the Senate is required.

title: ALLEGED CONSPIRACIES IN THE 50'S AND NOW
description: President Reagan recently told journalists that those resisting his efforts to provide $100 million to the contras remind him of the participants in the Hollywood Communist fronts of the 1950's. To others who remember that period, the tactics of the President and his associates are also reminiscent of the struggle back then over what was, or who was or was not, ''un-American.''

title: Comedy Report
description: The Rangers' Pierre Larouche, who as a stand-up comic is a pretty good hockey player, issues a report after returning from a session of X-rays on his sore thumb: ''It's a T.W.A. injury. You know, an airline fracture.''

title: City Employee Found Hanged in Storeroom
description: A 53-year-old city worker was found hanged in a back room at Queens Borough Hall yesterday afternoon, an apparent suicide, the police reported.

title: A Rebellion in the Stacks
description: To thousands of citizen-scholars who since 1897 have burned the midnight candle under the magnificent dome of its main reading room, the Library of Congress is the library of the nation, arguably the largest and greatest library in the world.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,316,666 for the latest year and $12,633,110 for the earlier period.

title: Israel in the Jaws of Success
description: That rowdy noise from Israel is the sound of ambition exploding under the stress of impressive economic achievements.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G. CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend distributed in October 1985.

title: 300 Trapped as Hotel In Singapore Topples
description: A six-story hotel collapsed today, trapping 300 people in the rubble, the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation reported.

title: ACID RAIN STUDY SHOWS ITS HARM TO ENVIRONMENT
description: The National Academy of Sciences said today that it had found conclusive evidence that the burning of coal and other fossil fuels causes environmental damage. The finding was in a report on acid rain that the academy called ''the most comprehensive to date.''

title: FMC Challenge
description: The FMC Corporation said that a shareholder suit challenging the fairness of its recapitalization plan had been filed against the company. The complaint contended, among other things, that the plan would pay shareholders too little for their shares. FMC, a military contractor and chemical and machinery company, announced last month that public stock holders would recieve $70 in cash and one new common share for each share owned.

title: GOODMARK FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net loss

title: The Background; Smetana's Personal Favorite
description: Smetana conceived ''Libuse,'' the fourth of his nine operas, as a festival piece and a tribute to the Czech nation. Completed in 1872, it opened the National Theater of Prague in 1881.

title: DAVID HICKS, OPERA DIRECTOR, SINGER, TEACHER AND ADVISER
description: David Hicks, an opera director, singer and teacher who directed and restaged more than 35 works for the New York City Opera, died of Kaposi's sarcoma yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 48 years old and had been suffering from Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome since 1983.

title: MANES'S DEATH: A FRANTIC CALL, A FATAL THRUST
description: Moments before Donald R. Manes plunged a knife into his heart Thursday night, his wife, Marlene, had urgently telephoned his psychiatrist about admitting the former Borough President voluntarily to a mental hospital, Mr. Manes's lawyer and police officials said yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN CREDIBILITY ON MILITARY
description: Contending that the Reagan Administration is losing its credibility on national security and military policy, two leading Congressional Democrats predicted today that their party was poised to regain the political advantage on this key issue.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $160,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,360,000.

title: PEACE MARCH ORGANIZATION DISBANDS HASTILY
description: The corporation responsible for financing and organizing the ''Great Peace March,'' which was to take thousands of people on a 3,325-mile march for nuclear disarmament, disbanded today.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ST. JOHN'S STRUGGLES IN BEATING MONTANA STATE, 83-74 HEMPEL GETS 13 POINTS
description: St. John's played with out its No. 1 reserve player, Marco Baldi, tonight. But the Redmen weren't hurt by the absence of their 6-foot-11-inch freshman center as another substitute, John Hempel, played a major role in helping the Redmen moved into the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Iraqi Armed Forces Have Thrown Back Huge Iranian Offensives
description: To the Editor:

title: CONVAIR SAYS IT HAS REGAINED U.S. SECURITY RATING
description: A division of the General Dynamics Corporation that makes cruise missiles said today that the Defense Department had lifted the division's unsatisfactory security rating.

title: U.S. Trade Negotiator
description: Peter O. Murphy was named today to coordinate United States trade negotiations with Canada and Mexico.

title: Sprinklers
description: On Court Street near Borough Hall in Brooklyn yesterday, 50 people milled around a house trailer that had been converted to look like a kitchen.

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year figures include a charge of about $1.5 million for inventory adjustments and a $500,000 increase in reserves for doubtful accounts.

title: FRENCH CAMPAIGN COMES TO A CLOSE
description: The campaign for the legislative elections, depicted here as one of the more important political contests in this country's history, came to an end today.

title: SPORTS SATURDAY
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Tampa, Fla., 1 P.M. (Radio -WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. University of Florida, exhibition at Gainesville, Fla., 2:30 P.M. Atlanta Braves vs. Baltimore Orioles, exhibition at Miami (Television - WTBS, 1:35 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 7 P.M.) Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 11:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Second Round: East Regional quarterfinals, at Greensboro, N.C. Duke vs. Old Dominion. (Television - Channel 2, 2:15 P.M) Midwest Regional quarterfinals, at Dayton, Ohio: Georgetown vs. Michigan State. (Television -Channel 2, noon.) Southeast Regional quarterfinals, at Baton Rouge, La. Georgia Tech vs. Villanova. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) High Schools: Public Schools Athletic League championships, at St. John's University, Utopia Parkway and Union Turnpike, Jamaica, Queens. Boys Class B - Campus vs. Graphic Arts, 11 A.M. Girls: James Madison vs. Murry Bergtraum, 1 P.M. and Boys Class A: Manhattan Center vs. Abraham Lincoln, 3 P.M. Fencing National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association Championships, at Hunter College Sportsplex, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, 9 A.M. The women of St. John's have won the title two years in a row and are back to defend it. Hockey Islanders vs. Devils, at Nassau Coliseum, 7:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio -WOR 710, WMCA 570, 7 P.M.) Rangers vs. Penguins, at Pittsburgh, 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Wrestling N.C.A.A. Championships, at University of Iowa, Iowa City.

title: SALSAS: EASY AND VERSATILE
description: This is an auspicious time to let in a little light on the slightly mysterious world of salsas because cumin, coriander, tomatillos and chilies are replacing andouille, tasso and roux in the lexicon of New Yorkers who keep up with the latest trends in food. Southwestern food is superseding Cajun, and salsas are an integral part of Southwestern cuisine.

title: SUICIDE BY MANES SHIFTS THE FOCUS OF GRAFT INQUIRIES
description: Federal prosecutors began yesterday to reorganize their search for the inside information on municipal corruption that they had been pressuring Donald R. Manes to give them in the days before he killed himself.

title: AMERICAN ADVENTURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: OBSOLETE COMPUTERS MAY HOLD KEY TO SHUTTLE
description: The use of obsolete computer memory technology aboard the space shuttle Challenger may prove the key to recovering a trove of new information about the last seconds of the flight, experts said yesterday.

title: Production Down 0.6% Last Month
description: Industrial production plunged by six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the steepest decline since the end of the last recession, as oil and gas drilling activity fell sharply, the Government reported today.

title: RAINOUT SETS BACK MET PITCHING PLANS
description: The Mets were rained out today for the second time in five days, and suddenly found their pitching timetable jumbled with a long line of jobholders and jobseekers waiting their turn to take the mound.

title: RUTLEDGE HELPED BERRY COME HOME
description: When the news had been received, checked and double-checked, when Ron Rutledge had been told last Sunday morning that it was all right to pinch himself because his hope had become reality, he decided that this news could not wait.

title: HANOVER COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $596,000 for the quarter and $2,173,000 for the 9 months.

title: Consumer Rates Pared
description: Banks across the country are cutting their interest rates on a wide variety of consumer loans in response to the lower interest rate environment.

title: KURZWEIL MUSIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hand-Bell Festival
description: Church hymns and music by Handel and Widor will be performed tomorrow at 4 P.M. at the annual Riverside English Hand-Bell Festival, at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

title: Sukarno's Daughter Sentenced to Prison
description: The daughter of a former Indonesian president was sentenced to 14 years in prison today and fined $10,000 for misappropriating $5.5 million.

title: POLITICS: AN UPHILL FIGHT FOR FRENCHWOMEN
description: This may be a woman's city, as the adage goes, but politics in France is a man's world. Never has this been more obvious than in the 1986 legislative campaign, which ends Sunday.

title: ST. JOHN'S STRUGGLES IN BEATING MONTANA STATE, 83-74 CLEVELAND ST. UPSETS INDIANA
description: During his three seasons of coaching Cleveland State, Kevin Mackey created a team that he called ''off-Broadway guys; players who watch every game on the tubes and eat their hearts out waiting for their chance.''

title: TELESCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $122,900 for the quarter and year and tax credits of $453,000 and $494,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After income from discontinued operations of $222,945 for the quarter and year and tax credits of $344,000 and $1,318,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: WHERE EVERYTHING'S COMING UP ROSES
description: For the next nine days, the New York Flower Show will be in bloom. This year it has greater intimacy because visitors will be able to stroll through the exhibits as well as around them.

title: PARENT UNION ORDERS LOCAL TO END HORMEL STRIKE
description: Leaders of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union today ordered meatpackers in Austin, Minn., to abandon their bitter seven-month strike against Geo. A. Hormel & Company, but the leader of the strike vowed to continue the walkout.

title: SALT-SOAKED SHUTTLE TAPES MAY STILL BE PLAYABLE
description: Spokesmen for the companies that made the tape recorders recovered this week from the wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger said today that it was ''conceivable that there is retrievable data'' on the tapes, even though the recorders had been submerged in sea water for more than six weeks.

title: THE MODULE: BLUNT, PRACTICAL AND PERFECTLY DECENT
description: It has taken a long time, but there is finally a building type in New York that seems safe forever from the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Spain voted to remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. 2. It showed hospitals with mortality rates for Medicare patients that were significantly higher or lower than the national average.

title: COMBATING NEW YORK CORRUPTION
description: The revelations of corruption in New York City's government have stirred new momentum for reforming campaign financing. One popular proposal would limit the size of individual contributions to state and city races. That idea is a good one. By itself, however, it is not broad enough to resolve the basic problems of the current system.

title: DOLLAR GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 15, 1986

The results for the latest year are after a deduction of certain one-time expenses related to its merger with Reed Stenhouse Cos. and prior year figures are restated to reflect that merger in July.

title: ANIMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A Special Tour
description: ''He's very much alive here,'' Marion Javits said yesterday standing in the new Convention Center named after her husband, the late former Senator Jacob K. Javits. ''It's an extraordinary architectural statement.''

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ALLEN & CO. MAY BUY TICKETRON
description: The financially troubled Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating the sale of its Ticketron division to the Wall Street house of Allen & Company Inc.

title: Tainted Scout Cookies Spur Indiana Warning
description: The State Health Commissioner has warned against eating Girl Scout cookies following six reports that needles and glass had been found in some cookies.

title: NOTRE DAME IS SHOCKED, 90-83
description: The grandly named Trojans from Arkansas-Little Rock started out with their two dozen fans whooping and hollering. By game's end, most of the crowd in the Metrodome cheered each improbable Arkansas score as the Trojans advanced to the second round in the Midwest Regionals with a 90-83 upset over nationally ranked Notre Dame.

title: RELIANCE GROUP HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: U.S. AIDES SAY HOPE OF SUMMIT TALKS IN 1986 IS FADING
description: Senior Administration officials said today that time was running out on holding the next Soviet-American summit meeting this summer and that it was possible the meeting might not occur before late this year or early next.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on March 6 about the Occupational Safety and Health Administration misidentified the agency office under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. It is the area office in Philadelphia, not the regional office.

title: Milk Processors Will Fall One by One, Like the Beer Brewers
description: To the Editor:

DEFENSE RESTS IN TRIAL ON ALIENS WITHOUT QUESTIONING ITS WITNESS
description: After Government witnesses testified for three months about the smuggling of Central Americans into the United States, defense attorneys for 11 church workers rested their case today without questioning a single defense witness.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF DOUBTS ANTI-ARAB TERRORISTS CAUSED CAPITAL FIRE
description: A fire that destroyed a large portion of a Washington office building where the American Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee had its headquarters was apparently not aimed at the committee, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:46 A.M. today and set at 1:02 P.M. On Sunday it will rise at 3:42

title: Letter: On Pentagon Reform; Packard Panel Didn't Go Far Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Third Navy Exercise To Be Held Near Libya
description: The United States will hold its third naval exercise this year off the coast of Libya this weekend, but the exercise will be more limited than previous ones, Pentagon sources said today.

SECURITY AMERICAN FINANIAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUCCESS STORY IN A STEEL TOWN: SHARING PROFITS
description: About 6 A.M. today, when the sky was still black and the streets were blanketed with thick, wet fog, men began to gather at the pay shack of the Weirton Steel Corporation.

title: Dash Mark by Pitt Runner
description: Lee McRae of Pittsburgh ran a world best 5.99 in the 55-meter dash today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Indoor Track Championships, breaking the 6.02 mark set by Carl Lewis in 1983. McRae was first out of the blocks, and beat Sam Graddy of Tennessee, who ran a 6.02. In the preliminaries, Graddy had broken his own N.C.A.A. indoor meet mark with a time of 6.03.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: b-Net loss

The credit was partially offset by after-tax charges of $2.8 million relating to costs associated with the buyout of limited partners' interests in a farming partnership, of which a subsidiary of the company is the general partner, and the writeoff of the company 897 acre wine-grape development. c-Net loss Share earnings are adjusted for a 10-for-1 stock split effected March 10, 1986.

title: Columbia Crafts Sale
description: Contemporary American crafts, from glass to leather goods, will be sold this weekend at the fourth spring crafts market at Columbia University, Ferris Booth Hall, Broadway and 115th Street.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
MILITARY POLICY DEBATED BY 2 HARVARD ALUMNI
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Senator Edward M. Kennedy have often enlivened hearings on Capitol Hill with vigorous, sometimes testy exchanges over military policy and spending.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Rich Falk, who compiled a 76-145 record in eight years as the Northwestern basketball coach, was told that his contract would not be renewed but that he would be offered an administrative position.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income including income of $2,000,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Transit Strike Deadline Is Postponed to Sunday
description: The union for bus, trolley and subway drivers agreed tonight to extend until 6 P.M. Sunday a deadline for a mass transit strike that threatened to strand 400,000 city commuters.

title: TERRA MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $4.6 million writedown of deferred exploration and development costs and property acquisition costs.

title: SENATE APPROVES AN $18 BILLION PLAN TO CUT DEFICIT
description: The Republican-controlled Senate, making the latest move in a deficit dispute with the Democratic-controlled House, today approved a three-year, $18 billion deficit-reducing package.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
Pitt Players Disciplined
description: The University of Pittsburgh coach, Mike Gottfried, saying he has a ''responsibility to teach responsibility,'' disciplined two sophomore football players yesterday and waited for a judge's action on a third in separate cases, the university said. Jim O'Brien, a Pitt spokesman, said the players affected were Brian Davis, 21 years old, a running back from Washington, Pa.; Craig Heyward, 19, a running back from Passaic, N.J., and Tony Williams, 19, a wide receiver from Freedom, Pa.

title: STATEMENT ON DESPOTS IS PRAISED
description: Lawmakers from both parties today generally praised the Reagan Administration's foreign policy statement of opposition to dictatorships of the right as well as of the left. But most of them said it would not have a significant effect on the battle over the Administration's request to send $100 million in military and other aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Battle Grows In GATX Bid
description: The bidding war for the GATX Corporation intensified as one suitor said it had finished its due diligence review of the company and had offered $40 a share, while another said it was in the process of obtaining financing.

title: Spirit Peaks At Valley
description: Mississippi Valley State, the predominantly black little Delta school that has been struggling for its very survival against a budget squeeze within the Mississippi university system, cleared a significant hurdle last month when a proposal that it be shut down was killed before reaching the floor of the State Legislature. Hard times lie ahead, however, because the legislators, who must vote on appropriations for the 1986-87 school year before recessing April 6, are likely to cut funds to Valley by at least 30 percent, from $7 million this year to $4.8 million.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Peru May Resume Debt Payments
description: A senior Peruvian Government official told commercial bankers this week that Peru will soon make its first payments in nearly a year on some of the $450 million in overdue interest it owes foreign banks, banking sources said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Spacecraft Lifts Orbit Of Payload
description: A PATENT was granted this week to TRW Inc. of Redondo Beach, Calif., for a spacecraft to be used in conjunction with a re-usable space shuttle. The concept has no relation to the current operations of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration or to the recent explosion of the Challenger shuttle.

title: THE MAN WITH THE EEPHUS
description: The old ballplayer's once auburn hair and mustache have turned nearly all white, and he has got shorter. Once he stood 6 feet 1 1/2 inches, but now he's 6 feet tall. ''That's because of termites,'' Rip Sewell said, making a joke about his wooden legs. ''But I still play 18 holes of golf three times a week, and I've got a 16 handicap. When I was fitted for the wooden legs, the doctors thought I'd be able to get around better if I was a little shorter, and so it's been fine.''

title: Your Money; Tax Guides On Cassette
description: WILLIAM SPEER of Bangor, Me., uses an accountant to handle his annual tax returns. Nevertheless, when he heard about a videotape that shows individuals how to prepare their tax forms, he purchased it to play on his video cassette recorder.

title: Co-founder Sells More Apple Stock
description: Steven P. Jobs, co-founder and former chairman of Apple Computer Inc., has sold another 885,000 shares in the company. The sales occurred between Feb. 3 and Feb. 24 for prices from $22.79 to $25.25, according to reports of filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Jobs could not be reached for comment on the sale, and it was unclear how many shares he still owns.

title: Premature Promises?
description: Pat Kennedy, the Iona basketball coach since 1980 who has accepted an offer to take over at Florida State, was in Tallahassee yesterday, sporting a borrowed F.S.U. tie and making big promises for the future of the F.S.U. basketball team. Back at Iona, however, where Kennedy has two years remaining on a four-year contract, the school's athletic director, Rick Mazzuto, was suggesting that Kennedy's promises might be a bit premature.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $77,000 for the quarter, $279,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $22,000 for the quarter and year. The quarter result also is after an extraordinary charge of $4,000. The year result also includes a tax credit of $8,000. c-After capital gains of $165,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the year and tax credits of $21,000 for the quarter, $25,000 for the year.

title: Chile Is Unfazed by U.S.
description: The Chilean Foreign Minister said today that the country's ''enemies'' wanted to see the Government act ''desperate and precipitously'' in the face of the United States-sponsored resolution criticizing its human rights record.

title: A Nobel for Aquino
description: To the Editor:

title: EATON VANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ISRAEL PARTY TRIES TO REPAIR CHAOS
description: Herut Party officials scrambled to patch together their fragmenting right-wing party today after the collapse Thursday of its national convention.

title: BOMBER COST TO STAY SECRET DESPITE CONGRESS'S REQUESTS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger has decided not to disclose the cost of the radar-eluding Stealth bomber despite Congressional complaints that more information is needed to determine the fate of the multibillion-dollar project.

title: GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After a net reduction of $920,000 for the quarter and year to the prior year Van De Kamp's gain, and including a net gain of $8,259,000, or 30 cents a share, for the year, from selling 20 percent of the All American Gourmet Co. c-After a loss of $181,000 for the quarter from discontinued operations and including income of $39,675,000 for the year from discontinued operations. Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed March 3, 1986.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALDI OF ST. JOHN'S BANNED FOR TOURNEY
description: Marco Baldi, St. John's 6-foot-11-inch freshman backup center, has been declared ineligible for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and for a number of games next season, the school said today.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CUOMO IMAGE GAINS LUSTER
description: Three years after barely winning election as Governor, Mario M. Cuomo has emerged as so popular a figure that the Republican Party has had difficulty finding a candidate to challenge him, and he is talked about as a possible Presidential candidate.

title: SCULPTURE TURNS INTO POLITICS IN PARIS
description: With the dust hardly settled from a 1985 battle over installing a pyramid in front of the Louvre, Paris is embroiled in another furor over the Socialist Government's ''modernizing'' of a historic monument.

title: Abortion Is a MAn's Problem as Well as a Woman's; Augustinian Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Banking on Barber Conable
description: President Reagan has chosen well in nominating Barber Conable to head the World Bank. The former Republican Congressman from upstate New York offers high intelligence, political experience and solid respect on Capitol Hill, where the Treasury must soon seek more funds for the bank. He lacks a background in development aid, but so did all his predecessors.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRIANGLE HOME PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net income

title: F.A.A. LISTS VIOLATIONS CHARGED TO EASTERN, WHICH DENIES MOST
description: The Government yesterday issued a detailed list of safety violations it says Eastern Airlines committed, and the carrier angrily asserted that most were unfounded.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28

PATENTS;
Method for Tracing Origin of Blood in Urine
description: Cleve W. Laird, a biochemist, received patent 4,575,486 this week for International Remote Imaging Systems Inc., in Chatsworth, Calif., on a method of tracing the origin of blood calls in urine and assisting in the diagnosis of disorders. Blood cells from the kidney, coded with a special protein, are identified by applying antibodies.

title: Ewing Begins Therapy
description: Patrick Ewing, the rookie Knick center, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday for the removal of what was described as ''a piece of lining under the surface of the kneecap.'' Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team doctor, performed the surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Allene T. Plaut Is Dead at 83; Ex-Associate Editor of Vogue
description: Allene Talmey Plaut, a former associate editor and columnist at Vogue magazine, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: FORMER DIRECTOR OF THE BBC
description: Sir Huw Wheldon, former managing director of the British Broadcasting Corporation and former chairman of the council of governors of the London School of Economics, died Friday in London. He was 69 years old and lived in Richmond, Surrey, England.

title: ECUADOR REBELS ROUTED AND LEADER IS CAPTURED
description: About 2,000 soldiers, backed by tanks and artillery, today recaptured a Quito air base held by the former armed forces Chief of Staff, who had called for the overthrow of the President.

title: G.M. Allison Unit In Pratt Venture
description: The General Motors Corporation said that its Allison Gas Turbine division had formed a joint venture with the Pratt & Whitney unit of the United Technologies Corporation to develop propane engine and propulsion systems. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Allison Gas said a demonstration propulsion system would be produced for commercial and military transport markets in the 1990's.

title: MELRIDGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $856,156.

title: ART PANEL'S COMPLAINTS FORCE THE REDESIGN OF MINI-SCHOOLS
description: The Board of Education sees them as a quick and efficient solution to the problem of overcrowded schools. But to the city's Art Commission, the modular school units that have begun popping up in schoolyards are just plain ugly.

title: PUT MISS LIBERTY IN THE MET, TOO?
description: Since July 9, 1776, when New York patriots, on first hearing the Declaration of Independence, pulled down the statue of George III, public sculpture has had the power to move Americans. Now, another statue raises important public issues.

title: COMPUTER RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Files Waldheim Cited Are Reported Missing
description: Personnel documents that Kurt Waldheim had said would disprove charges that he once was a Nazi Brownshirt are missing from Foreign Ministry archives, a spokesman said today.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect the effect of the 5 percent stock dividend declared in February 1986.

title: DATA SHOW NUCLEUS OF HALLEY'S COMET BLACKER THAN COAL
description: Elated scientists at the European Space Agency said today that the spinning Giotto craft that streaked past the heart of Halley's comet early this morning revealed the comet's mysterious nucleus to be extremely dark, rough and irregular, and bigger than had been thought.

title: Five Performances of 'No, No, Nanette'
description: ''No, No Nanette,'' a hit musical from the 1920's with music by Vincent Youmans and lyrics by Otto Harbach and Irving Caesar, will be presented in five concert performances between April 2 and 6 at Carnegie Recital Hall. The cast includes Rebecca Luker, George Dvorsky, Judy Kaye, Cris Groenendaal, Robert Nichols, Jane Connell and Betsy Joslyn.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 15, 1986
description: The Economy

title: INFORMATION SCIENCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Includes a $2 million loss from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A BIG PAYDAY FOR WALL STREET
description: As the markets surge, Wall Street is reaping the biggest payday in memory.

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,841,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $4,793,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DR. EDWARD LEWIS, 84, EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Edward Shakespeare Lewis, an educator and former executive director of the Urban League of Greater New York, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Medical Center after complications from surgery. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: AT CLUB, DEMOCRATS COURT THE TRENDY
description: Gary Hart was doing an imitation of Billy Crystal doing an imitation of Fernando Lamas.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS IT HAS CRACKED A C.I.A. SPY RING
description: The security police have arrested three Nicaraguans who are accused of working to infiltrate the Interior Ministry under orders from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Death of a Politician
description: The suicide of Donald Manes completes the personal and political nightmare that burst into public consciousness in January, nine days after he was sworn to a new term as Queens Borough President. The mysteries that surfaced then, when he first tried to take his life, survive.

title: GENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. The national referendum in which this ballot was cast was a dramatic victory for Felipe Gonzalez, the country's Prime Minister. What country is it and what was the result of the vote? 2. A Federal agency released data on the nation's hospitals, arousing immediate criticism and debate. What did the data show and why was there controversy? 3. Despite the municipal corruption scandal that has shaken his administration since January, Mayor Koch's popularity remains near the highest level he has attained in public polls, according to a New York Times/ WCBS-TV survey. True or false? 4. John B. Sias cultivates an image counter to that of the urbane sophisticate projected by many of his peers, but beneath his practical jokes and joviality is a sober-minded businessman who intends to cut to the bone any fat in the company he has just been named to head. What company is it? 5. In one of the most computerized nations of the world, the Data Inspection Board has ordered the destruction of computer tapes containing 15,000 names. What nation is it and what was the reason? 6. A former American League second baseman and a former National League catcher were voted into the Hall of Fame by the Committee on Veterans. Who are they? 7. In his first formal move to insulate his appointments from political influence, Mayor Koch created a committee to seek out and screen potential appointees on city commissions and boards.

title: SUNRESORTS LTD reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,476,000 from 'business interruption proceeds and foreign currency transactions.' The results include tax credits of $1,554,000 for the latest year and $365,000 for the previous year.

title: January Inventories Up
description: Business inventories climbed by seven-tenths of 1 percent in January, the biggest increase in 16 months, while total business sales were dropping by three-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today The combination of falling sales and a rising backlog of unsold goods is normally a signal that future production and employment will weaken as businesses cut back on orders to work down inventories.

title: Smart
description: In the wake of the Senate's embarrassing rejection of Edward Curran last fall as head of the National Endowment for the Humanities, the White House has come up with a candidate regarded as bulletproof: Lynne Cheney, an editor of The Washingtonian magazine who has a Ph.D. in comparative literature and is the author of two novels and the wife of Representative Dick Cheney of Wyoming, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee.

title: LIFETIME COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $156,850. c-Net loss and includes a valuation reserve on real estate of $800,000.

title: BEIRUT TERRORISTS HOLDING 3 GIVE FRANCE A 'LAST CHANCE'
description: A radical Moslem group today gave France a ''last chance'' to meet its demands for the release of French hostages, and it released a videotape of three captives begging for an end to their ordeal.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $141,000 for the quarter and $3,376,000 for the year.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $177,000.

title: PRODUCER PRICES FALL RECORD 1.6% AND STOCKS SOAR
description: Tumbling oil and gasoline prices helped drive down the Producer Price Index by 1.6 percent in February, the biggest drop since this key inflation gauge was first calculated in 1947, the Labor Department reported today.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
John Grimm Wed To Miss Doolan
description: Talbott Chapman Doolan and John Robert Grimm were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ Congregational in West Hartford, Conn., by the Rev. Sidney Lovett.
