title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT DEVILS BY 3-1
description: On a regular basis, the Islanders seem compelled to create a touch of artificial pressure for themselves, as if they've deemed insufficient the challenge provided by their opponents.

title: 'POP' LIVED AND DIED BY HIS OWN SET OF RULES
description: POP had the last laugh; indeed, he would have enjoyed it hugely. He usually jollied everyone to his way, so why were we so surprised?

title: A WILD RIDE ON STORAGE TECH
description: Investors got a wild ride on the Storage Technology Corporation last week. Stock of the computer manufacturer, which has been under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since late 1984, rose as high as $7.38 on Tuesday before falling to $5.50.

title: A NAZI AT OLE MISS
description: ROMMEL AND THE REBEL By Lawrence Wells. 415 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. FIVE German Army officers, traveling under assumed names, arrive in New York in June 1937, on their way to Oxford, Miss., where an R.O.T.C. professor of tactics at the University of Mississippi is to explain to them the fighting methods of the Confederate General Nathan Bedford Forrest. German officers openly visited United States military sites and even attended American military schools before the war, but in his novel, ''Rommel and the Rebel,'' Lawrence Wells packs this delegation with three future field marshals: Erwin Rommel, who would become ''the desert fox''; Walter Model, who succeeded von Rundstedt as the commander in chief in the west; and Ferdinand Schorner, later to head three different army groups in Russia.

title: SOPHISTICATED ITALIAN IN SMITHTOWN
description: TO DISCOVER just how sophisticated Italian food has become, compare the menu at Casa Rustica in Smithtown with that of your local pizzeria take-out place. It's an evolution long overdue.

title: Route 4 Mall Paramus Filene's
description: Paramus, the mecca of malls in Bergen County, N.J., is gaining another. But what sets this new mall apart, the developer says, is the opening of New Jersey's first Filene's Basement, a large discount retailer.

title: THE VATICAN FINDS A FIGHT IN AMERICA
description: It is said that the three subjects that should never be broached in polite company are sex, religion and politics. Last week, all three combined with a vengeance in the Vatican.

title: REACHING OUT TO OTHER COUNTRIES
description: I am writing in response to Charlotte Libov's article, ''Communities Grow Closer to Their 'Sisters' Abroad'' [ Feb. 23 ] . The concept of outreach was magnificently illustrated and described. This is the kind of person-to-person activity that is a positive step in educating adults to the realities of living in a nation that is only part of a big world, and in a sense of reality that might help overcome the arrogance of power so implicit in the minds of so many Americans.

title: THE SCREEN: AGNIESZKA HOLLAND'S 'ANGRY HARVEST'
description: ''Angry Harvest'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times Sept. 30. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza 2, Broadway at 64th Street.

title: Susan Rosen to Wed Andrew Alisberg in August
description: The engagement of Susan Ellen Rosen to Andrew D. Alisberg has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Martin W. Rosen of Greenwich, Conn., and Palm Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned.

title: Rural Greenburgh Strip Yields to Housing
description: A BUCOLIC area in Greenburgh that until recently was used only by golfers, horse fanciers and campers is rapidly being given over to housing for the affluent, with houses priced at more than $500,000 and condominiums at more than $300,000.

title: TERRORISTS AND BEAUTY QUEENS
description: TOURIST SEASON By Carl Hiaasen. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. THE small puzzle Carl Hiaasen uses to lure one into ''Tourist Season'' fades away by page 80. By then it doesn't matter that we know who done it. What matters now is what is going to happen next to a very human (if slightly bizarre) cast of characters operating in a world that the author tilts a few degrees beyond reality. We're caught up in another remarkable example of what talented writers are doing these days with the mystery novel.

title: DANCE: INDIA'S INFLUENCE IN CAPONIGRO OFFERINGS
description: DANCES that are significant to their creators are not necessarily of equal significance to audiences unfamiliar with the philosophical views that inspired them. That was demonstrated Friday night when the Angela Caponigro Dance Ensemble appeared at the New Dance Alliance.

title: 'AIDA' AT THE MET
description: ''You're either Aida, or you're not,'' Anna Tomowa-Sintow said the other day. She was preparing for her first appearance in the role at the Metropolitan Opera and had been asked why there are so few singers suitable for the assignment in big opera houses nowadays.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'I SNOOP ON MY CHILDREN - HERE'S WHY'
description: If Linda Flayton can seriously compare her children's borrowing clothing from her without asking, to her sneaking about reading their diaries, she is dangerously misguided.

title: PANAMANIAN IS KILLED IN LABOR LAW PROTEST
description: Soldiers armed with M-16 rifles reinforced scores of riot policemen outside the National Assembly today after at least one person was killed and an undetermined number of people were hurt in anti-Government protests.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE perennial debate over paying for shore protection has spilled over into other environmental concerns.

title: PRIVATE JOBS SOUGHT FOR STATE'S INMATES
description: CONNECTICUT could become the first state in the Northeast to allow private industry to hire inmates and set up shop within prison walls, under legislation being proposed by the State Department of Corrections.

title:
ART;
BENDING PAPER INTO A COMPLEX MODERN MEDIUM
description: ONE of the great revolutions in 20th-century art has involved artists' materials.

title: CHANEL LOOK, OR LOOK-ALIKE
description: THERE is something quite special about the Chanel look: trim and understated, yet well defined, oh-so-chic and, these days, oh-so-imitated. Take a look around.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: BEAUX ARTS IN MADISON The Beaux Arts Trio, one of the world's most distinguished instrumental groups, will perform next Sunday afternoon in Madison.

title: CLOTHING HAS VINTAGE YEARS, TOO
description: Does vintage clothing experience the same caprices of fashion as contemporary apparel? Several recent auctions, and a perusal of several shops devoted to antique clothes, suggest that it does. Edwardian and Victorian clothing, which was the rage of the 1970's, now seems to be the stuff of very special occasions; garb of the 1920's through the 50's is of the moment for street wear.

title: WHY SO MANY ARE PRICED OUT OF THE MARKET
description: PROPERTY has long been an important ingredient in the stability of the nation's democratic system, and home ownership long a cornerstone of the American Dream, leading households to work harder, providing savings through equity and inspiring faith in free enterprise. But the opportunity to own a home, once available to the majority of families, has moved beyond the reach of many -particularly of young people seeking to buy homes for the first time, whose real incomes would have allowed them to do so in past generations.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 2 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 4 17 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 3 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 2 7 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 4 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 3 29 Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a small American town. 5 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 7 3 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned to them. 6 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 5 8 Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. 7 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 6 23 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 8 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. 10 3 (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 9 THE LEBARON SECRET, by Stephen Birmingham. 9 6 (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Love and conflict among the LeBarons, a wealthy family of California vintners. 10 CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Simon & Schuster, 11 23 $18.95.) The commotion that follows the reception of a signal from intelligent life beyond Earth. 11 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. 13 26 (Knopf, $16.95.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 12 STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor 12 6 House, $17.95.) The pursuit of a stolen crystal with curative powers climaxes atop St. Patrick's Cathedral. 13 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. 8 5 (Bernard Geis/Warner, $17.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates when a woman's art gallery is wrecked by an eerie explosion. 14 SECRETS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, 14 21 17.95.) Behind the scenes during the production of a blockbuster television series. 15 THE STORYTELLER, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & 9 Schuster, $17.95.) A poor boy from Brooklyn makes it big in the world of glamour as a writer. Nonfiction 1 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 1 5 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 2 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 2 72 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 3 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 3 36 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 4 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 4 5 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 5 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 1 House, $9.95.) A medical checkup at the Golden Years Clinic, in pictures and rhyme. 6 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 12 2 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 7 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 5 3 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 8 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. 7 25 (Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions of the past and future. 9 HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, 8 21 $17.95.) An account of the construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts. 10 NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and 1 Speed Vogel. (Putnam, $18.95.) The novelist's encounter with a nearly fatal disease told by Mr. Heller and his friend Mr. Vogel. 11 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 6 5 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 12 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 11 158 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse and drawings. 13 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES 9 23 KURALT, by Charles Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of people he's encountered while journeying around America. 14 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and 14 38 Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 15 THE FRINGES OF POWER, by John Colville. 10 5 Norton, $25.) The diary of the private secretary of three British prime ministers illuminates the career of Winston Churchill. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 30 Diamond. (Warner, $16.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 16 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 4 19 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 4 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 3 24 (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 5 EAT TO SUCCEED, by Robert Haas. (Rawson, 5 3 $15.95.) A nutritionist's regimen designed to achieve ''maximum performance in an active daily life.''

title: JAMES JONES'S DAUGHTER PICKS UP THE PEN
description: ''SOMETIMES I wish I had never written the book,'' Kaylie Jones said recently. ''I can't stand what people say. 'Oh! Following in your father's footsteps!' I think it's very stupid.''

title: Effort to Salvage Lost Steel Jobs
description: IN prosperous times the Bethlehem Steel Corporation smelting complex in Lackawanna, N.Y., employed 22,000 people, but when it closed in 1983, only 7,000 were still there. All but a handful were laid off.

title: SELF SPEAKS TO SELF
description: A DAY AT A TIME The Diary Literature of American Women From 1764 to the Present. Edited by Margo Culley. 341 pp. New York: The Feminist Press at the City University of New York. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95. THIS anthology of ''The Diary Literature of

title: THOUSANDS DEFY PRETORIA TO ATTEND FUNERAL FOR 7
description: Thousands of mourners at the funeral for seven blacks killed in a police raid shouted and sang support for the outlawed African National Congress today, defying official restrictions on the service and attacking the Government in speeches.

title: Catherine Linsly Indig Weds Gregory Bangs
description: Catherine Linsly Indig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Sanford Indig of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory Bernet Bangs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Bangs of Setauket, L.I. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin performed the ceremony at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., assisted by the Rev. David Schlaver, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: GEORGETOWN ELIMINATED BY MICHIGAN STATE, 80-68
description: Scott Skiles scored, passed and even helped to coach his Michigan State teammates to an 80-68 victory over Georgetown today in second-round play of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament at the University of Dayton.

title: NOT AGAIN, PLEASE
description: Exciting Facts I Wish I Didn't Know (1): At times of mortal stress, the engine of the human mind sometimes throws a rod.

title: THE RISKS OF A ONE-COMPANY SHOW
description: AT various times during the year, in 11 cities across the country, more than 60,000 corporate athletes huff and puff their way through a 3.5-mile road race sponsored by Manufacturers Hanover Trust. And in concert halls in 20 cities, audiences clap along to Barbara Mandrell, Alabama, and other performers in Philip Morris's Marlboro Country Music Festival.

title: Dorian Ho
description: The late-afternoon slot was filled by Dorian Ho, who comes from Taiwan and studied piano at the Juilliard School and in Vienna. She is now working for her doctorate at New York University and studying with Gregory Haimovsky.

title: REISLING FIRST IN WINE CONTEST
description: A 1984 white Reisling produced by Tewksbury Wine Cellars of Lebanon has won the Governor's Cup in the state's first wine competition.

title: A PRIMER FOR PROJECT MANAGEMENT
description: ONE of the most talked about areas in software today is project management. These programs use the computer's calculating prowess to schedule people and resources in any task, from planning a wedding to setting up a new office to launching a satellite. Whether they will find a place on the general user's shelf of programs, however, has yet to be determined.

title: TRUE ADVENTURE: Machu Picchu The Hard Way
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. And then there was the time I fell off the Inca terrace on the trail to Machu Picchu, proving that even with 30 Quechua Indians to carry the duffels, pitch the tents, cook dinner and play their wood flutes, you may get more than you had in mind when you bought your elegant hiking boots at Kreeger.

title: COMPLAINTS AT IONA
description: Pat Kennedy, the Iona basketball coach who on Thursday accepted an offer to take over the Florida State program, is apparently going to be released from his Iona contract, but not before Iona finishes raking him over the coals. The Iona president, Brother John Driscoll, yesterday renewed the complaint that Kennedy and Florida State had violated collegiate guidelines by not seeking Iona's permission before opening negotiations.

title: SUSHI AND SASHIMI IN GREENWICH
description: THE first time it was reviewed, some years ago, Kagetsu in Greenwich did not have a sushi bar. Two years ago, one was added, and it is a welcome addition, indeed.

title: ONE CONDUCTOR'S PRESCRIPTION FOR MUSICAL SURVIVAL
description: Many of my colleagues will agree with the diagnosis that ''today's orchestras are adrift'' in a sea of conflicting pressures, as an article in this paper suggested not long ago. The ailments may be more apparent now, but they have been part of the musical scene since at least the end of World War I. To separate various symptoms of the malaise it is necessary to distinguish between symphonic activity in Europe and in America. In this endeavor my limited credentials are: personal working acquaintance with 50 orchestras, of which 13 are located in the United States, 34 in Europe and the others in South America and Canada.

title: PANEL TO STUDY CHIEF EXAMINER IN CONNECTICUT
description: A panel of four out-of-state medical examiners and a retired state chief justice will begin an investigation Monday into the administration of the office of Connecticut's Chief Medical Examiner.

title: SOMETIME SPORTSMAN GREETS THE SPRING
description: When winter's glaze is lifted from the greens,

title: CAN FIDELITY MAINTAIN ITS FRENZIED GROWTH?
description: PAUL STUKA worries. As manager of the Fidelity Over-the-Counter Fund, one of the nation's fastest-growing mutual funds, he is handling an avalanche of cash. His fund had $162 million under management on Jan. 1. By February it had reached $300 million. Last week it passed the $460 million mark.

title: Fair Rents
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT CITES PILOT ERROR IN BLUE ANGELS CRASH
description: Pilot error caused a fatal mid-air collision of two Navy Blue Angels jets at an air show at Niagara Falls last summer, according to a report by Navy investigators.

title: MOST JERSEY DRINKING WATER PASSES STATE'S PURITY TESTING
description: Drinking water used by 93 percent of New Jersey residents is of excellent quality, the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Richard T. Dewling, said recently as he released the results of two rounds of statewide testing of water supplies.

title: INFANT SWIMMING CLASSES DEBATED
description: WHEN they first began on Long Island about a decade ago, swim programs for children under 3 years of age were hailed as a way to reduce drownings. Since young children are most vulnerable to water accidents, many of these programs were designed to give them the skills to survive long enough for help to arrive, including holding their breath under water.

title: CARDS SHED SCARS AND BRACE FOR CHALLENGE
description: If you think Whitey Herzog spent the winter cowering in a corner haunted by the memory of how his St. Louis Cardinals blew the World Series, forget it. And if you think Herzog is haunted this spring by the loss of Joaquin Andujar and those 21 victories, he wants you to forget that, too.

title: Meg Newhouse; Gallery Official, Plans to Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Mortimer Newhouse have announced the engagement of their daughter Meg Newhouse to Stuart Fordyce Kirkpatrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Bertine Kirkpatrick of Princeton, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: For Better or Worse, a Wife Sues Her Husband in Injury
description: A woman who sued her husband for negligence after she was injured on their snow-covered driveway has lost the suit but succeeded in overturning the legal idea that spouses cannot sue each other.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HANNIE RICHARDS. By Hilary Bailey. (Random House, $16.95.) Hannie Richards is a 34-year-old Englishwoman with a husband, two daughters and an old farm in Devon whose upkeep requires massive amounts of cash.

title: BACK ON THE TRACK
description: BREAK IN By Dick Francis. 317 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95. IT is ''winter and horses, the old song in the blood'' again for Dick Francis, whose last few books spooked some readers into thinking he had hung up his racing colors for good. Christmas (Kit) Fielding, the hero of Mr. Francis' 25th mystery adventure, is neither a computer systems analyst nor a banker nor an international kidnapping consultant nor a wine merchant - to identify the heroes of Nos. 21, 22, 23 and 24 respectively - but a bona fide professional steeplechase jockey. The man rides horses the way Mr. Francis' heroes used to before they began rooting in wine cellars and data banks. Furlong for furlong, ''Break In'' makes up in sheer track time for some of those lean years since ''Reflex.''

title: Katherine Weeks To Wed a Writer
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Robert Oliver Weeks of Jacksonville, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Anne Weeks to Stewart Hardison. A June 7 wedding is planned.

title: STRONG TECHNOLOGY, WEAK MUSIC
description: The other evening, after attending the New York premiere of Pierre Boulez's much-heralded ''Repons,'' I dozed off and fell to fantasizing. An artist named Ludwig van Beethoven, it seemed, had decided to compose several works for digital processor that would sum up his mature musical thoughts and take the electronic medium itself into areas of the imagination previously unexplored by man. Unfortunately, he discovered, the digital processor had not yet been invented. Beethoven decided, therefore, not to wait but to channel his genius into alternative media such as the string quartet, with results that somehow came to be regarded as satisfactory even though technically benighted.

title: HEEBIEJEEBIEVILLE EXPRESS
description: CHILDREN OF LIGHT By Robert Stone. 258 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95. ROBERT STONE is the apostle of strung out. People in his novels have reached the end of the tether: alone, desperate, scared, doing a lot of hard liquor and drugs, they hit the road. And as they go they keep listening in the dark, against all odds, for something that might be a moral channel marker, or love, or God, or just a way to get through the night.

title: Miss Wainwright Becomes a Bride
description: Diane Harvey Wainwright, a daughter of Jane Gray Wainwright of Cambridge, Mass., and William Harvey Wainwright of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Kevin Arthur Connolly, a son of Pauliana Quilty Connolly of West Hartford, Conn., and Walter Justin Connolly Jr., of North Granby, Conn., and Boston. The Rev. Joseph C. Gengras performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Victories Roman Catholic Church in Boston.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in the Sports section last Sunday quoted Keith Hernandez of the Mets as saying that Commissioner Peter Ueberroth had ''incorrectly categorized'' him as one who had facilitated other baseball players' use of cocaine. The article added that while Hernandez had admitted the use of cocaine, he denied having sold it or dealt in it.

title: July 12 Wedding For Mary Kurtz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Kurtz of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Patricia Kurtz to John McWilliams Stone 3d, a son of Mr. Stone of Wayne, Ill., and Hays Clemens Stone of Geneva, Ill. A July 12 wedding is planned.

title: SHORT LIVED GLORY
description: If there is one thing wrong with the contemporary tournament scene, it is that you can scarcely savor success anymore.

title: THE MYSTERIES OF AYERS ROCK
description: Australians have a habit of calling it simply The Rock. It becomes clear after a time what rock they are talking about - the vast single stone, larger than an island, that lies at Australia's heart and that until recent times was as infrequently visited by Europeans as Timbuktu or the South Pole. Since the late 19th century it has borne the name Ayers Rock, but for the Pitjantjatjara tribespeople and their kinsmen in the Great Western Desert it has another name, Uluru, a name of towering antiquity, a name from before the ice ages.

title: About Men; Businessman's Flight
description: WHEN I GET ON an airplane alone, I often feel as if the flight is, in many ways, comparable to six or seven hours in the Army. Traveling overseas or across the continent, I am surrounded almost exclusively by men who, like me, are separated from families and home territory. We have never met before, but we share a great deal. Although we all have our purposes, for the time being we are merely in a state of transition. We have identical accommodations. We are subject to the same bumps and delays.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT RETURNS HOME FOR VISIT
description: Smiling and waving to well-wishers, Murray Haydon, the recipient of an artificial heart, visited his home today for the first time in 13 months.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 'IS AMERICAN JUSTICE HERE?'
description: ON the St. John's bench today, Marco Baldi will be wearing the same pink credential marked ''participant'' round his neck that he had on Friday night. But it's as if that pink credential were a noose.

title: ANOTHER CAUSE, ANOTHER CONCERT FOR PETER, PAUL AND MARY
description: There are framed gold and platinum albums on the wall of Mary Travers's midtown office, reminders of the million-selling hits she sang as a member of Peter, Paul and Mary in the 1960's. Hanging next to them, however, are other kinds of citations - including, for instance, one from the Korean Institute for Human Rights. Twenty-five years after Miss Travers first sang with Peter Yarrow and Paul Stookey, the trio has been marking its anniversary with concerts for causes - standard operating procedure for the pop-folk singers who have played more than 300 benefits for causes and candidates in the past three years alone.

title: Vienna
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading the article ''What's Doing in Vienna (Travel, Jan. 26).

title: Talking: Closing Costs; 6% Outlay In Cash Is Common
description: ANYONE who is buying a home must be prepared to lay out a significant amount of cash to cover the incidentals - lawyers' fees, loan origination fees, title insurance and other charges - that commonly are called closing costs.

title: WIDESPREAD COMPLIANCE IN SUFFOLK
description: WHEN Lorraine Mitchell, a cigarette smoker for 22 years, wants to smoke at her job in Suffolk County, she's told to step outside - literally.

title: DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAS TEACHERS TOOK IT. NOW YOU CAN TEST CLASSROOM SKILLS
description: The desks were turned on 205,000 Texas teachers and administrators last week. They showed up at schools across the state, with sharpened No. 2 pencils, to take reading and writing tests mandated by a 1984 law. Teachers who fail - perhaps 5 percent, according to officials - will get a second chance in June. If they fail again, they will not be allowed to teach next year unless there is a teacher shortage in their district. (They can, however, continue to take the test until they pass.) ''The test will go a long way toward building the public's confidence in teachers,'' said a spokesman for the Texas Education Agency. But James Butler, executive director of the Texas State Teachers Association, warned, ''the state is going to lose a lot of qualified teachers.'' He cited as an example an automotive shop teacher who was praised by his principal despite a lack of English skills, a shortcoming that now puts his job in jeopardy.

title: IN HONG KONG: OF THE NEWEST, 10 OF THE BEST
description: Hong Kong is a city of ceaseless conspicuous wonders. It supports the world's biggest neon sign, the 328-foot-long Citizen watch sign atop Elizabeth House in Causeway Bay. It has the densest concentration of Rolls-Royces, 580, or one for just about every mile and a quarter of Hong Kong road, according to Asia Magazine. Its new stainless steel subway carries 1.2 million people a day over its 16-mile length. It has the world's longest escalator ride, a 700-foot moving stairway in its Ocean Park recreation center. Its Star Ferry boasts a 9-cent harbor ride. It is the largest exporter of clothing, watches and toys in the world.

title: DEEPEST TEXAS
description: Leaving Houston, less than an hour from the glass and plastic, the rush and hustle of the city, after you have crossed the Old and Lost rivers, the wide and wild green spaces begin, and the ancient water. Another half-hour and you can find yourself deep in the Big Thicket of East Texas, where the city is a dream, a rumor, a purposeless memory.

title: FOR AUBURN STAR, ACCLAIM IS MISSING
description: Perhaps if his body had matured before his senior year in high school, Chuck Person would have enrolled in college and played basketball in a place like Chapel Hill or Lexington and the all-America votes would have been cast in waves. Or maybe if he just kept getting larger, some opposing fans might have sent him a pizza at courtside and another Auburn University legend would have grown.

title: Bethlehem 1, Donahue 0
description: IT'S true. Phil Donahue has apologized to Bethlehem, Pa.

title: IMELDA'S NEW YORK STAND-IN: WHERE IS SHE NOW?
description: She is described as a demure, quiet-spoken woman who served Imelda Marcos in New York as a personal, confidential aide. What the new Philippine Government would like to know is where she is and exactly what it was she did.

title: 'RUSSELL OF THE APES' BATTLES TO SAVE WILDLIFE
description: ''IT'S an uphill battle in many cases,'' said Russell A. Mittermeier of Stony Brook and the world. ''You can't let the defeats and problems get you down.''

title: NEW ORLEANS AWAKENS TO NEED FOR CHANGE ON SCHOOLS, TAXES AND ECONMOMY
description: In the years when oil revenue and Federal grants flowed into the coffers of state and local governments, New Orleans paid 50 men to sweep the French Quarter each morning, brooming away the litter of good times the night before. Two of them did nothing but pry chewing gum from the streets.

title: TIMELY ELEGANCE
description: WE LIVE IN a time that contrasts vividly with the home-cooking customs of 20 years ago. Back then, we thought little of creating a recipe for a dish that we had dined on aboard the late, lamented S.S. France, specifically a chartreuse of partridge. As prepared in the kitchen of that elegant vessel, it was sublime, both to the eye and the palate.

title: Kim Alison Galton, Buyer, To Marry Gary Felsenthal
description: Kim Alison Galton and Gary Felsenthal, 1980 graduates of Ithaca College, plan to be married June 21, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Galton of Newton, Mass., have announced. Mr. Felsenthal is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Felsenthal of Woodmere, L.I.

title: Hilary Morton to Marry David Shontz
description: The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, and Mrs. Morton of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Hilary Morton to David Beard Shontz, a son of Col. Howard B. Shontz, United States Army, retired, and Mrs. Shontz of Kensington, Calif.

title: RONDO COMPANY CELEBRATES ITS 15TH
description: THE Rondo Dance Theater's celebratory weekend of performances at the State University of New York at Purchase on Friday marks the troupe's 15th anniversary, but the roots of the Bedford-based company reach back to 1956, when Elizabeth Rockwell opened her namesake school of dance.

title: WITH THE PARADES, A BLARNEY CONTEST
description: TODAY is the day that the green, with resounding fanfare, goes on parade throughout the state.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MASTERFUL ARTISTS Two major forces in 20th-century American art, Larry Rivers and Alice Neel, figure in exhibitions opening today. With ''Alice Neel: Paintings and Drawings,'' the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art in Roslyn Harbor offers a representative survey of the long and distinguished career of the realist painter, who died in 1984. Some 65 works on loan from Miss Neel's estate, her gallery and private and public collections illustrate, according to the show's curators, her ''bold, gutsy realistic style of painting'' that manifested itself primarily in her main subject, people. The show - augmented by a lecture by the noted critic-curator Henry Geldzahler on ''Alice Neel, an Artist Outside the Mainstream'' on April 8 - can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and from 1 to 5 P.M. weekends through May 18 at the museum, off Northern Boulevard.

title: 100 TRAPPED
description: A six-story hotel collapsed here Saturday, and hope faded today for about 100 people still thought to be missing under a huge mound of rubble, 15 hours after rescue operations began. Four people were confirmed dead. Nine injured people were pulled from the wreckage of the 67-room Hotel New World after it collapsed at 11:20 A.M. Saturday, said Lim Siam Kim, director of the Ministry of Home Affairs.

title: AT THE DAWN OF AN ERA OF LOW INTEREST RATES
description: A FEW years ago, with their children grown, Liz and Nelson Casmer bought a piece of land not far from their home in suburban Pittsburgh, planning to build a smaller house on it. But it was not until November, when interest rates made houses more affordable, that they found a buyer for the four-bedroom house they had owned for 22 years.

title: RICHARD SERRA'S RADICAL MESSAGE IS ROOTED IN TRADITION
description: The Richard Serra retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art through May 13 is one of the best sculpture shows in some time. It is not large in the number of works - there are only 10 sculptures in the show, plus a new site-specific installation in the sculpture garden, covering a 20-year period - but it is large in the physical space it takes up and in the ideas that bang and rattle through it. And, not surprisingly since its subject is the sculptor of ''Tilted Arc,'' it is also large in the feelings of devotion and hostility it induces.

title: DANCE: 'NATIVE GREEN,' BY MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: A CREAMY, frothy delight seemed about to unfold as the curtain rose on Merce Cunningham's ''Native Green,'' Friday at the City Center. But nothing is simple with that ranking simplicist of modern-dance choreographers. The world of ''Native Green'' is creamy and frothy and delightful. But it is also Mr. Cunningham at his most goofily mysterious.

title: NEW YORK WARNS OF WELL PUMPS WITH PCB'S
description: The State Department of Health is warning homeowners with private wells that their submersible water pumps might be a source of PCB contamination.

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: As one who experienced the rigors of freshman English with W. K. Wimsatt some 15 years ago, I was highly entertained by Colin Campbell's article.

title: William D. Briner And Miss Mansell Become Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Mansell of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jessica Lyman Mansell to William Drew Briner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Briner of Tahoe City, Calif. A July wedding is planned.

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: Colin Campbell's playful article portrays Yale's deconstructionists as rebels against the old New Criticism. Yet both schools avoid the truly revolutionary conclusions of reader-response critics.

title: NEW HOTELS SPROUTING, AND JUST IN MIDTOWN
description: USUALLY edgy New York real-estate developers are more tense than ever these days because of a rush to get into hotel deals. But some speak of the transactions in the conditional, got their plans have nt yet solidified to the point of yielding crystal chandeliers and red carpets.

title: A BELLEROSE 'TO RETURN TO'
description: It was with pleasure that I read Solomon R. Kunis's article ''3 Faces of Bellerose: Charms and Disputes'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 23 ] . I grew up and lived in Bellerose Terrace for 23 years and can well identify with Mr. Kunis's observations on my hometown.

title: CORNELL WINS TITLE IN E.C.A.C. HOCKEY
description: A goal by Chris Grenier at 8 minutes 26 seconds of overtime gave Cornell a 3-2 victory over Clarkson at the Boston Garden tonight in the final of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference hockey tournament.

title: FRENCH RIGHTISTS FAVORED BY POLLS IN VOTING TODAY
description: French voters elect a new Parliament on Sunday and, unless virtually all the opinion polls are wrong, a rightist coalition will gain a majority, ending five years of Socialist legislative rule.

title: TRUE ADVENTURE: A Sojourner In North Yemen
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. With the exception of a few adventurous French people, no one visits Yemen - North Yemen on the Arabian Peninsula - yet it is the most interesting place I've found on earth. (North Yemen, here called Yemen, is agreeable to American travelers; it is South Yemen where one Marxist faction recently ousted another.) I nearly perished of boredom in Rome, solely because I'd so recently seen Yemen, where the people were so civilized and the cities so beautiful. This conviction arose while I was in Yemen, although fat-tailed sheep walked in the village streets, and the buildings were partly mud, and the women wore black veils, and the men wore big, curved knives.

title: RAIN FALLS ON METS AND CARDS
description: After the rain came, wiping out the Mets for the third time in six days, John Tudor walked across the soaked field to the Mets' clubhouse in the red uniform of the St. Louis Cardinals. He started up the steps to the old-fashioned porch, and suddenly found his path blocked by the looming figure of Darryl Strawberry.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Spider Souffle Finding that Laotians ate giant water bugs, scorpions and spiders, the British entomologist W. F. Bristowe tried them. In ''Good to Eat'' (Simon & Schuster), Marvin Harris quotes Mr. Bristowe's reaction to this exotic diet.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'COCOON' AUTHOR Some years ago David Saperstein helped his in-laws settle into a retirement condominium in Delray Beach, Fla. ''We brought the grandchildren down to visit, and I spent many hours by the pool listening to other people's conversations,'' he said. ''It was amazing. Here were all these bright, active, healthy older people, bored to distraction. We as a nation were doing everything possible to make people healthier so that they can live longer, yet when they get to a certain age we shunt them off to places where we don't have to see them anymore.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SOME things, like death and taxes, seem inevitable, but the Rev. Robert Moore, a leading member of the Princeton-based Coalition for Nuclear Disarmament, says there is a right to withhold that part of Federal taxes used to build up and maintain nuclear weapons. He and other coalition members have been doing just that for four years.

title: NEW CASSETTES: HITCHOCK, HEIFETZ AND 'HARD BOP'
description: Heifetz Featuring Jascha Heifetz; with Brooks Smith, piano, and the French National Orchestra Video Arts International 63 minutes. $59.95 Jascha Heifetz lives quietly in California today, aged 85; yet, through a 15-year-old television program now committed to commercial cassette, the great violinist steps briefly out of the past.

title: NEW WAYS SOUGHT TO SAVE ANTIQUITIES
description: CONNECTICUT is rich in archeological heritage, but some state scholars are concerned that priceless pieces of antiquity are being needlessly destroyed for lack of a centralized way to handle them.

title: GROWING PROBLEM OF HOMELESS FAMILIES ATTRACTS NEW ATTENTION
description: THE problems of homeless families, which have largely taken a back seat to those of homeless single men and women, have suddenly leaped into the spotlight in Connecticut.

title: Mitchell-Lama
description: To the Editor:

title: A Judicial Ghetto For the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
The Comforts of Home in 2 Office Projects
description: LONG before Nathan L. Serota started building shopping centers and commercial structures, he was building houses.

title: RACER PLEADS GUILTY
description: Bill Whittington, the race car driver who was accused of heading a drug ring that smuggled 400,000 pounds of Colombian marijuana into the United States from 1977 to 1981, pleaded guilty to that and related tax-fraud charges after agreeing to a 15-year prison sentence and the forfeit of $7 million of his assets. The plea was entered in Federal court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., as the defendant's brother, Don Whittington, and an associate, Gary R. Levitz, the son of the founder of the Levitz furniture chain, pleaded guilty to lesser charges in exchange for 18-month sentences. All three were released on bail pending sentencing April 25.

title: TASSO WINS 1986 DEBUT
description: Tasso, last year's Eclipse Award-winning 2-year-old colt, made a successful return to competition yesterday when he scored a three-length victory in the $55,000 Manassa Mauler Stakes for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct.

title: COURT REJECTS DECISION IN A FORCE-FEEDING CASE
description: A state appellate court has ordered a judge to set aside his rejection of a request by a cerebral palsy victim to stop a hospital from force-feeding her.

title: THE MARCOS EMPIRE: GOLD, OIL, LAND AND CASH
description: A more complete picture of the financial empire of Ferdinand E. Marcos is slowly emerging, with some estimates placing its worth at more than $5 billion.

title: Opera Watchers
description: It's going to cost a cool $1 million to put on the world premiere and four more performances of Gian Carlo Menotti's opera ''Goya'' at the Kennedy Center in November, but the Washington Opera has completed the financing and is breathing a little easier. About one third of the money will come from E. F. Hutton, the brokerage house, and the rest from Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Getty of San Francisco, the Gramma Fisher Foundation of Marshalltown, Iowa, and the Kennedy Center itself.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 16, 1986
description: International

title: THE REVOLUTION STILL HAS SOFT SPOTS
description: Six and a half years after the Sandinista revolutionaries swept into power, they have not achieved their goals. Unemployment is chronic and widespread; factories stand idle; export earnings have tumbled; housing construction is at a virtual standstill; foreign debt has tripled; goods are often scarce or unavailable. Many Nicaraguans are frustrated and angry that their conditions of life are, in some ways, worse than before the revolution.

title: NEW CASSETTES: HITCHOCK, HEIFETZ AND 'HARD BOP'
description: Lenny Starring Dustin Hoffman, Valerie Perrine, Jan Miner; directed by Bob Fosse, 1974 (R) Key Video 111 minutes. $59.98 Dustin Hoffman gives an excoriating performance in this Bob Fosse movie dramatization of the rise and self-destruction of the ground-breaking comedian, Lenny Bruce.

title: MONMOUTH: AN 'EXPANDING VIEW'
description: LIKE a temple guardian, an overscaled ceramic sculpture suggesting a figurative column stands at the Monmouth Museum's entrance.

title: TRUE ADVENTURE: Pilgrim's Path On Shikoku
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. There has always been a stricture against walking these paths alone, and it makes sense, for if a lone pilgrim should be injured or fall ill there would be no companion to care for him. Yet here I am, lunging down a dark gorge, slipping on mossy boulders, throwing my weight on my staff to check a fall that would end with an ankle twisted or worse. I did not mean to do this. I left my friends on the road above and backtracked only to keep those following us from trying this tempting shortcut. I chalked a warning on the road, peered again down the shadowy descent, succumbed to temptation and plunged. I tell myself I am a fool; I should climb back. I cross a deep gully on a rotting log and keep going. The trail begins to level; sunlight breaks through; I emerge into the valley's paddy fields. A startled farmer interrupts his rice harvest to bring me tangerines. I reach the road and sit in the shade to wait for my friends who are taking the long way around. They will scold me, and I deserve it.

title: DATA BANK: March 16, 1986
UGANDA TO SET UP PANEL TO INVESTIGATE ATROCITIES
description: The Ugandan Government will set up an international commission to investigate atrocities committed by past administrations since independence in 1962, the official Ugandan radio said today.

title: NEITHER SIN NOR DUTY
description: THE PURITAN CONSCIENCE AND MODERN SEXUALITY By Edmund Leites. 196 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $17.50. SEX on bed linen usually surpasses sex on paper by such an order of magnitude that it's a wonder people write about the subject at all. Yet whenever scribblers do put sex into words, it is most often to make rules, an extremely bizarre approach considering how hard it is these days even to govern small islands, much less the national orgasm. Eastern ancients, like today's behaviorists, have written lessons on the sex act; medieval Western churchmen issued austere injunctions against earler pagan rhapsodies. Lately we've got into the habit of analyzing sex as we continue to cope with the efforts of those dark inquisitorial times, so far from the Garden of Eden.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'I SNOOP ON MY CHILDREN - HERE'S WHY'
description: An Opinion Page article on Feb. 23 by Linda Flayton, ''I Snoop on My Children - and Here's Why,'' drew a number of letters to the Long Island editor. Here are excerpts from the letters:

title: Rosemary Coghlan to Wed Lawrence J. LaMaina 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Coghlan of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Rosemary Theresa Coghlan to Lawrence Joseph LaMaina 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. LaMaina Jr. of Hanover, Pa., and Ocean City, N.J. A September wedding is planned. Miss Coghlan, a media planner at Homer & Durham Advertising in New York, graduated from St. Bonaventure University, as did Mr. LaMaina.

title: NEW HAVEN TAKING ATOMIC PRECATUIONS
description: AS a safeguard against small-scale nuclear accidents, it has been proposed that New Haven monitor the handling of all radioactive material in the city.

title: IN MANILA, THE ARMY MAY STILL HOLD THE SWING VOTE
description: In quiet pain, the Philippine armed forces accepted President Corazon C. Aquino's release of top Communist leaders from prison, and they seem ready to accept her tactic of a cease-fire with the insurgents, though military leaders say it may cost soldiers' lives.

title: SAFARI DELUXE: UNDER CANVAS WITH STYLE
description: Night falls quickly in the Ngorongoro Crater. The African sun disappears behind the rim 2,000 feet above, the air turns cool, the gazelles and zebras and waterbucks move from the open plains in search of shelter, and the magnificent crowned cranes fly off in pairs to their roosts in the acacia trees behind the camp.

title: ON NOISE POLLUTION IN MOVIE THEATERS
description: The article on the Westchester Cinema Club [ About Westchester column, Feb. 9 ] went on at length about the discussions that follow the showings. But it completely neglected the subject of talking in the audience during a performance.

title: Taking a Chance in Housing for Cities
description: THE economic turnaround in New Jersey over the last five years has touched almost every community in the state but the cities. Except for those on the Hudson River, they have not benefited from the state's widespread growth and commercial expansion.

title: CLOSE ENCOUNTERS WITH HALLEY'S COMET
description: THE European spacecraft Giotto provided the closest view yet of Halley's comet last week, and it proved a little too close for comfort. As it passed about 400 miles from the comet's core, the half-ton satellite was bombarded by dust particles that struck it at 155,000 miles an hour, 50 times the speed of a bullet.

title: DIVIDING TO CONQUER: HOW TO REMODEL THE CLUTTERED CLOSET
description: BECAUSE OF their inefficient layout, most clothing closets in homes and apartments waste a lot of potential storage space.

title: LIFE-AND-DEATH QUESTIONS THAT HAVE NO ANSWERS
description: RECENTLY, I have been particularly burdened by the responsibility of parenthood in today's complex world. Lately, it seems to my children that I frequently have no answers -not that I ever pretended to have all the answers.

title: A Chicago-Free Zone
description: To win the unanimous support of Chicago's fractious City Council these days, an issue must be either motherhood or meaningless. Small wonder, then, that a proposal to declare the city a nuclear- weapon-free zone won swift approval last week.

title: MOLLOY TAKES TITLE
description: Ken Anderson's tie-breaking 3-point play with five seconds remaining helped give Archbishop Molloy an 89-88 overtime victory over St. Anthony's tonight for the New York State Catholic High School championship. Anderson finished with 28 points as the Stanners (26-2) won their 18th in a row.

title: FOREIGN POLICY WITHOUT TEARS
description: THINKING IN TIME The Uses of History for Decision-Makers. By Richard E. Neustadt and Ernest R. May. 329 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. IN 1948 George C. Marshall, then President

title: PUTTING TEEN-ANGERS UNDER THE LENS
description: Two radically different new films, ''Pretty in Pink'' and ''Smooth Talk,'' tell us more about adolescence than all of last year's youth movies put together.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing Atlanta 500, at Hampton, Ga. Bill Elliott is the defending champion in this Nascar race. (Television -Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.) Baseball Mets vs. Minnesota Twins, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Sarasota, Fla. 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at Boston. The Sixers have lost three of the four previous meetings. (Television - WTBS, 1:05 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Tournament, second-round games: West Regional quarterfinals, at Long Beach, Calif.: Nevada-Las Vegas vs. Maryland (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M.); St. John's vs. Auburn (Television -Channel 2, 4:30 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 4 P.M.) East Regional quarterfinals, at Syracuse: Syracuse vs. Navy. (Television - Channel 2, noon. Radio -WNYE-FM 91.5, 11:35 A.M.); St. Joseph's vs. Cleveland State. Southeast Regional quarterfinals, at Charlotte, N.C. Kentucky vs. Western Kentucky, (Television - Channel 2, 2:15 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Islanders, at Madison Square Garden. The season series is 2-2-1. (Television - MSG, 8 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, and WOR 710, 7:50 P.M.) Devils vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia, 7:05 P.M. ( Radio - WMCA 570, 7 P.M.) Indoor Soccer New York Express vs. Irish National All-Star Team, at the Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. 5:05 P.M. Track and Field Third annual Pathmark National Scholastic Classic, at Coxe Cage, Yale University, New Haven, 10 A.M. Among the local competitors in this national invitational meet that has almost 1,000 boys and girls from 38 states is Shola Lynch, the Hunter High School junior, running in the mile.

title: Carol Alfenito Affianced
description: A May 10 wedding is planned by Carol Josephine Alfenito and Stephen Craig Wheeler, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ralph P. Alfenito of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., and Sosua, Dominican Republic, have announced.

title: EXHIBITION IN VENICE, FESTIVAL IN NEW ORLEANS
description: Host to Future: A Palazzo 226 Years Old When spring arrives in Venice, more than 250 works of art, gathered from around the world, will be displayed to the public under the title ''Futurismo e Futurismi'' in the inaugural exhibit at the Palazzo Grassi, a restored 18th-century residence on the Grand Canal in Venice.

title: DESPITE BOMBING'S SCARS, MANY SAY PHILADELPHIA RESURGENCE IS GOING ON
description: Last year at this time, Philadelphia's reputation was soaring. People who had not been here in a while found themselves charmed and excited by the city's resurrected physical beauty, its comparatively easy living, its fusion of civilized gentility and post-industrial economic vitality.

title: Social Events; All Around Town
description: Wines Galore March 17 - Sonoma County in California is known for its lush vineyards, and 40 of the area's premier growers will supply wines bottled under 80 labels at a benefit for the Vineyard, a five-year-old group that cultivates new theater talent in New York. The 7 P.M. wine tasting will be at La Belle Epoque, 827 Broadway (13th Street). Tickets, $25, from 212-683-0696 or 212-696-4103. Worldwide Aid March 18 - Elizabeth Swados, the composer, writer and director, will be honored at a benefit for the business and professional women's group of the UJA-Federation Campaign, which is seeking to raise $150 million in 1986 for basic welfare services in some 30 countries. The benefit, a cocktail buffet with Spanish tapas, is scheduled from 5:30 P.M. to 7:30 P.M. at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street. Tickets from 212-980-1000, extension 638. Admission is $15 for those who have contributed $500 to the UJA-Federation Campaign this year and $515 for others. Briefly Noted: March 19 - The Manhattan School of Music will perform a new opera, ''The English Cat,'' at a 7:30 P.M. benefit performance, followed by supper at the school, Broadway at 122d Street. Tickets, $150, from 212-749-2802, extension 501. March 19 - A black-tie dinner to honor outstanding Columbia College freshmen and alumni will start with cocktails at 6 P.M. in the rotunda of Low Memorial Library at Columbia. The actor Brian Dennehy, class of '60, will be among those honored.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: A DEEPENING SCANDAL HAS A CITY OFF BALANCE
description: FOR 14 years, Donald R. Manes was one of the most powerful figures in New York politics. As Borough President of Queens, a sprawling county that by itself would be the nation's fourth-largest city, he voted on municipal contracts, shaped development and influenced decisions on who became a judge. In his second role as Democratic county chairman, he presided over one of the most powerful political organizations in the state.

title: Computer Shoes
description: SHORT of offering shoes that do the running for you, manufacturers did not appear to have much room a year ago to improve the fortified sneakers that millions of people run in. But Dr. Peter Cavanagh, a professor of biomechanics at Pennsylvania State University, saw an opportunity.

title: NEW MALE RITE OF PASSAGE: GETTING AN EAR PIERCED
description: When Mrs. Palermo's son Tom was 15, he asked if he could get an earring. She told him to wait a year. She was hoping it might blow over.

title: BAUDELAIRE ON MONEY AND OTHER AFFAIRS OF THE HEART
description: To Caroline Aupick [ Baudelaire's mother ] 3 August [ 1838 ] I'M very cross with myself: it looks as if I'm not going to have any success; I admit my self-esteem is deeply affronted; I try to react philosophically and tell myself that success at college isn't worth a jot, that it proves very little, etc. It's still true that such successes bring great pleasure. So I'm cross with myself and others make me even crosser. You'll tell me: read a book. Well, goodness me, I've done nothing but read since I last saw you, that is, since we've been left to our own devices at school. You know that at the end of the year there are two empty months, and that then anyone who hasn't enough money to buy books is really unhappy: they spend their time sleeping. I myself spent almost all my money on getting books because I had to pay for a 4-volume work that had been confiscated from one of my classmates. I only read modern books. As for those works that are the talk of the town, highly valued, read by all and sundry, the best in fact: well, all that's false, exaggerated, puffed up. Above all I've got it in for Eugene Sue. I've read only one of his books and that bored me to death. I'm disgusted with all that: only Victor Hugo's theater and poetry, and a book by Sainte-Beuve (''Volupte'') gave me any pleasure.

title: RUNNING IN CIRCLES IN THE OVAL OFFICE
description: THE WHITE HOUSE MESS By Christopher Buckley. 227 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. ANYBODY setting out to write a comic novel about the White House confronts an obvious problem. How do you top the material generated by the gagsmiths who've been running the country for the last couple of decades? You could people the place with bumbling Teutons who skulk around in false beards with bags of cash while their boss glowers and mutters over his afternoon glass of bourbon, but it's been done. You could go the zany relatives route - beer-swilling brothers, motorcycle-momma sisters - but ditto. Well, then, how about inventing a President who conducts meetings seated on the commode, or who can't seem to deplane without a spectacular pratfall, or who baffles visitors with irrelevant anecdotes culled from obscure right-wing newspapers? Boffo stuff, yes, but there might be copyright problems. Only a few authors - Philip Roth and Joseph Heller come to mind - have written White House burlesques that manage to exaggerate the seemingly unexaggeratable.

title: NEW 'TEMPERANCE MOVEMENT' SEEN BY HISTORIAN
description: AN evolution has begun in society's attitudes about alcohol, according to a medical historian at Yale University who is an authority on the history of alcohol and drug use in the United States.

title:
THUS SPAKE AUGUSTINE;
THE INEXORABLE LAW OF THE BUNGLE
description: ''Augustine's Laws'' is a biting and irreverent commentary on management, business and government by Norman R. Augustine, soon to become president and chief operating officer of the Martin Marietta Corporation, the military contractor. Published first in 1983 by a small technical press, it quickly became a best seller in the only bookstore that carried it - the Pentagon's. Following are excerpts from a newly released revision that is aimed at a more general audience. xhrrDollars for Peace From the days of the Wright brothers to the era of modern high-performance aircraft, the cost of an airplane has unwaveringly grown by a factor of four every 10 years. This rate of growth seems to be inherent in such systems, with the unit cost being most closely correlated with the passage of time, rather than changes in maneuverability, speed, weight or other technical parameters.

title: TRUCK WITH RADIOACTIVE MATERIALS IS WEDGED UNDER ELEVATED TRACKS
description: A tractor-trailer carrying 246 containers of low-level radioactive waste through Long Island City, Queens, split open last night as it passed below an elevated subway track, the police said.

title: OHIO STATE FILLS POST
description: Gary Williams, the basketball coach at Boston College for the last four seasons, was named head coach at Ohio State yesterday, but he will have to wait a while before taking over.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a review March 2 of Daniel Patrick Moynihan's book ''Family and Nation'' incorrectly described the origin of the 1965 report ''The Negro Family: The Case for National Action.'' Mr. Moynihan prepared the report for the Johnson Administration in his capacity as Assistant Secretary of Labor for Policy Planning and Research.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: FINDING THE CENTER: Two Narratives, by V. S. Naipaul. (Vintage, $4.95.) These two essays - ''Prologue to an Autobiography'' and ''The Crocodiles of Yamoussoukro,'' about a trip to the Ivory Coast in 1982 - are an ''artistic triumph,'' reviewers wrote in 1984. The writings exemplify Mr. Naipaul's ''narrative line at its most penetrating and refining'' as well as reveal new layers of the author's complex personality, they said. GLITZ, by Elmore Leonard. (Warner, $3.95.) In this crime thriller, Vincent Mora, a Miami police lieutenant who is in Puerto Rico to recover from a gunshot wound, encounters Teddy Magyk, the psychopath he helped convict on rape charges years ago. Stephen King said in The Book

title: Port of New York
description: To the Editor: In the Travel section of Feb. 9 you published a comprehensive list of sailings of ships from various United States ports from New York southward as far as New Orleans.

title: 48% OF MOTHERS OF INFANTS ARE FOUND TO HOLD JOBS
description: A new Labor Department study shows that nearly half of all American women with children less than a year old worked outside the home last year, with the number of married mothers who worked more than doubling since 1970.

title: AMERICAN CATHOLIC IN ROME
description: ONE DOES NOT SPEND ALL one's time in Italy, even in Rome, thinking of the Roman Catholic Church. Even in Italian churches one does not think always of what has been called ''the only, The Church.''

title: SOVIET ASTRONAUTS ON SPACE STATION
description: Two Soviet astronauts today boarded the new Soviet space station that is expected to become the first permanently manned orbiting laboratory.

title: THE CHALLENGE OF MOUNT MARCY
description: The trailhead into the High Peaks at Keene Valley is called the Garden.

title: PARKING POACHING CHARGED
description: A GROUP of Lawrence merchants who complain that business people in neighboring Cedarhurst are poaching their parking spaces have come up with a plan they say will help local apartment dwellers as well as themselves.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE BIG STICK. By Lawrence Alexander. (Doubleday, $16.95.) This country, by all recent evidence, seems to prefer its heroes brawny, sentimental and unreflective, so perhaps Teddy Roosevelt - Bull Moose, Rough Rider, family man - is due for a revival.

title: KING TESTS WATERS UPSTATE
description: IN A year when more prospective candidates have been dropping out of races than entering them, Nassau County Comptroller Peter T. King is the only nonincumbent Republican actively campaigning to get on the party's state ticket for November.

title: BEYOND THE POT, CLAY SCULPTURE
description: ''FIRST there was clay,'' says the sculptor Wendy Foster, ''then there was nature.''

title: A DISPLAY OF REAL CARDS, FROM OTHER CENTURIES
description: WHO are those familiar faces -the kings, queens, and jacks -that evade our gaze when we pick up a hand of bridge? According to Lucy Fellowes of the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, those enigmatic faces are the distant descendants of 15th-century French royalty. ''Playing Cards,'' an exhibition researched and organized by Miss Fellowes, covers the 600-year evolution of those faces and surrounding symbols.

title: HOSPITAL PROPOSES BYPASS ALTERNATIVE
description: WHILE other hospitals battle regulators for the right to perform open-heart surgery, Mt. Sinai Hospital in Hartford has announced plans to provide an alternative to the coronary bypass operation.

title: A Guarded Report On U.S. Hospitals
description: Dragging its heels all the way, the Government released last week lists of hospitals in which patients undergoing certain treatments die at unusually high or low rates. The rosters, compiled from Medicare records for 1984, showed that at some hospitals more than twice as many patients died than would have been expected under standards established by Washington's health-care pulse-takers.

title: Pop/In the Clubs
description: Michael Feinstein, the singer and pianist whose engagement in the Oak Room of the Algonguin Hotel has been extended through April 19, has redefined the image of the stylish male piano-bar entertainer. Unlike Bobby Short, Steve Ross, and other veterans of the hotel and club circuit, Mr. Feinstein eschews brittle high society airs and simply sings from the heart in an impassioned, light tenor that focuses directly on the emotions of the songs.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH TO HELP DUARTE
description: As many as 20,000 backers of the Government of President Jose Napoleon Duarte marched through the streets of the capital today in the latest stage of a battle for support of peasant and labor unions.

title: POPULARITY OF YOUTH CENTERS WIDENS
description: OF the 40 or so high-school students gathered at The Last Resort, a center for teen-agers in New Canaan, one recent Friday night, only a few were juniors and even fewer were seniors.

title: NEW TRANSPORTATION COMMISSIONER EXPECTED TO FOCUS ON FINANCIAL ISSUES
description: WHEN Eric B. Langeloh takes over tomorrow as Acting Commissioner of Transportation, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke will have achieved two purposes with one appointment. Mr. O'Rourke will have ''let some air in'' his administration by offering early retirement to the outgoing Commissioner, R. Raleigh D'Adamo; and he will have demonstrated his belief that ''you can work in this government without any political ties to anybody and you can rise to the highest office,'' which he said Mr. Langeloh has done after 15 years in county government.

title: Headliners; The World Bank Choice
description: The announcement last week that President Reagan had chosen Barber B. Conable Jr., an upstate New York Republican who served 20 years in Congress, to become head of the World Bank caught many in Washington by surprise. After all, the 63-year-old Mr. Conable, a fiscal conservative who retired from the House in 1984, is not a banker as was A. W. Clausen, the current president, who will step down in June.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ISADORA: Portrait of the Artist as a Woman. By Fredrika Blair. (McGraw-Hill, $24.95.) No dancer - perhaps no American performing artist - continues to exert as strong a pull on biographers as Isadora Duncan.

title: On the Slippery Slope To Another Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: WATERGATE BURGLAR IS TRYING TO REOPEN HIS CASE
description: One of the Watergate burglars says he will use recently disclosed records to show that prosecutors withheld information raising questions about whether telephones at Democratic Party headquarters at the complex were actually tapped 13 years ago.

title: A Poet of Vilnius
description: To the Editor:

title: Allison Fern Reisman Marries Peter Menkes
description: Allison Fern Reisman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Reisman of New York City and Armonk, N.Y., and Peter J. Menkes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Menkes of Toronto, were married yesterday in New York.

title: CITY LABOR LEADERS HAVE THEIR WORK CUT OUT FOR THEM
description: ABOUT 750 delegates from 500 labor organizations representing 650,000 workers will meet Thursday in New York City to replace Harry Van Arsdale Jr., who died last month, as president of the city's Central Labor Council.

title: EFFORT BEGUN TO GET OUT THE SCHOOL VOTE
description: FROM now until April 15, the New Jersey School Boards Association - a federation of more than 600 school districts - will work to get out the vote in the school-board elections.

title: Elizabeth C. Ziehl to Wed John G. Petti 3d on May 31
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Ziehl of Greens Farms, Conn., and Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Cornelia Ziehl to John G. Petti 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Petti Jr., of Westport, Conn. A May 31 wedding is planned.

title: Dalmacio Gonzalez
description: All of the debut recitals considered here took place March 8, and all in Carnegie Recital Hall, in the afternoon, late afternoon and evening. Of the two pianists and one singer, the best-known name was Dalmacio Gonzalez, the Metropolitan Opera tenor who made his debut in the evening.

title: AN ENTERNAL LIGHT IN EVERY SOCKET
description: PRACTICALITY being one of his traits, Kevin Keating likes things to last - really last. So when it comes to choosing light bulbs for his home, he screws in the kind that burn for half a century.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'I SNOOP ON MY CHILDREN - HERE'S WHY'
description: At the risk of sounding melodramatic, I must say I was revolted by Linda Flayton's cavalier and joking attitude about her periodic snooping raids through her adolescent children's belongings. She maintains that it is the only way to learn what is doing with her offspring. She implies that open communication with teen-age children is impossible.

title: HELPING TO GUARD WILDLIFE WHILE IN THE CITY
description: FLANKED by advertisements for cognac and aspirin, a peregrine falcon perched on a stump in the autumnal woods glared at me from a subway car poster.

title: SOUTHLAND'S QUEST FOR GLAMOUR
description: IN this status-conscious land of high finance, big oil and high-tech electronics, the maverick Southland Corporation, parent of the unglamorous 7-Eleven convenience stores, has not commanded much respect.

title: NEW CASSETTES: HITCHOCK, HEIFETZ AND 'HARD BOP'
description: Western Light A Windham Hill production Paramount Home Video 55 minutes. $29.95 Much of the so-called new-age music on Windham Hill, the successful northern California record label, is contemporary acoustic mood music that evokes a picture-postcard vision of the American West.

title: ADVENTURES AND EPICS
description: The true adventurer,'' wrote O. Henry in ''The Green Door,'' ''goes forth aimless and uncalculating to meet and greet unknown fate. A fine example was the Prodigal Son - when he started home.''

title: RIVER WONDERLAND
description: He who travels alone may indeed travel fastest, but I can think of little else to recommend solitary travel. In nearly a dozen trips to the Amazon, my Brazilian-born wife had accompanied me only once, and we had more or less agreed that I would wait until our son, Eddie, turned 12 before I exposed him to the potential hazards of the adventure. But my impatience to share the Amazon's beauty with my son weakened my resolve, and after specialists in tropical medicine told me simply to follow normal precautions, I decided to take him with me on a recent trip, when he was only 8. He agreed to submit to the necessary inoculations if I would let him fish for piranhas. A few weeks later we stood side by side on the deck of a riverboat watching freshwater dolphins cavort off our bow. And for the next three weeks, journeying nearly a thousand miles into the Brazilian Amazon, we shared each other's wonder at the grandeur and mystery of one of the world's last frontiers.

title: IOWA DOMINATING AS IT REPEATS TITLE
description: Iowa today captured its ninth straight wrestling title, tying a record for consecutive N.C.A.A. titles.

title: REACTION MIXED TO DEMISE OF MAINE DAM PLAN
description: The Great Northern Paper Company's announcement that it was dropping plans to build a huge hydroelectric power project on the Penobscot River has brought expressions of joy from environmentalists and of anger and disappointment from supporters.

title: THE FEISTIER OPPOSITION IN SOUTH KOREA
description: For the first time in several years, the diverse elements that loosely make up South Korea's anti-Government camp have an issue they can rally around. Dissident politicians, clergymen and activist students have begun to demand direct Presidential elections next year to supersede an electoral college system generally presumed to favor President Chun Doo Hwan and anyone he may want as his successor when his term expires in early 1988.

title: 'BLUE LEAVES' IS BACK AND GUARE'S IN THE PINK
description: The photograph is old, 16 years old now, but something about it still arresting.

title: Q and A
description: Temporary Tenant Question: I manage a rent-stabilized, walk-up building in Manhattan. I now have a vacant apartment that the building's owner wants to rent to a friend who will be coming to New York in a year. I don't want to leave the apartment empty until then. If we rent in the meantime to someone who will not use the apartment as a primary residence, will we have to offer a renewal lease? . . . B. R., Alexander, N.Y. Answer: Yes. Once a tenant is in the apartment, he or she has all the rights of a rent-stablized apartment dweller, one of which is the right to a one- or two-year renewal lease at the tenant's option. Towers on the Park Question: Some time ago, I read about plans to break ground for an ambitious condominium project in Harlem. How can I get information on how to apply for a unit in this development? . . . F. B., Manhattan Answer: You are referring to a $72.5 million residential condominium called Towers on the Park that is going Michael Bartalos up on the northwest corner opposite Central Park. Ground was broken late last year for the project, a joint venture of Housing for People Inc., the Glick Organization and the New York City Partnership. The Harlem Urban Development Corporation is providing technical assistance.

title: IN CHINA: ROCK'S KINGDOM
description: And over Li Chiang, the snow range is turquoise Rock's world that he saved us for memory a thin trace in high air -- EZRA POUND, ''CANTO CXIII'' It is a cold, sunny Sunday in Yun-nan. On the plain below Jade Dragon Mountain, the villagers of Beisha are letting off firecrackers to celebrate the building of a house, and the village doctor is holding a feast in his upper room, in honor of his firstborn grandson.

title: A REAL SOLUTION TO 'MEDICINE FOR PROFIT'
description: Now who said that doctors don't have a good sense of humor? Dr. Selvan Davison's letter to the editor [ Feb. 16 ] portrays the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York as both noble and compassionate.

title: FISH AND CHIPS: BRITAIN'S BARGAIN FARE
description: Thanks to proselytizing by dedicated epicures, the notion that it is now possible for two people to go out for dinner in London and have a truly admirable meal for $80 or so, if they're not too picky about their wines, has long since registered with alert travelers. But more than any other in Western Europe, Britain remains a country where a traveler on a tight budget, or one who is simply feeling overfed, has to think twice before indulging in the ordinary food of ordinary people.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JACK RIVERS AND ME. By Paul John Radley. (Ticknor & Fields, Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95.) If, in his adolescence, Henry Miller had set out to write a raunchy memoir of childhood, the result might have resembled this first volume of the Australian Paul John Radley's Boomeroo Trilogy.

title: BURT IN BONN: AMBASSADOR CHARMS PRESS
description: The new United States Ambassador to West Germany has been busy making headlines, but this one was special.

title: DEPAUL STUNS OKLAHOMA; L.S.U. WINNER AT BUZZER DUKE NEXT FOR DEMONS
description: DePaul, perhaps the worst free-throw shooting team of the 64 in the tournament, made only 10 of 21 attempts in its second-round game with Oklahoma today. In fact, the Blue Demons shot better from the floor, 58.2 percent, than they did from the line, 47.6 percent. But eight of those successful free throws came during the last six minutes as the Blue Demons staved off repeated challenges for a 74-69 upset victory.

title: RELIGIOUS THEMES A CHALLENGE
description: THIS is the last day to see two plays that have captivated most critics and confused some audiences.

title: Sending Missiles To Saudi Arabia
description: The Reagan Administration informed Congress last week that it intends to sell Saudi Arabia $354 million worth of advanced missiles, probably provoking a new battle in an old war over arms for Arab nations. The battle may be different in two respects from some past conflicts over Saudi arms deals.

title: Mayor Goode Begins Rebuilding
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia has begun to dig him himself out from under the rubble of last May's explosive confrontation with the radical group Move. In an eight-minute television appearance Sunday, the Mayor issued a formal apology for the incident, which led to the deaths of 11 people and one of the worst fires in the city's history.

title: VATICAN BRIEFS BRAZILIANS ON NEW DECREE
description: Leaders of Brazil's Roman Catholic Church were briefed by the Vatican today on a new document on liberation theology that is designed to combat left-wing versions of the teaching, which has divided the church in Latin America and other parts of the world.

title: 6 BOWL GAMES LOSE TV CONTRACTS OVER MONEY PROBLEMS
description: The financial woes plaguing television sports have claimed their first college victims.

title:
TREKS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER;
TRUE ADVENTURE: Samothrace, Home of the Gods
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. In the Iliad, Mount Phengari on Samothrace served as a lookout post for Poseidon. Homer describes the sea god and earthshaker sitting ''high on wooded Samothrace'' from which he could view the Trojan War.

title: CAR CHASES? NOT FOR THESE GENTLEMANLY SLEUTHS
description: Entering a sleek, self-service cafeteria in London, the two elderly gentlemen, impeccably attired, are shocked to find that not only are there no waitresses but the coffee is served in plastic cups accompanied by nasty little plastic tubs of what is supposed to be milk. With some difficulty, they manage to get through the ordeal with dignity intact, albeit slightly askew. Played to a marvelous fuddy-duddy turn by Robin Bailey and Michael Aldridge, the gentlemen are, respectively, ''Charters and Caldicott,'' the delightful centerpieces of a new six-part ''Mystery!'' series beginning on public television this week (on most PBS stations on Thursday; on WNET/13 on Saturday night at 9).

title: A SURPRISING CHOICE FOR THE WORLD BANK
description: The choice of Barber B. Conable Jr. to head the World Bank was a surprise to many, although most concede it was a pleasant one. Others that had been mentioned for the job included Paul A. Volcker, Bill Brock and William E. Simon, all of whom have far more experience with developing nations than Mr. Conable, a former Congressman from upstate New York. But analysts say that Mr. Conable may be a more effective leader than A. W. Clausen, the incumbent. A conservative Republican, Mr. Conable gets along well with the Reagan Administration and is likely to be of greater help with the Baker plan to increase the lending role of the multinational development agency.

title: LOGGING BOOMS ON REFORESTED CONNECTICUT FARMS
description: William Treadwell straightened up, shook sawdust from his flannel shirt, and then watched four tons of red oak crash to the ground.

title: Plan to Relocate Wall Sculpture
description: TO some critics, ''Tilted Arc,'' a sculpture on Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, is a masterpiece. To 7,000 workers in the area who signed a petition for its removal, the artwork is simply a 120-foot-long steel wall and an eyesore.

title: BEHIND 'ANGRY HARVEST': POLISH POLITICS
