description: A dash of schizophrenia and paranoia comes all too naturally to Agnieszka Holland, the director of ''Angry Harvest,'' West Germany's nominee for an Oscar as best foreign film.

title: NETS DEFEAT CAVALIERS, 102-100
description: Buck Williams hit a baseline jumper with five seconds remaining and blocked John Bagley's shot at the buzzer, giving the New Jersey Nets a 102-100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: David Kreider
description: Like Miss Ho, the pianist David Kreider studied in Vienna, preceding that stint with one at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore and following it with the acquisition of a doctorate from the Catholic University of America.

title: The National Psyche in Post-Reagan America
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUE ADVENTURE: Crowned King of The Cannibals
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. When the roosters that scratch in the yard of Brastagi's best hotel crowed me awake that dawn a few months ago, I knew it was destined to be a memorable day, but I couldn't have imagined that before the tropical sun went down I would be crowned King of the Cannibals.

title: Classical Music
description: The obvious choice for Sunday night is Elisabeth Soderstrom, that most most human of operatic actresses, in Strauss's ''Intermezzo,'' in which her sophistication and understanding is likely to yield rich dividends. I'm aware of the limitations of the comparison, but there are ways in which Miss Soderstrom is the Lotte Lehmann of our time, shedding (as Lehmann did) the light of rich experience on her chosen repertory in the autumn of her career. The performance is at Carnegie Hall at 7:30 P.M.

title: Topics Modes of Sharing; Live Aid
description: The first anniversary of the ''We Are the World'' project is a good time to reopen the subject of helping the hungry in Africa. Recent events in Uganda create a special opportunity to make such help count.

title: SENATE DEBATES $11.1 BILLION WATER PROJECTS BILL
description: The Senate has begun debating legislation to provide $11.1 billion for 170 new water construction projects by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: NEW BOOKLET
description: The Postal Service will issue five attractive multi-color stamps featuring fish common to United States waters. The stamps will be sold in $2.20 booklets containing two identical panes of five 22-cent stamps.

title: Reagan to Back Acid Rain Plan
description: Everybody talks about acid rain, but Canadians believe that Americans don't do enough about it. With Prime Minister Brian Mulroney due in Washington Tuesday, President Reagan let it be known last week that he will back a new plan drawn up by envoys of the two countries to curb acid rain, which the Canadians believe is largely created south of the border, particularly in the Midwest.

title: Not All Military Spending Is Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CASSETTES: HITCHOCK, HEIFETZ AND 'HARD BOP'
description: Jazz at the Smithsonian: Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers Produced and directed by Clark Santee Sony Video 58 minutes. $29.95 For the past 30 years, Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers have maintained a stylistic consistency that has been remarkable both because their groundbreaking ''hard bop'' style of 1956 has remained viable and distinctive ever since and because this consistency has been achieved despite a steady coming and going in the group of young musicians, many on their way to jazz stardom.

title: DEFENDING A CONTROVERSIAL TV NEWS DECISION
description: To the Editor: I can't figure out what John Corry had in mind when he accused NBC of pursuing ''a separate foreign policy,'' except that perhaps he got carried away by his own metaphor [ ''Why the Networks Shouldn't Act Like Sovereign Nations,'' March 9 ] .

title: 'HOTEL KID' BECOMES SYMBOL FOR THE HOMELESS
description: Before the trip to Washington, 10-year-old David Bright was just another hotel kid, as they are called, one of about 1,400 homeless children growing up in the Martinique, a 16-story welfare hotel in midtown Manhattan.

title: Art
description: When Vasily Kandinsky, held by many to have painted the first abstract paintings, was asked in the early 1940's about the upcoming crop of artists in Paris he said: ''For the future, my money's on Poliakoff.''

title: TORTURED SEX, GREAT COLLECTION
description: PEGGY The Wayward Guggenheim. By Jacqueline Bograd Weld. Illustrated. 493 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $24.95. THE life of Peggy Guggenheim, the pioneering art dealer and collector who died in Venice in 1979, was dominated by two major impulses: her promiscuous rebellion against the straitlaced hypocrisy of her parents' milieu, New York's German Jewish elite; and an inner drive that led her to become one of the most prophetic art connoisseurs of her generation. The most grievous flaw of Jacqueline Weld's book ''Peggy, The Wayward Guggenheim,'' along with its trite, cliche-ridden style, is that it exploits the more sensationalistic aspects of her private life at the expense of any solid insight into her artistic vision.

title: COLLEGES SCRAMBLING TO AVERT A POSSIBLE FACULTY SHORTAGE
description: James Shapiro, a promising young Shakespearean scholar, was happily teaching at Goucher College in Maryland last year when he was approached by recruiters from Columbia University.

title: Spain
description: To the Editor: ''Fire, Fire Burning Bright'' (Travel Advisory, Feb. 9) is only half the story of what will happen in Spain this March.

title: Statue Watchers
description: She is only a fifth the size of her sister across the Atlantic, but American visitors to France are often struck by the extraordinary family resemblance. On the Allee des Cygnes, a spit of land in the Seine, stands a smaller version of the Statue of Liberty that is also a century old and like her American sister, alas, showing her years.

title: BANKS LOOKING TO LIFTING OF CAP AND EXPANSION
description: THE interstate banking legislation that was expected to become New Jersey law last week would allow banks to grow bigger, pave the way for the state's gradual entry into the nationwide banking arena and move deregulation a giant step forward.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ALTERED HARVEST: Agriculture, Genetics, and the Fate of the World's Food Supply. By Jack Doyle. (Viking, $25.) Along with an astonishing amount of food, farming and its related businesses produce about a quarter of the nation's gross national product.

title: ORCHESTRAL SOUNDS MINUS A CONDUCTOR
description: Like a vegetarian, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra acts on a conviction that sets it apart.

title: COMMITMENT REQUIRED TO URBAN EDUCATION
description: I am surprised that someone as articulate and interested as Sheryl Kayne bought such a simplistic interpretation of the results of our new fourth-grade proficiency test [ ''Higher Standards Promote Excellence in the Classroom,'' Feb. 23 ] . This is all the more puzzling since she professes an interest in what can be learned from research and claims firsthand experience with urban school systems.

title: Million-Dollar Apartments Becoming Commonplace
description: ESTHER KAPLAN remembers the first time she got a $1 million apartment listing, in the late 1970's.

title:
INVESTING;
PLAYING THE OIL PATCH FOR THE LONG TERM
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom has it that the oil patch will be gushing nothing but red ink for quite some time.

title: U.S. Officials Seek Wider AIDS Tests
description: Because it has become ''increasingly obvious'' that AIDS is being spread largely by infected people who have not become ill, Federal health officials said last week, the millions of Americans at high risk of contracting it should undergo periodic blood tests.

title: THOSE PERPLEXING PENSION OPTIONS
description: YOU may be close to retirement, looking forward to relaxing in the sun. Or you may be younger, and contemplating a mid-career job switch. In either case, you face a major decision: how to handle the balance in your pension account. Whether you cash in the pension for a lump-sum distribution, opt for monthly payments or roll over the money into an I.R.A is a choice that can dramatically affect your future finances.

title: CALLING FOR CLOUT
description: CAMP DAVID Peacemaking and Politics. By William B. Quandt. 420 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $12.95. THE OTHER WALLS The Politics of the Arab-Israeli Peace Process. By Harold H. Saunders. 179 pp. Washington: American Enterprise Institute. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95. FOR the Middle East, the years 1974-79 were a sort of golden age for American diplomacy. American officials achieved in that space of time five different Arab-Israeli agreements: the Egyptian-Israeli disengagement accords of January 1974 and September 1975; a Syrian-Israeli disengagement agreement in May 1974; the Camp David agreement of September 1978; and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty of March 1979.

title: THROUGH TANZANIA IN TRUCK AND TENT
description: If you go to Kenya, somebody told us, you'll see the animals and fellow tourists. If you go to Tanzania, you'll see the animals and you'll see Africa.

title: A Discarded Son
description: I hope David Sherwood and his brother will make the time to get together. Uncle Andy sounds like a charming man.

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: A few facts should be mentioned lest the nonacademic reader gain some false impressions from Colin Campbell's article ''The Tyranny of the Yale Critics'' (Feb. 9).

title: O'ROURKE LOOKS AT GUBERNATORIAL ISSUES
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who last week continued to weigh the decision of whether he wanted to be the Republican candidate seeking to unseat Governor Cuomo in November, has begun to address some of the issues he believes should be raised in the campaign.

title: A June Wedding For Kempy Miles
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ward Miles of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Kemp Miles, to William Haden Minifie, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Benjamin Minifie of Newport, R.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: ASH FILL SITE'S THREAT TO WATER DEBATED
description: TWO recently released reports indicate that a Yaphank site recommended for a regional ash dump for garbage-burning incinerators may lie within a critical recharge area for Long Island's drinking water.

title: AN 'ASPEN' DEVELOPING AT FISH HILL
description: Fifty-one years ago, a dentist named G. W. Northrup took the engine from an old Dodge and set up a rope tow for skiers on Fish Hill. It was Ellicottville's first ski lift.

title: CHARLESTON
description: Not long ago a movie producer with a big budget, a script about the Old South and Elizabeth Taylor as his star, asked for and got permission from the city of Charleston to cover one of the downtown streets with dirt. He could have saved his money. No one need add anything to Charleston: It is the best-preserved and most authentic 18th-century urban environment in the United States. When visitors go south of Broad Street - or below Broad as people say in Charleston - they are seeing one of the most elegant and extensive collections of 18th- and early 19th-century buildings in the United States.

title: IS NICARAGUA'S REVOLUTION EXPORTABLE?
description: IS Nicaragua the first drop of red in a Communist stain that will spread across the mainland of North America, or is it just a scruffy little country where nothing works, least of all the export of revolution? Both caricatures have been served up during the last two weeks in Washington, a city impressed by the power of images, as debate has raged over President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the contras, the guerrillas who have been trying to overthrow the Sandinista Government in Managua. If the aid is approved, Defense Department officials said last week, the President was prepared to send American military advisers to train the contras in Honduras, though not in Nicaragua itself.

title: A MULTILAYERED FETE FOR MARGUERITE DURAS
description: THE novels and films of Marguerite Duras have been variously described as forceful, interesting, precise, quasi-musical; symbols of listless, patternless existence that convey boredom so effectively we quickly succumb to it; similar in effect to a 40-hour, nonstop airplane flight.

title: TAINTED ANTICOAGULANT DRUG FOR TREATING CANCER RECALLED
description: An anticoagulant drug used in the treatment of several types of cancer is being recalled by its manufacturer because of contamination by potentially dangerous bacteria, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

title:
GARDENING;
DRY SOIL IS THE KEY TO EASY SEEDING
description: EACH day in March brings us closer to spring and the new gardening season. Those of us who are anxious to get outdoors will not have to wait much longer to get our hands into the soil.

title: CONQUERED BY MEXICO
description: Once more on my adventure brave and new'': there is a wonderful comprehensiveness about Robert Browning's words. Adventure is novelty; we experience it with awe, it changes our habits. But it is also a ''once more'': perhaps a memory come true, a presage. It is also brave: in this, the poet is generous. And how many unsung adventures are far more valiant than those in history books?

title: SYMPHONY, PLANNING SEASON, LOOKS TO 'CHALLENGING' FUTURE
description: A NEW approach to programming - one designed to ''challenge and stimulate'' both audiences and musicians - and a new chamber-music series are planned by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra for its 1986-87 season.

title: LONG SPEARS AND SHORTWAVE RADIOS
description: IN SOUTHERN LIGHT Trekking Through Zaire and the Amazon. By Alex Shoumatoff. 239 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. IT is easy to be interesting about travel in the third world. One can arrive in a country like Zaire and, simply by walking into a hotel bar or taking an internal airline flight and recording what one hears and sees, come up with something revealing about the place. Alex Shoumatoff, a writer for The New Yorker, does this in ''In Southern Light.'' He flies from Kinshasa to Isiro in Zaire. At the Isiro airport, he waits with his fellow passengers while baggage handlers dump their luggage onto the runway and then devote themselves to the more important task of loading valuable tusks, some of them from elephants killed by poachers, that are owned by a local government official. (Mr. Shoumatoff learns the provenance of the tusks from a Belgian coffee planter he meets on the plane.) Two hours elapse before ''an official announced that nothing was going to be done about the baggage, and we were al-lowed to walk past the soldier in spotted fatigues who had been guarding it with an automatic rifle and retrieve it ourselves.'' Clearly, we are not at O'Hare. This is a glimpse into another world.

title: SMALL PRIVATE UTILITY FACES UNCERTAIN FUTURE
description: THEY wake up each morning with the aid of wind-up alarm clocks, they watch movies at night on their battery-operated VCR's, and they go to sleep dreaming of Con Edison. A local church has had to postpone weddings because the electricity for the organ failed, and the local hospital placed a rock garden where steam leaks killed the flowers.

title:
GARDENING;
DRY SOIL IS THE KEY TO EASY SEEDING
description: EACH day in March brings us closer to spring and the new gardening season. Those of us who are anxious to get outdoors will not have to wait much longer to get our hands into the soil.

title: NICARAGUA, AN ECHO OF THE BAY OF PIGS
description: April 17 marks the nearly forgotten 25th anniversary of the invasion of the Bay of Pigs in Cuba - organized, financed and directed by the United States. That sorry enterprise provides an uncannily real analogy with President Reagan's latest efforts to arm the Nicaraguan contras in order finally to oust the Sandinistas. Congress might do well to ponder this analogy as it prepares to vote on President Reagan's request for $100 million in new aid to the rebels.

title: Israeli Convention Turns Into a Brawl
description: Israel's right-wing Herut Party convened last week for the first time since Prime Minister Menachem Begin resigned as its leader in 1983, and the meeting turned into an extraordinarily bitter four-day free-for-all.

title: WAS CONNECTICUT LEGISLATOR
description: State Senator Andrew J. Santaniello, Republican of Norwalk, died of an apparent heart attack today. He was 59 years old.

title: Debate on Arms Raises Doubts About a Summit
description: There was a lively exchange of arms control statements between Washington and Moscow last week, but no signs of progress toward new disarmament agreements. And the apparent stalemate seemed to push back the probable date for the next meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR DENIES HIDING INFORMATION ON UNION LEADER
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, asserts that the bureau did not hide information from the Justice Department while the Government was investigating Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: VALLEY SEEKS TO DISPEL ITS BAD IMAGE
description: AS a State Senator in the early 1970's, William C. Powanda spent much of his time dispelling negative perceptions of the the region he represented, the lower Naugatuck River Valley.

title: A.C.L.U. PLANS SUIT ON PRISON HOSPITALS
description: I HAVE AIDS and I am dying, and it appears that most people have developed the negative attitude that we are not worthy of anyone's attention.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's been a pretty rough year.'' -Peggy Say, whose brother, Terry A. Anderson, was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. [ 35:1. ]

title: AN HONOR GUARD FOR THE CHALLENGER'S CREW
description: Even from two miles away, the distance at which observers were held at bay, the scene was haunting: a small armada of salvage ships just off the Florida coast dragging to the surface the wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger's cabin with the remains of its crew. Aboard the U.S.S. Preserver, a Navy honor guard was glimpsed Wednesday night wearing dress blues, standing in formation as a fleet of ambulances met the ship at port and raced off. The destination was apparently NASA's Life Science Facility, where pathologists waited to make positive identifications.

title: Peter Cawley to Marry Leslie Keating
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Keating of Wellesley Hills, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Patricia Keating, to Peter Belden Cawley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Cawley of Bristol, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: INTO THE LABYRINTH OF DREAMS WITH KITAJ
description: Some of the more enigmatic paintings of our time are on view through March 29. in the R. B. Kitaj exhibition at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street. It is now more than 12 years since Kitaj - a 53-year-old American painter long resident in Europe - showed paintings in New York. During that time he has had a retrospective exhibition at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington and in the great museum in his native Cleveland; and museums the world over have coveted his work.

title: TRUE ADVENTURE: Best Seller on Little Diomede
description: Seven travlers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. I have a photograph that I treasure, not because it's sensational, but because it depicts the kind of adventure that can befall the traveler.

title: IT WASN'T PARADISE
description: THE ISLAND OF THE WHITE COW Memories of an Irish Island. By Deborah Tall. 234 pp. New York: Atheneum. $14.95. FEW of us have the chance to realize a dream. For Deborah Tall chance took the shape of a wild Celtic professor who whisked her off to find passion and her poetic self on a barely inhabited lump of rock just off the west coast of Ireland. ''The Island of the White Cow'' tells us the story of that time and of the lives that Miss Tall, her lover and the islanders made for themselves on its rocky and inhospitable shores. Miss Tall's narrative is divided into four main parts - ''The First Spring,'' ''Summer,'' ''Autumn'' and ''The Last Winter'' -and the device serves as framework for recollection of what was, in fact, a five-year stay.

title:
DINING OUT;
CLASSIC FRENCH IN THE LIGHT MODE
description: IN the last few years Le Chateau has undergone some renovation, but those who have long admired the elegance of the 80-year-old mansion need not be alarmed. The main dining room has been expanded to even greater seigniorial proportion, and the addition blends imperceptibly with the original wood paneling and carved ornamentation. More recently Albert Bouchard, the chef, and Joseph Jaffre, the owner, have designed a new menu, one that favors light dishes preferred by today's diners and, at the same time, doesn't compromise the precepts of classic French cooking.

title: ROBIN SUE SLATER PlANS TO BE WED TO MARC WOLPOW
description: Mrs. Allyn Levy of West Newton, Mass. and Delray Beach, Fla., and Paul D. Slater of Newton, Mass. and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Robin Sue Slater to Marc Brian Wolpow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Wolpow of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: THOSE MISLEADING ECONOMIC INDICATORS
description: A discordant note was sounded recently amid the steady chorus of good economic news. The index of leading economic indicators declined by six-tenths of 1 percent in January, which might lead someone to suppose that a recession lies around the corner. Immediately after that, total employment, an important ''coincident'' indicator that could signal a recession in progress, declined in February. And that bit of bearish news was followed on March 7 by a fall in the prime rate, an important lagging indicator, which might prove that a recession is already under way.

title: SENATE HOPEFUL IN ALABAMA
description: Jim Allen Jr. announced plans Friday to seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate seat once held by his father, Jim Allen, who was a conservative voice in the Senate from 1969 until his death in 1978. The seat is now held by Jeremiah Denton, a Republican. Also seeking to oppose Mr. Denton is Representative Richard C. Shelby.

title: OFF THE DEEP END
description: We dove down to 25 feet and began following a surge channel straight out from the shore. The sandy bottom of the channel was a pale, glimmering path sunk through tangled heaps of staghorn coral. In the late afternoon, it was already twilight underwater. A scattering of incandescent blue chromis fish flashed in the general violet, and sea whips and fans stood out ahead of us like sentinels. Beyond, there seemed to be a kind of purple gathering, an event, waiting.

title: SEMINOLE HANDICAP WON BY MINEAPPLE
description: Mineapple shot to the lead from post 1 on a sloppy track and then lasted by a nose over Darn That Alarm to win the $122,000 Seminole Handicap today at Hialeah Park.

title: CUOMO OFFERS PLAN TO CUT BORROWING
description: The Cuomo administration today announced a plan that would lower the state's short-term borrowing needs by $800 million as early as next month and by close to $1 billion by the end of next year.

title: AIDING CONTRAS OPPOSED
description: THE New Jersey Central American Network began public opposition last week to President Reagan's proposal to increase military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: TRAINING SCIENTISTS
description: Charles E. Ziegler believes that the emphasis on science and on creating new scientists had declined in the United States in recent years. But as corporate vice president and member of the management committee of the Swiss-based Ciba-Geigy Corporation, which has its American headquarters in Ardsley, he has been trying to do something about that.

title: WHEN THINGS GO WRONG, IT'S ALL RIGHT
description: ''When you're traveling and something goes wrong,'' a friend told me, ''you shouldn't be annoyed, you should be grateful.'' In his view, a little adventure like missing the last train and having to sleep in the station may well be one of the lasting rewards of travel.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
A BILL SHAKESPEARE PRESENTATION
description: THE fairies will be dressed as punks; the music draws on everything from rock to folk to classical to 1940's swing. The script includes words that Shakespeare never knew would one day exist.

title: ON THE RIGHT SCENT SINCE THE POWDERED WIG
description: In 1730, an enterprising young Spaniard, Juan Famenias Florez, set sail from Minorca for London to open a barbershop in the smart section of the city. He Anglicized his name and founded J. Floris, a business that was to flourish and remain in the same location and the same family for eight generations.

title: THE SECRET IS OUT
description: THEY had never met until they shook hands before the game on Friday afternoon, but Kevin Mackey knew who Bobby Knight was, and vice versa.

title: 7 CHICAGO COUNCIL SEATS ARE TOP PRIZE IN VOTING
description: Of the 120 offices at stake in the state's primary elections Tuesday, seven City Council seats are the real prizes.

title: Ellen Fauver, Vogue Aide, Weds Eric Squier Reimer
description: Ellen Sayre Fauver, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John King Fauver of Perrysburg, Ohio, was married yesterday to Eric Squier Reimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Squier Reimer of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Jack S. Miller performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: March 16, 1986 Fiction

title: PROBLEM OF DRUGS GROWING IN INDIA
description: After years of relative immunity to the trade in hard drugs, India has become a major transit point for narcotics shipments to the United States and Europe, according to American and Indian officials.

title: Kyle Conroy Plans to Wed In September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Conroy of New York and Ocean Reef, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kyle Ann Conroy to Raymond Alan Dargan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael J. Dargan of Dublin. A September wedding is planned.

title: TWO LEAD AT 1-UNDER
description: Chris Johnson birdied her 12th and final hole today to share the lead with Jane Geddes at one-under-par before rain suspended the third round of the d $250,000 Glendale Federal-GNA Classic. A total of 51 players were still on the course.

title: Eagle Watchers
description: The bald eagle was recognized as the national bird by Congress when the lawmakers adopted the Great Seal of the United States in 1782, even before the country began electing Presidents. The fierce birds were common in the Washington area for 180 years thereafter, until DDT began to pollute their habitats.

title: A CULTURAL LOGJAM OF SPECIAL OFFERINGS
description: SOME computer expert ought to devise a system to avoid the frustrating sort of cultural logjam that exists this week, but since no one has, let's look at the long list of musical possibilities.

title: LEGALITY, PSYCHOLOGY AND THE HOMOXEXUAL RIGHTS BILL
description: Opponents of the latest homosexual-rights bill argued at a City Council committee hearing last week that the legislation would force schools to teach children that homosexuality and bisexuality were acceptable alternatives to the norm. Proponents, including Mayor Koch, testified persuasively in rebuttal. But with the Council scheduled to vote Thursday, the debate continues as to what impact the proposed law might have on life in New York City.

title: Frequent Bad Air Reported In 1985 in Philadelphia Area
description: The quality of the air in Philadelphia and 11 surrounding counties was below healthful levels about once every 12 days last year, an environmental group has reported.

title: Changing East Side Yorkville Towers
description: Yorkville, the historic ethnic neighborhood that every day seems to be blending a little further into the Upper East Side, is gaining two new residential towers. At the same time, though, it is losing parts of the heritage that helped to define its character.

title: A NEW MAGAZINE CHARTS NEW PATH
description: IN a way, David E. Davis Jr. is trying to do to one of the automotive publishing world's Big Three what Chairman Lee Iacocca of Chrysler did to Ford: rub the corporate nose in the folly that lost his services.

title: LENORE SORIN
description: Lenore Sorin, who directed marketing and fund-raising activities for Foster Parents Plan for 25 years, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WHEN ACTORS SMOKE, AUDIENCE MAY FUME
description: Leah D. Frank merits commendation for calling attention in her review of ''The Hollow'' [ Feb. 9 ] to the continuing ventilation problems at the Arena Players Main Stage Theater.

title: 'GIRL GROUPS' LEAVE BEHIND THE OLD STEREOTYPES
description: Not every pigtailed Beatlemaniac dreamed of growing up to be Mrs. Paul McCartney. Some of them wanted to grow up to be Paul McCartney himself. A generation later, those aspiring female musicians are working female musicians, and the phrase ''girl group'' no longer connotes four smiling young women in sequined sheaths toeing the company line.

title: THERAPIST-FILM MAKER EXAMINES SUICIDE
description: DALE LINDQUIST, in making the documentary videotape ''Sometimes I Wonder if It's Worth It - Coping With the Wish to Die,'' has drawn upon both his present and past professional life: therapist and film maker.

title: CONTRADICTORY PLEASURES
description: THE GOOD LIFE By Yi-Fu Tuan. 191 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. $19.95. YI-FU TUAN, the John Kirtland Wright Professor of Geography at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, is a good man to whom nothing human is alien. Well, almost nothing. In ''The Good Life,'' he has undertaken an ambitious task. He explores answers to an old and unanswerable question: how should we live? He knows he cannot provide an answer to suit everybody but indicates the directions his own answers take. With modesty he suggests that his book may be ''best seen as an expedient for conversation.''

title: PLANTE: JUST WHO WAS THAT MASKED MAN?
description: IN his time, Jacques Plante was called a lot of things, not all of them complimentary. Iconoclastic? Yes. Hypochondriacal? At times. Idiosyncratic? Yes. Superstitious? Definitely. But, above all, Frere Jacques was a unique individual, a marvelous teacher, ahead of his time, and the man who quite literally changed the very face of hockey with the introduction and the popularization of the goalie's mask.

title: SISTER PRESSES EFFORT ON MAN HELD IN BEIRUT
description: The yellow ribbons tied to a tree outside Peggy Say's side door are torn and bedraggled. Sunday marks a year since her brother, Terry A. Anderson, was abducted in Beirut by an Islamic terrorist group, Islamic Holy War.

title: F.B.I. 9-YEAR INVESTIGATION OF MAGAZINES DISCLOSED
description: Recently released documents show that the Federal Bureau of Investigation once conducted a nine-year analysis comparing the positions of the Communist Party and those expressed in articles published by The Nation and The New Republic.

title: A CENTER FOR TRADE IS PLANNED IN HARTFORD
description: CONSTRUCTION of a World Trade Center in Hartford is expected to start this summer, creating an export opportunity for small and medium-sized businesses in Connecticut.

title: ARKANSAS IS FIRST
description: Arkansas captured a record-tying third consecutive title tonight in the men's indoor championships.

title: NORTH CAROLINA AND LOUISVILLE ADVANCE
description: Joe Wolf, the junior forward who scored 10 points and had a game-high 16 rebounds, hit six consecutive free throws and had two key assists late in the second half to lead North Carolina to a 77-59 victory over Alabama-Birmingham in a West Regional second-round game today.

title: ST. PATRICK'S DAY FARE FOR SOME OTHER TIMES OF THE YEAR
description: MARCH 17 inspires menus that begin with Irish smoked salmon and end with Irish coffee. Soda bread, corned beef, lamb stew, cabbage and potatoes are some of the other predictable foods.

title: SHULTZ AND SOVIET PREMIER MEET AT PALME FUNERAL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met here today with Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov of the Soviet Union in what was characterized as a review of relations between the two countries since the summit meeting in November.

title: OPPOSING TYRANTS OF THE LEFT AND RIGHT
description: ''THE American people believe in human rights and oppose tyranny in whatever form, whether of the left or the right,'' President Reagan told Congress in a foreign policy statement last week. The statement differed from the Administration policy declaimed by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former delegate to the United Nations, who maintained that ''traditional authoritarian'' regimes were ''less repressive'' than Marxist regimes and therefore more acceptable to the United States. The newly defined policy seemed to reflect the Administration's recent achievements in helping remove right-wing dictators, Ferdinand E. Marcos from the Philippines and Jean-Claude Duvalier from Haiti, as well as its decision to deplore publicly the human rights violations of the Pinochet Government in Chile.

title: A DIFFERENT KIND OF FAMILY AFFAIR
description: When the Soviet-born violinist, Dmitry Sitkovetsky, makes his Carnegie Hall debut on Wednesday night, the audience will be witness to a rare if not unprecedented event - a major New York recital performed by a rising young artist in consort with his mother. That his mother happens to be the noted pianist, Bella Davidovich, does not diminish the novelty of the occasion. While well-known fathers and sons, and other familial duos have often shared the concert stage, the mother and son combination may be unique.

title: 38 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 38 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: A Discarded Son
description: David Sherwood's article ''A Discarded Son'' (About Men, Feb. 9) tells an all too familiar tale about a boy who was deprived of his father's love because he was a little ''different'' from the other boys.

title: HERE COMES THE 'AUTHENTIC' MUSIC OF BEETHOVEN
description: The symphonies of Ludwig van Beethoven sit serenely at the center of our concert life. They are integral to the repertories of our modern, 100-member-plus symphony orchestras, with their gleaming, modern (meaning, mostly, perfected in the late 19th century) instruments. And the record companies continue to pour forth new Beethoven recordings by our star conductors and leading orchestras - most recently, Philips's new set of the complete symphonies with Kurt Masur and the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig.

title: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION DAY
description: President Reagan has signed a resolution designating Sunday as Freedom of Information Day. Sunday is the birthday of James Madison, the fourth President, who, the Congressional resolution says, recognized ''the need to guarantee individual rights through the Bill of Rights.'' The resolution, approved two weeks ago, was prepared by the First Amendment caucus of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Mr. Reagan signed it Friday.

title: Spaniards Decide To Stay in NATO
description: Spain, which became the 16th member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization four years ago, voted last week not to become the first in the alliance's 36-year history to leave. The margin was nearly 53 percent to 40 percent, with the rest of the ballots blank or invalid.

title:
GARDENING;
DRY SOIL IS THE KEY TO EASY SEEDING
description: EACH day in March brings us closer to spring and the new gardening season. Those of us who are anxious to get outdoors will not have to wait much longer to get our hands into the soil.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
WHEN A HAND EXTENDS FROM A PHONE, PUT A FOOT DOWN
description: LET'S say it's 7 o'clock Thursday night and the nightly news is just coming on. It was a cold day and you were outside for the duration, pushing a wheelbarrow, mixing cement and spreading gravel. When you got home, dinner was a blur because your wife works at night and supper time is more like the changing of the guard.

title: Court Upholds Police Trickery
description: It may be distasteful for the police to trick a defense lawyer into staying away so they can interrogate a suspect, but it is not unconstitutional. So ruled the United States Supreme Court last week in upholding a Rhode Island murder conviction by a 6-to-3 vote.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE ACCENT IN HOBOKEN IS ITALIAN
description: 9401>ADD a stylish little ristorante called Da Vinci to the growing list of engaging dining spots that are popping up in Hoboken.

title: HOW SWEET IT IS
description: TO INTRODUCE ITS NEWEST CHAMPAGNE, Brut Sauvage, the firm of Piper-Heidsieck came up with advertisements featuring a fierce-looking black panther skulking through the jungle. It was an imaginative attempt to convey the idea that this particular Champagne was really dry - savagely dry, if you like.

title: PENQUINS' RALLY TIES RANGERS
description: PITTSBURGH, March 15 -

title: We Need Federal Tax Amnesty
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
VARIED COLLECTIBLES AT SHOW IN WILTON
description: EIGHTY-FOUR exhibitors from seven states are in Wilton today for the 19th-annual Antiques Show held by the Wilton Historical Society at the high-school field house. The show includes all types of antiques and collectibles, from American and European furniture to paintings, quilts and jewelry.

title: Elizabeth Moseley, Securities Trader, To Marry Jonathan Edwards, Broker
description: Elizabeth Howland Moseley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Moseley 3d of Hamilton, Mass., and Jonathan Petterson Edwards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Edwards Jr. of Villanova, Pa., plan to be married in July, the parents of the bride-to-be have announced.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Having participated in an architectural tour of London organized by the Pratt Institute, I am interested in similar tours to other European cities and would like to know how I can find about them. -D. H. T., Sausalito, Calif. Answer:Many museums and academic institutions with an interest in architecture sponsor tours in Europe and other parts of the world. A shortcut to discovering what is planned is to approach Academic Travel Abroad (1346 Connecticut Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036 (202-785-3412 and, outside the 202 area code, 800-556-7896), a travel company that arranges tours for museums and cultural organizations and alumni and college groups. Academic Travel Abroad does not plan travel for individuals but can supply information on the tours it is organizing for its various clients.

title: THE COMFORT OF A FEMALE DOCTOR
description: A little over one year ago I had the pleasure of having a ''covering'' doctor visit me in the emergency room of North Shore Hospital. My male doctor was generally not available on weekends.

title: AT EL MUSEO DEL BARRIO, TANGLED LEDGERS, OPEN DOORS
description: WHEN rumblings of internal dissension at El Museo del Barrio began to attract attention last year, the institution's trustees, senior staff members and key supporters hoped the issues could be settled as family matters, quietly and privately.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THOSE GIANTS: LET THEM RISE! By Erika Duncan. (Schocken, $14.95.) Making art out of pain is the unadorned and undisguised subject of Erika Duncan's second novel.

title: THERE'S WISDOM IN KEEPING QUIET
description: It is not only the victims of Orwellian and other totalitarian regimes that are criticized and punished for dangerous thoughts. It happens also to bridge-players, who may find that silence is golden, especially in the post-mortem.

title: EXPERT EARS TAKE A TEST TO RESOLVE THE GREAT CD DEBATE
description: Hans Christian Andersen wrote a treatise on the fallacies of perception titled ''The Emperor's New Clothes.'' As a fairy tale, it might get a PG rating - not because of the nudity, but because it opens the scary chasm between appearance and reality. It also makes the point that perception is governed as much by social as by sensory factors, which may explain the widespread belief in things that aren't so.

title: REMEMBERING THE ALAMO, AND THE GOOD OLD DAYS, IN TEXAS
description: Few Americans are more conscious of their history than Texans, and as residents of the Lone Star State celebrate the sesquicentennial of the founding of the independent Republic of Texas amid blood and heroism in 1836, nearly one-fifth of them say they would have been better off never joining the Union, according to the Texas Poll, a sample of opinion taken quarterly by Texas A & M University.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A BASEBALL WINTER: The Off-Season Life of the Summer Game. Edited by Terry Pluto and Jeffrey Neuman. (Macmillan, $16.95.) Had Paul Owens, a front office executive for the Philadelphia Phillies, not left his room at the Houston Hyatt on the night of Dec. 5, 1984 (he was downstairs in the bar), Murray Cook, the general manager of the Montreal Expos, would have been able to reach him by phone.

title: FOR PENNSYLVANIA ELDERLY, A SURE BET
description: The Pennsylvania lottery is looking toward sales for the 1985-1986 period of $1.32 billion, and almost all of a projected $589 million profit will finance programs for the elderly.

title: Leslie Lobel Engaged To Naomi Reichman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Irwin Reichman of Dix Hills, L.I., and Jerusalem have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Elizabeth Reichman to Leslie Israel Lobel, the son of Lee Lobel-Zwang of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Irving Lobel. The wedding is planned for June.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THIS WELL-WOODED LAND: Americans and Their Forests From Colonial Times to the Present. By Thomas R. Cox, Robert S. Maxwell, Phillip Drennon Thomas and Joseph J. Malone.

title: Packwood's Plan For Tax Revision
description: For months, it has been certain that any tax revision measure emerging from the Senate this year will be different from the bill the House passed in December and from the proposal put forward by President Reagan last spring. A possible shape to the dissimilarities emerged last week when Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is chairman of Senate Finance Committee, gave his colleagues a point of departure for the work they will begin Wednesday: his own draft bill.

title: EVENTS SET A QUEENS WORLD SPINNING
description: Forty Yards was the name Sheldon Chevlowe gave his bar on Queens Boulevard.

title: BERRY PLANS TO PLAY
description: Lou Carnesecca said that when he saw Walter Berry collapse and grab his left ankle in the first half of Friday night's game with Montana State, the only thought that entered his mind was ''Get up!''

title: ARCHITECTURE THAT PAYS OFF HANDSOMELY
description: KOHN PEDERSEN FOX ASSOCIATES USED to begin its presentations to prospective clients by showing a slide of its softball team. Most architecture firms start with pictures of their buildings, but Kohn Pedersen is young, only nine years old, and for a while it didn't have many buildings to show. Besides, several of the founding partners actually played softball, and displaying the team picture sent a message that this was not just another stuffy, old-fashioned architecture practice.

title: BAN ON WOMEN AT A CHURCH CEREMONY IS PROTESTED
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of Pittsburgh has ordered women to be excluded from a ceremony that commemorates an episode at the Last Supper, provoking sharp debate on the status of women in the church and threats by some priests to defy the ban.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE SHORT, TRAGIC LIFE OF A SMALL NEGLECTED GIRL
description: I READ the other day of the death by starvation of a 3-year-old child, locked for weeks in an unheated room for the crime of stealing sweets, left to die by a stepfather indifferent to the pitiful cries of his wife's infant daughter. It was a small item at the bottom of an inside page, the kind of horror story that fills the papers daily, certainly no worse than the recent savage murder of two young children by their mother's boyfriend in New Jersey. So why did this single death so trouble me?

title: Ann Gofton Is Married To Leonard Greenberg
description: Ann Gofton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gofton of Warwick, R.I., was married yesterday to Leonard Marc Greenberg, a son of Drs. Gerald and Abby Greenberg of East Hills, L.I. Judge Martha Zelman of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RAIDERS AND REBELS: The Golden Age of Piracy. By Frank Sherry. (Hearst Marine, $19.95.) The memory of Erroll Flynn's Captain Blood cutting down sailors as a smile plays on his lips sweeps aside the reality that Henry Morgan, the inspiration for Captain Blood, was a vicious criminal who counted women and children among his victims.

title: SUFFOLK VICTIMS' LAW SUFFERS COURT SETBACK
description: Suffolk County is barred from enforcing parts of a 1985 law that expanded the rights of crime victims, under a ruling by a State Supreme Court justice.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A GOOD WEEKEND FOR ENTHUSIASTS
description: A PRIME weekend for antiques enthusiasts is in the offing, what with two events that encompass the breadth of collecting on a grand scale.

title: Financial Records
description: Tumbling oil and gasoline prices helped drive a main inflation gauge - the Producer Price Index - down a record 1.6 percent for February. Friday's report of the decline ignited another of the week's almost daily stock market rallies. Trading was so heavy late in the session that statistics on New York Stock Exchange activity were delayed.

title: N.F.L. OPPOSES SETTLING SUIT
description: ''These were the most boring meetings I can ever remember,'' a National Football League general manager said toward the end of last week. ''Nothing happened.''

title: Coming Attraction 10-Screen Complex for Mt. Pleasant
description: National Amusements Inc. of Dedham, Mass., which about 50 years ago gave New York State its first drive-in movie theater, is now preparing to build a 10-screen theater complex in Mount Pleasant, N.Y.

title: MELTING POT CANNOT DIMINISH IRISH PRIDE
description: BACK in February I had a birthday.

title: BRITAIN TO AID KUWAIT IF IRAN-IRAQ WAR SPREADS
description: A British official said today that Britain would extend military help to Kuwait if asked in the event that the Iraq-Iran war spills over into Kuwait.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
BOOKLET ON EMERGENCIES
description: Because so many people know so little about the emergency medical department of a hospital, the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center Department of Emergency Medicine has issued a booklet covering the questions most often asked in emergencies. The booklet also covers other aspects of emergency medicine.

title: NEW LIFE FOR AGING WATERFRONTS
description: FOR most of this century, New Haven's Long Wharf section has been used as a landfill and the site of the city's refuse incinerator.

title: Kitty Hanna Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Hanna of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kitty Hanna, to John Hunt Marshall 3d, a son of John Hunt Marshall Jr. of Dedham, Mass., and Mimi Marshall of Millis, Mass.

title: 'CASEY AT THE BAT' BECOMES A TALL TALE
description: In some circles, the replacement of mud with sludge might not matter all that much. But for the denizens of mythical Mudville, it would mean untold travail of spirit - as well as a quick downturn in the local economy. You see, fiendish Boss Undercrawl needs to find a dump site for his factory's runoff sludge, and he has his shifty eyes set on tumbledown Mudville Stadium, where the nascent sport of baseball is being tested with its first, gawky games.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE SPECIAL EVENTS
description: CAN a country music concert sell cigarettes? Or skydiving get people to buy more beer? Or a runner's marathon pull them into a bank?

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: Does the work of the deconstructionists differ so from that of the sixth-century Talmudists? It presupposes a knowledge that makes commentaries a necessity. Contemporary ideas appear to have ancient precedents and deconstruction, like other interpretations of literature, will be judged by its survival. BENNETT LUM Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: PALME IS EULOGIZED AS A CHAMPION OF PEACE
description: With the unsolved mystery of his killing still hanging heavily over Sweden, Olof Palme was eulogized today as a world citizen and champion of peace at a secular funeral designed to reaffirm his political values.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE TWO FARMS. By Mary E. Pearce. (St. Martin's, $12.95.) This pleasant yet ultimately unexciting novel, set in 19th-century rural England, centers around the life of Jim Lundy, an orphan whose fortunes become bound up with those of two rival farms: the prosperous Peele and the struggling Godsakes.

title: Camera; OFF ON THE ROAD TO A WELL-EQUIPPED DARKROOM
description: DARKROOMS are where the art is put into a photograph. Procedures carried out there are as important as the work done behind the camera.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'I SNOOP ON MY CHILDREN - HERE'S WHY'
description: Spying, denial of rights, entrapment and building up ''weapons of war'' are conducive for peace neither for a state nor for a family. It is obvious that what ''Agent'' Flayton refers to as the P.I.A. or Parents Intelligence Agency has none. May I take this moment to remind ''Agent'' Flayton that repression, whether it be of countries or children, ultimately leads to revolution. KENNETH KATZ

title: NIGHTCLUB FOR YOUTH A SMASH HIT
description: HANGING out downtown and unsupervised house parties are passe for Princeton-area high school students, who now have a weekend drop-in place of their own - Teen Cafe, in the gymnasium of the Valley Road School here.

title: SOVIET ENVOY TO SPAIN NAMED CHIEF REPRESENTATIVE AT U.N.
description: The Soviet Union has named Yuri V. Dubinin, currently the Ambassador to Spain, as the chief delegate at the United Nations.

title: BISHOP BACKS ROME ON PRIEST
description: Bishop James W. Malone, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, is supporting the Vatican in its efforts to discipline the Rev. Charles E. Curran. But Bishop Malone has also expressed hope that Father Curran's interests will be considered in any resolution of the controversy.

title: CREDIT UNION THRIVES AT UCONN
description: THE University of Connecticut at Storrs has a classroom where students control more than $1 million.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE TREK Written and illustrated by Ann Jonas. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75. (Ages 5 to 9) DAYDREAMING is a private canvas on which we can all paint. The fantasies we sketch can get us into deep trouble or lift us even into the realm of genius.

title: Miss Alexander, Medical Student, To Marry in July
description: Gretchen Barlow Alexander, a third-year medical student at the University of Pennsylvania, and George Murnane 3d, who is studying for an M.B.A. degree at the university's Wharton School, are planning a July wedding, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. John A. Alexander of Alton, Mass., have announced.

title: HISTORY A LA CARTE
description: ALL MANNERS OF FOOD Eating and Taste in England and France From the Middle Ages to the Present. By Stephen Mennell. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. $24.95. CULINARY history has come into fashion and is about to come of age.

title: ECONOMIC RECOVERY IS SEEN AS BYPASSING AT LEAST 10 MILLION
description: Although most Americans are benefiting from the nation's robust economic recovery, economists say that at least 10 million to 15 million are receiving little direct gain.

title: Kotcha!
description: EDWARD KOCH, A best-selling author who moonlights as a city official, recently referred to a compatriot under investigation by hordes of leaky law-enforcement officials as a ''close friend - in the abstract.''

title: HOUSE DELEGATION LEAVES NICARAGUA
description: Nine Republican members of Congress left Nicaragua today after a 20-hour visit that appeared to have strengthened their support for anti-Government guerrillas.

title: Verbatim; The Next Oil Crisis?
description: 'The United States is now in the process of creating a substantially increased oil dependency for the 1990's. We are sowing the seeds of the next oil crisis.'

title: PRESERVE THE OLYMPIC 'AMATEUR'
description: THE OLYMPIC GAMES are about two years away, and they are little in our thinking at this time. However, the International Olympic Committee will be meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, next October to make a monumental decision that could affect the future of the Olympics. And if the purists are to have any input into that decision, we'd best make our voices heard now, and every day until the meeting.

title: FARM LEGISLATION IS PRAISED
description: American farmers should see their economic fortunes improve under the new farm program, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng has said in his first appearance on Capitol Hill since his confirmation by the Senate.

title: VALLEY COTTAGE
description: IN late winter, with its trees bare and the remnants of recent snows still covering parts of its rolling landscape, the quiet Rockland County hamlet of Valley Cottage is the very picture of what many have sought there over the last 100 years - a rural redoubt from the pressures of urban life.

title: UTILITIES STUDY THE LESSONS OF SHOREHAM
description: WHILE there are no new nuclear power plants planned anywhere in the United States, utility officials faced with increased energy consumption have not ruled out the nuclear option for the future, according to nuclear industry spokesmen. In their considerations, however, the utilities are looking very carefully at the troubled licensing history of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

title: AN ODE TO A GRAY DAY
description: THERE'S a lovely color that I associate with the most serene of Long Island days. It is gray.

title: JERSEY SCHOOLS TRY COMPUTER LIBRARY
description: In the library of the Brunswick Acres School, 11-year-old Margie Kan and some sixth-grade classmates searched a computer's memory, checking out colleges they might like to attend someday or looking up airline schedules to plan imaginary trips following the routes of Christopher Columbus or Lewis and Clark.

title: O'GRADY WON'T BACK DOWN
description: Three volunteer workers at the Hertz Bay Hill Classic approached Mac O'Grady for his autograph the other day, and as he politely obliged, one of them said: ''I sure hope you win. It's time someone stood up to them.''

title: Moynihan: Of Counted Cows and Bloodied Noses
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is a stickler for details and has a zest for intellectual combat, was making a point about his recently published book, ''Family and Nation,'' in which he examines the state of the American family, when he branched into a telling aside.

title: Mayor of Nablus
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CLASS OF KHAKI
description: KHAKI IS THE PIVOTAL STYLE POINT FOR the coming season, a look based on familiar clothing put together in a not-unfamiliar way - and revived, in part, by the popularity of the television mini-series ''The Jewel in the Crown'' and the movie ''Out of Africa.'' There are pants that for years served as bottoms to a blue blazer with button-down shirt and tie.

title: MARCOS LAWYERS ASK COURT TO FREE PLANES' CARGO
description: Lawyers for Ferdinand E. Marcos appeared in the International Court of Trade in Manhattan yesterday in an attempt to prevent the United States from providing the new Manila Government with financial documents that Mr. Marcos took to Hawaii when he fled the Philippines.

title: Rosenberg Sisters Planning to Wed
description: Debra Lynn Rosenberg plans to marry Richard Marc Klapow on June 1, and her sister Joyce Ann Rosenberg plans to marry Alan Harris Figman on Aug. 17, the parents of the brides-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Rosenberg of Lake Success, L.I., have announced.

title: Miss Beh to Wed Thomas Werblin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Beh of Plandome, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Elizabeth Beh to Thomas David Werblin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Werblin of Rumson, N.J. A May wedding is planned. Miss Beh, the advertising and public relations director of Karl Lagerfeld Womenswear Inc., graduated from Manhattan College.

title: SMALLER SHOWS RAISE THE SIGHTS OF GARDENERS
description: Although many people attend the major flower shows, how many are familiar with smaller plant society shows which differ considerably? These shows are usually given by local chapters and include displays of daffodils followed by iris, rhododendrons, roses and daylilies with chrysanthemums and dahlias filling out the autumn schedules. Schedules of these events are usually printed in local papers and posted on the bulletin boards of horticultural and plant societies.

title: Wendy Klein Engaged To Alan Jeffrey Stitzer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klein of Pearl River, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Wendy Elise Klein to Alan Jeffrey Stitzer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Stitzer of Westport, Conn. A May 1987 wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BUCKMINSTER FULLER Supplementing the Buckminster Fuller exhibition at John Cusano's Art Gallery, 136 Washington Street, South Norwalk, are special events sponsored by several organizations and businesses.

title: MARCOS APPEALING FOR AID IN FINDING HAVEN OUTSIDE U.S.
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, reportedly unhappy with his reception in Hawaii, has asked the United States to help him find a safe haven in Spain or some other country, Administration officials said today.

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
PARIS
description: THIN, THINNER, thinnest - such are the silhouettes that French designers are stitching, or rather knitting, for next fall and winter. The new ready-to-wear clothes will be introduced in Paris this week.

title: LINGUISTIC WHIZ-BANGS
description: LOVE IS THE CROOKED THING By Lee K. Abbott. 182 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill. $13.95. THE implicit code behind Lee K. Abbott's fiction seems to be: if you haven't gone too far, you haven't gone far enough. Or as a California comic put it back in the 1970's, ''There is a light within you - burn it out!''

title: YOU DON'T HAVE TO MARCH ON ST. PATRICK'S DAY TO BE IRISH
description: I HAVE never marched in a St. Patrick's Day parade. I'm Irish, and therefore as eligible as the next person. I may soon be more eligible than some because I was born in Northern Ireland. (I attained the use of reason before I ever heard that name; my family always called it Occupied Ireland).

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: There's nothing I like better Sunday morning than to relax over a second cup of coffee with an article in The Times Magazine that's smarter than I am. ''The Tyranny of the Yale Critics'' was perfect.

title: Ann S. Derrey to Wed Douglass Bermingham
description: Plans for the May wedding of Ann Stewart Derrey and Douglass Andrew Bermingham have been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Fairbairn Derrey of Westfield, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt.

title: TURNING DOWN CALIFORNIA FOR A CHANCE TO STAY HOME
description: I ARRIVED at my parents' house late last night after a one-month business trip to Los Angeles. As the plane neared the airport and I saw the lights of the city, I knew that finally I was home again. Driving up the Hutchinson River Parkway, past the inconvenience of never-ending construction, I felt the warmth of familiar surroundings. The Hutch, unlike the first-rate freeways in Los Angeles, is narrow and winding; nevertheless it has been part of my life and signals home. That road has taken me to college, jobs, friends and the major events of my life.

title: EX-AIDE TO PERONS FACES EXTRADITION
description: Extradition proceedings have begun for Jose Lopez Rega, the mysterious and powerful former offical of the Argentine Government who was arrested in Miami this week and is being sought by Argentina to face charges of corruption.

title: ITALIAN MEN'S WEAR DESIGNER
description: Angelo Litrico, the men's wear designer who clothed world leaders and provided Nikita S. Khrushchev with the shoe he banged at the United Nations in 1960, died Thursday of heart failure in Gemilli Policlinic. He was 58 years old and had been recovering from a fractured hip, according to Italian news reports. The reports said he had also suffered from circulatory problems.

title: Joan D. Roth Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Roth of Monsey, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Deborah Roth, to Ronald Stack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Stack of Franklin Square, L.I. An August wedding is planned. Miss Roth, a graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, is an environmental engineer with the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades, N.Y. Mr. Stack, a graduate of the State University of New York at Oswego, is a programmer analyst at Forbes magazine in New York.

title: METHODISTS SAY FEARS DELAY RESPONSE TO AIDS
description: Deeply held ''fears and prejudices'' have delayed the response of the 9.1-million-member United Methodist Church to the AIDS crisis, the church's Board of Discipleship said today.

title:
ART;
AMERICAN HISTORY (AS SEEN BY FERRIS) AT THE MORRIS MUSEUM
description: ON THE one hand, the impulse is to consign the current offering at the Morris Museum to the category of kitsch and camp and leave it at that.

title: What's the National Interest?
description: You might think, listening to all the tumult here about Nicaragua, that it is a partisan issue between President Reagan and the Democrats, which in a way it is. But Nicaragua is merely a symbol of a much deeper confusion over the true interests of our nation.

title: WRITERS IN THEIR CELLS
description: POLAND UNDER BLACK LIGHT By Janusz Anderman. Translated by Nina Taylor and Andrew Short. Introduction by Stanislaw Baranczak. 131 pp. New York: Readers International/ Persea Books. $12.50. ''POLAND UNDER

title: HOW THE RUSSIANS CAUSE A NUISANCE BY THEIR PRESENCE
description: WHEN the Reagan Administration ordered Soviet missions to the United Nations to cut their personnel, United States officials said the missions were used for espionage and the resources of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were strained by monitoring the movements of so many potential spies. How much damage the order will do to U.S.-Soviet relations was not imediately clear. Moscow said it would not help the atmosphere of the summit that is to be held in Washington this year or early next year; but the Russians did not threaten to cancel the meeting. While the diplomats pondered, the F.B.I. kept tracking suspected spies.

title: MARCOS AIDE SETS UP 'LOYAL OPPOSITION' IN MANILA
description: A backer of Ferdinand E. Marcos today announced the formation of a new political party that would distance itself from the former President while offering a ''loyal opposition'' to President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: THE NEW HOMELESSNESS HAS ITS ROOTS IN ECONOMICS
description: THIS winter, operators of emergency shelters across the country have been coming to a common conclusion: The homeless are no longer the lone drifters and former mental patients who were the vast preponderance of that population just a few years ago. In dozens of cities, including New York, Washington D.C., and Los Angeles, and even in rural communities, emergency programs for the homeless are being flooded by functioning adults and families with children.

title: SCHOOL-BOARD ROLE OF STUDENTS ON RISE
description: EARLIER this month, 590 students at Lyndhurst High School voted for the first student representative on the local Board of Education. Russell Ciffo, a 17-year-old junior, won and will serve on the board through June 1987; David Anders, 17, the runner-up, also will serve on the board, but only through June.

title: Cable TV
description: Film buffs will find some old friends and lesser-known rewards on cable this week, starting with that long-absent Bette Davis-Miriam Hopkins beauty, ''The Old Maid'' (1939) - Monday at 10 A.M. on Showtime. This moving drama vivified Zoe Akins's tamely sentimental stage play (from an Edith Wharton story), which had won the 1935 Pulitzer Prize and provoked a Broadway storm. The award snub to Lillian Hellman's ''Children's Hour'' and Robert E. Sherwood's ''Petrified Forest'' had one lasting result: the formation of the New York Drama Critics Circle.

title: THE AIR IS LEAKING OUT OF CLEVELAND'S CUSHION
description: MORE than 3,500 mayors and other municipal officials, members of the National League of Cities, met in Washington last week to seek ways of containing the damage done by Federal aid cuts required under the new budget-balancing law. One of the mayors' principal efforts - many of them said privately it is almost sure to fail - is to save general revenue sharing, which has provided $4.2 billion a year for local governments to use as they wish. Among the most successful beneficiaries of that program is George V. Voinovich , the Republican Mayor of Cleveland and a former president of the national league, whose city is said to have acquired more Federal funds per capita than any other major municipality since President Reagan entered the White House. In Cleveland recently, John Herbers, national correspondent of The New York Times, talked about the state of the cities with Mayor Voinovich, who has become increasingly outspoken in his opposition to the urban policies of his national party. Excerpts from their discussion follow. Question. What will Cleveland's situation be next year if cuts in Federal aid under the new balanced-budget law go into effect?

title: Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUMP BUYING OUT PARTNER IN HIS 2D CASINO
description: Donald J. Trump has signed an agreement to buy out his partner in the Trump Casino Hotel by July, making Mr. Trump the only owner of two casinos here.

title: Headliners; Epilogue to a Lynching
description: Seventy years after Leo M. Frank died in a lynching that has been called the country's worst incident of anti-Semitic violence, the State of Georgia awarded him a posthumous pardon last week for the crime that led to the lynching: a murder he said he had not committed. Mr. Frank was sentenced to death for the 1913 slaying of a 13-year-old girl in the Atlanta pencil factory where both worked. When the sentence was commuted in 1915 to life in prison, a mob hanged Mr. Frank.

title: WHEN IRISH WIVES ARE DINING
description: FOR years, the angry wives of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick would sit home alone on the evening of March 17 while the sons went off to a formal stag dinner. One of them, the Irish-born Greta Quinn, mightily resented having to press her husband's tuxedo and fiddle with his bow tie so that ''himself'' could step out in style without her. ''Every year,'' her daughter, Kathleen Murray, recalls, ''my mother used to say: 'What is this? I'm the only one in the family who was born on the other side, and I'm the only one at home on St. Patrick's Day.' ''

title: G.O.P. IS LISTENING TO KEAN'S WORDS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN moved in last week on those who want to be the next Republican candidate for President.

title: RECORDS BACK COACHES' COUNSEL ON HITS AND WALKS
description: THE SPEECH is a familiar one in the minor leagues. The pitching coach gathers the fledgling pitchers around him and outlines what it takes to win in the major leagues. What the coaches tell the pitchers could be reduced to a formula titled, ''Guidelines for a Winning Pitcher'': Allow fewer hits than innings pitched and strike out at least twice as many batters as you walk.

title: TAINTED FEED BRINGS MILK RECALLS IN A COSTLY NIGHTMARE TO FARMERS
description: Roger Dunn squatted beside a gleaming stainless-steel storage tank, turned a tap and released a sudden flood of fresh milk.

title: LAND OF THE LABYRINTH
description: For more than 4,000 years, Crete has been a battleground in the warrior's dance of civilizations. Asian, African and European peoples, seeking empire on land and sea, have attempted to possess this rugged island of craggy mountains and deep, green valleys studded with millions of olive trees, situated in the Mediterranean midway between Greece and Africa, the Middle East and Italy.

title: 'Rat Man of Paris'
description: To the Editor:

title: Double Trouble
description: Popsicles, those vibrant flags of summer, are feeling the heat of the marketplace.

title: KNICKS LOSE TO HAWKS, 106-101
description: The major difference between winning and losing can often come down to what Coach Mike Fratello of the Atlanta Hawks called ''the right bounce, the right break.''

title: THE CONSEQUENCES OF PLANTING TOO SOON
description: All the experts tell you to plant hardy, cool-weather crops - lettuce, peas and onions - as soon as the ground can be worked. How many times have I read that the traditional pea-planting time for gardeners who live in the Northeast is St. Patrick's Day, March 17?

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''The time has come to treat all banks alike until we have a mechanism in place to permit any bank to fail, irrespective of size.''

title: LINCOLN CAPTURES P.S.A.L. FINAL
description: Bernard Mitchell scored 8 points in the final minutes yesterday and sparked Abraham Lincoln of Brooklyn to its first Public Schools Athletic League championship in 37 years. But when the 61-52 victory over Manhattan Center in the Class A final was completed at St. John's Alumni Hall, the game's offensive hero said it was the defense that had made the difference.

title: Pamela J. Timmerman Marries J. R. Mousseau
description: St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Pamela Jane Timmerman, a senior financial analyst, and John Robert Mousseau, an assistant vice president, both at E.F. Hutton & Company in New York. The Rev. Edward Hogan, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Georgia's Latest Loss
description: After a jury decided last month that an English teacher at the University of Georgia had been wrongfully dismissed when she complained of preferential treatment for athletes, Dr. Fred Davison, the school's president for 19 years, continued to defend the sports program. But the State Board of Regents, stunned by the $2.57 million verdict, set out to investigate.

title: LE CARRE'S TOUGHEST CASE
description: IT IS ALMOST TOO OBVIOUS TO POINT OUT, BUT THE man behind the novels of John le Carre has a lot in common with his characters. This is so not only because of his presumed emergence from the shadowy world of Her Majesty's secret service and his multiple personae. It is so also when you meet him, for David Cornwell - the creator of the le Carre mask and oeuvre - customarily discloses himself the way his books disclose their plots: disarmingly, in artfully controlled stages, never entirely.

title: HELP HAM RADIO OPERATORS, SO THEY'LL BE ABLE TO HELP YOU
description: Once upon a time, back in the Middle Ages, a young surgeon-barber returning to his home in Gudlux from a distant land stopped for the night at an inn. When he awoke, he was greeted with the news that the village was in the midst of an epidemic of plague.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: DURING March, which is National Social Workers Month, the state's professional organization gathers to honor one of its members and a private citizen for their work in making life a little better for those in need of help.

title: Eastern May Face A Record Fine for Air Safety Lapses
description: In September, the Government docked American Airlines $1.5 million for maintenance irregularites; last week, the Federal Aviation Administration confirmed that it had proposed fining Eastern Air Lines a whopping $9.5 million for 78,000 safety-related infractions uncovered in a two-month inspection.

title: MUSICAL CONFECTION ON FAIRFIELD'S MENU
description: DO not think that William H. Edgerton, a resident of Darien and a part-time producer, does not dote on opera. He does, indeed, traveling around the world to see the newest productions of the oldest war horses.

title: MULRONEY PRAISES U.S.-CANADA TIES
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney says he thinks most Americans, though not President Reagan, take Canada for granted.

title: NORDIQUES CAPTURE TOP SPOT IN ADAMS
description: Dale Hunter's power-play goal in the second period was the decisive score tonight as the Quebec Nordiques moved into first place in the Adams Division with a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: 'MY BEAUTIFUL LAUNDRETTE' PROBES THE LIFE OF LONDON'S PAKISTANIS
description: Recent films like ''A Passage to India,'' ''Gandhi'' and ''Heat and Dust'' - not to mention public television's ''Jewel in the Crown'' -have explored the cultural conflicts of the British in India. In contrast, ''My Beautiful Laundrette'' offers a refreshingly complementary angle. Far from the epic canvases and pavilions of the ''Raj'' dramas, this offbeat British satire cast a wry eye on Pakistanis in contemporary London.

title: Kohl Is Facing A Second Inquiry
description: A few months ago, West Germany's Christian Democrats, led by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, seemed to be looking ahead to victory in national elections early next year. Now, they are getting anxious. The Bonn prosecutor's office said last week that it was opening a judicial investigation into the possibility that Mr. Kohl had given false testimony to a parliamentary inquiry. The investigation will be the second into Mr. Kohl's testimony about his role in the country's biggest political corruption scandal, which involves allegations of bribery by Flick, the giant company whose holdings include paper, chemicals and steel.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
EVENING SWEATERS TO 'WONDERBREADS'
description: Bonnie Case Designs is having a sweater and yarn sale in Crugers -between Croton and Montrose -Thursday through Saturday only between noon and 5 P.M. Two hundred hand-knitted and hand-loomed sweaters - both samples and overproduction items will sell for $30 to $175, depending on the yarn and the size, plus the beading, pearls, paillettes, ribbons or other trim in the design.

title: KEEP THE PRESSURE ON CONGRESS FOR A NEW SUPERFUND BILL
description: NEW JERSEY residents have an enormous stake in the decisions that the Congress will make in the next few weeks on the Federal Superfund program. Unless action is taken quickly, the chances for a strong Federal program to clean up the nation's toxic wastes may perish.

title: MANES SPENT THE 'MISSING' HOURS ALONE IN HIS CAR, ASSOCIATE SAYS
description: No witnesses have given authorities any account of Donald R. Manes's movements on the night of his first suicide attempt, in January, because he spent seven ''missing'' hours alone in his car, brooding about whether to kill himself, according to one of his associates.

title: Robin Tufts Wed To Dr. R. J. Kaner
description: Robin J. Tufts, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Kearns Tufts Jr. of Ashland, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert J. Kaner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. S. Lawrence Kaner of Two Rivers, Wis. The ceremony was performed at the bridegroom's home in Yeadon, Pa., by Judge Thomas Lacey of the Delaware County Court in Media, Pa.

title: HARM TO ECONOMY OF CAPITAL IS SEEN
description: Federal spending cuts could cause ''serious damage'' to the capital region's economy over the next year, a private research organization here says.

title: HAWKS DO TURNABOUT ON FRESH LEGS
description: TWO years ago, after the Atlanta Hawks had made their customary early exit from the N.B.A. playoffs, Ted Turner decided it was time to take his team off his television network and give the Hawks' front office a chance to rebuild without the public scrutiny of a 41-game television schedule.

title: SUFFOLK PANEL TO STUDY WORKER DRUG TESTING
description: A panel to study whether Suffolk County employees should be tested for drug use has been appointed by the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan.

title: Marcia Jacobs to Wed J. E. Hooper 3d in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Jacobs 3d of Old Saybrook, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Marcia Davoren Jacobs to James Edward Hooper 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hooper Jr. of Owings Mills, Md., and Nantucket, Mass. The wedding is planned for May 29.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MAKE WAY FOR SAM HOUSTON By Jean Fritz. Illustrations by Elise Primavera. 109 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12) SAM HOUSTON was the kind of larger-than-life hero about whom legends of Texan proportion have been woven. The ''Hero of San Jacinto'' and the first president of the Republic of Texas, Houston was a soldier, politician and statemaker. In the hands of the fine biographer Jean Fritz, Houston's life retains its drama and vigor.

title: BRIDGE TOLLS MAY RISE
description: A 15-cent increase in automobile tolls on four Delaware River bridges is expected to be approved Wednesday by the Delaware River Port Authority.

title: Jews and Christians in Poland
description: To the Editor:

title: ELIZABETH TILT WENTWORTH IS TO MARRY CHRISTOPHER DAVID FERRONE IN OCTOBER
description: Mrs. Henry Brandon and Eric Wentworth, both of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Tilt Wentworth to Christopher David Ferrone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard A. Ferrone of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: Tenniel and the Ugly Duchess
description: To the Editor:

title: HOSPITAL CARE: INSULT ADDED TO INJURY
description: WORSE, far worse, I say in response to the Feb. 2 Opinion article, ''Is Care in Our Hospitals Better Now or Worse?''

title: The Acid Test of Friendship
description: Canada's Prime Minister Brian Mulroney is visiting Washington this week. He has been working to encourage American investment and defense relationships and should expect a warm welcome. But he and President Reagan are divided on a serious issue. Mr. Mulroney believes acid rain, soured by polluting power plants of the Ohio River valley, threatens North America's lakes and forests. So far, Mr. Reagan has given no sign of sharing that concern.

title: Marietta P. Edmunds to Marry May 10
description: Marietta Page Edmunds and Dennis Louis Zakas, both graduates of the University of Virginia School of Law, plan to be married May 10, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Coles Edmunds Jr. of Richmond, have announced. The future bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Dennis Zakas of Atlanta.

title: Intermission
description: On March 26 the National Theater will open Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title:
GARDENING;
DRY SOIL IS THE KEY TO EASY SEEDING
description: EACH day in March brings us closer to spring and the new gardening season. Those of us who are anxious to get outdoors will not have to wait much longer to get our hands into the soil.

title: A LONG TIME, BUT NOT THE LONGEST
