description: I have just finished reading about Cantor Ephraim Steinhauer of Temple Emanuel, New Hyde Park, who is retiring this June after 35 years with the temple [ ''About Long Island,'' March 2 ] . The cantor claims that his is the longest uninterrupted tenure in the same temple of any rabbi or cantor currently active on Long Island.

title: BRAZIL INMATES FIND MEDITATION A CALM ISLAND
description: Every dawn when the reveille bell rings, the 36-year-old inmate sits up in bed, adopts the lotus position and closes his eyes again.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BLUE LOBSTERS SEEK HOME THEY are an amazing sight. Although only one out of 30 million lobsters is blue, several hundred of these rare color mutants are living in a small laboratory building in Montauk.

title: DOMED STADIUM JUST THE TICKET
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: RED WINE, WHITE WATER
description: A short while ago, when I announced that I was about to embark on a white-water rafting trip in the Sierras of California, my friends responded with mock shock and unrehearsed hilarity.

title: NEW CASSETTES: HITCHOCK, HEIFETZ AND 'HARD BOP'
description: Suspicion Starring Gary Grant and Joan Fontaine; directed by Alfred Hitchcock, 1941 RKO Home Video 90 minutes. $29.95 After a whirlwind courtship, the young, rich, almost criminally unsophisticated Lina McLaidlaw (Joan Fontaine) marries penniless playboy Johnny Aysgarth (Cary Grant).

title: SUMMER JOBS EFFORT BEGINS 5TH SEASON
description: ''THE Summer Jobs for Youth Program represents the success of a true partnership between government, private sector and community organizations,'' said Kenneth Katzeff, the Westchester Private Industry Council coordinator with the jobs program, which will officially begin its fifth season at a breakfast at the Westchester Marriott Hotel on Wednesday.

title:
TREKS FOR THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER;
TRUE ADVENTURE: Galapagos Unretouched
description: Seven travelers' tales from all corners of the globe. Adventure is where you find it -- or sometimes where it finds you. Nothing had prepared me for what I saw and felt when I traveled to the Galapagos Islands. Even now, four years after I trekked across the lava heaps that are the Galapagos, images of that adventure come to me like photographs, whole in their description and deep in their potential for recapturing the moment.

title:
ART;
FIDELITY AND CLARITY ARE HALLMARKS OF WILLIAM TROST RICHARDS
description: THE apparent leanness of the main offering at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is balanced by an appreciation that presenting in-depth exhibitions of artists associated with the Hudson River School is what this museum almost has a mandate to do.

title: Reagan Takes Up The Cudgel for Immigration Bill
description: Ronald Reagan has not been shy about lobbying for such matters as cuts in domestic spending and aid to the rebels in Nicaragua; now, for the first time, the President has apparently decided to twist a few arms on behalf of immigration legislation.

title: A LEGACY OF POETS AND CANNIBALS: LITERATURE REVIVES IN ARGENTINA
description: I AM afraid that my country from the moment of its discovery has been faithful to a literary tradition that has promoted misrepresentation and fantasy. In 1516 Juan Diaz de Solis, sailing from Spain, knew he had reached the new continent and not the East Indies, so he began to search for a passageway to the other ocean. He thought he had found it to the far south, entering what he called the Freshwater Sea, now known as the Rio de la Plata, on the Atlantic coast of southern South America. (Four centuries later Jorge Luis Borges would dub it the river of ''dreamery'' and mud.) To its discoverers it appeared only as a vast body of water with swampy shores. On its west bank a handful of men were left to establish a settlement. Poetry was already lurking: on board with Solis was Martin del Barco Centenera, who wrote an ode titled ''The Argentina,'' thus giving a name to the new lands. A misnomer, since there was practically no argentum, no silver, there. The ode bestowed on the newly named Argentina Tritons, sirens and other European mythical creatures. It was written while the first settlers, surrounded by Indians, were forced to eat their dead.

title: RETIREES WHO LEARN AND TEACH AT HOFSTRA
description: It is somewhat surprising to note that the article ''A Hofstra University Dean With Students From 3 to 83'' [ Long Islanders, Feb. 16 ] has a glaring omission. Overlooked is the extraordinary program within the College of Continuing Education at Hofstra University called Professionals and Executives in Retirement (P.E.I.R.).

title: Elizabeth Stetson Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Elizabeth Stetson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Edward Stetson of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Jay Bennett Einbender at the New York home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alvin H. Einbender. Rabbi Alvin J. Reines, a cousin of the bridegroom's mother, officiated.

title: A.M.A. SETS ETHICS ON COMA PATIENTS
description: The American Medical Association said today that it would be ethical for doctors to withhold ''all means of life prolonging medical treatment,'' including food and water, from patients in irreversible comas even if death was not imminent.

title: VIOLINIST IS TOP FINALIST
description: Four talented state musicians received awards in the finals of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's ninth annual Young Artists Auditions, held last week at the John Harms Plaza Theater here.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: HASTE ON LONG ISLAND As fast as they can, 440 employees of banks all over Long Island will high-step it from the center of one rubber tire to another today in the Nold Hall Gymnasium at the State University of New York at Farmingdale, L.I..

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOLD FROM FRANCE
description: Many coins and medals are being issued this year to honor the Statue of Liberty. Few are as important as two new coins recently unveiled by the French Mint in Paris.

title:
SMOKING BAN GAINING ACCEPTANCE;
NASSAU OFF TO MIXED START ON NEW LAW
description: LITTLE more than a month after the enactment of the most sweeping smoking restrictions in the nation, Nassau County's public places show no clear pattern of compliance.

title: Susan J. Furman To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Furman of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Furman, to Andrew Wallace Walter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Walter of Chappaqua, N.Y. The wedding is planned for the fall. Miss Furman is a civil engineer for Tippetts-Abbett-McCarthy-Stratton in New York.

title: Looking to Freddie Mac for Loans
description: ''IT has been a good 25 years since mortgage money was available in the Bronx,'' said Michael Laub, a partner in groups that own 63 Bronx apartment buildings. ''Now the ball is rolling. The effect is tremendous.''

title: DEVELOPMENT AND STONY BROOK
description: The article about Dorothy Melville entitled '' 'Grande Dame' Looks Ahead'' [ Feb. 2 ] was a fitting tribute to a fine person. Unfortunately, the article did not accurately reflect the position of the Stony Brook Village Civic Association concerning the Stony Brook Community Fund's proposed $13 million residential and commercial expansion.

title: AGAINST THE SEA
description: Travel is an attitude. It is not a matter of place, though some places, more than others, appear to be convincing backdrops for adventure. But I have come to believe that travel is mostly in the mind.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a technical error today on page 63 of The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of The Times Magazine, the continuation for ''Off the Deep End'' is indicated illegibly. The article continues on page 100.

title: THE L.I.R.R. NEEDS MORE POLICE ON TRAINS
description: Long Island Rail Road Commuter's Council spokesman Sheldon Schachter's remark that ''walking up and down the trains looking for smokers in nonsmoking cars is not the way to improve the quality of life for commuters'' [ ''L.I.R.R. Trains Get Police Patrols,'' Feb. 16 ] is shocking.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE? DEPENDS ON WHERE
description: MAIA HAUSER, director of promotions and events marketing for Members Only, a maker of men's jackets and sportswear, reports to the president of the company. Barbara Paddock's division at Manufacturers Hanover is part of the marketing department. And at Wrangler Jeans, special events are part of the advertising department. ''Companies are just beginning to juggle under whose department special events will take place,'' said Mr. Stevens, the public relations specialist.

title: BYZANTINE WAYS OF ISTANBUL
description: It is the first rain Istanbul has had in four months and one half,'' the cabdriver declares with the pride of a father announcing the weight of his newborn child. As I have not thought to bring a raincoat, my response, instead of congratulations, is silence and a beady look. The road from the airport skirts the Sea of Marmara. There are lights from Asia, a mile across the Bosporus, and a nearby amusement park. It resembles the approach road to Athens. Then lightning flashes, and there is an impression, seared upon the eyes, of minarets, impossibly slender. Ahead, the view is a cliche from a score of travelogues: the Galata Bridge across the Golden Horn. As a reality it is stunning.

title: DANCE: ABSTRACTIONS BY KENNETH KING COMPANY
description: A CHOREOGRAPHER of mysterious abstractions, philosophical ruminations and science-fiction fantasies, Kenneth King delights in perplexity. On Thursday night, Kenneth King and Dancers Company took audiences at St. Mark's Church off to Wonderland.

title: MUSIC: VOICELESS OPERA, BY CONCERTS PLUS
description: CONCERTS PLUS scrutinized recycled opera themes at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday. There were two piano paraphrases of ''Carmen,'' Beethoven's seven variations for cello and piano on a theme from ''The Magic Flute,'' and then several fantasies - Castelnuovo-Tedesco treating Rossini's ''Largo al Factotum'' (cello and piano) and Percy Grainger's two-piano arrangement from ''Porgy and Bess.''

title: Carol Dawes Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Dawes of Richmond have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Winfield Dawes to Lawrence Kenyon Williamson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Williamson of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: NEWELL PUTS THE IRISH AWAY AND HIS SCHOOL ON THE MAP
description: They didn't even bring along their cheerleaders, but the chancellor is here, along with a few dozen fans and a basketball team named the University of Arkansas-Little Rock Trojans.

title: HENZE IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Hans Werner Henze celebrates his 60th birthday this year and, beginning Tuesday, the Manhattan School of Music is throwing the composer a week-long party.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THERE CAME A PROUD BEGGAR. By Mark Linder. (Carroll & Graf, $18.95.) The narrator of this first novel is himself a novelist, a garrulous type named Jacob Whiteside who has earned a large and loyal readership through a series of ironic romances that have marked him a ''Master of Civilized Despair.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: THE SWISS LOOK HARD AT THE U.N. AND THEMSELVES
description: AS the European headquarters of the United Nations and its adjuncts, this Swiss city is host every year to 30,000 diplomats and international civil servants, 120 international organizations and some 13,000 meetings. So it is something of an anomaly that Switzerland is the only major European country and, with North and South Korea, one of only a handful of states that are not members of the United Nations.

title: COMMISSIONER TELLS OF CONCERNS ON NUCLEAR SAFETY
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a House subcommittee Friday that an Oklahoma accident suggested the Government was not concerned enough about chemical safety problems at nuclear facilities.

title: NO STARS, BUT WORTH A DETOUR
description: It's the secure way to travel in France.

title: Karen M. Dunn Weds Physician
description: Karen Marie Dunn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomas Dunn of Colts Neck, N.J., and New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Leo Kelley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelley 2d of Mahwah, N.J. The Revs. William Bausch and James Tobin performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Colts Neck.

title: Aid Bill Defeated In Massachusetts
description: THE Massachusetts Legislature has narrowly defeated a proposed amendment to the state Constitution that would have allowed public aid to private and parochial schools.

title: BONE THOUGHT TO BE FROM PIRATE IS FOUND IN 1717 SHIPWRECK
description: A shoe containing a leg bone that may have been torn from a pirate nearly 270 years ago has been found on the ocean floor in the wreckage of the Whydah, a pirate ship that sank in a storm off Cape Cod in 1717.

title: YOU ARE WHAT YOU THROW OUT
description: MY wife has always believed that there is only one sure guide to status in the suburbs: garbage cans. The more garbage or refuse, and the more upscale the refuse, the higher the economic status.

title: FATHERS AND SONS: TRADITION CARRIES ON
description: STANDING 6 feet 6, Martin Berger's son Brad tops his father by an inch. ''He's not only taller, he's smarter,'' said Mr. Berger, president of the Robert Martin Company. ''We're lucky to have him working for us.''

title: CRIME
description: For a first novel, FINDING HOSEYN by Colin MacKinnon (Arbor House, $16.95) moves with an unusually sure hand. It helps that the author, an American journalist who has worked in Iran, is writing about something of which he has had personal experience. Mr. MacKinnon clearly has a decent acquaintance with the spy novels of John le Carre and has even looked back to such masterpieces as Eric Ambler's ''Coffin for Dimitrios.'' But he remains very much his own man and has written a most satisfactory thriller.

title: BREEZY, BOOZY AND BYELORUSSIAN
description: A FAMILY MADNESS By Thomas Keneally. 336 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. THE prolific Australian writer Thomas Keneally obviously likes to give himself tough assignments. Undeterred by the accidents of nationality or the hard facts of embryology, he has, in his recent fiction, chosen the American Civil War as the subject of one novel (''Confederates'') and a preternaturally sophisticated fetus as the narrator of another (''Passenger''). Still more ambitiously, he has written a gripping ''nonfiction novel'' of the Holocaust, ''Schindler's List,'' in which he tells the true story - embellished with an abundance of historical and imagined detail - of a Sudeten German industrialist and bon vivant, Oskar Schindler, who ingeniously and recklessly managed to snatch several thousand Jews from the very gullet of the Nazi death machine. ''Schindler's List'' won the Booker Prize in England, where it was published as a novel, and brought Mr. Keneally a wide audience in this country, where it was published as nonfiction. His new work, which seems to be in part a spinoff from the research undertaken for its predecessor, is again bold in its scope and its choice of subject.

title: Recent Sales
description: Florham Park $240,000 1 Dellwood Drive *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; *2*cathedral ceiling in living room, bay window, office; taxes $3,017. Glen Rock $147,000 23 Lehigh Place *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 47-year-old Tudor; living room with *2*fireplace, enclosed porch, 2-car garage; taxes $2,474. Kenilworth $144,000 525 Oak Street *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; *2*rec room with bar, attic fan, full basement; taxes $1,811. Leonia $177,400 33 Linden Terrace *2*2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; *2*fireplace in living room, sun porch; taxes $2,528. Mahwah $293,500 12 Green Way *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; *2*deck, pool, fenced yard; taxes $3,279. Maplewood $195,000 54 Burnett Terrace *2*4-bedroom, 2-bath, 56-year-old Tudor; *2*leaded windows, curved fireplace, natural-wood moldings; taxes $3,723. OTHER AREAS Larchmont, N.Y. $262,500 9 Birch Lane *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old frame split-level; *2*eat-in kitchen, family room, beach privileges; taxes $5,157. Cheshire, Conn. $194,500 100 Knob Hill Road *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; *2*fireplace in living room and family room, *2*large screened porch; taxes $2,622. Shirley, L.I. $88,000 37 Linden Lane *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old ranch; *2*dining room, basement, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $2,000.

title: NEW YORK SUES FORD ON REPAIR CHARGES ON SOME NEW CARS
description: New York State has filed suit against the Ford Motor Company, charging that it violated the state's ''lemon law'' by requiring customers to pay a $100 fee for repairs on new cars.

title: FLETCHER ENDS SLIDE IN WORLD CUP RACE
description: Pam Fletcher, who was nearly dropped from the United States Ski Team earlier this season, captured her first World Cup victory today, winning the final women's downhill of the season.

title: SHORT CUT TO MALL DISPUTED
description: SMITHTOWN Supervisor Patrick Vecchio has threatened legal action to prevent the Village of Lake Grove from closing a short cut to the Smith Haven Mall.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING DELAYED
description: PROPOSALS to create a total of 77 units of public housing for families in Huntington and Islip Towns are moving slowly through the bureaucratic process. But more than a year after the plans were proposed, housing officials are not certain whether either project will receive final approval.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AUGUSTINE'S LAWS. By Norman R. Augustine. (Viking, $18.95.) ''Augustine's Laws,'' a hilarious, elegantly crafted book, is, at 380 pages, profoundly overlong.

title: AMERICA'S FUTURE IN SPACE AFTER THE CHALLENGER
description: THE WARMING WINDS OF MARCH SWEEP THE EMPTY LAUNCHING PADS AT Cape Canaveral. It is a forlorn scene, like a seaside resort in the off-season, unsure that its season will return anytime soon. What is left of the space shuttle Challenger, which exploded after liftoff on Jan. 28, lies submerged offshore and in twisted fragments on the floor of a huge hangar at Florida's Kennedy Space Center. The remaining shuttles - Columbia, Discovery and Atlantis - sit in their hangars with nowhere to go. No shuttles, not much of anything, will be taking off for months, perhaps not for a year or two.

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA: INSIGHTS FAIL TO HALT RISING TOLL
description: Schizophrenia is emerging as the worst mental health problem facing the nation. Yet it has long been the most neglected.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
BUILDINGS AND NONBUILDINGS
description: Are architectural drawings works of art to be collected and presented according to the criteria applied to such artifacts, or are they mainly archival, documenting the architectural projects and ideas they represent? POSTMODERN VISIONS: Drawings, Paintings, and Models by Contemporary Architects (Abbeville Press, $55) will not answer this question. This book - or is it a catalogue? - edited by Heinrich Klotz, director of the new Deutsches Architekturmuseum in Frankfurt, presents a slightly curious mixture of the museum's own holdings and drawings and models borrowed on the occasion of an inaugural exhibition.

title: LTV AND STEELWORKERS REACH A TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The LTV Steel Company and the United Steelworkers of America today reached a tentative agreement on a contract that would pare wages and benefits in return for stock and a profit-sharing program.

title: Reagan Becomes a Force for Rights
description: As the world watched the remarkable transition from dictatorship to democracy in the Philippines, another dramatic change was unfolding in the corridors of Washington. In the wake of recent developments in Haiti, Chile, the Philippines and the Shcharansky case, the Reagan Administration must now be viewed as a significant force for international human rights. It is a role this Administration neither sought nor relishes - notwithstanding the credit it took for its human rights policy in a statement issued by the President on Friday.

title: Photo of Dr. Walbot at work in a laboratory at Stanford University; photo of genetically altered corn cells grousing in salt soluntion (NYT/Terrence McCarthy) RESEARCHERS SEE GAIN IN EFFORTS TO DESIGN CROPS
description: A team of Stanford University researchers recently reported breaking through a critical biological barrier and brought significantly closer the day when the world's major crops can be custom-designed.

title: THE MEXICANS AWAKE TO HARD TIMES
description: In the days of the oil boom, said a purchasing agent for a chain of restaurants, she would make two or more trips a year to the United States to shop or sight-see.

title: NEWBORN BOY IS FOUND SLAIN
description: Police are searching for clues in the death of a newborn baby boy whose body was found Friday morning near a trash can in a wooded area near Lake Mohegan.

title: Suzanne Namm to Wed
description: Judge and Mrs. Stuart Namm of Stony Brook, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Lizabeth Namm, to Richard Wolonick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wolonick of De Land, Fla.

title: Headliners; Wages of Spying
description: In 1961, Heinz Felfe, a former Nazi SS officer in charge of gathering information on the Soviet Union for West German intelligence, was revealed to have been working for a decade for the K.G.B., the Soviet spy agency.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'I SNOOP ON MY CHIDLREN - HERE'S WHY'
description: I am not damning the snooper. I pity her. I have compassion for Linda Flayton. I understand her dilemma. I have been there, but decades of experience have taught me that love and understanding can do more to help others than spying.

title: GOOD SPRING STIRS YANKS' MEMORIES
description: The players, and the manager, welcome exhibition victories because they keep the owner happy. The early success, though, does not register much significance in their view of the upcoming season. Nevertheless, two players and a former player still around from the Yankees' last World Series championship teams believe that the current team can match that success.

title: LOVE, LOVE, HOORAY FOR LOVE
description: THE BOURGEOIS EXPERIENCE Victoria to Freud. Volume Two: The Tender Passion. By Peter Gay. Illustrated. 490 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95. THE second volume of Peter Gay's projected five-volume survey of middle-class culture in the 19th century is a less tidy affair than its predecessor. In ''The Education of the Senses,'' (1984), the first volume of ''The Bourgeois Experience: Victoria to Freud,'' Mr. Gay took issue with received wisdom about Victorian sexuality. Despite their exaggerated fears of masturbation and their insistence on confining sex to marriage, the Victorians, he argued, appreciated sexual pleasure and pursued it avidly. His exploration of 19th-century love (the ''tender passion'' of the title of this volume) yields no such sharply etched revisionist thesis. To be sure, his book contains an argument of sorts, and many telling insights, but it is often overwhelmed by biographical detail, textual commentary and psychoanalytic speculation whose significance for his general portrait is not entirely clear.

title: AUCTION CENTRAL
description: Some bidders will buy what they can see, such as a six-foot-tall Paddington bear; some will buy what they can't see, like a sail down the Hudson River; and some will buy what they can't see, don't know the price of or even who else wants it.

title: Privatization
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN HONORS 26 FOR ACHIEVEMENTS
description: National medals for achievement in science and technology have been presented to 26 researchers, including four Nobel laureates.

title: THE ALPS, ON FOOT
description: If you are ready,'' Henry David Thoreau wrote at the end of his life, ''to leave father and mother, and brother and sister, and wife and child and friends, and never see them again - if you have paid your debts, and made your will, and settled all your affairs, and are a free man -then you are ready for a walk.''

title: Looking for 'Democratic Revolution'
description: President Reagan has moved firmly to the American center by at last condemning dictators of every shade, from Leninist red to rightist khaki. His broad commitment to aid ''democratic revolution'' everywhere follows his Administration's impressive diplomacy in Haiti and the Philippines and its heightened denunciation of tyranny in Chile.

title: MALAYSIA HOLDS 706 IN SECURITY CRACKDOWN
description: The police said today that they had rounded up 706 foreigners for deportation in the eastern state of Sabah as part of a stiffer security program after bombings there.

title: Julie M. Lewin Is to Marry Guy M. Barudin on May 18
description: Julie M. Lewin, a fourth-year student at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Guy M. Barudin, a candidate for a master's degree in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, plan to be married May 18. Miss Lewin graduated cum laude from Princeton University in the class of '82, and Mr. Barudin graduated cum laude from Princeton in the class of '83.

title: Boringly Close
description: I WAS NOT AMONG those who shouted, ''Oh boy!'' when President Reagan endorsed a flying machine to get people from the East Coast to Japan in two hours. There is something dull about places that are just two hours away, and I can't believe Japan will be an exception.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
FACULTY STABILITY CRUCIAL TO SCHOOLS
description: RECENT surveys show that the average public school teacher is just over 40 and has been teaching just under 20 years - often in the same system. When this teacher entered the profession, S.A.T. scores had just peaked nationally. Ten years later, the bottom fell out, and everyone had his pet reason why.

title: NASA AIDE ASSAILS METHODS OF INVESTIGATORS
description: The director of the Kennedy Space Center said today that the space program could be ''permanently damaged'' because investigators of the Challenger disaster questioned the integrity of NASA officials before they understood what caused the shuttle to explode.

title: LOVE, LUST AND THE PASSING OF SEASONS
description: DREAM PALACE By Herbert Morris. 87 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $8.95. ALMA By Linda Gregg. 69 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $7.95. ORRERY By Richard Kenney. 108 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $17.50. Paper, $10.95. HERBERT MORRIS is not a newcomer, though his first book, ''Peru,'' appeared just three years ago. He had been publishing poems for a quarter century before he was persuaded to collect them, and he had devised such a distinctive style that ''Peru'' was greeted with surprised acclaim by those unfamiliar with him. A strong style is like any other landmark - it seems always to have been there. And Mr. Morris is an original, in part because he is a throwback.

title: IS TELEVISION DOING ITS NEWS JOB?
description: AMERICAN Cablesystems of Beverly, Mass., shocked its viewers recently with a public-service announcement asking people to turn off their television sets at least part of the day and do some reading.

title: MUSIC: DAVID WEINSTEIN IN AVANT-GARDE SHOW
description: ROULETTE is a performance space at 228 West Broadway, a second-floor room small enough to get uncomfortably smoky from a single cigarette, as David Weinstein demonstrated by lighting one during a jittery piece called ''Calm'' on his program of electronic and vocal music there Friday.

title: RENT SUIT
description: The Rent Guidelines Board was sued last week by several tenant associations and by one of its own members, Alfred F. Corbo, for a decision last September allowing landlords to increase rents by 6 percent on a one-year lease and 10 percent on a two-year lease. The suit asks the courts to set aside the increases.

title: WHO IS THE ENEMY?
description: ECLIPSE By William Stevenson. 370 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. NO doubt about it, a terrific story awaits the first reporter who can get into Spandau Prison and wangle an exclusive interview with Hitler's onetime deputy, Rudolf Hess.

title: HOW 'CHEERS' KEEPS ITS SPARKLE
description: It looks like an ordinary studio set, yet what goes on within its three walls is anything but ordinary.

title: Trilby Holmes Is Engaged
description: Frank E. Holmes Jr. of Fort Lee, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., and Joan S. Holmes of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Trilby Hollingsworth Holmes, to Parker Corning Barrett Jr., a son of Elizabeth Payne Freet, also of Ridgefield, and Mr. Barrett of Bronxville, N.Y. The wedding is planned for September. The future bride is a computer programmer with Nynex in White Plains. Her father is the executive vice president of Encyclopaedia Britannica U.S.A. in Fort Lee, N.J. Mr. Barrett is an associate of the Oscar R. Barrett Insurance Company in Bronxville, a concern of which his father is a vice president and his grandfather, Oscar R. Barrett, is president.

title: Boston University Wins
description: A five-goal second period propelled Boston University to 7-1 lead, and the Terriers went on to a 9-4 victory over favored Boston College tonight to capture the Hockey East championship at the Providence Civic Center.

title: NEW YORK SCRUTINIZING BUSINESS SCHOOL AGENTS
description: An increase in complaints from students about the recruiting practices of private business schools has led state education officials and lawmakers to closely examine the rapidly growing business-school industry and the way it enrolls students.

title: Management and Budget Plan Would Cut University Research
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AUDIT UNDER FIRE
description: THE fight over the remains of the bankrupt DeLorean Motor Company is still pitting an array of investors and creditors against the company's flamboyant founder, John Z. DeLorean. But now the spotlight also is falling on the normally shrouded work of the auditors that assessed the company's books.

title: KEY SENATOR OFFERS A COMPROMISE ON CONTRA AID
description: The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that the Administration should provide money to the Nicaraguan insurgents, but withhold military aid if the Sandinistas agree to a series of internal changes.

title: Von Bulow Speaks At Harvard
description: CLAUS von Bulow was supposed to have spoken on the differences between the American and English judicial systems at Harvard this week, but professional commentary gave way to a personal reflection on his two trials for the attempted murder of his wife, Martha.

title: LADY KNIGHTS IN SEMIFINAL
description: Rutgers defeated Villanova, 85-58, today to advance to the semifinals of N.C.A.A. East Regional in women's basketball.

title: OPERETTA GROUP PLANS DEBUT
description: DO not think that William H. Edgerton, a resident of Darien, Conn., and a part-time producer, does not dote on opera. He does travel around the world to see the newest productions of the oldest war horses.

title: JOBS FOR RETARDED AIM OF STATE EFFORT
description: THE State Department of Mental Retardation has allocated $6.5 million to help the mentally retarded gain employment in private industries, marking the first time the agency has earmarked financing for a program of this kind.

title: Florida Watchers
description: Republicans in the Florida legislature have invited Vice President Bush to address a joint session of State Senate and House in May, and his office said Friday that such a visit was under consideration.

title: RENTING A HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: For many vacationers, there is no better way to spend a couple of weeks than to rent a small cottage in unfamiliar countryside and absorb a way of life far different from their own. In France, for example, hundreds of modestly priced country places are available that abide by government standards. In the free brochure in English that describes them, they are classified with symbols resembling ears of corn - similar to the way the Michelin guides rate restaurants with stars. One ear means that a place offers basic comfort but little else; two usually means more comfort and greater proximity to leisure facilities and three means very comfortable and situated in an area of outstanding interest or recreational opportunity.

title: JAKARTA GOVERNMENT EXPELS ECONOMIC WEEKLY'S REPORTER
description: A correspondent for the Hong Kong magazine Far Eastern Economic Review has been told his visa will not be extended and he must leave Sunday, an official said today.

title: Jane Bernstein to Wed Jonathan Wells in May
description: Lord and Lady Bernstein of Leigh, Kent, and London have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Isobel Bernstein to Jonathan Wells, a son of Arnold Wells of New York and Jean Wells of Easton, Conn. The wedding is to be in England in May.

title: EX-MAYOR IS CONVICTED IN WEST HOLLYWOOD CASE
description: A member of the West Hollywood City Council who was the first avowed lesbian Mayor of an American city was found guilty Friday of embezzling $9,000 intended for the poor.

title: Playing To Win - and Gain
description: In ''A Courtship With Fame'' (Feb. 2), Karen Stabiner provides an interesting commentary on the state of sport today. It may be true that 15-odd years at $60,000 a year might not make Debbie Spence financially independent by the end of her playing career, but this sort of attitude contrasts strongly with that of an earlier generation of athletes.

title: PRIDE OF THE NAVY TEAM SYMBOLIZED BY ROBINSON
description: When David Robinson made the decision last summer that would shape his life for the next decade, many who did not know him well expressed disbelief.

title: DEATH AND THE RITUALS THAT HEAL
description: WITHIN the past few months five of my friends have lost their mothers. For one, the loss came with a stinging suddenness when her mother died during sleep. For the others, who had spent months shepherding their mothers through long-term illnesses, there had been time to prepare for the end of a relation that, for some, had begun over half a century ago.

title: 10 FAIRFIELD WOMEN OVER 40 SING JUST FOR THE FUN OF IT
description: MEMBERSHIP in Touch of Class is limited to 10 and is by invitation only. Newcomers are chosen for their ability to blend in with the group. But the foremost requirement is that you be a woman over 40 years old who can sing her heart out.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Less Urge to Merge With stock prices at record highs, mergers and acquisitions - just too costly - are likely to drop off sharply. That is the view of several economists, among them Maury N. Harris at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. Not only are costs discouragingly high, says Mr. Harris, but many of the corporations likely to be acquired have already been bought up. ''It is going to get harder and harder to find something cheap,'' he said.

title: JUDITH IVEY TRIES ON A 40'S PROM QUEEN FOR SIZE
description: Just to get one thing out of the way quickly, this is what it was like to kiss Don Johnson:

title: A VERMONT PLEA IS DUE FOR MAPLE
description: There were humorous speeches by old-time sugar makers, some low-key politicking and plenty of maple-saturated food as the maple sugaring season officially opened this week. But beneath the gaiety and boosterism ran an undercurrent of concern for the future of one of Vermont's oldest and most profitable agricultural endeavors.

title: CHINA'S BALLET DANCERS ADAPT TO NEW INFLUENCES
description: When Margot Fonteyn lived in China in the 1920's (her father was there on business) she studied ballet as a child in Shanghai with the Russian emigre teacher George Goncharov. There were no Chinese children in her class.

title: A PERPETUAL MOTION MACHINE IN THE LAND OF THE STIFF UPPER LIP
description: The sour-looking commuter is sitting in his best business suit on the subway, quite unaware that the Invisible Man is in a playful mood and riding beside him. Suddenly someone, something is blowing in his ear, then down his neck. The commuter jumps and wriggles and earnestly inspects the train's windows, trying desperately to keep his composure in the face of a bewildering attack. Then something, someone is grabbing his arms, his legs, and making them behave in wild, undignified ways; and pomposity just can't be sustained. Before long the poor city gent is bug-eyed on the floor, regarded no doubt as a lunatic by his fellow-travelers - and certainly a figure of delirious fun to the audience jammed into London's Shaftesbury Theater.

title: Translator of 'The Unloved'
description: To the Editor:

title: POTSDAM ENDS PERFECT SEASON
description: Tim Harris scored 7 straight points in the final 47 seconds tonight as Potsdam State beat LeMoyne-Owen, 76-73, to win the Division III championship and become collegiate basketball's first unbeaten titlist in 10 years.

title: POSTER SHOWS LOVE FOR THE STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: LOU BONAMARTE of New London says he grew up with a special admiration for the Statue of Liberty, but it went beyond lump-in-the-throat patriotism. ''I have always been artistically fascinated with it,'' he said.

title: PLUNGING INTO THE JUDEAN DESERT
description: What I remembered most after-ward were two moments of pure, unadulterated fear, and then a spectacular silence. The first moment came when I felt the rappelling ropes grow taut in my hands, signaling that my descent down the 250-foot salt chimney into the heart of Mount Sodom was about to begin. The second came at the moment my feet left the rock ledge and I began to hang in midair and glide down the ropes into the yawning silence. It was a special silence, not the kind you get from closing a window and shutting out the noise. It was the silence of a place where there had been virtually no noise for two million years, which is what it took for nature to produce Mount Sodom, the salt dome rising 755 feet from the western bank of the Dead Sea near the spot where the Bible says Lot's wife cast her fateful look back.

title: A Welcome Reversal
description: An encouraging new tide seems to be surging in various parts of the world with growing support for democracy and rejection of violence. It is by no means a flood; there are still oceans of dreadfulness around emerging islands of hope.

title: GIVING CLIENTS A RUN FOR THEIR MONEY
description: FRED LEBOW, who started the New York Marathon in 1970, can still recall the days when corporations laughed at the mere suggestion that they tie their names to a race. Today, Mr. Lebow has a committee to pick suitable corporate sponsors from a raft of applicants.

title: The Tyranny Of the Yale Critics
description: When I stumbled through the Yale Comp. Lit. program in the mid-1970's, the English department looked on ''the Yale Critics'' (Paul de Man, J. Hillis Miller, Geoffrey H. Hartman and even their own Harold Bloom) with barely veiled contempt. Graduate students in English, uncomfortable reading Jacques Derrida's then-untranslated work in the original French, dismissed him as a parasitic practitioner of ''meta-criticism'' (gasp! criticism of criticism).

title: BLOOM AGENCY CHOSEN IN U.S. BY ALFA ROMEO
description: The New York office of Dallas's Bloom agency has been named to do United States advertising for Alfa Romeo, the Italian-made automobile. Billings could be between $8 million and $10 million.

title: PHILADELPHIA'S TRANSIT SYSTEM IS HALTED AS WORKERS GO ON STRIKE
description: City buses, trolleys and subways stopped running today as thousands of mass transit workers went on strike, shutting down transportation for 440,000 daily riders in the nation's fifth largest city.

title: A DANCE FESTIVAL IN INDIA MELDS THE EROTIC AND THE DIVINE
description: It was as if the sculptures adorning the ancient stone walls of the Hindu temples had come to life.

title: PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS IN 'TRIPLECROSS'
description: ONE of the few bright spots in ABC's ratings picture over the last year has been ''Moonlighting.'' So it is only business as usual to find the network searching for imitations. One painful contender can be found in ''Triplecross,'' the television movie at 9 this evening. Clearly designed as a pilot for a possible series, this Tisch-Avnet production strains desperately to be a light-hearted caper.

title: TREASURY RETURNS AS TOP BORROWER
description: The Treasury will reassert itself as the largest borrower in the credit markets this week with a regular monthly auction of two-year notes and an announcement of note and bond auctions next week totaling an estimated $19 billion.

title: Dander on the Right
description: Step with me into the tumultuous, complicated, fun-filled world of politics as practiced in the democracy called Israel.

title: A 'FAMILY' REUNION FOR A FORMER MET
description: Next to Darryl Strawberry, the Mets had no young player with a bigger bat or bigger future a few years ago than Billy Beane, the tall, handsome Californian with the storybook name. Then, fine-tuning the team for a shot at the pennant, they made a trade with the Minnesota Twins this winter for a platoon second baseman, and suddenly Billy Beane was gone.

title: CELTICS ROUT 76ERS, 118-101
description: The guards Dennis Johnson and Danny Ainge sparked a 20-7 third-quarter surge that carried Boston to a 118-101 victory today over the Philadelphia 76ers and brought the Celtics to within one of tying their record for consecutive home victories.

title: A Choice, Not an Echo
description: Any President has the political advantage in his ability to frame issues for decision. A President as articulate as Ronald Reagan, and as determined as he is on the issue of Nicaragua, has an enormous momentum going for him.

title: REGAN ASKS SHIFT IN SENATE TAX PLAN
description: As the Senate Finance Committee prepared to begin drafting a sweeping tax-revision plan, a top White House official said today that some changes would ultimately have to be made to the working blueprint for President Reagan to endorse it.

title: EVANGELISM AND A FIGHT WITH PERIL TO BOTH SIDES
description: Last fall 50,000 copies of a fund-raising letter signed by the Democratic national chairman went out describing in typically partisan direct-mail language a potential Republican Presidential candidate ''too radical even for Ronald Reagan.''

title: SAUDIS WARN ON CURRENCY
description: The Saudi Arabian monetary agency, the Saudi central bank, has told banks in the kingdom to stop speculating against the riyal, bankers said Saturday.

title: HELMS ON A NEW TARGET: TAX TREATY WITH CHINA
description: Senator Jesse Helms is worried that someday China might end up like the Netherlands Antilles.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN COMPOSERS GROUP
description: ALTHOUGH we take pride in our jazz and popular songs, Americans have always had a peculiar inferiority complex when assessing our homegrown concert music. For far too many American concertgoers, ''serious'' music is something written by dead Europeans.

title: REAGAN CONDEMNS NICARAGUA IN PLEA FOR AID TO REBELS
description: President Reagan, condemning Nicaragua as a ''cancer'' that poses a direct threat to the United States, said tonight that stopping Communism and international terrorism there would serve as a historic test of his Presidency.

title: JOHN NOBLE PROMOTED TO TOP AT DOYLE DANE
description: John Noble, 46 years old and one of six creative directors at Doyle Dane Bernbach/New York, has been promoted to executive creative director, the top man.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Miami dispatch yesterday about Frank A. Sturgis, a Watergate burglar who says he will try to reopen his case, described Federal District Judge John J. Sirica incorrectly. He is alive.

title: 7 Killed in Tribal Clashes At South African Mine
description: Seven people were killed and 67 wounded today in clashes between rival tribal factions at the world's second largest gold mine. The death toll in two days of violence among miners reached 14, officials said.

title: BUDGET CURBS BANK AGENCIES
description: SENATOR JAKE GARN of Utah had some unkind words for the Administration's budget officials late last week. ''I can't believe O.M.B. has any brains,'' the Republican chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said of the Office of Management and Budget. ''When we have this many banks in trouble, it's not the time to cut back the banking agencies. That is just plain stupid.''

title: JAMES V. CASEY
description: Archbishop James V. Casey, spiritual leader of more than 750,000 Roman Catholics in Colorado and Wyoming, died Friday after being stricken with a brain aneurysm March 1. He was 71 years old.

title: A Smaller I.C.C. Still Has a Rail-Regulatory Role
description: To the Editor:

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;
Impressive Jockey
description: Once in a while, a fresh feminine breeze airs out the male-dominated world of the race-horse jockey. Last year Abigail Fuller was the darling of the game with her exploits in New York aboard Mom's Command. This winter the spotlight shifted to northern California, where fans at Golden Gate Fields were frequently rewarded by betting on Vicky Aragon, a 21-year-old apprentice who gave Russell Baze, the 11-time local champion, more than enough competition at the top of the standings.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:38 A.M. today and set at 12:43 P.M. On Tuesday it will rise at 3:33 A.M. and set at 12:33 P.M.

title: FLYERS DEFEAT DEVILS
description: Brad McCrimmon scored twice and Murray Craven had a goal and two assists as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Devils, 4-1, tonight for their fourth consecutive victory. The triumph gave the first-place Flyers a 3-point lead over idle Washington in the Patrick Division.

title: FOREIGN-STOCK MUTUAL FUNDS
description: MUTUAL funds that invest only in foreign stocks are continuing their winning ways in 1986. Portfolio managers, meanwhile, report growing interest on the part of investors who seek diversification, along with potential profits, in overseas markets.

title: For Holtzman at Harvard, A Chance to Share Ideas
description: Crime and punishment is a suitable topic for a Harvard conference. But Elizabeth Holtzman did not go to Cambridge to talk about Dostoyevsky.

title: Five Years and $1.7 Billion Later, the Salvadoran War Rages On
description: To the Editor:

title: ONE ARTIST'S VIEW OF 1920'S 'FLICKS'
description: It was raining, that day in 1928, and Batiste Madalena was taking a shortcut home from lunch when something caught his eye behind the Eastman Theater in Rochester: A pile of movie posters had been tossed into a trash heap, now dripping with colors.

title: Marjorie S. Dammann, Active In Westchester Social Work
description: Marjorie Spiegel Dammann, who was active in establishing social welfare agencies in Westchester County, died yesterday in Boston. She was 74 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: WINNERS AND LOSERS: PROMINENT POLITICAL LEADERS IN FRANCE
description: Raymond Barre Member of Parliament from Lyons . . . Prime Minister under President Valery Giscard d'Estaing from 1976 to 1981 . . . Declared presidential candidate . . . Generally disliked as Prime Minister, when he was identified with unpopular anti-inflationary policies . . . Now the strongest potential vote-getter among the major conservative figures . . . A man with no formal party affiliations who has benefited from appearing to be above politics . . . Born April 12, 1924, on Reunion in the Indian Ocean, now a French department . . . Academic career as professor of economics at the Institute of Political Science . . . Author of classic textbook on political economy used in French universities . . . Married and has two children . . . Stout, jovial, a habitue of Lyons's great restaurants . . . Divided the right in legislative campaign by refusing in advance to govern under President Francois Mitterrand. Jacques Chirac

title: BEIRUT MISSING HONORED IN PRAYER
description: Hundreds of people attended a church service today in honor of six Americans kidnapped in Lebanon, who were described by the Rev. Jesse Jackson as ''victims of a faceless war.''

title: NO ANGER FOR THE REDMEN
description: Their predecessors had cried at the end of losses in tournaments past when last-second shots fell off rims or when time ran out before the St. John's Redmen were willing to believe their season had ended.

title: AS MORE FAMILY FARMS FAIL, HIRED MANAGERS TAKE CHARGE
description: The wave of farm failures that has swept the country is swamping public and private lenders and stimulating the rapid growth of professional farm management.

title: Southern Cal Women Advance
description: Cynthia Cooper scored 19 points today as Southern Cal routed Montana, 81-50, in the second round of the N.C.A.A. women's West Regional.

title: NAVRATILOVA DOMINATES LLOYD
description: Martina Navratilova overpowered Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-2, 6-1, in 57 minutes today to capture the Virginia Slims of Dallas tournament for the seventh time.

title: SLUMP IN OIL PRICES IS TROUBLING BRAZIL
description: At first sight, the slump in world oil prices should be all good news for Brazil, a major oil importer that will save $1.7 billion if prices stay down throughout 1986. Yet, so far, it has brought mostly problems.

title: Joanne Zeides Is Married To Michael M. Kornbluth
description: Joanne Zeides, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Solomon Zeides of Spring Valley, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael M. Kornbluth, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Mendel Kornbluth of Monsey, N.Y. The bride's father officiated at Singer's Hotel.

title: JAZZ: AL COHN, SAXOPHONIST
description: LAST Friday and Saturday, New Yorkers could hear Al Cohn - the tenor saxophonist who used to perform in New York in tandem with Zoot Sims - in the kind of situation in which a jazz musician is often heard out of town.

title: West German Wins Ski Title
description: Marina Kiehl of West Germany won the 1986 women's World Cup super-giant slalom title today, winning the final race of the season by 24 hundredths of a second over Anita Wachter of Austria.

title: Saudis Ready to Come To Kuwait's Defense
description: Saudi Arabia declared today that it would come to the defense of Kuwait if the Kuwaitis were attacked by Iran.

title: THE CHILL REMAINS IN SYRACUSE
description: ALL winter long - and that is indeed a long time up here in the snow belt - Dwayne Washington felt the hopes of the Syracuse fans heaped on his sloped shoulders.

title: China Project Weighed
description: The United States has offered to provide equipment, technology and management skills to build a dam on the Yangtze River in what could be one of the world's largest power projects, United States officials said Friday. But China has to decide whether to go ahead with the the Three Gorges project in Sichuan in southwest China.

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA'S VICTIMS INCLUDE STRAINED FAMILIES
description: The greatest numbers of schizophrenics do not now live in hospitals or in the streets or jails, but rather with their families, representing a profound change in the way the nation cares for its most severely mentally ill.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN TO DECIDE
description: THEY are the kinds of experiences that nearly every child faces at some time or another. Being teased. Feeling shut out of a group of friends. Playing with schoolmates when there's homework to be done. Accepting a playmate's dare. Going along with peer pressure to do something dangerous, mean or destructive.

title: TALKS, NOT GUNS, DEMOCRAT URGES
description: The Democrats tonight drew a distinctly different picture of the strategic threat posed by the situation in Nicaragua than President Reagan, and they said the President should use diplomatic methods, not military ones, to halt the spread of Communism in Central America.

title: QUITE A PERSON
description: IN a quiet moment after St. John's was eliminated rudely and roughly by Auburn, 81-65, from the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Lou Carnesecca shook hands with Chuck Person.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: Accounts

title: NEW PRODUCTS GALORE
description: New-product introductions in February continued the upward curve begun in January, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. The total was 218, compared with 176 in February 1985. While 218 was the basic figure, the newsletter noted, 477 different flavors, colors and varieties of products were introduced.

title: SOUTHWEST AIR IS FACING CHALLENGE OF ITS MAKING
description: All but obscured these days by the giant shadow of Frank Lorenzo and his expanding Texas Air Corporation empire, a colorful Texas rival is coming under growing pressure from forces it unleashed as one of the original low-fare airlines.

title: ZEAL AND FEAR MINGLE AT VORTEX OF SHUTTLE INQUIRY
description: The Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., is bustling with investigative zeal and proclaiming its confidence in the future of the space program. But it is also seething with resentment, hostility, depression and exhaustion in the wake of the shuttle catastrophe.

title: Salary History a Must
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS PRODUE NO GAINS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz returned to Washington early this morning after a meeting with the Soviet Prime Minister that apparently failed to advance prospects for the next Soviet-American summit meeting or produce progress on other major issues.

title: 2 Feared Drowned Upstate
description: A Cornell University student and a rescue worker are missing and presumed drowned after falling into the falls at Buttermilk Falls State Park yesterday, the park police said. Lieut. Don Murray, the police spokesman, said the student was Paul J. Schreurs of Corning and the rescue worker was William Chapin, who the lieutenant said fell into the water where the student did.

title: TV Officials Approve Air Time for Reagan
description: The air time for the nationally televised address by President Reagan last night was requested by the White House and approved by the top news executives of the major networks, CBS, NBC and ABC, who also authorized air time for the response by the Democrats.

title: NASA Called Wasteful On Shuttle Contracts
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has wasted millions of dollars on shuttle contracts because of excessive markups on parts, freeloading contractors and loafing work crews, The Miami Herald reported today.

title: BRITISH AIR BID IS REPORTED
description: Executives of British Airways plan to start a $1.46 billion bid for the state-owned carrier early next week, a London newspaper has reported.

title: SHARON STARTS MEDIATING STRUGGLE FOR LEADERSHIP OF THE HERUT PARTY
description: Ariel Sharon took on the role of mediator today in the bitter struggle between Yitzhak Shamir and David Levy for the leadership of the right-wing Herut Party.

title: KIRI TE KANAWA IN 'SIMON BOCCANEGRA'
description: Verdi is not quite home ground for Kiri Te Kanawa, but many pages of ''Simon Boccanegra'' stand to benefit from the creamy sounds she can make. Moreover, she has found a special feeling for the role of Amelia; she gave a beautiful performance, spirited and involved, at Saturday's Metropolitan Opera matinee.

title: BRAZIL BISHOPS STILL SPLIT AFTER MEETING WITH POPE
description: Brazil's Roman Catholic leadership ended a meeting with the Vatican today with an expression of ''full adherence'' to the teachings of Pope John Paul II, but apparently without any agreement to settle their differences.

title: BRIDGE: SPRING NATIONAL TITLES WON BY PLAYERS WITH EXPERIENCE
description: Experience prevailed here Saturday night when two major championships were decided at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: CREWS RAISE LARGE CHUNK OF SHUTTLE BOOSTER
description: A 3,250-pound chunk of booster rocket was raised from the ocean floor today as efforts to recover Challenger debris, including the space shuttle's damaged crew compartment, resumed after two days of storms and rough seas.

title: Susan Wolf Wed to Richard Friedman
description: The wedding of Susan M. Wolf and Richard David Friedman took place yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1986
description: International

title: WHAT IS OIL? A DISPUTE AND A TEXAS HARDSHIP
description: A powerful drama is unfolding across the vast oil and gas fields of the Texas Panhandle, and people like Gilbert Haiduk are cast as the innocent victims.

title: ANOTHER WARNACO OFFER
description: Warnaco Inc., a leading apparel manufacturer, received a buyout offer last night of $36 a share, or about $360 million, from the W Acquisition Corporation of Delaware.

title: IN ULSTER, THE 'SHOOT TO KILL' RUMORS WILL NOT DIE
description: Frederick Jackson, a middle-aged Protestant businessman, was never involved in the turbulent politics of Northern Ireland until he became one of its more unlikely victims. He was shot dead by a British Army undercover unit 17 months ago under circumstances that have never been explained.

title: ZENITH FORESEES DEFICIT
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation, a leading television manufacturer and a growing factor in the microcomputer industry, said it expected to report a loss in the first quarter. Zenith, which lost $7.7 million last year on sales of $1.6 billion, said the first-quarter loss would be caused by lower consumer electronics ''selling prices carried over from 1985'' and limited availability in televisions and microcomputers. Zenith, based in Glenview, Ill., made the statements in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of $100 million in convertible subordinated debentures.

title: A REVAMP FOR ABC'S 'GOOD MORNING'
description: The new management of ABC, eager to halt the swift decline of the network's once-dominant morning news and talk program, ''Good Morning America,'' is planning an extensive reworking of the program. It may transfer the broadcast from the entertainment division to ABC News, according to network executives.

title: Bolshoi Ballet Dancers To Join Joffrey for Gala
description: Nadezhda Pavlova and Aleksei Fadeyechev of the Bolshoi Ballet will dance with the Joffrey Ballet on April 1 in the gala performance that opens the Joffrey's three-week, 30th anniversary season at the New York State Theater. The Bolshoi dancers will perform two pas de deux on a program that includes appearances by Fernando Bujones and the cabaret performers Barbara Cook and Wally Harper.

title: How to Read the Hospital Death List
description: The mix of computer technology and Washington's determination to control hospital costs produces a volatile byproduct: a list of hospitals where death occurs at an abnormally high rate. Will the list's benefit to research outweigh the risk of its abuse? Only time will tell, but there is plenty of reason to think positively.

title: Israel Retains Chief of Staff
description: The Israeli Cabinet agreed today to extend by a year the term of the Chief of Staff, Gen. Moshe Levy, a Cabinet statement said. General Levy, a 49-year-old former paratroop commander, took on the three-year post in 1983.

title: SANDINISTA VIEW OF CONTRA DEBATE: ORTEGA TAKES A VACATION
description: When Congress was debating aid to the Nicaraguan rebels last year, it seemed that most Government business in Nicaragua came to a halt as every Sandinista in the country joined the campaign against the proposals.

title: FRANCE IN NEW WATERS
description: France's five-year experiment with Socialism, the longest period of left-wing rule it has known since the Revolution of 1789, appears to have ended with the country heading for uncharted political waters.

title: THE LONG ARM OF CABLE
description: A. C. Nielsen, measurer of most things measurable, has reported that household penetration by cable TV in all 50 states reached 46.8 percent last month, a 5 percent gain from a year earlier. The estimate of total households with cable is 40.4 million.

title: DANCE: ST. PAULY GIRLS
description: NO one could accuse ''The St. Pauly Girls Go Hawaiian'' of not striving to be clever.

title: HORMEL STRIKERS VOTE TO CONTINUE
description: Union meatpackers, acting in defiance of their parent union, voted today to continue their seven-month strike against the Geo. A. Hormel & Co.

title: FORMER S.E.C. MEMBER NAMED HUTTON COUNSEL
description: Stephen J. Friedman, a partner in the law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton and a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been named executive vice president and general counsel at E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and a member of the firm's eight-man management committee.

title: Shepherd Wins Atlanta Auto Race
description: Morgan Shepherd ended a 112-race stretch without a victory today by holding off Dale Earnhardt to win the Motorcraft 500 Nascar stock car race at Atlanta International Raceway.

title: HIGHER GAS TAX URGED AS AID TO MASS TRANSIT
description: With gasoline prices falling, gasoline taxes in the New York metropolitan area should be raised to help pay for a better subway system, according to a private study to be released today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STRANGERS IN THEIR OWN LAND:

title: NO HAVEN FOR MARCOS, SPAIN SAYS
description: A spokesman for the Spanish Foreign Ministry, responding to reports that Ferdinand E. Marcos had expressed a wish to live in Spain, said tonight that the ousted Philippine President would not be offered a haven here.

title: REED SARRATT
description: Reed Sarratt, executive director of the 442-member Southern Newspaper Publishers' Association, died Saturday. He was 68 years old.

title: Warren Katz Weds Deborah Bronston
description: Deborah Tamar Bronston and Warren Richard Katz were married yesterday at the Gill/St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J. Judge Miriam Span of the Superior Court of New Jersey performed a civil ceremony, followed by a religious ceremony performed by Michael Cohen, a rabbinical student and cousin of the bride.

title: Canal St. Flea Market Closes After 12 Years
description: After 12 years as a thriving business in SoHo, the Canal Street Flea Market closed yesterday.

title: Edith Atwater Is Dead at 74; Actress in Theater and Film
description: Edith Atwater, an actress whose career covered more than 50 years on the stage, in films and television, died of cancer Friday at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 74 years old and lived in the Los Angeles community of Westwood.

title: Consumer Awareness in High-Tech Births
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITSON RECALLS UNHAPPY SEASON
description: When his two innings were complete, Ed Whitson returned to the visiting clubhouse and slowly began to strip off his uniform. In a symbolic sense, the Yankee pitcher was trying to rid himself of some horrendous memories. But they won't go away. Whitson is still trying to forget a nightmarish 1985 season, although he does not believe he will be free of it until he changes uniforms for good. He wants a trade - and he reportedly disagrees with management on whether his contract allows him to demand one - but the Yankees neither hope nor intend to make a deal. Manager Lou Piniella has already made the right-hander one of his five starting pitchers.

title: The U.N. Today: March 17, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: OF WHINE, MOB CRIME AND WINE
description: ''Helicopter'' is becoming a fighting word in Hawaii.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM 'INLETS 2'
description: A PROGRAM note for ''Inlets 2,'' presented by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Saturday afternoon at City Center, describes the dance as a variation of a previous work with the same ''gamut of movements'' subjected to different chance operations and danced by seven rather than the original six performers. That bit of information suggests abstruseness and dry procedure.

title: Catching Up
description: * An update on the careers of the four players who, in the following order, were selected ahead of Dwight Gooden in the amateur draft of June 1982:

title: NEW TRISLER SEASON
description: Mel Tomlinson, a soloist with the New York City Ballet, will appear with the Joyce Trisler Danscompany in a one-week spring season that opens tomorrow at the Joyce Theater, on Eighth Avenue at 19th Street. Mr. Tomlinson will perform in a dance set to music by Colin McPhee, one of two new works created by the company director Milton Myers.

title: A Centenarian in the Bronx Who Can Put on the Charm
description: Robert Browning complains about the cost of living. ''He thinks it's too much, that it's outrageous,'' said Edna Campbell, his home attendant for nearly seven years.

title: Happy Birthday
description: There are those who will tell you that the baseball bible has been backsliding ever since World War II, when it began regularly covering the apocryphal sports. If so, the slide is of a kind that most publications would envy. For The Sporting News, apostasy has proved profitable.

title: Outdoors: Trout Rituals
description: ONE might be tempted, because so little time remains to get one's equipage in order, to say to hell with preparations for the April 1 opening of the New York State trout season.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Did any teams in the Big East and Atlantic Coast Conferences play each other this season?

title: RIGHTIST PARTIES APPEAR TO REGAIN POWER IN FRANCE
description: An alliance of France's two major conservative parties appeared tonight to have won a slender majority in legislative elections, ending five years of Socialist government, according to computer projections of the vote count.

title: Tax How-To by Dukakis
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts will be back in Washington tomorrow to give the Federal government another suggestion on solving one of its problems, again a solution he has been testing successfully at the state level.

title: FORSMAN, AT 11 UNDER, WINS BAY HILL
description: As he approached the end of the longest day of golf on the PGA Tour this year, Dan Forsman sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the 33d hole for a one-shot lead. Then he concluded the 36-hole day with three successive pars to win Arnold Palmer's Hertz Bay Hill Classic by a stroke over Ray Floyd and Mike Hulbert.

title: Football Filibuster
description: Tennessee politicians have grown a bit more civilized since the days when Andy Jackson would shoot people who crossed him. But Senator Albert Gore Jr., who wants Congress to force the National Football League to add six expansion teams, is prepared to revert to some distinctly uncivil tactics if he doesn't get his way.

title: Agreement Ends Dispute Over Capital Shelter
description: The Federal Government has agreed to give $5 million and a decrepit building used as a shelter for the homeless to the District of Columbia, ending a 32-day-old hunger strike by Mitch Snyder and 12 other activists, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. announced today.

title: Toward Afghanistan Peace
description: The three-year-old United Nations negotiations on a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan made significant progress immediately after the summit meeting. But the negotiations again are stalled and progress appears unlikely unless the United Nations effort is accompanied by superpower talks on related security issues in the Afghanistan region.

title: OPEC SET TO DISCUSS STRATEGIES
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, after holding two preliminary sessions today, is expected to start Monday to try to devise a strategy to deal with plunging oil prices and a diminishing share of the world oil market, in what may be a weeklong emergency session.

title: Sticking Together
description: What does the International Maple Syrup Institute have in common with the Sierra Club and the National Clean Air Coalition? It will become clear at a breakfast at the National Press Club this morning that they all share a deadly hatred of acid rain, which is anathema to the maple sugar industry specifically and the environment generally. Speakers hope to make some telling points that will influence discussions between President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada at the White House tomorrow.

title: SHOCHETMAN PERFORMS AT CARNEGIE RECITAL HALL
description: The pianist Igor Shochetman shared his Saturday afternoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall with the soprano Margo Alexander and a fellow pianist, George Edelman.

title: Petersen Wins
description: Pat Petersen of Brooklyn, who placed third in last November's New York City Marathon, turned the tables on Orlando Pizzolato of Italy, winner of the marathon, in the Paine Webber/Jacob Javits Convention Center 4-mile run. A field of 3,174 competed in a race that started and finished at the new center on the West Side.

title: DISGRUNTLED RANGERS BLAME COACH FOR POOR MORALE
description: On Wednesday, Mark Pavelich cited difficulties with Coach Ted Sator as his main reason for quitting the Rangers. Apparently, he was only one disgruntled Ranger among many.

title: Keep the Bite On Corporations
description: The tax reform bill passed by the House last year eliminated or tightened provisions used by corporations to reduce their tax burden by billions of dollars. Now it's the Senate's turn, and already corporate lobbyists are prowling Senate corridors warning that if the Senate fails to reopen those loopholes, corporate investment in new plant and equipment will wither and thousands of Americans will lose their jobs.

title: Dr. Joyce A. Kornfeld Weds Jay P. Rosenthal
description: Dr. Joyce A. Kornfeld, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Kornfeld of North Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Philip Rosenthal, the son of Judge and Mrs. Jerome R. Rosenthal of Port Chester, N.Y. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: If a Strong Man Shall Keep His House Guarded
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronze Sculpture Is Stolen
description: A bronze sculpture weighing more than a ton was stolen off its pedestal in Garfield Park, the authorities said Saturday.

title: Reed Achieves 2 Schoolboy Bests
description: William Reed, a 15-year-old sophomore from Central High School in Philadelphia, achieved national indoor schoolboy bests for both the 300 meters and 300 yards today at the Pathmark National Classic interscholastic track and field meet in Coxe Cage at Yale University.

title: GRASS IN NO GREENER THAN IN SPRING
description: BOB TEWKSBURY didn't understand why he had been chosen, why Lou Piniella, the Yankee manager, was handing him the ball on Opening Day at Yankee Stadium, and saying, ''You're starting today.'' Tewksbury glanced around the Yankee clubhouse and saw Ron Guidry and Phil Niekro looking at him. They are the stars, thought Tewksbury, the veteran pitchers, the guys who always start on Opening Day. So why me? He couldn't worry about this any longer, though, and had to begin thinking about how to get the hitters out, about going down the other team's batting order.

title: A Dog-in-the-Park Story That Ends With a Paean
description: William Hower lives upstate in a tiny Ulster County hamlet called Accord. Over the weekend, he discovered a small town called Manhattan.

title: 'TOO LONG A SACRIFICE' LOOKS AT ULSTER
description: WE lose our way early on in ''Too Long a Sacrifice.''

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPEECH
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech tonight on aiding rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: SCRIPPS MERGER SET
description: In a move that will combine two media companies founded by separate branches of the Scripps family, the E. W. Scripps Company said it had agreed to a merger with the John P. Scripps newspaper group, which operates six daily and four weekly newspapers in California and one daily in Washington State. Terms of the merger were not disclosed. E. W. Scripps, which is based in Cincinnati and owns operations under the Scripps Howard banner, has interests in newspaper publishing, broadcasting, cable television and other media-related areas.

title: SOUTH BRONX PROCESSION MARKS PASSION OF JESUS
description: For a moment yesterday afternoon, the corner of 167th Street and the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx became the spot where Jesus met the women of Jerusalem. Two blocks south He was placed in the tomb, and the corner of 161st Street became the site of His Resurrection.

title: JAILED CHIEF OF CITY LEASES INTERROGATED ON CORRUPTION
description: Alex Liberman, who pleaded guilty in 1984 to extorting $1.2 million from landlords when he was New York City's director of lease negotiations, told Government officials last week that he had no new information to give them about municipal corruption, Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: A.M.A. RULE: STEP TOWARD A SOCIAL POLICY ON DYING
description: A decision this weekend by the American Medical Association that it would be ethical for doctors to withhold ''all means of life prolonging medical treatment,'' including food and water, from patients in irreversible comas is seen as another cautious step in the evolution of a broad social policy in the delicate area of dying and death.

title: ON LEFT, GLOOM
description: The Champagne - 1,800 bottles of France's most festive wine - flowed freely tonight at the headquarters of the far-right National Front.

title: DANCE: KAZO KAMIZAWA TROUPE
description: THERE is more to Japanese modern dance than the dark portentousness of Butoh, which we have seen so much of lately. On Saturday at the Asia Society, Kazuo Kamizawa offered dance that drew from the past to create something unique and uniquely compelling, in a program that promises to be one of the most fascinating of the dance year. The company must soon return.

title: GLOOMY DATA MAKING ECONOMISTS UNCERTAIN ON OUTLOOK FOR GROWTH
description: During the first two months of this year, many economists became steadily more upbeat about the outlook for the nation's economy. Their growth estimates rose as the dollar and oil prices fell, until their consensus neared the Reagan Administration's optimistic projection that the economy would expand at a healthy rate of 4 percent.

title: N.C.A.A. Sets Hockey Lineup
description: Boston University and Denver were seeded first in the East and West yesterday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, which begins Friday at four campus sites.

title: Don't Give Insurers Any More Advantages
description: To the Editor:

title: A CORPORATE RITE OF SPRING UNITES TOP TALENT
description: FOR hundreds of photographers, writers, designers, typographers and printers here, the annual report is as good as a full-employment act. Some 10,000 corporations issue annual reports and, because most of them complete their fiscal year on Dec. 31, the reports flower in March and April.

title: T.W.A. and Union In Dispute Over Training
description: A new dispute between Trans World Airlines and its striking flight attendants has erupted over the adequacy of training of replacement attendants.

title: Convention Competition
description: Competition between cities for the publicity and profit that come with a Presidential convention can be fierce and expensive. It's worth a lot for a mayor and his community to obtain two weeks of intensive television and newspaper coverage, not to mention income from the rooms, meals, drinks and assorted souvenirs purchased by several thousand free-spending politicians, hangers-on and observers.

title: CITY LOOKING FOR PLACES TO PUT JULY 4 SPECTATORS
description: New York City officials are examining all the piers in the harbor, testing views and making intensive preparations for the Statue of Liberty centennial over the July 4 weekend when the city is expected to draw the largest crowds in its history.

title: HONDA STUDIES 2D PLANT
description: The Honda Motor Company will decide within a year whether to build a second car assembly plant in the United States with the decision linked to the success of the company's new Acura luxury cars, an executive said. Clifford Schmillen, an executive vice president for Honda's subsidiary, said it was possible a new plant would build cars for its new Acura division, which aims to compete against such European imports as Audi, BMW, Saab, Volvo and lower-priced Mercedes-Benz cars.

title: No Trial - and No Punishment Either
description: New York's Governor Cuomo has no trouble spending hundreds of millions to build more prisons. Why then does he balk at $12.6 million to restore order in New York City's chaotic criminal courts? Dollar for dollar, money spent on courts would yield more in public safety and reassurance than money spent on prisons.

title: 30,000 in Los Angeles Rally for Abortion Right
description: About 30,000 people marched in a winter downpour today in support of a woman's right to a legal abortion.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES AGAINST YEN
description: After months of steady declines, the dollar sank to a record low against the Japanese yen in early trading this morning. A flurry of selling after exchange markets opened plunged the dollar to 174.80 yen, well below the previous record low of 175.50 hit on Oct. 31, 1978.

title: From the Assembly Line
description: Say ''America'' and a lot of images spring to mind. The Pilgrims, of course. Indians. The Great Plains. Mount Rushmore. Coca-Cola. Freeways. Malls.

title: MANILA MAKES PITCH FOR CHURCH RADIO
description: President Corazon C. Aquino and the leaders of the revolt that took her to power last month appealed to the public today for donations to repair the transmitters of a radio station that played a key role in the ouster of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Minnesota's Drinking Age
description: The Minnesota House voted 68 to 64 Saturday to raise the drinking age from 19 years to 21 on Sept. 1. The bill, to avert losing part of the state's Federal highway money, now goes to Gov. Rudy Perpich.

title: MONAHAN EXPLORES PIANO MUSIC AND NOISE
description: The Canadian pianist and composer Gordon Monahan is trained in physics as well as music, and his compositions for the prepared piano and for prerecorded tape explore in meticulous detail the physical possibilities of keyboard sound. On Saturday evening at Roulette, Mr. Monahan presented two medium-size works, each less than half an hour long, that carefully investigated the relationship between conventional musical consonance and noise.

title: U.N.L.V. SURVIVES RALLY BY MARYLAND
description: In a region marked by the presence of some of the most outstanding inside players in the nation, Len Bias of Maryland dominated the final minutes of the second-round game against Nevada-Las Vegas this afternoon, but not quite enough to extend his final college season.

title: WALKER SCORES 32 AS KENTUCKY WINS
description: Kenny Walker scored 32 points as Kentucky survived a late charge to beat Western Kentucky, 71-64, today in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Southeast Regional.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
