description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Clearwater, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Yankees vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Dunedin, Fla., 1:30 P.M. College: Maine at Miami (Fla.)

title: ANTICORRUPTION TO BE A THEME OF CUOMO RACE
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that following corruption charges in New York City, he planned to make a campaign issue of a package of ''anti-corruption'' measures that Republicans in the State Legislature have long opposed.

title: Time to Call in Dollars
description: When Paul G. Kirk Jr. became Democratic National Chairman early last year, he assumed personal control of the party's ''major donor'' fund raising, realizing that the Reagan landslide had buried many big party contributors under a heavy load of political pessimism. In 1985, he managed to produce $2.7 million, about half of it after Labor Day when the numbing effect of the Republican national victory began to wear off.

title: Rights Enforcement Is Cited
description: The Supreme Court's 1984 decision restricting the scope of Federal civil rights sanctions has created barriers to effective enforcement, two public interest groups said today.

title: FUTURES UNIT LIFTS PENALTY
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has lifted a suspension against Owen J. Morrissey, co-owner of the Volume Investors Corporation, a small brokerage firm whose accounts at the Commodity Exchange were frozen a year ago when it went into receivership.

title: LTV STEEL CALLS LABOR PACT $140 MILLION BOON
description: A contract agreement reached between the United Steelworkers of America and the LTV Steel Company will increase the steelmaker's cash flow by an estimated $140 million in the first year, its chief negotiator estimates.

title: MORE WORLD BANK LATIN LOANS
description: The World Bank is expected shortly to approve a $400 million loan to Mexico for earthquake rehabilitation as part of a series of loans to Latin America totaling more than $1 billion. The bank will meet on March 25 to approve loans for Ecuador and Colombia in addition to Mexico.

title: ST. JOHN'S SEASON ENDS WITH ROUT BY AUBURN
description: What had been a season of exhilarating success against the odds came to a crushing end for St. John's here this afternoon as Auburn, in a dramatic display of speed and power, defeated the Redmen, 81-65, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association West Regional.

title: JAPAN IS PLEASED WITH COMET ROLE
description: Although they were on the outer fringes of the study of Halley's comet, Japanese scientists describe themselves as immensely pleased with the information relayed by the two spacecraft they launched.

title: ACCENT PUT ON SPARKLE BY IMPORT
description: ''THIS country likes cold, sweet and bubbly,'' said Roger D. Groves, appearing quite knowledgeble in the presence of a client who is preparing to introduce a product with all three assets in the New York market in May.

title: THEATER: U.S. PREMIERE OF FASSBINDER'S 'TEARS'
description: SOMETHING is missing from the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's American premiere of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's ''Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant.'' Call it a point of view or a coherent style. However identified, it leaves you puzzled over whether you should be laughing at Petra or crying with her as she suffers troubles of the heart, or is it the mind?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. REPORT ON CRIME IS BACKED
description: Several business groups and prosecutors have endorsed the recommendation of the President's Commission on Organized Crime that the Justice Department become more active in targeting corporations and business executives suspected of dealing with organized crime.

title: AFTER THE SUICIDE: WIDER INQUIRIES AND CATHARSIS
description: In the days since Donald R. Manes's suicide - as those who knew him mourned, judged and dealt with the shock - there has been the hope that his death would somehow break the fever that has gripped the city's political establishment for more than two months.

title: PANEL TO URGE CAP IN LIABILITY SUITS
description: A commission investigating the state's liability-insurance crisis plans to recommend tighter state control of the insurance industry and limits on the size of some court awards to injured people, the panel's executive director said today.

title: LABOR SCARCITY IS FORCING UP LOW-LEVEL PAY
description: A shortage of young workers, caused by two decades of lower birthrates and a booming service economy, has pushed wages well above the Federal minimum at shops and restaurants throughout the New York metropolitan area.

title: GRAF IS QUIETLY HEADING TO TOP
description: IN an era of self-promotion, Steffi Graf is rapidly becoming an aberration. In the past 15 months, she has quietly climbed the tennis ladder, overlooked at times, overshadowed by those who have had spectacular but fleeting encounters with success. Miss Graf has moved into the sport's upper crust at the age of 16 without the benefit of a single tournament victory or heralded upset of those tennis perennials Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova. She is No. 3, and widely touted as the sport's future queen.

title: RALLY LURING SMALL INVESTORS
description: Enticed by the extraordinary stock market rally of recent months, individual investors are opening new brokerage accounts and calling their stockbrokers at a pace not seen since the 1970's.

title: MANES IS RECALLED AT RITES
description: Donald R. Manes was buried yesterday after eulogies by friends and colleagues who urged that the suspicions raised about him in the last months of his life be vanquished by memories of the good he had done in his 20 years as a public official.

title: DIRECTORS CLEAR REPUBLIC BID
description: The directors of the Republic Health Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest publicly held health services company, have agreed in principle to a leveraged buyout led by three company executives for $19.25 a share in cash and notes, or a total of $335 million.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1986
description: International French conservatives are leading in legislative elections and appeared to have defeated the Socialists who have governed France for five years. An alliance of two major conservative parties was headed for a slender majority in the National Assembly, according to computer projections of the vote count. The conservative majority, if confirmed by the final count, was far smaller than had been predicted. With the Socialists no longer in control of Parliament, President Francois Mitterrand, whose term still has two years to run, is expected to have to appoint a Prime Minister from the ranks of his opponents. The situation is unprecedented in the Fifth Republic. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: THE ODDS ON CUSTODY CHANGE
description: An increasing number of divorced women are unfairly losing custody of their children to their former husbands because American society has devalued the maternal role, according to speakers at a recent conference entitled ''The Politics of Child Custody: Mothers on Trial.''

title: PROMISING MEADOWLAKE KEEPS TRAINER IN SUSPENSE
description: FOR the last six months, Bert Sonnier has been waiting, and the racing world has been watching.

title: IOWA STATE UPSETS MICHIGAN
description: Iowa State, whose coach left Michigan six years ago because the university would not give him a raise, ended the Midwest Regional today by adding to the list of upsets in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: O'CONNOR SEES COUNCIL BILL SHIELDING HOMOSEXUAL 'SIN'
description: With a final vote on the city's homosexual rights bill coming up Thursday, John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday again condemned the legislation, calling it an affront to Judeo-Christian values that would offer legal protection to sexual behavior that is ''abnormal'' and ''a sin.''

title: OF LITERATURE AND ELECTRONIC DERRING-DO
description: BOOK publishers and others concerned with the future of literacy sometimes worry that the hypnotic allure of computer video games is about to steal the hearts and minds of children away. Heck, I know some grown-ups - even a few in the book business -who worry about their own minds as they duck flying barrels hurled by a glowering gorilla or try to fly a plane between the twin towers of the World Trade Center.

title: YOUNG BRITISH DESIGNERS IN THE FAST LANE
description: At the close of the Hyper Hyper group fashion show Thursday, the first day of London's fall collections, a runway in the tents on King's Road filled with a group of prancing male models. They 44,0,8.8,2.6,8.8,2.11,8.8, 3.4,8.8,3.9>wore only white underpants and waved white scarfs over their heads that bore a one-word slogan: ''Hype.'' That word sums up the problem facing new British designers today.

title: INVESTIGATOR'S PERSISTENCE WIDENS DEATH INQUIRY BUT THREATENS JOB
description: The death of a mentally retarded woman at a state institution in 1984 is being examined by Federal authorities because of the persistence of a state investigator, but he may lose his job as a result.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Adventure Inc., Kirkland, Wash., a private recreational vehicle campground, said it named John M. Nye president and director.

title: TURNAROUND AT ITALY'S E.N.I.
description: For years the largest corporation in Italy was known as ''the hospital,'' and the nickname reflected a reputation for illness rather than healing. The company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, regularly used to run up losses proportionate to its size as the world's third-largest, non-American multinational company.

title: DELAY SOUGHT ON T.W.A.
description: The Justice Department asked the Department of Transportation to delay action on a proposed voting trust to be established by Trans World Airlines in conjunction with its bid for Ozark Airlines until the transportation agency does a review of the impact of the proposed merger.

title: Land Mine Kills 19 Near Afghan Border
description: A land mine Saturday destroyed two pickup trucks filled with Afghan refugees on their way to a wedding, killing 18 women and a man, guerrillas and newspaper reports said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For our own security, the United States must deny the Soviet Union a beachhead in North America.'' -President Reagan, speaking about Nicaragua. [ A1:3. ]

title: CANADIAN DANCE DEBUT
description: The national folk dance ensemble of Canada, Les Sortileges, will make its New York debut Thursday at Carnegie Hall.

title: SWITZERLAND VOTES NOT TO JOIN THE U.N. BY A 3-TO-1 MARGIN
description: Swiss voters today rejected by a 3-to-1 margin their Government's plan to join the United Nations.

title: MORE RATE DROPS SEEN LIKELY
description: Hopes for continued declines in interest rates will be kept alive by some weak economic statistics expected in the next few weeks, but many analysts are now looking ahead to the second half of the year when they foresee a stronger economy possibly accompanied by upward pressure on rates.

title: AD INDUSTRY HEIGHTENS ITS WATCHDOG FUNCTION
description: What the advertising industry regards as a desire to tamper with the freedom to advertise is apparently still strong at the state level because the Washington-based American Advertising Federation, which has long used its grass-roots organization to monitor such activity, has now joined with the two other major forces in the industry to give the watchdog operation still greater observation power.

title: AFTER 36 HOURS, 2 ARE RESCUED FROM THE RUINS IN SINGAPORE
description: More than 36 hours after being buried in the collapse of a six-story hotel here, two men were pulled alive from the wreckage late Sunday night. It took six hours to free them once they had been located.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * A.B. SKF, Stockholm, said its U.S. subsidiary, SKF Inc., had signed a letter of intent to purchase the bearing division of TRW Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: LEGISLATORS AND CHEF AMONG 143 GETTING CITY PARKING PERMITS
description: New York City provides special identification to 143 officials, including five state legislators and the Mayor's chef at Gracie Mansion, that entitles them to park in some no-parking zones and to ignore alternate-side-of-the-street rules, city officials said yesterday.

title: Peg Picotte and William Hassett Jr. Are Married
description: Margaret Brennan Picotte was married yesterday to William Dennis Hassett Jr., chairman of the New York State Dormitory Authority. The ceremony was performed in the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Manhattan by the Rev. John J. Dunnigan.

title: Storms on Both Coasts Have Killed 2 People
description: Thunderstorms struck the nation's East and West coasts yesterday, causing tornadoes that killed a man in a Florida strawberry field and leaving a 10-year-old boy missing after he was swept away by a rain-swollen California river.

title: POLAND INCREASES SOME FOOD PRICES
description: The prices of bread, milk, sugar and alcohol were raised today as the Polish Government sought to reduce food subsidies before it is admitted to the International Monetary Fund.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRITAIN'S DIVERSITY A photographic exhibition briefly titled ''Neal Slavin: Britons'' takes a look at many facets of the contemporary British population. In 48 group portraits, there are the dukes and duchesses, fledgling cricketers, Channel swimmers and members of the Royal Shakespeare Company. And there are the expected English: the Distressed Gentlefolk Aid Association, the Smithfield market workers in the comfortable-looking Hope Pub and the London staff of James Smith & Sons: Umbrellas.

title: SHIFTING OF OFFICERS EXPECTED AT FORD
description: As part of a major series of changes among its top international executives, sources close to the Ford Motor Company said that the company was expected to announce today that Philip E. Benton Jr., an executive vice president in charge of Ford's diversified products operations, will be put in charge of international automotive operations.

title: ALLEN'S 'PURPLE ROSE' IS 'BEST FILM' IN BRITAIN
description: Woody Allen's ''Purple Rose of Cairo'' was named best film of 1985 at the British Academy Awards ceremony tonight, and the director Steven Spielberg was given the prestigious Fellowship of the Academy.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: OUTSIDE, KIND WORDS FOR A FALLEN 'KING'
description: The police officers shoved the blue sawhorse barrier forward one final time, bumping some bodies, and a captain yelled at the crowd to disperse.

title: Nevada Motel Fire Kills At Least 4
description: A fire of suspicious origin at a residential motel today killed 4 people and injured 29, the authorities said.

title: LATE RANGER SURGE TOPS ISLANDERS, 3-1
description: Mike Ridley skated past the blue line. The puck came to him crisply on his stick and he shot from 40 feet, scoring with a low line drive that zipped past the right toe of the goaltender Kelly Hrudey.

title: 300 Determined Walkers Press On for Peace
description: About 300 determined hikers resumed their ''Great Peace March'' for nuclear disarmament today, walking along a dirt road in the Mojave Desert to continue the trek to Washington that was interrupted when organizers ran out of money.

title: SHULTZ TO VISIT ATHENS AS ITS CRITICISM EASES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, are scheduled to visit Greece this month, and diplomats say they believe the visits are a result of an easing in the anti-Western statements that dominated Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's earlier years in office.

title: The Lost Irish Tribe
description: It is not amiss on this St. Patrick's Day to say a good word for two British Prime Ministers, William Ewart Gladstone and Margaret Thatcher. A century ago, on April 6, the great Gladstone introduced a bill to grant home rule to all of Ireland, north and south. He took account of fierce opposition, but told the House of Commons: ''Sir, I cannot allow it to be said that a Protestant minority in Ulster or elsewhere is to rule the question at large for Ireland.'' He was mistaken, riots erupted in Belfast and the bill eventually died.

title: BILL ON DEFECTIVE-PRODUCT SUITS
description: A Cabinet group headed by Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has reached agreement on a proposed Administration bill to give manufacturers relief in suits brought by people injured by defective products.

title: ACCOUNTANTS UNDER FIRE
description: A CARELESS accountant is a dangerous person. An auditor, for example, who issues an unqualified report about a company - a few days before it collapses - can lull investors and creditors into trusting the company and thereby losing millions of dollars.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income

title: COMMANDED THE ARAB LEGION
description: Lieut. Gen. Sir John Bagot Glubb, the legendary Glubb Pasha who built Jordan's Arab Legion into one of the most formidable fighting forces in the Middle East, died yesterday in his native England. He was 88 years old.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED
description: Two police officers were shot last night by a gunman who walked up to their patrol car and fired through a window as the car was stopped at a traffic light in the South Bronx, the police said.

title: Maria Kramer, 103, Operator Of Hotels With Noted Bands
description: Maria Kramer, who owned several major hotels - including the Lincoln and the Edison in Manhattan - died last Wednesday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 103 years old.

title: On Rebel Aid
description: The House is due to vote Thursday on President Reagan's plan to provide $100 million to the Nicaragua rebels, and at least one House member has dug in his heels against a publicity barrage in his upstate New York district designed to persuade him to change his mind and vote for the plan.

title: HOW MANES'S DEATH AFFECTS INQUIRIES
description: At the time of his death, Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President, was the major target of a broad investigation into corruption in the city. His suicide last week caused a number of prosecutors to rethink their goals and strategy.

title: ALLIES IN U.N. PROTEST ON BUDGET
description: The Western Europeans have told the United States that it would violate its treaty obligations by reducing its share of the United Nations budget.

title: MERET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Revenue figures were not reported because they are not comparable since they include discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Includes a gain of $1,938,338 from debt restructuring.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
History and the Law, As Seen by Prof. Shenton
description: James P. Shenton, a professor of history at Columbia University, has a way of bringing the past up out of the grave.

title: DOW DROPS 15.92 IN SLOWER TRADING
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday on Wall Street as investors, already fat with profits from last week's record gains, decided to trim their portfolios.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MARCH WINDS New and seldom-heard chamber music combining voice and woodwind instruments is the niche the Fiati Chamber Players (304-1689) have set out to occupy in this chamber-music mecca. The group consists of a soprano, Cheryl Bensman; an oboist, Melissa Bohl, and a bassonist, Edwin Alexander. Today, they are adding a harpsichord, played by Dana Ragsdale, and a flute, played by Laura Weiss, and the entire ensemble will perform.

title: FINAL ARGUMENTS IN PATIENT DEATH
description: After 22 weeks months of testimony, closing arguments begin here Tuesday in the first corporate murder trial in Texas history, in which a nursing home chain and four of its current or former managers are charged with killing an 87-year-old patient through conscious neglect.

title: DANCE: PEACE PROGRAM AT LA MAMA
description: AS part of its Third World Theater Arts Festival, La Mama has been offering a series of programs called ''Seven Women Choreographers Dedicated to Peace.'' Sunday night's concert featured three choreographers whose creations ranged from the turbulent to the tranquil.

title: FOUR-PART OFFERING BY SANTA FUNDING
description: Santa Funding I Inc., a subsidiary of the Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara, is offering $240 million of collaterlized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The obligations, rated triple-A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are backed by Federal National Mortgage Association pass-through securities.

title: COLLEGE ADMINISTRATOR ADDS PEPSI FRANCHISE
description: William R. Harvey is an educator with a penchant for business. Until yesterday Dr. Harvey, who is president of Hampton University, had confined this interest to within the walls of academia. But now, with the encouragement of Pepsico Inc., Dr. Harvey is getting into the soft drink business.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
AMID SCANDALS, OFFICIALS SAY CITY BUSINESS IS TOUGH TO DO
description: Since early last month, New York City's Board of Estimate has ruled on 40 percent fewer matters than it did during the same period last year.

title: OCCIDENTAL SLASHES CAPITAL SPENDING
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation became the latest oil company to slash its exploration and development budget in the face of plummeting prices, reducing its 1986 expenditures by 25 percent from the 1985 level.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SMITHSONIAN BONES REVEAL TALES OF SUFFERING LONG AGO
description: THE human vertebrae in Dr. Donald J. Ortner's hand looked as if they had been corroded by acid. Only fragments remained of several of the key bones near the base of the spine.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:33 A.M. today and set at 12:33 P.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 3:29 A.M. and set at 12:23 P.M.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlantic Aviation, an aircraft maintenance concern, has named Malcom S. Graham executive vice president.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $377,000 on the sale of idle facilities.

title: ROTECH MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THATCHER'S POLICY ON OIL QUESTIONED
description: When Margaret Thatcher became Britain's Prime Minister in 1979, she inherited an economic windfall: oil. The wealth pumped from the big North Sea oilfields rose sharply during her tenure, providing a stimulus for the five-year economic recovery that Britain has enjoyed.

title: 'I FEEL I AM TRAPPED INSIDE MY HEAD, BANGING AGAINST ITS WALLS, TRYING DESPERATELY TO ESCAPE'
description: The following first-person account of the ordeal of schizophrenia was written by a woman who recently completed college despite repeated hospitalizations. Her identity is withheld to protect her privacy.

title: TRAINING IS CONSIDERED REBELS' MAJOR NEED
description: Diplomats and military experts here say they believe anti-Government rebels must be trained by experienced soldiers if they hope to develop into a fighting force that can threaten the Sandinista Government.

title: WINCOM CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
HABIB SAYS LATINS BACK U.S. AID PLAN
description: The special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, back from a visit to Central America, said today that a recent poll had found that ''a majority'' of people in the region supported President Reagan's policy and wanted pressure put on the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Homer Jones, a Monetarist And Federal Reserve Official
description: Homer Jones, a longtime official of the Federal Reserve Bank and leading proponent of monetarism, died Friday near his home in suburban St. Louis. Mr. Jones, who had collapsed while taking a walk, was 79 years old.

title: Advertising; Snapple Beverage Co. To Margeotes/Fertitta
description: The Snapple Beverage Company, which had the briefest of stays with Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Humphrey, has found a new agency, Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

title: CAPACITY USE DROPS TO 80% IN MONTH
description: American industry operated at just 80 percent of capacity in February, the second consecutive month that the operating rate at the nation's factories, mines and utilities has declined, the Government reported today.

title: GRAF DEFEATS SABATINI IN 3 SETS
description: What the tennis fans at Madison Square Garden may have been witnessing last night was a glimpse into the future of women's tennis. In a few years, Steffi Graf and Gabriela Sabatini could be competing for the top ranking, matching slingshot forehands, tracking down apparent winners with long, court-gobbling strides.

title: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM BY WARNACO SUITOR
description: For Andrew G. Galef, a deal isn't over till it's over.

title: ROCKWELL BUYBACK OF 8% OF ITS SHARES
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, a leading manufacturer of military aircraft, space systems and rocket engines, said yesterday that its board had authorized a program to repurchase $500 million, or about 8 percent, of its common stock.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The year-earlier quarter and 6 months results include a gain of $1,397,500 from the sales of non-liveried aircraft.

title: NEW BID FOR BL
description: BL P.L.C., the former British Leyland, said it had firm proposals from a British company, Lancashire Enterprises, to take over parts of the state-owned auto maker that the British Government wants to sell to the General Motors Corporation.

title: SOVIET REPORTED ACTING TO BEGIN NEW ATOM TESTS
description: The Soviet Union has started preparations for the possible resumption of nuclear weapons testing, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: GEORGE G. COUGHLIN
description: George G. Coughlin, a former president of the New York State Bar Association, died of a heart attack last Friday at Candler General Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 86 years old and lived in Savannah.

title: Bonds Approved To Aid Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh City Council voted today to sell $20 million in municipal bonds and lend the proceeds to the public-private partnership that will buy and operate the Pirates for at least the next five seasons.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings results represent fully diluted figures.

title: Official Disputes Groups On Canyon Flights
description: The superintendent of Grand Canyon National Park said today that he would not move immediately to ban flights in the canyon area.

title: AMATEUR SLEUTHS TRACK SOVIET SPACE PROGRAM
description: PHILLIP NARANJO had a hunch on Feb. 14. ''I put the whole group on alert,'' he said. ''I told them we picked up something strange, that the computer said it was in a Cyrillic code. So I briefed everyone, I said let's be ready for a launch.''

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL
description: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said that shareholders controlling 40 percent of its 7.5 million shares outstanding had formed a group to explore a possible merger or the sale of their shares. The group, whose shares are worth about $59.3 million, includes Northwestern Steel's chairman, W. Martin Dillon; his son, Peter W. Dillon, vice chairman and chief executive, and the Aim Corporation N.V. Northwestern Steel, based in Sterling, Ill., produces electric furnace steel and other steel products. Its shares closed at $19.75, up 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

title: South Korean Dissidents Announce New Alliance
description: Dissident leaders formed a new alliance today to bolster their campaign for election-law change after more than 1,000 clergymen signed a petition calling on the Government to revise the Constitution.

title: Attacks on Posner Were Diversionary Tactic
description: To the Editor:

title: On Drug Testing
description: Representative Gary Ackerman, Democrat of Queens, will hold a hearing today on the recommendation of the President's commission on organized crime that Federal employees be tested for drug use.

title: 'Les Miserables' to Open in Washington Dec. 17
description: The producers of ''Les Miserables'' today set the American opening of their musical for Dec. 17 with an eight-week run at the Kennedy Center before it is taken to New York.

title: Poor Effort Again by Ojeda
description: Bob Ojeda sat with his left elbow dunked in an ice bucket and with his right thigh wrapped in an ice pack, and considered the prime fact: The Mets traded four players to the Boston Red Sox this winter to get him.

title: BIG-STUDIO ADVANTAGE ON OSCARS
description: ''The Shooting Party,'' ''Wetherby,'' ''Smooth Talk'' and ''Dance With a Stranger'' have several things in common. They are art films, they were made outside the Hollywood establishment, they got glowing reviews and they failed to get a single Academy Award nomination this year.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Detroit Tigers, at Lakeland, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Sarasota, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Basketball Nets vs.

title: JUMPING-JACKS SHOES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 25
description: b-After tax credits of $162,000 for the quarter and $1,288,000 for the 52 weeks. c-After tax credits of $407,000 for the quarter and $1,416,000 for the 52 weeks. The year-ago 52 weeks also includes a credit of $663,000 representing cumulative effect on prior years of an accounting change.

title: JAPANESE SEE THREAT TO THE ECONOMY
description: As the dollar sank to a postwar low of 175 yen, Japanese bankers and senior Government officials warned today that increases in the yen's value were ''too rapid'' and threatened to slow Japan's economy.

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SWEDEN CHARGES A SUSPECT IN THE MURDER OF PALME
description: Swedish authorities today charged a man they have in custody as an accomplice in the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Jan. 31, 1986.

title: Army Would Use 8 Sites To Burn Chemical Arms
description: The Army said today that burning outmoded chemical weapons at the eight sites in the United States where they are stored would be safer but slightly more expensive than moving them to centralized destruction centers.

title: Bush Is a Grandfather Again
description: Vice President George Bush and his wife Barbara became grandparents again over the weekend. Pierce Mallon Bush was born Saturday at Rose Medical Center. He weighed 8 pounds, 3 1/2 ounces and is the second child of the Bushes' son Neil and his wife, Sharon.

title: INDIA TO BUY 21 COPTERS
description: Britain will supply India with 21 Westland helicopters for $:65 million, or about $98 million, for use in oil exploration, British officials confirmed today.

title: POPE PLANS A VISIT TO ROME SYNAGOGUE
description: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II would visit the central Rome synagogue next month in what church officials described as a historic step intended to improve Roman Catholic-Jewish relations.

title: REGGIE'S SOUND STUDIO
description: In the batting cage, Reggie Jackson squeezed his black bat and settled into the stance that has uncoiled for 530 home runs. With five more, he will pass Jimmie Foxx; with seven more, he will pass Mickey Mantle and rank sixth on the career list. Now, behind the screen, Moose Stubing, the California Angels' hitting coach, uttered the three little words that Mr. October loves to hear. ''Going long ball?'' the coach asked. ''No, just hitting line drives,'' Reggie Jackson said, grinning. ''Line drives, that's enough so the people can say Reggie looks good.'' But on his next swing, he hit a soft fly ball. ''Even when I pop it up, the people know I'm hitting,'' Reggie Jackson said, laughing. ''They can tell by the sound. When I hit 'em, it's stereo, it's a compact-disk player. It's not AM radio.''

title: MUNICIPALITIES CRACK DOWN ON SCOFFLAWS TO AID BUDGETS
description: Cities, towns and villages in the New York metropolitan area have stepped up the collection of overdue parking fines to help ease the financial pinch on their local budgets.

title: KOCH REBUTS SHELTER BOY'S TESTIMONY
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the testimony of a young boy living in a welfare hotel who told a Congressional committee that he was often hungry ''simply does not reflect reality.''

title: STRUGGLE OVER BALDWIN
description: A battle is heating up for the $4.2 billion in assets of the Baldwin United Corporation.

title: LONDON'S NEW MOOD: CLASSIC DASHING FASHION
description: Alistair D. Blair was an unknown designer until his fashion show Sunday afternoon catapulted him into the first rank of designers here. His elegantly stylish fall and winter clothes have captured the new mood of British fashion.

title: SENTEX SENSING TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOUTHWEST MISSOURI DEFEATS MARQUETTE
description: Winston Garland scored 22 points and Phil Schlegel added 21 tonight as Southwest Missouri beat Marquette, 83-69, in the second-round of play.

title: BANK REDUCES ENERGY LOANS
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation, the parent of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, said in an annual report issued today that the bank had $2.4 billion in oil and gas loans last Dec. 31, down from $3.2 billion a year earlier.

title: Dropping Colt Suits
description: In Baltimore, city officials have tentatively agreed to drop a lawsuit against the Colts' owner, Robert Irsay, who moved the team to Indiannapolis in 1984. In exchange, Irsay will drop his team's countersuit against Baltimore, return Colts memorabilia to Baltimore, and help the city in its bid for a National Football League expansion team.

title: GUNSHOTS AND BOMB THREAT PLAGUE END OF CHICAGO COUNCIL RACE
description: As campaigning wound down today, violence continued to mar the special aldermanic races that on Tuesday could give Mayor Harold Washington control of the City Council for the first time.

title: Leading Edge: One Name, Two Computers
description: MANY people, the editors of Consumer Reports magazine included, regard the Leading Edge Model D as the best bargain in the realm of I.B.M. PC-compatible computers. However, some readers have reported that when they get to the stores, they are shown the Leading Edge Model M and told the machines are very similar.

title: TECHNALYSIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THOMAS A. MESEREAU
description: Thomas A. Mesereau, a former head of the restaurant division of W. R. Grace & Company and a one-time partner in Mama Leone's restaurant, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Irvine, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: MAXIMUM YIELD 7.689% IN NEW YORK CITY BONDS
description: A $450 million issue of New York City bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets with a maximum yield of 7.689 percent on 7 5/8 percent bonds due in 2016 that are offered at a price of 99 1/4.

title: RICHARG PRYOR SHOWS REVIVED ON 9
description: THERE was a period in the mid-1970's when television comedy suddenly came alive with new forms. ''Laugh-In'' having paved the way, ''Saturday Night Live'' opened in 1975 and made calculated irreverence its trademark with a repertory company including Chevy Chase, Gilda Radner, John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd. Lily Tomlin, a ''Laugh-In'' veteran, began appearing in her own ground-breaking specials portraying a gallery of characters ranging from precocious children to a cocktail-lounge organist.

title: KOREA'S TECHNOLOGICAL PUSH
description: For most of his adult life, Dr. Min Pyung-June believed his future lay in the United States. The South Korean computer scientist and electronics engineer was educated at Purdue University and then found a home at the International Business Machines Corporation, where he worked on an absorbing range of projects. His children, born in the United States, spoke no Korean. And he had few business ties to his native land.

title: Earthquake Panel To Hold Session
description: Earthquake experts will gather in Nashville, Tenn., later this month to review the dangers of earthquakes in the south-central United States, and ways to cope with the problem.

title: Library of Congress; Reading the Revolutionary Mail
description: One member of Congress is carrying on a flirtation by mail with the prominent wife of the United States representative while he is off in Paris. Another member comments with disdain on his colleagues' drinking, suggesting that because of it Congress shouldn't try to meet in the afternoon. Other members write about crime or the weather.

title: VICTORIA FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $142,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss after a capital loss of $15,000. d-After a capital gain of $146,000 and a tax credit of $62,000.

title: Inventories Of Autos Up
description: Inventories of unsold new cars made by American automobile companies rose to a six-and-a-half-year high of 1.87 million on March 1, according to the trade paper Automotive News.

title: Cambodian Rebels Offer A Plan for Peace
description: A Cambodian rebel coalition issued a peace plan today calling for a partnership with the Hanoi-backed Cambodian Government and the gradual withdrawal of Vietnamese troops under a United Nations-supervised cease-fire.

title: D. DORTCH WARRINER
description: Federal District Judge David Dortch Warriner died today, apparently of a heart attack, his office said.

title: Topics; Cheap Shots Deflating Safety
description: Across-the-board Federal spending cuts now claim an especially dismaying victim: Government purchases of cars equipped with air bags. The true casualty will be highway safety.

title: CONSECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the gains are attributable primarily to the February 1985 acquisition of Lincoln American Life Insurance Co.

title: BURNS'S HIP PAIN CONCERNS YANKS
description: Every time he walked off the mound, the limp seemed to get worse. Now, there is growing concern that the chronic hip problems that have plagued Britt Burns could require further examination and extensive treatment - and perhaps even affect his ability to pitch for the Yankees this season.

title: ENVOYS BREAK NEW GROUND IN MANDELA VISIT
description: A Commonwealth delegation appears to have broken new ground on a visit to South Africa by meeting with the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela.

title: GETTING VITAL DATA TO OFFICERS
description: TWO tragic events - the explosion of the shuttle Challenger and the chemical leak at a United Carbide division in India -have pointed to a possible communications gap between top and lower-level management. Management consulting firms will be pondering the problem and trying to determine who can fill that job.

title: 150,000 MARCH FOR ST. PATRICK IN THE 224TH PARADE
description: Irish New Yorkers of every nationality turned 40 blocks of Fifth Avenue into a bobbing green sea of bagpipes and balloons yesterday as they swept up the street in the city's 224th annual St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: Indiana Inmates in Outbreak
description: More than a dozen inmates, some wielding sharpened broomsticks, rebelled at the Indiana State Prison today and held two hostages for 12 hours before releasing them unharmed shortly before 10 P.M. The inmates, who released one hostage earlier, were returned to their cells after a television station broadcast an agreement with prison officials. No injuries were reported in the uprising over what the prisoners said were crowded conditions and frequent shakedowns.

title: Coach Wrestles With Defeat
description: ''We got shoved around and we didn't like it,'' said Coach Bob Bubb of Clarion State College yesterday after his school finished 28th Saturday at the N.C.A.A. Division I wrestling championships in Iowa City. ''Right now we've got a bunch of sick puppies out here, but I'm going to sit down and figure out what went wrong.

title: George Palmer Is Dead; A Former Times Editor
description: George Palmer, a former editor with The New York Times and a former correspondent for news agencies in Europe and Asia and at the United Nations, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home near Bedford, Pa. He was 71 years old.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Nicaragua Horror Show
description: President Reagan left no stone unthrown in his Sunday prime-time TV appeal for $100 million to help the ''contras'' against Nicaragua's leftist tyrants. The Sandinistas, he declared, are Communists, a cancer, outlaws who smuggle dope, bomb synagogues, slash the ears of evangelicals. They have made Nicaragua a safe house for Cubans, Libyans, Iranians, East Germans, North Koreans, Bulgarians, the Red Brigades and the P.L.O. They threaten sea lanes, the Panama Canal, NATO choke points, 11 Latin democracies and the United States, which they intend to reach through Mexico.

title: PRESIDENT VS. PRIME MINISTER: WHO WILL RULE?
description: The result of the French legislative elections is focusing attention on the constitutional powers of President Francois Mitterrand and his next Prime Minister.

title: TEST OF A PRESIDENCY
description: In presenting the Nicaraguan issue as a historic test of his Presidency, Ronald Reagan has decided to try to convert his firm anti-Communism, dating back to personal experiences in union politics in Hollywood, into national policy.

title: Bridge: Spring National Open Pairs Start Early With 392 Entries
description: For many years the National Open Pairs Championship has wound up the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League. But a recent scheduling change has put this event before the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams instead of after it. Open Pair play began here Sunday with an entry of 392 pairs and was to end today.

title: NORTH AMERICAN HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WORK SHIP AIDING SALVAGERS
description: The salvage ship Preserver, her decks darkened, showing only running lights, returned to port here tonight, bringing back more debris from the broken crew compartment of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Vandals Paint Arabian Horse
description: Vandals painted white stripes on a black Arabian horse and left a threatening note over the weekend, according to a ranch owner.

title: NEW VOTING SYSTEM AIDS MITTERRAND
description: The new voting system of proportional representation instituted by President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government has accomplished almost exactly what the Socialists intended, political analysts said today.

title: U.S. TO GIVE COPIES OF MARCOS PAPERS TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: The United States plans to turn over copies of 1,500 pages of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos's documents to the Philippine Government on Tuesday, State Department officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today: March 18, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Decolonization - 10:30 A.M.

title: NEW CLIMATE FOR UNIONS
description: The strike at Trans World Airlines, where flight attendants are resisting the airline's demands for concessions on wages and work rules, illustrates the problems unions face as a result of Government deregulation of airlines, telecommunications, trucking and railroads. In some cases, the end of

title: FIGHTING A LOSING BATTLE FOR SPACE IN THE GARAGE
description: When Joe Dore woke this morning, the sun was out, the air felt warm, like spring, and Joe knew it would be good weather for working on cars.

title: Short Tenures Reflect Troubles of College Chiefs
description: COLLEGE and university presidents, who used to be secure in their seats of power, today face ''the seven-year hitch.'' This conclusion emerges from a major study by two experts, Clark Kerr, former president of the University of California, and Marion L. Gade, a research associate at the Center of Studies in Higher Education at Berkeley.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
Switch at Stern College
description: Deborah Cohen has become the first student at the Stern College for Women of Yeshiva University to be accepted at the Harvard University Law School.

title: Brennan Reports For Prison Term
description: William C. Brennan, a former New York State Supreme Court justice who was convicted last year of taking bribes to fix criminal cases, surrendered to Federal authorities yesterday in Rochester, Minn., to begin serving a five-year prison term.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE CO (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The 1985 net earnings included gains of $7.1 million on sales of marketable securities, compared to nominal gains on such sales in the current year-to-date.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
INTERACTIVE TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $12,000 for the latest quarter and $113,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Society's New Order Takes Over
description: THE spring social offensive slammed into high gear last week. Saul and Gayfryd Steinberg gave yet another of their elaborate, black-tie dinners. Armies of the rich and famous pushed in to celebrate 10 years of Mortimer's, the restaurant where established overachievers go to escape and analyze the ongoing glitz wars. And Ann Getty managed to get to La Cote Basque in time to host a luncheon.

title: THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM PLANS TO DOUBLE ITS SIZE
description: The Brooklyn Museum said yesterday that it planned to nearly double the size of its building over the next 20 years, to rebuild its interior and link the museum to the adjacent Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: SIERRA SPRING WATER reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pretoria's Ban Signal
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday as market participants waited for additional information about the health of the economy and future of oil prices as well as a heavy supply of new Treasury issues expected next week.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: SCHIZOPHRENIA FOCUS SHIFTS TO DRAMATIC CHANGES IN BRAIN
description: THE architecture and chemistry of the brains of schizophrenics can be actually different from those of normal people, new studies show. As a result, a revolution in psychiatry has occurred in which biology has become the main focus of the research on this most devastating and intractable disease of the mind.

title: Acid Rain, North And South
description: Prime Minister Mulroney of Canada, in his meetings in Washington this week, may have the leverage to get President Reagan moving at last on the long-neglected issue of acid rain - a major political question in Canada, as it should be here.

title: Seat-Belt Lights
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMERS SEEK LOAN AIDE'S OUSTER
description: About 150 farmers and representatives of farm groups interrupted operations at the office of the Farmers Home Administration here today to demand the departure of the office supervisor.

title: A QUIET OLD FORT FACING BUSTLE OF FERRY CROWDS
description: In its 175 years, Castle Clinton has never fired a shot in war. But it has never been left in peace.

title: CROWLEY, MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said income in the latest quarter was favorably affected by net LIFO adjustments of about $1 a share, caused prinicipally by the reduction of certain lines of merchandise.

title: 8 1/4% EUROPEAN BANK NOTES SET
description: The European Investment Bank is offering $200 million of 8 1/4 percent notes, due in 1998 at a price of 99 5/8 to yield 8.30 percent, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Catchy Tune
description: As part of the program for their ''Bleeker to Broadway'' 25th anniversary concert tour, Peter, Paul and Mary have included a song with which anyone who played Little League or sandlot ball can easily identify. ''Playing Right Field,'' with lyrics and music by Willy Welch, recalls the youthful shame and pain of being assigned that desolate position:.

title: Cuomo Again Vetoes Bill for Death Penalty
description: A bill to restore the death penalty in New York State for some murderers was vetoed today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Vatican Cites Donation Drop After News of Bank Scandal
description: The head of the Vatican's economic affairs department said today that the Vatican's involvement with the scandal surrounding the Banco Ambrosiano had led to a reduction in donations by Catholics.

title: Resigned to City Scandal
description: ''Is this an isolated case, or should we be concerned about broader areas of corruption?'' That is how John Martin, the former United States Attorney, described his mandate when Mayor Koch named him chairman of a new Special Commission to Investigate City Contracts. Now, just two months later, Mr. Martin has resigned, saying his job is redundant. Amazingly, the Mayor has accepted both Mr. Martin's resignation and his assessment.

title: UNR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $301,179 for the quarter and $5,889,279 for the year. c-Net loss d-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,680,762 for the quarter and $5,856,698 for the year.

title: PHILADELPHIANS COPE WITH TRANSIT SNARL
description: More than 440,000 people who usually ride the city's trolley, subway and bus lines scrambled to get to work today on the first full day of a strike by 5,200 transit workers.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 15
FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
McDONNELL IS OUT OF REPUBLIC BID
description: The Republic Health Corporation said the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had withdrawn from an investment group that had agreed to a leveraged buyout of Republic at $305 million, or $18.50 a share in cash, because the buyout price was raised.

title: I'm Splendid Wins Stakes
description: I'm Splendid, rated last year's top 2-year-old filly by the Jockey Club's handicappers but narrowly denied an Eclipse Award, survived a close finish today to win her first start as a 3-year-old in the Hibiscus Stakes at Hialeah Park.

title: INTERTRANS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SUNGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1985 net reflects a non-recurring gain of $1,531,500 on the sale of three radio stations in June.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1986
description: International

title: 'CINDERELLA' TEAMS EMERGING
description: That grande dame of improbable dreams, the fairy godmother, is on a wand-waving roll.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Peter Paris, a senior vice president, has been named executive creative director of Leber Katz Partners.

title: NORTHVIEW CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax loss of $3,099,000 on sale of equity in Financial Corp. of Santa Barbara, and a pre-tax gain of $5.7 million on the sale of Beverly Heritage Hotel in Milpiltas, Calif.

title: WOMAN, 90, SEXUALLY ASSAULTED
description: A 90-year-old woman was sexually assaulted and robbed in her Upper East Side apartment yesterday morning, and a 16-year-old grocery deliveryboy has been charged in the case, the police said.

title: 20 Killed in a Weekend Of South Africa Unrest
description: A weekend of tribal battles, rioting, bombings and arson left more than 20 blacks dead and hundreds injured, according to reports by officials and witnesses.

title: 30 Australian Scientists Rescued in Antarctica
description: An Australian ship has rescued 30 Australian scientists stranded in Antarctica, reaching them just ahead of advancing winter ice, Science Minister Barry Jones said today.

title: PULITZER VETO SEEN
description: Holders of almost 70 percent of Pulitzer Publishing Company stock have stated in writing that their shares should be voted against a $500 million purchase offer by Taubman Media Inc., a Pulitzer official said. Joseph Pulitzer Jr., chairman of the publishing company, said in a news release that the offer would be considered at a special shareholders meeting Tuesday. Pulitzer Publishing owns the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, the Arizona Daily Star in Tucson and a group of community newspapers in the Chicago area, along with seven television stations and two radio stations.

title: Study Finds Malnutrition Is Rampant
description: AS of 1980, about 730 million people, one-third of the populations of 87 developing countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America, did not eat enough to lead active working lives, according to a new study by the World Bank. Almost half of them, 340 million, were acutely malnourished, subsisting on a diet that stunts growth and severely jeopardizes health.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BAXTER UNIT SALE
description: Baxter Travenol Laboratories, based in Deerfield, Ill., announced an agreement in principle to sell its American Medical Optics subsidiary to the SmithKline Beckman Corporation. The unit, based in Irvine, Calif., had sales of more than $60 million last year of intraocular lenses and other eye-care surgical products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ALTMAN PICKS PRESIDENT
description: John J. Schultz has been appointed president and chief merchandising officer of the B. Altman & Company chain of department stores, which is based in New York. Before joining Sanger Harris two years ago, the 49-year-old Mr. Schultz was associated with Bloomingdale's for 22 years, last as executive vice president and general merchandise manager.

title: Comings and Goings
description: World B. Free has had a change of heart concerning his future with the Cleveland Cavaliers. Free, 32 years old, who had said he wanted to play with another team, now says he wants to remain with the Cavaliers.

title: STAGE: ONE-ACT PLAYS ABOUT VIETNAM
description: THE common theme of three one-acters by Stephen Metcalfe at the Vineyard Theater is the suffering of families that lost sons in the Vietnam War. But it is the comedy in each that makes the hurt poignant, and Mr. Metcalfe explores some aspects of the war at home that were mostly neglected in angrier Vietnam plays of the 70's.

title: PRODUCT LIABILITY REVISIONS RECOMMENDED TO PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan today received a series of recommendations from a Cabinet group for changes in laws dealing with product liability claims against manufacturers, a White House official said.

title: Paul Taylor Troupe To Open Season April 1
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company will open its four-week spring season at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, with a gala benefit on April 1 celebrating a 26-year artistic collaboration between Mr. Taylor and the painter Alex Katz. The performance will be followed by a reception at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue at 75th Street, where there is a retrospective of work by Mr. Katz.

title: 'Loot' to Move to Broadway
description: ''Loot,'' a revival of Joe Orton's farce directed by John Tillinger, will move to Broadway after a five-week run at the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: SCIENCE DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Mexico Is Winning The Population Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: Persson Gets Award
description: Stefan Persson, the Islander defenseman who chose to retire rather than report to the Winnipeg Jets after being traded for future considerations last Tuesday, came out of seclusion yesterday to accept an award from the Long Island chapter of the Professional Hockey Writers Association. Persson was a nine-year Islander veteran who played on all four Stanley Cup Championship teams.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $253,000 for the quarter and $1,559,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $557,000 for the quarter and $1,213,000 for the year.

title: Advertising; Ally & Gargano Ads Cite Accomplishments
description: Ally & Gargano has another ad ready to pop. This one it is not doing for free. Nor is it making money on it, as it does with client ads.

title: GENERAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TEXAS BANK LOAN WOES
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares, showing further evidence of this state's sputtering economy, reported today on troubled loans to current or former directors. It said, for example, that it wrote off $18 million of a $30 million loan to one of its former directors, Henry F. LeMieux, and said the balance of the loan was in default.

title: U.S. Urges Freedom For Hostages in Lebanon
description: The Reagan Administration called on ''all civilized governments'' today to urge Iran, Syria and other countries that might have influence to try to bring about the release of all hostages in Lebanon.

title: Jury Chosen for Trial Of Espionage Suspect
description: Jury selection was completed here today for the trial of Jerry A. Whitworth in what Federal prosecutors have called the most important espionage case in decades.

title: ADVANCED LOGIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year ended on Dec. 31, while the previous year ended Nov. 30, reflecting a recent change to a calendar year.

title: Estonians' Pensive Refrain: We Are Not Russians
description: While the rest of the Soviet Union watches state-controlled television programs these wintry evenings, residents of this Estonian capital have been following the latest episodes of ''Dallas'' and ''Dynasty.''

title: Emphasize Scientific Information
description: The time has come to take the moralism and politics out of the informational part of the debate over AIDS.

title: RAINS RAISE RESERVOIRS TO 96.6% OF CAPACITY
description: Water levels in New York City's reservoirs have risen to 96.6 percent of capacity - about 6 percent above normal - after heavy weekend rains in the upstate watersheds, city officials said yesterday.

title: Let Those Liberal Arts Ph.D.'s Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: OTHER BOROUGHS TOP MANHATTAN IN '85 JOB GAINS
description: Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island gained more new jobs in the first six months of last year than did Manhattan, the city reported yesterday. It was the first time since 1965 that the economic growth of the other boroughs had exceeded Manhattan's.

title: 'FRONTLINE' EXAMINES NICARAGUA'S CONTRAS
description: CREDIT ''Frontline,'' public television's weekly documentary series, with staying on top of the news. ''Who's Running This War?'' looks at the Nicaraguan rebels, the contras. Tomorrow the House of Representatives debates whether to give the contras $100 million in aid, and on Thursday it is scheduled to vote on the issue. Representatives swayed by ''Frontline'' are likely to vote no. ''Frontline,'' on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight, knows which side it favors.

title: On Admired Texans
description: The first one is fairly easy: Who, in the history of the state, is the Texan that Texans themselves admire the most? There are places in the Lone Star State that actually have signs proclaiming ''Sam Houston slept here,'' so that should give you the answer to that one.

title: SON OF DIPLOMAT IS SLAIN AS HE INTERRUPTS ROBBERS
description: The son of a Dominican diplomat was shot to death early yesterday when he went to the aid of neighbors being robbed in their Washington Heights apartment, the police said.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago share earnings was adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January 1986.

title: WEST TEXAS OILMEN STRUGGLE TO ENDURE
description: Perkins D. Sams acquired luxury cars, a penthouse office and expensive artworks before the oil boom ended four years ago. Now, having lost much of that personal wealth, he is straining to keep together the small oil exploration business that created it.

title: Friedman Chooses Sides In Co-op City Dispute
description: As if the Bronx Democratic leader, Stanley M. Friedman, does not enough problems, with investigations of his role in a Parking Violations Bureau contract for hand-held computers, he took sides in a feud between two longtime Bronx Democratic allies. The feud has split one of the biggest and most powerful Democratic clubs in the city - the Co-op City Democratic Club.

title: Computer Atlas Puts Globe on a Disk
description: I HAD the world at my fingertips.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER SHUTS VIDEOTEX
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said today it would shut its videotex information service, a pioneer venture begun three years ago on which Knight-Ridder said it had spent $50 million. Viewtron, based in Miami, attracted 20,000 subscribers by delivering news, stock prices and shopping information through customers' home computers.

title: PENGUINS BEATEN
description: Dave Christian ended an 11-game scoring drought with two goals tonight to help the Washington Capitals to a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: THE STAGE: EQUITY'S 'GIRL CRAZY'
description: IF a Tony were awarded for the musical with the all-time smartest songs and dumbest story, ''Girl Crazy'' would be right up there with the best and worst of them. The production, now at the Equity Library Theater, leaps and sinks like a crazed thermometer. There are the highs of the Gershwins' ''I Got Rhythm,'' ''Embraceable You,'' ''Treat Me Rough,'' ''But Not for Me'' and ''Can You Use Me?'' (it was apparently a big season for pronouns); and there are the lows when the music stops for the story slapped together by Guy Bolton and Jack McGowan about a girl-crazy young New Yorker who sets up a dude ranch in Arizona, where he falls in love with a wholesome Western miss.

title: BILL DUE IN SENATE TO CURB ACID RAIN
description: A sweeping new legislative initiative to curb acid rain at an estimated cost of $6 billion a year was announced today by the chairman and other key members of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: OPERA SERENADES AND OTHER MUSINGS
description: IF you were a young man out on the street with lovemaking on your mind, and you had a woman friend indoors and two flights up, susceptible to musical persuasion, what would you do? Perhaps the answer for the 80's is that you would take along one of those portable radios with blasting speakers and turn the volume all the way up. Some sort of thinking along those lines, at any rate, seems to have infected the delivery of serenades, once thought of as essays in tender seductiveness, in our opera houses.

title: Setting Goals
description: Cheryl Bartels, Karen Willoughby and Ann Cernicek of Colorado College played on a Division I women's soccer team last fall that captured the N.C.A.A. Western Regional championship. And not long ago the trio narrowly failed to win the women's Mountain Region championship at Denver in the Schick Super Hoops three-on-three basketball tournament.

title: REAGAN AIDES AT ODDS ON CIGARETTES RULING
description: The issue of whether cigarettes ought to be sold to military personnel at cut-rate prices has divided high members of the Reagan Administration, as a result of a ruling by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the practice should continue, at least for now.

title: Working Profile: Senator Jim Sasser; Evolution of a Stand: Memphis, Marines, Managua
description: When Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee was selected to deliver the Democratic response to President Reagan's speech on Nicaragua Sunday night, even some of his own colleagues were surprised. In nine years in the Senate, Mr. Sasser has seldom played a major role on foreign policy issues or appeared on the television talk shows.

title: MAN OF THE HOUR
description: ''What I like is simple,'' Alistair Duncan Blair said after his sophisticated collection captivated fashion viewers here. ''There is nothing better than a great jacket with a great skirt or pants. That's what a woman should start with.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SAMURAI AND SILK. A Japanese and American Heritage. By Haru Matsukata Reischauer. Illustrated. 371 pages. Harvard University Press. $20. HARU MATSUKATA

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year net includes a gain of $2,493,000 from the sale of partial equity interests in unconsolidated affiliates.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $218,000 from the early retirement of debt. The year-ago results have been restated for a pooling-of-interest acquisition.

title: MITTERRAND TURNS TO A CONSERVATIVE AS PREMIER TODAY
description: After a day of uncertainty and closed-door meetings among political leaders, President Francois Mitterrand announced today that he would ask a conservative on Tuesday to become the new Prime Minister and form a Government.

title: On Scott Joplin
description: It was a great idea. Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland on trumpet, Charles Z. Wick of the United States Information Agency on the keyboard, and former Representative Jim Symington and his wife, Sylvia, singing a cabaret routine. Then, alas, it was discovered that Mr. Wick, who was to take part in a ragtime group called the Scott Joplin Players, could not manage Scott Joplin tunes.

title: DEBATE OVER READING IS REKINDLED
description: REMEMBER when you learned to read? Chances are you learned some words like ''c-a-t'' or ''mo-th-er'' by sounding them out, letter by letter. Other words, like ''the'' or ''and,'' you probably memorized by sight, not by sound.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CBS DRAMA TO LOOK AT TV NEWS ETHICS
description: When Billy Wilder made ''Sunset Boulevard,'' one of the first films to portray the movie business in an unflattering light, M-G-M's Louis B. Mayer told the director: ''You have disgraced the industry that made you and fed you.'' Now, in a rare instance of television scrutinizing itself, CBS has recently completed filming ''News at Eleven,'' a two-hour movie that shows a television news operation perverting news for the sake of ratings. It will be broadcast on April 2.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a tax credit of $395,000. c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $286,000.

title: PAINT PERIL CONFIRMED AT SHELTER
description: An authority on lead poisoning said yesterday that he had found extensive lead-paint hazards at a Manhattan shelter where the city houses homeless families with children.

title: Topics; Cheap Shots Net Nit
description: Lest anyone become confused, what the National Collegiate Athletic Association did last week to Marco Baldi of St. John's University had more to do with its own impotence than with protecting the integrity of collegiate sports.

title: DUVALIER ACCUSED OF GRAFT ON FOOD
description: Haiti's new Government has charged that the Duvalier family received millions of dollars annually by overcharging Haitians for staple foods, including products donated by the United States.

title: Pro Football; RIGGINS, THEISMANN MAY GO
description: The Washington Redskins are in the midst of saying goodbye to two of the most productive players in the franchise's history, the quarterback Joe Theismann and the running back John Riggins.

description: Colonia Inc., the United States marketing arm of the House of 4711, the Cologne, West Germany, fragrance company, has assigned its advertising to Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, a Mickelberry company.

description: In addition to being president of the New York office of Carl Byoir & Associates, a major international public realtions company, William W. Galvin 3d will also be president of the domestic company, a newly created job title. It will put him in charge of 10 regional offices and 18 affiliates.

title: STRONG FIRST HALF POWERS NETS' ROUT
description: The Nets played a perfect first half tonight en route to their easiest victory this season, a 130-102 rout of the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre.

description: b-After a provision for plant closure of $4,952,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income and is after a gain on the sale of real estate of $2,515,000, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

DOLLAR PLUMMETS TO POSTWAR LOW IN TRADING AGAINST JAPANESE YEN
description: The dollar tumbled yesterday to its lowest level against the Japanese yen since the end of World War II, promising a lift for American industry.

title: Welterweight Dies After Fight
description: Steve Watt, the Scottish welterweight boxing champion who collapsed in the ring after a fight last week, died tonight, a hospital spokesman said.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AIR SAFETY CHIEF MINIMIZES SURVEY FINDINGS
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration today minimized the importance of a survey by a Congressional agency that reflected a high level of dissatisfaction among air traffic controllers.

description: b-After extraordinary charges of $8.5 million for the quarter and $9.4 million for the 9 months, and losses from discontinued operations of $105.3 million and $79.7 million for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title:
CRUCIAL STEPS IN COMBATING THE AIDS EPIDEMIC;
Identify All the Carriers
description: I have read and listened, and I think now that I can convincingly crystallize the thoughts chasing about in the minds of, first, those whose concern with AIDS victims is based primarily on a concern for them and for the maintenance of the most rigid standards of civil liberties and personal privacy, and, second, those whose anxiety to protect the public impels them to give subordinate attention to the civil amenities of those who suffer from AIDS and primary attention to the safety of those who do not.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: NORMAN L. CAHNERS
description: Norman L. Cahners, a publisher who built an empire of trade magazines, died of pneumonia Friday.

title: Johnson Shoots 67 To Win By 2
description: Chris Johnson, completing the final six holes of a round she began two days ago, finished with a five-under-par 67 today and won the rain-abbreviated GNA-Glendale Federal Classic.

title: GRIDCOMM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Gridcomm is a development-stage company which began operations in May 1984.

title: CITY TAXI MEDALLIONS NOW UNDER SCRUTINY WERE FIRST USED IN 1980
description: A program to test diesel-powered taxicabs on New York City's streets, a matter now under investigation by city, state and Federal authorities, got under way in 1980 to determine the effects on the city's air.

title: THE MAKING OF A DESIGNER
description: Tommy Hilfiger is headed for the top - just ask him.

title: U.S. PLANS AGENCY TO SERVE FAMILIES
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will create a new agency in his department to operate programs serving low-income families, department officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You have elected a new majority of deputies to the National Assembly.

REDMEN REFLECT ON GOOD AND BAD
description: As St. John's New York-bound flight swept through the indigos and soft orange colors of predawn, the pain of the Redmen's season-ending defeat began to soak in.

title: C.I.A. IS REPORTED SET TO CHANNEL AID TO CONTRAS
description: If Congress approves the military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that President Reagan has requested, the Central Intelligence Agency is ready with a basic plan for providing them with arms and training, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: REFAC TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago quarter and year earnings include nonrecurring income of $1,435,000, or 33 cents a share, from the acquisition of 700,000 Patlex Corp. common shares as a consideration for the sale of Refac's exclusive right to license the Laser patents of Gordon Gould. The share earnings reflect a 20 percent stock dividend distributed in December 1985.

title: Getting Homosexual Rights Bill Right

title: Chess: Sokolov Will Meet Yusupov In Candidates Tourney Final
description: The Russian grandmaster Andrei Sokolov won his semifinal world championship candidates match with his countryman Rafael Vaganian in Minsk by a decisive 6-2 score. It thus became superfluous to play the last two games of the contest.

title: WILLIAMS GETS 40
description: Herb Williams scored a career-high 40 points as the Indiana Pacers routed the Knicks, 112-92, today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Princess Anne, turned out in coral taffeta, attended a black-tie fashion pageant at the Savoy Hotel here. Many of the city's top designers were represented and after the show the Princess reflected on the clothes. ''It does seem awfully gray,'' she said. ''Do you think it's a sign of the times?''

title: NATIONAL HMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Pennsylvania Man, 49, Gets an Artificial Heart
description: Doctors tonight implanted a Penn State artificial heart into a Pennsylvania man whose body was rejecting a transplanted heart, the Hershey Medical Center said.

title: FARM TECHNOLOGY IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Genetic engineering and other emerging technologies, often cited as cost-cutting tools that will help save small and medium-size farms, could instead raise costs and cut the number of farms in half, a Congressional report predicted today.

description: b-Net income

title: DWINDLING KING SALMON GET SOME HUMAN HELP
description: King salmon, which weigh up to 30 pounds each, are disappearing from Puget Sound here, but an ambitious effort by public and private groups has begun to reverse this trend.

title: NUCLEAR REACTOR HAZARD IS NEW CONCERN IN SHUTTLE FLIGHTS
description: The Energy Department said today that a shuttle explosion on the launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida could, under certain circumstances, release enough radioactive material to contaminate up to 386 square miles of land and cause 43 cancer deaths over a 50-year period.

description: Saudi Arabia signaled a willingness today to discuss a fresh OPEC production accord to stem the decline in oil prices.
