title: Soviet Pair Leads In Figure Skating
description: Yekaterina Gordeyeva and Sergei Grinkov of the Soviet Union took an early lead over the defending champions today in pairs competition at the World Figure Skating Championships with a routine set to a ragtime beat.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Right's Turn in France
description: France, which turned left to elect Francois Mitterand as President in 1981, has now turned right, giving control of the next parliament to the parties of a conservative alliance. But not very far right; a notable aspect of Sunday's election is how fast the nation's political pendulum has slowed.

title: Harold W. Arlin Dead; An Early Radio Figure
description: Harold W. Arlin, the world's first full-time radio announcer, died Friday at his home in Bakersfield, Calif., after having suffered a heart attack on March 2. He was 90 years old.

title: Happy Goalie Buoys Rangers
description: Glen Hanlon spent most of the fall exiled to the minor leagues, he has spent most of the winter readjusting to a new role, and now, with spring approaching, he says that he feels more comfortable than perhaps ever before in his career.

title: Parker Comments
description: The Cincinnati Reds outfielder Dave Parker, one of the seven players who faced a year's suspension from baseball as a result of their involvement with cocaine, described his use of cocaine while he was with the Pittsburgh Pirates from 1980-82 as recreational, and denied he ever had a drug problem. ''It was a fad.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward benefit of $343,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss and includes charges of $13,031,000 from the sale of assets, or from assets held for sale, and $6,406,000 from the settlement of litigation for the quarter and year.

title: STANLINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ECKERD, JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $5,016,000 for the quarter and $3,247,000 for the 6 months. The discontinued operations are from two units sold in August 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 18, 1986
description: International Francois Mitterrand plans to appoint a rightist Prime Minister to form a new government after legislative elections Sunday that gave a slender majority in the French Parliament to the rightist opposition. President Mitterrand, a Socialist, did not specify who the new Prime Minister would be. [ Page A1, Column 6. ] Washington moved to give Manila access today to 1,500 pages of documents taken by Ferdinand E. Marcos when he fled the Philippines. The new Government has said the documents could be essential in helping to trace and reclaim $10 billion it says he and his associates diverted. [ A1:4. ] The dollar tumbled to its lowest level against the Japanese yen since 1945. The dollar is down 33 percent from its record high, set last March, and some benefits are beginning to show up in the American economy. [ A1:2-3. ] A resumption of Soviet nuclear tests is likely, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said satellite photographs show that the Russians have been digging holes and tunnels in which nuclear explosives could be placed and moving monitoring equipment to a test area. [ A1:5. ] Swedish authorities charged a man they have in custody as an accomplice in the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme. The Times of London identified the suspect as Victor Gunnarsson, 32 years old. [ A1:3-5. ] Nicaraguan rebels must be trained by experienced soldiers if they hope to develop into a force that can threaten the Sandinista Government, in the view of diplomats and military experts in Managua.

title: Advertising; Cancer Society's New Ads
description: ''WE'VE always benefited from the best,'' said Irving Rimer, vice president for public relations of the American Cancer Society, after viewing the first contribution from Ally & Gargano, the society's volunteer agency for the next three years.

title: FORD SHIFTS CONFIRMED
description: The Ford Motor Company today announced that, as expected, Robert A. Lutz, chairman of Ford of Europe, would be brought to the United States to run the company's truck operations. Philip E. Benton Jr., most recently in charge of diversified products, was elevated to executive vice president for international automotive operations.

title: NU-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HOUSE DEMOCRATS PLAY DOWN SPEECH
description: House Democratic leaders said today that despite President Reagan's nationally televised plea on Sunday for aid to the rebels in Nicaragua, they still had the votes to defeat his aid request this week.

title: AMERICAN PHYSICIANS SERVICE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $32,836 for the quarter and $232,000 for the year. c-Net income

title: SOLITUDE, PRECISION CHALLENGE TO FENCER
description: Most athletes have predictable heroes, such as Walter Payton, Larry Bird, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar or Pete Rose. Mike Lofton has his own heroes.

title: CRYSTAL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,253,000 for the quarter and $14,158,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $722,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $415,000 for the year and an extraordinary credit of $1,675,000 for the quarter and year.

title: New Rubber Source
description: The guayule shrub, which grows wild in the American Southwest and northern Mexico, has long been seen as a potential new source of natural rubber and the basis for a domestic industry. Its product is almost identical to that from tropical rubber trees.

title: CENTRAL MAINE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $4.2 million reserve related to the recapture of investment tax credits. c-After a reserve of $10 million for possible losses related to canceled power plants for the quarter and year. d-After a net charge of $45.2 million from the writedown of investments.

title: NEW ISSUES IN TECHNOLOGY
description: THE market for new issues of high-technology stocks is showing signs of recovery. The reception for new offerings had been quite inhospitable after a speculative binge in 1983 led to losses for many investors.

title: Farm Workers Are Snared in Agricultural Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: VETERANS VALUE PERSONAL GROWTH OVER JOB SKILLS
description: The Army has found that young men and women who have left the service think the military experience was more valuable in personal development than it was in teaching job skills, according to a survey.

title: THE MARCOS LEGACY: A TOURIST DRAW
description: The graven images that Ferdinand E. Marcos left behind have begun to trouble Filipinos as they seek an inviting identity for the post-Marcos nation.

title: GUT AND MAN AT HARVARD: WHEN A FELLOW NEEDS A FRIEND
description: ''Snowmobiles,'' ''Heroes for Zeros,'' ''Roman Coins'' and ''P.M.&A.'' are the nicknames of some unusually popular courses at Harvard.

title: LAWYER HIRINGS SAID TO BE URGED BY CUOMO STAFF
description: Governor Cuomo's staff has recommended the hiring of politically connected law firms by both the State Insurance Department and the State Insurance Fund, according to officials at both agencies.

title: South Carolina Offering Bonds
description: South Carolina is offering $85 million of general obligation bonds, rated triple-A, through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank with yields ranging from 4 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 5.30 percent in 1991, 6.05 percent in 1996 and 6.70 percent in 2002.

title: The Problem of Gift-Giving
description: What does the President of the United States give a sultan? Or a Prime Minister? And what do they give the President?

title: Guess Who Came to Dinner
description: Following is the list of people invited to the White House dinner tonight for Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada and his wife, Mila:

title: RIGHTS INQUIRY FOCUSES ON THE SECRET SERVICE
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating a group of Secret Service agents in a squad that combats counterfeiting in New York, according to court documents in Manhattan.

title: AQUINO PLANS A PILOT PROGRAM FOR REBEL AMNESTY
description: President Corazon C. Aquino has decided to offer Communist insurgents an amnesty plan that includes job training and safe haven for the rebels and their families, according to her aides.

title: Gooden Hit Hard, But Feels Great
description: Dwight Gooden says not to worry. True, the Detroit Tigers reached him for five hits and three runs in four innings this afternoon. True, the curveball wasn't working, and they were tagging the fast one. And there was no doubt that this was the least elegant of the three exhibition games he has started this spring.

title: The U.N. Today: March 19, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: BROWN & WILLIAMSON, which makes Kool cigarettes, had New York jazz fans worried when it announced Kool would no longer sponsor the annual jazz festival here. But George Wein, who has produced the festival since its inception in 1954 in Newport, R.I., has lined up another sponsor; a New York jazz festival with a new name is scheduled for June 20-29.

title: BRAZIL SURPRISED TO BE ON REAGAN'S LIST
description: For the second time in three weeks, Brazil has expressed surprise and puzzlement at being included by the Reagan Administration among countries in the Western Hemisphere potentially threatened by Nicaragua.

title: CONSULTANT SHIFTING TO SECAUCUS
description: THE continuing high cost of office space in Manhattan has pushed many companies to the suburbs and the outer boroughs. Such moves, often made reluctantly, usually are a leap into the unknown.

title: California Cheese Company Cleared in Listeriosis Cases
description: A plant that made Mexican-style soft cheese linked to three listeriosis cases in Arizona won conditional clearance today to reopen under prescribed conditions, state officials said.

title: King Dispute Heard
description: Kingman Brewster, the court-appointed special master in labor problems for the National Basketball Association, heard eight hours of testimony yesterday in the league's dispute over the Knicks' salary-sheet offer that was signed by Albert King last fall and then matched by the Nets. The sheet, for $3.3 million over five years, called for only $75,000 in salary in each of the first two years and included a $960,000 signing bonus was originally approved by Brewster.

title: UNION CARBIDE'S FINE IS CUT TO $4,400 FOR CHEMICAL LEAK
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has reduced by 86 percent the fines it proposed against the gust's chemical leak in Institute, Union Carbide Corporation for the proposed fining the company $32,100 last October. At the time, it called three of the violations ''willful,'' thus warranting the maximum $10,000 penalty for each.

title: CHURCH AIDES SAY O'CONNOR MEANT NO THREAT TO COLLEGE
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York say John Cardinal O'Connor never meant to threaten to drop church support of a medical college affiliated with two city hospitals that perform abortions.

title: MRS. LOUIS J. LEFKOWITZ
description: Helen Schwimmer Lefkowitz, the wife of former New York State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ONE CRITIC'S VIEW OF PERFECT MARRIAGE
description: Television has its share of critics, but few can claim to be tougher than Neil Postman. His opinion, expressed most recently in his 16th book, ''Amusing Ourselves To Death,'' is that television, having little interest in substance, is merrily reducing public issues and discourse to entertainment. He asks why newscasts have music if not to entertain and warns that ''culture death'' could be the outcome.

title: WASHINGTON STATE BEGINS BOND SALE
description: The State of Washington is offering $110.7 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citicorp Investment Bank.

title: AUTO WORKERS GIVE UP HONDA PLANT ORGANIZING
description: The United Automobile Workers has halted its six-year drive to organize workers at a Honda Motors plant in Ohio in a major setback to its drive to represent workers at the growing number of Japanese-owned plants in the United States.

title: Large Obstacle
description: Learning to sail an America's Cup contender in the roily waters off Perth, Australia, proved to be a challenge all its own last month during the 12-Meter World Championships. Rough seas tossed crewmen from four different boats into the turbulent Indian Ocean during racing, and crewmen below deck found themselves sloshing around at times in water up to their kneecaps.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:29 A.M. today and set at 12:23 P.M. On Thursday it will rise at 3:25 and set at 12:12 P.M.

title: Formal Release
description: Pat Kennedy, the Iona basketball coach who was named the Florida State coach last Thursday, was formally released from the remaining two years of his Iona contract yesterday after school officials decided to let him go without a fight. ''We will take no legal action against Pat,'' said Iona's president, Brother John Driscoll. ''We feel disappointed that he is leaving us, but we will not hold him to his contract.''

title: Pillaster to Run In the Bay Shore
description: Pillaster, one of the early favorites for the Kentucky Derby May 3, will run in the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct Saturday, the colt's trainer, Leroy Jolley, said today.

title: Legislators Say Marcos Mustn't Get Immunity
description: Three members of a key House subcommittee asked President Reagan today for assurances that the Administration would not try to shield Ferdinand E. Marcos from criminal proceedings. They said there was a ''real possibility'' that the former Philippine President had misappropriated United States foreign aid funds.

title: GENERIC FOOD BRANDS ARE GETTING A FACE LIFT
description: After a bloom of popularity a few years ago, the black-and-white labels of generic food products are seen less often, but careful shoppers can still find bargains in most markets.

title: U.S. SKI TEAM ON DOWN SIDE
description: After nearly a decade of winning, the United States ski team has gone into a two-year slump. Last season the male racers were hardly on the charts with any World Cup points, and this season the much-heralded women's team has not shown many scoring performances.

title: Bird and Celtics Roll On
description: Larry Bird scored 43 points tonight, 34 in the first half, to power the Boston Celtics to a 126-96 trouncing of the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Policeman Stumbles And Shoots Another
description: A police officer was accidentally shot by his partner last night as they searched for two drug dealers in an abandoned building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: SINDONA GETS LIFE TERM IN MURDER CASE IN ITALY
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier already facing prison terms in the United States and Italy for bank fraud, was convicted today of contracting a murder.

title: Liberian Schoolchildren Riot for Teachers
description: Schoolchildren demanding their teachers be paid rioted today, smashing windows, stoning cars, beating other students and fighting with riot policemen who hurled tear-gas canisters at them.

title: MITTERRAND ASKS CHIRAC TO ASSUME THE PREMIERSHIP
description: President Francois Mitterrand today asked a longtime political rival, Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, to form a new Government.

title: Bradley Coach Honored
description: For a team that had a 32-3 record and won 22 consecutive games, the longest streak in major college basketball this season, Bradley University and its coach, Dick Versace, did not get much preseason recognition from the national news media. None of the preseason polls, for example, listed the Peoria, Ill., school among the top 40 teams.

title: JUDGE'S ORDER REMOVES INMATES FROM A BANKRUPT PRIVATE PRISON
description: The state's only privately owned prison was emptied of inmates today under a judge's order, one day after the owners filed for reorganization in United States Bankruptcy Court.

title: Big Assist
description: Marcel Dionne had only one assist last night during the Los Angeles Kings' 5-3 victory over the Washington Capitals, but he made a big point with it.

title: HASSEY ACCEPTS ROLE AS RESERVE
description: His bats had already been shipped south for spring training. Ron Hassey said he was making plans to travel here, where the Chicago White Sox make their camp, and perhaps to earn a spot as the club's primary catcher.

title: RHODE ISLAND PAPER IS CITED FOR DEFYING PUBLISHING BAN
description: A Federal judge yesterday found the Journal Company of Providence, R.I., and the executive editor of The Journal newspaper guilty of criminal contempt for publishing an article in defiance of the judge's order.

title: BLUNT JAPANESE OFFICIAL PUSHES TRADE MESSAGE
description: When Michio Watanabe served as Japan's Finance Minister a few years ago, he embarked on a public relations campaign to convince the nation of the need for fiscal austerity. As the new Minister of International Trade and Industry, however, Mr. Watanabe may have a more formidable task -convincing Japanese consumers and business executives to buy foreign goods.

title: JUDGE REISSUES JAIL TIMETABLE
description: A Federal judge, reversing his decision of a month ago, has ordered New York State prisons to accept sentenced inmates from the city's jails within 48 hours of their processing.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RAIN OR SHINE. By Cyra McFadden. 178 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95. WHEN Cy Taillon, the

title: AGE: HUMOR IN INFIRMITY AND JOY IN LIFE
description: FOR years I have been lying about my age. When I was young I said I was older.

title: RABBI DISPUTES REAGAN POINT ABOUT THE JEWS IN NICARAGUA
description: Although President Reagan said in a televised address Sunday night that the Nicaraguan Government had persecuted Jews, several outside investigations have found the charge baseless.

title: Soviet Pair Skate to Title
description: Sergei Grinkov and Ekaterina Gordeeva of the Soviet Union performed a lively, well-synchronized long program tonight to beat the defending champions and win the pairs competition at the world figure skating championships.

title: Pressure Managua with Arms. . .
description: The testimony from Nicaragua's neighbors leaves little doubt that the Sandinista Government is determined to wipe out opposition at home while subverting fragile democracies elsewhere in Latin America.

title: A YOUTH CENTER FOR THE DISABLED
description: DELINDA STERLING, an 18-year-old who was born with a bone disease that caused her limbs to grow improperly, has lived all her life in a Bronx hospital. At times, her life seemed unbearable. ''I even felt suicidal at one time,'' Miss Sterling said. ''Now I wouldn't kill myself for anything. My self-esteem is up.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I told the President of the Republic that I would give him my answer within the shortest possible time.'' -Jacques Chirac, after being asked to form the next French Government. [ A1:3. ]

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FIBER is being touted today as a treatment or preventive of many of the major and minor ailments afflicting people in the overly refined 20th century -from heart disease, cancer and diabetes to constipation, hemorrhoids and obesity.

title: WOMEN NOW THE MAJORITY IN PROFESSIONS
description: MARKING a major shift, the United States Labor Department has reported that women now hold the majority of professional jobs in the country, after edging out men by 29,000 jobs last month.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article on Sunday about private business schools reported that New York State was examining complaints involving their recruiting.

title: COURT THREATENS PRESIDENT OF HOSPITAL UNION WITH JAIL
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday ordered the leader of the city's largest organization of hospital workers to jail unless she tells the rank and file that the union violated a court order barring strike-related violence.

title: Farewell
description: Ralph Harris, who has covered the White House for Reuters under the past seven Presidents, is retiring next week, and a group of his current colleagues - he has outlasted several generations there - are giving him a farewell party March 28.

title: KNICKS SURPRISE NETS IN OVERTIME
description: The Knicks, who have found dozens of ways to lose in regulation, finally found a way to win one tonight in overtime.

title: FOCUS ON DAY-TO-DAY SUPPORT OFFERS HOPE TO SCHIZOPHRENICS
description: Innovative programs scattered around the country are offering the first rays of hope in decades for millions of tormented victims of schizophrenia, which has become the nation's worst mental health problem.

title: DOLLAR, IN UNEASY DAY, UP AGAINST YEN IN U.S.
description: The dollar bobbed and weaved in nervous trading yesterday, at one point touching a record low against the yen for the second consecutive day.

title: EXXON REALIGNING OIL AND COAL UNITS
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would restructure its oil and gas operations outside North America and its coals and minerals division because of the recent sharp drop in oil prices.

title: SEOUL'S BOOK PIRATES SHARE THE BOOTY
description: In a move hailed as significant by book industry officials, a leading South Korean book publisher recently negotiated contracts with an American literary agency for 10 books by Alvin Toffler. Moreover, several other South Korean publishers have signed contracts in recent weeks to pay royalties for books by Norman Mailer, Leo Buscaglia, Carl Sagan, Daniel Boorstin, Ken Follett and Senators William S. Cohen and Gary Hart.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings results are after a 5-for-4 stock split, in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend, payable April 14 to holders of record MArch 12.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Lamb for Easter In many parts of the world, especially in the Christian countries of the Mediterranean, lamb, not ham, is the centerpiece of the Easter feast.

title: DRUG AGENCY REBUTS REAGAN CHARGE
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration today disputed an assertion by President Reagan that ''top Nicaraguan Government officials are deeply involved in drug trafficking.''

title: REPORT ON MENTAL HEALTH CARE CRITICIZES NEW YORK
description: New York State once ran one of the best mental health systems in the country but is ''no longer a leader,'' according to a national evaluation that said the state was now providing ''very mediocre services'' for the seriously mentally ill.

title: Helping Hands
description: Mark Jackson picked up 12 assists in St. John's season-ending loss to Auburn on Sunday, extending his National Collegiate Athletic Association single-season record to 328 in 36 games. Jackson, a junior, ran his three-season total to 545.

title: DAYS OF RECKONING: PICKING THE CLASS OF '90
description: The girl who wrote an essay about how much she hated her parents did not get in. Neither did the boy whose main extracurricular activity was spiders.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO LACK 10 VOTES ON AID TO REBELS
description: Congressional leaders of both parties agreed today that President Reagan must persuade at least 10 more House members to vote for his $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels or face defeat.

title: FOR MISS LIBERTY'S 100TH, TICKETS BY LOTTERY
description: Given the message, the method seemed apt. What better way to satisfy the national demand to see the Statue of Liberty Centennial on July 4 - a celebration of democracy and opportunity - than to hold the most democratic and least discriminating of contests - a lottery?

title: N.F.L. Union Will Propose Its Drug Plan
description: The National Football League Players Association said it would announce a new drug program today that could be implemented in time for the 1986 season.

title: QUEENS LEGISLATORS LOOKING TO A FUTURE WITHOUT MANES
description: Among the mourners at Donald R. Manes's funeral last Sunday were most of the 23 members of the Queens legislative delegation, a collection of state senators and Assembly members whose special working relationship is vulnerable because of the death of the man who molded them into a unit.

title: MUSIC: NEW AMSTERDAM
description: THE New Amsterdam Singers gave a song recital for chorus at Merkin Concert Hall Sunday evening: 30 poems (or parts of poems), set for multiple voices, as opposed to the larger works that large ensembles usually sing. The program was more interesting than satisfying, but it gave food for thought, for reflection on one facet of the myriad interactions of word and tone.

title: NASA TEAM HOPES TO WIND UP INQUIRY AND SALVAGING BY APRIL 18
description: Space agency investigators hope to complete by next month their preliminary findings on what caused the Challenger explosion, even if key portions of the spaceship's right-side booster rocket have not been recovered from the sea by then.

title: EISENHOWER AIDE IN '52 RACE
description: Robert R. Mullen, who was a campaign press secretary for Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1952 Presidential campaign and later worked in the unsuccessful effort to win the 1964 Republican nomination for Henry Cabot Lodge, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Frederick, Md. He was 77 years old.

title: SWEDISH SUSPECT WAS ONCE IN RIGHTIST GROUP
description: A right-wing group said today that a 32-year-old man charged Monday with involvement in the killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme was a former member of the group.

title: Singapore Woman Saved After 3 Days in Rubble
description: Rescuers saved a woman Tuesday night who survived three days in the rubble of a collapsed hotel, protected by a table.

title: OFFICIAL SPURNS DRUG TEST DEMAND AT HOUSE HEARING ON FEDERAL PLAN
description: A member of the President's Commission on Organized Crime refused a demand Tuesday that he give a urine sample for a drug test before he could testify about making such tests mandatory for all Federal workers.

title: RECORD U.S. TRADE DEFICIT
description: The deficit in the nation's broadest measure of foreign trade hit a record $117.7 billion last year, the Government reported today.

title: MANAGING EDITOR NAMED AT FORTUNE
description: In a series of changes among the senior editors at Time Inc., Marshall Loeb, editor of Time's magazine development group, was named managing editor of Fortune magazine, effective May 5.

title: HOUSING STARTS FELL LAST MONTH
description: Home construction dropped slightly last month from the two-year high reached in January, the Government reported today. Analysts dismissed the decline, however, as only a small setback in what remains a boom time for housing.

title: Gretzky Gets 50th
description: Wayne Gretzky reached the 50-goal plateau for the seventh straight season as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Winnipeg Jets, 6-2, tonight.

title: The Right Way to Test Teachers
description: If students must get back to basics can teachers be far behind? No. The educational reform movement is putting increasing pressure on teachers to prove their competence in the classroom. It's a sound enough principle, but without thoughtful execution and the involvement of the teachers themselves it will not become useful policy.

title: TAXI CONCERNS' PAPERS SEIZED
description: Federal investigators have seized records from two Queens taxi companies in an attempt to determine if payoffs were made to the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission, a source close to the investigation said yesterday.

title: Duell Endowment Created
description: The Joseph Duell Education Fund has been established as an endowment to benefit special programs presented by the New York City Ballet Education Department. Mr. Duell, a popular principal dancer with City Ballet who died last month, was a frequent participant in the department's programs for New York schoolchildren. Contributions, which are tax-deductible, may be sent to the New York City Ballet, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, New York, N.Y. 10023. Information: 580-5426.

title: Destination Geneva
description: Avis Bohlen, daughter of the late Charles E. Bohlen, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union and longtime State Department adviser, is reported to be in line to become deputy to Max M. Kampelman, chief American negotiator at the arms control talks in Geneva. She would succeed Warren Zimmerman, who will move to the 35-nation conference on carrying out the Helsinki accords on human rights, diplomatic sources say.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM PRESENTS 'GRANGE EVE'
description: MERCE CUNNINGHAM grew up in Centralia, Wash. and by his own account his was a childhood full of small-town delights -family picnics and tours of rural granges to perform tap or vaudeville numbers taught by a local and respected dance teacher.

title: POPPE TYSON
description: Poppe Tyson, the business-to-business division of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, has been named to do advertising for the Wells Fargo Guards Service, which operates nationally and is carefully guarding its advertising spending plans. The client, formerly served by the Lowery Swan Group in Springfield, N.J., has its headquarters in Parsippany, N.J., and is a division of Baker Industries, which in turn is a division of Borg-Warner.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE mother and her son - he was in his stroller and looked to be about 2 1/2 or 3 years old - were passing the St. Agnes branch of the New York Public Library on Amsterdam Avenue and 81st Street. Their conversation was overheard by Heller McAlpin.

title: Ballesteros Critical Of PGA Tour Ban
description: Seve Ballesteros said today it was unfair to require that he and other European players compete in a minimum of 15 American tournaments each year to qualify for the PGA Tour and that he would not be able to meet such a requirement in the future.

title: JUDGE TO ADMIT KEY LETTERS IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that four anonymous letters detailing a Soviet spy ring could be used as evidence against Jerry A. Whitworth at his espionage trial.

title: Spring, and the Fiscal Apprehension Is Blooming
description: You can sense it on the buses and the subways, in the anxious shoptalk of Federal workers that turns, again and again, to three names: Gramm-Rudman-Hollings.

title: PANEL MAY SEEK SHARPER LIMIT ON PENTAGON
description: Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee are discussing a compromise that would limit the Pentagon budget for 1987 to an increase to make up for only about half the rate of inflation, several senators said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Sent Gary Parmenter, Carl Hamilton and Steve Engel, pitchers, and Damon Berryhill, catcher, to minor leagues. Sent Ray Fontenot, pitcher, to minor league camp for a week.

title: 'WINDOWS ON WOMENH,' DOCUMENTARY
description: THE United Nations Decade for Women (1975-1985) is celebrated tonight from 11 o'clock to midnight in an ''Intercom'' documentary called ''Windows on Women'' on WNET/Channel 13. The program is an olla-podrida that borrows pieces from previously broadcast shows, seasons the mixture with commentary by Ruby Dee, the actress, and leaves at least one viewer unimpressed by the diversity of its good intentions.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including a charge of $1,890,000 for asbestos litigation costs.

title: RIOJA TAKING ITS PLACE IN THE SUN
description: BENEATH this Romanesque stone village in Spain's premier red wine region of La Rioja, 60 feet underground, inside the dank cellars of Marques de Riscal, is ''the cathedral,'' as it is called. There on long, tall racks rest thousands of bottles of wine that go back year by year to the winery's founding in 1860. A grayish mold, thick like wool on many of the bottles, blankets this almost priceless collection.

title: Edward J. Dimock, 96, A Senior Federal Judge
description: Edward Jordan Dimock, a senior Federal district judge, died Monday at his home in Forestburgh, N.Y. He was 96 years old.

title: B.Y.U. Advances
description: Jeff Chatman's 20 points led five Brigham Young players in double figures as the Cougars romped to a 93-80 victory over California-Irvine in the only National Invitation Tournament game tonight. The victory sent Brigham Young (18-13) into the Friday quarterfinals against Ohio State.

title: CITICORP MAKES OFFER TO PURCHASE QUOTRON
description: In its boldest move yet into the world of information systems, Citicorp offered yesterday to buy Quotron Systems Inc., the worldwide provider of stock quotations and other financial data.

title: STOCK BOOM, BUSINESS CRAWL
description: THE United States economy is going to have to perform brilliantly to justify the huge run-up in the stock market. Using the Dow industrial average as the measure, the stock market climbed 43.72 percent in the 12 months ended March 14, 1986, one of the fastest and steepest rises in history.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Halston Fragrances, a Beatrice company, to Korey, Kay & Partners for two new high-end fragrance entries.

title: U.S. Has the Right to Limit Soviet U.N. Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: COALITION OPPOSES COURT ACCESS CURB
description: An unusual coalition of major labor, business and environmental groups united today in opposing a Reagan Administration request that the Supreme Court reverse years of precedent by limiting organizations' access to the courts.

title: A Scholar's Ultimate Safeguard: Integrity
description: To the Editor:

title: EARLY GRADUATION IS ORDERED FOR STUDENT HELD IN 2 RAPES
description: A Darien High School honor student who has been charged with two rapes has been graduated early against his wishes and those of his family.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: OVER the past decade, the taste of Americans has become progressively more cultivated, and Americans have been more accepting of foods that once seemed too exotic for practical use: fine mustards, vinegars and oils; ''new'' salad greens such as radicchio, endive, dandelion and arugula, and herbs such as fresh coriander, fennel and basil. Most are now widely available throughout the country.

title: NEW LOOK IN DESSERTS: THE SOPHISTICATED SAMPLER
description: RESTAURANT dessert carts bearing tiers of fancy cakes may be going the way of the horse and buggy, replaced in many dining rooms by stunning dessert plates, jewel-like samplers of sweets, often variations on a theme.

title: U.S. Has the Right to Limit Soviet U.N. Mission
description: To the Editor:

title: PIRATES DIFFER ON WHETHER TO JUMP SHIP
description: In the last few years, a player on the Pittsburgh Pirates was like a passenger on the Titanic: given a choice, you'd leave.

title: PLAN FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO REAGAN AND CARTER FOUND IN MARCOS FILES
description: Administration and Congressional officials said today that one of the documents brought to the United States by Ferdinand E. Marcos showed a plan to make payments to several American political candidates, including $50,000 each to Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter.

title: TRACEY-LOCKE FILLS KEY POST Tracy-Locke Fills Key Post
description: Howard W. Davis, who has never worked for another agency, has been named chief executive of Tracy-Locke, the Dallas-based, $300 million-in-billings subsidiary of BBDO International.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CAPITAL RATIO
description: The First Chicago Corporation announced that the Comptroller of the Currency and the bank holding company, the nation's 10th largest, had agreed to end an unusual pact that required First Chicago's banking subsidiary to increase its primary capital to 6 percent of its assets by last Dec. 31.

title: Protester Is Banned By Library of Congress
description: A lawyer who has been a leader of recent protests against the new, earlier closing hours for the Library of Congress said today that he had been banned by library officials until October.

title: Two Condemned Men Win Stays of Execution
description: Two condemned killers won stays of execution today, a day before they were to die in the electric chair, with the United States Supreme Court sparing one man and a Federal appeals court ruling for the other.

title: TREASURY BOND PRICES CLIMB
description: After a day of erratic trading, the Treasury bond market closed strongly yesterday after the Treasury announced that it would not offer a 20-year bond issue that had been expected for sale next week.

title: Downtown Jam . . .
description: There was a wall of water at Water and Wall yesterday.

title: PHELPS DODGE'S TURNAROUND
description: A few years ago this rugged country - home to bighorn sheep, cactus and the nation's largest surviving copper mine - seemed a likely cemetery for the Phelps Dodge Corporation.

title: MARTIN'S PROSPECTS ON FED JOB
description: Preston Martin, President Reagan's first appointee to the Federal Reserve Board, remains undecided about whether to accept a second term as vice chairman, according to a source familiar with Mr. Martin's thinking, despite an extraordinary setback for Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, that seemed to enhance Mr. Martin's prospects for succeeding him.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on abandoments and impairment of $142,200,000 for the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $74,700,000 for the quarter, $75,200,000 for the year. c-After losses on abandonments and impairment of $15,500,000 for the quarter and year, and losses from discontinued operations of $28,400,000 for the quarter and $26,500,000 for the year.

title: Topics; Reproduction The Sexual Sell
description: Advertisements celebrating adolescent sexuality have become commonplace. Those that commemorate its consequences are exceedingly rare. But last week, as part of its new teen-age pregnancy prevention campaign, the Children's Defense Fund unveiled four posters that do just that.

title: ALBANY ACCORD REACHED ON APARTMENTS FOR CITY
description: A $400 million plan to build or rehabilitate 24,000 low-and middle-income apartments in New York City was tentatively agreed upon today by the Cuomo administration and legislative leaders.

title: South Korean Cars Recalled
description: Less than a month after their official introduction, all South Korean-made Hyundai cars sold in the United States are being recalled because a missing or damaged part could cause total brake failure, the importer says. Four thousand cars may be involved in the recall, Bruce Matthias, spokesman for Hyundai Motor America Inc., said Monday. The Hyundai Excel subcompacts, which have a list price of $4,995, are the first Korean cars to be sold in the United States.

title: If Waldheim Were A 'Great Statesman'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
U.S. DETAILS ARMS TO SANDINISTAS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Nicaragua's Soviet bloc allies were expected to supply the Sandinista Government with a number of aircraft and helicopters that would add substantially to the country's air combat ability.

title:
ADVERTISING;
PEOPLE
description: * Jodi Goodhart has joined Austin, Bernier Advertising, Springfield, Va., as executive vice president and partner, and her name is going on the door.

title: DELTA, T.W.A. IN STUDY
description: Delta Air Lines has discussed the possibility of operating a reservations system with Trans World Airlines in a move that could improve Delta's access to passengers and increase cash for T.W.A., according to industry sources.

title: 3-STAGE SHARPENER FOR KNIVES
description: IT is a constant source of amazement to me how so many cooks spend substantial money on quality knives, yet fail to maintain them. The best knife in the world with a dull edge is like a Rolls-Royce with a lawnmower engine - it may get you there, but the journey is slow and frustrating.

title: U.S. Publicity Concern Ends Its Angola Links
description: Gray & Company, a public relations concern that was criticized by conservatives for representing the Marxist Government of Angola, has ended its business ties with that country, company officials said today.

title: INSPIRED ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS
description: This was the way the Islanders wanted to be remembered. They outshot their opponents, 37 to 21, outscored them by four goals and forced out one goalie after collecting their fifth goal midway through the game, leaving a record crowd at Nassau Coliseum more than satisfied.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TEXAN'S NOMINATION AS U.S. JUDGE CONFIRMED
description: The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Sidney A. Fitzwater to be a Federal district judge in Dallas, rejecting arguments by Democrats who said he was insensitve to the rights of black and Hispanic people.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 19, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Man Accused in the Shooting Of Officers Is a Paroled Killer
description: A 31-year-old man charged with shooting two police officers in their patrol car in the Bronx Monday night is a paroled killer who repeatedly committed assaults while in prison, the police said yesterday.

title: A.T.& T. FALLS OUT OF FAVOR
description: BEFORE the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at the start of 1984, Ma Bell was a stock that many brokerage firms kept recommending, rain or shine. It was viewed as a safe harbor in periods of general market weakness and a growth opportunity when investment skies brightened. But times have changed.

title: MITTERRAND AND RIGHT
description: Since the legislative elections Sunday, President Francois Mitterrand has delighted connoisseurs of French politics with a classic performance of the President's role, played in the grand style reminiscent of Charles de Gaulle.

title: CHRONICLED HUMAN STRUGGLE
description: Bernard Malamud, the novelist and short story writer who won two National Book Awards and the Pulitzer Prize for his chronicles of human struggle, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 71 years old.

title: THE MOUSE MAKES THE GRADE
description: Ken McFadden wanted Paul Nicelli to watch him play in Syracuse last weekend but Nicelli said he couldn't make it upstate. He had to coach a few boys' basketball games around New York, ''and Kenny understands my commitments.''

title: THE WIT AND WISDOM OF THE PROSE OF BERNARD MALAMUD
description: ''The Jewbird''

title: MITSUBISHI INTERNATIONAL APPOINTS A NEW LEADER
description: The Mitsubishi International Corporation, the American subsidiary of the giant Japanese trading company, announced yesterday that Noboru Takahashi had been named president and chief executive. He is currently general manager of the parent company's Osaka branch, Mr. Takahashi succeeds Takeo Kondo. Mr. Kondo, who is 63, will return to Japan as executive vice president of the Mitsubishi Corporation, the parent company.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: THE STAGE: 'QUIET,' AMISH TALE
description: BLACK frock coats and false beards do not disguise the actors of the Circle Repertory Company as they play members of a remote Canadian Amish community in Anne Chislett's ''Quiet in the Land.'' Behind heavy whiskers there is Zane Lasky looking glum and, standing next to him, is Tanya Berezin playing his wife. They and most of the 18 other actors on stage at the Triplex Theater (in Manhattan Community College) seem ill at ease in costume and with their dialogue - a discomfort that is shared by the audience. The play, which opened last night, is as aggravating as a hair shirt.

title: The American Academy Announces '86 Awards
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has announced the recipients of its 1986 art and music awards. Receiving art awards were the painters Pat Adams, Gregory Botts, Lois Dodd and Paul Georges and the sculptor Lowell Reiland.

title: A Long Shadow Is Stalking New York Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: CHASE OFFERS PLAN TO BAR TAKEOVERS
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation has become the first major banking organization to ask shareholders to adopt stiff anti-takeover provisions.

title: Bernard Malamud Dies at 71
description: Bernard Malamud, the novelist and short story writer who won two National Book Awards and the Pulitzer Prize for his chronicles of human struggle, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 71 years old.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After net charges from the consolidation of Lazarus and Shillito Rikes divisional operations and of gold circle and Ridgeway operations, of $23,928,000 for the quarter and $17,298,000 for the year. c-Including net of taxes, equity in gain on sales of shopping center of $27,929,000, or 57 cents a share, for the quarter, and $42,609,000, or 88 cents a share for the year.

title: GERMAN TESTS CONCLUDE ON ADULTERATED WINES
description: An inquiry into the spiking of wines with a chemical used in antifreeze has ended with the finding that 684 foreign wines had been tainted with traces of diethylene glycol.

title: IN DOWNTOWN SAN DIEGO, A FREEWHEELING FANTASY
description: There is a bit of Disneyland inside every shopping mall, struggling to get out. In Horton Plaza in the center of downtown San Diego, the struggle is over: Disneyland has burst through with a vengeance.

title: Topics; Reproduction Copying Manners
description: It's been 25 years since photocopiers entered the office, an anniversary duly noted by Xerox and other manufacturers. What deserves equal note is the elaborate etiquette that has developed around their use.

title: RESEARCH UNIT MARKS 50th YEAR
description: AT a time when advertising, with powerful help from marketing research, is being increasingly recognized as one of the most powerful and important forces on the American business scene, the Advertising Research Foundation is celebrating its 50th anniversary, not by looking back on its accomplishments, but by looking ahead to the future.

title: BIGGER DEDUCTION FOR NON-ITEMIZERS IS PROPOSED
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, is proposing a sharply increased standard deduction for taxpayers who do not itemize deductions and tax brackets lower than those approved by the House of Representatives, according to a document presented to committee members tonight.

title: NATWEST USA CLIMBS BACK
description: Looking more like a meat inspector than the head of a major New York City financial institution, William T. Knowles recently donned a hard hat and long white coat to tour the meat-cutting operations of American Frozen Foods in Stratford, Conn. The 51-year-old chairman and chief executive of the National Westminster Bank USA was giving the company a final once-over before taking it on as a new lending customer.

title: 'BENEFACTORS' A RARE FINANCIAL SUCCESS
description: ''Benefactors,'' the Michael Frayn drama that many Broadway insiders considered too serious and too British for New York, has succeeded where many other recent dramas have failed, recouping its investment in the unusually short period of 11 weeks.

title: TREASURY WILL ALTER PAPER MONEY TO AVERT COPYING-MACHINE THREAT
description: Acting to avert everyday counterfeiting by amateurs using new, advanced office copiers, the Treasury Department today announced the first substantial change in United States paper money since 1929.

title: SHAD STATUS UNDECIDED
description: A senior White House official said today that President Reagan was willing to reappoint John S. R. Shad to a second five-year term as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. The official said that at the moment Mr. Shad was undecided and had expressed his desire to leave the commission for another Administration post. The official, who asked not to be identified, did not say which new position he had requested. Mr. Shad, who would not comment on the official's statements, was appointed by President Reagan and began serving as chairman in May 1981.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Including a gain of $3.4 million on the sale of real estate for the quarter and a charge of $1.5 million related to the company's food service segment, and a gain of $7 million on the sale of real estate and marketable securities for the year. c-Including a charge of $5.9 million related to the company's food service segment and a gain ofn $2.4 million on the sale of real estate and marketable securities. d-Net income.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Boston Red Sox, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 7:30 P.M.) Fencing N.C.A.A. men's championships, at Jadwin Gymnasium, Princeton, N.J., 9 A.M. The saber finals begin at 12:10 P.M., and one of the favorites is Michael Lofton of N.Y.U. The foil and the epee finals follow at 1:05 and 2:40 P.M. Hockey Devils vs.

title: Opposed to Change
description: The United States Olympic Committee, citing the ideal of amateurism, said it opposed an ''Open Olympic Games,'' in which professionals would be allowed to compete in all Olympic events.

title: The Nixon Papers
description: The chairman of the House Subcommittee on Government Information has scheduled hearings next month to explore with the Department of Justice whether a legal opinion issued by the department last month would improperly impede public access to papers and other records of the Nixon Administration. The opinion was issued as the National Archives and Records Administration issued new rules to make the material available.

title: Talk So Big, Do So Nothing
description: I don't know about you folks, but after listening to President Reagan talk about Nicaragua . . . Well, I mean, what's wrong with this country? For that matter, what's wrong with President Reagan?

title: Money for Embassies Voted
description: The House of Representatives voted 389 to 7 today to spend $4.4 billion to enhance the security of embassies abroad and to provide cash payments for Americans taken hostage by terrorists.

title: 6 INDICTED IN LAUNDERING
description: Six people, including a Bank of America investment officer, were indicted today on Federal charges in what the Justice Department called a $36 million money-laundering scheme.

title: On Connecting the West Side Dots
description: Manhattan abhors a vacancy, and its desolated west shore, once the home port of ocean liners, freighters, ferries, barges and excursion boats, offers an emptiness that lures public and private development with magnetic urgency. The problem is transportation. The danger is hasty, badly scaled growth that will obstruct harbor views. The City Planning Commission has an ingenious idea that might answer both needs.

title: ANNOUNCEMENT BY CONTROL DATA
description: The Control Data Corporation prompted renewed speculation that it might sell its Commercial Credit Company unit by announcing that it would hold a news conference in Baltimore today.

title: Avian Rescue, Part I
description: To see a peregrine falcon in this city is thrilling.

title: VIRGIL AKINS
description: Virgil Akins, administrator for the Eleo Pomare Dance Company, died of pneumonia Sunday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SUPPORTERS AT RALLY PREDICT THE PASSAGE OF AN ANTI-BIAS BILL
description: More than 1,000 men and women rallied in front of City Hall last night, predicting jubilantly and defiantly that their 15-year fight for homosexual-rights legislation would end in victory tomorrow when the City Council votes on the latest bill.

title: A Reagan Victory?
description: President Reagan will probably get $100 million more out of Congress for the rebels in Nicaragua, but if he does, it will be a very expensive ''victory.'' He stunned Congress but didn't really persuade it, and now will have to live with its resentments for three long years.

title: LEADERS CHARGE VOTE STEALING IN CHICAGO RACE
description: Mayor Harold Washington and his political rival charged that votes had been stolen at the polls today, as a Cook County judge ordered ballots impounded in three of seven wards in which City Council elections were held.

title: KEY BIG BOARD OFFICIAL IS RESIGNING HIS POST
description: William M. Ellinghaus, former president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, will step down as executive vice chairman of the New York Stock Exchange to pursue personal interests. The resignation will take effect in mid-April.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
TOPS 1,800 BRIEFLY
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average briefly surmounting the 1,800 level for the first time.

title: OFFICERS FACING DRUG CHARGES CALL 11 OTHERS COCAINE USERS
description: Two New York City police officers charged with cocaine trafficking have accused 11 other officers of using cocaine, a top police official said yesterday. As a result of the allegations, 1 of the 11 has been suspended and 2 others have been transferred to new posts.

title: THE SCREEN: 'COURTESANS OF BOMBAY'
description: IT'S a good season for the team of Ismail Merchant, James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala.

title: PULITZER HOLDERS TURN DOWN OFFER
description: Shareholders of the Pulitzer Publishing Company of St. Louis voted to reject a $500 million buyout offer from A. Alfred Taubman, who said he would continue his effort to acquire additional shares in the media company. Mr. Taubman, a Denver entrepreneur, holds an option to acquire 20 percent of the shares of the family-held company. He said he intends to exercise that option.

title: Tale of 2 Awards for an M.V.P.
description: In an open letter to Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, in its April issue, Sport magazine complains that the recognition of its annual World Series most valuable player award has been withdrawn by major league baseball.

title: PIONEERED A METHOD FOR CORNEAL SURGERY
description: Dr. John H. King Jr., a pioneer in corneal transplants who developed a method of preserving eye tissue, died Sunday at Walter Reed Army Hospital here after a stroke. He was 75 years old.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Have you ever heard of a Southern dessert called a mud hen or mud hen cake? A. Yes, but it is not a traditional Southern specialty, rather a relatively recent ''invention.'' The dessert is made with butter, sugar, eggs, flour and pecans, baked in two layers, a butterscotch meringue being the top layer, and when cooked it is cut into squares. The texture resembles nonchocolate brownies. Sometimes mud hens are referred to as butterscotch brownies. Q. Are you familiar with an English dish called pickled oysters? A. Pickled oysters were reportedly quite fashionable once in England. They are rarely prepared today. A recipe appears in that venerable volume, ''Mrs. Beeton's Book of Household Management.'' In her version, 100 oysters are gently cooked in their own liquor. They are then put into jars. The liquor is reserved and added to an equal volume of vinegar along with a blade of mace, a piece of lemon peel and 12 black peppercorns. This mixture cooks five minutes, cools, and is poured over the oysters. The jars are then sealed tightly and stored. Q. I have read of a salad made with something called hartshorn. What is it? A. Hartshorn, a European delicacy, is an edible weed with green leaves vaguely resembling the antlers of a deer. It grows in sandy soil near salt water and must be plucked and eaten while young. Hartshorn is sometimes called star of the earth or buckthorn plantain. Q. Recently I was given a set of attelets.

title: CANADA TO RENEW AIR DEFENSE PACT
description: The United States and Canada announced today that they would extend a mutual air defense agreement for five years.

title: Soviet Lodges a Protest
description: The Soviet Union said today in a protest note that the American naval incursion into its territorial waters ''was of a demonstrative, defiant nature and pursued clearly provocative aims.''

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Including a pretax LIFO credits of $4,396,000 for the quarter and $6,396,000 for the year, and a charge of $2,450,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including pretax LIFO tax credits of $17,947,000 for the quarter and $17,247,000 for the year. The year result also includes income of $62,540,000 from discontinued operations, a pretax charge of $7.1 million for costs associated with an unsolicited tender offer and after-tax gain of $62.5 million on the sale of Waldenbooks.

title: 6 Die in Factional Fights At South African Mine
description: Six miners died in factional fights today at the huge Vaal Reefs gold mine, bringing to 21 the death toll from fighting at South African mines in the last five days, the authorities said.

title: SEARS AND RUNDLE
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that it ''has no interest in supporting'' the proposed sale of its controlling interest in the Universal-Rundle Corporation.

title: IT'S ONE OF THE BETTER BUYS IN A RED
description: IN the old days, vintage dates on Spanish wine were mostly wishful thinking. There is a story about an earnest enophile visiting a bodega in the Rioja in the late 1950's and remarking on the freshness and flavor of a wine from the 1930's. ''Oh, that was the year of my son's birth,'' the wine maker said. ''It was a good year for me, so I've used it ever since.''

title: Driver for U.N. Agency Kidnapped in Beirut
description: A driver for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency was kidnapped in Beirut today, the agency's headquarters in Vienna announced.

title: Put Ordinary Citizens On Corruption Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: TRADE BILL WARNING
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has warned that Congress must tread a narrow path in writing trade legislation this year that will not draw a Presidential veto.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STILL ON THE TRACK When it comes to calling the roll of venerable working musicians, few are more venerable than 73-year-old Lionel Hampton. In some 60 years Mr. Hampton has led a number of orchestras whose personnel included Dizzy Gillespie, Dexter Gordon, Illinois Jacquet and men of similar caliber. Mr. Hampton, basically a swing drummer, was an early exponent of the vibraharp as a jazz instrument. And paralleling his musical career has been his interest in politics. He also helped create in Harlem the housing development that was subsequently named for him.

title: Avian Rescue, Part II
description: To see a white dove in this city is not exactly thrilling.

title: HOME LOAN BANKS OFFERING 3 ISSUES
description: A three-part financing is being offered by the Federal Home Loan Banks through various dealers. The package consists of $1.25 billion of 7.45 percent three-year bonds, $1.515 billion of 7 3/4 percent five-year bonds and $935 million of 8.10 percent 10-year bonds.

title: New York Man Held in Rapes
description: A paroled killer pleaded not guilty today to 26 counts of kidnapping, rape and other felonies involving 15 girls, most of whom were attacked in secured apartment buildings.

title: RESTAURATEUR WITHDRAWS PROPOSAL FOR BRYANT PARK
description: After more than three years of meetings and negotiations, the restaurateur Warner LeRoy has withdrawn his plan to build and operate a $12 million glass-walled restaurant as part of the redevelopment of Bryant Park, a city official said yesterday.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC BID
description: The Danaher Corporation of Florida offered to pay $38 a share for the 4.28 million shares of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company, or about $163 million. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chicago Pneumatic stock rose $2, to $37, in advance of the announcement.

title: USA TODAY PROMOTIONS
description: USA Today, a subsidiary of the Gannett Company, announced yesterday that Thomas Curley, 37 years old, had been promoted to president from vice president and general manager, and Thomas J. Farrell, 41, was promoted to general manager from business manager.Mr. Curley succeeds Lee J. Guittar, who resigned to join the Hearst Corporation.

title: Bridge: Winners of National Event Hadn't Played Long as Pair
description: The result of the open pair championship at the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League here Monday night cast some doubt on the traditional view that partnership experience is essential for tournament success.

title: New Zealand Leader Seeks Better Ties to Paris and U.S.
description: Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand sought to put relations with France and the United States on a less antagonistic footing today, urging better ties with the new Government in Paris and a return to what he called a practical working relationship with Washington.

title: MUSIC: BOULEZ IN 'L'HISTOIRE'
description: PIERRE BOULEZ'S visit with his onetime orchestra took him Sunday afternoon to the Church of the Holy Trinity on East 88th Street, where members of the New York Philharmonic play chamber music in a series entitled ''Philharmonic Ensembles.'' He led the suite from Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat,'' and, under his precise, economical direction, the music snapped like a whip and danced like the very devil (indeed, that's part of the histoire).

title: NOTE CARDS RECALL BARD'S LONDON
BACHE-CLIVE DEAL
description: The Bache Group Inc., parent of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., has agreed to acquire Clive Discount Holdings P.L.C., a London banking firm active in the sterling money markets, for about $18 million, the companies announced. Bache had acquired an interest in Clive last May.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Paltridge Inc., a Princeton, N.J., agency that thinks of itself as a marketing communications company, has just picked up the Lawn Doctor account, which could bill in the neighborhood of $1 million.

title: RENEWED ENTHUSIASM FOR NAVRATILOVA
description: There were no press-room soliloquies, expounding on the burden of being No. 1. There have been no lengthy sabbaticals to escape pressures real or imagined. What may be the most remarkable aspect of Martina Navratilova's four-year reign in women's tennis has been her ability to conceal those times when the last place she wanted to be was on a court, defending her reputation against eager upstarts and top-ranked opponents alike.

title: Moving Backward on Tax Reform
description: Senator Bob Packwood, chairman of the Finance Committee, let it be known last year that he wasn't much interested in tax reform. That's still true, as is plain from the backward plan he has just put forward. It perpetuates loopholes even President Reagan feels pressure to close. It proposes excise tax increases that don't belong here. It curtails deductions for state and local taxes. And over all, it's less fair than the tax reform bill already passed by the House. In short, the Packwood ''reform'' plan cries out for reform.

title: 'ASSASSIN,' A CBS MOVIE ABOUT A KILLER ROBOT
description: ''ASSASSIN,'' the television movie on CBS at 9 o'clock tonight, is poker-faced serious about its action-adventure cavortings, but between the cracks, so to speak, there can be detected what looks suspiciously like a sense of humor. At least, I hope that's what it is. Any other explanation would be sorely disappointing.

title: The Republican Convention
description: President and Mrs. Reagan have both indicated to Republican leaders that, despite reports to the contrary, they do not prefer Los Angeles as a site for the 1988 Republican national convention. As a result, the competition among 11 cities for the honor and profit of playing host to the convention is wide open.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alco Standard Corp., Valley Forge, Pa., a distributor of paper, pharmaceuticals and other products, said Ray B. Mundt, president and chief executive, had been named chairman.

title: FOR CHAD VILLAGERS, ENEMIES ARE SAND AND WAR
description: A quilt of pale yellow sand smothers the land here like an act of cruelty. But sprinkled about, tufts of green in saucered depressions pock the relentless landscape to form wadis, or oases - the only pinpoints of hope that remain in this place.

title: CHILED SEX ABUSE SAID TO RISE
description: Reports of sexual abuse of children increased 59 percent from 1983 to 1984, and most of the children were abused at home by parents, a recent study has reported.

title: WINE TALK
description: A NUMBER of American wine makers are toying with the idea of selling wine futures.

title: ON NEW YORK STAGES, FOOD'S THE THING
description: KEITH REDDIN has to gulp down an entire pitcher of milk, which he hates, without pausing for breath. Andrew Bloch has to devour at top speed a plateful of what he describes glumly as ''cold, glutinous potatoes.'' Penn Jillette has to eat an apple while juggling it and two machetes, a feat that could disrupt anyone's digestion.

title: PENSION BOARD IS TO SELL STOCKS OVER APARTHEID
description: Giving final approval to a policy endorsed 18 months ago, trustees of the city's largest public employee pension fund voted unanimously yesterday to withdraw about $150 million in investments from companies doing business in South Africa.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 19, 1986
description: International President Reagan must persuade at least 10 more representatives to vote for his $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels or face defeat in the House, according to both Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders. Vote counters on Capitol Hill say Mr. Reagan has apparently won over a handful of wavering legislators in recent days. The House is scheduled to vote on the measure tomorrow. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: Artificial Heart Recipient Conscious but Bleeding
description: The latest recipient of an artificial heart regained consciousness today but was bleeding moderately and was in unstable condition on his first full day of life with the decvice.

title: . . . and Midtown Chaos
description: But at the same time, the traffic bureau had to deal with heavy traffic outside the New York Coliseum, the site of the International Beauty Show, and the chaos at Columbus Circle radiated east to Fifth Avenue, north past Lincoln Center and south nearly to Times Square.

title: MAYOR REBUFFS FRIEDMAN DINNER
description: Distancing himself from a Democratic county leader under investigation, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would not attend the annual dinner of the Bronx Democratic organization, which is headed by Stanley M. Friedman.

title: CBS AIDES MEET JACKSON OVER CHICAGO BOYCOTT
description: A group of CBS executives, concerned by a boycott of the network's troubled Chicago station by a minority organization, met yesterday with the Rev. Jesse Jackson to discuss its policy toward minorities.

title: TAKING THE LONG VIEW OF BUILDING A CATHEDRAL
description: ''They aren't finished with this thing yet?'' Verona Montgomery said impatiently, putting her hand to the window and looking in at the stone carvers.

title: OIL SLIDE HURTS BRITISH BUDGET
description: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, told the House of Commons today that there would be a deficit equivalent to $10.22 billion in the previously announced budget of about $203 billion for the fiscal year starting in April.

title: WILL ORTEGA, NOW 1 OF 9, BE UNDISPUTED NO. 1?
description: Fourteen months after assuming the presidency, Daniel Ortega Saavedra appears to be making clear headway in establishing himself as the first among equals among Nicaragua's nine-member governing body.

title: 2 U.S. SHIPS ENTER SOVIET WATERS OFF CRIMEA TO GATHER INTELLIGENCE
description: Two United States warships heavily equipped with electronic sensors entered Soviet territorial waters in the Black Sea last week to test Soviet defenses, Pentagon officials said.

title: WEST POINT-PEPPERELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include revenue and sales of Cluett, Peabody & Co., acquired in January. After deducting after-tax interest costs and goodwill amortization associated with the acquisition, Cluett, Peabody contributed about $3.3 million to net income for the latest quarter.

title: Steroids at Issue
description: The facts of the case are undisputed. On three nights last June, Michael David Williams, a Navy enlisted man with a solid eight-year service record, broke into six Maryland homes, robbed them of jewelry and cash and set fire to three of them.

title: Sheet Metal Workers Now Suffer Reverse Bias
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSFER OF FUNDS TO F.A.A. IS REPORTEDLY SOUGHT
description: The Department of Transportation plans to ask Congress to transfer $115 million in the agency's budget to the Federal Aviation Administration and the Coast Guard to help the two agencies avoid temporarily laying off thousands of workers in the coming months, sources in Congress and the department said today.

title: ...Why Not Try Diplomacy Instead?
description: The United States' choices in Nicaragua are not, as the Administration asserts, between aiding the ''contras'' and seeing the whole region engulfed by Communism. There are alternatives, if we would but grasp them. Among the most promising are the efforts of most Latin American countries to produce a diplomatic solution.

title: BRITISH BAR OUTPUT CURB
description: OPEC ministers made no progress today toward breaking a deadlock over ways to curb oil output to raise prices, amid a clear warning from Britain that it would not take part in any such plan.

title: Ethiopia Asks Transport Aid
description: Ethiopia appealed to Canada today for assistance in moving tons of famine relief food held up at the ports for lack of transport. Taye Gurmu, deputy head of the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, told a Canadian parliamentary delegation that delays in moving food to distribution centers ''could have catastrophic consequences'' for the country's 6.8 million famine-afflicted people.

title: SINGERS' GALA TO HONOR GEORGE LONDON
description: ''This will be the proper tribute to George,'' the soprano Catherine Malfitano said. ''He had such a sad career, and it ended in such frustration. But he cared so passionately for young singers that he turned his adversity into a positive force. And now it's our turn to celebrate his life and achievement.''

title: TURNER'S DEBT PACKAGE TO HELP PAY FOR MERGER
description: To help finance its acquisition of MGM/UA Entertainment, Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. yesterday offered a three-part package of debt securities with a face amount of $1.4 billion through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: ORR FEELS AT HOME WITH IOWA ST.
description: With his Marine Corps-recruit bristle haircut, his ''Oooeee's'' and his cackling chuckle, Johnny Orr enjoys playing the rube. And what more rustic-sounding school could he coach than Iowa State, long the ''other'' basketball team in the Hawkeye State?

title: CALENDAR: CRAFTS, THE S.I. GREENBELT, EARLY AMERICAN DESIGN
description: Designed and Made for Use, Gallery of Parsons School of Design, 2 West 13th Street; 212-741-8900.

title: HALF A TOWN FLEES IN ERROR
description: Water that spilled from a truck Tuesday night was mistakenly believed to be a toxic chemical, and the authorities evacuated half of this town's 3,500 residents. They returned to their homes today after five hours when the mistake was discovered.

title: EX-IM BANK OFFERS FIRST U.S. LOAN
description: The Export-Import Bank, a Government agency that provides credit for foreign buyers of American goods, today for the first time offered a loan to a buyer in the United States to meet what it said was heavily subsidized export financing from a foreign government.

CSS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $4,158,000. c-Including a tax credit of $248,000 and a loss of $570,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Yankee in Silks
description: George Steinbrenner is fooling around with another sport down in Florida this month. And, as in another athletic pastime, involving bats and balls, with which his name has become well known, Steinbrenner is not content to be just another laid-back owner.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including exraordinary credits of $29,000 for the quarter and $1,761,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months result also includes a pretax gain of $5,821,000 on the sale of real estate and investments. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $629,000 for the quarter, $5,433,000 for the 9 months. The 9 months result also includes a pretax gain of $1,714,000 from the sale of real estate and investments. Year-ago 9 months net includes a gain of $6,298,000 from the sale of common stock of Raymark Corp. and the sale of two excess warehouses. This year's 9 months net includes a gain of $3,888,000 from the sale of a surplus building and certain investment securities, the sale and leaseback of a manufacturing facility and a tax benefit.

CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a dispatch on March 13 from Kawaihae, Hawaii, about a debate over growth in that state, misidentified Moanikeala Akaka. She is a woman.

title: BERNARD MALAMUD, AUTHOR, DIES AT 71
description: Bernard Malamud, the novelist and short story writer who won two National Book Awards and the Pulitzer Prize for his chronicles of human struggle, died Tuesday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 71 years old.

title: Congress; Words, Words and More Words on Nicaragua
description: All over Capitol Hill, telephones were ringing with calls from constituents.

title: 'Friendly Fratricide'
description: ''There is strong, strong disagreement on this issue,'' said Michael Kinsley, editor of The New Republic, whom some will recognize as the successor to Richard L. Strout as the writer of the magazine's TRB column. ''But there is no spirit of rancor.''

title: Ballet Theater Season To Open on May 5
description: An all-Tchaikovsky program on May 5 will open American Ballet Theater's nine-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ACTS OF WAR: The Behavior of Men in Battle. By Richard Holmes. Illustrated. 436 pages. Free Press. $19.95.

description: Two more towns were placed under curfew in the Punjab today after renewed clashes between Hindus and Sikhs.

description: A jury took nine minutes to convict a New York woman of illegally selling hot dogs from an outdoor food cart to which she chained herself in protest of unsuccessful efforts to get a permit.
