title: CUOMO SUBMITS BILL TO CREATE 'OPPORTUNITY ZONES' IN STATE
description: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation today to create enterprise zones to revive blighted New York communities.

title: TAX PLAN PARALYZES MUNICIPALS
description: Trading activity in the tax-exempt bond market ground to a virtual standstill yesterday as dealers and issuers reacted with alarm to a proposal in the Senate Finance Committee that would subject interest payments on all municipal bonds to the alternative minimum income tax.

title: WHITE HOUSE LIABILITY PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration today disclosed its proposals for dealing with what it described as a severe crisis in liability insurance.

title: Closing Central Park to Auto Traffic Doesn't Congest Midtown
description: To the Editor:

title: BEATRICE DEBT IS DOWNGRADED
description: The debt rating on about $1.5 billion of outstanding long-term debt securities of the Beatrice Companies and its subsidiaries was downgraded yesterday by Moody's and S.&P.

title: Enough Delay on Immigration
description: With fanfare last month, the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced it had apprehended 131,500 aliens trying to cross our borders in January - a 50 percent increase over the number in January 1985. The message was that illegal immigration, out of control, is getting worse. It points up the necessity of passing an immigration reform bill now in the House.

title: RAVES FOR MOLLOY FRESHMAN
description: Even if the comparisons are unwanted, Kenny Anderson invites them. When the slender freshman at Archbishop Molloy in Queens dribbles lightning-like down the basketball court and flicks up a high-arcing jump shot that seems to have no chance of touching anything but the bottom strands of the net, Johnny Dawkins, the silky Duke guard, comes to mind.

title: YUGO SUES TOYOTA
description: Yugo America, importer of the Yugo automobile, which sells for under $4,000, said it had filed a lawsuit against Toyota for interfering in its dealerships. The suit named Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A., Toyota Motor Distributors and Robert McCurry, senior vice president of Toyota Motor Sales. The suit contended that Toyota had intentionally interfered with Yugo's existing and prospective contractual relationships, adding that two automobile dealers who had signed agreements to sell both cars requested termination of their dealer relationships with Yugo because of threats by Toyota.

title: TOYS 'R' US CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: The latest periods had 13 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year, compared with 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year. Toys 'R' Us said due to price reductions in electronic merchandise during both years, the company had LIFO credits of 3 cents a share in both fiscal years.

title: Blast Kills 7 Turkish Children
description: Children trying to chop up an unexploded mortar shell with an ax detonated it today, killing seven boys, the Hurriyet news agency reported.

title: MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $888,000.

title: Two Women Charged In Slaying of a Couple
description: Two women have been charged with stabbing a man and woman to death in an argument after a party in the couple's Brooklyn apartment last week, the police said yesterday.

title: FINAL FOUR TEAMS ARE NOT CLEAR-CUT
description: After a month of conference tournaments and early-round national tournament games, the wheat has been separated from the chaff, and the search for a new national champion has come down to 16 teams in four well-balanced regions.

title: Marshall Criticizes Court On Death Penalty Issue
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall today accused his colleagues on the Supreme Court of ''a bizarre willingness'' to sacrifice standard procedures to execute convicted murderers.

title: Mrs. Manes's Resume Is Questioned by State
description: An inquiry has cleared Marlene Manes, the widow of Donald R. Manes, of practicing psychology without a license, a state official said yesterday. But he said a question remained over the accuracy of Mrs. Manes's listing of herself as a psychologist on a job resume.

title: U.S. LIBRARY BANISHES 7 PATRONS AFTER SIT-INS
description: The leader and six other members of a group that has staged sit-ins in the main reading room at the Library of Congress to protest early closing hours dictated by budget cuts has been formally barred from entering or using the facilities, the library said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wish I could say today that our action takes acid rain off our bilateral agenda.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: LONDON DEALER INDICTED IN FOILED QUEENS ART THEFT
description: A London antiquities dealer was indicted yesterday on charges of masterminding the attempted theft of his $18.5 million art collection from a United States Customs warehouse in Queens in January.

title: IN MILAN, A LOOK AT HOW WE LIVE
description: Architectural constructions - assemblages of walls, floors and objects - are the punctuation points in a free-ranging survey of the past three centuries of household architecture and home life at the Milan Triennale's ambitious exhibition ''The Domestic Project'' at the Palazzo dell'Arte.

title: NEW HEAD OF CBS UNIT IN CHICAGO
description: CBS appointed Johnathan Rodgers, executive producer of the ''CBS Morning News,'' yesterday as vice president and general manager of its Chicago television station, which has been the object of a boycott by a minority organization.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,959,000 for the quarter and $3,128,000 for the 6 months.

title: STOCK MARKET OPEN IN ISRAEL
description: The Tel Aviv stock exchange re-sumed trading today after a one-day shutdown because of reports that the Israeli Government might impose a tax on stock transactions, and share prices dropped as much as 10 percent, a spokesman said.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a credit of $508,000 for the quarter and year and after non- cash pretax charges of $51 million for the quarter, and $70.2 million for the year. The charges for the quarter and year include writedowns of oil and gas properties, provisions for contingent liabilities, including a charge from writedown of oil and gas properties, provisions for uncollectable accounts receivable and a provision for inventory price decline. c-Net income including a credit of $1,191,000 for the quarter and year from exchange of debt.

title: HOLMES IS PUNCHING TO A MUSICAL BEAT
description: The sign pointing visitors to Club 54 on the lower level of the Konover Hotel says that the little cabaret room is now the ''training headquarters of the heavyweight champion.'' Inside, though, the scene and even the star performer lend the feeling of the room's original purpose, with just another aging entertainer playing for a small crowd on the frayed beachfront circuit.

description: b-The company went public Feb. 4 and did not report figures for year- ago periods.

title: CITY TO SPLIT UP 'CLUSTER' AT BUREAU FOR S.I. FERRY
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it would break up what it described as a ''cluster'' of politically connected officials at the top of the agency that runs the Staten Island Ferry.

title: LIMA PLANS PURGE OF POLICE OFFICERS
description: President Alan Garcia, campaigning to eliminate corruption and reduce the number of police officers in Peru, will force more than 200 high-ranking officers into retirement, according to reports here today.

title: SPORTS ENTHUSIAST LEADS GROUP SEEKING PIRATES
description: Malcolm M. Prine, the chairman of the Ryan Homes Inc., one of the nation's largest home builders, is a sports enthusiast who for 25 years played fast-pitch softball, golf and tennis and refereed college football.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss including a gain of $1.3 million from the sale of a unit and a $6.6 million charge related to the writedown of assets.

title: Bridge: Top 16 Seeds Survive Round In Tourney Knockout Play
description: There were no surprises in the first round of Vanderbilt Knockout Team play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here Tuesday. The top 16 seeds all survived to play today in the round of the 32.

title: PAPER IN MANILA PALACE LISTS $60,000 GIFT FOR MRS. REAGAN
description: A document found in the presidential palace lists a $60,000 emerald necklace that Imelda Marcos, wife of Ferdinand E. Marcos, supposedly gave to Nancy Reagan. [ In Washington, Elaine Crispin, the press spokesman for Mrs. Reagan, said no such gift had been received. She said she had checked with Mrs. Reagan and with the White House gift unit, and had found no record of such a necklace. ] The Philippine palace document, now in the possession of a commission seeking to recover the Marcoses' wealth, does not specify when the gift was made. An accompanying handwritten note to Mrs. Marcos's secretary is dated Aug. 2, 1985.

title: MEESE IN MIDDLE AS POLICE AND RIFLE GROUP FIGHT OVER LEGISLATION
description: Police groups are battling the National Rifle Association over major revisions of the Federal gun control law, and Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has found himself in the middle of the increasingly bitter dispute.

title: FOR THE TABLE
description: SAN MARCO, one of the china patterns by the jewelry designer Angela Cummings, and her Shells flatware are already in the Cooper-Hewitt Museum's collection.

title: STUDY OF OPTION TACTICS CITES DISRUPTIVE EFFECT
description: Professional traders who use stock index options and futures have occasionally dominated the stock market, according to a report, paid for by options exchanges, that raises concern about the fairness to small investors.

title: Calling for New Limestone
description: They have been trampled by thousands of angry citizens who want to fight City Hall, paced by hundreds of political aspirants who want to run City Hall and trod by legions of publicity seekers who want to have their pictures taken in front of City Hall.

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 16
MUSIC: BELLA DAVIDOVICH AND DMITRY SITKOVETSKY
description: MEMBERS of the same family do not necessarily see eye to eye on all matters. I suppose anyone who is a member of a family would agree to that. Nor, if they are musicians, do they necessarily hear ear to ear. So it was anything but certain that last night's recital by Dmitry Sitkovetsky and Bella Davidovich, who are son and mother, would turn out well. Both have acquired splendid reputations as soloists, but the question before the house was how they would fare as a duo.

title: Sumerian Dictionary Sells Out First Printing
description: The first volume of the first modern dictionary of Sumerian, the world's oldest written language but dead for 4,000 years, has sold out in its first printing, four years earlier than expected.

title: G.E. DEBENTURES
description: The General Electric Company yesterday began offering $300 million of 8 5/8 percent sinking fund debentures, due 2016, at a price of par through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The triple-A-rated issue is priced to yield 63-hundredths of a percentage point more than the 30-year Treasury bond and carries a 10-year non-refunding provision. A sinking fund beginning in 1997 to retire 5 percent of the issue annually will give the debentures an average life of 20.5 years.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: FOREIGN OIL, A LUBRICANT OF APARTHEID
description: To some observers, the white minority South African Government looks invincible. The regime has the strongest military force on the continent. Its jets and tanks regularly invade neighboring black states. Inside the country, its police force uses rifles and tanks against unarmed black children. It would seem the racist system of apartheid is here to stay. Yet, these observers overlook an important fact: South Africa has an Achilles' heel.

title: EXTRA-POTENT COCAINE: USE RISING SHARPLY AMONG TEEN-AGERS
description: In dramatically rising numbers in the last five months, teen-agers in New York City and its suburbs have been using ''crack,'' an especially potent and addicting form of cocaine, according to state and local drug officials, educators and experts on drug abuse.

title: 3d U.S. Aircraft Carrier Reported Near Libya
description: A third American carrier entered the Mediterranean Sea today for what President Reagan called ''routine exercises'' that may involve flights over the disputed Gulf of Sidra.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: Year-ago quarter net included a gain of 32 cents a share from the sale of a store.

title: MUSIC: SPECULUM MUSICAE
description: The tag of ''minimalist'' comes with Simon Bainbridge's name in promotional material, but the young British composer's ''Concertante in Moto Perpetuo,'' which won the liveliest audience response Monday at Speculum Musicae's Merkin Concert Hall concert, is about as minimalist as the third-act prelude of ''Lohengrin.'' It is also a well spiced, invigorating and rather seductive piece.

title: JEM RECORDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PRESIDENT AGREES TO ALTER HIS PLAN ON AID TO REBELS
description: President Reagan, faced with likely defeat in the House of Representatives, agreed today to compromise on his proposal on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: NEW MANVILLE PLAN EXPECTED
description: The trade creditors of the Manville Corporation, who object to the company's proposed plan of reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, said yesterday that they would propose an alternate plan.

title: Living Longer? Or Just Dying Slower?
description: Last year the New Jersey Supreme Court gave a thoughtful answer to an agonizing question: When is it time to let the dying go? The court ruled that all life-sustaining medical treatment, including feeding tubes, could be withheld from terminally ill nursing-home patients, both incompetent and competent, who were known to desire no heroic measures to prolong life.

title: PHILIPPINES CUTS FUEL PRICES BY 9%
description: President Corazon C. Aquino ordered a 9 percent cut in fuel prices today in an attempt to support the sagging Philippine economy.

description: b-Net income. c-Including nonrecurring gains of $1,778,000, or $1.16 a share, for the quarter and $4,964,000, or $3.18 a share, for the year. Latest quarter and year share earnings results include a deduction from earnings of $750,000 and $1,500,000, respectively, associated with preferred dividends. Latest year results include the results of Rowe International Inc. effective June 1, 1985.

title: Mendelssohn Quartet To Perform at Merkin
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet will perform the second of two concerts featuring quartets by Haydn, Ives and Schubert, tonight at 8 at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.

title: TIME FOR SPRING PRUNNING OF ROSES
description: SPRING arrives today at 5:03 P.M. Are the pruning shears sharp? It is time to tackle the rosebushes.

title: ISRAELI ENVOY'S WIFE IS KILLED, 3 ARE HURT BY CAIRO GUNMEN
description: Gunmen opened fire on a car carrying two Israeli diplomats and their wives tonight, killing one of the women and wounding the three others.

SEA CONTAINERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter and year results include a $10 million writeoff to cover losses arising from two leases and its unsuccessful bid on the English Channel Expressway Project.

title: POP: PETER, PAUL AND MARY
description: ONE of the remarkable things about Peter, Paul and Mary, who are celebrating their 25th anniversary in show business, is how little their music has changed over the years. The trio has made no concessions to contemporary pop technology. As in the 1960's, they continue to make spare acoustic folk-pop, accompanying themselves on two guitars augmented only by a light acoustic bass.

title: CABARET: 'BALLROOM BRIEFS'
description: ''BALLROOM BRIEFS,'' a new weekly variety show that opened at the Ballroom Theater (28th Street and Eighth Avenue) on Monday evening, describes its mixture of comedy, music and clowning as ''new vaudeville.'' Alas, most of the entertainment offered at Monday's opening night program was a far cry from the cosmically zany fun of Penn & Teller, the Flying Karamazovs and other acts that have been lumped together under the heading.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 20, 1986
description: Markets

title: Shuttle Layoffs Are Seen
description: Up to 700 workers at an aerospace plant here will lose their jobs because of the space shuttle disaster, a company spokesman said today.

title: Officer's Weapon Wounds Partner
description: An undercover police officer was accidentally shot in the back yesterday when a fellow officer's gun discharged as he was getting out of their unmarked car, the police said.

title: 14 FRENCH RIGHTISTS NOW IN DEMAND
description: On Sunday night, Marc Becam, the Mayor of Quimper in Brittany, was elected to the French Parliament as an independent. By Monday morning, he had become an enormously popular fellow.

title: BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
STATE PANEL CUTS REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR MILITARY IN '87
description: Rejecting President Reagan's military and domestic priorities, the Senate Budget Committee today approved a 1987 budget that would give the military $25 billion less than Mr. Reagan proposed and would raise $18.7 billion in new revenue.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,904,000. c-Including income of $139,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GROWTH IN G.N.P. 0.7% IN 4th QUARTER
description: The economy slumped to a sluggish growth rate of seven-tenths of 1 percent from October through December, the Commerce Department reported today in its third downward revision of that quarter's performance.

title: ANDERSON SAYS HE BACKS RISE IN AID TO PROTECT TRANSIT FARE
description: The leader of the State Senate's Republican majority said tonight that he supported an increase in state aid to help prevent a New York City transit fare increase in January 1987.

title: TRANSLATING COMPARABLE PAY INTO MONEY
description: Helen Castrilli, a secretary at Western State Hospital, is looking forward to a $106 raise next month.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Waived Ed Jurek, utility infielder.

title: Farrell vs. Koch (Cont.)
description: Mayor Koch is having Democratic county leader problems. No sooner did he refuse an invitation to a Bronx Democratic dinner because of the investigations of the county chairman, Stanley M. Friedman, than Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratric leader, called for Mr. Koch's resignation because of the investigations of city agencies.

title: MORE AUDITORS TO STUDY TEXAS-AREA THRIFT UNITS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank System is sending 250 additional examiners to Texas and four nearby states to assess the health of savings and loan associations, an official of the Federal Home Loan Bank in Dallas said today.

title: CHILEAN ATTACKS A U.N. PANEL
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet issued a rebuke Tuesday to a United Nations agency for denouncing reported killings and torture by Chile's security police.

description: The ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee urged President Reagan today to withdraw a nominee from consideration for a Federal district judgeship in Alabama.

title: No Place Like Home
description: She has a house in Guildford, England, that she insists is her legal residence, but Zola Budd, the 19-year-old distance runner, has been spending a lot of time in her native South Africa recently, and that, according to some British sports officials, could cost her a place on England's team in the 1986 Commonwealth Games. Miss Budd shrugged off an official warning from the Women's Amateur Athletic Association that her prolonged absences from England might jeopardize her eligibility for the national team.

title: TAX AMNESTY STIRS DOUBTS
description: Tax amnesty probably would not produce the windfall predicted by some of its advocates, according to Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d. Supporters of such a program have estimated it would prompt the payment of as much as $20 billion in back taxes owed to the Government.

title: IMPACT OF COUNCIL ACTION DRAWS DIVERGING VIEWS

The bill's opponents feel it would send an indirect message to society that homosexuality is a legitimate way of life.

title: JAZZ: LAURA TAYLOR CONCERT
description: LAURA TAYLOR, a pianist, singer and songwriter whose trio is currently performing in the Cocktail Terrace of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, gave a concert on Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall that placed her low-key, tightly controlled singing in settings that occasionally developed lively jazz elements.

title: Girl Killed in Beirut Fighting
description: A girl was killed and several people were reported wounded in battles between rival militias across the Green Line dividing the eastern and western sectors of the city today. About 250 militiamen from 10 pro-Syrian groups, meanwhile, took up five positions in West Beirut to help the army and the police keep order and prevent further fighting between the Communists and the Moslem radical Hezbollah faction.

title: METS' EXODUS PUZZLES MANY
description: There's a chill in the air in the Sunshine City, and it was put there by the Mets when they acknowledged that the 1987 spring training season would be their last here.

The latest 9 months results include those of Chaparral Steel Co. from June 1985 and before that time, Texas Industries' results included 50 percent of Chaparral's results.

title: Soviet-Bloc Ministers Meet
description: Foreign ministers of the seven Warsaw Pact countries opened a two-day meeting today at which they were expected to discuss policies on arms control and other international issues. The Warsaw Pact members are the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Bulgaria and Rumania. The pact is the Soviet-bloc counterpart of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: 'ALL IS FORGIVEN,' NEW NBC SITCOM
description: A NEW series called ''All Is Forgiven'' is being given a ''sneak preview'' on NBC this evening at 9:30 o'clock, following an episode of ''Cheers.'' Both shows, as it happens, are Charles/Burrows/Charles Productions made in association with Paramount Television. The executive producers are James Burrows, Glen Charles and Les Charles, all graduates of the series ''Taxi.'' The point is that, given the right scripts and performers, producing talent will out. Charles/Burrows/Charles appears to have come up with another strong contender for sitcom longevity.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Marcos Linen
description: Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos, formerly of Manila, are for the time being guests of the United States, currently in Hawaii. They complain that they're not being treated with honor, much less the dignity they were promised. They're being pilloried in the media and dragged, step by step, into American courts.

title: IMPROVEMENTS IN THE BICYCLE
description: THE pace of bicycle evolution has increased in recent years, thanks largely to the well-publicized and startlingly successful effort to design cycles that would give the United States Olympic team in 1984 an advantage over riders from other countries.

title: Well-Earned Bonus
description: Richard Sandoval, the former World Boxing Association bantamweight champion who was hospitalized after being knocked unconscious by Gaby Canizales in a fight March 10, has gotten something of a consolation prize for his suffering, a $25,000 bonus from Bob Arum and a $500-a-week job as a media consultant to the promoter. Although doctors have cleared Sandoval to return to the ring, a spokesman for Arum said that a condition of the job offer was Sandoval's agreement that he would not fight again. . . . Mike Tyson, the 19-year-old heavyweight who has knocked out 19 opponents in 19 fights, has signed a $1 million, three-fight deal with HBO. The first of the fights will be against Mitch Green at Madison Square Garden May 20.

title: AIR CARGO EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
U.S. AID TO THE CONTRAS: THE RECORD SINCE '81
description: Aid to the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government has been a major point of discussion between President Reagan and Congress since 1982. The Central Intelligence Agency was financing the rebels as early as 1981, covertly channeling money and arms.

title: A SCARCITY OF HARMONY FOR TWO ROLLING STONES
description: MICK JAGGER and Keith Richards, collaborators for more than 20 years as songwriters and record producers for the Rolling Stones, don't seem to be on the same wavelength at the moment. ''The fact of the matter is, Keith and I aren't getting on too well,'' Mr. Jagger said in a recent telephone conversation. With the first Rolling Stones album for Columbia due in the stores on Monday, Mr. Richards has been telling the press he wants the band to tour this year, and thinks, or hopes, that it will. ''I'd love to be out there playing, and of course the money would be great,'' Mr. Jagger admitted. ''But there's no point unless it's going to be fun, and right now things are just too difficult. We are not going to tour this year.'' Tension between the two musicians, who referred to themselves for a time as ''the Glimmer Twins,'' is nothing new, nor is it surprising. But this is the first time any of the Rolling Stones have chosen to air their differences in such plain language and in public. Business-wise, a tour would seem to be the sensible thing to do. The forthcoming ''Dirty Work'' is the Stones' first album for Columbia since the band signed a multimillion-dollar contract with the company last year. The first fruits of that contract, last year's Mick Jagger solo album ''She's the Boss,'' was a success but hardly a blockbuster. And nothing sells records like a heavily publicized tour, which any Rolling Stones outing would be, by definition.

title: Joe Niekro Is Ailing
description: John Montefusco and Don Mattingly seemed recovered from their ailments in their spring debuts for the Yankees tonight, but Joe Niekro, who has a spot secured in the pitching rotation, made an early exit in the fourth inning after feeling a twinge in his left groin.

title: JOY AND DOUBT ON POPE'S PLAN TO VISIT SYNAGOGUE
description: Rome's chief rabbi has praised Pope John Paul II's decision to visit Rome's main synagogue as ''courageous and coherent,'' and the Israeli Foreign Ministry said it hoped the visit might be a prelude to Vatican recognition of Israel.

title: IN CHILE, VELVET GLOVE CANNOT HIDE THE IRON FIST
description: The spotlight falls on an actor named Roberto Parada, and he is trembling with emotion.

title: SANDINISTAS ARE OFTEN TOUGH, BUT THE POLITICAL DEBATE IS LIVELY IN NICARAGUA
description: An unexpected guest made his first full-length appearance on Sandinista television Tuesday night, much to the astonishment of many viewers.

title: MIAMI BEACH ART DECO: RESTORING A FLAMBOYANT 1935 HOUSE
description: EVER since 1949, when she stepped from her silver Jaguar and squinted through a monocle to size up the elderly male physicians lined up to greet her, the young woman taking over as chief of surgery at a sedate Boston hospital, Dr. Annella Brown has made a point of doing things her way.

title: MINERALS CONCERN
description: The International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation, the world's largest private producer of phosphate rock and potash, said it had approved an anti-takeover plan involving a rights distribution.

title: Chess Championship Opens July 28 in London
description: The world chess championship rematch between the defending champion, Gary Kasparov, and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, will begin July 28 in London, Tass, the Soviet Government press agency, said today.

title: Market Place; TAKEOVER TALK IN HEALTH FIELD
description: WHEN American Medical International Inc. announced a major write-off last week, conventional wisdom was that the price of its stock would suffer. But that did not happen. In fact, shares of A.M.I., one of the nation's largest hospital companies, have been rising steadily over the last few days as takeover conjecture overpowers the bad earnings news.

title: 11-POINT ATTACK PROPOSED ON BUILDING CORRUPTION
description: After a four-year inquiry, the New York State Commission of Investigation will recommend 11 steps today to attack what it characterizes as the ''deeply rooted'' problems of labor racketeering, bid-rigging and governmental mismanagement in public construction programs.

title: 2 WOMEN 'DRIVEN' TO PUBLISH
description: A PAIR of young women, both under 30, are planning to start a publishing empire with a giveaway magazine and survival guide for city parents that makes its bow April 1. Experience? One of them was an editor of her high school paper, whose name she can't remember, and worked briefly in the business press.

description: European Space Agency officials said a computer malfunction aborted today's planned launching of the unmanned Ariane III rocket, which was to have sent United States and Brazilian telecommunications satellites into orbit.

title: Berenyi Not Convinced
description: In the season of hope for baseball players, Bruce Berenyi is wracked with doubt. He pitched three innings for the Mets in an exhibition game against the Boston Red Sox today, and should have been overcome with joy.

But they never had a President and a Prime Minister from opposing parties doomed by the voters to try to govern together, and simultaneously driven by self-interest to try to outmaneuver each other.

title: KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MISS FERGUSON PLANS BRIDAL FOR SUMMER, PALACE SAYS
description: Cynics regard it as pure soap opera. In the popular press, it is always a ''fairy tale.'' But whether the descriptive language is mawkish or a shade satiric, when a member of the Windsor family in direct line to the throne teeters on the brink of matrimony, the British love of ritual and ceremony is thoroughly indulged. Prince Andrew, the second son and third child of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh, is fourth in line to the throne at the moment and therefore highly unlikely ever to be king. But a royal event is a royal event, and Buckingham Palace's announcement today that he is going to wed Sarah Ferguson, the daughter of a former cavalry major who happens to be Prince Charles's polo manager, was preceded by a ritual brouhaha in the Fleet Street press. This led to ritual refusals to comment by the palace, her father and the young woman herself until, finally, ending the suspense became the business of highest priority in Britain.

title: The U.N. Today: March 20, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10 A.M and 3 P.M.

title: MOST DEPEND ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: THE average monthly Social Security benefit for retired women is $379.60, compared with $495 for men, according to the most recent Social Security Administration statistics. Sixty percent of women age 65 and older rely solely on Social Security for income, according to the American Association of Retired Persons.

title: STUDY FINDS OLIVE OIL EASES CHOLESTEROL

After being hired as a Milwaukee Bucks assistant for the 1976-77 season, several months after the end of his playing career, Nelson was thrust into the head coaching job only 18 games into the season when Larry Costello was forced to resign.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: THE musical highlight of the Y Chamber Symphony's Monday night concert at Carnegie Hall was a limpid reading of the opening Sextet from Richard Strauss's ''Capriccio'' in an orchestral transcription. The serenity of this music, crafted by the septuagenarian Strauss during some of the darkest hours of World War II, is profoundly moving; it seems removed from the cares of the world.

title: HERS
description: THE most compelling question of my girlhood was whether nuns had hair. Occasionally, when we were taken by Mother Therese to the yard beside the school, as we eddied about her long black legless skirts in our duffel coats and saddle shoes, a strong wind would lift the heavy black serge of her veil, and one of us - that day's celebrity - would glimpse a strand or two at the nape of her neck. For days we would conjecture whether it was merely the popular pixie cut under there, or whether her entire scalp had been shaved and what we had seen was just an oversight. A few girls of a Jesuitical turn of mind suggested that perhaps she had hair just like ours and that it was braided or pinned up. No one ever took them very seriously.

title: SAVIN CREATES A NEW OFFICE
description: The Savin Corporation, a marketer of office copying machines that has had losses in the last two years, said yesterday that it was forming an office of the chief executive consisting of three top executives. The new office will include

He performed two works, Haydn's Cello Concerto in C and Tchaikovsky's arrangement for cello and string orchestra of the Andante Cantabile from his String Quartet No. 1.

The United States delegation is expected to focus on an accord restraining most types of textile and clothing exports. The accord expires at the end of 1987 but some industry officials believe that American negotiators may press for further curbs.

title: On the Bud Watch
description: After having already said that the National Park Service's cherry trees were displaying buds that are ''well developed and turgid,'' the service's chief scientist and blossom watcher, Dr. William Anderson, now, on this, the first day of spring, is making the more or less firm prediction that the trees will burst into flower the first week in April, just in time for the Cherry Blossom Festival, set for April 6-12.

title: WESTLAND IN COPTER DEAL

description: Radicals in cowboy boots, refugees from Morningside Heights in the 50's, overage hippies with granny glasses, pin-striped young executives and even youths in punk hairdos and wearing earrings shared popcorn and beer and opinions Tuesday night in the atmosphere of a 70's political convention.

title: MONEY FUND, C.D. YIELDS FALL
description: Average yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds continued to slide in the week ended yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Before installing new carpet in our bedroom we want to do something about the squeaks in the floor. A carpenter says second-floor squeaks are very difficult to cure because the second floor does not have the same support as the first. He won't guarantee success. Is this true? If so, will installing carpet help? A.Squeaks on the second floor are sometimes harder to cure, but not because the supports are any different. On the ground floor you can normally get at the flooring from underneath if necessary; the second floor has a finished ceiling under it.

title: TCBY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Making Bad Things Even Worse
description: Over the years, Americans have made good-natured allowance for President Reagan's fondness for whoppers. Flustered White House aides routinely amend some of his fanciful statistics and unverifiable anecdotes. But the argument over Nicaragua, and a commitment to support war against it, has gotten ugly enough to require a stricter standard. Mr. Reagan in his zeal has heaped catsup and snake oil into the dish of disputation. This time he has evoked corrections even from the Government of Brazil, an eminent New York rabbi and his own drug enforcement agency - surely a record for a single speech.

description: The ultimate example of how badly things have been going this season for the Devils occurred tonight in their game against the Penguins.

title: A DUTCHMAN'S QUEST FOR A BLACK TULIP
description: A black tulip, flowering at midnight, sounds like something from an old Dutch fairy tale. But it happened in the tiny village (pop. 300) of Oude Niedorp, a one-windmill town about 35 miles northwest of Amsterdam. And after a month of newspaper and television interviews, Geert Hageman, the 29-year-old horticulturist who developed the new black tulip, is still euphoric about this somber variety of his national flower.

title: N.F.L. PLAYERS PROPOSE TESTS

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FIRE AND FASHION The Fashion Institute of Technology, which puts as much style in its exhibitions as it does in generating fashions, has two dramatically different shows on view.

title: PIERRE PHILIPPE IS DEAD AT 71
description: Pierre Philippe, founder and chairman of the Philippe Foundation, a New York-based organization that provides exchange grants to doctors and scientists in the United States and France, died of heart disease Sunday at his home in Paris. He was 71 years old.

title: CHIEF EDITOR QUITS AT BOSTON GLOBE
description: After months of rumors of unhappiness and disputes in the newsroom of The Boston Globe, the editor, Michael C. Janeway, announced yesterday that he was resigning, effective immediately.

title: Riggins's Next Move
description: In his 14 professional seasons, John Riggins, the workhorse Redskins' running back, has courted the reputation of being something of a maverick in the National Football League. Now with his future as a professional in doubt because of back and hip problems, the 36-year-old Riggins announced late Tuesday after a meeting with Coach Joe Gibbs, that he had been released by Washington.

title: Text of the Amendment
description: Following is the proposed amendment to the administrative code regarding homosexual rights:

title: DOW DOWN BY 1.92 IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices fell slightly in subdued trading yesterday. Investors remained nervous about the economy, the oil situation and the expiration of stock index futures and options later this week.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $192,962 and an extraordinary gain of $584,271 from a pension plan reversion. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $170,754 for the quarter and $39,870 for the year. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $593,431, a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $977,049, an extraordinary gain of $584,271, and a gain of $1,670,717 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. title: OLD WALDHEIM FILE IS FOUND
description: The Austrian Foreign Ministry says it has found a missing personal file of Kurt Waldheim in an abandoned safe.

title: College President Appointed New Director of 92d Street Y
description: Ira Silverman, president of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College of Philadelphia, has been appointed executive director of the 92d Street Y. The 41-year-old Mr. Silverman replaces Dr. Robert Fisher, former president of John F. Kennedy University in San Francisco, who left in July 1985 to return to California. Mr. Silverman will assume his new post July 1.

title: BIAS IN NICARAGUA REPORTED BY JEWS
description: The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted yesterday that President Reagan was correct when he accused the Nicaraguan Government of persecuting Jews in Nicaragua.

title: LLOYD DEFEATS POTTER, 6-2, 6-4
description: Perhaps the most disheartening aspect of playing against Chris Evert Lloyd is that an opponent often leaves the court feeling she could have won. Only the scores are a sobering reminder of how one-sided Mrs. Lloyd's victories tend to be. Barbara Potter had that feeling last night after she faced Mrs. Lloyd in an opening round match of the Virginia Slims championships at Madison Square Garden. ''Would have, could have and should have'' was the theme of Miss Potter's concession speech after the 6-2, 6-4 defeat.

title: SHIP RETURNS TO PORT WITH PARTS OF CHALLENGER'S BOOSTER ROCKETS
description: A salvage ship returned to port tonight carrying three sections of broken casing from the space shuttle Challenger's booster rockets. The wreckage included a 10-by-14-foot piece retrieved from the ocean floor earlier in the day.

title: Top-Seeded 4 Have the Edge
description: If a trend that began in the National Collegiate basketball tournament in 1981 continues, two of the four teams that were top-seeded in the tournament's four regions will reach the Final Four and one of them will become the national champion.

title: LOAN FOR WHEELING
description: The financially troubled Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation has gotten approval from a Federal bankruptcy judge for a $60.7 million loan needed to help it ride out a lull in revenues, a company spokesman said today.

BUYING A THERMOMETER
description: THERMOMETERS are available in many designs. Some are miniature weather stations that give not only temperature readings in Fahrenheit and Celsius, but the wind-chill factor, the amount of fallen rain, the wind direction and the barometric pressure.

description: Two officials of the Federal Reserve System today challenged the accuracy of the Labor Department's most recent report on unemployment, contending that the Government had provided some dubious data and questionable explanations of it.

description: Fourteen college students, including Amy Carter, a freshman at Brown University, were arrested today in an anti-apartheid protest at a local office of the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: BURROUGHS SEES 'POOR' 1st QUARTER

W. Michael Blumenthal, the company's chairman and chief executive, said net income would be down ''not insignificantly'' from the first quarter of 1985, a company spokesman said.

title: CHOOSING FRAMES TO SUIT POSTERS
description: WHEN it comes to selecting a frame for a poster, the process can be as perplexing as choosing the poster itself. Frames are as varied as the posters themselves. This is especially true in the case of contemporary posters, those which may not appreciate in value and are purchased mainly for decorative purposes. While more valuable posters require specific, archival care, there are no set rules for framing less-expensive, mass-produced works.

title: Hanoi Condemns Plan By Cambodian Rebels
description: Vietnam today condemned a peace proposal from a rebel coalition fighting Hanoi-backed forces in Cambodia as ''unjust'' and ''hostile,'' but stopped short of rejecting it.

description: A state appeals court yesterday ordered the city's Fire Department to give a competitive Civil Service examination, within 60 days, for the department's No. 2 job, which has been filled by appointment for eight years.

description: The Gulf Canada Corporation, recently revamped under the control of the Reichmann family of Toronto, is offering to buy as much as 38 percent of the outstanding voting shares of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. - a deal that could be worth as much as $832 million (Canadian).

description: Robert R. Mullen, who was a campaign press secretary for Dwight D. Eisenhower in the 1952 Presidential campaign and later worked in the unsuccessful effort to win the 1964 Republican nomination for Henry Cabot Lodge, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Frederick, Md. He was 77 years old.

description: Two followers of the far-right conservative Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., both political unknowns, won election upsets in the Illinois Democratic primary Tuesday. Their victories created chaos in the campaign of the party's gubernatorial nominee, former Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d.

title: Strength in Serenity
description: Justice Hugo L. Black of the Supreme Court was speaking, 25 years ago, to law students at Harvard. Some of them were from Alabama, his home state, and he said he hoped they would go back. Alabama is ''a good place,'' he said, ''even though you'll find there, as in every state of the Union, men and women who are not tolerant, who are not gentle and kind.''

title: No Headline
description: The number of foreclosure proceedings on homes fell during the final three months of 1985, but the number of late payments rose slightly, the National Association of Mortgage Bankers reported today.

description: A senior aide to Yasir Arafat said this week that thousands of guerrillas who left Lebanon three and a half years ago under pressure from Israeli invaders had returned.

title: UNOCAL SEEKS NEW STOCK
description: The Unocal Corporation, which last year defeated a hostile bid by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said today that it would ask shareholders to approve the issuance of 100 million new preferred shares to be used as a possible anti-takeover defense. The company said it had no current plans to use the new preferred stock to fend off unwanted suitors but added that the new shares could ''render more difficult the accomplishment of mergers or other business combinations.''

description: What threatens the decent folk of Holly Hill, Fla.? According to their police chief, J.P. Finn, a ''bureaucratic nightmare'' that menaces ''honest gun owners'' with ''prosecution for clerical error.'' Chief Finn stars in a National Rifle Association advertising campaign designed to persuade Congress to disable the 1968 Gun Control Law.

description: Six months ago, a takeover bid from Citicorp would not have surprised Milton E. Mohr, the chairman and chief executive of Quotron Systems Inc.

title: CLOROX ELECTS CHAIRMAN
description: The Clorox Company, based in Oakland, Calif., said today that Charles R. Weaver, 57 years old, had been elected chairman, effective April 1, and would continue as chief executive officer. John W. Collins, 55, will succeed Mr. Weaver as president and continue as chief operating officer. The company said Calvin S. Hatch, 65, would retire as chairman, a position he has held since 1982, and would continue as a director. Mr. Hatch served as Clorox's chief executive officer from 1981 until October 1985. Mr. Weaver, who was elected president and chief executive officer last October, has been with Clorox for 22 years.

title: 'NO POLICY' OF SUGGESTING LAW FIRMS, CUOMO SAYS

Something was wrong in the building, and the landlord made payoffs. I don't want to take it any further. It wouldn't serve nothing but trouble for me.''

title: CALVIN KLEIN AD PLEASES MS. MAGAZINE
description: There is a great difference between a sexist ad and a sensual ad, and the April issue of Ms. magazine, which quickly turns away the former, has accepted with pleasure what it considers to be the latter.

title: CAN THE CUBS RECUPERATE?
description: In all the assessments of the National League East, it's as if the Cubs suddenly don't exist anymore. The Mets talk about the Cardinals, and the Cardinals talk about the Mets. Nobody talks about the Cubs, who finished fourth last season. But the year before, the Cubs stirred Chicago with a divisional title. And in early June last year the Cubs had baseball's best record until five starting pitchers were on the disabled list - by August all five together.

title: DOCUMENTARY ON WOMEN IN SPORTS
description: EQUALITY under the hoop, on the gridiron and around the diamond - that's the theme of a half-hour ''Currents'' documentary called ''Settling the Score,'' tonight at 8:30 on WNET/ Channel 13. Much of its information should come as news to those who watch sports on television. The women on the program maintain that the stations and networks, major purveyors of the fame that leads to fortune, neglect serious female athletes. And it's true enough that, as John Dryden once put it in the quill-pen days, ''these athletic brutes whom undeservedly we call heroes'' (he meant, of course, the big boys in knickers who earn more than poets) do get a great deal of attention.

title: THEATER: JOHN GUARE'S 'HOUSE OF BLUE LEAVES'
description: RETURNING to ''The House of Blue Leaves'' 15 years after its Off Broadway premiere, one expects to find a musty, archetypal artifact of late 1960's black comedy. Set in Sunnyside, Queens, on that 1965 day when Pope Paul VI visited New York, John Guare's early, breakthrough play features mockingly observed nuns, a lethal (but farcical) political bombing, a G.I. earmarked for Vietnam and, as a protagonist, a zoo keeper who dreams in vain of making it big in Hollywood as a songwriter. As if that weren't enough countercultural loopiness, the zoo keeper, Artie Shaughnessy, has a wife named Bananas who really is bananas. In the period's R. D. Laing-Ken Kesey tradition, Bananas, a schizophrenic destined for a cuckoo's nest (the house of Mr. Guare's title), is the sanest character in the work.

title: Kenya Makes Museum Of Dinesen's Home
description: Kenya has converted into a museum the Nairobi house of Baroness Karen Blixen, the Danish author who wrote under the name Isak Dinesen and whose life in Kenya at the beginning of the century is depicted in the book and movie ''Out of Africa.''

title: GRAF BEATS SHRIVER TO GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: Sometimes, the closer one comes to victory, the more elusive it appears to be. Pam Shriver can understand that paradox after her match against Steffi Graf last night. Miss Shriver was just 2 points away from advancing to the semifinals of the Virginia Slims tennis championships, perhaps just two swings away, given the manner in which she had overpowered Miss Graf with serves the West German teen-ager still hasn't seen.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: The Judds, Radio City Music Hall, 1260 Avenue of the Americas (751-3100). Naomi and Wynonna Judd, the mother-daughter vocal duo who have risen to the top of the country music field in just two years, belong to a time-honored rural tradition of close family harmonizing. The Judds hail from the same region of northwestern Kentucky that produced Ricky Skaggs, the country star whose music, like theirs, contains strong old-timey and bluegrass elements. But the seven years that the duo spent in Los Angeles is also reflected in a polish that echoes the influences of singers like Bonnie Raitt and Emmylou Harris. The Judds are opening for the far slicker and more conventional Oak Ridge Boys, who crossed over from gospel to country-rock music in 1975. Performances are tonight and tomorrow at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $22.50 and $20.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday BLUES FOR DEM BUMS Koko Taylor and the James Cotton Blues Band kick off a new blues series at the Arts at St. Ann's in Brooklyn this weekend. Called ''Dodger Blues'' in memory of the Brooklyn Dodgers, the series will continue until May. Tonight's performance features Koko Taylor and her Blues Machine, with James Cotton scheduled for tomorrow night. Both performances begin at 8 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: (718) 834-8794. title: BLUEFIELD SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,289,988 from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $23,097 from discontinued operations.

title: GCA CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $52 million from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: Allen Ginsberg to Teach At Brooklyn College
description: The poet Allen Ginsberg has been appointed to teach in the poetry division of the master of fine arts program in creative writing at Brooklyn College of the City University of New York for the 1986-87 adademic year.

title: Reagan Won't Address Harvard's 350-Year Fete
description: President Reagan will not address Harvard University's 350th anniversary celebration in September because of a heavy fall schedule, the university announced today.

title: SLOW GROWTH STIRS CONCERN
description: THE American economy is looking a lot weaker than most economists had expected.

title: Obstacles to a Soviet Role in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: GABO AT THE GUGGENHEIM VISIONS OF A UTOPIAN
description: WHETHER they helped precipitate modernism or were its justification, ''Art for Art's Sake'' and its descendant, formalism, proved liberating philosophies. Yet the distortions they have caused may ultimately make the 20th century seem like a dark age, especially where the history of abstraction is concerned. As the critic Hilton Kramer observed some 15 years ago, there's much to be said for taking a work of art at its face value, divorced from the convictions and foibles of its maker. But to do this with the achievements of the pioneer abstractionists is to ignore the probability that some were based on ''silly'' ideas or that the ''historic leap'' could have been made at all without some such support, silly or not.

title: 'Yes' for an Answer
description: Has the Reagan Administration been unwilling ''to take 'yes' for an answer'' in its arms control exchanges with the Soviet Union? A former American negotiator, Paul Warnke, thinks so and charges that as a result the Administration may be missing an ''opportunity to make very major steps toward minimizing the nuclear risks.''

title: ORTEGA EXPECTS MORE U.S. HOSTILITY
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said tonight that he expected continued hostility from the United States despite today's House vote rejecting renewed aid to anti-Government rebels.

title: ART PEOPLE
description: IN a Quonset hut studio in upstate New York, Bob Schuler has spent the last five years sculpting and painting a series of granite blocks. The blocks, about a foot and a half square, are carved and painted with images, phrases and thoughts that make up an autobiography-fantasy.

title: Of Politics and All-Terrain Vehicles
description: These days, as Stuart M. Statler sees things, being a good Republican means clicking your heels and subscribing to a party line that expresses a right-wing ideology.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Howell Corp., Houston, a petroleum refining company, appointed Robert H. Nunnallee vice president of land at Howell Petroleum Corp., the company's oil and gas exploration and production unit.

title: LEVOLOR PUTS STRESS ON FASHION
description: BECAUSE window blinds as furniture have a moderate amount of permanence in one's residence (good for you, not so hot for the manufacturer), wouldn't it be smart to convert them into a fashion accessory, since fashion is fleeting?

title: TURKEY PRESSING FOR MORE ARMS AID
description: State Department officials said today that they hoped to insure American base rights in Turkey with an exchange of letters committing the Administration to seeking as much military aid for Turkey as possible.

title: CYCLING SEASON BRINGS JOY, AND SALES, TO HUFFY
description: Today is one of Richard L. Molen's favorite days.

title: DEFYING LEADERS, HOUSE PASSES DEFICIT REDUCTION
description: Over the objections of the Democratic leadership, the House of Representatives this evening approved a bill to reduce the Federal budget deficit by $18 billion over three years.

title: Spoof From Harvard
description: The Hasty Pudding Theatricals of Harvard University, now in its 138th season, will bring its musical comedy ''Between the Sheiks'' to New York City this weekend for three performances at the Norman Thomas High School, 33d Street and Park Avenue.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: 'WALL TO WALL AMERICAN SONG,'' the free Symphony Space musical marathon that begins tomorrow at 11 A.M., poses a question that has intrigued critics and scholars for decades: What is ''American'' music?

title: Nuclear Power, to Save the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: BROADWAY
description: THE news this morning may boggle some minds. George C. Scott is going to play Huckleberry Finn. As if that weren't enough, John Cullum will be Tom Sawyer. There is no part for Becky Thatcher. Now, Mr. Scott may be known as one of America's most dazzlingly versatile actors, filling out unforgettable roles from General Patton to Willy Loman, but enough already - this 58-year-old is not about to get up behind the footlights in knickers. And although some actors would do anything for a Tony, of which Mr. Cullum, also in his 50's, has won two - for ''On the Twentieth Century'' and ''Shenandoah'' - that's not it either.

title: It Was Cuomo's Turn
description: Several weeks ago at a Conservative Party dinner in New York City, Vice President Bush used a sledgehammer to criticize Governor Cuomo, accusing him of inciting bigotry and coddling criminals. The criticism boomeranged, with even a conservative columnist questioning Mr. Bush's judgment.

title: SCREEN: 'BETWEEN FRIENDS'
description: THOUGH they seem to have little in common, Holly Davis and Sandy Dunlap become instant best friends.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AT first glance, a scene playing on a videotape in Christie's New York showroom seems as though it were taken from a Jules Verne adventure story: Capt. Michael Hatcher, a salvage expert, and his crew are shown diving leagues and leagues under the sea to find treasures from a European merchant ship wrecked in the South China Sea around 1750. Their bounty - more than 100,000 pieces of Chinese export porcelain as well as Western metalwork, stoneware and gold.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST
WICKES PICKS UP PACE OF ITS CHANGES
description: The Wickes Companies, as part of a major redirection of strategy, said today it would sell most of its general retailing stores and also raise at least $500 million in debt to finance acquisitions. ''We're changing the nature and direction of our business,'' said Sanford C. Sigoloff, the chairman and chief executive of the Santa Monica-based concern.

title: SECOND WITNESS AGAINST GOTTI DROPS FROM SIGHT
description: Two months after the disappearance of a man scheduled to testify against John Gotti, the reputed organized-crime leader, the chief witness in a second case against Mr. Gotti failed to show up in court yesterday. Detectives said they believed he was hiding in fear. The detectives, who asked not to be identified, said they thought the man, Romual Piecyk, a 37-year-old mechanic, had not been harmed, but was afraid to testify ''because of who the defendant is.''

title: VOLCKER'S POWER EBBING, SOME ECONOMISTS SAY
description: In the wake of revelations of dissent among the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board over the recent cut in the discount rate, some economists say the board's imposing chairman, Paul A. Volcker, has lost authority to others on his board, and through them, to the White House.

title: BOSSY SCORES 3 IN 7-1 VICTORY
description: Tonight's game did not have the built-in ferocity of a divisional match, but had a multitude of practical usages for the playoff-bound Islanders. They used it to flex their power play, which connected on four of five attempts, and their penalty-killing, which halted the opponent six times. Mike Bossy used it to exercise his wrists with his 37th career hat trick, and Greg Gilbert used it to score his first goal in 22 games.

title: RATES TO BE CUT AT WELFARE HOTEL
description: The city will reduce by more than a third the rates it pays to the Holland Hotel, which earns a profit of nearly 50 percent for housing homeless families, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: PENNZOIL READY TO SEE TEXACO
description: The Pennzoil Company chairman, J. Hugh Liedtke, agreed yesterday to meet with the Texaco Inc. chairman, John K. McKinley, to discuss a settlement of their dispute, according to a Pennzoil lawyer.

title: On the Block
description: The Denver Gold, which will merge with the Jacksonville Bulls and play in Florida as the United States Football League moves to an autumn schedule, is now only a memory in the Mile High City.

title: STUDY SUGGESTS IRT EXTENSION TO NEW JERSEY
description: New York City's IRT Flushing line should be extended beneath the Hudson River to New Jersey to help meet the region's growing transit needs by the year 2000, according to a private study released yesterday.

title: OIL COMPANIES' OUTLOOK NOW
description: IN the last week the Exxon Corporation, the Chevron Corporation and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation all substantially reduced their planned capital and exploration budgets.

title: U.S. Condemns Iraq, Charges Use of Chemical Arms in War
description: The United States strongly condemned Iraq today for what Washington says is Baghdad's use of chemical weapons in its six-year-old war with Iran, saying it marked a ''serious violation of international law.''

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest year net includes unremitted earnings from Du Pont of $75,694,000, down from $141,352,000 in the prior year. Latest year net also includes after-tax dividends of $150,838,000, compared to $141,294,000 in the prior year. Seagram attributed the decline in its latest year's net to one-time charges against spirits and wine operations and reduced earnings of Du Pont, in which it holds a 22.5 percent interest.

title: SLAP FROM ENVOY'S WIFE
description: Sondra Gotlieb, the wife of the Canadian Ambassador, and one of the best known members of the diplomatic community here, was reported today to have slapped her social secretary in the face in public on Wednesday night.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $6,572,000 for the quarter and $12,572,000 for the year and extraordinary gains of $7,587,000 for the quarter and $35,482,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $12,246,000 for the quarter and $16,090,000 for the year and extraordinary gains of $271,836,000 and $279,522,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Abortion's Non-option
description: To the Editor:

title: SHIFT AT BLACK & DECKER
description: The Black & Decker Corporation announced yesterday that Nolan D. Archibald, president and chief operating officer, had been named chief executive officer.

title: NAVY AND NASA TO ADD 2 SHIPS AND SUBMERSIBLE TO SHUTTLE SEARCH
description: The space agency and the Navy have decided to add two more surface ships and one more manned submersible vehicle to step up the search for wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: CLAIM ON MARCOS IS FILED IN TEXAS
description: Attorneys for the Philippine Government today sued Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos and numerous associates for $1.5 billion, charging they had converted millions of dollars in stolen money into Texas real estate Among the properties are prime beach front acreage and a hotel in Corpus Christi.

title: DELAY IS EXPECTED IN RESEARCH CUTS
description: The Reagan Administration today agreed to a three-month delay in a plan to cut Federal funds for research at the nation's universities. The Administration also agreed to consult with universities about the best way to reduce their administrative costs related to federally financed research projects.

title: PERSONAL INCOME ROSE STRONG 0.6% IN FEBRUARY
description: Americans' personal income rose a healthy six-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government said today.

title: OPERA: 'THE ENGLISH CAT,' BY HENZE
description: HANS WERNER HENZE'S ''English Cat,'' which received its New York premiere at the Manhattan School of Music Wednesday night, would have made a fine one-acter, but it has burst its bounds. Despite the charm of its premise and the many excellences of its score, ''The English Cat'' overstays its welcome, like a ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch drawn out to Shakespearean length.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about a joint venture of William Douglas McAdams and the International Medical Tribune Group misidentified the venture. It is Medical Projects International.

title: STANWOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE CITY SINGS OUT TO EASTER AND SPRING
description: YESTERDAY was the first day of spring, the day of the vernal equinox, and by a centuries-old agreement among Christians in the West, Easter falls on the first Sunday following the full moon that comes after the vernal equinox - March 30 this year.

title: Russian Girl, 11, to Start Peace Tour in Chicago
description: A Russian girl making a two-week peace tour of the United States is scheduled to start the tour here Friday with a hotel breakfast, a school visit and a chat with Mayor Harold Washington.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Thomas H. Gow and David W. Henke, creative directors at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, have been promoted to senior vice president.

title: FILING BY JACOBS
description: Investors led by Irwin L. Jacobs of Minneapolis said they ''have determined not to support'' the offer by Mesa Petroleum to acquire the Pioneer Corporation.

title: Some Telephone Lines Damaged at The Times
description: Some telephone service at The New York Times was interrupted yesterday, with brief disruptions in the classified advertising department, according to a Times spokesman, Leonard R. Harris.

title: YANKS TO GIVE YOUNG PITCHERS A CHANCE
description: The manager says he is optimistic, that it is much too soon to panic just because a starting pitcher has begun taking tests to determine the extent of a chronic hip condition. But even though he will not fully admit it, Lou Piniella is preparing for the worst.

title: 7 Are Killed and 21 Hurt In Fighting in Beirut
description: A second day of fierce fighting erupted today between Lebanon's rival Moslem and Christian factions in Beirut and the eastern mountains, and the police said 7 people were killed and 21 wounded.

title: EX-AID CITES 'OBLIGATION' TO BLOCK NOMINEE
description: The former deputy to a nominee for a Federal judgeship told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that it should not approve the nomination.

title: CHARLES GNYS
description: Charles Gnys, a former Broadway company manager and managing director of the Playwrights Unit, an experimental theater group that introduced new writers in the 1960's and early 1970's, died of cancer on March 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 51 years old.

title: Shuler, Ex-Champion, Killed in Road Accident
description: James Shuler, the middleweight boxer, was killed today when the motorcycle he was driving was involved in an accident with a tractor-trailer, authorities said. He was 26 years old.

title: SCREEN: CARE BEARS IN A SEQUEL
description: PRODUCT merchandising marches on: ''Care Bears Movie II: A New Generation'' is a follow-up to last year's animated film, ''The Care Bears Movie,'' perhaps the first feature film in motion-picture history to be spun off from a line of stuffed toys. The G-rated movie, which opens today at the Embassy 2 and other theaters, is for esoteric 3-year-olds.

title: DUST JETS FROM COMET'S CORE CALLED PUZZLING
description: The sharpest pictures yet of the black, irregular-shaped nucleus of Halley's comet were released here today, revealing unexplained ''focused emissions'' of gas and dust streaming from fissures on the surface of the nucleus.

title: Obstacles to a Soviet Role in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; March 21, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Russians and Pepsi
description: Despite uncertainty over the United States-Soviet summit planned for this year, Donald M. Kendall, chief of Pepsico Inc., is convinced that relations are improving.

title: Gramm-Rudman Is Subject to Court Review
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW FRENCH CABINET
description: Following is a list of Cabinet members in the new French Government, with party affiliation and some background: Prime Minister - Jacques Chirac, Rally for the Republic, Mayor of Paris. Foreign Affairs - Jean-Bernard Raimond, unaffiliated career diplomat, most recently Ambassador to the Soviet Union.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:21 A.M. today and set at noon.

title: MALPRACTICE-BILL AIDE HELPS INSURER
description: A key staff member of the State Legislature who is helping shape medical-malpractice insurance legislation is simultaneously involved in private business dealings with the state's largest malpractice insurer.

title: CALLS IT U.S. AID FUND USED BY MARCOS
description: A total of $1.1 million in interest is missing from a United States foreign aid account that former President Ferdinand E. Marcos had tapped during the recent election campaign, a Government auditor reported today.

title: I.B.M. Seeks Dismissal Of Student Protest Case
description: The International Business Machines Corporation asked a judge today to drop trespassing charges against 14 college students who staged a sit-in at the company's office to protest its business dealings with South Africa.

title: RUTGERS AND W. KENTUCKY GAIN IN EAST
description: Rutgers played tight defense and executed well offensively toward the end of the game tonight in defeating Penn State, 85-72, in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. women's East Regional at the Palestra. It was the fourth time in five games this season Rutgers has defeated Penn State.

title: Europe Rocket Liftoff Reset
description: Launching of the European Space Agency's Ariane 3 rocket, aborted seconds before liftoff Wednesday, has been rescheduled for March 28, Charles Bigot, director general of the Arianespace project, said today.

title: 3d GENERATION AT COMSTOCK
description: Comstock Group Inc., a diversified engineering construction company that had $450 million in revenues in 1985, announced yesterday that George Scharfe had been named president and chief operating officer. He is currently executive vice president of business development.

title: NIGHT OF CELEBRATION IN SHERIDAN SQ.
description: It was cold in Sheridan Square last night, but the hundreds of people who gathered to celebrate the passage of a homosexual rights bill took little notice.

title: AUBURN GAINS
description: The Western Region of the N.C.A.A. tournament has come down to a classic confrontation on Saturday between imposing physical strength and outstanding athletic talent.

title: VOTE IS 222 TO 210
description: The House of Representatives today rejected President Reagan's request to send $100 million to the rebels fighting to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: DOCKS ARE TARGET OF BRIBE INQUIRY
description: Federal investigators say they have uncovered evidence of widespread racketeering on the New York-New Jersey waterfront, including kickbacks, embezzlement and conflicts of interest in the administration of $40 million in pension and welfare funds for longshoremen.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami, 7:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees A team vs. Chicago White Sox A team, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 7:14 P.M.) Yankees B team vs. Texas Rangers, at Pompano Beach, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Basketball Suns vs. Detroit Pistons, at Phoenix. (Television - WTBS, 9:05 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Men's Regional Semifinals: East, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J.: Navy vs. Cleveland State, 7:15 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 12:30 A.M. tape delay). Duke vs. DePaul, 9:45 P.M. (Television -Channel 2, 10 P.M.) Midwest, at Kansas City, Mo.: North Carolina State vs. Iowa State, 7:35 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Kansas vs. Michigan State, 10:10 P.M. Division II men's final four, at Springfield, Mass: Cheyney State (Pa.) vs. Southeast Missouri State; Florida Southern vs. Sacred Heart (Conn.). Fencing N.C.A.A. women's championships, at Jadwin Gymnasium, Princeton, N.J., team championship finals, 9 A.M. New York international saber competition, at Columbia University's Levien Gymnasium, 119th Street and Broadway, 1:30 P.M. Hockey Devils vs. Sabres, 7:35 P.M. at Buffalo. The Sabres have not lost to the Devils in the 1980's, going 19-0-3 since Nov. 11, 1979. (Radio - WMCA 570, 7:30 P.M.) Tennis Virginia Slims Championship, quarterfinals, at Madison Square Garden, 6 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7 P.M.) Other Events BOWLING: $150,000 Lite Beer Open, at North Olmsted, Ohio.

title: Photo Exhibition Shows City From On High
description: Nineteen photographs by Peter B. Kaplan showing New York City from its loftiest vantage points are on view at the Urban Center, Madison Avenue and 51st Street. Drawn from Mr. Kaplan's book, ''High on New York,'' which was published this month by Harry N. Abrams Inc., the photographs are a celebration of the city's vast scale.

title: Cards' Smith Back In Fielding Form
description: Ozzie Smith started a game at shortstop today for the first time since the World Series, as the St. Louis Cardinals finally fielded the team that will defend the National League pennant.

title: Supreme Court; When Is Justice a Bargain and When Isn't It?
description: In the tradeoff between fighting crime and protecting civil liberties, the Supreme Court in recent years has settled into a fairly steady pattern, limiting but not overruling major decisions favorable to criminal defendants that the Court made under Chief Justice Earl Warren.

title: Providence Fails
description: Maurice Jackson and Robert Godbolt scored Louisiana Tech's last 11 points to withstand a late threat from Providence for a 64-63 victory tonight in the quarterfinals of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: AD DIRECTOR AND OTHERS NAMED AT NEW YORKER
description: The New Yorker has gotten its second new ad director since it was acquired by the Newhouse family's Advance Publications last May. And it is a 23-year-veteran of The New Yorker, Owen Hochreiter, who is stepping into the hot spot as national advertising sales director in charge of all the ad sales staff.

title: Bowdoin Trio
description: The Bowdoin Trio will perform music by Brahms Sunday at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall. Tickets are $8; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: 247-7800.

title: 38 WERE PAID $100,000 A YEAR
description: In 1984, through overtime and special bonuses, 38 longshoremen in the Port of New York were each paid more than $100,000 in wages.

title: ADJUSTABLE-RATE PAPER IN FREDDIE MAC DEBUT
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, at a news conference yesterday, introduced a new type of security called a capped, adjustable-rate mortgage participation certificate.

title: Book Awards Given for Jewish Themes
description: Winners of the seventh annual Present Tense awards, sponsored by Present Tense magazine and the American Jewish Committee, are:

title: ASHLAND OIL GETS A PRESIDENT AT LAST
description: Ashland Oil Inc., the nation's largest independent petroleum refiner, yesterday named Charles J. Luellen president and chief operating officer.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Doctor Is On
description: President Reagan, who does a national radio broadcast every Saturday, is getting competition from his newest Cabinet officer. Dr. Otis Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, is recording a 60-second spot, ''Housecalls,'' on health and medical subjects, and distributing it free to radio stations.

title: SUKARNO DAUGHTER, A FUGITIVE IN FRAUD, GIVES UP IN TEXAS
description: After fleeing Texas upon her conviction on felony charges, Rukmini Sukarno Kline, a daughter of Sukarno, the Indonesian leader from the early postwar years until 1966, has surrendered to the authorities and is in jail in Houston.

title: REVERE REPORTS ACQUISITION OFFER
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. said it had received an offer from an investment group to be acquired for $16 a share, or about $127 million. The investment group included the Oxford Financial Group, the Jamie Securities Company and Prudential Equities Inc. The investor group said the proposal was friendly and added that it wanted Revere's management to continue to operate the company.

title: ROUND 1 FOR DERBY ASPIRANTS
description: Nearly 50 3-year-olds will be running in graded stakes races around the country this weekend, in the first of three rounds of winnowing out legitimate candidates for the Kentucky Derby on May 3.

title: A Civilian Official Quits Haitian Council
description: Justice Minister Gerard Gourgue, one of the two civilian members of Haiti's six-member governing council, resigned today.

title: Nell Carter Is Host For NBC Music Special
description: When a musicianly singer with an interest in and feeling for the traditions of black popular music gets to play host for an hourlong network special, it's no time to look a gift horse in the mouth. But good music and good intentions do not an hour of television make. ''Nell Carter -Never Too Old to Dream,'' which will be aired by NBC tomorrow night at 8, is loaded with musical talent. But the producer-director Don Mischer, and the writer, Buz Kohan, have loaded down the show with more dialogue and dramatic set pieces than one is likely to encounter in a Broadway musical these days. Whenever the music flexes its wings and prepares to soar, it's a sure sign that an overlong dramatic set-piece is just around the corner.

title: KEY EXECUTIVE RESIGNS HIS POST AT B.B.D.O.
description: Irwin Warren, an executive vice president, and one of three top creative directors at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne, surprised the high command of the agency yesterday by announcing his resignation. He is believed to be headed for the top creative spot at Geers, Gross Advertising.

title: Greek Church Bazaar
description: Greek pastries, antiques, crafts, jewelry, books and clothes will be sold at a bazaar Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Annunciation, 91st Street and West End Avenue, to celebrate the church's feast day.

title: EVEN IF ONLY BRIEFLY, AN OLD CITY IN OHIO REIGNS AS A WINNER
description: Paul Zaremba is a 21-year-old junior at Cleveland State University who says he is majoring in marketing and earning a minor in ''basketball sports analysis'' even though he has not been to any basketball games this season.

title: ART: ANTHONY CARO AT EMMERICH GALLERY
description: DURING the 30 years that have passed since his first solo exhibition, Anthony Caro has established himself as a stayer, an indestructible professional and a man who consistently sets himself new problems and tussles with them till they come out right.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Chicago dispatch yesterday about the Illinois primary election misstated the relationship of former Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d to the former Vice President of the United States from whom he took his name. The Vice President was Mr. Stevenson's great-grandfather.

title: 2 KILLED IN BLAST IN A PARIS ARCADE
description: Two people were killed and 28 wounded, 10 seriously, when a bomb exploded in a crowded shopping arcade at rush hour on the Champs-Elysees.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ONE, two, cross over, cross over, one, two. A hot-blooded Robert Duvall was sweeping a slit-skirted Vivian Serota around the living room floor of her Park Avenue co-op as musicians from the Broadway show ''Tango Argentino'' played ''Jealousy.''

title: Vienna String Sextet
description: The Vienna String Sextet will perform works by Boccherini, Schoenberg and Brahms tomorrow night at 8 o'clock at the Metropolitan Museum. Tickets are $10. Information: 570-3949.
