title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: Shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend in May 1984, a 5 percent stock dividend in May 1985, and a 3-for-2 stock split in August 1985.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CATS OF THE TEMPLE. Poems by Brad Leithauser. 70 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $14.95; paperback, $7.95. ''CATS OF THE TEMPLE'' is Brad Leithauser's second collection of poems. In an introductory note, he expresses the hope that readers will greet it as ''a sibling companion'' to his first collection, ''Hundreds of Fireflies.'' It is an understandable request, since the earlier book was exceptionally well received. It is also one that can be readily granted - in the new book, Mr. Leithauser both extends his range and confirms his promise, making it clear that he is one of the most gifted American poets to have come over the horizon in years.

title: CONTRAS ARE CRITICAL OF HOUSE BUT HOPE FOR A COMPROMISE
description: Nicaraguan rebel spokesmen said today that they were disappointed by the House of Representatives vote against President Reagan's proposal to send them $100 million in aid, but they expressed hope for a compromise later.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $4 million, or 72 cents a share, relating to the company's energy division.

title: TAYLOR CONFIRMS 'SUBSTANCE ABUSE' CARE
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' all-pro outside linebacker, admitted yesterday that he had been receiving professional help for ''substance abuse'' problems.

title: BAN ON BALLESTEROS DISPUTED
description: Ben Crenshaw said today that several professional golfers wanted the PGA Tour to lift its one-year ban against Seve Ballesteros and allow him to play in as many tour-sponsored events as he wishes.

title: Four Blacks Are Killed In South Africa Incidents
description: A policeman shot two black people who commandeered a car from a white motorist today, the authorities said. The police said two other blacks were stabbed to death in other attacks.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
description: Assets of the nation's 361 money market mutual funds increased $1.96 billion, to $215.37 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the fifth consecutive weekly increase since the week of Feb. 19, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: CONSUMER FUND URGED
description: The California Supreme Court, in a ruling today, suggested that unclaimed refunds from a class action suit filed in 1978 against Levi Strauss & Company might be used to set up a consumer trust fund, which would engage in lobbying and education on consumer issues. Attorneys said establishment of a consumer fund was a rarely used but growing means of distributing the awards in class action suits, which have a large number of claimants but relatively small individual awards.

title: DOCUMENTS TAKEN FROM AQUINO AIDE
description: The head of a Philippine Government commission investigating the finances of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos reported that a briefcase containing documents ''of a sensitive nature'' was stolen from him last night in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: MUNICIPALS RECOVER SLIGHTLY
description: Conditions in the tax-exempt bond market improved marginally yesterday from the paralysis that stunned the market on Wednesday.

title: The Good Fight
description: Consider the rejection of Mr. Reagan's Central American policy as a lesson in geology: the political quakes and tremors that led to the decisive defeat of the President in Congress yesterday, denying aid to the anti-Communists fighting Nicaragua's dictator, lay bare the two great stresses on the fundaments of our foreign policy.

title: Boitano Rallies to Capture Title
description: Brian Boitano of the United States combined aerodynamics and Hollywood flourishes in a jazzy, prize-winning long program to defeat the defending champion, Aleksandr Fadeyev of the Soviet Union, and win the men's world figure skating crown today.

title: Peter Serkin to Play
description: The pianist Peter Serkin will play Bach's ''Goldberg Variations,'' among other works, at Avery Fisher Hall Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Tickets are $8 to $16. Information: 874-6770.

title: CONTROL DATA PLAN
description: The Control Data Corporation said that it would create an independent board for the Commercial Credit Company, its Baltimore-based financial subsidiary, and reduce intercompany dealings and the dividends paid by the subsidiary to Control Data. The changes ''will result in more autonomy for Commercial Credit and improve its access to the capital markets where it gets its primary funding,'' said Robert M. Price, the chairman and chief executive of Control Data, which is based in Bloomington, Minn. Commercial Credit will make a one-time $200 million dividend payment to the parent company.

title: Italians and Gary Hart
description: Senator Gary Hart, the Democratic Presidential hopeful, picked up a strong Italian endorsement the other evening without even making the politically obligatory trip to Rome.

title: M.L. ZALK, GELCO PRESIDENT, IS DEAD IN MINNEAPOLIS AT 63
description: Morton L. Zalk, president of the Gelco Corporation of Eden Prairie, Minn., died early Wednesday in Mount Sinai Hospital of complications from a recent illness.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Including net gains from the sale of properties of $14.7 million and net losses totaling $5.9 million for writedowns of property, equipment and provisions for closing certain facilities for the quarter and year.

title: Grievance to Youngblood
description: Baseball's impartial arbitrator ruled yesterday that the San Francisco Giants had to honor the two-year, $900,000 contract they negotiated with Joel Youngblood, then withdrew when he didn't immediately agree to a drug-testing clause.

title: PLAYING A PUNK AND A SNOB
description: JOHNNY is a Cockney street punk with a two-tone brush haircut topped by a layer of bleached whitish spikes. Insolent and tough, he sleeps in abandoned buildings, hangs around his seedy neighborhood, gets into trouble and abuses the dark-skinned foreigners who have invaded London -until he falls in love with one of them and begins a torrid affair.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS PLANS FOR ZAPMAIL
description: The Federal Express Corporation said it would accept no orders for its Zapmailer document-transmission machines for ''three to six months'' in order to concentrate on upgrading the system. The company, based in Memphis, said its Zapmail system had suffered losses of more than $200 million since it was introduced in July 1984.

title: A Correspondent Finally Gets a Job
description: When Texas' top-rated high school quarterback, Lance Pavlas, signed a football letter of intent with Texas A&M, it was the culmination of a six-year correspondence with Coach Jackie Sherrill.

title: THEATER: 'ALCESTIS'
description: Acting as a theatrical conceptualist, Robert Wilson creates his own scenarios, sometimes in collaboration with others. Then, with himself as director and principal designer, he activates his vision, flooding a stage with iconographic imagery. In contrast to his previous work, ''Alcestis,'' at the American Repertory Theater here, is the first instance of Mr. Wilson's applying his talent to a classic dramatic text, in this case, Euripides' profound study of sacrifice and rebirth.

title: LONDON'S PASSING PARADE
description: The springlike weather here this week brought out contrasts in styles as Londoners continued to do their own highly individual thing.

title: HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS BILL IS PASSED BY CITY COUNCIL IN 21-TO-14 VOTE
description: The New York City Council ended an often intense and emotional 15-year battle last night and approved a homosexual rights bill by an unexpectedly wide margin of 21 to 14.

title: MARKET IS SET FOR WILD DAY
description: There is widespread expectation that the New York Stock Exchange could see an unprecedented flood of orders in the closing minutes today.

title: Obstacles to a Soviet Role in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Guatemala Posts Ex-Officer
description: Former Gen. Rodolfo Lobos Zamora, accused by civil rights groups of being responsible for the disappearance of hundreds of people during the military regime of Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, has been named by the new civilian Government of President Vinicio Cerezo as Ambassador to Panama, Foreign Ministry sources confirmed today. The appointment means Mr. Lobos Zamora will be immune to prosecution. The private Mutual Support Group had been trying to bring him to trial on charges of human rights abuses, sources said.

title: OGLIVY & MATHER WINS ITS 3d TOP KELLY AWARD
description: At the fifth annual Stephen E. Kelly Award luncheon Wednesday Ogilvy & Mather, the house built by David Ogilvy, a star of print advertising, won its third top prize for ''execellence in magazine advertising.''

title: ACCORD BY OPEC SEEN AS UNLIKELY
description: Amid growing indications that OPEC's five-day-old emergency meeting might break up without agreement, member countries said they would propose production cuts to the nonmembers attending the talks, while conceding that the group was unable to agree on an output ceiling for itself.

title: Trouble Off Court
description: The way Xavier McDaniel and his wife, Sylvia, were telling it in Seattle yesterday, it was just one of those marital spats that got a bit out of hand early Saturday morning. So much so, in fact, that the star SuperSonic rookie was charged with assault and later agreed to a year of supervised probation to avoid prosecution on the misdemeanor.

title: DANCE: 'SHEER ROMANCE' BY BALLROOM THEATER
description: ''SHEER ROMANCE'' is sheer delight. That's what the American Ballroom Theater's choreographic revue seemed when it was presented last season in a small-scale version at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. On Tuesday night, a revised and expanded production opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and it remains sheer delight. It's great fun and one of the most unusual dance productions in New York.

title: VOTE ON RIGHTS BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the City Council approved a homosexual rights bill yesterday:

title: STAGE: ELISABETH WELCH IN ONE-WOMAN SHOW
description: EARLY in ''Time to Start Living,'' her one-woman show of songs and reminiscences, Elisabeth Welch recalls when she was 8 years old and obsessed with a tune on the next-door neighbor's Pianola. Doggedly she set about learning the song, but when she finally sang it to her mother, instead of praise she was greeted with a swift smack. ''I didn't know why,'' Miss Welch recollects with a twinkle in her eye, before launching into a zippy little foxtrot, ''When I Get You Home Tonight,'' whose lyrics would have been considered ''suggestive'' in the 1950's, not to mention 1917.

title: Obstacles to a Soviet Role in the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: The Azaleas Can Wait
description: Under normal circumstances, Vernon Butler would be going home to work in his parents' yard in Maryland this weekend, a healthy respite from his load at the Naval Academy. But he has indoor work ahead of him tonight, some of it as strenuous and inelegant as lugging a railroad tie onto a hillside terrace of 600 azaleas.

title: A CORNER OF MALAYSIA IS ROCKED BY POLITICAL RAGE
description: It has been a week of terror and violence in this frontier state of Sabah. More than two dozen bombings and fatal fires have left five people dead and many wounded.

title: CHILD WORLD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: Year-ago quarter share earnings result was not reported because the company went public last August.

title: CITADEL BID BEGUN BY GREAT WESTERN
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation began its unsolicited tender offer of 1.2 shares of Great Western common stock for each common share of the Citadel Holding Company, the parent of Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan Association of Glendale, Calif.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report yesterday about an exhibition at the Jewish Museum celebrating the centennial of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America misstated the opening day. It is Sunday.

title: U.S. Debt-Collection Vote
description: The Senate on Wednesday approved, by a 95-to-1 vote, a bill that would permit the Federal Government to retain private lawyers to help collect $23.6 billion in nontax delinquent debts. The bill now goes to the House. The money is owed by people who have defaulted on various types of Government loans.

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7,615,000.

title: Seales Bankrupt
description: Sugar Ray Seales, the only American boxer to win a gold medal at the 1972 Olympic Games, has declared bankruptcy in Tacoma, Wash. The 33-year-old Seales, who as a professional fighter suffered eye damage that necessitated seven operations, listed debts of $160,000. Bankruptcy Court Judge Robert Skidmore said Seales ''was so poor he couldn't even pay the bankruptcy filing fee.''

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Including a net LIFO credit of $188,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and a net LIFO charge of $225,000 for the year. c-Including a net LIFO credit of $407,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and a net LIFO charge of $15,000 for the year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF you have a nostalgic longing for the ingenuous hash-house grub of simpler days, you might stop by the new Broadway Diner, at Broadway and 55th Street, for a cup of java and a wedge of pie, or maybe a hot open-face sandwich flanked by volcanos of mashed potatoes and lavalike gravy.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: KING VIDOR was a man obsessed.

title: Unusual Double
description: Shot-putters are large people. But large fast people?

title: FIVE CITIES IN JERSEY ARE SUED BY THE U.S. ON HARBOR POLLUTION
description: The Federal Government has filed suit against five New Jersey cities charging them with discharging excessive pollution into the Hudson River and other bodies of water in New York harbor.

title: Congress; Two Cases of Computer Burglary
description: Jennifer Kuiper was working late at her computer terminal in the office of Representative Ed Zschau of California on March 7 when she heard a beep that told her someone had entered the computer system from an outside telephone line.

title: CAUSES OF SHIFT AT GLOBE DEBATED IN NEWS ROOM
description: Confusion lingered today over some of the reasons for the resignation of Michael C. Janeway Wednesday as editor of The Boston Globe.

title: Guess Who?
description: When Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter became President Reagan's fourth national security adviser last December, he served notice that, unlike some predecessors, he planned to maintain a low profile.

title: 'BY THE SWORD DIVIDED,' ON 'MASTERPIECE THEATER'
description: CELEBRATING its 15th anniversary this year, public television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' is unfortunately not having one of its more memorable seasons. There is no ''Jewel in the Crown'' on tap to provide distinction and glitter. For the next nine weeks, loyal viewers will have to make do with ''By the Sword Divided.'' Patience will not necessarily be rewarded.

title: ROLL-CALL IN THE HOUSE
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 222 to 210 today by which the House of Representatives rejected President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the aid. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 46 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 206 Democrats and 16 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Reagan and U.N. Chief To Meet on Budget Ills
description: President Reagan will meet Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar at the White House on Friday to discuss the world organization's financial crisis, the United Nations announced today.

title: Music of the Andes
description: Fabian Mozaurieta and Tahuantinsuyo will present music of Peru and the Andes at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, tomorrow night at 8 o'clock.

title: PHILIPPINE PANEL LINKS MARCOS KIN TO ILLEGAL DEALS
description: Government investigators have uncovered new evidence that Ferdinand E. Marcos's children and their spouses improperly acquired a lucrative group of businesses and were draining some of the companies of cash for themselves.

title: FORD INCREASES ITS NOTE OFFERING
description: The Ford Motor Company is offering $250 million of 8 7/8 percent notes due 2006 at a price of 99 to yield 8.984 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 21, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Black Writers' Meeting Opening in Brooklyn
description: The first national black writers' conference will take place this weekend in Brooklyn, based on the theme ''The Social Responsibility of the Writer to the Community.'' Writers scheduled to participate include Maya Angelou, Claude Brown, John A. Williams, Ishmael Reed, Paule Marshall and Ossie Davis.

title: Japanese and Lobbyists
description: Powerful Japanese corporations are apparently becoming more selective about hiring Washington lobbyists to protect and advance their considerable economic interests in this country. At a January meeting at the Japanese Embassy, officials from the Foreign Ministry in Tokyo and Japanese consular representatives stationed in this country discussed Japan's public relations in the United States and, according to one account, agreed that some lobbyists were charging ''naive'' Japanese corporations too much for less than effective service.

title: How to Avoid the Next Drought
description: New York City's water supply is too slim for safety. The right remedy, says the private Citizens Union, is to reduce demand. No, says a governmental committee, increase supply. When the alternatives are so costly and so vital, how can the public decide which to do? The answer, precisely because water is vital, is to do both.

title: FARM PANEL'S CHIEF WOULD BLOCK CUTS FOR EXTENSION UNIT
description: The chairman of a House Appropriations subcommittee said today that Congress would prevent the Reagan Administration from cutting the budget of the Agriculture Extension Service by 60 percent in the fiscal year 1987.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest third quarter and 9 months' losses include about $4.9 million of unusual charges taken in preparation for the company's anticipated emergence from Chapter 11 proceedings.

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,708,000 for the quarter and $38,565,000 for the year.

title: STEVENSON BARS A CAMPAIGN WITH 2 EXTREMISTS ON SLATE
description: As Illinois Democrats assessed the damage of two ultraconservative unknowns' upset victories in the party's statewide primary Tuesday, Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the party's nominee for Governor, asserted today that he would never run on any ticket with them.

title: MAKING DEBUT AT PURIM PARADE: A JEWISH MARCHING BAND
description: For six years, the annual Queens Purim Parade has depended solely on marching bands such as St. Michael's Archangels Drum Corps, St. Fidelius Majestic Knights Drum and Bugle Corps and St. Anne's Fife, Drum and Brass Corps. Not this year. The Liberal Jewish Day School Marching Band of West Hempstead, L.I., will be there this Sunday, too.

title: SOME TO GO TO N.J. TRANSIT
description: Most of New York City's fleet of Flxible buses, once called ''junk'' by the president of the Transit Authority, will be sold back to their manufacturer at bargain prices, refurbished, and resold to New Jersey's mass transit agency, under agreements announced yesterday.

title: Is The Ballot Really Secret in New Jersey?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT TURNS TO THE SENATE IN FIGHT FOR BILL
description: White House officials said today that, with the House rejection of President Reagan's $100 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, they were placing their hopes on the Senate.

title: To Smoke Out Spies, Offer an Amnesty
description: Amnesty for spies? Ridiculous! Who could think of leniency for traitors?

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MARCOS LINKED TO FOUR MANHATTAN SITES
description: The Philippine Government made public a document yesterday that it said linked Ferdinand E. Marcos to ownership of four Manhattan buildings thought to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: NEWARK POLICEMAN ACCUSED OF DEALING DRUGS AT WORK
description: An 18-year veteran of the Newark police force was charged today with negotiating a cocaine sale with an undercover Federal agent while in uniform in police headquarters.

title: ALABAMA MAN DIES IN ELECTRIC CHAIR
description: A man convicted of two murders who came within 16 hours of execution in 1984 died in Alabama's electric chair early today for the shooting death of a cab driver in a robbery.

title: SHOPPING IN PARIS: CHIC NEW STOPS
description: A taxi pulled up in front of a building on the Rue du Parc-Royal in the Marais district. The driver looked at the windowless ground floor, the discreet silver plaque on the door, the television camera that monitors arrivals and the chic and beautiful women who were leaving. ''Is this a brothel?'' he asked his startled passenger. It wasn't. Here, at Azzedine Alaia's shop, one of the latest pleasure palaces of Parisian style, women pulled denim dresses and leather jackets off two small racks, changing quickly in the dressing cabins made of perforated metal. As they postured before the mirrors, they bemoaned the fact that already, on this rainy, not-yet-spring morning, many of Alaia's current styles were sold out.

title: CAPSULES OF 3 DRUGS ARE TAINTED
description: A leading drug company today urged consumers not to take three types of capsules, including Contac, that have been purchased since Saturday. The company said investigators had discovered tampering with the products.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: NEARLY every college campus has its ''fancy'' restaurant, the place you take mom and dad on their biannual inspection tour to reassure them that you have not forgotten how to behave in public or use a steak knife. Usually, it is a stuffy and over-upholstered establishment serving doctored-up dining-hall rations on alma-mater china. But the Terrace atop Butler Hall at Columbia University is a surprising exception - it is a serious and charming French restaurant that can be recommended without hesitation to off-campus ''townies.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mauro Panaggio of the Bay State Bombardiers was named the Continental Basketball Association's coach of the year. The team, which finished sixth in the Eastern Division under Dave Cowens, improved to a second-place finish under Panaggio. . . . Michael Young, the former University of Houston star, was the league's most valuable player, averaging 26.8 points and 8.6 rebounds for the Detroit Spirits. . . . Tomas Sandstrom of the Rangers was fined $500 by the National Hockey League for butting Bobby Carpenter of the Washington Capitals with his head in a game March 2. The Rangers said there would be no appeal.

title: OPERA: CHANGES IN 'CARMEN'
description: PLACIDO DOMINGO'S recent cancellations around the globe have caused considerable consternation in an operatic world whose first-rate tenors can be counted on the fingers of one hand. So particular interest attached to his return Tuesday to the Metropolitan Opera for ''Carmen.'' The news is good: he has returned in solid representative form, and his public welcomed him back warmly.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Share earnings results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in February.

title: House Leaders Put Off Vote on Gun Measures
description: House leaders decided today to put off a vote on two bills that would make major revisions in the Federal law on gun control.

title: CITY DATA SHOW REPORTS OF AIDS LEVELING OFF
description: The number of new AIDS cases reported in New York City has leveled off in the last six months, the city's Health Department said yesterday.

title: Bennington Fee to $16,950
description: Bennington College will raise its total charges to $16,950 next year under a plan to meet its financial emergency. Tuition alone will rise to $13,720 from $12,780, Michael Hooker, the president, announced Wednesday. The Massachusetts Institute of Technology costs more to attend than Bennington, $17,000, with tuition at $11,800 a year.

title: PARK AVE. SOUTH HOUSING WILL KEEP BANK'S FACADE
description: In 1981, when a web of scaffolding went up around the New York Bank for Savings building on Park Avenue South at East 22d Street, community activists believed it marked the end of the structure, a distinguished example of classical revival design.

title: A CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE EASTER SEASON
description: Following are some of the musical presentations planned for the Easter season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted.

title: REAGAN BUDGET STRATEGY: RISKING A LOSS
description: The White House is sitting out this year's budget battle in the Senate, at least for now, in a high-risk strategy that seems to ignore the political impact the new budget balancing law might have on Capitol Hill. The law might drive the Senate and the House, without Administration participation, to write a bipartisan budget that defies President Reagan's priorities of a growing military budget and no tax increases.

title: Tanner Is Angry
description: Chuck Tanner, the former Pittsburgh manager, has denied a suggestion by John Candelaria, the former Pirate pitcher, that Tanner and his coaches may have known about drug use among Pirate players before it was uncovered by Federal investigators in 1984. Candelaria, who was traded to the California Angels last August, said in a recent interview that drug use had been so widespread among the Pirates that he was surprised it had not been dealt with sooner.

title: Boyd Reprimanded
description: After missing 10 days of training while doctors determined there was nothing seriously wrong with him, Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd appears ready to reclaim his starting job with the Boston Red Sox. First, however, it appears the right-hander will have to get his act together off the field.

title: DEE MAKES BID FOR HERMAN'S
description: The Dee Corporation, a large British food retailer and wholesaler, said it was making a $410 million cash bid to buy Herman's Sporting Goods, the largest American sporting goods chain.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Opens Season Tuesday
description: Dance Theater of Harlem will present ''Harlem Homecoming Season,'' opening on Tuesday and running through April 6 at City College's Aaron Davis Hall, Convent Avenue and 134th Street. Dedicated to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the season will open with a gala evening starring Maxine Sullivan, Chris Calloway, the Keith Ingram Band and the Williams Brothers, who tap in the style of the Nicholas Brothers.

title: GEN. EDWARD GILLETTE Jr.
description: Brig. Gen. Edward Gillette Jr., the former head of the department of physics and chemistry at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., died of a stroke last Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Nashville. He was 85 years old and lived in Nashville.

title: STAGE: 'PRECIOUS SONS,' WITH HARRIS AND IVEY
description: IN the most affecting speech in George Furth's new play, ''Precious Sons,'' Freddy, a 14-year-old child of Chicago's South Side, describes the joy of the theater. The year is 1949, a golden time for the American stage, and Freddy (Anthony Rapp), a fledgling child actor, may soon be offered a small role in the national company of ''A Streetcar Named Desire.'' The boy's meek voice grows musical as he describes his past experiences acting in theaters in the Loop. ''Of all the things there are,'' he says, ''a stage play is far and wide the most wonderful thing.''

title: Suit Over Hairdressing
description: A woman who hoped to compete in the Miss Oregon pageant has sued a hairdresser, contending her hair was left ''greenish-yellow'' after a highlighting treatment. Lisa L. Van Domelen, 18 years old, of Banks, sued Gary Luckey Hair Designs of Portland for $15,000 damages and $136 for medical treatment.

title: A WHIRLWIND OF DANCE, BALLROOM TO AVANT-GARDE
description: THE curtain will rise tonight at the Joyce Theater and the dancers will raise their arms with the first strains of Tchaikovsky's ''Serenade for String Orchestra.'' But there is a surprise in store. The music does not accompany George Balanchine's classic ''Serenade,'' so inextricably associated with that score for half a century now. Instead, the dancers are modern-day ballroom dancers, and the music takes them through first love and teasing dalliances.

title: THE DANCE: TRISLER
description: MILTON MYERS makes taste, intelligence and invention look so natural that it is easy to take him for granted as a choreographer. But Mr. Myers was full of surprises on Tuesday, when the Joyce Trisler Danscompany opened for a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater.

title: CHIRAC BECOMES FRANCE'S PREMIER AND FORMS CONSERVATIVE CABINET
description: Jacques Chirac, the leader of the neo-Gaullist party, formally assumed the post of Prime Minister today and formed a new, conservative Government.

title: A Really Joint Chief?
description: Congress has few more serious issues before it than a little-noticed proposal by the Senate Armed Services Committee to reorganize the Joint Chiefs of Staff. This is no mere box-shuffling of the Pentagon's vast bureaucracy. The committee aims for radical change of the military command structure. But that high goal risks a high danger: weakening civilian control of the military.

title: DUKE PLAYERS FEEL FORTUNATE
description: ''We're really honored to be one of the teams still participating in the N.C.A.A. tournament,'' said David Henderson, Duke's strong, elegant reserve guard.

title: Smith Award Winner
description: Dayton, Ohio, doesn't have a major league team, so Si Burick, who has spent 57 years as sports editor and columnist at The Dayton Daily News, has had to extend himself to cover big-time sports. He has covered every one of the 20 Super Bowls, all but one World Series since 1934 and five Olympics.

title: Again, the Balanced-Budget Pablum
description: The balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution, which comes before the Senate next week, is hypocritical, absurd and maybe dangerous. It would load down the Constitution with procedural detail that doesn't belong there. If rigorously observed, it could cripple the economy; if not, it would be trivial or meaningless. Though it deserves not a single vote, its demagogic appeal assures it of more than 60 of the 67 required for passage.

title: Mr. Murtaugh Wins Feature
description: Mr. Murtaugh closed swiftly on the rail to reach the wire a length ahead of favored Hot Cop and take the feature race, the $40,000 Jamie K. purse, at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Including earnings from discontinued operations of $17,382,000, or 39 cents.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 21, 1986
description: International The House rejected the request by President Reagan to send $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan guerrillas. The vote was 222 to 210, with 16 Republicans joining 206 Democrats in rebuffing Mr. Reagan in what he called a major test of his Presidency. [ Page A1, Columns 5-6. ]

title: Union Busting Made Easy
description: The strike by Trans World Airlines flight attendants is only the latest illustration of a major threat to the labor movement. The threat is the two-tiered wage system, and either the movement will defeat the two-tiered wage system or the system will continue to accelerate labor's decline.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes a gain of $16.1 million, or 37 cents a share, from asset redeployment. c-Includes a gain of $15.7 million from the sale of a unit.

title: POP: REGGAE SUNSPLASH
description: REGGAE SUNSPLASH -four well-known Jamaican reggae acts sharing a solid band, the Syndicate -came to Radio City Music Hall Thursday, making its New York stop on a national tour.

title: FANNIE MAE PLANS YIELD-CURVE NOTES
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced its first issue ever of yield-curve notes with interest rates tied to the London interbank offered rate.

title: Sindona Slips Into Coma After Collapsing in Jail
description: Michele Sindona, the Sicilian financier sentenced to life imprisonment two days ago for contracting a murder, was rushed to a hospital today in a grave coma with little chance of recovery.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BRIDGE: 2 WORLD CHAMPIONS OUSTED IN A VANDERBILT TEAM MATCH
description: A stunning upset here Wednesday night left a team of stars on the sidelines when Vanderbilt Knockout Team play resumed here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: PANEL SET TO DEFEAT BOND TAX
description: A majority of the members of the Senate Finance Committee indicated today that they would vote Monday to defeat a proposal by the chairman, Bob Packwood, that has paralyzed the municipal bond market.

title: DOW PARADES PAST 1,800 MARK
description: Wall Street passed another milestone yesterday when the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,800 level for the first time and passed its third hundred-point marker this year.

title: NATO-WARSAW PACT TROOP TALKS STALL
description: Talks on reducing the number of NATO and Warsaw Pact troops in Europe ended today without progress, the White House announced.

title: Van Arsdale's Son Gets Top Labor Group Post
description: Thomas Van Arsdale, the son of the longtime leader of the New York City Central Labor Council, was elected last night to succeed his father.

title: Embarrassing Commercial
description: Chagrined and perplexed by how it got on the air in the first place, Nynex executives have ordered the withdrawal of a radio commercial that employs a crude ethnic stereotype.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BAHIA,' FROM MARCEL CAMUS
description: IN the late 1950's, Marcel Camus, the French film director, hit the jackpot with ''Black Orpheus,'' the legend of Orpheus and Eurydice as retold against the background of Rio de Janeiro's Mardi Gras and backed by a samba beat. Though he tried, Mr. Camus was never able to duplicate the popular success of that film, which went on to win the Oscar as the best foreign film of 1959.

title: HUNDREDS OF CATS AND DOGS FOULD ILL IN FORMER SHELTER
description: The police and animal protection officers raided a building in the Bronx yesterday and found nearly 500 animals that were dying or living under life-threatening conditions, the authorities said.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT STRIKE PACT
description: Negotiators for striking public transit workers and the transportation authority reached a tentative contract agreement today to end a five-day strike after more than 20 hours of negotiations.

title: DROP IN PRICE OF OIL AGAIN BATTERS TEXAS ECONOMY, SPURRING LAYOFFS
description: A new round of layoffs is battering the Texas economy as falling oil prices continue to take their toll on the state.

title: WARNER'S SCENARIOS FOR HITS
description: Warner Brothers did not release any of the top five films last year, but no one at the studio panicked. The studio had seven of the next 15 movies, including ''Goonies'' and ''Police Academy.''

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
PANAMA REPORTED TO REJECT MARCOS REQUEST FOR ASYLUM
description: Reagan Administration officials said tonight that the United States had received word from Panama that it had turned down a request for asylum for former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines.

title: Hormel Demonstration Marked by 24 Arrests
description: Twenty-four people were arrested today in a demonstration at the Geo. A Hormel & Company plant that the company said was incited by ''outside agitators'' and ''a lawless element'' in the striking meatpackers' union.

title: CLARK URGING SHIFT IN CONTROL TO AID FAILING URBAN SCHOOLS
description: With newly enacted academic reforms ''unlikely to reach the inner-city students who need it most,'' Dr. Kenneth B. Clark has called on the New York State Board of Regents to supersede the authority of local school boards and put public schools with chronically low test scores into ''receivership.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1986
description: Markets

title: HARVARD CANCELS PLAN FOR SOUTH AFRICAN STUDY
description: Harvard University, under pressure from students and faculty, has dropped a $1 million program to send students to study and work at South African schools.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What a day! What a day!'' - Gerald Kuschuk, senior vice president of options trading at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. [ 39:5. ]

title: JOHN M. RUSSELL
description: John M. Russell, former president of the John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, died of a heart attack March 15 at Canossa Hospital in Hong Kong, where he was vacationing.

title: Minnesota Rallies, 6-4
description: Three goals by Minnesota, scored in 67 seconds of the third period, gave the Gophers a 6-4 victory over Boston University tonight in a quarterfinal game of the national collegiate hockey tournament.

title: AIDES SEEK TO RESOLVE RIFT OVER STATE BUDGET
description: Aides worked today to repair strained relations between Governor Cuomo and the leader of the State Senate's Republican majority, after top-level negotiations on the state's proposed $41.4 billion budget broke off late Thursday night.

title: Westinghouse To Sell 42 Units
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 42 of its repair plants to the Eastern Electric Apparatus Repair Company for an undisclosed amount.

title: ICH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including investment gains of $20,894,000 for the quarter and $38,128,000 for the year. c-Including investment losses of $903,000 for the quarter and investment gains of $546,000 for the year.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
70 Years of Advocating Good Government
description: Seventy years ago, the Women's City Club published a tract asking, ''Should Women Be Admitted to Columbia Law School?'' Since then, the club has become one of New York's most influential good-government groups, testifying at hearings and issuing reports on a range of problems, from truancy to equal employment for women.

title: ALIENS AND POVERTY LAY A HEAVY BURDEN ON HOSPITAL IN EL PASO
description: Like many public hospitals, the R. E. Thomason General Hospital here is trying to provide health care to a population increasingly unable to pay for it, but the difficulties it faces are more complicated than those of most public hospitals.

title: PANAMA REBUFFS MARCOS, CITING NATIONAL SECURITY
description: Citing national security concerns, Panama formally rejected a request for asylum from former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos today.

title: FRENCHMAN SLAIN IN UGANDA
description: A French diplomat was shot dead today by intruders who broke into his home, a French Embassy spokesman said. The spokesman identified the diplomat as Andre Dalpra, an administrative attache at the embassy. Several European embassies in Kampala did not open today in response to the killing.

title: ARKANSAS TO PAY FOR TEST OF MOTHERS' MILK
description: Gov. Bill Clinton says he will release up to $10,000 from the state's emergency fund to pay for mothers to have their breast milk tested for traces of a banned pesticide.

title: Linda Amster
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50. 1. This has ended speculation. Explain. 2. An arrangement the French refer to as ''cohabitation'' is a result of a situation France has not faced since the advent of the Fifth Republic in 1959. What is the situation and what is the arrangement? 3. A flower identified as ''Zwart 0-8-35-79-1,'' the progeny of a mother named Queen of the Night and a father named Wienerwald, is causing a horticultural sensation. Why? 4. Tiny letters around a portrait is one of two subtle modifications of something that has remained substantially unchanged since 1929. What is it and why is it being altered? 5. ''A dark day for freedom,'' said President Reagan after a political defeat. To what was he referring? 6. Some results of the Democratic statewide primary voting in Illinois left the party's gubernatorial nominee in shock. Identify him and explain. 7. An event that occurs four days each year has a large and sometimes disruptive impact on stock prices, according to a recent report. What event is it? 8. ''In the spirit of Christ I must love my homosexual brothers and sisters, even though I don't understand them,'' said City Councilman Wendell Foster of the Bronx as some observers cheered. What were the circumstances? 9. The greatest numbers of schizophrenics now live (in hospitals/in jails/in the streets/with their families). 10. ''It's old hat,'' an observer said about an event that generated less excitement on Wall Street this time than ever before.

title: IN WAKE OF OFFICER'S ARREST, NEWARK POLICE TO TEST EMPLOYEES FOR DRUG USE
description: The Newark Police Department will begin mandatory drug testing of all 1,100 employees in the next few weeks, the city's Police Director said today.

title: PENN WOMEN WIN TITLE
description: Mary Jane O'Neill scored three victories today as the top-seeded University of Pennsylvania gained its first National Collegiate Athletic Association women's fencing team title with an 8-6 victory over Notre Dame.

title: Oil Soars in Last Hour On OPEC's Statement
description: Crude oil prices shot up in the final hour of trading today following a statement by Arturo Hernandez Grisanti, president of an OPEC conference in Geneva, that OPEC and non-OPEC delegates had agreed to defend a price structure of $28 a barrel, traders and analysts said.

title: WHO KILLED OLOF PALME? THE TRIAL GROWS FAINT
description: Stockholm's lean and laconic police commissioner, Hans Holmer, has been given the nickname Clintan by his colleagues for a certain resemblance in appearance and manner to Clint Eastwood.

title: SINGAPORE TOLL PUT AT 33
description: Thirty-three people died in the collapse of the Hotel New World on Saturday, and 17 people were rescued, the Government announced today. The total was much less than the approximately 100 people originally believed buried in the rubble of the six-story building.

title: Russian Supply Craft Docks With New Space Laboratory
description: A spacecraft carrying supplies docked today with the manned orbiting space laboratory Mir, the Soviet news agency Tass reported.

title: STOPGAP BILL ON TOXIC CLEANUP IS PASSED AND SENT TO REAGAN
description: The Senate today passed and sent to the White House stopgap legislation to salvage a toxic waste cleanup program that is fast running out of money.

title: 'TRIPLE WITCHING HOUR' HAVOC
description: For Richard Kent, an institutional trader at Wertheim & Company, the first sign of real trouble - like seeing a cannon muzzle poke out of the woods - was at 3:35 yesterday afternoon. ''The market's getting killed,'' he said, watching a computer screen flash stock index price information. ''This is getting vicious now, real vicious. It's horrible.''

title: BREAKING THE CONCRETE FEATHERBED
description: The New York State Investigation Commission's list of criminal, wasteful and otherwise outrageous practices in construction demands a response. While some of its suggestions are helpful, the commission's main recommendation against a special prosecutor ought to be reversed.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNAIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including writedowns of $175 million for the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $53,700,000 for the quarter, $32,900,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: IKEA VENTURE IN U.S. A HIT
description: Last year IKEA, the Scandinavian furniture giant, nervously spent nearly $2 million to promote the opening of its first store in the United States, a sprawling warehouse-style outlet in a shopping mall in this Philadelphia suburb.

title: Turnpike Crash Kills One
description: A Brooklyn man was killed and two other people, including a member of the Atlanta Falcons football team, were injured today when a limousine was struck from behind by a tractor-trailer on the Connecticut Turnpike, authorities said. Hou Chat Yuen, 34 years old, the limousine driver, was killed in the 2:05 A.M. collision. Robert C. Holly, 25, of Norwalk, a Princeton graduate who was reserve quarterback for the Falcons, received multiple injuries.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Sent Dave West, Reggie Dobie, Jose Bautista, Augie Garcia, Kyle Hartshorn, John Mitchell and Tom McCarthy, pitchers; Marcus Lawton and Shawn Abner, outfielders, and Dave Magadan and Kevin Elster, infielders, to their minor-league complex for reassignment.

title: SHULTZ SAYS TECHNOLOGY MAY AID IN EASING OF EAST-WEST TENSIONS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that to compete with the West in computer and communications technology, the Soviet bloc might be forced to expand the liberties of its peoples.

title: MEESE RESTRICTS SETTLEMENTS IN SUITS AGAINST GOVERNMENT
description: The Reagan Administration today sharply limited the power of Federal agencies to consent to court decrees that settle lawsuits against the Government without litigation.

title: BankAmerica
description: In an apparent anti-takeover move, the BankAmerica Corporation said it was asking its shareholders to approve at the annual meeting on April 29 an amendment to the company's bylaws requiring that any action by shareholders be taken only at meetings. Previously, shareholder action could also be by written consent. While the amendment could increase the length of time required for a majority of the shareholders to take action, the company said it could also ''discouurage some efforts to change control of the board of directors between annual meetings.''

title: 3 KILLED AS SIKHS MARCH ON PUNJAB LEGISLATURE
description: At least three people were killed and 25 wounded today in the capital of Punjab State, where the police battled hundreds of militant Sikhs who tried to march on the state legislature.

title: 'CBN News Tonight' Canceled by Network
description: ''CBN News Tonight,'' a half-hour nightly newscast started on the Christian Broadcasting Network two months ago, is being canceled because of a lack of advertising, CBN announced today.

title: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $546,716 for the quarter and $706,246 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $148,339 for the quarter and $219,717 for the year.

title: AQUARIUM CONSTRUCTING A NEW COMPLEX
description: The New York Aquarium has begun building a $6.5 million educational exhibition complex known as Discovery Cove, the first of a series of projects aimed at giving the public ''a real feel for the aquatic environment.''

title: MARCOS U.S. BANK DEALINGS MODEST
description: American banks and financial institutions played a modest role in the finances of Ferdinand E. Marcos and his family, according to documents brought to Hawaii by the Marcos party.

title: BASE NEW YORK CITY FARES ON DISTANCES TRAVELED
description: Proposals to end New York City's transit crisis have focused only on the most obvious solutions: raising fares and shrinking service. But neither is politically easy. Transit officials might find greater success by increasing the role of private companies in providing services, by structuring fares to reflect distance traveled and substituting buses for subways in some areas.

title: ITALY SAYS IT FOUND CYANIDE IN SINDONA
description: Michele Sindona, the jailed Sicilian financier who fell into an irreversible coma on Thursday, is the victim of cyanide poisoning, the Justice Minister said today.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results include tax credits of 5 cents a share in the latest quarter and 13 cents a share in the latest year.

title: DOW FALLS BY 35.68 IN A WILD SESSION
description: Wall Street was expecting a wild session yesterday, and it wasn't disappointed.

title: BAFFLING COOKING DIRECTIONS
description: In response to a column that explored the proper way to write a cookbook, a writer asked when authors were going to ''shape up.'' What do you mean by three medium apples, he wanted to know. And why don't you tell us how many ounces and pounds to buy instead of how many cups?

title: THOMAS CAPTURES WORLD SKATE TITLE
description: Debi Thomas, an American pre-med student at Stanford University, won the women's world figure skating championship tonight with an elegant, cleanly executed program that took the title from Katarina Witt, the Olympic gold medalist and two-time defending champion from East Germany.

title: THE POET SINGS OF ARMS AS WELL AS ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'COHABITATION,' NOT CHAOS
description: A kind of shiver, the thrill of the unexpected, seemed to sweep through this country when President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, turned to a longtime conservative political rival, Mayor Jacques Chirac of Paris, to form a new government after legislative elections here.

title: ROCKY MOUNT UNDERGARMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: FRANZESE ENTERS A PLEA OF GUILTY TO RACKETEERING
description: Michael J. Franzese, a reputed organized-crime figure, pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal racketeering and tax conspiracy charges. Under a plea agreement, he will be sentenced to 10 years in prison and 5 years' probation, and will have to pay nearly $15 million in fines, forfeiture and restitution.

title: LEWIS GALOOB TOYS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TRACES OF POISON LEAD TO RECALL OF THREE DRUGS
description: A leading drug company today ordered an immediate recall of capsules of Contac cold medicine and two other popular over-the-counter drugs after eight capsules were found with trace amounts of rat poison.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Autos IMSA 12 Hours of Sebring. (Television - WTBS, 10:35 A.M. preview and beginning of the race and hourly updates.) Baseball Mets vs. Atlanta Braves, at West Palm Beach, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 1:35 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami, 7:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 7:14 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Houston Rockets, at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. (Television - MSG, 7:50 P.M. Radio - WPAT 930, 8 P.M.) Nets vs. 76ers, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.) N.C.A.A. West Regional final, at Houston: Auburn vs. Louisville (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Southeast Regional final, at Atlanta: Kentucky vs. Louisiana State (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) N.C.A.A. Division II men's championships, at Springfield, Mass. (Television - ESPN, 12:30 A.M. tape). N.C.A.A. Division II women's championships, at Springfield, Mass. (Television -ESPN, 3 A.M. tape). Women: N.C.A.A. Division I East Regional final, at Philadelphia: Rutgers vs. Western Kentucky. (Television - ESPN, noon); Division I Mideast Regional final, at Iowa City (Television - ESPN, 6 P.M.); Division I Midwest Regional final, at Austin, Tex. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Division I West Regional final, at Long Beach, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M.) High Schools: New York State Public High Schools Athletic Association tournament, at Glens Falls: Hempstead of Long Island vs. Binghamton and Lincoln of Brooklyn vs. Archbishop Molloy of Queens. Boxing Pinklon Thomas, champion, vs.

title: WITNESS AGAINST GOTTI IS SAID TO BE HOSPITALIZED
description: A Queens man who disappeared before he was to testify Thursday that he had been assaulted and robbed by a reputed organized-crime leader was reported yesterday to be in a hospital and ''will be available Monday,'' the prosecutor in the case said.

title: U.S. SAYS NO DEALS ON 'STARS WARS'
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he had told NATO defense ministers assembled here that the Reagan Administration's space defense research program would not be abandoned in order to reach an arms control agreement with the Soviet Union.

title: MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BIRD SONGS RETURN, AND CASH REGISTERS RING
description: Spring is sprung, The grass is riz, I wonder where the birdies is. Anon. Whether to watch the wood warblers' migration to Long Island Sound or to view the arrival of red-winged blackbirds at Cape May, N.J., bird watchers these days are engaging in their own spring ritual.

title: AN ELECTRICAL FAILING
description: The new budget-balancing law bids fair to overtake original sin and the ever-popular computer crash as the all-purpose excuse for all sorts of failings in Washington these days.

title: RECOVERED WRECKAGE OF SHUTTLE IS SAID TO BE FROM RIGHT ROCKET
description: The leader of the recovery team in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger said today that a quarter-ton piece of the orbiter recovered this week was ''most probably'' part of the right solid-fuel booster rocket. But he said it did not contain the section suspected of initiating the explosion.

title: KEY SECTIONS OF TESTIMONY AT HEARING ON CHALLENGER DISASTER
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of hearings on the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger held by a Presidential investigative panel yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC Radio News:

title: BIFOCAL CONTACT LENSES
description: IN theory, bifocal contact lenses would seem to be the perfect solution for people whose vision has changed with the years, but whose vision of themselves does not include bifocals or, for that matter, spectacles of any sort.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Net income.

title: Packwood Sees Defeat Of Bond Tax Proposal
description: Senator Bob Packwood, the chairman of the Finance Committee, acknowledged today that the committee would probably reject his proposal to place a minimum tax on all income from municipal bonds received by wealthy people with low tax rates.

title: WITH AIDS ABOUT, HETEROSEXUALS ARE RETHINKING CASUAL SEX
description: The eyes of Ellen Parks scanned C. J. Bretts, a popular singles bar and restaurant in the Hermosa Beach section of Los Angeles: soft rock music, schooners of beer, sports stars framed on the walls.

title: MINOR FINANCIAL IMPACT FORECAST FOR SMITHKLINE
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation, the latest in a series of companies to undergo the trauma of product tampering, would face minimal financial problems if sales of its encapsulated over-the-counter drug products had to be halted for a long period of time, Wall Street analysts said yesterday.

title: Retrial Planned In Fire Fatal to 24
description: A man who pleaded guilty to and was convicted of murder in a 1974 fire that killed 24 people at a discotheque -only to have each overturned - will be tried again, the Westchester County district attorney's office said today.

title: Guy Nearing Is Dead at 96; Author and Horticulturist
description: Guy Nearing, a writer and horticulturist, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Community Hospital in Troy, Pa. He was 96 years old and lived in Ulster, Pa.

title: GUEST FOUND SLAIN AT MARRIOTT
description: A Miami man was found slain Thursday in his $200-a-day room at the Marriott Marquis Hotel near Times Square, the police said yesterday.

title: 2 STUDENTS DIE IN FALLS FROM FLORIDA BALCONIES
description: Two college students fell from hotel balconies to their deaths in separate incidents.

title: APARTHEID'S VICTIMS
description: MATING BIRDS. By Lewis Nkosi. 184 pages. St. Martin's Press. $13.95. ''In a few days I am to die. Strange, the idea neither shocks nor frightens me. What I feel most frequently now is a kind of numbness, a total lack of involvement in my own fate, as though I were an observer watching the last days in the life of another man.'' So begins Lewis Nkosi's ''Mating Birds,'' and the echoes of ''The Stranger'' by Albert Camus that vibrate through these first sentences, it turns out, will be sustained throughout the novel.

title: Continental Illinois Files an Offering
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said it had filed a registration statement to make a $150 million public note offering. The offering, which will be managed by Goldman, Sachs & Company, would be Continental's first offering since its banking subsidiary, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, was saved from collapse in 1985 by a $4.5 billion Federal rescue plan.

title: 2 Promoted By A.M.C.
description: Directors of the American Motors Corporation today promoted the company's president, Jose Dedeurwaerder, to vice chairman and promoted its chief operating officer, Joseph Cappy, to president and chief executive.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including income from a minority shareholders interest of $21,095. c-Including income from minority shareholders' interests of $104,314. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend in August 1985.

title: Making the Grade
description: He had to overcome the effects of a heart attack, a stroke and phlebitis, and he needed a wheelchair to get into St. John Arena, but when he got there yesterday, Woody Hayes stood and gave 1,700 winter graduates of Ohio State a pep talk they're not likely to forget.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Bond prices fell slightly yesterday in dull trading, but the 30-year bond yield remained under 8 percent. Analysts said the market's performance was good considering the uncertainties regarding the efforts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise prices.

title: Kaiser Aluminum In Credit Pact
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had signed a new credit agreement that consolidates into a single debt agreement its total bank debt of about $1 billion, which had been previously covered under a variety of agreements with approximately 40 domestic and foreign banks. The new agreement also provides for a $165 million, four-year revolving credit, the company said.

title: SOME CONTRA AID IS EXPECTED TO PASS
description: Congressional leaders agreed today that lawmakers would eventually approve some form of military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. But they said major battles remained to be fought in the weeks ahead over how the aid would be used, and what restrictions would be placed on the Administration's actions in Central America.

title: U.S. TO CONDUCT UNDERGROUND NUCLEAR TEST TODAY
description: The United States will conduct an underground nuclear test on Saturday, its first in nearly three months, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET AGREE TO EXCHANGE TECHNICIANS
description: China and the Soviet Union formally agreed today on an exchange of engineers and technicians.

title:
PATENTS;
Dialer Picks Program For 'Music on Hold'
description: In 1966, Alfred Levy received a patent to permit music to be played while a telephone call was put on hold.

title: On The Record
description: With the National Hockey League regular season drawing to a close, Denis Potvin, the Islander defenseman, is closing in on another record. Potvin, who had four assists against the Toronto Maple Leafs Tuesday, is just four assists away from tying Brad Park's N.H.L. career record for most assists by a defenseman, 683.

title: Suicide Essay Writer Buried
description: A boy who wrote about a homesick youngster's suicide in a school essay and then carried out the act himself was buried in a simple ceremony today.

title: POCKETBOOK ISSUES
description: Faced with an economic picture considerably rosier than in the Carter years and with a President politically invulnerable much of the time, worried Democrats have been casting about for strong domestic issues to raise in this year's Congressional elections. Increasingly, they are settling on two: the trade imbalance and the farm crisis. Both are pocketbook problems, and the farm issue in particular is fraught with emotion.

title: Swastika Painting Is Laid to Vandals
description: Spray-painted swastikas and anti-Semitic remarks have been found on a stone wall near the Greenwich, Conn., home of Harry Helmsley, the New York City real-estate developer.

title: Devils Set Victory Mark
description: Mel Bridgman, Pat Verbeek and Uli Hiemer all scored in the third period tonight to lead the Devils to a 6-3 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres. The Devils scored the last five goals of the game to end a six-game losing streak and post their first victory against the Sabres after having had a 0-9-2 record.

title: NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $73,527 for the quarter and $357,203 for the year and tax credits of $28,000 and $138,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After capital losses of $2,759,828 for the quarter and $2,847,447 for the year.

title: ARAB TERRORISTS CLAIM PARIS ARCADE BOMBING
description: An Arab group demanding the release of three terrorists from French prisons took responsibility today for a bombing that killed 2 people and wounded 28 at a shopping center on the Champs-Elysees.

title: FILM: 'GoBots,' A TV SPINOFF
description: ''You are a sight for sore optical receptors,'' exclaims Nuggit, a good-hearted robot, to his human allies during a brief lull in the battles that make up most of the animated feature, ''GoBots: Battle of the Rock Lords.'' The remark is one of the few glimmerings of wit in this extended cartoon spinoff of a television series that features cute toy extraterrestrials who can change shape at will to become air and motor vehicles.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said costs associated with the closure of 27 Oregon stores continued to impact fourth quarter results. These costs totaled $987,000 in the quarter.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method to Apply Private Labels
description: Susan E. Farrelly of New York, who has worked extensively in the apparel industry, and George Spector were granted patent 4,576,668 this week for a way to apply private labels to manufactured goods. A tag with a heat-activated bonding agent is sewed inside the garment, and the label placed on it is fastened in place by squeezing with a heated tool.

title: THE ANCHOR IS NOT THE NEWS
description: ''Trusted More. Voted Best.'' No, the full-page advertisement in major newspapers is not promoting a politician who aspires to higher office. CBS is beating the drums for Dan Rather as ''the nation's best network news anchor.'' The ad claims he is ''Number one,'' and cites independent polls to ratify his standing as ''one of the most trusted men in America today.'' His larger than life-size photograph smiles broadly at us, square-jawed, confident in the knowledge that ''Clearly, when America makes a choice, it's not by chance.''

title: RESTAURANTS TOO SHOULD LIST FOOD INGREDIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SIX
description: A creature applying for a job asserted that it was a male human. This office called attention to the ''Warning of Hideous Penalties for Making False Statements on Application Forms.''

title: IN JAPAN, A 'HAMLET' SET IN '45
description: The stage is set for 1945 Japan, and the lights dimly illuminate a scene of destruction and desolation. Enter Hamlet, clad in khakis, a rising sun emblazoned on his sleeve. The melancholy Dane is lost in postwar Japan, a world reduced to rubble and despair.

title: A PROFILE OF GIVERS
description: The most generous contributors to religion and charities in the United States tend to be 50 to 64 years old, married or widowed, with college degrees and professional careers, according to a national study.

title: ROSENKRANZ TEAM REPEATS HISTORY AT SPRING NATIONALS
description: History repeated itself in the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams here Thursday night at the American Contract Bridge League Spring Nationals.

title: NAVY JETS TO FLY OVER LIBYA GULF
description: The Navy intends to fly combat aircraft on training exercises over the Gulf of Sidra near Libya during a 10-day period beginning Saturday night, a Pentagon spokesman disclosed tonight.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. IS WARY ON EASTERN AIR MERGER
description: The Department of Justice said today that the proposed merger of Texas Air and Eastern Airlines ''raises concerns about reduced competition in the airline industry,'' especially in the Northeast.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. The engagement of Prince Andrew of Britain to Sarah Ferguson ended speculation about whom he would marry. 2. Because conservatives won a majority in legislative elections, President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, appointed a Prime Minister with an opposing political philosophy. 3.

title: L.I. TOWN SEEKS ON GROWTH BAN FOR ITS SURVIVAL
description: In the two decades since office buildings began sprouting here along Route 110, a four-lane, north-south highway, Melville's main drag has become the Main Street of Long Island's economy. But now, town officials are preparing to bring the development to a halt.

title: IUD Verdict Won by Searle
description: A Federal District judge in Baltimore today granted a verdict in favor of G.D. Searle & Company in a case in which 17 plaintiffs sued the company, charging it with producing a defective copper intrauterine contraceptive.

title: OPEC HAS AGREEMENT, BUT NO PLAN, ON CURBS
description: Oil ministers from OPEC and non-OPEC countries announced today that they would seek to re-establish a price of $28 for a barrel of crude oil. But they said they had failed to agree on specific measures to achieve that goal.

title: SUNBELT NURSERY reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
DOLE SEEKS TALKS ON BUDGET PLAN
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, today told the White House chief of staff, Donald T. Regan, that he wanted to open discussions on the 1987 budget approved in the Senate Budget Committee this week.

title: MORGAN STANLEY'S STOCK SOARS TO BIG PREMIUM
description: Shares of the Morgan Stanley Group soared to a huge premium yesterday in the initial public offering of the holding company for one of the nation's most prestigious investment firms.

title: Ballesteros Trailing by 7
description: Seve Ballesteros opened with three bogeys in his first four holes today, then played par over the next 14 holes to score three-over-par 75 in his first round of golf on the PGA Tour this year. This put the 28-year-old Spaniard seven shots off the first-round lead of four-under-par 68 shared by Calvin Peete and Nick Faldo of England in the USF&G Classic at the cold and windy Lakewood Country Club.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After reserves of $800,000 for nonrecurring charges. The losses also include losses of $1.2 million for the quarter and $2 million for the year from a decontamination plant. The loss for the fiscal 1986 year is after a pre-tax gain of $2.4 million from sale and leaseback of headquarters facility.

title: COMSTOCK GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HERITAGE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ohio State in Semifinal
description: Dennis Hopson scored 16 points and Brad Sellers had 15 tonight to lead Ohio State to a 79-68 victory over Brigham Young in a quarterfinal of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: THE ACCOMPLICE CORROBORATION RULE IMPEDES CORRUPTION CASES
description: To the Editor:

title: A FORMER PRESIDENT OF SETON HALL
description: The Rev. John J. Dougherty, retired Auxiliary Bishop of Newark and a former president of Seton Hall University, died Thursday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. Bishop Dougherty, who was 78 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J., had suffered a stroke in 1980.

title: Atalanta Lists Triangle Stake
description: A group of investors led by the New York-based investment adviser Atalanta Sosnoff Capital Corporation said that it held the equivalent of 2,246,771 Triangle Industries common shares, or 39.9 percent of the New Brunswick, N.J., company's shares outstanding. In a filing with the S.E.C., the investment group said it had purchased the shares ''solely for investment.''

title: TANKER SPILLS OIL IN DELAWARE RIVER
description: A Liberian tanker spilled up to 84,000 gallons of crude oil into the Delaware River today after hitting a pier here and putting a 30-foot gash in its hull, the Coast Guard said.

title: OSCAR RACE BIGGEST TOSSUP IN YEARS
description: ''Prizzi's Honor'' has the Oscar for best picture sewed up, says a studio executive, because ''The Color Purple'' and ''Out of Africa'' will cancel each other out.

title: DEPT. OF GREAT COMMUNICATORS
description: It is Ronald Reagan who is known as the Great Communicator. But in the capital, the Government communicator with what is probably the longest and most comprehensive tenure is Walter R. Roberts, a career bureaucrat and diplomat.

title: April Meeting Canceled By Broadcasting Board
description: The 10 directors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, five of whose terms end next Wednesday, have canceled their April meeting, at which efforts could have been made to elect a new chairman.

title: FUDDRUCKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $3.4 million for losses anticipated on disposition of certain restaurants and a charge of $700,000 from its franchise restructuring. c-Net income.

title: Boston Loses Jones
description: Steve Jones, the world's top-ranked marathoner, has withdrawn from the 1986 Boston Marathon, citing a slow-healing injury. Jones, who had previously withdrawn from the world cross-country championships in Switzerland tomorrow, developed tendinitis after placing a disappointing 15th in a 10-kilometer race in Phoenix March 1. He had hoped that a regimen of light training would allow him to recover in time for the Boston race April 21, but the injury persisted and he was forced to withdraw, marathon officials said yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
Device to Fight Fires In Tall Buildings
description: What the inventor calls a Walking Elevator, designed to fight fires in high buildings, was patented this week by John P. Zima of Newhall, Calif. Patent 4,576,249 explains that the elevator consists of a pair of platforms that will lift firefighters and rescue people trapped in a building.

title: SATELLITE MUSIC NETWORK INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $157,717, or 2 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: In Dante Park
description: ''Lovers' Bench,'' a sculpture that attracted some controversy when it was displayed in the lobby of the Penta Hotel, is getting a public airing in Dante Park, the triangular sliver on Broadway opposite Lincoln Center.

title: Close Quarters
description: Jay Seltzer, president of the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, is awaiting the release in mid-April of the National Football League's schedule for the 1986 season. When he has it, he will try to resolve the problem facing Donald Trump's team: where to play its nine-game home schedule this fall beginning in mid-September.

title: JOY AT EXPORT-IMPORT BANK
description: To the muted delight of the people at the Export-Import Bank, James C. Miller 3d has accepted an ivitation to deliver the keynote address at the annual exporters' conference of the bank next Tuesday at the Capital Hilton. Mr. Miller's predecessor as director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, David A. Stockman, not to put too fine a point on it, would not have been caught dead at such a conference. He considered the bank an unlocked vault for big corporations and sought to terminate its existence in one budget recommendation after the other. J. Russell Boner, the Export-Import Bank's vice president for public affairs, said the keynote acceptance was ''a very encouraging sign to us.''

title: WINNIE MANDELA URGES MORE DEFIANCE
description: Winnie Mandela and other black leaders called today for increased defiance of the white authorities.

title: Mayor Suggests U.S. Eliminate $100 Bills
description: With the Treasury Department announcing changes this week in paper money to combat counterfeiting, Mayor Koch has sent the White House a currency proposal of his own: the recall and elimination of the $100 bill.

title: TIME TO MAKE BANKS SPEED CHECK-CLEARING
description: To the Editor:

title: 3COM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Results for the latest third quarter and nine months include the effect of expenses related to the proposed merger of 3Com and Converted Technologies Inc.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page incorrectly described a television appearance by Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, the President's adviser on national security. He appeared Wednesday on the ABC program ''Good Morning America.''

title: 400 Mourn for a Child Left Dead Beside Road
description: Nearly 400 people attended services today for an unidentified boy whose body was found last Christmas Eve near a country road here.

title: LEO KOBRIN
description: Leo Kobrin, an owner of Kobrin Brothers, a Manhattan jewelry concern that closed in 1971, died of a heart attack March 13 at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Tire Import Drop Cited
description: Tire imports dropped in January, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company reported today, and the company said a sluggish economy and not a stronger dollar brought about the decline.

title: CHATHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FILM: 'POLICE ACADEMY 3: BACK IN TRAINING' OPENS
description: The gang from ''Police Academy'' (1984) and ''Police Academy 2'' (1985) carry on rudely and with a lot of good, low humor in ''Police Academy 3: Back in Training,'' written by Gene Quintano and directed by Jerry Paris.

title: NONCHALANTLY, MAYOR CHIRAC STEPS OUT IN A DIFFERENT HAT
description: Jacques Chirac's first official act since becoming Prime Minister was on Thursday evening, when he visited the scene of a terrorist bombing at the Champs-Elysees.

title: VOICEMAIL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: KENZO RAINBOW LIGHTS UP PARIS OPENINGS
description: Kenzo Takada established a joyous mood on the first day of the fall and winter ready-to-wear openings here as he showed what was probably his best collection in years. It had a lively but unpretentious look and was filled with brilliant color.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:17 A.M. today and set at 11:48 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 3:13 A.M. and set at 11:35 A.M.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch by The Associated Press on Feb. 23, about Navy efforts to apprehend deserters, misstated the military laws involved. There is a three-year limitation on filing formal charges of desertion, but thereafter there is no time limit for apprehending and trying a desertion suspect.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
POP: 'BASS DESIRES' QUARTET
description: Bass Desires is led by its bassist, Marc Johnson. But at the quartet's late set Wednesday, in a two-night stand at Fat Tuesday's marking the release of its debut album, the music revolved around the guitarists Bill Frisell and John Scofield.

title: SHELTER PAINT HAZARDS CONFIRMED
description: An expert hired by the city said yesterday that he had found numerous lead-paint hazards at a city shelter for homeless families in lower Manhattan.

title: HOMANS REVISES OFFER FOR ALAMITO
description: The Alamito Company, a Tucson, Ariz., electricity wholesaler that is the subject of a bidding contest, said it had received a revised merger proposal that was valued at $357.5 million by Homans McGraw Trull Valeo & Company, a Boston-based investment bank.

title:
PATENTS;
New Thermometer
description: An optical fiber thermometer, made of a single crystal aluminum oxide, was patented this week by Ray R. Dils of Vancouver, Wash. He assigned patent 4,576,486 to the Commerce Department, the parent agency of the National Bureau of Standards. Mr. Dils is a former staff member of the bureau. Tests show the invention should prove useful for measurement and control of high temperatures in gas turbines and internal combustion engines, as well as in chemical processes.

title: LAW FIRM DISMISSED BY ROBINS
description: The A. H. Robins Company, which went into bankruptcy proceedings last summer because of mounting legal problems related to its Dalkon Shield birth-control device, announced yesterday that it had dismissed the law firm handling the bankruptcy.

title: STOCKER & YALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including $230,000, or 17 cents a share, from the reversal of deferred taxes on DISC income.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HOSPITAL AIDES ARE SUSPENDED IN ABUSE CASE
description: Fifteen therapy aides at a state institution for the mentally retarded have been suspended after allegations that patients there were abused, officials said yesterday. The Brooklyn District Attorney's office is investigating the allegations.

title: MANILA OPENS INQUIRY ON GRAVES
description: The Aquino Government announced today that it is investigating reports of mass graves containing the bodies of foes of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos or his allies.

title: RESTAURANTS TOO SHOULD LIST FOOD INGREDIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1986
description: International

title: OPERA: PAVAROTTI IN 'AIDA' AT THE MET
description: THERE is a tradition among opera tenors that encourages them to think of their vocal talent as a bank. A specific amount of voice is put on deposit early in life and is spent little by little until only at an advanced age, it is hoped, will the balance read zero.
