Some such thinking must explain why great lyric tenors such as Beniamino Gigli and Jussi Bjoerling felt it necessary or advisable to move from light roles into progressively heavier parts in their later years. Both, for instance, eventually took on Radames in ''Aida,'' one of the more taxing roles in the Italian repertory, though their voices never did come to sound at home in such hefty music.

title: OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $278,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Legislator Admits Guilt in Sex Case
description: Assemblyman Richard S. Ruggiero, Democrat of Utica, pleaded guilty today to a felony count of attempted sexual abuse in connection with an incident involving a teen-ager at his office here last Jan. 3.

title: GENERAL DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $114,000.

title: ROBINSON SINKS CLEVELAND STATE, 71-70; DUKE ROLLS DEPAUL ELIMINATED BY 74-67
description: In the clutch, versatile Duke displayed its No. 1-ranked form tonight as it wound up with the loose balls, got the second rebounds and made the tough second-half baskets in beating DePaul, 74-67.

title: 2 Correction Officials Will Be Leaving Posts
description: The chief of operations of the City Department of Correction and the official in charge of the Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island yesterday indicated that they will retire, a department spokesman said.

title: INMATE EXECUTED IN ALABAMA PRISON
description: Inmates shouted and clanged on prison bars today as Arthur Lee Jones Jr. was led to the electric chair and executed for shooting a cab driver to death in a robbery.

title: Preventive Measures
description: Addressing the issue of collegiate athletic corruption for the first time since his own school was found guilty of 59 football recruiting violations in 1984, Marshall Criser, the president of the University of Florida, called on the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday to ban freshmen from varsity athletics and adopt other reforms designed to remove students ''from the pressure-cooker of intercollegiate athletics'' and improve graduation rates. In addition, Criser said the N.C.A.A. should allow schools to give academically unprepared student athletes scholarship money for the summer before their freshman year. It was the first time Criser had spoken out on the issue since Florida's football program was banned from television and bowl games in 1984.

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including tax credits of $180,000 for the quarter and $415,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $14,000 for the quarter and $60,000 for the 9 months and tax credits of $135,000 and $725,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: OPPENHEIMER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago year figures reflect the acquisition of two companies in mid-year.

title: PHILADELPHIA TRANSIT SERVICE RESTORED AFTER 5-DAY STRIKE
description: The city's buses, subways and trolleys were back in full force today after transit workers ended a five-day strike.

title: CIVIL-JUSTICE ABUSE SKEWS THE CYCLE
description: To the Editor:

title: THOMPSON KNOWS PERSON'S LETDOWN
description: For the last week, Billy Thompson Louisville's 6-foot-7-inch senior forward, has been reading, with curiosity and a touch of amusement, about Chuck Person, Auburn's 6-8 senior forward, and Person's personal quest for national credibility.

title: WINGS WEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $161,000 for the quarter and $700,000 for the 9 months. c-After tax credits of $47,000 for the quarter and $754,000 for the 9 months.

title: FRENCH RIGHT PLANS BROAD CHANGES
description: The new conservative coalition Government led by Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has taken office already committed to a far-reaching program of economic and electoral change.

title: South African Debt Revision
description: South Africa's lead bankers will propose to the rest of the country's creditors certain changes in a debt-rescheduling agreement reached last month, industry sources in London said.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

PATENTS;
Detecting Drugs in The Body
description: DR. S. THOMAS WESTERMAN, an ear, nose and throat specialist in Shrewsbury, N.J., was granted a patent this week for his non-invasive method of detecting a drug, such as cocaine, heroin or alcohol, ingested by an individual.

title: DREAMING OF FAME AND FORTUNE ON A POGO STICK
description: At 2:06 P.M. yesterday, a ''sea creature'' was spotted in New York waters - the Central Queens Y.M.C.A. swimming pool in Jamaica, to be more precise - by children in the Polliwog and Guppy swim classes, who were scared half out of their wits.

title: U.N. CRITICIZES IRAQ ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The Security Council today issued a statement in which it strongly condemned the continued use of chemical weapons by Iraq.

title: Bouncing Back To the Majors
description: When Steve Boros was dismissed as manager by Oakland in 1984, he vowed to never again manage except on the major league level. When he signed with the San Diego Padres later that year as coordinator of their minor league instructional program, the prospects for a return to the dugout did not seem rosey. Guess who will lead the team in 1986?

title: SWISS BANKS CAUTIONED
description: The Swiss federal banking commission, in an unusual move, issued a statement today cautioning the nation's banks that they faced possible legal complications growing out of the handling of any transfers of money in accounts held by Mr. Marcos or his representatives.

title: MUSCLE-FLEXING AT THE FED
description: The dust-up at the Federal Reserve Board over the recent cut in interest rates may properly reflect a Washington power balance, but such reckless muscle-flexing also risked economic damage. Vice Chairman Preston Martin, perpetrator of the fiasco, is right to resign.

title: LILCO AND FRIENDS PRESS FOR SHOREHAM IN ADS
description: In one newspaper advertisement, Eena-Mai Franz, a gray-haired woman of distinguished mien who is also a nuclear chemist, gazes sympathetically at the reader and asks, ''Are you concerned about the safety of Shoreham?''

title: Girardelli Wins 2d World Cup Title
description: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg won his second consecutive World Cup overall ski racing title today when the only man who could overtake him came up short.

title: U.S. AIDES REJECT REAGAN-BONNER MEETING
description: House officials decided against a meeting between President Reagan and Yelena G. Bonner, wife of the Soviet critic, Andrei D. Sakharov, because such a session could set back United States efforts to win freedom for Soviet dissidents, Administration officials said today.

title: REPUTED MOB LEADER AMONG 15 INDICTED ON RACKETEERING COUNTS
description: A reputed Mafia boss and 14 men described as associates were named yesterday in a Federal indictment charging extensive labor racketeering, construction bid-rigging, extortion, gambling and murder conspiracies.

title: DATA ARCHITECTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $108,000.

title: Caracas in Oil Push Abroad
description: Continuing its program of internationalization, the state oil company is negotiating possible investments in five overseas marketing and distributing companies, according to press reports.

title: GONE TODAY, GONE TOMORROW
description: New York, above all, is a city of change. The skyline expands, buildings come and go. Even when structures stay the same, the businesses in them don't. Even a weekend away can bring the loss of a favorite restaurant.

title: CALIFORNIAN DENIES FUNNELING MARCOS MONEY
description: A San Francisco physician who is under scrutiny as a possible channel of illegal contributions from Ferdinand E. Marcos to American politicians says he was ''the eyes and ears'' of Mr. Marcos here but denies making any illicit political donations.

title: A ROSE IN SPRINGTIME
description: A young left-handed pitcher named Rob Murphy tells a story about his manager, Pete Rose.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Health column in The Living Section on March 12 misstated the incidence of sickle-cell anemia in relation to the incidence of Marfan's syndrome. Sickle-cell anemia afflicts 40,000 to 50,000 Americans, twice the number with Marfan's syndrome.

title: A RECORD FALLS
description: Sometime early today, attendance at the ''Treasure Houses of Britain'' exhibition at the National Gallery of Art is expected to surpass the museum's record of 835,000 visitors now held by the 1976-77 show of Tutankhamun (also known as King Tut). A museum spokesman said that despite the pending record, crowds this week were not as great as earlier in the exhibit, suggesting that the word has still not spread that it has been extended to April 13.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MARTIN RESIGNING FROM FED
description: Preston Martin, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and President Reagan's first appointee to the board, announced today that he was resigning.

title: Plumber Fined
description: Arizona authorities ruled yesterday that the gas explosion that rocked the Brewers' new spring training clubhouse last month had been caused by the improper training of a plumber who had not been told to open doors and windows before discharging natural gas into the clubhouse. The decision by the Arizona Industrial Commission, which fined the Comfort Plumbing Company $640, came a day after Federal safety investigators told the commission that the mishap had been inadvertently caused by a Comfort plumber, Jeff Sutton. The only blast victim who remains hospitalized is Tony Muser, a Brewer coach.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Senate Opens Trust Study
description: The Senate opened hearings today on the White House's far-ranging antitrust proposals and heard Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York say that all 50 state attorneys general oppose the Administration's proposal to narrow triple-damage awards to antitrust lawsuits involving bid-rigging and price-fixing.

title: NICARAGUA LOW-KEY ON AID VOTE
description: Although the House of Representatives on Thursday rejected President Reagan's proposal to renew aid to the rebels in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government has not claimed a victory.

title: Company Indicted In Man's Death
description: A plating company and its vice president have been indicted in the death of a man who was overcome by fumes from a chemical the company purportedly discharged into the Woodbury sewer system, authorities announced today.

title: Woman Is Proposed For the Harmonie Club
description: ''We're fully prepared,'' the gentlemanly manager of the Harmonie Club, Frank E. Saris, said. ''We're ready to step into 1986.'' The occasion of Mr. Saris's proclamation is the proposal of a woman for membership in the all-male club, which was founded in 1852 by German Jewish immigrants and is the second oldest social club in the city.

title: REMEMER THE ALAMO: NOT MYTH
description: When Texas history buffs recently gathered in San Antonio to remember the fall of the Alamo, in commemoration of the battle that took place 150 years ago within the walls of the old Spanish mission, participants re-enacted the famous scene in which Col. William Barret Travis supposedly traced a line in the dirt and said: ''Those of you who are willing to stay with me and die with me, cross this line.''

title: JOHNSON SETS ROSTER DEADLINE
description: With just over two weeks to go before the season starts, Manager Dave Johnson gave his Mets a collective grade of A-minus today. But he said that the time had come to make several critical decisions to determine which 24 or 25 players would go north.

title: Celtics Clinch Division Title
description: The Boston Celtics built a 22-point halftime lead behind Larry Bird's 24 points and Kevin McHale's 22 points on way to defeating the Chicago Bulls, 126-105, tonight to clinch the Atlantic Division title.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
E.P.A. TO MOVE AGAINST COMPANY IN TESTING OF A GENETIC CHEMICAL
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will take action against a California biotechnology company that it has accused of violating Federal policies on the release of genetically altered farm chemicals into the environment, a spokesman said today.

title: MANDLIKOVA GAINS SEMIFINAL
description: Hana Mandlikova played frantically, bursting with a nervous energy that she said was difficult to control. On occasion, she was enthusiastic to a fault, slamming a ball into the loge seats at Madison Square Garden in a fit of pique during her match against Claudia Kohde-Kilsch, and uttering an obscenity.

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $252,000 and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $44,000. c-Net income and after loss from discontinued operations of $7,000 and a tax credit of $311,000.

title: KOCH CALLS FOR ANTISMOKING LAW: TERMS IT NATION'S MOST STRINGENT
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday that smoking be outlawed in a wide range of public places in New York City and that private employers be required to provide no-smoking work areas for employees who want them.

title: RESTAURANTS TOO SHOULD LIST FOOD INGREDIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Luring I.R.A.'s To New Plans
description: INDIVIDUALS can open or add to Individual Retirement Accounts at any time of the year, but about two-thirds do so between Jan. 1 and April 15. Most of the new I.R.A. money, moreover, will arrive at banks, mutual funds, insurance companies and other institutions in the last four weeks of the period, as the various retirement account trustees step up their marketing efforts to attract more funds.

title: TV: 'WITNESS TO REVOLUTION,' ANNA LOUISE STRONG
description: Speak no ill of the dead, we are told, but that does not mean we have to make things up. ''Witness to Revolution: The Story of Anna Louise Strong'' does not just apologize for Miss Strong; it presents her as something she never was. In real life, she was a press agent for some of this century's least attractive people. In the 30-minute documentary, on Channel 13 at 3:30 this afternoon, she was ''a woman ahead of her time.'' History is turned upside down.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LA BELLE BRONX The Bronx, which many point out is the only part of New York City on the United States mainland, has a wide diversity of structures, which include Georgian colonial farmhouses, Queen Anne row houses, Art Deco apartment houses, a Byzantine-style church, a 19th-century manor house, a Hudson River castle, the Edgar Allan Poe Cottage, the Valentine-Varian House and the Snuff Mill.

title: THE SCREEN: 'HAMBURGER'
description: If the Food and Drug Administration labeled movies, the warning on ''Hamburger'' might be that it is likely to cause heartburn. This hamburger-handed movie, which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner and other theaters, takes place at Busterburger University, where aspiring Busterburger franchisers learn everything there is to know about bulls and buns, customers and ketchup.

title: FAILURE OF JOINT ACCEPTED BY NASA AS DISASTER CAUSE
description: NASA officials testified today that a failure in a joint on a solid-fuel booster rocket was the probable cause of the explosion that destroyed the shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, killing its crew of seven.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR SWEETENS ADVERSITY
description: The way some of his supporters see it, Gov. Mark White has a chance to make the most of adversity.

title: PANEL CUTS RETIREMENT PAY TO KEEP PEOPLE IN MILITARY
description: The House Armed Services Committee, seeking to induce experienced people to remain on duty, has voted to reduce the pensions of future military personnel who retire after 20 years of service, Representative Les Aspin announced today.

title: KANSAS, WOLFPACK SURVIVE
description: The ability to cope with the crises of the national collegiate basketball tournament determined the two teams that tonight won the chance to play for the Midwest Regional championship and a spot in the Final Four.

title: WHOLESALE CLUB reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
U.S. Deficit Up Sharply
description: The Federal budget deficit surged to $24.58 billion in February, four times higher than the January imbalance, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BURNS WILL MISS ENTIRE SEASON, STEINBRENNER SAYS
description: Britt Burns, the left-handed pitcher the Yankees had considered their key to capturing a division title, will not pitch for the team this season and may never pitch again, George Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief report in Weekend yesterday about a piano recital by Peter Serkin tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall listed the time incorrectly. It will begin at 7:30 P.M.

title: EDUCATION, A POWERFUL DRUG-USE PREVENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: SECOND THOUGHTS ON RADIO MARTI
description: Our March 12 editorial, ''Cruel and Unusual Banishment,'' was unfair to Radio Marti, the U.S. Information Agency station that has been broadcasting to Cuba since May 1985. Contrary to our statement, the station appears to have found a responsive audience and filled a void in Cubans' information.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
KOCH TO SEEK AMENDMENTS TO HOMOSEXUAL RIGHTS BILL
description: Mayor Koch, hoping to calm continuing opposition to the homosexual rights bill the City Council approved Thursday, will seek two amendments to clarify what the measure can and cannot do.

title: THE IMPACT OF AMERICAN STYLE
description: Step into the closet or open the bureau drawers, and there they are, as diverse and yet somehow as united as the 50 states themselves. They are the constant classics that have come to define a uniquely American style, clothes undisturbed by the chimerical gusts that often pass for ''fashion.'' Button-down shirts and natural-shouldered suits, dungarees and cowboy hats, crew-neck sweaters and madras sports jackets, saddle shoes and Western boots, emblem-patterned golf trousers and kaleidoscopic surfing trunks, jogging suits and Top-Siders.

title: WASTE MAKES HASTE IN HIRING TO CONTROL IT
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency estimates that American industry, which works with more than 400 highly toxic chemicals, annually produces more than a ton of liquid and solid hazardous waste per citizen. A growing public awareness of environmental concerns and a series of chilling experiences in the last two decades has hardened public attitudes toward such substances and how to dispose of them.

title: Women of Influence?
description: How do women influence the way men dress? As men gain a fashion consciousness all their own, how many women still shop for their mates or set their styles for them? Are wives and women friends helpful in the face of the exhilarating, confusing and sometimes even paralyzing numbers of options deemed acceptable in male attire today? The answers are as varied as the ways men dress. Herewith, responses from the wives of nine well-known men. Susan Weitz on her husband, fashion designer John Weitz (above): ''How do you influence someone who knows what he wants? I don't think the wife of a designer can ever tell him how to dress. How do you buy for a man who has his name on things? I wouldn't hesitate to speak up, but I quite like his taste.'' According to Elaine Crispin, the press secretary to President Reagan's wife, Nancy (above), the President calls even a 15-year-old suit ''new.'' ''Mrs. Reagan said, 'When I hear him say that, I might suggest that it's time to order a new suit or two.' '' The fashion designer Liz Claiborne on her husband and business partner, Art Ortenberg: ''I have absolutely no influence whatsoever!'' The actor/producer Michael Douglas's wife, Diandra, says, ''He has a strong sense of his own style, but I have opinions about what becomes him most. When you're married to someone, you never tell them not to wear something. You can suggest it might not be as becoming as something else.

title: JULIA BERMUDEZ WEDS GEORGE NORMAN BUXTON
description: Julia Aurora Bermudez and George Norman Buxton were married yesterday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. Armando Bermudez of Santiago, the Dominican Republic. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by Cardinal Octavio Beras of the Dominican Republic and his assistant, Bishop Priamo Tejeda.

title: A FLAWED PROPOSAL TO HELP MEDICARE PATIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSCRIPT OF INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Following is a transcript of an interview with President Reagan on Friday by R. W. Apple Jr., Gerald M. Boyd and Bernard Weinraub of The New York Times:

title: LOUISVILLE AND LOUISIANA STATE ADVANCE TO N.C.A.A. FINAL FOUR: TIGERS UPSET KENTUCKY
description: Led by the inside work of a guard forced to play center, 11th-seeded Louisiana State continued its unlikely mastery of top teams, stunning top-seeded Kentucky, 59-57, this afternoon to capture the Southeast Regional championship.

title: MUSEUM SHOW MARKS NEWARK'S BIRTHDAY
description: THE first in a series of spring exhibitions, tours and programs commemorating the 150th anniversary of Newark's incorporation opened yesterday at the Newark Museum.

title: GIULIETTA MASINA: FILM'S ETERNAL WAIF
description: There are certain roles that mark a performer forever.

title: FOR BUSCAGLIA, A LOYAL PUBLISHER
description: LEO BUSCAGLIA is not only one of the biggest selling authors of the past decade, he is one of the most loyal: All 10 of his books have been published by the same small house. Although a number of big publishers have tried to woo him away, Mr. Buscaglia - whose ''Bus 9 to Paradise'' is currently the No. 2 nonfiction best seller in America - has refused to budge.

title: DEATH FROM ALLERGY TO FOOD SPURS STUDY IN RHODE ISLAND
description: The death of a Brown University student who ate chili at a restaurant last month has moved the state health director to consider new protective measures against allergic reactions.

title: POETIC VOICES SING OF BLACK LIFE IN AFRICA AND ENGLAND
description: Musicians and storytellers have always maintained a special position as court historians and social critics in West Africa. In modern Nigerian literary circles, the most notable writer is Wole Soyinka, whose prison poems and odes to soldiers and corrupt bureaucrats are legendary. But his fame is far outstripped by Africa's most celebrated and controversial musician, Fela Anikulapo Kuti, the creator of a style called Afro-Beat and the epitome of what Nigerians refer to as indiscipline.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: AGING MYTHS: Reversible Causes of Mind and Memory Loss. By Siegfried Kra. (McGraw-Hill, $17.95.) The message is not new, but to the 62 million Americans who have passed their 50th birthday, it is positive and reassuring: according to Siegfried Kra, a cardiologist and associate clinical professor of medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine, ''confusion, depression, hallucination, and memory loss are not part of the aging process.

title: What Price Fitness?
description: In his article ''What Price Fitness'' (Feb. 16), Robert Lipsyte concludes that he will not force himself to exercise beyond the point that he reaps enjoyment.

title: MUSIC: MENDELSSOHN QUARTET
description: THE MENDELSSOHN STRING QUARTET, which played a recital Thursday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, is an excellent young ensemble with synchronous musical instincts; a full, elegant tone, and ideas about the works they play.

title: SCIENCE AND SELFISHNESS
description: EVOLUTION AS A RELIGION Strange Hopes and Stranger Fears. By Mary Midgley. 180 pp. New York: Methuen. Cloth, $33. Paper, $11.95. This is a book from which one goes away to ponder without having to push back against philosophical bullying. In a genre in which polemics are the rule, the hallmark of Mary Midgley's style is civility. Her topic is ''the distortion that afflicts science when it is put into the place of religion.'' Her ruminations are cautionary: the Victorian impulse to define progress as the replacement of religion by science has led to overgeneralizations by scientists on nature, life and humanity that range from the sanguine or euphoric to the cynical or despairing - all of which are fatalistic attitudes.

title: WOMEN AND WHITE SAUCE
description: PERFECTION SALAD Women and Cooking at the Turn of the Century. By Laura Shapiro. Illustrated. 280 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95. LAURA SHAPIRO'S delightful new book has cast some light on one of the more peculiar mysteries of my adolescence. This was eggs a la goldenrod, the first lesson in eighth-grade home economics class, and it was prepared by hard-boiling an egg, separating the white from the yolk, stirring the chopped-up white into freshly prepared white sauce, pouring the white mixture over toast and topping the whole production artistically with the crumbled yolk. Since no one, to my knowledge, had ever eaten such a thing, it was unclear why anyone should be obliged to cook it -especially while the boys were off in shop learning useful things like carpentry and radio repair. For the first time I realized that puberty was not, after all, the nadir of human existence: if eggs a la goldenrod defined the business of womanhood, then the worst might be yet to come.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Zeil Young: Live In Berlin VidAmerica 60 minutes. $29.95 Recorded in 1982, ''Live in Berlin'' is a sweeping retrospective that finds one of rock's most stubborn eccentrics near the peak of his form.

title: Vast Project Heads for '93 Finish
description: BATTERY PARK CITY was conceived in the late 1960's by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller in part as a good way to make use of the acres of rock excavated from the site of the World Trade Center. The new city is just a rock's throw, across West Street, from the World Trade Center, and the 92-acre landfill runs from the Battery all the way up to Chambers Street.

title: More Housing On the Way
description: Construction of 24,000 new or rehabilitated apartments for low-income and middle-income families in New York City could begin in about a year if a tentative agreement reached last week by Governor Cuomo and state legislators holds up.

title: PHYSICISTS CALL MISSILE SHIELD AN ERROR, POLL FINDS
description: Most physicists say President Reagan's program to seek a defense against intercontinental missiles is a mistake, is unlikely to protect the American population from attack and will cost more than it will be worth, according to an opinion poll.

title: Marlow Fisher
description: Marlow Fisher's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night was hardly a glittering show business event, but in its quiet, determined way it made its points quite clearly. Mr. Fisher is a violist and an proselytizer for his instrument. On Monday, he appeared on stage alone playing five pieces for unaccompanied viola, all by 20th-century composers.

title: AROUND TOWN WITH A FRENCH TEEN-AGER
description: When my good friends in France sent me their 17-year-old daughter Veronique for a three-week visit to New York - her first - I was filled with trepidation. Would she be bored? Would I? My friends assured me that it is ''the dream of every French girl'' to come to New York, and that whatever we did together would be interesting to her, even a trip to the supermarket. Nevertheless, I called numerous New York friends asking for suggestions of things she would enjoy, and made a long list.

title: Bangladesh Removes Martial Law Leaders
description: The Government, in moves to accommodate opposition parties, removed all army commanders from their civilian jobs today and set a new date for a parliamentary election.

title: Covert C.I.A. Operations Are Not 'Illegitimate'
description: To the Editor:

title: FREEHOLDER'S LOGIC CALLED 'CONVOLUTED'
description: Freeholder Alex DeCroce of Morris County [ New Jersey Journal, March 9 ] seems to be willing to let sexually active teen-age girls become pregnant by not providing ''all kinds of contraceptives'' because the two county-financed antiabortion pregnancy counseling agencies ''are providing a service that is necessary: shelter homes for pregnant teen-agers.''

title: SYSTEM OF ASSURING SAFE AIR TRAVEL FACES GROWING STRAIN, EXPERTS SAY
description: The Government's system of assuring air travelers' safety is becoming increasingly strained, according to aviation professionals and Congressional investigators.

title: CONGRESS CRITICS OF PAC'S SET UP THEIR OWN
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois and Representatives David R. Obey of Wisconsin and Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, liberal Democrats who have criticized political action committees, have formed their own PAC's.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: TURNING FORTY IN THE EIGHTIES: Personal Crisis, Time for Change. By Michael P. Nichols. (Norton, $15.95.) It is harder on the soul to turn 40 in the 1980's than it was in the 70's, 60's, 50's or 40's, according to Michael P. Nichols, a psychologist and professor of psychiatry at Albany Medical College.

title: Talks on Troops In Europe Stalled
description: Nineteen nations have once again met to discuss ways of reducing the NATO and Warsaw Pact garrisons in Europe, and once again, the White House announced last week, not much has been accomplished.

title: OLIVER A. PARKER TO MARRY BARBARA J. ZENKER, A NURSE
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Ogden Zenker of New Vernon, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jeanne Zenker to Oliver Ames Parker, a son of Mrs. Dudley Ian Knott of Manchester, Mass., and Charleston, S.C., and the late William Amory Parker of Beverly Farms, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Mayor Koch's Sweet Adversity
description: ''Sweet are the uses of adversity,'' sayeth New York's City Hall, quoting Shakespeare. The spreading scandals are mortifying, but Mayor Koch perceives a hope for changes that could not be achieved in quieter times. For example, it may be a good time to curb the influence of self-enriching party leaders like the late Donald Manes of Queens and Stanley Friedman of the Bronx.

title: DAUGHTER'S REACTION TO A 'SNOOP'
description: I feel that the people who wrote letters to the Long Island editor [ March 16 ] about Linda Flayton's article, ''I Snoop on My Children - and Here's Why'' [ Opinion Page, Feb. 23 ] , are terribly misguided. I know, because I'm the victim.

title: KEEPING THE FOCUS ON DEALS, NOT DELI
description: THE 44th floor ''club room'' at the First Boston Corporation's offices on Park Avenue is a pleasant eating place. It has impressionist-style paintings, fine linen and smiling waiters who serve decent food.

title: LESSENED RISK SEEN FOR BANKS
description: THE interstate banking laws passed by the Legislature earlier this month will let banks spread their risk over a broader deposit base, according to Roger F. Wagner, a deputy commissioner of the state's Department of Banking.

title: HISPANIC JOURNAL TO MAKE ITS DEBUT
description: WHEN a new literary journal makes its debut in Hartford next month, more of the Hispanic writers and artists in the state will have an outlet for their work.

title: HOMES VS. FARMING DEBATED
description: ABOUT 40 civic organizations in the Town of Huntington have banded together to try to halt proposed development on 300 acres near the Nassau-Suffolk County border and to keep the land producing vegetables.

title: G. J. MILLER WED TO LOUISE WILDE
description: Louise Pressler Wilde and George John Miller were married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. George Hollingshead, who was assisted by the Rev. Stephen Godsall-Meyers of Philadelphia.

title: Diane Monroe
description: Diane Monroe does not make a particularly rich sound on the violin; her bowing arm is not consistent -I'm also not convinced she was playing a very good instrument - but her recital at Merkin Concert Hall with Marian Hahn Wednesday night had at its center a heart of gold. The Franck Sonata was conveyed directly and touchingly.

title: Keeping Ahead Of the News
description: A NEWSPAPER HEADLINE caught my eye. It said: ''Famed Psychic's Head Explodes.'' I didn't buy the paper. Afterward, I worried. What was wrong with me?

title: RADU ALDULESCU, CELLIST, INTRODUCED TO NEW YORK
description: Radu Aldulescu began his professional career as a cellist in 1943 - before most of the week's other debut performers were born. Thus his recital at Alice Tully Hall last Saturday night was really an introduction to New York's listening audience, not to the music world at large, where he already enjoys a distinguished reputation.

title: INDISPOSED AND DISPENSABLE
description: A COUGH and the unwelcome discovery that the world can survive without me are the remnants of a winter illness. A family reunion happened; my children missed me but enjoyed each other.

title: MAKING SURE THE FACTS ARE FACTS
description: THE National Football League traveled a long, long road -ending with a quantum leap -before adopting the use of instant replay in applying the rules of play. And you do need rules of play. When you go to the history of sports, and I'm going way back, it became clear immediately that ''organized'' games and leagues required a set of rules. If you had rules, you had to have people to administer them. But it was never intended for the rules, or the officials, to be a determining factor in the outcome of a game. Rules and officials merely provided the format for the players to compete. It was understood that the players and participants would make mistakes, and that was all part of winning and losing. In the early days, it was accepted, even expected, that since it was a game of humans even the officials would make mistakes.

title: INDUSTRY'S M.I.S. ROMANCE
description: WHEN Barry Miller began as a data programmer at Western Electric, the manufacturing division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, few opportunities existed for a computer specialist to make strategic decisions. But now as a management information systems director at Hapag Lloyd of America, a subsidiary of the German shipping company, he coordinates development and operations of all the company's information systems.

title: What Happens in 'The Search'?
description: To the Editor:

title: PEETE'S EAGLE GAINS LEAD BY ONE ON 135
description: Calvin Peete, the most accurate golfer hitting to greens on the PGA Tour, holed out a 150-yard 6-iron shot for an eagle 2 at the 16th hole today, finished with a 5-under-par 67 and took the lead by a shot after 36 holes of the USF & G Classic.

title: CHANGERS RETURN TO PROVE THAT PLUS CA CHANGE...
description: New evidence that history really moves in circles has just turned up. Automatic changers - those Rube Goldbergish relics of bygone days - are reborn in the laser age. The dinosaurs are coming alive.

title: DEVILS SET BACK MAPLE LEAFS BY 6-3
description: Paul Gagne and Jan Ludvig got third-period goals in a 1-minute-25-second span tonight to help the Devils score a 6-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: WEST SIDERS MAY GET A REPRIEVE FROM THE IRT
description: During the first third of the century, when gritty, labor-intensive factories dominated New York City's economy, getting people to their jobs was accomplished largely by a transportation system that seemed to rumble out of the industrial revolution: the subway.

title: The Turning Point on Acid Rain
description: The web of nature is so resilient that it tears only under the roughest insults. That's why biologists concerned about acid rain have had so hard a case to prove. Rain made acid by industrial pollution doesn't eat visible holes in leaves or poison fish in a single downpour. The mildest of toxins, its damage is subtle and accumulates over decades. The hundreds of lifeless lakes now found from Florida to Maine are only the most obvious symptoms of a whole seaboard under severe environmental stress.

title: IN SHORT
description: KEEPING HOPE ALIVE: On Becoming a Psychotherapist. By F. Robert Rodman. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) This memoir is supposed to be a guide for prospective psychotherapists.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: THE LOSS OF SELF: A Family Resource for the Care of Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders. By Donna Cohen and Carl Eisdorfer. (Norton, $18.95.) Alzheimer's disease, believed to afflict over two million middle-aged and older Americans, has been called the silent epidemic. But in recent years this condition has been widely publicized, and the availability of information and other resources for patients' families has greatly increased. Among the latest contributions is this book by Donna Cohen, a professor of geriatrics in the School of Public Health at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and Carl Eisdorfer, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Miami School of Medicine, who for over 15 years have studied the disorder and worked with patients and their families. Intended mainly to assist families caring for members who have Alzheimer's disease, the book deals with psychological, logistical, biomedical, legal and financial issues. It does not shy from such sensitive topics as the sexuality of patients and their partners, the possibility of suicide among disease victims and the risk of serious depression in care givers. Material on the interaction of family members with patients and among themselves is a particular strength of the book. Almost without exception, the authors provide concrete advice without being dogmatic. Thus they present many guidelines (often in the convenient form of lists) and useful facts, even as they emphasize again and again, both explicitly and through many anecdotes about patients and their families, that every situation is different and no single right formula exists.

title: SAILING TO THE TOP
description: It began as a collaboration between man and dog. During the early 1930's, the man, Paul Sperry, worked as an executive at the Pond Lily Company in New Haven, Conn., which was in the business of dying and finishing fabric. In his spare moments he would invent things, usually having to do with dying and finishing. Away from the office, he most often could be found aboard a sailboat.

title: What Overcame Javits Wasn't Conservatism
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS' STANCE ON INSURANCE DECRIED
description: For the fourth year in a row, New Jersey motorists are paying the highest car-insurance rates in the nation. The evidence is overwhelming that unnecessary lawsuits are a significant factor.

title: SALVADORANS SUSPECTED IN KILLING OF U.S. MAN
description: A Salvadoran Army officer is being investigated for possible involvement in the mysterious killing last month of an American here, according to several officials following the case. They said other soldiers might also be involved.

title: SPLIT ON THE ISRAELI RIGHT IS STILL WIDE
description: Ten days after Israel's right-wing Herut Party was torn asunder by internal power struggles, the party's rival contenders for leadership have still not sorted out their differences. Some Herut insiders are begining to wonder whether they ever really will.

title: JEAN SEIBEL TO WED IN FALL
description: Jean Seibel, a dance therapist at the Young Adult Institute in Bedford, N.Y., and Wayne Jeffrey Forrest, director of the American-Indonesian Chamber of Commerce in New York, plan to be married in the fall. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Seibel of Arlington, Va., and Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Forrest of Ardsley, N.Y.

title: IS IT TOO LATE FOR THE LITTLE GUY?
description: LINES formed 10 deep in front of the stock quotation machines at the Merrill Lynch kiosk in Grand Central Station last week. Brokers all around the country heard from long-forgotten customers and mutual fund managers were button-holed in restaurants for stock tips. From cocktail parties and subway platforms to suburban golf courses and country stores, conversations kept erupting about the most powerful rally to hit Wall Street in years. Now even the little guy, who has lingered on the sidelines during the last few years, is wondering whether he should jump in.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
THE READER'S LIFETIME SADOMASOCHISM DIET
description: READING a book by a good writer is the most pleasurable experience possible, even better than eating a freshly baked brownie topped with chocolate-chocolate-chip ice cream and sprinkled with macadamia nuts. With a side of champagne truffles.

title: POLICIES AND PRACTICES ON PATIENT RESTRAINTS
description: This is in response to the Feb. 16 essay by Lucille G. Natkins [ '' 'My Mother Would Be Treated Better if She Were a Dog' '' ] , regarding the use of patient restraints in nursing homes. Although I have not been able to confirm the source of information or verify the accuracy of the facts detailed by her, I feel compelled to comment.

title: ART 'CENSORSHIP' CHARGED
description: CERTAIN kinds of nudity in art might have raised cries of moral outrage among the museum public in the past, but today nearly every kind of nudity is almost as common as still lifes in public institutions. Even pornography, if believed to have redeeming artistic value, does not stir up the controversy it used to. (The art of Eric Fischl, currently the subject of a retrospective at New York's Whitney Museum, is viewed for its esthetic power more than for its subject matter, sexuality.) In view of this current climate of opinion, Ben Jones, a Jersey City artist, was shocked that the State Museum in Trenton refused to display as part of his current exhibition there two works depicting male nudity.

title: MOSCOW SIGNS THE CHECKS BUT WATCHES ITS WORDS
description: THE Kremlin is not usually hesitant about responding to President Reagan, and steamy Russian rhetoric rich in imperialist diktat and rampant militarism is apt to follow quickly any anti-Soviet polemics from Washington. Yet Moscow's response was curiously low-key last week when Mr. Reagan declared that excising the ''cancer'' of Communism from Nicaragua would have a high priority in the years he has left in the White House.

title: LAUREN JEAN OSHRY TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lester Oshry of Canton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Jean Oshry, to Elias Reichel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Reichel of New York.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: THE FOOD AND DRUG INTERACTION GUIDE. By Brian L. G. Morgan. (Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.) As Brian L. G. Morgan impressively shows in ''The Food and Drug Interaction Guide,'' most therapeutic drugs, from humble aspirin to the exotic levodopa used to relieve symptoms of Parkinson's disease, can cause nutritional deficiencies by blocking or impairing the intake of certain vitamins and minerals.

title: NATO'S CONTENTIOUS SOUTHERN FRONT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's first trip to Turkey and Greece, the southern flank of NATO, comes when questions are being raised once again about the status of American bases in both countries. Here, where Soviet and NATO forces face each other along thousands of miles of land and water frontiers, Mr. Shultz is attempting one of his more difficult diplomatic tasks: to reduce the friction between Greece and Turkey, NATO allies who distrust each other more than they distrust the Soviet Union. And specifically Mr. Shultz needs to use his skills to insure continued American access to the bases.

title: TABLE-TOP OR PORTABLE VCR? 'DOCKABLE' DESIGNS HAVE IT BOTH WAYS
description: Some VCR's lead a double life. They perform equally well indoors, outdoors, at home and afield. Video fans no longer need to choose between a tabletop VCR and a portable one. With so-called dockable models, they have it both ways with a single unit.

title: ERUMPENT THINGS
description: FROM MY FATHER, SINGING By David Bosworth. 120pp. Wainscott, N.Y.: Pushcart Press. $13.95.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LESS MAINTENANCE
description: LOW-MAINTENANCE gardening has become an important topic in light of the prevailing shortage of professional gardeners and the limited time that we have to work in our own gardens.

title: FAMILY GUIDE TO MUSEUMS IN LONDON
description: Standing among the Greek sculptures in the British Museum, clutching a screaming baby in one hand and an incomprehensible museum guide in the other, I thought, ''There has to be a restroom here somewhere!'' There was. ''Three flights up and six galleries along,'' as an employee so complacently informed me. As I knelt on the cold damp floor, simultaneously trying to dispose of a diaper and dissuade my 9-month-old from crawling under the door, I reflected that there had to be an easier way.

title: My Son, The Rastafarian
description: Mario Vargas Llosa's story of his son's experience as a Rastafarian leaves us unsure as to who, son or father, was going through a phase.

title: WHEN RADIO MAINTAINED THE MYSTERY IN LIFE AND SPORT
description: I WATCHED the first half of this year's Super Bowl at home with all the slo-mo, instant replay and hoopla that was only slightly distinguishable from what I had been watching for years. The television viewer was again being force-fed a steady diet of visuals and information that kept the mind at rest. I had no opportunity to explore the ''mystery'' of the occasion. Then I hailed a cab to take me to one of the ''Bowl Parties'' I had been invited to attend and the game became exciting.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
THE NEW HYSTERIA
description: HUNGER STRIKE The Anorectic's Struggle as a Metaphor for Our Age. By Susie Orbach. 201 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $15.95. IN ''Fat Is a Feminist Issue'' (1978) Susie Orbach, a psychotherapist and co-founder of the Women's Therapy Center Institute in New York City, offered one of the first feminist analyses of women's obsessions with food and body size. In ''Hunger Strike: The Anorectic's Struggle as a Metaphor for Our Age,'' a cultural and clinical study of anorexia nervosa, Miss Orbach reads anorexia as ''a dramatic expression of the internal compromise wrought by Western women in the 1980s in their attempt to negotiate their passions and desires in a time of extraordinary confusion.'' She decodes the anorexic's emaciated body and iron control as ''at once an embodiment of stereotyped femininity and its very opposite.''

title: TURNING A TRAINED EYE ON A TENSE FED
description: J. Charles Partee, who retired earlier this year as a member of the Federal Reserve Board, was asked to reflect upon a career at the central bank that spanned nearly a quarter century. Following are excerpts of his conversation with Robert D. Hershey Jr. of The Times's Washington bureau:

title: THE METROPOLITAN'S NEW 'CARMEN' NEEDED A CARMEN
description: By the time the Card Song arrived in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Carmen,'' all I could think of was the luckless gambler's lament: Who dealt this mess? Maria Ewing, in the title role, had already twisted her voice and body out of all recognition while attempting to deal with the Habanera, the Seguidilla and other landmarks of French opera. A more eccentrically sung and acted Carmen has probably never been heard and seen in this opera house than the one delivered by Miss Ewing on this opening night. The melodic line was persistently torn to shreds by her nasty lunges into notes, her disregard for phrasing in pursuit of who knew what theatrical effects and her disconcerting register separations, which sometimes made it sound as if three or four different voices were attacking the part of Carmen simultaneously. It was clear rather early that someone at the Metropolitan had made a serious miscalculation in planning this production. At the premiere, at least, the audience was offered a ''Carmen'' without a Carmen.

title: CABLEVISION SEEKS NEW WIRING SCHEDULE
description: The company that won the right to provide cable television service to the Bronx and most of Brooklyn has told city officials it cannot raise the $300 million it needs to fulfill its contract and has asked to be allowed to do the work in stages.

title: POLICE ENCOURAGE SPEED WARNINGS
description: ASSISTANT CHIEF Robert R. McCue of the West Hartford Police, was taking a walk one recent evening when he noticed a motorist blinking his headlights at an oncoming, speeding car. The car slowed down. The Chief got an idea.

title: JOANNE L. WALSH WEDS ROBERT PRIER, A LAWYER
description: The wedding of Joanne Lisa Walsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Walsh of Blauvelt, N.Y., to Robert Jeffrey Prier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Prier of Blauvelt, took place there yesterday. Msgr.

title: WESTERN KENTUCKY ROUTS RUTGERS
description: Rutgers was unable to handle the strength, quickness and experience of Western Kentucky today and bowed out of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 23 about the Central Ballet of China starting its United States tour in Binghamton, N.Y., misidentified the orchestra that performed at its premiere. The orchestra was the Brooklyn Philharmonic.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: NEW JERSEY is represented by 16 companies in a trade show, the US Pro '86 Exhibition, which opens a six-day run tomorrow in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: JERSEY CITY TENANTS 'TAKE CHARGE'
description: WHEN the residents of Gregory Park, a 786-unit apartment complex here, get their final conversion papers from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development (H.U.D.) this month or next, they will have formed a cooperative, acquired one of the few remaining real-estate bargains in the area and become what they call a ''United Nations of families.''

title: FRANCES BRONSON LIPPINCOTT TO MARRY wILLIAM bRYCE tHOMPSON 4TH IN MAY
description: Frances Bronson Lippincott and William Bryce Thompson 4th plan to marry in May. The announcement was made by the future bride's parents, Barton Hirst Lippincott of Philadelphia and Mrs. Anthony N. B. Garvan of Spring House, Pa.

title: PROSPECTS
description: JOB GROWTH MAY QUICKEN So far, the economy has not been strong enough to drive down the stubborn jobless rate or to rev up annual employment growth. But that could change soon. A recent survey of 5,000 American businesses conducted by Dun & Bradstreet shows that companies plan to hire more new people this year than last.

title: FLYERS FRUSTRATE RANGERS, 4-2
description: It was a frustrating afternoon for the Rangers at the Spectrum, for they did so many smart things. At times they bottled up the Philadelphia Flyers and certainly they met them push for push, but the Flyers are a team of many talents. They kept coming, nudging their way toward the net, shooting from all the angles, and eventually, they forced the mistakes out of the Rangers and won, 4-2.

title: AMY C. KIESTER TO WED IN JUNE
description: A June 14 wedding is planned by Amy Clare Kiester and Richard Carey Leonard Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard of Westport, Conn. Their engagement has been announced by the future bride's mother, Elizabeth Kiester, also of Westport.

title: JAPAN PONDERS ITS RICHES WITH EMBARRASSMENT
description: The postwar high the Japanese yen reached against the dollar last week demonstrates the degree to which Japan has become the sorcerer's apprentice of international trade and finance. The money has kept piling up despite efforts to control the flow. It has reached the point that the trade minister, Michio Watanabe, acknowledged that Japan's accumulation of wealth is ''a pleasant and, at the same time, an embarrassing thing.''

title: VALLEY OF BLOSSOMS IN THE WEST
description: March winds tug at the fields of Skagit Valley in western Washington and heavy rainfalls interrupt the days. But spirits are high in this agricultural and dairy farming region just an hour north of Seattle. Long, yellow-tipped daffodil bulbs signal the coming of spring with a golden glow that spreads along the valley. Even more thrilling, daffodils herald the April tulip season and, before long, fields will shimmer with the pinks, reds, yellows, mauves and even purple-blacks of Skagit Valley tulips. Dutch irises in shades of deep purple, fragile blue and creamy white will bloom there until June.

title: JAZZ: SPHERE, A QUARTET
description: SPHERE, the group formed in 1982 by three former sidemen of Thelonious Sphere Monk plus the pianist Kenny Barron, now splits its sets, half and half, between Monk and other composers. The quartet, which is appearing through tonight at the Village Vanguard (178 Seventh Avenue South), honors the stubborn angularity of Monk's music, stating the original tunes with scrupulous care.

title: PORTRAIT OF A PLAYWRIGHT AS AN ENEMY OF THE STATE
description: The cottage belongs to Vaclav Havel, the Czechoslovak playwright, and although it sits in the hills near the Polish border it resembles nothing so much as a Manhattanite's Litchfield County retreat. Mr. Havel built the house himself 16 years ago and he has furnished it well, thanks to the royalties from productions of his works abroad. In photographs taken by a recent visitor, one sees stereo components and a wood stove, embroidered tableclothes and goose-down comforters, and a tiled hearth from which the after-dinner fire throws warm light into the room.

title:
CRITICS' CHOICES;
Photography
description: Paris and its people is the principal subject of Willy Ronis's photographs, not the Paris of the fashionable boulevards of the artistic and historic monuments, but the Paris of ordinary people and obscure neighborhoods that always looks so picturesque and appealing in photographs, no matter what the reality might be.

title:
DINING OUT;
A FAMILIAR SITE IN SOUTH ORANGE
description: EVERYONE loses when a good restaurant closes, such as the two-star-rated Sonia Rose in Madison. But when the chef moves to another restaurant, particularly one of his own, then all is not lost.

title: DR. DEBRA ANN DAUNT PLANS A MAY WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Daunt of Richmondtown, S.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Debra Ann Daunt, to Joseph Peter Lacerenza, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Lacerenza of New Rochelle, N.Y. A May wedding is planned. Dr. Daunt is an internist in private practice in Plainfield, Conn. She and Mr. Lacerenza graduated from Georgetown University, from which she also received a medical degree.

title: ZACK A TO Z
description: CONFESSIONS OF A PREGNANT FATHER By Dan Greenburg. 214 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $16.95. LIVES there a writer who, upon joining the ranks of fatherhood, hasn't felt the urge - no, the compulsion - to tell the world of his firstborn's arrival? Good sense or perhaps good editors fortunately prevail and temptation is set aside. These fond recollections are saved instead for family, friends and Lamaze class reunions.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: HUNGARIAN CHOIR Although the 40-voice Kantus of Debrecen College in Hungary is nearly 250 years old and has toured widely in Europe, it has just begun its first American tour. It will perform in Montclair tomorrow, in New Brunswick on Tuesday and Wednesday, in Perth Amboy on Wednesday and in Princeton on Friday.

title: PETER DAVIES ENGAGED TO SUZANNE M. TUSSING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Tussing of Severna Park, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter Suzanne Miller Tussing of Alexandria, Va., to Peter Andrew Davies. A May wedding is planned.

title:
HIGH TECHNOLOGY;
A BOOKSHELF OF TECHNOLOGY
description: INTERESTED in brushing up your high-technology writing skills? Know something about computers and think you'd like to be in business for yourself? How does someone with a college degree in history make himself marketable to the high-technology world? Or perhaps you work in an industry that needs information on where to get technical specialists for a given field?

title: Family Values, Without Sugary Pieties
description: The family is likely to become one of the central issues of the 1986 and 1988 political campaigns. Family concerns and family values cut across ideological lines and involve millions of Americans in ways that most issues simply do not. But while any public figure with an ounce of sense ought now to be staking a claim to this subject, most will content themselves with the same sugary pieties about the sanctity of family life.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY MAY ALTER AMERICAN FARMERS, TOO
description: Across the country, molecular biologists are hunched over microscopes and working in climate-controlled chambers, nursing new forms of plant and animal life. Their emerging ability to mix hereditary material from one species with that of another open exciting possibilities for American agriculture.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: EDUCATION WITH BODY OIL COLLEEN BENZA of Kings Park wanted to take belly dancing, but since it wasn't offered, she was massaging the neck muscles of Jon Goldblatt of Smithtown instead. ''I plan to use what I learn on my husband,'' Mrs. Benza said, in explaining why she had signed up for a Swedish massage course at Smithtown High School East.

title: LAWN THATCH
description: The term thatch is the scorn of most lawn owners. By definition it is an organic layer that accumulates above the soil surface and is composed of dead and living turfgrass parts such as roots and stems. In a lawn the thatch layer is similar to the leaf litter in forests except the lawn clippings (leaves) do not add to thatch development.

title: LITTLE NECK
description: EVEN though it is a part of New York City, Little Neck likes to think of itself as just a small town tucked away in the corner of a big city. It lies in the hilly northeastern tip of Queens on the Nassau County border, overlooking Little Neck Bay.

title: OPPOSITION FOCUSING ON REPORT
description: IN ISSUING a lengthy Finding of No Significant Impact (FONSI) last October, John H. Riley, Administrator of the United States Department of Transportation's Federal Railroad Administration, removed a major potential impediment to the Atlantic City railroad project.

title: THE FUTURE MAY AGAIN BE IN PLASTICS
description: TWO DECADES AGO, Dustin Hoffman, playing the title role in the movie ''The Graduate,'' was pulled aside by one of his parents' friends at a party and told that the future could be summarized in one word - ''plastics.'' At that time, at least to the movie's audience, ''plastics'' stood for low-quality consumer items like plastic forks whose prongs broke off in Jell-O and ink pens that burst in a pocket. Mr. Hoffman's character shrugged off the advice.

title: RMS W/VU
description: Close proximity to the President's residence has long been a symbolic selling point for the increasingly competitive downtown hostelries.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
TORAH'S NEW HOME
description: THE Nazis had hoped to display it as a symbol of destruction. But instead, the Torah that was rededicated at the Westchester Jewish Center in Mamaroneck last weekend was, in the words of the synagogue's Rabbi Irving Koslowe, ''a symbol of survival.''

title: COMPANY DELAYS FIELD TEST OF GENE-ALTERED AGENT
description: The California biotechnology company that gained approval for the world's first field test of a genetically engineered farm chemical has notified the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that it will delay the test until it repeats a battery of disputed safety studies.

title: Niebuhr and La Rochefoucauld
description: To the Editor:

title: THE INDUSTRY CLIMBS BACK UP
description: INSIDE Micron Technology Corporation's starkly modern semiconductor-manufacturing building, constructed in brighter times outside Boise, Idaho, 700 remaining employees are struggling to get back on their feet. Nearly crushed in the computer slump that sent much of America's high-technology industry reeling last year, the innovative chip-maker had to dismiss half its work force, saw its revenues shrink to nearly nothing, and filed a trade complaint against Japanese competitors that, at best, seems likely to end in a hollow victory.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LESS MAINTENANCE
description: LOW-MAINTENANCE gardening has become an important topic in light of the prevailing shortage of professional gardeners and the limited time that we have to work in our own gardens.

title: The '88 Rhetorical Watch
description: AS A PRESIDENTIAL campaign approaches, great rhetorical and metaphoric strain is placed on the language. Candidates, spokesmen and even thinksmen are tempted to scale heights of hyperbole and word-configuration that are never attempted in pursuit of less-exalted office.

title: CORPORATIONS BACK PROGRAM FOR DISABLED
description: HE had gone diving off the pier into the cool water of the Long Island Sound many times before. Peter Damiano and his friends knew where the treacherous rocks were and the trajectory that was needed to avoid hitting them. But one day two years ago, Mr. Damiano made a fateful misjudgment.

title: U.S. DIPLOMAT REPORTEDLY HELD TALKS IN LIBYA
description: A senior American diplomat, apparently without authorization and contrary to Reagan Administration policy, held a secret meeting with Libyan officials in early January, according to Administration officials.

title: CANADA PRESSING ACID-RAIN ISSUE
description: ONTARIO gets a heavy dose of acid precipitation from this country, and Jim Bradley, the province's Minister of the Environment, is not ecstatic over the results of last week's meeting between President Reagan and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada.

title: ITALY SEEKS TRIAL IN SHIP HIJACKING
description: Italian prosecutors have asked for indictments against 13 people for the hijacking last fall of the Achille Lauro cruise ship, and among them is the Palestinian guerrilla leader Mohammed Abbas, judicial sources said today.

title: The Facts in 'Kabul'
description: To the Editor:

title: EMILY BLUMBERG, PHYSICIAN, TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Blumberg of Lake Success, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Emily Anne Blumberg to Dr. John Gregory Mezochow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mezochow of West Hartford, Conn. An Aug. 31 wedding is planned.

title: TRASH FEES KEEP RISING, BUT WHY?
description: IN recent weeks, as garbage collection rates have risen to complement garbage dumping rates, Long Island homeowners have found themselves caught between their towns and their carters over key questions of waste disposal.

title: EASING THE DOCTOR-PATIENT STRAIN
description: ONE summer day, my pediatrician told me that he wanted to give my daughter a newly released vaccination against meningitis. Never having heard of this new vaccination before, I hesitated, then asked to see some literature on it.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TWENTY-eight years ago, a Short Hills woman with a severe congenital hearing loss underwent what was then radically new middle-ear surgery called a stapedectomy. The operation was a success, and a world of sound suddenly opened for her.

title: A Flawed Proposal to Help Medicare Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plea for Sakharov's Release
description: When Soviet officials allowed Yelena G. Bonner, the wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, to travel to the United States for heart surgery and other medical treatment, they attached one important restriction: that she refrain from making public statements. But at a private reception in Washington last week, she broke her silence.

title: MACDONALD IS BEATEN AS CAMBRIDGE LOSES
description: Fiona Macdonald, the first woman to compete in the 108-year history of the annual golf match between Britain's Oxford and Cambridge universities, was beaten today.

title: HARSH QUESTIONS FOR POLICE IN SUFFOLK
description: STATE and Federal investigations of the Suffolk County Police Department over allegations of drug use and official corruption have put the force under the most intense scrutiny in recent years.

title: BUMPER STICKER AS PUNISHMENT
description: AFTER having won a county court election in Sarasota, Fla., by denouncing the incumbent as soft on drunken driving, Judge Becky Titus found herself accused last June of being too hard on violators. The accuser was her husband, Elliott Metcalfe, the county's public defender.

title:
NATURE WATCH;
SANDBAR SHARK
description: Carcharhinus milberti Size: Average six and a half feet; reaches eight feet.

title: TOLERANT POLICY ON HOMELESS DIVIDES SANTA MONICA
description: Palisades Park, with its panoramic view of Santa Monica Bay, is one of California's scenic treasures, a favorite place for tourists and residents to stroll at sunset.

title: Nakasone Views Rise of Yen Against Dollar as Too Sharp
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone said today that the yen's recent appreciation against the United States dollar had been too sharp.

title: Talks on Sudan Peace Appear to Have Failed
description: Exploratory talks between southern Sudanese rebels and backers of Khartoum's military Government appear to have collapsed, and sources close to both sides said today that there was no possibility of a cease-fire.

title: LESSON FOR YOUTH: SAYING 'NO' IS O.K.
description: A 10-YEAR-OLD boy was sent into a convenience store to buy a gallon of milk while his mother waited outside in the car. When he did not come back after a reasonable amount of time, she went into the store to look for him. He was reading magazines filled with pictures of scantily clad and nude women.

title: Headliners; A Business Decision
description: Officials at the International Business Machines Corporation's offices in Providence, R.I., reacted straightforwardly last week to an anti-apartheid sit-in by 14 college students: They called the police, and the students were arrested and charged with trespassing. A spokesman said I.B.M. opposed South Africa's policy of apartheid and for that reason considered itself ''not an appropriate target.''

title: BELL ASSAYS STATE OF U.S. EDUCATION
description: THE former United States Secretary of Education, Dr. Terrel H. Bell told an audience of businessmen and educators in the county last week that although the nation's education system is still at risk, the outlook is improving.

title: HOUSING GROUP HONORS MCKINNEY
description: UNITED STATES Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Westport, was honored by a national housing group last week for his devotion to providing ''a decent home and suitable living environment for every American.''

title: A WIFE NAMED X, A POODLE NAMED ELVIS
description: THE SPORTSWRITER By Richard Ford. 375 pp. New York: Vintage Contemporaries. Paper, $6.95. MANY of our best novelists are obsessed with exploring the nature of the family, and for good reason. What is more fascinating than these disparate beings who inhabit the same households, breathe the same air, inspire hope and expectation and - all too often - cause disappointment? The disintegration of a family, particularly one in which a young child has died, moves us directly into a territory of sorrow. In fiction, the loss of a child is by definition an exploration of a loss of faith. For the novelist, it generates a mysterious, perhaps impossible equation with which to struggle: how much does such a death contribute to upsetting the precarious balance of a faltering marriage?

title: EX-PARKS CHIEF IN PROVIDENCE INDICTED OVER STOLEN ARTIFACT
description: Merrick A. Cook Jr., former Parks Superintendent of Providence, has been indicted on a charge of embezzlement in connection with the disappearance from a bank safe-deposit box of a Hawaiian artifact owned by the city.

title: OLDER DANCERS SHOULD HAVE A PLACE IN THE THEATER
description: Growing old is something people often hate to think about. Dancers may be especially reluctant to do so, for in their art the accent is decidedly on youth. Most dancers are young.

title: A FLAWED PROPOSAL TO HELP MEDICARE PATIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDREA G. SCHACHT MARRIES DR. PAUL SAVOCA, RESIDENT
description: Andrea Gail Schacht, a third-year student at the Fordham University School of Law, and Dr. Paul E. Savoca, a surgical resident at Yale-New Haven Hospital, were married yesterday at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill, N.Y. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and John Savoca, the bridegroom's father and a Roman Catholic deacon, jointly officiated.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: HOOPLA, by Harry Stein. (St. Martin's, $7.95.) Part fact and part fiction, ''Hoopla'' re-creates the year 1919 and baseball's infamous ''Black Sox'' scandal, when eight members of the Chicago White Sox were accused of conspiring to throw the World Series to the Cincinnati Reds and were banned from major-league ball. In The Book Review in 1984, Ira Berkow said that Harry Stein's work, ''kaleidoscopic, vivid, tragic - earns a place among the splendid novels about sports.'' LINDEN HILLS, by Gloria Naylor. (Penguin, $6.95.) An adaptation of Dante's ''Inferno,'' this novel by Gloria Naylor has as its locale the affluent suburb of Linden Hills, a thriving community of black professionals. But beneath the facade of material success is revealed a grim world of lost black souls trapped in the American dream. Mel Watkins said in The Book Review in 1985 that while Miss Naylor was not entirely successful in adapting the ''Inferno'' to the world of the black middle class, she displays ''wit and insight into the tensions and anxieties that plague assimilated blacks.'' DISTANT NEIGHBORS: A Portrait of the Mexicans, by Alan Riding. (Vintage, $4.95.) A study of Mexico and its people by Alan Riding, a former Mexico City bureau chief for The New York Times. Last year our reviewer, Richard R. Fagen, called the work ''a useful and well-informed book. . . . No recent book on Mexico has tried to cover so much, with all the difficulties and challenges this entails.'' DAVITA'S HARP, by Chaim Potok.

title: VOICE OF MOTHER SPURS A DAUGHTER, AT 90, TO MAKE USE OF EVERY MOMENT
description: I WILL be 90 years old in October and my life should be smoothing out a little. I ought to be able to goof off when I want to and enjoy bouts of lazy idleness now and then, reflect on my long, good married life, enjoy my children and grandchildren.

title: A SLIVER OF LAND HAS DEVELOPERS DREAMING
description: FOR 18 miles from the George Washington Bridge south to Bayonne, N.J., the Hudson River waterfront opposite Manhattan is littered with abandoned railroad yards and burned-out piers. Yet over the last five years, as the railroads have released the land and the regional economy has boomed, this has become one of the nation's most valuable development sites. On paper, it is the scene of $5 billion in new construction that will attract 60,000 new residents and 75,000 office workers.

title: MAKING BUILDINGS 'SMART'
description: TWO YEARS AGO, David M. Jacobs, the president of Financial Place Communications Company, left his comfortable job in Milwaukee with Johnson Controls Inc.

title: HENRI DUTILLEUX - AN ELDER STATESMAN OF MUSIC IN FRANCE
description: Attending the first full performance of your own composition if you haven't helped shape its interpretation is ''like listening to a work of plastic,'' according to the composer Henri Dutilleux, whose Concerto for Violin will have its New York premiere on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall. His several work sessions with Isaac Stern - for whom the piece was commissioned - in the five years it took to complete the concerto were therefore ''invaluable,'' the composer said.

title: AUSTRALIAN GOTHIC
description: RINGARRA By Coral Lansbury. 220 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. GOTHIC fiction's appeal is rooted in the fear of -and attraction to - the irrational. Relying upon exaggeration and the macabre, the genre slips easily into self-parody (the plot of the first Gothic novel, Horace Walpole's 1764 ''Castle of Otranto,'' all but defies rational summation) and has long inspired such deliberate spoofs as Austen's ''Northanger Abbey'' and Peacock's ''Nightmare Abbey.'' In ''Ringarra,'' Coral Lansbury (Australian-born, now a professor of English at Rutgers University) has attempted to write a straight Gothic novel, undiluted by levity, but leavened by a strong infusion of literary and psychological self-consciousness.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE FIRST FLOWERS OF SPRING'S AWAKENING
description: Early spring wildflowers -even the ugly and fetid ones - are treasured. Often tiny, many of the flowers seem too delicate to withstand frigid nights and leonine blasts of March. To deal with such harshness, the plants have evolved special techniques, even trickery.

title: KURDISH CULTURE FINDS BROOKLYN HOME
description: Kurdistan today is a diffuse place, a state of mind instead of a country, a broad expanse of mountains and plateaus that stretches across eastern Turkey, northern Syria, northern Iraq and western Iran.

title: MARTIN BOWING OUT OF THE FED SPOTLIGHT
description: Preston Martin will quit as vice chairman of the Fed when his term expires at the end of April. The resignation was something of a surprise, since the grip of the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, is apparently loosening, and Mr. Martin appeared amenable to taking over that job. Mr. Martin and the other three Reagan appointees overruled Mr. Volcker's objections to the recent discount rate cut, and the Fed chairman was sharply criticized by one of the new members, Martha R. Seger, who said he was moving too slowly on lowering interest rates. Mr. Volcker is used to being at odds with the Administration, but dissension from the Fed board is another matter and was seen by some as a signal that he should resign. Instead, it is Mr. Martin who is leaving, indicating that the chairman is digging in his heels.

title: EUROPE'S EUREKA PROJECT AIMS TO NARROW U.S. LEAD
description: EUROPEAN GOVERNMENTS have borrowed Archimedes's triumphant shout of discovery - ''Eureka'' - as the name of their latest combined attempt to close the technological gap with the United States and Japan. But it remains unclear what if anything the Eureka Project will find. Nearly a year after President Francois Mitterrand of France launched it with great fanfare last April, vagueness and uncertainty still dog this plan for collaborative high-technology research.

title: PLAY LOOKS AT LIFE IN A WOMEN'S BAR
description: PLAYS that take place in bars (''The Time of Your Life''), diners (''Bus Stop'') and hotel lobbies (''The Hot l Baltimore'') or gathering places for motley characters are theatrical conventions. Such settings represent microcosms wherein life secrets are revealed and relationships resolved.

title: A PLACE FOR LIBERAL ARTS
description: WHEN careers in technology first sparked Diane Piliere's interest eight years ago, she had a combined M.A. in psychology and business, and little technical training. But with her previous managerial experience in personnel and the ability to design performance-appraisal systems, Mrs. Piliere was eagerly courted by a high-technology company in New Jersey that specifically needed her particular skills.

title: Hindus Seek Army Help In a Clash With Sikhs
description: Sikhs and Hindus clashed today in a riot-torn Punjab city, and prominent Hindu residents asked that the army be sent in, an Indian news agency reported.

title: CHERYL M. STEWART IS BRIDE OF PAUL GREGORY HOMDROM
description: Cheryl Mae Stewart, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Stewart of Tarpon Springs, Fla, was married yesterday to Paul Gregory Homdrom, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Theodore Homdrom of St. Paul, Minn., in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Dr. Bryant Kirkland officiated, assisted by the bridegroom's father and the bride's uncle, the Rev. Dr. Dwight C. Stewart, a Church of Christ minister.

title: BUDAPEST: MAKING A FRONT
description: To describe Budapest as lying somewhere between Prague and Vienna, besides being geographically wacky, would be a disservice to three inimitable cities. Yet for a tourist who has lately visited them, there seems to be something to the proposition. Like Prague, Budapest is deep in the Soviet sphere of domination; the residents of both cities suffered grievously from the Nazis, only to endure repression and invasion from their Soviet ''liberators.'' But like Vienna, to which it was for centuries joined as the capital of the Hapsburg monarchy, Budapest is a city of lush history and luscious desserts.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:13 A.M. today and set at 11:35 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 3:09 A.M. and set at 11:22 A.M.

title: MURDER ON THE FAMILY FARM
description: IN THE CLOSING DAYS OF SEPTEMBER, the fields along the roads of Lincoln County, Minn., like those along thousands of miles of prairie roads from Ohio to Colorado and Minnesota down to Texas, are lined with dead or dying things. Waves of leaves scuttle back and forth. The dried, crushed carcasses of birds or rabbits, victims of some speeding pickup truck's wheels, have been picked clean by brazen crows with beady eyes and oily feathers. Some of the corn has been picked by then; much has not, and in the winds, the crisp stalks rub against one another in a strange kind of death rattle.

title: GREAT COMPOSERS CELEBRATE THE CHARMS OF THE CLARINET
description: The clarinet has seduced some very creative ears.

title: SECOND TRIAL OF LOUISIANA GOVERNOR TO BEGIN
description: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and four co-defendants will return to Federal District Court on Monday to be retried on charges of racketeering and fraud.

title: PAYING FOR THE CHARTER DISCOUNT
description: As spring dawns, the lowest fare being quoted by British Airways for midsummer travel between New York and London is $639 round trip. A company called Travac Tours and Charters, however, is offering the same journey for $460. Similarly, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines is selling July round trips between New York and Amsterdam for $719, while the fare advertised by Council Charter for the same route at the same time is $463.

title: WILL THE SEA CLAIM SHOREHAM PLANT?
description: A National Academy of Sciences panel predicts a rise in sea level of one foot within the next few decades. What does this mean for Long Island, and most particularly for the Shoreham nuclear plant?

title: 5-OPERA SEASON SET IN PHILADELPHIA
description: LEONA MITCHELL will portray Madama Butterfly and Louis Quilico will sing Leporello to his son Gino Quilico's Don Giovanni in the Opera Company of Philadelphia's 1986-1987 season, the company's director, Margaret Anne Everitt, has announced.

title: Recent Sales
description: Dumont $134,000 72 Sherwood Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 1-bath, 42-year-old Cape Cod; *2*hardwood floors, eat-in kitchen, attached garage; taxes $1,845.
