Hillsborough $115,000 488-3B Auten Road *2*3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 6-year-old town-house condominium; *2*attached garage, basement, balconies, $90 monthly charges; taxes $1,938. Lakewood $66,900 114 Ronald Road *2*3 bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old ranch; *2*pool, new bathroom; taxes $942. Randolph $170,000 2 Schooner Court *2*4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; *2*central air-conditioning, full basement; taxes $3,175. South Orange $230,000 450 North Ridgewood Road *2*6-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old colonial; *2*library, den with quarry-tile floor, fireplace; taxes $4,681. Westwood $164,500 175 Lexington Avenue *2*3-bedroom, 2-bath, 56-year-old colonial; *2*pool, new bathroom; taxes $2,202. OTHER AREAS Peekskill, N.Y. $76,000 Chestnut Road *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 46-year-old frame ranch; *2*new eat-in kitchen and bath, well; taxes $1,334. New Haven, Conn. $82,000 12 Downing Street *2*2-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old Cape Cod; *2*wood stove, large closets, walk-in pantry; taxes $1,393. Mastic Beach, L.I. $97,920 22 Ann Road *2*6-bedroom, 2-bath, 12-year-old Cape Cod; *2*eat-in kitchen, laundry room, pool, deck; taxes $2,450.

title: SUSAN S. POWELL TO MARRY IN JULY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard McConnell Powell of Chevy Chase, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Sargent Powell, to Steven Michael Rosstad, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olav Rosstad of Clearwater, Fla.

title: AUDIO OPPORTUNITIES, NEW AND TOUGHER
description: NOT SO LONG AGO, an aspiring recording engineer might knock on the doors of a few recording studios, start out with a job sweeping floors, and gradually learn the business. Recent technological developments in sound reproduction have changed all that, and while today's budding audio specialist may still start work with broom in hand, he or she will probably need a degree just to get in the door.

title: Leaking of Radioactive Gas Reported at Three Mile Island
description: A small amount of radioactive gas spewed into the atmosphere at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant today in an ''unusual event'' for the Unit No. 1 reactor at the plant.

title: Israeli Lobby Dropping Its Objection on Saudis
description: The American-Israeli Public Affairs Committee, a lobby for Israeli interests, has dropped its opposition to a $350 million arms deal with Saudi Arabia, according to Administration sources.

title: Man and Woman Found Slain In an Apartment in the Bronx
description: A man and a woman were shot to death last night in an apartment in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: TOXIC CLEANUP FINANCING UNCLEAR
description: ALTHOUGH the Legislature is scheduled to tackle the question, ''How should we pay for the cleanup of hazardous-waste sites?'' next month, it still lacks several key pieces of information.

title: THE SHAPE THAT HE'S IN
description: YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! Written and illustrated by Dr. Seuss. Unpaged. New York: Random House. $9.95. YOU can't arrest Arnold Schwarzenegger for trying to be an actor, or Mayor Koch for wanting to be Fiorello La Guardia, or Norman Mailer for attempting elder statesmanship, and certainly nobody wants to arrest kindly Dr. Seuss for trying to write and illustrate a book for adults. It's a free country.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 3 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 4 30 (Viking, $17.95.) Recollections of a small American town. 3 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 2 18 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 4 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 3 8 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 5 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 5 4 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned to them. 6 CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 6 9 Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. 7 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 7 24 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 8 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. 8 4 (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 9 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 1 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 10 CONTACT, by Carl Sagan. (Simon & Schuster, 10 24 $18.95.) The commotion that follows the reception of a signal from intelligent life beyond Earth. 11 ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER, by Andrew M. Greeley. 13 6 (Bernard Geis/Warner, $17.95.) Father Blackie Ryan investigates when a woman's art gallery is wrecked by an eerie explosion. 12 THE LEBARON SECRET, by Stephen Birmingham. 9 7 (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Love and conflict among the LeBarons, a wealthy family of California vintners. 13 STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor 12 7 House, $17.95.) The pursuit of a stolen crystal with curative powers climaxes atop St. Patrick's Cathedral. 14 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. 11 27 (Knopf, $16.95.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 15 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 1 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 1 Nonfiction 1 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 5 2 House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 2 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 1 6 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 4 6 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 4 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 2 73 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 5 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 3 37 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) The story of the first man to fly faster than sound. 6 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 6 3 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 7 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 7 4 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 8 HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, 9 22 $17.95.) An account of the construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts. 9 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 11 6 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment bankers Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 10 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles 13 24 Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of Americans he's encountered. 11 DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. 8 26 (Bantam, $17.95.) The entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions. 12 NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and 10 2 Speed Vogel. (Putnam, $18.95.) The novelist's encounter with a nearly fatal disease. 13 THE FRINGES OF POWER, by John Colville. 15 6 (Norton, $25.) The diary of the private secretary of three British prime ministers illuminates the career of Winston Churchill. 14 A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 12 159 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 15 A PASSION FOR EXCELLENCE, by Tom Peters and 14 39 Nancy Austin. (Random House, $19.95.) Ways to achieve distinction in management. 16* ONLY ONE WOOF, by James Herriot. (St. 15 Martin's, $9.95.) The profusely illustrated true story of a Yorkshire sheepdog. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 31 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 17 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 4 25 (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 4 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 3 20 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 5 ONE MINUTE FOR MYSELF, by Spencer Johnson. 2 (Morrow, $15.) Advice on our relationships with ourselves and others.

title: STUDY FAULTS CLOSINGS OF TOXIC WASTE PLANTS
description: The Federal Government and six states have failed to make sure that facilities for storing and treating toxic wastes are following proper procedures to prevent harm to humans and the environment when they close down, a Congressional study says.

title: HIRING PRACTICES OF RIGHTS PANEL ARE CHALLENGED
description: The General Accounting Office says it has found numerous irregularities in the personnel practices, travel records and financial management of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The office is to present its findings to Congress Tuesday.

title: Manila Official Gives Stock to Investigators
description: Defense Minister Juan Ponce Enrile has turned over stock in a suspect corporation to the new Philippine Government, investigators announced today.

title: S-H-U-L-T-Z
description: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz spends increasing time in the national and international spotlight, you might think that Americans would learn to spell his name right. Well, they haven't.

title: WHOLESALE OUTLETS ARE EMERGING
description: CUTTING across the crafts community is the recognition that ''crafts are changing.'' Some people refer to a ''shakedown,'' others to ''a time of soul-searching.''

title: PERFORMANCE ART: 'DEAD STORIES'
description: THE downtown performing arts have recently been dominated by ''performance art,'' which is not as tautological as it sounds. Instead of music or dance or poetry or theater or video, the scene has been taken over by solo and group ''performances'' that owe no particular allegiance to any of those disciplines. Performers lap happily from art to art, most often in an atmosphere of cheerful amateurism or camp mockery.

title: OPERA: PAVAROTTI IN 'AIDA' AT THE MET
description: THERE is a tradition among opera tenors that encourages them to think of their vocal talent as a bank. A specific amount of voice is put on deposit early in life and is spent little by little until only at an advanced age, it is hoped, will the balance read zero. Some such thinking must explain why great lyric tenors such as Beniamino Gigli and Jussi Bjoerling felt it necessary or advisable to move from light roles into progressively heavier parts in their later years. Both, for instance, eventually took on Radames in ''Aida,'' one of the more taxing roles in the Italian repertory, though their voices never did come to sound at home in such hefty music.

title: GAINING BY LOSING
description: NECESSARY LOSSES The Loves, Illusions, Dependencies and Impossible Expectations That All of Us Have to Give Up in Order to Grow. By Judith Viorst. 447 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95. BACK in 1968, when the youthquake shook our land and anyone over 30 was deemed untrustworthy, Judith Viorst consoled an entire generation with her hilarious book of poems and perceptions, ''It's Hard to Be Hip Over Thirty and Other Tragedies of Married Life.'' A few years later, sensing the terror of those who would soon turn 40, Mrs. Viorst came to the rescue again, with ''How Did I Get to Be Forty and Other Atrocities.'' And so it has gone - through the years her many adult and children's books as well as her monthly columns in Redbook magazine have amused and instructed her readers as they struggle with the small and big challenges of everyday living.

title: MISS MONTGOMERY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: The wedding of Katherine Montgomery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Montgomery of Amityville, L.I., to Frederick C. Porter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred C. Porter 3d of Chesterland, Ohio, took place yesterday. The Rev. Margaret R. Eddy performed the nondenominational service at Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I.

title: WREN FLOECKHER WEDS G.N. SMITH
description: Barbara Wren Floeckher, a daughter of Peter Wren Floeckher of Stuart, Fla., and the late Diana Prosser Floeckher of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Nason Smith, a son of Philo Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Jane Nason Smith, also of Greenwich. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

title: KEAN BUDGET FOR SCHOOLS IS ATTACKED
description: DESPITE a proposed record $2.9 billion appropriation for state aid to education, Governor Kean's 1986-87 budget is under bipartisan attack for allegedly shortchanging public schools.

title: Q and A
description: Paying for Repairs Question: I am one of the owners in a 16-year-old, 57-unit condominium residence. It has become necessary to do extensive work on our building at a cost of nearly $500,000. Are there any Federal or state funds that might be available as a loan or a grant to help pay for this work? . . . E. P., Yonkers Answer: Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, says she knows of no way a co-op or condominium could qualify for such loans or grants. The Sound of Music Question: Does any city law restrict the time of day during which an apartment resident can practice a musical instrument? . . . E. P., Manhattan Answer: No, according to Martha Holstein, a spokesman for the New York City Department of Environmental Protec-Michael Bartalos tion. The municipal noise code, which includes restrictions such things as the hours for construction and the closing time for discotheques, does not limit the hours during which a resident can play a musical instrument. If a dispute arises, the agency encourages neighbors to work things out between themselves. Open House Question: If an apartment dweller chooses not to buy his unit when it is converted to a co-op or condominium, does the management or sponsor have the right to show the apartment to outside buyers at any time? What are a tenant's rights in this situation? . . . M. F., Brooklyn Answer: David Fishlow, a spokesman for the Attorney General's Office, says that management or a sponsor has the right to reasonable access to all units.

title: Martin Resigns From the Fed
description: Preston Martin, first of President Reagan's appointees to the Federal Reserve Board, surprised everyone last week except those who know how much he wanted the top job. After he cited personal reasons in announcing his resignation as vice chairman and a member of the Fed, a White House official who declined to be identified said Mr. Martin had ''wanted an assurance we couldn't give'' - a promise he would get Chairman Paul A. Volcker's post after Mr. Volcker's term expires next year. Mr. Martin's term in the second spot is up next week; he could have remained a member until 1996.

title: Rumiko Isaksen
description: Rumiko Isaksen, who began her music education in Japan and is continuing it at the Juilliard School, played an ambitious program of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday afternoon. Miss Isaksen has a healthy technique, a robust feeling for music, and in a Bach organ transcription (Fantasy and Fugue in A minor) she drew the musical line along with steady momentum.

title: WHERE REAGAN'S CONTRA PLAN WENT WRONG
description: The rhetorical line could not have been more clearly drawn in the final moments before the House of Representatives voted on President Reagan's proposed aid package to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: FOGLER TO WICHITA
description: In his 13 seasons as assistant to Dean Smith, North Carolina's acclaimed head basketball coach, Eddie Fogler has seen his name pop up from time to time as a possible head-coaching candidate. Yesterday, it popped up and stayed up. He was named head coach at Wichita State, replacing Gene Smithson, who was dismissed after compiling a 155-81 record in eight seasons.

title: A'S RELEASE GARBEY
description: Barbaro Garbey, the refugee from Cuba who helped the Detroit Tigers win a pennant and World Series in 1984 before being traded to Oakland, has been released by the A's. The 30-year-old Garbey, who plays first and third base and the outfield, was obtained by Oakland last November in exchange for the outfielder Dave Collins.

title: ALLISON A. BROWN TO MARRY IN JULY
description: Allison Ann Brown, an account executive for Ralph Lauren Womenswear, and Edward Barry McGeough, a corporate finance associate at Kidder, Peabody & Company Inc., both in New York, plan to marry in July. The engagement was announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. W. Perry Brown of Summit, N.J.

title: CITIES FACE 25% CUT IN U.S. HOUSING AID
description: COMMUNITY development programs in Connecticut's smaller cities will face a budget shortfall as a result of a change in the State Department of Housing's financing schedule.

title: GROWING POPULARITY WORRIES LITCHFIELD
description: IN the last few years, residents in Litchfield County have watched their rural communities become increasingly sought-after places to live.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: MAXIMUM IMMUNITY. By Michael A. Weiner with Kathleen Goss. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) Responding to current interest, Michael A. Weiner, the author of ''Nutrition Against Aging,'' ''Earth Medicine - Earth Foods'' and other books, tells us how to improve the functioning of the immune system through stress-reduction techniques, exercise and changed diet and attitudes.

title: MARY A. O'REILLY IS ENGAGED
description: A May wedding is planned by Mary Anne O'Reilly and Thomas Somerville Leffel, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. O'Reilly of Utica, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Leffel is a son of Joan Roberts of Corning, N.Y. and the late Phillip Clark Leffel Jr. Miss O'Reilly, a graduate of Skidmore College, is in sales with Morgan Stanley & Company. Mr. Leffel, a graduate of Hobart College, is a government bond trader for Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith.

title: FEW LEADS AND NO SUSPECTS FOUND IN TYLENOL DEATH IN WESTCHESTER
description: Six weeks after 23-year-old Diane Elsroth died of poisoning from cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules, the authorities appear to have made little progress toward solving the case.

title: WHAT MAKES A SUIT AMERICAN
description: The sack suit, first popularized at the turn of the century, typifies American tailoring. Originally the suit's jacket was made without a waist seam to taper its fit.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: THE PURSUIT OF HEALTH. By June Bingham and Norman Tamarkin. (Walker, $16.95.) The idea that the mind can influence the body's response to disease (and vice versa) has had a long and at times controversial history. In ''The Pursuit of Health,'' June Bingham, a writer, and Norman Tamarkin, a psychiatrist, travel two steps farther in the quest to determine ''why one person gets sick and another doesn't or why someone gets sick today and not tomorrow.'' To ''mind'' and ''body'' they add ''other people'' and ''the environment'' as factors that directly influence our state of well-being. They have constructed a model that integrates these four dimensions around a core, the ''intimate connector,'' that is the central force responsible for a patient's will to live or will to health. The authors cite examples of people who, against all odds and for reasons that defy clinical explanation, have survived an illness far beyond the expectations of their doctors. The book also includes six case histories that exemplify ways in which attention to dimensions other than the one causing the illness was the turning point in the patient's recovery. For example, a young woman who was suicidal (mind) is given a prescription for exercise and an enriched diet to improve her health (body) so she can begin to work on the weakened relationships (other people) that caused her illness in the first place. The message for physicians is that when examining patients, they should look well beyond the symptoms that brought the patient to them in the first place.

title: CONSIDERING DAY CARE AT THE WORK PLACE
description: As a social worker and founder of a self-help organization for women (WISH, Women-in-Self-Help), I read with great interest the article on day care on Feb. 2. WISH receives many calls from women in Westchester County seeking day care who have to ''make do'' with the inadequate resources that are available. Our calls confirm that there is, indeed, a ''crisis in day care'' in Westchester, as Lyn Yanuck, the executive director of the White Plains Children's Center, states.

title: REPORT ON TEXAS
description: University of Texas football players are selling their complimentary tickets to boosters at prices up to $600 per ticket in violation of collegiate rules, according to a report published today by The Dallas Morning News. The newspaper quoted former players as saying that Fred Akers, the coach, not only knew about the practice but also routinely cautioned players to be careful not to get the school in trouble with the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: DIANE ENGLANDER WEDS FELLOW LAWYER
description: Diane Englander, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Englander of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Alan Underberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan J. Underberg of Rochester. Justice Martin Evans of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title:
ART;
ON THE WALL: 7 ARTISTS WHO FIND BIGGER IS BETTER
description: AT THE beginning of this month, seven artists began to transform the Hillwood Gallery of Long Island University's C. W. Post Center into a giant art environment by creating large-scale works directly on the gallery walls. The result is an impressive exhibition titled ''Drawing in Situ,'' which not only confronts the viewer with provocative contemporary images but also expands the conventional definition of drawing itself.

title: Sharon Harrison
description: Sharon Harrison's soprano is full-sounding and well-made throughout its registers, but still has not quite acquired the easy flexibility to negotiate intricacies or shift smoothly from one timbre, mood or dynamic level into another. Her voice, which Miss Harrison gave us a chance to hear at Carnegie Recital Hall last Saturday afternoon, has some encouraging attributes, in other words, which remain either embryonic or only part-way grown.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLER
description: March 23, 1986 Fiction

title: OPEC Remains Split on Strategy
description: The 13 ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries gathered in Geneva last week to try to plug the leaks in their once-mighty cartel. On the table were various proposals to cut production - now about 17 million barrels a day - by as much as 5 million barrels, thus pushing prices up.

title: CANADA SEEMS TO PROFIT BY KEEPING A LOW PROFILE
description: PRIME MINISTER BRIAN MULRONEY has said that to most Americans Canada means snowstorms and the hockey star Wayne Gretzky. But this American misperception may well have done him more good than harm when he visited Washington last week.

title: HARTFORD STAGE OFFERS NEW WORKS
description: GIVEN the precariousness of producing an unknown play, world premieres are relative rarities in the state's regional theaters. To come upon a new work that is a predetermined winner, of a sort, is rarer still.

title: Fraternity Suspended For Anti-Semitic Acts
description: A fraternity and a sorority have been suspended at the University of Southern California because members chanted anti-Semitic slogans and painted ''Jew Week'' on a sidewalk outside a predominantly Jewish fraternity, university officials said.

title: PAVAROTTI AND SOLOISTS IN PHILADELPHIA CONCERT
description: Luciano Pavarotti and three winners of the Opera Company of Philadelphia-Luciano Pavarotti International Voice Competition will be the soloists in a performance of the Verdi Requiem on April 5 at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

title: ANN M. SCOTT PLANS TO WED
description: Lieut. Gen. Willard W. Scott Jr., Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, and Mrs. Scott of West Point, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ann Marie Scott to Francis Xavier Kilkelly, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Kilkelly Jr. of Flushing, Queens.

title: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Midway Collides With a Korean Boat
description: The aircraft carrier Midway collided with a South Korean fishing boat in the Yellow Sea on Friday, damaging the 45-foot fishing boat but leaving the 52,000-ton warship unscathed.

title: RAISSA MULHOLLAND WEDS MICHAEL ANTHONY PETRACCA
description: Raissa Mulholland, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Mulholland of Douglas Manor, Queens, was married yesterday to Michael Anthony Petracca, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Petracca of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Burns and the Rev. H. Charles Mulholland, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: HOW THE CALENDAR COULD COMPLICATE CAMPAIGNING
description: With Southern states organizing a regional Presidential primary in 1988 and states in other parts of the country talking about moving up their delegate-selection contests, some political experts are wondering why Democrats are congratulating themselves for having avoided another major overhaul of their nominating process.

title: HOW TO DRESS FOR SUMMER
description: There is not a summer spent in or around New York City when the wisdom of donning the conventional coat and tie for male business wear is not - heatedly - debated. I can remember attending a seminar on men's fashions in Paris during the late 1960's, at which the general consensus was that by 1980 men would finally be liberated from these sartorial contrivances and be able to wear jump suits or other androgynous outfits to the office. Given the highly volatile state of fashion then, this prediction did not seem in the least farfetched. It was. The principles of summer dressing, in fact, never really changed. If anything, there is a marked resurgence of traditional elements of style. On heat-ridden days, therefore, it is a great challenge to dress comfortably while not sacrificing some polish in the process. Allow me to offer some suggestions.

title: My Son, The Rastafarian
description: Apparently, Mario Vargas Llosa's son viewed the Rastafarian religion as a trend to dabble in, without really grasping its true meaning. It is not a form of rebellion, but rather a personal decision to celebrate life and living without prejudices. More simply said, contemporary Rastas believe in unification, brotherly love and spiritual awareness, nothing more and nothing less. KAREN RICKENBACH New York City

title: MUSIC GREETS THE EASTER SEASON
description: THE tone will be reverential as Christians throughout Long Island begin their celebration of Holy Week today with Palm Sunday services. As usual, much of the music will be familiar, with an emphasis on the liturgical compositions of such composers as Bach, Beethoven, Handel and Faure. But there are some different programs as well.

title: MUSIC, DANCE, ART, PARTIES
description: Coming Home March 25 - After its season at the Metropolitan Opera House last year, the exuberant Dance Theater of Harlem is staging a ''Harlem Homecoming,'' performing this year's season at Aaron Davis Hall on the campus of City College, 134th Street and Convent Avenue, marking the company's first performance season in Harlem. George Balanchine's ''Stars and Stripes'' and Glen Tetley's ''Voluntaries'' are among the works to be performed at the black-tie opening night performance and party to raise money for dance scholarships. Performance at 7:30 P.M. with champagne reception followed by a buffet dinner and cabaret review. Valet parking and taxi service available. Tickets, $100 for performance and champagne, $250 for performance, champagne and party, and $500 with a backstage pass at intermission, from 212-977-7751. Fledgling Cause . . . March 27 - Founded to support institutions and artists in the fine and performing arts, the Metropolitan Society for the Arts is holding its ''First Anniversary Gala,'' with cocktails, dessert and dancing at the Lycee Francais de New York, 3 East 95th Street, starting at 9 P.M. Tickets for black-tie evening, $60 at the door. . . . Mature Agency March 31 - The University Settlement House, founded 100 years ago, was the first of the neighborhood social agencies that were to be a major force in 19th- and 20th-century social reform. In conjunction with the Statue of Liberty's centennial, the history of University and other settlement houses will be shown at an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street, with a preview reception including chamber music, wine and hors d'oeuvres from 6 P.M. to 8 P.M. Tickets, $50, from 212-674-9120, extension 63.

title: HOTEL PREM, ANTIQUES-LADEN HAVEN IN HAMBURG
description: When one travels a lot, there come those terrible moments in the recesses of the night when one awakens in an antiseptic hotel room, fumbles with the multiple switches and buttons on the nightstand console, finds the button that turns on the table light (perhaps after first illuminating the bathroom and detonating the radio), gropes for the embossed matchbox of the establishment and squints at it for a sense of place: ''Ah, yes, I'm in Zurich.''

title: INTERPRETING LA GROSSE POMME: VIEW FROM JAPAN
description: Japanese-language guidebooks to New York readily reflect their publication in, and for, a country that is middle-class, racially homogeneous and relatively crime-free: they are entranced by those neighborhoods and stores catering to moneyed classes; they are more than a little bewildered by the city's multi-ethnic makeup, and they are appalled by so much public chaos. New York is, in the words of one paperback guide, ''a mixture of hell and heaven.''

title: WITH THE BORING PARTS LEFT OUT
description: ACTS OF WAR The Behavior of Men in Battle. By Richard Holmes. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. SOLDIERS A History of Men in Battle. By John Keegan and Richard Holmes with John Gau. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $22.95. THE great success of John Keegan's ''Face of

title: PURCHASING POWER Military Benefit?
description: Given that cigarette smoking is a formidable enemy to health, it seems strange that the military services continue to encourage the habit. How else to construe a discount of up to 35 percent on cigarettes sold at military installations?

title: LAUREN A. BONOFF, A BANKER, MARRIES H. W. FESSENDEN AT BROWN UNIVERSITY
description: Lauren Ann Bonoff and Hart Wade Fessenden were married yesterday at the Manning Chapel at Brown University by Judge Pamela Macktez of the Circuit Court of Rhode Island.

title: PURCHASING POWER Coin of Opportunity
description: With New York's transit fare at an even dollar, there is some consolation for subway riders in faster token booth sales. But there's none for bus riders; a dollar bill can't be digested by the bus coin machines.

title: ABBIE BOOKBINDER TO WED MARK R. MEYER IN AUGUST
description: The engagement of Abbie Constance Baker Bookbinder, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Coleman Bookbinder 3d of Gulph Mills, Pa., to Mark Rittman Meyer, the son of Donald Wayne Meyer and Janice Rittman Meyer, both of Long Beach, Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents. An August wedding is planned.

title: REAGAN, ANGERED, DENIES HIS POLICY AIMS AT LATIN WAR
description: President Reagan says some opponents of aid to the Nicaraguan rebels have engaged in ''scurrilous'' attacks on him and in ''outright falsehoods'' exceeding the bounds of fairness.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Mozart's 'Cosi fan tutte' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Thomas Allen, Helena Dose and Sylvia Lindenstrand, with the London Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by John Pritchard Video Arts International 150 minutes. $69.95 Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' is the best of all ensemble operas - perhaps the most inspired opera of any kind - and Glyndebourne's carefully rehearsed cast, its even blend of talents, more than compensate for the absence of ''star'' singers.

title: PATRICIA I. DOLAN WEDS ANDREW J. WELLENBACH
description: Patricia Irene Dolan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Myles F. Dolan of Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Andrew J. Wellenbach, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton L. Wellenbach of Philadelphia. The Rev. Ronald Pecci performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia.

title: OPENING IS MARKED AT HEALTH SCHOOL
description: State health officials formally inaugurated today the School of Public Health Sciences of the State University of New York, the first public-health school in the country to offer training within a major state health department.

title: THE ARMS RACE SHOW NO SIGNS OF SLOWING DOWN
description: SINCE 1945, the United States has conducted about 800 nuclear tests. Yet the Reagan Administration's decision to conduct another one yesterday sparked special concern in Congress and among arms-control specialists.

title:
ANTIQUES;
GALLIC FLAIR IN CLAIRIDGE COMMONS
description: WITH more than a touch of Gallic flair, Paris to Provence opened its doors at 476 Bloomfield Avenue 10 months ago in an enclave of smart shops surrounding the venerable Clairidge Theater.

title: FREEZING THOSE SUBJECTS IN ACTION PHOTOGRAPHY
description: CAPTURING high-speed action with a camera has traditionally been an important aspect of photography. When Dr. Harold Edgerton developed a practical electronic flash unit in the 1940's, making it possible to produce superior-quality pictures of high-speed sports and news events, his discovery enabled a generation of photographers to capture images of pole vaulters at the peak of a jump, boxers being hit in the face - even drops of milk exploding into liquid crowns upon hitting a surface.

title: BUZZING NEW ZEALAND
description: Wearing jeans, sneakers, a parka and goggle sunglasses, the helicopter pilot turned to his two passengers, after carefully checking his instruments, and asked whether they wanted the flight to be the regular one or ''a bit of a buzz.'' The passengers elected the buzz.

title: INDISCRETIONS OF THE BOURGEOISIE
description: BOHEMIAN PARIS Culture, Politics, and the Boundaries of Bourgeois Life, 1830-1930. By Jerrold Seigel. Illustrated. 453 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $25. FOR all its mystery and exoticism, bohemia has seemed definable - a place of free thinking and free love, where young and impoverished artists and poets flout middle-class pieties and conventions. Jerrold Seigel, a historian at Princeton University, sets out to challenge and deepen our thinking about this subject in ''Bohemian Paris,'' and he succeeds admirably.

title: BALLESTEROS FEELS STUCK IN THE ROUGH
description: Seve Ballesteros hooked a big downwind drive at the sixth hole Friday, and his ball was 20 feet behind a huge tree in the short rough of the par-5 hole. First he took his 3-iron iron and waggled it a few times over the ball. Then he put that back in the bag and pulled out a 4-wood. This wasn't just right, so he took out the 3-iron again, only to finally put it back and take out the 2-iron.

title: SUPPORTERS OF LaROUCHE ARE WINNING LOCAL BALLOT SPOTS IN GROWING NUMBERS
description: With their upset victories in the Democratic primary in Illinois, the followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche, an eccentric far rightist and anti-Communist who has run for President three times, have penetrated the American political system in a way that few had thought possible.

title: SALVAGE EFFORT YIELDS CLUES ON SHUTTLE CREW CABIN
description: From the slow, painful recovery of debris from the ocean floor near here, a picture is emerging of what happened to the Challenger's crew compartment after the explosion that ripped the space shuttle apart.

title: RULES SEEK TO CUT POWERBOAT ACCIDENTS
description: A rash of serious accidents last year among offshore powerboat racers has sounded an alarm among race officials who are concerned that attempts at speed records could drive the accident rate even higher.

title: WHEN DON QUIXOTE LEFT HIS VILLAGE, THE MODERN WORLD BEGAN
description: While visiting the rare-book collection at the University of Virginia in the late 1970's, Carlos Fuentes happened on a 1755 edition of Miguel de Cervantes' ''Don Quixote'' translated by Tobias Smollett. Mr. Fuentes had not known the translation existed and was intrigued. He hardly slept that night, reading what he felt was the best English translation of the Spanish classic. Shortly thereafter he called Roger Straus, the president of his New York publisher, Farrar, Straus & Giroux, and suggested that he reissue the translation. The following essay is adapted from Mr. Fuentes's foreword and introduction to Smollett's ''Adventures of Don Quixote de la Mancha,'' published this month for the first time in America. WHEN I was a young student in

title: NICARAGUA'S NEIGHBORS ARE WARY
description: It is difficult to find a Central American government official who is not highly critical of Nicaragua's Sandinistas. Still, no leader in the region was willing last week to support President Reagan's campaign to provide $100 million for anti-Sandinista guerrillas. This public silence seemed particularly galling to United States officials who contended that Central Americans had recently confided to Mr. Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, that indeed they supported the President's position.

title: PHILADELPHIA BRACES FOR UNION TALKS
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode, in what shapes up as another critical confrontation for his battered administration, this week set himself on what appeared to be a collision course with the four unions that represent Philadelphia's 25,000 municipal employees.

title: GRACE ABOUNDING IN BOTSWANA
description: WHITES By Norman Rush. 150 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. A CHILDHOOD spent on the Laguna Pueblo

title: PRESIDENT VOICES REGRET AT CARTER'S CRITICISM
description: President Reagan, saying he ''felt very bad'' about Jimmy Carter's recent criticisms of him, has praised the former President's record on national defense and wants to tell him so face-to-face.

title: What Price Fitness?
description: Perhaps it is the role of a 48-year-old writer to complain that dragging himself to the gym on a regular basis will not guarantee him life eternal. Mr. Lipsyte may be in ''average'' physical condition, but many (if not most) people in his age group are way below that standard. And while he continues to work out, many of your readers may not.

title: SHAPING A LANDFILL INTO A NEIGHBORHOOD
description: AN idealized New York City neighborhood -one combining Fifth Avenue-style apartment houses, reproductions of Central Park's lamps and benches, and the views and atmosphere of the Brooklyn Heights Promenade - is rising on 92 acres of landfill between the Hudson River and the World Trade Center.

title: 2 CULTURES ARE SUCCESSFUL PARTNERS
description: IF YOU ever doubted that it is possible to do two things at once and do both well, try the new East West Cafe in Merrick. As its name implies, it serves both Chinese and Continental food.

title: STEPS TO STAMP OUT CORRUPTION
description: WHILE New York City's ongoing corruption scandal has grabbed the attention of the public and the press for the last two months, we on Long Island would do well to remember that we are not immune from similar abuses.

title: NEW CODE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Massachusetts will get a third telephone area code by early 1989 to prevent the state from running out of telephone numbers, the New England Telephone Company says. The 617 code area in the eastern part of the state will be split to create the new area, the company announced Tuesday. The new code number has not been selected.

title: IN SHORT
description: HOME HEALTH CARE: A Complete Guide for Patients and Their Families. By Jo-Ann Friedman. (Norton, $22.50.) The very successes of modern medicine have, ironically, generated increasing demands for new forms of health care.

title: Housing Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA CREATES INDUSTRIES FROM DUNG AND MUD
description: On the plains of central India, followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi are working with scientists and technicians to develop ''village technology'' for the country's rural masses.

title: LIGHT-BULB CHANGING: A WORD OF ILLUMINATION
description: President Sheldon Grebstein [ of the State University of New York at Purchase ] apparently has never changed a light bulb. He must call an electrician every time a burned-out light bulb in his home needs replacement.

title: ASSURANCE SOUGHT ON TV COVERAGE
description: NEW JERSEY'S Congressional delegation is pressing for fresh assurances that WOR-TV, currently the state's only commercial VHF television station, will increase its coverage of New Jersey under its new ownership.

title: DEMOCRATS ON BOARD PRESENT REPLY TO O'ROURKE
description: THE Democratic minority on the Board of Legislators challenged County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's leadership last week, saying that he consistently fails to follow through on changes he proposes to the county legislative body.

title: DUAL-POWER ENGINES ALREADY EXIST
description: The Feb. 23 article on the delay in electrifying the Long Island Rail Road's Port Jefferson branch suggests as an alternative to electrification the use of dual-power (i.e., diesel-electric/straight-electric) engines to bring passengers directly into Pennsylvania Station with neither a change of train nor a change of engine required, as at present.

title: JANICE FARRELL WEDS OWEN HEARTY JR.
description: Janice Elizabeth Farrell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Farrell of Washington, D.C., was married yesterday to Owen E. Hearty Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hearty of Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. John Duffell performed the ceremony at the Lady Chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: WORDS THAT HEAL -- DOCTORS TALK ABOUT THEIR WRITING
description: The Book Review asked 10 men and women who work in the field of medicine and also write about it how their books have affected their place in the discipline and their relations with patients. RICHARD RESTAK, neurologist: ''The Brain.'' I don't discuss my writing with medical colleagues any more than I discuss my patients with journalists and editors. With patients, the situation is more complicated. They often can tell if their doctor is interested in them for themselves or only as background for a book. I constantly remind myself, therefore, that my patients are like patients in every age and every place: they seek a cure or some palliation for their suffering or, at the very least, someone who will accept them, listen to them and thereby help them in ways that cannot always be explained. PENELOPE LEACH, psychologist: ''Your Baby and Child.'' One day I was a research psychologist discussing Apgar scores (a measure of newborns' physical condition) with medical colleagues. Next day I was a mother, asking my baby's Apgar and being told, ''Leave that to us.'' Still resenting the authoritarianism, the chauvinism of some doctors dealing with people they insist on addressing as ''Mother,'' I have learned how deep a communication gulf there can be, even when doctors acknowledge parents' rights and try to explain. Sick children mean anxious parents who may be unable to hear the doctor's messages. Parents say that honest medical information, absorbed calmly from books and magazines, radio and television, paves the way for understanding.

title: CITY VAN TAKES HOUSING INFORMATION INTO BOROUGHS
description: ON a frigid winter morning, Ernie Donalson opened the door to his carpeted, wood-paneled office. He set the radio dial to a lite-FM station, drew back the curtains and set space heaters on high. He straightened sofa cushions and swivelled upholstered chairs to face their mates across intimate tables. An adjustment to the rear-view mirror, a glance at the gas gauge and his workday had officially begun.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: THE HIDDEN ADDICTION: And How to Get Free. By Janice Keller Phelps and Alan E. Nourse. (Little, Brown, Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $9.95.)

title: STATE'S RESEARCH CENTERS ARE MAKING HEADWAY
description: NEW JERSEY'S ambitious long-range project to transform its economy by encouraging and feeding an expanding network of high-technology businesses continues to gain momentum and open doors to new careers. Five shared-research centers capable of conducting theoretical experiments beyond the scope of their individual industrial members have been established on university campuses in the state, and two others are about to start up. The project's current budget is nearly double that of the last fiscal year, and entrepreneurship and venture capital are being stimulated.

title: A CHRONIC INVALID
description: FIFTH ROW CENTER A Critic's Year On and Off Broadway. By Benedict Nightingale. 346 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95. BENEDICT NIGHTIN=

title: DANCE: JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE PERFORMS
description: THE Juilliard Dance Ensemble is presenting a program of ''New and Repertory dances'' this afternoon and tomorrow night and the new is a work by Michael Uthoff, a Juilliard School graduate who is now the director of the Hartford Ballet.

title: DEFENDING 'ALL THE DECENT DRAPERY OF LIFE'
description: MARRIAGE AND MORALS AMONG THE VICTORIANS Essays. By Gertrude Himmelfarb. 253 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. WHEN introducing Cambridge undergraduates to Victorian marriage and morality, I direct them first to Sir John Plumb's sparkling little piece ''The Victorians Unbuttoned'' for some flavor of the distinctive nature of the Victorian moral code and for some sense of the political, economic and social anxieties that led to the development of those remarkable moral attitudes. Thereafter I introduce them to the work of Martha Vicinus, Peter Cominos, Wanda Neff, Elaine Showalter, Keith Thomas, Lawrence Stone and Peter Gay, among others. When I now add Gertrude Himmelfarb's ''Marriage and Morals Among the Victorians'' to my list of recommended reading it will have to be with warning words of explanation and qualification.

title: GOVERNOR AND REPUBLICANS STILL DIVIDED ON BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders resumed negotiations today on a $41.4 billion state budget, but they remained far apart on several key issues, including the size of tax cuts.

title: ...AND BABY MAKES FOUR
description: We were going to southern France alone. Ah yes, just the two of us. Our first trip since the baby was born 18 months earlier. We talked to infant psychologists and made elaborate plans to ease the impending separation: daily telephone calls, tape recordings of our voices, visits by selected family and friends.

title: EAST IS EAST AND WEST IS CHANGING
description: On a recent flight between Los Angeles and San Francisco, the passenger on my right was a young Ivy League-educated lawyer, the man on my left an engineer in the oil business. The lawyer had moved to Los Angeles to practice entertainment law. After 18 months of seemingly unflagging sunshine and ubiquitous palm trees, he said he still found it disorienting to negotiate a deal dressed in a polo shirt, khakis and jogging shoes. The oil man had come to California after having spent the early part of his career in Houston. He had expected the same informal dress code - cowboy boots included - that he had known in Texas. To his surprise, his new boss in Los Angeles had encouraged him to wear a suit and tie.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 2 WORRIES FOR BANGKOK: GROWING AND SINKING
description: This is a city with more than five and a half million people and no sewage system. It is a city sinking into its soft-clay base at a rate of almost four inches a year, officials say. Most of it will soon be below sea level. It is a city whose storied canals are now ecologically dead, polluted by organic and chemical waste.

title: CUSTODIANS TO BE TESTED FOR ASBESTOS EXPOSURE
description: More than half of the custodians in New York City's public schools are to be screened for diseases caused by asbestos, according to school and union officials.

title: LONGTIME GOVERNOR AND SENATOR
description: John W. Bricker, a Republican Governor who ran for Vice President on the party's ticket in 1944 and served in the United States Senate for two terms, died today. He was 92 years old.

title: RAINCOAT OF THE YEAR
description: LAST fall a number of New York women discovered a stylish and practical wool-lined vinyl raincoat that is ideal for cool, in-between days. Now that heavy winter clothes are being put away, this shiny raincoat is showing up again, this time in even greater profusion.

title: IT'S HOMECOMING TIME FOR HARLEM'S BALLET COMPANY
description: When I think about the Dance Theater of Harlem, whose ''Harlem Homecoming'' opens Tuesday at City College's Aaron Davis Hall, I begin to reminisce against a flood of images that lead back to that dreadful moment in 1968 when a bullet ended the life of Martin Luther King Jr. I remember wandering aimlessly, feeling only the emptiness, the loss. Then came the call from Arthur Mitchell. I remember how we wrestled with out thoughts, trying to find a way to perpetuate Dr. King's dream.

title: Arctic Foxes on Island In Aleutians to Be Killed
description: All the Arctic foxes on an Aleutian island are to be poisoned because they threaten the survival of the rare Aleutian Canada goose, officials say.

title: BOSTON CASE REVIVES PAST AND PASSIONS
description: SENDING a baseball player down to the minor leagues is usually a routine matter. But when the Boston Red Sox shipped a rookie named Pumpsie Green to their Minneapolis farm team in 1959, it caused an uproar. The local chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. called the move ''outrageous,'' and team officials were called to testify before the state commission against discrimination.

title: IN DENMARK, RELIEF FOR THE TORTURED
description: When Luciano Vasquez landed in Denmark as a political refugee after three years in Chilean military prisons, he carried a double burden in addition to the anxieties that normally accompany exile.

title: FLORIDA RAPIST EVADES INTENSE POLICE INVESTIGATION
description: The Dade County police are seeking a rapist who has attacked 45 women in south Florida since 1981 in what has become one of the most intensive investigations in county history.

title: Pop Music
description: The Blasters, from Los Angeles, have filled their albums with blues and country-rock songs as tersely meaningful as the old classics that were the original staples of their live performances. Nevertheless, their records haven't really conveyed what the band is like live - the energy, the raw edge, the drive.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 'GAMES' BY BREHM Alvin Brehm, dean of the music school at the State University of New York at Purchase, will contribute to the concert of the Saxon Wood Chamber Players at 3 P.M. today through a premiere performance of his short work called ''Games.'' He composed it on commission from the New York State Council on the Arts especially for the ensemble. Sections within the piece are titled ''Tag,'' ''King-of-the-Hill,'' ''Seesaw'' and ''Tug of War.''

title: CONTROVERSY INTENSIFIES ON SHELLFISH SAFETY
description: JAMES REDMAN, a shellfish biologist with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, has a map in his office in Stony Brook. On the map are shaded areas that represent Long Island waters closed to shellfishing because of high coliform bacteria counts.

title: CORRECTION AGENCY REPLACES ITS CHIEF UNIFORMED OFFICIAL
description: The highest uniformed official in the City Department of Correction has been replaced as part of a major reorganization intended to improve the management of the city's jails, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Article 990686 -- No Title
description: The Union Carbide Corporation and lawyers for victims of the gas leak in Bhopal, India, have reached a tentative settlement of the tens of billions of dollars in damage claims from history's worst industrial disaster, according to sources involved in the case.

title: Verbatim; Supply and Demand
description: 'The young people just aren't there. It's a shift from youngsters competing for jobs to jobs competing for youngsters.

title: Uganda Starts New Paper
description: The Ugandan Government started publishing a weekly newspaper, New Vision, today as the voice for President Yoweri Museveni's National Resistance Movement.

title: ILLINOIS POLITICS PRODUCES SOME STRANGE RESULTS
description: WHEN Gov. James R. Thompson, a Republican, went to cast his ballot Tuesday in the Illinois primary election, precinct workers in this heavily Democratic city could not immediately find a G.O.P. primary ballot for him.

title: RUMORS REAPPEAR WITH SOUTH KOREAN COUPLE
description: In January 1978 one of South Korea's most prominent film actresses disappeared while on a trip to Hong Kong. Six months later her former husband, South Korea's most famous film director, disappeared while ostensibly searching for her.

title: Marcos's Papers Given To a U.S. Grand Jury
description: All documents impounded by the United States Customs Service after former President Ferdinand E. Marcos sought sanctuary in Hawaii have been turned over to a Federal grand jury, a Justice Department attorney said here Friday.

title: GERBER'S MCKINLEY STARTS TO RELAX
description: AT the height of the scare over glass in Gerber baby food, William L. McKinley was asked to contrast his stubborn style of crisis management with Johnson & Johnson's quick decision to halt production of Tylenol capsules after one laced with cyanide killed a 23-year-old woman.

title: FREUD, THE GREATEST MODERN WRITER
description: SIGMUND FREUD began his characteristic work exactly a century ago, when in 1886 he opened a private practice in Vienna for the treatment of hysteria. A decade later, just before his 40th birthday, he began to use his personal term, ''psychoanalysis,'' to describe his mode of therapy. Psychoanalysis still survives among us, as an isolated and disputable therapy, a particular variety of psychiatry. As such, though international in scope, it can be said to have become a small subbranch, almost a sect, within American psychiatric medicine. Freud hated the notion that his legatees would be part of the American medical profession, since he cordially disliked both the United States and most doctors of medicine. His preference in disciples would have continued to be European intellectuals, lay analysts with broad cultural interests who could have applied the Freudian theory of the mind to every sort of cultural or social question. In some sense, Hitler destroyed Freud's world, and with it such hopes.

title: IN 3 STATES, BIDS TO CUT FUEL LEAKS
description: Amid growing concern about the pollution of water supplies from leaking gasoline and fuel oil tanks, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are intensifying their efforts to regulate the tens of thousands of underground storage tanks in their states.

title: Tampering Scare Rekindles Doubts About the Capsule
description: Should companies stop making over-the-counter drugs in capsule form? The debate began anew last week after small traces of rat poison were found in Contac cold medicine and two other products made by SmithKline Beckman Corporation.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO WORK HARD FOR REPUBLICAN CANDIDATES
description: President Reagan says he intends to involve himself deeply in this year's Congressional elections, traveling widely to speak in behalf of Republican candidates.

title: A TOWN'S PURSUIT OF ITS OWN TRIVIA
description: WHEN the Windham Federation of Teachers decided to devise a game to test people on town trivia, it originally considered printing 50 or 100.

title: A (DATA) BANK OF FLOWERS
description: The flowers appear on the earth . . .

title: MUTANT ELITES
description: THE DOG IS US And Other Observations. By Marcelle Clements. 338 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. THIS is a collection of articles and essays reporting that surviving members of the 1960's ''youth movement'' are getting through their middle years only because psychotherapy and antidepressant drugs like Elavil are there to console them. Reading it, I kept thinking of the La Brea tar pits in Los Angeles, where eons ago animals of kinds that no longer exist went to drink and were trapped by the treacherous tar. I also kept envisioning Idealism and Intensity and Political Awareness and, especially, Social Conscience as large, innocent, unadaptable ungulates, sinking like future fossils into the merciless pits of Neurosis and Materialism.

title: THE PRICE OF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THE BIBLIOPHILE, A BOOK IS MORE THAN A BOUND VOLUME
description: ''HAVE you actually read all these books?'' That's usually the first question asked of me by people who, on coming to my home for the first time, see the almost 12,000 books that line the walls and fill the attic and basement.

title: PROTESTERS INCREASE PRESSURE ON HAITI'S NEW RULERS
description: Protesters chanting ''Down with the Government!'' set up roadblocks north of the capital today as pressure intensified on the military and civilian officials who came to power when the Duvalier regime fell six weeks ago.

title: MONICA A. ROGERS PLANNING TO WED
description: Dr. and Mrs. O. Carlisle Rogers of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Monica Arnette Rogers, to Thomas Barker Hollingsworth Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollingsworth of Rock Hill, S.C. The wedding is planned for July 26. The future bride, a teacher at the South Carolina School for the Deaf and Blind in Spartanburg, S.C. graduated from Ashley Hall in Charleston, S.C., and from Converse College.

title: CHINESE COKING METHODS CAN BE APPLIED TO DAILY FARE
description: MORE and more, the ideas I pick up from Chinese cooking influence the way I make regular meals. Like many people, I stir-fry food in a wok and steam vegetables as a matter of course. But recently I've been improvising freely and combining Chinese tastes and techniques with basically Western dishes.

title: ENDURING AFFECTION FOR THE DOUBLE-BASS
description: ''The double-bass has an extraordinary sound,'' Gary Karr said the other day. ''I think of it in terms of chocolate: it's rich, dark and creamy. I love chocolate so much that if I couldn't play the bass, I think I'd weigh 500 pounds.''

title: A CRY IN THE SOFT MORNING, A SPRING'S PROMISE LOST
description: IT was a sound I will never forget; a sound I pray I will never hear again.

title: COMEDIANS TO HARNESS HUMOR ON BEHALF OF THE HOMELESS
description: As many socially concerned humorists have pointed out, comedy is not only a laughing matter. And such is the case with ''Comic Relief,'' an effort to harness the forces of humor on behalf of the nation's homeless that will be presented on HBO Saturday evening at 9.

title: MARGOT MURTAUGH BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Margot Thorington Murtaugh and John McCullough Snell were married yesterday in Inverness, Calif. The Rev. Richard Raines and the Rev. Jamie Baraz officiated at a nondenominational service in a private home.

title: DEMOCRATIZING LUNCHES, I.R.S. STYLE
description: FOR now, few workers are being affected by a new I.R.S. rule that taxes cheap company meals as a fringe benefit. Companies are finding loopholes in the law, and ways to exploit them.

title: ALEXANDRA TRUITT TO WED ADAM REMEZ ON MAY 17
description: A May 17 wedding is planned by Alexandra Truitt and Adam Frederic Remez, the future bride's mother, Anne Dean Truitt of Washington, has announced.

title: DO NEURONS CRY?
description: THE THREE-POUND UNIVERSE By Judith Hooper and Dick Teresi. Illustrated. 410 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25. MIND is such an odd predicament for matter to get into. I often marvel how something like hydrogen, the simplest atom, forged in some early chaos of the universe, could lead to us and the gorgeous fever we call consciousness. If a brain is just three pounds of blood, dreams and electricity, how does it manage to contemplate itself, worry about its soul, do time and motion studies, admire the shy hoofs of a goat, know that it will die, enjoy all the grand and lesser mayhem of love? What is mind, that one can be ''out of one's . . .''? How can a neuron feel compassion? What is a self if, as Judith Hooper and Dick Teresi observe, ''what our Victorian grandparents used to call 'character' is contained in an intricate matrix of speech centers, motor pathways, and minute electrical circuits''? Why did automatic, hand-me-down mammals like our ancestors somehow evolve brains with the ability to consider, imagine, project, compare, abstract, think of the future? If our experience of mind is really just the simmering of an easily alterable chemical stew, then what does it mean to know something, to want something, to be?

title: Harvard Drops Plan to Send 30 Students to South Africa
description: Harvard University, under pressure from students and faculty members, has dropped a $1 million program to send students to study and work at South African schools.

title: IT WASN'T ST. LEO'S
description: KENTUCKY always brought out the underdog in Dale Brown - starting with the history of five national championships in Lexington, moving onto the missiles launched from the seats at Rupp Arena and including the physical poundings Kentucky administered to Louisiana State University out on the court.

title: OF MEDIEVAL ENGLAND, MODERN SCOTLAND
description: Celebrating Domesday's 900 Years At Christmas in the year 1085, nearly two decades after the Norman invasion of England, King William the Conqueror commissioned a survey and census of his new realm.

title: MEDIA-LASHED AND SEX-LISTED
description: RECKLESS EYEBALLING By Ishmael Reed. 148 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95. AN interloper ties up feminist writers at gunpoint, denounces them for defaming black men, shaves their heads and departs, leaving a chrysanthemum behind. The Flower Phantom's first victim is the playwright Tremonisha Smarts, at once lauded and despised for ''Wrong-Headed Man'' - a stage drama in which a black man batters and sodomizes his wife, commits incest and attempts unnatural acts with fish. Farther down the leather-clad avenger's list is Becky French, the queen archfeminist producer who controls the New York theater establishment, advocates castration of rapists and administers the ''sex list,'' a roster of male playwrights whose careers she keeps in ruin because their works are not politically correct. As the Phantom's attacks become commonplace, black men show their approval by wearing chrysanthemums on their lapels.

title: National Bridge Tourney Won By a Couple From New Jersey
description: The top-seeded team was upset in one national championship and David and Lisa Berkowitz of Harmon Cove, N.J., won a decisive victory in the National Mixed Pairs Friday night in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: WHERE TO HEAR EASTER MUSIC
description: THE joy of Easter Day, following the solemnity of Holy Week, has its most familiar musical expression in two works, the ''Hallelujah Chorus'' from Handel's ''Messiah,'' and the ''Toccata'' or final movement of the Fifth Symphony for organ by Charles-Marie Widor. Widor was a late 19th- and early 20th-century French organist and composer of great ability, but his output and fame are at best minimal compared with Handel's.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:My wife and I are going to Europe and have Blue Cross and Blue Shield medical insurance as well as Medicare. We would like to buy more insurance and want to know where we can get it and the cost. -J. P., Largo, Fla. Answer:Access America, a subsidiary of Blue Cross and Blue Shield, offers a travel protection package that covers medical expenses overseas of up to $10,000 a person and $20,000 a family. Payment is made directly to the doctors, dentists or hospitals whose services are used, a spokesman for Access America said. She added that the coverage also included a 24-hour hot line that travelers can call from anywhere in the world for help and advice. The company, she said, provides transportation overseas to a suitable medical facility and evacuation back to the United States if recommended by local and Access America doctors. For a two-week vacation, the cost of the insurance ranges from $3 to $6 a day a person. The top rate includes baggage and accident insurance and trip cancellation due to illness. All clients are covered for legal assistance in case of an accident or other problem. A family (traveler, spouse and dependents under age 25) pays up to 40 percent more. Information about the plan is available by calling 800-851-2800 between 8 A.M. and 6 P.M. Monday through Friday and 800-453-8000 at other times.

title: CHINESE COOKING METHODS CAN BE APPLIED TO DAILY FARE
description: MORE and more, the ideas I pick up from Chinese cooking influence the way I make regular meals. Like many people, I stir-fry food in a wok and steam vegetables as a matter of course. But recently I've been improvising freely and combining Chinese tastes and techniques with basically Western dishes.

title: HANDICAPPED AID: A FIGHT ON COSTS
description: AS the cost of educating physically and mentally handicapped children continues to climb on Long Island and around the state, local and state officials are locked in a disagreement both over how to serve the children best and who should pay the bills.

title: Beach-Home Owners Fear Inroads of Sea
description: VISITORS to the 74-year-old shingle waterfront home of Robert Werner, an artist who lives on a sandy peninsula in Fairfield, Conn., marvel at its proximity to the sea. Waves toss and churn seemingly right up to the rear windows, and sitting on the wooden back porch is like relaxing on the deck of a ship.

title: A COZY SPOT OFFERING LIGHT FARE
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY has its share of small, informal restaurants where young professionals gather for fare that is generally light and easy to put together.

title:
DINING OUT;
FRENCH FLAIR IN HUNT-CLUB THEME
description: NEW and well-situated in central White Plains, Le Jockey Club occupies the site of and takes its name from the old Jockey Club. Those who knew the old place will feel at home, for any change in decor is imperceptible. The theater-lobby carpeting remains, as do the trappings from the subdued hunt club theme: hunting horns, equestrian prints and polished brass against wood paneling. But, as the Francofied name suggests, these days the menu has a French accent.

title: MANAGUA PRELATE IS PRESSED ON WAR
description: More than two dozen disfigured war veterans, some in wheelchairs and others missing limbs, arrived Friday morning at the office of Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo.

title: A LOCAL QUARTET SCORES A POPULAR VICTORY
description: An American player who decides to try his luck in a major European tournament has a few surprises in store, most of them welcome ones. There is likely to be a corporate sponsor, providing substantial cash prizes. A day's play will consist of one long session instead of two short ones, permitting a carefree dinner on Saturday and a quick getaway on Sunday.

title: HOT-SHOOTING 76ERS TOP NETS
description: As if the Nets haven't had enough problems lately, tonight they confronted a Philadelphia team that broke shooting records.

title: COPPER'S PLUNGE IS PUSHING MINING TOWNS TO THE BRINK
description: Boiling with fury at copper companies and indignation at the plight of her town, Pat Morales, a long-time resident, pointed at empty storefronts. ''That service station is closed,'' she exclaimed. ''That furniture store is closed. There are 41 businesses here that are closed.''

title: Macy's Forced to Lock Doors As Group Protests Fur Coats
description: Macy's at Herald Square was forced to lock its front doors for about an hour yesterday after a scuffle between customers and demonstrators protesting the use of animal fur in coats.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN COURT BARS BANNING OF ACTIVIST
description: The Supreme Court, in a rebuff to the Government, today invalidated severe restrictions imposed on a black activist.

title: Meese in India for Talks
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d arrived here today for talks on fighting heroin trafficking. He said on arrival that the United States is determined to wipe out ''the worldwide network of drug criminals.'' He heads a Presidential delegation on drug trafficking and terrorism that will also visit Thailand, Burma and Pakistan.

title: SUSAN W. ALDEN TO MARRY IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ellinwood Alden of Riverside, Conn., and Penobscot, Maine, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Wolcott Alden, and Denis de Viry Frelinghuysen, a son of Mrs. Thomas T. K. Frelinghuysen of Princeton, N.J., and Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Frelinghuysen. A May 31 wedding is planned.

title: Shhhhh
description: Sondra Gotlieb, the author of several books and the wife of the Canadian Ambassador to the United States, Allan E. Gotlieb, said at a lunch last fall that the three things Americans say to her most often are: ''Whatever happened to Margaret?'' (a reference to the former wife of former Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau); ''Are you separating from Quebec or Nova Scotia?'' and ''Too bad about the Blue Jays.'' Last week she might have added, ''Why did you slap your social secretary?'' The incident was reported to have occurred at the embassy residence in Washington before a dinner for the Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney. Except for confirmation from a spokesman that ''an incident of a purely personal character'' had occurred and that an apology had been ''extended at once and at once accepted,'' the diplomatic community drew a veil.

title: BERBICK WINS W.B.C. CROWN
description: Trevor Berbick, a 6 1/2-1 underdog, got into the trenches with previously unbeaten Pinklon Thomas and took away the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship tonight with a unanimous 12-round decision.

title: INTERPRETING LA GROSSE POMME: VIEW FROM ITALY
description: If you are Italian and getting ready for a trip to the Big Apple, your guidebook may advise you to pack at least the following items: a Walkman (not for listening to music, but to drown out the noise); a pair of running shoes (so that you can fit in with the hordes of office workers on the street), and at least one well-trained animal to keep you company, preferably a dog. If none of the above is available, then a monkey suit will do.

title: SPEAKERS DISCERN LESS ANTI-SEMITISM IN U.S.
description: Fifty years ago, Milton Himmelfarb of the American Jewish Commitee recalled, there was a charged debate at Columbia University over whether Lionel Trilling should be made a tenured professor. Mr. Trilling, the late literary critic, was a Jew, and his religion was the key issue in the debate.

title: GIVING EQUAL TIME TO BAD ART AS THE STUFF OF HISTORY
description: ''From Courbet to Cezanne: A New 19th Century'' at the Brooklyn Museum is an exhibition of the greatest curiosity. A loan show, billed as a preview of the upcoming Musee d'Orsay in Paris, it includes paintings, sculptures, photographs, playbills, posters, models for stage sets, illustrated books, a quick scamper through the decorative arts in all their variety and some vivid extracts from the incunabula of the movie industry. Its time span is from 1850 to 1905.

title: COPING WITH ANXIETIES THAT GO WITH SUCCESS
description: CAREER ANXIETY. It comes at different times, for different reasons, very often during college or just after.

title: KEEPING A LID ON A DIVORCE LAWYER'S BILL
description: SUPPOSE your marriage is in shreds, and you and your spouse agree on just one thing -that you cannot live together anymore. You need an attorney, but where should you turn?

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 33 FOOD OUTLETS FOR HEALTH OFFENSES
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 33 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
MATH GATHERING
description: More than 200 people are expected at the State University of New York in Purchase on April 25 and 26 to hear discussions on such topics as the last 500 years in number theory and the analysis of the curvature of spaces. While these are not everyday topics for most people, they hold particular interest for the audience of outstanding college undergraduate mathematicians who will participate.

title: CONSUMER RATES
WHAT REAGAN LOST
description: You can always tell that a politician or an actor is getting into trouble when the people stop laughing at his jokes or begin to clap at the wrong places.

title: MAKING THE PENTAGON MORE COST-EFFECTIVE
description: After years of debate, legislation that would change the organization of the Pentagon is about to move to the floor of the House and Senate. At the same time, President Reagan has promised to act on recent recommendations from a commission led by former Deputy Secretary of Defense David Packard that are intended to improve management of the nation's defenses and the way the Pentagon does business with the arms industry.

title: WHY WE NEED TO TAX CONSUMPTION
description: IN HIS recent State of the Union address, President Reagan said, ''I believe our tax-rate cuts for the people have done more to spur a spirit of risk-taking and help America's economy break free than any other program since John Kennedy's tax cut almost a quarter-century ago.''

title: PRICE RIFT IN OPEC TAKES ON POLITICAL TONE
description: The struggle by OPEC to achieve higher oil prices moved into the political arena today, as the Iranian Oil Minister reiterated accusations that the United States sought to force crude oil prices downward to crack the oil-producing cartel ''because it is an organization belonging to the third world.''

title: TUCKERTON PUTS LOSS OF POLICE TO A VOTE
description: IN WHAT they describe as a cost-cutting move, officials of this small Ocean County community have proposed abolishing the eight-member Police Department, but many residents say they would rather pay higher taxes and keep the police.

title: 'THE ROBE' AND I: THE MAKING OF A CHRISTIAN STORYTELLER
description: I WAS in eighth grade, 14 years old, when I read Lloyd C. Douglas's novel ''The Robe,'' a story about the Roman officer who crucified Jesus and won his seamless robe in a toss of the dice.

title: The Case of Hilary Tamar
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD CASES, HARD CHOICES
description: BORN TO DIE? Deciding the Fate of Critically Ill Newborns. By Earl E. Shelp. 250 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. ''PARENTS bear the burden and authority, except in rare instances, to decide the medical care of severely defective newborns in the light of their moral values, commitments, principles, and norms.'' Earl E. Shelp's thesis in ''Born To Die? Deciding the Fate of Critically Ill Newborns'' may seem so obvious that one might reasonably ask: why is it necessary to write a book to defend it? The answer is that in the past several years parents' authority has been challenged, at least when their decision is to withhold or withdraw treatment.

title:
TAKING TAX REFORM A STEP FURTHER;
HOW A V.A.T. WOULD HURT OUR EXPORTS
description: WHEN the Senate Finance Committee turns to tax reform, several members will push an approach different from the one advocated by the President or passed by the House. That approach is a ''business transfer tax,'' proposed by Senator William V. Roth.

title: And Now, Again, Waterfront Crime
description: It sounded like an echo of long-ago headlines about racketeering on the New York-New Jersey waterfront: extortion and kickbacks, gambling and loan sharking, conflicts of interest in the administration of union funds, payoffs for ''labor peace,'' a pervasive presence of organized crime. But only last week Federal officials confirmed that despite numerous investigations and convictions over the last 30 years, they believe corruption still seethes around the piers.

title: NAVY COACH STIRS THE WATERS AND WINS
description: PAUL EVANS possesses all of the qualities one expects in a Navy man. He stresses discipline, believes strongly in the benefits of a service academy career, speaks in a straightforward manner and has the respect of each of the men whose lives he affects.

title: AT TASTING, TAPE IS AS RED AS WINE
description: HARRAH'S Marina Hotel-Casino drew another enthusiastic crowd to its annual Wine Festival last weekend, but found tiptoeing through the thicket of New Jersey regulations as perilous as ever.

title: GENETIC COUNSELORS MULTIPLY
description: OVER the last 10 years thousands of families have been helped by genetic counseling, a service that is growing along with the sweeping advances in the genetic sciences. And the task of educating the layman or family about the implications of birth defects and the genetic mechanisms that cause disorders is shifting from physicians and geneticists to a new class of health professionals, genetic counselors. They are becoming the trusted experts who also give emotional and psychological support to families confronted by genetic disorders.

title: HOLLY TUPPER WED TO WILL BEINHORN
description: Holly Tupper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Baldwin Tupper of New York, was married yesterday to Will Alston Beinhorn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Beinhorn Jr., of San Antonio and Catarina, Tex. The Rev. Ephraim Rathner performed the Episcopal ceremony at Grace Church in Brooklyn.

title: PENTAGON IS FAULTED FOR ACTION IN 1984 CAMPAIGN
description: The General Accounting Office has concluded that the Defense Department violated its own rules when it gave the Reagan-Bush Campaign Committee the names and addresses of 1.4 million members of the armed services just before the election in November 1984.

title: VOTING SYSTEM IN TRENTON IRKS DEMOCRATS
description: THE new Speaker of the State Assembly took time last week to assess how he was doing, and decided that the current session was ''off to a fine start.''

title: MUSIC TO EVOKE THE EASTER MOOD
description: THE joy of Easter Day, following the solemnity of Holy Week, has its most familiar musical expression in two works: the Hallelujah Chorus from Handel's ''Messiah,'' and the Toccata, or final movement, of the Fifth Symphony for organ by Charles-Marie Widor. Widor was a late 19th- and early 20th-century French organist and composer of great ability, but his output and fame are minimal when compared with Handel's. Listeners may not remember Widor's name, but they do not forget his Toccata.

title: BRIAN KEGELMAN AND JOAN A. CLARK PLANNING TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis Adams Clark of Cooperstown, N.Y., and St. Simons Island, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter Joan Alexandre Clark to Brian Joseph Kegelman, a son of Harry J. Kegelman of Jersey City and Spring Lake, N.J. A September wedding is planned in Cooperstown.

title: ATLANTA GETS TANNER'S CHEERY STYLE
