description: Chuck Tanner, the ''player's manager,'' admits that it wasn't much of a year: The Pittsburgh Pirates finished with the worst record in baseball, their locker room was prominently mentioned in the Federal drug trial that shook baseball and, when the season ended, the ''player's manager'' was dismissed after nine years on the job.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CHILDREN'S BOOK AWARD
description: It was a Sunday when Jean Fritz of Dobbs Ferry learned that she had won the 1986 Laura Ingalls Wilder Award from the American Library Association for her ''substantial and lasting contribution'' to children's literature. ''My husband, Michael, was doing dishes at the sink. When he heard the news, he dropped a dish,'' Mrs. Fritz related.

title: OYSTER BAY'S LANDFILLS AT ISSUE
description: OYSTER BAY residents and officials are locked in disputes over the future of two landfill sites and a polluted area in the town - disputes that reflect the growing concern across Long Island about how to handle waste and a myriad of related environmental problems.

title:
ANTIQUES;
BOOK HIGHLIGHTS AMERICAN FURNIISHINGS
description: ELIZABETH STILLINGER, of Westport, has been working in and around antiques since 1962, when she took her first job in Manhattan as an assistant editor of The Magazine Antiques. Her latest work, a collaboration with Marshall B. Davidson called ''The American Wing,'' highlights the American furnishings found in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City.

title: ELEGANT OLD OIL LAMPS LURE COLLECTORS
description: Adequate artificial light was one of man's most slowly developed technologies.

title:
HIGH TECHNOLOGY;
PROFILES OF YOUNG INNOVATORS
description: THEY ARE hard-driving, persistent, often unconventional, and always boundlessly optimistic. Most are great admirers of successful entrepreneurs like Steven P. Jobs, founder of Apple Computers, and William H. Gates, president and founder of Microsoft, to whom they often refer in conversation.

title: BERNICE WEI CHU MARRIED TO GUILLERMO DEGAUDENZI
description: Bernice Wei Chu, an architect and a team manager in the architectural department of Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, was married yesterday to Guillermo Hernan Fidel Degaudenzi, a management consultant in New York. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Federal Hall National Memorial in New York.

title: NEW FRENCH CABINET HOLDS FIRST MEETING
description: President Francois Mitterrand held his first Cabinet meeting today with the leaders of a new conservative Government made up of his political opponents.

title: BADGER LAND BETTERS RECORD
description: Snow Chief solidified his position as the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby today without setting foot on a race track. His stock went up when Badger Land, who finished second to Snow Chief in his last two starts, set a track record while posting a four-length romp in the $120,000 Everglades Stakes at Hialeah.

title: ZABALETA, BUCK ALY WIN IN BAY SHORE
description: Zabaleta, a California shipper, scored a 4 1/2-length victory yesterday in the first and stronger division of the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: NAVY'S TALL SHIP
description: JUST when American heroes appeared virtually extinct, David Robinson is now up there on the horizon, a tall ship, its sails puffed by a fresh breeze in our Naval history. John Paul Jones spoke like a coach when he snapped, ''We have not yet begun to fight,'' but he never shot a jumper. Adm. George Dewey steamed into Manila Bay but he never snatched a rebound. Adm. Chester Nimitz commanded the South Pacific fleet in World War II but he never blocked a shot.

title: Majorca
description: To the Editor: The piece on ''Not-So-Obvious Majorca'' by Malcolm MacPherson (Travel, Feb. 23) highlighted Majorca as an island which, contrary to popular belief, has plenty to offer besides beaches and summer hordes of sun-thirsty European vacationers - one of whom I am fortunate to have been in August of 1984.

title: LOW-COST HOME PLAN FOUGHT
description: A GROUP of Selden residents are fighting a Brookhaven Town proposal to build 15 to 30 moderately priced homes and sell them to moderate- and middle-income families in their area.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE U.S. Metals Refining Company in Carteret, fined earlier this month and the focus of a continuing legal battle between New Jersey and New York, has posed problems for New Jersey's air-pollution enforcement efforts for years.

title: DEIDRE MCSWEENEY TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Patrick McSweeney of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Deidre Leigh McSweeney to James Callen Tyson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Tyson of Islip Terrace, L.I., and Jamestown, R.I. The wedding is planned for May. The future bride and bridegroom are fourth-year students at the New York Medical College at Valhalla.

title: LEADER OF MINISTRY TO FIGHT ZONING RULE IN STRATFORD
description: WILLIAM T. NICHOLS says that holding religious meetings in his home is ''a way of life.'' But to some of his neighbors and to Stratford officials, the meetings disturb the peace and violate zoning regulations.

title: U.S. Restricts Consent Decrees
description: The Reagan Administration pressed its case against judge-made law last week, sharply limiting the power of Federal agencies to consent to court decrees settling lawsuits. Such decrees, often sought by the Government to avoid expensive and complex cases involving civil rights, environmental protection, housing and prisons, will now be much more difficult to use if they mandate new regulations or new money.

title: A CITY OF LOVE AND DEATH: VENICE
description: IT IS LIKE NO OTHER PLACE ON EARTH. YOU arrive from Tokyo, New York, Paris, Delhi, Seattle, Rio, Rome, and the first thing you notice, descending from whatever vehicle has brought you - train, plane, automobile - is that your foot rocks a little with its first step onto the shimmering surface. For this is the lagoon city (or rather it is two cities: one above and seemingly solid; one below and reflected in the waters), and that slight wobble tells you everything about its essence. It is the city of mirrors, the city of mirages, at once solid and liquid, at once air and stone. The stones themselves are thick with history, and those cats that dash through the alleyways must surely be the ghosts of the famous dead in feline disguise. Many noted artists, after all, died here: Wagner, Browning, Diaghilev - though some, like Dante, merely died of maladies contracted on their last visit. These illustrious deaths have given the city a certain spooky patina and a faintly macabre reputation - like New Orleans, only more so. Or maybe it is the time-stopped nature of the place, the fact that so many vistas still look exactly as they do in Carpaccio or Bellini paintings (except for the television antennas, of course) which gives you the sense that you can turn a corner and walk into the past - as the accompanying photographs by Michael O'Neill illustrate.

title: Foreigners In Their Own Land
description: There is a price East Germans must pay for gaining their freedom and entering West Germany (''Foreigners in Their Own Land,'' by Ernest Gill, Feb. 16).

title: DOROTHY SMITH IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thurlow Vought of Mahopac, N.Y., have announced the engagement of her daughter Dorothy Louisa Smith to Santo Antonio Credendino, a son of Mr. And Mrs. Orlando Credendino of Ossining, N.Y. A May 31 wedding is planned. The future bride, a daughter also of the late Bradford Lloyd Smith of New York, is a print production assistant with Omega Engineering Inc., in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Credendino is a software engineer in the engineering system products division of the International Business Machine Corporation in Danbury, Conn.

title: HISTORIC LISTING DEBATED FOR ROADS
description: LONG ISLAND'S extensive road system began to take its present shape in the mid-1920's when Robert Moses, the State Park Commissioner, envisioned a network of parkways to carry New York City residents to the state parks that were planned on the Island.

title: Simone Thomas
description: Simone Thomas's evening at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday demonstrated a small, husky, poorly supported soprano voice that was ill-equipped, unfortunately, to negotiate her basically bel canto program.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE DINING
description: THE words ''corporate dining room'' usually conjure up one of two images. There is the dingy basement cafeteria, replete with acres of dried-out meatloaf, soggy green beans and stainless steel smelling of strong cleanser. Or there is the wood-paneled executive suite 30 or 40 stories above, where bigwigs stuff themselves with filet mignon and shrimp cocktail at company expense.

title: ALMOST ANYTHING BEATS PLEDGE WEEK
description: In the same sense that torture is a persuasive argument, the fund-raising days and weeks - or is it months? - that have lately concluded on WNET/ Channel 13 are powerful arguments for permitting public television to sell commercial time. For more than a year now, it has been permitting sponsors to celebrate themselves with enhanced logos and more elaborate claims of their value to civilization without any noticeable deterioration in programming. Let's stop flirting and go all the way; let the advertisers shuck off the camouflage and advertise their products, if there is any chance that it will spare us some of the mind-softening soliciting, which now goes on for 16 days at a stretch.

title: NOT AS RARE AS THE COMET
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH THE COMPUTER AGE
description: INSPIRED by his three sons, his staff and top management at his company, all of whom are using computers, Ron Zier, vice president of public affairs at Warner-Lambert, the pharmaceuticals company, learned to use spreadsheet and word-processing software and to telecommunicate. ''I figured,'' he said, ''if the people I worked and lived with could learn to use programs, I could too.''

title: A TRAGEDY THAT ECHOES STILL
description: SEVENTY-FIVE years ago this Tuesday, the Triangle Shirtwaist Company, east of Washington Square Park in New York City, went up in flames, killing 146 workers and sparking a nationwide crusade for safer working conditions.

title: THE LAWYERS ARE ON NEW GROUND
description: THE litigation burgeoning around the wealth of Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos poses complex issues that could keep squadrons of lawyers busy for years, with no close precedents to guide them.

title: A Clean-Air Mandate For Nonsmokers
description: After weeks of tilting at old-time politics, Mayor Koch last week had at the smoke-filled room. Following close on the heels of a report by the United States Surgeon General that called second-hand smoke a health hazard, the Mayor proposed an antismoking law that he said would be the nation's strongest.

title: Dollars That Fight Temptation
description: When it comes to copying machines, modern technology has gotten just a little too miraculous for the Department of the Treasury. To thwart amateur counterfeiting on new office copiers that can reproduce in color and great detail, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d announced last week, the United States is about to change the dollar.

title: Cable TV
description: ''Stevie'' (1978), a fascinating film about the brilliant, eccentric British poetess Stevie Smith, will have its American cable premiere this week on Arts & Entertainment - Sunday at 9 P.M. and 1 A.M.

title: Disney World
description: To the Editor: Your readers should know that Visa cards are not accepted for admission or any purchases at stores or restaurants within the confines of Walt Disney World or Epcot Center. Since this announcement is not made until you are at the point of purchasing your admission tickets, the traveler who has little cash and is without either a MasterCard or an American Express card faces a time-consuming journey to a bank to get a cash advance on his or her Visa card.

title: STUDENT WINNERS TO PRESENT CONCERT
description: AS gifted students wend their long, difficult, often frustrating way toward artistic fulfillment, they are in need of both moral support and performing opportunities. It was to provide both that the Westchester Conservatory of Music established its Concerto Competition 12 years ago, and you can enjoy the results of the 1986 auditions at 3 P.M. today, when the first-place winner, Chui-Tan Lee, plays the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto with the Conservatory Orchestra, under Eliot Magaziner.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LESS MAINTENANCE
description: LOW-MAINTENANCE gardening has become an important topic in light of the prevailing shortage of professional gardeners and the limited time that we have to work in our own gardens.

title: BOSTON IN TRANSIT WAR AGAINST UNEASY RIDING
description: The subway line that links Boston's downtown section with the suburbs is officially called the Orange Line, but it is also unofficially called The Terror Train.

title: Homosexuals Win Their Bill at Last
description: Voting hearts, minds or political nerve ends, the New York City Council last week approved an amendment to the administrative code that adds homosexuals to the categories of people who are protected by its human-rights provisions. The vote ended - at least for the time being -a 15-year battle to ban discrimination on the basis of ''actual or perceived'' sexual orientation in housing, employment and public accommodation.

title: SOVIET SPOKESMAN IS EXPECTED TO BECOME ENVOY TO BRITAIN
description: Leonid M. Zamyatin, the Soviet Union's chief press spokesman, is soon to be named Ambassador to Britain, diplomats say.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
CHEW WELL AND SWALLOW WHOLE
description: FIT FOR AMERICA Health, Fitness, Sport, and American Society. By Harvey Green. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $24.95. TWENTY years ago I heard a mildly funny story about the heyday of psychoanalysis in America.

title: What's Wrong With Five-Hour Speeches?
description: To the Editor:

title: EYE ON MARCOS BILLIONS: JOVITO REYES SALONGA
description: Almost 20 years ago, just as Ferdinand E. Marcos began amassing his enormous wealth, one of the most popular politicians in the Philippines publicly accused the President of manipulating the nation's Securities and Exchange Commission for his own end.

title: Dance
description: As part of its 15th-anniversary celebration, the Bucket Dance Theater comes to the Joyce Theater for a week's engagement opening Tuesday night. When it was founded in 1970, the troupe from Rochester, N. Y. was known as Bottom of the Bucket But . . ., a name that emphasized both its humble origins and its determination to succeed.

title: Group in Orange to Fight Housing Decay
description: THE decay of a neighborhood often starts with small signs - the front door without a lock, a dead bush on an untrimmed lawn, graffiti that are not washed off.

title: RARITIES WILL BE SOLD NEXT MONTH
description: The 1986 Rarities of the World auction will be held April 5 at 1 P.M. in the Knickerbocker Room of the New York Helmsley Hotel, 42d Street near Third Avenue. Catalogues for the auction are available by mail or over the counter for $5 from Robert A. Siegel Auction Galleries, Inc., 160 East 56th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022.

title: HOMER JONES, A REMINISCENCE
description: The following was excerpted from an article that appeared in The Journal of Monetary Economics in 1976, on the occasion of Homer Jones's retirement from the St. Louis Fed. Mr. Jones, a popular and respected monetarist economist, died last week at 79.WHEN I first met Homer

title: 'Marya': A Middle-Class Genre
description: To the Editor:

title: VAUDEVILLE WITH A MYSTICAL SPIN
description: Many artists, looking back on their careers, remember a single moment - an epiphany - that crystallized their aspirations. For Bob Berky, the clown artist who, with the juggler Michael Moschen, is half of the duo who call themselves ''The Alchemedians,'' that moment came 15 years ago in a Toronto hotel room.

title: HIS SPECIALITY: TURNING TROUBLED BUSINESSES AROUND
description: ''I HAVE no ego for sales volume,'' said P. James Massa of Upper Brookville. ''My only ego is for the bottom line - the black bottom line. I don't like red.''

title: WITNESS IN GOTTI TRIAL LOCATED
description: A Queens man who disappeared before he was to testify Thursday in an assault and robbery case against John Gotti, the reputed organized-crime leader, was found and taken into custody yesterday to insure that he would appear in court tomorrow.

title: The Alps
description: To the Editor: Jan Morris, in describing a crossing of the Alps on Crossair Airlines (''Above the Alps,'' Travel, March 2), made a common error in referring to Mont Blanc as the highest mountain in Europe. It is, of course, the highest mountain in Western Europe, but Mount Elbrus, an 18,481-foot peak in the Caucasus Range, is the highest mountain in Europe.

title: EXTENDING LIFE OR PROLONGING DEATH?
description: ''You find all kinds of patients trying to cope with dying - angry patients, calm patients, happy patients, sad patients,'' said Dr. Richard B. Freeman, a kidney specialist. ''And there are patients who just curl up and die far sooner than necessary.''

title: Moratorium Vs. Test Ban
description: The prospects for a Soviet-American summit this year have ebbed away, largely because of Mikhail Gorbachev's overambitious attempt to set conditions. The arms control negotiations in Geneva aren't moving. And now the Russians are reportedly preparing to resume nuclear tests because the U.S. rejects their moratorium.

title:
MIND/BODY/HEALTH;
IN SHORT
description: BATTLES OF LIFE AND DEATH. By David Hellerstein. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) A woman receives poisonous chemotherapy to treat her cancer. It works, but the same poison that cures her produces leukemia a few years later.

title: TIME IS LOST FOR MICHIGAN ST.
description: It was not unusual for questions to linger in anticipation of the game between Kansas and North Carolina State for the Midwest Regional championship. What was unusual was that many of the questions concerned the scoreboard clock at Kemper Arena. Will it work? What would happen if it does not work? What should happen if it does not? The questions were inspired by the commotion that began with 2 minutes 21 seconds to play in the second half of the 96-86 Kansas semifinal victory over Michigan State Friday night. An apparent mechanical error, an oversight by the timer and the rule book combined to create confusion in the climactic moments of one of the most important games of the season.

title: SOVIET SKATERS KEEP TITLE IN ICE DANCING
description: Natalya Bestiamanova and Andrei Bukin of the Soviet Union made perfection look easy today and won their second straight title in ice dancing, the final event of the World figure skating championships.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 23, 1986
description: International

title: LEONIE GLEN PLANS TO WED PETER SABIN WILLETT IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Dulaney Glen of Pfafftown, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leonie Glen to Peter Sabin Willett, a son of Peter S. Willett of Glens Falls, N.Y., and Carolyn Willett of Larchmont, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Time Out for Nicaragua
description: The House's rejection of a $100 million aid package for the ''contra'' rebels last week was as much a test of domestic wills as of foreign policies. President Reagan and House Democrats, representing broad constituencies, resent and distrust each other's basic instincts in dealing with Nicaragua. But however our checks and balances are finally calibrated, the Sandinistas should have no doubt about Americans' disapproval of their present course. What produced the 222-210 vote against giving Mr. Reagan free rein was agreement to vote again next month on a better hedged package of sanctions. A more sophisticated American response requires a comparable step backward in Managua.

title: HELLO LETTUCE, GOODBYE CREAM SAUCE
description: 'WE almost had to push the healthier, lighter foods on employees a couple of years ago,'' recalled Joseph P. Kingrey, president of ARA Services' Business Dining Division. ''Lately, it's become a craze.'' Indeed, corporate dining facilities are picking up on the same trends that have swept through expensive restaurants. A recent study by the National Restaurant Association indicates that decaffeinated coffee, fresh fruit and main-dish salads are among the fastest-growing items in restaurants.

title: IN SHORT
description: STOLEN MIND: The Slow Disappearance of Ray Doernberg. By Myrna Doernberg. (Algonquin, $14.95.) The slowest deaths can prove the most painful, for sufferers and survivors alike.

title: ISTANBUL BAZAAR IS CLOSED OFF SO SHULTZ CAN SHOP
description: For an hour today, security agents closed off parts of the Great Bazaar to allow Secretary of State George P. Shultz, his wife and the two dozen members of their party to shop undisturbed.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S a good thing that misery loves company, because there's a lot of both at 1500 Privado Road in Westbury, where everybody who has anything to do with a motor vehicle has to go sooner or later. Every time I have to go to the central Long Island bureau of the Motor Vehicles Department, it's as if everybody on the Island is there, and the company makes the misery a little easier.

title: 5 in Oklahoma Family Die in Boating Accident
description: Five members of a family drowned after a small boat they were in capsized on a large pond, and the body of the last of the victims was recovered today. No one who drowned was wearing a life jacket, said Charles Blunt of the State Highway Patrol.

title: Chilling Effect?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WEATHER VANES Second to a current preoccupation with decoy ducks, collectors seem to be craziest about weather vanes. So prized are the rooftop silhouettes that some agile black-marketeers have been known to filch them from barns, churches and houses.

title: 20 Reported Wounded In a Flare-Up in Beirut
description: At least 20 people were reported wounded today in militia clashes in central Beirut and in battles that raged from the southern suburbs to the city's port in the north.

title:
ART;
AT WILLIAM PATERSON, LARGER-THAN-LIFE RELIGIOUS VISIONS
description: THE FACTS in an artist's biography do not always have bearing on his art.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ON SHOREHAM
description: THE Nuclear Regulatory Commission plans new investigations of operations at the Shoreham nuclear power plant because of ''serious deficiencies'' uncovered during a recent Federal investigation at the facility, an official of the commission said last week.

title: JERSEY'S ROUTE 1 STORY: SLOW GAINS, HIGH HOPES
description: NEW JERSEY officials envision a new ''Silicon Valley'' blooming in the central part of the state, a critical mass of high-technology talent anchored by two top-flight research universities and spawning promising new enterprises at the cutting edge.

title: Two If By Sea
description: The ad, placed by the developer of a 34-unit condominium in Greenport, L.I., read: ''Have building, will travel.''

title: COMFORT-FOR-RENT ARRIVES AT AMERICA'S AIRPORTS
description: AFTER capping a two-month cycling trip with 14 hours on a plane from New Zealand to Los Angeles, Henrietta Stern was not up to sitting in a cocktail lounge or waiting room until her connecting flight to her home in Monterey departed. What Miss Stern wanted was a shower and a nap.

title: KANSAS CITY HOLDS HOPE FOR SCHOOLS
description: Up in the northwest section of Kansas City is an elementary school that is now, at the age of 101, old enough to have earned some respect.

title: FISHERMEN CAUGHT IN DISPUTE
description: A GROUP of commercial fishermen says it has unwittingly become embroiled in a longstanding political dispute between officials of Suffolk County and the Town of Southampton.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Vidal in Venice By Gore Vidal. Edited by George Armstrong. Photographs by Tore Gill. 160 pages. Summit Books. $22.95.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Asphalt Jungle Starring Sterling Hayden, Sam Jaffe, Louis Calhern, Jean Hagen, Marilyn Monroe, James Whitmore; directed by John Huston, 1950 MGM/UA Home Video 112 minutes. $69.95 John Huston's black-and-white ''Asphalt Jungle'' set a new style for caper films in the way it implicates the audience while depicting the details of a particular crime -the heist of a half-million dollars in loot from a fancy jewelry store in a large Middle Western city.

title: ARKANSAS PAPERS BATTLE OVER MORE THAN MONEY
description: Nearly 30 years ago, The Arkansas Gazette's coverage and support of school desegregation won two Pulitzer Prizes but so outraged the citizens of Little Rock that the newspaper was almost ruined by a boycott while its conservative rival, The Arkansas Democrat, prospered.

title: ECHOES OF 19th-CENTURY NEW YORK
description: In 1836, a 35-year-old lawyer, who would later make his name as Secretary of State, journeyed by carriage into the wilderness that enveloped the western pocket of New York State. The isolated landscape that appealed to William H. Seward remains as an area of beauty - and solace - for those wishing to venture beyond the creeping gentrification of more accessible parts of the state.

title:
GARDENING;
PLANNING FOR LESS MAINTENANCE
description: LOW-MAINTENANCE gardening has become an important topic in light of the prevailing shortage of professional gardeners and the limited time that we have to work in our own gardens.

title: SPRING SIMPLY BRINGS OUT THE ANIMAL IN MOTHER NATURE
description: FAREWELL, winter doldrums, I'll miss you. Spring, Samuel Butler's ''overpraised season,'' is once again upon us, and not everyone is rejoicing.

title: VARIETY MARKS SPRING'S START
description: VARIETY seems to be the keynote as we turn the corner into spring. Whether your taste runs to orchestral or chamber music, classical dance or modern jazz, intimate recitals or grand opera, you should be satisfied over the next two weeks.

title: PIKE PLAN IS CALLED TOO BIG
description: THE proposal to widen the New Jersey Turnpike at a cost of $2 billion has come under sharp criticism by the Regional Plan Association, which recommends a drastic scaling back of the project.

title: SUZANNE WOLBERS WED IN BROOKLYN
description: Suzanne M. Wolbers, a photo editor with Business Week in New York, was married yesterday to Julius Chil Spiegel, Brooklyn Commissioner of Parks and Recreation for the New York City Department of Parks. Judge Robert G. M. Keating of the Criminal Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn.

title: My Son, The Rastafarian
description: I enjoyed Mario Vargas Llosa's article ''My Son the Rastafarian'' (Feb. 16). It seems that quite recently I, too, was 16 and thoroughly committed to socialism, afraid to share this with my family and certain that I would never again cut my hair, use makeup, eat flesh food of any kind or wear an item of clothing which cost more than 50 cents at a thrift shop.

title: SWITCH AT LA SALLE
description: La Salle basketball boosters are laughing and crying. The men's team got a new basketball coach with a championship record, and the women's team lost the coach who had taken the team to the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament championshionship.

title: MURDERED COUPLE MOURNED BY DALLAS BLACKS
description: If life's most haunting riddle comes in the conjunction of a rich life and a dismal death, blacks in Dallas have seen few days as somber as the one this week when they buried Fred and Mildred Finch.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
IMPORTED MODERN LACE FOR MYRIAD USES
description: La Dentelliere, or The Lacemaker, is the name of a shop with imported lace curtains from France, England and Italy. Most of the polyester-and- acrylic fabrics are machine washable and can be hung to dry without ironing - and without the care problems of earlier cotton lace curtains, needing to be hand-washed, stretched over every tiny nail along an adjustable large and heavy frame and possibly ironed at the edges as well.

title: SERVICE JOBS START TO DRIFT ABROAD, TOO
description: AS AMERICAN manufacturing jobs have moved overseas in huge numbers in the last few years, office work and other service jobs, many of them in high-technology areas, have been presented as saviors of the American economy and of its work force. But there is rising evidence that the jobs are also vulnerable to going overseas and are starting to do so, according to experts on labor and information technology. The movement is still tiny in comparison with the loss of manufacturing jobs but is a worrisome trend, some say.

title: LAND OF THIEVES AND KILLERS
description: NEW JERUSALEM By Len Jenkin. 214 pp. Los Angeles: Sun & Moon Press. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $10.95. LEN JENKIN has pulled off something striking here: with comic-book exaggeration and a cynical luridness, he has created a delicate, moving novel set in a blasted, despairing future, early in the 21st century. New Jerusalem is the bitter, mocking name given to an island prison where the dregs of the earth are dumped by an uncaring world government. Criminals and misfits are exiled here, but so are the indigent and the eccentric - in Mr. Jenkin's vision of the future, sympathy is an unaffordable luxury.

title: SUMMER SPORTS
description: As the days grow longer, people who have sat cramped behind desks in office buildings all winter will head outdoors in running shoes, on bicycles and roller skates, to tennis courts, golf courses, jogging paths and swimming pools to enjoy the warm weather. Some will get out to relax and be with friends while others, conscious of the extra pounds that have gathered around certain vulnerable parts of their bodies, will want to get themselves back into shape while having a good time.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FESTIVE PURIM Purim, the holiday commemmorating the deliverance of the Jews from the massacre plotted by Haman, comes but once a year. So celebrators tend to make the most of it - with festive parties that give children and adults the chance to make merry. On Long Island, the Y's stage these community festivals, and today's the day most of them hold their programs - complete with costume parades, games, music and, of course, the sampling of hamantaschen, the pastries symbolic of the holiday.

title: MIND/BODY/HEALTH
description: ACTUAL MINDS, POSSIBLE WORLDS By Jerome Bruner. 201 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15. PITY today's generalist - or, for that matter, any scholar who aspires beyond the ever more narrowly drawn confines of his own specialty. Today, the degree of incomprehensibility to nonprofessionals seems almost a measure of the progress made within a given domain. And I'm not just speaking here of fields like relativistic quantum mechanics, which outsiders are quite prepared not to understand. I mean research even in the humanities, the study of literature, say, or philosophy, which not so very long ago an educated person might have regarded as his territory through a kind of inherited ownership. These areas too have become laden with theories dictating new forms of language, incrusted with technical terms that are necessary for the very formulation of the problems under consideration.

title: TURKEY TRAPPER'S AIM: MATCHMAKING
description: Huddled in a cramped, camouflaged tent in the middle of a snowy field, swathed in layers of wool to ward off the sub-zero chill, Arnold C. Elithorpe was an unlikely Cupid.

title: MUSIC FOR EASTER SEASON IS BOUNTIFUL
description: THROUGHOUT history, Holy Week -Palm Sunday to Easter, the most important time on the Christian calendar -has inspired some of music's most impassioned works.

title: CONTAC PACKAGE SHOWS HOLES
description: A package of 10 Contac cold capsules found today in a store in San Francisco had been subjected to tampering, with pin or needle holes in the package, according to the city's police department.

title: Statue Bombed in Greece
description: A bronze statue of President Harry S. Truman in the center of Athens was blown up shortly before midnight tonight.

title: Books From The Times
description: ''Enchanting Places and How to Find Them; From Pleasant Hill to Katmandu,'' the fourth volume of The Sophisticated Traveler Series, has been published by Villard Books ($15.95).

title: NATION'S TEST-GIVER OFFERS SOME ANSWERS
description: STANDARDIZED tests are popular again. They are used to screen applicants for all sorts of occupations, from teaching - prospective teachers in Texas had to take a competency examination earlier this month - to police work. Many states now use standardized tests to determine whether a student should move up a grade or get a diploma. Education Secretary William J. Bennett recently pointed to a rise in scores on college admission tests as a sign that schools are doing a better job.

title: Unrest in Haiti Prompts Ouster Of 3 Officials
description: Since President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled Feb. 7, there has been public protest in Haiti because some of the dictator's close aides became influential members of the new Government. There was also growing unrest among workers demanding higher wages than the average $3 a day.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Woodland Walks in Britain By Gerald Wilkinson. Illustrated. 320 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $19.95.

title: HOW THE BILLS GOT BLOATED
description: AMERICA'S HEALTH CARE REVOLUTION Who Lives? Who Dies? Who Pays?. By Joseph A. Califano Jr. 241 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95. A REVOLUTION, precipitated by seemingly uncontrollable costs, is occurring in our system of medical care, and the battle is joined between those who provide the care and those who pay for it. This is Joseph A. Califano Jr.'s thesis in ''America's Health Care Revolution.'' He believes that the traditional control of health care by doctors and hospitals is shifting to large corporations and to the Government because those who ultimately pay the doctor bills can determine the way their money is spent if they wish to.

title: Taping A Family History
description: Thom Schwarz can, indeed, keep his family's history and legends alive (''A Sense of History,'' About Men, Feb. 23).

title: My Son, The Rastafarian
description: Perhaps the most important move Mario Vargas Llosa made, in the painful effort to forge some kind of connection with his son, was to read everything he could about the Rastafarian movement.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
North Hills Controlling Surge in Building
description: BORDERING busy Shelter Rock Road in the Village of North Hills, just south of Manhasset's ''Miracle Mile'' shopping thoroughfare, lies an 81-acre tract of meadows and woods with several old barns and outbuildings and a white frame manor house.

title: ALISON L. SPEAR WED IN FLORIDA
description: The wedding of Alison Leelyn Spear, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Charles Spear of Miami Shores, Fla., to Campion Acheson Platt, the son of Mrs. Dennis Covel Dickson and the late Jeremy Acheson Platt, took place yesterday. The Rev. Timothy L. Croft performed the ceremony at the Miami Shores Presbyterian Church.

title: BETTER WAY SOUGHT TO RUN PROBATION
description: THE Connecticut Office of Adult Probation turned 30 years old this month, but instead of celebrating, officials say they are grappling with a basic problem - how to make the probation system work.

title: MARY R. MELLOWN WEDS IN DURHAM
description: Mary Ruth Mellown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elgin Wendell Mellown of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday to John Myers Houston, a son of Tom Rappe Houston of Pebble Beach, Calif., and the late Geraldine McGuire Houston. The Rev. John Steed performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Episcopal Church in Durham.

title: WHEN CHARACTERS FROM THE PAGE ARE MADE FLESH ON THE SCREEN
description: Some years ago in the American Southwest there surfaced a tabloid psychopath known as ''The Pied Piper of Tucson.'' I have forgotten his name but his specialty was the seduction and occasional murder of teen-age girls. He may or may not have had actual accomplices, but his bizarre activities were known among a circle of teen-agers in the Tucson area; for some reason they kept his secrets, deliberately did not inform parents or police. It was this fact, not the fact of the mass murderer himself, that struck me at the time. And this was a pre-Manson time, this was early or mid-1960's.

title: TEACHING COMPUTERS TO HEAR
description: THE notion of a computer that responds to orders that are spoken rather than typed on a keyboard has long bedeviled inventors and inspired the plots of science-fiction movies. The 1980's, however, have seen considerable progress in the field of speech recognition, and several machines are now on the market that respond to limited voice commands. The next few years are expected to make this mode of interaction between man and machine faster, easier and more natural.

title: AID FOR PARALYZED VETERANS
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh has signed into law a measure that provides a $100 monthly state pension for 852 paralyzed veterans in Pennsylvania.

title: No Headline
description: Cynthia J. Blish Is Affianced Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Blish of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Cynthia Joan Blish to Robert Joseph Philpott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Philpott of Middeltown, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: CRIME
description: Bertie Denham's TWO THYRDES (St. Martin's, $15.95) is a father-and-son story told in alternate chapters labeled ''Then'' and ''Now.'' The events concerning the father, Lord Thyrde (pronounced third), who was killed in action, take place during World War II. The son is of the here and now.

title: THE WHOLE HOLISTIC THING
description: THE HEALER WITHIN The New Medicine of Mind and Body. By Steven Locke and Douglas Colligan. Foreword by Norman Cousins. 272 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $22.50. IF the title of this book is somewhat misleading -the authors are more concerned to document the effect of psychosocial factors on disease than to show us how we can heal ourselves - the subtitle is simply remarkable. For a very long time, it has been clear that the Cartesian separation of mind and body was a philosophical fiction. (In non-Western cultures, Descartes would have been laughed out of the room.) As a practical matter, dualism has been refuted by the successful use of biofeedback, faith healing, placebos, and hypnosis, among other things. But only recently has medical science begun to take official notice that attitude and temperament are intertwined with neurobiological phenomena. Thus the straight-faced reference to a new medicine of mind and body.

title: LIVE ONCE, AND BOLDY
description: THOSE DAYS An American Album. By Richard Critchfield. Illustrated. 419 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $19.95. THIS powerful memoir begins with a wedding in the garden of an Iowa parsonage on April 19, 1913. Anna Louise Williams and Jim Critchfield, the author's parents, are married by the bride's father, the Rev. Hadwen Williams. Neighbors have filled the house with daffodils, tulips, violets, ferns and lilies of the valley; from the cellar come the creak and groan of grinding ice and salt muffled by a wet gunnysack: ''Anna Louise's brother, Hadwen, down from his teaching job in Minnesota, was cranking out some tutti-frutti ice cream in the freezer.''

title: JOURNEY AMONG TYRANTS
description: WHEN I WAS YOUNG AND writing from Korea, I met a boy from Manistee, Mich., as he was standing guard in the chilly spring along a forgotten front.

title: The Egypt-Israel Treaty, 7 Years Later
description: Seven years have passed since that chilly afternoon in late March 1979 when a festive crowd gathered before the north portico of the White House to witness a historic drama - the signing of the first peace treaty between Israel and an Arab state. A new era was dawning, or so it seemed. The pageantry of peace-making silenced, for a heady moment, the doubts and fears of the skeptics.

title: There's No Monopoly On Blame for Ulster
description: To the Editor:

title: EXHIBITION OF 'GAMES' FOR YOUNG
description: ON a recent Sunday, 8-year-old Jake Rothermel of Carlisle, Pa., played a rather big game of checkers with his 6-year-old brother, Sam. The two boys, on a weekend visit to the Children's Museum of Manhattan, knelt on the floor at the edges of a 10-foot-square, bright orange-and-blue checkerboard and pushed markers the size of hubcaps.

title: A CALL IN THE DEEP OF NIGHT SETS OFF SEARCH FOR A SUICIDE
description: DEC. 13, 2:05 A.M. The insistent ringing of the phone wakes me from a dreamless slumber and my arm reaches toward the night table to still the jangling. As the receiver is pressed to my ear, I hear: ''I can't take it any more.'' A pause. I say gently: ''Who is this?'' The voice continues, rasping out the words: ''I've just taken a bottle of sleeping pills.'' And more slowly: ''Don't . . . try to save me . . . you can't.''

title: HARVARD IN FINAL 4
description: Harvard's first line, the one properly called the Firing Line and led by Scott Fusco, accounted for five goals tonight as the Crimson defeated Western Michigan, 7-2, on home ice at Bright Center.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: PHILADELPHIA GRAPHICS Without even wincing, the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia has announced an event called ''Sunday Your Prints Will Come.''

title: USING COMPUTERS TO PLAY THE MARKET
description: WHILE most investors continue to rely on brokers - and intuition - for their stock picks, many larger investors are turning to personal computers to tap electronic libraries for stock market information. In most cases, all that is needed is a modem, the device that allows computers to communicate over telephone lines.

title: SEPTEMBER BRIDAL FOR RACHEL GELIN
description: A September wedding is planned by Rachel Gelin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques B. Gelin of Rockville, Md., and Bartley James Breinin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Goodwin M. Breinin of New York and East Hampton, L.I., the parents of the future bride have announced.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Vanishing Prairie A Walt Disney True-Life Adventure, narrated by Winston Hibler; directed by James Algar, 1954. (G) Walt Disney Home Video 60 minutes.

title: AQUINO ISSUES PLEA TO END INSURGENCY
description: With a crisp salute to her troops, President Corazon C. Aquino exercised the power of Commander in Chief today with an appeal to ''our brothers and sisters'' in the Communist insurgency to join the nation in reconciliation.

title: BUSINESSES FIND NEW HAMPSHIRE TO THEIR LIKING
description: On a 87-acre tract of land along the Everett Turnpike, construction workers are putting the final bricks in place for the state's largest shopping mall. Across the highway and up a hill, workers are completing the latest addition to a plant belonging to Sanders Associates, New Hampshire's biggest employer.

title: BANKING REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPASSION FOR MISTAKES
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ISLANDERS, BRUINS STRUGGLE TO 3-3 TIE
description: They called it a game custom-designed to hone the team's playoff mettle, and even though the Islanders didn't win it, they were grateful at its conclusion, which required a full five minutes of overtime to reach.

title: LaRouche Backer's Trial Set In '85 Attack on Archbishop
description: A supporter of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. who apparently won the Democratic nomination for secretary of state has been granted a jury trial, on her request, on charges of disrupting an archbishop's speech by handing him a piece of raw liver.

title: MUSIC: ACCARDO, VIOLIN
description: BY all accounts, Nicolo Paganini was not just one of the first media-manipulating classical-music superstars, but also a genuinely charismatic personality. He composed violin music of unprecedented difficulty, and it was the mastery of that difficulty that lent his virtuosity its diabolical allure.

title: REAGAN SHOWS THE FLAG...TO CONGRESS, TOO
description: For consumption at home as well as abroad, the United States has stepped up its shows of power on the seas. Last week, another aircraft carrier - the third - entered the Mediterranean for exercises that may involve flights above the Gulf of Sidra, which Libya claims but the United States describes as international waters.

title: THE PRICE OF OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: A WOEFULLY WIMPY WINTER
description: I CAN sense a feeling of uneasiness everywhere. True, spring is finally here with all its attendant glories and yet somehow people don't feel they deserve to enjoy it. I think I may have the answer.

title: 3 Children Die in Texas Fire
description: Three children were killed early today in an fire that firefighters said appeared to have been fueled by a gas space heater. The dead were Raymond Radford 2d, 2 years old, and his year-old twin sisters, Latoya and Latosha Radford, the Harris County medical examiner said. The authorities said the children's father had left them with their uncle and had gone to pick up his wife at her place of work when the fire broke out while the uncle was asleep.

title: CONCERT WILL AID HOSPITAL
description: SINCE 1973, the annual Good Friday concert at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church has netted $82,282 for Muhlenburg Hospital here.

title: ROOKIE'S HOMER HELPS METS ESCAPE
description: Kevin Mitchell, a 24-year-old rookie from California, took a long stride toward a job with the Mets today when he hit his third home run in seven games as the Mets edged the Atlanta Braves, 6-5.

title: SPOUSE ABUSE: POLICE PREDICT RISE IN ARRESTS
description: AS Torrington braces for its second major negligence lawsuit in less than a year, police departments throughout the state are reviewing how they handle domestic abuse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Those statistics are alarming. The conclusion to me is that America is in last place in physical fitness.''

title: LISA HOLLAND TO BE WED TO DR. RICHARD POPIEL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd A. Holland of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Anne Holland to Dr. Richard Popiel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles I. Popiel of Rockville Centre, L.I. A May 3 wedding is planned.

title: TRIUMPHS AND TRAVAILS OF AN L.I. PUBLICIST
description: ''This is my poop sheet,'' said Danny Frank, holding a list of 40 television, radio and newspaper people. ''Consider each one a door. I have to open every one of these doors.''

title: MEXICO CITY
description: Mexico City is practically back to normal. It is becoming increasingly difficult to find evidence of the earthquakes that struck the center of the city last September. Most of the heavily damaged buildings have been torn down, and some of the spots where they stood have been turned into parks. Diego Rivera's murals in the National Palace sustained minor damage, but they have been repaired. Hotel del Prado, known for its Rivera in the lobby, is closed for repairs, but the mural survived without a scratch. Some earthquake victims who lost their homes are still camped in small parks on side streets or living in makeshift shelters in the median strips of some boulevards, and some buildings in Colonia Roma are waiting to be torn down. But on the whole, Mexico City has put the earthquake behind it and is again a vibrant, traffic-clogged metropolis.

title: MICHELE SINDONA, JAILED ITALIAN FINANCIER, DIES OF CYANIDE POISONING AT 65
description: Michele Sindona, one of Italy's most successful financiers, whose empire collapsed amid charges of fraud and murder, died today in a Voghera hospital of cyanide poisoning. He was 65 years old.

title: THE JOY OF ORIGINAL SIN
description: SEXUAL DESIRE A Moral Philosophy of the Erotic. By Roger Scruton. 428 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25. ROGER SCRUTON is not a sexologist and this is not a sexy book. He is an English philosopher and a founder of the Conservative Philosophy Group, which advises the Thatcher Government. He views the Enlightenment as a perversion, and his goal in ''Sexual Desire'' is to dignify the sexual act of heterosexual lovers by restoring to modern consciousness a sense of original sin.

title: 24-HOUR STORE PLAN OPPOSED IN HEWLETT
description: A PROPOSAL to convert a service station in Hewlett into a 24-hour convenience store with self-service gas pumps is being opposed by local residents and school officials.

title: ASIA ON 10 DIAPERS A DAY
description: We are standing with our 2-year-old son before the Taj Mahal.

title: AFTER DEREGULATION: DIALING FOR DOLLARS
description: WHEN in 1980 the Federal Communications Commission made its historic decision to deregulate the telecommunications industry, M.C.I., with regional headquarters in Rye Brook, began installing its own transmission facilities and started competing with American Telephone and Telegraph for long-distance customers. Although A.T.&T. still controls most (about $39 billion) of the $46 billion long-distance telephone service market, M.C.I. earned $3.5 billion in revenues last year, according to its director of communications, Susan Sheridan, who added: ''With a customer base of 3.5 million, we have captured approximately 6 percent of the total market.''

title: My Son, The Rastafarian
description: The young are naturally more inclined to, sometimes bizarre, changes that might, at the time, seem like answers to them.

title: Finding A Place For Piping Plover
description: GENTLE lapping waves, a secluded beach - the perfect place for love. At least that's what the Federal Government is hoping.

title: SUING FOR ANNULMENT
description: DAMNING THE INNOCENT A History of the Persecution of the Impotent in pre-Revolutionary France. By Pierre Darmon. Translated by Paul Keegan. 234 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95. THIS is a very curious piece of book publishing. Consider, for example, the title: in the French original (and the British version) it was neutral and descriptive: ''Le Tribunal de l'Impuissance: Virilite et Defaillances Conjugales dans l'Ancienne France''; in the American edition it becomes shrill, a story of ''persecution'' and ''damning'' of ''the innocent.'' In defense of the new title, it has to be admitted that it fairly accurately describes the tone of Pierre Darmon's book, which is a polemical attack on the canon law and canon lawyers in early modern France -and by implication also against the plaintiff wives.

title: INTERPRETING LA GROSSE POMME: VIEW FROM FRANCE
description: ''New Yorkers are demonstrative with their friends,'' says a guidebook from Gallimard, one of France's biggest publishers.

title: FOR STUDENTS, 'HANDS ON' ECONOMICS
description: At Brooklyn Technical High School last semester, capitalism was not so much a subject for cool, objective study as it was a way of life.

title: Russians Headed Back to China
description: Soviet experts will be welcome in China for the first time since the two Communist powers had their historic falling out a quarter of a century ago. Under an agreement signed last week culminating a three-year thaw in relations, the two countries will exchange technicians and engineers.

title:
ART;
WORKS OF GWEN JOHN AND THOMAS GIRTIN IN NEW HAVEN
description: ''GWEN JOHN: An Interior Life'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven until April 20 is something of a revelation. Many Americans can remember having seen isolated works by this foremost female artist who lived from 1876 to 1939, but the more than 50 paintings and 75 drawings on view here have the force of an absorbing narrative.

title: TOWNS STUDY HOSPITAL USES
description: OFFICIALS of three Long Island towns are looking at possible uses for state hospital property to control the use of the land if the hospitals should close.

title: NEW PRINTER'S RULE: DO IT BY COMPUTER
description: IF you want to understand how vastly technology has changed the printing industry, as well as to work in it, consider the following:

title: WHITE SOX HINTING AT NEW YANK DEAL
description: The Chicago White Sox have no intention of undoing the trade that sent Britt Burns to the Yankees last December, but Ken Harrelson, their executive vice president, said today that the teams might eventually make another separate transaction.

title: IN CASE OF FIRE, 1,001 RULES TO ABIDE BY
description: In most cities, when a fire breaks out the main task at hand is clear enough: rescue people and save as much of whatever is burning as possible.

title: HUMANITARIAN ACTS CAN HAVE UNFORESEEN RESULTS
description: WE OFTEN act in ways that we think are humane yet that turn out later to have consequences that cause suffering.

title: CHARD, A LEAFY CROP
description: Chard is easy to grow and, requiring little space, it is ideal for a small garden. In spring, tender greens arise from plants that have survived winter under mulch. From seeded rows, yields are abundant from July through severe frosts of autumn. Stalks may be cooked separately and served like asparagus or they may be chopped up together with the leaves. In my garden, it is a standby for spinach.

title: ELECTRONIC LOVE
description: A NEW role for college computer networks was detected in 1982. They were not only of increasing value as educational tools; they were also reported reshaping social life on American campuses in many cases.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY: A NEW WONDERWORLD
description: THE first medical product manufactured by gene-splicing technology, human insulin for treatment of diabetes, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration less than four years ago. Since then several others have emerged, all as a result of advances in biological research that have made it possible to find, reproduce and study human genes, the blueprints for all living things, as well as modify them to produce substances different from any that have developed naturally.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MOONLIGHT MAN By Paula Fox. 192 pp. New York: Bradbury Press. $12.95.(Ages 12 and up) ''WHERE was he?

title: THE MINIMUM WAGE
description: Congress set the first minimum hourly wage at 25 cents in the depression year of 1938 and mandated that it be raised in steps to 40 cents over the succeeding seven years.

title: SACRED HEART CAPTURES TITLE
description: Kevin Stevens scored 19 points, Roger Younger had 18 and Keith Johnson added 17 to power Sacred Heart to a 93-87 victory over Southeast Missouri State tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship game at the Springfield Civic Center.

title: U.A.W. Ends Drive At a Honda Plant
description: In a move that was widely seen as a major setback in its drive to represent workers at foreign-owned plants, the United Automobile Workers decided last week to halt a six-year organization drive at a Honda Motors plant in Marysville, Ohio.

title: WILL THE FIRST REAL BIPARTISAN BUDGET STICK?
description: ''THIS is pretty close to a consensus budget,'' said Senate Budget Committee chairman Pete V. Domenici of the blueprint for 1987 that his committee approved last week. The proposal, which defies President Reagan's insistence on no new taxes and an 8 percent rise in the military budget and preserves many domestic programs the White House would eliminate, is ''what will ultimately have to be done,'' the New Mexico Republican added.

title: ROYAL BLISS
description: ''Some commoners are less common than others'' was how The Times of London appraised Sarah Ferguson, who, after a frenzy of speculation, last week became officially engaged to Prince Andrew, the 26-year-old son of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh. Although palace-watchers clucked about her other boyfriends and marginal royal pedigree, Miss Ferguson, also 26, was judged a fine match for Andrew, whose romances have been exhaustively chronicled in the British press.

title: COMMUNITY COLLEGE TO TRACK COURSE OF LOCAL HISTORY ORALLY
description: IT could cure depression, get you out of your shell, make you a better person and might even help to get you a better job.

title: ENFORCING SAFETY LAWS LOCALLY
description: LAST June, three executives at Film Recovery Systems were found guilty of murder in the death of Stefan Golab, a worker who died near a vat of cyanide at the company's silver-reclamation plant near Chicago. Their convictions marked the first time that executives have been convicted of homicide in a corporate matter.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This proposal isn't going to hurt rich people. It is going to hurt people who ride the subways.

title: Benefiting From Drop In Rates
description: A BORROWER normally is concerned with how to protect himself from a rise in interest rates between the date a mortgage lender commits to making a loan and the day of the closing. That concern is so pervasive that the lender's commitment letter typically promises that the rate cannot be increased for the period of the commitment, usually 30 to 90 days.

title: DOING HOMEWORK
description: What is it that tournament players bitterly deplore but cannot do without? Homework.

title: NASA Finally Says A Booster Seam Caused the Blast
description: Until last week the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had maintained that it was considering several possible causes for the explosion Jan. 28 that consumed the shuttle Challenger and its crew. But on Friday, the space agency conceded what many authorities have been saying for weeks: The disaster almost certainly resulted from the failure of a seam in the aft portion of the right solid-fuel booster rocket.

title: NINA B. ECKHOFF MARRIES B.J. FITT
description: Nina Buckler Eckhoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Sheppard Eckhoff of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and Stockport and Lake George, N.Y., was married yesterday to Benjamin Jones Fitt, a son of Patricia Hewitt Fitt of Hamden, Conn., and Alfred Bradley Fitt of Washington. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Stretching Words In ''Selected Essays of R. P. Blackmur'' (Ecco), edited by Denis Donoghue, Blackmur describes the way Wallace Stevens ''stretches'' words to their full size.

title: SHOREHAM KEY TO SPECIAL VOTE
description: THE political potency of the Shoreham nuclear power plant issue is evident as the campaign for a special election for the Suffolk County Legislature begins in the Smithtown-Brookhaven area.

title: Thrifty Buyers Turning to U.S.-Foreclosed Properties
description: ALDO AGAZZI, a 60-year-old restaurant worker from the Bronx, was scanning a local newspaper early last month when he saw an ad placed by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development inviting bids on a recently built three-bedroom, one-bath house on a quarter-acre in Orange County, N.Y. The minimum price was set at $84,500.

title: ELEGANT TASTE TREATS FOR EASTER
description: Easter sweets are all over town. There are chocolate and candy eggs plain, decorated and stuffed with sweet creams and caramels. There are chocolate bunnies and chocolate chickens, large and small. And don't forget traditional Easter sweets from other cuisines: Italian bakeries prepare rich, sweet ricotta pies, called pastiera di grano, stuffed with grains of boiled wheat - a seasonal symbol of fertility - while Greeks offer tsoureki, a sweet yeast bread decorated with red-dyed eggs. Russians make pots of paskha, a cross between pudding and cake, made of pot cheese and eggs and studded with candied fruits.

title: HARRIET A. TUCK PLANS TO MARRY JOHN SNYDER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Dandridge Tuck of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Anne Tuck, to John Harper Snyder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Snyder of Bernardsville, N.J. A May 31 wedding is planned. The future bride is a sales assistant with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The Generals obtained the running back, Ernest Anderson, a former all-American from Arizona State, from the Arizona Outlaws. Anderson, who was the Outlaws' leading rusher in 1984 but who was used sparingly last season, was obtained for past considerations. . . . Saying ''let them work it out and get it done, and then maybe we can get it resolved,'' Coach Raymond Berry of the New England Patriots has backed off of his decision to institute voluntary drug testing for his players in the hope that Commissioner Pete Rozelle and the players' union can develop a plan. . . . Bill Blair, a former Nets assistant who spent two years as a Chicago Bulls assistant under Kevin Loughery, the Washington Bullets' new head coach, has joined the Bullets as an assistant. . . . Kevin McHale, the Boston Celtics' all-star forward, signed a contract extension that he said would keep him with the Celtics for the rest of his career. No terms were disclosed. . . . William Bidwell, the owner of the football Cardinals in St. Louis, has reportedly decided to keep the team at Busch Stadium for the 1986 season.

title: LOUISVILLE AND LOUISIANA STATE ADVANCE TO N.C.A.A. FINAL FOUR: CARDINALS TOP AUBURN
description: For 40 minutes of electrifying basketball, Auburn and Louisville went after each other today at a pace that intensified as the game progressed. Louisville, known for its high-flying finesse, also proved that it could slug it out. Auburn, whose trademark had been its pulverizing power, ran with the Cardinals and even outran them in stretches.

title: Front Row on 43d Street
description: The buildings, three dilapidated tenements at 33l, 333 and 335 West 43rd Street, were in the heart of Hell's Kitchen and their decay reflected the rundown condition of much of this old West Side neighborhood. Today, the tenements are being renovated into new rental apartments, and, along with a new building at 337, they represent the gentrifying trend of the area, now called Clinton.

title: A SPECIAL EASTER FEAST
description: THE FRENCH CAN HAVE their snails, and the English can have their plum pudding and goose, but I beg of you, give us the old stuffed ham.''

title: MISS MINTON TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Church Minton of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Valerie Haven Minton to Lieut. James Gillis Webster 4th, U.S.N. Supply Corps, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Webster 3d of Englewood, N.J. A May 24 wedding is planned.

title: FACES NAVRATILOVA
description: The rivalry is like an old movie classic that people never tire of watching, and in which they know all the lines by heart. But much to the disappointment of most of those in the record crowd of 16,549 at Madison Square Garden yesterday, Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd will not play it again in the final of the Virginia Slims championship. Check the local tennis listings for the time and place they next meet. And be advised that it is never a certainty when Hana Mandlikova is in the same tournament.

title: BIRTH CONTROL FOR WILD ANIMALS
description: WHEN the Black Beauty Ranch in Murchison, Tex., a haven for unwanted domestic and wild animals, faced a goat population explosion, it called in Dr. Ulysses S. Seal, developer of an animal contraceptive.

title: Politburo Member Is Elected To Be the Premier of Bulgaria
description: Georgi I. Atanasov, a member of the Communist Party Politburo, was elected Prime Minister of Bulgaria by Parliament on Friday, the official Bulgarian press agency reported.

title: EQUAL DISTRIBUTION: JUSTICE HAS ARRIVED
description: IT was a classic divorce story: Michael and Loretta O'Brien of Yonkers met and married; she worked for nine years to put him through the final semester of college, medical preparatory courses, four years of medical school, and finally the internship that led to his obtaining his license to practice medicine. During this time, Mrs. O'Brien contributed all of her earnings (which amounted to 76 percent of their total income) to her husband's education and their joint living expenses, in addition to performing the household work and managing the family finances.

title: LINCOLN IN FINAL, FACES BINGHAMTON
description: Sean Williams drove through traffic for a lay-in with a second left in overtime tonight to give Abraham Lincoln of Brooklyn a 66-64 victory over Long Island Lutheran in a Class A semifinal game at the New York State boys' high school basketball championships.

title: Olive Oil Gets An Endorsement
description: Medical researchers in the United States are concluding that olive oil, consumed around the Mediterranean for thousands of years, may be good for what ails many Americans. According to a report in last week's New England Journal of Medicine, switching from saturated fats (including lard, suet and butter) to olive oil or other mono-unsaturated fats (such as peanut oil) helps lower the cholesterol in the blood, reducing the risk of coronary disease.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
CANADIAN HONORS FOR THE OLYMPICS
description: The Royal Canadian Mint has released two more coins in its series to commemorate the 1988 Winter Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta. Both are silver coins with a face value of $20 and bear designs depicting winter sports.

title: MUSIC: CINCINNATI OPERA'S 'SCHWANDA'
description: CINCINNATI, March 21 - The Cincinnati Opera's audience, which likes a colorful novelty or two from the past mixed in with its standard fare, has been enjoying the colorful adventures of Svanda Dudak -''Schwanda the Bagpiper,'' or in the mouthful of a German translation by which the opera is best known, ''Schwanda der Dudelsackpfeifer.''

title: DIABETES CAMPAIGN LED BY DAUGHTER OF IACOCCA
description: When a 12-year-old girl with diabetes wrote to the Iacocca Foundation for help in finding a pancreas for transplant, the foundation's president could only refer her to a hospital. That, the president said, ''made me weep buckets.''

title: LENORE LONIGRO TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Francis Lonigro of Roselle, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lenore Lonigro, to William S. Macdonald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Weir Macdonald Jr. of Kenilworth, Ill.

title: A Condo Community on a Platform
description: In 1811, the Village of Nyack grew a bit by extending its first pier into the Hudson River. This year, the site of that first pier is once again the scene of growth in Nyack.

title: Foreigners In Their Own Land
description: Reading Ernest Gill's article made me recall those other German refugees, in the 1930's.

title: ALL THE YOUNG SPELLBINDERS
description: 20 UNDER 30 Best Stories by America's New Young Writers. Edited by Debra Spark. 269 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $7.95. DOESN'T it seem that commercial publishers are willing to open the window of opportunity a crack more to writers in their 20's or late teens than they were, say, a generation ago? The 1960's, when I was coming up, were certainly as fixated on youth as the 80's, but the publishing world still presumed it necessary for a young writer to go out and get Experience first. Perhaps the salutary dethroning of this macho ideal (the writer as ex-stevedore/mercenary) has made it possible to give more credence to the imaginations of the young; or perhaps this new generation is simply so preternaturally talented that it cannot be denied.

title: LORI A. STRUMPF TO WED ENGINEER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel M. Strumpf of Milford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Anne Strumpf, to Ronald K. Dritz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Dritz of Hawthorne, N.Y.

title: AIRPORT NOISE PROBLEM: A NEIGHBOR'S REPORT
description: Contrary to the opinion expressed by Mr. [ Samuel F. ] Smith [ ''Changing of the Guard at the County Airport,'' March 2 ] , the Westchester County noise problem has not been resolved. The sophisticated computer system notwithstanding, the increasing noise from helicopters is not controlled. There is no regulation of helicopter noise but simply local noise-abatement procedures, which are in effect for a five-mile radius around the airport. Beyond that helicopter operators are requested to maintain an altitude of at least 1,000 feet.

title: At the Center of Scandals
description: Michele Sindona was a self-made international financier and master swindler who unloosed what, 12 years later, remains the largest bank collapse in United States history.

title: IN FRANCE, OPPOSITES MAY DETRACT
description: WITH fascination and unease, the French watched last week as a new twist unfolded in the theatrical spectacle called politics. After two days of hard bargaining with members of his own conservative coalition, Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris, managed to put together a Government that will ''cohabit,'' as the phrase here has it, with Socialist President Francois Mitterrand. The event, beginning with the conservatives' narrow election victory last weekend, suggested something about French life: After decades and even centuries of experimentation with different systems of government, this is a country still trying to find a way to transfer power from one group to another as a matter of course.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
WEDDING BELLES
description: BEING engaged isn't easy.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
AN ARTIST WHO CAPTURED THE ESSENCE OF CELEBRITY
description: What a period piece the collected photographs of Philippe Halsman represent, and how distant that period seems. Although his career as a photographer began before World War II and spanned more than four decades, although he himself was Latvian-born and Paris-trained, his most characteristic work seems to express an American moment after World War II when the world was once again young, free and full of promise, and Life magazine was the spokesman of its truth.

title: A PUZZLE OF SORTS: ACROSS THE FOREST, DOWN THE SWALE
description: IF YOU are a Long Island isolationist like me - one who hates the proliferation of new signs on the parkways, one who feels that if you don't know where something is, that's good - then this puzzle is for you.

title: MAYOR ORDERS REVIEW ON EX-SANITATION CHIEF
description: Mayor Koch has ordered an investigation into whether a former Sanitation Commissioner, Norman Steisel, was involved in a conflict of interest during the city's negotiations for a $290 million garbage incinerator planned for the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Minnesota Twins, exhibition game, at Orlando, Fla, 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, exhibition, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Houston Astros, exhibition at West Palm Beach, 1:35 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 1:35 P.M.) Basketball N.C.A.A. Division I East Regional final, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J.: Duke plays Navy, and the winner goes to the Final Four next weekend in Dallas. (Television - Channel 2, 1:30 P.M. N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional final, at Kansas City, Mo.: Kansas vs. North Carolina State. A Final Four spot is at stake here, too. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Boxing Tyrell Biggs vs. Jeff Sims, 10 rounds, heavyweights, at Reno. Biggs, a gold medalist from the 1984 Olympics, is going after his ninth straight victory as a professional in his first 10- rounder. He has won six bouts by knockout. Sims has knocked out eight of his last nine opponents. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) Fencing Enterprise Press New York International Saber individual championships, at N.Y.U. Coles Athletic Center, Bleecker and Mercer Streets, 10 A.M. The three medalists from the 1984 Olympics - Jean Francois Lamour of France, Marco Marin of Italy and Peter Westbrook of the United States, nine-time defending national champion -will be joined by the current national champion, Michael Lofton of N.Y.U., in this world- class tournament that features electronic scoring on the saber for the first time.

title: WHY THE SECRECY ABOUT DRILL TEAM?
description: I was glad to see the Rutgers drill team mentioned [ New Jerseyans, March 2 ] .

title: RYAN HAS EAGLES AT WORK ALREADY
description: BUDDY RYAN, innovative genius and mastermind at discovering the most creative procedures for people to mash people, was standing on the Pepin/ Rood Football Field here with his master plan, or a condensed version of it. It was inked onto a slip of paper that he held in his left hand and referred to regularly.

title: SULFUR, ENERGY, GOLD -- AND 12%
description: Freeport-McMoran Inc., a major agricultural minerals producer - mainly sulfur - with interests in energy and gold, has been restructuring: spinning off its oil and gas properties and gold operations, paying down debt, buying back stock.

title: FILIPINO STRIKERS PICKET U.S. BASES
description: Thousands of striking Philippine employees today blockaded the gates of the large United States naval and air bases near here in a widening pay dispute.

title: Poll Shows Doubts on NASA
description: The overwhelming majority of Americans say the United States should continue the space shuttle program despite the explosion of the Challenger on Jan. 28, but many are not confident that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will be able to prevent accidents in the future, according to a recent poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: FINALLY, DESKTOP SOFTWARE FOR APPLES
description: DESKTOP accessory programs have been with us for a couple of years now.

title: KOCH EXPECTS CUTS IN SOME SERVICES
description: No new programs or improved services will be included in Mayor Koch's proposed city budget for the coming fiscal year, and some nonessential services will have to be cut back, the Mayor has advised his commissioners.

title: AKIN'S PORSCHE WINS SEBRING 12-HOUR RACE
description: Hans Stuck, Jo Gartner and the car owner Bob Akin drove a nearly flawless race in a Porsche 962 today to win the Coca-Cola Classic Sebring 12-Hours sports car endurance race.

title: A LUMINOUS 'MENAGERIE' GLOWS AT THE LONG WARF
description: While acknowledging Amanda Wingfield's cruelty, Tennessee Williams also made it clear that this stage portrait of his mother in ''The Glass Menagerie'' was intended to be sympathetic. She is a woman of gentility and warmth, someone who acts out of love - or, rather, her idea of love - for her children. In Amanda's memory, she is still that Southern belle, who, one Sunday afternoon, received 17 gentlemen callers. Years later, abandoned by her husband, a telephone man who ''fell in love with long distance,'' she sustains herself and the remnants of her family with dreams of her own romantic past and with hopes for the future of her crippled daughter, Laura. In the mother's fantasy, a gentleman caller will come for Laura, who - a sleeping princess - will be magically transformed into the lost Amanda. Again, the mother's life will be filled with jonquils.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CHARACTERS, ELEGANT VERSE
description: IN naming James Merrill the poet laureate of Connecticut, the state's Commission on the Arts has indulged itself in a moment of sly wit that would amuse some of the illustrious dead who populate Mr. Merrill's vast comic epic, ''The Changing Light at Sandover,'' and speak through a Ouija board.

title: CONNECTICUT RACE PUTS SPEECHWRITER ON STAGE
description: The unwritten rule that speechwriters should be heard and not seen is being broken these days in the campaign for governor of Connecticut.

title: ROCKETS TROUNCE KNICKS BY 114-99
description: They came in droves: James Bailey, Bob Thornton, Chris McNealy, Ken Bannister and Louis Orr.

title: U.S. OFFERS DAIRYMEN A BUYOUT
description: THE Federal Government will announce Friday who of Connecticut's dairy farmers it will pay to go out of business next year. Those chosen will be among the about 75 who applied under a Federal program to reduce the nation's milk surplus. The State Department of Agriculture, meanwhile, is poised to help keep the farms as farms once they stop being dairies.

title: CONNECTICUT IS INSTALLING ITS FIRST POET LAUREATE
description: JAMES MERRILL, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet from Stonington, will be installed this week as the state's first poet laureate. The title will be presented to Mr. Merrill by Governor O'Neill at ceremonies Wednesday in Hartford.

title: ENVOY ASSERTS U.S. IS ISOLATED
description: The new Nicaraguan Ambassador to the United Nations said yesterday that the rebels could not win the war against the Sandinista Government and that, therefore, a military intervention by the United States was ''a real possibility.''

title: 'SESAME STREET' GIRDS FOR BUMPY TIMES
description: Watching her brainchild, ''Sesame Street,'' while dressing one recent morning, Joan Ganz Cooney laughed out loud when Oscar the Grouch sang deliriously about trash.

title: CATHEDRAL CONCERT SPRING SERIES SET
description: THE Cathedral Concert Series, which traditionally opens its spring series on Palm Sunday, has scheduled an all-Tchaikovsky program this year.

title: Anti-Homosexual Bias Violates a Moral Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: REPLACING CEILING LIGHTS: GET TO KNOW YOUR FIXTURE
description: REPLACING a ceiling lighting fixture that no longer works, or installing a new model that is more decorative or more efficient, is a fairly simple electrical project.

title: Mitterrand vs. Chirac: Poll Rates Them Even
description: President Francois Mitterrand and the new Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, are about equal in popularity, according to an opinion poll.

title: RAIL PLAN FACING NEW SUIT
description: WITH state and Federal officials in final agreement to revive railroad passenger service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, there is talk that work to restore the rusting rails and clear the weed-tangled right of way may begin in months, perhaps within weeks.

title: COMPUTER TELLS LEFT-HANDERS: OUTSIDE FASTBALLS TO MATTINGLY
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE pitchers know that Don Mattingly won the batting championship in 1984 and was the most valuable player last year when he drove in more runs than anyone in baseball. What they would like to know is how to get Mattingly out this year.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
The Dare
description: THE SECRET TO DIVING UNDER A moving freight train and rolling out the other side with all your parts attached lies in picking the right spot between the tracks to hit with your back. Ideally, you want soft dirt or pea gravel, clear of glass shards and railroad spikes that could cause you instinctively, and fatally, to sit up. Today, at 37, I couldn't be threatened or baited enough to attempt that dive. But as a seventh grader struggling to make the cut in a tough Atlanta grammar school, all it took was a dare.

title: IRISH RUGBY: THE ATTENTION IS UNDIVIDED
description: To the sports fan, Ireland's rugby team has just ended an unremarkable season. It lost to Scotland, leaving Ireland winless in four matches in international competition this year.

title: OSCAR NIGHT CASTS ITS MAGIC SPELL
description: Like it or not, the odds are that tomorrow you'll be spending at least part of a long evening in front of a television set watching the 58th annual Academy Awards ceremonies (on ABC, starting at 9 E. S. T.). Any insurance man's actuarial tables will tell you so.
