You might tune in to see whether, after eight nominations, Geraldine Page finally wins her first Oscar (for ''A Trip to Bountiful''), and whether Steven Spielberg, who wasn't nominated, will show up to support his ''Color Purple'' colleagues, who were. It could be that your interest is in who gets the sound recording award. Possibly you're at home only because there's no one around to go bowling with. Whatever the reasons, you're part of the show's dizzy ratings.

title: BURNS RESIGNED TO HIS FATE
description: He was not dressed like a ballplayer. He wore boots and blue overalls and glasses that kept sliding down his nose. And he looked alone, standing by himself in the half-empty clubhouse, reading a newspaper as two men folded uniforms and placed them into neat piles on large trunks.

title: Matthew Goodman
description: This busy week of newcomers was also brightened by a clarinetist named Matthew Goodman, who with his excellent young pianist, Elena Ivanina, played at Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday evening. Mr. Goodman creates a beautiful range of colors and knows when and how to go from one to the other. The Romanza from Poulenc's duo Sonata was especially sensuous and appealing, creating a softness and timbral breadth to be recreated later in the evening in Debussy's First Rhapsody.

title: UNIONS PUSH RETRAINING PROGRAMS
description: IN a windowless basement room in downtown Washington, down a short flight of stairs from the Chesapeake & Potomac Telephone Company headquarters, resides an adult-education program whose contributions to workers stand in sharp contrast to its unassuming surroundings. Since 1983 this, and dozens of makeshift classrooms like it, have played a key role in helping tens of thousands of employees train for jobs in the rapidly changing telecommunications industry.

title: CHEERS (AND STUFFING) FOR THE POTATO
description: WOULDN'T you know it! Just as the last of the East End potato farmers is probably selling the last potato farm to yet another new and hopeful vineyard, March is designated National Potato Lovers Month.

title: BIG BOOKS FROM SMALL HOUSES
description: PHIL WOOD, founder of the Ten Speed Press here, was non-plussed when David Arora approached him with a 680-page book on mushrooms. But Mr. Wood took it home and ''found myself laughing at this mushroom book that was so witty and well written. I called him the next day and said I'd publish it.''

title: Bridging the Gulf of Affordability
description: INTEREST rates have declined. Tax-abatement programs for housing construction, at least ous. The need for an increase in the production of housing at prices that middle-income people can afford is taken for granted. So what can make it happen? Mayor Koch raised that question last December when he asked 34 large construction organizations for suggestions on how to meet an annual production target of 10,000 units of new or substantially rehabilitated housing units for moderate- to middle-income households. By adopting a definition of ''moderate- to middle-income'' drawn from government-assisted housing programs - households with incomes in the range of $15,000 to $48,000 a year - he called, in effect, for a program that requires city participation, usually in the provision of land owned by the city.

title: What Price Fitness?
description: It would have been interesting to consider how other cultures approach the subject of health and fitness. Oriental exercises are becoming better known in this country, and it is no secret that the Japanese not only outproduce us -they outlive us as well.

title: POUND RIDGE NURTURES FAMILY LEGACY
description: BY all accounts, the Lockwoods were hard-working, civic-minded Puritans who were among Pound Ridge's first settlers. They fought the British during the Revolutionary War, and later prospered as farmers and merchants. They built a church, a schoolhouse and more than a dozen farmhouses.

title: HEADED CIVIL AERONAUTICS BOARD
description: Secor D. Browne, the chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board from 1969 to 1973 and an unflagging critic of the 1978 legislation deregulating the airlines, died yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: All About Stockman
description: Heaven help any printer who drops the type at Haddon Craftsmen Inc. up in Scranton, Pa., these days.

title: GAS PRICES OFF AT PUMP
description: Retail gasoline prices fell nearly 8 cents a gallon over the last two weeks, and Dan Lundberg, who surveys 17,000 gasoline stations in 50 states biweekly for his Lundberg Letter, said today that the reduced rates could save motorists nearly $19 billion the rest of this year.

title: A.M.C. Recovery SEEN BY NEW HEAD
description: Joseph E. Cappy, who was elected president and chief executive officer of the American Motors Corporation on Friday, found it hard in an interview to contain his enthusiasm on the future of the small auto maker, despite its past heavy losses.

title: Saber Champion
description: Robert Kostelniakowski of Poland scored several upsets to win the Enterprise Press New York International Saber championship yesterday at New York University's Coles Athletic Center.

title: CHEAP OIL AND WEAKER OPEC ARE EASING ISRAEL'S BURDENS
description: In 1974 when the Arab oil-exporting states were just reaching the pinnacle of their economic and political power, Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin prophesied that Israel was headed for seven lean years. But reversing Joseph's warning in the Bible, Mr. Rabin added that the seven lean years would be followed by seven fat years - if Israel could just weather the oil price storm.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: PARADISE POSTPONED. By John Mortimer. 374 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Andrea J. Smiley Marries Keith Higgins in the Bronx
description: Andrea J. Smiley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Douglas G. Smiley, was married yesterday at her parents home in Riverdale, the Bronx, to Keith F. Higgins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Higgins of Sebastian, Fla. United States District Judge Charles P. Sifton of the Eastern District of New York, officiated.

title: MARGEOTES AGENCY'S OLD FRIEND, KIRIN BEER
description: When Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss opened its doors as an ad agency in 1973, its only client - billing a low, low $10,000 a year - was Kirin Beer, the import from Japan. Agency and client grew together.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.Monday None Tuesday Durable GoodsJanuary Wednesday None Thursday Merchandise Trade BalanceJanuary Friday Leading IndicatorsFebruary

title: PEOPLE
description: * Gordon L. Link, an exeutive vice president, has become the first worldwide director of media services for McCann-Erickson.

title: FOR YOGI BERRA, A HAPPY RETURN
description: IN a period spanning a little more than 40 years, Yogi Berra has survived both D-Day and George Steinbrenner, and is alive and well and coaching in Kissimmee.

title: ROCK: COLE AND KEENE
description: FOLK-ROCK will never die. Or so it seems, as a style now entering its third decade continues to attract young songwriters.

title: DEJOHNETTE APPEARS WITH SPECIAL EDITION
description: The drummer Jack DeJohnette and his current lineup of Special Edition, a quintet, played an old-fashioned blowing session for their first set Friday at Fat Tuesday's.

title: Getting Your Wires Crossed With a Price From the Past
description: Their telephone call was going from an apartment on the Upper West Side to a home in Jackson Heights via the Twilight Zone. At least, that is what two friends thought when they overheard a faint voice during their conversation:

title: Out-of-Wedlock Births Found Rising in State
description: One in four babies was born out of wedlock in New York in 1984, an increase of 4.8 percent from 1983, according to a report on vital statistics issued today by the State Health Department. A spokesman for the department said the figures were the latest available.

title: STAGE: 'SAVE THE LOOPHOLES!'
description: FOR Richard and Marsha, New York yuppies who meet in front of Penn Station, the language of love fastens on things like salaries, stock options and triple-A bonds. Within minutes of meeting, Richard (Dale Carman) proposes ''merger,'' and Marsha (Marianne Leone) coyly counters, ''so long as it's not a takeover.'' Once agreed, they take off to Marsha's place where her roommates and friends are busy ''networking'' and watching the season's premiere episode of ''Travesty.'' Richard and Marsha eventually reach orgasmic frenzy as they free-associate sensory impressions of a high-powered business meeting while standing back to back in Marsha's cedar-scented closet.

title: By Hate Possessed
description: Not for many years has this country known a political atmosphere as vicious as Washington experienced in the days leading up to the House vote on aid to the contras. And it is not over. For a number of reasons, the Nicaraguan issue will continue to poison our politics.

title: SUCCESS CATCHES UP WITH WEISS IN 'HAMLET'
description: The first time Jeff Weiss was cast in a New York Shakespeare Festival production, he attended a rehearsal and then went to Joseph Papp's office and said, ''Joe, I'm totally crazy, I can't do this.''

title: STOCKHOLDERS BACK KAISER
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said today that its shareholders had rejected an investor group's attempt to replace its directors. The group, led by Joseph A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., had until March 22 to present the company with consents representing a majority of the common shares, but did not do so.

title: Honors for a Notable Mix Of Contributors to City Life
description: A movie director whose most notable star is New York City. A retired executive who turned his attention from Green Stamps to greenswards. A dissenting voice on the City Planning Commission who was denied reappointment.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN SONG IN DAYLONG MARATHON
description: SONG permeates America coast to coast, and no other nation can claim so many diverse denominations of it. In our melting pot, great distinctive musical chunks have clung together, flavoring the stew without losing themselves in it. So the challenge facing Symphony Space with its ''Wall to Wall American Song'' marathon Saturday morning, noon and night was not whether enough variety could be found to fill 12 hours, but rather how on earth to squeeze everything in.

title: Deficit, Taxes and Blacks
description: The campaign for reduction of the Federal deficit has been joined by black economists, who foresee continued imbalance in the budget forcing reductions in Government spending on programs that help support blacks and other low-income families. Assessing the effect of tax-revision proposals on blacks, Dr. Lynn Burbridge, a research associate at the Joint Center for Political Studies, says, ''To blacks and the poor, the crucial question is whether a tax reform bill will generate enough revenue to reduce the U.S. budget deficit.''

title: ARMED ROBBER SHOT DEAD DURING MIDTOWN CHASE
description: An armed robber was killed and his suspected accomplice was captured yesterday after a brief chase through midtown Manhattan that began on the ninth floor of the Prince George Hotel on East 28th Street, the police said. A number of shots were fired in the incident but no other serious injuries were reported.

title: Sudan to Get Saudi Oil
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia has ordered his Petroleum Ministry to give the Sudan 2.92 million barrels of oil over four months, the state-owned newspapers Al Ayyam and Al Sahafa reported. The gift is worth $62 million and will cover all of the Sudan's oil needs for four months, they said.

title: DESSOFF CHOIRS SING TANEYEV'S '10 CHORUSES'
description: The clear highlight of the Dessoff Choirs' Saturday night program at Merkin Concert Hall was the American premiere of Sergei Taneyev's ''10 Choruses'' (Op. 27) to texts by Yakov Polonsky.

title: Optimism on Northern Ireland
description: The most intractable political problems are, arguably, those involving a conflict of rights. A classic example is the Middle East where Israel's right to exist in peace and security has to be reconciled with the Palestinians' right to a homeland. And what is most required to resolve such conflicts is a spirit of compromise that softens, even if it does not altogether remove, the tribal reflexes of one side to dominate the other.

title: IMPORT BARGAINS VANISHING
description: For American consumers, who for several years enjoyed cheap imports ranging from felt pens to cars, the bargains are ending.

title: 4 Children are Killed in Fire
description: Fire and thick smoke engulfed a single-story brick home early today, killing four children and presumably a man who has yet to be found, fire officials said. Among those killed were a 2-week-old boy, male and female twins about 4 months old, and a 2-year-old boy, fire officials said.

title: A FORD CHANGE SET IN GERMANY
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been serving the Ford Motor Company, its biggest client, in 23 countries, is losing it in West Germany, an executive at the subsidiary's headquarters in Cologne confirmed Friday. Billings are between $30 million and $40 million.

title: Robin Neimark And F. M. Seegal Wed in Purchase
description: Robin Margery Neimark and Frederic Milton Seegal were married yesterday at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., by Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Neimark of Harrison, N.Y. Mr. Seegal is the son of Miriam Emden of New York and the late Milton Seegal of Los Angeles.

title: FOR 3D DAY, WEATHER STALLS SALVAGING OF SHUTTLE
description: For a third day, salvage ships involved in the search for wreckage from the space shuttle Challenger remained in port today, waiting out strong winds and 14-foot seas off the Florida coast.

title: Burma Reports Rebel Toll
description: Government troops killed 1,870 insurgents in battles over the last 12 months and 416 of its soldiers were killed, the Government radio said today. In the 12 months ended March 20, the radio said, another 506 insurgents were captured and 920 surrendered.

title: Public Policy Role of Liability Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat Seeks Answer From Reagan on Peace
description: Yasir Arafat demanded today, after meeting President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, that the United States respond to his ideas on a Middle East peace formula.

title: From Learned Hand To Henry Friendly
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKINGS BETS ON THE SPREAD
description: THE MOB ran wild in the Chicago futures pits last week.

title: Outdoors: Making Lures at Home
description: ALTHOUGH the art of tying flies receives much attention in both print and practice, relatively few anglers fashion their own plugs, spoons, jigs and spinners.

title: FILIPINOS AND U.S. DIFFER ON STRIFE
description: United States Navy officials and local labor leaders disputed one another today over allegations that American servicemen had stabbed picketing Filipino workers who walked off their jobs this weekend at the Subic Bay Naval Base here.

title: Lucia Victor, Director And a Stage Manager
description: Lucia Victor, a production stage manager and director of the Broadway theater who was long associated with the producer David Merrick and the director-choreographer Gower Champion, died Saturday at her home in Chappaqua, N.Y. She was 74 years old.

title: AQUINO'S RULE MARKED BY SLOW PACE
description: Just once in her first three weeks of leadership, people in the corridor outside the President's office have heard Corazon C. Aquino raise her voice, and the story is being told and retold with excitement among her aides and Cabinet ministers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map on Feb. 25 with a Rio de Janeiro dispatch about an Amazon kayak trip incorrectly labeled a coastal area south of Peru. It is part of Chile, not Argentina.

title: HOUSING POLICEMAN FATALLY SHOT BY ROBBERS
description: An off-duty New York City Housing Authority police officer was shot to death last night when he was robbed in a housing project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: PEETE, ON 66 AND 68, WINS BY 5
description: Calvin Peete, by far the most accurate and victorious golfer on the PGA Tour in recent years, made the game look easy again today as he shot successive rounds of 6-under-par 66 and 4-under-par 68 to win the USF&G Classic by five shots.

title: POP: PALMER AND WADE DUO
description: THE pop-soul duo of Jeree Palmer and Adam Wade, performers who have been associated with the successful nightclub revue ''Shades of Harlem,'' have created an Atlantic City-oriented cabaret act that carries on the professional lovebird tradition of Nickolas Ashford and Valerie Simpson. In their show ''Here's to Love,'' which played at Sweetwater's (Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street) through Saturday night, the duo concentrated on mainstream pop-soul hits, including Stevie Wonder's ''Part-Time Lover,'' Lionel Richie's ''Missing You'' and three Ashford and Simpson songs.

title: Michigan State In Final Four
description: Mitch Messier had a goal and an assist tonight to lead Michigan State to a 4-2 victory over Boston College, sending the Spartans to the Final Four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

title: POLICE METHODS TO BE CONCERN IN SUFFOLK TRIAL
description: A 22-year-old drifter, drug user and convicted felon, James Diaz, goes on trial Monday on charges of sexual abuse and assault. He faces similar charges in another case next month.

title: OUTLAYS FOR PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: The importance of public relations is not lost on Government agencies, and according to a recent study by the General Accounting Office, spending in this area by the Reagan Administration, after dipping three years ago, is back on the rise.

title: Under Cover
description: If a soldier has the the skills, the strength and the desire, it's usually easy enough to enter Army wrestling matches, but it hasn't been easy for one 20-year-old soldier stationed in West Germany. After a three-month battle with Army bureaucrats, however, the soldier was finally authorized last week to participate in the military wrestling program, but only after the seven-man sports council of the United States Army in Europe had spent three months grappling with such issues as safety, competitive parity, equality of athletic opportunity and modesty.

title: Reading On in Luke
description: To the Editor:

title: Cronyism at Its Worst
description: During the Carter Administration our Ambassador to the U.N., Andrew Young, made an unauthorized visit to representatives of the P.L.O., undermining our agreement with Israel and encouraging terrorists in the belief that no renunciation of terror was needed to establish relations with the United States.

title: STATES FORCED INTO LEAD ON HOUSING FOR POOR
description: In an old neighborhood here that has been plagued for decades by poverty and abandonment, residents were surprised recently to see a cluster of new houses for low-income families going up on Breckinridge Street.

title: Conboy Report Offers No Incentives for Transit Police in Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIAN BALLET IN 'ALICE'
description: The National Ballet of Canada will present the American premiere of ''Alice,'' a ballet by Glen Tetley, when it opens at the Metropolitan Opera House on July 22 for a one-week engagement.

title: 4 Children Are Hurt as Roof Collapses on a Pool at Club
description: The roof of a private swim club collapsed today, sending chunks of wood and masonry into a pool and injuring four children who had been sitting at poolside, the authorities said.

title: INDIA MAY PRESS CLAIM
description: Indian officials said today that the Indian Government, which was not a party to the tentative settlement reached between Union Carbide and plaintiffs' lawyers, reserves the right to continue to press its own claim in the case.

title: HOMES SERVING MENTALLY DISABLED MEET RESISTANCE
description: Ten years ago, when New York State established a policy that would allow thousands of mentally disabled people to move from institutions to homes in residential communities, most mental health experts hailed the new approach.

title: CORRECTING THE TRADE GAP WITH TAIWAN
description: Last summer, when Taiwan was heading for a $13 billion trade surplus with the United States, the Boeing Aircraft Company was lobbying hard for China Airlines, the nation's flag carrier, to fill its need for a new wide-bodied airliner by buying a third twin-jet 767.

title: A Conscience of Education
description: Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the educator, is perhaps best known for a study of the damaging psychological consequences of ''separate but equal'' schooling, a study that in 1954 helped persuade the Supreme Court to outlaw racial segregation in public schools.

title: FEARS ON ROLE OF BUSINESS
description: The Southern Pacific Transportation Company, descended from the company that built the first transcontinental railroad, has been based in the same 11-story brick building at the foot of Market Street since 1917.

title: Louisiana Derby To Country Light
description: Country Light hugged the rail early, then took the lead near the eighth pole and went on to win the $200,000 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds by two lengths today.

title: Insurance Problems Might Close Burn Unit
description: Doctors from Jo Ellen Smith Medical Center in New Orleans have complained that a critically burned 2-year-old was turned away Thursday from West Jefferson General Hospital because his mother's health insurance could not immediately be verified.

title: DUKE AND KANSAS WIN AND ADVANCE TO FINAL FOUR
description: The Blue Devils of Duke usually win with overwhelming talent, overcoming opponents with players whose skills are rich and diverse. But on a day when they were not at their peak, the nation's top-ranked college basketball team reached the Final Four for the first time in eight years by showing that they can also win with plain hard work.

title: CASUALTIES
description: ''THE custody battle left me and my children with terrible feelings of anger and depression,'' said Judith, a California mother of three.

title: Impressionist Paintings On Display in Moscow
description: An exhibition of French Impressionist paintings from the National Gallery in Washington opened in Moscow last week under the cultural agreement reached last November between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: HOUSING PROJECT SETS OFF DISPUTE IN OLD MILL TOWN
description: A land parcel approved by the Federal Government as the site for a million-dollar housing project for farm workers has become the focus of an intense controversy in this old mill town.

title: PRESSED BY TRAFFIC, GREENWICH SEEKS A QUIET LIFE
description: When a village official, Cindy Rubicam, suggested building a wall at the edge of town here, she was not kidding. ''It would discourage the commuter traffic,'' she said.

title: Frederic Kessler Wed To Roberta J. Schoen
description: Roberta Jane Schoen, the daughter of Marilyn V. Schoen of Morristown, N.J., and Albert Schoen of Dover, N.J., was married yesterday to Frederic Stuart Kessler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Kessler of Union, N.J. Rabbi Gershon Chertoff performed the ceremony at the Livingston (N.J.) Country Club.

title: TREASURY TO RETURN TO DEBT MARKET
description: The Treasury Department, which has been absent from the intermediate and long-term Government debt markets for some weeks, is scheduled to return this week, selling $13.5 billion worth of new four-year and seven-year notes.

title: A Psychedelic Cadillac That's Easy to Park
description: It looks like a vision from an acid trip. Flamingos fly from its fins. Ducks swim on its hood. Bowlers bowl on its bumper.

title: GATX ACCEPTS BID MADE BY LEUCADIA
description: The GATX Corporation has accepted a $40-a-share cash offer from the Leucadia National Corporation to buy the 91.1 percent stake it does not already own in GATX for a total of $495.8 million.

title: MUSIC: RENATO CAPECCHI IN BARITONE RECITAL
description: RENATO CAPECCHI, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut in 1951, has never been a huge star there. But he has enough admirers that he could easily have made his program Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall - billed as his New York debut recital, if that term can be applied to a 63-year-old baritone - a comfortable vanity affair.

title: Supermarket Chain Recalls Dairy Products
description: A chain of supermarkets has recalled all containers of its house brand and generic ice cream, ice milk and sherbet from 463 stores in three states after consumers reported finding shards of glass.

title: LINCOLN BEATEN FOR STATE TITLE
description: Abraham Lincoln of Brooklyn, riding a string of tight and improbable victories, ran into a vengeful team from Binghamton in the Class A New York State boys' high school basketball championship game today and didn't have a chance.

title: AS BEETHOVEN ROLLS OVER, HOUSTON LISTENERS ARISE
description: The city of Houston has fine ballet, opera, symphony and museums and Texas-size cultural aspirations. But, as of a few days ago, it became the largest city in the country without a full-time classical music radio station.

title: Catching Up
description: * Brian Sipe, the quarterback who suffered two severe injuries to his right shoulder last year while playing for the Jacksonville Bulls of the United States Football League, has decided that at the age of 36 he has played his last professional game. ''My career it over, that's final,'' he said the other day from his home in Encinatas, Calif.

title: N.I.T. SEARCHES FOR 'HOME TEAM'
description: The hope that one or more teams with fan appeal would reach the semifinals of the National Invitation Tournament began soon after the 32-team field started play without a local team for the first time in its 49-year history. Seeking to capitalize on the popularity of the Big East Conference, the tournament committee at first hoped for Providence to reach tonight's semifinal round at Madison Square Garden.

title: CONCERT: THE VIENNA STRING SEXTET
description: THE Vienna String Sextet distinguished itself Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Museum with a silken, seductively restrained and precise performance of Arnold Schoenberg's study in the decadence of Romantic harmony, ''Verklarte Nacht'' (''Transfigured Night''). The six (Erich Hobarth, Peter Matzka, Thomas Riebl, Siegfried Fuhrlinger, Rudolf Leopold and Susanne Ehn) played as one, meticulously revealing the strands of counterpoint, eschewing or minimizing ritards and accelerations, keeping the potentially dense textures always utterly transparent.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In the history of the N.C.A.A. Division I basketball tournament, which team has played the most games, which has won the most and which has been the biggest loser?

title: BUOYANT ANTI-DRUG PARLEY PLANS A GLOBAL ALLIANCE
description: A roar came out of the doors of the auditorium here Friday that could be heard hundreds of feet away. The audience had just heard the idea for a new organization uniting youth around the world to fight drugs, presented to the International Conference on Drugs.

title: WEARY OPEC OFFICALS FAIL TO DEVISE OUTPUT PLAN
description: OPEC ministers emerged from an eighth weary day of talks here today unable to come up with any specific agreement to stop the plunge of oil prices.

title: AN ARMED WOMAN IS NOT A MORE SECURE WOMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. TALKS ON BL BROKEN OFF
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that talks had broken down with the British Government on the purchase of Land Rover and the trucks division of BL P.L.C., the former British Leyland.

title: COACH LAUDS SPIRIT OF LOUISIANA STATE
description: One morning earlier this year, the Louisiana State coach, Dale Brown, was shaving when his wife, Vonnie, decided to offer criticism. An award-winning folk dancer and a dance instructor at Louisiana State University, Mrs. Brown had previously refrained from commenting on her husband's occupation. But, with his team struggling and the 51-year-old Brown contemplating retirement, she felt compelled to intervene.

title: CIGARETTE AD BAN IS RECOMMENDED
description: The American Cancer Society today called for the elimination of all advertising of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco.

title: So What if Castro Dislikes Radio Marti?
description: It would be a sad mistake indeed if Washington were to heed the recent calls to close down Radio Marti, the service created by the Reagan Administration to provide Cubans with the kind of programming that Radio Free Europe offers in Eastern Europe.

title: DANCE: 'QUARTET' FOR 5, BY MERCE CINNINGHAM
description: WHEN does a quartet have five people? When it's Merce Cunningham's ''Quartet,'' which was performed for the first time this season by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company last Wednesday night at the City Center. The unusual work for five proved to be both a working out of formal problems and an implicitly dramatic, though plotless, dance evoking isolation and loneliness.

title: Frommelt Is Winner
description: Paul Frommelt of Liechtenstein won the men's parallel and Vreni Schneider of Switzerland won the women's parallel today in the final World Cup races.

title: OCCIDENTAL GETS PERU PACTS
description: Peru has signed two oil exploration and operation contracts with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation over the vocal objections of the country's sizable Marxist opposition.

title: HEART FAILS 3 TIMES BEFORE MAN RECEIVES EMERGENCY IMPLANT
description: A 43-year-old factory foreman suffered cardiac arrest three times just before surgeons implanted a Jarvik-7 artificial heart in him as an emergency lifesaver, hospital officials said today.

title: LEBANON CHRISTIANS REPORTED TO RESUME LINKS WITH ISRAEL
description: Lebanese Christians here have resumed their ties with Israel after abandoning the links for 10 months, according to Moslem leaders and news accounts in Beirut.

title: MUNICIPAL UPTURN IS EXPECTED
description: Conditions in the municipal bond market are almost certain to improve significantly this week, bringing to an end an unusual three-day period of uncertainty and instability.

title: BUDD CAPTURES RACE
description: John Ngugi, a 21-year-old student from Kenya, was the surprise winner in the World cross-country championships today, while Zola Budd led all the way and won the women's race, beating Lynn Jennings of the United States.

title: DANCE: PAWEL AND HOVDA
description: LAURA PAWEL and Eleanor Hovda, who have been collaborating since 1973, offered samples of their works, with choreography by Miss Pawel and music by Miss Hovda, when the Laura Pawel Dance Company performed Saturday night at the Cunningham Studio.

title: DANCE: 'ELVIS DANCE' BY AERODANCE GROUP
description: THE Multigravitational Aerodance Group engaged in a problematical exercise on Friday at its pretty new theater at the Sirovich Senior Center on the Lower East Side. Clinging to vertical ropes, sliding on horizontal ones and dangling from harnesses in the upper air, the performers offered theater that seemed intended to mock gravity. Often, however, the effect was comparable to riding a bicycle with training wheels.

title: HAWKS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 5-3
description: The Rangers intended to teach the playoff-bound Chicago Black Hawks a lesson in tenacity last night at Madison Square Garden and hoped that their desperate need of a victory would help them achieve one. Instead, the Black Hawks used two ingredients so simple as to be cliches, hard work and a hot goaltender, Murray Bannerman, to beat the Rangers, 5-3, and sweep the season series.

title: SYMPTOMS OF A FEVER IN CHICAGO
description: One of the hottest-selling videotapes across the country in recent days has nothing to do with music, movies or Rambo.

title: HILL, HOLIDAY, CONNORS WINS LABATT ACCOUNT
description: Labatt Importers, which brings in the Canadian brewery's products, was reportedly looking for a New York ad agency after splitting with Tracy-Locke, BBDO International's Dallas subsidiary, in February.

title: FILIBUSTER STALLSS TWO AIRLINE BILLS
description: Senate consideration of a bill that would prevent airlines from selling arrival and departure slots at four major airports in private transactions has been stalled by a filibuster over another transportation bill.

title: BUILDING ISSUES AND RATE DROP
description: THE plunge in crude oil prices this year depressed energy stocks, but it proved a bonanza for home building issues by paving the way for a spectacular decline in interest rates.

title: CALIFORNIA DERBY CROP STRONG
description: California-based colts have won only four of the last 20 Kentucky Derbies, but if the run for this year's roses were held today instead of May 3, there might be an all-Californian parade to the finish line.

title: COACH K'S SILENT 36-2
description: IN repose, he has the face of a Polish parish priest. Neatly cut black hair.

title: PARENTS OF PREMATURE INFANTS FORMING SELF-HELP GROUPS
description: As doctors and nurses are increasingly able to treat babies born prematurely or with congenital or birth complications, they are realizing that the parents as well as the babies need special attention. Intensive care nurseries and communities have responded by developing support groups.

title: WHEN WRITERS TURN TO BRAVE NEW FORMS
description: IN talking about artists, most of us are inclined to think of them as virtuoso-practitioners in a specific category. We tend to think of Tennessee Williams's plays, rather than his fiction; of Woody Allen's movies, rather than his stories; of John Updike's novels, rather than his poetry or reviews. The fact remains, however, that these artists have all demonstrated a remarkable fluency in a variety of forms, as have others throughout history. Had Chekhov been required to state his occupation on a passport application, would he have chosen ''playwright'' or ''short-story writer''? Would William Blake have opted to be identified as a poet or a painter? And what about Wyndham Lewis - painter? novelist? polemicist? or simply professional malcontent?

title: ZALE REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
description: The Zale Corporation, the nation's largest jewelry retailer, yesterday rejected an unfriendly bid by Peoples Jewellers Ltd. to acquire Zale's for $45 a share in cash and securities, or about $475 million (United States).

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EAST MEETS WEST The College of Fine Arts at Shanghai University is one of China's leading art schools, and one of the oldest. The City University of New York calls itself the nation's leading public urban university. A cultural exchange between the City University and the College of Fine Arts has brought to New York more than 100 works of art by 70 Shanghai University artists. The works will go on exhibition today in a show, ''Art From Shanghai University.''

title: U.S. EXPORTS ARE BEGINNING TO PICK UP
description: The first beneficial effects of a lower dollar on American exports are starting to appear, although the impact has been spotty.

title: THE WRITES OF SPRING
description: THIS week's ''bad news on the doorstep'' - Don McLean's phrase for the headline announcing the death of Buddy Holly - was that the New York Mets are abandoning their base in St. Petersburg after next spring.

title: Oscar Program to Offer All-Star Variety Show
description: The 58th Annual Academy Awards presentations have a built-in finale every year with the announcement of best actress, best actor and best picture. But the three-hour-plus gala from the Los Angeles Music Center Monday night - on ABC starting at 9 - will again provide a musical-variety show.

title: Military Jets Just Miss Hitting T.W.A. Liner
description: Four military jets narrowly missed a Trans World Airline plane carrying 141 passengers from Columbus, Ohio, to St. Louis, a report by the pilot of the Boeing 727 charges.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
description: International Renewal of U.S. base rights in Turkey appeared to falter as the Turkish Government insisted on linking the renewal to major trade concessions by the United States. The demands seemed to have caught American officials off guard. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who had hoped for an early renewal, complained that the Turks had ''sandbagged'' him and accused them of ''beating me over the head about it.'' The United States is using the bases on an interim basis while negotiations proceed on an accord to replace one that expired Dec. 31. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: DANCE: LES SORTILEGES, FROM CANADA
description: LES SORTILEGES, a troupe from Montreal that terms itself Canada's National Folk Ensemble, appeared Thursday night at Carnegie Hall in a program of folk dances from many lands.

title: 'CRUEL CAMERA,' ABOUT ANIMAL ABUSE
description: ''CRUEL CAMERA'' is something like counter-programming; WNYC-TV is raising an issue. Most of the television audience may watch the film industry congratulate itself tonight at the Academy Awards ceremony; ''Cruel Camera'' is about the unpleasant things that can happen to animals in films. The one-hour program, on Channels 3 and 31 at 9 P.M., makes a case.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1986
description: International

title: Hidden Light Stays Unbeaten
description: Heavily favored Hidden Light remained unbeaten in four career starts as she held off the challenge of Twilight Ridge today and scored a 1 1/2-length victory in the $160,700 Santa Anita Oaks for 3-year-old fillies.

title: Putter Out
description: The United States Golf Association said last Friday that one of the two versions of the new Peltz putter used by some pros ''does not conform to the rules of golf.''

title: Chicago's Bitter Fruit
description: The warfare among Chicago Democrats claimed an unintended victim last week: Adlai Stevenson 3d, the Democratic nominee for governor of Illinois. The fiasco should send an instructive message to Chicago and the nation about the dangers of extremist politics and an uninformed electorate.

title: NURSE IN JOHNSON-WILL CASE TESTIFIES HE APPEARED ALERT
description: A nurse who cared for an heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune near the end of his life testified last week that the multimillionaire was alert and cogent at a time when his six children say he was incoherent and near death from cancer.

title: The U.N. Today; March 24, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: RECITAL: KAREN HOLVIK SINGS
description: KAREN HOLVIK'S evening at Alice Tully Hall on Friday introduced us to a singer who will certainly make her way in the music world. Miss Holvik's light, pleasant soprano has a liquid fluency, first of all.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have been brought here in order to have a nice luncheon and instead get hit behind the ear.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Ankara, Turkey. [ A1:6. ]

title: SEAVER STILL A YANKEE PROSPECT
description: George Steinbrenner poked his head out of his private box just long enough to swirl a little uncertainty into the Yankees' pitching situation. He is growing increasingly impressed by the work of his young staff, yet he did nothing to quash speculation that Tom Seaver could still wind up wearing pinstripes by opening day.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anheuser-Busch Inc., the St. Louis beer maker, promoted Paul J. Morrissey to director of national accounts.

title: RAYMOND B. ALLEN, EX-CHIEF OF UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON
description: Raymond B. Allen, a former chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles and former president of the University of Washington, died March 15 at the Mary Washington Hospital in Fredericksburg, Va.. He was 83 years old and had lived in retirement in Virginia since 1967.

title: Objective of Drug Tests Is Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: APPALACHIAN TRAIL SITE FEARED TO BE HAZARDOUS
description: This summer, a new stretch of the Appalachian Trail is to open through a 1,000-acre tract of National Park land here. The new stretch, which winds for two miles through rolling hills, was blazed carefully to avoid a shimmering pond with the ominous name of Nuclear Lake.

title: Peres Rejects Pressure To Break Likud Pact
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres vigorously rejected pressure today from his Labor party to break a 1984 agreement with the Likud bloc to rotate offices with Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The switch is to take place in October, at the midway point in the Parliament's four-year term.

title: A PRIEST WAITING AND A CAMPUS DEBATING
description: It seems an unlikely epicenter for so many shock waves: a sitting room in a rambling academic building, a room piled high with books and papers and decorated with a scattering of religious items.

title: Lewis Hoff, an Executive, Weds Miss Tovi, Teacher
description: Nechama Hanna Tovi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Shalom Tovi of Tel Aviv, was married yesterday to Lewis Hoff, a son of Sylvia Dashott of Philadelphia and the late Julius Hoff of Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Arthur Schneir and Cantor Moshe Gefin performed the ceremony at the Terrace-on-the-Park restaurant in Flushing, Queens.

title: BROOKLYN RESIDENTS PROTEST SWITCH IN SHELTER PLAN
description: When 24 men stepped off a bus from Manhattan to enter the city's newest shelter for the homeless, they were met by protesting residents of the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: TURKS LINK TRADE TO PACT ON BASES, SURPRISING SHULTZ
description: Hopes for a quick renewal of American military base rights in Turkey appeared to falter today as Turkey insisted on linking the renewal to major trade concessions by the United States.

title: LOUISVILLE THRIVES WITH FRESHMAN HELP
description: After a spectacular triumphant march through the West Regionals, Louisville returned home Saturday night to an airport jammed with 5,000 fans who had begun assembling shortly after the 84-76 victory over Auburn.

title: MOYNIHAN DENOUNCES LAROUCHE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, speaking in a Manhattan neighborhood where supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche have campaigned for local offices, chastised the Democratic Party yesterday for accepting Mr. LaRouche's followers as legitimate participants in party affairs.

title: WALL ST. FIRMS USE 'GOLDEN HANDCUFFS'
description: All over Wall Street, investment banking houses are slapping their employees in handcuffs - ''golden handcuffs'' to be precise.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at St. Petersburg, 1:05 P.M. College: Florida at Oklahoma State. (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.) Basketball Celtics vs.

title: Using Guns to Push Policy Can Backfire
description: To the Editor:

title: PULITZER PLANS STOCK
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company, the family-owned communications giant, announced Saturday that it had scheduled a special stockholders' meeting for April 2 to authorize an initial public offering of common stock. The move was the latest in a family dispute over retaining control of the company. Last week, Pulitzer shareholders rejected a buyout offer from Alfred Taubman, the entrepreneur and real estate developer.

title: METS GO WITH BEST, AND LOSE
description: The Mets were ready to mount their most serious offensive of spring training this afternoon against the Twins at Tinker Field here.

title: NEW FOCUS ON SOVIET TRADE TIES
description: American industrialists, anticipating increased business with the Soviet Union under its economic modernization plans, are stepping up pressure on the Reagan Administration to relax trade curbs that they say are undermining their ability to compete.

title: GREEK COMMUMNISTS PROTEST FILM 'ELENI'
description: Members of the Communist Party youth organization demonstrated Thursday night at several Athens theaters to protest the first showing of the film ''Eleni.''

title: Capitals Win, 6-5, Close In on Flyers
description: They played with an extra quick step, the goalies were a bit off, and it became clear from the first moments that this would not be one of those old-fashioned defensive battles.

title: Bridge: Veteran and New Face Lead Teams for Knockout Finals
description: Teams captained by Edgar Kaplan of Manhattan, long one of the world's great players, and Jim Whitaker of Warner Robins, Ga., a new face on the national scene, clashed here this afternoon in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams.

title: PULZ VICTOR BY 4 SHOTS
description: Penny Pulz fired a course-record 8-under-par 64 today to emerge from the pack and capture the $200,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association Circle K Tucson Open.

title: CARTER DEBT CRISIS SYMPOSIUM
description: Former President Jimmy Carter will try to focus attention on world debt next month when the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta holds a debt crisis symposium, with Mr. Carter and the former Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., as co-chairmen. Mr. Carter has periodically held such conferences on global subjects, which tend to draw some significant names.

title: AT VERSAILLES, ROYAL TIME FOR FASHION FOLK
description: Karl Lagerfeld blended culture, commerce, cuisine and couture Friday night and celebrated his favorite French period by bringing royalty back to the Sun King's palace at Versailles.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GRAND PRIX TO PIQUET
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil led virtually all the way today in winning the Brazilian Grand Prix, the opening race of the 1986 Formula One season.

title: TEXAS WRITERS LOCK HORNS OVER ROLE AS KEEPERS OF THE MYTH
description: When Gov. James V. Allred proclaimed Texas Literature Week 50 years ago to mark the first meeting of the state's new literary society, he urged Texans ''to read the saga of romantic Texas, from the time the Anglo-Saxons first crossed the Sabine River until this our centennial year.''

title: Robert Edelman Wed To Victoria Yablonsky
description: St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Victoria Yablonsky, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Yablonsky of Westfield, N.J., to Robert Edelman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham H. Edelman of New York. Rabbi David Teutsch performed the ceremony.

title: NEW CHIEF AT INTELLICORP
description: Intellicorp, a leading supplier of artificial intelligence software based in Mountain View, Calif., said Friday that its board had appointed Dr. Thomas P. Kehler as chairman and chief executive officer. Dr. Ralph E. Kromer, the company's president, will take on the role of chief operating officer. Dr. Kehler was previously executive vice president and general manager of Intellicorp's Knowledge Systems division. He succeeds Laurence H. Kedes, a co-founder of the company, who will continue as a director.

title: Israel Praises Cairo Stand
description: Israel issued a statement of praise today for Egypt's reaction to an attack in Cairo last Wednesday in which an Israeli Embassy staff member was killed and three were wounded. Egypt had said it was determined to capture the assailants and would not let the attack harm relations with Israel. The Israeli statement, issued after the weekly Cabinet meeting, said that Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir expressed satisfaction at the way Cairo had handled the incident, and at coverage of it by the Egyptian press.

title: G.O.P. IN CITY DIVIDES ON TIES TO DEMOCRATS
description: As they seek to capitalize on the corruption inquiries into the Koch administration, New York City Republicans are divided among themselves over tactics and the question of whether some party officials are too close to city Democrats.

title: Wheels for Lawyers
description: What kind of car does the typical American lawyer drive these days? Washingtonians, who have more lawyers available per capita than any other city-dwellers, would probably guess Cadillac among the domestic products and Mercedes among the imports.

title: MILITARY MISSIONS TO DOMINATE ROLE OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: In an important shift, the space agency is planning to devote most space shuttle flights to military missions once launchings resume, senior officials say.

title: HIRAM WALKER SIFTS GULF'S BID
description: Hiram Walker Resources delayed a decision yesterday on an offer by the Gulf Canada Corporation to buy as much as 38 percent of Walker's outstanding voting shares, a deal worth up to $1.2 billion (Canadian), or almost $860 million in United States currency.

title: Calling Up the Teamsters
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters has its headquarters in Washington, almost in the shadow of the Capitol, but sometimes it is more difficult to establish communication with the largest of the nation's unions than with those a continent away. About two weeks ago, the President's Commission on Organized Crime issued a report charging that the teamsters' leaders ''have been firmly under the influence of organized crime since the 1950's'' and accusing their president, Jackie Presser, of an ''extensive record of organized crime associations.''

title: MUSIC: JEFFREY KAHANE, PIANO
description: IT was curious how Jeffrey Kahane's piano recital at Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon raised so many questions yet exuded such promise. Some of the problems arose from Mr. Kahane's obsession with cleanliness, often in music that glows most beautifully from beneath a little layer of dust.

title: EMOTIONS STIR A TIGHT RACE
description: A FEW players cried in the shower and a few others sat in their dressing stalls not crying, unblinking. The big game had come and gone, the Washington Capitals had lost, and though sports is filled with teams confronting bitter nights, the sight of all those players, shaken so, was memorable.

title: FOR NBC, TROUBLE AT 'A-TEAM'
description: There are tides in the life of a television series, but what is happening to ''The A-Team'' this season is beyond the normal ebb and flow. In the last few months, suddenly and without warning, ''The A-Team'' has been been upended by a riptide.

title: 6 Killed and 294 Hurt In Snowstorm in Tokyo
description: A spring snowstorm that dumped up to 20 inches of snow on the Tokyo area left six people dead, seven crew members from three ships missing at sea south of Tokyo and at least 294 injured, most in a train crash, the police said today.

title: OAK RIDGE BOYS SHARE BILL WITH THE JUDDS
description: The Oak Ridge Boys and the Judds, who shared the bill at Radio City Music Hall on Friday and Saturday, represent very different ideas of what direction Nashville-produced music should take in order to reverse a slowly shrinking country-music market. The Oak Ridge Boys, who hit a peak of popularity in 1981 with their country-rock novelty ''Elvira,'' originated as a gospel quartet and crossed over into the country mainsteam more than a decade ago. The group is typical of the Nashville status quo in the way it modernizes rural folksiness with flashy pop-rock instrumentation and stagecraft. The Judds, the Kentucky-bred mother-and-daughter duo, search out a purer essence of country music, both through their steel-guitar flavored instrumentation and their close harmonies that evoke a classic rural simplicity.

title: MARCOS CRONY RETURNING DESPITE FRAUD EVIDENCE
description: The company is not listed in the telephone directory. Its articles of incorporation and annual reports, required by law to be filed with the Philippine Securities and Exchange Commission, are ''missing,'' clerks at the agency say. And a secretary who answers the phone at the company's office says she does not know where any of the company's officers are.

title: Sugarloaf Ski Resort Files for Reorganization
description: The Sugarloaf Mountain Corporation, the parent company of the Sugarloaf USA ski resort, today filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, a spokesman said.

title: Japan and Trade: It Must Be Spring
description: In addition to blossoming cherry trees along the Tidal Basin, a 1912 gift from Yukio Ozaki, then the Mayor of Tokyo, spring has begun in recent years to bring something else to the capital from the East: more Japanese trade negotiators than in any other season. Why spring? It's a matter of numbers. Trade numbers.

title: STERN CALLS QUEENS GRAND PRIX 'DEAD'
description: Plans to build a Grand Prix automobile race track in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Queens, are ''dead,'' Henry J. Stern. the City Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, said yesterday.

title: The Right Track
description: Pierre Goode set up the hurdles for his workout. He was just about to burst out of the starting blocks when a car came along. He got up and moved one hurdle so the car could pass. Then he replaced the hurdle and started again.

title: MUSIC: HARVARD SINGERS
description: FEW collegiate ensembles can boast more than a century of activity, annual concert tours and a history of commissioned works by men such as Darius Milhaud, John Harbison, Randall Thompson and Irving Fine, among others. As such, the Harvard Glee Club's Friday night performance at Town Hall, its first local appearance in 10 years, was not only musically gratifying but intriguing from a historical perspective as well.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of a Washington dispatch on Feb. 8 about suspicion of Soviet violations of an arms-control provision misstated the position of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. A military spokesman said the Chiefs agreed with President Reagan that Moscow had violated a pledge to avoid deploying more long-range missiles and bombers than it had in 1979, when it signed the second treaty to limit such weapons. But the spokesman added that he could not account for intelligence data, made public by the Joint Chiefs and described in the article, that seemed to contradict Mr. Reagan's view.

title: New Fossil Find in Antarctica
description: Scientists working in a mountain range in Antarctica have found fossils 225 million years old, and they say the fossils may broaden the range of time experts believe reptiles and amphibians lived on the now-frozen continent.

title: CARBIDE SETTLEMENT MAY AID STOCK
description: Reacting to the news of the Union Carbide Corporation settlement in the Bhopal case, analysts said they expected Carbide's stock to respond favorably this week, but they were less certain about the long-term impact on the company.

title: The Work, and Fairness, of Workfare
description: Workfare! The very word used to provoke ideological battle. Liberals feared that forcing welfare recipients to work, even if only to rake leaves, would be punitive. Conservatives felt it was essential, even if they only raked leaves, to keep deadbeats off the dole. Both sides sold the poor short.

title: PRAVDA CONDEMNS ATOM TEST
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda said today that a test by the United States of a nuclear device showed ''great contempt for world public opinion'' and that Washington bore responsibility for the consequences of ''this shortsighted step.''

title: 60,000 Pakistanis Rally Against Zia and U.S.
description: About 60,000 protesters shouted anti-Government and anti-American slogans today, and opposition leaders said that Gen. Mohammed Zia ul-Haq's pro-American Government was in its last days.

title: FRANC DEVALUATION IS DENIED
description: France's newly appointed Finance Minister denied reports this weekend that the country's new conservative Government planned an early devaluation of the franc, as many analysts had predicted.

title: IMASCO UNIT MAKES BID FOR GENSTAR
description: A subsidiary of Imasco Ltd., a diversified company based in Montreal and known mostly as Canada's largest cigarette maker, offered yesterday to buy the Genstar Corporation, a Canadian building materials and financial services company, for about $1.7 billion (United States).

title: DANCE: SUSAN HADLEY IN 'CAUGHT IN THE MIDDLE'
description: THERE was a lot to look at on Saturday night at Performance Space 122, when Susan Hadley and Bradley Sowash presented ''Caught in the Middle,'' a new piece of performance art that featured dance by Miss Hadley, music by Mr. Sowash and visual tableaux designed by Ann Hamilton and Bob De Slob. The piece opened evocatively with the performers, wearing an assortment of contraptions, walking or standing about the space. The stage picture looked as if it had been designed by Magritte with a little postmodernist fine-tuning by Robert Wilson. Magical effects like a slow-swinging jump rope made of light lived up to the opening moments. And ''Caught in the Middle'' engaged the audience physically. Seated in the center, audience members had to swivel to see what was happening on three sides and occasionally the fourth.

title: Advertising; ABC-TV'S 4th OF JULY PROMOTION
description: Tickets for the rededication of the Statue of Liberty will be available in many forms and at many prices. But one source that has not been mentioned yet is the ABC television network. It will provide tickets to TV sponsors of ABC News coverage of the four-day event on the Fourth of July weekend.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:09 A.M. today and set at 11:22 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 3:04 A.M. and set at 11:07 A.M.

title: COCA-COLA GIVING $10 MILLION TO HELP SOUTH AFRICA BLACKS
description: The Coca-Cola Company is providing an initial gift of $10 million to establish new foundations in South Africa to open up opportunities in business, housing and education for black South Africans.

title: This Time, Bush Came In Fourth
description: If you were to believe the speakers and performers Saturday night at the 101st dinner of the Gridiron Club, the key players on the American political scene this year are Lee A. Iacocca, Ferdinand E. Marcos and David A. Stockman, with Vice President Bush as a runner-up.

title: GOLDEN FLEECE LTD. OFFERS NEW TRIPLE BILL
description: For 10 years now, Golden Fleece Ltd., the Composers Chamber Theater, has been presenting short music drama works by a variety of contemporary composers, under the artistic direction of Lou Rodgers. On Saturday afternoon, the troupe, now in residence at the Actors Outlet Theater Center, offered a new triple bill.

title: NAVRATILOVA GETS TITLE AGAIN AND CONFIDENTLY LOOKS AHEAD
description: She made her entrance, stage right, and sat behind a battery of microphones, trading small talk with journalists in the first row while pouring a cup of soda.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Rent Controls Made Even Worse
description: While New Yorkers wail about a grinding shortage of rental apartments, the state's Housing Division proposes to frighten away rental owners by offering tenants a gratuitous partnership in the property they occupy and making reinvestment in older buildings even riskier than it already is.

title: 10 SEIZED IN CHILD-SEX CASES
description: Five men were arrested over the weekend on charges of sexual abuse involving juveniles, and five others were arrested and charged with operating a child-pornography ring, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. LEGISLATOR IN MANAGUA BACKS USE OF ADVISERS
description: An influential Democratic Congressman, Representative G. V. Montgomery of Mississippi, said today that American military advisers should be part of any aid that Congress votes for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD CHIEF SEEKS BALDWIN'S ASSETS
description: When it comes to investments, Eli Broad speaks with authority on contemporary art, single-family homes and single-premium deferred annuities. And Mr. Broad (whose name rhymes with road) has cultivated his eclectic personal and professional interests and produced personal and professional fortunes.

title: SHAKE-UP IN HAITI: OUSTING OLD GUARD
description: The shake-up in the Haitian Government, just six weeks after it took over, appears to politicians and diplomats to be the result of continuing popular pressure to eliminate remnants of the ousted Duvalier regime from the structure of power.

title: INTERNAL BATTLE CHANGES TONE OF FEDERAL RESERVE
description: Not since the Truman era has the proud and powerful Federal Reserve experienced the drama, consternation and internal hostilities of the sort that shook it during the past four weeks.

title: KOCH TO PURSUE 3 TAXI PROPOSALS DESPITE REBUFFS
description: Mayor Koch, rebuffed in the City Council and in the courts in several attempts to improve taxi service and put more cabs on the streets, will resubmit an old proposal and revise two others this spring, according to city officials.

title: FARM BANK RELIEF PUSHED
description: THE Senate's efforts to help the nation's farmers and agricultural banks have bogged down, so the Government's bank regulators are planning to move on their own this week in one critical area of regulatory relief for farm banks.

title: AIDE WHO RESIGNED SAYS HAITI IS ANGRY
description: Gerard Gourgue, the popular human rights activist who resigned in protest from the interim Haitian Government three days ago, described his country today as ''an angry nation'' crying out for social and economic justice.

title: THE OSCARS TONIGHT: ARGENTINA WAITS WISHFULLY
description: Despite the thousands of miles that separate this country from Hollywood, the attention of Argentines is fixed on the distant land of stardom, and the nation seems to have become obsessed with its Oscar prospects.

title: IN NICARAGUA, A CAN-DO VICE PRESIDENT
description: As Nicaragua's confrontation with the United States intensifies, Vice President Sergio Ramirez Mercado has emerged as one of the principal Sandinista strategists.

title: MERRILL PROPOSALS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is seeking shareholder approval of a series of anti-takeover measures including one that would require approval by 80 percent of the firm's shareholders for any merger with a company that had acquired a stake of 5 percent or more in transaction not approved by the board. Merrill Lynch also seeks to divide its board into three classes of directors, each elected for three-year terms. The measures will be voted on April 29 at the company's annual meeting.

title: VIDEOTEX PLAYERS SEEK A WORKABLE FORMULA
description: The withdrawal this month of two major players from videotex - the business of offering information and services through computers in the home - does not signal the end of the industry, but may well help redirect it, most analysts believe.

title: MARCOS AGENTS OFFER TO TALK
description: Two New York real estate agents facing contempt charges for their refusal to testify about New York properties linked to Ferdinand E. Marcos have offered to cooperate with congressional investigators, a House member said today.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Rabbi Isaac Toubin, 70, Dies; Ex-Jewish Education Official
description: Rabbi Isaac Toubin, a former national executive vice president of the American Association for Jewish Education, now the Jewish Education Service of North America, died of a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $129,000.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL MONTREAL (NL) - Sent Mike Hocutt, first baseman; Billy Moore, outfielder; and Rich Stoll and Brian Holman, pitchers, to the club's minor league complex for reassignment.

title: AVALON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $188,000 for the quarter and $738,000 for the year. c-After a charge of $188,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards and including a tax credit of $563,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: A LIVING FOSSIL
description: As a rule, the fossil record leaves little doubt as to whether an animal or plant is extinct or alive, but every now and then a surprise turns up. One such surprise occurred in 1938, when fishermen off the coast of Africa caught a living coelacanth: a lobe-finned fish thought to have been extinct for 60 million years.

title: Gauging the Air Traffic Risk
description: When airlines were deregulated in 1978, a main part of the deal was that safety controls by the Federal Aviation Administration would not slacken. There is growing concern that the nation's aviation cop has been less than fully alert.

title: ZYTEC COMPUTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 98 Purims
description: The aged rabbi leaned forward in his chair, carefully removed an old megillah, or scroll, from a chest of drawers and spoke of Jewish survival.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Swedish Chief Condemns Nuclear Test by U.S.
description: The new Swedish Prime Minister, Ingvar Carlsson, in his first foreign policy comment since succeeding Olof Palme, today condemned the latest United States nuclear test as ''a great disappointment.''

title: HARVARD OARSMEN FAVORED
description: The rowing season gets under way this week with Harvard a clear favorite to retain its title as the National Intercollegiate champion.

title: A Revolution Looms In American Health
description: The revolution in the American way of health will be as profound and turbulent as any economic and social upheaval our nation has experienced. At stake are not only billions of dollars but who lives, who dies - and who decides.

title: JAPAN CALLS YEN VALUE TOO HIGH
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and other Japanese officials have begun trying to talk down the value of the yen, which last week hit its highest level against the dollar since World War II.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $693,000 for the quarter and $3.4 million for the year. c-Including tax credits of $500,000 for the quarter and $2.3 million for the year.

title: BOND PRICES ADVANCE WIDELY
description: The bond markets found a range of encouraging news yesterday, and traders reacted by pushing up prices on a wide range of taxable and tax-exempt securities.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $996,000 from the reversal of tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income, including a gain of $10,230,000 from a pension plan settlement. d-Including a tax credit of $1,173,000. e-Net loss, after a gain of $10,230,000 from a pension plan settlement. The results include income from discontinued operations of $661,000 for the year-ago quarter and $1,512,000 for the previous year.

title: SAXON OIL DEVELOPMENT PARTNERS LP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a writedown of oil and gas properties of $42,317,582 for the quarter and year. c-Including a writedown of oil and gas properties of $14,206,684 for the quarter and year.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including a tax loss carryforward benefit of $300,000.

title: Q&A
description: Assuming that ''Star Wars'' becomes a reality and can knock out Soviet intercontinental missiles, what happens to their nuclear warheads? A. Michael Ross, a spokesman for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, one of the country's nuclear weapons design laboratories, said military experts there believe a warhead on a missile would be destroyed if struck by a laser of sufficient intensity or some other weapon in the missile shield program. He said a continuous laser would burn a hole through the warhead, in much the same way that lasers in industry cut metal, and would possibly ignite the high explosives. There would be no nuclear explosion, he said, because the warhead's explosives must be set off in a special way to create one. If the laser is a pulse laser, such as an X-ray or free-electron laser, the warhead's outer surface would be heated very quickly, producing internal shock waves that would tear the warhead apart, Mr. Ross said. If the warhead is hit at an altitude below about 250 miles, most fragments would eventually fall to earth and vaporize on re-entry. Only the largest fragments would survive re-entry to hit the surface, he said. If the warhead is hit above 250 miles many fragments might float into space. The large chunks of the warhead might contain hazardous material such as uranium or plutonium but could readily be detected and collected. ''The hazard of the vaporized material would be much much less than if the warhead had actually detonated over its target,'' Mr. Ross said.

title: Japanese Again Vote Against U.S. Navy Plan
description: The voters of Zushi, 30 miles southwest of Tokyo, have signaled their opposition to a planned American military housing complex for the second time this month.

title: CITY EASES BAN ON TRUCK STOPS IN BUSY STREETS
description: The Koch administration, faced with opposition from businesses, announced yesterday that it would shorten the ban on truck deliveries that it plans to impose on two of the city's busiest crosstown streets, 49th and 50th.

title: EXCERPTS FROM NEWS SESSIONS ON CLASH WITH LIBYA'S FORCES
description: Following are excerpts from the news conferences today by Secretary of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, on the confrontation between the United States and Libya:

title: The Paper Chase
description: The Supreme Court took a tiny step toward orderliness yesterday when it issued its Monday list of grants and denials on ordinary 8 1/2-by-11-inch paper instead of the traditional ''legal size'' of 8 1/2 by 14. The Court will still require the use of two sizes of filing cabinets, but the step at least brings it partly in line with the standard size of paper adopted four years ago by all other Federal courts.

title: EX-NAVY MAN IN SPYING CASE GOES TO TRIAL IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: The prosecution today characterized a man accused of spying for the Soviet Union as someone whose love of luxury and gadgets led him to compromise his position handling secret Navy codes and join a spy ring.

title: INDIA REJECTS ACCORD IN BHOPAL CASE
description: India today rejected a tentative agreement by the Union Carbide Corporation to pay $350 million to victims of the gas leak at Bhopal and indicated that it would challenge the settlement in Federal court in New York City.

title: IS SEX NECESSARY? EVOLUTIONISTS ARE PERPLEXED
description: THE subject of sexual reproduction, an exasperated Charles Darwin concluded more than a century ago, ''is as yet hidden in darkness.''

title: ADMINISTRATION FAULTED ON FREEZING OF BILLIONS FOR TRANSPORTATION
description: Transportation groups and their advocates in Congress are waging an intense battle with the Reagan Administration over the freezing of billions of dollars for transportation projects.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: DISEASE IS SPREADING TOWARD U.S. BORDER
description: Scientists in the South are closely watching the spread of dengue fever, a painful tropical disease, north through Mexico toward the United States border.

title: TENNECO DEBT UNDER REVIEW
description: The outstanding debt of Tenneco Inc. and its subsidiaries, totaling about $6.6 billion, is under review for possible downgrading, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: BOEING IN BELFAST DEAL
description: A Belfast aerospace company, Short Brothers, signed a contract today with the Boeing Company for the joint production of a plane scheduled to begin service in 1992. Short will begin work on the 7J7 150-seat aircraft in the near future under the terms of the deal, which is worth more than $150 million.

title: DWI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Including a loss of $57,438 in the company's 95 percent-owned subsidiary Inotex Inc. for the quarter and a loss in subbsidiary of $126,118 for the 6 months. c-Including a loss of $44,574 in the subsidiary for the quarter and 6 months. The year-ago results are restated to give effect to year-end audit adjustments relating to the sale of product development projects and a note receivable to Inotex Inc. which occured during the quarter ended Dec. 28, 1984.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SETBACK FOR MACY
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Bankers Trust Company have declined to participate in the financing for the R. H. Macy & Company $3.5 billion leveraged buyout, according to Bank Letter, a newsletter that covers the banking industry.

title: WALDHEIM FIGURES IN 1948 ARMY LIST
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations, was identified as a suspected war criminal on lists kept by the United Nations and the United States Army, according to a document in the National Archives.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 8
description: Effective July 28, the company changed its method of accounting for investment tax credits from the deferral to the flow-through method. The effect of this was to increase net earnings in the latest 6 months by $1,408,000.

title: ANCIENT ASTRONOMY POINTS TO NEW VIEWS OF MAYAN LIFE
description: CHICHEN ITZA, Mexico - Eleven hundred years ago the massive pyramid of Kukulkan was built by the Mesoamericans in a clever feat of ancient engineering so that the shadow of a snake moves along the balustrade of a stairway as the sun sets during the vernal and autumnal equinoxes.

title: CONNORS GETS FINE AND SUSPENSION
description: More than a month has passed since Jimmy Connors walked off the court in the fifth set of a semifinal match against Ivan Lendl in the Lipton International Players Championships, claiming that after 16 years as a professional, he was fed up with incompetent officiating and would not tolerate it any longer. Connors refused to resume play and was defaulted by the chair umpire, Jeremy Shales.

title: ROCKET BOMBS FIRED AT THE U.S. EMBASSY AND PALACE IN TOKYO
description: Small homemade bombs were fired this afternoon at the United States Embassy and the Imperial Palace, the police said.

title: CHALLENGER INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BANCTEXAS REACHES NEW CREDIT AGREEMENT
description: BancTexas Group Inc., the deeply troubled Dallas-based lender, has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has renegotiated a credit agreement with a group of banks led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: As if $6 million in campaign money was not enough, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, has invited President Reagan and 1,500 other friends to a $1,000-a-plate lunch at the Waldorf-Astoria next month.

title: NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits representing the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $7,000 for the quarter and $88,000 for the year. The year result also includes a loss of $659,000 on settlement of an arbitration claim. c-Net income including extraordinary credits representing the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $109,000 for the quarter and $1,471,000 for the year. Revenue results represent sales and other revenues from operations amounts.

title: PANCREATIC CANCER: CIGARETTE SMOKING IS STRONGEST LINK TO DEADLY DISEASE
description: WITH pancreatic cancer rapidly increasing as a killer disease, researchers are redoubling their efforts to find ways to combat it.

title: J.W. ROBINSON'S LEADER QUITS; SUCCESSOR NAMED
description: Michael Gould resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the J. W. Robinson department stores in Los Angeles, a division of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation.

title: REGGIO EMILIA TOURNAMENT ENDS IN 3-WAY TIE FOR FIRST
description: The elite all-grandmaster Reggio Emilia International Tournament in Italy ended in a tie for first place this year among Ulf Andersson of Sweden, Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia and Oleg Romanishin of the Soviet Union. Each scored 7-4.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SPRING BOOKS BLOOMING
description: THE spring computer book season is full upon us, and a flood of new volumes is inundating the stores. Computer book publishing is a something-for-everyone industry, but far too often it turns out to be a something-for-no-one endeavor. Picking and choosing the useful book from the mass can be as difficult as selecting functional software.

title: STUDY SEES 'GROWING DANGER' IN PROFIT-SEEKING HOSPITALS
description: Hospitals that are in business to make profits are a ''growing danger to our health care system'' that fail to measure up to the standards of nonprofit hospitals, the National Council of Senior Citizens has charged in a report.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CBS AND ABC PRESENT TWO SERIES PREMIERES
description: TWO new series that begin this evening return to the past for what they hope is inspiration. CBS's hourlong ''Morningstar/Eveningstar,'' at 8 o'clock, tries valiantly to evoke the soothing warmth that in the 1970's was the trademark of ''The Waltons.'' The executive producers are Earl Hamner, creator of ''The Waltons,'' and Fred Silverman, the former CBS programming chief who gave Mr. Hamner his big break. ABC's ''Perfect Strangers,'' a half-hour comedy that airs at 8:30 P.M., goes back even further, to vaudeville and comedy with a funny accent, this time provided by a young man named Balki who comes from ''a small Mediterranean island country'' that sounds very much like Greece. The good news is that Balki is played by a gifted comic actor named Bronson Pinchot.

title: Weather Advice to Pilots Cited
description: A Congressional study said today that the system of providing information about hazardous weather to pilots is slow and unreliable, prompting a Congressman to call the system a ''prescription for catastrophe.''

title: KNICKS LOSE BAILEY
description: Maybe all future Knick contracts should carry the warning label, ''This job can be hazardous to your health.''

title: SENTIMENT CO-STARS ON OSCAR NIGHT
description: Sentimentality was on stage at this year's Academy Awards.

title: EDUCATION BONDS FROM ALABAMA
description: The Alabama Higher Education Loan Corporation tentatively priced about $52.5 million of bonds through underwriters led by the Bankers Trust Company.

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Abortion-Notice Law Takes Effect in Ohio
description: A state law requiring physicians to notify parents of unmarried minors seeking abortions went into effect today after a Federal judge refused to block it.

title: Roosevelt Opens Despite Strike
description: Roosevelt Raceway opened its season tonight with replacements for about 200 ticket sellers who walked picket lines.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $4,895. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $32,527.

title: RELIABLE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
