description: b-After a capital loss of $1,174,419 for the latest year and a capital gain of $954,931 for the previous year.

title: Topics; Freer Spirits Lighthearted Pasta
description: Some Americans have always known that olive oil is what the gods really meant when they were talking nectar. So to read in The New England Journal of Medicine that olive oil reduces cholesterol only confirms their long-held conviction that in eating spaghetti with garlic and olive oil the human race is doing something wonderful for itself.

title: Topics; Freer Spirits Loose Cannon
description: In the movie of Queens politics, let someone like Tom Hanks play John Sabini, the 29-year-old district leader who rises on a series of flukes to head the entrenched political machine.

title: Transition
description: The Association of American Medical Colleges, one of the most cohesive and effective professional lobbies on Capitol Hill, is getting a new president. Dr. Robert G. Petersdorf, dean and vice chairman for health sciences of the University of California at San Diego, is taking over the post from Dr. John A. D. Cooper, who is retiring after having headed the association since 1969, which makes him something of a Washington landmark.

title: MARCHERS IN HAITI URGE CIVILIAN RULE
description: Thousands of young people marched through this faded capital today, chanting, ''We want a civilian government!''

title: U.S., CITING LIBYAN FIRE, REPORTS ATTACKING A MISSILE SITE AND SETTING 2 SHIPS ABLAZE
description: American and Libyan forces clashed today in and around the disputed waters off the Libyan coast.

title: Plenty of Chances
description: Denny Crum is off to the Final Four for the sixth time since he became head coach at Louisville in 1971. And if that's not enough of a recruiting tool, then there's this: The spacing of those appearances (1972-75-80-82-83-86) means that only one player who has competed in the Cardinal program under Crum for the maximum of four years has failed to make it to the last big weekend. The one who fell through the cracks was Larry Williams, a 6-foot-8-inch forward from Chicago who played for Louisville from 1975 to 1979.

title: DO-NOTHING HUMMINGBIRDS
description: Hummingbirds, the ultimate symbol of nervous energy, actually spend three-fourths of their days on a perch doing absolutely nothing. The reason, it appears, is that they need this time to process all the nectar they have ingested in their frenetic bouts of feeding.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

description: Debt

title: MARCOM TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 22
STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Net loss The latest results include tax credits of $37,000 for the quarter and $57,000 for the year.

title: Scare for Sampson
description: Ralph Sampson, the Houston Rockets' all-star center, was released from a local hospital this morning after an examination and X-rays revealed he suffered no serious injuries when he fell while rebounding in a game with the Boston Celtics.

title: U.S. Sets Off Explosion In Test of Missile Silo
description: The Air Force detonated 1,750 tons of conventional explosives today to test how a hardened missile silo would withstand an attack.

title: CIRCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAR LUBOVITCH TROUPE
description: Lar Lubovitch Troupe The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company will present a gala performance April 7 at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $67,800.

CONTROVERSY REAWAKENS AS DISTRICTS END BUSING
description: A year ago, 10-year-old Cedric Doakes had to get up at 5 A.M. to take a bus across town to a school he says he ''didn't particularly like.''

title: TM COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: QUARTET LED BY NEW YORKER TAKES KNOCKOUT TEAM TITLE
description: An experienced quartet headed by Edgar Kaplan of Manhattan came from behind in the final quarter here Sunday night to capture the Vanderbilt Knockout Team title at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: AS CLINT EASTWOOD RUNS FOR MAYOR, SMALL-TOWN RACE HANGS ON BIG ISSUE
description: Members of the League of Women Voters are knocking on doors in this scenic resort community to check if everybody registered to vote in the April 8 municipal elections really lives here.

title: AMERICAN LOCKER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $600,482 for the quarter, and $1,071,592 for the year. d-Including a gain of $91,641 from discontinued operations.

title: Some in Philadelphia Return to Rebuilt Area
description: As a bricklayers' walkout threatened to delay completion of homes in the neighborhood destroyed last May in the police confrontation with the radical group Move, a woman who was among the few people who have returned said she was pleased with her house.

title: SHAWMUT OFFERING
description: The Shawmut Corporation, a Boston-based multibank holding company, is offering $150 million of 8 7/8 percent, 10-year notes at a price of 99 1/2, to yield 8.95 percent through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. The notes, which are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard and Poor's Corporation, are noncallable for the life of the issue and offered to yield 1.23 percentage points above Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: AQUINO MAY DISBAND LEGISLATURE WHILE A NEW CHARTER IS DRAFTED
description: President Corazon C. Aquino is expected to abolish the National Assembly and begin exercising ''nearly absolute power,'' the national television station reported tonight.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains for a tax loss carryforward for an overseas subsidiary of $39,000 for the quarter and $278,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss.

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: LAWMAKERS BACK ACTIONS ON LIBYA
description: Members of Congress today generally expressed support for the action taken by American warplanes against Libyan land and sea targets, but the chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Commitee charged that President Reagan had not fully complied with the War Powers Resolution of 1973.

title: Falling Beam Kills Worker
description: A 54-year-old construction worker was killed yesterday in Manhattan when a beam being lifted by a crane fell on him, the police said. He was identified as Albert Tibak of Perth Amboy, N.J. The pier, at 57th Street and the Hudson River, is being refurbished by Mr. Tibak's employer, Simpson & Brown of Cranford, N.J.

title: YANKEES IMPRESSED BY COTTO
description: In the beginning, he simply did not fit into the Yankees' plans. They had no room for Henry Cotto. By April 8, he would surely be sent down to the minors, and he would wait there until an opportunity - that is, an injury or a demotion - arose.

title: FOSTER GRANT SOLD
description: The Foster Grant Corporation, the world's leading sunglass producer, said it had been acquired by Andlinger & Company, a private investment banking and management company in Tarrytown, N.Y. The company was bought from Roussel-Uclaf Holdings Corporation, a subsidiary of Roussel-Uclaf S.A., a French pharmaceutical and chemical company. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1986
description: International American and Libyan forces clashed in and around the disputed waters off the Libyan coast. Washington said the encounter began in the Gulf of Sidra when Libyan ground batteries fired six missiles at American planes and the aircraft retaliated by attacking two Libyan patrol vessels and a missile site. Officials said one vessel was set afire and dead in the water while the second was ''severely damaged'' and the missile site was ''out of action.'' [ Page A1, Columns 1-6. ]

title: NOVO CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $569,000 and an extraordinary gain of $2.9 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $578,000 and an extraordinary gain of $875,000.

title: LATIN DEBT EFFORT URGED
description: Sustained economic growth through greater coordination of economic policies by creditor and debtor nations is needed for Latin America to repay its $370 billion foreign debt, Antonio Ortiz Mena, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, said here today in a speech opening the bank's 27th annual meeting. ''The alternative of international economic disintegration offers such bleak prospects that a special effort on an extraordinary scale is more than justified,'' he added.

title: O'CONNOR QUESTIONS CHURCH'S RELIANCE ON BINGO
description: John Cardinal O'Connor has suggested that bingo, the game of chance, may not be an appropriate way for the Roman Catholic Church to raise money. But, for now, he has not ordered parishes to stop the weekly games or indicated that he would do so.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE POWER OF THE PRESS. The Birth of American Political Reporting. By Thomas C. Leonard. Illustrated. 273 pages. Oxford University Press. $22.50. AMERICAN journalism has seldom been shy about proclaiming its own achievements, and a free press, we must all agree, stands high among the forces that have made the United States a working democracy. But how did journalists first acquire political power? What part did they play in creating a popular interest in politics? How did the conventions and emphases of political reporting develop, and how steep was the price that had to be paid for them? These are relatively neglected questions, and ones that can rarely have been raised as pointedly as they are by Thomas C. Leonard in ''The Power of the Press.''

title: MANAGING CLOSINGS OF PLANTS
description: THERE is a new managerial career developing called director of plant closings, according to Ronald E. Berenbeim, a senior research associate at the Conference Board. He realized the need when he did a study that was titled ''Company Programs to Ease the Impact of Shutdowns'' for the board, a business research group.

title: PROMOTIONS BY BURNETT IN ITS INTERNATIONAL UNIT
description: Leo Burnett Company (another Philip Morris agency, incidentally) has announced a number of corporate promotions in its internatonal operation.

title: GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: RATE DECLINE SPURS HOME-BUYING RISE
description: Housing sales have been doing well for some time. But with the latest declines in interest rates, the home-buying surge that began a few years ago is moving into high gear, sweeping American communities and enlivening an otherwise so-so economy, according to real estate experts and economists.

title: FORMER AD DIRECTOR WILL HEAD INTERMARCO
description: Frederick K. Rhines, who until earlier this month was ad director of New York magazine, is been named president of Intermarco, the United States subsidiary in New York of France's Publicis Group.

title: Successes of Public Development Corporation
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
Marcos Leaves Base For Honolulu Suburb
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, the deposed Philippine President, moved tonight from Hickam Air Force Base to a private home in a Honolulu suburb, military and police officials said.

title: U.S. and India Agree On Anti-Narcotics Aid
description: India and the United States agreed today to work out a program of increased American aid for India's program to curtail the flow of narcotics to the West.

title: ESSEX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STEPHEN PETRONIO
description: WHEN a spotlight hit Stephen Petronio in ''No. 3,'' one of the works Stephen Petronio and Dancers presented Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Mr. Petronio winced. Standing in bright light, he was the center of attention. Yet the man he portrayed hated being there, and the solo showed his attempts to escape.

title: XIOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Figures were not appropriate because 1984 was the company's development year. The latest quarter's net was on a pro forma basis. The company went public in February.

title: MOSCOW GIRL CHARMS HER BROOKLYN SCHOOL HOSTS
description: Eleven-year-old Katerina Lycheva of Moscow came to Public School 276 in Brooklyn yesterday, saw something of the give and take of a New York City classroom and charmed her curious Canarsie hosts in the process.

title: Working Profile: Patrick J. Buchanan; Eating Lightning Bolts and Liking the Taste
description: Seated in shirtsleeves in a cramped, windowless office only yards from the Oval Office, Patrick J. Buchanan recalls that his fierce conservatism is steeped in a Washington family that is, improbably, even more conservative than he is.

title: OIL PRICES PLUNGE AFTER OPEC ADJOURNS
description: Prices of crude oil and petroleum products plunged dramatically on the world market yesterday, after a nine-day-long OPEC conference in Geneva ended inconclusively.

title: Milwaukee and Nine Suburbs Devise Desegregration Plan
description: Thousands of city and suburban students would transfer voluntarily under a desegregation plan announced today by negotiators for the Milwaukee School Board and nine suburban districts.

title: CARDINALS STIR CITY'S PRIDE AND PROFIT
description: The depth of commitment to the team doesn't hit all at once. There are no basketball standards at the airport, no highway posters advertising Louisville basketball.

title: OUSTED MAN HIRED BY NUCLEAR AGENCY CONTRACTOR
description: A man dismissed as a reactor operator at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant for cheating on licensing examinations worked for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission later, the commission said in papers released yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, MARCH 25, 1986
description: International

title: CHICAGO SCHOOLS UPSET BY RASH OF TEACHER ARRESTS
description: A series of arrests on molestation and pornography charges have led the public school authorities here to establish more stringent background checks for new teachers.

title: Yes, It Is Worse for Vietnam Combat Vets
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK CITY BEGINS A $450 MILLION OFFERING
description: The Senate Finance Committee, by rejecting plans to subject all outstanding tax-exempt bonds to the Federal tax treatment, yesterday provided enough encouragement for the City of New York to proceed with its $450 million offering of general obligation bonds.

title: Pictures of a Canal At an Exhibition
description: Sir Robert Cotton did more than practice diplomacy while serving as Australia's Ambassador to the United States from 1982 until retirment last year. He fell in love with the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal, the picturesque waterway that wends its way through the capital.

title: OSCARS GO TO 'OUT OF AFRICA' AND ITS DIRECTOR, SYDNEY POLLACK
description: ''Out of Africa,'' a stately epic about the Danish novelist Isak Dinesen's years on a coffee plantation in Kenya, swept its way to seven Oscars tonight at the 58th annual Academy Awards ceremonies - including best picture, director, and adapted screenplay. Sydney Pollack was the surprise winner as director of the movie. He won a second award as its producer.

title: DYSLEXICS LEARN COLLEGE SKILLS
description: At Landmark College, all students have high school diplomas before they arrive, and many have spent a year or two in college elsewhere, often making fair grades. But most are told that before they can begin college-level work here they must spend a year, or maybe two or three, in the school's intensive ''precollege'' classes to master reading and writing.

title: BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation is offering $150 million (Australian currency) of five-year zero coupon notes that pay no interest, through undewriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes, rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA+ by S.& P., are offered at a price of $551.50 per $1,000 face amount, to yield 12.26 percent if held to maturity.

title: SADLIER, WILLIAM H INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $176,000. c-Net loss and after deducting separation benefits costing $470,165.

title: MLX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring adjustment of $141,000 to eliminate previously recognized income on a long-term note receivable. The company which emerged from the reorganization proceedings of McLouth Steel Corp. in December 1984, did not have any operating business until the acquisition by its Sintermet Corp. subsidiary of the aircraft brake lining business from Abex Corp. in September 1985.

title: Add One Strad
description: It was reported on this page some months ago that Washington had become the world's Stradivarius capital, with 14 of Antonio Stradivari's violins, violas and cellos owned by institutions and individuals in the city. Now there are 15.

title: Biggs Out With Injury
description: Tyrell Biggs, the undefeated heavyweight, will miss up to eight weeks of training after suffering a broken right collarbone in his 10-round victory over Jeff Sims on Sunday. Biggs, the super-heavyweight champion in the 1984 Olympics, was injured in the third round but then he danced and jabbed the rest of the way for a unanimous decision over Sims. The ring physician, Dr. Charles Filippini, checked Biggs several times during the bout but said he could not get much information from the corner. Dr. Filippini said he probably would have stopped the fight if he had known about the injury. . . . Jose Gregorio Padrino, a 20-year-old Venezuelan flyweight, died Sunday in Maracaibo from head injuries he received Friday night when he made his professional debut.

title: DUKE CELEBRATION IS UNPRETENTIOUS
description: It was supposed to be a time for delirious celebration, an occasion when the Blue Devils of Duke would congregate underneath the basket and begin the kind of made-for-television net-cutting ceremony that has become commonplace for teams that achieve a berth in the Final Four. But as the final seconds of their commanding 71-50 triumph over Navy in Sunday's East Regional championship passed, the players for the nation's top-ranked team - and the favorite to win the national title next week in Dallas - remained restrained.

title: School Checking For Steroid Use
description: San Diego State University announced today it has suspended track and field competition pending completion of a university investigation into possible anabolic-steroid use by some members of the men's and women's teams.

title: AGENCIES' MEDIA JOBS TO CHANGE
description: THE dramatic changes in media, driven by new technologies, will force equally dramatic changes in the structure and function of agency media departments, according to Ira Carlin, an executive vice president of McCann-Erickson.

title: 15-YEAR-OLD ON PATH TO GREATNESS
description: William Reed Sr. is a field inspector for the Philadelphia Water Department. In 1960 and 1961, at Germantown High School in suburban Philadelphia, he ran 100 yards in 9.9 seconds.

title: A BENEFIT AMID THE FLOWERS
description: ''CBS, right?'' ''Right.'' '' 'As the World Turns,' right?''

title: STUDENT LEADER DECIDES TO QUIT POST AT CUNY
description: The chairman of the Student Senate of the City University of New York resigned abruptly last week after it was disclosed that he was not a registered student at any of the school's branches.

title: Teofilo Carvalho dos Santos, Portuguese Socialist, Dies
description: Teofilo Carvalho dos Santos, who helped found Portugal's Socialist Party in 1973, died of cancer today at his home here.

title: SETTLEMENTS ON MOON AND MARS PROPOSED BY PANEL
description: A Presidential panel is proposing a long-range, $700 billion space program that would put manned settlements on the moon in 30 years and envisions an eventual 1 million space travelers a day, according to a published report.

title: Coach Jumps to Pros
description: Dennis Green, the football coach at Northwestern University, announced he was leaving the Big Ten school to take an assistant coaching job with the San Francisco 49ers. Green said he would serve as a receivers coach under Bill Walsh, with whom he previously worked as an assistant at Stanford and the 49ers before joining the Wildcats in 1980. Doug Single, the director of athletics at Northwestern, said a replacement for Green, the only black head football coach in the history of the conference, could be named as early as Wednesday.

title: THRIFT UNIT CASE SETTLED
description: A former senior vice president and treasurer of the American Savings and Loan Association, the principal operating subsidiary of the Financial Corporation of America, today became the third official of the company to settle Federal charges involving violations of insider-trading laws.

title: WEISSMAN IS ELECTED LINCOLN CENTER CHAIRMAN
description: George Weissman, a longtime leader in corporate support for the arts, was elected chairman of Lincoln Center yesterday. He will assume the position on June 2, replacing Martin E. Segal, who had decided not to seek re-election as chairman. Mr. Segal will continue to serve as a member of the Lincoln Center board with the title of chairman emeritus.

title: UNIVERSAL MEDICAL BUILDNGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-The company went public in July 1984 and did not report figures for 1984.

title: The Missiles of Sidra
description: Colonel Qaddafi's ''line of death'' in the Gulf of Sidra is no mere figure of speech. U.S. warplanes said to be the targets of Libyan missiles responded by attacking the missile site and sinking at least one patrol boat, with all hands presumed dead. The two sides disagree on whether planes were downed but agree that Libyan missiles were fired.

title: LEBANESE REPORT ISRAELI SHELLING
description: The state-controlled Lebanese radio said today that Israeli forces had shelled Nabatiye, the largest Shiite Moslem town in southern Lebanon, killing 3 civilians and wounding 22.

title: MILITARY DEBATES MEASURE OF CONTRACTOR EFFICIENCY
description: Factions within the Pentagon and Congress are debating how and when to measure the productivity of military contractors' employees.

title: Congress; Devising Strategy On Rebel Aid
description: In both the House and the Senate, the leadership tries to use legislative rules to its advantage. But in the House, which sets separate rules for debating each bill, seizing the advantage is sometimes easier than in the Senate, where rules allow a single legislator opportunities to thwart the leadership.

title: NICHOLS INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter results include those of American Clinical Laboratories and Biodiagnostic Laboratories, acquired in December and September, respectively.

title: Relieved Jayhawks Reach Destination
description: The first time he took his team on a ride to the Final Four, when the U.C.L.A. Bruins headed for Indianapolis six springs ago, the trip seemed so surreal that Larry Brown figured maybe these things happen all the time.

title: IN THE FRONT RANK: LAGERFELD AND MONTANA
description: Karl Lagerfeld flung out new ideas by the handful and ended up with his best collection since he started designing under his own name three years ago. Claude Montana also showed his finest work to date.

title: BLACK CAUCUS ASSERTS CUOMO INSULTED GROUP
description: The chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus accused Governor Cuomo today of ''insulting'' caucus members by refusing to wait for them to arrive at a meeting.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $194,000 for the quarter and $664,000 for the 9 months.

description: b-Net income

title: COMMODORE NAMES PRESIDENT AS CHIEF
description: Commodore International Ltd., the struggling home computer maker, yesterday promoted Thomas J. Rattigan to chief executive officer, effective April 1.

title: METROMAIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
FULL-PAGE THANK YOU TO W.R.G.'S FIRST CLIENT
description: The fifth page of SportsMonday in The New York Times was a full-page ad (although it wasn't so labled) of a rather distinguished older man smoking a bent cigarette.

title: FREUHAUF'S INVESTOR IDENTIFIED
description: Asher Edelman, the New York investor, approached the Fruehauf Corporation earlier this month proposing a leveraged buyout but was turned down by the Detroit manufacturer of truck trailers and other automotive equipment.

title: MARYLAND PACT SET BY MELLON
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had definitively agreed to buy certain assets and assume certain deposits of the defunct Community Savings and Loan Inc. of Bethesda, Md. The purchase will enable the Pittsburgh-based Mellon to establish its first full-service banking operation in Maryland.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: This is a city not unused to invasions, so Parisians take the semiannual arrival of the fashion flock in stride. The visitors come seeking fashion's next direction. And now, with their trek on the Milan-London-Paris trail almost done, themes are beginning to emerge. The consensus here is that Italy is in a slump, London in a fog and Paris has regained its rightful place atop fashion's pyramid.

title: AIDES TO CUOMO CITED FOR FAILING TO NAME DONOR
description: The State Board of Elections today sent a letter to Governor Cuomo's campaign organization requesting information improperly omitted from disclosure forms filed during the 1982 gubernatorial race.

title: RICHARDSON ELECTRONICS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Yes, It Is Worse for Vietnam Combat Vets
description: To the Editor:

title: SNAGS SEEN ON CARBIDE SETTLEMENT
description: The Indian Government's announcement that it will not accept Union Carbide's tentative $350 million settlement for the victims of the Bhopal gas leak is likely to create many obstacles for the plan - both legal and practical.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of Tokyo Ltd. named Tamotsu Yamaguchi chairman of the board and chief executive of the Bank of Tokyo Co. and managing director for the Americas of Bank of Tokyo Ltd.

title: POPE SET TO MEET WITH JARUZELSKI
description: Pope John Paul II is prepared to receive Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski if the Polish leader visits Italy, the Vatican said today.

title: POLICE FOCUS ON CHILD SEX IN TIMES SQ.
description: An undercover police task force focusing on sex crimes involving teen-agers and children has made 73 arrests in the Times Square area in the last five months, city officials reported yesterday.

title: WHITE SOX GUIDED BY STARS
description: Shortly before their ball clubs met in an exhibition game here recently, Ken Harrelson, the new executive vice president for baseball operations for the Chicago White Sox, and Dick Howser, the Kansas City Royals' manager, stood behind home plate trading good-natured barbs. ''Someone in your organization said you didn't have enough guys to play a B-squad game against us,'' Howser said to the man he nicknamed Hawk when they played together over 20 years ago. ''Heck, you could just put all your minor league instructors out on the field.''

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 22
description: The prior year net includes a tax credit of $394,000.

title: LIBYA'S GULF CLAIM: 13-YEAR DISPUTE WITH U.S.
description: The United States and Libya have been at odds over Libyan claims to the Gulf of Sidra since 1973, when Libya announced that it considered all of the gulf to be part of its internal waters.

title: UNIVERSAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THAILAND RETIRES MILITARY LEADER
description: The head of the armed forces, who had become a persistent critic of the Government, was ordered into retirement today by Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda.

title: TWO MISSILE TYPES USED BY U.S. NAVY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that Navy warplanes used long-range air-to-surface missiles to strike a missile site in Libya and two Libyan naval patrol craft.

title: WARNACO PLANS RECAPITALIZING
description: Warnaco Inc., a leading apparel manufacturer that is in the midst of a takeover battle, said its board had unanimously approved a recapitalization proposal. The plan replaces a board-approved leveraged-buyout bid made by RLL Inc., a group led by Warnaco executives, the company said.

title: A & M FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for 17 weeks to Dec 31
What $70,000 Buys for the Homeless
description: The story provokes instant outrage: How can New York City pay $70,000 a year for a family's emergency housing on the open floor of a vast armory in the Bronx? Why not just give the families the money and let them buy condos?

title: HOSPOSABLE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: NEW HEARING HELD IN DARTMOUTH RAID
description: A new hearing began today on the suspension of Dartmouth College students who attacked shanties built as a protest against South Africa's policy of racial segregation.

title: GENETIC COMPANY LOSES PERMIT FOR FIELD TESTING
description: Charging a California biotechnology company with deliberately falsifying key scientific data, the Environmental Protection Agency today suspended its permit to field-test a genetically engineered farm chemical.

title: D.M.B.& B. EXECUTIVE PLANS RED BANK AGENCY
description: Mario Botti mailed out his announcement of plans to start his own agency on his letterhead from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which he is leaving after 10 years. It was accompanied by an old commuting ticket from the North Jersey Coast Line to Red Bank, which he plans to never need again.

title: Understudy
description: What's this? Dick Howser sending in somebody to pinch hit for George Brett?

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a net gain of $118,074 from cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: DEERE PLANS CUTS
description: Deere & Company said it planned to reduce its work force by 6 percent, or 750 people, this spring. A spokesman for Deere, based in Moline, Ill., said the action, which would result in an after-tax charge of $30 to $35 million in the second quarter, was necessary because of reduced agricultural equipment schedules.

title: INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $147,965 for the quarter and $326,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $131,000.

title: EAGLE TELEPHONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

THOUSANDS MOURN TALMUDIC SCHOLAR
description: More than 20,000 Orthodox Jews filled the blocks of the Lower East Side yesterday to listen to sorrowful eulogies for Rabbi Moshe Feinstein, a towering scholar whose rulings guided the religious practices of millions of Jews around the world.

title: Pact at South Carolina
description: George Felton edged several familiar names in college basketball that were mentioned for the vacant position as head coach at South Carolina. Felton left as an assistant at Georgia Tech to replace Bill Foster, who resigned after a losing season. Felton signed a four-year contract at $65,000 a year.

title: FIRST AMERICAN HEALTH CONEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Tyson Bows Out
description: Mike Tyson, the undefeated young heavyweight, yesterday bowed out of his scheduled fight Saturday with James (Quick) Tillis because of an infected right ear. Tyson's co-manager, Jim Jacobs, said the ear had been hurt during a sparring session and that Tyson would behospitalized for five or six days. The fight has been rescheduled for May 3.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 split of common stock distributed on Nov. 11, 1985.

title: LANCER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent fully diluted figures.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This attack was entirely unprovoked and beyond the bounds of normal international conduct. U.S. forces were intent upon only making the legal point that beyond the internationally recognized 12-mile limit, the Gulf of Sidra belongs to none, and that all nations are free to move through international waters and airspace.'' - Larry Speakes, White House spokesman. [ A10:1. ]

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SOUTHWEST REALTY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a $3,437,000 gain on property sales realized in the second quarter. c-Including a gain of $1,769,000 on sale of property.

title: Drug-Testing Bill Could Be Sleeper
description: Three months ago, San Francisco's Board of Supervisors passed a piece of omnibus right-to-privacy legislation that, at the time, didn't seem to have much relevance to sports. Aimed at several large corporations that maintain offices in the city, the bill, which became law in January, among other things forbade employers' restricting off-hours activities of their workers, such as dating or living with the employees of rival firms.

title: SANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3:04 A.M. today and set at 11:07 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 3 A.M. and set at 10:52 A.M.

title: J.S. BACH AND 'RATS:
description: THERE has been much debate on the correct way to perform Bach cantatas. One approach (which, until Sunday afternoon, seems to have been unaccountably neglected) is to dress actors up in blankets, pig masks and wooden rodent heads, blast air-raid sirens, stage a tentative waltz (in four-four time) between an animated mannequin and a woman made faceless by tangled hair, and build to a grand finale featuring the image of a Sun God that closely resembles a fried egg, and placards of happy third-world peasants who seem to have been lifted from a Sandinista mural.

title: DOW RECOVERS BY 14.37, TO 1,782.93
description: Trading on Wall Street returned to a more normal pace yesterday as blue-chip stocks recovered after substantial losses Friday. Secondary issues, however, drifted lower and over all, more issues fell than rose.

title: ANNA MARIA STANCZYK GIVES PIANO RECITAL
description: THE pianist Anna Maria Stanczyk neatly bisected her Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, devoting the first half to a selection of varied works by Franz Liszt, the second to works by Szymanowski, Rachmaninoff and Chopin.

title: The Final Four Formula
description: The Duke guard Johnny Dawkins ''can get his shot anytime he wants.'' The Kansas forward Danny Manning is ''the best all-around player in the country - not the best player but the best all-around player.'' Louisville has ''the most talent,'' and the Louisiana State forward John Williams is ''as great an individual talent as anybody in the Final Four'' that will gather at the Reunion Arena in Dallas on Saturday for the National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinals.

title: WHITE HOUSE LEERY OF SENATE ON BUDGET FOR 1987
description: The director of the Office of Management and Budget said today that he did not expect the Republican-controlled Senate to approve a 1987 budget acceptable to the White House.

title: OILMAN SAID TO BID FOR CBS
description: Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman and former owner of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, has apparently made an offer to buy CBS Inc., Wall Street sources disclosed last night.

title: LAND-ROVER IS STILL 'WRAPPED IN THE UNION JACK'
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's drive to sell off, or ''privatize,'' the country's nationalized industries has been thrown out of gear by a burst of patriotic sentiment that has turned a rugged and deliberately unstylish product of the English Midlands into a symbol of true British grit.

title: Suit Against Governor Of Maryland Is Halted
description: The Gerber Products Company decided today to drop a $150 million lawsuit charging that Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland acted irresponsibly by banning the sale of the company's strained peaches.

title: PARTY CHIEFS SEEK 'COMMON GROUND' ON CONTRAS
description: The Republican and Democratic leaders of the Senate said today that Congress should search for a ''common ground'' on United States policy toward Central America and try to draft a plan aiding the Nicaraguan rebels that could command wide bipartisan support on Capitol Hill.

title: REAGAN BACKS ENVOY DESPITE TRIP TO LIBYA
description: The White House, responding to a report that a senior American envoy had had unauthorized contacts with the Libyan Government, said today that President Reagan still had confidence in the official, William A. Wilson, the Ambassador to the Vatican.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Baltimore Orioles, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 7:35 P.M. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Bulls, at Chicago, 8:30 P.M. The Knicks and Chicago have split the previous four meetings this season and the Bulls are struggling to gain one of the eight playoff berths in the Eastern Conference. (Television - Channel 9; 8:30 P.M.) Nets vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee, 8:35 P.M. The Bucks have a 3-2 edge in the series, and this is the regular-season finale. (Television - SportsChannel, midnight tape. Radio - WPAT, 930; 8:30 P.M.) Nuggets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Denver. The Lakers, who defeated Denver in six games for the Western Conference title last year on the way to winning the N.B.A. title, have lost three of four games to the Nuggets this season. (Television - WTBS; 9:35 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. St. Louis Blues, at Uniondale, L.I., Nassau Coliseum. The Islanders haven't lost in the two meetings against the Blues this season. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WOR, 710; 8 P.M. ) Devils vs. Rangers, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Rangers hold the season edge, 3-2, but both Devils' victories were in overtime. The Rangers are fighting Pittsburgh for the final playoff spot in the Patrick Division. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; and WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Other Events BOWLING: $235,000 Toledo Trust P.B.A. National Championships at Toledo, Ohio.

title: DELLA FEMINA CREATES A HOLDING COMPANY
description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has created a holding company called the DFT Corporation under which is Della Femina, Travisano & Partners of New York, Los Angeles and Atlanta; Della Femina, Sherman & Olkin; Della Femina, Travisano Internatonal, and Sherwood & Schneider.

title: Suns' Foster in Mishap
description: Rod Foster, the guard for the Phoenix Suns, underwent surgery for a severe leg fracture suffered when his four-wheel drive vehicle overturned Sunday in a remote desert area. Dr. Paul Steingard, the physician for the Suns, who spent three hours operating on Foster, said the break was serious enough to be ''career-threatening.''

title: CULTURAL ACTIVIST: GEORGE WEISSMAN
description: George Weissman saw his first opera, ''La Traviata,'' in Palermo, Sicily. The memory is particularly clear, and fond, because the performance came two days after American forces, including Mr. Weissman, liberated the Sicilian port. Half the orchestra performed in white tie and tails, the rest in fatigues.

title: ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-After income from an accounting change.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MAYTAG TO ACQUIRE MAGIC CHEF FOR $740 MILLION
description: The Maytag Company announced yesterday that it planned to acquire Magic Chef Inc. as the appliance industry continued its pattern of consolidation.

title: DELTA COMPUTEC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL PROCESSING reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $457,286.

title: How the President Gets on the Air Live
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW BREED OF LEGISLATOR: TOO MODERN TO BE CLUBBY
description: Schmoozing in Albany used to be simple: there was a bar for the Republicans and a bar for the Democrats -backroom haunts where legislation was passed or defeated before the second round of beers.

title: BOESKY CAPITAL GAINS
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager, has closed a financing deal that gives him $880 million - more than four times his current capital - with which to play the takeover game. Sources close to the deal confirmed yesterday that the complicated financing was closed Friday.

title: Man, 20, Is Charged In Policeman's Death
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with slaying an off-duty Housing Authority police officer Sunday night, the police said.

title: LABOR MARKING 75TH ANNIVERSARY OF TRIANGLE SHIRTWAIST FIRE
description: It began about 4:30 P.M., Saturday, March 25, 1911.

title: THRIVING SWEATSHOPS FEED ON IMMIGRANTS' DESIRE FOR WORK
description: Noise might have assaulted you first as the elevator doors opened, a ceaseless din of impatient machinery. What voices could be heard were not speaking English.

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $16,508 and a tax loss carryforward of $28,000. c-Net loss including income of $98,318 from discontinued operations.

title: 2 APPEALS OF LIMITS ON POLICE SEARCHES TO BE HEARD
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to hear two appeals in which prosecutors seek further relaxation of constitutional restrictions on police searches and seizures.

title: 2,000 SALVADORANS MARCH IN CAPITAL
description: An estimated 2,000 demonstrators marched through the capital of San Salvador ths morning to mark the anniversary of the slaying of the country's Roman Catholic Archbishop six years ago.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EFFORTS RESUME IN ALBANY TO RESOLVE POLITICAL DIFFERENCES OVER THE BUDGET
description: With only a week to go until the current state budget expires, Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders resumed negotiations today on a $41.4 billion spending plan. But they remained far apart on several key issues, including the size of tax cuts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in The Home Section last Thursday with an article about the Milan Triennale exhibition omitted the name of the designer whose setting was shown. He is George Ranalli, a New York architect.

title: BROOKS RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A LOOK AT SUCCESS OF YOUNG ASIANS
description: THE Westinghouse Science Talent Search, arguably the most prestigious of all awards open to American high school students, came dramatically close this year to a clean sweep for a single small minority: America's ethnic Asians. The five top scholarship awards all went to Asians, some of them native Americans and some of them immigrants. Tied for first place were Wendy Kay Chung of Miami and Wei-Jing Zhu of Brooklyn, both of Chinese ancestry and born and educated in the United States. But Yoriko Saito moved to Alabama from Japan only three years ago. George Jer-Chi Juang came to Bayside, Queens, from Taiwan. Anh Tuan Nguyen-Huynh, a Vietnamese whose father was killed in the war, settled in Cleveland.

title: 'EXECUTION OF JUSTICE' CLOSES
description: ''Execution of Justice,'' a drama written and directed by Emily Mann based on the 1979 trial and conviction of Dan White, who killed Mayor George Moscone of San Francisco and Harvey Milk, a city Supervisor, closed after Saturday evening's performance at the Virginia Theater. The play ran for 12 regular performances and 8 previews.

title: ASSISTANCE IN BUYING STOCKS
description: TENS of thousands of new investors have joined in the feeding frenzy on Wall Street in the past year, and for many of them simply following the ascending prices on the stock pages has not been enough. They are turning to personal computers for assistance in analyzing stocks, making decisions whether to buy or sell, executing trades and managing portfolios.

title: POWER FOR THE POOR
description: FRANCES FOX PIVEN and Richard A. Cloward simply won't give up. The two professors never forget that in an affluent nation the poor are powerless. They still seek ways to pull these people into the national decision-making process and they have been working toward that goal for 20 years.

title: REAGANS ADMIT BEING HURT BY PARTS OF DAUGHTER'S BOOK
description: President and Mrs. Reagan today admitted they were hurt, angry and annoyed at apparent descriptions of their roles as parents in the autobiographical novel ''Home Front,'' by their daughter Patti.

title: T.W.A. Talks to Resume
description: Striking flight attendants and Trans World Airlines will resume contract talks Wednesday, the National Mediation Board announced today. A board spokesman, Meredith Buel, said the negotiations, with the aid of a Federal mediator, were to start at 11 A.M. at an undisclosed place in New York City. The union says it has offered T.W.A. a 15 percent wage cut and other concessions, but the airline says it needs more in order to survive.

title: FULLER, H B CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Europe Acts to Interlock Arms
description: Sam Nunn, who wanted to pull out American troops unless Europe spent more in its own defense, has changed his mind. The Senate's most influential military expert no longer sees the issue as whether America is carrying too much of the burden, but whether the Atlantic alliance is spending its money effectively. He clearly is asking the right question - especially at a time when pressure to cut American spending could revive ''let Europe defend itself'' sentiment.

title: COMATOSE WOMAN'S FAMILY PRESSES FOOD-TUBE REMOVAL
description: The family of a 31-year-old brain-damaged woman sought court authority here today to remove the feeding tube that has kept her alive for six years so she can ''exercise her right to die with dignity.''

title: Realist of La Mancha
description: To the Editor:

title: By Concorde or Cab
description: Air & Space, the new magazine published by the Smithsonian Institution, has its first issue out this week, just in time to mark yesterday's 10th anniversary of the first flight of the 1,350-mile-per-hour Concorde, which it notes may be chartered for $16,000 per hour.

title: Hoyt to Return
description: The pitcher LaMarr Hoyt, who has been treated for alcoholism, will be allowed to return to the San Diego Padres at the end of the week, according to his agent, Ron Shapiro, who said Hoyt had been in a Minnesota clinic. ''He has come to the point where he understands that he not only had a history of alcohol in his family, but that he himself had the problem,'' Shapiro said. Hoyt entered the treatment center Feb. 27.

title: G.M. VERIFIES CANADA PLANS
description: The General Motors Corporation confirmed today that it would spend $1.4 billion to renovate its Oshawa, Ontario, assembly plants for production of new lines of midsize cars and pickup trucks.

title: Harriette Arnow Dies at 78; Author of 'The Dollmaker'
description: Harriette Simpson Arnow, author of ''The Dollmaker'' and other novels, has died of natural causes. She was 78 years old and had lived since 1950 at the Washtenaw County farm where she was found dead Saturday.

title: VALUE LINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WORLD BANK PLANS $1.5 BILLION IN NEW AID TO LATIN DEBTORS
description: The World Bank, beginning Tuesday, is expected to approve $1.5 billion in loans to Latin America as part of its effort to help resolve the debt crisis.

title: YARDSTICK OF MEDICAL PERFORMANCE IS SOUGHT
description: WHEN the Health and Human Services Department recently released the lists of the nation's hospitals that have death rates significantly higher or lower than the national average, it took another step toward fundamentally altering the medical profession's accountability to the public.

title: THALIDOMIDE FOUND TO EASE TRANSPLANTS
description: THALIDOMIDE, the ill-fated sedative and tranquilizer that is seldom mentioned these days except as the classic example of drug tragedy, may have another limited chance at respectability.

title: Citizenship in Belize May Soon Be for Sale
description: Belizean citizenship will be for sale under a plan proposed by Prime Minister Manuel Esquivel.

title: HIGH COURT TO DECIDE LIQUOR SUIT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a New York State law that restricts discounting by liquor retailers violated Federal antitrust laws.

title: LESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
AVATAR HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits totaling $3,538,000. c-Including income of $455,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $3,351,000.

title: Berry Named Player of Year
description: Walter Berry, the lifeblood of St. John's Big East champions, was named yesterday as college basketball's 1986 Player of the Year by United Press International.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $720,000 for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,042,000 for the quarter and $1,824,000 for the year.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
JOFFREY'S BIRTHDAY VARIATION
description: The Joffrey Ballet has so many birthday celebrations coming up this year, its 30th anniversary, that it is amazing the company has time to celebrate someone else's birthday as well.

title: What Price Safety?
description: In an era of Federal budget cutbacks, deregulation is attracting millions more travelers into flying and creating a host of new airlines to accommodate them. Has the combination put at risk the safety of an expanded flying public? Maybe not yet, but the evidence is unsettling:

title: South African Police Accused of Child Killings
description: A group of women from 10 anti-apartheid groups said today that the South African police killed 201 children under the age of 18 during racial rioting last year.

title: BELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $437,393 from a restructuring of debt of an unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: BEAUTICONTROL COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company acquired Jinger Lee Inc. in June 1985 and had no operations before that date. The 1986 results reflect new basis of accounting which resulted from the acquisition. Therefore, in accordance with Securities and Exchange Commission guidelines, share earnings for the year-ago quarter was not listed.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TRAFALGAR/GLEN SUIT DISMISSED
description: A Japanese court dismissed a suit filed by Trafalgar/Glen Ltd., a company jointly owned by Trafalgar Holdings Ltd. and the Glen International Financial Service Company, that sought to block the merger of the Minebea Company and the Kanemori Company. The Nagano District Court dismissed the case on the ground that the April 1 merger of the two companies is for legitimate business reasons and not to dilute the holdings of Trafalgar/Glen, whose parent companies are attempting a tender offer for Minebea.

title: CADE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a non-recurring gain of $1,635,000 reflecting an increase in value of the company's equity in its Edac Technologies Corp. unit as a result of Edac's sale of its common stock to outside investors.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FIRE AND FASHION The Fashion Institute of Technology, which puts as much style in its exhibitions as it does in generating fashions, has two dramatically different shows on view.

title: BROOKLYN JUDGE IS ACCUSED OF PAYING TO HAVE FIRES SET
description: A Civil Court judge in Brooklyn was arrested early yesterday and accused of paying an arsonist to set fire to his Bedford-Stuyvesant law offices on two occasions so that he could collect insurance money.

title: APPLIED SOLAR ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $133,000.

title: HEAD OF SMITHKLINE FORCED TO SHIFT STRATEGY
description: Henry Wendt is the latest drug manufacturer to fall victim to tampering. The 52-year-old president and chief executive of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation has begun reformulating the company's strategy after a recall of capsule formulas of three of its over-the-counter drugs.

title: Arms and Hard Choices
description: For years the standard position of the American-Israeli Public Affairs Committee, a group that lobbies for Israeli interests, has been to oppose the sale of sophisticated United States arms to Arab nations. Most recently, Aipac, as it is known, had announced that it would fight a proposed new sale of more than $1 billion in fighter aircraft equipment, helicopters, heavy tanks and missiles to Saudi Arabia.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GLOBAL EFFORT URGED FOR OZONE
description: International laws banning the use of products containing chlorofluorocarbons has been urged at a conference on the global environment.

title: DOCUGRAPHIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Tug Rams Submarine
description: The Secota, a Navy tugboat, accidentally struck a Trident submarine off Midway Island and sank, and two of the tug's crew members were missing, the Navy said Sunday.

title: U.S.-TURKISH TALKS REACH AN IMPASSE
description: Senior United States and Turkish officials said today that their differences were too great to permit agreement on a new defense and economic pact during Secretary of State George P. Shultz's current visit.

title: GENSTAR UP ABOVE BID BY IMASCO
description: Responding to a takeover bid over the weekend, shares of the Genstar Corporation reached a high of $41 in heavy trading yesterday before ending the day at $39.75 - well above the offering price of $38.66.

title: METROMEDIA SELLING 9 RADIO STATIONS
description: Metromedia Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell nine of its 11 radio stations, including WNEW-AM and WNEW-FM in New York, to an investor group and Morgan Stanley & Company for $285 million.

title: STATE INSURANCE CHANGES SEEN
description: New York State insurance laws are generally regarded as the toughest in the country. Moreover, when New York enacts a law affecting insurance companies, two trends often develop: many other states pass similar legislation and many insurers change their contracts in such a way that policyholders in other states where their products are sold reap the benefits of the New York requirements.

title: YAMANI ISSUES WARNING AS OIL SESSION ADJOURNS
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian oil minister, warned today that the world faced a fresh round of oil price shocks in the 1990's, similar to those that jarred the world economy in the 1970's, if persistently low prices eliminate high-cost oil production and the incentive for new energy exploration.

title: In This State, Wildlife Also Includes Hunters
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; March 25, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CARTER IS CATCHING ON A STEADY BASIS
description: Gary Carter reached into his locker and pulled down a strange device of metal and sponge. It was supposed to be the brace that Carter would wear this season, but instead it has become something of a conversation piece, a thing to remind the Mets' catcher how fragile his right knee really is.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Devils returned the rookie goaltender Craig Billington to Belleville, his junior team in the Ontario Hockey League, for the second time this season and promoted Karl Friesen from their top affiliate, the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League. . . . The Islanders promoted Brad Dalgarno from Hamilton of the Ontario Hockey League.

title: COMMUNISTS OFFER AQUINO PEACE TALKS
description: Leaders of the Philippine Communist insurgency said today that they were prepared to negotiate a cease-fire ''on a nationwide scale'' with the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title:
MARKET PLACE;
WEAKER DOLLAR HELPING PROFITS
description: WITH the dollar's drop against foreign currencies - about 30 percent from its peak in February 1985 to the end of the year and an additional 7 percent in the first quarter of 1986 -some stocks should carry a double punch.

title: ABC NEWS PAYS $25,000 FOR A TAPE OF SAKHAROV
description: For ABC News, the temptation proved irresistible. The network paid $25,000, possibly to an agent of the K.G.B., for 18 minutes of videotape of Dr. Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident living in internal exile in the city of Gorky.

title: WITNESS IN GOTTI TRIAL FAILS TO IDENTIFY DEFENDANTS AS ATTACKERS IN QUEENS DISPUTE
description: The man who had accused John Gotti, the reputed Mafia boss, of assault and robbery confronted him yesterday in a Queens courtroom and said he could not indentify him as one of his two assailants.

title: DEL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: LADD SEEN AS MGM HEAD
description: Alan Ladd Jr. is expected to be named chairman today of the MGM film studio being bought by Turner Broadcasting System, according to Hollywood sources.

title: Well-Paid Servants
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBANY FEUDING TIME: IT'S COUNTRY VS. CITY
description: Senator William T. (Cadillac) Smith, from up in Big Flats, N.Y., said he really couldn't recall a meeting back home in the district where at least one of his constituents didn't rise and ask if there might be some way to just kind of saw off New York City and float it out to sea.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
INTERNATIONAL HYDRON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $7,000 for the quarter and $88,000 for the year. The year result also includes a loss of $659,000 in an arbitration dispute. c-Net income. d-Including extraordinary credits of $118,000 for the quarter and $275,000 for the year. The year-earlier fourth quarter and prior year results include $2 million from the sale of a license.

title: HAITI'S EXILES, RETURNING STEADILY, CARRY HOME FORMULAS FOR CHANGE
description: Jean Dominique was in from New York and walked into what used to be Haiti's most outspoken radio station, now a place covered with dust, unraveled tapes and smashed cabinets. The transmitters were carted off five years ago by the political police.

title: MUNICIPAL BOND TAX IS REJECTED
description: The Senate Finance Committee, in a 19-to-0 vote, today rejected the idea of making interest from both new and previously issued municipal bonds subject to the alternative minimum tax. But committee members left open the possibility of making municipal bonds issued after this year subject to the minimum tax.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to MArch 1
PEOPLE
description: * H. John Burke, director of client services, and Neil V. Harrison, executive media director, promoted to senior vice president at Weightman Inc., Philadelphia.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on a gift by the Coca-Cola Company to establish new foundations in South Africa incorrectly described Africare, a Washington organization. It supports economic development programs in a number of African nations, but none in South Africa.

title: ALARM OVER ALIENATION OF THE YOUNG
description: THE forces that produce alienated young Americans are growing at a dangerous rate.

title: No Forwarding Allowed
description: Edward I. Koch's postman did not ring twice and did not know that the Mayor still uses his Greenwich Village apartment as a voting address.

title: HONDURANS MEETING AMID U.S. REPORTS OF NICARAGUAN RAID
description: President Jose Azcona Hoyo of Honduras tonight called an urgent meeting of his National Security Council to discuss reports of a Nicaraguan military incursion into Honduran territory.

title: LOS ANGELES: MONEY CENTER
description: Itinerant New Yorkers ambling through downtown Los Angeles these days are likely to encounter gleaming new buildings bearing familiar corporate names. Workers recently put the finishing touches, for instance, on a 41-story building for Citicorp. And a few blocks away a 22-story office tower is going up for another New York-based banking giant, the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
The Hamantaschen Of Lincoln Square
description: Boxes of three-cornered cookies sat invitingly in the lobbies of apartment buildings around 69th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. ''Take one,'' a sign urged.

title: OHIO STATE GAINS BERTH IN FINAL
description: Brad Sellers drew the pro scouts to last night's semifinal final round of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden, but for the first half, it appeared that watching the 7-foot Ohio State center, tagged for immediate delivery, was a waste of time. After a 1-for-6 shooting first half, however, Sellers put on a scoring, rebounding and shot-blocking performance that made the trip worthwhile.

title: BOUNTY OF EASTER GIFTS
WATER DISTRICT IN A FINANCING
description: The Metropolitan Water District of Southern California is tentatively offering $100 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 6.835 percent for a 6 3/4 percent bond at a price of 99, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE word is out: California wines are back. European wine prices are going up and California is waiting in the wings with great wines at sensible prices, eager to win us all back.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Business People column on Feb. 27 misidentified the leading marketer of Eurobonds. It is Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: STATUE OF LIBERTY COIN DRIVE
description: GREY ADVERTISING, which is particularly enamored of Government advertising assignments, is prepared to break with a $17 million, one-shot campaign sponsored by the Department of the Treasury to sell Statue of Liberty centennial commemorative coins.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $4,737,000 for the quarter and year; a loss of $77,000 for the quarter and income of $27,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss of $77,000 for the quarter and income of $129,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations.

title: SOVIET ARMS GAINS DESCRIBED
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union's modernization of its weapons arsenal was continuing at such a pace that it was ''challenging the technological edge'' on which American security depends.

title: A Teleconference
description: For some years the Bureau of National Affairs, a publisher of specialized information services, has been holding conferences on current issues, with participants coming to Washington from all over the country. Last November, for example, such a session on ''Alcohol and Drugs: Issues in the Workplace'' attracted about 150 executives and personnel managers.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Martina Navratilova, the tennis star who was born is Czechoslovakia and is now a citizen of the United States, was officially named to the United States team that will play for the Federation Cup in Prague in July. The appointment, which had been expected, means that Miss Navratilova will be returning to her homeland for the first time since she defected in 1975. . . . Bill Ranford, a 19-year-old goaltender who was the Boston Bruins' second pick in the 1985 draft, was called up from his junior club in Canada. . . . Walter Berry, the St. John's junior sensation, has won another player of the year award, this time from The Sporting News. . . .

title: JUDGE CLEARS GOTTI OF ASSAULT CHARGES AT A TRIAL IN QUEENS
description: A judge yesterday dismissed assault and robbery charges against the reputed Mafia boss John Gotti and an associate, a day after the complainant failed to identify them in court as his assailants.

title: ELLIOTT RESIGNS AS JOURNALISM DEAN AT COLUMBIA
description: Osborn Elliott has resigned as dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism after seven years, the school announced yesterday.

title: REFORM MUST START WITH DRUG POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: 15 Hurt in Parkway Crash
description: A slow car caused a chain pileup in fog on the Garden State Parkway here that involved 14 vehicles and injured 15 people at 5:50 A.M. today, the police said. No one was reported seriously injured in the crash, near the Mullica River. The injured were taken to hospitals in Pomona and Manahawkin.

title: Pakistani Dissident Says She'll End Her Exile
description: A key leader of the Pakistani opposition said today that she planned to end her exile in London and to return home for a series of political rallies.

title: BANKS TO COMPLY
description: The Swiss Government said today that it was freezing ''until further notice'' all bank deposits in Switzerland belonging to the family of Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: MAINE SAYING NO TO U.S. NUCLEAR WASTE PLAN
description: Six hearing officers from the Department of Energy are in town to gather opinion on the possibility of storing highly radioactive nuclear waste here, but if they had any question it was answered on the way in from the airport. Utility poles are covered with signs reading ''No!''

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: YANKEES' PITCHING OUTLOOK SCRAMBLED
description: When the Yankees began spring training, Manager Lou Piniella looked at the horde of pitchers in camp with major league experience and said he envisioned a starting rotation of Ron Guidry, Britt Burns, Joe Niekro, Phil Niekro and Ed Whitson. With only two weeks to go before the start of the season, the Yankees could be on their way to having a rotation of Guidry, Joe Niekro, Whitson, Dennis Rasmussen and either Doug Drabek or Bob Tewksbury.

title: DAVIS IS CRITICAL OF U.S.F.L.
description: Al Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders and the only National Football League owner who was not named as a defendant in the United States Football League's antitrust suit against the N.F.L., says he is ''inclined'' to testify in the case, which is expected to begin late next month in New York. But U.S.F.L. owners, he said, may not be too thrilled to hear what he has to say.

title: LISTLESS ISLANDERS BLANKED
description: The Islanders could have clinched a playoff berth tonight but instead were shut out for the third time this season in a game they would soon like to forget.

title: A SUNBURN IN YOUTH MAY INCREASE CANCER RISK, STUDY FINDS
description: A person who suffers even one case of blistering sunburn in adolescence may double the risk of developing a serious skin cancer later in life, a Harvard researcher reported today.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $117,000.

title: SOUTH TEXAS DRILLING & EXLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METS' KNIGHT PUTS 1985 TO REST
description: The look on Ray Knight's face seemed to be one of exuberance. He spoke with a kind of evangelical fervor, his words occasionally singing the praises of a new season, of better days ahead.

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter and year results include a writedown of inventories of $2.4 million.

title: U.S. and Minnesota Sign Chippewa Land Measure
description: President Reagan and Gov. Rudy Perpich have signed legislation providing property and money to Chippewa Indians for land illegally taken from them nearly 80 year ago and to clear up titles for present landowners.

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LIBYA FORCES REPORTED INFERIOR TO MANY IN REGION
description: Although it comes as no surprise that Libya's forces are no match for the United States Sixth Fleet, military analysts say its air, naval and air-defense forces are also inferior to those of many Middle Eastern nations.

title: PRESIDENT ORDERS EMERGENCY AID FOR THE HONDURAN ARMED FORCES
description: United States Army helicopters, piloted by American soldiers, are being readied to ferry Honduran troops Wednesday morning into the border area where Nicaraguan Army units are reported to have attacked Nicaraguan anti-Government guerrilla bases, according to diplomatic sources here.

title: A State Insult to City Schools
description: Albany's traditional upstate-downstate battle over New York State's education budget usually leaves New York City slighted on state aid. This year the maneuvering threatens to deepen the insult.

title: Charles Starrett Dies at 82; Actor on Stage and Screen
description: Charles Starrett, an actor who played the Durango Kid in a series of westerns in the 1930's and 40's, died Saturday in Borrego Springs, Calif. He was 82 years old.

title: 'NEW' CHICAGO COUNCIL SWORN IN WITH ONE SEAT TIED UP IN COURT
description: There was a festive air around City Hall today as aldermen chosen in City Council elections a week ago waited to take their seats. A five-piece mariachi band played. Balloons and flowers poured in.

title: Angola Rebels Report Damaging Oil Complex
description: Angolan rebels asserted today that they had attacked and seriously damaged American-operated oil installations in the northern part of the country.

title: Rangers to Start Rookie
description: As a first-year pro fresh out of college, Pete Incaviglia seemed likely to begin this season on a Texas Ranger minor league team, perhaps even on a Triple A team. After all, as a junior at Oklahoma State last year, Incaviglia set collegiate records with 48 home runs and 143 runs batted in and led Oklahoma State to the College World Series.

title: GOVERNMENT BY CAUCUS MEETS AN AGGRESSIVE PRESS
description: In recent years, Republicans have held control in Schoharie, an upstate county of dairy farms. Eleven of the 16 men who make up the Schoharie Board of Supervisors are Republicans.

title: CHAPTER 11 AT TOWLE
description: The Towle Manufacturing Company, a leading maker of silverware and giftware since 1880, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company said the action had been necessary because of a poor operating performance in this year's first quarter resulting from softness in the retail market.

title: HANOVER TO SELL MORTGAGE UNIT
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its mortgage bank subsidiary, the Manufacturers Hanover Mortgage Corporation, to the Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies for $260 million.

title: CONSUMER PRICES, AIDED BY SLUMP IN OIL MARKET, OFF 0.4% IN MONTH
description: Consumer prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent in February as the effects of the collapsing oil market made their first full impact at the retail level, the Labor Department reported today.

title: INSURANCE COSTS CURB TASTINGS
description: At least one Finger Lakes winery has sharply curtailed the popular tradition of wine tasting, citing the rising cost of liability insurance, industry officials say.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD OHIO RIGHTS SUIT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a local government may be required to pay damages for a single incident in which officials responsible for setting official policy violate the Constitution.

title: Staying in the Pulpit
description: Representative Bill Green is engaging in some unusual name-dropping. In fund-raising letters, the Republican of Manhattan refers to the Rev. Dr. F. Forester Church as a potential opponent this year.

title: Getting Ready to Flap
description: The flying model of a prehistoric flying reptile commissioned by the Smithsonian Institution will make its Washington maiden flight on May 17, but not down the Mall as originally planned. The Quetzalcoatlus northropi, a model of a pterodactyl with an 18-foot wingspan, will flap, instead, over a more open area, probably Andrews Air Force Base southeast of the capital.

title: BYE, BYE ACADEMIC RESEARCH
description: Given the budget reductions dictated by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, and the proposed cuts in federally funded student aid, colleges and universities are not faring well in the current budget cycle. But there is one other proposal, largely ignored, that would not only cost universities further millions but also have the perverse effect of undermining the very research on which our society and Federal Government depends.

title: MEXICO DEBT EXTENSION
description: Mexico has won a second six-month extension on repayment of $950 million in principal on its $96 billion foreign debt, bankers in New York said yesterday.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: The latest results include charges of $1.4 million for the quarter and $2.4 million for the 6 months which are related to a settlement involving its L.B. Darling division.

title: MALNUTRITION IS FOUND ON RISE IN RURAL AREAS
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to limit food assistance programs, coupled with a lingering economic depression in rural America, has caused increasing hunger and malnutrition, according to year-long study released today by a Washington-based research and policy group.

title: SEABOARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 8
FILM: 'THE MONEY PIT,' A DOMETIC COMEDY
description: IF you can imagine a remake of Steven Spielberg's ''Poltergeist'' in which the spirits of the dead have been shoved aside by equally loud, unruly plumbers and carpenters, you'll have some idea of ''The Money Pit,'' opening today at Loew's Astor Plaza and other theaters.

title: SPECIALTY STORES PLANNED BY WARD'S
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, said yesterday that it would convert 116 stores, or 40 percent of its more than 290 stores across the country, into specialty stores. The plan carries out a test-market program that Ward said had proved to be ''very successful.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Winning Produce A basket filled with New York State produce won the first prize at the National Direct Marketing Association Conference in Des Moines last week in a competition that included entries from such prominent agricultural states as California, Florida and Texas. Direct marketing refers to the sale of agricultural products by the farmer directly to the consumer.

title: LEWIS, GILMAN CHANGES
description: Robert G. Wilder, chairman and chief executive officer of Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, a Foote, Cone & Belding subsidiary in Philadelphia, has relinquished the chief executive title to John K. Kaiser, who is president and has been chief operating officer. Mr. Kaiser, 42 years old, joined the agency in 1980 as senior vice president and director of client services. His route to that position was a little different from most. He did have a previous agency job with Ketchum Advertising in Pittsburgh, but before that he ran his own foo brokerage company and headed the business department of Allegheny College.

title: BACK TO BASICS WITH OLD-WORLD YOGURT
description: LOW in fat and high in protein and calcium, yogurt rode in on the crest of the health-food wave in the United States some years ago. Today most grocery stores carry a plethora of commercial yogurts. But gussied up with blueberries and a host of other fruits and flavorings, in an appeal to the popular palate, these yogurts are a far cry, in terms of flavor and texture, from the original.

title: EX-ESPN CHAIRMAN IN WATER SPORTS PROJECT
description: Stuart W. Evey, who helped found the ESPN cable network as an executive of Getty Oil and then served as its chairman until the cable network's sale to ABC, has now linked up with a Seattle adman to help create Water Sports Network, which plans to turn out a weekly, fast-moving water sports television magazine that will be distributed through barter syndication and will, it is hoped, go on the air next September.

title: MODERN MAN'S ORIGIN LINKED TO A SINGLE FEMALE ANCESTOR
description: Calculations of the slow changes that have taken place in human DNA over the millennia indicate that everyone alive today may be a descendant of a single female ancestor who lived in Africa 140,000 to 280,000 years ago, scientists at the University of California at Berkeley have reported.

title: BRAZIL MARCHES TO WAR AGAINST GOLIATH OF INFLATION
description: The enemy was finally identified, a war of ''life and death'' was solemnly proclaimed and, within hours, regiments of housewives responded to President Jose Sarney's recruitment call and began rushing to the front line of Brazil's new crusade against inflation.

title: ISSUE LANDS IN COURT: IS PUTTER PLAYABLE?
description: Golfers have had a love-hate relationship with their putters ever since the game was first played on the flat expanses along the North Sea in Scotland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 26, 1986
description: International American Navy forces struck against Libya for a second day. United States officials said Sixth Fleet forces destroyed two more fast attack patrol boats in the Gulf of Sidra and bombed a missile site on the Libyan coast a second day. The attacks were made as the Reagan Administration vowed to continue American Navy operations in the gulf, which Libya claims as its own. [ Page A1, Columns 4-6. ]

title: Churches in Brooklyn Agree To a Modified Housing Plan
description: A coalition of 52 Brooklyn churches agreed yesterday to proceed with a scaled-down version of the housing plan they had proposed for East New York.

title: OPEL ERA AT I.B.M. ENDS JUNE 1
description: John R. Opel, the chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, who surmounted antitrust complaints against the company and braced it for a new era of low-cost desktop computers, said today that he would retire June 1.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Borden Inc. said its board had approved a 3-for-2 stock split and a 10.5 percent increase in its annual dividend.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income and after net from discontinued operations of $9,291,000 for the 9 months.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ZENITH COMPUTER UNIT SHINES
