description: With two-thirds of its revenues coming from the import-battered consumer electronics business, the Zenith Electronics Corporation has struggled to eke out a profit in recent years. That struggle has largely eclipsed one of the company's proudest accomplishments - the transformation of its once-tiny computer subsidiary into one of the nation's most successful computer companies.

title: TAX PANEL FAVORS FASTER DEPRECIATION
description: Members of the Senate Finance Committee voiced sentiment today for including in the tax revision bill they are writing more generous incentives for business investment than current law provides.

title: C.B.A. Honors Drew
description: At the age of 31 he's a bit old to be a rookie, but John Drew, the former National Basketball Association star, has been named newcomer of the year in the Continental Basketball Association.

title: CHERRY-PITTER SYNDROME, OR WHY GADGETS SELL
description: MARLENE BLOOM is drawn to kitchen gadgets the way others are attracted to clothes. ''I find them irresistible,'' says Miss Bloom, a computer consultant whose Greenwich Village home has three drawers filled with cherry pitters, vegetable peelers and lots of garlic presses (she hasn't found the ''right'' one yet).

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: THE POP LIFE
description: OTIS CLAY, who is making his first New York appearance in more than a decade at Tramps this weekend, is a master of soul singing, a contemporary and peer of vocalists like Otis Redding and Solomon Burke. But for a soul singer, he has had an unusual career, as he is the first to admit.

title: LaRouche Backer Faces Challenge in California
description: The chairman of the Orange County Democratic Party said today that he would run a write-in campaign for Congress to try to stop a follower of Lyndon H. LaRouche, a far-right extremist, from winning nomination by default.

title: BUDGET-BALANCING AMENDMENT LOSES
description: In a dramatic loss for the Republican leadership and President Reagan, the Senate this evening barely defeated a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget. The vote was 66 to 34 in favor, one vote short of the required two-thirds majority.

title: WALKER IN APPEAL
description: Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. said it would appeal to the Ontario Securities Commission a decision by the Toronto Stock Exchange permitting the previously announced Gulf Canada Corporation takeover bid to proceed on April 4.

title: AFRICA,' FIRST OF 8 PARTS ON A&E
description: ''AFRICA,'' an eight-part series that begins on the Arts and Entertainment Network at 8:30 tonight, promises to be something special. Breadth and imagination are joined. Judged by its first episode, at least, it appears to be a winner.

title: DOW FALLS 4.43 AS VOLUME ALSO SLIPS
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday on Wall Street in the quietest session in more than a week.

title: Good Numbers for Duke
description: Duke, ranked first in the final polls, has survived to become the East Regional representative in this weekend's Final Four. But if one recent trend can be trusted, then the Blue Devils will have a difficult time capturing the national title: Since the 1978-79 season, the only top-ranked team that went on to win the championship was North Carolina, in 1982.

title: BUCKS BLITZ NETS IN 4TH PERIOD
description: Craig Hodges scored 24 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to their fifth consecutive victory, 118-105, over the Nets tonight.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: SIX-YEAR-OLD Sarah cannot eat doughnuts or chocolate-chip cookies, pasta or pizza, pretzels or puddings. And it's not because her parents are health fanatics. Rather, these foods, along with bread, cereals, pancakes, malted milk, fish sticks, meat loaf and gravy, contain wheat and other grain products that Sarah - and about 80,000 other Americans - cannot properly digest.

title: 2 MARCOS ADVISERS DESCRIBE DEALINGS
description: Two of Ferdinand E. Marcos's top financial advisers have agreed to cooperate with the Philippine Government's efforts to recover the deposed President's wealth, a senior Filipino official said yesterday.

title: TEXACO TALKS TO RESUME
description: The chief executives of the Pennzoil Company and Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to resume talks aimed at settling the legal feud between their companies out of court.

title: NEW YORK CITY MINI-SCHOOLS GET FAILING GRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT ENTERS A PLEA OF GUILTY IN FATAL '74 FIRE
description: A Connecticut man, whose conviction for the murder of 24 people in the 1974 arson of a discotheque was recently overturned on appeal, pleaded guilty today to manslaughter in connection with the fire and could be released soon.

title: White South African Is Slain and Burned
description: A white South African policeman was shot dead while off duty and his body was burned in a black squatter camp near here today, the police said.

title: JEWISH GROUP OFFERS DOCUMENTS IT CONTENDS IMPLICATE WALDHEIM
description: The World Jewish Congress disclosed new documents today that it said showed that Kurt Waldheim, as an intelligence officer in the German Army, took part in campaigns against Yugoslav partisans in World War II.

title: THE SIDRA ACCOUNT
description: With two days of combat in the Gulf of Sidra, the United States establishes the hard credibility of its determination to resist Libya's annexation of international waters. That was the stated purpose of the naval exercise that provoked the conflict. But are there other, unstated goals as well? That is the question for day three, and while the answers to the question are hardly obvious, speculation is healthy.

title: LIQUOR STORE OWNER FIGHTS DISCOUNT LAWS
description: Five years ago George S. Alpert placed a newspaper ad for a liquor sale at his store in Manhattan. A flood of competitors complained that Mr. Alpert had violated New York State liquor pricing laws, and the State Liquor Authority slapped him with a $1,000 fine and suspended his license for 10 days.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
LONGTIME DIPLOMAT WAS 93
description: Loy W. Henderson, one of the nation's first career Foreign Service officers and a former Ambassador to India and Iran, died of congestive heart failure Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 93 years old.

title: Chapel Closed for Repairs
description: The Rev. Leo F. Halpin was saddened yesterday as he recounted how he had to tack up a sign last Saturday on the front door of the Chapel of Saints, Faith, Hope and Charity.

title: GURU'S ROLL-ROYCES FETCH TOP PRICES
description: To Chappie Cannon Jr., happiness is a two-tone, metal-flake, purple and silver Rolls-Royce Spur from the Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh collection.

title: LAZAR, EX-CITY AIDE, SEEN AS A KEY FIGURE IN INQUIRIES
description: Michael J. Lazar, who held several major city posts before leaving government a decade ago to become a real-estate developer, has emerged as an important figure in the continuing investigations by Federal and local prosecutors into New York City government, law-enforcement officials say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 26, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Buildup of Radioactive Gas Halts Three Mile Island Work
description: Work inside the Three Mile Island Unit 1 reactor was suspended for 12 hours today after radioactive gas built up inside the containment building, a plant spokesman said.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a charge of $1,580,000 reflecting the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior periods.

title: BOOK SET ON SINDONA, ITALIAN BANKER
description: Arbor House, after going to unusual lengths to protect itself from libel suits, will publish the story of Michele Sindona, the shadowy Sicilian financier who died in a hospital Saturday of cyanide poisoning - four days after he was sentenced to life imprisonment for hiring a hit man to murder the lawyer appointed to liquidate the assets of his failed Italian banks.

title: AQUINO PROCLAIMS INTERIM GOVERNMENT
description: President Corazon C. Aquino abolished the National Assembly and claimed all legislative powers for herself today.

title: Raveling Considered
description: University of Houston officials seeking a replacement for Guy Lewis, the Cougar basketball coach who retired after 30 seasons, have received permission from the University of Iowa to talk to the Hawkeyes' coach, George Raveling. Raveling, who was on a recruiting trip, had no immediate comment.

title: REPORTERS' POOL KEPT FROM ACTION
description: No American journalists have been allowed to observe the clashes between the American fleet and Libyan forces in the Mediterranean.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SPRING NOTED In Carl Schurz Park, an abundance of lark.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
SANFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TIMES MIRROR
description: The Times Mirror Company began offering $100 million of 8 1/4 percent, 10-year notes at a price of par through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The notes, which are noncallable for the first seven years, are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P. They are offered to yield about 56-hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: STAGE: 'LARGO DESOLATO,' BY HAVEL, AT THE PUBLIC
description: THE lesson Public Theater audiences are likely to learn at ''Largo Desolato,'' the new play by the Czechoslovak dissident writer Vaclav Havel, is not necessarily the one its author intended. Mr. Havel, whose past works include ''The Memorandum'' and ''A Private View,'' has once again attempted to transmute the nightmare of totalitarian repression into bleak comedy of high linguistic absurdity. But as staged at the Public by Richard Foreman, the experimental director of Ontological-Hysteric theater pieces, ''Largo Desolato'' doesn't fully vent Mr. Havel's pressing concerns. This evening tells us less about the suffering of writers in a police state than it does about the self-indulgence of American directors who plaster their egos over playwrights' words.

title: Divorce Football Style
description: Circuit Court Judge Aubrey Kaplan has ruled that the Indianapolis Colts football team could be considered as part of any settlement in the divorce case of team owner Robert Irsay and his wife. However, an attorney for Irsay said there was no chance that Irsay's wife would some day control the franchise.

title: N.I.T. FINAL FEATURES SELLERS
description: Brad Sellers and Eldon Miller are headed for new fields after they lead Ohio State against Wyoming tonight in the final of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After equity in losses from discontinued operations of $94,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the year. c-After losses from a discontinued operation of $2,336,000 which was related to the company's holding in Modular Data Systems Inc.

title: Mayor Defends Paramedics Who Responded to Dying Girl
description: The Emergency Medical Service responded ''appropriately'' when asked to assist a 10-year-old Brooklyn girl with heart disease, who died a half hour later at Coney Island Hospital on March 2, Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: COLUMBINE EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-After a writedown of oil and gas properties of $1,615,000. c-Net income.

title: NOT JUST CHICKENS: FOR EASTER FEASTS, A CHOICE OF EGGS
description: THE egg has been savored and celebrated for at least 4,500 years, although the egg in question was not always that of the chicken. Ancient Egyptian paintings show pharaohs breeding geese, for example, to insure a supply of eggs for their larders and a symbol of creation for their homes.

title: CONSUMERS FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $206,000 on investments. c-Including a gain on investments and a nonrecurring gain from the sale of buildings of $1,187,000.

title: RIVERSIDE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,834,000 for the quarter and $2,898,000 for the year. The quarter also includes an extraordinary loss of $52,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $45,000. d-After income from discontinued operations of $79,000 and an extraordinary gain of $1,408,000. The latest quarter and year income from discontinued operations includes a gain on the sale of health food operations of $2,747,000.

title: STAGE: 'GODS AND GODDESSES'
description: ''GODS AND GODDESSES,'' an adaptation of two mythological tales taken from Bulfinch, is the third production by the New York Art Theater Institute to bring together the talents of the director Donald Sanders, the composer Henry Threadgill and the costume designer Vanessa James. The trio has evolved a highly visual style of musical theater that is an extension of tableau vivant stage entertainment. The centerpieces of ''Gods and Goddesses'' are Miss James's costumes, which weave synthetic materials like foam rubber, plastic wrap and tinfoil into grandly witty, eclectic parodies of royal garb.

title: NEW YORK-FLORIDA TRAIL OF A MEDICAL 'IMPOSTER'
description: Six months ago, Dr. Charles Hall was a low-profile advertising copywriter at a small medical products company in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: CHAIRMAN OF AMAX JOINS PAINE WEBBER
description: Pierre L. Gousseland, whose long and successful career at Amax Inc. faltered as the company's fortunes declined, is joining the Paine Webber Group as a senior consultant to Paine Webber's Capital Markets.

title: What Yank Fans May Miss
description: In the tug-of-war between the Yankees and WPIX-TV, the status remains for the most part quo: The Yanks will play their home night games at 7:30, but, unless there's a late settlement, the station won't begin the telecasts until 8. That's a total of 33 telecasts in which viewers will almost certainly miss all of the first inning, maybe a little more.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The results include losses from the company's Christie Brinkley division, which was terminated Nov. 4, 1985, of 6 cents a share for the year-ago quarter, 40 cents a share for the latest year and 19 cents a share for the previous year.

title: Q&A
description: Q. On a recent visit to Venice and northern Italy, I frequently dined on a dessert known as tiramisu. Are you familiar with this dish? A. This dessert is sometimes found in Italian restaurants in Manhattan, but it is curiously absent from most Italian cookbooks printed in this country. It resembles a charlotte, but is made with a very rich and creamy cheese known as mascarpone and does not contain cream.

title: UTILITY RATE RISE UPHELD IN CASE OF UNUSED UNIT
description: The State Public Service Commission can allow utilities to charge customers for the cost of power plants that never open, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: N.J. Transit Proposes 12.7% Fare Increase
description: Officials of the state transportation agency proposed fare increases today averaging 12.7 percent for 305,000 daily bus and rail riders.

title: No Headline
description: Orders to factories for durable goods, after two monthly gains, fell five-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.

title: BIOTECHNICA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday about the drug case against John A. Zaccaro Jr. misstated the charge he is facing. It is possession of a regulated drug.

title: NBC Close to Deal On Olympics TV Rights
description: NBC is close to completing a deal with the South Korean Olympic Organizing Committee for the television rights to the 1988 Summer Games, with a final agreement expected as early as today, network executives said.

title: JET FIGHTERS ESCORT SHULTZ FROM TURKEY TO GREECE
description: The United States called in Air Force and allied jet fighters today to protect Secretary of State George P. Shultz's aircraft as it brought him here from Turkey.

title: Dispute on Honoring Homosexual Activist
description: A resolution to honor a homosexual activist who died of the effects of AIDS has provoked a dispute among State Senate leaders.

title: MORTON THIOKOL ROCKET UNIT IS DESTROYED BY BLAST IN UTAH
description: An explosion today destroyed a Morton Thiokol building containing material used in Trident missile rocket propellent, a spokesman said.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 3 A.M. today and set at 10:52 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:57 A.M. and set at 10:33 A.M.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED AFTER 6 MONTHS IN MURDER TRIAL OF NURSING HOME
description: A mistrial was declared today in the six-month-long murder trial of a nursing home chain and four of its current or former managers, and prosecutors said their attempt to win a guilty verdict against a corporation in Texas was over.

title: The Committees and the Money
description: Following are major Congressional political action committees and, unless otherwise specified, the amount they raised in 1984, the latest year for which figures are available from the Federal Elections Commission: 13th C.D. Committee: Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, $68,588. 24th Congressional District of California PAC: Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat, $223,376.

title: LATE WIEMER GOAL HELPS RANGERS OUTLAST DEVILS
description: James Patrick displayed glimpses of brilliance while scoring two goals 11 seconds apart to break a 2-2 deadlock early in the third period tonight, but the biggest accolades went to another defenseman for the Rangers.

title: INTERCITY BUS IS BOUND FOR LIMBO
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATION HOPES PUSH BOND PRICES HIGHER
description: Bond prices continued to advance in light trading yesterday amid signs that inflation was moving to much lower levels.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: An Iacocca Poll
description: Despite his disavowals of interest in seeking public office, Lee A. Iacocca remains the subject of intense Washington speculation on the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination. A survey by Regardie's, a business-oriented local magazine, indicates that its predominately (5 to 3) Republican readers think well of the Chrysler chief and predict that he would defeat two of three potential Democratic contenders for the nomination and four of four likely Republican aspirants for the White House.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRESSED TO KILL Some have been taught ''clothes make the man.'' Shakespeare wrote, ''Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy / But not expressed in fancy; rich, not gaudy / For the apparel oft proclaims the man.'' The current guideline for both sexes is ''dress for success.'' The truth is, as the 18th-century poet Isaac Watts said, ''Let me be dressed fine as I will / Flies, worms, and flowers, exceed me still.''

title: STAGE: RINGLING BROTHERS AND BARNUM & BAILEY
description: THE circus, a bit of old news that anyone with a wisp of cotton candy in the memory bank is always glad to run into, arrived at Madison Square Garden yesterday. There are things to report, but nothing that strays far from the idea that a circus should be devoid of message and barren of significance; in other words, it should be sheer fun.

title: THE ACADEMY AWARDS CEREMONY
description: ABC'S presentation of ''The 58th Annual Academy Awards'' began at 9 o'clock, Eastern time, Monday evening and, more than three hours and a dozen commercial breaks later, television could lay claim to its best Oscar show in years, perhaps ever. Suddenly, it seemed, somebody had listened to the complaints that had grown deadeningly familiar over the years. Clumpy film clips and smirking patronization were out. Spiffy electronic techniques and pure celebration were in, leavened with generous dollops of good-natured and sometimes outrageous humor.

title: OSCAR WINNERS LISTED FOR 1986
description: Here is a complete list of winners at Monday night's 58th Academy Awards: Picture: ''Out of Africa.'' Director: Sydney Pollack, ''Out of Africa.''

title: DR. EUGENE Y. BERGER
description: Dr. Eugene Y. Berger, an authority on Alzheimer's disease and director of medical services at the Morningside House nursing home in the Bronx, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Yonkers. He was 66 years old.

title: TOKYO BEGINS INVESTIGATION INTO BOMBING ATTACKS
description: Government officials called for tighter security measures today and the police established a special investigative unit after small homemade bombs were fired this afternoon at the United States Embassy and the Imperial Palace.

title: LUDWIK KRZYZANOWSKI
description: Ludwik Krzyzanowski, editor in chief of the Polish Review, published by the Polish Institute of Art and Sciences of America, died of a heart attack Sunday at South County Hospital in Wakefield, R.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Shannock, R.I., and Manhattan.

title: New York Buildings Get Special Security
description: Special security measures for less than a dozen Federal buildings and properties in the metropolitan New York region were introduced yesterday by the regional office of the General Services Administration.

title: BROOKLYN INDUSTRIAL COMPLEX
description: AN industrial building intended to provide low rent as well as administrative support for up to six fledgling businesses is due to go up next fall in a city-sponsored industrial park in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: U.S. SEEKING CHANGES IN LATIN BANK'S POLICIES
description: The Reagan Administration is pressing for sweeping changes in the lending policies of the Inter-American Development Bank and says if these are accepted it is prepared to support a ''substantial'' increase in capital to increase future lending by the bank.

title: Propellant Explosion Kills Worker in Jersey
description: A solid propellant being tested for shipment on railroads exploded today in a remote range in a marsh, killing one man and injuring another, the authorities said.

title: Making Music
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: DAVIS SAYS THAT CBS VETOED BID
description: Marvin Davis, the billionaire oilman, said yesterday that he had offered to buy CBS Inc. for $160 a share, or $3.75 billion in cash, but that the company turned him down.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Amoco Corp., Chicago, has nominated Ruth S. Block, executive vice president and chief insurance officer of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, to the board of directors.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Yankees vs. Montreal Expos, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 7:30 P.M. (Radio -WABC, 770; 7:14 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs.

title: HOLY WAR, HOLY WEEK
description: It's odd that the Reagan Administration chose the Christian Holy Week to risk a holy war with Colonel Qaddafi and his zealots in Libya, but the missiles are flying.

title: ACI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Since the company became public in June 1985, the year-ago quarter results were not available.

title: FINK CRITICIZES PLANS TO SET ASIDE LUMP SUMS IN STATE BUDGET
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink objected today to proposals that the Legislature set aside large sums of money now for particular programs but not vote until later in the year on the specifics of how the money should be spent.

title: Dining Alone
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BROILING is probably the single most important cooking technique for those who want to spend as little time as possible in the kitchen. An omelet can also be made quickly, but it is far too limited where flavors and textures are concerned.

title: Orders to Admit Pupils With AIDS Overturned
description: A three-judge appeals panel today overturned orders by the New Jersey Education Commissioner intended to force two local school districts to admit pupils with AIDS.

title: Erik Bruhn Hospitalized
description: Erik Bruhn, the artistic director of the National Ballet of Canada and a former star with American Ballet Theater, has entered a Toronto hospital for treatment of lung cancer. Mr. Bruhn, who is 57 years old, became the Toronto company's director in July 1983 after a career in his native Denmark and other countries as one of ballet's finest danseurs nobles. Greg Patterson, a National Ballet spokesman, said that Mr. Bruhn's illness was discovered during recent tests and that he was continuing to be ''involved in the company's decision-making process.''

title: HERITAGE INTERNATIONAL BANK reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Meese Is Visiting Pakistan
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d arrived today for a two-day visit to show American support for Pakistan's policy toward Afghanistan and its fight against drugs. He will see some of the three million Afghan refugees here when he visits a camp in Peshawar on Wednesday. He is also scheduled to meet President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: HAITI'S FREEDOM, WASHINGTON'S WORDS
description: Haitians who risked all to end nearly three decades of dictatorship hoped for more than a mere change of faces at the top. But in the first six weeks of the new regime not even that cosmetic change was fully achieved. As the junta's leader, Gen. Henri Namphy, moves to contain spreading unrest, a Reagan Administration rightly proud of its role in speeding the departure of his predecessor, Jean-Claude Duvalier, needs to make clear its continued support for Haiti's democrats.

title: Judge Blocks the City's Ban On Midtown Truck Deliveries
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has temporarily barred the city from putting into effect a regulation banning truck deliveries on two midtown streets.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for 12mo to Feb 28
Adoption Has Long Been Part of Human Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Fazio Hard at Work
description: As the new defensive coordinator at Notre Dame, Foge Fazio doesn't have as much pressure on him as he did as the head coach at Pittsburgh, and he doesn't have the full range of responsibilities a head coach has. This does not mean that Fazio is taking it easy in his new position as an assistant to Notre Dame's head coach, Lou Holtz.

title: Concern Over Hostages
description: Some officials here expressed concern today about the fate of American hostages held by Moslem extremists in Lebanon in light of the clashes between Libya and the United States.

title: U.S. SAYS ONE VESSEL IT HIT HAD COME WITHIN 10 MILES
description: A Libyan missile patrol boat, equipped to carry antiship missiles, came within 10 miles of American ships that were protecting United States carriers in the Mediterranean before it was destroyed by American forces, a Pentagon official said today.

title: 5 STUDENT DEATHS MARK SPRING BREAK IN FLORIDA
description: The deaths of five college students in falls while vacationing in Florida comes at a time when this mecca for those engaging the annual rite of the spring break has tried to control the visitors' public drinking and behavior.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Announced that Dave Gumbert, John Abrego, and Ron Meridith, pitchers, would be assigned to minor league teams.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: The figures are a pro forma basis. The company had been a wholly owned unit of Revco D.S. Inc. General Computer commenced operations as a publicly held company on March 4, 1986.

title: VIDEO CASSETTE DEVELOPMENTS
description: LIKE a car in every garage, there will be a video cassette recorder in every living room, analysts are predicting. They say the home video industry, now celebrating its 10th year, can expect another decade or more of spectacular growth.

title: MUSIC: LORIN MAAZEL LEADS THE PITTSBURGH
description: LORIN MAAZEL has been without a full-time post since his unexpectedly early departure from the Vienna State Opera in 1984, and the Pittsburgh Symphony has been without a music director since Andre Previn's withdrawal in the same year. The conductor and the orchestra, who appeared together Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, have been playing musical footsie ever since.

title: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
OREGON IN A DITHER OVER ILLEGAL BREAD
description: The man who set off the Great Portland Bread Crisis still isn't quite sure how it happened. ''I was a little surprised that it got so blown out of proportion,'' said Leonard Kunzman, director of the Oregon Department of Agriculture. ''There must have been no news in the paper that day.''

title: Lure of the Great Indoors
description: Indoor soccer complete with accouterments - Astroturf and dasher boards - didn't disappear entirely from the metropolitan area when the Arrows folded two years ago or when the Cosmos went kaput a season later. Shep Messing, the goalie who played for both those teams, now operates two indoor arenas on Long Island, in Setauket and Syosset, and there's a third such facility up in Glastonbury, Conn., outside Hartford. The arenas are home to amateur leagues of players weaned on a sport that the Major Indoor Soccer League brought forth in 1978.

title: Call for U.N. Council Session
description: George Agius, the chief delegate of Malta, today requested an urgent meeting of the Security Council to discuss ''the grave situation which has arisen in the central Mediterranean and to consider what appropriate action could be taken to reduce tension and restore peace and stability in the region.'' Council members are to begin private consultations on Wednesday.

title: Congress; I'll Scratch Your PAC if You'll Scratch Mine
description: The dramatic growth of political action committees owes much to those who sought to fight fire with fire.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHTS TO RESUME UNDER STRICT RULES, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The new director of the space shuttle program said today that flights would resume under extremely conservative rules, and he asserted that such an approach would not impede the nation's space endeavors.

title: Tiffany Windows Stolen At Brooklyn Cemetery
description: Three Tiffany stained-glass windows were stolen from mausoleums in the Salem Fields Cemetery in Brooklyn over the weekend, the police said.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 28
LIBYA: TEST OF WILLS
description: The military clash between Libya and the United States during the last two days represents a confluence of varied elements. On the surface, it is the American assertion of its right of passage through international waters in conflict with Libya's territorial claims.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SLASHES ITS OFFERING OF BONDS
description: Massachusetts, which orginally planned to sell $215 million of general obligation bonds, is instead offering $100 million of the securities while the memory lingers of last week's virtual paralysis of credit markets. The state, which was worried that the size of the issue might be unattractive in an uneasy atmosphere, initiated the cut in the size of its financing.

title: COSTS IN NEW YORK AREA FALL 0.2%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in February, the first decrease since October 1984, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: ON BLUE DEVILS' CAMPUS, THERE'S NO FRENZY SO FAR
description: At 9 o'clock Monday morning, Tommy Amaker was sitting alone in a room in the Social Psychology Building here on the campus of Duke University waiting for his class - The History of the American Economy - to begin when a classmate wandered by. ''She said, 'Nice game,' '' Amaker recalled. ''That was all she said. That was it. That was the victory celebration.''

title: TURNER CONTROL OF MGM/UA
description: After months of uncertainty about whether he could pull it off, the entrepreneur Ted Turner took control of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company today and was expected to immediately begin selling off some of its assets to reduce the huge debt he is incurring.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD CURB ON YARMULKE
description: Broadly asserting the primacy of military discipline over constitutional rights, the Supreme Court ruled today that the military can bar an Orthodox Jewish officer from wearing a yarmulke indoors while in uniform.

title: EX-PRINCIPAL FROM BROOKLYN IS APPROVED AS STATE REGENT
description: For nearly 40 years, Adelaide L. Sanford shepherded thousands of schoolchildren through their multiplication tables and their first field trip outside Brooklyn.

title: ASHLAND OIL SEEN AS BELZBERG TARGET
description: Ashland Oil Inc., a Kentucky refiner and marketer, said yesterday that it had been informed that the Belzberg family of Canada had accumulated 8 to 9 percent of its stock in a move viewed by Wall Street as a possible prelude to a takeover try.

title: HOUSEHOLD TO BUY DYSON'S HOLDINGS
description: The Household International Corporation said it would buy almost all of its common and preferred stock owned by the Dyson-Kissner-Moran Corporation for about $190 million. The purchase of Household's 500,000 common and 1.8 million preferred shares completes the previously announced share repurchase program that began in January.

title: Right to Strike
description: To the Editor:

title: DECISION DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
QADDAFI THREATENS A WIDER STRUGGLE
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi said tonight that he was ready ''for war'' with the United States over the Gulf of Sidra.

title: BROOKLYN RENEWS A SYMBOL OF PRIDE
description: The Italianate-style courtroom with cast-iron columns and arches where in 1939 a young lawyer, Thomas E. Dewey, helped prosecute corrupt officials, is now full of dust and scaffolds.

title: OTHER CYCLISTS RESENT DAREDEVILS ON WHEELS
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM VALENTINO, A PRACTICAL ELEGANCE
description: PARIS, March 25 - Valentino's collection is one of the hits of the current season.

title: HOLIDAY STOCK SALE
description: The Holiday Corporation, the largest hotel company in the world, said the estate of William F. Harrah and a trust created under his will to benefit his sons would sell one million Holiday Corporation common shares. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Holiday said the estate obtained the shares in exchange for convertible debentures issued to it when Holiday Inns Inc., a subsidiary, acquired the Harrah's Casino Gaming Company in 1980. Holiday will receive no proceeds from the sale, a company spokesman said.

title: TO VIEW SCHIZOPHRENIA WITHOUT STIGMA
description: To the Editor:

title: GAME WITHIN A GAME
description: By 10:30 A.M. yesterday, fans were already surging into the bleachers, the only way they were going to see two recent pennant winners, the Tigers and the Cardinals, since all reserved seats had long been sold.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Executive Changes column in Business Day on Monday misidentified a new executive vice president for the Paper Corporation of America. He is Niel Christensen.

title: Union Moves to Control Local in Hormel Strike
description: The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union today moved to take over a dissident local that has been waging a seven-month-old unauthorized strike against the Geo. A. Hormel & Company's meatpacking plant in Austin, Minn.

title: HELEN A. MURPHY
description: Helen A. Murphy, who was for more than 45 years the director of the Children's Theater and the Adult Theater of Greenwich House, a community center in lower Manhattan, died Friday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 96 years old and lived in Pigeon Cove, Mass.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Vanderbilt Event Winners Excelled in Home Stretch
description: The winners of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams in Portland, Ore., Sunday night are a remarkable fighting foursome.

title: PHILADELPHIA REACHES ACCORD ON REBUILDING
description: The rebuilding of most of the 61 houses destroyed in the confrontation with the radical group Move halted abruptly today as a result of a financial dispute between the city and the building contractor. But a tentative agreement reached tonight appeared to clear the way for work to resume.

title: NEC FILES CHIP SUIT
description: In the continuing United States-Japan trade dispute over semiconductors, the NEC Corporation, a Japanese electronics manufacturer, has filed a countersuit against the Japanese subsidiary of Texas Instruments Inc.

title: LOSING THE FIGHT TO HOUSE THE NATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What you have is the equivalent of an individual walking on a public road and getting shot at and then feeling that it's perfectly required under those circumstances for his safety to deal with other elements of the same group that fired the first shots at him.

title: DANCE: GARTH FAGAN, 'MASK MIX MASQUE'
description: GARTH FAGAN'S Bucket Dance Theater, celebrating its l5th anniversary, opened for a week at the Joyce Theater last night and there is no doubt that the company from Rochester has a vociferous and enthusiastic following in New York.

title: West German Seized in East
description: The East German Government's press agency today reported the arrest of a West German man on suspicion of spying. The man was identified only as Rolf B.

title: The U.N. Today; March 26, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 2 MORE LIBYAN VESSELS SUNK AND BASE HIT AGAIN, U.S. SAYS, VOWING TO KEEP UP PATROLS
description: United States naval forces launched additional attacks against a Libyan missile site and against Libyan patrol vessels overnight and today, the Reagan Administration said.

title: LOS ANGELES MAYOR SKIRTS COURT ISSUE
description: With the record of the state's top judge looming as the dominant issue in this year's race for Governor, the challenger, Tom Bradley, said today that he would neither support nor oppose her retention nor judge her performance on the bench.

title: OFFICIALS DETAIL HEALTH HAZARDS AT CITY SHELTER
description: State health officials cited a number of serious hazards yesterday at the city's shelter for homeless families in lower Manhattan and said they would order the removal of the 320 people there if the problems were not corrected immediately.

title: Famine Relief Auction
description: An auction to benefit the Live Aid fund for African famine relief will be held today at 8 P.M. at the Hard Rock Cafe, on 57th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for 13wks to Feb 1
description: b-Including $340,000 from the cancellation of a senior officer's retirement plan. The latest results consisted of 13 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year, compared with the year- earlier 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
GENERAL SEEKS TO RETAIN ANTIMISSILE 'OPTION'
description: The director of a program aimed at exploring a high-technology defense against nuclear missiles said today that one of his goals was ''to protect an option'' for early deployment of a defense modeled on present antiballistic-missile technologies.

title: State Department; Diplomacy and Drugs
description: In just a few days, Jon R. Thomas is leaving his job as the State Department's senior ''narc,'' pleased with his successes, he says, but realistic too as he reflects on the limits of what Government, and especially diplomacy, can do to hinder the international flow of illegal drugs.

title: SURGEON GENERAL WARNS ON SNUFF
description: The Surgeon General of the United States, C. Everett Koop, said today that the recent significant rise in the use of snuff and chewing tobacco could result in more cancer and other illnesses among users.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
NEW ILLINOIS ISSUE TOTALS $200 MILLION
description: Despite the uneasiness of issuers and investors, market conditions remained firm enough for a $200 million issue of Illinois general obligation refunding bonds to be offered through underwriters led by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: BULLS SET BACK KNICKS, 111-98
description: The Knicks, already undermanned because of injuries to their players, were without their coach tonight as they lost, 111-98, to the Chicago Bulls.

title: REAGAN BASED MISSION APPROVAL ON REPORTS OF DANGER TO ENVOYS
description: President Reagan approved a plan to engage Libyan forces in the Gulf of Sidra after intelligence reports disclosed that Libya was trying to ''pinpoint'' American diplomats for possible terrorist attacks, White House officials said today.

title: Letter: On Disability Insurance; New Judicial Hurdle for the Handicapped
description: To the Editor:

title: ALC COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company was formed as a result of the business affiliation between Allnet Communication Services Inc. and Lexitel Corp. The ALC operating results for the 3-month period reflect only those of the operating subsidiary, Allnet, prior to the affiliation with Lexitel. The Lexitel Corp.'s results for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1985 included revenue of $127,153,000 and net income of $2,774,000, compared revenue of $67,593,000 and a net loss of $5,335,000 for the same period a year ago.

title: LAWMAKERS SAY NEW RAID WILL HELP CAUSE OF CONTRAS
description: Congressional leaders said today that a reported thrust into Honduras by Nicaraguan troops would strengthen President Reagan's request for $100 million in aid to the insurgent forces that are trying to topple the Nicaraguan Government.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON AMENDMENT
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today defeated, 66 to 34, a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget. A two-thirds majority, 67 votes, was necessary for passage.

title: In Lebanon, 5 Forgotten Americans
description: It's hard to find mention in the European and American press of what the United States is doing to free its hostages who remain in Lebanon. The Reagan Administration's ''quiet diplomacy'' remains quiet. The forgotten Americans remain forgotten.

title: AMIGA MARKDOWN
description: Commodore Business Machines Inc., said it would offer a $500 discount on its Amiga personal computer from April 7 through May 31.

title: CONISTON OFFERS NL 2 PROPOSALS
description: Coniston Partners, an investment group, yesterday offered to buy NL Industries, proposing two alternative ways of payment.

title: IS EUROPE CONTRARY
description: Europeans seem predictably contrary. Why?

title: Rockets' Sampson Not Seriously Hurt
description: Ralph Sampson, who briefly lost the feeling in his right leg after a fall Monday night, accompanied the Houston Rockets as they left Boston for Indianapolis yesterday afternoon for tonight's game against the Pacers. The 7-foot-4-inch center will not play in the game, however, and his status was listed as day-to-day for the remaining two games on the team's road trip, against the Pistons Friday and the Bullets on Saturday.

title: U.N. DINING ROOM IS LABOR BATTLEFIELD
description: More than 200 waiters, waitresses, bartenders and other food-service workers here, many of them employed for decades, are about to lose their jobs and say the United Nations, an organization dedicated to the spirit of fair play, has done little to help them.

title: ALLIES' SUPPORT TEMPERED BY CONCERN
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, today criticized the American naval activity off Libya, saying ''Italy does not want wars on its doorstep.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS OF JUSTICES
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision today that upheld a military ban on wearing yarmulkes and other headgear indoors while in uniform, and from the dissents. Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,735,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,354,000. The latest year results reflect $932,000 in acquisition-related and non-recurring expenses. The 1985 results reflect two months of operations of Nico Inc., which was acquired Oct. 31, 1985.

title: Haiti Asks Extradition Of Police Chief in Brazil
description: Haiti has requested the extradition from Brazil of the former police chief of Port-au-Prince, Col. Albert Pierre, who has been accused of murder, torture and other human rights abuses.

title: OFFICIALS INVESTIGATE ACCUSATIONS OF KICKBACKS AT TAXI COMMISSION
description: Federal, state and city investigators are looking into assertions that taxi owners are often forced to pay bribes at inspection stations for the Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Chilean TV Cuts Foreign Film Oscar
description: Chile's state television channel, controlled by the Government, cut the best foreign film award to Argentina's ''Official Story'' from its live broadcast of the Oscar ceremonies on Monday.

title: Knots
description: Donald T. Regan, the White House chief of staff, was on Capitol Hill yesterday lobbying for Senate approval of the legislation for financial aid to the Nicaraguan rebels that the House defeated last week. When he emerged from a meeting with the majority leader, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, he was wearing a navy blue tie inscribed over and over with the slogan ''Don't Give Up the Ship.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANOTHER MARVELOUS THING. By Laurie Colwin. 130 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: YARMULKE: A SIGN OF PIETY
description: Orthodox Jewish men keep the head covered as a sign of reverence.

title: BRIGHT FUTURES FOR SOME, BLEAK PROSPECTS FOR MANY
description: ''I think my work history is going to be the pattern for many younger women in the future,'' said 63-year-old Ella Wright, who retired three years ago as director of shareholder relations at the Sun Oil Company in Pennsylvania.

title: FAMILIES SAY REMAINS OF 2 ASTRONAUTS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED
description: The remains of two of the astronauts killed when the space shuttle Challenger exploded over the Atlantic have been identified, their families say.

title: NICARAGUA DENIES ITS TROOPS INVADED HONDURAS
description: Nicaragua denied today that its troops had participated ''in any invasion'' of Honduras.

title: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF U.S. ON LIBYA
description: The Soviet Union today condemned United States military actions against Libya, but stopped well short of threatening to intervene.

title: P & F INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $496,000 for the quarter and $1,107,000 for the year. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $373,000 for the quarter and $446,000 for the year. The 1984 figures include results of Florida Pneumatic Manufacturing Corp. from March 29, 1984, the date of its acquisition.

title: Galaxy Air Suspended From Military Charters
description: An unattended oil leak prompted the Air Force to suspend Galaxy Airlines from further charter flights until inspectors are satisfied the carrier has cleared up maintenance problems, a spokesman said today.

title: Fiber and Sodium
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NEW INDOOR GRILL: VERSATILE AND SAFE
description: GRILLING foods in a fireplace is often more romantic than practical, especially if you lack the proper equipment. Some fireplace grills on the market are awkward to use and difficult to assemble. Others are flimsy and dangerous. The Tuscan Fireplace Grill pictured here is one of the best I have seen. It came to my attention through an associate of Alice Waters of Chez Panisse restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., where it is used for all kinds of open-fire cooking.

title: FED'S FUTURE AFTER MARTIN
description: THE events surrounding the departure of Preston Martin as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board have been disturbing for everybody concerned. Nominally, the chairman, Paul A. Volcker, often called ''the second-most powerful man in the country,'' comes out the winner. But, as one veteran Fed-watcher, Lawrence A. Krause of the Brookings Institution, puts it, ''Paul has been hurt, even though Martin is leaving.''

title: AUTO SALES DOWN 17.2% IN MARCH 11-20 PERIOD
description: Automobile manufacturers said today that they sold 226,712 new American-made cars in the March 11-20 period, a 17.2 percent decline from last year at this time. Light-truck sales of 108,679 fell 7.4 percent in the same period, bringing total light vehicle sales, including cars and light trucks, to 335,391, down 14.3 percent from mid-March 1985.

title: Naval Spy Trial Hears Description of Security
description: A Navy communications expert testified today in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth that a ship's communication center was its ''vital lifeblood'' and took several years to rebuild once its security had been compromised.

title: Chairman to Resign At Todd Shipyards
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, the nation's largest independent shipbuilder, said yesterday that John T. Gilbride will resign as chairman and chief executive in July.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The latest quarter and year nets are after provision for loss on sale and disposition of assets.

title: ADULT ADVICE Ptui!
description: Once, the first pack of cigarettes followed hard on the heels of the first pair of long pants. Not anymore. Now more teen-age girls than teen-age boys take up smoking.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
TRACING A TRAIL OF CORRUPTION
description: The fuse that ignited the corruption investigations focusing on the New York City Parking Violations Bureau was lighted 950 miles from the city almost two years ago.

title: CITIES FINDING THAT ART OFTEN BEAUTIFIES BUDGETS
description: Cities around the country are increasingly embracing the arts as a key to economic development, investing millions of dollars in cultural activities despite strained municipal budgets and fading Federal support.

title: EASTER GOINGS-ON BEYOND THE PARADE
description: KATHRYN BESARANY will put eggs in her rock garden in Mountain Lakes, N.J., and Anita Tighe will make Easter Bunny tracks with a powder puff in Garden City, L.I.

title: A Comparison Of Indicators
description: How closely does the Dow Jones industrial average track the stock market as a whole?

title: AND AFTER TATTOOING?
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: GUARNERI STRING QUARTET
description: ONE of Haydn's most curious and most problematical works is ''The Seven Last Words of Our Saviour on the Cross,'' which received an efficient and ultimately affecting performance last night at Alice Tully Hall by the Guarneri String Quartet. John Houseman read the words (which are not single words at all but famous Latin phrases taken from the New Testament), as well as a terse commentary provided by Sidney Feshbach. Mr. Houseman, with a keen sense of when theatricality should not intrude, spoke his lines in a restrained way that avoided false drama. The result was a performance that promoted contemplation but never lapsed into the oily piety that is always a danger in such devotional enterprises.

title: Politics; Watching Kennedy Not Run for President
description: He remains a political superstar, attracting crowds, money and the news media. He has traveled extensively on three continents and conferred with world leaders. Yet three months after stunning the political world by announcing that he would not be a candidate for President in 1988, Senator Edward M. Kennedy says he relishes his freedom from Presidential politics.

title: PANEL PUSHES WIDER USE OF ANTI-CLOTTING DRUGS
description: A Federal scientific panel recommended today that all surgery patients over the age of 40 years receive drugs to prevent blood clots, a common complication that kills more than 50,000 people annually.

title: RIGHTS GROUP SEEKS CHANGES AT CBS OUTLET
description: Operation PUSH, the minority group behind the boycott of CBS's Chicago television station, has asked the station to sign an agreement mandating dramatic increases in the number of minority anchors, reporters and managers.

title: 'CURRENTS' LOOKS AT INSURANCE COSTS
description: WHY are insurance costs so high? ''Currents'' doesn't really answer, but it's doing a service by asking. Rising insurance costs, the program argues, imperils individuals, businesses and whole communities. Meanwhile, there is no end in sight. This segment of ''Currents,'' Channel 13's weekly series on societal change, can be seen at 8:30 tonight.

title: WHITE HOUSE TELLS OF HONDURAN PLEA
description: The White House, moving to counter criticism that it had overstated the seriousness of a reported Nicaraguan attack on rebel bases in Honduras, today made public a Honduran Government request for United States military assistance.

title: WILL OSCAR HELP LOW-BUDGET FILMS?
description: What will those golden Oscar statues mean to two low-budget art movies, both of which were distributed by Island Pictures?

title: ALLIANCE WELL SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of $15.8 million on its well servicing rigs and related equipment for the quarter and year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,000 for the quarter and including income from discontinued operations of $992,000.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTION
description: A dispatch on the Washington Talk page yesterday, about political action committees operated by members of Congress, misidentified the leadership of one such committee, Independent Action, Representative Morris K, Udall, Democrat of Arizona, the leader in 1984, relinquished that role in 1985. The new leaders are Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Representative Sala Burton of California, both Democrats.

title: COMPUTER AGE COMES TO ESKIMOS IN CANADA
description: Eskimos need iceboxes too, so 11 settlements in Canada's eastern Arctic are building walk-in freezers to store the game that hunters shoot to feed their families from the land.

title: THE DANGER IS NOT TO HONDURAS
description: It is hard to know what to make of the news of a flare-up in Honduras without knowing more precisely what Sandinista and ''contra'' Nicaraguans did there to each other. But it is easier to dope out the Reagan Administration's exploitation of the affair: it aims to use it to rush Congress into approving the $100 million aid package for the contras and the use of Americans at the fringes of the battle. Military and political events that were probably a coincidence are being turned to a contrivance.

title: LIGHT QUAKE IN VIRGINIA AREA
description: A light earthquake, measuring 3.1 on the Richter scale, was reported today in southwestern Virginia, the United States Geological Survey said. The tremor, which was centered a few miles west of Blacksburg, Va., occurred at 11:36 A.M. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, a spokesman for the Geological Survey said.

title: OLIVE DEERING
description: Olive Deering, a stage and screen actress, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67 years old.

title: U.S. SAYS IT MAY LIMIT MANEUVERS IF LIBYA STOPS ARMED RESISTANCE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that United States flight and naval operations in disputed waters near Libya may end before the scheduled conclusion next Tuesday provided that Libya did not resume armed opposition to the American maneuvers.

title: ACCORDING TO PLAN
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi is a satisfying target for American military action: a bullying menace to his neighbors, a sponsor of international terrorism. We have bloodied him now in the Gulf of Sidra. The question is what, if anything, we have accomplished by doing so.

title: JUDGE FINDS BIAS BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had discriminated against older employees and he ordered the company to pay damages estimated at more than $10 million.

title: 120 EXPOSED TO RADIOACTIVE GAS AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: A radioactive gas buildup in the Unit 1 containment building at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant resulted in 120 workers ingesting small doses of radioactive iodine, officials said today.

title: 'A DEDICATED MANAGEMENT
description: Dedication, progress and integrity were the hallmarks of the Parking Violations Bureau. So said its former director, Lester N. Shafran, who was indicted yesterday on charges of conducting the bureau's affairs to promote his own ''corrupt ends.''

title: Money, Money, Money
description: No matter where their district, candidates for national office usually find sooner or later that Washington itself is a major source of campaign donations. So candidates like to hold fund-raising affairs in the capital.

title: VIDEOTAPES STUDIED IN PALME INQUIRY
description: Swedish newspapers reported today that the police hunting for Prime Minister Olof Palme's killer had obtained several hours of videotape shot near his home before his assassination.

title: POP: ZAPP AT SOUNDS OF BRAZIL
description: ZAPP, which performed Monday and Tuesday at Sounds of Brazil, is a funk band caught between musical fashions. When the band, which is based in Dayton, Ohio, made its first album in 1980, it was allied with George Clinton's P-Funk, playing mid-tempo vamps anchored by swampy, synthesized bass lines.

title: 2 Hurt by Debris Of Fallen Balcony
description: A cast-iron balcony fell from the ninth-floor of the Chelsea Hotel onto a busy street yesterday afternoon, injuring two passers-by, the police said.

title: STRIKING UNION TO DRAFT PROPOSAL TO T.W.A.
description: The Independent Federation of Flight Attendants plans to make a new offer to Trans World Airlines today or tomorrow in an effort to end a strike by 5,700 attendants, which began March 7.

title: DON'T COME TO ME FOR POLITICAL FUNDS
description: Everyone agrees that the cost of political campaigns and the sums raised are scandalous. Incumbents are engaged in a year-round never-ending solicitation of funds to pay off an old deficit or to fund the next campaign, which frequently is unidentified. I can't change the system, but I can change my practices. So, from here on in, count me out.

title: AFTER OIL EUPHORIA, PROBLEMS WILL REMAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Forecast Of $1 Trillion
description: The international debt of 131 poor countries will pass the trillion-dollar mark this year, the World Bank predicted today.

title: DENG TELLS CHINA HE WEIGHS TIME TO RETIRE
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's 81-year-old leader, emerged from more than 14 weeks of seclusion Tuesday, saying that he had deliberately stayed out of view to demonstrate that the country's economic and social policies ''do not hinge on myself alone.''

title: ACA JOE EASTERN reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: b-Net income. c-Includes a $15,000 tax benefit.

title: Body of Girl, 9, Is Found
description: The partly burned body of a 9-year-old Washington Heights girl missing since Tuesday was found in a black plastic bag in Fort Tryon Park yesterday morning, the police reported. The girl, Bertha Acquaah, who lived three blocks away on Broadway Terrace, was reported missing by her parents on Tuesday when she did not return home school. Early today the girl's stepmother, who was not named, was being questioned by detectives.

title: Crash Course
description: Red Auerbach assesses the biggest thing in Navy's armada, David Robinson: ''He's got a lot to learn, but not that much.''

title: CONCERT: 'OPERA' BY HILDEGARD
description: THERE have been all manner of women's concerts in recent years, but surely no composer brought to new popularity by feminism can stake a greater claim to excellence than Hildegard of Bingen. Of course, the recent attention paid to this 12th-century German Bendictine abbess has something to do with the early-music movement, too. But whatever the reasons we seem to be hearing more of her music, they're to be applauded.

title: NETS FALL ON FLUKE BASKET
description: A remarkably unusual series of events for the usually luckless Cavaliers propelled them to a 110-108 victory over the Nets tonight, Cleveland's first triumph in 15 games at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: HI-PORT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $444,932 for the quarter and $537,950 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary loss of $33,492 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $1,815,751 for the year.

title: 11 in Queens Held In Car-Theft Case
description: Eleven Queens men have been charged with participating in a major ''chop shop'' operation that stole 8 to 10 cars a week in Nassau County and Queens, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: SENATE VOTES BILL FOR WATER PLANS
description: The Senate voted today to authorize new water construction projects that could cost up to $11.5 billion and, for the first time, adopted a broad requirement that beneficiaries share the costs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 1986
description: Markets

title: THE U.N. TODAY: March 27, 1986
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets on the Libyan situation at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: INERTIA DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $87,449 for the quarter and 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $231,695 for the quarter and $323,223 for the 6 months.

title: FRIEDMAN ARREST EXPECTED IN COMPUTER CONTRACT CASE
description: Stanley M. Friedman, a former deputy mayor who is the Bronx Democratic leader, will be arrested today on charges connected to a $22 million contract for hand-held computers that he negotiated in 1984 with the city's Parking Violations Bureau, his attorney said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial yesterday misstated the amount New York State expects to increase aid to local education this year. The correct figure is $500 million.

title: MUSIC: MONTREAL AND STERN
description: CHARLES DUTOIT and his Orchestre Symphonique de Montreal have for several seasons now taken and held a place among the ''hot'' attractions in Carnegie Hall's annual parade. Tuesday night, at the second program of their current visit, it took only about five minutes for them to remind us why.

title: STAGE: 'EDEN CINEMA,' BY MARGUERITE DURAS
description: BY the standards of the rest of the Marguerite Duras oeuvre, ''The Eden Cinema'' is not notably obscure; the main puzzlement is why a work so lacking in drama should be imposed on a stage. Perhaps it is meant to maintain the distinguished French writer's reputation for tedium.

title: MANILA MOVING TO RECOVER FUNDS
description: Swiss banking authorities took further steps today to freeze assets in Switzerland of Ferdinand E. Marcos, as Philippine officials began talks with Government representatives exploring ways to recover the funds.

title: IN BROOKLYN, MINOR LEAGUE OFFER BUOYS BASEBALL DREAMS
description: In the spring, baseball people say, anything seems possible. Everyone is still a winner, and any dream just might come true.

title: MEXICO SAID TO PREDICT NO RISE IN LOAN NEEDS
description: Mexico is quietly telling its lenders around the world that it will not need to increase its request for new financing this year beyond the $4 billion it forecast in December before the price of oil began to plunge, international bankers said yesterday.

title: SENATE TALKS ON NICARAGUA BREAK DOWN
description: Attempts to forge a bipartisan compromise on United States policy toward Nicaragua collapsed today as the Senate opened debate on President Reagan's request to send $100 million in aid to the guerrillas fighting to topple the Managua Government.

title: SOUTHLAND EXPECTS BIG LOSS
description: The Southland Corporation, the nation's largest independent gasoline retailer, said yesterday that it expects to report a loss of $100 million for the first quarter because of a ''substantial'' pretax operating loss and an inventory charge by its Citgo Petroleum Corporation subsidiary.

title: 10 ARE KILLED AND 86 WOUNDED
description: A car packed with four hundred pounds of TNT exploded in Christian East Beirut today, killing 10 people, wounding 80 and damaging buildings in a half-mile radius, the police and witnesses said.

title: SIFTING CLUES, OFFICER LINKS 3 SLAYINGS
description: The clues were like something out of a hardboiled thriller: a man who spoke Cantonese with a heavy Burmese accent, indicted in one murder, suspected of another and no way to link the two.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: In a $306 million refunding, the Chicago School Finance Authority is offering bonds with a maximum yield of approximately 7.772 percent for a 7 3/4 percent issue due in 2009 at a price of 99 3/4, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

title: CONCERT: STRAVINSKY PROGRAM
description: ROBERT CRAFT, the conductor and essayist whose entire career has been a curious and brilliant homage to Stravinsky, led a concert under that title for the Composers Showcase Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Its highlight was a beguiling ''Soldier's Tale'' (''L'Histoire du Soldat'') in a new version by Frank Corsaro, who also directed.

title: Pal Racz Dies in Budapest; Led Hungary's U.N. Mission
description: Pal Racz, the Hungarian delegate to the United Nations since 1980, has died here, the Government journal Magyar Hirlap reported Tuesday.

title: MARKET AND THE DOW IN STEP
description: At times, investor preoccupation with the Dow Jones industrial average has been misplaced because its performance was out of step with the rest of the stock market. But in the last six months, as the Dow surged a record 500 points, the market as a whole has followed close behind.

title: AULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
THE ADVANCE MARKS 100 YEARS OF COVERING LIFE ON S.I.
description: Ever since that spring 100 years ago when 150 copies of a four-page newspaper were printed in a small shop in West Brighton, S.I., The Staten Island Advance has been as integral a part of the borough as the beloved ferry that began operation three weeks earlier.

title: 7% Convertibles
description: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation is offering $150 million of 7 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2011 at a price of par, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. They are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by S.&P. The debentures, noncallable for the first three years, are convertible into the company's common stock at $56 a share.

title: Up to the Brim
description: Even before April showers fall, there is 547 billion gallons' worth of good news: the city's reservoirs are full for the first time since June 1984.

title: 11 IN TENNESSEE ARRESTED IN CORRUPTION INQUIRY
description: Eleven people, including a Grundy County deputy sheriff, were arrested today in an undercover investigation of narcotics and public corruption that has already led to the arrests of two sheriffs and a judge.

title: Hold That Tiger
description: Last week the Kellogg Company confirmed that it was talking to the Seoul Olympic Organizing Committee about the organizers' designation of a happy little cartoon tiger as the official logo of the 1988 Summer Games. The cereal maker's fur has been ruffled because, in its eyesight, the Olympic tiger looks a little too much like Tony the Tiger, the trademark mascot whose smiling countenance has adorned every box of Kellogg's Frosted Flakes since 1952.

title: Indebtedness Is Hell
description: In 1864, the Confederate General Jubal Early surrounded Frederick, Md., and threatened to sack the town unless he was paid $200,000. The citizens of Frederick conferred and did what one might expect.

title: DOLLAR IS HUMBLED IN JAPAN
description: Modern Japan has long been an expensive place, but for many Americans who visit or live here, things are starting to get out of hand.

title: RAINOUTS UNSETTLE YANKEES
description: Lou Piniella stood behind the desk in his office at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today trying to sort out the havoc created by an unusually pestiferous Florida rain. He was speaking to Stump Merrill, the Yankees' first-base coach, telling him to call Bobby Hofman, the club's director of player development, at the minor-league complex in nearby Hollywood.

title: 'SNOW WHITE' TO ROCK, RADIO CITY DIVERSIFIES
description: It was a peculiar sight. At a concert of the raucus, heavy-metal rock group Twisted Sister at Radio City Music Hall last January, hundreds of teen-agers in black leather were lined up to be frisked and to check their spikes at the door, and among them were grandparents with grandchildren in tow.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc. Toronto, the world's largest newsprint producer, said it would continue its inventory reduction measures by running its Canadian mills on short time in April.

title: MARRIAGE RATE FALLS 3 PERCENT
description: Americans were about twice as likely to marry as to divorce last year, but new Government statistics show the divorce rate was rising while the marriage rate was on the decline.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Waived Reggie Patterson and Lary Sorensen, pitchers.

title: BONN TO GET 'STAR WARS' ROLE
description: Administration officials said today that agreement had been reached with West Germany to have West German industry take part in the space-based missile defense program, popularly known as ''Star Wars.''

title: NBC IN OLYMPIC PACT WITH A BOYCOTT CUSHION
description: NBC signed an exclusive contract today for United States radio, television and cable broadcast rights to the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. In an innovation, the agreement provided for a credit arrangement meant to protect the network against losses from boycotts like those that marred the Olympics of 1980 in Moscow and 1984 in Los Angeles.

title: CHOOSING AN ABORTION
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Advertising; Xerox and Needham Are Reported in Rift
description: There was talk along the street yesterday that there might be a rift developing in the 17-year relationship between Xerox and Needham Harper Worldwide.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'SPECIAL RISK'
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have demonstrated that we have the right to operate in international waters.

title: CRIME CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for both latest periods include a provision of about $2.3 million to cover the company's costs of settling its class action litigation.

title: COSTCO WHOLESALE reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 16
description: b-Including tax credits of $659,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $676,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Imasco Chief Directs Expansion Campaign
description: Paul L. Pare, chairman and chief executive of Imasco Ltd., the largest producer of cigarettes in Canada, has been leading the company into new consumer product markets for almost 20 years.

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $22 million writedown of the company's oil and gas properties for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: Big-Time Bagels
description: Fraises des bois and raspberries, smoked sturgeon and smoked salmon, croissants, bagels and champagne were offered. But nobody ate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WEST SIDE STORY Among the ''Girl Crazy'' cast on opening night, Oct. 14, 1930, were Ethel Merman, the comedian Willie Howard and Ginger Rogers. The New York Times reviewer wrote that Miss Rogers was ''an oncoming young person of the type whom, at her first appearance, half of the audience immediately classifies as 'cute'.'' The reviewer said George Gershwin had written ''some good tunes, while Ira has provided tricky and ingratiating lyrics that should stimulate any ear surfeited with the usual rhyming insipidities of musical comedy.'' Some of these tunes were ''Embraceable You,'' ''But Not for Me,'' ''Bidin' My Time'' and ''I Got Rhythm.''

title: WILSON TO GO ON DISABLED LIST
description: Mookie Wilson has come further than anyone could reasonably expect. But the Met center fielder offered no argument today when he learned that the club intends to put him on the 15-day disabled list on March 30.

title: ILLINOIS UPSET: LaROUCHE INROADS AID REPUBLICANS
description: So far the big winner from last week's Illinois Democratic primary seems to be the state's Republicans. In upsets that stunned both parties, two supporters of the ultraconservative millionaire Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. snatched victories from regular Democrats in primaries for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State, the second- and third-highest state offices.

title: Advertising; Thomas Little Buying T.J. Ross & Associates
description: T.J. Ross & Associates, founded in 1904 and probably the country's oldest public relations firm, is being sold to Thomas M. Little, which, though somewhat younger, has considerable experience in the field.

title: Elly Ameling Recital
description: The Dutch soprano Elly Ameling will give a recital of German lieder set to poems by Goethe next Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. She will also sing works by Beethoven, Mozart, Schubert, Schumann, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Wolf, accompanied by the pianist Rudolf Jansen. Tickets, at $15, $12.50, $10 and $8, are available at the box office or through Carnegiecharge, 247-7800.

title: ECONOMIC 'MIRACLE' OR ILLUSION?
description: Is the United States economy really healthier than it has been for decades, and is it, as President Reagan asserts, headed for an even greater boom? Is it performing ''an economic miracle?''

title: PEASANT WHO ROSE TO THE TOP
description: Chen Yonggui, a model peasant who was brought into the ruling Politburo by Mao Zedong in 1973, but was dropped nine years later, died here of lung cancer today. He was 72 years old.

title: Patent Filing By Genentech
description: Genentech Inc. said today that it had notified seven Japanese competitors that it had filed in Japan for a patent on tissue-plasminogen activator, a substance the company hopes to sell for treatment of heart attacks. The notification, which is not unusual in Japan, puts the Japanese companies on notice that they can be liable for damages if the patent is eventually granted.

title: MURPHY TOP N.H.L. PROSPECT
description: There will be a lot of eyes watching Joe Murphy tonight in Providence Civic Center because of a special distinction. The talented 18-year-old freshman center for Michigan State is likely to be the first player from an American college team to be the first choice in the National Hockey League's entry draft in June.

title: FIGURES IN PARKING VIOLATIONS BUREAU INQUIRY
description: Marvin H. Bergman Has a general law practice in Forest Hills, Queens . . . former law partner of Donald R. Manes in the early 1960's, shortly after both men graduated from Brooklyn Law School . . . 54 years old . . . indicted for mail fraud and charged with paying more than $30,000 in bribes to Mr. Manes and Geoffrey G. Lindenauer to obtain a Parking Violations Bureau contract for a Manhattan collection agency he represented . . . accused of keeping an additional $15,000 in illegal payoffs from the company for himself . . . admitted to bar in 1957 . . . graduate of Long Island University . . . lives in Beechhurst, Queens. Stanley M. Friedman

title: PATRICK MATURING ON DEFENSE
description: Hockey players sometimes talk about the flow, as if it were some sort of invisible jetstream blowing down the ice. The object is to ''find it'' or ''get into it.'' A player may not know precisely how to place himself in the flow, but once there, he can recognize it and he does all he can to stay on for the ride.

title: THE POWER OF PATRONAGE
description: The Federal indictment handed up yesterday marked the first time in the city's deepening corruption scandal that prosecutors have sought to show that the city's political system was itself part of the problem.

title: NL Studying Coniston Bid
description: NL Industries, which has received a proposal from Coniston Partners to acquire the company, said it was studying the financial and legal issues raised by the offer. The oilfield services and chemical company, based in New York, said it would continue ''its evaluation of alternatives available to it.''

title: STAGE: 'THE TEMPEST' AT NEW AUDIENCE
description: ENCHANTMENT is the business of ''The Tempest'' and the Theater for a New Audience has gone great distances - even to classical Japanese theater and the Italian commedia dell'arte - to provide it in its production of the play at CSC Repertory. The artist Caterina Bertolotto has created gossamer light sculptures that let us share the belief of the castaways on Prospero's island that the place is magic, and Elliot Goldenthal has written virtually a complete score for this, one of Shakespeare's most musical plays. Altogether the production is a splendid vehicle to draw in the young audiences the company mostly aims for, and it's hard to imagine an adult who could resist its charm.

title: Surgery for Ruland
description: Jeff Ruland, the Washington Bullets' 6-foot-10-inch center, was scheduled to undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee this afternoon.

title: Decorative Accessories
description: THE gallery, co-owned by Sandy Peabody, Lois Ehrenkranz, Barbara McEntee, right, and Frank Pereira, far right, specializes in one-of-a-kind and limited-edition pieces by American artists and designers. The varied range in the shop, which has been in Southampton, L.I., for 12 years, includes glassware and ceramics, as well as perfume bottles and jewelry. The new branch of the Works Gallery is at 1250 Madison Avenue, between 89th and 90th Streets.

title: CALENDAR: HOUSING LECTURE
description: Brownstone Lecture, Donnell Library, 20 West 53d Street, 212-561-2154.

title: Mitsubishi Deal
description: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation and the Mitsubishi Corporation have jointly agreed to an order worth about $400 million for four 350-megwatt coal-fired power plants from the Huaneng International Power Development Corporation of China.

title: Bridge: Success of Georgia Player Is Big Surprise in Tourney
