description: The biggest surprise of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams events that ended Sunday night in Portland, Ore., was the success of Jim Whitaker of Warner Robins, Ga., playing in his first national tournament.

title: TWO EX-CITY AIDES INDICTED IN GRAFT AT PARKING AGENCY
description: Two former city officials were indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they turned the New York City Parking Violations Bureau into a criminal, racketeering enterprise that collected at least $542,000 in bribes and payoffs.

title: O'Neill to Face Inquiry By Election-Law Panel
description: The State Elections Enforcement Commission voted unanimously today to investigate charges that workers in Gov. William A. O'Neill's office have been used in his re-election campaign. The Governor has denied the charges.

title: Reynolds Issue
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries yesterday began offering $250 million of 9 3/8 percent sinking fund debentures due 2016 at a price of par, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. The debentures, rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P., are offered to yield 1 1/2 percentage points more than 30-year Treasury bonds. A sinking fund that starts in 1997 will retire 5 percent of the issue annually, resulting in a maximum average life of 20.5 years for the securities.

title: ADMINISTRATION SPLIT ON ARMS-TREATY COMPLIANCE
description: The Reagan Administration is still divided over whether it should dismantle two Poseidon submarines this spring in order to continue to adhere to the provisions of the second treaty on limiting strategic arms, Administration officials said today.

title: Mexico Sugar Price Up
description: The official price of sugar rose 25 percent today but still remains the lowest in the world for consumers, the federal Treasury Department said.

title: Advertising; Silver Anvil Winners Announced by Judges
description: The judges for the Silver Anvil Awards of the Public Relations Society of America, the most important recognition in that field, have released the names of the 33 winners who will be given the statuettes at a banquet on June 12 at the New York Hilton.

title: SPECIALISTS IN DESIGNING STORAGE SPACES
description: BASICALLY, there are three ways to cope with an inefficient clothes closet: live with it, tackle the job yourself or commission a design specialist to do it for you. If you chose a specialist, you enter the world of precision hanging systems and made-to-measure closet interiors.

title: JAPAN COURT UPHOLDS BAR ON AMERICAN'S RE-ENTRY
description: A court today upheld a Justice Ministry decision to deny a re-entry permit to an American woman because she refused to be fingerprinted when renewing her alien registration card.

title: SURINAME OFFICIAL HELD IN DRUG CASE
description: Three Surinamese men, including a high-ranking military official, have been arrested here on drug conspiracy charges.

title: Boeing Reports $3.3 Billion Deal
description: Singapore Airlines has ordered 14 of Boeing's 747-400 jumbo jets and has taken options on six more in a $3.3 billion deal that officials of the Boeing Company called the largest in commercial aviation history.

title: U.S. AND FRENCH TEAMS REPORT AIDS VIRUS FINDS
description: Competing scientists from the United States and France contended independently today that each group had discovered new viruses related to the deadly disease AIDS.

title: ZIMBABWE STILL DIVIDED ON RIGHTS FOR WOMEN
description: The friend of a newly widowed woman traveled to her home to offer sympathy. When the visitor arrived, the widow asked if she could borrow cups, saucers, spoons and forks to serve the other expected guests. The family of the widow's husband had taken most of her belongings. Under traditional law, they were entitled to do so.

title: A FILM THAT SINGS RENOVATION BLUES
description: THEY were being evicted from their apartment and needed to find a new place to live in a hurry. They were sick of the city, and the tree-shaded suburban mansion - a gracious white Colonial with big rooms and high ceilings - looked like the home of their dreams. But the decision had to be made quickly - so they bought it. That was when their lives turned into a comic nightmare.

title: ARCHITECTS MAKE STORAGE CONTRIBUTE TO DESIGN OF THE ROOM
description: FOR New Yorkers who live in small apartments under compressed circumstances, the usual solution for finding more storage is to organize closets methodically, using every cubic inch. But for some architects and designers, tight packing is only one way to increase storage capacity.

title: Forest Fires Burn in 4 States
description: More than 500 firefighters today battled a wave of forest fires that have blackened the eastern Kentucky mountains while hundreds of blazes scorched parts of three other states.

title: NUNS AT PLAY
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: GORBACHEV MAKES OFFER ON 2 NAVIES
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed today that the Soviet and United States navies leave the Mediterranean Sea.

title: TAXING OF MILITARY CONTRACTORS DEBATED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it preferred the Senate Finance Committee's approach to taxing military contractors to the more stringent method approved by the House of Representatives last year.

title: TO MAKE CLOSETS WORK, ORGANIZATION IS THE KEY
description: ''T HIS is a study in contrasts,'' Alan Flusser said, pulling open two closet doors in his Upper West Side bedroom. Indeed, two storage spaces could hardly be more different than those of the men's wear designer and his wife, Marilese, who is a fashion consultant.

title: 6 ARRESTED AT ABORTION CLINIC
description: Six protesters were arrested today after storming into an abortion clinic that was bombed twice in 1984. Equipment was damaged and two women were injured.

title: Lear Siegler Buyback
description: Lear Siegler Inc. said that it had bought back about 4.9 percent of its stock for about $54.6 million, but the company declined to give other details of the transaction or the reason for it. The company makes systems for military and commercial aerospace industries, machine tools, farm and automotive equipment and electronics. A Lear Siegler spokesman, Jack Cressman, declined to say from whom the stock had been purchased or whether the holder had indicated an intention to seek a larger share of the company.

title: AQUINO DRAWS IRE OF MARCOS LEGISLATORS
description: President Corazon C. Aquino came under criticism today from former Marcos loyalists, who called her provisional constitution a ''Magna Carta of enslavement.''

title: 2 From City Housing Agency Are Found Guilty of Extortion
description: A Federal jury in Uniondale, L.I., yesterday convicted two New York City Housing Authority employees of racketeering, extortion and income-tax evasion.

title: FESTIVAL WITH A DIFFERENCE DEVELOPS FLEDGING PLAYS
description: ''A gun will be fired during the production.'' A sign to that effect was frequently posted during last weekend's Tenth Annual Humana Festival of New American Plays at the Actors Theater of Louisville. In the course of nine plays (seven full-length, two one-act) on two stages, guns were shot, knives were brandished and a chain saw buzzed - and there were incidents of child abuse and rape. It was a festival like other festivals in the history of the Actors Theater - with several differences.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PAPERS SHOW EARLY MARCOS EXCESSES
description: A wealthy Filipino industrialist who has admitted serving as a secret financial adviser to Ferdinand E. Marcos bought property on Mr. Marcos's behalf as early as 1967, according to documents discovered in the presidential palace.

title: Advertising; McCann's Rescue Squadron
description: YES there is a special John Bergin Group at McCann-Erickson just as the trade press last summer promised there would be. And, with John F. Bergin at its head, the group is prepared to leap into the breach anyplace in the world where a McCann office needs a troubleshooter or help in landing an account or assistance in devising a new strategy for a brand.

title: BEAR & BULL GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
RUMSFELD WILL SUCCEED FORD AT EISENHOWER FELLOWSHIPS
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld will succeed former President Gerald R. Ford as chairman of the Eisenhower Exchange Fellowships, according to an announcement by Mr. Ford. The change will take place on May 28.

title: Evans Joins Pitt
description: The lack of athletic scholarships and other military recruiting restrictions didn't keep Paul Evans, the acclaimed Navy basketball coach, from taking his team to the East Regional final of the national collegiate tournament this year. Now he's getting a chance to find out what it's like to coach without one hand tied behind his back. The 41-year-old Evans was named head coach at Pitt, the Big East school that limped to a 15-14 record this season despite a wealth of talented recruits. Evans, who compiled a 119-60 record in six years at Navy, including an 80-19 record the last three seasons, succeeds Roy Chipman, who resigned the Pitt post and left coaching. Evans, calling Navy's success this year a fluke, said it was unrealistic to expect a military academy team to be among the top teams in the nation every year. Describing the Pitt job as ''just what I was looking for,'' Evans said his first task would be to impose a bit of Navy-style discipline on the Panthers. ''They need the discipline and they realize that,'' he said after a meeting with the Pitt team. ''They tailed off at the end of the season despite some good players. I don't know if the talent is as good as the press makes it out to be, but we'll find out.'' Pitt sources estimated that Evans's four-year contract would bring him about $800,000, including broadast fees, or about four times his salary at Navy. . . . Jim O'Brien, the St. Bonaventure basketball coach, was named head coach at his alma mater, Boston College, replacing Gary Williams, who resigned to take over at Ohio State. . . . George Raveling, the Iowa basketball coach, said he had withdrawn as a candidate to take over at the University of Houston but would remain a candidate for the job at Southern California.

title: YUGOSLAV DAILY JOINS IN ACCUSING WALDHEIM
description: A Yugoslav mass-circulation newspaper today published a 1947 document showing that Kurt Waldheim was wanted by Yugoslavia as a war criminal after World War II. United Nations officials reacted with concern and embarrassment to the latest report about the man who was their Secretary General from 1972 to 1982.

title: LIGHTING UP THE NIGHT
description: NIGHT lights can be a great comfort to children afraid of the dark and overnight guests unfamiliar with the layout of a house or apartment.

title: 8 KILLED IN SRI LANKA CLASHES
description: Eight people were killed in clashes involving Tamil guerrillas, Government officials said today.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $6,960,000 from repayment of debt and tax credits. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $7,180,000 from a gain on termination of a pension plan and tax credits and a loss of $5,127,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ITALY'S ANXIETY REFLECTS DISAGREEMENT WITH U.S. ON LIBYA
description: Italy's anxiety over the United States naval confrontation with Libya goes beyond worries that the conflict might worsen and reflects basic disagreements with the Reagan Administration's policy toward the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Italian political leaders said today.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:57 A.M. today and set at 10:33 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:53 A.M. and set at 10:15 A.M.

title: ICE CREAM OUTPUT RESUMES
description: State inspectors say glass found in Lady Lee ice cream could not have come from the manufacturing plant, and the plant's operator says production will resume. Production was halted and Lady Lee ice cream was recalled from 463 Lucky and Gemco supermarkets in California, Nevada and Arizona over the weekend after glass was found in products at some of the stores, a Lucky spokesman, said Monday.

title: Advertising; Another Job Guide
description: Another literary offering on the important question of how to break into the agency business is coming from Dick Wasserman, vice president ond associate creative director of Needham Harper Worldwide, New York.

title: History Will Be Kind To Reagan, 62% Say
description: A growing number of Americans believe President Reagan will go down in history as an outstanding or above-average President, according to the latest poll by the Gallup Organization.

title: JAVITS CENTER, POISED TO OPEN, IS BOOKED FAR INTO THE FUTURE
description: Ground had been broken for the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center - but not much else - when Michael R. Primavera went to work five years ago booking space inside it.

title: Princely Lad Is First
description: Princely Lad, a proven mud runner, rode a sloppy track to an upset victory over the highly regarded Big Jolt in the $26,400 Joseph O'Farrell Memorial Stakes for 3-year-olds today at Hialeah.

title: FISHER HALL FESTIVAL SET
description: The New York Philharmonic's third Horizons new-music festival, following such festivals in 1983 and 1984, will take place from May 21 through June 4 at Avery Fisher Hall, the orchestra announced yesterday.

title: MAYOR OPPOSES LAZAR IN PROJECT IN TIMES SQUARE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that if it was legally possible, he wanted to remove Michael J. Lazar as a developer in the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment plan and end his involvement in other city programs.

title: Ford Credit Notes
description: A $300 million financing by the Ford Motor Credit Company is offering 7 7/8 percent, three-year notes at a price of 99.85 to yield 7.931 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes, which are noncallable, are rated A-1 by Moody's and A by S.&P.

title: RUSSELL F. HARNEY
description: Russell Francis Harney, a retired Navy captain who was in charge of daily news briefings in Saigon in the Vietnam War and more recently was associate editor of The News and Courier in Charleston, died at home Tuesday of cancer. He was 54 years old.

title: THE DANCE: 'HARLEM HOMECOMING'
description: DURING the final curtain call at Aaron Davis Hall on Tuesday night, the members of Dance Theater of Harlem came on stage waving sparklers. That was only appropriate, for these dancers had given a sparkling performance.

title: DANCE: EVA DEAN OFFERS 'RIFFLING WITH FIFTEEN'
description: ''RIFFLING WITH FIFTEEN,'' which the Eva Dean Dance Company performed Sunday night at St. Mark's Church, contained many moments well worth watching.

title: Conflicting Stories
description: Responding to published reports that Longhorn football players have regularly received cash and other improper benefits from Texas boosters known to the players as Sugar Daddies, the University of Texas said it had hired a Houston law firm to investigate the reports, including a charge that a lawyer previously hired to investigate the activities of the boosters had himself contributed $20,000 to a booster organization. ''We'll keep the N.C.A.A. informed at all times of what our findings are,'' said the Texas athletic director, DeLoss Dodds, who said the firm of Vinson & Elkins had been engaged to conduct the new investigation.

title: SEVEN ASTEROIDS ARE NAMED FOR CREW OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Seven recently discovered asteroids were named yesterday for the seven astronauts who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: OHIO STATE WINS N.I.T.
description: The Buckeyes had talked about wanting to send Eldon Miller, their coach, off a winner and last night they did. Ohio State defeated Wyoming, 73-63, in the final of the 49th annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: TUDOR'S NEW WORLD
description: After a spring-training workout at Al Lang Field here recently, John Tudor sat in the Cardinals' locker room, in T-shirt and green walking shorts, and recalled that last season just wasn't him. He's not a star, he said, and he's not a villain. ''It's no fun to keep picking up newspapers and magazines,'' he said, ''and reading that I'm a jerk.''

title: A NEW HANDBOOK ON V.A. BENEFITS
description: The latest edition of the Veterans Administration's benefits handbook has been issued, with updated information on programs and services.

title: TARGET: ORGANIZED CRIME
description: The Federal law under which Michael J. Lazar and Lester N. Shafran will be prosecuted - the ''Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act,'' or RICO statute for short - is a broad-based law passed by Congress in 1970 and aimed primarily at pursuing and dismantling organized-crime syndicates.

title: NAVY FLIERS VOICE FEELINGS
description: Airmen of the United States Sixth Fleet who took part in retaliatiory attacks on Libya said today they regretted Libyans were killed but said the action was necessary.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
WOES SEEN AT 'ENERGY BANKS'
description: Federal banking regulators say that up to 30 percent of the nation's energy banks are in trouble or are borderline problem cases.

title: LONGER PACT ON DU PONT STAKE
description: The Seagram Company Ltd. and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced yesterday they had renegotiated a standstill agreement to limit Seagram's ownership of Du Pont stock through the end of the century and to increase Seagram's representation on the Du Pont board.

title: O'Grady Holds To Position
description: Mac O'Grady, who is facing the possibility of suspension and a $12,000 fine for conduct unbecoming a professional golfer, said today he was not going to back down from his contention that a $500 fine was improperly taken out of his tournament earnings.

title: Designated Students Win
description: Academic emphasis at little Rose-Hulman Institute in Terre Haute, Ind., is such that this year's freshmen averaged 1,220 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test, and 95 percent of them had grade-point averages that placed them among the top 10th of their high school graduating classes. On Tuesday, the Fightin' Engineers baseball team struck a small but unusual blow for the maxim that collegiate athletics can coexist with collegiate scholarship.

title: REALIGNMENT OF EUROPEAN CURRENCIES IS EXPECTED
description: Rumors of a realignment in the value of European currencies over the long Easter weekend are creating nervous trading on European currency markets, bankers and dealers said today.

title: PREVENTING AN OVERLOAD OR A SHORT CIRCUIT
description: FUSES and circuit breakers are ''safety valves'' built into electrical circuits to protect the wiring against overheating due to an overload or a short circuit. If excessive current flowed through the wires they would overheat and eventually start a fire.

title: Q & A
description: Q.Over a year ago I finished the walls in my basement with tongue-and-groove pine paneling, installing it with the rough side out. I then sealed the panels with a satin finish polyurethane. I removed some pictures recently for cleaning, and found that the paneling behind each picture was lighter than the rest of the wood. What caused this, and what I can do correct it? A. My guess is that dust in the basement air, or possibly fine soot fumes from the heating system, coated the pine paneling with a light film of soil or grime, all but where the pictures were hanging. Many have found that installing spacers behind each picture lets air circulate freely behind them, assuring that all interior paneling ''weathers'' or darkens equally.

title: Congress and Drugs
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, is requiring 50 employees in her Florida and Washington offices to undergo tests of their urine to detect drug abuse, in line with the recommendation of the President's Commission on Organized Crime that all Federal employees be given such tests.

title: Technology; Beams Reveal World of Detail
description: IN a domed building here that houses an aging cyclotron, there will soon be a new tenant - a machine capable of emitting extremely powerful light and X-rays. Such intense radiation beams will enable scientists and industrial researchers to examine materials at a new level of detail, providing information about the workings of everything from biological cells to computer chips.

title: BELZBERG FAMILY OFFERS $60 A SHARE FOR ASHLAND
description: Ashland Oil Inc. has received an acquisition offer of $60 a share from the Belzberg family of Canada, according to a filing made yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SOUTH AFRICA POLICE SAID TO KILL 30, ONE OF WORST DAILY TOLLS IN YEAR
description: At least 30 people were reported killed by the police around South Africa today. It was one of the highest 24-hour death tolls in this country in a year.

title: SCREEN: 'APRIL FOOL'S DAY' DIRECTED BY FRED WALTON
description: ''APRIL FOOL'S DAY,'' which opens today at Loew's State and other theaters in time for April Fool's Day next Tuesday, is a jocular horror film about a group of college students who spend a horrible April Fool's weekend together.

title: Hers; THE IGNOMINY OF BEING PREGNANT IN NEW YORK CITY
description: I HAVE two enduring memories of the hours just before I gave birth to my first child. One is of finding a legal parking space on 78th Street between Lexington and Park, which made my husband and me believe that we were going inside the hospital to have a child who would always lead a charmed life. The other is of walking down Lexington Avenue, stopping every couple of steps to find myself a visual focal point - a stop sign, a red light, a pair of $200 shoes in a store window - and doing what the Lamaze books call first-stage breathing. It was 3 A.M. and coming toward me through a magenta haze of what the Lamaze books call discomfort were a couple in evening clothes whose eyes were popping out of their perfect faces. ''Wow,'' said the man when I was at least two steps past them. ''She looks like she's ready to burst.''

title: RIGHTS AT TRIAL WERE NOT VIOLATED BY TROOPERS' PRESENCE, COURT SAYS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the presence of four uniformed, armed state troopers in the front row at a robbery trial did not deny the defendant's right to an unbiased jury.

title: Warner-Lambert To Sell Reichert
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it had agreed to sell its Reichert Scientific Instruments subsidiary to the Cambridge Instrument Company, a British manufacturer of scientific equipment.

title: ADULT ADVICE GUIDANCE GAP
description: During its fiscal crisis a decade ago, New York City laid off half the guidance counselors in its public schools, retaining the oldest ones. They began retiring last year, creating a sudden shortage.

title: MEESE ACCUSES SOVIET OF AFGHAN WAR CRIMES
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d of the United States accused the Soviet Union today of using torture, rape and genocide in Afghanistan as part of a drive to dominate the world.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday on a new book about the Italian financier Michele Sindona omitted the title and the author's full name. The book, scheduled for publication by Arbor House in September, is ''Power on Earth: Michele Sindona's Explosive Story,'' by Nick Tosches.

title: JURY HOLDS LITTLE ROCK PAPER'S TACTICS LEGAL
description: A Federal jury found today that The Arkansas Democrat had not engaged in an illegal effort to drive its rival newspaper, The Arkansas Gazette, out of business.

title: OLD MAN OF MEXICAN LABOR IS HARDLY A HAS-BEEN
description: Every Monday morning a group of Mexican journalists are ushered into an office here and cluster around an 85-year-old man with snow-white hair who is seated at one end of a conference table. They have come to hear his latest pronouncements.

title: U.S. Store Plan By Paris Chain
description: Printemps, the big French department store chain, will open its first United States store in Denver next year and plans a chain of similar stores in other major United States cities, the company's president, Jean-Jacques Delort, announced today.

title: Arms and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: Taking another step away from its historic unqualified support of military spending, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indusrtrial Organizations has joined a campaign calling for an actual reduction in military outlays.

title: No Headline
description: THE BAD HUMOR OF MR. SESSIONS

title: 32.20 JUMP PUTS DOW AT 1,810.70
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday to record levels, as another steep decline in interest rates brought Wall Street back to life.

title: LTV Missile Contract
description: The LTV Corporation said today that a subsidiary received an Army contract for a missile system. The company said it expects its share of the program to total between $2 billion and $3 billion. The initial award, for engineering development, is $180.4 million, it said.

title: AIDS NEEDS MEDICAL, NOT EMOTIONAL SOLUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: London Metal Clearing House
description: The London Metal Exchange has decided to conduct its trading through a clearing house, one of the exchange's most significant changes since it was founded in 1877.

title: 9 SIKHS KILLED BY POLICE IN CLASH IN PUNJAB STATE
description: The police shot dead 9 Sikhs and wounded 22 today when militants firing guns and waving swords attacked the Chief Minister of Punjab State at a mass meeting, the authorities said.

title: GRAPHIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CHOOSING AN ABORTION
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: New Top Officer Named by Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, announcing its plans for management succession, said yesterday that Robert D. Kennedy would be named president and chief executive.

title: RECITAL: ALEXANDER MARKOV
description: ALEXANDER MARKOV'S Tuesday evening concert at the 92d Street Y was the most exciting violin recital this listener has heard in quite some time.

title: Advertising; Gatefolds to Introduce Campaign for Time
description: ''Time. All that matters'' is the theme of the new campaign for the news magazine that breaks Monday in consumer and trade publications, largely as dramatic three-page, four-color gatefolds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ALBANY'S EASTER BUDGET
description: New York State's annual rush to budget before the start of the new fiscal year April 1 has produced four proposals worth noting: Tax-exempt clothes. Though personal income taxes are already scheduled to decline, the Senate's Republican majority leader, Warren Anderson, seeks additional tax relief credit with a plan to exempt clothes costing less than $75 from the state's 4 percent sales tax. The benefit, $40 saved on $1,000 of qualifying clothing per year, seems slight and would appear to benefit the middle class more than the poor. So dubious an item shouldn't be allowed to complicate the budget negotiation. Subsidized drugs. Medicare doesn't pay for prescription drugs. The Democratic Assembly would pay for those purchased by the elderly poor. In other states, the lack of any contribution by the recipient has led to abuses as the elderly acquire free drugs for relatives, or even for sale. A Senate version of the plan would pay for drugs costing more than 5 percent of the elderly patient's income and 4 percent for the elderly poor. That is clearly the better concept. Transit bridge. In the Assembly, Speaker Stanley Fink sees the probability of a transit fare increase later this year. He proposes allocating now the $28 million necessary to keep fares from rising in December. Senator Anderson agrees money will be needed, and much more in fiscal 1988, but, preferring to hold New York City's huge share hostage to programs he may push later in the year, he objects to allocating the appropriation now.

title: INQUIRIES EXPLORE LEGALITIES OF U.S.-MARCOS TIES
description: During the long presidency of Ferdinand E. Marcos, his associates made continuing efforts to strengthen Philippine business and political ties in the United States. These efforts are now the subject of investigations in the Philippines and in the United States.

title: Lev N. Smirnov Dies; Leading Soviet Judge
description: Lev N. Smirnov, one of the top Soviet jurists for nearly three decades, has died here after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: BARFIELD BLOSSOMING AS LEADER
description: It looked like any other wind-blown pop fly to right field. Jesse Barfield can still see it floating above him, the ball carrying toward the fence at Exhibition Stadium in Toronto. He can see it dropping into his glove, the catch blunting a Kansas City surge in the seventh game of the American League playoffs.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
WATER PROJECTS IN LOCAN AREAS
description: Several water projects and studies in the metropolitan area are among those under being considered in Congress.

title: CODING TECHNIQUES ARE DETAILED AT NAVY SPY TRIAL
description: Attorneys on both sides in the espionage trial of Jerry A. Whitworth continued today to struggle with the task of making the world of secret cryptography understandable to the jury within the strictures imposed for discussing classified work.

title: SCHOOLS ADOPT KOCH IDEA: COURSE IN CORRECT SPEECH
description: It began, as many city policies often do, with a complaint from Mayor Koch: too many students and teachers say ''axed'' instead of ''asked,'' so why not a ''Rain in Spain Falls Mainly on the Plain'' course, the Mayor suggested (with a whimsical bow to Henry Higgins).

title: How F.B.I. 'Bug' Was Found
description: For more than three years, a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has been trying to find out how some reputed organized-crime figures knew they were under electronic surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: A TRIUMPHANT HERITAGE REBOUNDS WITH JAYHAWKS
description: Mark Turgeon was nearly born too little and too late. Even now, in his junior year at Kansas, he is generously listed as 5 feet 10 inches and 150 pounds. In his freshman year, he wore braces on his teeth.

title: More Shuttle Identifications
description: The remains of two more of the astronauts who died in the space shuttle Challenger have been identified, relatives and space agency sources said today.

title: High Court Ruling Backs Japanese TV Makers
description: The Supreme Court gave 21 Japanese television manufacturers a victory today in an antitrust suit by the Zenith Electronics Corporation and another company, which contended that the Japanese have conspired to destroy American producers by depressing prices to unprofitably low levels in the United States.

title: THE PROBLEM OF LETTING CLOTHES STEEP
description: THE rule for keeping your clothes closet from becoming an impassable jungle is explicit. If you haven't worn it for three years, get rid of it. Give it away - to a thrift shop, a factotum or an unemployed friend who is the same size.

title: CONCERN EMPLOYING SUSPECTS IS LARGEST COLLECTION AGENCY
description: Datacom Systems Corporation, the debt-collection company that employed a former New York City official, Michael J. Lazar, who was charged yesterday with racketeering, began 23 years ago as a small data-processing service.

title: Advertising; The Insurance Industry Takes Its Case to TV
description: The television phase of the Insurance Information Institute's new advertising campaign aimed at combating the growing litigious bent will begin to run Monday.

title: MALTESE PREMIER IN TRIPOLE TALKS
description: The Prime Minister of Malta met tonight with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, in an effort to defuse the confrontation with the United States over the Gulf of Sidra.

title: Short of Goal
description: Two months ago, when Wayne Gretzky went nine straight goal-less games, there was barely a sports fan anywhere who didn't take note of the drought, the longest of Gretzky's career. Mere mortals should have it so bad.

title: DON'T JUST DO SOMETHING
description: Americans may feel gratified to see the professional bully Muammar el-Qaddafi get a punch in the nose. But beyond self-satisfaction, it is hard to see how the U.S. Navy's operations against Libya can have served any American interest.

title: MEANWHILE, IN NICARAGUA, THEY ARE FROLICKING ON THE BEACHES
description: If conditions in Nicaragua are reaching crisis proportions, it is a crisis far from the minds of most Nicaraguans this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, MARCH 27, 1986
description: International 14 U.S. Army helicopters transported a battalion of Honduran troops close to a border area where Nicaraguan Government forces were said to be fighting Nicaraguan rebels. An American Embassy spokesman in Honduras said the helicopter crews consisted of 50 American soldiers. [ Page A1, Column 3. ]

title: PRESS UNITS FRUSTRATED ON LIBYA, BUT FEW BLAME PENTAGON
description: Some news organizations expressed continued frustration today over their inability to venture into the waters off the Libyan coast, where American and Libyan forces clashed this week.

title: Locked Up Tight
description: Peter Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner, promised to tighten clubhouse security last month when he announced his decision concerning players involved in the Pittsburgh drug trials, and yesterday he made it official.

title: Market Place; Seers Bullish On Earnings
description: IT may be the onset of spring, or simply optimism over prospects for the companies they follow, but security analysts are projecting robust earnings growth of 29 percent this year for the companies represented in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

title: REPUTED CRIME FIGURE GETS 16 YEAR TERM
description: A reputed Kansas City organized crime figure, Carl DeLuna, was sentenced today to 16 years in prison and was ordered to pay more than $120,000 in fines for conspiring to skim profits from Las Vegas casinos.

title: CUTTING BACK RESEARCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Leucadia Delays On GATX
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, after reaching an agreement to acquire the GATX Corporation last weekend, said today that it was not prepared to enter into a definitive agreement because of what it termed ''new information that was significant from a financial point of view.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday with a picture of Duke University basketball players misidentified the figure to the right of David Henderson. He was not Tommy Amaker; he was unidentified.

title: C.D., Other Yields Fall Again
description: Average yields for certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds continued their downward slide for the third consecutive week in the period ended yesterday.

title: CONTINGENT FEES ARE NO GOLD MINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Revlon Sets Officer Shifts
description: Revlon Inc., making the first executive changes since it was purchased by Ronald O. Perelman in November, yesterday named Lawrence Wechsler to the new post of president of the Revlon Beauty Group-U.S. and executive vice president of Revlon Inc.

title: DECISION ON WESTWAY TRACT SHOULD PRECEDE STUDY OF LIGHT RAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome for Exile
description: After breakfast, Dr. Brademas and Preston Robert Tisch went downtown to New York University for lunch. It honored Yuri Lyubimov, the celebrated Soviet director who was stripped of his citizenship two years ago and has been roaming Europe since.

title: PENTAGON REVISES LIBYAN SHIP TOLL
description: Pentagon officials, sifting through after-action reports on fighting between American and Libyan forces in the Gulf of Sidra, today backed away from earlier statements that Navy aircraft and ship-to-ship missiles had destroyed three Libyan vessels.

title: U.S. Sues Dynamics on Overcharges
description: The Justice Department filed a civil lawsuit today against the General Dynamics Corporation, seeking to recover sums that the big military contractor is accused of fraudulently billing the Government.

title: DAISY BACON
description: Daisy Bacon, a writer and for many years editor of the now-defunct Love Story magazine, died Tuesday at her home in Port Washington, L.I. She was 87 years old.

title: Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said its shareholders had overwhelmingly approved a previously announced restructuring plan that would reduce the company's debt by about $280 million and spin off 60 percent of its troubled combine manufacturing division. The restructuring plan replaces five series of preferred shares with two new classes of preferreds.

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax loss carryforward benefit of $310,000. c-Net loss and after a $715,000 gain from the termination of a pension plan.

title: OPEN AIR MARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 9
COUNCIL AT U.N. MEETS ON U.S.-LIBYA CLASHES
description: The Security Council met today to discuss the clashes between Libyan and American naval forces.

title: No Perjury Found At the Gotti Trial
description: The Queens District Attorney's office said last night it saw ''no foundation'' for bringing perjury charges against a man whose claimed memory losses in court caused assault and robbery charges against a reputed Mafia boss to be dismissed.

title: TAKE HEART, TERRACE TILLERS
description: IF you watch for spring on a Manhattan terrace you must disregard the poet's ode to the daffodil and the naturalist who spots a trillium on a walk in the woods. You till your soil in tuns and barrels on a narrow ledge that is high in the sky but low on the list of anyone's vision of verdant paradise.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Pompano Beach, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Basketball Knicks vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Madison Square Garden. In their only other meeting this season, Rolando Blackman's 29 points and Mark Aguirre's 22 were wasted as Patrick Ewing and Gerald Wilkins combined for 44 points in leading the Knicks to a 116-112 victory in Dallas. The Mavericks are still very much in the hunt for a Western Conference playoff spot. (Television - MSG, 7:50 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:50 P.M.) Golf Tournament Players Championship, at Ponte Vedra, Fla., opening round. Calvin Peete, who has already won two tour events this year including last week's USF&G Classic, won this tournament last season with a spectacular 14-under-par 274. Johnny Mathis Senior Classic, at Los Angeles, opening round. Hockey Devils vs. St. Louis Blues, at East Rutherford, N.J., Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Blues are battling Chicago for first place in the Norris Division, but they usually have no trouble against the Devils, who haven't beaten them in 11 games since the team moved to New Jersey from Colorado. (Radio -WMCA, 570; 7:30 P.M.) Bruins vs. Montreal Canadiens, at Boston. Neither the Canadiens nor the Bruins have yet clinched a playoff spot in the Adams Division. (Television -ESPN, 7:30 P.M.) Colleges: N.C.A.A. national semifinals at Providence, R.I. Minnesota vs. Michigan State, (Television - ESPN, midnight, tape.) Other Events BOWLING: $250,00 Toledo Trust PBA National Championships. HARNESS RACING: Roosevelt, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 11:30 P.M. The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG, midnight.)

title: Texas Air Raises Stake in Eastern
description: The Texas Air Corporation said today that it had moved closer to acquiring control of Eastern Airlines by raising its stake in the Miami-based airline to the equivalent of 47 percent, from 43.5 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: A list in The Living Section yesterday of stores that carry exotic eggs misidentified a supplier of quail eggs. It is Flying Foods International, 43-43 Ninth Street, Long Island City, Queens; telephone (718) 706-0820.

title: Gulf Bid Opposed
description: The board of Hiram Walker Resources Ltd. unanimously recommended today that shareholders reject the Gulf Canada Corporation's $1.2 billion (Canadian) bid for control of the Toronto-based company. In a statement, Hiram Walker, which controls a vast array of liquor, resource and utility companies, criticized the Gulf offer as ''a coercive attempt to pressure shareholders into a hasty decision to sell their Hiram Walker shares.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Brad Ragan Inc., Spruce Pine, N.C., has elected James W. Barnett chairman and R. Melvin Morrison was elected chief executive officer.

title: Batus Income Off 28% in '85
description: The Batus Retail Group, which operates Saks Fifth Avenue, Gimbels, Marshall Field and other American retailers, suffered a 28 percent drop in net income last year on a 5 percent increase in sales, its British parent, B.A.T. Industries, said yesterday.

title: WORKERS BACK TO SITE OF HOMES
description: City officials negotiated with the contractor today over the completion date and the cost of rebuilding the 61 homes destroyed last year in the police confrontation with the radical group Move.

title: 3 DEAD IN PARIS HOTEL FIRE
description: Fire swept through the upper floors of a Paris hotel on Tuesday night, killing three people and injuring 10 others. Fire officials said today that two of the dead were West Germans. Officials said the blaze was apparently was caused by careless smoking in a second-floor room of the hotel, the Trinity Palace, in the Pigalle area.

title: SPEED VOGEL MOVES INTO CENTER RING
description: At the back of the Lone Star Cafe, where flashbulbs cast the fickle light of fame, stood Irving (Speed) Vogel. There were better-known people around him, from Abbie Hoffman to Professor Irwin Corey, but they had come to salute Mr. Vogel. For once, the sidekick was the main attraction.

title: MONDAY NIGHT: 4TH-AND-LONG
description: ''Apres moi, le deluge,'' Howard Cosell said, more or less, when he left ''Monday Night Football.''

title: AT SAINT LAURENT, GLAMOROUS CLASSICS
description: Yves Saint Laurent scored a triumph this morning with a glamorous collection of classics. Like a simply but elegantly dressed woman at a party who makes other women look overdone, he caused a lot of clothes shown in the past week to seem unnecessarily complicated.

title: Bond Prices Continue Surge
description: Bond prices, bolstered by lower oil prices and hopes that inflation will move to even lower levels, surged for the third day in row.

title: REAGAN'S MANEUVERS
description: President Reagan believes he has succeeded in bringing about a more favorable Soviet-American balance of power, thus enabling him to act with greater freedom and decisiveness around the world, according to Administration officials.

title: SHULTZ, IN ATHENS, CONDEMNS TERROR
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz publicly and privately urged the Greek Government today to take a sterner line against what he called ''the insidious threat of terrorism.''

title: Military Job Goes to Pratt
description: The Allison Gas Turbine division of the General Motors Corporation has chosen Pratt & Whitney to be the second production source for engines that will power a new tilt-rotor plane for the military, the companies said today.

title: CONVERGENT, 3COM FAIL IN MERGER PLAN
description: The proposed merger between Convergent Technologies and the 3Com Corporation has fallen apart at the last minute, the companies said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BREAK IN. By Dick Francis. 317 pages.

title: Dual-Currency Yen Bonds Set
description: In separate offerings, the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Bank of China plan yen-denominated dual-currency bonds for the Japanese capital market.

title: U.S. ARMY COPTERS CARRY HONDURANS TO BORDER REGION
description: Fourteen United States Army helicopters today transported a battalion of Honduran troops close to an area where Nicaraguan Government forces were reported to be fighting anti-Government rebels.

title: SENATE APPROVES REAGAN'S REQUEST TO HELP CONTRAS
description: The Senate tonight narrowly approved President Reagan's request to send $100 million to the rebels trying to depose the Nicaraguan Government.

title: New Medical Standards For Pilots Are Urged
description: Prospective airline pilots would be more rigorously scrutinized for heart disease and such associated risk factors as smoking and obesity under medical standards made public today by the American Medical Association.

title: NEW YORK AS RACKET ENTERPRISE
description: Stanley Friedman, the political boss of the Bronx who was indicted yesterday for fraud and bribery, might well summon impressive character witnesses for his defense. By reputation, he is much too clever and well connected an operator to resort to payoffs to win a city contract for one of his many legal clients. ''I help people do business with the city,'' he has boasted. ''No one, frankly, has got more knowledge of how government functions and operates. No one has more access to the process in the bureaucracy than I do.''

title: EQUAL SPENDING FOR EQUAL EDUCATION IS STILL THE GOAL
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMB WOUNDS 21 IN MELBOURNE
description: A car bomb exploded today in front of police headquarters, wounding 11 police officers and 10 passers-by, officials said.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''IT'S hard to say whether there's any deep, profound message in the movie,'' says Bruno Lawrence.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEF OF BRONX INDICTED ON BRIBE CHARGES
description: Stanley M. Friedman, a former deputy mayor who is the Bronx Democratic leader, was indicted yesterday on charges of bribing Donald R. Manes and a Parking Violations Bureau official to obtain fraudulently a $22 million contract for a computer company he represented.

title: Another Student Hurt in Fall
description: Tim Zahler, 19 years old, a student from the University of Minnesota, suffered a head injury in a fall from a motel balcony here Monday and is in serious condition in a hospital, officials said today. Five students in Florida for spring vacations have died so far this year in falls and six have been injured. Hotel and motel owners here said Wednesday they would ask the Legislature to change a state law so they could detain any student they saw climbing on balconies.

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Assault In East Side Crane Accident
description: The operator of a crane that toppled at an Upper East Side construction site last May pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree assault charges in the accident, in which a Manhattan woman was pinned for more than six hours, her legs nearly severed.

title: Children's Zoo Opens
description: Youngsters can don turtle shells, climb on spiders' webs and sit in birds' nests this weekend as the Children's Zoo season opens at the Bronx Zoo, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road.

title: Sindona Confederate Vanishes in Sicily
description: Rosario Spatola, a convicted Mafia member linked to the poisoned financier Michele Sindona, has disappeared and may have fled to the United States, police sources said today.

title: Hormel Talks Put Off
description: Negotiations between Geo. A. Hormel & Company and meatpackers who struck the Hormel plant here seven months ago have been postponed until next week because of scheduling problems. Lynn Huston, vice president of Local P-9 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, and Charles Nyberg, Hormel's senior vice president, announced the postponement Wednesday. The strikers have rejected a $10-an-hour wage in a three-year contract.

title: Keep Out
description: Don Fehr, the head of the Major League Players Association, had no immediate reaction, but at least one player agent believes that Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's new guidelines barring friends, agents, lawyers, business associates, equipment salesmen and others from major league locker rooms, dugouts and playing fields is long overdue.

title: SCHOOLS' VIEWS SOUGHT ON PROPOSED VATICAN RULES
description: The Vatican is seeking educators' comments on proposed rules designed to give the church greater control over what is taught and who teaches it in Roman Catholic colleges and universities around the world.

title: THEATRICAL PAIR TRY OFFBEAT CASTING
description: In white socks and black high-top sneakers, Billy Hopkins arrived at the Ensemble Studio Theater on his five-speed bicycle and said hello in his one-of-a-kind, high-pitched voice. Risa Bramon recalled their first meeting, backstage. ''I said, 'Who's that weird guy with the high voice?' ''

title: ILLEGAL SOLICITING FROM PATIENTS IS CHARGED TO 3
description: Two of New York City's most prominent nursing homes and three of their officials were indicted yesterday on charges of soliciting $55,000 in contributions in return for admitting Medicaid patients.

title: WHERE THE AUDIENCE COUNTS AS MUCH AS THE COMICS
description: ''I THINK theater is a conversation between the stage and the audience,'' said Randy Nelson, known as Alyosha of the Flying Karamazov Brothers. ''It's a conversation in which one party has the bulk of the speech, but we're all there in one room together; the artist is important and so is the theatergoer, because both are shaping the waveform in that room. If, as an actor, you don't spend your entire energy listening, you're just not doing the job.''

title: SUGARBUSHES READY, WEATHER PERMITTING
description: A little later than usual because of consistently cold weather, the maple syrup season has finally arrived in the sugarbushes of upstate New York and Connecticut. Paradoxically, if the weather is too good this weekend, the crop may be adversely affected.

title: 2 MORE BLACKS REPORTED SLAIN BY POLICEMEN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Two more blacks were reported slain by the police in ambiguous circumstances today, and a newspaper accused the police of ambushing black protesters from behind.

title: WESTINGHOUSE FOUND GUILTY OF 'BLATANT, WILLFUL' AGE BIAS
description: A Federal district judge ruled Wednesday that the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had discriminated against older employees and ordered the company to pay damages estimated at more than $10 million.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC IN TWO COPLAND WORKS
description: THE New York Philharmonic's season-long celebration of Aaron Copland's 85th birthday moves on apace. Only one more program, the season's finale, remains in what has been as comprehensive a retrospective as any contemporary composer has been treated to by the orchestra in many a year, if indeed ever. Last night's concert included two Copland works that grew out of commissions: the 12-tone ''Inscape,'' written for the Philharmonic's 125th anniversary in 1967, and the 1950 Clarinet Concerto, done at the behest of Benny Goodman, who was soloist at the first performance.

title: NEW ALAMITO OFFER
description: The Alamito Company said that the Ventana Electric Company had raised its leveraged buyout offer to $147 a share in cash, or $335.2 million, and that its special shareholders meeting to vote on the merger has been rescheduled from Saturday to Monday. Ventana, which raised its offer from $140 a share, is restricted by a temporary restraining order from consummating the merger pending a preliminary hearing on Monday. Three competing bids have been made for Alamito.

title: 'New Television' Series Offered on Channel 13
description: A series called ''New Television'' is now in its second season of half-hour shows on Channel 13. It is designed as a showcase for independent film makers, presenting what the producers call ''innovative video art.'' Innovative, probably; video, undoubtedly; as for art - well, a series of 13 shows by different producers, directors, writers and performers is bound to be uneven in style and quality. The same could probably be said for any 13 first (or even second) novels.

title: A Protest at Base in Spain
description: About 80 anti-NATO protesters demanding the dismantling of United States military sites in Spain marched to the Navy base in Rota today, the police said. Rota, in southern Spain, is one of four joint Spanish-United States bases.

title: AMID TENSION, EUPHORIA STAYS
description: EUPHORIA is the order of the day on Wall Street. Market sages, remembering 1929 and other disasters, tell us that euphoria always self-destructs and that belief in a ''new era'' is always the beginning of the end.

title: FILM: 'TROUBLE IN MIND,' WITH KRIS KRISTOFFERSON
description: RAINCITY is a misty town, outdoors and in, but not nearly as misty as ''Trouble in Mind,'' which is set there, wherever there is. Alan Rudolph's latest movie, which opens at Cinema 1 today, seems to be striving to say something but isn't able to break through the fog of his script.

title: The Blasters
description: The Blasters, a California rock band, will perform tonight and tomorrow at the World, 254 East Second Street, near Avenue C and Houston Street.

title: Parking Bureau Cuts Backlog
description: The city's Parking Violations Bureau has reduced the backlog of one million unprocessed parking tickets that have piled up since the emergence of the corruption scandal involving the agency, according to Joseph Bruno, the agency's director.

title: GOOD FRIDAY CLOSINGS
description: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. The credit markets will also be closed, as will most foreign stock markets. Government offices and most businesses, however, will be open.

title: THE REAGAN DOCTRINE
description: The Reagan Administration Foreign Policy (regional division) has two immediate personal objects: to bring down the totalitarian regimes of Muammar el-Qaddafi and Daniel Ortega.

title: GOOD FRIDAY RITE REFOCUSES THE ROLE OF JEWS
description: St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan will replace the traditional Good Friday Gospel reading about Jesus' Crucifixion with a dramatic liturgy that is free of references the church's pastor regards as anti-Jewish.

title: EXXON NAMES HEAD OF NEW GLOBAL UNIT
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that Richard G. Reid, president of Esso Europe Inc., a subsidiary, had been named president of the new international oil and gas organization.

title: ROCKET HITS TOWN IN ISRAEL, AND ITS JETS RETALIATE
description: A rocket struck a town in northern Israel today, and hours later Israeli Air Force planes attacked Palestinian targets around the Lebanese port city of Sidon.

title: CORRUPTION STUDY MAY LAST 2 YEARS
description: Investigations of corruption in the New York City government are likely to go on for two more years, a key Federal investigator said yesterday, as Federal agents and prosecutors pursue allegations about wrongdoing beyond the Parking Violations Bureau.

title: PRESIDENT BUYS STATIONS OF METROMEDIA RADIO
description: Thirty years have passed since Carl C. Brazell Jr. first sat in front of a microphone as a 15-year-old newscaster.

title: For Renting, a Proposal For an Intelligible Law
description: Nothing is simple about rental housing in New York City. But the State Housing and Community Renewal Commissioner, William B. Eimicke, thinks one thing could be simpler - the Rent Stabilization Code.

title: WALDHEIM CHARGES 'CONSPIRACY' AGAINST HIM
description: Kurt Waldheim says in an interview published today by a Belgrade daily that the publication of documents asserting that he joined in Nazi war crimes in Yugoslavia was part of an ''almost incomprehensible conspiracy.''

title: Shock Waves Found Effective For Some Gallstone Patients
description: Shock wave therapy, which has revolutionized the treatment of kidney stones, can also smash gallstones inside the body, potentially eliminating the need for some of the 500,000 gallbladder operations performed in this country each year, researchers say.

title: From Our Mild-Mannered Surgeon General
description: As a crusader against the ills of tobacco use, Surgeon General C. Everett Koop has few peers.

title: SOVIET ADVISERS IN LIBYA KEPT OUT OF THE WAY
description: Scores of Soviet military advisers near this coastal town stayed mostly inside a local air base to avoid being drawn into the conflict with the United States Sixth Fleet, foreign workers said today.

title: FRUEHAUF RECEIVES NEW EDELMAN OFFER
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, the Detroit-based maker of truck trailers and auto parts that rebuffed a leveraged buyout proposal from Asher Edelman earlier this month, said yesterday that it had received a $41-a-share takeover offer from the New York financier.

title: NEW OASIS FOR LOOM OPERETTAS
description: Click, went the combination lock after several twirls. ''Ah - got it - finally,'' murmured Jerry Gotham, entering the Cherry Lane Theater with his partner, Raymond Allen, and flicking a switch that poured light on the stage and front rows. Sipping coffee, the co-artistic directors began a full day for their Light Opera of Manhattan: company rehearsals of Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H. M. S. Pinafore,'' then matinee and evening performances of Sigmund Romberg's ''Desert Song.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Boston Red Sox, at Winter Haven, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 7:44 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Chicago Bulls, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. The Bulls are struggling to make the playoffs even with Michael Jordan playing again. (Television - SportsChannel, midnight, tape. Radio -WPAT 930, 7:30 P.M.) Detroit Pistons vs. Houston Rockets, at Pontiac, Mich., 7:35 P.M. Ralph Sampson, who injured his back on Monday against the Celtics is not expected to be back in the Houston lineup tonight. (Television -WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Colleges: N.C.A.A. women's national semifinals, at Lexington, Ky. Texas vs. Western Kentucky and Southern California vs. Tennessee. (Television -ESPN 7 P.M. and 9 P.M.) Boxing Dwight Pratchett, champion vs. Raphe Sims, 12 rounds for the N.A.B.F. super-featherweight championship at Houston. (Television - MSG, 11:30 P.M., tape delay). Golf Tournament Players Championship, at Ponte Vedra, Fla., second round. (Television - Channel 2, 11:30 P.M., tape. USA Network, 4 P.M., live.) Johnny Mathis Senior Classic, at Los Angeles, second round. Hockey Rangers vs. Edmonton Oilers, at Madison Square Garden, 8:35 P.M. Final meeting of the season. The Rangers are trying to get into the playoffs. (Television - MSG, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8:20 P.M.) Islanders vs.

title: Chamber Music Society
description: Salvatore Accardo will perform with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8 and Sunday afternoon at 5 in works by Sarasate, Paganini, Brahms and Tchaikovsky. Tickets are $15; information: 362-1911.

title: 24 SENATORS FIGHT MILITARY BUDGET CUT
description: Twenty-four Republican senators said today that they opposed the deep reduction in military spending included in the bipartisan 1987 budget plan approved by the Senate Budget Committee.

title: New Rocket Casualties
description: The four Israelis wounded today in the attack on Qiryat Shemona were the first civilian casualties suffered by Israel as a result of rocket attacks from Lebanon since Israel invaded Lebanon in June 1982.

title: DOW UP 11.02 TO CLOSE AT HIGH OF 1,821.72
description: The stock market improved again yesterday, despite some afternoon profit taking, as investors continued to react favorably to declining interest rates.

title: CUOMO NAMES SPECIAL JUDGE FROM UPSTATE IN FRIEDMAN CASE
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday appointed a special judge from upstate to preside over the Manhattan trial of Stanley M. Friedman and four others on bribery and conspiracy charges in the city's municipal corruption scandal.

title: DELAYS FEARED IN CHANGES IN TIMES SQ. PLAN
description: A majority of the members of the city's Board of Estimate said yesterday that changes being considered in arrangements for the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment plan would probably have to come before the board, a process that could cause delays.

title: U.S. SAYS NAVY HAS COMPLETED LIBYAN EXERCISE
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that Navy ships and planes had completed their exercise in the Gulf of Sidra and had moved north of the gulf region.

title: POSITIVE DRUG TESTS AMONG PROSPECTS WORRY N.F.L.
description: Three players eligible for the National Football League draft next month, one of them a projected first-round pick, tested positively for cocaine use at a recent camp for the top college seniors in the country, according to N.F.L. sources familiar with the test results. It was the first time in the five years in which the camp had been held that any player tested positively for cocaine.

title: STRONG FIELD OF 6 IN WIDENER
description: The $200,000 Widener Handicap at Hialeah on Saturday is the best horse race so far this year and the purest: A tidy field of six was drawn this morning, all of them major stakes winners. They will go a mile and a quarter under a set of handicap weights that should make things interesting.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The veteran pitcher Burt Hooton was given his unconditional release by the Texas Rangers, who said they would begin the season with three rookie pitchers in the starting rotation. Hooton, 36 years old, has a 151-136 career record but has been ineffective since the Rangers signed him as a free agent prior to the 1985 season. He was 5-8 with a 5.23 e.r.a. last year. . . . Joan Benoit Samuelson, the 1984 Olympic marathon champion, has reportedly decided not to enter the Boston Marathon next month because she is still recuperating from leg surgery. . . . Todd Bell, the Chicago safety who sat out the Bears' championship season in a contract dispute, will never play for the Bears again, his agent has told the club's general manager, Jerry Vainisi, but Vainisi says he wants to hear it directly from Bell before giving up on him.

title: METROPOLITAN MUSEUM UNVEILS $26 MILLION WING
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art gave a first tour yesterday of its newly completed $26 million wing for 20th-century works. The addition - which will be named after Lila Acheson Wallace, the co-founder of Reader's Digest - will become the second-largest space for showing 20th-century art in Manhattan after the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Connors 'Weary'
description: When Jimmy Connors walked off the court last month, forfeiting a match to Ivan Lendl, he was presumably protesting an official's call. Listening to the 33-year-old Connors huff and puff at a tournament in Chicago this week, however, suggests that he may simply have been too tired to go on.

title: ASHLAND OIL MOVE
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had retained the First Boston Corporation in what Wall Street analysts view as the start of a defensive campaign to fend off a surprise $1.8 billion takeover bid from the Belzberg family of Canada. Earlier this week the Belzbergs disclosed that they controlled 9.2 percent of Ashland's stock and had offered to pay $60 for each of the remaining shares.

title: SCREEN: FELLINI'S 'GINGER AND FRED'
description: MORE than 40 years after the height of their fame, which wasn't exactly international to begin with, Amelia (Giulietta Masina) and Pippo (Marcello Mastroianni) are brought out of retirement to reprise their ballroom dance act, ''Ginger and Fred,'' on a television variety show called ''We Are Proud to Present.''

title: FANS GREET OHIO STATE
description: Ohio State's National Invitation Tournament championship came too late to save Coach Eldon Miller's job, but the welcome he and his Buckeyes received when they arrived home today surely sent him on his way to Iowa with fond memories.

title: Debt
description: * Associates Corp. of North America is offering $100 million of 7 3/4 percent notes, rated A-1/AA- and due in 1989, at par through Salomon Brothers.

title: CBS Boycott Extended Over Minority Hiring
description: A six-month boycott of a CBS-owned station, sparked by the demotion of a black anchorman, has been extended to CBS stations nationwide, a spokesman for the sponsoring group, Operation PUSH, said yesterday.

title: TEAM TO DIRECT OVERHAUL OF SPACE SHUTTLE BOOSTERS
description: In one of the first steps toward getting the space shuttle ready to fly again, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has formed a team of engineering experts to direct a major overhaul of the solid-fuel boosters that it believes malfunctioned and caused the Challenger's explosion.

title: CONNECTICUT REFUNDING
description: The South Central Connecticut Regional Water Authority is offering $230 million of refunding water system revenue bonds with a top yield of 7.25 percent for a 7 1/8 percent bond due in 2012. The underwriters are led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Robert Kennedy's Killer Is Again Denied Parole
description: Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, who shot Senator Robert F. Kennedy to death in 1968, was denied parole for the eighth time today.

title: NORTHWEST AIR'S TIES WITH GREY REAFFIRMED
description: In a logical move - which is not necessarily something adland is famous for - Northwest Orient Airlines has decided to keep Grey Advertising in Minneapolis as its agency if and when it acquires and absorbs Republic Airlines and becomes the country's third-largest airline.

title: HEPBURN, IN 'DELAFIELD,' PLAYS A WIDOW IN LOVE
description: IF you had the impression that Katharine Hepburn was about to settle down to something resembling ladylike propriety in her advanced years, think again. The 76-year-old actress has now made a television movie titled ''Mrs. Delafield Wants to Marry'' (Channel 2 Sunday at 9 P.M.) and she is clearly determined to remain as spirited, eccentric, outspoken and, indeed, gloriously silly as ever. She still has the courage to make a fool of herself with style and verve. Her very last words in this odd romp are, ''Isn't life delicious?'' It can be, when Miss Hepburn is around.

title: HAITI CIVILIAN LEADERS URGE HALT TO PROTESTS
description: After several days of new political turbulence, many of Haiti's most prominent civilian leaders have begun urging restraint in public protests, saying Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy should be given time to fulfill his promises of constitutional changes and early elections.

title: TROUT GROUP PLANS ACTIVITIES
description: This is the time of year the various chapters of Trout Unlimited, a nonprofit international conservation organization devoted to the enhancement of trout and salmon fishery resources, usually hold their annual forums and banquets.

title: IMPROVE SEAT BELTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SANTA BARBARA UNIT IN 4-PART OFFERING
description: Santa Barbara Funding I, a subsidiary of the Santa Barbara Savings and Loan Association in California, is offering $250 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Dining Out Guide: Easter
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. CHATFIELDS, 208 East 60th Street (753-5070) -

title: COURT REBUFFS PENNZOIL
description: A Federal appeals court denied a request yesterday from the Pennzoil Company for additional financial security in its legal fight with Texaco Inc.

title: REAGAN SAYS SANDINISTAS 'SLAP' CONGRESS
description: President Reagan said today that the reported Nicaraguan drive against rebel camps in Honduras was ''a slap in the face'' to members of Congress who voted against his plan to send $100 million in aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: AIR FORCE IS SAID TO CANCEL FAIRCHILD PLANE
description: The Air Force has decided to cancel its $3.5 billion program for production of new T-46 trainer planes produced by the Fairchild Republic Company in Farmingdale, L.I., Pentagon sources and several Congressmen said today.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES LIABILITY COVERAGE BILL
description: A proposal to solve a national ''liability insurance crisis'' seen by physicians, business executives and insurance carriers won approval today from the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: BEYOND CORN TO PRICKLY PEAR: COMPANY SEEKS CROPS OF FUTURE
description: Long before the farm crisis became apparent, Gordon Fisher recognized that one of the secrets of making money in agriculture was to grow something other than conventional crops.

title: G.M. PLANS 2.9% PRICE INCREASE
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would increase the price of its cars by an average of 2.9 percent, or about $350 a unit, on April 14.

title: Harvey L. Williams Dies at 85; An International Consultant
description: Harvey L. Williams, an international management consultant and former head of the United States Council for International Business, died of cancer Sunday at the Bethesda Memorial Hospital, Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: New Deadlines Set In Steelworker Talks
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation and the National Steel Corporation today recessed talks with the United Steelworkers of America for the Easter weekend and set a new deadline, April 7, for contract agreements.

title: THE DANCE: 'TOCCATA,' BY HARLEM TROUPE
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM brought a little spring into Aaron Davis Hall on Wednesday with the New York premiere of John McFall's ''Toccata e Due Canzoni.'' The handsome theater, on the City College campus, has a feeling of air and space to it that extends to the stage. And the dancers fill the stage with the fast, arching ebb and flow and wistful sensibilities of this new ballet, driven along by the tender urgency of the score, by Bohuslav Martinu.

title: FILM: 'LUCAS,' TEEN-AGE ROMANCE
description: AS agreeable a teen-age triangle, or pentagon, as you are likely to come across is the subject of David Seltzer's ''Lucas,'' which opens today at the RKO National Twin and other theaters. Lucas, ''accelerated'' in his high school, falls for a 16-year-old newcomer to town - and who wouldn't fall for friendly, pretty Kerri Green? She likes Lucas, too, but not that way. When it comes to that way, she prefers his protector, the high school's football star played by sturdy yet tender Charlie Sheen. This distresses the football star's possessive girlfriend as well as the shy, poetically inclined girl who has a crush on Lucas.

title: Shopping Around
description: With O. J. Simpson out as an ABC commentator on ''Monday Night Football,'' the former National Football League star has been talking to CBS about switching networks, according to his agent.

title: Yiddish Book Fair
description: Sunday at the Workmen's Circle will be an afternoon of storytelling, readings and book browsing.

title: MUDD, ARAI FINED
description: Some controversy has become an annual part of the Tournament Players Championship, the event held on the Tournament Players Club course owned and operated by the PGA Tour. The 13th annual T.P.C. was no exception today when unrest boiled into angry words from the first group of golfers to finish the opening round on the 6,857-yard stadium course.

title: NEW YORK CITY TRYING TO CUT WATER WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: SPARTANS GAIN FINAL
description: With six players getting goals, Michigan State advanced to the final of the N.C.A.A. hockey tournament tonight with a 6-4 victory over Minnesota at the Providence Civic Center.

title: U.S. DEFENDS ITS POLICY ON COVERAGE OF SIDRA
description: The Defense Department today rejected criticism of its handling of news coverage of the combat off the Libyan coast, saying that several news organizations were consulted last week about how they wanted to cover naval exercises by the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean.

title: Couperin Work
description: Couperin's ''Trois Lecons de Tenebres'' will be performed at St. Stephen of Hungary Church, 414 East 82d Street, this afternoon at 2.

title: WESTERN AIR RUMORS
description: Western Airlines' stock continued its third week of active trading yesterday on speculation that the carrier may be acquired. Several securities analysts said that Western was a logical target by a number of airlines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, MARCH 28, 1986
description: International

title: 'Fidelio' in Concert
description: The Westfield Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Brad Keimach, will present a concert performance of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' at Carnegie Hall tomorrow afternoon at 2.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Irving Trust Co. has elected Witold S. Sulimirski executive vice president and manager of its Middle East and Africa Group.

title: OCCIDENTAL VOTE
description: Shareholders of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation approved the acquisition of the Midcon Corporation and the transaction is expected to be concluded Tuesday. Midcon held a separate shareholders meeting in Lombard, Ill., to approve the deal, but because Occidental already held 53 percent of Midcon, there was no doubt about the outcome.

title: POP: NEW YORK'S BEST FOLD: BOSTON ALL-STARS
description: NEW YORK CITY may be America's ultimate cultural melting pot, but like many other big cities in the country, it has its own distinctive pop-music climate. Punk rock and rap music, two of the most influential styles of the last decade, were born here - the former in Lower East Side rock clubs like CBGB and the latter on the streets of the South Bronx.

title: ACCORD ON $41 BILLION BUDGET REACHED IN ALBANY
description: Governor Cuomo and leaders of the Legislature reached agreement tonight on a $41.4 billion state budget, including increased aid for the New York City transit system intended to help freeze the fare through 1987.

title: TOXIC GAS UNDETECTED FOR HOURS
description: A buildup of gas at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant that caused 126 workers to ingest small doses of radioactive iodine went undetected for hours, the plant operator said today.

title: DOLLAR BROADLY LOWER; GOLD PRICES ALSO DOWN
description: By The Associated Press

title: BROADWAY
description: WHAT would it be like to spend an evening watching seven of America's most provocative playwrights wrestle with Anton Chekhov? You will not have to wait long to find out.

title: GENE FOUND TO CONTROL AIDS VIRUS PRODUCTION
description: Scientists have found a way to make the AIDS virus harmless by inactivating one of its genes in laboratory experiments, according to two new reports.

title: ARAB OPEC MEMBERS KEEP PRETORIA IN OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: KAREL APPEL PAINTINGS ON SHOW
description: MONET lived long enough to see Impressionism demolished but not to experience the revival of his own art - in the 1950's - as a justification for Abstract Expressionism. Being elected the ancestor of a movement on the basis of a surface similarity is a backhanded compliment at best, but it's one that increasingly is being handed out to the living masters as well as the dead - hence the reappearance in Manhattan of Karel Appel, as it were, courtesy of Neo-Expressionism.

title: Educational Theater
description: A boy walks on a tightrope, recalling his prenatal life. ''That was the only nine months of my life I remember feeling safe,'' the boy, Joel Lucas Jr., said.

title: VOLCANO ERUPTS ON ALASKA ISLAND SPEWING ASH OVER MUCH OF STATE
description: Augustine volcano erupted today for the first time in 10 years, spewing smoke and a wide blanket of ash that stopped flights to the Anchorage airport 180 miles away and lighting the Alaskan sky with a bright orange glow.

title: BOEING GETS RECORD ORDER
description: The Boeing Company formally received an order today from Singapore Airlines for 14 of its new 747-400 jetliners and options on six others, for a total package valued at $3.3 billion.

title: Christ's Last Words
description: Haydn's ''Seven Last Words of Christ'' will be performed in its original version for full orchestra at the Church of the Good Shepherd, 240 East 31st Street, tonight at 8. Maurice Peress will conduct the Queens Symphony Orchestra. Admission is free; information: 689-1595.

title: Astroland Reopens
description: Rides will spin and video games flash this weekend as Coney Island's Astroland ends its winter hibernation.

title: NAVY USED NEW ELECTRONIC TACTICS AGAINST LIBYA THAT PROTECTED PILOTS
description: In its air attacks on Libyan missile sites and naval craft, the Navy has used new tactics that military analysts in and out of Government said today had enhanced the safety of its pilots without reducing the effectiveness of its firepower.

title: DAWKINS'S SEASON IS ENDED BY INJURY
description: The Nets lost another key player yesterday when Darryl Dawkins was declared out for the season - and the playoffs - because of a back injury.

title: Hesitant Falcon
description: A peregrine falcon's flight ended March 17, when its right wing became entangled in a rope under the deck of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday 'BOSOMS AND NEGLECT' One of John Guare's plays, ''The House of Blue Leaves,'' has just been revived to glowing reviews uptown at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. This week another Guare work, ''Bosoms and Neglect,'' began performances downtown at the Perry Street Theater in a production by the New York Theater Workshop. Directed by Larry Arrick, this revival features Richard Kavanaugh, Anne Meara and April Shawhan as a man, his sick mother and the young woman with whom he shares a psychiatrist. This weekend's performances are today and Saturday at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $14. The theater is at 31 Perry Street, west of Seventh Avenue. Information: 279-4200.

title: MONEY FUND ASSETS UP
description: Assets of the nation's 360 money market mutual funds increased $1.14 billion, to $216.48 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Raveling to U.S.C.
description: A day after he withdrew as a candidate for the University of Houston basketball coaching job, George Raveling, the Iowa coach, was named head coach at Southern California, replacing Stan Morrison, who resigned to become an associate athletic director. The 48-year-old Raveling, a former Washington State coach, compiled a 54-38 record in three seasons at Iowa, bringing his 14-year coaching record to 221-74. . . . Tom Davis, the Stanford basketball coach, meanwhile, emerged as the leading candidate to succeed Guy Lewis as the head coach at Houston. . . . Danny Nee, the Ohio University basketball coach who led his team to a 22-8 record and a trip to the National Invitation Tournament, has been named head coach at Nebraska, replacing Moe Iba, who resigned after the Cornhuskers lost in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The 40-year-old Nee had an overall record of 107-67 in six seasons at Ohio.

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES PAYS $400,000 FINE FOR SAFETY VIOLATIONS
