description: Continental Airlines yesterday paid a $402,000 fine levied by the Federal Aviation Administration for violations of safety rules, the agency announced.

title: Will Handgun Foes Be Over a Barrel?
description: Once again, Congress is staring down the barrel of the mighty National Rifle Association, and reasonable gun control laws may become the first of many casualties. Considering that nearly 10,000 Americans are killed in handgun crimes each year - about 25 handgun murders day after day - the last thing we need is exactly what the N.R.A. wants: looser handgun laws.

title: BOND PRICES SURGE BY 2 1/2 POINTS
description: Bond prices jumped about 2 1/2 points yesterday, causing the yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue to fall to 7.59 percent, the lowest level in about nine years.

title: Landau to Be Renamed To Broadcasting Board
description: Sonia Landau will be reappointed to the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the White House said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Jimmy Heath
description: The saxophonist Jimmy Heath and his quartet will be featured in an evening of jazz tonight at the Terrace Room of Newark Symphony Hall, 1020 Broad Street (201-643-4550). The Chris White Trio will play sets at 6 and 7:30 P.M.; Mr. Heath and his group will perform at 9:30 and 11 P.M. Admission is $10, including a free drink.

title: ART: AT COOPER-HEWITT, MEMORIES OF NIJINSKA
description: IF you have an hour to spare on a pretty day this Easter weekend, you cannot do better than go to the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, where two new exhibitions gave this visitor a sensation of unlimited well-being. It helps if you are interested in the interaction between art and dance, and it wouldn't actually hinder if you take some young people who are crazy about toys. But, in any case, ''La Nijinska: A Dancer's Legacy'' and ''The Nuremberg Toy Museum'' make juicy billing.

title: FOLK CITY ENDS 25-YEAR WEST VILLAGE STAND
description: With a blare of electric guitars and a roar of drums, Gerdes Folk City ended its 25-year stay in Greenwich Village on Wednesday night. Forced to move by rising rents, the club threw a last rock-and-roll show for a full house.

title: FILM: 'THE QUIET EARTH'
description: ''THE QUIET EARTH'' is New Zealand's contribution to the last-man-on-earth genre, or to be precise, the last-two-men-and-one-woman genre. It has the usual huggermugger about tremors and grids and the sun acting peculiarly, plenty of computer screens and significant beeps and colorful special effects signifying commotion in the universe, some cautionary words about the dangers of man playing God and no noticeable psychological sense, but it's easy to watch most of the time and never positively painful. This relatively lighthearted exercise in apocalypse opens today at the New Carnegie.

title: PAINE WEBBER CITES 20 STOCKS
description: WITH the start of the second quarter near, Paine Webber Inc. has compiled a list of 20 stocks it finds attractive for potential price gains over the next six to 12 months.

title: Graphic Display
description: In Paris in the late 1940's, a group of Abstract Expressionist artists from Copenhagen, Brussels and Amsterdam formed what later became known as the Cobra movement, an acronym from the names of those cities.

title: THEATER: CAST CHANGES IN 'AUNT DAN'
description: AT the beginning of Wallace Shawn's ''Aunt Dan and Lemon,'' a sickly but terribly polite young woman known as Lemon addresses us, ''the dear audience,'' from her London parlor and promises ''a special treat - a night at the theater.'' It's the only time the audience can relax with the assurance that Mr. Shawn is in sync with the customary order of things theatrical. The next two hours bring us a rude play in which incidents of murder and raunchy sex intermingle with monologues about economic Darwinism in England, the role of menial labor in industrialized nations and the moral imperatives of Henry Kissinger's foreign policy during the Vietnam War. The last time we see Lemon, she is no longer quite so endearing. In the same English tea-party cadences of her initial greeting, she defends the crimes of Nazi Germany.

title: 2 Officials Accused Over Tainted Cheese
description: A cheese company, now out of business, and its president were charged today with criminal violations of state agriculture, health and safety laws after an investigation of tainted cheese that killed 39 people.

title: 4 Nimeiry Comrades Put on Trial in Sudan
description: Four associates of the former Sudanese President, Gaafar al-Nimeiry, went on trial today on charges of rebellion.

title: ALIEN-TORT PRECEDENT CAN'T ENCOURAGE FILIPINOS
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY FRIENDSHIP IN SPY CASE BAFFLED A SAILOR, JURY HEARS
description: A longtime Navy friend of Jerry A. Whitworth, who is accused of spying for the Soviet Union, testified today that he could not understand the friendship between the defendant and John A. Walker Jr., who has pleaded guilty to espionage charges in the same case.

title: CAPITAL UP 40% AT GOLDMAN
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the largest private partnership on Wall Street, sharply increased its capital and assets last year, apparently enjoying an excellent year in line with the securities industry. As a private partnership, Goldman, Sachs publicly discloses little about its financial position.

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE handsomely refurbished Loeb Boathouse on the lake in Central Park, with its spiffy new glass-enclosed cafe and outdoor tables overlooking the water, has opened for the season. The brick colonial-style boathouse, built in 1954, previously had only a snackbar; for this season, however, the structure has been ambitiously redone.

title: All Hail the Pesticidal Amnesty
description: It was almost as if President Reagan had embraced Mikhail S. Gorbachev; as if the Palestine Liberation Organization and Israel had signed a mutual defense pact; as if Ferdinard and Imelda Marcos had taken a vow of poverty.

title: J.W.T. PULLS OUT OF BID FOR THE DOLE ACCOUNT
description: J. Walter Thompson's San Francisco office announced yesterday that it had withdrawn from the competition for the $25 million Dole Foods account because of an emerging, unidentified conflict at an undisclosed J.W.T. office.

title: HOW NEW JERSEY PROTECTS SECRECY OF THE BALLOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers School Board Rejects Racial Accord
description: A negotiated settlement in the Yonkers school desegregation suit was rejected Wednesday by the Board of Education. The major obstacle to agreement was the future of a single school, according to a spokesman for the Board.

title: STEVENSON MOVES TO RUN FOR ILLINOIS GOVERNOR AS INDEPENDENT
description: Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the Democratic nominee for Governor, who found himself on a statewide party ticket with two ultraconservatives, announced today that he would seek to run on an independent ticket in the November election.

title: PATH TO THE SUMMIT?
description: Maybe no pattern is intended but one seems to be forming anyway:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SEAFOOD restaurants are forever banging the gong of freshness on their menus, using such dubious terms as ''From Local Waters'' and ''Catch of the Day,'' even when the locale is Greenland and the catch is iced onboard for a week at sea. It is so rare these days to find really fresh seafood, and rarer yet to get it prepared with passion and skill. At Le Bernardin, a stunning three-month-old restaurant in the new Equitable Assurance Tower on Seventh Avenue at 51st Street, the fish is so fresh and lovingly prepared as to be an epiphany of sorts.

title: U.S. and Greece Fail To Reach Base Accord
description: The United States and Greece failed today to agree on the future of American military bases in Greece after the current agreement expires in 1988.

title: OFFER TO GENSTAR
description: Imasco Ltd. had offered to increase its bid for the company from $54 to $56 Canadian, or the equivalent of $1.43 a share, to $39.95, but only if Genstar endorsed the deal.

title: LEVELS OF RADON IN JERSEY TOWN EXCEED LIMITS
description: Unsafe levels of the radioactive gas radon have been found in 45 houses in and around this village in rural western New Jersey, including one with the highest level yet detected in a building in the state.

title: RANGERS STRIVING TO EARN PLAYOFF SPOT
description: They were billed at the outset of the season as the new-look Rangers, with a new coach, new young players and a new approach to the game. They talked of one rather ordinary goal -to play at the .500 level.

title: POLICE LINK THE ROBBERY-MURDER OF 3 HOMOSEXUAL MEN IN QUEENS
description: Homicide detectives have linked a series of three robbery-murders in Queens since July in which all the victims were black Hispanic homosexuals, the police said yesterday.

title: 3 Rockets Fired At Osaka Police Building
description: Three homemade rockets were fired at the headquarters of the Osaka State Police Department today, and a van that may have been used to launch them burned up, Japanese news agencies reported.

title: 10 PENALIZED IN SHANTY ATTACK
description: A discipline committee at Dartmouth College today reinstated the suspensions of 10 students who attacked shanties built to dramatize the plight of blacks in South Africa.

title: A HOTEL-STYLE MIDTOWN CONDOMINIUM
description: If a development site in midtown Manhattan is too narrow for an office building, something else may work. On East 48th Street, that something else has turned out to be a 35-story residential condominium that will provide many of the services of a hotel.

title: A POWERFUL FEW WHITTLE AT STATE BUDGET
description: There are 12 chairs around the polished wooden table in Governor Cuomo's conference room, a few too many in the last delicate days of budget negotiating, when a small circle of men put the finishing touches on a spending plan that is virtually certain to be endorsed by 209 legislators.

title: EDITOR'S LETTERS REARGUE THE NEWS
description: ''Dear Turner,'' friends and cousins would write from the little town of Philadelphia, Miss. And then, in long, neighborly letters, they would take Turner Catledge to task for the way The New York Times was reporting the violence with which his homeland was resisting racial integration.

title: U.S. BLAMES NEW FORM OF HEROIN FOR OUTBREAK OF OVERDOSE DEATHS
description: An unusually potent and dangerous new form of Mexican heroin is being spread rapidly across the United States, Federal drug enforcement officials say. They say it has led to dozens, perhaps hundreds, of deaths by overdose, as well as to thousands of injuries in the last year.

title: JOHNSON MUST TRIM ROSTER
description: Each day, the time for decision-making comes closer. Dave Johnson, who will trim the Mets' roster to 24 players this spring, is not enthusiastic about the prospect, but he knows it is inevitable.

title: IN APARTHEID'S WEB: THE BATTLE FOR THE TOWNSHIPS
description: Since the grenade exploded against the window of the room where the child was sleeping, Ethel Kose said, she has not spent a night at home, preferring, like her husband, Peter, to seek refuge elsewhere.

title: Defendants in Handcuffs
description: When Stanley M. Friedman and four co-defendants were arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan they were all wearing handcuffs.

title: AUCTIONS
description: SOME years ago, when his good friend Elizabeth Taylor was coming to New York for a visit, Rock Hudson made a hospitable gesture. He offered her the use of the six-room apartment he owned at the Beresford. Even though the apartment had views of Central Park from every room, including the sauna, Miss Taylor found the quarters lacking in one respect: she was too short to use the sink in the bathroom, which Mr. Hudson had remodeled to suit his 6-foot 4-inch frame.

title: SPARROW IS HURT
description: The Knicks went down again last night, and so did another one of their players. Rory Sparrow, the playmaker, suffered a fractured left ankle in the opening minutes of the 110-105 loss to the Dallas Mavericks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Indian Transport Crashes
description: India lost its second Soviet-built transport plane in a week when a new AN-3, capable of carrying 39 passengers or 30 parachutists, crashed into the Arabian Sea while on its way to join the Indian Air Force Tuesday, an Air Force official said today.

title: AGENTS SEIZE 2 IN ATTEMPTED SALE OF $20 MILLION IN STOLEN SECURITIES
description: A Brooklyn lawyer and a self-described Long Island real-estate speculator were charged yesterday with trying to sell $20 million in stolen bank securities to undercover agents.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:53 A.M. today and set at 10:15 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:48 A.M. and set at 9:55 A.M.

title: PURCHASE BY FORD
description: The Ford Motor Company's purchase of the New Holland farm equipment business has been completed in the United States, Canada, Belgium and Spain, but separate closings are pending in seven other countries, Ford said. The auto maker announced in October that it would buy the Sperry Corporation's New Holland division, based in New Holland, Pa., for $330 million plus $110 million in liabilities.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''These are difficult days for New York City. There is no doubt that, with our revelations, people have become more cynical about their government.

title: LABORATORIES VS. A NUCLEAR BAN
description: The United States committed itself to seek a comprehensive nuclear weapons test ban in 1963 in the Limited Test Ban Treaty and in 1970 in the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. Negotiations between Washington, Moscow and London established agreement on the technical basis for effective verification, including detailed arrangements for in-country monitoring. In the past two years, both houses of Congress have urged President Reagan to negotiate a ban. The Kremlin has shown its seriousness with an eight-month unilateral moratorium on testing, and offered to extend it indefinitely if America refrained from testing, but America didn't. Why is there no agreement?

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON AID TO CONTRAS
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 53 to 47 tonight by which the Senate approved President Reagan's plan to provide $100 million in aid to rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government:

title: DEVILS' NEW GOALIE SHUTS OUT THE BLUES
description: The Devils promoted the goaltender Sam St. Laurent from the minor leagues this morning and he responded with some self-promotion tonight, achieving a shutout in his first National Hockey League start.

title: The Archivist Nominee
description: President Reagan plans to nominate John Agresto, acting chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities for the past year, as Archivist of the United States, a $73,600-a-year post that has been vacant since last April. The appointment to head the National Archives and Records Administration is subject to confirmation by the Senate, which has been notified of the President's plans.

title: The Comet Watch
description: Over Easter weekend, those who call the Halley hot line at the United States Naval Observatory will get a special children's program. Jamie Corbin, 10-year-old son of Dr. Thomas Corbin, a staff astronomer, has recorded a message about comets, especially Halley's Comet and when and how to observe it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 28, 1986
description: The Economy

title: Soviet Frees 3 Activists
description: Three members of a self-styled Soviet peace group have been released from detention, a member of the group, Aleksandr Rubchenko, said today. He identified the three freed members of the organization, the Group for Establishing Trust Between the U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R., as Viktor Smirnov, Nina Kovalenko and Irina Pankratova. Mr. Rubchenko said three others were still in jail - Aleksandr Shatravka, Vladimir Brodsky and Annetta Fadeyeva.

title: AVONDALE DEAL
description: Avondale Mills, a textile manufacturer based in Sylacauga, Ala., said it had signed an amended agreement to be acquired by Walton Monroe Mills Inc., a producer of yarn and unfinished fabrics, and two other companies affiliated with it, for $28.20 a share, or $112.9 million. The agreement follows by nearly two months a definitive pact between the companies under which Avondale, the largest domestic producer of knitting yarn, agreed to be acquired for $23.41 a share. But higher offers were later received from two other suitors.

title: CASS CANFIELD, A TITAN OF PUBLISHING, IS DEAD AT 88
description: Cass Canfield, one of the country's leading book publishers, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old and had been ill with heart trouble for several months.

title: COPTERS TO GO ON AIDING HONDURANS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that so long as Honduran troops stayed near their border with Nicaragua, United States Army helicopters would remain at their disposal to fly in weapons, ammunition, food and other supplies.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A WELL-KNOWN New York lawyer bounded up the steps of the Puck Building in SoHo with a bulging leather briefcase in his hand. Once inside, he opened the case and took out a large blue caftan, which he threw over his dinner jacket. Next came a large maroon turban and a complaint: ''It's too big. It's swallowing my ears.''

title: MUSIC: CONCORD GROUP PLAYS HENZE QUARTETS
description: THE West German composer Hans Werner Henze has had a spate of New York performances recently, including Speculum Musicae's account of ''El Cimarron'' and the Manhattan School of Music's staging of ''The English Cat.'' Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, the Concord String Quartet presented an entire concert devoted to Mr. Henze's Third, Fourth and Fifth String Quartets.

title: SCREEN: '3:15,' YOUTH CHALLENGES SCHOOL GANG
description: MUCH of the action in ''3:15'' is set in and around a southern California high school that looks more like a war zone than an educational institution. With its graffiti-spattered walls and packs of hoodlums who stalk the halls, flicking switchblades and dealing drugs, Lincoln High suggests a teen-age prison that has been taken over by its inmates. ''They're not students -they're a bunch of little terrorists,'' the school's fuss-budget principal (Rene Auberjonois) fumes to the local police chief, whom he enlists in his campaign to clean up the place.

title: Bridge: New York Association Finds New Home at Javits Center
description: Since its birth 38 years ago the Greater New York Bridge Association has had many homes for its events: large hotels, small hotels, church halls, college facilities and other areas less easily classified.

title: Embassy Row; The Sound of a Slap Reverberating
description: ''I had a big bet on she wasn't going to show up,'' said Dorothy Gazzolo, a member of the Woman's National Democratic Club, where Sondra Gotlieb, an author who is the wife of the Canadian Ambassador, Allan E. Gotlieb, was to speak today about her book, ''Wife Of . . . An Irreverent Account of Life in Powertown.''

title: KENYA'S FERTILE CURSE
description: Kenya seems a cheery place these days. After years of economic malaise, luck is smiling again on this island of stability in East Africa. Thanks to drought in Brazil, Kenya's long-stagnant earnings from coffee exports have skyrocketed. Tourism, another important source of income, benefits from the success of ''Out of Africa.'' To compound this good fortune, Kenya's bills for imported oil and debt service are falling. More foreign exchange will thus be available to create jobs and boost productivity.

title: CITY ACTS TO TAKE $250,000 FROM ASSETS LEFT BY MANES
description: The city's Corporation Counsel said yesterday that his office would move against the estate of Donald R. Manes to recover the $250,000 in bribes and payoffs that authorities say he took.

title: THE REPORT FROM PARIS: CLEAR COLOR, EASY SHAPES
description: The good news that came out of the fall and winter fashion openings is that clothes are finally easing up. Full skirts, a rarity in the past few seasons, appear in the three best collections, those of Yves Saint Laurent, Valentino and Karl Lagerfeld. That these skirts are longer, descending to midcalf or beyond instead of stopping at the knees, also contributes to the graceful look of clothes for next season. Even fitted coats rarely clutch the waistline. Women are beginning to be released from their tight sausage wrappings.

title: XEROX SEEKS AGENCY FOR DOMESTIC ACCOUNT
description: The Xerox Corporation, in the person of Michael E. G. Kirby, its director of corporate advertising and promotion, confirmed yesterday that it was already involved in the selection process to find a replacement domestic agency for Needham Harper Worldwide, which has served it for 18 years. Mr. Kirby made it plain that the move in no way affects the relationship between Needham and the Xerox operating companies that retain Needham elsewhere in the world.

title: RODINO FAULTS JUSTIC DEPT.'S INQUIRY
description: The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee expressed concern today that the Justice Department might not be conducting a ''fair and objective'' investigation into charges that the department's lawyers lied to Congress in a Congressional inquiry into allegations of wrongdoing at the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: BID TO END MAINE RAIL STRIKE
description: Gov. Joseph E. Brennan today asked Federal officials for a 60-day back-to-work order in the strike against the Maine Central Railroad. The Governor sent telegrams to President Reagan and Walter Wallace, president of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, seeking creation of an emergency board to investigate the strike, which began March 1, and find ways to resolve it. The Governor wants a 30-day cooling-off period followed by another 30-day period in which the two sides would negotiate.

title: 2 CHARGED AS INSIDERS IN GAF BID FOR CARBIDE
description: A lawyer with a prominent New York law firm and a securities analyst were charged yesterday with illegally obtaining and using insider information to trade in Union Carbide and other stocks before takeover bids were announced to the public.

title: AT SHOWS, SOUND AND FURY
description: Fashion shows in Europe are a lot like rock-and-roll concerts. On such grand sites as the Duke of York's barracks in London and in the courtyard of the Louvre in Paris, huge tents are set up containing enough light and sound equipment for a Rolling Stones tour. Within these 1,500-or-so-seat amphitheaters, designers set the stage for presenting their seasonal collections with elaborate spectacles full of sight and sound.

title: SURPRISING TIGERS GIVE LIFT TO COACH, SCHOOL AND STATE
description: On the eve of its trip to the Final Four, the normally bustling lilac-lined walkways of Louisiana State University have been emptied by Easter recess.

title: YANKS' RASMUSSEN HIT HARD
description: As George Steinbrenner watchedz the ball sail over the left-field wall, he said, in a tone not so harsh as the one that often accompanies such assessments, ''Columbus, here I come.''

title: QUOTRON EXPECTS BOARD TO REJECT CITICORP BID
description: Quotron Systems Inc. said last night that its directors would probably reject the $19-a-share cash offer made by Citicorp.

title: HYPING HYPER TUESDAY
description: Southern Democrats are fed up. We're not going to take it anymore, they say. ''Iowa and New Hampshire [ will ] no longer tell us who the nominee is going to be,'' says Bert Lance, the former Georgia party chairman. Dick Lodge, the present Tennessee chairman, refers back several elections and says, ''When your dog bites you four or five times, it's time to get a new dog. We've been bitten and it's time for the South to get a new dog.''

title: RETESTING DEBASES THE TEACHING PROFESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT ASSERTS U.S. STILL PERMITS MINING CLAIMS ON PROTECTED LAND
description: A report for Congress released today charges that the Interior Department is continuing to permit mining claims on public lands designated for parks, wilderness areas and other nonexploitative purposes.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED LAST MONTH
description: The gaping deficit in the nation's foreign trade shrank by $4 billion, to $12.5 billion, in February, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: On Time
description: He's seen a lot in his 20 years as a college basketball expert, but Edward S. Steitz, the official editor and interpreter of the N.C.A.A.'s men's basketball rules, says he's never seen anything quite like the contrary clock contretemps that helped Kansas come from behind to beat Michigan State in the Midwest Regional semifinals in Kansas City last Friday night. ''They blew it,'' said Steitz, who blamed the official timer, Larry Bates, and the other officials for allowing the game to continue for about 15 seconds while the clock was stuck with 2 minutes 21 seconds to play in the second half, and then not correcting the error before the end of the regulation game.

title: LISTING PRIORITIES
description: Paul Evans explains why, after being interviewed for the post of basketball coach at the University of Houston, he got back on the road and didn't stop until he reached Pittsburgh: ''At Houston, they told me the five most important things there were football, spring football, church, family and something else I don't remember. That wasn't a real positive situation I wanted to get involved in.''

title: EUROPEANS STEP UP SECURITY FOR U.S. ENVOYS AND TROOPS
description: Western European governments have stepped up security at United States diplomatic missions and military bases in the aftermath of the American naval confrontation with Libya.

title: SCANDAL RAISES QUESTIONS ABOUT DEMOCRATIC PARTY'S FUTURE
description: The scandal in the Parking Violations Bureau has left the Democratic Party in one of the nation's most Democratic cities short on leadership and fearful that the continuing investigations could handicap its candidates in a very busy election year, various Democrats acknowledged yesterday.

title: Gorbachev Again Asks Five-Power Conference
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in a message to the United Nations, today renewed his call for a roundtable conference of the leaders of the five permanent members of the Security Council to ease international tension.

title: ART: KNOWLTON'S WORKS ON SHOW AT THE MODERN
description: THERE is a lot to inspire confidence these days at the Museum of Modern Art. Its major painting and sculpture exhibitions have been impressive in their professionalism and imagination. Under its new curator, Linda Shearer, the museum has just revived the ''Projects'' series, which was designed in 1971 to present recent work by less known contemporary artists. The program, which was discontinued in 1982, indicates the museum's awareness of its responsibility to engage contemporary artistic issues.

title: Trumpet Duo
description: The trumpeters Clark Terry and Jon Faddis are performing together through Sunday at Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). Sets begin at 8 and 10 P.M. and midnight tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10 P.M. Sunday; there is a $10 cover and a $7.50 minimum.

title: FIRES TAKING A HEAVY TOLL
description: An unusually rapid succession of barn fires has made the beginning of the 1986 season a time of no little tragedy in thoroughbred racing. Flames that swept a stable at the Festoon Farms near Camden, S.C., earlier this week killed 27 horses, most of them untested 2-year-olds that were ticketed for the races in New York, and brought the year's nationwide toll to 129, including six in a fire at Thistledown in Ohio two weeks before the one at Camden. Two major blazes in January - at Belmont Park and at a training center in southern Indiana - killed 45 and 51, respectively.

title: FIRST ARTS FESTIVAL OPENS IN JUNE '88
description: The opening of the first New York International Festival of the Performing Arts, a month-long celebration of cultural events featuring artists from all over the world, was set yesterday for June 13, 1988.

title: SIGN AND FLY
description: Most coaches like to be known as the kind of people who'll go that extra mile for a player. Now an assistant football coach at the University of Colorado has extended the principle in an unlikely kind of way, going 10,000 miles for a player's parents. ''I've been on recruiting trips from coast to coast,'' says the assistant, appropriately named Les Miles, ''but I never dreamed of anything like this.''

title: Hart Appears on 'Cheers'
description: Following the lead of the House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Senator Gary Hart of Colorado will make a cameo appearance on the NBC television program set in a bar, ''Cheers.''

title: Suspect Is Convicted In Philadelphia Arson
description: George Stewart, who is white, has been convicted of violating the civil rights of a black family for playing a role in setting afire the home of a black family that had fled because of racially motivated incidents.

title: SAN ANTONIO ISSUE YIELDS UP TO 7.40%
description: San Antonio is offering $172 million of prior lien sewer system revenue improvement and refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 7.40 percent for a 7 1/4 percent issue due in 2012 at a price of 98.278. The First Boston Corporation is the lead underwriter.

title: QADDAFI EXPECTED TO CLAIM VICTORY
description: Arab and Western diplomats here said today that now that the United States Sixth Fleet has ended its maneuvers in the Gulf of Sidra, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi can be expected to claim victory for what he has called a ''brave repulsion of American aggression.''

title: KETCHUM HIRES TOP TALENT
description: KETCHUM COMMUNICATIONS, billing a total of more than $400 million, may be based in Pittsburgh, but its biggest office is in San Francisco in a beautifully refurbished one-time seed warehouse. Thom R. Miller used to work there so he knows what a moderately large - $140 million or so - office is like. Apparently he got fond of size because now that he has become president of Ketchum Advertising/New York, which bills only $18 million, he would like to see this office grow, too.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BOHEMIAN PARIS. Culture, Politics, and the Boundaries of Bourgeois Life, 1830-1930. By Jerrold Seigel. Illustrated. 453 pages. Elisabeth Sifton/ Viking. $25.

title: MOOKIE WILSON: NO COMPLAINTS
description: When he was in medical school, James Parkes III learned that throwing a baseball was ''an unnatural act,'' not what Mother Nature and her engineers had in mind when they designed the human body.

title: 'St. John Passion'
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine will present its fifth annual staging of Bach's ''Passion According to St. John'' tonight at 7:30. Soloists will include Thomas Bogdan, Bruce Kramer, Glenn Billingsley and Nathaniel Watson, with the massed choirs of the cathedral under the direction of Paul Halley. Tickets are $10 and $15; information: 662-2133.

title: NEW BIOGRAPHY SAYS BESS TRUMAN FELT ANGRY AS FIRST LADY
description: Bess Truman, feeling cut off from her husband when he abruptly became President, felt ''a smoldering anger that was tantamount to emotional separation,'' her daughter says in a new book.

title: Hoyt Coming Back
description: LaMarr Hoyt completed a monthlong chemical dependency treatment program Thursday, primarily for alcohol, and said in a prepared statement that he would rejoin the San Diego Padres today with the hope of returning to the team's pitching rotation three weeks into the regular season. Hoyt, who won the American League Cy Young Award with the Chicago White Sox in 1983, entered a Hazelden Foundation facility in Center City, Minn., on Feb. 28, a few days after spring training began.

title: U.S.-KOREA VENTURES STRIVE FOR COMPATIBILITY
description: When the Amoco Chemicals Corporation and Samsung of South Korea embarked on a joint venture some years ago to produce polyester fibers, they ran into an unexpected hitch. Their factory began producing fibers just as a supply surplus hit the market, inventories piled up and profits seemed a remote possibility. But it was when the venture finally started to make money that the real problems began.

title: F.D.I.C. DETAILS SHIFT ON BANKS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday disclosed details of its plan to permit banks lending to farmers and to oil and gas producers to live with far less capital than now required.

title: HONDURAN PEASANTS CONFIRM REPORT OF BATTLE
description: Eight Honduran peasants told today of heavy fighting near this area close to the border with Nicaragua and Honduran soldiers showed reporters five bodies that they said were Nicaraguan soldiers killed inside Honduras.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Walter Norris, Hanratty's, 1754 Second Avenue between 91st and 92d Streets (289-3200). Walter Norris is a pianist who has been in the neighborhood of fame on several occasions but has managed to stay out of the limelight. In the 1950's, he was playing in California with Gerry Mulligan, Stan Getz and Ornette Coleman. He moved to New York in 1960, but he had trouble finding steady work as a jazz pianist. After two years, Mr. Norris was hired by the trombonist Kai Winding as ''house pianist'' at the New York Playboy club.

title: SALE BY INTERNORTH
description: HNG/Internorth Inc., the giant pipeline company formed by the merger of the Houston Natural Gas Company and Internorth Inc., said it would sell a half-interest in its Florida Gas Transmission Company subsidiary to Sonat Inc., another pipeline company, for $362 million. A spokesman said HNG/Internorth would use the funds to reduce the debt, now $4.2 billion, from the merger.

title: STAGE: 'ALCHEMEDIANS,' BERKY AND MOSCHEN
description: COMBINE Michael Moschen's juggling virtuosity with Bob Berky's tomfoolery and you have ''The Alchemedians,'' an evening of light-fingered, high-vaulting New Vaudeville. In its new version, the show, conceived and choreographed by its performers, opened last night at the Lamb's Theater.

title: KOCH'S MOOD TURNS ANGRY
description: Mayor Koch, described lately by his closest associates as bouncing back from the corruption scandal that has haunted his third term, reacted to this week's indictments of friends and former city officials with the temper of a man under siege.

title: 2 KEY CATHOLIC CLERICS TRADE INSULTS IN NICARAGUA
description: Nicaragua's two most controversial Roman Catholic clerics exchanged insults Wednesday night and today, using some of the strongest language yet heard in the continuing conflict between the Nicaraguan Government and Roman Catholic bishops.

title: THE SCREEN: 'QUILOMBO'
description: TOWARD the end of the 17th century, a sizable number of slaves from Brazil's great sugar plantations escaped to the northeast where, in Pernambuco, they formed a legendary community (or quilombo), the Republic of Palmares.

title: Kemp Shows a Film
description: Representative Jack F. Kemp sponsored a showing in the Rayburn House Office Building Tuesday night of a film made by Accuracy in Media, the conservative organization headed by Reed J. Irvine that frequently complains of what it sees as liberal bias in news coverage. The film, ''Television's Vietnam: The Impact of Media,'' is narrated by Charlton Heston.

title: DELTA GRAPPLES WITH CHANGE
description: In its advertising campaign, Delta Air Lines says it is the airline that ''can get you there.'' But the question on many minds these days is not where Delta takes its passengers. Instead, as the airline industry continues to merge, the big issue is where Delta itself is going.

title: Love Califano Style
description: The March award for Most Inflammatory Book Dedication by a Prominent Washingtonian goes to Joseph A. Califano Jr., the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. His book ''America's Health Care Revolution,'' published by Random House, is dedicated to his wife, Hilary, whom he married in 1983. The dedication reads: ''When I fell in love with her, I knew how man felt when he discovered fire.''

title: LINKS BETWEEN TUROFF, CREDIT UNION AND TAXI-METER COMPANY INVESTIGATED
description: The former head of the city agency that regulates taxis, Jay L. Turoff, is under investigation for obtaining $244,000 in loans from a credit union that has extensive dealings with the taxi industry, according to state officials and lawyers.

title: A Stroll, With Poetry
description: Grace Paley will read from her poems on a walk Sunday through Brooklyn's Prospect Park.

title: FRIEDMAN'S TIES GO FROM CLUBHOUSE TO THE COURTHOUSE AND THE STATEHOUSE
description: Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, built a potent network of political loyalists in key city and state government posts that enabled him to boast of his unparalleled ''access to the process in the bureaucracy.''

title: CENTER CONFRONTING PARKING PROBLEM
description: Next week, on the West Side of Manhattan, the third-largest convention center in the nation is to open without public parking and and little service by public transit.

title: REPORTERS IN THE HALLWAY -- A SURE SIGN OF SPRING
description: ''It's a bit of a joke,'' said Governor Cuomo. Ann Buck of the Capitol's night cleaning staff concurred - ''A little silly for grown-ups.''

title: SLEUTHS UNCOVER DENTAL RECORDS, CLINCHING MENGELE IDENTIFICATION
description: United States and Brazilian scientists announced today that newly discovered dental records provided definitive proof that a skeleton exhumed in Sao Paulo last year was that of Josef Mengele, the Nazi war criminal.

title: ST. AUGUSTINE, TOO, OPPOSED ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
FLORIDA BANK PENALIZED
description: The Treasury Department said today that Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., a holding company in Jacksonville, had agreed to pay $112,000, the latest penalty imposed in a crackdown on failures to report large currency transactions.

title: TELEPHONE UNIONS SET TO BEGIN TALKS
description: For the first time since the breakup of the Bell Telephone System, negotiators for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its unions are about to begin contract talks, with lifetime employment security the central issue.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:48 A.M. today and set at 9:55 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:44 A.M. and set at 9:33 A.M.

title: Welcome to Pretoria
description: To raise student consciousness of the laws on racial separation in South Africa, a student group at Georgetown University will conduct a daylong simulation of the system Wednesday: Black students at the predominantly white institution will be ''in power,'' campus facilities will be segregated, white student ''passports'' (identification cards) will be checked, and the campus radio will pump out a steady background of African music.

title: Virginia Gilmore Dead at 66; Was Stage and Film Actress
description: Virginia Gilmore, an actress who appeared on stage and in more than 40 films, died Friday at her home in Santa Barbara, Calif., of complications from emphysema. She was 66 years old.

title: BAYTREE OFFERS TO BUY CARSON PIRIE
description: Baytree Investors Inc., a two-week-old private investment banking firm, offered today to buy Carson Pirie Scott & Company, a retailer that is considered No. 2 in the Chicago market behind Marshall Field's.

title: CONEY I. OPENING SEASON WITH HOPE
description: All around the Coney Island Boardwalk, the signs of winter have again been swept away: the pony rides, bumper cars and kiddie coasters have been cleaned and tested in preparation for this weekend's opening.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After writedowns of $37.5 million on oil and gas properties. c-Net income.

title: Youths on Rampage In Palm Springs
description: Hundreds of rampaging young people hurled stones at the police, ripped clothing from women, and dumped water into open-top cars today, shutting down this desert resort's main street in the worst outbreak of Easter weekend violence since 1969, the authorities said.

title: TUROFF IS LINKED TO TAXI COMPANY
description: State investigators said yesterday that they have evidence that the former head of the City Taxi and Limousine Commission, Jay L. Turoff, was a secret investor in a Yonkers taxi company with partners whose New York City holdings were regulated by Mr. Turoff's agency.

title:
PATENTS;
THREE-DIMENSIONAL SCULPTURED PAINTINGS
description: A method of making three-dimensional sculptured paintings is the subject of a patent granted this week to Floyd A. Hawkins Jr., an artist in Stanardsville, Va., who is a retired Government employee. Patent 4,578,131 explains that a mixture of sand and white glue is spread over the canvas and certain areas are scored, built up and sculptured.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after a $27,823,975 gain on the sale of radio stations.

title: CONCERT: BACA ENSEMBLE
description: The violinist Robert Mann juggles a lot of activities. In addition to being first violinist of the Juilliard Quartet, he is also president of the Naumburg Foundation and director of the Mann-family-centered Baca Ensemble.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Sondra Gotlieb, left, the wife of the Canadian Ambassador to the United States, posed with Connie Connor, her social secretary, after publicly slapping her before the start of a formal dinner at the embassy in honor of the Canadian Prime Minister. 2. Mr. Shultz, who was on a trip to Turkey, was referring to the Turkish Government's unexpected insistence that renewal of American military base rights be linked to major trade concessions by the United States. 3. May. 4. The fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Company. 5. Firms that go public can no longer offer their stars ''brass rings,'' as partnerships are known in the Wall Street vernacular. Instead, they are being offered ''golden handcuffs, or extremely lucrative arrangements, on the condition that they stay around to collect. 6. The payment was for 18 minutes of videotape of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident living in internal exile in the city of Gorky. 7. That Libya was trying to ''pinpoint'' American diplomats for possible terrorist attacks. 8. The trial of Stanley M. Friedman, a former Deputy Mayor who is the Bronx Democratic leader, on charges of bribery. 9. Clint Eastwood is a candidate for Mayor in a hotly contested municipal election April 8. The major issue is development, which Mr. Eastwood advocates. 10. Pancreas. 11. Miss Navratilova scored a four-set victory, marking the first time since 1901 that a women's tournament match went beyond three sets. 12.

title: YOUTH SEIZED FOR TRASH FIRES
description: A 16-year-old boy was seized by an off-duty police detective early yesterday and accused of setting a series of trash fires on Brooklyn Heights streets that blew up a car, burned another vehicle and a shed, and endangered residents and firefighters.

title: 25 Dance Groups Set For Israel Folk Festival
description: Twenty-five dance groups from the United States and Canada will perform in the Israel Folk Dance Festival and Festival of the Arts, on Sunday at 4 and 7:30 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

title: 28 SOUTH KOREAN PROFESSORS ISSUE PLEA FOR CONSTITUTIONAL REVISIONS
description: A group of scholars added their voices today to those calling on the Government to revise the nation's Constitution.

title: JUDGE SKEPTICAL ON BHOPAL PROPOSAL
description: The Federal judge handling the Bhopal claims has made it clear that he is skeptical that a proposed $350 million settlement can succeed.

title: A JERSEY TOWN PRIZES THE DANDELION
description: The common dandelion, one of the first weeds to burst across lawns and gardens these mild spring days, is pampered like a rare orchid here in South Jersey.

title: JERSEY BICYCLE RIDER SEIZED AS INTOXICATED
description: A 34-year-old Wallington man was arrested and charged with bicycling while intoxicated, the first such arrest the police officials in this Bergen County community said they could recall.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After $8.2 million in writeoffs on the value of certain equipment and related inventories for the quarter and year. c-After an extraordinary credit of $4 million.

title: HILLMAN SALE STUDY
description: The Hillman Company, a privately held investment concern based in Pittsburgh, is considering whether to sell part or all of its interests in the Copeland Corporation and the Pameco Corporation, according to Morgan Stanley & Company, which has been hired to evaluate the situation.

title: WEST SIDE FERRY
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
I.M.F. LOAN PLAN TAKES NEW TACK
description: The International Monetary Fund's plan to create a $3 billion pool of economic adjustment loans for the poorest nations marks another halting step toward international cooperation on the world debt problem.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK CAPITALS
description: They needed this victory for a restoration of morale, as well for the modest task of clinching a playoff spot for the 12th consecutive season. It's been an easy assumption for the last several weeks that the Islanders will finish third in the Patrick Division, but lately they had been able to assume nothing about their capacity for controlling the Washington Capitals.

title: THE DANCE: ARMENIAN TROUPE
description: Armenians have settled in so many parts of the world that it was not a total surprise to learn that the exuberant Armenian folk ensemble that performed at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night actually hails from Paris.

title: Quakes Jolt Logging Town
description: Four earthquakes ranging from slight to moderate rattled windows and shook this logging town Thursday but apparently caused no damage, the authorities said.

title: RITE OF PASSAGE
description: FAMILY RESEMBLANCES. By Lowry Pei. 264 pages. Random House. $16.95.

title: DON'T LOCK UP RUNAWAY CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: WATER: NOT FREE AT LAST
description: Pssst - I'll vote to widen your barge canal if you vote to dredge my harbor . . . In mixing water with politics, Americans have usually ended up with pork. Typically, the decision to invest Federal dollars in water projects has had a lot to do with deal-making and little with economic merit. Now, thanks to a decade of stubborn effort by two Presidents, the system is on the verge of change.

title: 2 OLD FILM PALACES CONFRONT MODERN TIMES
description: The Beacon and the Rivoli - two Broadway movie palaces built with the exuberantly extravagant stamp of Roxy - may soon become buildings that the impresario would scarcely recognize.

title: NO MORE IVY-COVERED CRITICISM FACTORIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Unless the U.S. Builds Better Housing, The Japan Will Take the Lead
description: With mortgage rates dropping and financial markets soaring, one might reasonably predict that the housing industry will prosper and that enough housing will be built to meet the nation's needs. But a key problem remains: Given our present methods, housing costs too much to build. It cannot be built efficiently or in large enough quantities.

title: L.I. DOCTOR GIVEN PROBATION FOR ROLE IN AN ABDUCTION PLOT
description: A Long Island doctor, convicted of plotting to abduct a Manhattan gynecologist, was sentenced to five years' probation today and barred from practicing medicine pending a State Health Department hearing.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
INDEX OF TRENDS IN ECONOMY RISES BY A STRONG 0.7%
description: The Government said yesterday that its index of future economic activity rose a sharp seven-tenths of 1 percent in February. The increase, along with an upward revision of January's figure, gave economists renewed confidence that 1986 would be a year of healthy growth.

title: Peay Steps In
description: A former Giant lineman, Francis Peay, defensive coordinator under Coach Dennis Green at Northwestern, has been named interim football coach at the school. The school's athletic director, Doug Single, said Peay may remain as interim coach through the 1986 season if a head football coach is not named by mid-June.

title: CONSUMERS POWER PLANS MIDLAND SHIFT
description: The Consumers Power Company said today that it would try to convert the Midland nuclear power plant to a gas-fueled generator, ending nearly two years of uncertainty over the fate of the shuttered facility.

title: CONGRESSIONAL BATTLE LOOMS OVER A CANCELED L.I. JET PACT
description: The decision by the Air Force to cancel its contract for the T-46 jet trainer, built on Long Island by the Fairchild Republic Company, has set off a struggle that is likely to pit New Yorkers in the House and the Senate against the powerful Senate Republican majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas.

title: Malaysian Rules an Election Is Needed in Embattled State
description: The Attorney General of Malaysia has ruled that Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad must allow the state of Sabah to proceed with a state election sought by its embattled government. The date will be set by the country's election commission.

title: KATY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,488,000 for the quarter, $651,000 for the year and including extraordinary gains from termination of defined benefit pension plans of $490,000 for the quarter, $1,438,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $29,463,000 for the quarter, $33,344,000 for the year and including gains from termination of defined benefit pension plans of $372,000 for the quarter, $842,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
QADDAFI CLAIMING VICTORY BY LIBYA
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi claimed victory tonight in his confrontation with the United States over the Gulf of Sidra.

title: GOOD NEWS FOR PROSPECTIVE LOTTERY REPEATERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would report a first-quarter loss exceeding the $62 million deficit it reported in the first three months of 1985. Walter F. Williams, president and chief executive of the nation's third-largest steelmaker, blamed steel prices, which he said remain significantly below the levels of the 1985 first quarter.

title: TEXAS AND U.S.C. REACH N.C.A.A. FINAL
description: There really wasn't a need for any more reminders. The Lady Longhorns of Texas had seen the films of their game against Western Kentucky in last year's women's collegiate basketball tournament and listened to motivational speeches from Coach Jody Conradt often enough to understand the significance of the second chance they were getting tonight. Having to travel to Kentucky for their first appearance in the National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinals and suffer the further indignity of hearing the strains of ''My Old Kentucky Home'' was like rubbing it in.

title: PREWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $363,000 for the quarter and $379,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $3,063,000 for the quarter and $5,393,000 for the year.

title: L.S.U.'s Williams Leads in Versatility
description: Many positive things can be said about Louisiana State's John Williams. But one scene from last season perhaps says more than words about the character of this 6-foot-8-inch, 237-pound sophomore forward.

title: TEMPLETON ENERGY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. The 1985 net loss included $2,897,000 of non-recurring costs that related principally to oilfield equipment writeoffs.

title: NIGERIAN CHARGED IN CONSULATE FIRE
description: A man the police described as irrational set a fire in the Nigerian Consulate yesterday and was later rescued from the office's 33d-floor window ledge, the authorities said.

title: JERSEY MAN IS HELD IN SLAYING OF YOUTH WHO WAS STRANGLED
description: A 22-year-old Parsippany, N.J., man was being held without bail yesterday on charges that he murdered a 17-year-old acquaintance, and authorities in nearby East Hanover were trying to identify another teen-age murder victim.

title: IN PARIS, AN UP-TO-THE MINUTE SHAPE
description: Ah, springtime in Paris. The chestnuts are almost in blossom, the rain is falling and the wind is blowing.

title: Gene Experiment Is Delayed
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had found a number of scientific flaws in an application the Monsanto Company submitted to field test a genetically engineered pesticide.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN GAMBLE
description: When the next generation of computer memory chips takes over, Texas Instruments Inc. is likely to be the only American challenger to the Japanese in a key sector of the semiconductor market.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Hanoi Schedules Return Of Remains of 21 to U.S.
description: Vietnam has agreed to turn over to the United States, on April 10 in Hanoi, at least 21 sets of remains thought to be those of American servicemen, Administration sources said today.

title: Thanks
description: In a gesture of appreciation for loyal service, the State Department is sending identification cards to retired Foreign Service officers.

title: AMID SIGNS OF BATTLE, QUESTIONS ABOUT ITS SCALE IN HONDURAS
description: A growing body of evidence confirms that there was a large Sandinista attack on Nicaraguan rebel camps inside Honduras early this week, but Reagan Administration officials may have exaggerated the size of the force and the danger it posed for Honduras, according to diplomats and Honduran sources.

title: Lebanese Christians Call For Syrians to Leave
description: Lebanon's main Christian leaders called today for Syrian disengagement from Lebanon and accused Syrian troops of bombarding Christian areas.

title: HIBERNIA ACQUIRES UNITED BANK
description: The Hibernia Bancshares Corporation said it had acquired United Bank, a financially troubled state-chartered savings bank with 26 branches in California.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
POLICE TO INCREASE PATROLS NEAR JAVITS CENTER
description: The Police Department has assigned extra officers to permanent duty near the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center to help handle the crowds and nuisances expected after it opens Thursday.

title: RULES FOR SMOKING IN NEW YORK
description: When Mayor Koch asked New York's 14,000 restaurants last year to reserve a fourth of their seats for nonsmokers, most knew a timid request when they heard one. They didn't even bother to respond. Now, with his re-election accomplished, the Mayor is making up for faint-heartedness with a call for stringent anti-smoking laws throughout the city.

title:
PATENTS;
RECEIVER TRACKS MISSILES
description: A RECEIVER that can determine the position and velocity of missiles, aircraft and spacecraft was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Through several channels, the receiver gathers data from a number of missiles and calculates the position and pace of the carrying vessel.

title: Bo Jackson Strikes Out
description: If Bo Jackson still had any doubts about choosing between a professional career in baseball or football, what happened to him this week may help him lean a bit more to the gridiron. Jackson, the 1985 Heisman Trophy winner, has ended his baseball career at Auburn University after inadvertently violating Southeastern Conference rules by accepting an airplane ride from the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Auburn athletic officials said yesterday.

title: 'TECHWORLD' V. L'ENFANT'S WORLD
description: Once again the preservationists and the developers are in a tug of war.

title: Opinion Split on Testing
description: The San Francisco Giants cannot be tested for drugs, but the San Francisco 49ers can be screened under the terms of a new city ordinance, the city attorney's office said late today.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $119,000 for the quarter and $2,031,000 for the year. The 12 months also included extraordinary litigation losses of $2.4 million. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary tax credit of $192,000 for the quarter and year. There were no share earnings in the latest periods because preferred dividends exceeded net income.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS
description: World Airways, which has been based in Oakland, Calif., since 1956, said it would discontinue its scheduled flights from Oakland International Airport, effective April 27. The aircraft from World's Oakland flights, which served Honolulu and New York, will be transferred to new routes between Los Angeles and Newark, and between Newark and San Juan, P.R. In October, World moved three daily flights, to Honolulu and Washington, to San Francisco International Airport from Oakland, joining People Express, which shifted its operations five months ago. A World spokesman said the airline's headquarters and maintenance facilities would remain at Oakland.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. These women posed for this picture shortly after an incident that has kept diplomatic circles abuzz for days. Who are they and what happened? 2. ''I have been brought here in order to have a nice luncheon and instead get hit behind the ear,'' said Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Where was he and to what was he referring? 3. The Supreme Court ruled that the military (may/may not) bar an Orthodox Jewish soldier from wearing a yarmulke indoors while in uniform. 4. At a commemorative ceremony, firefighters raised a ladder to the sixth floor of a building near Washington Square and a fire bell tolled 146 times, once for each victim of a catastrophe there 75 years ago. What catastrophe was it? 5. ''Golden handcuffs'' are increasing on Wall Street as ''brass rings'' decline. Explain. 6. The ABC television network paid $25,000, possibly to an agent of the K.G.B. What was the payment for? 7. According to White House officials, President Reagan approved a plan to engage Libyan forces in the Gulf of Sidra after receiving reports from intelligence sources in the Middle East and southern Europe. What did the reports indicate? 8. Governor Cuomo's appointment of a judge from upstate New York to preside at a trial in Manhattan will serve to dispense firm, swift justice and the appearance of it, according to Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: NICARAGUA LEADER WARNS OF RISKS IN USE OF U.S. FORCES IN HONDURAS
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra warned today that the use of American helicopters and possible deployment of American military advisers at rebel camps near the Honduran border could draw the United States more directly into Nicaragua's battle against the insurgents.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PHOTOJOURNALISM EXHIBITS The French photographer Willy Ronis, now 75 years old, has said ''It is content rather than form that should be stressed, and a photograph, graphically impeccable but ambiguous in meaning (or without the ne plus ultra of art), will be of doubtful value next to another less perfect technically but in which the idea strikes home at once.''

title: CHESS OPEN'S TOP PRIZE DRAWING WORLD'S BEST
description: Starting today and until April 7, New York City will be host to more than 1,000 chess players - including about 30 grandmasters - competing in the fourth New York Open.

title: DUKE'S LUCKY 'BOGGERS'
description: Duke students take a course they also teach. Creative cheering, or creative jeering. When their top-seeded basketball team was blowing Navy out of the water in the East Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament last Sunday, the Duke students suddenly began to chant.

title: Antioch Law School To Be Taken Over
description: Antioch Law School, a 14-year-old branch of Antioch University of Yellow Springs, Ohio, found a new home Thursday when the trustees of the University of the District of Columbia voted to take it over.

title: JUDGE REJECTS ROBINS PLAN
description: A Federal judge ordered the A. H. Robins Company today to recover $6.8 million in debts it paid without the court's permission after filing for protection under bankruptcy laws.

title: THE STRANGE CASE OF 'FROM TIME IMMEMORIAL,' CONTINUED
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''We will impose our sovereignty on the Gulf of Sidra with our blood.

title: JAVITS CENTER RECORDS SOUGHT FOR INQUIRY ON CONCRETE BIDS
description: Records on the construction of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center that were subpoenaed Thursday were sought as part of an investigation into possible bid-rigging by its concrete suppliers, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Sikhs Kill 13 Hindus; Punjab Toll Reaches 80
description: Sikh extremists killed at least 13 Hindus and wounded 20 today in the Punjab city of Ludhiana, a city official reported.

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: PLEDGES DOWN IN PBS DRIVE
description: Although the size of the average gift was up, the number of donors and the total pledged to the nation's Public Broadcasting Service stations were down during the network's March fund-raising campaign, PBS said today.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $235,313,000 for the quarter and $342,867,000 for the year. c-Including realized investment gains of $17,924,000 for the quarter and $78,694,000 for the year.

title: LAWYER SWORN IN AS FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A former Wall Street lawyer, Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, has been sworn in as a Federal judge in Manhattan.

title:
PATENTS;
MAGNETIC CARD RECORDER; INJECTION CATHETER
description: Jerome H. Lemelson of Princeton, N.J., who is the president of the Licensing Management Corporation in New York, has nearly 400 patents and received two more this week. No. 4,578,717 covers a magnetic card recorder that may be used as a memory for personal and business computers and has applications in the medical records field, including such pictorial data on hospital patients as X-ray images.

title: TWO CHAIN STORES HALT SALES OF ENCAPRIN AFTER A THREAT
description: An anonymous caller to the Procter & Gamble Company said he placed cyanide-filled capsules of the pain reliever Encaprin in drugstores in Chicago and Detroit, prompting two store chains to remove the product from shelves nationwide, officials said today.

title: PUNTA GORDA ISLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year loss reflects a reduced tax benefit because all deferred tax credits for financial reporting purposes were used in the first quarter of l985.

title: John Pratt Dead at 74; Designer for the Dance
description: John Pratt, a scenic and costume designer for the dance and the theater, died Wednesday at Barnes Hospital in St. Louis. He was 74 years old and had lived in East St. Louis, Ill., and Port au Prince, Haiti.

title: TFC TELESERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company was formed in December 1985 from the merger of two companies, one of which commenced operations in June 1985.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT OILERS, 4-2
description: Pierre Larouche floated into position, shot and scored in his snappy way. John Vanbiesbrouck stopped Wayne Gretzky cold. Other Rangers scratched for the puck. And for an evening at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers were more graceful, more resourceful than the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Fresno State Coach
description: Ron Adams, architect of Fresno State's stingy defense, has been named the Bulldogs' head basketball coach.

title: Razing the Roof
description: The visiting goalies hated the place, and no wonder. Year after year, for two of the three periods at every home game played by Boston College's hockey team, the Screaming Eagles band performed long and loud right behind the opponents' cage.

title: U.S. QUIETLY ASKS MIDDLE EAST AND EUROPE FOR MORE SECURITY FOR DIPLOMATS
description: The United States, concerned about the possibility of Libyan acts of revenge against Americans abroad, has privately asked Western European and Middle East nations to increase their security for American diplomats, Administration officials said today.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Black Policeman Killed In Anti-Apartheid Unrest
description: A black policeman was killed and set afire and another black man was shot dead in anti-apartheid unrest reported today.

title: END TO CEILINGS ON PASSBOOKS
description: THE deregulation of bank accounts - a historic process that has steadily been gathering momentum during the last 39 months -comes to an end on Tuesday, when the federally imposed 5 1/2 percent interest rate ceiling on passbook accounts is lifted. At that point, banks and thrift institutions will be able to pay whatever interest rates they choose on passbook, as well as on all other, accounts.

title: Barry Harris and Trio
description: The be-bop pianist Barry Harris and his trio are performing tonight at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue, at 28th Street (502-4300). Sets are at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; admission is $8, or $5 for students and the elderly.

title: Important Points
description: Tom Yeager, commissioner of the Colonial Conference, on the total of 1,320 that David Robinson achieved in an entrance exam before enrolling at Navy: ''We're all proud that it took him over two and a half years to score more points on the court than in his S.A.T. score.''

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to March 1
description: b-Including a tax credit of $177,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $824,000 for the quarter and $1,421,000 for the 9 months. Latest quarter and 9 months figures also include a gain of $1,857,000 from the sale of land. Year-ago quarter and 9 months figures also include a gain of $643,000 related to the sale of idle production facility and a charge of $260,000 for potential losses on the disposition of non-operating assets.

title: COSMO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PRICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 16
AN UNSEEDED QUEENS TEAM UPSET TOP-RANKED PLAYERS
description: Favorites, whether they are steeplechase horses or bridge teams, sometimes fall at an early fence. It happened March 1 in the second knockout round of Grand National Team play in New York City.

title: RECITAL: JAMES KREGER, CELLO
description: James Kreger's cello recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night got off to an uncertain start but warmed and strengthened as the evening progressed. Mr. Kreger, the young American prizewinner at Moscow's Tchaikovsky Competition 12 years ago, began with Jean-Baptiste Breval's Sonata in G (Op. 12, No. 5), a piece in late Classical style that sat uneasily amid this otherwise darkly powerful collection of music. The Breval's unusually sopranic tessitura also strained Mr. Kreger mightily in the higher positions and musically didn't really seem worth all the annoyances in the first place.

title: IONIAN ODYSSEY: TO AMERICA AND BACK
description: On a wind-battered knoll on this quiet island north of Corfu stand the remnants of an old mill. On them, in bold blue letters, someone has written, ''U.S.A.''

title: CLOUDS OF ASH FROM ERUPTING VOLCANO SPEW ACROSS ALASKA
description: The eruption of Augustine Volcano continued for a second day today, disrupting life in much of the Kenai Peninsula with businesses closed, mail deliveries halted and air travel disrupted. Hospitals were handing out gas masks to people as a protection against volcanic ash, which has now spread as far as 600 miles to the north.

title: The Contents of Lincoln's Pockets, And What They Suggest About Him
description: Abraham Lincoln's memory is a memory Americans want to keep green.

title: 20TH CENTURY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid April 4, 1986.

title: EIGHT ARE NAMED IN SUITS ON PIRATING OF CABLE TV
description: Three Philadelphia-area Home Box Office distributors have stepped up their fight against ''signal pirates,'' suing eight people for $10,000 apiece for purportedly watching the pay-television channel for free.

title: K-TRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,744,000 on the sale of the company's scale business assets for the quarter and year. c-Net income including a tax credit of $160,000 for the quarter and the year.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 1
description: The year-earlier share earnings were restated to reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid on July 15, 1985.

title: Red Rodney, Trumpet
description: The trumpeter Red Rodney will join the clarinetist Mike Morgenstern and the Jazzmania All-Stars tonight at A Discovery of Soho, 451 Broome Street, at Mercer Street (334-1222). Sets begin at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,155,850 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for 5-for-4 split in the form of a 25 percent common stock dividend on all outstanding shares, paid Sept. 18, 1985, and Sept. 12, 1984.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY LEROY
description: The composer A. Leroy, whose debut at Dance Theater Workshop last spring was very well received, writes music whose special strength is a smooth integration of rhythm, texture and musical structure in pieces characterized by a breezy effervescence.

title: HARVARD GAINS FINAL, 5-2
description: Harvard, playing most of the game without its top player, beat Denver, 5-2, here tonight to advance to the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship.

title: JUSTICE OFFICIAL SAYS DATA SHOW QUOTAS MISUSED
description: The Justice Department today released numerous documents that it said were evidence that Federal contractors had been required to meet illegal quotas in hiring women and members of minority groups.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
YANKEES TRADED BAYLOR AND RELEASE PHIL NIEKRO
description: The Yankees, in their most hectic day of the spring, traded a relieved Don Baylor to Boston for Mike Easler today and released a bitter Phil Niekro. The trade produced an instant change in Manager Lou Piniella's plans for two positions, designated hitter and left field. Niekro's release indicated that Bob Tewksbury and perhaps Tommy John had won spots in the starting pitching rotation.

title: RAPE SUSPECT HELD IN OTHER ASSAULTS
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man, arrested this month on charges of raping and knifing a Brooklyn College student, was charged yesterday with three more rapes and a sexual assault, the police said.

title:
PATENTS;
GENETIC MATERIAL USED IN BACTERIA PROCESS
description: A process of introducing genetic material into the cells of bacteria to induce the production of similar materials, such as interferon, hormones and insulin, was patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: NETS DOWN BULLS TO END SKID
description: The Nets would prefer to play the Philadelphia 76ers in the opening round of the playoffs, and tonight they moved a step closer to that end.

title: DRUG CASE ROCKS POLITICAL ESTABLISHMENT IN A KENTUCKY TOWN
description: When a small plane from Florida banked over the Licking River and landed here last Nov. 20, as Federal investigators tell it, the Morgan County Judge-Executive was waiting, a machine gun at his side.

title: FOR SALE: SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN
description: Scientific American Inc., the privately held company whose monthly magazine is respected throughout the scientific community, has been put up for sale, Gerard Piel, its chairman, said yesterday.

title: FLUOROCARGON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $374,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for the quarter and including a gain from the sale of discontinued operations of $261,000 and income of $286,000 from discontinued operations, both for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $113,000 for the quarter and including income from discontinued operations of $378,000 and an extraordinary gain of $608,000, both for the year.

title: OFFICIALS NAME EXTORTION TARGET IN TOWING CASE
description: The unnamed towing company from which an official of Datacom Systems Corporation was charged with extorting money was identified yesterday by law-enforcement officials as Interstate Recovery Inc.

title: DR. WILLIAM S. BERNARD
description: Dr. William S. Bernard, professor emeritus of sociology at Brooklyn College, died Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: Woman Wins $1 Million In Psychic Power Suit
description: A woman who blamed an advanced X-ray test for loss of her psychic powers has been awarded more than $1 million by a jury, but a hospital attorney said today that the verdict would be appealed.

title: CONCERT: MUSIC TODAY OFFERS WORKS FUSING EAST AND WEST
description: Gerard Schwarz's program for the Music Today concert Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall - the final concert of that estimable organization's fifth season - proved neatly symmetrical. The first and fourth pieces were examples of accessible Serialism, even if modernist-resistant conservatives might find it hard to believe such a thing was possible. In between came two piquant incidents of East-West fusion, one from the East and one from the West.

title: FILM: BIKE ACROBATICS IN HAL NEEDHAM'S 'RAD'
description: The bicycle acrobatics behind the credits at the opening of ''Rad'' are so spectacular that you wonder what the movie can do to improve on them. The short answer is, nothing. It's all uphill once the tale gets under way of the hometown rider of a BMX, a type of two-wheeler designed to fly and bounce as well as roll, who beats the arrogant and corrupt outsiders in the big race.

title: Radon Test: Some Surprising Results
description: A few months ago, 46 people in northern Virginia, Maryland and the District of Columbia agreed to have their houses tested for radon gas, a substance that seeps out of natural uranium deposits in the soil and, if inhaled in sufficient quantity, is believed to cause lung cancer.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. REJECTED ALLIES' ADVICE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States had disregarded the advice of several allied governments against using military force against Libya.

title: JULIAN K. ROOSEVELT IS DEAD: SERVED ON 2 OLYMPIC BOARDS
description: Julian K. Roosevelt, a member of the boards of the United States and International Olympic Committees and a former Olympic yachtsman who won a gold medal in 1952, died of liver cancer Thursday at the Glen Cove Hospital near his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 61 years old.

title: KAPLAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
CITY WILL CLOSE FAMILY SHELTER FOR RENOVATION
description: One of the largest shelters for homeless families in the city will be closed temporarily because the city cannot renovate the building safely without removing its 217 residents, city officials said yesterday.

title: HEALTHCARE USA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $800,000 for the quarter and $4,700,000 for the year. The year also had a loss of $497,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $156,000 for the quarter and $675,000 for the year.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. (Radio -WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs. Atlanta Braves, at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. (Radio -WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at West Palm Beach, Fla. (Television - WTBS, 1:35 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Chicago Bulls, at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. The Knicks are going the rest of the way with only four guards, after the season-ending injury to Rory Sparrow Thursday night. (Television - MSG, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WNBC 660, 7:50 P.M.) College: Louisiana State vs. Louisville, 3:42 P.M., and Duke vs. Kansas, 6 P.M., N.C.A.A. semifinals, at Dallas. (Television - Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 3:15 P.M. and 6 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs. Edmonton Oilers, at Nassau Coliseum, 7:05 P.M. In their two previous meetings this season, Edmonton was a 6-4 winner and the teams played a 4-4 tie, (Television - SportsChannel, 7 P.M. Radio - WOR 710, 7 P.M.) Devils vs. Chicago Black Hawks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 1:35 P.M. (Radio - WMCA 570, 1:30 P.M.) Rangers vs. Flyers, at Philadelphia, 7:35 P.M. The Flyers are battling the Washington Capitals for first place and the Rangers are battling the Pittsburgh Penguins for fourth. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.) Michigan State vs. Harvard-Denver winner from last night, N.C.A.A. championship final, at Providence, R.I (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.) Running Perrier 10 K, at 69th Street and Fifth Avenue Central Park, 11 A.M..

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FINAL FOUR SHARE FLEXIBILITY
description: Call it the Flexible Final Four.

title: DAMON CREATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
Jackson and Pass
description: The vibraphonist Milt Jackson will lead his quartet and the guitarist Joe Pass will play solos in a double bill through tomorrow at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. tonight, and at 9 and 11 P.M. tomorrow. There is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: MILITARY DETAINS MIKE WALLACE AT NUCLEAR SITE IN MISSOURI
description: Mike Wallace and two CBS News colleagues were detained temporarily by the authorities today while covering a demonstration at two nuclear missile silo sites where five protesters were arrested, officials said.

title: INVESTMENT 'FEVER' IS SWEEPING JAPAN
description: Many years ago, when Eikan Kyu was a young and prize-winning novelist, he appalled his contemporaries by abandoning fiction for the more prosaic career of writing about money.

title: On Credit Card Interest
description: With interest rates dropping across the board, why are credit card rates remaining high?

title: Transactions
