description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Traded Mike Easler, designated hitter, to New York Yankees for Don Baylor, designated hitter. Assigned Kevin Romine, outfielder, and Mike Trujillo, pitcher, to minor league camp.

title: Gooden Goes 6 and Is Pleased
description: Dwight Gooden was satisfied. So far, it is the only barometer by which the Mets can measure their young pitcher. The numbers, at this point, don't seem to matter.

title: CHILDREN'S LETTERS VOICE SORROW ABOUT ASTRONAUTS WHO DIED
description: ''Dear Mr. McAuliffe,'' one child wrote to the husband of Christa McAuliffe, ''I'm very sorry that you lost your wife. I was watching the news and I saw your children say, 'Don't go, Mom,' and I'm sure they are very unhappy. I wish I could help you and your family. Sincerely yours, Mike Bonanno.''

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 23
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago quarter loss includes a tax benefit of $10,948,000.

title: U.S. COWS TO BE SLAUGHTERED TO CUT SURPLUS MILK OUTPUT
description: Nearly one million cows will be heading to the slaughterhouse starting next week as part of a new program designed to reduce milk production 7 percent, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,253,000 for the quarter and $29,337,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: A TOAST FOR MIES
description: Six undecorated, minimalist chocolate cakes sat symmetrically in a row, waiting to be placed on white, unadorned plates.

title: COVERAGE OF THE PALME KILLING TOUCHES OFF SWEDISH DEBATE
description: Three weeks after the killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme, the police investigation has not shed much light on the crime. Yet the press coverage of the investigation has brought to light not only the special rules controlling news reporting here but also the Swedish practices regarding the rights of suspects.

title: AID TO CONTRAS: CONGRESS EDGES TOWARD PACKAGE
description: Congress, although wrestling with the ghost of Vietnam, seems to be moving toward giving President Reagan the military aid he wants for the insurgents fighting to oust the Nicaraguan Government.

title: U.S. AIDE TERMS NICARAGUA 'AGGRESSOR STATE' IN REGION
description: The State Department said today that Nicaragua was an ''aggressor state'' and therefore had no right to claim self-defense as the basis for its reported attacks this week against United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels in Honduras.

title: New York: Loser?
description: We are not accustomed to thinking of New York State as a developing country - much less as a competitive enterprise - but we had better begin to do so. Without effective strategies to use our capital, labor markets and public-sector agencies, the state's economy will be pulled into a downward free fall.

title: Tax-Free Bonds That Shouldn't Die
description: Senator Bob Packwood's plan to subject to taxation existing municipal bonds held by some owners is now dead. But the Oregon Republican and other tax reformers in Congress are pushing for a change that could endanger the renaissance of America's cities - the elimination of tax-free bonds that benefit private entities.

title: REPORT FINDS IMMIGRATION SERVICE VIOLATED RULES
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service violated Federal regulations and wasted taxpayers' money in awarding a $61.3 million computer contract to the International Business Machines Corporation, according to a Congressional report made public today.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Giants Eye Zimmerman
description: The Giants say they still are interested in signing the offensive lineman Gary Zimmerman of the now-defunct Los Angeles Express, but only if he's willing to accept less money than he wants. The Giants' N.F.L. rights to Zimmerman, their first selection in the 1984 supplemental draft of United States Football League players, were upheld Thursday by Judge Barrington Parker of United States District Court in Washington.

title:
PATENTS;
JAPANESE PATENT DATA PRINTED IN U.S. GAZETTE
description: Detailed information prepared by the Japanese patent office on the accelerated examination and appeal procedure effective there was published this week in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

title: DEVON RESOURCES INVESTORS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Dept. of Hostilities
description: Once the White House had decided to send the Sixth Fleet into the Gulf of Sidra and risk a military confrontation with Libya, one question was how to do it without setting in motion the provisions of the War Powers Resolution of 1973. And so, State Department officials say, lawyers there and at the Pentagon were prepared when the House Foreign Affairs Committee complained about not being consulted.

title: WARNINGS ON FOOD ALLERGIES
description: ON Feb. 18, Kate Brodsky, an 18-year-old freshman at Brown University, ate a few spoonfuls of chili at a Providence, R.I., restaurant and then felt ill. She told a friend she thought the chili tasted spoiled. Three hours later, she was dead. The chili was not spoiled, but the restaurant, Montana, had used peanut butter to thicken it and Miss Brodsky, a nationally ranked squash player, was allergic to peanuts. Just the smell made her lose her appetite.

title: FOR SPRING, LAMB THAT'S BOTH SUCCULENT AND EASY
description: Lamb's association with spring has deep religious roots. It is closely associated with Easter and Passover.

title: TECHNITROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILITARY ADVISED MOBILITY IS VITAL FOR NEW MISSILES
description: A report commissioned by the Pentagon on the future of small land-based missiles concludes that the Air Force should develop and deploy a mobile, 37,000-pound version that would probably carry one warhead and decoys to fool Soviet defenses.

title: A SLOW START FOR EFFORTS TO DRAW NEW TEACHERS
description: Efforts by New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to attract people to teaching by paying some of their college costs are off to a slow start.

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The income in the latest quarter was increased $53,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting change in the estimated useful lives of certain assets.

title: DRIVER-HARRIS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $1,042,000 for expenses related to the restructuring of the company's domestic alloy business. c-Net income, including a reduction of prior year's pension expense of $795,000 related to the restructuring of a foreign subsidiary's pension plans and subsequent return to the subsidiary of the excess of the plan's assets over liabilities.

title: Tidbits of Trivia On the Final Four
description: It wouldn't be much of an American sports classic if it didn't have its own share of trivia for its followers to play with. As the rival members of the Final Four head for their high noon in Texas today, here are some things to consider:

title: FRONTIER AIRLINES
description: Frontier Airlines will increase its ticket prices by $20 to $40 next week, nearly a month earlier than planned.

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After investment losses of $27,227, net from discontinued operations of $819,651 and a gain of $1,459,397 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Including investment gains of $3,191 and net from discontinued operations of $382,409.

title: ALBANY COMPROMISE
description: The agreement on a $41.4 billion budget struck Thursday night between Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers was an important turning point for a Governor who is running for re-election and who is considered likely to run for President.

title: COLLEGE STUDENT QUANDARY: HUNTING FOR AID
description: Not since 1980 - when the Reagan Administration proposed its first cuts in aid for education - have college students been as uncertain as they are this year about financial aid for the fall, according to guidance counselors, educators and education lobbying groups in Washington.

title: SCIENCE EDUCATION FAULTED IN REPORT
description: Academic programs in college-level science, mathematics and engineering have severely declined, posing ''a grave long-term threat'' to the nation, according to a report issued today by the National Science Board.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, MARCH 29, 1986
description: International

title: ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNCERTAIN FUTURE FOR FRENCH BOSSES
description: The poachers-turned-gamekeepers of French industry and banking are wondering how long they will keep their jobs, now that France has a conservative Government again.

title: INSIDER REPORTS
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE CROWN ZELLERBACH CORPORATION-Edgar H. Grubb, senior vice president, sold 10,047 shares leaving him directly with a balance of 11,203 shares.

title: UNION ORGANIZING: SETBACK AT HONDA CASTS LONG U.S. SHADOW
description: The United Automobile Workers's suspension of its highly visible organizing drive at the Honda Motors plant at Marysville, Ohio, is a major setback for the union and seems to portend greater organizing difficulties. The union is placing the most favorable interpretation on the situation, saying there was a ''poor climate'' for a vote of the 3,300 hourly workers to see if they wished union representation. It said it would assign more organizers and ultimately organize the plant.

title: HANDCUFFS FOR SCHOOL BOARDS
description: With a teacher shortage looming, why not welcome the agreement between Governor Cuomo and New York's legislative leaders to add $95 million to teachers' salaries? Because a close look shows that the plan would tie the hands of localities in distributing the money, drastically limiting its value. Before the final vote, legislators still have time to make sensible adjustments.

title: DEVISING A SOLUTION FOR STRANDED SEAMEN
description: After an unexpected and unpaid three-month stay on the Brooklyn waterfront, 10 seamen from Colombia, Chile and Peru may be going home - with the unusual twist of being paid to guard the very source of their misery.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,264,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,043,000 for the quarter, $1,901,000 for the year and an extraordinary charge of $249,000 for the quarter, extraordinary gain of $1,441,000 for the year.

title: 26 STATES CHALLENGE REGULATIONS ON ERRORS IN WELFARE PROGRAMS
description: Twenty-six states, the District of Columbia and three California counties sued the Federal Government today to block regulations that would impose $200 million in penalties in connection with two major welfare programs.

title: PHILIPPINE BASES SEE A LONG STRIKE
description: A weeklong strike by Philippine workers has undercut normal operations at the United States naval and air bases in this country, and a military commander warned today that labor troubles could last ''quite a while.''

title: PACIFIC SOUTHWEST, NORTHWEST AIR TIE
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines said it would integrate its flight schedule with Northwest Airlines in an effort to pick up a substantial amount of additional travelers.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a provision for loss on the disposal of container ship operations of $16 million for the quarter and year. c-After a similar provision of $4 million for the quarter and year.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $17,746,000, or 64 cents a share, from the issuance of common stock by subsidiaries. c-Net income and includes a similar gain of $18,922,000, or 81 cents a share. The 1985 results include losses from terminated rental contracts and an erosion of inventory values that reflect market pricing.

title: Cordero Looks Ahead
description: Angel Cordero Jr., who was seriously injured in a spill at Aqueduct on March 8, has been released from New York University Medical Center.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE ACCEPTS SOME COMPROMISE ON RATES
description: The New York Telephone Company today accepted key portions of a compromise rate increase proposed by state utility regulators that would allow the company to raise its bills by an estimated $375 million in two steps.

title: CAN'T WE DEACTIVATE RADIOACTIVE WASTE?
description: To the Editor:

title: MURPHY AND MIZE SHARE LEAD
description: Bob Murphy, who hasn't won on the PGA Tour in more than 11 years, shot a seven-under-par 65 today to set a 36-hole course record of 10-under 134 at the Tournament Players Club.

title: OVERCOMING DISADVANTAGES
description: ''Negative Prediction Defiers'' is what Prof. Charles C. Harrington calls those unlikely achievers from disadvantaged backgrounds whom he has been studying for four years.

title: BARRY LOPEZ, A WRITER STEEPED IN ARCTIC VALUES
description: One winter afternoon, in a village in the Northwest Territories, Barry Lopez was speaking to a 70-year-old Eskimo who was trilingual - in addition to his native Inuktitut, he also knew French and English. Aware that Mr. Lopez had come there as a writer, the Eskimo asked him in English how long he planned to stay. Then he smiled, and, illustrating his point by counting on his fingers, the Eskimo politely answered for him:

title: NEW TOLLS JAM STREETS DOWNTOWN
description: The change to one-way tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has eased traffic on Staten Island but has increased congestion in Manhattan and Brooklyn, preliminary figures indicate.

title: THE WALDHEIM DOSSIER
description: Daily come fresh charges - and denials - concerning the wartime activities of Kurt Waldheim, the former Secretary General of the United Nations. Mr. Waldheim, who is running for President of Austria, says the evidence of his service to Nazis is stale stuff, the fruit of a conspiracy and in any case overblown. His nonchalance is staggering and his denials are disingenuous.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary on Tuesday of Rabbi Moshe Feinstein carried an erroneous reference from Who's Who in World Jewry about his affiliation with the Union of Orthodox Rabbis in America and Canada. He was president until his death.

title: Accord on TV Start
description: The Yankees and WPIX have settled their differences over the Yankees' new 7:30 P.M. starting time for night games this season.

title: REAGAN SEEN RESISTING SOVIET SUMMIT TERMS
description: Administration officials say President Reagan will resist any Soviet efforts to create conditions for the next summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MARCH 29, 1986
description: THE ECONOMY

title: WITH MET OPERA FOR 60 YEARS
description: George Cehanovsky, a baritone whose association with the Metropolitan Opera spanned 60 years, died Tuesday. He was 94 years old, according to most sources, and lived in Yorktown Heights, New York.

title: U.S. READIES NEW CHARGES IN INQUIRY
description: Federal prosecutors plan to seek a broad new racketeering indictment within weeks against figures involved in the scandal at the city's Parking Violations Bureau, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: VACANCY SIGN OUT IN MANHATTAN REALTY BOOM
description: After nearly a decade of explosive growth, Manhattan's real estate market has run out of steam, according to investors, brokers, developers and bankers who have lived through the industry's ups and downs.

title: NAVY CREWS REPORT FINDING 4 BIG PIECES OF SHUTTLE'S DEBRIS
description: Navy salvage ships today reported finding four more large pieces of the space shuttle Challenger, including possibly additional fragments of its crew compartment, according to ship radio communications monitored here.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: Renata Scotto: Prima Donna in Recital Accompaniment by Thomas Fulton Video Arts International 99 minutes. $59.95 Renata Scotto is seen here in a 1984 concert recorded in Japan, singing everything from Handel, Scarlatti and Rossini to Mascagni and Puccini.

title: Margaret Hager Wed To Andrew D. Hart Jr.
description: Margaret Q. Hager and Andrew D. Hart Jr. were married yesterday at the bride's home in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Bedingfield, senior minister of the Reformed Church of Bronxville, N.Y., officiated.

title: Stephanie Stifel And P. M. Britton To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Stephanie Elizabeth Stifel to Peter Mills Britton has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Stifel of Short Hills, N.J., and Stratton Mountain, Vt. The wedding is planned for May 24. Mr. Britton is a son of Mrs. Audley Clarke Britton of West Hartford and Kent, Conn., and the late Mr. Britton.

title: AID TO INNOCENTS ABROAD
description: JAPANESE BUSINESS ETIQUETTE: A PRACTICAL GUIDE TO SUCCESS WITH THE JAPANESE. By Diana Rowland. 176 Pages. Warner Books. $8.95.

title: RESCUE MISSIONS Helping Sleepy Swim
description: At a time when countless patients are giving countless physicians the fish eye, there's one American who can't possibly complain about his medical care. He is Sleepy the seal, an epileptic, whose progress down the East Coast has been monitored by one emergency room after another.

title: PADUA
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MEXICO IS DECLARED SANCTUARY FOR REFUGEES
description: Gov. Toney Anaya has formally declared New Mexico a ''state of sanctuary'' for Central American refugees and says he hopes the action will start a ''snowball effect'' among political leaders around the country.

title: RESCUE MISSIONS Live Question
description: On a recent night, a Brooklyn man who sits up late writing a book that would make sense of the nation's crime problem, found his concentration pierced by screams rising nine floors to his window. He looked out to see a woman in the street shouting ''Stop him! Stop him!'' as a man dashed toward Prospect Park with her purse under his arm.

title:
DINING OUT;
SIMPLICITY AND STYLE IN NEW MENU
description: PERSNICKETY has a kitchen philosophy and a charm and informality that have always made us want this restaurant to be better than it was. Now it is. The owner, Mark Kaplan, and his co-chef, James Philips, have designed an appealing new menu featuring light dishes that, while imaginative, never disguise that what one is eating is good clean food prepared with simplicity and style. The chefs are stingy with salt, frugal with fat and timid with starchy thickeners; and those who maintain that what is left might not be worth eating couldn't be more wrong. Persnickety's dishes arrive redolent with lemon, mustard, green peppercorns, garlic, sage, tarragon or other herbs; and benefit from char-grilling, baking, roasting, braising and expert sauteeing.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO CHOOSE A LANDSCAPE EXPERT
description: A WELL-DESIGNED, well-planted and well-maintained garden represents a considerable investment over the years. The initial cost alone may exceed 15 percent of the price of your home.

title: Karen Kasner Is Married
description: Karen Ann Kasner and Allen Glenn Winik were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kasner of Roslyn, is enrolled in the master degree's program in social work at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., and is a graduate of C. W. Post College in Greenvale, L.I. Her father is the president of the Coordinated Graphics Packaging Corporation, a Long Island City manufacturer of printed boxes. Mr. Winik, the son of Victor Winik of North Hills, L.I., and Doree Smith of Bayside, Queens, is technical sales director of the Bixon Chemical Company in Corona, Queens, manufacturer of cleaning products. His father is president of the company.

title: DEAR DOCTOR, DO YOU HAVE A CURE FOR A ARTBURN?
description: People sometimes have problems in living with art, problems that peer pressure makes them reluctant to acknowledge or discuss. Newspaper ''advice'' columns offer help in such matters as love, money, employment, gardening and home repair, but they have overlooked the needs of the artlorn, those who crave support in coping with the emotional demands made on them by painting, sculpture, and more esoteric manifestations. To remedy this lack, a distinguished psychiartrist, Dr. Les Fauves, author of ''Kunst Without Angst,'' has turned his attention to their difficulties in a new column, ''Advice to the Artlorn.'' Dear Dr. Les: Our Labrador retriever, Dada, keeps bringing home paintings, but we don't know where he gets them. In recent months he has dragged into the house a Keith Haring, a Jean-Michel Basquiat, and a canvas by Futura 2000. Our local museum says it is not missing anything, and there is no one else in the neighborhood who would have such stuff. We have tried following him to see where he gets it, but he always manages to give us the slip. Should we encourage him?

title: Sara Traberman Plans To Wed E. J. Schreiber
description: Meyer Traberman of Woodbridge, N.J., and Dr. Tama Traberman of Glen Gardner, N.J., have announced that their daughter, Sara Valt Traberman, plans to marry Elliot Jay Schreiber, a son of Dr. Herbert Schreiber of Windsor Locks, Conn., and Lois Conway of San Diego.

title: A Setback in The Biotech Race
description: In the crowded race for success in the booming biotechnology market, one competitor seems to have stumbled. The Environmental Protection Agency charged last week that Advanced Genetic Sciences Inc. of Oakland, Calif., falsified data about the proposed field testing of a genetically engineered microbe designed to reduce frost damage to plants.

title: Eris Perese Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Dogan M. Perese of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter Eris Munivver Perese to Peter Herrick Saari, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reino Saari of East Meadow, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Perese is an administrator in the jewelry department at Sotheby's. Mr. Saari is a painter.

title: THE NATIONAL GALLERY: ASSESSING A RISEN STAR
description: At the National Gallery of Art, Washingtonians are being treated to the most ambitious exhibition extravaganza in the history of this hyperactive institution.

title: 76er Centers Hurt
description: The Philadelphia 76ers may be without a center in today's game against the Dallas Mavericks because of injuries to Moses Malone, Bob McAdoo and Clemon Johnson. A team spokesman, Harvey Pollack, said Malone would be out for two weeks, the rest of the regular season, after suffering a fracture of the orbit of his right eye during Friday's game against the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: DON'T WRITE OFF OLD FIGHTERS
description: You have to be wary of a great player who has grown older. In some respects he may evince chinks in his armor that were not there, but in others, his renowned skill may be all too intact.

title: ANNEX PLAN SPURS NEW JAIL BATTLE
description: THE angry debate over how to solve the problem of overcrowding at the Nassau County jail intensified last week after County Executive Francis T. Purcell, declaring he had no other choice, called for construction to begin as soon as possible on a 300-bed annex to the jail in East Meadow.

title: BHOPAL'S LEGAL KNOT TIGHTENS
description: UNION CARBIDE and many of the lawyers representing victims of its gas leak in Bhopal, India, agreed last week on a $350 million settlement. But the Government of India, which last year passed a law making itself the sole legal representative of the victims and says it has retainers from 487,000 of them, rejected it. In the process, it may have paved the way for months of legal battles about who represents the victims and how and where the claims should be handled.

title: I.O.C. EXPECTED TO EASE AMATEUR POLICY
description: The International Olympic Committee, one of the last defenders of the amateur faith, is about to turn the other cheek. In October, it is expected to abandon its traditional amateurs-only stance and allow each international federation governing an Olympic sport to decide which of its athletes - professional or amateur or both - will be eligible for the Olympics.

title: KOREAN RALLY: SYMBOLIC CITY IS SITE TODAY
description: In this southern city whose very name has become a symbol of resistance to the Government, talk of opposition plans for a major rally Sunday is evoking memories of Kwangju's bloody past.

title: CUOMO AND EX-SENATOR BAKER TO END THEIR RADIO PROGRAM
description: Governor Cuomo has decided to end his radio commentary, which was broadcast nationally on about 80 stations of the Mutual Radio Network.

title: A TOUGH COMPETITION
description: If one had to pick the expert with the strongest will to win, an obvious candidate would be the late Lew Mathe. He was tough on himself and tough on his partners, who knew that he was ready to pounce like a tiger - even when he was the dummy.

title: Books From The Times
description: THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER: Enchanting Places and How to Find Them: From Pleasant Hill to Katmandu. Edited by A. M. Rosenthal and Arthur Gelb in association with Michael J. Leahy, Nora Kerr and the Travel staff of The New York Times.

title: WORKER DISMISSED FOR LEAVING JOB TO SAVE AN ELDERLY COUPLE
description: A man has been dismissed after leaving his maintenance job to respond to an emergency call to help two victims of heart attack.

title: Catherine Reilly Is to Wed John W. Uhlein 3d in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Reilly of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Maureen Reilly to John Wyatt Uhlein 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Uhlein Jr., of Litchfield, Conn., and formerly of New Canaan, Conn. The wedding is planned for July.

title: ADVICE FOR THE ANXIOUS SPRING ATHLETE: EASY DOES IT
description: PEOPLE for whom spring is a time to get back in shape after a sedentary winter may find, as T. S. Eliot wrote, that April is the cruelest month.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL '86: TEXAS vs. U.S.C.; WOMEN'S FINAL FOUR DRAWS FEW FANS BUT STIRS BIG HOPES
description: THERE are no former coaches-turned-television-commentators working the hotel lobby like nightclub comics. Elevator service is close to normal, and guests are rarely crowded inside as if part of an assault on a record found in the Guinness Book: ''Most people in one elevator during the week of a major sports event.'' There are even plenty of tickets available at the box office for the price that is stamped on the ticket. Obviously, a scalper would not make a living here this weekend.

title: 3 CHILDREN ARE KILLED IN A FIRE IN ALABAMA
description: Three children burned to death in a brick apartment building 500 feet from a fire station here today.

title: THE SOUNDS OF THE BIG BANDS OF THE '40's ARE BACK -- AND LIVE
description: FOOD isn't the only thing on the menu one night a week at Perretti's restaurant on Paterson Plank Road here.

title: MIDTOWN EAST
description: ''I FEEL like a kid in F. A. O. Schwarz at Christmastime,'' says Robert B. Friedman, who recently moved into an apartment on East 58th Street in Manhattan, just six blocks from the famed toy store and from his office.

title: CAMBRIDGE DEFEATS OXFORD IN THE RAIN
description: The Light Blues of Cambridge survived appalling weather conditions as they ended a decade of Oxford domination to win the 132d University Boat Race by seven lengths today.

title:
SHOULD CONGRESS RAISE THE MINIMUM WAGE?;
THE WORKING POOR DESERVE A RAISE
description: ECONOMISTS are predicting continued economic growth and prosperity for the foreseeable future, and that is good news. Unfortunately, the millions of Americans who work for the minimum wage are not sharing this prosperity. The real value of the minimum - which was designed to protect the working poor by placing a floor under their meager earnings - is now at its lowest level since 1955.

title: NORTHERN ITALIAN AT A HIGH PRICE
description: RESTAURANT prices, which have been creeping up for months around the state, take a quantum leap at Delmonico's, the new restaurant in Greenwich in the townhouse that formerly was home to Cinquante Cinq.

title: BLAMING GOLD FOR EVERYTHING
description: THE RANDLORDS By Geoffrey Wheatcroft. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Atheneum. $17.95. IN the preface to his hard-to-put-down book, ''The Randlords,'' Geoffrey Wheatcroft, a talented British journalist and columnist for The Evening Standard of London, observes that the social and economic forces enveloping South Africa today relate directly to one industry - gold. Then he disclaims: ''A mighty book could be written on such a mighty theme. This is not that. What has emerged from my efforts is a modest little book with a good deal to be modest about. All that I have been able to do is to pick out some themes here and there and highlight them.''

title: SHUTTLE SEARCH MAY BE NAVY'S BIGGEST, AIDE SAYS
description: Asked if the search for the wreckage of the space shuttle Challenger was the biggest salvage operation ever undertaken by the Navy, Capt. Charles A. Bartholomew at first recalled the recovery of the hydrogen bomb lost off Spain in 1966 and the search for the Korean Air Lines plane shot down off Siberia in 1983.

title: GUIDED NISSAN CAR COMPANY
description: Katsuji Kawamata, who as chairman of the Nissan Motor Company built the manufacturer into the second-largest carmaker in Japan, died today, the company said. He was 81 years old.

title: WHERE SERVICE OUTSHINES FOOD
description: FEW restaurants on Long Island make you feel as welcome, comfortable and catered to as Emilia in Carle Place. The owners and staff go out of their way to be accommodating, and when they inquire as to whether everything is all right, it is not merely a perfunctory going through the motions.

title: RELIGIOUS BOOKS: SEVEN THAT MADE A DIFFERENCE
description: ''THE religious revival confronting us is . . . primarily a literary tour-de-force'' having ''very little to do with American life as a whole,'' William Phillips, the editor of Partisan Review, wrote in his magazine's 1950 symposium, ''Religion and the Intellectuals.'' It was a rash claim, and not just because the postwar revival ended up reaching well beyond those who had heard of T. S. Eliot. In a religious tradition that has been obsessed with texts ever since the Ten Command-ments, literary tours de force should not be taken lightly.

title: Place Names in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: TOPICS
description: IT is late at night. As I lie in my bed, tossing in search of sleep, a voice from across the room assaults my inner world. I pretend to be asleep, but the voice knows otherwise and persists in calling me. Finally, in a burst of unwarranted anger, I whine, ''What do you want?''

title: Eichmann Trial Is Subject At Jewish Museum
description: ON April 24, 1961, Salo W. Baron, professor of Jewish history, institutions and literature at Columbia University, testified as a ''historic witness'' at the trial in Jerusalem of Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war criminal.

title: SOME THINGS SWEDISH WEREN'T PALME'S DOING
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS'S FORTUNE: INQUIRY IN MANILA OFFERS PICTURE OF HOW IT WAS ACQUIRED
description: With one of his lesser-known presidential decrees, Ferdinand E. Marcos once ordered that a remote island in the South China Sea be made into a preserve for African animals. It was to be a natural sanctuary, he said.

title: Amy Lewis Plans to Wed P. E. Doering
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Lewis of Southport, Conn., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Thorne Lewis to Peter Eckart Doering, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eckart Doering of Riverside, Conn. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Verbatim; Sharing Responsibility
description: 'The bill is a reflection of changing times and changing roles between the Federal Government, the states and the private sector. It shows a greater appreciation of the need to share responsibility for the infrastructure and of the environmental problems caused by these projects.'

title: THE RICHEST FOUNDATION
description: DR. DONALD S. FREDRICKSON settled into a heavy leather chair in Yale University's Corporation Room, the school's decorous inner sanctum where the trustees meet and visitors are seldom allowed.

title: DECISION TO FREE RUBIN CARTER IS APPEALED BY PROSECUTORS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 29 (AP) -

title: CHINA PLANS TO LAUNCH A SATELLITE FOR SWEDEN
description: China, apparently taking advantage of the gap created by the loss of the United States space shuttle Challenger, has announced plans for its first commercial space venture, in which it will launch a Swedish communications satellite.

title: MUSIC: BY THREE WOMEN
description: THE Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris (Park Avenue and 42d Street) has been presenting weekly concerts at 6 in the evening. It's a good way to sit out the Grand Central Terminal rush hour and, not so incidentally, to hear some engrossing music.

title: Art
description: Fifty years ago the English pre-Raphaelite painters had their full share of the derision that at that time attached to the mid-Victorian era in all its esthetic aspects. Holman Hunt, Madox Brown, Burne-Jones, Dante Gabriel Rossetti and John Everett Millais were an embarrassment - an aberrant episode in the history of English taste that would best be forgotten.

title: REVISED PROPOSAL OF SALES TAX IS WEIGHED
description: A REVISED version of a sales-tax plan that died two years ago in Albany - one that would now provide revenue for Westchester's three largest cities as well as for the county's towns and villages - is making its way again through State Senate and Assembly committees.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO CHOOSE A LANDSCAPE EXPERT
description: A WELL-DESIGNED, well-planted and well-maintained garden represents a considerable investment over the years. The initial cost alone may exceed 15 percent of the price of your home.

title: LAXALT, LEAVING SENATE, TESTS POLITICAL MUSCLE
description: In the year before he leaves public office, Senator Paul Laxalt has risked his prestige in an attempt to persuade Nevada voters to accept his hand-picked candidate as his successor.

title: BERMUDA DEPICTS HISTORIC SHIPWRECKS
description: The Bermuda Philatelic Bureau is issuing a three-part set of new definitives in 1986. Definitives are regular issues of a country and usually contain a sufficient mix of values to meet all domestic and international rates. They are printed in larger quantities and over a longer period of time than are commemoratives.

title: NORWALK GATHERS UNWANTED GUNS
description: NORWALK residents have been giving the police guns in an effort to get unwanted weapons out of circulation.

title: A PASSION BORN IN KINDERGARTEN
description: ANGELS OF SEPTEMBER By Andrew M. Greeley. 451 pp. New York: A Bernard Geis Associates Book/ Warner Books. $17.95. ANDREW M. GREELEY is a caution, as my friend Mrs. O'Brien would say, that is, someone who astonishes or causes mild apprehension. Sociologist, Roman Catholic priest, syndicated columnist, college teacher, theologian - deeply concerned with the role of religion in modern life - he is the author of more than 100 scholarly and popular articles and dozens of nonfiction books (variously characterized as truculent, cantankerous, controversial, crotchety, contentious, argumentative, brilliant, lucid, reasonable, readable, witty), as well as a volume of poetry brashly called ''Women I've Met.''

title: Cardinal Frowns On Parish Bingo
description: Some convictions demand more courage than others, but John Cardinal O'Connor evidently is not lacking in grit. He has suggested that the Roman Catholic Church might find ''a dignified substitute'' for bingo.

title: YOUR ERRANDS DONE, FOR A FEE
description: LIVING in Connecticut but working in New York City can put a damper on anyone's weekend. Catching a 7:04 A.M. train to Manhattan and not getting back until after 7 P.M. means that errands do not get done until Saturday or Sunday.

title: IN 1936, SURREALISM RULED THE CREATIVE ROOST
description: The Zabriskie Gallery, at 724 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, could not have picked a better moment for its current exhibition, which is called ''1936:

title: BACKMAN IS FACING ANOTHER BATTLE
description: The little man at the end of the bench is trying to talk. But there are constant interruptions. One teammate grabs him playfully by the arm, another gently flips the cap off his head. The little man smiles, then carries on.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, MARCH 30, 1986
description: International

title: CUT IN RENT ALLOWANCE LEADS TO A SHIFT TO CONVERSIONS
description: CHANGE is coming to Hampton Court -not the one in England, but the apartment complex in Kew Gardens, Queens. The name itself is an early harbinger of the change.

title: COOKING OIL KILLS 6 IN INDIA
description: Contaminated cooking oil sold at government shops killed 6 children and injured 85 people Saturday in the western state of Gujarat, the news service United News of India reported. Three people were hospitalized in serious condition after food poisoning in five villages, the news agency said. It was not immediately known how the oil became contaminated.

title: Elizabeth Gowen Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis I. Gowen of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Cabell Gowen to Scott Lee Kuensell, a son of Mrs. Dean Burtch of Devon, Pa., and Dr. S. Lee Kuensell of Marlton, N.J. An October wedding is planned. Miss Gowen, an assistant portfolio manager with the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, graduated from the St. George's School in Newport, R.I., and Washington College in Chestertown, Md.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A FORGETFUL DRIVER
description: WHEN Harold, who pumps gas down the street, opens my tank and gets ready to fill it up, he often comments on the Hide A Key tucked just inside.

title: RULING AMBIGUOUS; ATTACK ON THE POPE: HOW CASE DEVELOPED
description: The verdict yesterday in the case arising from the shooting of Pope John Paul II came nearly five years after the assassination attempt. These were some of the key developments in the case:

title: Dr. Wendy Ellen Mahler to Wed Douglas Linker
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Mahler of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Wendy Ellen Mahler, to Douglas Richard Linker, a son of Sylvia Linker Matles of Fort Lee, N.J., and the late Joseph Linker.

title: YANKEES GIVE TEWKSBURY STARTING ROLE
description: Bob Tewksbury, having pitched six additional shutout innings for a string of 13, was headed out the door of the Yankees' clubhouse when his manager's voice stopped him.

title: WHITE HOUSE COOL TO MOSCOW'S PLAN
description: The White House today criticized Mikhail S. Gorbachev's proposal for a meeting in Europe with President Reagan to seek an agreement to end nuclear tests, saying a summit meeting must deal ''with the entire range of important issues between our two countries.''

title: BECKER DEFEATS CONNORS
description: Boris Becker of West Germany, 18 years old, said he felt more like 39 after his three-set semifinal victory over Jimmy Connors today at the Volvo-Chicago Tournament.

title: MIZE POSTS 66 TO LEAD BY FOUR
description: Larry Hogan Mize came close to settling the issue in the 13th annual Tournament Players Championship today when he ran off to a four-shot lead as the winds affected the performances of most of the other players.

title: NASA Promises More Flights And Tighter Rules
description: ''We want to make it clear to all our customers that we are getting back into business,'' Adm. Richard H. Truly, the space shuttle's new director, told employees of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in an upbeat speech last week. But he made it clear that it would hardly be business as usual.

title: ARCHITECT'S PRINCETON WORK PROVOKES LIVELY CAMPUS DEBATE
description: A recent announcement by Princeton University that Robert Venturi's architecture firm would design its third major building on campus has renewed discussions about his work among students and architecture professors.

title: DISPUTE CONTINUES AT COUNTY HOSPITAL
description: THEY stormed the boss's office in January, and they marched in front of the hospital earlier this month, but interns and residents at the Westchester County Medical Center were still without a contract last week.

title: CONCERT: TOCCO, TATE AND MASSED CHORISTERS
description: IN view of the astonishing expense of putting on a concert involving the American Symphony Orchestra, the pianist James Tocco, the bass Joseph Tate, hundreds of choral singers brought from as far away as Iowa, Minnesota and Arkansas and an ensemble of brass players from California, the event put on at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night was simply mind-boggling. It was presented by MidAmerica Productions, of which Peter Tiboris is general director, and he conducted the concert.

title: May Wedding Is Planned By Deborah S. Neuberger
description: A May wedding is planned by Deborah Sue Neuberger and Glenn Maron, her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Frank W. Neuberger of Bethesda, Md., have announced.

title: Alice Moyer Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. F. Stanton Moyer of Haverford, Pa., and Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Eyre Moyer, to Dana Haines Stewardson, the son of Mrs. Jeremiah Ford 3d of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late William Emlyn Stewardson. A September wedding is planned.

title: Brooklyn Revival
description: Downtown Brooklyn has for decades dreamed of a Manhattan-style office rejuvenation. Recently, with several large developers announcing plans for more than 2.5 million square feet of office and residential space, borough leaders saw those hopes start to come to fruition.

title:
ART;
AMERICAN ABSTRACT ARTISTS LOOKS BACK AT 50-YEAR HISTORY
description: AMERICAN Abstract Artists was an embattled organization for the first part of its 50-year history. Some unsympathetic critics even labeled as un-American the group's renunciation of popular social realism in favor of modern, nonfigurative work. With the dust from those skirmishes long settled, the the organization is calling its current exhibition at the Bronx Museum for the Arts, commemorating 50 years, a celebration.

title: PENSION-FUND LOSS IS CALLED 'MARGINAL'
description: ROLAND M. MACHOLD, director of the state's Division of Investment, says that the reported loss of $6 million in the value of state pension funds stemming from New Jersey's new divestment law was ''marginal'' and not a cause for immediate concern to the 380,000 beneficiaries of the funds.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: If you recall Bette Davis as the pathological governess in ''The Nanny,'' you'll be chilled. Read the British author Patricia Angadi's first novel, THE GOVERNESS (Gollancz/David & Charles, $18.95) and initially you'll be left cold. The novel opens in 1918 in London; the first narrator in this book of many narrators is Eleanor Lane-Baker, a stereotypical weary wife and exasperated mother of six. Eleanor raises questions that by 1918 standards were bold: ''Why should not men, at some time in their lives, be made to suffer as women do? Why should they not have the agony of both menstruation and giving birth?'' The futility of these questions aside, Eleanor does the only thing she believes a woman can do - she hires another woman, Violet Mabel Herring, known as Herry, to be governess in her household. Once Herry becomes part of this family's fabric she is referred to as a saint by Edward, Eleanor's husband, and five of their children, and perceived as an evil force by the not-quite-reliable son, Justus. All the reader knows for certain is that Herry seems quite capable, smiles a lot and is quite tolerant of Eleanor's and Justus's sarcasm. Patricia Angardi supplies the reader with each family member's point of view on Herry between 1918 and 1938; what these alternating narratives make clear is that the book has less to do with Herry's sainthood or evil than with the ubiquitous neuroses of the family. So while the author's intention may have been to create a black tale about the insidious nature of blind benevolence, the family's dissolution - which includes Edward's seduction of Herry, Miles's suicide and Helen's nervous breakdown - seems inevitable regardless of Herry's role as a ''red herring,'' blamed for the problems of the Lane-Bakers.

title:
WHY CHEAP OIL IS NO BOON FOR THE U.S.;
A PERIL TO SECURITY
description: The collapse of the Geneva talks involving members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and oil-producing countries that are not OPEC members leaves the world with no mechanism to restore the stability of oil prices. And as long as Saudi Arabia sticks to its program of increased production, prices will continue to plunge. This problem not only harms the United States' petroleum industry but also threatens national security. The answer is an oil import fee.Americans who hope for a price war do not appreciate what it would cost the nation. Cheap oil threatens our security and economic vitality by crippling the petroleum industry. The Government should immediately enact a tax on all imported crude oil and petroleum products.

title: BUSINESS AND ARTS: A PARTNERSHIP THAT SERVES BOTH
description: ACROSS the country in leading centers of business and the arts, and certainly in Connecticut, there are extraordinary opportunities for corporations to invest in culture.

title: PALESTINIANS AND SHIITES BATTLE IN BEIRUT
description: Palestinian guerrillas battled Shiite Moslem militiamen with rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns in two Beirut refugee districts today, and militia sources reported 4 gunmen killed and 30 people wounded.

title: TRYING TO USE THE MILITARY AS AN INSTRUMENT OF DIPLOMACY
description: WITH quick precision, President Reagan inserted American armed forces into two complex international problems last week, demonstrating again the measured activism with which he has tried to inch the United States out of its deep, post-Vietnam aversion to using military power in support of foreign policy. But the two moves, against Libya and Nicaragua, were so fleeting, so low in risk for American servicemen and so tangential to the basic conflicts that they also showed the severe restrictions on America's power.

title: BRASILIA
description: Laid out with precision beside an artificial lake on a green landscaped plain, engulfed by distant horizons and a vast, always changing sky, Brasilia is a monument to dreams -the generations-old dream of moving Brazil's capital inland and the dream of President Juscelino Kubitschek to build a city in just three years. On April 21, 1960, when the capital was moved from Rio de Janeiro to Brasilia, both dreams were fulfilled.

title: Driver Extradited
description: John Paul Sr., the former race car driver who fled to Switzerland and forfeited a $500,000 bond rather than face an attempted-murder charge in Florida, has been returned to the state to stand trial. The 46-year-old Paul, who also faces Federal drug charges that he conspired to import 200,000 tons of Colombian marijuana into the United States from 1975 to 1983, is accused of shooting a Federal drug witness at a Florida boat dock in 1983.

title: SUPERMAGNETS: MORE PULL, LESS WEIGHT
description: THE new generation of supermagnets made from rare earth elements are the mighty mites of the business. G.M., for instance, says that by using these magnets - which are the size of a quarter - in the starter motor of a car, it can shrink the weight of the motor from 20 to 10 pounds, halve its bulk and get the same horsepower, all with 20 percent less use of electrical energy.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BONNETS AND JELLY BEANS The city of Bridgeport celebrates Easter and spring from 2:30 to 4:30 this afternoon, with bonnets and jelly beans during its annual Easter Promenade at Baldwin Plaza.

title: ASPEN FESTIVAL TUNES UP ON L.I.
description: THE dynamic between a master teacher and a young virtuoso usually takes place in private, but Long Island will get a rare opportunity to sit in on the give-and-take next Saturday afternoon in a special concert at the Hillwood Commons Lecture Hall of the C. W. Post Center in Brookville.

title: CORRECTION
description: A concert review last Sunday misidentified the New York Philharmonic musician who played the glockenspiel bell in the ''Campanella'' movement of Paganini's Violin Concerto No. 2. He was Christopher Lamb, not Morris Lang.

title: Amanda H. Boe Will Wed in May
description: Mrs. Deon Woolfolk Boe of Stamford, Conn., and Roy Lars Magnus Boe of Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amanda Harding Boe to William Foster Faulkner, a son of Mrs. Thomas Curtiss Taylor of Rochester and Dwight Foster Faulkner of New York. A May wedding is planned.

title: SURGE IN BUILDING DRAINING LABOR POOL
description: THE surge in building sweeping New York is triggering the greatest demand for construction workers in almost two decades, straining the supply of the most highly skilled tradesmen and increasing the labor costs of some new homes, apartments and offices.

title: Data Bank: March 30, 1986
LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: EASTER PARADE In suburbia, anything that lasts more than a quarter of a century tends to be considered ''traditional.'' Therefore, Garden City's Easter Antique Car Parade and Exhibit, which makes its 27th annual run today, is a fixture on the Long Island scene. At 1 P.M. the cars start parading down Franklin Avenue. The festivities will end across from the Village Hall on Stewart Avenue, where there will be an Easter egg tree, costumed bunnies, lollipops for the children and, of course, the vintage cars, parked for closer scrutiny. Everything is free.MATZOH BAKE

title: An Earring
description: I am lucky to have familial support for my earring: my father and I both had our ears pierced, in keeping with the old mariners' tradition of piercing the winchward ear if you survive a disaster at sea (for us, it was being shipwrecked on a reef during a hurricane in 1973).

title:
ANTIQUES;
ESTATE ITEMS SOLD ON THE AUCTION BLOCK
description: ALTHOUGH snow had been predicted, inclement weather was of the least concern last Monday night to Regina Madigan and Linda Stamm, auctioneers who own Winter Associates in Plainville. The estate auction promised went on as scheduled, selling 97 percent of the 394 lots put on the block.

title: Erica Judith Kirsners Weds Adam Silk
description: Erica Judith Kirsners and Adam Jonathan Silk were married yesterday at the De Cordova Museum in Lincoln, Mass., by Rabbi Ben-Zion Gold, director of the Hillel Foundation of Harvard University.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Some Never Worn, Some Gently Used Instant Replay, a consignment boutique that opened 11 years ago in Harrison, has ''gently used'' women's wear from major manufacturers and designers and some never-worn items brought in by a purchaser who changed her mind once home or obtained from a retail store at the end of a season. The sportswear and dressy clothes are dramatically reduced; handbags are marked $5 or $6 to $40; evening bags begin at about $15; shoes are $15 to $28, sometimes to $39; wallets sell for $3 to $15; belts are $1 to $20; scarves are $3 to $15 and costume jewelry begins at $2.

title: 'LES MISERABLES' IS REBORN AS A LAVISH ROCK OPERA
description: According to most of the rules, customs and formulae, ''Les Miserables'' ought to be a mega-flop.

title: 2 DIE IN SOUTH AFRICA AS MEETING OPENS
description: Two people were killed today in street fighting in this Indian Ocean port city shortly before the start of a conference by parents, teachers and scholars that will decide whether hundreds of thousands of black South African pupils resume classroom boycotts.

title: WHEN THE OFF SEASON IS THE BEST SEASON
description: The theory of travel I am about to expound is certainly not original. Nor is it born of deep reflection. It is the result of having tried in the month of May to steal an unimpeded glimpse of the Botticellis and Bellinis in the Uffizi in Florence, in between the massed battalions of organized tour groups dispatched by various nations hostile to my purpose, including my own.

title: ...AND DRAWING A RELUCTANT ALLY INTO A DIFFICULT CONFLICT
description: IT began early last week with a Sandinista attack on Nicaraguan guerrilla bases in Honduras. It ended four days later with 14 United States Army helicopters, piloted by American soldiers, flying Honduran troops into a border war zone - a major step up in Washington's efforts to protect the rebels.

title: SHULTZ DEFENDS U.S. LIBYA POLICY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz seemed to express frustration today over the lack of support from most European and Middle East nations for the tough American policy against Libya.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SOUTHERN LIGHT. By J. R. Salamanca. (Knopf, $19.95.) ''They ain't no man on the earth that is free of corruption,'' a dying black man says to the hero of ''Southern Light.''

title: ISLANDERS ARE TIED BY OILERS
description: Few things are more ephemeral than a one-goal lead over the Edmonton Oilers. The Islanders nursed theirs off and on for most of the evening tonight at Nassau Coliseum, only to see it evaporate at 11 minutes 52 seconds of the third period when Jari Kurri scored his second goal of the game, which ended in a 4-4 tie.

title: NAVY DOMINATES PRINCETON CREWS
description: Navy's heavyweight crew opened its season in convincing fashion, defeating Princeton in four of the six races today on an unusually calm Severn River course. The Middies captured the featured varsity race to win the Navy-Princeton Cup for the eighth consecutive year.

title: Elizabeth Jimenez Becomes Bride of G. A. Stern, an Investment Banker
description: Elizabeth Anne Jimenez, an associate with Paine Webber, the brokerage house, and Geoffrey Adlai Stern, a vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment bank, were married yesterday at the Harmonie Club in New York. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: JAZZ: TERRY AND FADDIS
description: BOTH Clark Terry and Jon Faddis play trumpet and fluegelhorn and both blend sly humor and virtuosity in their playing. They are teamed at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue and 17th Street, through today in duets, solos and challenges that induce each to listen to the other with amused amazement.

title: AUTHORITY ON LIVER DISORDERS
description: Dr. Gerald Klatskin, the David Paige Smith Professor Emeritus at the Yale School of Medicine and a developer of liver biopsy techniques, died Thursday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: MAGAZINE SAYS MAO WAS NOT A PLAGIARIST
description: An official Chinese magazine denied today that Mao Zedong could ever have been guilty of plagiarism.

title: EUROPE QUESTIONS OUR WILL ON TEST BAN TREATY
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSERTIVE HERBS RISING TO THE OCCASION AT MARKET
description: HERBS can be divided roughly into two categories: the sturdy ones with assertive, lasting flavors and the more delicate, fragile varieties. Interestingly enough, this division also applies generally to the way they grow. The sturdy herbs are often the perennials and the fragile ones are the annuals.

title: Donna Kane Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. James P. Kane of Packanack, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna Maureen Kane to Mark Robert Staples, a son of Everett M. Staples of Augusta, Me., and Elizabeth M. Staples of Camden, Me.

title: THE DOLLAR'S DOWN, BUT NOT ENOUGH
description: THE initiative to lower the value of the dollar started by Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the Group of Five countries has been a major success - so far. The United States currency has fallen by about 25 percent from its peak a year ago, and half of the decline has come since the largest industrial countries met at New York's Plaza Hotel last September.

title: A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine
description: Dr. Hilfiker decided that the major cause of inadequate health care for the poor is the greed of American doctors.

title: DEAR PRESIDENT MUBARAK
description: THE Jaffe family was making plans last fall for a vacation in Egypt. In October, however, an American was slain by terrorists on the Mediterranean cruise ship Achille Lauro, seized off Egypt; and a month later an Egyptair Boeing 737 on an Athens-to-Cairo flight was hijacked to Malta, where Egyptian commandos stormed the plane. Sixty of the 98 people aboard eventually died.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: FAMILY 'SNOOPING': ANOTHER VIEW
description: If the reason you printed no letters to the editor in support of Linda Flayton's recent article ''I Snoop on My Children - and Here's Why'' [ Opinion Page ] is that you received none, I feel very guilty. Those who attacked her do not have their fingers on the pulses of today's children.

title: Robin Greer Is Engaged To Kevin Patrick Hallock
description: The engagement of Robyn Lewis Greer to Kevin Patrick Hallock has been announced by Miss Greer's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Kirk Greer of Cos Cob, Conn., and East Dennis, Mass.

title: BALLET: HARLEM DANCE THEATER IN 'SAFFRON KNOT'
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem presented the company premiere of ''Saffron Knot,'' a strange and effective duet, Friday night at Aaron Davis Hall as part of its continuing and exuberantly received ''Harlem Homecoming'' Season.

title: A CAREER OF 56 YEARS IS STILL GOING STRONG
description: IF one wishes to revel in theater lore -accounts of legendary performances or historic productions - a conversation with Margaret Barker of Fairfield is called for.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: ONE of the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society's customary sorties into the unexpected Friday night was Paganini's Quartet for Guitar and Strings in A - the 14th of 15 he wrote for this combination of instruments.

title: Q and A
description: Question:I want to go to China and travel independently. Can you name a travel agency that could assist me? -M. K. C., Milton, Mass. Answer:The best approach is to have a travel agent ask a wholesale tour company that plans travel in China to make arrangments for accommodations and transporation. Most of the wholesalers that specialize in China still prefer to concentrate on group travel but some are prepared to plan trips for individuals. However, during the peak seasons, from late April through early June and in late September and October, getting permission for a visitor to travel alone and making independent arrangements are difficult, members of some of these firms report. Many hotels and chauffeur-driven cars are overbooked at these times. Furthermore, the China International Travel Service in Peking, through which most independent travel arrrangements are made, does not provide any documentation for hotel and other bookings in advance, although it grants visas ahead of time.

title: VIEWS INTO THE WORLD OF R. BUCKMINSTER FULLER
description: RICHARD BUCKMINSTER FULLER died in 1983 at the age of 87, bedecked with honors from the establishment that he had spent his life bucking. These included membership in the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, the Presidential Medal of Freedom and - most significant of all for an architect manque - a gold medal from the American Institute of Architects.

title: Nancy Kuniholm To Marry May 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. John G. Kuniholm of Chadds Ford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Church Kuniholm to Craig Thomas Aronhalt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Aronhalt of Hockessin, Del. A May 24 wedding is planned.

title: SUPERFUND BILL 'A HUGE BOONDOGGLE'
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg urges New Jersey residents to keep the pressure on Congress for a new Superfund bill [ Opinion Page, March 16 ] .

title: GORBACHEV SEEKS TO TALK TO REAGAN ON ATOM TEST BAN
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev proposed today to meet President Reagan anywhere in Europe ''in the nearest future'' to discuss an end to nuclear testing.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHERE DID OUR LOVE GO?: The Rise & Fall of the Motown Sound. By Nelson George. (St. Martin's, $17.95.) Nelson George, Billboard's editor most concerned with black music and a frequent writer on the subject, has given us this biography of Motown Records, which grew from its formation in Detroit in 1959 to become one of the largest black-owned companies in the United States.

title: CARDINALS SMOTHER L.S.U.'S BEST HOPE
description: Throughout all Dale Brown's happy rhetoric this month - all the talk about his brave overachievers from Louisiana State getting down on hands and knees and scrubbing the floors if necessary to reach the national semifinals - there was one truth.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO CHOOSE A LANDSCAPE EXPERT
description: A WELL-DESIGNED, well-planted and well-maintained garden represents a considerable investment over the years. The initial cost alone may exceed 15 percent of the price of your home.

title: VOODOO AND SUBTLER POWERS
description: THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE By Charles Johnson. 169 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. CHARLES JOHNSON'S brief, highly concentrated ''Sorcerer's Apprentice'' has the feel of a good short novel rather than a collection of stories. These tales - or are they fables? - are realistic without strictly adhering to realism, fantastic without getting lost in fantasy. Mr. Johnson, a professor of English at the University of Washington, writes of truths that intersect and sometimes intercept our everyday trajectories.

title: Dr. Marsha J. Seidelman Plans a September Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Seidelman of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Marsha Joyce Seidelman to Dr. Gerald Mark Scheinman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Scheinman of Deal Park, N.J. A September wedding is planned.

title: TED TURNER'S SCREEN TEST
description: FOR many Americans, Ted Turner is a buccaneer entrepreneur, an imaginative egocentric who takes on improbable ventures - and somehow makes them work.

title: PLAN TO GIVE MORE POLES ASYLUM IS UNDER STUDY BY ADMINISTRATION
description: The Justice Department is drafting new procedures that would make it easier for citizens of Poland and other Communist countries to gain asylum in the United States.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
EASTER RITES
description: TODAY, Phyllis Mezzancello and her father and her sisters and their children will go to Easter services at their church. They will ooh and ah over eggs died lavender and yellow and robin's egg blue, and baskets filled with green cellophane grass and chocolate bunnies and little white lambs made of porcelain or sugar. And they will eat pizza rustica, pies made of cheese and meat, and later, a nice roast lamb.

title: LAW BANS SALE OF FALSE IDENTIFICATIN CARDS
description: Governor Cuomo signed into law last week a measure banning the sale or production of counterfeit identification cards, used primarily by underage liquor buyers.

title: A SHOT IN THE ARM FOR A GERIATRIC CENTER
description: THE newest buildings at the John E. Runnells Hospital complex in Berkeley Heights are at least 25 years old, and some of its structures date to the turn of the century when the facility opened as the Bonnie Burn Tuberculosis Sanatorium.

title: 2 WOMEN LEADING IN NEBRASKA RACE
description: If the primary election in this conservative farm state was being held now instead of May 13, Nebraska would probably become the first state ever to name women to lead the tickets of both major parties, political experts here say.

title: An Earring
description: The summer after graduating from college, I embarked upon my lifelong dream of touring Europe by motorcycle, and, not coincidentally, with a gold hoop firmly stationed in my left ear (''An Earring,'' by Douglas Ford, About Men, March 2).

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 1:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: AS THE DOLLAR COOLS OFF, THE GRAY MARKET HEATS UP
description: The falling dollar is jolting the audio trade, which depends heavily on imports, and the effect is magnified by the anticipation of a further decline of United States currency. Faced with stiff price hikes scheduled for midyear, many audio fans may find their desires exceeding their budget and of necessity may look for special bargains.

title: BEFORE THE PROFESSORS TOOK OVER
description: A HISTORY OF MODERN CRITICISM: 1750-1950 Volume Five: English Criticism, 1900-1950. 343 pp. Volume Six: American Criticism, 1900-1950. 345 pp. By Rene Wellek. New Haven: Yale University Press. $22.50 each. WE live in a time when literary criticism is dominated by the academy. The days of the great poet-critics or novelist-critics - of Dryden or Johnson, Coleridge or Arnold, Flaubert or James, Eliot or Pound - seem to be over. If such people still exist, and I see no sign of it, the chances are that they are employed by a university. The leading reviewers, who were once men of letters or men of affairs, from Hazlitt and Macaulay to Ford Madox Ford and Orwell, are now for the most part professors. Compare the contributors to the great earlier periodicals, from the Edinburgh and Quarterly Reviews to Eliot's Criterion, with those of modern quarterlies like The Sewanee Review or such papers as The New York Review of Books, the London Review of Books or The Times Literary Supplement.

title: A Lesson in Tragedy
description: As a teacher, I have followed students' reactions to the space-shuttle disaster intently and was moved by Mr. Bryan's article. But his closing conjecture about Ellison Onizuka's views on continuing manned space flights and his abrupt interpretation of his stepson Derek's expressive glance disturbed me.

title: MANILA REGION WITH 2 MAYORS: A SYMBOL OF BATTLE TO CONTROL LOCAL OFFICES
description: In what some of them regarded as an act of political obligation and others a mere attention-grabbing gimmick, several hundred men and women blockaded the entrance to the cream-colored City Hall of the San Juan district of Manila today.

title: TEST MAY PINPOINT VICTIMS OF BONE DISEASE
description: A new test could help predict a woman's susceptibility to the bone disease osteoporosis and determine how best to treat the malady, which ranks third as a cause of death among women over 50 years old, doctors say.

title: AN INCREASE WOULD HURT TEEN-AGERS
description: IS it time once again to raise the minimum wage? It has indeed fallen since it was last raised in 1981, after adjustment for inflation and relative to average wages. But we should look carefully at the consequences of raising the minimum.

title: Hammer Death: Killing or Suicide?
description: WHEN a man is found dead of 32 hammer blows to the head, is it murder or suicide?

title: BOSTON U. OFFERS PLACE TO SOVIET JEW
description: Boston University, in a move to focus attention on the condition of Jews in the Soviet Union, has granted admission and scholarship aid to the son of a Soviet dissident.

title: FOR NORTHVILLE, SHIFTING FORTUNES
description: THE sharp decline in the world price of oil is forcing Northville Industries Corporation, the largest independent supplier of home heating oil and other petroleum products on Long Island, to consider closing or sharply scaling down its 5.2-million-barrel tank farm in Riverhead Town, company executives say.

title: BOOM ON MAUI PROMPTS A LONGING FOR SERENITY
description: A resident of this old whaling port on the island of Maui, in a recent letter to the local newspaper, heaped praise on residents of the nearby island of Kauai for their fight against overdevelopment.

title: THE RECTOR'S WILL AND OTHER MYSTERIES
description: PARADISE POSTPONED By John Mortimer. 374 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95. EVER since Virginia Woolf and James Joyce dynamited the conventional English novel, those of us who love the old Victorian-Edwardian form have been looking for a modern-day equivalent. John Mortimer may well have provided one.

title: Exporting Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
IN HONOR OF THE CHALLENGER'S ASTRONAUTS
description: When Alex Shagin learned that the space shuttle Challenger had exploded and killed seven astronauts, he was stunned and stirred into action. Working around the clock, Mr. Shagin, a gifted artist, fashioned a striking new medal that embodies a heartfelt tribute to the crew.

title: BULLS HAND KNICKS RECORD-TYING LOSS
description: The Knicks, a team with an injury list full of stars, tied a team record last night by dropping their fifth consecutive home game. The Chicago Bulls, a team whose brightest star, Michael Jordan, returned from an injury just eight games ago, recorded a 106-96 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: PENNY FOR THEIR THOUGHTS -- HOW AUTHORS CAN GET LIBRARY 'ROYALTIES'
description: THE dreams of many American authors are connected to a computer and information bank in this small industrial town near Darlington in the northeastern corner of England. Stockton-on-Tees has a quaint literary air about it; it could be the locale for a mystery story set on the nearby moors. In fact, it serves as the little-known headquarters for a fairly new and highly welcome source of income for British authors - based on loans of their books from public libraries - called P.L.R. (for Public Lending Right). Nothing like it has happened before in the long history of struggle by wits and by words in the Grub Streets of Great Britain.

title: Mari-Kim Wolter Engaged
description: Mari-Kim Wolter, a second-year medical student, and Bruce Willard Bunnell, a third-year medical student, both at the University of Connecticut, plan to marry June 28.

title: INDUSTRY AND STATE FAULTED ON INSURANCE
description: ASSEMBLY Democrats have blamed the state's Department of Insurance and the industry itself for New Jersey's liability-insurance crisis. In a report issued earlier this month, the Democratic leadership proposed a series of legislative remedies to return the industry to a normal footing.

title: WALDHEIM'S PAST IS MAKING THE U.N. ANXIOUS
description: DELEGATES, officials and other employees of the United Nations reacted with dismay last week, and many said they were concerned that the world organization could be damaged by the picture emerging in newly uncovered documents from German and Yugoslav archives of Kurt Waldheim's role as a German officer in World War II.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
LANGOSTINOS: PRIZED SHRIMP OF ANDALUSIA
description: Mention the langostinos of Sanlucar de Barrameda to an Andaluz far from his native land and watch his eyes come alive with pride and longing. Then be prepared for a lengthy, lively discourse describing the succulence of this prized shellfish, the delicacy, the pure sea flavor, the delight of each bite, after which the listener is ready to hop the next plane for Spain. Such is the mystique surrounding these langostinos, members of the shrimp family found near the seaside village of Sanlucar de Barrameda in western Andalusia.

title: BASEBALL'S HITS AND MISSES
description: BASEBALL FANS HAVE witnessed many developments in their game of choice during the 40 years since the end of World War II, some favorable, some not so. In my opinion, the three worst have been: 1) Artificial turf. 2) Expansion. 3) The evisceration of the minor league system.

title: TURNED DOWN MUSSOLINI OFFER
description: Prince Michel Petrovitch-Niegoche, who refused Mussolini's offer during World War II that he reclaim the family throne in the Balkan state of Montenegro, died Monday in Paris, officials said.

title: THE EASTER PLANT
description: The Easter bonnet is gone now, remembered mostly in Irving Berlin's song. And though we lack the poll to prove it, children don't seem to be dyeing as many eggs as they used to.

title: OMAHA ASKS IF AN UNWED MOTHER CAN BE A FIT ROLE MODEL FOR TEEN-AGERS
description: To the officers of the Omaha Girls Club, it was a question of propriety. They felt that Crystal Chambers, a part-time arts and crafts teacher, could not be a good role model for teen-age members when she became pregnant out of wedlock. So they dismissed her. To Miss Chambers it was a question of discrimination. She contended that, as a black woman, she was unjustly dismissed by the club's predominantly white board. So she filed a multimillion-dollar suit against the club alleging that her civil rights had been violated.

title: Seagram House
description: To the Editor:

title: Jo-Ann Weil Fox Plans a Wedding For the Summer
description: Mrs. William Fox Jr. of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter Jo-Ann Weil Fox to Allen L. Weingarten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Weingarten of Monsey, N.Y. A July 13 wedding is planned. Miss Fox, also the daughter of the late Mr. Fox, is a lawyer in the corporate benefits department of the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York.

title: A CONCISE HISTORY OF MUNICIPAL MALFEASANCE
description: SEVERAL weeks after New York City's municipal scandal began unfolding in January, former Mayor Robert F. Wagner had a few observations on corruption. A little is inevitable, he said; a mayor just has to ''try to keep it down as much as possible.''

title: CATCHING UP ON SOME READING
description: THE myth of a paperless office has by now been relegated to the scrapheap by all but the most diehard electronics fanatics. The reality behind the death of this dream is simple: Only copiers produce more paper than personal computers.

title: STANDOFF IN THE CONTRA WAR
description: Considering his firepower on Nicaragua, President Reagan has snatched a meager victory from the Republican-ruled Senate. It has approved $100 million for the U.S.-backed ''contra'' rebels by a wobbly 53 to 47 - but only after Mr. Reagan submitted to delays that he had vigorously opposed. The unconditional aid he wanted was voted down, 60 to 39. The compromise moves back to the House, which narrowly balked at the aid package, for another vote on April 15. This means there is still a chance to strengthen diplomacy before plunging into a wider war.

title: IN QUOTES
description: The Dow may have gray hair, but there's still plenty of spring in its step.'' William M. LeFevre, Purcell, Graham market strategist

title: Marjorie Sonia Mawby Weds Jon Didriksson
description: Marjorie Sonia Mawby and Jon Didriksson, both of Reykjavik, Iceland, were married yesterday in the Friends Meeting House in Manhattan by the Rev. Stephen Pillsbury, a Methodist minister.

title: TAMING AMERICA'S THIRST FOR IMPORTED OIL
description: IN the spring of 1977, with the United States importing a record 8.5 million barrels of oil a day -46 percent of its needs -President Carter unveiled a program to meet an energy challenge that he called ''the moral equivalent of war.'' Among the plan's seven goals was cutting imports in half by 1985.

title: RARE BRICK WINNER BY A HEAD IN REBEL
description: Rare Brick, the unbeaten speedball who was being tested for the first time at more than a mile, was hard pressed today to score a narrow victory over Clear Choice in the $132,600 Rebel Stakes for 3-year-olds at Oaklawn Park.

title: TRAINS THAT FLY ON MAGNETIC CUSHIONS
description: CURRENT TV commercials portray passengers reclining in the roomy comfort of an Amtrak passenger train that is moving so fast that they appear to be flying to their destination. If proponents of an advanced highspeed rail technology called magnetic levitation, or maglev, have their way, such comparisons will not require such a leap in faith.

title: 'YOU'VE GOT TO STAY PUT'
description: ONLY minutes after Kansas had been eliminated by Duke, 71-67, in yesterday's semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, Larry Brown talked about next season with a sense of where he was and where he would be - at Kansas, not with the Knicks.

title: On Presidential Disability
description: The everpresent issue of Presidential disability and succession, made more acute by the potential need for swift retaliation in a nuclear attack, is under serious study in the capital once again. Two fathers of the 25th Amendment, former Attorney General Herbert Brownell and former Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana, are co-chairmen of a new private commission that will draft recommendations to deal with the possibility that a future President may be unable or unwilling to declare himself unable to serve.

title: A BROTHER'S MURDER
description: IT HAS BEEN MORE THAN TWO years since my telephone rang with the news that my younger brother Blake - just 22 years old - had been murdered. The young man who killed him was only 24. Wearing a ski mask, he emerged from a car, fired six times at close range with a massive .44 Magnum, then fled. The two had once been inseparable friends. A senseless rivalry - beginning, I think, with an argument over a girlfriend - escalated from posturing, to threats, to violence, to murder. The way the two were living, death could have come to either of them from anywhere. In fact, the assailant had already survived multiple gunshot wounds from an incident much like the one in which my brother lost his life.

title: PACE OF EXECUTIONS SLOWS IN FLORIDA AS STATE PROVIDES LAWYERS FOR INMATES
description: Florida's electric chair, once the busiest instrument of capital punishment in the nation, has not been used in 10 months, thanks in part to a state office created, paradoxically, to speed up executions.

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: HOROLOGY IN BRISTOL If you ask the time in Bristol, Conn., you may be referred to 100 Maple Street, where 1,000 clocks and as many watches or watch workings, some dating to the 1600's, are on view from April 1 through Oct. 31 at the American Clock and Watch Museum.

title: RESCUE MISSIONS Animal Outreach
description: When the Beatles wrote ''Can't Buy Me Love,'' they didn't know about the New York A.S.P.C.A.'s Mobile Adoption Unit, a cross between a camper and a pet shop that has been engaged in animal outreach since last fall. It travels to parks and greenmarkets carrying up to 35 animals begging for adoption.

title: PRINCE'S 'PARADE' STAKES A CLAIM TO POPULARITY
description: Prince became a big star with the 1984 release of his first film, ''Purple Rain,'' and its attendant soundtrack LP and hit singles. But it's sometimes easy to forget that he's only 25 years old. Even though he's a practiced pop-music veteran, having released an album a year since 1978, he's still coalescing as an artist. Unlike a student or a garret-dwelling Bohemian, however, his maturation is taking place in the glare of modern celebrity publicity - an exposure likely to distort as much as it reveals.

title: U.S. REPORT EXPECTS SOVIET TO SELL MORE ARMS
