description: A United States intelligence report issued today says that the Soviet Union may try to make up for declining revenue from oil exports by increasing its arms sales abroad.

title:
ANTIQUES;
2 ANNUAL SHOWS WITH A LOT GOING
description: AMONG hardy perennials, the Newark Academy Antiques Show continues to flourish.

title: Dutch Muse
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection, having been rebuffed by the Pentagon, is looking for another place to decontaminate radioactive soil.

title: Clock-Watching
description: There were those who said the 45-second shot clock would change college basketball so much that it would be hard to recognize the game. Now after reviewing statistics of 7,783 games in which the shot clock was used this past season, Edward Steitz, the editor and interpreter of collegiate basketball rules, said the fears had been unfounded.

title: EFFORTS TO HELP WORLD JEWRY BRING PLAUDITS TO EXECUTIVE
description: Edgar M. Bronfman, the elegantly tailored chairman of The Seagram Company, sits in a suite of offices decorated with Rodin statues and Miro tapestries, and considers a question: Why would one of the most successful business executives in America spend almost 40 percent of his time working for the World Jewish Congress?

title: CHINA TEES OFF IN STYLE
description: The urge to play golf in China had been with me since a balmy spring day in London in 1971. Over lunch at the Royal Aero Club, a friend of my father regaled me with tales of his doings in China in the 1930's, when he had been an aviation pioneer. When he wasn't doing stunts in early monoplanes over the Great Wall, he told me, he was playing golf at a splendid course outside Peking. If the caddy master was still there, would I pass on his regards?

title: OSCAR PETERSON RETELLS THE STORY OF EASTER IN JAZZ
description: The elegance and easy grace of Oscar Peterson's pianism has brought him a renown that stretches across continents and has spanned three decades. But for ''Oscar Peterson,'' an hourlong performance receiving its American television premiere Friday night at 10 on Bravo, the pianist, composer and ensemble leader faced a challenge that he initially found daunting: To create a jazz transcription of the passion of Jesus.

title: 4 BROTHERS -- COUNT 'EM -- 4
description: MINSKY'S BURLESQUE By Morton Minsky and Milt Machlin. Illustrated. 312 pp. New York: Arbor House. $15.95. WHO in the New York of the 1920's, that sunny world of lounge lizards and flappers, didn't know about Minsky's National Winter Garden on Second Avenue and Houston Street? The notorious downtown burlesque house packed into its seats such regulars as John Dos Passos, Robert Benchley, George Jean Nathan and Conde Nast. Even Hart Crane shared the Minsky experience; squinting through the smoke-filled air of the magenta hall, he hailed in verse the ''outspoken buttocks in pink beads.''

title: Meredith Mack To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilber Hadley Mack of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Meredith Bingham Mack to Bradford Stuart Elvidge, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Stuart Elvidge of Grosse Pointe. A May wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHERE ARE YOU, ERNEST AND CELESTINE? Written and illustrated by Gabrielle Vincent Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $11.75.(Ages 4 to 8) WITH ''Where Are You, Ernest and Celestine?'' Gabrielle Vincent adds to her growing list of winning books about Ernest, a gentle bear, and his precocious mouse-ward, Celestine. Varying in theme and format (some are wordless), the series devotes itself to the trials and tribulations in the relationship between the caring duo. This book, the seventh, continues the exploration. First published in Belgium under the title ''Ernest et Celestine au Musee,'' the new book brings Ernest and Celestine to a museum - the Louvre in Paris, no less. Ernest applies for a job there, but will only accept the position if Celestine can accompany him daily to work. He doesn't get the job. Nevertheless, they spend the day enjoying the splendid art in the museum. So engrossed is Ernest in the art that he momentarily loses track of Celestine. Happily, they are reunited. Yet Celestine is worried that Ernest is more fond of the paintings than of her. The concern is temporary, for Ernest sets her mind at ease by saying: ''There is nothing I like better than you, Celestine!''

title: CHASING THE MARCOS FORTUNE
description: THE new Philippine Government advanced last week on the trail of hundreds of millions of dollars pocketed by former President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Switzerland, in an unusual breach of banking secrecy, froze all holdings of the Marcos family and their associates.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: Captain Kangaroo's Scary Tales and Silly Stories Starring Robert Keeshan Maljack Productions 59 minutes. $39.95 Among the compilations of sketches from Captain Kangaroo's TV programs that have been repackaged for the home-video market, ''Scary Tales and Silly Stories'' ranks high.

title: HAITI IS AWAKENING TO A BITTER MORNING AFTER
description: CHOKING black smoke from bonfires tended by men and women in ragged clothing clouded a street layered with garbage near a main boulevard last week. A man named Jean Vital stood by the fire, one of many on the streets of the capital. ''It's against General Namphy,'' he said. ''He is not doing anything for the people. I don't have a job. I'm hungry. I have six children, and I can't feed them. We're going to keep doing this until we overthrow the Government.''

title: IRISH-AMERICANS SAID TO HAVE LOST HERITAGE
description: Tom Mackin's article [ Speaking Personally, March 16 ] on the true meaning of one's Irishness - and St. Patrick's Day - reminded me of an inscription on a memorial near Jerusalem that applies every bit as much to the historic struggle of the Irish as to the Jewish people:

title: PROLIFIC BROOKLYN
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Success
description: To the Editor:

title: No. 1 BLUE DEVILS OVERCOME KANSAS, 71-67
description: Everyone waited. And waited. But the moment never came.

title: HOMEWORK: A PARENT CAN LEARN, TOO
description: IT was midnight. The brights of the car were focused on a marshy bog in Huntington. My husband was holding onto a white picket fence with one hand and my wrist with the other as I stood ankle deep in marsh, valiantly trying to scoop up a half-pail of stagnant water, which I hoped would be riddled with paramecia and amoebas.

title: A TOUCH OF TWO CLASSES
description: RICH AND POOR By Jim Goldberg. Unpaged. New York: Random House. Paper, $15.95. IF Studs Terkel's ubiquitous tape recorder suddenly went dead and he relied on a camera instead, the outcome might resemble this collection of 78 black-and-white portrait photographs by Jim Goldberg, who offers these grainy pictures, taken over seven years, in support of the sociological conceit of his title. As he explains in his afterword, Mr. Goldberg discovered the subjects for his ambitious project in only two places: a transient hotel in San Francisco and on the board of trustees of an unnamed art school that he attended, also in San Francisco. He also warns us not to expect ''an 'accurate,' descriptive, educational tool about the issue of poverty and wealth in America.'' He should have said something earlier, perhaps in his title.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am ready to meet President Reagan already in the nearest future in London or Rome, or in any other European capital that will agree to receive us, to reach agreement on this issue.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, referring to a possible end to nuclear tests. [ 1:3. ]

title:
MEN'S STYLE;
SUMMER'S STRAWS
description: SUMMERTIME IN New York may often be too hot to handle, but no one can deny that it has at least two positive aspects: fresh peaches and straw hats. The straw hat occupies a special place in the smart wardrobe, and whether in town or at the seaside, a man is never quite so breezy as when he sports a gleaming boater or spanking white Panama.

title: REMAKING THE MAGNET
description: MAGNETS are at the heart of many a modern machine. Technologies that are opening up an array of new applications are pushing the magnet-making industry far beyond traditional uses in telephones, tape recorders, pot holders and children's toys into a more exciting and glamorous, as well as lucrative, world.

title: A CATCH OF FISH CAKES
description: I HAVE, OVER THE years, collected casual bits of prose and poetry that relate to one dish or another. Among them are Lord Byron's observation in ''Don Juan'' that ''An oyster may be cross'd in love, - and why? because he mopeth idly in his shell.''

title: Trinidad
description: To the Editor:

title: East Side Park
description: The East Side has long been known for its paucity of public parks. Community Board 6, which covers much of the East Side, says the area has the least amount of park space per capita.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The crossword puzzle ''Designer Collection'' in some copies of The Times Magazine last Sunday included a misplaced definition and a partly illegible one. No. 78 Down should have read ''Tiki, e.g.''; there should also have been an 87 Down, ''Use a sudatorium.''

title: TURKOMAN SETS TRACK MARK
description: Turkoman finally confirmed the brilliance he had flashed throughout his career by setting a track record while scoring a dramatic victory in the $230,000 Widener Handicap today at Hialeah Park.

title: STUDY FINDS CONTINUING INCIDENTS OF TORTURE IN TURKISH JAILS
description: Although Turkish authorities have recently allowed greater exercise of civil liberties, prisoners in Turkish police stations and prisons continue to be subjected to torture and inhumane cell conditions, a human rights organization has charged.

title: AIDS TEST CENTERS ARE SET FOR CITY
description: In an effort to curb the spread of AIDS among intravenous drug users in New York City, state and city health officials plan to offer free blood tests and counseling at four storefront centers in neighborhoods with large numbers of drug addicts.

title: DANCE: YVONNE MEIER WITH UNUSUAL PROPS
description: IT was hard not to feel at least a little cheated when an evening of dance by Yvonne Meier came to an end, on Thursday at the Kitchen. The untitled, hour-long piece wasn't unusually short. It was just that one wanted the dance's humor, poignancy and gutsy physicality to go on all night.

title: LONG ISLAND JORUNAL
description: CAMPUS AS ART GALLERY JAMES M. SHUART, president of Hofstra University, envisions his campus as a ''238-acre art gallery,'' and with the arrival last week of a new sculpture by the artist Henry Moore, the grounds of the Hempstead school are indeed becoming one of the premier art showplaces on Long Island.

title: CONSUMER RATES
DEFINITION OF TERRORISM
description: Everybody is talking about terrorism, but not everybody means the same thing. For some time, readers have been writing to ask: ''What about American aid to the Nicaraguan contras?'' ''What about Angola's Savimbi?'' ''What about the Israelis in southern Lebanon?'' ''What about Afghanistan,'' both sides?

title: A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine
description: Dr. Hilfiker brings up the argument of ''cognitive'' versus ''noncognitive'' services. Granted, an operation may take only an hour to perform, but we ''noncognitive'' physicians must examine the patient, review laboratory results and X-rays, arrive at a diagnosis (using ''cognitive'' reasoning) and explain to the patient and family the alternatives, risks and benefits of the procedure. The surgeon's fee is uniform in that it is irrespective of the patient's age or condition, difficulty of the procedure or severity of postoperative complications. JAMES E. ARONE, M.D. Trenton

title: TAIWAN CURBS ITS COUNTERFEITERS
description: ON a drizzly night there are myriad bargains in Snake Alley, a covered market in one of this city's farther suburbs. You can eat a bowl of noodles while a chimpanzee chained to the restaurant counter tumbles for your amusement. For $70 you can buy a live cobra, watch the proprietor kill it and drink its blood as an elixir.

title: 'Ladies' Night' As a Bias Issue
description: BARS and nightclubs in Connecticut were told to stop ''ladies' night'' promotions after the state's Human Rights Commission ruled that they discriminated against men.

title: Cable TV
description: The event of the cable week for movie buffs is a rare run-off of ''City Lights,'' Charlie Chaplin's masterful 1931 comedy about his own Little Tramp and his furtive adoration of a beautiful, blind flower vendor (Virginia Cherrill). In revival theaters, this silent classic seems to mellow and deepen each time. It should indeed be interesting to watch now in the proximity of the home screen. The wonderful old film, with its exquisite fadeout, can be seen on Thursday at 11 A.M. and 7 P.M. on WHT.

title: Social Events; For New and Old Causes
description: Comedy on 42d Street April 1 - The Manhattan Punch Line on West 42d Street, founded seven years ago as New York's only all-comedy theater, is holding a benefit evening, starting with dinner at 6 P.M. at Jolsons Restaurant, 42d Street and Ninth Avenue. Afterward, there will be an unusual auction at the Southern Funk Cafe, 330 West 42d Street. Items will include a 1948 Bentley and rare tapes of ''The Honeymooners'' television series, and bids will be taken for a walk-on part in the next Woody Allen film. Tickets, $100 and $175 a couple, or $35 for the auction alone, from 212-239-0827. All Around Manhattan April 3 - There will be dinner in Manhattan homes and a Champagne reception at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street at Lincoln Center, followed by a performance of ''The House of Blue Leaves'' with Stockard Channing, Julie Hagerty, Swoosie Kurtz and John Mahoney. The evening benefits Creative Alternatives of New York, which produces theater workshops serving psychiatric patients. Tickets, $125 or $75 for Champagne and the performance alone, from 212-650-7177 or 212-650-6636. Cooper Union Concert April 3 - Founded in 1894 as a choir school affiliated with Grace Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village, the Grace Church School now enrolls more than 300 boys and girls from prekindergarten through the eighth grade. To aid the school's scholarship endowment fund, a concert by Gene McDaniels, known for his hit ''100 Pounds of Clay,'' will be held in the Great Hall of Cooper Union.

title: BLEACHING WOOD: TWO WAYS TO GET DOWN TO THE NITTY-GRITTY
description: PAINT removers will take off old paint, varnish and most other finishes from wood surfaces, but they will not remove wood stains because these are more like dyes that have soaked into the pores of the wood. That is why removers also will not lighten or remove discolorations or blemishes in the wood, nor can they be used to lighten a naturally dark piece of wood.

title: JAZZ: THE STEVE KUHN TRIO
description: THE trio that the pianist Steve Kuhn formed two years ago with Ron Carter on bass and Al Foster on drums is doing some unusually searching playing at the Village Vanguard.

title: A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine
description: As a physician, I read and closely follow the American medical literature, much of which is world-class.

title: PENTAGON AIDE SHIFTS POSTS
description: President Reagan appointed James A. Kelly, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, to a White House national secuity post on Friday. Mr. Kelly succeeds Gaston J. Sigur Jr. as Assistant to the President for National Security Affairs and senior director of Asian affairs on the National Security Council staff. Mr. Sigur is now Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA'S GREAT COLONIAL GARDEN
description: In 1678 a group of Barbados planters left the island because, as one of them said, it was such a ''brutish'' place. They set sail for Charleston, where they hoped to find or create a more genteel place to live. In a surprisingly short time they had done so. The rice economy was making Charleston one of America's richest cities, with a sophisticated 18th-century urban environment.

title: DARTMOUTH TRIES TO CLEAR ITS DOCKET
description: STUDENTS, administrators and faculty members at Dartmouth College burned the midnight oil for several days last week in an unusual disciplinary hearing that seemed to put on trial the college's procedure for enforcing its rules.

title: MIDLIFE SHIFTS TO TEACHING RISE SHARPLY
description: TWO years ago, David Robinson was working as a claims adjuster for Aetna Life and Casualty in Hartford, struggling to keep up with a heavy caseload, nursing an ulcer and wondering what the point of it all was.

title: Sarah Williams Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Williams of Hopewell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sarah Whitlock Williams to David Weston Major a son of Mrs. Kenneth D. Wallace of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Ralph H. Major Jr.

title: CONTRASTING VOICES FILL THE EMPTY SEATS AT THE S.E.C.
description: IN early January, the Securities and Exchange Commission met to vote on a host of smoldering takeover issues. Wall Street lawyers and lobbyists emerged in force that day -but the expected debate on greenmail and poison pills was not the only attraction. Rather, many had come to size up the S.E.C.'s newest commissioners - Joseph A. Grundfest and Edward H. Fleischman.

title: JOHNSON'S WIFE MISTREATED HIM, A FORMER MAID ASSERTS IN COURT
description: A former maid for J. Seward Johnson testified last week that his widow, Barbara Piasecka Johnson, was a tyrannical shrew who raged at the household staff and regularly insulted and abused her dying spouse, often reducing him to helpless tears.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GENTLEMAN BEAR Written and illustrated by William Pene du Bois. 78 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95. (Ages 8 and up) HAVE the tales of William Pene du Bois become increasingly arcane over the years, or have today's children - and perhaps their elders -simply lost the patience needed for his leisurely and delectably convoluted prose style?

title: WHY NICARAGUA PICKED A CURIOUS TIME TO STRIKE
description: FROM a distance, it might have seemed that Nicaragua's Sandinista leaders had taken leave of their senses. In the midst of the debate in Washington on the Reagan Administration's request for $100 million in aid to Nicaraguan rebels, a force of more than 1,000 Sandinista soldiers was reportedly conducting raids inside neighboring Honduras. The Sandinistas seemed to be confirming the Reagan Administration view that they are incurably militaristic and expansionist, that there will never be peace in Central America as long as they retain power in Managua. The launching of such a military operation just as Congress was considering aid to the rebels, or contras, seemed to be either calculated defiance or sheer stupidity.

title: AN ACTOR'S ACTOR PRESIDES OVER 'DROOD'
description: From the moment he steps in front of the red plush curtain clad in flowered waistcoat and checked frock coat, his consonants as true and vowels as round as a silver spoon, he is a man completely at home. He has never felt even vaguely welcome on a movie set or television sound stage, but here, with an audience to keep him company and years of craft to support him, George Rose feels perfectly at ease.

title: Headliners; Hindsight?
description: It was the complainant, not Justice, who seemed blind in State Supreme Court in Queens last week. Assault and robbery charges against John Gotti, who is believed to be the new head of the Gambino organized crime family, and an acquaintance, Frank Colletta, were dismissed after Romual Piecyk testified that he could not identify them. Mr. Piecyk had told the police that he was ''punched and smacked'' and robbed of $325 by two men during a traffic dispute.

title: MODERN COMPOSERS TAKE THEIR CUE FROM TWO MASTERS
description: When the history of 20th-century music is written, Schoenberg and Stravinsky may well be perceived as our era's most influential composers. Though they developed two very distinct lines of musical thought, they are no longer viewed as the polar opposites they once appeared to be. Not only were both primarily concerned with the contrapuntal integrity of musical lines, but their methods began to converge as well. Schoenberg's hyper-expressive late Romanticism was eventually distilled into a leaner neo-Classicism, while Stravinsky's anti-Romantic neo-Classicism ultimately absorbed Schoenberg's 12-tone technique.

title: BEWARE GREEKS...
description: ANCIENT HISTORY Evidence and Models. By M. I. Finley. 131 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/ Viking. $17.95. THE most influential writers of history in the Western world are the Greek and Roman historians, yet in the way we tend to think of history today, they were rarely, and then often inadvertently, historians. To write about ancient society in a form that modern historians would regard as history, scholars must try to construct an account from reluctant and elusive source materials: the fragments of stone and papyrus that have survived the ravages of earthquake, weather and vandalism; whatever literary evidence ancient writers chose to give us; and whatever facts can be gleaned from the scattered and partial evidence of archeology. If we now have some notion of the economic life and the underlying political motives of Greek and Roman society, it is largely because of Sir Moses Finley, the emeritus professor of ancient history at the University of Cambridge, who in his own books and through the works of his pupils has given economic and political factors the attention the ancients neglected to pay them.

title: CRIME
description: The Ross Macdonald tradition is kept alive in BEYOND BLAME by Stephen Greenleaf (Villard, $15.95). This is the fifth in the series that started with ''Grave Error'' in 1979, and it features John Marshall Tanner, a protagonist who has much in common with Macdonald's Lew Archer. Both are competent; both are governed by the need to see justice done; both are sensitive and yet, in a curious way, passive. They watch the misery around them; they sympathize with the plight of their clients; they can even empathize. But they also are realists who accept things as they are, knowing full well that they cannot change the system.

title: SOME VIOLINISTS ARE STRAD PLAYERS, WHILE OTHERS GO FOR GUARNERI
description: Four years ago, violinist Young Uck Kim was a ''Guarneri player.'' Today, he is a ''Stradivarius player'' - he thinks. The switch involved some changes in attitude and several hundred thousand dollars. Mr. Kim, who will play a recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, now owns the 1716 ''Cessole'' Stradivarius. The instrument is named for Count Eugene de Cessole, of Nice, who owned the violin from 1845 to 1870 when he traded it for a Guarneri and a sum of money in cash.

title: END OF MORATORIUM
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO CHOOSE A LANDSCAPE EXPERT
description: A WELL-DESIGNED, well-planted and well-maintained garden represents a considerable investment over the years. The initial cost alone may exceed 15 percent of the price of your home.

title: Miss Murphy to Be Bride of Guthrie Byron Woolard
description: Jack Murphy of North Hollywood, Calif., and Lucia Juliano of Massapequa, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Erin Murphy to Guthrie Byron Woolard, the son of Col. Reginald Wallace Woolard, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Woolard of Boston. A September wedding is planned.

title: SHOPPING CENTER PLAN IN SOMERS DEBATED
description: SOMERS is ''in a state of siege,'' according to one resident, Richard Reid - and many others in the rural town of 60,000 residents appear to agree with him.

title: SAMUEL L. TEITLER
description: Samuel L. Teitler, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Teitler & Teitler, died Tuesday at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 79 years old and lived in Jamaica, Queens.

title: SPLITTING THE ASSETS FAIRLY IN DIVORCE
description: THE advent of no-fault laws has transformed the American way of divorce. In the old days, couples who wished to part had to prove that one of them had ''sinned,'' and usually the sinner paid.

title: BURGUNDY INNS, FAMILY STYLE
description: One of the best things about France is that entrepreneurship thrives among its small hotelkeepers.

title: DANCE: BUCKET THEATER IN FAGAN'S 'OATKA TRAIL'
description: GARTH FAGAN likes to choreograph strenuous dances that challenge performers. That seemed clear when his Bucket Dance Theater presented a new program Thursday night as part of its season at the Joyce Theater. However, that program also suggested that Mr. Fagan can sometimes be fond of gimmicks.

title: MARY TYLER MOORE: A SITCOM PRISONER
description: ''Just Between Friends,'' Mary Tyler Moore's latest starring vehicle, is full of things to put one off it. Most prominent among these is Holly Davis (Miss

title: ANOTHER BIRTHDAY BUT NO FANFARE
description: HOW does it feel to be middle-aged?'' my daughter wants to know. Middle age, I remind her, is a state of mind, and she senses immediately that this is one of those subjects better left alone.

title: Linda K. Durfee To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Durfee of Spokane, Wash., have announced the engagement of their daughter Linda K. Durfee of New York to Robert L. McLean of New York and Southampton, L.I., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter R. McLean of Bronxville, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June. The future bride is a vice president of Paine Webber in New York.

title: Delicious Delicto
description: AN ODDLY NAMED cast of characters domiciles itself in the attic of my mind. The leading lady is Norma Loquendi, a sassy modern woman with the common touch who levels every hoity-toity suitor with her street smarts. She has a serious-minded sister with less of an attic shape named Licentia, a member of the media who shoves microphones in people's faces. Both women are menaced by N. Flagrante Delicto, a big guy in a white suit who looks like an easily catchable Sydney Greenstreet, and are in love with Lex Terrae, played by Tarzan.

title: ENDING L.I.E. JAM-UPS
description: AUG. 15, 1985: Thousands of motorists abandon their cars on the Long Island Expressway after a tractor-trailer rig hits a support post for an overhead sign. Traffic is tied up for 14 hours in blistering heat.

title: Shades of Snider! Is Dat Dem Bums?
description: Hope springs eternal in Brooklyn. Twenty-eight years after the Dodgers abandoned Ebbets Field for the greener pastures of Los Angeles, Brooklyn officials are still looking for a replacement.

title: STOP NOW
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING ABOUT LIFE FROM AUNT LEO
description: THE BOBBY-SOXER By Hortense Calisher. 281 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $17.95. HORTENSE CALISHER'S 10th novel and 17th book, ''The Bobby-Soxer,'' begins as one kind of novel, the story of a bright, sensitive teen-age girl growing up in a New Jersey town in the 1950's. But as she learns more of her family's history, and as she gets to know a famous playwright who is mining that material for his new work, it turns from a Bildungsroman into a fairy tale for grown-ups, built on old lore that leaves the social world behind and tests the bounds of credibility. The novel is full of solidly observed details of small-town life, family conflicts and wild adolescent yearnings. But finally, it may be less about these things than about Hortense Calisher's odd, offbeat way of telling a story.

title: June Wedding for Elizabeth Geacintov And Alexander M. D. Churchill Guest
description: Tamara Geacintov of Mountainside, N.J., and Dr. Cyril Geacintov of Cranford, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Geacintov, to Alexander M.D. Churchill Guest, the son of Mrs. Winston F.C. Guest and the late Mr. Guest of Old Westbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. The future bride is an assistant to the senior vice president in charge of the jewelry division at Sotheby's, the auction house in New York.

title: CONCERT: ELECTRONICS AND CHOIR
description: THE New Calliope Singers' Thursday evening concert at Merkin Concert Hall was made memorable by two works for chorus and electronic sound.

title: STRATEGY STUDIED ON MANES LAWSUIT
description: New York City, in seeking to recover what it calls bribe money from the estate of Donald R. Manes, the former Queens Borough President, could file civil suits in either Federal court or State Supreme Court, according to lawyers for the city.

title: FUTURE IS CLOUDY FOR SURVIVOR OF INDUSTRIAL DETROIT
description: Jefferson Avenue, one of the main streets on Detroit's east side, runs through the middle of a brooding old automobile plant, one of the last survivors of the city's once booming industrial economy.

title: MIGRATING MITES THREATEN BEES IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: New Hampshire officials are worried that migrant beekeepers from the South, hired to help pollinate apple orchards here, will bring with them mite-infected bees and seriously threaten local hives.

title: PROMMISE AND REALITY AT GALLERIES
description: A COMPREHENSIVE selection of works in clay by Barbara Schaff of Stockton is on view on the second floor of the Lee Sclar Gallery in Morristown.

title: AQUINO MAKES SOME MOVES BUT STILL SEEMS IN LOW GEAR
description: THERE are a distracting number of Cory Aquino look-alikes in the land, proud women who sport yellow frocks and yellow eyeglass frames with the demure manner and close-set hairdo of the new President, Corazon C. Aquino. It is an odd phenomenon, rather as if the streets of New York were loud with the vanities of men voluntarily resembling Edward I. Koch.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: March 30, 1986 Fiction

title: Breakthroughs In AIDS Research
description: With his research team ready to announce the discovery of a new virus related to AIDS, Dr. Max Essex of the Harvard School of Public Health apparently did not want to take any chances. When he sent the study to reporters Wednesday, he told them to wait until the next afternoon to release it - unless a French team out with ''a similar story about which we've heard rumors.''

title: PUTTING COMEDIANS ON THE ROAD TO FAME
description: Everybody at Great Neck South High School who ever looked at Rory Rosegarten and said he would be in show business some day was right.

title: THE RIGHT CONNECTIONS
description: IN 1942, WHEN A REAL-ESTATE developer joined a pair of neighboring cast-iron buildings in TriBeCa, the result was somewhat unusual even for industrial space. One was a corner building whose large windows flooded the raw space with sunlight.

title: WHO'S IN CHARGE HERE -- PHOTOGRAPHER OR CAMERA?
description: I HAD to get rid of my precision German single-lens-reflex, automatic-talking camera. It was beginning to get rude.

title: QUESTIONS AND CHOICES REGARDING CHILD CARE
description: Shelley B. Mayer airs her unhappiness about the difficulty in finding ''high-quality'' child care for her children when she moved to Westchester. [ March 9 letter to the Westchester editor.

title: Susan Merdinger To Marry in June
description: Susan Merdinger and Steven Greene, pianists who perform as the Merdinger-Greene Duo, plan to marry in June.

title: TROUT SEASON OPENS SATURDAY
description: EVERY year, workers from the Pequest Trout Hatchery in this Warren County community toss 700,000 rainbow, brook and brown trout into more than 200 public lakes, rivers and streams throughout New Jersey.

title: REAGAN AND THE PHILIPPINES: A WINNING STYLE
description: TWO EVENTS OF FAR-REACHING SIGNIFIGANCE for American foreign policy occurred in the last several weeks. One was the Reagan Administration's role in the peaceful transition of power in the Philippines. The other was President Reagan's proclamation of support for ''democratic revolutions'' and human rights. But as with any success or policy change, the risks of misunderstanding and misapplication are enormous.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Saving Olmstead In Massachusetts NEW York may have Frederick Law Olmstead's Central Park and Prospect Park, but Massachusetts claims 300 ''pastoral pleasure grounds'' designed by Olmstead or his firm, more than any other state. So it is appropriate that after much neglect, 12 Olmstead parks in eight Massachusetts cities will be spruced up in the first statewide effort in the nation to preserve the work of the father of American landscape architecture.

title: EARLY WRIGHT CHAIRS ARE PRIZED
description: Frank Lloyd Wright's attitude toward designing a chair was, he wrote, ''something between contempt and a desperation.'' He thought that reclining was ''the only attractive posture of relaxation,'' and called sitting ''an unfortunate necessity.''

title: Dr. Susan C. Adelman To Marry Daniel Raff
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Adelman of New York and Kent, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Susan Claire Adelman to Daniel Martin Raff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Raff of Chevy Chase, Md. A May wedding is planned.

title: By Senator Hawkins
description: It was the sort of thing that catches the eye of The New Republic.

title: GETTING ON THE GOLD STANDARD
description: GOLD jewelry, both the real thing and the costume variety, is enjoying one of its periodic revivals. And among the revivalists, there appear to be two distinct philosophies.

title: CAMPUS REFLECTS IMPACT OF RETIREES
description: AT 78 years old, Dr. Walter Einhorn of Purchase, a retired family physician, generates a special kind of enthusiasm when he talks about attending classes at the State University of New York at Purchase. ''It actually saved my life,'' he said, citing the benefits of ''being with young people and discussing ideas.''

title: Gambling as Addiction In Philadelphia Area
description: There are at least 123,000 compulsive gamblers in the Philadelphia metropolitan area, according to a study that asserts that part of the reason is state lotteries and casino gambling in nearby Atlantic City.

title: Margaret Drew To Marry June 1
description: Dr. and Mrs. James T. Drew of Cobleskill, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Mary Drew to Dr. Thomas Dignan Rizzo Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Rizzo of Bronxville, N.Y., and Sea Island, Ga. The wedding is planned for June 1.

title: Miss Barzman to Marry Bruce Heiman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Barzman of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Lee Barzman, to Bruce Jeffrey Heiman. A May 25 wedding is planned.

title: MORE SUBDUED PROTESTS GREET PLAYBOY AT YALE
description: A VISIT by a photographer, David Chan, last week to New Haven has prompted little protest on the campus of Yale University. Mr. Chan is seeking female students to pose for a Playboy magazine ''Women of the Ivy League'' feature, to appear next October.

title: WHEN SOCIAL DANCE MEETS THE AVANT-GARDE
description: Social dancing and Merce Cunningham's choreography would seem, at first glance, to have little in common. What could possibly be shared by dancers whose loyalty is to a recognized avant-garde esthetic and by ballroom dancers who practice a recreational form of activity theoretically open to all - one that defines social mores rather than an artistic belief?

title: Q&A
description: Vacant Lots Question: I live on Clinton Street in the Tompkinsville section of Staten Island. Next to my property is a vacant lot that I believe is owned by the city. I understand that the lot, which measures 25 by 100 feet, is too small to build on and that I can buy it from the city. I would like to put up a fence and plant a garden, and have made several calls to the city but have not been able to get information. Can you help me?. . .J. G., Staten Island Answer: The Adjacent Homeowners Program of the Department of General Services allows private owners of adjacent properties to buy city-owned lots. According to Barbara Perkins, a spokesman for General Services, such lots must be under 2,600 square feet, have an appraised value of less than $3,000, be in an area zoned for residential use and be surrounded by privately owned properties. Only homeowners whose property abuts such a lot for at least 10 contiguous feet are eligible, and the lots are restricted to such ''accessory'' uses as a garden, a side yard or a parking area. A house cannot be built on the lot, and it cannot be sold separately from the owner's home for five years after the sale. Eligible lots are auctioned off through a sealed bidding process, with minimum bids of $500. Interested homeowners can call the program office at 566-3841. Restaurant Odors Question: Nine months ago a restaurant opened on the ground floor of the apartment building where I live.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Feb. 16 about Jason Findley, a New Jersey teen-ager electrocuted by a power surge from lightning while using a telephone, misstated data on telephone safety.

title: Subsidized Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: POLLING PLACE FOR STUDENTS STIRS HARRISON DISPUTE
description: THE recent decision by the Republican-dominated Harrison Town Board to move the campus polling place at the State University of New York in Purchase to a firehouse a mile and a half away has angered students, voting-rights advocates and Democrats who charge the action would disfranchise campus voters.

title: FOR ERICHETTI, LIFE BEGINS ANEW
description: RELEASED from prison after serving 34 months of a six-year sentence stemming from the Abscam investigations, former Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden says he ''holds no bitterness.''

title: ETHIOPIA JEWS HAVE TROUBLE FITTING IN
description: Integrating the 15,000 Ethiopian Jews who have been brought to Israel in the last eight years is proving, in the view of those who deal with it, to be as difficult an immigration problem as this nation of immigrants has faced.

title: 'MRS. WARREN' PAYS VISIT TO GEORGE ST.
description: ONCE scandalous and scabrous, George Bernard Shaw's ''Mrs. Warren's Profession,'' circa 1894, can be staid indeed, if done too literally. But it is, ostensibly, about money and sex (that is, those things are talked about a lot), so it can still be titillating as well as ideologically valid.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: You Were Never Lovelier Starring Fred Astaire, Rita Hayworth, Adolphe Menjou, Gus Schilling; directed by William A. Seiter. 1942 RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video 98 minutes. $59.95 This genial, slender Hollywood musical would probably waft away without the Jerome Kern music (and Johnny Mercer lyrics) to hold it down.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: John Lennon - Live in New York City Sony Video 55 minutes. $29.95 The Beatles had helped shape the sensibility of a generation, and the music that Beatle John was making with Yoko Ono in 1972 was perplexing - raw-edged, defiantly political (peace, feminism), backed by a scruffy, unoriginal New York street band, Elephant's Memory.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DAUGHTERS OF JERUSALEM. By Roger Cleeve. (Adler & Adler, $15.95.) The bold organizing threads of this novel of the Arab-Israeli conflict are family matters -those crossings of love and bitter hatred, almost indistinguishable from love, that at once make and mar our lives.

title: TOPICS
description: THE school I work in has a Sunshine Fund. At the start of the school year, you contribute a modest sum of money. If you become ill, get married, have a baby or a death in the family, you receive a gift, flowers or a plant.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: The Third Man Starring Joseph Cotten, Orson Welles, Trevor Howard, Alida Valli, Wilfred Hyde-White; directed by Carol Reed, 1950 Voyager Video 104 minutes. $39.95 Holly Martins (Joseph Cotten) a down-on-his-luck author of pulp novels, arrives in postwar Vienna with a promise of a job, which, however, has disappeared with the best friend who offered it.

title: PEERLESS POSTER MAKER
description: Adolphe Mouron, whose pseudonym was A. M. Cassandre, greatly contributed to the distinct graphic style of Paris during the 1920's and 30's and worked prodigiously until his death in 1968. For over two decades Paris was full of his striking posters, including those advertising the luxury train Etoile du Nord, the steamship Normandie, the furniture store Au Bucheron and the aperitif Dubonnet - his comic Dubonnet man is the emblem still used today.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM WELLES TO CAPTAIN KANGAROO
description: The Killer Performance Featuring Jerry Lee Lewis Passport Video 50 minutes. $29.95 ''The Killer Performance'' opens with a bang - a live, black-and-white clip of Jerry Lee Lewis knocking out ''Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On'' from an unidentified 1950's television show.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: BOMBS CUT RAILROAD IN PERU
description: Leftist guerrillas set off bombs at three points on Peru's central railroad overnight, severing the only train link between Lima and the Andes and wounding an 11-year-old boy, the police said. Two explosions tore up tracks in a shantytown north of the capital, where the boy was hurt, and the third took place 13 miles east of Lima. No one took responsibility for the bombings, but the police accused leftist rebels.

title: MICHIGAN ST. BEATS HARVARD FOR TITLE
description: A goal by Mike Donnelly, college hockey's leading scorer this season, broke a tie late in the third period tonight and gave Michigan State a 6-5 victory over Harvard in the final game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: THE MADCAP BEHIND 'MOONLIGHTING'
description: SOMETHING PECULIAR IS HAPPENING on the television screen. On a recent Tuesday night, the leading characters on ABC's hit detective series ''Moonlighting'' opened their show by facing the camera, leaning against a desk and answering fan mail.

title: YOUNG CHEFS COOK WHILE LEARNING
description: WARREN GULDE, a 23-year-old Sayville resident, has worked in restaurant and hotel kitchens for a year and a half, but now he's on his way to becoming a professional chef.

title: Tania Levy Plans to Wed
description: An August wedding is planned by Tania Levy and Clifford Roy Medney, the future bride's mother, Paulette Levy of Kew Gardens, Queens, has announced. Mr. Medney is a son of Jerry J. Medney of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Mrs. Medney. Miss Levy, a daughter also of the late Samuel Levy, graduated cum laude from the State University of New York at Albany. She is a media representative at Young & Rubicam. Mr. Medney, a graduate of the University of Georgia with a master's degree in sports marketing from Western Illinois University, is an account executive at BBDO Promotion.

title: PAPER DRESSES FOR TRIPS DOWN THE AISLE
description: SUSAN LANE is giving new meaning to the saying, ''Marriage is just a piece of paper.''

title: VOLCANO ERUPTS AGAIN, DAMAGING 2 PLANES
description: The 4,025-foot Augustine volcano erupted again today after a brief lull, sending up five-mile-high clouds of abrasive ash that damaged two passenger planes that later landed safely at Anchorage International Airport.

title: TENNIS PLAYER MOVING AHEAD
description: TENNIS fans may remember Terry Phelps as a gawky kid in pigtails, flying around the Larchmont courts at age 9 and hammering away at the ball with a frown of concentration. She was all arms and legs, not as smooth as other youngsters but compensating with a stubbornness that usually kept her in matches when all seemed lost. With her long strides, she would run down shots that seemed impossible to get and, in the end, it was her opponent who gave up in frustration.

title: Deborah Jane Stein Weds Don D. Grubman, Lawyer
description: Deborah Jane Stein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Stein of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Don D. Grubman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Grubman of Rego Park, Queens. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony at the Tavern on the Green.

title:
DINING OUT;
MADISON: DESSERT TAKES THE CAKE
description: FIVE years ago, I chanced upon a tiny cafe in a Chatham shopping center called Joie de Vivre and reviewed it in this space. At that time, it rated one star for its simple, Americanized French food and very high marks for its cozy, unpretentious charm.

title: BAKER'S DEBT PLAN STARTS TO TAKE HOLD
description: Progress on the debt crisis came on several fronts, and although he was not a participant, the presence of Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d was keenly felt. The World Bank approved $1.5 billion in new loans to Latin debtors by the end of April, its largest single commitment in so short a time. The United States also dangled a multibillion-dollar carrot in front of the Inter-American Development Bank, saying it would increase its support if the lending agency adopted the proper lending policies. The new loans appear to be right in line with Mr. Baker's plan to solve the problem of heavily indebted developing countries by spurring their economies. Separately, the I.M.F. said it would set up a $3 billion loan pool for the poorest nations.

title: U.N. CHIEF OUTLINES PLAN TO SETTLE CYPRUS DISPUTE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today presented a draft agreement outlining a solution to the Cyprus problem to Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot representatives.

title: TEEN-AGER IS FEARED DROWNED AS 12-FOOT MOTORBOAT SINKS
description: A teen-age boy was feared drowned today and a man was rescued after their small boat sank in the Connecticut River, the authorities said.

title: EASLER HOPES TO FIT IN AS YANKEES' PLATOONING D.H.
description: How did Mike Easler get to the Yankees? He got into his car in Winter Haven at about 10 o'clock Friday night and drove to Fort Lauderdale, arriving at about 4 A.M. But he also came by way of 10 years in the minor leagues, pit stops in Houston and California, five seasons in Pittsburgh and two in Boston. At various points along that lengthy itinerary, Houston lent him to the St. Louis organization, then traded him there, and Pittsburgh sold him to Boston, then reacquired him in a trade five months later.

title: THE CLOUD OVER CITY HALL
description: Until last week, the accusations and investigations that have dominated New York City's public affairs for more than two months had produced only one indictment. But the pace picked up when, in rapid succession, Federal and state grand juries indicted eight people, including Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader and one of New York's most influential political figures - all on charges involving bribes allegedly paid by private companies to obtain contracts with the city's Parking Violations Bureau.

title: Lisa Karen Rubin To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rubin of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Karen Rubin to Kenneth James Kornblau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules H. Kornblau of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: NUCLEAR-FREE ZONELET
description: To the Editor:

title: Videotapes Offer Helpful Advice
description: HAVING persuaded myself that I could no longer avoid evaluating the instructional role of videotapes in the world of the outdoors, I bit the bullet several days ago and watched more than four consecutive hours of television.

title: Headliners; Assurance
description: Many medical experts said last year that they were reasonably sure the bones exhumed in June in Brazil were those of Josef Mengele, the Nazi war criminal. But some skeptics speculated that the so-called Angel of Death of Auschwitz was still on the run.

title: COSBY LEADS THE WAY, BUT TV STILL STUMBLES IN DEPICTING BLACKS
description: The enormous success of ''The Cosby Show'' is studded with ironies. When Bill Cosby first submitted his idea for the series several years ago, the networks were convinced, courtesy of their ratings-research departments, that not only was the situation-comedy form dead in general but that the ''mass public'' would be unreceptive to any new series about blacks in particular. Rejected by ABC, ''The Cosby Show'' was eventually accepted by NBC, then still last in the ratings and willing occasionally to buck conventional programming wisdom. The rest is the kind of television history that sends competitors scurrying for imitations.

title: POLES FINDING THEIR LOVE OF DOGS IS TAXING
description: In Poland, a country of 37 million people, where meat is rationed and apartments are hard to find, there are said to be seven million or eight million dogs.

title: RANGERS OVERPOWERED BY FLYERS, 8-2
description: It was a matter of strength, the Flyers and the Rangers, and when it was over, some may have wondered just why the Rangers want to get into the playoffs.

title: LEAD PAINT: THOMPSON PREPARES FOR INQUIRY
description: ALTHOUGH lead poisoning is usually associated with children living in big-city tenements, over the last two years 15 children a year in the rural town of Thompson have been diagnosed as suffering from it.

title: AN 'OLDER BOY OF SUMMER' FULFILLS DREAM AT METS CAMP
description: IN the hearts, if not in the minds, of each of us is the notion that but for one thing or another we would have been major leaguers. With 100 other ''older boys of summer'' (you must be over 30 to participate) I spent a week last February at the Met training camp in St. Petersburg, Fla. That week replicated what might have been.

title: ARGENTINES CONFRONT A NEW REALITY: POVERTY
description: On a recent afternoon, five scruffy children were working as valets at the busy downtown corner of Corrientes and Reconquista, where taxis wait to pick up passengers. Alberto Navarro, 10 years old, and his sister Naomi, 12, said they could each earn the equivalent of $5 a day in tips.

title: A Bowling Alley With Federal Aid
description: OBJECTIONS came from a Congressional leader when it became known last fall that the tiny city of Duchesne, Utah, was about to get a $450,000, six-lane bowling alley, financed largely by the Federal Bureau of Reclamation.

title: CHILD SAFETY: AUTO DEVICES HELD MISUSED
description: IN THE three years since New Jersey's Child Restraint Law took effect, the number of children 4 years old or younger killed in automobile accidents has dropped to 5 a year, down from 11 to 14 before the law was enacted.

title: ARE TRUCKS MORE THAN NEW YORK CITY'S TRAFFIC WILL BEAR?
description: THE skirmish over the city's decision to limit truck deliveries on 49th and 50th Streets in an effort to help speed traffic to and from the new Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was the latest in a long-running battle between truckers and transit planners for elbow room on New York streets. And though a driver trapped in truck-clogged crosstown traffic might be hard put to agree, there is merit on both sides.

title: LEBANON'S DEADLY CYCLE BEGINS ANEW
description: IN the summer of 1982, Israel, hoping to clear its northern border of guerrillas and protect the towns of Galilee from the Palestine Liberation Organization's rocket attacks and infiltrators, drove an estimated 12,000 P.L.O. guerrillas out of Beirut and southern Lebanon.

title: Rockets Defeat Bullets, 114-109
description: Allen Leavell scored a season-high 28 points tonight to lead the Houston Rockets to a 114-109 victory over the Washington Bullets, the Rockets' second triumph in three games without the forward Ralph Sampson.

title: DARTMOOR IN A GENTLER LIGHT
description: The bulky hill wastes of Exmoor, Dartmoor and Bodmin Moor all but rub shoulders. They present a formidable series of obstacles to the motorist to this day, and they still protect the ultimate mysteries of Cornwall from most of the English, whom the Cornish traditionally and correctly regard as a foreign race.

title: MUSIC: JON ROSE IMPROVISES WITH FIDDLES
description: JON ROSE, the Australian-born instrumentalist and improvisatory composer, plays assorted amplified violin instruments in styles that run from accelerated, tonally centered solos with late Romantic associations to free-form sonic explorations.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE IDEOLOGICAL ORIGINS OF NAZI IMPERIALISM. By Woodruff D. Smith. (Oxford, $39.95.) Woodruff D. Smith, a professor of history at the University of Texas at San Antonio, asserts that Nazism drew upon the imperialist ideologies of the Weimar period and before -including the desire for Lebensraum, more land to accommodate Germany's growth, and Weltpolitik, which refers to foreign policy directed toward the achievement of Germany's economic success.

title: THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS UNINTERPRETED MUSIC
description: Here's material for a nightmare. Scholars, after sifting through more than a century and a half of evidence, announce their final verdict, based on irrefutable computerized data: Beethoven meant his symphonies to be played in rigid tempos, without rhythmic nuances, dynamic shadings, pliant phrasings or other interpretative fripperies. By order of the Department of Esthetics and Correct Performance Practice, all musicians must comply with the composer's intentions or risk losing their licenses. Recordings by conductor-criminals such as Furtwangler, Beecham and Bernstein are henceforth outlawed for general use though these relics of the age of unfettered individualism may be auditioned by authorized persons upon application to the Smithsonian Institution.

title: CITY PANEL URGES SCHOOLING FOR ALL 4-YEAR-OLDS
description: A mayoral commission appointed to study the education needs of preschool children has concluded that New York City should make formal instruction available to all 4-year-olds.

title: SIZING UP THE WORLD FROM A BANKING PERSPECTIVE
description: PLUMMETING oil prices. Falling interest rates. Zero inflation. Surging stock and bond prices.

title: A Lesson in Tragedy
description: I have never been so touched by an article as I was by C.D.B. Bryan's, ''A Lesson in Tragedy'' (Feb. 23), concerning the space shuttle Challenger.

title: A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine
description: I felt a sense of shared struggle reading David Hilfiker's article ''A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine'' (Feb. 23). I am a New England family practitioner with a computer in my office, networks of computers in my hospital and a myriad of computer forms from the various Government and big-business (third-party) bureaucracies that send me my pay for caring for my patients.

title: NASA SAYS NEW BOOSTERS CAN BE READY IN 12 MONTHS
description: Top space agency officials say they are confident that the space shuttle's booster rockets can be redesigned and tested within 12 months, paving the way for flights to resume.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
AIDS SYMPOSIUM
description: An all-day symposium on AIDS and AIDS-related diseases will be held Wednesday at the Tarrytown Hilton. Organized by the pathology department of the New York Medical College in Valhalla, the event has been coordinated by Dr. Rosalyn E. Stahl, an assistant professor of pathology at the medical college and assistant phsycian in pathology at the County Medical Center. The event is part of the 125th anniversary celebration of the college.

title:
INVESTING;
A STOCK PICKER TURNS SKITTISH
description: Early this month, Growth Stock Outlook Trust Inc. raised $125 million in a public offering - twice the amount originally expected. That made it one of the largest new-issue, closed-end funds on record. And more shares could have been sold, according to the underwriter, but the trust's manager, Charles Allmon, got the maximum he wanted.

title: MOUNTBATTEN'S HOME, HERZL'S LIFE
description: At Broadlands, Lodge Opens To Guests Roughly an hour by train to the southwest of London, at Romsey in the Test Valley, stands the Georgian mansion known as Broadlands, the centerpiece of a 6,000-acre estate in the heart of Hampshire.

title: WHY NOT GIVE BACK THE BIG MONEY?
description: Now that he is safely re-elected, New York's Mayor Koch favors limits on campaign contributions. So does Governor Cuomo, now that he's raised $9 million for his coming campaign. Retroactive virtue is better than none, but why not try retroactive atonement as well?

title: IS THERE LIFE AFTER PRIME TIME DEATH
description: When Officer Joe Coffey (played by Ed Marinaro) was mortally wounded during a holdup last month on ''Hill Street Blues,'' it wasn't a shot heard round the world. But Mr. Marinaro, who had wanted to leave the series since last summer, clearly hopes it will be a shot in the arm to his listless career.

title: HEALTH MAINTENANCE PLANS: A GROWING MARKET
description: THE Kaiser Foundation Health Plan and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York are housed in their own medical-center buildings, the former in White Plains, the latter in Yonkers. Physicians Health Service is based in a suite of offices in Hartsdale. Although their functioning styles differ, all three organizations are health maintenance organizations that offer alternative health-care plans to American workers.

title: Korean Activists Are on the March
description: Anti-Government activists in South Korea kept up the pressure for constitutional reforms last week, with tens of thousands filling the streets of Pusan in the biggest anti-Government rally since President Chun Doo Hwan assumed power in 1980.

title: ACTRESS LIVES ROLE OF EMILY DICKINSON
description: THERE are light-years between a dying mushroom and Emily Dickinson, but if Jean Linzee is involved, the distance could blur.

title: Margaret Butler to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Butler of Gladstone, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Mary Butler to John A. Lawrence, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Lawrence of Rumson, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 3. The future bride is a registered nurse at the Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. Mr. Lawrence is a manager in the finance department of A.T.&T. Communications in Morristown, N.J.

title: EASTER, HIGHLIGHT OF HOLY WEEK, IS CELEBRATED IN ST. PETER'S
description: Pope John Paul II entered a darkened St. Peter's Basilica that was suddenly flooded with light to celebrate Christianity's most joyous night.

title: Reagan's SPRING REVIVAL
description: In his first White House term, the complaint against President Reagan was that he wasn't in charge. Now the complaint is that he is in charge. This new White House staff wants ''Reagan to be Reagan,'' and he seems to think it's a good idea.

title:
WHY CHEAP OIL IS NO BOON FOR THE U.S.;
A THREAT TO SUPPLIES
description: The dramatic gyrations in the price of oil this year are certain to provide a significant short-run boost to the world economy. Prices have dropped so far and so fast that consumers will pay much less for energy on average this year than last, even if the cartel of major oil exporting nations were to succeed soon in pushing petroleum prices back up again.

title: Ariadne Callas to Wed John P. Fitton May 31
description: The engagement of Ariadne Ramos Callas to John Paul Fitton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Fitton of West Nyack, has been announced by her mother, Mary R. Callas of New York. The wedding is planned for May 31.

title:
ON LONG ISLAND;
Innovations in Parking for Offices
description: THE high cost of land and concerns over the environment are forcing commercial developers on the Island to take more innovative approaches in providing parking at new buildings. The usual requirement in Nassau and Suffolk Counties is five parking spaces for every 1,000 square feet of office space.

title: STATE OF THE STATES
description: IT HAD TO HAPPEN, I GUESS. A SAN Francisco hotel has put together a wine list that is truly American. It includes wines from 34 states. Yes, 34 states. Everyone knows about California and New York, and quite a few know now that they make wine in Oregon and Washington. But Wisconsin? And Georgia? And Hawaii and Idaho and New Jersey?

title: TALKS HALT IN T.W.A. STRIKE
description: Talks broke down yesterday in the 23-day-old strike by Trans World Airlines flight attendants after union negotiators rejected a company demand to submit its latest offer to a vote by the rank-and-file membership. No further talks were scheduled.

title: OPERA: DAVIES LEADS CONCERT VERSION OF 'PELLEAS ET MELISANDE'
description: The most ardent Wagnerians of the late-19th century were the French, so it is appropriate that they - speaking their own special thoughts through their own special voice - were to create one of the genre's most satisfying examples. Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande,'' like Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' communicates the nature of tragedy through its orchestra. For tragedy posits a degree of helplessness - a controlling and consuming force surrounding its protagonists. What better way to express this than opera that wells up from the pit and pulls its singers to it?

title: CABARET: SYLVIA SYMS IN SONG
description: SYLVIA SYMS is giving a second chance to a cabaret program she first did six and a half years ago - a program drawn from the film songs of Fred Astaire. There was nothing wrong with it the first time. How can you go wrong with some of the best songs of the Gershwins, Irving Berlin, Cole Porter, Jerome Kern, Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer - songs such as ''How Long Has This Been Going On?,'' ''Change Partners,'' ''One For My Baby,'' ''The Way You Look Tonight'' and ''Dream Dancing''?

title: At Least 30 Die In South Africa
description: Even by its own bloody standards, South Africa was particularly violent last week. On one day alone -Wednesday - at least 30 people were reported killed by the police.

title: HAVING IT ALL IS TOO MUCH
description: A LESSER LIFE The Myth of Women's Liberation in America. By Sylvia Ann Hewlett. Illustrated. 461 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95. A YOUNG lawyer friend of mine once worked out this response to the prospective employer's query whether marriage might conflict with her fast-track career: ''I'm so glad you asked. I believe that men have struck a perfect balance between personal and professional lives. Reasonable accommodation of private lives? Nonsense. Humanization of the work world? Who needs it? I've made it clear to my friends and family that love, affection, friendship and human emotion play a small role in the life of a real professional.'' And what if the interviewer asks about children? ''Not to worry. Test tube babies for me. That way I can wait until I'm 40, 50, even 60 before I start a family, until my career is really well established. I'm no fool.''

title: ROBOTS THAT CAN TEACH
description: THE center of attraction stood a little over four feet high. About 40 students at

title: FOUNDER OF NEWSPAPER IN PATERSON RECALLED
description: The March 9 Opinion article ''A View of Paterson's Past'' overlooked a Paterson woman who contributed much to the city.

title: WHAT IT MEANS TO CALL A PEOPLE A TRIBE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THESE days, Jack Elliott, a writer who lives in Warren Township, Somerset County, is flying high. That is because he will be inducted into the Aviation Hall of Fame of New Jersey on May 20.

title: Tampa Man Is First In Pro Bowling Event
description: Tom Crites of Tampa, Fla., defeated Mike Aulby of Indianapolis, 190-184, here today to win the $235,000 Toledo Trust National Championship, his first Professional Bowlers Association championship.

title: ISN'T IT FUNNY WHAT MONEY CAN DO?
description: THE GREAT GETTY The Life and Loves of J. Paul Getty -Richest Man in the World. By Robert Lenzner. Illustrated. 283 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $18.95. THE HOUSE OF GETTY By Russell Miller. Illustrated. 362 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95. HERE are some interesting facts about J. Paul Getty (1892-1976): He was, for a while, the richest man in the world; he refused to pay a penny of ransom for his grandson and namesake, J. Paul Getty 3d, until the boy's severed ear was shipped through the mail by his kidnappers; as a monument to himself, he built a museum in the farther reaches of Malibu, Calif. He never saw it, but he left it so heavily endowed - $2 billion - that it must spend about $2 million a week to avoid taxes; throughout his life, every night, he hand-washed his own underpants.

title: OPTIONS ABROAD FOR STUDENTS OF ALL AGES
description: For parents and children alike, a time arrives when a family vacation no longer seems appropriate. Often when children reach their teens, both sides of the generation gap seek liberation from the family tensions that can arise when they don't like to do the same things. Some youngsters feel they have outgrown summer camp and may want to seek new horizons and new adventures on their own by traveling abroad.

title: COLLEGE IN BROOKLYN TO TRAIN WORKERS FOR EXPECTED SEAFOOD INDUSTRY BOOM
description: When Dr. Milton Drucker discusses areas of growth in New York City's economy, he does not talk about banking and finance, publishing or telecommunications. He talks about fish.''Growing demand has made New York City the second largest seafood-consuming market on earth, next to Tokyo,'' said Dr. Drucker, the dean of marine education at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.

title:
DANCE;
INNER CITY TROUPE IN TWIN BILL
description: THE Inner City Ensemble, a theater and dance company that has achieved national recognition for its training and performance programs for teen-agers, will open its spring season this week at Passaic County Community College.

title: Seminar on TV Directing
description: A seminar on directing for television will be led by Jay Sandrich tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: HONDA IN UPSCALE MARKET
description: IT is always an event when a new car arrives on the scene, particularly when that car comes from one of your favorite manufacturers. In this case, it is Honda's entry into the upscale market, and the vehicles - which went on sale Thursday - are the top-of-the-line Legend and the far-less-pricey Integra, both bearing the Acura brand.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PAGODA, SKULL & SAMURAI: 3 STORIES BY ROHAN KODA. Translated by Chieko Irie Mulhern. (Charles E. Tuttle, $12.50.) The literature of Japan's Meiji period (1867-1912), the era when the nation first opened to Western ideas, remains surprisingly little known.

title: TENDER BULBS FLOWER WITH A TROPICAL AIR
description: Most gardeners are familiar with the hardy spring-flowering bulbs that are planted in fall. But many other fine bulbs called tender because they cannot survive northern winters in the ground are planted in spring to produce flowers for summer.

title: THREAT OF POISONING OF MEDICINE IS DISMISSED
description: Officials said today that there was no evidence supporting an anonymous caller's assertion that some capsules of the aspirin substitute Encaprin had been poisoned.

title: RULING AMBIGUOUS
description: An Italian court today acquitted three Bulgarians and three Turks of conspiring to assassinate Pope John Paul II. The court ruled that the evidence against them was ambiguous.

title: LATIN RITE RETURNS TO CATHOLIC WORSHIP
description: AS Christians around Connecticut celebrate Easter today, some Roman Catholics are also heralding the return of the traditional, Latin mass that was banned by the church 20 years ago.

title: ADULTS RESCUE GIRL'S DOLLS
description: A 6-year-old girl whose dolls were snatched from her arms by two adults got them back because of the efforts of the police and onlookers.

title: ALEX NORTH AND HIS OSCAR MAKE MUSICAL MOVIE HISTORY
description: Alex North is not entirely comfortable with all the attention he's receiving these days. Short and vigorous and looking much younger than his 75 years, the composer paces his study overlooking the Pacific Ocean, chain-smokes cigarettes that he refers to as ''nails,'' and has even broken out in shingles because of the anxiety he feels about his recent public appearances.

title: Cocoa Haters
description: To the Editor:

title: North Carolina Upset For First Lacrosse Loss
description: A goal by Tom Worstell with 25 seconds left capped a comeback that saw Maryland score five goals in the final period to upset top-ranked North Carolina, 10-9, in an Atlantic Coast Conference lacrosse match today.

title: FOR CHADIANS, SMALL LOANS REBUILD HOPE
description: Near where the one-lane asphalt bridge crosses the Shari River, Mariam Moutnon, like her father before her, runs a small drug dispensary for the people of the Chaguoa neighborhood.

title: WAKING UP, GETTING OUT
description: THE LIBERATION OF ONE By Romuald Spasowski. Illustrated. 687 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $24.95. A WEEK after martial law came crashing down in Poland in December 1981, smashing Solidarity and the most far-reaching mass movement for freedom the Soviet bloc had ever seen, Romuald Spasowski, the Polish Ambassador to the United States, defected. At a crowded news conference in the State Department he read a dramatic and emotional message: he expressed support for Lech Walesa, called imprisoned Solidarity activists ''the best sons and daughters of the Polish nation'' and insisted he could no longer have any association with a regime capable of such brutality and inhumanity. ''A cruel night of darkness and silence was spread over my country,'' he lamented.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report last Sunday on the wedding of Holly Tupper and Will Alston Beinhorn misidentified the priest who performed the Episcopal ceremony. He was the Rev. Ephraim Radner.

title: STAGE: BUTCH MORRIS'S MUSICAL SEASCAPE
description: BUTCH MORRIS'S ''Image of None,'' which will be at the Performing Garage (33 Wooster Street) through today, is an ambitious music-theater seascape - a performance piece that brings Mr. Morris into the realm of Peter Maxwell Davies or Schoenberg's ''Pierrot Lunaire.''

title: Mailbox; Defense of Hunting Based on Faulty Logic
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART;
WOMEN INTERPRET THEIR OWN IMAGES
description: WOMEN'S History Month is being celebrated in a very personal way by the 42 artists participating in the current exhibition at the Smithtown Township Arts Council's Mills Pond House Gallery in St. James.

title: ADIRONDACKS GROUP CRITCIZES STATE SENATE ON ENVIRONMENT
description: The Adirondack Council, a private, nonprofit organization that monitors developments in the Adirondacks, awarded its booby prize to the State Senate this week for what it called a ''consistently anti-environmental posture.''

title: PUT ATHLETIC PROGRAMS UNDER ACADEMIC SCRUTINY
description: LIKE many today, both within universities and without, I am mystified, angered and shamed by the current state of college athletics in the United States. Financial payoffs, grade-fixing, relaxed eligibility requirements - these practices, marking athletics at some universities, have sadly become a burden that all of us who attend the academic tradition must somehow shoulder. For not only do we feel shame, but also deep anxiety: The university requires decades to grow, and the credibility of a university - more important, the credibility of the entire university system - can be brought low by the vicious blows of the few.

title: WHY SOME STATE SPENDING ROSE TWICE AS FAST AS INFLATION
description: ''THIS is the last of my term's budgets,''

title: SCHOOL-BUS SEAT BELTS SOUGHT
description: EVERY state now has a child restraint law, but none requires seat belts on school buses. State Senator C. Louis Bassano wants New Jersey to be the first.

title: 'VERBAL THRESHOLD' NO PANACEA
description: THE CALL to ''reform'' New Jersey's auto-insurance laws will dominate much of the debate and activity of the 202d session of the Assembly.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
VINTAGE BOUTIQUE
description: If your taste runs to a 1920's flapper dress with a trim of silver brocade with jungle motifs, a 1930's tan lace dress with a matching cape or a 1950's black taffeta with a lace underskirt, the place to find them will be at the Vintage Boutique at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers on Saturday.

title: STEEL UNION FACES OBSTACLES ON PACT
description: The United Steelworkers of America is attempting to reach early agreements with five companies before bargaining with the industry leader, the United States Steel Corporation.

title: FOR SOME, TRACK IS A WAY OF LIFE
description: IT IS 6 P.M. at the Meadowlands Race Track here and, although racing will not start for two hours, the ''early birds'' are ready, tip sheets in hand.

title: PHILANTHROPY MAY NEVER BE THE SAME AGAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA IS IN THE SPOTLIGHT FOR A FORTNIGHT
description: OPERA has long been something of a stepchild in Westchester, and while some brave attempts at forming a resident company materialize from time to time, the county does not have a single operatic series of a quality to match that of our many fine orchestras. What a treat it should be for vocal fans over the next fortnight, then, to find a recital by two superb Metropolitan Opera singers; a program of grand and light opera favorites; two performances of Mozart's ''Magic Flute,'' a pair of concerts highlighting his ''Coronation'' mass, and a third presenting the Requiem; a bouquet of Rodgers and Hammerstein show songs; even a symphonic program with three soprano soloists.

title: AFTER DECADES, A FACTORY FOR WILLIAMSBURG
description: CONSTRUCTION is to begin this June on what officials say will be the first major new industrial plant in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn in almost 40 years.

title: A HOUSE-TO-HOUSE SEARCH
description: FOR those who have recently wakened from a deep coma and haven't heard, Connecticut is celebrating its 350th birthday, and as part of the heraldry each of the state's 169 towns has been asked to identify its oldest house and adorn it with a plaque . In a fit of civic patriotism, I agreed to serve on a committee to so designate the one in my town, Hampton.

title: NEW EPISCOPAL HYMNAL INTRODUCED, GENTLY, TO PARISHONERS
description: ''THY strong word did cleave the darkness'' rang off the stone walls of St. James the Less Episcopal Church in Scarsdale as Raymond F. Glover began leading 150 people in an exploration of Hymnal 1982. The tune was familiar. Most people knew it from ''Once to Every Man and Nation,'' an old warhorse given the coup de grace by the Episcopal Commission on Church Music because its theology was considered erroneous.

title: LITERARY EVENTS FILL APRIL
description: WHILE April may have been ''the cruelist month'' for the poet T. S. Eliot, for writers living in the county and those who will be visting, April promises to be an unusually beneficent time. In response to a proposal by the Westchester Chapter of the National Writers Union, it has been proclaimed ''Writers Month in Westchester'' by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, and throughout the county numerous literary events, meetings and readings will take place.

title: DEVILS EDGE HAWKS
description: The loudest cheers came when the rookie goaltender waved to the crowd after the announcement that he had been voted the star of the game. It was the second such honor in two games for Sam St. Laurent since his promotion by the Devils three days ago.

title: ENGLAND ON THE WILD SIDE
description: In an unfamiliar land it is all too easy to become stranded on the conveyor belts of the tourist industry, to see the most celebrated of the historical places, yet to return with an uneasy sense of having missed the essence or diversity of the country. The most heralded sights in a country's portfolio of tourist attractions may be linked to or surrounded by a number of wildlife habitats where one's travel-worn senses can be recharged and tranquillity restored.

title: Wendy Wallace To Wed in June
description: Mrs. Guy Darby Drake of Boston and Osterville, Mass., and Robert Edgar Wallace Jr. of New York and Falls Village, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Wallace, to Richard Scott Murphy, a son of Audrey Murphy of Worcester, Mass., and David L. Murphy of Boston. A June wedding is planned.

title: CROP OF ROOKIES READY TO PAY DIVIDENDS
description: WITH one week to go in spring training a year ago, no one knew that Vince Coleman would be the catalyst who would lead St. Louis to the World Series or that Tom Browning would win 20 games for Cincinnati or that Ted Higuera would win 15 for Milwaukee. The Chicago White Sox couldn't even be certain that Ozzie Guillen was ready to be the shortstop he would show himself to be. And, of course, the Los Angeles Dodgers had no hint that Mariano Duncan would become their shortstop and solidify their infield, and their teams had no idea of the sterling relief efforts they would receive from Tom Henke (Toronto), Roger McDowell (Mets) and Brian Fisher (Yankees).

title: FOR A GRAIN GIANT, NO FARM CRISIS
description: IT is no wonder that a mystique surrounds Cargill Inc. It is easily the world's leading company in the highly secretive, fiercely competitive grain trading business. With $32 billion in revenues last year, it is also the nation's largest privately held company and is thus rarely forced to reveal details about itself.

title: TO MANY ARABS, QADDAFI CAN'T LOSE FOR WINNING
description: AS seen from Washington, the Sixth Fleet gave Col.

title:
MUSIC;
CELLIST FACES BUSY SCHEDULE
description: LYNN HARRELL, the cello soloist with the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra next weekend, will play 115 concerts this season - all around the globe, and nearly all as soloist with major orchestras.

title: FOR U.S. IN TAIWAN, IT'S STILL BUSINESS ('UNOFFICIAL') AS USUAL
description: In the heart of the city's shopping district stands a derelict mansion, its gutters rusted, its upper windows open to the weather and its veranda overgrown with weeds.

title: PUBLISHING OF REPORT ON HOSPITALS CRITICIZED
description: The premature publication of the Federal report naming hospitals purported to have death rates ''higher than the national average'' was irresponsible, unfair and destructive to those hospitals and their hard-working staffs.

title: PHIL GRAMM'S CRUSADE AGAINST THE DEFICIT
description: THE WASHINGTON PRESS CLUB DINNER is one of those annual events when politicians and journalists dress up in formal at-tire to eat bad food and reassure each other that they really are important. The highlight of the evening is provided by a few selected speakers who are dared to be funny, and many do not survive the ordeal. This year, one of the featured guests was Senator Phil Gramm, the first-term Republican from Texas who fathered Gramm-Rudman-Hollings, the measure that requires Congress to balance the Federal budget by 1991.

title: POSTHUMOUS PUBLICATION, DOMESTICATED DREAMS
description: WHILE the old saw urges us to say only good about the dead, there seems to be a trend now to bring out, after a writer's death, work that he could not or would not publish during his lifetime. We just saw Hemingway's earliest stories and the unpublished essays of Delmore Schwartz. A short novel John Gardner chose not to publish will be brought out in June. In the final edition of Dylan Thomas's poetry there were poems he had held back.
