Another poet, Hilda Doolittle, brought out an ill-advised novel in a limited edition of 100 in the 1930's -and of course it's being reissued. In his introduction to ''Henry's Fate,'' John Berryman's last collection, John Haffenden says that Berryman left ''several hundred unpublished Dream Songs, and as many more miscellaneous poems.'' But though the 400 published Dream Songs already show signs of exhaustion, it seems inevitable that we'll get the rest.

title: 'Casablanca' Postscript
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance
description: Dance Theater of Harlem moves into its last week at City College's Aaron Davis Hall with a typically wide-ranging repertory of ballets. For classicists, there is Frederic Franklin's production of the second act of ''Swan Lake,'' and Dance Theater is offering two Balanchine ballets - ''Pas de Dix'' and ''Stars and Stripes'' - for the neo-classicists in the crowd.

title: FELLER STILL PITCHES COAST TO COAST
description: Fifty years after his first appearance in a major league game and 30 years after his last, Bob Feller remains a part of baseball. At age 67, he still promotes the game in small towns each summer, and the following article chronicles one such week late last summer. Tuesday Evening; Richland, Wash. THE light towers almost always offer the first clue that Bob Feller is near his destination. Sometimes they are silhouetted against a sunset, and sometimes they are the brightest lights for miles around, but almost always they tell him that he can put away that dogeared road atlas because he is close to the ball park.

title: HOME SLIDE SHOWS GET A FACE LIFT
description: The traditional home slide show, in which slides of a vacation or other event are loaded into a carousel and then projected onto a wall or a portable screen, may one day be a thing of the past.

title: TAX PLAN JOINS SHORE AND FLOOD PROTECTION
description: FOR SEVERAL years now, legislators from Shore counties have been trying to come up with some steady source of funds for beach protection, while lawmakers from flood-prone areas in the northern part of New Jersey have been trying to capture elusive state budget money for flood-control projects.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LIFE DRAWING. By Emily Arnold. (Delacorte, $15.95.) With the return of figurative painting to the foreground of the contemporary art scene, the New York of the Abstract Expressionists assumes the archaic, tinted dignity of a daguerrotype.

title: SACRED HEART POINTS WITH TITLE PRIDE
description: DESPITE a long winning tradition, the men's varsity basketball team at Sacred Heart University in Bridgeport has long been overshadowed by its counterparts at the University of Connecticut and Fairfield University.

title: James Russell 3d Plans To Wed Celeste Orteig
description: Mr. and Mrs. George E. Orteig of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Celeste Yvonne Orteig to James MacGregor Russell 3d, a son of Mrs. Albert Bozzo of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., and Mr. Russell Jr. of Glen Rock, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 3. The future bride is the coordinator of international personnel administration for the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York.

title: 10 REPORTED KILLED BY SIKHS IN PUNJAB
description: Gunmen identified as Sikh terrorists fired submachine guns from a jeep at residents of three Punjab villages today, killing at least 10 people and wounding as many as 15, the police said.

title: Writers Strike Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Timothy P. Pettee And Sheila Peck Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rankin Philip Peck Jr. of Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sheila Peck to Timothy Platt Pettee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Ottaway Pettee of Westport, Conn. The wedding is planned for July.

title: U.S. SAID READY TO SEND MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to rush advanced portable Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to rebels in Angola and Afghanistan, informed officials said tonight.

title: More Tape Space
description: Some of the city's most valuable property sits squirreled away 14 feet beneath the sidewalks of East 58th Street, locked securely in a 1,200-square-foot safe. Known as Univault and owned by the Universal Safe Deposit Corporation, it is popular with financial corporations that keep computer tapes of crucial data as well as with jewelers and art dealers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONJURING: Black Women, Fiction, and Literary Tradition. Edited by Marjorie Pryse and Hortense J. Spillers. (Indiana University, cloth, $29.95; paper, $10.95.)

title:
INVESTING;
PROTECTING THOSE WINDFALL STOCK PROFITS
description: WITH the stock market scaling record heights - the Dow Jones industrial average is up 500 points over the last six months and many individual stocks have doubled or tripled since the bulls began running in the summer of 1982 - many investors are considering taking some profits. At the very least, they are wondering how they can protect some of their gains.

title: Pop Music
description: Although Peter Allen was born in Australia and didn't move to the United States until the 1960's, for a large audience he has come to symbolize a certain kind of Manhattan sophistication. Mr. Allen, who opened a 10-show engagement at the Radio City Music Hall on Saturday night, is part flamboyant showman and part sensitive romantic, and the two sides complement one another wonderfully.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Weeks This Last on Week Fiction Week List 1 THE BOURNE SUPREMACY, by Robert Ludlum. 1 4 (Random House, $19.95.) The hero of ''The Bourne Identity'' foils a plot to seize Hong Kong and bring China into conflict with the West. 2 LAKE WOBEGON DAYS, by Garrison Keillor. 2 31 (Viking, $17.95.) Yarns about life in a small Minnesota town. 3 THE MAMMOTH HUNTERS, by Jean M. Auel. 3 19 (Crown, $19.95.) Ayla continues her adventures in the prehistoric world. 4 LIE DOWN WITH LIONS, by Ken Follett. 4 9 (Morrow, $18.95.) An Englishwoman caught between the C.I.A. and the K.G.B., romance and loyalty, in Afghanistan. 5 BREAK IN, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) 9 2 Mystery, melodrama and bitter family rivalry in the world of British steeplechase racing. 6 THE HANDMAID'S TALE, by Margaret Atwood. 5 5 (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) In the America of the future, a k a the Republic of Gilead, men and women perform the services assigned to them. 7 SEASONS OF THE HEART, by Cynthia Freeman. 1 (Putnam, $17.95.) A businesswoman is torn between devotion to her husband and her mentor. 8 PRIVATE AFFAIRS, by Judith Michael. 8 5 (Poseidon, $17.95.) A couple's marriage is seriously strained when they strike it rich in journalism. 9 HOME FRONT, by Patti Davis with Maureen 1 Strange Foster. (Crown, $15.95.) A semi-autobiographical novel by the daughter of President and Mrs. Reagan. 10 TEXAS, by James A. Michener. (Random House, 7 25 $21.95.) Four hundred fifty years of history in fictional form. 11* CYCLOPS, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & 6 10 Schuster, $18.95.) The quest for a vanished ship involves Fidel Castro, the Kremlin, the White House and the moon. 12 JOANNA'S HUSBAND AND DAVID'S WIFE, by 15 2 Elizabeth Forsythe Hailey. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Two sides of a marriage revealed through diary entries. 13 STONE 588, by Gerald A. Browne. (Arbor 13 8 House, $17.95.) The pursuit of a stolen crystal with curative powers climaxes atop St. Patrick's Cathedral. 14 THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST, by Anne Tyler. 14 28 (Knopf, $16.95.) Family and friends impose order of a kind on the errant life of a travel writer. 15 THE LEBARON SECRET, by Stephen Birmingham. 12 8 (Little, Brown, $17.95.) Love and conflict among the LeBarons, a wealthy family of California vintners. Nonfiction 1 YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random 1 3 House, $9.95.) A checkup at the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme. 2 BUS 9 TO PARADISE, by Leo Buscaglia. (Slack/ 2 7 Morrow, $16.95.) Another trip with the ebullient advocate of the virtues of love. 3 IACOCCA: An Autobiography, by Lee Iacocca 4 74 with William Novak. (Bantam, $19.95.) The rise of an immigrants' son to top jobs at Ford and Chrysler. 4 WISEGUY, by Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & 3 7 Schuster, $17.95.) The experiences of Henry Hill as a member of a Mafia family. 5 YEAGER: An Autobiography, by Chuck Yeager 5 38 and Leo Janos. (Bantam, $17.95.) From West Virginia hillbilly to World War II fighter pilot to the first man to fly faster than sound. 6 THE GREAT GETTY, by Robert Lenzner. (Crown, 6 4 $18.95.) The life and loves of J. Paul Getty, who was the richest man in the world. 7 ADRIFT, by Steven Callahan. (Houghton 7 5 Mifflin, $15.95.) One man's survival for 76 days on an inflatable raft in the Atlantic. 8 GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET, by Ken 9 7 Auletta. (Random House, $19.95.) The fall of the investment banking firm of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. 9 THE FRINGES OF POWER, by John Colville. 13 7 (Norton, $25.) The diary of the private secretary of three British prime ministers illuminates the career of Winston Churchill. 10 HOUSE, by Tracy Kidder. (Houghton Mifflin, 8 23 $17.95.) An account of the construction of a Greek Revival house in Massachusetts. 11* NO LAUGHING MATTER, by Joseph Heller and 12 3 Speed Vogel. (Putnam, $18.95.) The novelist's encounter with a nearly fatal disease narrated by Mr. Heller and his friend Mr. Vogel. 12* A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. 14 160 (Harper & Row, $13.50.) Light verse, with drawings by the author. 13* DANCING IN THE LIGHT, by Shirley MacLaine. 11 27 (Bantam, $17.95.) In her 51st year, the entertainer wins an Oscar, survives a stormy romance and has new visions of the past and future. 14 ON THE ROAD WITH CHARLES KURALT, by Charles 10 25 Kuralt. (Putnam, $16.95.) The television reporter tells of people he's encountered while journeying around America. 15 BLESSINGS IN DISGUISE, by Alec Guinness. 1 (Knopf, $17.95.) The autobiography of the distinguished English actor. Advice and Self-Help 1 FIT FOR LIFE, by Harvey Diamond and Marilyn 1 32 Diamond. (Warner, $17.50.) A diet for weight loss and physical fitness. 2 CALLANETICS, by Callan Pinckney with Sallie 2 18 Batson. (Morrow, $17.95.) Exercises to enable women to look ''10 years younger in 10 hours.'' 3 THE BE (HAPPY) ATTITUDES, by Robert 4 21 Schuller. (Word, $12.95.) Inspiration from a California clergyman. 4 WOMEN WHO LOVE TOO MUCH, by Robin Norwood. 3 26 (Tarcher/St. Martin's, $14.95.) Ways to avoid or end addictive, unhealthy relationships with men. 5 EAT TO SUCCEED, by Robert Haas. (Rawson, 4 $15.95.) A nutritionist's regimen designed to achieve ''maximum performance in an active daily life.''

title: PHONE LINES FOR INQUIRY TIPS
description: The newly appointed State Inspector General, Joseph A. Spinelli, has established two telephone lines for citizens to call with information on corruption, waste or other abuses in state agencies under his jurisdiction - the Departments of Environmental Conservation, Insurance and Transportation; the Divisions of Housing and Community Renewal, Youth and the State Lottery, the State Liquor Authority and the Office of General Services. The telephone numbers are (800) 367-4448 and (800) 367-4448.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE SWEEPING EFFORT TO COMBAT MUNICIPAL CORRUPTION
description: Federal prosecutors say they are waging an unparalleled campaign against municipal corruption in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Washington and other major cities around the country.

title: Melanie E. Brown To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brown of Demarest, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melanie Elizabeth Brown to Miles Benjamin Neustein, a son of Mrs. Rodman Fischer of Franklin Lakes, N.J., and David Neustein of Westerly, R.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Motive Is Focus Of Espionage Trial
description: Espionage trials tend to be complicated, drawn-out affairs, and the case of Jerry A. Whitworth, who is accused of providing the Walker family spy ring with details about highly classified Navy codes, clearly will be no exception. Nearly three weeks were devoted to such preliminaries as settling on a jury.

title: DEMOCRATS SCRUTINIZE LAROUCHE BLOC
description: To the followers of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the surprise victories of their candidates in the Democratic primary in Illinois were a vindication of their ''rich ideas'' and the first fruits of their 1986 campaign to run hundreds of candidates in Democratic primaries around the country.

title: MEMORIES ROOTED IN THE LAWN
description: SPRING fever:

title: MARCOS'S MOTHER, AND HER HOSPITAL BILL, ARE LEFT BEHIND
description: Josefa Marcos still passes the day playing mah-jongg, unaware of the uprising in the Philippines or that her son, Ferdinand E. Marcos, fled the country last month.

title: Of Pads and Pods of Fat
description: WHEN I BECAME old enough to notice the shape of things human, ''curvaceous'' was the word that described the ideal female form. ''Having a full or voluptuous figure,'' is how the American Heritage Dictionary defines curvaceous, and that is precisely the kind of form I envisioned upon hearing a woman so described.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TRUE FISH STORIES If the name Esopus Creek rings a bell, you are a trout fisherman, probably with rod poised for the season to open on Tuesday. Esopus Creek, for the benefit of the uninitiated, is a natural rainbow trout hatchery in Ulster County, renowned for early-season fishing when the trout swim upstream from the Ashokan Reservoir to spawn. It is no fish story that four- to five-pound catches are customary.

title: A CORRECTION
description: Several lines were transposed in Lonye Debra Rasch's Opinion article, ''Easing the Doctor-Patient Strain,'' last week. The affected paragraphs should have read:

title: DOG DOES THE LISTENING FOR DEAF OWNER
description: AS the telephone rang, a light above it flickered on and off. That was Radar's cue. But instead of swinging into action, the mini-Pinscher jerked his head in confusion as he stood among a group of people in Judy Williams's living room in Bridgeport.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Harvard Farce Faculty meetings have discouraged many a university scholar. Here is the philosopher George Santayana reflecting on them at Harvard near the turn of the century. He is quoted in ''Glimpses of the Harvard Past'' (Harvard University), by Bernard Bailyn, Donald Fleming, Oscar Handlin and Stephan Thernstrom.

title: A SIGNIFYING MAN
description: TRACTATUS DE SIGNIS The Semiotic of John Poinsot. Edited and translated by John N. Deely with Ralph Austin Powell. 607 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $70. IT would be easy to get the notion that semiotics, which is now a chic undertaking in and out of the academy, is a brand new subject born in the last 15 years or so. Some general readers, seeing the word, might think of Umberto Eco, whose works of semiotics are substantial, but whose popular fame rests on his novel ''The Name of the Rose,'' which drew attention to his scholarly interests. Others might think of the semijournalistic works of Roland Barthes. A more select readership, interested in literary theory, would mention Ferdinand de Saussure, the Swiss linguist who hinted at a science of semiology (alias semiotics) during the first decade of this century. It would be astonishing if the ordinary intelligent reader thought of anyone else or could supply any kind of definition of semiotics.

title: J. P. Otero to Wed Dr. Susan Early
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Howard Early Jr. of Hillsville, Va., and Deerfield, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Susan Howard Early to Juan Pablo Otero, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rene Otero of Chevy Chase, Md., and La Paz, Bolivia. A May wedding is planned in Hillsville.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: WORLD WAR II FORUM Distinguished scholars, including John Toland and Forrest C. Pogue, will discuss World War II at a free public conference at Rutgers-Newark next weekend.

title: Marla P. Goldstein to Wed Mark Paige, Law Student
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur D. Goldstein of Wesley Hills, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marla Pam Goldstein, to Mark Steven Paige, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Paige of New Hempstead, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May 31.

title: More Time for Art Show
description: The National Gallery of Art has announced that it has received a grant from A.T.&T. to extend the hours of its popular exhibition ''The New Painting: Impressionism 1874-1886.'' Hours from Monday through Saturday will be 10 A.M. to 7 P.M., extended from the present 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Sunday hours will remain noon to 9 P.M. The show, which runs until April 6, had drawn 312,753 visitors by last Sunday.

title: HEART RECIPIENT MEETS HIS BENEFACTORS
description: LONG before they met Donald DiMaggio, Frank and Jane Walach knew all about him.

title: Sheila Brownlie Is Married To Timothy E. A. Gibbon
description: Sheila Brownlie, the daughter of Nan Brownlie of Babylon, L.I., and the late John Brownlie, was married yesterday in the Pierre to Timothy E. A. Gibbon, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward Gibbon of Farnham, Surrey, England. Judge Judith Kaye of the State of New York Court of Appeals officiated.

title: Talking: Interviews; Winning Admission To a Co-op
description: SHOULD you wear your club tie or your favorite Hawaiian shirt? Say you listen to Beethoven or the Beatles? Extol the glories of your home on the West Coast or give the clear impression that you will be living in New York for most of the year?

title: SUPPORT FOR RETESTING DRIVERS' VISION
description: The Opinion article by State Representative Edith Prague [ ''Why a Law to Test Drivers' Vision, Especially for the Elderly, Is Needed,'' Feb.16 ] was not just timely, but also long overdue.

title: WHEN POLITICIANS STRETCH THE TRUTH
description: Something seems to be happening to our traditions of political discourse.

title: REFINERIES SEEK TAX REDUCTIONS
description: A MAJOR fight is shaping up between big oil companies, which are appealing the assessments on their refineries, and municipalities, which fear that a multimillion-dollar tax burden could be shifted to homeowners.

title: Tax Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: PAWTUCKET TESTS NEW WAY OF LIFE
description: For years doctors have been telling their patients that the risk of heart disease is increased by smoking, eating too much salt and fat, and exercising too little. Now a long-term experiment is under way here to see what will happen if that message is drummed into a larger audience: an entire city.

title: Shultz, in Drive To Save Bases, Visits Testy Allies
description: Air Force and NATO jet fighters escorted George P. Shultz last week as he flew from Turkey to Greece to Italy - to protect him from possible attack by Libya, officials said. The only assaults were verbal, however, and they came from friends.

title: EATING WELL IN THE KEYS
description: The restaurant called simply Marker 88 looks like something out of a Somerset Maugham South Seas novel with enough palm trees and white sand for Sadie Thompson and an occasional tropical rainstorm to complete the picture. Inside is what is considered the best restaurant in the Florida Keys, the string of emerald and bone white islands that curve southwestward from the southern tip of Florida along 110 miles of U.S. 1 and over 42 bridges to Key West.

title: WHEN SOPHISTICATED MEDICINE DOES MORE HARM THAN GOOD
description: THE family of Nancy Ellen Jobes, a 31-year-old woman in a coma, asked the New Jersey Superior Court last week for permission to remove the feeding tube that has kept her alive for six years.

title: Zoning Urged to Spur Housing for Aged
description: ADVOCATES of housing for the elderly are trying a new approach in Bedford and Cortlandt: persuading local officials to zone some land exclusively for apartments for older people. The Supervisors of both Westchester towns say the objective is to fill a gap left by the current wave of development, which concentrates on high-priced condominiums and large single-family houses.

title: THE COMPLICATIONS OF BURNING GARBAGE
description: This is in response to the article ''8500 Tons of Garbage a Day - and Counting'' [ Feb. 23 ] .

title: Can't Something Be Done To Help the Old-Timers?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EDUCATORS REVIEW SCIENCE INSTRUCTION
description: CONCERNED about what they consider an inability among schoolchildren to understand scientific principles, educators around the state are searching for ways to improve the quality of science education.

title: Doctors and the Draft
description: Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery of Mississippi has introduced legislation to require all doctors and nurses to register for a military draft, and the proposal has received predictable attention in the newspaper published by the American Medical Association. Mr. Montgomery, a Democrat who is chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, cited continuing shortages of doctors in the armed forces and declared that ''it simply isn't right to ask mothers and fathers to send their children to war for this country and not give them proper medical care.''

title: Gillian Grosewald To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter Grosewald of Putnam Valley, N.Y., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Gillian Eve Grosewald to Steven Marshal Raye, the son of Beatrice Raye of Sussex, N.J., and Deerfield Beach, Fla., and the late Charles Raye. The wedding is planned for May 11.

title: CARDINALS RALLY TO TOP LOUISIANA ST., 88-77
description: Louisiana State's dream of a miracle season crumbled in the face of overwhelming talent this afternoon as Louisville overcame an 8-point halftime deficit and raced to an 88-77 victory in the national tournament semifinal at Reunion Arena.

title: More Radon Gas In New Jersey
description: New Jersey officials said last week that a new cluster of houses with potentially dangerous levels of the radioactive gas radon had been found, this time in and around Clinton, a rural village in the west-central part of the state. The finding was particularly disturbing, environmental officials said, because it represented the first such concentration discovered outside the Reading Prong, a uranium-laden geological formation that stretches in an irregular band as much as 35 miles wide from Reading, Pa., across seven northern New Jersey counties and into parts of four New York counties.

title: YONKERS JOBS EFFORT: ITS STATUS DEFINED
description: The article dealing with the start of the 1986 Summer Jobs for Youth Campaign [ ''Summer Jobs Effort Begins 5th Season,'' March 16 ] contained some inaccuracies that need to be corrected.

title: Holocaust History
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: RAFFLES - THE AMATEUR CRACKSMAN, by E. W. Hornung. (Leete's Island Books, Box 1131, New Haven, $8.95.) E. W. Hornung's dashing man about town and gentleman crook, A. J. Raffles, was a great favorite on both sides of the Atlantic at the turn of the century. Hornung's popularity, in fact, rivaled that of his brother-in-law, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and Raffles's daring exploits were dramatized for the stage with great success and later brought to the screen in film versions starring Ronald Colman and David Niven. ''One reads what Mr. Hornung has written with a kind of fascination such as the serpent is credited with exercising,'' our reviewer wrote in 1899, asserting, ''There is not a prosaic line in one of the eight stories in the book.'' This edition includes an essay written in 1944 by George Orwell. THE FALCONER OF CENTRAL PARK, by Donald Knowler. (Bantam, $8.95.) The English journalist and amateur ornithologist Donald Knowler chronicles 12 months in the life of Central Park, following the fortunes of the human and animal species that populated its 834 acres during 1982. August Heckscher said in The Book Review in 1984 that the park, ''itself an almost miraculous survivor in the clogged and asphalt city . . . has been caught, like one of its own birds in flight . . . upon the pages of this lovely book.'' THE WAR BETWEEN THE TATES, by Alison Lurie. (Avon, $3.95.) This novel by Alison Lurie takes place in a college town in the late 60's, as 48-year-old Brian Tate, head of the political science department at Corinth College, and his 40-year-old wife, Erica, deal with career insecurities, Brian's infidelity and the increasing alienation of their children.

title: A GRAND TOUR OF SPACES AND PLACES JUST MISSES THE MARK
description: Architecture is an art of movement as much as it is an art of stasis: though buildings stand still, we must move through them to understand them. It would seem, then, that film would be the ideal medium to capture architecture. With motion pictures, we can walk through buildings, and not simply look at them as static objects fixed in space as we do with still photography. On film, we ought to be able to feel the interior space that is so essential to the experience of being within a building.

title: A HAMPTONS PAPER UPHOLDS TRADITIONS
description: When the first issue of The East Hampton Star appeared on the doorsteps of this seaside village, Grover Cleveland was President, the Statue of Liberty was under construction, and the newspaper's editor was commuting to work, with difficulty, by stagecoach.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE CASE FOR ANIMAL EXPERIMENTATION: An Evolutionary and Ethical Perspective. By Michael Allen Fox (University of California, $24.95.) In this long and often repetitious essay, Michael Allen Fox, a professor of philosophy at Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, stresses the evolutionary and ethical perspective of the argument for animal experimentation. Mr. Fox hammers home the view that such experimentation is essential for furthering scientific advances that benefit mankind and that humans have the moral right to use animals for this purpose.

title: DEFENSE OF PLEDGE WEEK ON WNET
description: To the Editor: Walter Goodman has offered a facile but flawed brief for commercials on noncommercial television [ ''Almost Anything Beats Pledge Week,'' March 23 ] .

title: STEWART AIRPORT OPEN FOR INDUSTRY
description: STEWART INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT, where the only international visitors are exotic animals, was once intended to become the metropolitan New York area's fourth major airport. The state, which spent more than $100 million assembling a site two-thirds the size of Manhattan and improving the little-used Orange County facility over the last 16 years, has now endorsed another amibitious idea.

title: BUSINESS VOLUNTEERS FOR ARTS HELP BALANCE THEATER COMMUNITY'S BOOKS
description: WHEN Rosetta LeNoire founded the AMAS Repertory Theater 17 years ago, she was no stranger to show business.

title: 54 FOOD OUTLETS CITED BY NEW YORK OFFICIALS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 54 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Early Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Jill Goldberger Plans a June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Goldberger of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Jill Goldberger, to Stuart Fuchsman, a son of Natalie Fuchsman of Fort Lee, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Harold Fuchsman. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Recent Sales
EVER-BETTER HOME ENTERTAINMENT
description: IMAGINE a computer that could do it all: play a Mantovani recording or, say, a home-recorded TV broadcast with impeccable sound reproduction, show the latest Woody Allen movie and perform all the tasks computers already do, such as word processing.

title: May Wedding Planned For Kathleen Vuillet
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vuillet of Glen Cove, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Vuillet to Roland J. Augustine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Augustine of Kingston, N.Y. A May 17 wedding is planned. Miss Vuillet is an assistant to Robert Dunning, a photographer in New York.

title: Tyson Under Care
description: Mike Tyson, the 19-year-old heavyweight sensation whose ear ailment forced him to cancel yesterday's bout against James Tillis, has been at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan since last Monday. Tyson, whose ear was hurt while sparring and was aggravated during a bout March 10, said he expected to leave the hospital Tuesday. The Tillis bout was rescheduled for May 1.

title: MAKE WAY FOR THE LOS ANGELES OPERA
description: ''It's been said that Los Angeles isn't really a city, but 27 cities joined together by freeways,''

title: A HEROIC HAMLET THAT MIGHT HAVE BEEN OUTSTANDING
description: Kevin Kline is the pride of the American theater - a homegrown actor who might yet be our Olivier (and a singing and dancing Olivier at that), a show business star who has never misplaced either his devotion to the stage or his integrity. One can safely speculate that commercial theatrical managements offer Mr. Kline nearly every starring role for which he might be remotely suited. Yet, since making his Broadway debut in a supporting part in the musical ''On the Twentieth Century,'' the actor has limited his Broadway appearances to classics (''The Pirates of Penzance,'' ''Arms and the Man'') and a superior contemporary play (Michael Weller's ''Loose Ends'') - all under the aegis of nonprofit theatrical institutions. Mr. Kline's choice of Hollywood film projects (''The Big Chill,'' ''Sophie's Choice,'' ''Silverado'') has been similarly schlock-free. Without making a public case of it, this actor is one of the very few of his generation and gifts who has made no discernible effort to sell out. He hasn't even served as a guest host on ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: LIVING WILL STILL DESIRABLE
description: The March 2 article, ''Living Will May Be Worth the Paper It's Written On,'' emphasizes the shortcomings of the Connecticut law sanctioning living wills and the difficulty or impossibility of specifying in precise legal terms how medical treatment of a patient near death should be conducted.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Boom in Savings Bonds A traditional favorite with grandparents and children learning to save, United States Savings Bonds will be a big hit with investors this year. The value of outstanding savings bonds - in denominations of $50 to $10,000 - may reach a record $81 billion in 1986, says James R. Wynn of the Treasury Department, which expects to sell $6 billion in savings bonds this year, up from $5 billion in 1985 and $3.1 billion in 1982.

title: HEARINGS SET ON FARE RISES
description: THE board of directors of NJ Transit has made official its intent to increase bus and train fares by midsummer to balance its $530 million operating budget for the 1987 fiscal year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BURIED DREAMS: Inside the Mind of a Serial Killer. By Tim Cahill with Russ Ewing. (Bantam, $17.95.) Listen to the inner voice of John Wayne Gacy, convicted in 1980 of committing more murders than anyone else in American history.

title: PUT-UPON MOTORISTS HAVE A NEW VOICE
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY'S highway commuters now have someone to speak up for them.

title: 8-Acre Warehouse
description: When developers talk about a building of 362,000 square feet, they usually mean a tower rising more than 30 stories. But in Port Elizabeth, N.J., a one-story warehouse of that size is under construction.

title: St. John's Weaknesses Exposed in Tournament
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Linda W. Denney to Wed Steven L. Wagner April 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lilley Denney of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Wainwright Denney, to Steven Lee Wagner, a son of Mrs. Samuel Good Wagner of Hudson, Ohio, and the late Mr. Wagner. An April 19 wedding is planned.

title: DANCE, AS BIG BUSINESS, MAY POSE A THREAT TO DANCE AS ART
description: ''Twenty years ago we just mimeographed and sent out announcements of our season to several hundred people on a list,'' Paul Taylor said. ''We'd stay up all night licking stamps.'' Times have changed. When the Paul Taylor Dance Company opens on Tuesday for a four-week season at City Center, at the official start of the spring dance season, the theatergoing public will have been bombarded by posters, advertisements, computerized subscription lists and sophisticated brochures laden with color photographs and rapturous critics' quotes.

title: Padua
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. TALKS WITH STALIN'S KIN
description: The State Department said today that American officials in Moscow had talked to Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, who reportedly wants to return to the West.

title: STATE ADDS BACKING TO CHILD SUPPORT
description: UNDER pressure from the Federal Government and divorced parents, the state is taking new measures, including allowing nonwelfare residents access to its information and collection services, to get absent parents to pay court-ordered child-support payments.

title: High Court Backs Military's Ban On the Yarmulke
description: To Jewish men, the yarmulke is donned as a sign of piety. But when Captain S. Simcha Goldman, a psychologist at March Air Force Base in Riverside, Calif., wore his skullcap to a court-martial at which he was to testify, the Air Force took offense. He was later reprimanded for continuing to wear the yarmulke in violation of a rule barring all headgear while in uniform indoors and warned that he, too, might be brought up on charges. Mr. Goldman left the service and headed for court, contending that his First Amendment right to free exercise of religion had been violated.

title: Merger Mania
description: To the Editor:

title: Going His Way
description: There are still formidable legal hurdles to be overcome, but Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the Illinois Democrat who wants to be Governor but does not want to share his party's ticket - much less office space in Springfield - with two followers of the ultraconservative Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., announced last week that he would try to run as an independent. Aides said Mr. Stevenson, whose plan was endorsed by many of the state's prominent Democrats, would not go his own way if the two LaRouche interlopers, nominated March 18 to be the Democratic candidates for Lieutenant Governor and Secretary of State, can somehow be bumped from the party line. Party officials in Washington subsequently sent out an all-points bulletin warning Democrats everywhere to be wary of LaRouche candidates.

title: DEATH ROW PRISONER ASSAILS SYSTEM
description: Prisoner 069063, in a locked holding cell on death row in Florida State Prison, is seated at a small table with a reporter. The condemned prisoner said it was the first press interview he had given in the six years since he was found guilty of killing two college sorority sisters and a 12-year-old schoolgirl.

title: A Doctor's View of Modern Medicine
description: Dr. Hilfiker vastly underestimates the forces that compel physicians to ration access of medical care for the indigent. The costs of modern medical practice are skyrocketing much faster than fees.

title: A FEW RECIPES FOR MAKING SOIL MIXTURES
description: My gardening season begins on my garage floor where I mix potting soil.

title: LONG ISLAND OPNION D>YES, I JUST CAN'T SAY NO
description: WHEN my husband heard about an adult education course in assertiveness training, he insisted that I register. ''It's about time,'' he said, ''that you learn how to say no to people without feeling guilty.''

title: An Earring
description: At Masai Mara Lodge, in Kenya, a gentle, seven-foot-tall Masai adopted me and made himself spokesman for his country and people. He spoke of my pierced ears.

title: THE EMPLOYER'S ROLE IN ON-SITE DAY CARE
description: The letter to the Westchester editor by Shelley B. Mayer [ ''Quality Child Care: The Need Is Real,'' March 9 ] correctly points out that, besides the problem of day-care availability, the question of quality day care is also part of the quandary for working mothers.

title: Fowler's Promise
description: It did not help his resume when he admitted giving money to some players and some of them admitted taking part in a point-shaving scheme, but Ned Fowler, the former Tulane coach, is determined to put the scandal behind him. ''I want to coach the game again desperately,'' he said, acknowledging that he has not had any job offer.

title: City Hall Is Dusting Off Some Taxi Plans
description: Even before Stanley M. Friedman's indictment was announced last week, City Hall seemed set to wheel out once again some proposals to improve taxi service that Mr. Friedman, who is the chief taxi lobbyist as well as Bronx Democratic leader, had so often defeated.

title: RECRUITMENT STEPPED UP AT COMMUNITY COLLEGES
description: LONG ISLAND'S two community colleges are aggressively instituting new recruitment and registration procedures and reaching out to businesses, older people and minorities to cushion the serious impact of shrinking enrollments.

title: Merger Mania
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY SELECTS DEVELOPERS FOR COMPLEX IN QUEENS
description: The city has chosen a five-member development team to build a $95 million commercial and residential complex in Flushing, Queens, Mayor Koch has announced.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BUT DO BLONDES PREFER GENTLEMEN?: Homage to Qwert Yuiop and Other Writings. By Anthony Burgess (McGraw-Hill, $24.95). A brief caveat before beginning this collection of almost 200 reviews and essays, most of which first appeared in The Times Literary Supplement, The Observer and The New York Times: skip the introduction.

title: CIRCUS WORK CONTINUES TO DRAW THE DREAMERS
description: Lisa Guarino played hooky from Louis D. Brandeis High School the other day. The circus had come to New York, and she wanted to join.

title: A MUSIC LESSON: COUNTY MAESTRO RECALLS CHILDHOOD
description: THE steel door squealed on its bearings as it slammed shut. The cage lurched. Tiny bulbs, flashing in succession above, heralded impending doom. At ''3'' his palms were clammy; by ''4'' his clothes were damp. The light hit ''5'' and the elevator broke its climb. The door began to grind open and a dark hallway gradually appeared. There would be no last minute reprieve.

title: AWARD FOR LIZARD IN COKE
description: Jurors awarded $500 Thursday to a woman who said she found a dead lizard in a Coca-Cola bottle she had drunk. The plaintiff, Brenda Rae Baker, had sought $1.1 million in damages in Tallapoosa County Court from the Coca-Cola Bottling Company over the incident Jan. 8, 1985. She said she became so upset that she developed psoriasis.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GORBACHEV SPEECH ON ARMS
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address tonight, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: 9-Year Sentence in Fraud
description: A Federal judge sentenced Nadine Gan, a 61-year-old Chicopee resident, to nine years in prison for running a pyramid scheme that swindled $2.5 million from investors nationwide.

title: The Athlete In the Booth
description: WITH ''Monday Night Football'' circling the wagons for a live-or-die skirmish next fall, this has been a bad week for the jockocracy, to use Howard Cosell's loaded word.

title: ANCESTORS AT HOME AND ABROAD
description: SAMURAI AND SILK A Japanese and American Heritage. By Haru Matsukata Reischauer. Illustrated. 371 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20. ''I TELL you, Mr. Arai, it is getting very hard to make money by Jap. business because as you know, in Japan there is not much necessary thing that we can export.'' This letter from one Japanese businessman to another, composed in English to express his international outlook, was obviously not written recently. It was sent in 1878. Mr. Arai was a silk merchant in New York, and the grandfather of the author of ''Samurai and Silk.'' Mrs. Reischauer's other grandfather, on her father's side, was Prince Masayoshi Matsukata, who was Prime Minister twice and Finance Minister for 15 years at the end of the 19th century. The story of these two gentlemen, an international businessman and a nation-builder, is meant to illustrate, as Mrs. Reischauer puts it, ''the reasons for Japan's economic success in modern times.''

title: SISTER CITIES PROMOTE PROGRESS
description: I thank you for your inclusion of the city of New Britain in your article ''Communities Grow Closer to Their 'Sisters' Abroad'' on Feb. 23.

title: Defection Reported
description: Jana Navratilova, the 23-year-old sister of Martina Narvatilova, who defected from Czechoslovakia in 1975, reportedly has defected to West Germany and is seeking to move to the United States. According to The Cologne Express, Jana and her fiance defected after arriving in West Germany on tourist visas. American authorities would not comment, but according to the report, Jana has applied to the United States Embassy in Bonn for permission to settle in the United States.

title: Senate Defeats Budget Measure
description: The new balanced-budget law has claimed an early victim in the Senate - the proposed balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution. Though the chamber approved the amendment 69 to 31 only three years ago, last week the Republican leadership was able to muster on its behalf only 66 votes, one short of the number required.

title: Mona Bienfait Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. A. Bienfait Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mona Perry Bienfait to Lieut.

title: 13 CORSICAN BOMBS ROCK SOUTHERN FRANCE
description: Thirteen bombs exploded Friday night in southern France, and the Corsican National Liberation Front said today that it was responsible.

title: Article 720886 -- No Title
description: The W Acquisition Corporation sweetened its offer yesterday for Warnaco Inc., a leading apparel manufacturer, to $40 a share in cash, or a total of $404 million.

title: 3,000 RALLY IN TOKYO AGAINST AIRPORT PROJECT
description: About 3,000 people, mostly leftists, protested today against the expansion of Tokyo's Narita International Airport and vowed to disrupt the Tokyo economic summit meeting in May.

title: O'ROURKE, A LIKELY FOE OF CUOMO, TO TOUR CITIES
description: Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive, who is considered the most likely Republican candidate for governor, is to begin a tour of several upstate cities today to gather sentiment about how he would fare in a November election against Governor Cuomo.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This year the verities of this great Christian feast have come to life in a way we never dreamed possible and in a manner which leaves us gasping and incredulous.'' - Jaime Cardinal Sin, Roman Catholic Primate of the Philippines. [ A1:1. ]

title: MOST WORLD STOCK MARKETS SOARED IN FIRST QUARTER OF YEAR
description: Investors and securities brokers have had little time to gloat about the excellent performance of stock markets around the world last year, as 1986 already threatens to outpace the generally robust 1985. The powerful combination of falling interest rates and declining oil prices gave a big lift to equities in most major stock markets in the last three months.

title: Advertising; Changes Up High In Y.&R.
description: ALEXANDER KROLL, after just a year as chief executive of Young & Rubicam Inc. and determined that it be one of the surviving multinational giants, has designed a restructuring to insure that survival.

title: West Captures All-America Game
description: Jim Les of Bradley hit a 30-foot jump shot at the final buzzer to rally the West to a 94-92 victory over the East today in the 24th annual National Association of Basketball Coaches all-America college basketball game.

title: THE JOHN WOODEN CONNECTION
description: DALLAS

title: Profits Jump At Hathaway
description: At a time when most investors in the stock market are doing very well for themselves, Warren E. Buffett has been making their gains seem paltry indeed.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: FALWELL MINISTRY TO DROP TOLL-FREE TELEPHONE LINE
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell said his ministry will drop its toll-free telephone line because it has received thousands of harassing calls.

title: OUTDOORS: APRIL RITUAL FOR TROUT
description: FISHING for trout in April is a ritual that celebrates the sport, more than it is the sport itself. Frigid opening days on Peekskill Hollow Brook, or even the illusory late afternoon warmth on the Esopus that invited that season's first efforts with dry flies, were the rites of respectful youth as much as they were seriously considered efforts to catch fish.

title: CITY'S NEW GLASS PALACE GETS HECTIC LAST-MINUTE POLISHING
description: The glass palace on the Hudson has been hit by fire, flood, hurricane and Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA EXTENDS HEALTH CARE FOR ITS POOR
description: When Gov. Richard W. Riley delivered his State of the State Message earlier this year, he introduced to his audience 2-month-old Ashley Faith Young and 80-year-old Mary Jane Lovett as beneficiaries of a state system of health care that has been radically changed in the last five years.

title: 'APPROACHING LAVENDAR,' A ONE-ACT DRAMA ON 13
description: THE Actors Theater of Louisville, one of the most original theatrical companies in the country, can no longer be considered merely ''regional'' since the works of several of its playwrights (among them Marsha Norman and Beth Henley, who first attracted attention there), are known to Broadway and Off Broadway audiences. Now, through a series called ''Actors Theater Presents!'' some of the plays are being made available to television audiences, too.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Guillermo Rios Plays Program for Guitar
description: Guillermo Rios, who presented a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night, is an unusually inventive flamenco guitarist: he plays with exhibitionist flair and an underlying sense of drama. Mr. Rios began his guitar studies in Spain, and has since performed with many of the leading flamenco singers and dancers both in Europe and the United States. He has appeared here with every major Spanish dance company, including the Jose Greco company, the Jose Molina company and several others.

title: Convergent Head Stays With Acquisition Plans
description: After the last-minute dissolution of the proposed merger between Convergent Technologies and the 3Com Corporation last Tuesday, Paul C. Ely Jr., Convergent's chief executive, conceded he was ''shocked and surprised.'' But now he says he is ready to get back to work, creating a ''federation'' of computer and communications companies.

title: WHY ADMIRAL FARRAGUT NEEDS TO COME IN FROM THE PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: Rogers & Wells Settles Suit
description: A Superior Court judge in San Diego approved a $40 million settlement on Friday by the law firm of Rogers & Wells, which was sued by investors over its representation of J. David Dominelli and some of Mr. Dominelli's investment companies.

title: SANTA BARBARA'S MOVES AGAINST THE HOMELESS DRAW PROTESTS
description: At a sunrise Easter service for the homeless today, they were asked to forgive the city fathers for engaging in what was described as a systematic program to arrest and prosecute them ''merely for sleeping.''

title: O'SULLIVAN'S STRENGTHS: GOOD IMAGE, HANDLERS, FISTS
description: ELEVEN fights into his professional career, Shawn O'Sullivan is a boxing franchise. At least in Canada.

title: Bridge: Women With Experience Are Still Taking the Titles
description: At the top levels, the women's game in North America has not acquired much new talent in recent years. This is another way of saying that the experienced stars who have been winning titles for 20 years or more are still doing it.

title: Lessons for Giants
description: In an era when athletes' off-the-field activities are too frequently a cause for punishment and rehabilitation, a refreshing breeze is blowing out of the Meadowlands these days.

title: NL Cost-Cutter Attracts Attention of Coniston
description: Since Theodore C. Rogers joined NL Industries six years ago, he has had to spend a lot of time figuring out how to cut costs at the oil-drilling equipment and chemicals company.

title: February Tool Orders Fell 11.1%
description: New orders for machine tools continued their decline in February, dropping 11.1 percent from the same month the year before, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: 30 KILLED AS TRAIN HITS TRUCK IN MEXICO
description: A train engine hit a truck at a railroad crossing north of Mexico City, killing 30 teen-agers on their way to Easter weekend religious celebrations and injuring 27 others, Red Cross officials said today.

title: MARCOS DECLARES HE IS STILL PRESIDENT
description: Ferdinand E. Marcos, breaking a monthlong silence, said today that he still considered himself President of the Philippines and denounced the Government of Corazon C. Aquino as ''a plain and simple dictatorship.''

title: A TOUGH ENCORE FOR REDS' PITCHER
description: It was not yet noon, but the Florida sun had already begun to beat down on the field at Al Lang Stadium. Tom Browning sat in the dugout watching his teammates stretch on the grass in left field, and he thought about how far he had come. One year ago, he was simply trying to find a spot on the Cincinnati Reds' pitching staff. Today, he was preparing for the season after becoming the first rookie pitcher in 31 years to win 20 games.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SARANAC: America's Magic Mountain.

title: UCLER DRUG SUCCEEDS, BUT GLAXO WON'T RELAX
description: Paul Girolami, the avuncular 60-year-old chairman of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., is facing the sort of problem most executives long for.

title: INSURANCE WOES SPUR MANY STATES TO AMEND LAW ON LIABILITY SUITS
description: Spurred by widespread difficulties in obtaining liability insurance, many states are modifying their civil justice systems to make it more difficult for victims of accidents to recover large sums in personal injury cases.

title: 'Parsifal' at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera will give its first performance this season of Wagner's ''Parsifal'' on April 10, with the tenor Peter Hofmann in the title role. The soprano Kathryn Harries will debut in the house as Kundry. Tickets: at the box office or 362-6000.

title: MIZE FALLS APART, SO MAHAFFEY WINS
description: Larry Mize, who held a four-shot lead with eight holes to go in the 13th Tournament Players Championship, let it all get away today. John Mahaffey, the only man in position to take advantage, stepped forward to par the final hole and win by a shot.

title: WASHINGTON STATE TAX ON TOBACCO GOING TO 31 CENTS
description: Washington State's cigarette and tobacco taxes become the highest in the nation at midnight Tuesday, with an 8-cent-a-pack increase raising the tax to 31 cents a pack.

title: No Headline
description: Two primary victories here by supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. were built on indifference among established politicians, voter ignorance of candidates' allegiances and carefully targeted campaigning by LaRouche workers, according to political experts.

title: CITY POLICE STRENGTHENED BY '72 PANEL
description: As prosecutors and special commissions investigate accusations of corruption in more than a dozen New York City agencies, one - the Police Department - is awaiting a report from a commission of another kind.

title: VIOLENCE IN KOREA FOLLOWS BIG RALLEY BY THE OPPOSITION
description: A huge anti-Government rally went off peacefully here today, but late tonight violence erupted as a small band of students burned placards and threw stones at riot policemen.

title: TEXAS OVERPOWERS U.S.C. TO WIN FINAL
description: For four years, their goal was always just out of reach, like a loose ball slipping through their fingers and rolling harmlessly out of bounds. Winning seasons were framed in disappointment for the Lady Longhorns of Texas and individual achievements seemed hollow. Thus, today marked one last chance for some to make an imprint on women's collegiate basketball. There would be no joy in being remembered as the best team that never won.

title: A NATURAL
description: Frank H. Dunkle, the man President Reagan nominated last week to head the Fish and Wildlife Service in the Interior Department, has an unusual combination of professional and political credentials. He worked for the Montana Fish and Game Department as a special warden in 1947 while he was in college and rose through the ranks to become director in 1963.

title: William Murray Dead at 77; Former Duke Football Coach
description: William Murray, the football coach at Duke from 1951 through 1965, died Saturday at age 77 after an extended illness. Murray, a native of Rocky Mount, N.C., died at Hillcrest Convalescence Home in Durham, where he lived since suffering a stroke in 1982.

title: SOME ALAMITO DIRECTORS VIEW A BID UNFAVORABLY
description: Osceola Energy Inc. sweetened its offer Saturday for the Alamito Company to $158 a share in cash, or $360.2 million, in the bidding war for the Tucson, Ariz., electricity wholesaler.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Joel Rosenwasser In Piano Concert
description: The pianist Joel Rosenwasser, who presented a Saturday afternoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, was at his best in an opening selection of three Haydn sonatas, played without interruption. Here his pianism was clean, straightforward and sensitive, with a classicist sense of structure.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ TE DEUM
description: INTIMACY and understatement have come to assume an esthetic - even a moral - quality in the creation and execution of music. But listening to the Berlioz Te Deum at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon forced one to consider another addition to the pantheon of musical virtue - sheer size.

title: 2 Bids Remain at Land Rover
description: The state-owned car company BL P.L.C., formerly British Leyland, said that it was pursuing two offers for its Land Rover division after negotiations with the General Motors Corporation collapsed.

title: HONORS IN INDIA
description: This afternoon in New Delhi, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi will present the Padma Bhusham award, the highest civilian honor accorded by his Government, to S. Dillon Ripley, former secretary of the Smithsonian. Mr. Ripley, the first American ever to receive this honor, will be cited for his role as chairman of the American Council for the Festival of India in 1985-86.

title: NOT-SO-GRAND PRIX AFTER ALL
description: The idea of a Grand Prix auto race in New York's Flushing Meadow-Corona Park stirred excitement only in the hearts of its private promoters. Queens residents and others argued vociferously for four years against so disrupting the park and distracting park officials.

title: JAVITS CENTER: NOBLE AMBITION LARGELY REALIZED
description: That the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center has happened at all is something of a miracle. For when the political squabbles that have surrounded the center since its inception fade away, it will become clear that this is a work of architecture that is grand in scale and sweeping in ambition. It is not the typical New York public building of our age at all.

title: Boza-Edwards, Alli Fight to Draw
description: Cornelius Boza-Edwards and Terrence Alli battled to a 10-round draw today, giving the World Boxing Association lightweight champion, Livingstone Bramble, a choice of opponents for his next defense.

title: GROUP OPPOSES SCHOOL BOYCOTT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: A conference of parents, students and teachers, seeking to avert widespread school boycotts in South Africa, today urged the nation's restive black schoolchildren to remain in their classes.

title: Electronic Point
description: For a contest derived from the clean-cut life-and-death struggle of swordplay, fencing was long a surprisingly subjective sport. That's because the parries and thrusts came so fast that the judges were often forced to guess whether a touch had been scored or which of two nearly simultaneous touches had come first. The result, according to many fencers, is that the competitor with the greater reputation almost always gained the benefit of any doubt.

title: CHURCHES USED BY MESSIANIC JEWS IN JERSEY ARE TARGETS OF VANDALS
description: Vandals early Sunday defaced two Bergen County church buildings , painting slogans attacking groups of Messianic Jews that had been holding weekly services at the churches, the police and church officials said.

title: EX-FINANCE MINISTER RETURNS TO A WARM WELCOME IN HAITI
description: Marc Bazin, a former Haitian Finance Minister, has come home to an enthusiastic welcome four years after he was dismissed by the Duvalier regime because of his attempts to curb Government corruption.

title: THE STREET'S WELL-PAID UPSTARTS
description: EVERYBODY should have Steven Gruber's money problems. Mr. Gruber, a 28-year-old investment banker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., goes skiing in Telluride, Colo., and Sun Valley, Idaho, drives an Alfa Romeo and is looking for a cooperative apartment just steps off Fifth Avenue, as the real estate brokers say. But it is not easy spending - or even investing - an income that tops $250,000 a year. ''It kind of piles up in the bank account,'' he admitted.

title: 7 HURT IN WEST BERLIN BY BLAST AT ARAB SITE
description: Seven people were wounded, one seriously, when a bomb exploded during the night at the offices of a German-Arab friendship organization and two other firebombs went off in unrelated incidents, the police said.

title: OIL BURSTS FRAGILE TEXAS BUBBLE OF PROSPERITY
description: To Robert Murff, the hardest part has been making so much progress and then watching helplessly as it all disappears.

title: Man, 53, Found Slain In His West Side Home
description: A man was found slain in his Upper West Side apartment last night, his hands and ankles bound by ropes, the police said.

title: EICHMANN TRIAL RECALLED IN EXHIBIT
description: The defendant was just a balding, middle-aged man with thick glasses and a slouch.

title: FED PANEL'S INTENTIONS UNCLEAR
description: The Federal Open Market Committee seems inclined to take a small further step to ease monetary policy when it meets Tuesday to plot the Federal Reserve's course for the next seven weeks, many analysts believe.

title: The U.N. Today; March 31, 1986
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Human Rights Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SERVING UP FOOD AND EMILY POST
description: The other night at the state dinner for Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, one of the butlers had to whisper to two different guests that the doily on the dessert plate under the finger bowl should be removed along with the finger bowl. Otherwise there would be no place to put the dessert.

title: NETS BEATEN: CELTIC VICTORY EQUALS MARK
description: During the 1949-50 season, when the National Basketball Association played a 68-game schedule, the Lakers ran off 27 straight victories at home in Minneapolis. No team has been able to match that feat until today, when the Celtics defeated the Nets, 122-117, at the Boston Garden.

title: SHORT-HANDED 76ERS EDGE MAVERICKS
description: The Philadelphia 76ers had five players, three of them centers, out with injuries, but managed to score a 114-113 victory over the Dallas Mavericks today.

title: PAVAROTTI AND SUTHERLAND TO SING AT GARDEN ON TOUR
description: Luciano Pavarotti and Joan Sutherland will celebrate separate anniversaries together when they undertake a four-city concert tour ending at Madison Square Garden on Sept. 16. The program, which was announced over the weekend, will consist of duets and arias from Donizetti and Verdi operas and will be shown live on public television. Richard Bonynge will conduct.

title: One-Handed Pitcher
description: Jim Abbott, the one-handed high school pitching sensation who passed up a contract with the Toronto Blue Jays last year to play for the University of Michigan, has begun his freshman season, though not exactly with a bang. In each of his first two starts, the big left-hander gave up five walks in the space of an inning, and after he made his third appearance, in relief, his earned run average for a total of three and a third innings had ballooned to 10.90. Although that has dropped in two appearances since, he is still above the level expected of a major-league prospect.

title: TALES FROM THE TABLESIDE
description: Tales told -anonymously - by White House butlers:

title: BILL WOULD HELP MIDWIVES
description: For the last year, about a third of the nation's 2,500 practicing nurse-midwives have faced a malpractice insurance crisis that could force them to give up their profession. But late last week a Senate committee approved a bill that could help to provide a remedy.

title: LOOKING TO NEW CLEAN COAL TECHNOLOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ WANTS U.S. AND SOVIET TO END PUBLIC DIPLOMACY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that ''we're not going anywhere'' in Soviet-American relations until Moscow and Washington agree to stop conducting their diplomacy in public. He called on both sides to resume regular, secret contacts.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Dunedin, Fla., 1:05 P.M. Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami, 1:30 P.M. College: Seton Hall vs.

title: Singapore Prescribes Own Remedy
description: The Government of Singapore, acknowledging that its economy is in a ''serious recession,'' has published a tough and comprehensive policy review calling for a reduction in the country's high rate of savings, a two-year freeze on wage increases and a lowering of both corporate and personal taxes. Some of the measures are already being put into effect.

title: Utah Bank Failure
description: Family Bank in Ogden, Utah, which had total assets of $23.3 million and four branches, was closed Friday by the state authorities and will reopen Monday as part of the Commercial Security Bank of Salt Lake City, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said.

title: Washington Watch; The Tax Talks Grind On
description: As the Senate Finance Committee neared the finish of its first week of drafting a tax revision bill, Senator Steven Symms, an Idaho Republican, suggested that the United States would be better off if the members just dropped the exercise. ''Just us meeting here,'' he told the committee chairman, Bob Packwood, ''is causing the biggest disruption.''

title: PRESIDENT GOES TO CHURCH
description: President and Nancy Reagan marked the fifth anniversary of the attempt on his life by attending Easter services today in a small Presbyterian church a few miles from his ranch. It was Mr. Reagan's first attendance at a regular church service since Easter 1984, when he worshiped in Honolulu. The Rev. Jeff Cotter singled out the President in a prayer, asking ''that your Holy Spirit might continue to guide him in the decisions he has to make.''

title: JOB LOSS IN MAINE TOWN BRINGS EXODUS OF YOUNG
description: Keith S. Bouchard carried his water bed, his fiancee's hope chest and some other belongings out of the house where he grew up and loaded them into an old boat trailer.

title: A First at Penn Mutual
description: The Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company has survived 139 years without an ad agency but has now decided to mend its ways. Doyle Graf Mabley was the agency of choice and the trade press has estimated the budget could run to $5 million.

title: Market Place; 2 Appliance Independents
description: A PAIR of rapid-fire mergers announced during March has left only two big independents - the Maytag Company and the Whirlpool Corporation - remaining in the major appliance industry. And some analysts believe these companies, too, eventually could become acquisition targets.

title: New Dances by Louis
description: Three premieres will highlight the Murray Louis Dance Company's season at the Joyce Theater, from tomorrow to April 20.

title: THOMPSON SPURRED BY SLIGHTS
description: Billy Thompson went to church today.

title: City to Check Report On Friedman Pension
description: The city's Corporation Counsel, at the request of Mayor Koch, plans to investigate a report that Stanley M. Friedman saved a lapsing portion of his city pension in 1983 with a gimmick - by teaching for only three hours and having the pension shifted to the Teachers' Retirement Fund.

title: SHIP RECOVERS CHUNK OF CHALLENGER BOOSTER
description: Searchers have recovered a large piece of one of the space shuttle Challenger's two booster rockets, but the salvage team did not know from which booster the chunk came, officials said today.

title: BAR GIRLS RETAKE BASE FROM PICKETS
description: The bar girls who thrive on the business of American servicemen took up the cry of ''People power!'' today as they stormed a civilian picket line and reopened the gates of Clark Air Base.

title: BLOOPERS ON THE STUMP
description: One of the more successful developers of political computer software has taken a cue from television entertainment: When you run out of fresh ideas for new shows, give the audience laughable material so bad that it was cut out of old ones. Aristotle Industries of Norwalk, Conn., produced a one-hour videotape last year of the best political commercials made for television in the 1984 campaign, and nearly 1,000 copies have been sold at $75 each.

title: SURPRISES, FROM RAIN AND CANAL
description: In February, with the rains ending and South Florida's dry spell beginning, fire once more seemed like a major threat.

title: A 'REBORN' MANILA HAS A JOYOUS DAY
description: In a celebration that was equal parts of sweetness and joy, Filipinos embraced Easter today as a vibrant symbol of their political rebirth.

title: Military Memories For Queens Leader
description: Two weeks after her election as Borough President of Queens, Claire Shulman crossed the border into Brooklyn to address an audience drawn from around the country - the United States Navy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1986
description: The Economy

title: WHY ADMIRAl FARRAGUT NEEDS TO COME IN FROM THE PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: AT COLISEUM, FINAL SHOW'S OVER
description: When the New York Coliseum opened on April 28, 1956, Mayor Robert F. Wagner called it ''one of the wonders of the modern world.'' For the ribbon cutting there were headlines like, ''World's Biggest Exhibition Building Opens'' and ''Coliseum: Another New York Superlative.''

title: Treasury Planning a Low-Key April
description: After last week's note auctions totaling $13.5 billion, the Treasury will take a low profile in the note and bond market for the next five weeks.

title: BREWERS' VUCKOVICH RETIRES
description: The former Cy Young Award winner Pete Vuckovich, who had been trying to make the Milwaukee Brewers as a nonroster player after undergoing shoulder surgery for a second time, has retired.

title: GOALS SET FOR SOUTHAMPTON CAMPUS
description: This affluent resort community may one day be known as a college town.

title: BRITISH SOLDIER SHOT IN ULSTER AS CATHOLICS RECALL UPRISING
description: A British soldier was shot and seriously wounded today as violence flared between security forces and Roman Catholics opposed to British rule, the police said.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SONG Easter music can still be heard in the city. And in that spirit, three sopranos are presenting ''Resurrexi'' in St. Paul's Chapel, in the financial district on Broadway at Fulton Street, this afternoon at 12:10.

title: MUSIC: WESTFIELD GROUP
description: CHARLOTTE BERGEN, an independently wealthy music lover, used to sponsor and then conduct annual concerts at Carnegie Hall. Four years after Miss Bergen's death, her devotion lives on: On Saturday afternoon, the Frank and Lydia Bergen Foundation, a trust set up in Miss Bergen's will, paid for a performance of Beethoven's ''Fidelio'' at Carnegie Hall.

title: Catching Up
description: * Dennis Leonard, the three-time 20-game winner for the Kansas City Royals, has pitched only two major-league innings since tearing a tendon below his left kneecap in May 1983.

title: 'F/X,' A SUSPENSE FILM WITH A MYSTERIOUS TITLE
description: The worst thing about ''F/X'' is its title. Unfortunately, everyone connected with the taut and clever suspense movie came to that conclusion several months too late.

title: VERDICT ON PAPAL PLOT, BUT NO ANSWER
description: An Italian court's decision on Saturday to acquit three Bulgarians ''for lack of proof'' leaves unresolved the question of whether they conspired to assassinate Pope John Paul II.

title: IT ISN'T EASY TO LABEL WHO IS TERMINALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: RANGERS SCRAMBLE IN STRETCH
description: The Rangers pulled their clothes off the metal hangers dangling from the steel bar in a corner of the clubhouse. They picked their shoes out of a row on the floor. A few, late out of the showers, threw their towels on the musty carpet that had been soiled by the hundreds of other players who had visited and, it should be added, frequently lost here.

title: THE REAGAN DOCTRINE
description: My fellow Americans, I have spoken to you in recent weeks about the rising tide of freedom in the world - the victory of democracy in the Philippines, the resistance to tyranny in Nicaragua. In all those struggles the United States, the historic fighter for freedom, must play its part.

title: TO CURB MEDICAL SUITS
description: In all the talk about how to deal with the medical malpractice crisis, a simple yet potent idea is being ignored: creation of a new kind of doctor-patient relationship in which information is fully shared and decisions jointly reached.

title: THE PERFECT LIBERALS
description: Who says that President Reagan and the conservative movement have pulled all former liberals over into the political center? Americans for Democratic Action, the unquenchable voice of liberaldom, has assessed 20 votes cast in 1985 by all members of Congress and found that five Senators and 20 Representatives, all Democrats, were ''perfect'' from a liberal prospective. The Senators who scored 100 percent agreement with the A.D.A. on key issues were Alan Cranston of California, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Gary Hart of Colorado, Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio and Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland.

title: Piano and Percussion
description: The Pridonoff Piano Duo and the Percussion Group/Cincinnati will give a joint concert at 8 P.M. on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall. The five musicians, all from the faculty of the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music, will play Bartok's Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion; Eugene and Elizabeth Pridonoff will play works by Mozart and Saint-Saens, and the percussion trio will offer pieces by John Cage and Mark Saya. Tickets are available at the box office or through Centercharge, 874-6770.

title: JOHN PAUL ASSAILS DEALERS OF DEATH
description: Pope John Paul II, in a passionate but somber Easter message assailing human callousness, declared today that man ''has often made death the method of his existence on earth.''

title: READING YAMANI'S MIND
description: What a foolish and self-defeating binge the Western world is on, thanks to my temporary discomfiture.

title: CORPORATE BORROWING INCREASING
description: The dramatic decline in interest rates in the first quarter - in some cases to levels not seen since the mid-1970's - has spurred a growing number of companies to raise cash for projects that had been long deferred because of the high cost of money.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Montreal, has announced the retirement of Nathaniel V. Davis, chairman. No successor was named.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: BRUINS TURN BACK SABRES, 5-3
description: Randy Burridge scored a third-period goal and added three assists tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 5-3 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: HELEN MERRILL, 50'S JAZZ SINGER, CREATES AN 80'S STIR
description: The celebrated but often elusive jazz singer Helen Merrill recently made her first New York appearance in two years at the Carlos 1 supper club in Greenwich Village. The critics heaped on the superlatives, and the week was so successful that Miss Merrill has been booked for a two-week run at the club starting April 15. And Polygram Special Imports is releasing ''The Complete Helen Merrill on Mercury.'' This four-record boxed set of her 1950's recordings was compiled and recently released in Japan, where her following is much larger than the circle of jazz aficionados. The four disks capture some of the most musicianly and emotionally compelling singing in modern jazz. ''Put it all together and I seem to be making some sort of comeback,'' Miss Merrill said recently, with some amusement.

title: WIDESPREAD RATE OPTIMISM
description: As long-term bond yields have fallen to the lowest level since 1977, market participants are finding that many of the conditions that led to lower rates still exist.

title: ALARIE BLOSSOMS AT THE PERFECT TIME
description: In a game in which strength, size, skill and quickness are valued highly, timing may be the most critical element in basketball success. It is timing that allows a player to block out a larger opponent underneath the boards, to break down a taller defender and create an opening for a shot or to step in the path of a pass that was not intended for him.

title: NICARGUAN FIGHTS OUSTER BY U.S., CITING MILITARY DRAFT IN HOMELAND
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has issued an order for the deportation Monday of a 28-year-old citizen of Nicaragua who says that at home he will be drafted into the army of the Sandinista Government, which President Reagan has called a brutal Communist aggressor.

title: 'COMIC RELIEF,' BENEFIT FOR HOMELESS, ON HBO
description: POP performers have discovered the rewards of a cause.

title: Washington Watch; Hesse Is Recommended
description: Energy Secretary John S. Herrington has recommended that the White House select Martha O. Hesse, Assistant Secretary for Management and Administration, for the chairmanship of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Another leading candidate is said to be Linda Stuntz, the minority counsel of a House energy subcommittee.

title: Chiat/Day Takes Over As Agency for Ricoh
description: Chiat/Day's New York office has been appointed by the Ricoh Corporation of West Caldwell, N.J., to be its agency.

title: DEREGULATION FAILING TO SATISFY BIG BANKS
description: For the banking and thrift industries, an era of deregulation ends Tuesday with the completion of a five-year program of removing controls on interest rates.

title: TAXI REFORM, AGAIN
description: Must New Yorkers continue to suffer at the hands of the city's taxi cartel? The revelations of influence-peddling have weakened the clout of the taxi lobby and offer Mayor Koch a fresh chance to push for reform. The question now is whether the Mayor is prepared to expend the political capital to get the job done.

title: L.I. MAN IS FOUND SLAIN BESIDE CAR ON HIGHWAY
description: A man who may have stopped to change a tire on his car was found shot to death about 9:30 this morning on Sunrise Highway, the Nassau County police said.

title: McDonnell Unit President
description: William S. Ross, a former test pilot, has been named president of the McDonnell Aircraft division of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. Mr. Ross, who was named executive vice president of the division last August, replaces Donald Malvern, who is retiring.

title: CABLE SERVICES STRESSING COMPATIBILITY WITH VCR
description: Facing a serious challenge from the booming video-cassette business, the major pay-cable services have decided to join rather than fight the enemy. In a modification of their previous position, they have begun a campaign to emphasize that cable television is compatible rather than competitive with the video-cassette recorder.

title: MASTER OF PUGNACIOUS GRACE
description: James Cagney, the cocky and pugnacious film star who set the standard for gangster roles in ''The Public Enemy'' and won an Academy Award for his portrayal of George M. Cohan in ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' died yesterday at his Dutchess County farm in upstate New York. He was 86 years old.

title: Texas Players Got Loans
description: Two former Texas assistant football coaches said they lent small amounts of money to players, actions they knew violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules.

title: SRI LANKA GIRDS FOR A FIGHT TO THE CENTURY'S END
description: After nine months of on-and-off talks to end the violence in Sri Lanka, fighting between the Government and Tamil guerrillas has reverted to the high level of early last year, and both sides say a negotiated settlement seems farther away than ever.

title: BECKER TOPPLES LENDL INDOORS
description: Boris Becker upset Ivan Lendl, the world's top-ranked player, 7-6, 6-3, today to capture the $315,000 Volvo-Chicago Tennis Tournament and end Lendl's winning streak at 29 matches.

title: STUTTERERS VIS A VIS THE WORLD
description: TEN men and two women sat around speaking in slow, measured sentences and interrupting one another with what seemed a total disregard of good manners.

title: 'KILLER IN THE MIRROR'
description: AZONG the least memorable of Bette Davis's films is a 1964 vehicle called ''Dead Ringer.'' Miss Davis played twin sisters, one rich and terribly nasty, the other poor and relatively virtuous.

title: Music/Noted in Brief; Gary Karr Presents A Double-Bass Recital
description: The problem of the double bass as a solo instrument lies not in its range or timbre but in the terrible difficulties of playing it in tune. Gary Karr, who performed at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, manages the instrument's technical problems better than most anyone around, yet, more important, he wants us to take the bass seriously as a musical tool.

title: WRITING ABOUT THE RICH, IN REVIVAL, GAINS NAME
description: TOM WOLFE has recently coined a useful term to describe a new phenomenon -''plutography,'' as in ''plutocracy.'' Literally it means ''writing about the rich,'' and you may object that there is nothing very new about that. There have been golden calves in the world for a long time now, and writers to write about them. But look at any current newsstand, and it is hard not to feel that we are in the presence of a journalistic obsession without parallel, or at any rate with parallels so long ago that most people have forgotten them.

title: MUSIC: BERG CONCERTO
description: THE highlight of the chamber concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon was a taut, engrossing rendition of Alban Berg's ''Chamber Concerto for Piano, Violin and 13 Wind Instruments,'' featuring the pianist Jeffrey Kahane, the violinist James Buswell and an ensemble under the direction of Leon Kirchner.

title: HALLEY'S COMET
description: Halley's Comet will rise over the New York City area at 2:39 A.M. today and set at 9:09 A.M. Tomorrow it will rise at 2:34 A.M. and set at 8:43 A.M.

title: DELTA BLACKS RALLY FOR 'WOMAN OF PRINCIPLE'
