description: Half a century ago, in another age entirely, when blacks and mules still tilled the cotton fields of the plantations here, a young journalist from Alabama arrived in the Mississippi Delta. She was full of bloom and ambition. She wanted to matter.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When Villanova beat Georgetown for the N.C.A.A. basketball championship last year, the Wildcats set a tournament record for field-goal percentage. What team held the previous mark? What's the best free-throw percentage in the tourney?

title: WORKING PROFILE
description: Dr. Otis R. Bowen, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has been on the job now for a little more than 100 days. How is he doing?

title: FARM BILL ANOMALY
description: To the Editor:

title: L.L. Bean's Business Moved to Hill, Holliday
description: L.L. Bean of Freeport, Me., whose name is synonymous with outdoor gear and furnishings, has switched its account from Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, which has handled it for a decade, to Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos of Boston.

title: SAVE BY BERENYI MAY SAVE HIS JOB
description: Nine days before the start of the season, Bruce Berenyi made his boldest bid yet to make the Mets' opening-day roster. His performance this afternoon against the Cincinnati Reds also may have cleared the way for a possible trade involving a Met pitcher.

title: Poodle Is Best
description: A black miniature poodle, Ch. Surrey in Clover, today was chosen best of 1,498 dogs at the 32d Riverhead Kennel Club show in the Nassau Coliseum. It was the first top award for the 2-year-old, who is owned by John Long and Chris Zama of Easton, Conn., and gaited by Kaz Hosaka, who in 1983 was the top handler of all breeds in Japan.

title: JERSEY LEGISLATURE TO REVIEW BOXING
description: Proposals to tighten the supervision of professional boxers and of the people who work in the sport will be the subject of legislative hearings starting next month.

title:
SCOUTING REPORTS;
WITH STYLES SO ALIKE, IT'S CLASH OF PERSONNEL
description: OVER the years, the final game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament has been one of the very special events in sports. Two outstanding teams remain. Every other team in the tournament has seen the season end with a loss. To add to the excitement, often there are two finalists with contrasting styles. Will the clever Villanova Wildcats be able to stay with an overpowering Georgetown team? Can an inspired North Carolina State team prevent the Phi Slamma Jamma group of Houston from running it out of the arena?

title: 2 in Bronx Seized On Drug Charges
description: A father and son, several guns and 10 pounds of a substance believed to be heroin were seized in a South Bronx apartment early yesterday by two police officers who were investigating a report of gunshots fired in the building.

title: PALESTINIANS BATTLE SHIITES FOR THIRD DAY
description: For the third day, Palestinian guerrillas and Shiite militiamen battled today around two Palestinian centers in southern Beirut.

title: Violence Erupts At Soccer Match
description: One fan was stabbed, at least 28 persons were arrested, and a bomb exploded without injuring anyone during a weekend of soccer violence in the Netherlands, the police said.

title: HARVARD'S EFFORTS FALL SHORT IN FINAL
description: In a metaphor often applied to sports, the Harvard players were the Davids dashing about in the national collegiate hockey final, slinging shots at the Goliaths from Michigan State.

title: Washington Watch; Mulford for the World Bank?
description: A void in the resume of Barber B. Conable Jr., the next World Bank president, is international finance. So the Administration has been considering how it might lend him a hand, with someone who is sympathetic to its free market views.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, MARCH 31, 1986
description: International Secrecy in U.S.-Soviet relations is necessary, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said. Expressing dismay over recent Soviet and American public statements, Mr. Shultz said ''we're not going anywhere'' in Soviet-American relations until Moscow and Washington agreed to stop conducting their diplomacy in public. He called on both sides to resume regular, secret contacts. [ Page A1, Column 6. ]

title: THE TEST BAN SHIBBOLETH
description: Mikhail Gorbachev sings a seductive tune in demanding a complete halt to further testing of nuclear weapons. The campaign is going so well that he has twice extended a self-imposed moratorium on Soviet nuclear testing, piously declared last July to mark the 40th anniversary of the American bombing of Hiroshima.

title: SILENCING THE COWBELLS ALL OVER THE NORTHEAST
description: To the Editor:

title: Deficit Pared By Renault
description: Despite a diminishing share of the car market, Renault narrowed its 1985 losses to $1.56 billion, from $1.79 billion a year earlier, Renault said Friday.

title: B.B.D.O.'s New Hire; Promotions at Esquire
description: Michael Becker, formerly chief creative officer of Ted Bates Advertising/New York, is going to work for Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn as a senior creative director.

title: 2 Bodies Found In an Apartment
description: The bodies of a man in his 60's and a woman in her 20's were found yesterday in a ransacked Brooklyn apartment, and the police said they both appeared to be victims of homicide.

title: Greengage-Sun Line
description: Greengage Associates, which served as agency to Sun Line Cruises from 1978 to 1981 and then lost the client to AC&R Advertising, has just won it back. Billings should be $1.5 million.

title: CABARET: ANDREA MCARDLE
description: ANDREA McARDLE, who was 13 years old in 1977 when she hit Broadway in the title role of the musical ''Annie,'' is making her first solo appearance in a New York nightclub at Freddy's, 308 East 39th Street, through next Sunday in an act that has been written and produced by Martin Charnin, whose lyrics she sang in ''Annie.''

title: Music/Noted in Brief; 'The Sirens,' by Diaz, At Alternative Museum
description: Although the Alternative Museum's policy of presenting works by young composers and performance artists is worthy of support, the fact remains that Wednesday night's production of ''The Sirens,'' with music by Frank Diaz and choreography by Jill Harrison, was not very interesting.

title: BEWILDERED AT SKID, PASQUA IS READY TO STEP DOWN
description: Dan Pasqua sat in front of his locker, staring blankly at the folded white towel on his lap. Mechanically, he turned the towel in his hands, then turned it back again. He unfolded it part way, then folded it again. He continued turning it and unfolding it and folding it. Then he played with the tape on his left hand, picking first at one spot, then another. He stared into his locker, he stared at the floor, he stared - still blankly -at no one or nothing, just empty space.

title: POP: PETER ALLEN IN SHOW
description: FOR years Peter Allen has played off the two sides of his personality - the romantic singer-songwriter versus the glitzy showman - with an impish glee that implied he knew the difference between classy pop and kitsch. But in his latest show at the Radio City Music Hall, which opened Saturday for 10 performances, indiscriminate showmanship and garishly extravagant production values obscure much of what is special about Mr. Allen.

title: DEMONSTRATIONS OF SALVADORAN OPENNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Account
description: Honda Canada to Grey-Canada for its Acura line.

title: SCANDAL UNFOLDS OVER TAPED ALLEGATIONS IN MIAMI
description: The arrest of a 36-year-old Hialeah man and the release of many court-authorized surveillance tapes has created one of the biggest scandals here in decades.

title: Washington Watch; Sprinkel Is Optimistic
description: AT the start of the year, Beryl W. Sprinkel, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, predicted that the economy would grow 4 percent this year, far better than last year, and that inflation would be up slightly, at 3.8 percent. Mr. Sprinkel won't have to consider revising the figures officially until July, but because of falling oil prices he already expects less inflation.

title: Danes Knight Kisselgoff
description: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark has bestowed the Order of the Dannebrog on Anna Kisselgoff, chief dance critic of The New York Times.

title: EASTER THEMES ARE SOUNDED IN CITY
description: At a sunrise service at the Salvation Army's Centennial Temple, the message rang out:

title: MUSIC: UNIVERSITY ORCHESTRAS DEBUT
description: CONCERTGOERS in New York are used to the idea of debut recitals, where young soloists present their credentials to the public. Something new on the scene is the ''American University Orchestra Debut Series,'' which brought ensembles from California State University at Northridge and the University of Minnesota to Alice Tully Hall Saturday under their respective conductors, Lawrence Christianson and Richard Massmann.

title: AMERICANS IN LIBYA: DESPITE BATTLE, LIFE AS USUAL
description: He is a Texan, a grizzled oil worker, and though President Reagan had ordered Americans to leave here by Feb. 1, he was in suburban Tripoli this weekend cutting his lawn.

title: TREATY IS SAID TO KEEP SOVIET FROM OUTDEPLOYING U.S. IN WEAPONS
description: Abandoning the second strategic arms treaty would enable the Soviet Union to add more weapons to its arsenal than the United States by 1990, according to an analysis by Representative Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO PRESS THE SPANIARDS AGAIN ON GIVING A REFUGE TO MARCOS
description: The United States has quietly reopened negotiations with Spain in an effort to find a haven for former President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, Administration officials said today.

title: COURT BACK DAMAGES ON DRUG FOR PREGNANCE
description: An appeals court has reinstated $750,000 to a Maryland teen-ager born with a deformed right arm, and the decision could be a turning point in hundreds of damage suits against the manufacturer of the drug Bendectin, said lawyers who filed the claims.

title: Old Induction Center Getting a New Skin
description: The bombs did not stop the Vietnam War. The bombs did not stop the draft. The bombs did not even stop the processing of young men through the Armed Forces Induction Center at 39 Whitehall Street in lower Manhattan.

title: NICARAGUA ASKS BORDER FORCE
description: Nicaragua has proposed the creation of a multinational force to patrol its border with Honduras.

title: A HAVEN FOR BOSTON'S 'INVISIBLE WOMEN'
description: The women begin appearing in early morning and, laden with bundles, find their way through the alley and down the steps to a daytime shelter for the homeless. They look on it as a refuge. Many say it is the only place they feel secure and welcome and are treated as guests in a home.

title: First-Night Tickets $1 For Flying Karamazovs
description: In a special opening-night stunt, all tickets for tomorrow night's performance of the Flying Karamazov Brothers in ''Juggling and Cheap Theatrics'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater will go on sale for $1.

title: POP: OTIS CLAY AND BAND
description: TRUE 1960's soul singing -that wondrous amalgam of grit and vulnerability, pyrotechnics and raw emotion -sometimes seems like a lost art in the slick, ironic 1980's. But Otis Clay, the Chicago soul veteran who came to Tramps (125 East 15th Street) over the weekend and will return there Thursday through Saturday, has never stopped singing soul music.

title: Bid for Carson Pirie Spotlights Investor
description: Gilbert K. Granet, a Chicago investment banker, has always prided himself on financing acquisitions and making deals without much fanfare.

title: THE HOTTEST TWO PLAY FOR THE TITLE
description: After more than four months of unpredictable twists and turns, the 1985-86 college basketball season ends here Monday evening when Duke plays Louisville for the national championship.

title: CHEAP OIL AND SOVIET NEEDS
description: In all the discussion about the economic consequences of the dramatic drop in oil prices, one country, which happens to be the world's largest oil producer, has received only scant attention: the Soviet Union. And yet when one tries to analyze what oil at $15 a barrel would mean to the rulers of the Soviet empire, it is impossible to escape the thought that the collapse in the price of oil might well contain the seeds of an improved and more mature relationship between the two superpowers.

title: Some Cultural Artifacts Unearthed for the Library
description: Something about the commonest objects of one generation makes them scarce in the next. When was the last time you saw original, hard-cover copies of ''The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care,'' by Dr. Benjamin Spock, or ''The Power of Positive Thinking,'' by the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale?

title: New Business Move in China
description: As part of its program of economic changes, China plans the creation of limited liability companies, the official China Daily said Friday.
